vi: The messenger rode back at a leisurely trot, occasionally stopping at a tavern for a sip but always maintaining his clarity, pulling up the brim of his hat so as not to obstruct his view. He had eyes that matched the hat perfectly, pitch-black eyes with indistinct shape or color, set too close together—as if they feared revealing something if they were farther apart. Those eyes gleamed with a sinister look beneath the old tricorn hat that resembled a three-sided spittoon, above a scarf that covered his chin and throat, hanging down to his knees. Each time he stopped to drink, he would use his left hand to pull down the scarf while his right hand lifted the cup to his lips; after a sip, he would pull it back up.
tr: The messenger on his horse had started to trot, occasionally stopping at bars along his route to drink something, pulling his hat down to his eyes to signal he wanted to be left alone. His eyes matched the decor well, pitch black, lacking any depth in color or shape, and –as if fearing something would happen if they were apart– set too close to each other. Under his old, three-cornered hat with upturned edges that looked like a spittoon, and over the long scarf wrapped around his chin and almost reaching his knees, his eyes had an unsettling expression. When he drank, he would part his scarf with his left hand, down the drink with his right hand, and immediately wrap himself back in the scarf.
es: The messenger mounted his horse and began the return journey at a slow trot, stopping at all the taverns and inns along the way to refresh his throat, but without engaging in conversation with anyone and always trying to keep his hat pulled down over his eyes. This precaution harmonized perfectly with his eyes, which were black and very close together; so close, in fact, that it seemed they feared someone might jump over them one by one if they were found separated. They had a sinister expression, perhaps contributed to by the fact that they shone between a hat that looked more like a triangular spittoon than a hat, and a sort of cloak that started from the eyes and ended at the knees of its wearer. When he stopped to drink, he would use his left hand to lift the cloak just enough to pour the liquid into his mouth with his right hand, and as soon as he finished drinking, he would pull it back up again.

en: “No, Jerry, no!” said the messenger, harping on one theme as he rode. “It wouldn’t do for you, Jerry. Jerry, you honest tradesman, it wouldn’t suit your line of business! Recalled—! Bust me if I don’t think he’d been a drinking!”
vi: − No, no way, Jerry, - the messenger kept mumbling to himself about that on horseback. - Bad luck for you, Jerry! You, an honest businessman, this matter doesn't suit your way of doing things! Revival...! If he wasn't drunk, may the heavens strike me down!
tr: While riding his horse, still preoccupied with the same issue, the messenger said, "No Jerry, it won't work!" "This is not for you at all, Jerry, you are an honest merchant, Jerry; you don't do such things ever! Revived-!, I bet the man was drunk!"
es: —No, Jeremiah, no!—murmured the messenger, always harping on the same theme. —Jeremiah cannot agree with that... You are an honest man, Jeremiah, a merchant who cannot approve of that kind of business... Resurrected!... Hang me if Mr. Lorry wasn't drunk when he gave me such a message!

en: His message perplexed his mind to that degree that he was fain, several times, to take off his hat to scratch his head. Except on the crown, which was raggedly bald, he had stiff, black hair, standing jaggedly all over it, and growing down hill almost to his broad, blunt nose. It was so like Smith’s work, so much more like the top of a strongly spiked wall than a head of hair, that the best of players at leap-frog might have declined him, as the most dangerous man in the world to go over.
vi: That message left him so bewildered that he repeatedly took off his hat to scratch his head. Except for the already bald top, his hair was black, stiff, bristly all over his head, and grew long enough to almost touch his broad nose. Like a blacksmith's work, it bristled like steel spikes embedded on a wall's edge, even the best sheep jumpers wouldn't dare leap over it, seeing it as the most dangerous obstacle in the world.
tr: The message had confused him so much that he frequently took off his hat to scratch his head. Except for the top of his partially bald head, his stiff and upright black hair almost reached his broad and blunt nose. It was like the work of a blacksmith; rather than a head with hair, it resembled a wall covered with long nails, so much so that even the best leapfrog players would probably find it dangerous and not want to jump over it.
es: So perplexed was he by the strange word that he frequently took off his hat to scratch his head mercilessly; and since I am talking about his head, I will say that, except for the crown, which was completely bald, it disappeared under a mass of coarse hair that descended down his back to his shoulders and grew in front up to the start of his broad and blunt nose. His head resembled the work of a blacksmith, a wall ridge bristling with thick spikes, which fans of the game "at one, the mule" would have looked at with respectful terror, surely considering it the most dangerous jump a man could make in the world.

en: While he trotted back with the message he was to deliver to the night watchman in his box at the door of Tellson’s Bank, by Temple Bar, who was to deliver it to greater authorities within, the shadows of the night took such shapes to him as arose out of the message, and took such shapes to the mare as arose out of her private topics of uneasiness. They seemed to be numerous, for she shied at every shadow on the road.
vi: While he was galloping to deliver the message to the night watchman at the guard post in front of Tellson's Bank near the Temple Bar gate, the spirits of the night seemed to emerge from that very message; even his horse might have seen shapes manifesting from the depths of its own fears. There must have been many ghosts because the horse kept jumping away from the shadows on the road.
tr: When he set out from Temple Bar to deliver the message to the night watchman waiting in the booth in front of Tellson Bank so that it could be passed on to more authoritative individuals, the shadows of the night took on various forms as if they had sprung from that message, and even the mare seemed to see shapes that were extensions of entirely different things that disturbed her. Judging by how often she shied, there were many shadows on the road.
es: The shadows of the night have truly strange whims. To the messenger, while he was returning with the mysterious message that he had to deliver to the night watchman of Tellson's Bank, so that he could in turn pass it on to his superiors, they were resurrected dead, ghosts risen from the graves, while to the mare he was riding, they were horses running without rest. For the three inscrutable travelers occupying the inside of the coach, while it jumped and bumped over the road's potholes, the shadows of the night took the forms of the thoughts that their respective imaginations conjured.

en: What time, the mail-coach lumbered, jolted, rattled, and bumped upon its tedious way, with its three fellow-inscrutables inside. To whom, likewise, the shadows of the night revealed themselves, in the forms their dozing eyes and wandering thoughts suggested.
vi: At the same time, the mail truck was chugging along, jolting, bouncing, and bumping on the endless road with three mysterious people inside. For them too, the ghosts of the night appeared in various shapes in their drowsy eyes and in their wandering thoughts.
tr: Meanwhile, the stagecoach, with its three mysterious passengers inside, was moving slowly and shakily along its arduous path. Who knows in what forms the shadows of the night appeared to their sleepy eyes and thoughtful minds.
es: For the three inscrutable travelers occupying the inside of the coach, while it jumped and bumped over the road's potholes, the shadows of the night took the forms of the thoughts that their respective imaginations conjured.

en: Tellson’s Bank had a run upon it in the mail. As the bank passenger—with an arm drawn through the leathern strap, which did what lay in it to keep him from pounding against the next passenger, and driving him into his corner, whenever the coach got a special jolt—nodded in his place, with half-shut eyes, the little coach-windows, and the coach-lamp dimly gleaming through them, and the bulky bundle of opposite passenger, became the bank, and did a great stroke of business. The rattle of the harness was the chink of money, and more drafts were honoured in five minutes than even Tellson’s, with all its foreign and home connection, ever paid in thrice the time. Then the strong-rooms underground, at Tellson’s, with such of their valuable stores and secrets as were known to the passenger (and it was not a little that he knew about them), opened before him, and he went in among them with the great keys and the feebly-burning candle, and found them safe, and strong, and sound, and still, just as he had last seen them.
vi: The Tellson Bank is experiencing a massive withdrawal right on this mail coach trip. While the bank employee dozed off, a hand slipped through the leather strap meant to keep him from bumping into the person next to him and pushing him into the corner each time the coach jolted; through his half-closed eyes, the small windows and the dim mail coach lights, along with the bulky figure of the passenger opposite, had transformed into the very bank itself during a moment of unexpected crisis. The clattering of the harness turned into the jingling of coins, and in five minutes, the amount of banknotes exchanged for cash was more than the total that Tellson, with all its branches at home and abroad, had ever paid out in a period three times as long. Then the vaults beneath Tellson Bank, filled with precious items and secrets that this passenger knew (and knew quite well), suddenly opened wide before him; he then took the large keys and a dim candle, walked through the vaults, and saw that everything was still safe, solid, secure, and quiet as it had been during the last inspection.
tr: Tellson Bank was not absent in the carriage either. The bank passenger –holding onto the leather strap to avoid bumping into the passenger next to him, and slumping into his corner as the carriage jolted– nodded his head with half-closed eyes, while the small windows of the carriage, the dim lamp casting light on them, and the large bundle of the passenger opposite him transformed into the bank, weighing down on him like a heavy task. The sound of the harnesses resembled the clinking of money; within five minutes, more forms appeared in the banker’s mind than from all the domestic and foreign connections of Tellson Bank. Then, the special rooms located underground at Tellson’s, which he knew well (and he knew quite a lot), with their vaults and secrets, came to his mind; he wandered through the rooms with large keys and a dimly lit candle in hand, seeing that everything was in its place and secure, just as he had last seen it.
es: It could be said that the Tellson Bank had moved to the stagecoach. For the bank employee, holding on with one hand to a strap, which allowed him to avoid colliding with his neighbor every time the vehicle jolted—and it jolted with exasperating frequency—the narrow windows of the coach, the lantern of the same, which filtered faint glimmers through them, and the dark bulk of the traveler he had before his half-closed eyes, were the Bank, in which he was conducting countless operations, each more successful than the last. The noise made by the harnesses seemed to him like the jingling of coins with which he paid bills, securities, and checks at a dizzying speed. It wasn't long before his imagination transported him to the underground vaults, whose secrets he knew so well, and armed with his large keys, he opened the enormous safe, which he found as intact, as full, as solid as he had left it the last time he had the chance to see it.

en: But, though the bank was almost always with him, and though the coach (in a confused way, like the presence of pain under an opiate) was always with him, there was another current of impression that never ceased to run, all through the night. He was on his way to dig some one out of a grave.
vi: But even though the bank was always on his mind, even though he still knew he was sitting in the mail truck (vaguely aware as if he could still feel the pain while drowsy from anesthesia), there was another stream of thoughts continuously running through, all night long. He was on his way to exhume someone's grave.
tr: Even though the bank and the mail coach (with a strange pain as if under the influence of a sleeping pill) always accompanied him, there was something else that never left his mind throughout the night. He was actually going to exhume someone from their grave.
es: But dominating the image of the Bank, which always accompanied him, and that of the stagecoach, which never left him, he felt another fixed, tenacious, and persistent idea that occupied him throughout the night. His journey had the purpose of bringing someone out of the grave.

en: Now, which of the multitude of faces that showed themselves before him was the true face of the buried person, the shadows of the night did not indicate; but they were all the faces of a man of five-and-forty by years, and they differed principally in the passions they expressed, and in the ghastliness of their worn and wasted state. Pride, contempt, defiance, stubbornness, submission, lamentation, succeeded one another; so did varieties of sunken cheek, cadaverous colour, emaciated hands and figures. But the face was in the main one face, and every head was prematurely white. A hundred times the dozing passenger inquired of this spectre:
vi: At this moment, the shadows of the night did not reveal the true face of the one buried among the myriad faces appearing before him; but all were the faces of a person around forty-five years old, differing mainly in the emotions expressed, and in the terrifying appearance of their emaciated and ghostly state. Pride, contempt, defiance, resilience, submission, lamentation, various states followed one another, as well as various images of sunken cheeks, pale skin, wrinkled hands, and emaciated bodies. But it was almost always the same face, and all heads were soon white with age. Hundreds of times, the drowsy passenger had asked this ghost: − How long have you been buried?
tr: Now, among all the faces appearing to him, which one was the face of the buried person? The shadows of the night hadn't revealed this, but all the faces he saw belonged to a man around forty-five years old. The main thing that distinguished them from each other was the ambition in their expressions and the horror of their exhausted and lost states. Pride, contempt, defiance, stubbornness, obedience, mourning always followed one another, and of course, there were the sunken cheeks, pale complexions, and hands and fingers reduced to skin and bones. But the face was the same and always completely white. The dozing traveler asked the ghost hundreds of times:
es: Now then; what the shadows of the night did not determine was which among the infinite number of faces that passed in an endless procession before his eyes was that of the buried person. They were, however, all faces of a man of approximately forty-five years, and they differed mainly in the passions that each of them reflected and in the livid paleness that characterized them. Before the half-closed eyes of the traveler paraded one after another faces that were mirrors of pride, contempt, defiance, obstinacy, submission, pain, faces with sunken cheeks, cadaverous color, thin and emaciated, but the general lines of all of them were the same, just as they all appeared framed in prematurely white hair. Dozens, hundreds of times the drowsy traveler asked the specter:

en: “Buried how long?”
vi: Hundreds of times, the drowsy passenger had asked this ghost: − How long have you been buried?
tr: "How long have you been buried?""
es: —When did they bury you?

en: The answer was always the same: “Almost eighteen years.”
vi: The answer was always: “Nearly eighteen years.” −
tr: The answer was always the same: "For almost eighteen years."
es: —Almost eighteen years ago—replied the ghost invariably.

en: “You had abandoned all hope of being dug out?”
vi: Have you given up all hope of being unearthed?
tr: "Did you still have hope of being rescued?"
es: —Had you lost all hope of seeing the light of day again?

en: “Long ago.”
vi: − Long ago. −
tr: "My hope had long been exhausted.""
es: —It's been a long time.

en: “You know that you are recalled to life?”
vi: Do you know you have been given a chance to live again?
tr: "Do you know that you will rise again?"
es: —Do you know that you are going to resurrect?

en: “They tell me so.”
vi: − I've heard so.
tr: "That's what they say."
es: —That's what they tell me.

en: “I hope you care to live?”
vi: − I hope you still want to live? −
tr: "I hope you want to be resurrected."
es: —I suppose you are interested in living?

en: “I can’t say.”
vi: It's hard to say. −
tr: "I don't know."
es: —I can't say it.

en: “Shall I show her to you? Will you come and see her?”
vi: Should I bring her to you? Or do you want to go meet her?
tr: "Shall I show it to you now? Do you want to come and see it?"
es: —Would you like me to introduce her to you? Will you come with me to see her?

en: The answers to this question were various and contradictory. Sometimes the broken reply was, “Wait! It would kill me if I saw her too soon.” Sometimes, it was given in a tender rain of tears, and then it was, “Take me to her.” Sometimes it was staring and bewildered, and then it was, “I don’t know her. I don’t understand.”
vi: This question was answered differently and contradictorily each time. Sometimes the choked response was: “Wait! I would die if I met her too soon.” Sometimes, the ghost, in tears and emotional, said: “Let me meet her.” Sometimes the ghost stared blankly, bewildered, and then the answer was: “I do not know her. I do not understand.”
tr: The answers to this question were very varied and contradictory. Some said sadly, "Stop! If I see him right away, I'll die!" Some, with heartfelt tears, said, "Take me to him." Some, in a state of bewilderment, stared and said, "I don't know him. I don't know what you're talking about," they said.
es: The answers that the different specters gave to this last question varied greatly and even contradicted each other. —Wait!—some exclaimed with a choked voice. —I would die if I saw her so suddenly! —Take me right away!—others responded, shedding seas of tears. —I'm dying to see her! —I don't know her!—responded other specters, looking astonished at the one who asked them. —I don't know what you're talking about! I don't understand.

en: After such imaginary discourse, the passenger in his fancy would dig, and dig, dig—now with a spade, now with a great key, now with his hands—to dig this wretched creature out. Got out at last, with earth hanging about his face and hair, he would suddenly fan away to dust. The passenger would then start to himself, and lower the window, to get the reality of mist and rain on his cheek.
vi: After such an imaginary conversation, the passenger in his dream would dig, dig, and dig - sometimes using a shovel, sometimes using a large key, sometimes using his bare hands - to unearth that wretched person from the ground. Finally, that person stepped out of the grave, with dirt clinging to his face and hair, and suddenly he vanished into dust. At that moment, the guest startled awake from the dream, lowered the window to let the mist and rain hit his cheeks, and returned to reality.
tr: After this imaginary conversation, the passenger, still in his dream, dug the earth to get this poor creature out – first with a shovel, then with a huge key, and finally with his hands. The man finally emerged, his face and eyes covered in soil, and as soon as he emerged, he blended into a cloud of dust. At that very moment, the passenger came to his senses and wanted to lower the window to feel the reality of the mist and rain on his cheeks.
es: The traveler interrupted these imaginary discourses to dig, dig without respite or rest, sometimes with a hoe, sometimes with a shovel, at times with an immense key, and at others with his own nails, in his eagerness to unearth the one who had been prematurely buried. Exhausted at last, lacking strength, he would fall face down on the disturbed earth, and at the touch of it on his forehead, he would wake up startled and lower the windowpane so that the slashes of fog and rain would bring him from the dream world to reality. However, he did not achieve his goal.

en: Yet even when his eyes were opened on the mist and rain, on the moving patch of light from the lamps, and the hedge at the roadside retreating by jerks, the night shadows outside the coach would fall into the train of the night shadows within. The real Banking-house by Temple Bar, the real business of the past day, the real strong rooms, the real express sent after him, and the real message returned, would all be there. Out of the midst of them, the ghostly face would rise, and he would accost it again.
vi: However, when his eyes widened to look into the misty rain, at the moving lights of the car lamps, and at the fence by the roadside receding into the distance, the dark shadows outside the night still blended into the chain of spirits in the carriage. The real bank near Temple Bar, the actual work of yesterday, the real bank vaults, the urgent messages that had chased him, and the reply messages, all remained intact. From within that chaos, the ghostly face reappeared, and he started a conversation with it. −
tr: Even though the traveler's eyes were open due to the fog and rain, the flickering light of the lamps and the trembling fences by the roadside caused the night shadows outside the car to blend with the shadows inside. The real bank next to Temple Bar, the real work he did the other day, the real vault underground, the real message sent to him, and the real reply he sent, they were all there. Then the ghostly face would reappear among them, and once again, it would approach him and ask.
es: Flanking the road, fleeing before the uncertain glow of the carriage lanterns, he saw the same images brought to life by his excited imagination. Before his eyes rose the Tellson Bank, his hands paid bills and checks, he walked through the underground chambers, visited the vault, and suddenly the ghosts with livid faces and white hair appeared before him, and the previous interrogation repeated itself:

en: “Buried how long?”
vi: How long has it been buried?
tr: "How long have you been buried?""
es: —When did they bury you?

en: “Almost eighteen years.”
vi: − Nearly eighteen years. −
tr: "Almost eighteen years.""
es: —It was almost eighteen years ago.

en: “I hope you care to live?”
vi: Do you still wish to live? −
tr: "I hope you want to be resurrected."
es: —I suppose you would be interested in living?

en: “I can’t say.”
vi: It's hard to say.
tr: "I don't know."
es: —I can't say it.

en: Dig—dig—dig—until an impatient movement from one of the two passengers would admonish him to pull up the window, draw his arm securely through the leathern strap, and speculate upon the two slumbering forms, until his mind lost its hold of them, and they again slid away into the bank and the grave.
vi: Dig... dig... dig... until an impatient gesture from one of his two companions reminded him to close the window tightly, secure his arm through the leather strap, and then ponder over the two figures dozing off, until his mind wandered again and everything turned into a bank and a grave. −
tr: One of the other two passengers fidgeted impatiently until he politely asked him to close the window, then he examined the two dozing people after securing his arm in the leather loop, until his mind wandered back to the bank and the grave.
es: And back to digging, and digging, and digging, until one of his travel companions indicated to him, somewhat brusquely, to raise the window glass. He then tried to focus his thoughts on his two travel companions; but it didn't take long for him to forget them and return to being absorbed in thoughts of the Bank and the grave.

en: “Buried how long?”
vi: How long has it been buried?
tr: "How long have you been buried?""
es: —When did they bury you?

en: “Almost eighteen years.”
vi: − Nearly eighteen years. −
tr: "Almost eighteen years.""
es: —It was almost eighteen years ago.

en: “You had abandoned all hope of being dug out?”
vi: Have you given up all hope of exhuming it?
tr: "Did you still have hope of being released?""
es: —Had you lost hope that they would unearth you?

en: “Long ago.”
vi: − Long ago.
tr: "My hope had long been exhausted.""
es: —A very long time ago.

en: The words were still in his hearing as just spoken—distinctly in his hearing as ever spoken words had been in his life—when the weary passenger started to the consciousness of daylight, and found that the shadows of the night were gone.
vi: Those words still echoed in the ears as if they had just been spoken - clearly audible as if those words had been uttered in real life - when this weary traveler began to realize that dawn had broken, and the ghosts and specters had vanished.
tr: The weary traveler, upon perceiving the daylight and realizing that the shadows of the night had vanished, still heard the words ringing in his ears – he could literally hear them all.
es: The words still rang in his ears, as clear and distinct as he had ever heard in his life, when he suddenly realized that the shadows of the night had fled in shame before the splendors of the new day.

en: He lowered the window, and looked out at the rising sun. There was a ridge of ploughed land, with a plough upon it where it had been left last night when the horses were unyoked; beyond, a quiet coppice-wood, in which many leaves of burning red and golden yellow still remained upon the trees. Though the earth was cold and wet, the sky was clear, and the sun rose bright, placid, and beautiful.
vi: He rolled down the window, looking out at the rising sun. Outside was a patch of farmland with a furrow left unfinished from last night when the horses had been unhitched; in the distance was a quiet grove of low trees, many leaves having turned red and golden still clinging to the branches. Though the ground was still cold and wet, the sky was clear and the sun rose bright, serene, and radiant.
tr: He rolled down the window and watched the rising sun. A plowed field stretched out on the hill ahead, with a plow left behind by horses in the middle; further beyond, a silent grove still covered with fiery red and golden yellow leaves extended. Even though the ground was cold and wet, the sky was perfectly clear, and the sun was rising slowly, shining brightly in all its beauty.
es: He rolled down the window and gazed at the bright disk of the sun. Embedded in the furrow of a field next to the road, he saw a plow. Beyond that, a grove full of trees could be seen, in whose branches many leaves remained, to which the king star gave red and golden tones. The ground was damp, the sky clear, and the sun rose solemn, placid, sparkling, beautiful.

en: “Eighteen years!” said the passenger, looking at the sun. “Gracious Creator of day! To be buried alive for eighteen years!”
vi: − Eighteen years! - The guest exclaimed while looking at the sun. - Thank God! Eighteen years buried alive!
tr: "Eighteen years!" said the traveler, looking at the sun. "My God! He was buried alive for a full eighteen years!"
es: —Eighteen years!—exclaimed the traveler, his eyes fixed on the sun.— My God... My God! Buried alive for eighteen years!

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: 4. Preparation
tr: IV
es: IV.

en: The Preparation
vi: 4. Preparation
tr: Preparation
es: THE PREPARATION

en: When the mail got successfully to Dover, in the course of the forenoon, the head drawer at the Royal George Hotel opened the coach-door as his custom was. He did it with some flourish of ceremony, for a mail journey from London in winter was an achievement to congratulate an adventurous traveller upon.
vi: When the mail coach arrived in Dover in the morning, the Manager of the Royal George Hotel opened the coach door out of habit. He pulled the door with a somewhat ceremonious gesture because a mail coach from London arriving in winter was an achievement worth celebrating for the daring traveler on board.
tr: When the stagecoach arrived safely in Dover before noon, it was the head waiter of the Royal George Hotel who opened the door, as usual. Since traveling from London to Dover on a winter's day was not something everyone could accomplish, the passengers who managed it were always greeted with a ceremonious air.
es: When the stagecoach arrived in Dover, on time and without mishap, the chief steward of the King George Hotel hurried to open the door, as was his custom. He managed to give his action a certain solemn and ceremonious air, and indeed it was deserved, for truly worthy of all congratulations and well-wishes was the fortunate traveler who, in the middle of winter, undertook and successfully completed such a perilous feat as a stagecoach journey from London to Dover.

en: By that time, there was only one adventurous traveller left be congratulated: for the two others had been set down at their respective roadside destinations. The mildewy inside of the coach, with its damp and dirty straw, its disagreeable smell, and its obscurity, was rather like a larger dog-kennel. Mr. Lorry, the passenger, shaking himself out of it in chains of straw, a tangle of shaggy wrapper, flapping hat, and muddy legs, was rather like a larger sort of dog.
vi: At that time, there was only one daring passenger left to celebrate as the other two had successively disembarked at destinations along the way. The carriage was damp with wet, filthy straw, an unpleasant odor, and darkness that made the inside no different from a large dog kennel. Shaking off the straw clinging to his boots, Mr. Lorry, that passenger, in his shaggy fur coat, soft-brimmed hat, and mud-covered feet, also looked like a large dog. −
tr: There was only one passenger to be met that day; because the other two passengers had gotten off along the way, near the places they were going. The damp and dirty, straw-filled and moldy carriage, with its unpleasant smell and dimness, was more like a large dog kennel. As our passenger Mr. Lorry got off, shaking off the straw that clung to him, he resembled a big dog with his furry scarf, drooping hat, and muddy legs.
es: The refined and accomplished butler could only congratulate a single traveler, simply because only one was in the carriage: the others had stayed at their respective destinations. The interior of the coach, dirty, full of straw and foul-smelling, looked more like a dark kennel than anything else, and Mr. Lorry, who occupied it, when he got out, shaking off the straw and filth that covered his clothing, wrapped in an old and dirty coat, wearing a battered hat and high boots covered in mud, looked more like a giant breed dog than a man.

en: “There will be a packet to Calais, tomorrow, drawer?”
vi: Is there a mail coach to Calais tomorrow, Mr. Superintendent? −
tr: "There's a ferry to Calais tomorrow, right chief?""
es: —Will a ship leave for Calais tomorrow, steward?—he asked.

en: “Yes, sir, if the weather holds and the wind sets tolerable fair. The tide will serve pretty nicely at about two in the afternoon, sir. Bed, sir?”
vi: Yes, if the weather is good and the wind is favorable. The tide will be very convenient for the ship to set sail around two in the afternoon, sir. Rest immediately? −
tr: "Yes sir, if the weather stays like this and the wind doesn't pick up, it will depart. In the afternoon, around two o'clock, the tide will be suitable for the journey, sir. Would you like a room, sir?"
es: —It will sail, sir, if the good weather continues and a favorable wind blows. Does the gentleman desire a bed?

en: “I shall not go to bed till night; but I want a bedroom, and a barber.”
vi: We can only rest in the evening; but we need a room and a barber right away.
tr: "I won't sleep yet, but I want a room and a barber."
es: —I don't plan to go to bed until night; but I need a room and a barber.

en: “And then breakfast, sir? Yes, sir. That way, sir, if you please. Show Concord! Gentleman’s valise and hot water to Concord. Pull off gentleman’s boots in Concord. (You will find a fine sea-coal fire, sir.) Fetch barber to Concord. Stir about there, now, for Concord!”
vi: − And having breakfast, sir? Yes, please. This way, sir, please. Take the guest to the Concord room! Bring the gentleman's luggage and hot water to the Concord room. Take off the gentleman's shoes in the Concord room. (You will find a very warm coal fireplace there, sir.) Call the barber to the Concord room. Hurry up, to the Concord room!
tr: "Would you like breakfast, sir? Very well, sir. This way, please, sir. Take the gentleman to Concord! Carry his luggage to Concord, prepare the hot water. Take off the gentleman's boots and leave them in Concord. (I am lighting the fireplace now, sir.) Call the barber to Concord quickly. Come on, everyone to Concord!"
es: —And lunch afterwards, sir? Very well... This way, sir. The Concordia for this gentleman...! The luggage of this gentleman to the Concordia...! Hot water to the Concordia!... Let a barber go up to the Concordia immediately!... In the Concordia, you will find, sir, a pleasant fire.

en: The Concord bed-chamber being always assigned to a passenger by the mail, and passengers by the mail being always heavily wrapped up from head to foot, the room had the odd interest for the establishment of the Royal George, that although but one kind of man was seen to go into it, all kinds and varieties of men came out of it. Consequently, another drawer, and two porters, and several maids and the landlady, were all loitering by accident at various points of the road between the Concord and the coffee-room, when a gentleman of sixty, formally dressed in a brown suit of clothes, pretty well worn, but very well kept, with large square cuffs and large flaps to the pockets, passed along on his way to his breakfast.
vi: The Concord room is always reserved for the mail coach passengers, and every mail coach passenger is always wrapped up from head to toe, so the peculiar feature of this room in the Royal George Hotel is that everyone looks the same going in, but coming out, they are all different types of people. Therefore, another manager, two porters, several maids, and the landlady who happened to be scattered between the Concord room and the dining room encountered a distinguished gentleman in his sixties, dressed in a formal brown suit, though worn but still neat, with large square cuffs and wide flapped pockets, on his way to have breakfast.
tr: They always gave Concord to the stagecoach passengers, and they all entered wrapped from head to toe. Royal George attached great importance to this room, and although these guests entered in uniform, they would emerge as completely different men. That is why, as the sixty-year-old gentleman, formally dressed in his rather old but well-kept brown suit with wide square cuffs and large pocket flaps, proceeded towards the breakfast table, another waiter, two luggage-carrying boys, a bunch of servants, and the hotel proprietress were lingering at various points between Concord and the dining room as if by coincidence.
es: The room known by the name of Concordia, which was invariably assigned to one of the travelers arriving by coach, offered a special interest. No one ever noticed the slightest difference between the various characters who entered it, for no human eye ever distinguished anything other than a travel coat, worn over usually dirty shoes, and topped by a hat almost always old and battered; but if it always seemed to be the same individual entering Concordia, over the years men of all ages, types, figures, and appearances emerged from it. It is not, therefore, surprising that chance led to the path between Concordia and the dining room being occupied by two butlers, three waiters, and several maids, not to mention the owner of the establishment herself, all of whom were engaged in various domestic tasks, when from the mentioned room emerged a gentleman of about sixty years, dressed in a dark-colored suit, almost new and very well preserved, and sporting very large square cuffs, although not larger nor squarer than the wallets that adorned his pockets.

en: The coffee-room had no other occupant, that forenoon, than the gentleman in brown. His breakfast-table was drawn before the fire, and as he sat, with its light shining on him, waiting for the meal, he sat so still, that he might have been sitting for his portrait.
vi: The dining room had no other guests that morning besides the nobleman in the brown coat. The dining table was pulled up in front of the fireplace, and while he sat waiting for his meal in the firelight, he remained so still that one might have thought he was posing for a portrait.
tr: That morning, besides this brown-haired man, there was no one in the dining room. His table had been pulled in front of the fireplace, the light of the fire cast upon him, and he sat so motionless while waiting for his breakfast that anyone seeing him would think he was posing for his portrait.
es: The gentleman in the dark suit headed to the dining room, and he was the only one who sat at the table that morning. They had placed it next to the fireplace, and by the warmth of the fire, our traveler sat, with one hand on each knee, waiting to be served breakfast, in such a rigid and composed manner that it seemed as if he had taken a seat to have his portrait painted.

en: Very orderly and methodical he looked, with a hand on each knee, and a loud watch ticking a sonorous sermon under his flapped waist-coat, as though it pitted its gravity and longevity against the levity and evanescence of the brisk fire. He had a good leg, and was a little vain of it, for his brown stockings fitted sleek and close, and were of a fine texture; his shoes and buckles, too, though plain, were trim. He wore an odd little sleek crisp flaxen wig, setting very close to his head: which wig, it is to be presumed, was made of hair, but which looked far more as though it were spun from filaments of silk or glass. His linen, though not of a fineness in accordance with his stockings, was as white as the tops of the waves that broke upon the neighbouring beach, or the specks of sail that glinted in the sunlight far at sea. A face habitually suppressed and quieted, was still lighted up under the quaint wig by a pair of moist bright eyes that it must have cost their owner, in years gone by, some pains to drill to the composed and reserved expression of Tellson’s Bank. He had a healthy colour in his cheeks, and his face, though lined, bore few traces of anxiety. But, perhaps the confidential bachelor clerks in Tellson’s Bank were principally occupied with the cares of other people; and perhaps second-hand cares, like second-hand clothes, come easily off and on.
vi: He looked very upright and neat with his hands placed on his knees, the pocket watch under his buttoned jacket ticking loudly and steadily as if it were arrogantly comparing its own dignity and longevity with the playful and ephemeral nature of the flickering firelight. He had strong legs and was somewhat proud of them, as his brown socks were of the finest quality, tightly woven and clinging to his calves; his shoes and buckles, though simple, were elegant. He wore a small wig of a strange brownish-yellow color, tightly curled on both sides and unusually shiny, fitting snugly to his head - wigs are usually made from human hair, but this one seemed to be spun from silk or fiberglass. Though not made of fine fabric like his socks, his shirt was as white as the waves crashing near the hotel, or like the sparkling spots of a sail in the distant sunlight. Underneath that peculiar wig, his calm face, accustomed to restraining emotions, still shone thanks to his bright, wet eyes; over the years, those eyes must have struggled greatly to master the expression of composure and indifference typical of a Tellson's Bank employee. His cheeks were rosy and healthy, his face lined with wrinkles but showing little sign of worry. Perhaps because the solitary employees at Tellson's mainly concerned themselves with other people's affairs, these non-personal concerns, like clothes passed down through two owners, were often easily changed.
tr: With his loud clock ticking under his closed vest like a pompous sermon, countering the nimbleness and gradual disappearance of the lively fire with its own weight and longevity, he looked extremely neat and meticulous while sitting with both hands on his knees. His legs looked good, and he seemed to take pride in that; his tight brown stockings were very shapely and of good quality; his shoes and buckles were simple but very elegant. On his head was a small, light yellow, shiny, spotless, peculiar wig; it was probably made of hair but looked as if it were spun from silk or glass threads. His shirt, though not as high-quality as his stockings, was as white as the foam of waves crashing on the neighboring shore or a sailboat shining under the sun out at sea. Although his face had been subdued and silenced for years, it was illuminated by a pair of moist, bright eyes under that strange wig, and who knows what pains this face had endured until it adopted the distant and dignified expression of Tellson Bank. His cheeks had a healthy color, and the worry lines on his face were almost nonexistent. Perhaps the real occupation of this reliable bachelor clerk of Tellson Bank was other people's problems; second-hand troubles, like second-hand clothes, transient troubles.
es: He seemed like a methodical and orderly man. From the depths of his vest pocket, a watch of extraordinarily large size let its powerful and sonorous voice be heard, whose undeniable gravity and longevity resembled a noisy and eloquent protest against the lightness and futility of the fire burning in the fireplace. The gentleman had good calves, and it is possible that he was proud of them, judging by the stockings that encased them, of the same tone as his suit, made of very fine material and perfectly fitted. His shoes, which adorned beautiful buckles, although of common class, revealed the hand of a skilled and experienced shoemaker. Perfectly fitted to his head, he wore a small, very fine, and slightly curly wig, which, one might suppose, was made of hair, although to tell the truth, it more closely resembled filaments of silk or glass. As for his shirt, if in fineness it could not compete with his stockings, in whiteness it rivaled the crests of the waves that gently came to kiss the sand of the nearby beach, or the sails that shone offshore in the rays of the sun. Adding animation to that face of tranquil expression, or rather, that expressionless face, for the persistent hand of habit had erased any expression from it, were two penetrating eyes, though a little soft, which in past years must have given their owner quite some trouble before he managed to tame them and give them that impenetrable reserve and composure that was characteristic of all the employees of Tellson's Bank. On the face, healthy in color though furrowed with numerous wrinkles, the anxieties and worries had left no traces, perhaps because the old bachelors employed at Tellson's Bank never concerned themselves with anything other than the affairs of other people, and those affairs are like used gloves, which go in and out without effort.

en: Completing his resemblance to a man who was sitting for his portrait, Mr. Lorry dropped off to sleep. The arrival of his breakfast roused him, and he said to the drawer, as he moved his chair to it:
vi: The stiffness of someone posing for a portrait was gone, Mr. Lorry dozed off and only woke up when breakfast was brought in. As he moved his chair closer to the dining table, he said to the attendant: − I want to have a large room prepared for a young lady who may arrive here at any time today.
tr: Mr. Lorry, after sitting for a while like someone having their portrait painted, began to doze off. Then, with the arrival of his breakfast, he woke up and said to the waiter as he pulled his chair forward:
es: Mr. Lorry eventually fell asleep. He woke up when lunch was served and said to the waiter who was serving him:

en: “I wish accommodation prepared for a young lady who may come here at any time to-day. She may ask for Mr. Jarvis Lorry, or she may only ask for a gentleman from Tellson’s Bank. Please to let me know.”
vi: As he moved his chair closer to the dining table, he said to the attendant: − I want to have a large room prepared for a young lady who may arrive here at any time today. She may ask for Mr. Jarvis Lorry, or she may simply ask for a gentleman from Tellson's Bank. Let me know when she arrives. −
tr: "Can you prepare a room for a young lady who might come here today? She may ask you about Mr. Jarvis Lorry or a gentleman from Tellson Bank. Please inform me."
es: —I want a room prepared for a young lady who will probably arrive today, though I don't know at what time. She might ask for Mr. Maurice Lorry, although it could also happen that she asks for the gentleman from Tellson's Bank: in either case, notify me.

en: “Yes, sir. Tellson’s Bank in London, sir?”
vi: Yes, sir. Tellson's Bank in London? −
tr: "Of course, sir. The Tellson Bank in London, sir?"
es: —It's very well, sir. The Tellson Bank of London, sir?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Yes, sir. We have oftentimes the honour to entertain your gentlemen in their travelling backwards and forwards betwixt London and Paris, sir. A vast deal of travelling, sir, in Tellson and Company’s House.”
vi: − Yes, sir. We have also had the honor of welcoming many gentlemen from this bank who travel back and forth between London and Paris many times, sir. They often go, sir, the people of Tellson's and the Society.
tr: "Of course, sir. We often have the honor of hosting your bank's employees here as they travel between London and Paris. The employees of Tellson and Company travel so much, sir."
es: —Yes. —We have often had the honor of serving the gentlemen of that Bank, sir, on their repeated journeys between London and Paris, and vice versa. Ah! Tellson's Bank and Company travels a lot, sir!

en: “Yes. We are quite a French House, as well as an English one.”
vi: − Correct. Our company operates both in France and in England. −
tr: "Yes." "We have branches both in England and France.""
es: —True. Our house is as French as it is English.

en: “Yes, sir. Not much in the habit of such travelling yourself, I think, sir?”
vi: Yes. And you probably don't travel far often, do you, sir? −
tr: "Yes, sir. But you don't travel that much, do you, sir?"
es: —But if I'm not mistaken, you don't usually travel much, sir.

en: “Not of late years. It is fifteen years since we—since I—came last from France.”
vi: Not in recent years. It's been fifteen years since we... since I... last came back from France.
tr: "I haven't been doing it much in recent years. Our – I mean my – last return from France was fifteen years ago."
es: —Very little in recent years. It must have been... fifteen years since I last went to France.

en: “Indeed, sir? That was before my time here, sir. Before our people’s time here, sir. The George was in other hands at that time, sir.”
vi: − Really, sir? That was before I started working here, sir. Before all of us worked here, sir. At that time, this George Hotel belonged to a different owner, sir. − I think so too. −
tr: "Is that so, sir? I wasn't working here in those times, sir. There wasn't anyone from us even, sir. The George Hotel belonged to other people back then, sir."
es: —I wasn't here on that date, sir... Neither I nor any of us who are here today. The Hotel del Rey Jorge had different owners, sir.

en: “I believe so.”
vi: At that time, this George Hotel belonged to a different owner, sir. − I think so too. −
tr: "So that's how it is."
es: —I believe so.

en: “But I would hold a pretty wager, sir, that a House like Tellson and Company was flourishing, a matter of fifty, not to speak of fifteen years ago?”
vi: But sir, I dare say that a company like Tellson and Company has been prosperous for fifty years, let alone fifteen years ago?
tr: "But I bet you, sir, that a company like Tellson and Partners was not only big fifteen years ago, but even fifty years ago.""
es: —On the other hand, I would bet without fear of losing, that a house like Tellson's Bank and Company has been prospering and flourishing, not just for fifteen years, but for fifty.

en: “You might treble that, and say a hundred and fifty, yet not be far from the truth.”
vi: − You could say three times that, one hundred and fifty years, and still not be wrong.
tr: "Actually, you can triple this number; in fact, it was large even a hundred and fifty years ago.""
es: —You can bet and say one hundred and fifty, without fear of losing and with the knowledge that you are very close to the truth.

en: “Indeed, sir!”
vi: − Really, sir?
tr: "Certainly, sir!""
es: —One hundred fifty years!

en: Rounding his mouth and both his eyes, as he stepped backward from the table, the waiter shifted his napkin from his right arm to his left, dropped into a comfortable attitude, and stood surveying the guest while he ate and drank, as from an observatory or watchtower. According to the immemorial usage of waiters in all ages.
vi: Eyes wide and mouth agape, the servant stepped back from the dining table, shifted the towel from his right arm to his left, adopted a more comfortable stance, and observed the guest eating as if he were standing on a watchtower or guard post. In accordance with the age-old habits of the waiting profession.
tr: As the waiter backed away from the table, he rounded his mouth and eyes as if in amazement, and shifted the napkin from his right arm to his left, assuming a comfortable position. Then, as his guest ate breakfast, he stood watching him as if he were in an observatory or a watchtower. With the centuries-old tradition of waitering.
es: Opening his eyes wide and forming his mouth into a perfect O, the waiter adopted the classic posture, passed the napkin from his right arm to his left, and remained silent, watching the traveler eat and drink, as waiters have been doing since time immemorial in all centuries and countries.

en: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and brought the coast down, madly. The air among the houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever, sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.
vi: After finishing his breakfast, Mr. Lorry went out for a walk on the beach. The city of Dover, winding, narrow, and small, nestled far from the shore, with one end jutting straight out to the chalk cliffs like an ostrich burying its head in the sea. The desolate beach had only waves tossing stones around; the sea did whatever it pleased, and its pleasure was destruction. The sea thundered down on the city, thundered down on the cliffs, and furiously pounded the shore. The air between the houses was so fishy that one might think all the sick fish had come to soak themselves in the city just like sick people soaking in the seawater. Few people fished in this harbor, but at night many loitered around and looked out to sea - especially during high tides and near floods. Many petty traders who did no business at all sometimes inexplicably amassed great fortunes, and it was noteworthy that no one in this area was comfortable with the night lamp lighter*.
tr: When Mr. Lorry finished his breakfast, he went for a walk by the seaside. The small town of Dover, with its winding streets, was hidden from the shore, burying its head in the white hillside like an ostrich. The shore resembled a desert where the stones rolled with the swelling waves of the sea, and the sea did whatever it wanted, which was to wreak havoc. Its roar echoed in the town, on the hillside, everywhere, turning the shore upside down. A heavy fish smell enveloped the houses so much that one would think all the sick fish had risen to the surface of the sea to mix with this air, unlike the sick people who sank to the bottom of the sea to merge with it. There was a bit of fishing in the harbor, and in the evenings, especially when the waters rose and flooded the surroundings, the place would become quite lively with walkers and sea watchers. The small tradesmen, who didn't do much business, sometimes – somehow – made great fortunes, and at those times everyone stayed away from the lighthouse keepers.
es: After lunch, Mr. Lorry went out for a little walk along the beach. The small and irregular town of Dover was not visible from there, except for its rooftops which, nestled among the peaks of limestone quarries, resembled a gigantic marine oyster. The beach was a desert bristling with rocks and plagued with reefs, where the sea did whatever it pleased, and what it invariably pleased to do was destroy. Almost continuously, it roared against the town, bellowed against the cliffs, charged against the rocks that tried to block its path and knocked them down with a crash. In the houses, there was such a strong smell of fish that it seemed as if the inhabitants of the waters came out to cure their illnesses in the houses, just as sick people often seek health in sea baths. A few, very few, engaged in fishing in those waters, and if during the day the beach was always deserted, at night, on the other hand, people could be seen staring anxiously into the vastness of the sea. Insignificant merchants who were never seen doing business suddenly amassed immense fortunes that had no rational explanation, and it was very noticeable that no one in those places could tolerate the presence of a light, from which they fled as if from the devil.

en: As the day declined into the afternoon, and the air, which had been at intervals clear enough to allow the French coast to be seen, became again charged with mist and vapour, Mr. Lorry’s thoughts seemed to cloud too. When it was dark, and he sat before the coffee-room fire, awaiting his dinner as he had awaited his breakfast, his mind was busily digging, digging, digging, in the live red coals.
vi: When the day had turned to evening, the sky, which had occasionally cleared up enough to see the shores of France across the sea, was now shrouded in mist, and Mr. Lorry's thoughts seemed to be just as foggy. As night fell, he sat before the dining room fireplace waiting for his meal, just as he had waited for breakfast that morning, his mind busy digging, digging, and digging into the glowing embers.
tr: As the hours passed and the weather, which occasionally cleared enough to show the French coast, was once again shrouded in mist and humidity, Mr. Lorry's thoughts also began to cloud over. When night fell, as he sat in front of the fireplace at the dining table waiting for his dinner, just as he had waited for his breakfast, his mind dug, dug, and dug at the red-hot coals without ceasing.
es: As the afternoon declined, and the air, so diaphanous and transparent during the day that there were moments when the coasts of France could be perfectly seen, became saturated with vapors and mists, Mr. Lorry's thoughts also darkened. When, as night fell, he sat by the warmth of the dining room fire to wait for his meal to be served, just as he had waited that morning for his breakfast, his imagination dug, dug without rest.

en: A bottle of good claret after dinner does a digger in the red coals no harm, otherwise than as it has a tendency to throw him out of work. Mr. Lorry had been idle a long time, and had just poured out his last glassful of wine with as complete an appearance of satisfaction as is ever to be found in an elderly gentleman of a fresh complexion who has got to the end of a bottle, when a rattling of wheels came up the narrow street, and rumbled into the inn-yard.
vi: A good bottle of red wine after dinner does no harm to that coal miner, except that the alcohol makes him distracted from his digging. He had been sitting there for a long time and had just poured the last glass with a completely satisfied expression - often seen in elderly people with rosy complexions who have just finished a bottle - when the sound of clattering wheels echoed on the narrow road and then thundered into the hotel yard.
tr: A bottle of red wine to be drunk after dinner would not harm someone who had plunged into the red-hot flames; at another time, it might have distracted him from his work. After lingering for quite a while, Mr. Lorry had reached the bottom of the bottle and filled his last glass with the pleasure an old but lively man might feel, when the sound of wheels rose from the narrow street and its noise reached the front of the hotel.
es: A bottle of aged claret does not harm the health of a good digger, although it may hinder his activity, if it is true, as they say, that claret, especially if it is good and aged, inoculates in the drinker a marked tendency to suspend all kinds of physical work. Mr. Lorry had long since suspended all his operations and had just poured the last liquid remaining in the bottle into his glass, his face revealing all the satisfaction that an elderly gentleman can show upon seeing the bottom of a bottle, when his ears were struck by the rapid rolling of a carriage entering the narrow alley and stopping within the hotel courtyard.

en: He set down his glass untouched. “This is Mam’selle!” said he.
vi: He placed the untouched glass of wine down. − The young lady has arrived! - He exclaimed.
tr: He left his drink on the table without touching it. "This must be Mademoiselle!" he said.
es: —The young lady!—exclaimed Lorry, setting down the glass he was about to raise to his lips.

en: In a very few minutes the waiter came in to announce that Miss Manette had arrived from London, and would be happy to see the gentleman from Tellson’s.
vi: Just a few minutes later, the waiter from earlier came in to announce that Miss Manette from London had arrived and was ready to meet the gentleman from Tellson's Bank. −
tr: Not long after, the waiter came in and informed that Miss Manette had arrived from London and wanted to see the person from Tellson's Bank.
es: Moments later, the waiter entered the dining room and announced that Miss Manette, newly arrived from London, wished to see the gentleman from Tellson's Bank.

en: “So soon?”
vi: So soon?
tr: "How quickly!"
es: —So soon?

en: Miss Manette had taken some refreshment on the road, and required none then, and was extremely anxious to see the gentleman from Tellson’s immediately, if it suited his pleasure and convenience.
vi: − Miss Manette had already taken a break on the way, so she did not need to rest and was very eager to meet the gentleman from Tellson's Bank immediately, if it was convenient and comfortable for him.
tr: Miss Manette did not want to eat anything now because she had snacked on the road, and if possible, she wanted to meet with the Tellson's employee as soon as possible.
es: —Miss Manette has had some refreshment on the way, and the only thing she now truly longs for is to see the gentleman from Tellson's Bank without any delay, provided he is willing to visit her.

en: The gentleman from Tellson’s had nothing left for it but to empty his glass with an air of stolid desperation, settle his odd little flaxen wig at the ears, and follow the waiter to Miss Manette’s apartment. It was a large, dark room, furnished in a funereal manner with black horsehair, and loaded with heavy dark tables. These had been oiled and oiled, until the two tall candles on the table in the middle of the room were gloomily reflected on every leaf; as if they were buried, in deep graves of black mahogany, and no light to speak of could be expected from them until they were dug out.
vi: The gentleman from Tellson's Bank didn't know what else to do but to down his drink with a hidden look of despair, smooth down the sides of his oddly small, tawny wig, and follow the waiter to Miss Manette. It was a large, gloomy room, full of a mournful atmosphere, furnished with black horsehair-upholstered chairs and several heavy, dark-colored tables. The tables had been polished many times, yet the two tall candles on the main table in the center of the room only cast a faint reflection on every surface; it was as if the candles themselves were buried in the deep grave of the dark mahogany wood, with no hope of light unless their bodies were exhumed.
tr: There was nothing to be done, the Tellson employee, in a state of indifferent despair, downed the last glass, pulled his small and peculiar light yellow wig over his ears, and then followed the waiter to Miss Manette's room. It was a large and dark room, reminiscent of funeral parlors, covered with horsehair fabrics and dark-colored tables. The tables were so polished that the dim light from the two long candles on the table in the center reflected on every grain of the wood; it was as if the candles were buried deep in black mahogany graves and couldn't give proper light until they were unearthed.
es: The only recourse left for the gentleman from Tellson's Bank was to empty the glass with a gesture of stolid desperation, adjust his silky wig over his ears, and follow the waiter, who guided him to Miss Manette's room. It was a large room, very dark, draped in black like a funeral chapel, and furnished with dark-toned objects, among which could be counted a number of tables, all heavy and all black. On the one in the center, smeared, like all the others, a thousand times with oil, there were two candlesticks, also black, whose light was not enough to dispel the darkness that reigned supreme in the room.

en: The obscurity was so difficult to penetrate that Mr. Lorry, picking his way over the well-worn Turkey carpet, supposed Miss Manette to be, for the moment, in some adjacent room, until, having got past the two tall candles, he saw standing to receive him by the table between them and the fire, a young lady of not more than seventeen, in a riding-cloak, and still holding her straw travelling-hat by its ribbon in her hand. As his eyes rested on a short, slight, pretty figure, a quantity of golden hair, a pair of blue eyes that met his own with an inquiring look, and a forehead with a singular capacity (remembering how young and smooth it was), of rifting and knitting itself into an expression that was not quite one of perplexity, or wonder, or alarm, or merely of a bright fixed attention, though it included all the four expressions—as his eyes rested on these things, a sudden vivid likeness passed before him, of a child whom he had held in his arms on the passage across that very Channel, one cold time, when the hail drifted heavily and the sea ran high. The likeness passed away, like a breath along the surface of the gaunt pier-glass behind her, on the frame of which, a hospital procession of negro cupids, several headless and all cripples, were offering black baskets of Dead Sea fruit to black divinities of the feminine gender—and he made his formal bow to Miss Manette.
vi: The room was so dark that Mr. Lorry, while groping his way on the worn-out Turkish carpet, thought that Miss Manette was in an adjacent room. It wasn't until he passed two tall candles that he saw a young girl, no older than seventeen, standing to greet him by the table between them and the fireplace. She was wearing a riding cloak and still holding the ribbon of her straw traveling hat. When his eyes settled on the graceful, pretty figure, with long blonde hair and blue eyes that met his gaze with a questioning look, and a forehead (so youthful and smooth) that had the characteristic of often furrowing into wrinkles not entirely of confusion, surprise, or alarm, but rather of attentive sharpness, though expressing all those emotions - looking at the girl, he suddenly vividly recalled the image of a child he had carried in his arms while crossing this very strait on a cold day of pouring rain and rough seas. That association vanished as quickly as breath on the narrow, long mirror behind the girl, framed by a carved group of pitifully blackened angels, most of them headless and all chipped, offering a blackened basket of Dead Sea fruits to a blackened saint - and so he solemnly bowed to Miss Manette.
tr: The uncertainty that filled the room was so intense that Mr. Lorry, as he moved across the worn Turkish carpet, for a moment thought Miss Manette was in the adjacent room; but after passing the two candles, he saw, beside the table between them and the fireplace, a young lady who couldn't have been more than seventeen, waiting for him with her cloak on and a straw hat with ribbons in her hand. His eyes fixed on this petite, delicate figure, the golden hair, the blue eyes examining him with curiosity, and the forehead shaped by a special expression that reflected neither astonishment, nor curiosity, nor anxiety, nor merely natural interest, but rather a combination of all these (and how young and smooth it was), a scene from the past suddenly flashed before his eyes; it was a cold day, hail was falling, and the sea was very rough, and during the crossing of the English Channel, he had held a child resembling this girl in his arms throughout the journey. Just like a breath dispersing on the surface of the gloomy wall mirror behind the girl, in which some headless, all crippled, black children were lined up and offering Sodom apples in black baskets to black goddesses, his thoughts scattered – and Mr. Lorry greeted Miss Manette with a formal nod.
es: The darkness was so dense that Mr. Lorry, while advancing on a carpet, quite worn out by the way, assumed that the young lady would be in some adjoining room, and he persisted in this belief until, after leaving the two candelabras behind him, he stumbled upon a person who was waiting for him, standing between the table and the fireplace. It was a young woman of about seventeen years of age, dressed in a riding habit, whose hands still held by the ribbon the straw hat she had worn during the journey. As he fixed his eyes on that tiny, perfectly oval face with graceful lines, framed by an abundant mass of golden hair, two blue eyes met his, looking at him with a penetrating gaze and an expression that was neither of perplexity, nor of astonishment, nor of admiration, nor of alarm, although it probably partook of all four. In Mr. Lorry's imagination, as he appreciated the features before him, the figure of a little girl he had carried in his arms many years before on a crossing journey through that same channel with cold weather and extraordinarily rough sea emerged. The image dissipated almost as quickly as the stain produced by breath on the not very clean cornucopia placed behind the young woman, and enclosed in a frame that offered a procession of headless black cupids, many of them limping or maimed, who offered black baskets full of Dead Sea fruits to some black female idols, and he bowed deeply and solemnly before Miss Manette.

en: “Pray take a seat, sir.” In a very clear and pleasant young voice; a little foreign in its accent, but a very little indeed.
vi: Please have a seat, sir. - The youthful voice was very soft and clear, with a slight foreign accent, but only fleetingly so.
tr: "Please have a seat, sir." The girl had a crystal-clear, very sweet, and youthful voice; it had a slight foreign accent, but it wasn't very noticeable.
es: —Please have a seat, sir—said a clear and musical voice, with a foreign accent, though barely noticeable.

en: “I kiss your hand, miss,” said Mr. Lorry, with the manners of an earlier date, as he made his formal bow again, and took his seat.
vi: − May I kiss your hand, Miss, - Mr. Lorry said with old-fashioned politeness as he solemnly bowed again and then sat down.
tr: With the courtesy of old days, bowing slightly in a formal manner, "With your permission, may I kiss your hand, young lady," said Mr. Lorry and then sat back down.
es: —I kiss your hand, miss—replied Mr. Lorry, making another bow in the old-fashioned manner, before taking a seat.

en: “I received a letter from the Bank, sir, yesterday, informing me that some intelligence—or discovery—”
vi: − Yesterday I received a letter from the Bank, sir, informing me that there was news... or a discovery... −
tr: "Yesterday, I received a letter from the bank, sir, about some news – or rather, a discovery."
es: —Yesterday I received a letter from the Bank, sir, in which they told me that it had been found out... or discovered...

en: “The word is not material, miss; either word will do.”
vi: The words are not important, Miss, use whichever you prefer.
tr: "Words have no physical form, young lady, either one works.""
es: —The word is the least important thing, miss: both express the idea.

en: “—respecting the small property of my poor father, whom I never saw—so long dead—”
vi: − ... something about a small inheritance from my poor father whom I never met... who passed away long ago...
tr: "It was about a small property left by my poor father whom I never saw – he passed away a long time ago."
es: —... Something about the few possessions my poor father left behind, whom I had the misfortune of never knowing...

en: Mr. Lorry moved in his chair, and cast a troubled look towards the hospital procession of negro cupids. As if they had any help for anybody in their absurd baskets!
vi: Mr. Lorry fidgeted on his chair and anxiously glanced towards the pitiful black angels carved on the mirror frame. As if they could help with those ridiculous baskets!
tr: Mr. Lorry fidgeted in his chair and glanced uneasily at the black children lined up in the frame of the mirror. As if they could help him by leaving those meaningless baskets!
es: Lorry squirmed in the chair, casting anguished glances at the mournful procession of black cupids, as if hoping to find in the absurd little baskets they carried the light that his intelligence denied him. —...

en: “—rendered it necessary that I should go to Paris, there to communicate with a gentleman of the Bank, so good as to be despatched to Paris for the purpose.”
vi: − ... saying that I need to go to Paris, to contact a gentleman from the bank, who is very trustworthy and has been sent to Paris for this matter.
tr: "I absolutely have to go to Paris, I need to meet with an official from the bank there, and this person will also be in Paris for this reason.""
es: And that, consequently, it was absolutely necessary for me to make a trip to Paris, where I would have to get in touch with a gentleman from the Bank, sent to the capital of France for that purpose.

en: “Myself.”
vi: − That’s me.
tr: "That person is me.""
es: —That gentleman is me, miss.

en: “As I was prepared to hear, sir.”
vi: − Just as I thought, sir.
tr: "I was expecting it to be like this, sir."
es: —I supposed so, sir.

en: She curtseyed to him (young ladies made curtseys in those days), with a pretty desire to convey to him that she felt how much older and wiser he was than she. He made her another bow.
vi: She curtsied to him (back then, young ladies often greeted this way) with the good intention of expressing respect for his age and superior wisdom. He bowed to the girl once more.
tr: The young girl greeted Mr. Lorry with a curtsy (in those days, young ladies would greet like this), as if she wanted to show that the man was much older and wiser than herself. Mr. Lorry also nodded to her once again.
es: The girl made a graceful curtsy (in those times, young ladies made curtsies). The gentleman bowed deeply.

en: “I replied to the Bank, sir, that as it was considered necessary, by those who know, and who are so kind as to advise me, that I should go to France, and that as I am an orphan and have no friend who could go with me, I should esteem it highly if I might be permitted to place myself, during the journey, under that worthy gentleman’s protection. The gentleman had left London, but I think a messenger was sent after him to beg the favour of his waiting for me here.”
vi: − I have replied to the bank, sir, that if knowledgeable people kindly advise, and if necessary, I will go to France. However, since I no longer have parents and no friends who can accompany me, I would be very grateful if I could be protected by such a venerable person on the journey. That gentleman has left London, but I think it is necessary to send a liaison to catch up with him and ask for his consent to wait for me here.
tr: "Then I immediately replied to the bank, sir, thanking them for informing me of this and advising me to go to France, and I asked them to find someone to accompany me since I have no one, saying I would be very pleased if a respectable gentleman could watch over me." "That gentleman had already set off from London; I believe they sent a messenger after him to ask him to wait for me here.""
es: I replied to the Bank that if the people who extend their benevolence towards me to the point of advising me considered the trip necessary, I would certainly go to France, but that, given that I am an orphan and have no friends who can accompany me, I would appreciate it as a special favor if they allowed me to place myself, during the journey, under the protection of the worthy gentleman with whom I was to make contact in Paris. The gentleman had already left London, but I believe they sent a messenger asking him to wait for me here.

en: “I was happy,” said Mr. Lorry, “to be entrusted with the charge. I shall be more happy to execute it.”
vi: − I am very pleased to be entrusted with this responsibility, - Mr. Lorry said. - I am even more pleased to carry it out. −
tr: "I am happy to be deemed worthy of such a task," said Mr. Lorry, and added, "Fulfilling it will be an even greater happiness for me."
es: —I considered myself happy to receive the assignment, and I will consider myself much happier fulfilling it, miss—replied Mr. Lorry.

en: “Sir, I thank you indeed. I thank you very gratefully. It was told me by the Bank that the gentleman would explain to me the details of the business, and that I must prepare myself to find them of a surprising nature. I have done my best to prepare myself, and I naturally have a strong and eager interest to know what they are.”
vi: Thank you sincerely, sir. I am deeply indebted to you. The bank has informed me that the gentleman will explain everything in detail to me, and that I should prepare myself for some shocking revelations. I am already prepared, and of course, I am eager to know what this matter is.
tr: "Thank you very much, sir. I am truly grateful to you. They told me at the bank that this gentleman would explain the matter to me in all its details, and they even said to be prepared to be surprised. But I am ready for everything, and I am almost dying of curiosity."
es: —Thank you very much, sir; believe me, I give them to you from the heart. The Bank informed me that the gentleman would explain the details of the matter to me, and that I should be prepared to receive surprising news. I have done everything possible to prepare myself, and you can be sure that I have a genuine desire to know what it is about.

en: “Naturally,” said Mr. Lorry. “Yes—I—”
vi: − Indeed, - Mr. Lorry said. - Yes... I...
tr: "Of course," said Mr. Lorry, "You are right, I..."
es: —I find it very natural—replied Lorry. —Yes... perfectly natural... I...

en: After a pause, he added, again settling the crisp flaxen wig at the ears, “It is very difficult to begin.”
vi: After a moment of hesitation, he continued speaking while smoothing the sides of his curly brown wig: − It is indeed very difficult to start.
tr: After pausing for a moment, she adjusted her shiny yellow wig back over her ears and added:
es: He paused, adjusted his toupee back over his ears, and finally replied: —The truth is that it is so difficult to begin...

en: He did not begin, but, in his indecision, met her glance. The young forehead lifted itself into that singular expression—but it was pretty and characteristic, besides being singular—and she raised her hand, as if with an involuntary action she caught at, or stayed some passing shadow.
vi: He did not start immediately but hesitated, looking into the girl's eyes. Her youthful forehead furrowed into that distinctive wrinkle - yet still beautiful and full of character - she raised her hand as if in an unconscious reaction, or as if trying to grasp a fleeting illusion.
tr: "I don't know where to start." Gene had fallen silent, but in that moment of hesitation, he met the young girl's gaze. The young forehead had taken on the same special expression again – in addition to being special, it was also sweet and characteristic – and as if trying to catch a shadow, he involuntarily raised his hand.
es: And he did not begin. In his indecision, his eyes met those of his interlocutor. On her forehead, a few wrinkles appeared, her expression changed, and her hand rose to the level of her eyes, as if she wanted to grasp some shadow that had just crossed before them.

en: “Are you quite a stranger to me, sir?”
vi: Surely you have met me before, haven't you?
tr: "Could I possibly know you from somewhere, sir?"
es: —Have we ever met before, sir?—he asked.

en: “Am I not?” Mr. Lorry opened his hands, and extended them outwards with an argumentative smile.
vi: − Really? - Mr. Lorry spread his hands and then extended them with a smile that implied denial.
tr: "Is that so?" Mr. Lorry opened his hands to the sides and smiled mischievously.
es: —Have we ever met before, sir?—he asked. —Do you believe so?—asked Lorry, extending his arms and smiling.

en: Between the eyebrows and just over the little feminine nose, the line of which was as delicate and fine as it was possible to be, the expression deepened itself as she took her seat thoughtfully in the chair by which she had hitherto remained standing. He watched her as she mused, and the moment she raised her eyes again, went on:
vi: Between her eyebrows and right above the petite nose of the young lady, with extremely delicate and slender features, a deep expressive wrinkle appeared as she thoughtfully sat down on the chair she had been standing beside. He looked at the pensive girl and waited for her to look up before continuing: −
