tr: As the young girl settled into the chair she had been standing by for a while with a thoughtful demeanor, the expression on her face, between her eyebrows and above her tiny nose, deepened into the most delicate and pleasant line possible. Mr. Lorry observed the girl lost in thought and continued as soon as he lifted his eyes again:
es: The delicate and fine line that had formed between the girl's eyebrows became deeper and more energetic as she sat down in the chair beside which she had been standing until then. Lorry watched her silently, and when after a while the young woman raised her eyes again, he hastened to ask:

en: “In your adopted country, I presume, I cannot do better than address you as a young English lady, Miss Manette?”
vi: In the country you have adopted as your homeland, I suppose I should call you "Miss" as I do with English ladies, Miss Manette? −
tr: "In this country, which you have accepted as your homeland, the most suitable description for you would probably be an English young lady, wouldn't it?""
es: —I suppose that in your adopted homeland you would like to be treated and spoken to as an English lady; isn't that right, Miss Manette?

en: “If you please, sir.”
vi: Yes, as you wish.
tr: "As you wish, sir."
es: —As you wish, sir.

en: “Miss Manette, I am a man of business. I have a business charge to acquit myself of. In your reception of it, don’t heed me any more than if I was a speaking machine—truly, I am not much else. I will, with your leave, relate to you, miss, the story of one of our customers.”
vi: − Miss Manette, I am a man of business. I have a duty to fulfill. While listening to my presentation, please consider me as nothing more than a talking machine. Miss, allow me to recount the story of one of our clients.
tr: "Miss Manette, I am a businessman. I have tasks that need to be completed. Just see me as a talking machine – I am truly nothing more than that. Now, young lady, with your permission, let me tell you the story of one of our clients."
es: —I am a businessman, Miss Manette, and I have been tasked with handling and successfully completing a business matter. When you hear all the details related to it from my lips, do not see in me anything more than a talking machine, for in truth, a talking machine I am. With your permission, Miss Manette, I will tell you the story of one of our clients.

en: “Story!”
vi: − The story!
tr: "A story?""
es: —History!

en: He seemed wilfully to mistake the word she had repeated, when he added, in a hurry, “Yes, customers; in the banking business we usually call our connection our customers. He was a French gentleman; a scientific gentleman; a man of great acquirements—a Doctor.”
vi: He seemed to deliberately misunderstand the word the girl had just repeated as he hastily continued: − Yes, client; in our banking industry, we often call customers clients. He was a French gentleman; a gentleman in the scientific community; a well-educated and knowledgeable person... a doctor. −
tr: Mr. Lorry hastily added, deliberately twisting the word the girl was emphasizing, "Yes, customers; we call everyone connected with us in the banking sector a customer. This gentleman was French; a scientist; he had achieved great success – he was a Doctor."
es: It seems that Lorry must have mistaken one word for another, for no sooner had his interlocutor repeated the word story than he hastily replied: —Yes, miss: from one of our clients. Those of us who are in the banking business usually call all our acquaintances clients. The client I am referring to was a French gentleman, a man of great talent and intellectual gifts... a doctor.

en: “Not of Beauvais?”
vi: Not from Beauvais, right? −
tr: "Was he from Beauvais?"
es: —Wouldn't it be from Beauvais, huh?

en: “Why, yes, of Beauvais. Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the gentleman was of Beauvais. Like Monsieur Manette, your father, the gentleman was of repute in Paris. I had the honour of knowing him there. Our relations were business relations, but confidential. I was at that time in our French House, and had been—oh! twenty years.”
vi: Oh, yes, from Beauvais. Like your esteemed father, Mr. Manette, this gentleman was also from Beauvais. Like your esteemed father, Mr. Manette, this gentleman was also well-known in Paris. I had the honor of knowing him there. Our relationship was a business one, but very close. At that time, I worked at the branch in France, and it has been... oh! Twenty years.
tr: "Ah yes, he was from Beauvais. Just like your father, Monsieur Manette, this gentleman was also from Beauvais. Again, just like your father, Monsieur Manette, this gentleman was also one of the respected figures of Paris. I had the honor of meeting him there. Our relationship was based on business, but it was secret. At that time, I was in the French branch of the bank, I stayed there for quite a while, that is – oh! twenty years."
es: —Precisely from Beauvais. Just like Mr. Manette, your father, the gentleman in question was from Beauvais: just like Mr. Manette, your father, he was a notable figure in Paris, where I had the honor of meeting him. Our relationship was purely and exclusively business, but confidential. At that time, I was at our French office, and this was... a trifle! Twenty years ago!

en: “At that time—I may ask, at what time, sir?”
tr: "When you say then – exactly what time are you referring to, sir?"
es: —In those times... Excuse my curiosity, sir, but I would like to know...

en: “I speak, miss, of twenty years ago. He married—an English lady—and I was one of the trustees. His affairs, like the affairs of many other French gentlemen and French families, were entirely in Tellson’s hands. In a similar way I am, or I have been, trustee of one kind or other for scores of our customers. These are mere business relations, miss; there is no friendship in them, no particular interest, nothing like sentiment. I have passed from one to another, in the course of my business life, just as I pass from one of our customers to another in the course of my business day; in short, I have no feelings; I am a mere machine. To go on—”
vi: At that time... may I ask, when was that, sir? − I just said, miss, twenty years ago. He married... an English lady... and I was one of the witnesses at the wedding. His personal affairs, like those of many other French gentlemen and French families, were entirely entrusted to Tellson's. Similarly, I am, or have been, entrusted with all sorts of personal matters of the clients. These were purely business relationships, miss; not friendships, no special interests, no emotions at all. Throughout my business life, I moved from one task to another, just as I moved from one client to another in a working day; in short, I had no emotions; I was just a machine. Let me continue... −
tr: "I am talking about twenty years ago, young lady. This gentleman was married to an English lady, and I used to handle his affairs. In fact, all his affairs, like those of all other French gentlemen and families, were handled by Tellson Bank. Similarly, now I look after the various accounts of our clients. These are just business relationships, young lady; they contain neither friendship, nor special interest, nor emotion. Just like the many clients I visit during the day, throughout my entire business life I have always gone from client to client; in short, I have no emotions; I am merely a machine. Where was I..."
es: —I am speaking of twenty years ago, miss. He married an English lady... and I was one of his trustees. The Tellson Bank handled all his business, as it did for almost all French gentlemen and families. Just as I was a trustee for that gentleman, I am or have been for dozens of the firm's clients. These are purely business relations, miss, free of friendship, free of interest, free of affection, relations in which there is nothing that resembles feeling. Throughout my life, I have moved from one to another without any leaving traces or almost any memories in me, exactly the same as I deal with the countless clients who come to the Bank daily with such varied purposes. In a word, miss: I have no feelings, I have no affection for anyone, I am a machine, I am a...

en: “But this is my father’s story, sir; and I begin to think”—the curiously roughened forehead was very intent upon him—“that when I was left an orphan through my mother’s surviving my father only two years, it was you who brought me to England. I am almost sure it was you.”
vi: But it sounds like a story about my father, sir; and I am beginning to think that, - that strangely furrowed brow directed straight at him, - when I was orphaned because my mother died two years after my father, it was you who brought me back to England. I am almost certain it was you.
tr: "But this is my father's story, sir, and if I'm not mistaken," –the girl's forehead wrinkled with curiosity, her gaze fixed intently on the man– "it was you who brought me to England after I lost my mother two years after my father and became an orphan. I'm sure of it."
es: —But you are telling me the story of my father, sir, and I begin to suspect that, when my mother died, who only survived my father by two years, leaving me orphaned and alone in the world, it was you who took me to England. I would almost dare to say that it was you.

en: Mr. Lorry took the hesitating little hand that confidingly advanced to take his, and he put it with some ceremony to his lips. He then conducted the young lady straightway to her chair again, and, holding the chair-back with his left hand, and using his right by turns to rub his chin, pull his wig at the ears, or point what he said, stood looking down into her face while she sat looking up into his.
vi: Mr. Lorry took the small hand that was hesitantly offered to him and raised it to his lips somewhat ceremoniously. Then he immediately helped the young lady to sit down as before, with his left hand holding the back of the chair, his right hand alternately stroking his chin and tugging at the sides of his wig, or gesturing as he spoke, while he looked down at her as she looked up at him.
tr: Mr. Lorry, taking the girl's hand which first extended hesitantly and then confidently, ceremoniously brought it to his lips. Then he led her to her chair and, while holding the back of the chair with his left hand, he alternately stroked his chin, adjusted his wig towards his ears, or pointed to something he was saying; the girl watched from her seat, and Mr. Lorry from where he stood, observing each other.
es: Mr. Lorry took the tiny hand that trustingly sought his, and ceremoniously brought it to his lips.

en: “Miss Manette, it was I. And you will see how truly I spoke of myself just now, in saying I had no feelings, and that all the relations I hold with my fellow-creatures are mere business relations, when you reflect that I have never seen you since. No; you have been the ward of Tellson’s House since, and I have been busy with the other business of Tellson’s House since. Feelings! I have no time for them, no chance of them. I pass my whole life, miss, in turning an immense pecuniary Mangle.”
vi: − Miss Manette, it is indeed I. You will see how sincere I am about myself when I tell you that I have no feelings, and all my dealings with my fellow humans are purely business transactions, if you remember that I have not seen you again. Not at all; since then, you have been cared for by Tellson's, and I have been busy with other matters of Tellson's. Feelings! I have no time, no opportunity for such things. All my life, miss, I have only known how to work for a colossal financial machine.
tr: "Miss Manette, yes it was me. You see how truthful I was when I said I had no feelings and that my connections were purely business, then I never saw you again. But of course, even though I have been involved in various other matters, you have been under the guardianship of Tellson Bank since that time. Feelings! I have no time to spare for them at all. My life has been spent turning a great money wheel."
es: —I was, indeed, Miss Manette—replied Lorry.— The fact that since then I have never seen you again will convince you of the accuracy of my words, will convince you of the truth with which I assured you a moment ago that I have no feelings, and that all the relationships I maintain or have maintained with my fellow beings have been exclusively business-related. No! No sentimentality! You have been since then the ward of Tellson's Bank, and I have had enough to do since then working on the affairs of Tellson's Bank. Feelings! I lack the time and the will to afford myself the luxury of having them! I have spent my entire life moving and turning over immense masses of money.

en: After this odd description of his daily routine of employment, Mr. Lorry flattened his flaxen wig upon his head with both hands (which was most unnecessary, for nothing could be flatter than its shining surface was before), and resumed his former attitude.
vi: After finishing the strange description of his usual daily work, Mr. Lorry pressed both hands flat on his yellow-brown wig (an unnecessary action since that shiny head could not be any flatter), then continued in the same manner: − Miss, as you have seen, the story so far resembles the story of your poor father.
tr: After this strange description of the work routine, Mr. Lorry pressed his bright light yellow wig firmly onto his head with both hands (what an unnecessary action this was, as that shiny surface was already quite flat) and resumed his previous posture.
es: Having made this singular description of his daily routines, Mr. Lorry smoothed his silky wig with both hands, an unnecessary operation, as it was impossible to smooth it more than it already was, and resumed his previous posture.

en: “So far, miss (as you have remarked), this is the story of your regretted father. Now comes the difference. If your father had not died when he did—Don’t be frightened! How you start!”
vi: After finishing the strange description of his usual daily work, Mr. Lorry pressed both hands flat on his yellow-brown wig (an unnecessary action since that shiny head could not be any flatter), then continued in the same manner: − Miss, as you have seen, the story so far resembles the story of your poor father. Now comes the difference. If your father had never died... Don't be alarmed! You are startled!
tr: "So, young lady –as you also mentioned– this was the story of your poor father up to this point. But now it changes. What if the father you thought was dead had not died –Don't be afraid, dear! How you flinched!"
es: —So far, miss, what I have just narrated is, as you have guessed, the story of your father. The differences come now. If your father had not died when he did... Don't be frightened! You are trembling like a leaf on the tree!

en: She did, indeed, start. And she caught his wrist with both her hands.
vi: Indeed, the girl was startled. And she clasped both hands around his wrist.
tr: The young girl was truly startled. She tightly grabbed Mr. Lorry's wrist with both hands.
es: It was true. The young woman was trembling convulsively and, without uttering a word, extended both hands in a pleading gesture.

en: “Pray,” said Mr. Lorry, in a soothing tone, bringing his left hand from the back of the chair to lay it on the supplicatory fingers that clasped him in so violent a tremble: “pray control your agitation—a matter of business. As I was saying—”
vi: − Calm down, - Mr. Lorry said soothingly, withdrawing his left hand from the back of the chair and placing it on the girl's fingers, which were clasping so tightly they were trembling. - Please calm down... it's just business. I was just saying that...
tr: "Please," said Mr. Lorry in a calming tone, placing his left hand, which he had pulled from behind the chair, onto the pleading fingers that were trembling violently on his wrist, "please calm down – this is just business after all. What was I saying-"
es: —Please, miss...!—exclaimed Lorry with extreme gentleness. —Control yourself... Calm that agitation... What do feelings have to do with this?... We are talking about business... You see: I was saying...

en: Her look so discomposed him that he stopped, wandered, and began anew:
vi: Her eyes were so bewildered that he had to stop speaking, losing his train of thought, and then start over from the beginning: − I just said that if Monsieur Manette had never died; if he had suddenly disappeared without a trace; if he had been taken far away to some dreadful place, which is not hard to guess but impossible to trace; if he had an enemy compatriot who had the privilege that, in my lifetime, I know, even the bravest on the other side of the channel only dared to mention him in whispers; for example, the privilege to write names on blank warrants that could throw anyone into the indefinite oblivion of prison; if this man's wife had begged the King, the Queen, the Court, the Church for news about her husband but still received no response... if so, then your father's story would also be the story of that unfortunate gentleman, the doctor in Beauvais.
tr: Mr. Lorry was so disturbed by the girl's gaze that he fell silent, waited for a while, and then continued from where he left off.
es: The look the girl gave the narrator unsettled him so completely that he hesitated, stammered, had to make a rather long pause, and finally replied:

en: “As I was saying; if Monsieur Manette had not died; if he had suddenly and silently disappeared; if he had been spirited away; if it had not been difficult to guess to what dreadful place, though no art could trace him; if he had an enemy in some compatriot who could exercise a privilege that I in my own time have known the boldest people afraid to speak of in a whisper, across the water there; for instance, the privilege of filling up blank forms for the consignment of any one to the oblivion of a prison for any length of time; if his wife had implored the king, the queen, the court, the clergy, for any tidings of him, and all quite in vain;—then the history of your father would have been the history of this unfortunate gentleman, the Doctor of Beauvais.”
vi: Her eyes were so bewildered that he had to stop speaking, losing his train of thought, and then start over from the beginning: − I just said that if Monsieur Manette had never died; if he had suddenly disappeared without a trace; if he had been taken far away to some dreadful place, which is not hard to guess but impossible to trace; if he had an enemy compatriot who had the privilege that, in my lifetime, I know, even the bravest on the other side of the channel only dared to mention him in whispers; for example, the privilege to write names on blank warrants that could throw anyone into the indefinite oblivion of prison; if this man's wife had begged the King, the Queen, the Court, the Church for news about her husband but still received no response... if so, then your father's story would also be the story of that unfortunate gentleman, the doctor in Beauvais.
tr: "Where were we? If Monsieur Manette had not died; if one day he had suddenly, quietly disappeared; if the ground had swallowed him up, even if we could guess what terrible place he had gone to, we would not know the way to reach him at all; then, on the other side, if he had an enemy somewhere who possessed a privilege that even the most daring people hesitated to mention; that is to say, these privileged people could fill out some papers and send anyone they wanted to prison and leave them forgotten for as long as they wished; if his wife had begged the king, the queen, the court, the church for news of him, all in vain – then your father's story would be the same as that of this unfortunate gentleman, the doctor from Beauvais."
es: —I was saying that if Mr. Manette had not died, that if instead of dying he had disappeared unexpectedly and silently, evaporating, so to speak, that if it had not been an impossible task to guess the dreadful place where he would have been buried, although it was possible to reach him, if he had had the misfortune of incurring the animosity of some compatriot of his, vested with a power that the bravest men of my time did not dare to mention without trembling, the power to fill out orders or decrees signed in blank, by virtue of which it was easy to condemn any mortal to imprisonment and temporary or perpetual oblivion, if that gentleman's wife had implored compassion from the king, the queen, the court, the clergy, and the nobility, seeking news of her absent husband, without managing to soften any heart, then the story of the doctor from Beauvais that I am recounting would indeed be that of your father.

en: “I entreat you to tell me more, sir.”
vi: − I beg you to explain further.
tr: "Please, continue telling the story, sir."
es: —For God's sake, sir, tell me more!

en: “I will. I am going to. You can bear it?”
vi: − I will speak. I am about to speak now. Can you endure it?
tr: "Alright. I will tell. But can you handle it?"
es: —For God's sake, sir, tell me more! —That's what I'm getting at: but do you have enough courage to listen to what I have to say? —I can bear anything except the uncertainty that your words leave me in.

en: “I can bear anything but the uncertainty you leave me in at this moment.”
vi: − I can endure anything, except for the uncertainty you are making me endure now.
tr: "If there's one thing I can't stand, it's this uncertainty."
es: —I can bear anything except the uncertainty that your words leave me in.

en: “You speak collectedly, and you—are collected. That’s good!” (Though his manner was less satisfied than his words.) “A matter of business. Regard it as a matter of business—business that must be done. Now if this doctor’s wife, though a lady of great courage and spirit, had suffered so intensely from this cause before her little child was born—”
vi: − She spoke very calmly, and she... also appeared calm. That's good! His tone was not as satisfied as his words. - It's just business. Just consider it business, a task that needs to be completed. Then if the wife of this doctor, although a woman of great courage and determination, had to suffer immensely because of that situation before giving birth to a child... −
tr: "Your voice is calm now, you have calmed down too. Good!" (Despite saying this, Mr. Lorry's demeanor showed that he was not very satisfied.) "This is a business matter. See this as a business matter – a task that needs to be handled. Now, although this doctor's wife is an extremely brave and noble lady, she had suffered such great pains while her little baby was still in her womb..."
es: —You speak calmly... and surely you are already composed: magnificent!—continued Lorry, with an expression that contradicted his last words. —We are talking about business... nothing but business. Do not see in what I say anything more than a business... that can be done... that, in all likelihood, will turn out well. Let's continue: if the good doctor's wife, a lady of exceptional courage and great presence of mind, endured such sharp pains and sufferings as a result of what I have just mentioned, before her son came into the world...

en: “The little child was a daughter, sir.”
vi: That child must be a girl, sir.
tr: "Was this little baby a girl, sir?"
es: —The son was a daughter, sir!...

en: “A daughter. A-a-matter of business—don’t be distressed. Miss, if the poor lady had suffered so intensely before her little child was born, that she came to the determination of sparing the poor child the inheritance of any part of the agony she had known the pains of, by rearing her in the belief that her father was dead—No, don’t kneel! In Heaven’s name why should you kneel to me!”
vi: − A girl. It's... it's just work... don't be sad. Dear lady, if this poor woman had suffered so much before the child was born, to the extent that she was determined to spare her child from any suffering that she herself had endured, by raising the child and teaching it to believe that its father was dead... Don't, don't kneel down! Oh my God, why are you kneeling in front of me! −
tr: "Yes, she was angry. This –this is a matter related to work– don't worry. Young lady, this poor woman suffered such great pains when her little baby was still in her womb, that she raised her child telling him that his father was dead so that he wouldn't experience the agony she went through –No, please stand up! For God's sake, why are you kneeling?"
es: —Well...! What difference does it make? Sex does not alter the business... I mean, miss, that if the poor lady suffered such severe pains before her daughter was born, in order to prevent this sad inheritance of her agonies from reaching her, she nursed and raised her in the belief that her father had died... Do not kneel, for God's sake...! In the name of Heaven!... Why do you fall to your knees at my feet?

en: “For the truth. O dear, good, compassionate sir, for the truth!”
vi: For the truth. Oh, please, merciful sir, have pity, tell the truth! −
tr: "To hear the truth. Oh merciful, kind-hearted sir, please tell me the truth now, I beg you!"
es: —To beg you to tell me the truth...! For pity's sake, sir, hide nothing from me!...

en: “A—a matter of business. You confuse me, and how can I transact business if I am confused? Let us be clear-headed. If you could kindly mention now, for instance, what nine times ninepence are, or how many shillings in twenty guineas, it would be so encouraging. I should be so much more at my ease about your state of mind.”
vi: It's... it's just about work. You are making me confused, and how can I solve the work when I am confused? We need to be clear-headed. Please kindly tell me, for example, how much is nine times nine pence, or how many shillings are in twenty guineas, that would be much better. I would feel more at ease about your state of mind.
tr: "This is a matter of business. You are confusing me, and if you confuse me like this, how can I do my work? Let's get our heads together first. For example, now, try to say how much nine times nine pence is or how many shillings twenty guineas make. Then I can be convinced that you are in your right mind."
es: —I will tell you everything... But calm down, for heaven's sake! We are dealing with a... a... business, miss, and its details confuse me... and it's not possible... I can't handle business properly if my ideas are confused and obscured. Let's try to clear our heads. If you can tell me right now... for example, how many pence are in nine coins of nine pence each, or how many shillings are in twenty guineas, it will greatly calm my spirit, as it will be a palpable proof of your calmness and serenity.

en: Without directly answering to this appeal, she sat so still when he had very gently raised her, and the hands that had not ceased to clasp his wrists were so much more steady than they had been, that she communicated some reassurance to Mr. Jarvis Lorry.
vi: Not bothering to respond to that plea, Manette sat still after he had helped her into the chair, her hands still gripping Mr. Jarvis Lorry's wrist but no longer trembling as they had been earlier, which gave him some reassurance. −
tr: The young girl sat calmly in her place without answering the questions, and Mr. Jarvis Lorry felt somewhat relieved because the girl's hands, still clasped to her wrist, were no longer trembling as they had before when the man gently lifted her from her seat.
es: Without directly responding to this call, the girl allowed herself to be lifted from the ground and sat back down with such composure that she imparted to her interlocutor the courage that he was beginning to lack.

en: “That’s right, that’s right. Courage! Business! You have business before you; useful business. Miss Manette, your mother took this course with you. And when she died—I believe broken-hearted—having never slackened her unavailing search for your father, she left you, at two years old, to grow to be blooming, beautiful, and happy, without the dark cloud upon you of living in uncertainty whether your father soon wore his heart out in prison, or wasted there through many lingering years.”
vi: That's good, that's good. Be brave! It's just work! You have work to do; necessary work. Miss Manette, your mother decided this for you. And when she passed away... surely with a broken heart... she never stopped searching for your father in vain, leaving you, then just two years old, to grow up fresh, beautiful, and happy, with a life unclouded by the worry of whether your father had perished early in prison or was languishing there for many years.
tr: "Ah, like this, now it's perfect. Courage! Work! Work comes first; useful work. Miss Manette, your mother struggled a lot in her time. Until the last moment, she never gave up searching for your father in vain, and when she died – who knows what great sorrows she was in, poor woman – you were two years old, and for all those years, without worrying whether your father was rotting in prisons or had already perished, you grew up as a cheerful and beautiful girl."
es: —Very good! Like that...! Much courage! Business and nothing but business! A business presents itself, a positive business, with returns. Your mother, Miss Manette, adopted with you the code of conduct that I previously hinted at. When she died... I believe from sorrow... without having ceased for a moment to search for her husband, and without ever finding out anything, she left you, a two-year-old girl, on the path to grow up beautiful, happy, without sorrows, free from the dark cloud that would have embittered your existence, if at her death she had revealed to you the story of your father, without being able to add whether he had died in prison or if he continued to be buried in the dungeon, suffering the tortures of being buried alive.

en: As he said the words he looked down, with an admiring pity, on the flowing golden hair; as if he pictured to himself that it might have been already tinged with grey.
vi: When he uttered those words, he looked down at Manette's flowing blonde hair with an expression of both admiration and pity, as if he were silently imagining that there might already be many strands of gray in that hair.
tr: After finishing his sentence, he looked at the girl's long golden hair with a mixture of admiration and compassion; as if he were imagining those hairs with streaks of gray.
es: He uttered the last words, casting a gaze of infinite compassion upon the golden hair before him, as if telling himself that, thanks to the compassionate discretion of the mother, those strands did not yet abound with silver threads.

en: “You know that your parents had no great possession, and that what they had was secured to your mother and to you. There has been no new discovery, of money, or of any other property; but—”
vi: − Surely you know that your parents do not have much wealth, and whatever they had has been entirely devoted to you and your mother. There have been no new discoveries about money or any other assets; but...
tr: "You know that your family doesn't have much wealth, and what they do have is already in your and your mother's name. There hasn't been any newly discovered money or property or anything; but-"
es: —You know perfectly well that your parents did not enjoy a great fortune, and that what they possessed passed to your mother and you. As far as money and material goods are concerned, no new discoveries have been made; but...

en: He felt his wrist held closer, and he stopped. The expression in the forehead, which had so particularly attracted his notice, and which was now immovable, had deepened into one of pain and horror.
vi: He felt his wrist being gripped tighter, and he stopped speaking. The wrinkles on that forehead, which had already drawn his special attention, now became immobile, etched deeply into an expression of horrifying pain.
tr: Mr. Lorry felt the girl's hand grasp his wrist even tighter and fell silent. The special expression that had previously caught his attention had settled firmly on the girl's forehead, now accompanied by pain and fear.
es: The narrator felt delicate hands forcefully gripping his wrists, and he stopped speaking. The expression on the girl's face was one of sorrow and horror.

en: “But he has been—been found. He is alive. Greatly changed, it is too probable; almost a wreck, it is possible; though we will hope the best. Still, alive. Your father has been taken to the house of an old servant in Paris, and we are going there: I, to identify him if I can: you, to restore him to life, love, duty, rest, comfort.”
vi: − But he... has been found. He is still alive. Changed a lot, perhaps; almost an invalid, possibly; nevertheless, we must hope for the best, still alive. Your father has been taken to an old servant's house in Paris, and we will go there. My task is to correctly identify him, if possible; your task is to bring him life, love, filial duty, peace, and comfort.
tr: "But – but now he has been found. He is alive. He must have changed a lot, naturally; he is probably in a ruined state; but let's look at the bright side of things. At least he is still alive. Your father is now staying in Paris, at the house of an old servant of his, and we are going there. I, if I can, to identify him, and you, to give him life, love, responsibility, comfort, and peace again."
es: —But he has been found... him. He lives, yes... very changed... I consider it probable; shattered, a wreck, reduced to a shadow of what he was... it's possible; but he lives, and we must harbor hopes that he will improve. His father has been taken to the house of a former servant of his, who resides in Paris, and we are going to meet him: I, to identify him, if I can; you, to embrace him, to restore his life, affection, calm, and rest.

en: A shiver ran through her frame, and from it through his. She said, in a low, distinct, awe-stricken voice, as if she were saying it in a dream,
vi: A shiver ran through her body and spread to him. She spoke in a soft, halting voice, full of fear as if she were speaking in a dream: −
tr: The young girl's body shivered, and so did the man's. As if in a dream, the girl spoke in a low, deep, and fearful voice:
es: The girl shuddered from head to toe. Trembling, moved, with a strange voice, like someone speaking in a dream, she said:

en: “I am going to see his Ghost! It will be his Ghost—not him!”
vi: We will see the ghost of my father! It will be the ghost of my father... not my father himself!
tr: "So, I will see his ghost!" "It really can't be him – It must be his ghost!""
es: —I'm going to see his ghost!... His ghost!... Not him!

en: Mr. Lorry quietly chafed the hands that held his arm. “There, there, there! See now, see now! The best and the worst are known to you, now. You are well on your way to the poor wronged gentleman, and, with a fair sea voyage, and a fair land journey, you will be soon at his dear side.”
vi: Mr. Lorry quietly soothed the hands clinging to his arm. − There, there, there! It's clear now, it's clear! You now know the best and the worst things. You must set out to meet that poor wronged gentleman, just a peaceful sea voyage and a peaceful land journey away, and you will soon be with your beloved.
tr: Mr. Lorry quietly rubbed the girl's hands that were holding his arm. "Hold on, hold on! Let's see what we'll see, how we'll see it! Now you know everything. To see your poor father who has been wronged, we will first travel by sea and then by land, and very soon you will be by your dear father's side."
es: Lorry gently detached the hands that were gripping his arm. —Calm down, calm down, miss!—he said. —It's all over now. You know all the good and all the bad. Let's go meet the unfortunate knight, unjustly punished, and after a happy sea voyage, followed by another no less fortunate by land, you will very soon have the sweet pleasure of embracing him.

en: She repeated in the same tone, sunk to a whisper, “I have been free, I have been happy, yet his Ghost has never haunted me!”
vi: The girl repeated the old tone, this time like a whisper: − I have lived freely, I have lived happily, but my father's ghost has never haunted me!
tr: The young girl continued in the same tone, her voice turning into a whisper, "How free, how happy I was, my father's ghost had never appeared to me!"
es: —I have lived peacefully, I have lived happily, and his ghost has never haunted me!—exclaimed the girl with the same tone of voice as before.

en: “Only one thing more,” said Mr. Lorry, laying stress upon it as a wholesome means of enforcing her attention: “he has been found under another name; his own, long forgotten or long concealed. It would be worse than useless now to inquire which; worse than useless to seek to know whether he has been for years overlooked, or always designedly held prisoner. It would be worse than useless now to make any inquiries, because it would be dangerous. Better not to mention the subject, anywhere or in any way, and to remove him—for a while at all events—out of France. Even I, safe as an Englishman, and even Tellson’s, important as they are to French credit, avoid all naming of the matter. I carry about me, not a scrap of writing openly referring to it. This is a secret service altogether. My credentials, entries, and memoranda, are all comprehended in the one line, ‘Recalled to Life;’ which may mean anything. But what is the matter! She doesn’t notice a word! Miss Manette!”
vi: − One more thing, - Mr. Lorry said, emphasizing each word with the good intention that the girl must listen, - they have found your father under another name; his real name has been forgotten or kept hidden for a long time. Now, asking for the name wouldn't be of any use; asking who was negligent or intentionally imprisoned him all these years wouldn't be of any use either. Now, asking anything would do more harm than good. It is best not to bring that matter up, anywhere, in any form, we must get him out of France... at least for a while. Even I, safe because I am a British citizen, and even this Tellson's Bank, powerful due to its high reputation with the French, avoid bringing this matter up. I do not carry a single piece of paper that directly mentions this matter. This is entirely a secret operation. All the authorizations, guarantees, and confirmations for me are encapsulated in one word "resurrection," interpret it however you want. But saying it is like saying nothing! She wouldn't listen anyway! Miss Manette!
tr: To draw the girl's attention to his words, Mr. Lorry emphasized, "There is one more thing," he said, "your father was found under another name; his own name had long been forgotten or hidden. Whether he was overlooked in prison all these years or deliberately kept, it is best not to delve too deeply. Investigating the reasons for this could be dangerous. Let's not discuss this matter anywhere, in any way, and let's get him out of France as soon as possible –by any means necessary– We must get him out of France. Even though I am safe as an Englishman, and even Tellson, whom the French hold in high regard, avoids talking about this matter. I do not carry even the smallest piece of paper related to this matter with me. It is a completely confidential matter. All my documents, records, and notes are hidden in a single line; "Recalled to Life"; this can mean anything. But what happened to you? Ah, she doesn't hear me at all! Miss Manette?"
es: —Lend me another observation—replied Lorry, emphasizing the word, undoubtedly to ensure the attention of his listener. When they found him, he was using another name. His own, either they forgot it a long time ago, or someone has had an interest in hiding it. It would be worse than useless to try to find out if one or the other occurred: it would be worse than useless to try to inquire if they forgot about him, or if deliberately and intentionally they have kept him imprisoned for so many years: it would be worse than useless to conduct any kind of investigation, and it would be, because besides being useless, we would expose ourselves to great dangers. It is preferable a thousand times not to even speak of the matter, and to get his father out of France. I myself, despite being shielded from such dangers by being an English citizen, and even the Tellson Bank, with all the importance it has in France, do not dare to even mention the matter. I do not carry a single line, a single written word that clearly refers to him. In a word: it is a secret. All the credentials that authorize me to resolve it, all the instructions I have received as an agent, are reduced to a single word: "Resurrected"... But what is this!... She hasn't heard a word of what I've been saying! Miss Manette!

en: Perfectly still and silent, and not even fallen back in her chair, she sat under his hand, utterly insensible; with her eyes open and fixed upon him, and with that last expression looking as if it were carved or branded into her forehead. So close was her hold upon his arm, that he feared to detach himself lest he should hurt her; therefore he called out loudly for assistance without moving.
vi: Sitting still like a statue, not even leaning back in the chair, still clinging to his arm but Manette was completely unconscious; her eyes wide open looking at him, the final look of astonishment seemed to be carved or deeply etched into her forehead. Manette clung tightly to Mr. Lorry's arm to the point where he was afraid he would hurt her if he tried to remove her hand; so he had to endure and loudly called for help.
tr: The young girl had turned to stone, she didn't even slump in her chair, sitting there completely numb under Mr. Lorry's hand; she stared at the man with eyes wide open, as if this final expression was etched or branded on her forehead. The young girl held onto his arm so tightly that Mr. Lorry couldn't move for fear of hurting her and called out for help.
es: The girl remained in the chair, perfectly still, perfectly calm, perfectly silent, perfectly upright, perfectly insensible, her eyes open and fixed on Lorry's face, but with that singular expression that the eyes sculpted under the forehead of a statue have. Her fingers continued to grip his arm with such force that he did not dare to release them for fear of hurting her, for which reason he shouted for help, but without moving.

en: A wild-looking woman, whom even in his agitation, Mr. Lorry observed to be all of a red colour, and to have red hair, and to be dressed in some extraordinary tight-fitting fashion, and to have on her head a most wonderful bonnet like a Grenadier wooden measure, and good measure too, or a great Stilton cheese, came running into the room in advance of the inn servants, and soon settled the question of his detachment from the poor young lady, by laying a brawny hand upon his chest, and sending him flying back against the nearest wall.
vi: A coarse-looking woman barged into the room ahead of the group of servants in the inn. Even in his flustered state, Mr. Lorry noticed that she was entirely red from head to toe, from her red hair to her unusually tight outfit, and the enormous bonnet on her head that looked both like a guard's hat and a large wooden grain measure, or a big wheel of cheese. This woman immediately resolved the issue of separating the old man from the poor young girl by placing a strong hand on his chest and shoving him forcefully against the nearest wall.
tr: A strange-looking woman entered with hotel staff behind her; even in his flustered state, Mr. Lorry noticed that the woman was dressed entirely in red, had red hair, and was wearing a peculiar tight outfit with a massive hat on her head that looked like either a soldier's cap or a large wheel of cheese. Mr. Lorry's problem of being unable to move from his spot was resolved when the woman pushed him against the nearest wall with her strong hand.
es: At the shouts, a woman of fierce appearance came running, red from head to toe, for red was the color of her face, red her hair, red her dress, red the monumental hat, similar to those worn by grenadiers or to an enormous Stilton cheese. Hot on the heels of the woman, who burst into the room, came all the maids of the inn. The first woman used little courtesy to solve the conflict of freeing Lorry's arm from the fingers that, clenched, held it, for with the first slap struck against the chest of the gentleman from Tellson's Bank, she sent him crashing against the nearest wall.

en: (“I really think this must be a man!” was Mr. Lorry’s breathless reflection, simultaneously with his coming against the wall.)
vi: ("A woman as strong as a man!" That was Mr. Lorry's thought as he collided with the wall, almost out of breath.) −
tr: (When Mr. Lorry was pressed against the wall, breathless, he thought to himself, "This must be a man!")
es: —That woman is a man!

en: “Why, look at you all!” bawled this figure, addressing the inn servants. “Why don’t you go and fetch things, instead of standing there staring at me? I am not so much to look at, am I? Why don’t you go and fetch things? I’ll let you know, if you don’t bring smelling-salts, cold water, and vinegar, quick, I will.”
vi: Ah, look at you all! - She shouted at the helpers. - Why are you just standing there staring at me instead of getting what we need? What's there to look at? Why don't you go get the things? I'm telling you, if you don't bring salt to smell, cold water, and vinegar here quickly, I'll go get them myself.
tr: This person shouted at the servants, "Hey, why are you staring like that?" "Instead of just standing there and staring, go and bring something! As if there's something to look at! Hurry up! Bring me ammonia spirit, cold water, vinegar immediately, or you'll regret it!"
es: —Lorry murmured to himself, as he bumped into the wall. —What are you looking for here, you silly girls?—roared the red woman, addressing the maids.—Why don't you go scrub, instead of standing there, staring at me like idiots? Am I some kind of monkey, by any chance? Get to work! You will soon know who I am if you don't bring me salts, cold water, vinegar, and everything else I need right away!

en: There was an immediate dispersal for these restoratives, and she softly laid the patient on a sofa, and tended her with great skill and gentleness: calling her “my precious!” and “my bird!” and spreading her golden hair aside over her shoulders with great pride and care.
vi: The servants immediately dispersed to fetch items to help revive her, while she gently laid Manette on the couch, caring for her with utmost skill and tenderness, constantly calling her "dear!" and "sweetie!" and proudly and attentively smoothing the girl's flowing blonde hair over her shoulders.
tr: They all scattered around like chicks to bring things to revive the girl, and he laid the young girl on the couch and attended to her with great skill and gentleness. He called her "my precious!" and "my bird!" and with great pride and care, he brushed her golden hair back.
es: The dispersion was general and immediate. The maids flew in search of the requested restoratives, while the red matron placed the patient on a sofa with great skill and gentleness, calling her "precious," "my little daughter," "dove," etc., etc.

en: “And you in brown!” she said, indignantly turning to Mr. Lorry; “couldn’t you tell her what you had to tell her, without frightening her to death? Look at her, with her pretty pale face and her cold hands. Do you call that being a Banker?”
vi: − And you, the man in the brown coat! - She angrily turned to Mr. Lorry. - If you have something to say, say it, but why scare her to death like this? Look at her, she's pale and her hands are ice-cold. How can someone from the bank behave like this?
tr: Turning to Mr. Lorry, he said angrily, "You with the brown coat! Couldn't you have said what you had to say without scaring her so much? Look at her, the poor thing's beautiful face has turned completely white, and her hands are ice cold. Is this how banking is done?"
es: —And you, you brute—she shouted next, turning furiously against Mr. Lorry,—couldn't you tell her your famous story without scaring her to death? Look at how you've made her! Pale as a corpse, cold as ice! Aren't you ashamed to call yourself a banker?

en: Mr. Lorry was so exceedingly disconcerted by a question so hard to answer, that he could only look on, at a distance, with much feebler sympathy and humility, while the strong woman, having banished the inn servants under the mysterious penalty of “letting them know” something not mentioned if they stayed there, staring, recovered her charge by a regular series of gradations, and coaxed her to lay her drooping head upon her shoulder.
vi: Mr. Lorry was so flustered by the difficult question that he could only stand at a distance, looking on with a sympathetic and humble expression, trying to suppress his feelings, while the strong woman, after driving away the helpers with a mysterious threat of punishment, saying “you'll see what happens” without clarifying what they would see if they dared to stand there gawking - continued her task of gradually reviving Manette and comforting the girl who had her head resting on her shoulder.
tr: Mr. Lorry was so flustered by this difficult question that he could do nothing but look on with a feeble interest and humility. Meanwhile, the strong woman who had dispersed the servants with the threat of showing them "what's what" if they continued to stand around, had gradually calmed the girl and managed to get her to rest her drooping head on her shoulder.
es: To such an extent did Mr. Lorry become bewildered by a question so difficult to answer, that he could do nothing but look from afar with an expression of extraordinary sympathy and humility, while the tremendous woman, after once again driving away the servants who had returned with water, vinegar, and salts, under the mysterious penalty of "letting them know something she had no reason to mention" if they continued staring at her in amazement, set to work and managed, after a long time, to get the girl to begin showing signs of life.

en: “I hope she will do well now,” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: − I hope she has recovered, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "I think he's coming to," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —It seems that he is feeling better—observed Mr. Lorry.

en: “No thanks to you in brown, if she does. My darling pretty!”
vi: − Even if I recover, it won't be thanks to that man in the brown coat. Oh, little girl!
tr: "Not thanks to you but the one in brown. Poor little thing!"
es: —But it won't be because of what you have done—replied the matron harshly. — My daughter!

en: “I hope,” said Mr. Lorry, after another pause of feeble sympathy and humility, “that you accompany Miss Manette to France?”
vi: − I hope, - Mr. Lorry continued after a moment of compassionate and humble hesitation, - that you can accompany Miss Manette to France? − That's easy to say! -
tr: "I hope," said Mr. Lorry, pausing again with faint interest and humility, "that you will agree to accompany Miss Manette to France?""
es: —Would you have any objection—asked Lorry with great humility, after a few moments—to accompanying her to France?

en: “A likely thing, too!” replied the strong woman. “If it was ever intended that I should go across salt water, do you suppose Providence would have cast my lot in an island?”
vi: The strong woman retorted. - If my fate forces me to cross the sea and go abroad, would God banish me to some island?
tr: "Look at this!" said the strong woman. "If it were my destiny to cross this salty water, would God have placed me on this island?"
es: —You don't know how to say anything but nonsense! If Providence had arranged for me to ever cross the pond, do you think it would have made me be born on an island?

en: This being another question hard to answer, Mr. Jarvis Lorry withdrew to consider it.
vi: This was another difficult question to answer, so Mr. Jarvis Lorry had to retreat to his private room to ponder.
tr: The woman had asked another difficult question to answer, and Mr. Jarvis Lorry left them to ponder it.
es: As answering such a question was also extremely difficult, Mr. Maurice Lorry thought it best to withdraw to ponder.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: 5. The Wine Shop A large wine cask fell and broke on the street.
tr: V
es: V.

en: The Wine-shop
vi: 5. The Wine Shop A large wine cask fell and broke on the street.
tr: Wine Shop
es: THE TAVERN

en: A large cask of wine had been dropped and broken, in the street. The accident had happened in getting it out of a cart; the cask had tumbled out with a run, the hoops had burst, and it lay on the stones just outside the door of the wine-shop, shattered like a walnut-shell.
vi: 5. The Wine Shop A large wine cask fell and broke on the street. While being unloaded from the cart, the incident occurred, the wine cask rolled too quickly, the hoops burst off, and it shattered like a nutshell on the stone road in front of the wine shop.
tr: A large wine barrel had fallen and broken in the street; the barrel had rolled, its hoop had come off, and it lay in front of the wine shop's door, shattered like a walnut shell.
es: A barrel of wine had fallen in the street, breaking into pieces. The accident occurred while taking the barrel out of a cart. It fell to the ground, began to roll, the hoops jumped off, and it burst open like the shell of a monstrous nut in front of the door of a tavern.

en: All the people within reach had suspended their business, or their idleness, to run to the spot and drink the wine. The rough, irregular stones of the street, pointing every way, and designed, one might have thought, expressly to lame all living creatures that approached them, had dammed it into little pools; these were surrounded, each by its own jostling group or crowd, according to its size. Some men kneeled down, made scoops of their two hands joined, and sipped, or tried to help women, who bent over their shoulders, to sip, before the wine had all run out between their fingers. Others, men and women, dipped in the puddles with little mugs of mutilated earthenware, or even with handkerchiefs from women’s heads, which were squeezed dry into infants’ mouths; others made small mud-embankments, to stem the wine as it ran; others, directed by lookers-on up at high windows, darted here and there, to cut off little streams of wine that started away in new directions; others devoted themselves to the sodden and lee-dyed pieces of the cask, licking, and even champing the moister wine-rotted fragments with eager relish. There was no drainage to carry off the wine, and not only did it all get taken up, but so much mud got taken up along with it, that there might have been a scavenger in the street, if anybody acquainted with it could have believed in such a miraculous presence.
vi: Everyone nearby immediately stopped their work or ceased their idleness to rush over and drink the wine on the spot. The rough, uneven, and sharp-edged paving stones, seemingly arranged solely to cripple any creature that came near, had blocked the flowing wine into small puddles; around each puddle was a group of people, clustering in fives or threes, depending on the size of the puddle, jostling each other. Some knelt down, cupping their hands to scoop up the wine and sip it; or raised their hands high so that the women leaning over their shoulders could drink before the wine trickled through their fingers. Others, both men and women, dipped chipped earthen cups into the puddles; or even some women dipped their headscarves into the liquid and then wrung it into the mouths of the infants they were carrying; some scooped up mud to build dams to prevent the wine from spilling away; some, following the instructions of those watching from high windows, ran around to block the wine that had started to flow in another direction; some focused solely on licking the wine-soaked fragments of broken barrels, even delighting in gnawing on the damp, wine-soaked wood. There were no drains for the wine to escape, and people not only drank up the spilled wine but also swallowed all the mud carried along with the wine, so thoroughly that one might think the street sweeper had just graciously passed by, if anyone familiar with this impoverished neighborhood could believe in such a miraculous appearance.
tr: Everyone around had left their work or laziness to come to the scene to drink wine. The rough and irregular stones of the street, facing different directions, gave the impression that they were designed specifically to cripple every living being passing over them; the spilled wine had formed puddles among the stones, and at the head of each puddle, there was a crowd jostling proportionally to its size. Some men were kneeling, using their cupped hands to drink the wine before it could slip through their fingers, either drinking it themselves or helping the women leaning over their shoulders to drink. Another group of men and women, with cracked earthenware in their hands, were huddled around the puddles; some women even dipped their headscarves into the wine and squeezed it into their babies' mouths; some were busy making small dams out of mud to prevent the wine from flowing away; some were running back and forth following the words of those watching from the windows above to block the small streams of wine; some, in a state of ecstasy, were licking the soaked barrel pieces, even gnawing on the wooden pieces that had absorbed the wine with great appetite. There was no channel for the wine to flow through, and quite a bit of mud was swallowed along with the wine; the place was as clean as if a street sweeper had passed through, so much so that anyone who saw it could believe that this miraculous event had taken place.
es: All the people in the vicinity suspended their tasks or ended their idleness to run to the scene of the accident and drink the wine. The rough, uneven, and pointed stones that made up the cobblestones of the street, seemingly placed on purpose to make as many limping people as fortunate mortals who had the luck to pass over them, had distributed the red liquid, forming a variety of ponds of different sizes, all of which were surrounded by larger or smaller groups, depending on their extent. Many men, lying face down, collected the wine in the hollow of their hands and drank, or made the women who eagerly leaned over their shoulders drink, before the liquid escaped through their fingers. Others, men and women, collected it with small earthenware vessels or soaked the women's headscarves, which they then wrung out into their mouths or those of the children: some built mud dams to stop the flow of the wine, while others, following the shouted advice from onlookers at the windows, jumped here and there to divert the course of new streams, and there were even those who, seizing the half-rotten fragments of the barrel, sucked and licked them with indescribable anxiety. It can be assured that the crowds collected not only the last drop of wine but also the last molecule of earth that had come into contact with it. The street was left as if all the city's street-sweeping brigades had just passed through, if the city had known the brilliant institution of street sweepers.

en: A shrill sound of laughter and of amused voices—voices of men, women, and children—resounded in the street while this wine game lasted. There was little roughness in the sport, and much playfulness. There was a special companionship in it, an observable inclination on the part of every one to join some other one, which led, especially among the luckier or lighter-hearted, to frolicsome embraces, drinking of healths, shaking of hands, and even joining of hands and dancing, a dozen together. When the wine was gone, and the places where it had been most abundant were raked into a gridiron-pattern by fingers, these demonstrations ceased, as suddenly as they had broken out. The man who had left his saw sticking in the firewood he was cutting, set it in motion again; the women who had left on a door-step the little pot of hot ashes, at which she had been trying to soften the pain in her own starved fingers and toes, or in those of her child, returned to it; men with bare arms, matted locks, and cadaverous faces, who had emerged into the winter light from cellars, moved away, to descend again; and a gloom gathered on the scene that appeared more natural to it than sunshine.
vi: The loud laughter, the enthusiastic voices - men's, women's, and children's alike - animated the street with this drinking game. A game that is somewhat crude but full of joy. A game with a special camaraderie, clearly everyone was eager to join in; especially those who were carefree or luckier than others, this camaraderie urged them to embrace each other in delight; toast to health; shake hands; even dozens of people held hands and danced. When the wine had run out, and the places with the most wine left were just streaks of finger marks scraping the bottom, this lively gathering ended as abruptly as it had begun. The man who had earlier left the saw embedded in the log now resumed sawing; the woman who had hastily placed the hot ash jar to warm her aching, emaciated fingers and toes, whether hers or her children's, now held the jar again; the few men in sleeveless shirts, disheveled hair, and gaunt faces who had come up from the basements to warm themselves in the winter sun now dispersed and returned to the basements; and the scene once again sank into its familiar gloom, no longer cheerful.
tr: Throughout this wine game, the street – filled with the voices of men, women, and children – echoed with cheerful laughter and screams. There was a bit of roughness and plenty of clowning around involved. A completely different sense of camaraderie enveloped everything; they acted with the instinct to move together, and those who were more cheerful and carefree among them were always entwined, drinking to each other's health, shaking hands, and forming circles to dance. When the wine ran out and the ponds were replaced by grill-like fingerprint marks, the commotion ended as suddenly as it had begun. The man who had left his saw on the wood he was cutting returned to his work; the woman who had left the ash-filled bucket she used to ease the aching hunger of her and her child's fingers outside her door returned to her brazier; the bare-armed, disheveled-haired, pale-faced men who had come out of their cellars into the winter sun went back down again, and a gloom that seemed much more natural than the recent daylight settled over the surroundings.
es: While the fun of the wine lasted, the street was filled with the clamor of joyful laughter and shouts of jubilation, launched by dozens of throats of men, women, and children. The distraction was a bit crude and very lively. Those who took part in it showed a special tendency towards affinities and confidences, which resulted in toasts of questionable taste, handshakes, hugs, and whimsical dances, in which those who had drunk the most, or those of a more jovial and fun character, took special part. When the wine ran out, and the stones and earth that had been soaked were dry and clean, the demonstrations of joy ceased as abruptly as they had begun. The individual who had left his saw leaning against the log he was sawing, grabbed it and set it in motion again; the woman who had left her pot cooking in front of her house door, returned to attend to it; the men with bare arms, dirty hair, and cadaverous faces who had emerged into the daylight minutes before, descended once again into the depths of the dark caves, and the shadows enveloped with their mantle a scene that, in reality, was painful to behold in the light of the sun.

en: The wine was red wine, and had stained the ground of the narrow street in the suburb of Saint Antoine, in Paris, where it was spilled. It had stained many hands, too, and many faces, and many naked feet, and many wooden shoes. The hands of the man who sawed the wood, left red marks on the billets; and the forehead of the woman who nursed her baby, was stained with the stain of the old rag she wound about her head again. Those who had been greedy with the staves of the cask, had acquired a tigerish smear about the mouth; and one tall joker so besmirched, his head more out of a long squalid bag of a nightcap than in it, scrawled upon a wall with his finger dipped in muddy wine-lees—blood.
vi: The wine was the red wine that had dyed the ground of the narrow street in the Saint Antoine district of Paris red. The wine also dyed many hands and many faces, many bare feet and many wooden shoes red. The hands of the woodcutter left red marks on the logs; the forehead of the nursing mother was stained red with the wine that had soaked through the tattered cloth now wrapped around her head. Those who had eagerly gnawed at the wine barrels now had their mouths streaked with a fierce red; and a mischievous person, also smeared red, with a filthy long nightcap almost slipping off his head, dipped his finger into the mushy wine residue and scrawled a word on the wall - BLOOD.
tr: The spilled red wine had painted the narrow street in the suburb of St. Antoine in Paris red. Of course, it had also stained many people's hands, faces, bare feet, and wooden clogs. Red stains had formed on the handle of the saw of the man cutting wood; the forehead of the woman feeding her baby was stained because of the old cloth she had wrapped around her head again. The wine marks were still visible at the corners of the mouths of those bloodthirsty people who had attacked the barrel planks with greed, and a tall fool, whose clothes were filthy and whose nightcap, resembling a dirty sack, was almost falling off his head, had written this on the wall with his finger smeared with mud and wine: BLOOD.
es: The wine that the shattered barrel contained was red, and it stained the narrow street of the San Antonio suburb where it had spilled. It also stained many hands and many faces and many bare feet and many clogs. The hands of the man who was sawing the log left reddish marks on the boards, and the forehead of the woman who was nursing her tender child was also stained when it collided with the forehead of the old witch with whom she embraced and danced in moments of fleeting joy. Those who eagerly seized the remnants of the barrel and sucked and licked them, left the revelry with reddish circles on their mouths that gave them the appearance of fierce tigers, and there was one, undoubtedly more fond of jokes than the others, who with his finger dipped in the mixture formed by the mud and the wine, scrawled the word blood on the wall.

en: The time was to come, when that wine too would be spilled on the street-stones, and when the stain of it would be red upon many there.
vi: There will come a time when that red liquid will also flow abundantly on the cobblestone streets, and will also soak many people there.
tr: The days when this type of wine would flow in the streets and its stain would cover everything were near.
es: The day would come when blood would be spilled in torrents, and many of those who took part in the aforementioned diversion would be drenched in blood from head to toe!

en: And now that the cloud settled on Saint Antoine, which a momentary gleam had driven from his sacred countenance, the darkness of it was heavy—cold, dirt, sickness, ignorance, and want, were the lords in waiting on the saintly presence—nobles of great power all of them; but, most especially the last. Samples of a people that had undergone a terrible grinding and regrinding in the mill, and certainly not in the fabulous mill which ground old people young, shivered at every corner, passed in and out at every doorway, looked from every window, fluttered in every vestige of a garment that the wind shook. The mill which had worked them down, was the mill that grinds young people old; the children had ancient faces and grave voices; and upon them, and upon the grown faces, and ploughed into every furrow of age and coming up afresh, was the sigh, Hunger. It was prevalent everywhere. Hunger was pushed out of the tall houses, in the wretched clothing that hung upon poles and lines; Hunger was patched into them with straw and rag and wood and paper; Hunger was repeated in every fragment of the small modicum of firewood that the man sawed off; Hunger stared down from the smokeless chimneys, and started up from the filthy street that had no offal, among its refuse, of anything to eat. Hunger was the inscription on the baker’s shelves, written in every small loaf of his scanty stock of bad bread; at the sausage-shop, in every dead-dog preparation that was offered for sale. Hunger rattled its dry bones among the roasting chestnuts in the turned cylinder; Hunger was shred into atomics in every farthing porringer of husky chips of potato, fried with some reluctant drops of oil.
vi: At this moment, the fog has once again enveloped Saint Antoine after a brief burst of light, and the face of the district named after the saint* has returned to its former darkness with cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and poverty - the five companions of the saint, each powerful but the last one the most dreadful. At every street corner, entering every threshold, standing in every window, wrapped in every ragged garment fluttering in the wind, are the people who have been crushed and ground down by the machinery of poverty. The machine that molded them is a machine that turns the young into the old; children with the faces of the elderly and serious voices; and on every face, whether child or adult, deeply etched in the wrinkles of age, there is a glaring sign: Hunger. Hunger is evident everywhere. Hunger overflows from the tall houses, in the tattered clothes hanging on poles and lines; hunger is padded, patched, combined, and glued together with straw, rags, wood, and paper; hunger manifests itself in every piece of scrap wood of the sawyer; hunger glares down from the smokeless chimneys, steps along the filthy, trash-filled streets where there is not a scrap of edible food. Hunger carves its name on the shelves of the baker, writes letters on every small, stale loaf of bread in the meager reserves; leaves its mark in the sausage shop selling concoctions made entirely from dead dog meat. Hunger crackles, rattling dry bones among the roasted chestnuts in the oven; hunger disintegrates into atoms in the low-grade bowls containing slices of unpeeled potatoes, fried in a few precious drops of oil.
tr: Now a huge cloud had covered St. Antoine, and although a light briefly escaped from his holy bulk, the predominant element was a dense darkness – and the cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and hunger that accompanied this saintly being – each was almost a powerful noble; especially the last one. Examples of people, ground repeatedly in a mill – and this was certainly not a mill that rejuvenated the old – were shivering at every corner, entering and exiting every door, looking out of every window, fluttering under every garment played by the wind. The mill that ground them was a mill that aged the young; the faces of children looked old, and their voices were serious. And on these adult faces, in every line progressing like the mark of a plow, the same thing was seen, Hunger. Hunger was everywhere. It hung from the miserable clothes thrown out of high buildings, lined up in rows; Hunger was patched into these with straw, rags, wood splinters, and paper; it showed itself in every piece of wood the man cut with his saw. Hunger stared out from the chimneys that did not smoke, stood tall in the filthy street where there wasn't a single crumb of food in the garbage. Hunger was an inscription on the shelves of the bakeries, written over the few remaining dry loaves of bread; it was in the shop where sausages made from rotten meat were sold. Hunger rattled its dry bones among the chestnuts cooking in the cylindrical stove; it spread over every slice of potato frying with a few reluctant drops of oil.
es: Once the street of San Antonio returned to its usual state and condition, from which it had been momentarily taken by a fortuitous incident, it remained sad, dark, and gloomy, groaning under the scepter of cold, filth, disease, ignorance, and hunger, all of them powerful nobles, but particularly the one mentioned last. In every corner, one could see crouched figures of the unfortunate who had been pressed and crushed one hundred times over by the heavy stones of the mill, shivering from the cold and collapsing from hunger. The mill that had crushed them was not that fabulous mill that has the property of turning the old into young people full of life, but the one that turns the young into old. The boys had the faces of old men, and the children had deep and grave voices. Their backs bent under the weight, not of years, but of hunger, which was the mistress and lady of those neighborhoods. Hunger was the word repeated in all the houses, hunger the fateful phantom mounted on the miserable rags hanging from poles or ropes stretched in front of the filthy shacks, hunger repeated all the fragments of sawdust falling under the carpenter's saw, hunger the dreadful monster that, finding no filth in the streets to feed on, climbed to the top of the chimneys, which also offered no smoke to its voracity; hunger was the inscription read in the shelves of all the bakers, hunger the word stamped on all the breads, expensive, of poor quality, and lacking in weight.

en: Its abiding place was in all things fitted to it. A narrow winding street, full of offence and stench, with other narrow winding streets diverging, all peopled by rags and nightcaps, and all smelling of rags and nightcaps, and all visible things with a brooding look upon them that looked ill. In the hunted air of the people there was yet some wild-beast thought of the possibility of turning at bay. Depressed and slinking though they were, eyes of fire were not wanting among them; nor compressed lips, white with what they suppressed; nor foreheads knitted into the likeness of the gallows-rope they mused about enduring, or inflicting. The trade signs (and they were almost as many as the shops) were, all, grim illustrations of Want. The butcher and the porkman painted up, only the leanest scrags of meat; the baker, the coarsest of meagre loaves. The people rudely pictured as drinking in the wine-shops, croaked over their scanty measures of thin wine and beer, and were gloweringly confidential together. Nothing was represented in a flourishing condition, save tools and weapons; but, the cutler’s knives and axes were sharp and bright, the smith’s hammers were heavy, and the gunmaker’s stock was murderous. The crippling stones of the pavement, with their many little reservoirs of mud and water, had no footways, but broke off abruptly at the doors. The kennel, to make amends, ran down the middle of the street—when it ran at all: which was only after heavy rains, and then it ran, by many eccentric fits, into the houses. Across the streets, at wide intervals, one clumsy lamp was slung by a rope and pulley; at night, when the lamplighter had let these down, and lighted, and hoisted them again, a feeble grove of dim wicks swung in a sickly manner overhead, as if they were at sea. Indeed they were at sea, and the ship and crew were in peril of tempest.
vi: As the person is, so is the dream. A narrow, winding road, full of unpleasant and foul things, branching into many other narrow, winding roads, everywhere were people in tattered clothes wearing nightcaps, everyone reeking, filthy, with gloomy, sickly faces. In the appearance of those people still lurked the instinctive resistance of wild beasts being hunted to the end of their tether. Though melancholic and desperate, their eyes still blazed with fire; their tightly pressed lips turned pale from restraint; their foreheads, wrinkled like ropes on a gallows, still harbored thoughts of resignation or revenge. The signs on every shop were almost all harsh illustrations of poverty. The butcher shops depicted the least nutritious scraps of meat; the bakeries showed skinny loaves made from the worst flour. The signs of the taverns crudely depicted people sitting and drinking, with frowning, suspicious faces over meager servings of beer and liquor. Nothing was depicted as prosperous, except for tools and weapons; yet the axes on the hardware store signs looked sharp and gleaming, the hammers on the blacksmith signs looked heavy, and the goods of the gun shops looked menacing. The cobblestone streets were uneven and dangerous, with muddy puddles, and there were no sidewalks, abruptly cutting off in front of houses. On the other hand, the sewers ran right down the middle of the street - if they weren't clogged, and they only cleared after heavy rains, and when they did, ironically, the water flooded into the houses. On both sides of the street, at regular intervals, there was a rickety lamp hanging high by ropes and pulleys; in the evening, the lamplighter would lower them, light them, and then pull them back up, a cluster of dimly burning wicks swaying overhead as if they were seasick. And they truly were at sea, and both the ship and the crew were in the peril of a storm.
tr: The never-ending presence of hunger had permeated everywhere and everything. A narrow, winding street where all kinds of faults and filth brewed, intersected by other narrow and winding streets, people wearing tattered clothes and nightcaps on their heads, smelling just like those tattered clothes and caps, and a morbid gloom in everything visible. Even in their disheveled state, people carried a terrifying hope within them to escape from the corner they were trapped in. Though they were overwhelmed and weary, flames were shooting from the eyes of some; their lips were tightly shut, turning white from the things they couldn't say; their furrowed brows had turned into the noose they thought would either be placed on their heads or on the heads of others. The pictures on all the signs (which were almost as numerous as the shops) depicted Hunger. The butcher and the pork seller had hung pictures of the scrawniest cuts of meat, while the baker had pictures of the stalest loaves. The coarse demeanor of people drinking in the wine shops was also depicted, with men conversing with sullen faces over the small amounts of diluted wine and beer in their glasses. Aside from tools and weapons, nothing was depicted in its entirety; the knives and axes of the cutler were sharp and shiny, the hammers of the blacksmith were heavy, and the goods of the armorer were lethal. The small puddles of mud and water and the loose cobblestones led nowhere, abruptly ending at doorsteps. In contrast, the open sewage channels flowed through the middle of the street – if they flowed at all – which only happened after heavy rain, finding various ways to seep into the houses. Along the streets, at wide intervals, there were shaky lanterns hanging from a rope and pulley; at night, when the lamplighter lowered and lit them before pulling them back up, they would sway above like a faint ember from the dim wicks, as if they were floating on the sea. Indeed, they were at sea, and the ship and its crew were facing the danger of a storm.
es: The districts where he had established his headquarters could not be more suitable for the purpose.
