A narrow and winding street, a filthy and foul-smelling dump, from which even narrower and more winding alleys branched off, inhabited by human rags and smelling of human rags, in which only people and things that caused nausea could be seen. In the grim expression of its inhabitants, one could glimpse fierce longings to turn things upside down. There was no shortage of emaciated faces with eyes that emitted flames, nor of clenched lips, nor of horribly furrowed brows. Even the shop signs were vivid illustrations of need. In the butcher shops and pork shops, they painted scrawny cattle, and in the bakeries, tiny, fraudulent loaves of bread. The only industry that seemed to be experiencing a period of flourishing prosperity was that of tools and weapons. The butchers' knives and axes were shiny, perfectly sharpened, the blacksmiths' hammers weighed many pounds, and the armories were packed with instruments of death. The streets, full of potholes, deposits of mud and corrupted water, lacked sidewalks. The lanterns, which hung at very long intervals from ropes, cast a sickly light that was not enough to dispel the darkness, just as the lights of lanterns placed high on the yards do not dispel the darkness of the sea. To tell the truth, Paris was a sea, and both the ship and those who manned it were in grave danger of shipwreck.

en: For, the time was to come, when the gaunt scarecrows of that region should have watched the lamplighter, in their idleness and hunger, so long, as to conceive the idea of improving on his method, and hauling up men by those ropes and pulleys, to flare upon the darkness of their condition. But, the time was not come yet; and every wind that blew over France shook the rags of the scarecrows in vain, for the birds, fine of song and feather, took no warning.
vi: Because it will soon come to a time when the ragged, gaunt figures like scarecrows in this area, who have long been sitting idly with empty stomachs watching the night lamp-lighters, will think of a way to improve their dark situation by using those ropes and pulleys to hang people. But that time has not yet come, and every gust of wind blowing through France still desperately shakes the tattered rags of the scarecrows, because the birds with the most beautiful feathers and the sweetest songs have not yet felt the need to be wary.
tr: The ragged-looking scrawny ones on the boulevard, with their idle and hungry states, would regret not following the lamplighter; yet, if they could comprehend and develop the man's method, when the time came, they could illuminate the darkness they were in by hanging people at the ends of these ropes and pulleys. But the time had not yet come, and while the winds blowing over France were pointlessly fluttering the clothes of these ragged-looking ones, the chirping beautiful feathered birds were indifferent to everything.
es: The day was bound to come when the famished inhabitants of those regions, by force of contemplating the miserable lanterns, would conceive the project of introducing improvements to the system and would hang men from those ropes to illuminate the darkness of their situation. However, the time had not yet come, and although all the breezes blowing over France were precursors of strong gales, the little birds with silky plumage remained unaware.

en: The wine-shop was a corner shop, better than most others in its appearance and degree, and the master of the wine-shop had stood outside it, in a yellow waistcoat and green breeches, looking on at the struggle for the lost wine. “It’s not my affair,” said he, with a final shrug of the shoulders. “The people from the market did it. Let them bring another.”
vi: The tavern is a shop located right at the corner of the street, its exterior and value are quite better than many other shops, and the owner wears a yellow tunic, green breeches that go past his knees, and has been standing at the door watching the scene of people fighting over spilled wine. − Not my business, - he said with a decisive shrug. - If the people from the trading company broke this barrel, they have to deliver another one.
tr: The wine shop was on the corner, better than many other shops both in appearance and quality, and the owner of the shop, wearing a yellow vest and green pants, was standing in front of the door, looking at the mess caused by the spilled wine. He shrugged his shoulders sharply, "It's none of my business," he said. "The market vendors knocked it over. Let them bring another one."
es: The tavern in front of which the scene that the readers of this story have just witnessed took place offered a better appearance than most of the taverns in those neighborhoods, and its owner, dressed in a yellow vest and green breeches, was calmly watching the struggle of those who ran to claim the spilled wine. —I don't care—he exclaimed, shrugging his shoulders.—The warehouse employees dropped it; they will bring me another barrel.

en: There, his eyes happening to catch the tall joker writing up his joke, he called to him across the way:
vi: Then, by chance, his eyes caught sight of the tall, lanky guy jokingly writing on the wall, and he called out across the street: −
tr: At that moment, his eye caught the tall jester who was busy writing his piece, and he called out from across the street:
es: The innkeeper then happened to see the individual who was writing the word blood on the wall, and asked him:

en: “Say, then, my Gaspard, what do you do there?”
vi: Hey there, Gaspard, what are you doing over there?
tr: "Hey Gaspard, what are you doing there?""
es: —Hey, Gaspar; what are you doing there?

en: The fellow pointed to his joke with immense significance, as is often the way with his tribe. It missed its mark, and completely failed, as is often the way with his tribe too.
vi: The guy, extremely pleased with himself, pointed at his prank, like mischievous kids often show off to each other. The joke wasn't funny, didn't cause any laughter at all, just like the pranks of these troublemakers. −
tr: Adam, thinking he was a joker, pointed to what he had written as if it were something immensely important. But, in a manner befitting clowns like himself, he missed the mark and failed miserably.
es: He responded with one of those significant gestures that are so common among people of his kind, and whose meaning often goes unnoticed, as happened in this case.

en: “What now? Are you a subject for the mad hospital?” said the wine-shop keeper, crossing the road, and obliterating the jest with a handful of mud, picked up for the purpose, and smeared over it. “Why do you write in the public streets? Is there—tell me thou—is there no other place to write such words in?”
vi: So what? Do you want to go to the insane asylum? - The tavern owner said as he crossed the street, grabbed a handful of mud, and smeared it on the wall to erase the mischievous writing. - Why are you scribbling nonsense on public streets? Is there no other place... tell me... is there no other place to write this?
tr: As the owner of the wine shop was crossing the street, he said, "What are you doing, man? Are you out of your mind?" and to erase the man's mischief, he took a handful of mud from the ground and smeared it over the writing. "Why are you writing on public places? Tell me – couldn't you find another place to write this?"
es: —Are you trying to earn your way into a madhouse?—replied the innkeeper, crossing the street and smearing a handful of mud he picked up from the ground over the word written on the wall. — Can't you find another place, tell me, to write words like that?

en: In his expostulation he dropped his cleaner hand (perhaps accidentally, perhaps not) upon the joker’s heart. The joker rapped it with his own, took a nimble spring upward, and came down in a fantastic dancing attitude, with one of his stained shoes jerked off his foot into his hand, and held out. A joker of an extremely, not to say wolfishly practical character, he looked, under those circumstances.
vi: Whether intentionally or not, he protested while wiping his still-clean hand on the prankster's chest. The guy clapped his hand on the tavern owner's hand, jumped up and then landed, striking a peculiar dance pose, yanking off his dirty shoe and holding it out in front of him. In this guise, that clownish fellow looked extremely cunning, if not downright vicious.
tr: While scolding the man, he had placed his relatively clean hand (perhaps accidentally, perhaps not) on the jester's heart. The jester lightly slapped this hand, jumped with an agile movement, and landed with a magnificent dance move, holding one of his stained shoes that had flown off his foot. In that state, he looked like an extremely skillful individual.
es: While he was formulating the second question, the innkeeper placed his less dirty hand (perhaps by chance, perhaps intentionally) over the region of his interlocutor's heart. The latter struck his chest with his own, made a prodigious leap, and remained motionless, in a fantastic dance posture with his left arm on his hip and his right arm raised, holding between the thumb and index finger of his right hand a dirty shoe that he had previously taken off one of his feet.

en: “Put it on, put it on,” said the other. “Call wine, wine; and finish there.” With that advice, he wiped his soiled hand upon the joker’s dress, such as it was—quite deliberately, as having dirtied the hand on his account; and then recrossed the road and entered the wine-shop.
vi: − Put your shoes on, put them on, - the tavern owner said. - Go find some wine to drink, it's done. - After saying that, he clearly intentionally wiped his dirty hand on the thug's shirt because that guy was the reason his hand got dirty; then he crossed the street and went into the tavern.
tr: "Wear it, come on, wear it quickly," said the other. "Give the wine its due and finish it." Upon this advice, the man wiped his dirty hand on the jester –as if to say it got dirty because of him, looking him straight in the eye– and then crossed back over and entered the wine shop.
es: The innkeeper crossed the street again and entered his establishment. He was a man of about thirty years, with a martial air and a bull's neck. He must have had a fiery temperament, for although the day was one of the coldest the Parisians had experienced in that harsh winter, he was in shirtsleeves and had them rolled up almost to his shoulders.

en: This wine-shop keeper was a bull-necked, martial-looking man of thirty, and he should have been of a hot temperament, for, although it was a bitter day, he wore no coat, but carried one slung over his shoulder. His shirt-sleeves were rolled up, too, and his brown arms were bare to the elbows. Neither did he wear anything more on his head than his own crisply-curling short dark hair. He was a dark man altogether, with good eyes and a good bold breadth between them. Good-humoured looking on the whole, but implacable-looking, too; evidently a man of a strong resolution and a set purpose; a man not desirable to be met, rushing down a narrow pass with a gulf on either side, for nothing would turn the man.
vi: The owner of the shop, around thirty years old, with a thick neck and a military demeanor, must be a hot-tempered person because even in the freezing cold, he only drapes his coat over his shoulder instead of wearing it. The sleeves of his shirt are rolled up high, exposing his sun-tanned arms up to the elbows. On his head, he neither wears nor wraps anything over his short, tightly curled black hair. His skin is dark, and his sharp eyes are set wide apart. Overall, his face appears cheerful but also stubborn; clearly a very determined and principled person; someone nobody would want to confront when he's charging down a narrow path between two deep chasms, as nothing would make this person turn back.
tr: The owner of the wine shop was a man in his thirties, with a thick neck and a bold appearance, and judging by the fact that he had thrown his coat over his shoulder despite the harsh weather, he seemed to have a rather warm disposition. The sleeves of his shirt were rolled up, revealing his tanned arms up to the elbows. There was nothing covering his head except for his short, curly, dark hair. He was a handsome man with beautiful eyes and a tanned complexion, with a pleasant gap between them. He generally seemed to be a good-natured person, but he could also be ruthless; clearly, he was a determined, resolute man, and it was better not to cross paths with him. Even if he had to pass through a narrow passage with cliffs on both sides, he would not turn back from his path.
es: He must have had a fiery temperament, for although the day was one of the coldest the Parisians had experienced in that harsh winter, he was in shirtsleeves and had them rolled up almost to his shoulders. As for headwear, he wore nothing but his natural covering: a mass of black, coarse, and curly hair. He had a dark complexion and good eyes, with an implacable gaze. He was evidently a man of great resolve and unyielding purposes, one of those men with whom it would be dangerous to meet on a narrow path bordered by two abysses, for it is certain that he would not turn back for anything or anyone.

en: Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in. Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of manner. There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided. Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head, though not to the concealment of her large earrings. Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but coughed just one grain of cough. This, in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way.
vi: Mrs. Defarge, his wife, was sitting behind the counter in the shop when he walked in. She was a stout woman around his age, with vigilant eyes that seemed to rarely look directly at anything, a large hand adorned with rings; a serene face with sharp features, and an extremely calm demeanor. Mrs. Defarge exuded an air that made one think this proprietor rarely made mistakes in financial matters. Unable to bear the cold, Mrs. Defarge wrapped herself tightly in a fur coat, her head covered with a large, brightly colored scarf twisted around, but still revealing large hoop earrings. The knitting lay before her, but she had stopped knitting to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Her left hand supporting her right elbow as she picked her teeth, Mrs. Defarge said nothing when her husband walked in, merely clearing her throat softly. Accompanying the throat-clearing, her thick, dark eyebrows above the toothpick raised slightly, signaling to her husband to look around at the customers in the shop to see who had come in while he was across the street.
tr: When the man walked into the shop, Madam Defarge – that is, his wife – was sitting behind the counter. Madam Defarge was a stout woman of her husband's age, with alert eyes that seemed to look at nothing, a large hand full of rings, a face with strong, sturdy features, and a calm demeanor. She had an air about her that gave the impression she never made a mistake in any calculation she undertook. Since Madam Defarge was sensitive to the cold, she was wrapped in furs and had tied a brightly colored scarf around her head, but her large earrings were still visible. She had set aside her knitting to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Since she was busy supporting her right elbow with her left hand, she didn't say anything when her husband arrived, merely contenting herself with a slight cough. Accompanied by this cough, the way she raised her dark eyebrows, which were like thin lines, was a gesture indicating that there had been customers while her husband was outside and that it would be good for him to attend to them.
es: Mrs. Defarge, the wife of the tavern keeper in question, was sitting behind the counter when he entered the establishment. She was a woman of robust constitution, approximately the same age as her husband, with watchful eyes, although very rarely did she seem to look at any particular object, large hands covered with rings, a face with energetic lines, a reserved expression, and an air of perfect composure. One of Mrs. Defarge's characteristics was never making mistakes that would harm her interests in any of the establishment's operations. Extremely sensitive to the cold, she was wrapped in furs and covered her head with a brightly colored shawl that completely covered her, though it left visible the large earrings that adorned her ears. She had her knitting in front of her, but she had left it on the counter to devote a few minutes to cleaning her teeth, which she was doing with a toothpick. Absorbed in her occupation, with her right elbow resting on her left hand, Mrs. Defarge said nothing when her husband entered the establishment, but she let out a barely perceptible little cough. The little cough, combined with a slight arching of her eyebrows, black as a raven's wing and perfectly arched, indicated to her husband the convenience of taking a look at the customers, among whom there might be someone new who had arrived at the tavern while he was out on the street.

en: The wine-shop keeper accordingly rolled his eyes about, until they rested upon an elderly gentleman and a young lady, who were seated in a corner. Other company were there: two playing cards, two playing dominoes, three standing by the counter lengthening out a short supply of wine. As he passed behind the counter, he took notice that the elderly gentleman said in a look to the young lady, “This is our man.”
vi: Understanding the intention, the shop owner glanced around until his eyes settled on an elderly nobleman and a young lady sitting in the corner of the room. There were still many customers in the shop: two people were playing cards, two people were playing dominoes, and three people were standing by the counter trying to savor their meager glasses of wine. When he went behind the counter, he noticed the distinguished old man giving the girl a look that implied: "This is my person."
tr: Upon this, the wine seller's eyes wandered around until they caught sight of the elderly gentleman and the young lady sitting in a corner. The others were still there: two people playing cards, two people playing dominoes, and three men leaning against the counter, sipping their small amounts of wine little by little. When the wine seller went behind the counter, the elderly gentleman signaled to the young lady with his eyes and said, "This is the man we've been waiting for."
es: The innkeeper cast his eyes around the room, soon fixing them on a gentleman, already advanced in years, and a young lady, seated in one of the corners. There were other patrons as well: two playing cards at a table, another two entertaining themselves at another table, their faculties focused on the domino pieces, and three more who, standing by the counter, were trying to stretch out the wine they had been served as much as possible. The innkeeper, while passing behind the counter, could notice that the elderly gentleman was saying with his eyes to his young companion:

en: “What the devil do you do in that galley there?” said Monsieur Defarge to himself; “I don’t know you.”
vi: “What are you people doing coming to this godforsaken place?” Mr. Defarge muttered to himself. “I don’t know you at all.”
tr: Monsieur Defarge muttered to himself, "What is this man saying? I don't even know him."
es: —That's our man.

en: But, he feigned not to notice the two strangers, and fell into discourse with the triumvirate of customers who were drinking at the counter.
vi: He pretended not to see the two strangers and started a conversation with three customers who were drinking at the counter. −
tr: He pretended not to notice these two strangers and engaged in conversation with the three customers drinking in front of the counter.
es: The innkeeper pretended not to notice the presence of the two unknown characters and struck up a conversation with the trio who were drinking by the counter.

en: “How goes it, Jacques?” said one of these three to Monsieur Defarge. “Is all the spilt wine swallowed?”
vi: How's it going, Jacques? - One of the three asked Mr. Defarge. - Have you finished off all the spilled wine?
tr: "So how's it going, Jacques?" one of them said to Monsieur Defarge. "Did they clean up the spilled wine?"
es: —How's it going, Santiago—asked one of the three to the good Defarge,—have they drunk all the wine that came out of the barrel?

en: “Every drop, Jacques,” answered Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − Not a drop left, Jacques, - Mr. Defarge replied.*
tr: "To the very last drop, Jacques," said Monsieur Defarge.
es: —To the last drop, Santiago—replied Defarge.

en: When this interchange of Christian name was effected, Madame Defarge, picking her teeth with her toothpick, coughed another grain of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.
vi: Hearing this exchange of names, Mrs. Defarge, who was still holding a toothpick, cleared her throat again and raised her eyebrows a little higher.
tr: While they were talking to each other, addressing each other by the same name, Madam Defarge, who was still picking her teeth with a toothpick, lightly coughed again and raised her eyebrows, forming a thin line, once more.
es: As soon as the interlocutors exchanged their first names, Mrs. Defarge coughed a little more and raised her eyebrows again.

en: “It is not often,” said the second of the three, addressing Monsieur Defarge, “that many of these miserable beasts know the taste of wine, or of anything but black bread and death. Is it not so, Jacques?”
vi: − How often do they get to drink, - the second person in the trio said to Mr. Defarge, - those poor wretches rarely get to taste wine or anything other than black bread and death. Isn't that right, Jacques? −
tr: "Generally," said the Second of the three men to Monsieur Defarge, "these wretched creatures do not know the taste of wine; what they know is a dark bread, and death. Isn't that right, Jacques?"
es: —Rarely—observed the second of the patrons at the counter—do those miserable beasts have the chance to know what wine tastes like, or anything other than black bread and death: isn't that right, Santiago?

en: “It is so, Jacques,” Monsieur Defarge returned.
vi: That's right, Jacques, - Mr. Defarge replied.
tr: "Right, Jacques," replied Monsieur Defarge.
es: —It's true, Santiago—replied the innkeeper.

en: At this second interchange of the Christian name, Madame Defarge, still using her toothpick with profound composure, coughed another grain of cough, and raised her eyebrows by the breadth of another line.
vi: The second time she heard them call each other "Jacques," still calmly picking her teeth, Madame Defarge cleared her throat softly and raised her eyebrows a little higher.
tr: While they addressed each other by the same name for the second time, Madam Defarge, who was still picking her teeth with a toothpick in great tranquility, coughed lightly once more and raised her eyebrows, forming a thin line, once again.
es: After the second exchange of first names, another little cough followed, accompanied by the raising of Mrs. Defarge's eyebrows.

en: The last of the three now said his say, as he put down his empty drinking vessel and smacked his lips.
vi: The last person in the trio finally spoke up after placing the emptied glass of wine down and smacking his lips. −
tr: This time, after the last of the three men put down his emptied glass and smacked his lips, he started to speak.
es: —Ah!—exclaimed the third drinker, finishing the last sip and leaving the glass on the counter.

en: “Ah! So much the worse! A bitter taste it is that such poor cattle always have in their mouths, and hard lives they live, Jacques. Am I right, Jacques?”
vi: Ah! That's even worse! Those poor people always endure suffering, living miserably like oxen, Jacques. Am I right, Jacques? −
tr: "Ah! Very bad, very!" "The poor always have a bitter taste in their mouths, Jacques, and their lives are even worse." "Am I wrong, Jacques?"
es: —Ah!—exclaimed the third drinker, finishing the last sip and leaving the glass on the counter. —They always have bile in their mouths, those sheep, and they live a dog's life! Am I right, Santiago?

en: “You are right, Jacques,” was the response of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: You're right, Jacques, - Defarge agreed.
tr: "You are right, Jacques," replied Monsieur Defarge.
es: —You are right, Santiago—was the bartender's reply.

en: This third interchange of the Christian name was completed at the moment when Madame Defarge put her toothpick by, kept her eyebrows up, and slightly rustled in her seat.
vi: This third calling of the name ended just as Mrs. Defarge took out her toothpick, her eyebrows still raised, and shifted noisily in her chair.
tr: When the men addressed each other by the same name for the third time, Madam Defarge had also put her toothpick aside, raised her eyebrows even higher, and shifted slightly in her seat.
es: After the third exchange of first names, Madame Defarge put down the toothpick and made an insignificant movement.

en: “Hold then! True!” muttered her husband. “Gentlemen—my wife!”
vi: − Wait! Hold on! - Her husband muttered. - Gentlemen... this is my wife!
tr: "That's right, indeed! You're right!" grumbled her husband. "Gentlemen... this is my wife!"
es: —It's true...! Distract them!—her husband murmured very quietly. —Gentlemen...

en: The three customers pulled off their hats to Madame Defarge, with three flourishes. She acknowledged their homage by bending her head, and giving them a quick look. Then she glanced in a casual manner round the wine-shop, took up her knitting with great apparent calmness and repose of spirit, and became absorbed in it.
vi: The three guests tipped their hats and made a ceremonious bow to Mrs. Defarge. To acknowledge their respect, she nodded in return, her eyes quickly glancing over all three of them. Then she calmly looked around the tavern as usual, serenely and leisurely picked up her knitting, and focused on it. −
tr: Three customers took off their hats and greeted Madam Defarge with a showy gesture. She also slightly bowed her head in response to their greetings and gave them a once-over. Then, glancing around the wine shop, she picked up her knitting with tremendous calm and tranquility and immersed herself in her work.
es: I have the pleasure of introducing my wife. The three patrons took off their hats and greeted the innkeeper with individual nods of their heads, to which she responded by slightly bowing her own and looking at them one by one. Then, she casually glanced around, calmly picked up her knitting, and began to work.

en: “Gentlemen,” said her husband, who had kept his bright eye observantly upon her, “good day. The chamber, furnished bachelor-fashion, that you wished to see, and were inquiring for when I stepped out, is on the fifth floor. The doorway of the staircase gives on the little courtyard close to the left here,” pointing with his hand, “near to the window of my establishment. But, now that I remember, one of you has already been there, and can show the way. Gentlemen, adieu!”
vi: Have a good day, gentlemen, - her husband, who had been watching his wife intently, spoke again. - The room prepared for the bachelor that you wanted to see and were inquiring about when I was out, that room is on the fifth floor. The entrance to the staircase is in the small courtyard right to the left here, - he pointed, - near the window of this tavern. But I remember now, one of you has been there before and can lead the way. Adieu, goodbye!
tr: With his bright eyes still obediently on his wife, the wine merchant said, "Gentlemen, the bachelor room you asked about and wanted to see is on the fifth floor as I was heading out. You can reach the courtyard immediately to the left of the stairs," he indicated with his hand, "from beside that window. But now I remember that one of you has been there before, let him show you the way. Come on, gentlemen, adieu!"
es: —Gentlemen—replied the innkeeper, who had observed his wife with a scrutinizing look,—the room you expressed a desire to see when I went out to the street, is on the fifth floor. The staircase starts from the left courtyard, next to the window of the... But now I remember that one of you has already been there, and can guide the others. Goodbye, gentlemen!

en: They paid for their wine, and left the place. The eyes of Monsieur Defarge were studying his wife at her knitting when the elderly gentleman advanced from his corner, and begged the favour of a word.
vi: The three men paid and left. While Mr. Defarge was intently watching his wife knit, the distinguished old man in the corner of the tavern came over and asked to speak privately.
tr: The men paid for their wine and left. While Monsieur Defarge's eyes were on his wife who was knitting, the elderly gentleman got up from his corner, approached, and said he wanted to talk to him.
es: The drinkers paid for what they had consumed and left. The innkeeper's eyes seemed to study his wife and the knitting she was doing, when the elderly gentleman stood up expressing a desire to speak a few words with Defarge.

en: “Willingly, sir,” said Monsieur Defarge, and quietly stepped with him to the door.
vi: − Willingly, sir, - Mr. Defarge agreed and quietly followed the old man out of the tavern.
tr: "With pleasure, sir," said Monsieur Defarge, and they quietly proceeded towards the door.
es: —With great pleasure, sir—he replied, accompanying the old man to the door of the establishment.

en: Their conference was very short, but very decided. Almost at the first word, Monsieur Defarge started and became deeply attentive. It had not lasted a minute, when he nodded and went out. The gentleman then beckoned to the young lady, and they, too, went out. Madame Defarge knitted with nimble fingers and steady eyebrows, and saw nothing.
vi: The exchange was very brief and decisive. Almost as soon as he heard the first sentence, Mr. Defarge was startled and showed utmost attention. The conversation lasted less than a minute before he nodded and went outside. The distinguished old man signaled to the girl, and then both of them went out. Madame Defarge continued knitting with her nimble fingers, her eyebrows motionless, pretending not to see anything.
tr: The conversation was very short but quite heated. From the very first word, Monsieur Defarge listened to him intently. Not even a minute had passed when he nodded and went outside. Madame Defarge continued knitting without moving her eyebrows, her fingers moving rapidly, and she saw nothing else.
es: The conference was brief, but its effects were as swift as they were decisive. Not four words had been exchanged when Defarge made a gesture of surprise, and before a minute had passed, he signaled to the old man and hurried out into the street. The gentleman nodded to the young lady, and both followed the innkeeper, leaving Madame Defarge absorbed in her knitting.

en: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette, emerging from the wine-shop thus, joined Monsieur Defarge in the doorway to which he had directed his own company just before. It opened from a stinking little black courtyard, and was the general public entrance to a great pile of houses, inhabited by a great number of people. In the gloomy tile-paved entry to the gloomy tile-paved staircase, Monsieur Defarge bent down on one knee to the child of his old master, and put her hand to his lips. It was a gentle action, but not at all gently done; a very remarkable transformation had come over him in a few seconds. He had no good-humour in his face, nor any openness of aspect left, but had become a secret, angry, dangerous man.
vi: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette left the tavern, following Mr. Defarge to the entrance of the staircase that he had previously directed his guests to. The door was located in a small, dark, and foul-smelling courtyard, serving as a common entrance for many houses, home to many people. At the dimly lit brick-paved entrance leading to the dimly lit brick-paved staircase, Mr. Defarge knelt on one knee before the daughter of his former master and lifted her hand to his lips to kiss it. It was a gesture of kindness, but the manner of its expression did not appear so; in an instant, his demeanor had visibly changed. His face no longer bore a cheerful or open expression but had become one of secrecy, fury, and danger.
tr: Mr. Jarvis Lorry and Miss Manette left the wine shop and went to Monsieur Defarge, to the entrance where the man had just described the room to the men. This led to a small, dark courtyard that smelled terrible and was used as a passage to an area with a bunch of houses and a lot of people living there. In this gloomy, tiled entrance that opened onto gloomy, tiled stairs, Monsieur Defarge knelt before his former employer's daughter and brought her hand to his lips. Although it was a polite gesture, it was not done in an overly polite manner; within a few seconds, the man's entire demeanor had changed. The cheerful, clear-faced man was gone, replaced by a mysterious, angry, and dangerous man. Mr. Defarge warned Mr. Lorry at the top of the stairs with a firm attitude.
es: Mr. Maurice Lorry and Miss Manette, who were the visitors to the tavern, as the readers will have undoubtedly guessed, found the innkeeper by the door that moments earlier he had indicated to the three patrons with whom we have seen him exchange a few words. In the gloomy entrance that led to the equally gloomy staircase, the innkeeper knelt on one knee and brought to his lips the hand of the daughter of his former master. It was a homage, a testimony of submission, though executed with a demeanor that was anything but gentle. A few seconds had sufficed to radically transform Defarge; his face no longer reflected good humor, nor was it a mirror of frankness: on the contrary, in his reserved expression, in his angry attitude, in the fury that sparkled in his eyes, it was easy to read the dangerous man.

en: “It is very high; it is a little difficult. Better to begin slowly.” Thus, Monsieur Defarge, in a stern voice, to Mr. Lorry, as they began ascending the stairs.
vi: − It's way up high; a bit difficult to climb. So start slowly. - In a stern voice, Mr. Defarge said to Mr. Lorry as they ascended the stairs.
tr: "It's quite high up; you might find it difficult. Take it slow." The other whispered, "Alone?""
es: —It is very high... the ladder is heavy... I think you would do well to climb more calmly—said the innkeeper with a harsh tone to Mr. Lorry, at the moment he began to climb the ladder.

en: “Is he alone?” the latter whispered.
vi: − He is alone? - Mr. Lorry whispered.
tr: The other whispered, "Alone?""
es: —Are you alone?—asked Lorry.

en: “Alone! God help him, who should be with him!” said the other, in the same low voice.
vi: − Alone! Only God, who else would be with him! - Mr. Defarge also lowered his voice.
tr: "Alone! May God help him, who else would be with him anyway?" said the other in the same low voice.
es: —Alone! Good heavens! Who do you want to accompany you?

en: “Is he always alone, then?”
vi: − So he is always alone? −
tr: "Always only then."
es: —Always alone?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Always.

en: “Of his own desire?”
vi: − Because he wants it that way? −
tr: "Does he want it that way himself?"
es: —Because that is what he desires?

en: “Of his own necessity. As he was, when I first saw him after they found me and demanded to know if I would take him, and, at my peril be discreet—as he was then, so he is now.”
vi: Because he needs it that way. It's always been like that, ever since I first met him, after they found me, asked me if I would take him in and keep it secret to avoid danger... he was the same then as he is now.
tr: "That's how it needs to be. Even then, I mean the day they found me, asked me to take him with me, and told me to keep my mouth shut – even then, when I first saw him, he was alone, and he is still alone now."
es: —Because the circumstances demand it. Just as he was when I saw him the day they came to ask me if I wanted to have him in my house and be discreet while running the consequent risk... just as he was then, he is now.

en: “He is greatly changed?”
vi: − Has he changed a lot?
tr: "Has he/she changed a lot?"
es: —Very changed?

en: “Changed!”
vi: − Changed!
tr: "Of course it has changed!"
es: —Changed!...

en: The keeper of the wine-shop stopped to strike the wall with his hand, and mutter a tremendous curse. No direct answer could have been half so forcible. Mr. Lorry’s spirits grew heavier and heavier, as he and his two companions ascended higher and higher.
vi: The innkeeper stopped, swung his arm, punched the wall, and let out a fierce curse. No direct answer could be half as emphatic as that curse. Mr. Lorry's mood grew heavier as he and the other two climbed higher and higher.
tr: The owner of the wine shop paused to punch the wall and let out a hefty curse. No response could be half as effective as what he did. As he climbed the stairs with the others, Mr. Lorry felt more and more anxious with each step.
es: The innkeeper slammed his fist against the wall and uttered a horrendous curse. Any clear and precise response would not have produced half the effects that that explosion of fury did. Mr. Lorry's melancholy increased as he ascended the steep staircase.

en: Such a staircase, with its accessories, in the older and more crowded parts of Paris, would be bad enough now; but, at that time, it was vile indeed to unaccustomed and unhardened senses. Every little habitation within the great foul nest of one high building—that is to say, the room or rooms within every door that opened on the general staircase—left its own heap of refuse on its own landing, besides flinging other refuse from its own windows. The uncontrollable and hopeless mass of decomposition so engendered, would have polluted the air, even if poverty and deprivation had not loaded it with their intangible impurities; the two bad sources combined made it almost insupportable. Through such an atmosphere, by a steep dark shaft of dirt and poison, the way lay. Yielding to his own disturbance of mind, and to his young companion’s agitation, which became greater every instant, Mr. Jarvis Lorry twice stopped to rest. Each of these stoppages was made at a doleful grating, by which any languishing good airs that were left uncorrupted, seemed to escape, and all spoilt and sickly vapours seemed to crawl in. Through the rusted bars, tastes, rather than glimpses, were caught of the jumbled neighbourhood; and nothing within range, nearer or lower than the summits of the two great towers of Notre-Dame, had any promise on it of healthy life or wholesome aspirations.
vi: Such a staircase, along with its dependencies, in the more crowded and older areas of Paris, must have been worse compared to today; but even at that time, it was already unpleasant for those who were not familiar and hardened. Every residence within the heart of this stinking nest, this tall house, in other words, every room, apartment behind any door that opened onto this common staircase - left a pile of their garbage at the top of the stairs of each floor, along with throwing other waste out the window. Even if one were not burdened by the stench of poverty, the heap of desperate decay and uncontrollable proliferation would have been enough to poison the entire atmosphere; but when both garbage and poverty join forces, the stench becomes unbearable. To proceed, one must pass through that atmosphere, traverse the dark, steep, filthy, and noxious staircase. Mr. Jarvis Lorry had to pause twice to catch his breath, exhausted by his own anxious thoughts and the restlessness of the young lady accompanying him. Each time he stopped at the miserable ventilation window, it seemed that any desirable fresh air had already escaped, and the foul, stinking fumes from outside had seeped in. Through the rusty bars of the ventilation window, one could almost taste rather than see this chaotic area; and within the range from here to the two high towers of Notre-Dame Cathedral, everything closer or lower offered no promise of a peaceful life or lofty aspirations.
tr: In the relatively older and more crowded areas of Paris, it would be natural for such a staircase to look bad with all its details, but that day, for these genteel individuals who knew nothing of misery, this place was utterly disgusting. The inhabitants of every small dwelling in this high filth nest of a building –in other words, every room or rooms opening onto the staircase– had piled all their rubbish onto their own landing and thrown the rest out of the windows. This out-of-control heap of hopeless trash had covered everything so much that even if the invisible filth of poverty and deprivation had not been added to it, it would have been enough to pollute the air; the combination of these two was truly unbearable. But to continue on their way, they had to breathe this air, dive into this steep, dark pit of filth and poison. Mr. Jarvis Lorry, unable to bear his increasing anxieties and the excitement of his young companion, stopped and rested twice. Each of these pauses was taken in front of sorrowful window grilles where a piece of clean, beautiful, and melancholy air had flown away, replaced by a foul vapor. Instead of the views of that chaotic neighborhood, the air was noticeable through the rusty bars, and as far as could be seen, there was no sign of healthy living or hope anywhere near or below the tops of Notre-Dame's two great towers.
es: Painful, very painful, it would be today to climb the stairs of one of the oldest houses located in one of the most populated neighborhoods of Paris; but at the time to which this story refers, it was almost impossible for those who did not have their senses atrophied by force of habit. All the neighbors of those immense hives left the garbage and filth on the landings of the main staircase, where they piled up without anyone caring to remove them, thus generating a mass of decomposition sufficient to poison the air, if it were not already saturated with the intangible impurities that are the natural result of misery and deprivation. Combined, the two sources of corruption created an unbearable atmosphere. Mr. Lorry, yielding to the discomfort caused by climbing that dark, dirty, and poisoned well, as well as to the agitation he observed in his young companion, which multiplied by the moment, stopped twice to rest. Each of those rests seemed to take away the last reserves of uncorrupted air, filling the space they left free with mephitic emanations that sprang from all sides.

en: At last, the top of the staircase was gained, and they stopped for the third time. There was yet an upper staircase, of a steeper inclination and of contracted dimensions, to be ascended, before the garret story was reached. The keeper of the wine-shop, always going a little in advance, and always going on the side which Mr. Lorry took, as though he dreaded to be asked any question by the young lady, turned himself about here, and, carefully feeling in the pockets of the coat he carried over his shoulder, took out a key.
vi: Finally, they reached the top of the staircase, and they stopped for the third time. There was still one more staircase to climb, steeper and narrower, to reach the attic. The innkeeper, always a little ahead, stayed close to Mr. Lorry, as if he feared the girl might ask any questions; at this point, he turned around, carefully searched through the pockets of the coat draped over his shoulder, and pulled out a key.
tr: Finally, they reached the last step and stopped for the third time. However, before reaching the attic, a steeper and narrower staircase stretched out before them. As if afraid that the young lady might ask a question, the owner of the wine shop, who had been walking slightly ahead and on Mr. Lorry's side since the beginning of the stairs, turned around here and carefully searched the pockets of the coat he was carrying on his shoulder, producing a key.
es: They finally reached the top of the stairs, where they stopped for the third time. They still had to climb another section, steeper than the previous ones, and of extremely reduced dimensions, before reaching the attic. The innkeeper, who was walking ahead and constantly trying to keep a respectable distance from the young lady, as if he feared she might ask him a question, upon reaching the attic door, put his right hand into his pocket and took out a key.

en: “The door is locked then, my friend?” said Mr. Lorry, surprised.
vi: − Does this door have to be locked, my friend? - Mr. Lorry asked in surprise. −
tr: "Is the door locked, my friend?" said Mr. Lorry, in a surprised manner.
es: —Ah!—exclaimed Lorry, unable to hide his surprise.—Is the door locked?

en: “Ay. Yes,” was the grim reply of Monsieur Defarge.
vi: Oh, yes, - came the ruthless reply from Mr. Defarge. −
tr: Monsieur Defarge said, "Yes, indeed," with a serious demeanor.
es: —Yes—replied Defarge curtly.

en: “You think it necessary to keep the unfortunate gentleman so retired?”
vi: Do you think it's necessary to keep this unfortunate man confined?
tr: "Is it necessary to keep the unfortunate man locked up like this?"
es: —Do you consider it necessary to keep that unfortunate gentleman in such extreme confinement?

en: “I think it necessary to turn the key.” Monsieur Defarge whispered it closer in his ear, and frowned heavily.
vi: − I think it's necessary to turn the key. - Mr. Defarge whispered close to his ear and frowned.
tr: "I think it's worth turning the key." Monsieur Defarge had whispered this into Mr. Lorry's ear, his eyebrows furrowed sternly.
es: —I consider it necessary to have the door locked—murmured the person addressed, lowering his voice significantly and furrowing his brows terribly.

en: “Why?”
vi: − Why? − Why?
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why?

en: “Why! Because he has lived so long, locked up, that he would be frightened—rave—tear himself to pieces—die—come to I know not what harm—if his door was left open.”
vi: − Why? − Why? Because he has lived in captivity for so long that if the door were left open now, he would panic, go mad, tear himself apart, die, or do any number of terrible things.
tr: "Why, you ask? The poor man lived locked up for so long that if we were to leave this door open, he would be scared – go mad – tear himself apart – die – who knows what he might do."
es: —Why! Because he has lived locked up for so many years that he would be frightened, horrified, he would throw himself headfirst against the walls, he would die... I don't know the extremes he would go to... if he were left with the door open!

en: “Is it possible!” exclaimed Mr. Lorry.
vi: − To that extent! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed.
tr: "Is such a thing possible?" shouted Mr. Lorry.
es: —Is it possible! —Possible?

en: “Is it possible!” repeated Defarge, bitterly. “Yes. And a beautiful world we live in, when it is possible, and when many other such things are possible, and not only possible, but done—done, see you!—under that sky there, every day. Long live the Devil. Let us go on.”
vi: − To that extent! - Defarge bitterly repeated. - That's right. And what a wonderful world we live in when such things can happen, and when many other similar things can happen, and not only can happen but have actually happened... Have happened, do you hear!... Under this sky, every day. Long live the devil. Let's move on.
tr: Defarge sternly repeated, "Is such a thing possible?" "Of course. In this beautiful world we live in, such a thing is possible, many other things are possible too, and not only possible but such things really happen every day under this sky – they truly happen! The devil enters a person's mind. Anyway, let's get back to our work."
es: It would be infallible, yes!—replied Defarge with a bitter tone. —Indeed, we cannot complain about the attractions offered by a world in which these and other atrocities are possible, nor about the beauty of a sky that impassively watches the horrors you are witnessing...! The devil rules us!... Long live hell! Let's go in, sir, let's go in!

en: This dialogue had been held in so very low a whisper, that not a word of it had reached the young lady’s ears. But, by this time she trembled under such strong emotion, and her face expressed such deep anxiety, and, above all, such dread and terror, that Mr. Lorry felt it incumbent on him to speak a word or two of reassurance.
vi: The two people whispered so no words reached the girl's ears. But by this time, she was trembling violently with strong emotion, her face showing extreme anxiety, and more than that, full of terror and horror, making Mr. Lorry feel obliged to say a few reassuring words.
tr: They had spoken so quietly that the young girl did not hear a single word of it. But when they reached the door, she was trembling intensely under the influence of such a strong emotion – and there was such deep concern, moreover, fear and anxiety on her face that Mr. Lorry felt the need to say a few words to comfort her.
es: The dialogue that has been copied was held in such a low voice that not a single word reached the girl's ears. However, the emotion that dominated her was so intense, her face reflected such an expression of fright and such vivid anxiety, that Mr. Lorry felt it necessary to address her with some words aimed at lifting her depressed spirits.

en: “Courage, dear miss! Courage! Business! The worst will be over in a moment; it is but passing the room-door, and the worst is over. Then, all the good you bring to him, all the relief, all the happiness you bring to him, begin. Let our good friend here, assist you on that side. That’s well, friend Defarge. Come, now. Business, business!”
vi: − Be brave, miss! Be brave! It's just work! In just a moment, this terrible feeling will end; just passing through the door, this terrible feeling will cease. After that, all the good things you bring to him, all the compensation, all the happiness you bring, will begin. Let our dear friend here guide you on one side. That's right, my friend Defarge. Let's go! Work, work!
tr: "Be strong, young lady! Be strong for a bit! Let's get our work done! The hardest part of the job will be over in a minute; once you pass through this door, the hardest part will be over. After that, it's all good, you'll give her kindness, peace, and happiness. Now let this kind-hearted brother of ours take your other arm. Ah, that's good, Brother Defarge. Alright now. Let's continue with our work!"
es: "Courage, my dear miss!" he said. "Courage!" We are pursuing a business, whose painful phase will pass in a moment. As soon as we pass through this door, we will have overcome the worst. In a few seconds, the unfortunate one will be able to begin to savor all the good, all the comfort, all the happiness that you are going to provide him. Our good friend Defarge will help us... To business, to business!

en: They went up slowly and softly. The staircase was short, and they were soon at the top. There, as it had an abrupt turn in it, they came all at once in sight of three men, whose heads were bent down close together at the side of a door, and who were intently looking into the room to which the door belonged, through some chinks or holes in the wall. On hearing footsteps close at hand, these three turned, and rose, and showed themselves to be the three of one name who had been drinking in the wine-shop.
vi: They went up, slowly, gently, this staircase was short, and soon they reached the top. Upon arrival, as they rounded the corner at the top of the stairs, they suddenly saw three people bending over, heads close together, on one side of the door, peering into the room through the cracks and holes in the wall. Hearing the approaching footsteps, all three turned around, stood up straight, and it turned out they were the three men named Jacques who had been drinking in the tavern earlier.
tr: They climbed the stairs slowly and silently. There weren't many steps, and soon they were at the top. There, as soon as they turned the corner, they unexpectedly found three men right in front of them, leaning against the side of the door, peering excitedly through various cracks and holes in the wall into the room where the door was open. Upon hearing the approaching footsteps, all three immediately straightened up and turned around, revealing that they were the trio with the same names who were drinking in the wine shop.
es: As they turned a very sharp corner, they found three men who were looking through the keyhole and the cracks of the door that our visitors were about to open. The men in question turned out to be the same ones who moments before were drinking while standing by the counter.

en: “I forgot them in the surprise of your visit,” explained Monsieur Defarge. “Leave us, good boys; we have business here.”
vi: − I forgot about them because you came unexpectedly, - Defarge explained. - Go away, friends; we have work to do here.
tr: "I had forgotten these due to the surprise of your visit," explained Monsieur Defarge. "Come on, you children go; we have work to do here."
es: —The surprise your visit caused me made me forget them—said Defarge by way of explanation. — Please be so kind as to leave us, friends.

en: The three glided by, and went silently down.
vi: The three people squeezed past them and quietly went down.
tr: The three of them slipped past and quietly went down.
es: The three men disappeared silently.

en: There appearing to be no other door on that floor, and the keeper of the wine-shop going straight to this one when they were left alone, Mr. Lorry asked him in a whisper, with a little anger:
vi: On this floor, there seemed to be no other doors. The innkeeper walked straight to that door when the three others had disappeared.
tr: Since there was no other door on the floor and the owner of the wine shop headed straight for this door when they were alone, Mr. Lorry whispered with a slightly angry demeanor:
es: —Have you made Mr. Manette an object of exhibition?—asked Lorry in a very low voice with an angry expression.

en: “Do you make a show of Monsieur Manette?”
vi: Mr. Lorry seemed angry and lowered his voice to ask Defarge: − You let people look at Mr. Manette?
tr: "Did you make Monsieur Manette into a showpiece?""
es: —Have you made Mr. Manette an object of exhibition?—asked Lorry in a very low voice with an angry expression.

en: “I show him, in the way you have seen, to a chosen few.”
vi: − I let a few selected people see him, as you have seen.
tr: "I show it, as I am showing you right now, only to a select few.""
es: —I display it, as you have just seen, to a very select group of chosen individuals.

en: “Is that well?”
vi: − Should we?
tr: "Is this a good thing?"
es: —And do you think that's right?

en: “I think it is well.”
vi: − I think we should. −
tr: "I think it's good."
es: —Yes, sir: I think it's fine.

en: “Who are the few? How do you choose them?”
vi: Who are the few? How do you select them?
tr: "Who are these chosen people?" "According to what criteria do you choose them?""
es: —And those chosen ones, who are they? How do you choose them?

en: “I choose them as real men, of my name—Jacques is my name—to whom the sight is likely to do good. Enough; you are English; that is another thing. Stay there, if you please, a little moment.”
vi: − I choose the righteous ones, those who share my name... my name is Jacques... seeing him will benefit them. That's enough; you are English, you wouldn't understand. Please stay still, wait a moment.
tr: "I choose men who have the same name as mine – by the way, my name is Jacques – and who are presentable. Anyway, that's enough; you are English; that's a different matter. Please wait here for a moment."
es: —I choose those who are true men... and are named like me: Santiago; men who should see it... But you are English, and it is useless to give you explanations that you will not understand. Please be kind enough to wait a moment.

en: With an admonitory gesture to keep them back, he stooped, and looked in through the crevice in the wall. Soon raising his head again, he struck twice or thrice upon the door—evidently with no other object than to make a noise there. With the same intention, he drew the key across it, three or four times, before he put it clumsily into the lock, and turned it as heavily as he could.
vi: Waving his hand to signal them to step back, he bent down to look through the gap in the wall. Then he raised his head and knocked hard on the door two or three times - clearly with the sole purpose of making noise. With the same intention, he dragged the key across the door three or four times before clumsily inserting it into the lock and deliberately turning it with all his might.
tr: Defarge, with a cautionary demeanor, signaled with his hand for them to stay back and bent down to look through the crack in the wall. Straightening up shortly after, he knocked on the door two or three times – clearly intending to make noise. With the same intention, he also struggled three or four times to insert the key into the lock – barely managing to fit it in – and turned it as slowly as possible.
es: By means of a gesture, he recommended to his companions that they remain still, and he pressed his face against a crack in the wall. Moments later, he raised his head, knocked on the door two or three times, with no other purpose, undoubtedly, than to make noise, passed the key through it several times with the same intention, finally put it in the lock, and opened it making as much noise as possible.

en: The door slowly opened inward under his hand, and he looked into the room and said something. A faint voice answered something. Little more than a single syllable could have been spoken on either side.
vi: The door slowly opened inward under Defarge's hand, he looked inside and said something. A vague voice replied something. Neither side said more than a single word.
tr: The door slowly opened inward, Defarge glanced into the room and said something. A feeble voice responded. Both sides uttered a single monosyllabic word.
es: Slowly and silently, the door opened from the outside in, pushed by the hand of the innkeeper. He leaned his head forward and said something. A very weak voice replied.

en: He looked back over his shoulder, and beckoned them to enter. Mr. Lorry got his arm securely round the daughter’s waist, and held her; for he felt that she was sinking.
vi: He glanced over his shoulder and then signaled for the other two to go in. Mr. Lorry wrapped his arm tightly around the girl's waist because he feared she would collapse.
tr: Defarge signaled them to enter by looking over his shoulder. Mr. Lorry extended his arm around the young girl's waist and held her tightly; because she seemed about to faint.
es: The innkeeper turned his face and indicated to his companions to follow him. Lorry wrapped his arm around the girl's waist, who was about to faint.

en: “A-a-a-business, business!” he urged, with a moisture that was not of business shining on his cheek. “Come in, come in!”
vi: − Ah, work, just work! - He urged, but the sparkling tear on his cheek had nothing to do with work. - Come in, come in!
tr: "This, this is just a job, just a job!" he insisted, but the wetness glistening on his cheek said otherwise. "Come inside, come on!"
es: —Bu... siness... my dear... busi... ness!—exclaimed Lorry, turning his eyes towards the girl, from which something emerged that is not usually a product of business. —Come in... come in!

en: “I am afraid of it,” she answered, shuddering.
vi: − I'm afraid of this, - the girl replied, trembling. −
tr: "I'm scared," said the girl, trembling.
es: —I'm scared!—replied the young woman.

en: “Of it? What?”
vi: This? What?
tr: "Why are you afraid?"
es: —Fear of what?

en: “I mean of him. Of my father.”
vi: − I mean that person. It's my father.
tr: "I am afraid of him. Of my father."
es: —Him... my father!

en: Rendered in a manner desperate, by her state and by the beckoning of their conductor, he drew over his neck the arm that shook upon his shoulder, lifted her a little, and hurried her into the room. He sat her down just within the door, and held her, clinging to him.
vi: Frenzied by the girl's distress and by the guide's beckoning gesture, Mr. Lorry pulled her arm around his neck, slightly lifted her, and quickly drew her into the room. He set her down just inside the doorway and kept her close to him.
tr: On one hand, the girl's condition, and on the other, the hurried signals from his guides, left Mr. Lorry helpless. He took the trembling arm over his shoulder and lifted the girl slightly into the room. As soon as they entered through the door, he put down the girl who was clinging tightly to him and held her.
es: Finding himself in a critical situation, due to the young woman's state of mind on one hand, and on the other hand the signals his guide was making for them to enter, Lorry lifted the former in his arms and crossed the door. Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window.

en: Defarge drew out the key, closed the door, locked it on the inside, took out the key again, and held it in his hand. All this he did, methodically, and with as loud and harsh an accompaniment of noise as he could make. Finally, he walked across the room with a measured tread to where the window was. He stopped there, and faced round.
vi: Defarge took out the key, closed the door, locked it from the inside, then took the key out and held it in his hand. Every movement was careful and deliberately made to create as much noise as possible. Finally, he crossed the room, his steps cautious, and went to the window. He stopped there and turned to face the room.
tr: Defarge took out the key, closed the door, locked it from the inside, and held the key in his hand after removing it again. He did all of this in a very systematic manner, making the loudest and harshest noises possible. Finally, he walked heavily towards the place where the window was. He stopped there and turned his face.
es: Defarge removed the key, locked the door from the inside, with the key, of course, and, having completed these operations slowly and methodically, and above all, making as much noise as he could, he began to walk with measured steps towards the window. He stopped next to it and turned halfway around.

en: The garret, built to be a depository for firewood and the like, was dim and dark: for, the window of dormer shape, was in truth a door in the roof, with a little crane over it for the hoisting up of stores from the street: unglazed, and closing up the middle in two pieces, like any other door of French construction. To exclude the cold, one half of this door was fast closed, and the other was opened but a very little way. Such a scanty portion of light was admitted through these means, that it was difficult, on first coming in, to see anything; and long habit alone could have slowly formed in any one, the ability to do any work requiring nicety in such obscurity. Yet, work of that kind was being done in the garret; for, with his back towards the door, and his face towards the window where the keeper of the wine-shop stood looking at him, a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very busy, making shoes.
vi: Once built as a storage for firewood and similar items, this attic room was dim and dark; because that dormer window was actually an opening to the roof, equipped with a small crane to hoist goods from the street below; it had no glass panes but consisted of two shutters folding in the middle like all French-style doors. To avoid the cold, one shutter was tightly closed, and the other was only slightly ajar. Through that narrow gap, very little light entered, making the room pitch dark; upon first entering, it was very difficult to see anything; one had to stay for a long time to gradually get used to it, to be able to do any meticulous work in such darkness. Yet, such a meticulous task was being carried out right in this attic room. With his back to the door and facing the window where the innkeeper was standing and looking, a white-haired man sat on a low bench, bent forward, busy making shoes.
tr: The attic, which was made to store wood and similar things, had a rather dim and mysterious appearance; the skylight was actually a door opening to the roof and had a small pulley mechanism used to get things from the shops below; it was unpolished and, like all other doors in French buildings, it was double-winged. To block the cold, one wing of the door was tightly closed, while the other was left slightly ajar. In this way, so little light came in that it was difficult to see anything upon first entering, and to do any work requiring descending in such darkness, one had to be doing it for a long time. However, the very work being done in the attic was just like this; the person, with his back to the door and his face turned towards the window where the owner of the wine shop stood watching him, was an old man with white hair, sitting on a low stool, hunched over, making shoes with all his might.
es: The attic, built to be a wood storage, barely received the visit of a very scarce light, as the window, extremely narrow and almost closed to avoid the cold, hindered the passage of light so much that it was impossible to see absolutely anything. And yet someone was working in that gloomy room, for next to the window he was facing, with his back turned to the door, there was a man with hair as white as snow, sitting on a very low stool and ardently engaged in the task of sewing shoes.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: The shoemaker − Hello!
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: The Shoemaker
vi: The shoemaker − Hello!
tr: Shoemaker
es: THE SHOEMAKER

en: Good day!” said Monsieur Defarge, looking down at the white head that bent low over the shoemaking.
vi: - Mr. Defarge said, looking down at the bowed white head working on the shoes.
tr: Monsieur Defarge, bending over the shoe in his hand, said to the white-haired man working, "Good day!"
es: —Good morning—said the innkeeper, fixing his eyes on the white-haired head of the shoemaker.

en: It was raised for a moment, and a very faint voice responded to the salutation, as if it were at a distance:
vi: That head lifted up a bit and responded to the greeting with a very soft voice as if it came from afar: − Hello! −
tr: The white-haired head lifted for a moment and responded to the greeting with a feeble voice, as if the sound was coming from a great distance:
es: —Good morning.

en: “Good day!”
vi: Are you still working diligently?
tr: "Good day!"
es: —Good morning.

en: “You are still hard at work, I see?”
vi: Are you still working diligently?
tr: "I see you're still working hard."
es: —Always so hardworking, huh?

en: After a long silence, the head was lifted for another moment, and the voice replied, “Yes—I am working.” This time, a pair of haggard eyes had looked at the questioner, before the face had dropped again.
vi: After a long silence, the head lifted up again and that voice replied: − Yes... I am working. - This time, a pair of vacant eyes looked at the questioner before the face dropped down again.
tr: After a long silence, the head lifted again and responded, "Yes – I am working."" This time, before his head fell forward again, he looked at the man asking the questions with a pair of weary eyes.
es: After a while of anguished silence, the shoemaker raised his head and replied: —Yes... I am working.

en: The faintness of the voice was pitiable and dreadful. It was not the faintness of physical weakness, though confinement and hard fare no doubt had their part in it. Its deplorable peculiarity was, that it was the faintness of solitude and disuse. It was like the last feeble echo of a sound made long and long ago. So entirely had it lost the life and resonance of the human voice, that it affected the senses like a once beautiful colour faded away into a poor weak stain. So sunken and suppressed it was, that it was like a voice underground. So expressive it was, of a hopeless and lost creature, that a famished traveller, wearied out by lonely wandering in a wilderness, would have remembered home and friends in such a tone before lying down to die.
vi: That weak voice was both pitiful and frightening. It was not the weakness of a physically exhausted body, although certainly the captivity and harsh treatment had contributed to it. The pitiful aspect was due to the voice having long been unused in loneliness. The response sounded like the final dying echo of a sound that had been extinguished long ago. The voice had lost all vitality and resonance of human speech to the point that it was no different from a once beautiful color now faded into a pitiful, dull stain. The voice was deep and muffled, as if it were rising from the depths of the earth. The voice of a lost and desperate person, so sorrowful that one might think a starving, exhausted wanderer, lonely in the wilderness, would express their homesickness and longing for friends with such a mournful sound before collapsing to die.
tr: The frailty of the voice evoked both pity and suspicion within a person. It did not contain a physical weakness, but undoubtedly the impact of being imprisoned and enduring harsh conditions was significant. The pitiful state of the voice stemmed from loneliness and not being used for a long time. It was as if it were the last faint echo of a voice that had sounded long ago. It was so far removed from the liveliness and resonance of a human voice that it gave the impression of a once beautiful color having turned into a pale stain. This voice was so deep and suppressed that it seemed to come from underground. It was so affecting that only a hopeless and lost creature, a traveler exhausted from wandering alone in the desert, on the brink of death from hunger, could produce such a voice while reminiscing about its home and friends before lying down to die.
es: The languor of that voice hurt the ear. It was not that languor that follows the decline of strength, physical weakness, no, although it is undeniable that insufficient nourishment, hardships, and mistreatment received during the terrible captivity played some part in it: its special and typical characteristic came from the fact that it was a languor produced by solitude and lack of use of the voice. It was something like the echo of a sound that was born many years before and at a considerable distance: a voice that had lost the life, the timbre of a human voice, a voice that produced in the senses the same impression that the sight of a most beautiful and delicate color turned by the hand of centuries into a faint stain of indefinable hue would produce, a voice that vividly reflected the despair of a lost and abandoned human being so eloquently that any traveler whom hunger and fatigue had overcome in the solitudes of the arid desert he was traversing would recognize in its timbre the voice of his home, the voice of the loved ones he left in the world, before bowing his head to draw his last breath.

en: Some minutes of silent work had passed: and the haggard eyes had looked up again: not with any interest or curiosity, but with a dull mechanical perception, beforehand, that the spot where the only visitor they were aware of had stood, was not yet empty.
vi: A few minutes of silent work passed and the vacant eyes looked up again, not out of attention or curiosity, but just a vague mechanical sense of something in front, at the position where those eyes knew the sole guest had stood, and the spot was still not empty.
tr: Adam worked quietly for a while longer, then his weary eyes looked up again; it wasn't interest or curiosity, but a soulless realization, the spot where his visitor had stood a moment ago was still not empty.
es: After a few minutes that the old man spent working silently, oblivious to everything around him, he looked up again. In his eyes, there was not a trace of interest, not a trace of curiosity: they simply reflected that mechanical perception, that unconscious awareness that the space where an object or a person was previously seen remains occupied.

en: “I want,” said Defarge, who had not removed his gaze from the shoemaker, “to let in a little more light here. You can bear a little more?”
vi: − I want to open the door a bit more to let in some more light, - Defarge, who had not taken his eyes off the shoemaker, said. - Can you endure a little longer?
tr: "I say," said Defarge, without taking his eyes off the shoemaker, "it would be good if a little more daylight came in." Can you bear it?"
es: —I would like to let a little more light in—said Defarge, whose eyes had not left the shoemaker for an instant. — Can you bear it?

en: The shoemaker stopped his work; looked with a vacant air of listening, at the floor on one side of him; then similarly, at the floor on the other side of him; then, upward at the speaker.
vi: The shoemaker stopped working; his eyes looked down at the floor beside him as if he hadn't heard anything, then looked over to the other side of the floor, and then looked up towards the speaker.
tr: The shoemaker stopped his work; with a distracted demeanor, he looked to his right, then to his left, and finally at the man speaking above him.
es: The questioned person paused his work; he cast his eyes on the ground, to the right and left, as if looking for something, and then raised them towards the one who had just questioned him, finally asking:

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say?
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What were you saying?

en: “You can bear a little more light?”
vi: − − Can you handle it if it gets a bit brighter?
tr: "Can you endure a bit more light?"
es: —I was asking if you could tolerate a little more light.

en: “I must bear it, if you let it in.” (Laying the palest shadow of a stress upon the second word.)
vi: − − I have to, if you want. − − The shoemaker's voice vaguely emphasized the second word. −
tr: "If I have to endure, I will endure." (There was a faint hint of emphasis on the second word.)
es: —I will have to tolerate her, if you let her in. Defarge opened the window a little more.

en: The opened half-door was opened a little further, and secured at that angle for the time. A broad ray of light fell into the garret, and showed the workman with an unfinished shoe upon his lap, pausing in his labour. His few common tools and various scraps of leather were at his feet and on his bench. He had a white beard, raggedly cut, but not very long, a hollow face, and exceedingly bright eyes. The hollowness and thinness of his face would have caused them to look large, under his yet dark eyebrows and his confused white hair, though they had been really otherwise; but, they were naturally large, and looked unnaturally so. His yellow rags of shirt lay open at the throat, and showed his body to be withered and worn. He, and his old canvas frock, and his loose stockings, and all his poor tatters of clothes, had, in a long seclusion from direct light and air, faded down to such a dull uniformity of parchment-yellow, that it would have been hard to say which was which.
vi: The slightly ajar door was pushed open a bit more and temporarily secured at that angle. A broad beam of light shone into the attic room, revealing that the craftsman had stopped working, with an unfinished shoe resting on his lap. At his feet and on the bench were a few common tools and pieces of leather of various sizes. He had a white, scraggly beard, but it wasn't very long, a deeply sunken face, and strangely bright eyes. The gaunt, emaciated face made his eyes appear even larger under still-black eyebrows and a tousled head of gray hair, although that wasn't actually the case; but his already large eyes now seemed extraordinarily big. The tattered yellow shirt, open at the collar, exposed a wrinkled, withered body. Both he, the old canvas cloak, the baggy socks, and all the tattered, ragged clothes had been away from sunlight and fresh air for so long that everything had turned the same yellowish hue as dried skin, making it hard to distinguish between the man and his clothing.
tr: The half-open wing opened a bit more and was fixed at a certain angle. With a broad beam of light entering the attic, the craftsman who had paused his work and was sitting with an unfinished shoe in his lap came into view. At his feet and on his workbench were a few tools and various pieces of leather. He had a short, patchy white beard, a sunken face, and bright, sparkling eyes. His face was so sunken and thin that even if his eyes, peering out from under his dark eyebrows and tangled hair, were small, they would certainly appear large; but his eyes were naturally large and did not look natural at all. His withered old skin was visible through the open collar of his shabby yellow shirt. Both the man himself, his sack-like work clothes, his loose socks, in short, all those rags he wore had not seen light or air for so long that they had all taken on a lifeless pale yellow like parchment paper, making it hard to distinguish one from the other.
es: Defarge opened the window a little more. The rays of light that penetrated the attic perfectly illuminated the shoemaker, who had an unfinished shoe on his thigh. Scattered on the floor, or placed on the bench, were various tools of the trade. He was a man with a beard trimmed in any manner, but not of excessive length. In his gaunt and emaciated face, two eyes shone extraordinarily, which would have seemed large and slanted, even if they were not naturally so. The yellowish shirt he wore open at the chest revealed flabby flesh as white as paper. His skin, the old canvas blouse that covered the upper part of his body, the stockings, which, full of wrinkles, served as a wrapping for his fleshless calves, and in a word, all his garments, had acquired, by being deprived of the contact of air and light, a parchment tone that made it extremely difficult to determine the material used in their manufacture.

en: He had put up a hand between his eyes and the light, and the very bones of it seemed transparent. So he sat, with a steadfastly vacant gaze, pausing in his work. He never looked at the figure before him, without first looking down on this side of himself, then on that, as if he had lost the habit of associating place with sound; he never spoke, without first wandering in this manner, and forgetting to speak.
