vi: He raised a hand to shield his eyes from the light, which seemed to penetrate even through his bones. Stopping his work, he sat there motionless with a blank, vacant stare. He neither looked at the figure in front of him nor glanced to his side first before looking up at the person, as if he had lost the habit of associating positions with sounds; he did not speak without first seeking the source of the voice, and then forgot to utter a word.
tr: He put his hand in front of his eyes to block the light, his bones were so visible that it gave the impression of being transparent. The man, with fixed eyes, paused his work and sat like that for a while. Before looking at the person standing in front of him, he would always look to the right and then to the left; it was as if he had lost the habit of connecting sound with place; he never spoke without looking around like that, and then he would forget what he was going to say.
es: He had placed his hand like a screen between his eyes and the light, and all the bones of that hand were visible. He never looked at the person speaking to him without first lowering his eyes to the ground and moving them in all directions, as if he had lost the habit of associating space with sound; he never spoke without rambling, never remembered what he had just been asked, nor even what he himself was saying.

en: “Are you going to finish that pair of shoes to-day?” asked Defarge, motioning to Mr. Lorry to come forward.
vi: − Will you finish those shoes today? - Defarge asked while signaling Mr. Lorry to come over.
tr: Defarge, while signaling Mr. Lorry to come with his hand, asked the man, "Will you finish those shoes today?"
es: —Do you plan to finish that pair of shoes today?—asked Defarge, signaling to Lorry to come closer.

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say? −
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What are you saying?

en: “Do you mean to finish that pair of shoes to-day?”
vi: Are you planning to finish the pair of shoes today?
tr: "Do you absolutely have to finish those shoes today?"
es: —Do you plan to finish those shoes today?

en: “I can’t say that I mean to. I suppose so. I don’t know.”
vi: − I don't know if I can finish them. Probably will finish. Can't say for sure.
tr: "It doesn't necessarily have to end. I think... I don't know."
es: —I can't say if I think it or not. I think I do; but I don't know.

en: But, the question reminded him of his work, and he bent over it again.
vi: But that question reminded the worker of his job, and he bent down to continue working.
tr: But this question reminded him of the work he had left aside, and he bent over the task in front of him again.
es: The question reminded her of the task, and she devoted herself to it once again.

en: Mr. Lorry came silently forward, leaving the daughter by the door. When he had stood, for a minute or two, by the side of Defarge, the shoemaker looked up. He showed no surprise at seeing another figure, but the unsteady fingers of one of his hands strayed to his lips as he looked at it (his lips and his nails were of the same pale lead-colour), and then the hand dropped to his work, and he once more bent over the shoe. The look and the action had occupied but an instant.
vi: Mr. Lorry quietly walked in, leaving the girl standing at the doorway. When Mr. Lorry stood for about one or two minutes beside Defarge, the shoemaker looked up. He did not show any surprise at seeing another person, but while looking at the newcomer, one of his hands brought trembling fingers to his lips (both his lips and fingernails were the same leaden gray color), and then the hand returned to his work, once again bending over the shoe. The glance and the movement happened swiftly.
tr: Mr. Lorry left the young girl by the door and quietly advanced towards them. As he stood by Defarge for a minute or two, the shoemaker looked up. He did not seem at all surprised to see a second person, but at that moment the trembling fingers of one hand found his lips (both his lips and nails were the same pale lead color), then his hand returned to his work and once again bent over the shoe. This glance and manner were very fleeting.
es: Mr. Lorry approached silently, leaving the girl by the door. He had been standing next to Defarge for one or two minutes when the shoemaker raised his head. He did not show the slightest surprise at seeing two people instead of one.

en: “You have a visitor, you see,” said Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − You have a visitor, - Mr. Defarge said.
tr: "You have a visitor," said Monsieur Defarge.
es: "You have a visitor," observed Defarge.

en: “What did you say?”
vi: − What did you just say? −
tr: "What did you say?"
es: —What are you saying?

en: “Here is a visitor.”
vi: There is a visitor here.
tr: "You have a visitor.""
es: —This gentleman has come to visit you.

en: The shoemaker looked up as before, but without removing a hand from his work.
vi: The shoemaker looked up as before, but his hands did not stop working.
tr: The shoemaker looked up just like before, but this time he didn't stop what he was doing.
es: The shoemaker looked up again, but did not stop working.

en: “Come!” said Defarge. “Here is monsieur, who knows a well-made shoe when he sees one. Show him that shoe you are working at. Take it, monsieur.”
vi: − Hey! - Defarge said. - This gentleman here can tell if the shoe is well-made just by looking at it. Show him the shoe you're working on. Here it is, sir.
tr: "Look!" said Defarge. "There is a gentleman here who understands good shoes. Show him the shoe you made. Look, Monsieur."
es: "This gentleman," replied Defarge, "knows a lot about shoes." "Show him the one you are making so he can appreciate your work." "Take it, sir."

en: Mr. Lorry took it in his hand.
vi: Mr. Lorry reached out to take the shoe.
tr: Mr. Lorry took the shoe in his hand.
es: Lorry took the shoe in her hand.

en: “Tell monsieur what kind of shoe it is, and the maker’s name.”
vi: − Please let this gentleman know what style these shoes are and who made them.
tr: "Tell the gentleman what type of shoe this is and the name of the maker.""
es: —Tell this gentleman what kind of shoe it is, and the name of the worker who makes it.

en: There was a longer pause than usual, before the shoemaker replied:
vi: After a longer than usual silence, the shoemaker finally replied: − I forgot what you asked.
tr: There was a longer silence than before, then the shoemaker replied:
es: There was a longer pause than usual before the shoemaker responded.

en: “I forget what it was you asked me. What did you say?”
vi: After a longer than usual silence, the shoemaker finally replied: − I forgot what you asked. What did you just say?
tr: "I forgot what you asked. What did you say?"
es: —I have forgotten the question—he said at last. — What were you saying?

en: “I said, couldn’t you describe the kind of shoe, for monsieur’s information?”
vi: − I asked if you could tell this gentleman about the style of the shoe.
tr: "I had said, could you tell what type of shoe this is for the gentleman?"
es: —I asked you to kindly tell this gentleman what kind of shoe this is.

en: “It is a lady’s shoe. It is a young lady’s walking-shoe. It is in the present mode. I never saw the mode. I have had a pattern in my hand.” He glanced at the shoe with some little passing touch of pride.
vi: − This is a women's shoe. A walking shoe style for young ladies. It's the current trend. I've never seen this fashion before. I made it based on an existing model. - He looked at the shoe, a hint of pride on his face. − Which cobbler made these shoes?
tr: "This is a woman's shoe. A walking shoe for a young lady. Latest fashion. I don't know fashion. But I had a model in my hand."
es: —It is a lady's shoe... a walking shoe, suitable for a young lady. It is fashionable, although the truth is I have never seen the fashion. —And the name of the shoemaker?—asked Defarge.

en: “And the maker’s name?” said Defarge.
vi: - Defarge said.
tr: "I wonder what the name of the person who did it is?" said Defarge.
es: —And the name of the shoemaker?—asked Defarge.

en: Now that he had no work to hold, he laid the knuckles of the right hand in the hollow of the left, and then the knuckles of the left hand in the hollow of the right, and then passed a hand across his bearded chin, and so on in regular changes, without a moment’s intermission. The task of recalling him from the vagrancy into which he always sank when he had spoken, was like recalling some very weak person from a swoon, or endeavouring, in the hope of some disclosure, to stay the spirit of a fast-dying man.
vi: Now with nothing left to do, he kept interlocking the knuckles of his right hand into the palm of his left hand and then interlocking the knuckles of his left hand into the palm of his right hand, then he would raise one hand to his chin to stroke his beard. These actions repeated incessantly in that exact sequence. Every time he spoke, his mind would wander; reminding him was no different from trying to wake someone who had fainted or trying to sustain the life of someone on the brink of death in the hope of revealing something. −
tr: Since the shoemaker's hands were idle, he first placed his right hand in his left palm, then his left hand in his right palm, then ran his hand over his bearded chin, and continued to do this at regular intervals without any pause. When he spoke, it was like trying to bring a very weak person to consciousness or trying to preserve the soul of a dying man with a glimmer of hope.
es: The unfortunate man placed the knuckles of his right hand in the palm of his left, then reversed the order, placing the knuckles of the latter in the palm of the former, next he passed both over his beard and then over his forehead. The task of pulling him out of the abstraction in which he always became immersed after speaking did not yield in importance and difficulty to that of reviving a fainted person or of infusing a bit of artificial life into an almost dead body from which some revelation is hoped to be obtained.

en: “Did you ask me for my name?”
vi: Are you asking my name? −
tr: "Did you ask my name?"
es: —Did you ask my name?

en: “Assuredly I did.”
vi: That's right.
tr: "Yes, I asked for his name.""
es: —Indeed, that's what I asked.

en: “One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”
vi: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower. −
tr: "One Hundred Five, North Tower.""
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: “Is that all?”
vi: Is that all?
tr: "Is that all?""
es: —Nothing else?

en: “One Hundred and Five, North Tower.”
vi: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower.
tr: "One Hundred Five, North Tower.""
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: With a weary sound that was not a sigh, nor a groan, he bent to work again, until the silence was again broken.
vi: Uttering a sound that was neither a sigh nor a groan, he bent over to work until the silence was broken again. −
tr: He bent over his work again, emitting a tired sound that resembled neither a sigh nor a moan, until the silence was broken.
es: Exhaling something that was neither a sigh nor a moan, he returned to the task, which he did not pause until Mr. Lorry, staring at him intently, asked:

en: “You are not a shoemaker by trade?” said Mr. Lorry, looking steadfastly at him.
vi: You're not a professional shoemaker, are you? - Mr. Lorry asked while staring intently at the shoemaker.
tr: "Actually, you are not a shoemaker, are you?" said Mr. Lorry, without taking his eyes off him.
es: —Your profession has not been that of a shoemaker, has it?

en: His haggard eyes turned to Defarge as if he would have transferred the question to him: but as no help came from that quarter, they turned back on the questioner when they had sought the ground.
vi: His weary eyes turned towards Defarge as if wanting to pass the question on to him; but receiving no help from that direction, the eyes searched for an answer on the ground before looking up at the questioner.
tr: The man's weary eyes turned to Defarge as if to transfer the question to him; but when no help came from that side, he looked around and then turned to the one who asked the question.
es: The interrogated man turned his sunken eyes towards Defarge, as if expecting him to answer the question for him, but since no help came from that direction, he directed them towards his interrogator, not without first fixing them on the ground:

en: “I am not a shoemaker by trade? No, I was not a shoemaker by trade. I-I learnt it here. I taught myself. I asked leave to—”
vi: − I'm not a professional shoemaker? Yes, I'm not a professional shoemaker. I... I learned the trade here. I taught myself. I asked for permission...
tr: "Actually, am I not a shoemaker? No, I wasn't actually a shoemaker. I... I learned this here. By myself. I asked for permission for the thing-"
es: —Hasn't my profession been that of a shoemaker? No: it hasn't been. I learned... I learned the trade... there. I taught myself. I asked to be allowed...

en: He lapsed away, even for minutes, ringing those measured changes on his hands the whole time. His eyes came slowly back, at last, to the face from which they had wandered; when they rested on it, he started, and resumed, in the manner of a sleeper that moment awake, reverting to a subject of last night.
vi: He was dazed for several minutes, his hands twisting together continuously as if searching through that period of time. Finally, his gaze slowly turned towards the face he had lost; fixing his eyes on it when found, he continued to answer like someone who had just woken up and wanted to return to the unfinished conversation from the night before: − I asked for permission to study on my own, and it was very difficult, very long, before I was granted permission, and I have been making shoes ever since.
tr: There he hesitated, for minutes, repeating the same routine movements with his hands again. Then his eyes finally, slowly, turned back to the face they had left earlier, and as they focused on it, the shoemaker continued from where he had left off, with the demeanor of someone who had just woken up and returned to a topic discussed the previous night.
es: He lost, upon reaching this point, the thread of what he was saying. His gaze wandered errantly from one place to another until he found again the person he was speaking with, and continued, with the tone of someone who, upon waking up, resumes a conversation that sleep had interrupted:

en: “I asked leave to teach myself, and I got it with much difficulty after a long while, and I have made shoes ever since.”
vi: Finally, his gaze slowly turned towards the face he had lost; fixing his eyes on it when found, he continued to answer like someone who had just woken up and wanted to return to the unfinished conversation from the night before: − I asked for permission to study on my own, and it was very difficult, very long, before I was granted permission, and I have been making shoes ever since.
tr: "I asked for permission to learn on my own for something, and after they made me struggle for a long time, they gave it to me. Since then, I have been making shoes."
es: —I asked to be allowed to learn on my own, and I learned through time and difficulties. Since then, I have done nothing but make shoes.

en: As he held out his hand for the shoe that had been taken from him, Mr. Lorry said, still looking steadfastly in his face:
vi: As the shoemaker reached out to take back the shoe, Mr. Lorry said, his eyes never leaving the face of the person opposite him: "Dr. Manette, do you not remember anything about me?"
tr: When the shoemaker reached for the shoe taken from his hand, Mr. Lorry, his eyes still persistently on the man, said:
es: At the moment he reached out his hand to take the shoe from Lorry's, the latter asked him:

en: “Monsieur Manette, do you remember nothing of me?”
vi: As the shoemaker reached out to take back the shoe, Mr. Lorry said, his eyes never leaving the face of the person opposite him: "Dr. Manette, do you not remember anything about me?"
tr: "Monsieur Manette, don't you remember me at all?"
es: —Mr. Manette, don't you remember me?

en: The shoe dropped to the ground, and he sat looking fixedly at the questioner.
vi: The shoe fell to the ground, and the shoemaker sat staring intently at the questioner.
tr: The shoe fell to the ground and the shoemaker fixed his eyes on the man asking the questions.
es: The shoe fell to the ground and the cobbler remained motionless, his eyes fixed on the face of the person who was asking him.

en: “Monsieur Manette”; Mr. Lorry laid his hand upon Defarge’s arm; “do you remember nothing of this man? Look at him. Look at me. Is there no old banker, no old business, no old servant, no old time, rising in your mind, Monsieur Manette?”
vi: "Dr. Manette," Mr. Lorry grasped Defarge's arm, "do you not remember anything about this man?" Look at him. Look at me. Does your mind not recall anything about the old banker, the old job, the old servant, the old times, Dr. Manette?
tr: "Monsieur Manette," said Mr. Lorry, placing his hand on Defarge's arm; "do you not remember this man? Take a look at him. Look at me. Do the old banker, your old job, your old servant, the old times not come to mind, Monsieur Manette?"
es: —Mr. Manette—repeated Lorry, placing a hand on Defarge's shoulder. —Don't you remember this man? Look at him closely! Look at me too! Don't the figures of your former banker, the memory of your old business, the image of your old servant rise in your mind?

en: As the captive of many years sat looking fixedly, by turns, at Mr. Lorry and at Defarge, some long obliterated marks of an actively intent intelligence in the middle of the forehead, gradually forced themselves through the black mist that had fallen on him. They were overclouded again, they were fainter, they were gone; but they had been there. And so exactly was the expression repeated on the fair young face of her who had crept along the wall to a point where she could see him, and where she now stood looking at him, with hands which at first had been only raised in frightened compassion, if not even to keep him off and shut out the sight of him, but which were now extending towards him, trembling with eagerness to lay the spectral face upon her warm young breast, and love it back to life and hope—so exactly was the expression repeated (though in stronger characters) on her fair young face, that it looked as though it had passed like a moving light, from him to her.
vi: As the man who had been imprisoned for years stared, shifting his gaze from Lorry to Defarge, the traces of clear recognition that had long been erased from his forehead now slowly struggled to tear through the dark cloud enveloping his memory. The signs of recognition were covered, faded, flickering, and lingering. And the same expression repeated on the forehead of the beautiful girl who had been stealthily following the wall to a spot where she could see the shoemaker. She stood there, her hands initially raised in fear, as if to ward off the sight of the man, now extended, trembling with a deep desire to embrace that ghostly face, to bring life and hope to him with her love. More clearly imprinted, the expression on the girl's forehead was the same as that of the shoemaker, as if it had been transmitted like a beam of light from him to her.
tr: The man who had been imprisoned for years sat down and stared alternately at Mr. Lorry and Defarge, the traces of intelligence that had almost faded from the center of his forehead slowly dispersing the dark fog that had settled over him. Then his mind clouded again, becoming vague and completely disappearing; but for a while, they were there. The expression on the beautiful face of the young girl who had slowly moved to a point from where she could see him from the wall and was now watching him from where she stood was the same; at first, she brought her hands to her face out of a mixture of fear and compassion, not to prevent herself from seeing him, but now her hands were reaching out to him, trembling with the excitement of pressing his ghost-like face to her warm chest and giving him life and hope again – the expression on the girl's beautiful, young face was so identical to the man's (but the girl's expression was stronger) that it gave the impression that a moving light had passed from the man to the girl.
es: While the unfortunate man, recently freed from the tomb where he had been buried alive for so many years, fixed his gaze now on Mr. Lorry, now on Defarge, his forehead revealed that in the depths of his brain, some sparks of intelligence were waging a fierce battle with the profound darkness that, reigning as the sole mistress, paralyzed all his activity. The darkness intensified, unwilling to lose its dominion; the sparks weakened and eventually died out; but they had shone, and what once shines, what once awakens, is not entirely extinguished, it can shine again. Thus it happened indeed. When moments later his gaze fell upon the youthful face of the girl who, crawling along the wall, had approached, and standing with outstretched hands, watched him, first with a mixture of infinite compassion and terror, and later with a fervent longing to press that spectral head against her chest and a fervent desire to instill in his soul the warmth of life, the light of love and hope, intelligence emerged again, but more powerfully than the first time, at the mysterious conjuring of the spark that, emanating from the young woman's soul, went to ignite that of the old man.

en: Darkness had fallen on him in its place. He looked at the two, less and less attentively, and his eyes in gloomy abstraction sought the ground and looked about him in the old way. Finally, with a deep long sigh, he took the shoe up, and resumed his work.
vi: The darkness once again covered the worker's forehead. He looked at the two men in front of him, becoming more and more distracted, then his gloomy eyes wandered around the floor as before. Finally, with a long sigh, he picked up the shoe and continued his work.
tr: A darkness had fallen over the man again. He looked at the two men with much less attention than before, and his eyes found their place again in that dim reverie, and just like before, he looked to the right and to the left. Finally, with a long and deep sigh, he picked up the shoe from the ground and continued his work.
es: The shadows, stubbornly resisting, finally remained masters of the field. The old man looked at the people in front of him with less attention than before, and his eyes sought the ground with the air of gloomy abstraction that was peculiar to them. After a few seconds, he sighed, picked up the shoe, and resumed his task.

en: “Have you recognised him, monsieur?” asked Defarge in a whisper.
vi: − Do you recognize him? - Defarge whispered.
tr: "Do you remember him, monsieur?" asked Defarge in a whisper.
es: —Have you recognized him, sir?—whispered Defarge in Lorry's ear.

en: “Yes; for a moment. At first I thought it quite hopeless, but I have unquestionably seen, for a single moment, the face that I once knew so well. Hush! Let us draw further back. Hush!”
vi: − Yes, just for a moment. At first, I thought it was hopeless, but clearly, in just a fleeting moment, I recognized the face that had once been so familiar to me. Shh! Let's move a little further away. Shh!
tr: "Yes; for a moment. At first, I had no hope at all, but then suddenly, that face I once knew so well came to life in my mind. Shh! Anyway, let's step back a bit. Slowly!"
es: —I deemed it impossible at first, but even if only for brief moments, I managed to recognize the face that was so familiar to me once... Shh... silence! Let's move a little further away!

en: She had moved from the wall of the garret, very near to the bench on which he sat. There was something awful in his unconsciousness of the figure that could have put out its hand and touched him as he stooped over his labour.
vi: The girl had moved from the wall of the attic room to very close to the cobbler's bench. It was truly frightening; he kept bending over his work, completely unaware of the presence of someone so close that they only needed to reach out to touch him.
tr: The young girl had moved away from the wall of the attic and had approached the bench where the man was sitting. The shoemaker was so engrossed in his work that it was a grave situation that he was unaware of a hand that could reach out and touch him at any moment.
es: The girl had separated from the wall and was silently approaching the bench where the old man was sitting. It was a simply impressive scene.

en: Not a word was spoken, not a sound was made. She stood, like a spirit, beside him, and he bent over his work.
vi: Not a word; not a sound. She stood still like a ghost beside him, while he remained bent over the shoe.
tr: There wasn't a sound. The girl stood next to the man like a ghost for a while, and the man continued to bend over his work.
es: No one uttered a word. Not the slightest sound came to disturb that august silence. The girl, resembling a spirit, stood beside the shoemaker, and he worked with fervor.

en: It happened, at length, that he had occasion to change the instrument in his hand, for his shoemaker’s knife. It lay on that side of him which was not the side on which she stood. He had taken it up, and was stooping to work again, when his eyes caught the skirt of her dress. He raised them, and saw her face. The two spectators started forward, but she stayed them with a motion of her hand. She had no fear of his striking at her with the knife, though they had.
vi: It was a long time after that before he put down the tool in his hand to pick up the skinning knife. The knife was lying on the far side from where the girl was standing. He picked up the knife, bent down to work again, and his eyes caught the hem of her dress. He looked up and saw the girl. The other two started to step forward, but she waved them back. They were afraid the shoemaker might use the knife to harm the girl, but she was not.
tr: At one point, he had to put down the tool in his hand and pick up the utility knife. The utility knife was on the ground, on the opposite side of where the girl was standing. The shoemaker had just picked it up from the ground and was about to bend over his work again when his eyes caught the hem of the girl's dress. When he lifted his head, he met her face. The two men watching them seemed about to step forward, but the young girl signaled them to stop with her hand. The girl was never afraid that the shoemaker would attack her with the knife, but the others were afraid of this.
es: It happened that after a while, the old man needed to switch the tool he was working with for the cobbler's knife. He picked it up, and when he was about to use it, he stopped. His eyes had just seen a skirt. Slowly, they rose until they found the girl's face, and there they stopped. Gusts of terror crossed the forehead of the unfortunate man; his lips moved as if they wanted to pronounce words that his throat refused to articulate, his breathing became labored and panting, and finally he was heard to murmur:

en: He stared at her with a fearful look, and after a while his lips began to form some words, though no sound proceeded from them. By degrees, in the pauses of his quick and laboured breathing, he was heard to say:
vi: He looked at Manette with a fearful gaze, and after a moment, his lips moved without forming words. Then slowly, amidst heavy, rapid breaths, a sentence emerged word by word: −
tr: The shoemaker looked at the girl with fear-filled eyes, and soon his lips began to move, but no meaningful sound was coming out yet. Then, amidst his hurried and weary breaths, something came out of his mouth in broken fragments:
es: Gusts of terror crossed the forehead of the unfortunate man; his lips moved as if they wanted to pronounce words that his throat refused to articulate, his breathing became labored and panting, and finally he was heard to murmur:

en: “What is this?”
vi: What is this?
tr: "Who is this?"
es: —What is this?

en: With the tears streaming down her face, she put her two hands to her lips, and kissed them to him; then clasped them on her breast, as if she laid his ruined head there.
vi: Tears streaming down her cheeks, the girl raised her hands to her lips to send the shoemaker a kiss, then clasped her hands together and placed them on her chest as if cradling his sorrowful head. −
tr: As tears streamed down her cheeks, the girl brought her hands to her lips and sent a kiss to the man; then, as if she were resting his devastated head on her chest, she clasped her hands over her chest.
es: The girl, down whose cheeks streams of tears were running, brought her hands, which were clasped in a pleading gesture, to her lips, kissed them, and then crossed her arms over her chest as if she held the beloved head of the old man between them.

en: “You are not the gaoler’s daughter?”
vi: Aren't you the daughter of the jailer?
tr: "Are you the jailer's daughter?"
es: —Are you the jailer's daughter?—he asked.

en: She sighed “No.”
vi: − No, - the girl sighed.
tr: The young girl sighed and said, "No."
es: —No—she sighed.

en: “Who are you?”
vi: − Who are you?
tr: The young girl sighed and said, "No."
es: —Who are you, then?

en: Not yet trusting the tones of her voice, she sat down on the bench beside him. He recoiled, but she laid her hand upon his arm. A strange thrill struck him when she did so, and visibly passed over his frame; he laid the knife down softly, as he sat staring at her.
vi: Not trusting her own voice, she sat down on the bench next to him. The shoemaker stepped back, but she had already grabbed his arm. As soon as her hand touched him, a strange shiver clearly spread throughout his body; the shoemaker gently placed the knife down, his eyes fixed on the girl.
tr: The girl was too excited to speak, she sat quietly next to the man. The shoemaker seemed to move aside, but the girl placed her hand on his arm. As a result, the man's body shivered with a strange excitement; he put the knife aside and fixed his eyes on the girl.
es: Understanding the impossibility of articulating a word, the young woman took a seat on the bench next to the old man. He wanted to move away, but felt the sweet pressure of his companion's hand on his arm, and, leaving the knife on the bench, he remained contemplating her.

en: Her golden hair, which she wore in long curls, had been hurriedly pushed aside, and fell down over her neck. Advancing his hand by little and little, he took it up and looked at it. In the midst of the action he went astray, and, with another deep sigh, fell to work at his shoemaking.
vi: Manette's golden curls had been hastily tossed to either side and hung loosely around her neck. The shoemaker's hand inched closer to her, lifting a lock of hair to examine it. His mind suddenly drifted away again, he sighed once more, then bent over the shoe he was working on.
tr: The girl's long, curly golden hair was hastily tossed to the side, cascading down her neck. The man slowly reached out his hand, took hold of the girl's hair, and examined it. But at that moment, his mind became confused, and with a deep sigh, he bent over the shoe again.
es: The girl's golden hair, styled in long ringlets, fell over her shoulders. The old man slowly and timidly reached out a hand to touch it; their eyes lit up, but the light that had momentarily shone in his intelligence faded, and, letting out a sigh, he bowed his head and tried to resume his work.

en: But not for long. Releasing his arm, she laid her hand upon his shoulder. After looking doubtfully at it, two or three times, as if to be sure that it was really there, he laid down his work, put his hand to his neck, and took off a blackened string with a scrap of folded rag attached to it. He opened this, carefully, on his knee, and it contained a very little quantity of hair: not more than one or two long golden hairs, which he had, in some old day, wound off upon his finger.
vi: But not for long. Releasing the shoemaker's arm, the girl placed her hand on his shoulder. After two or three times looking at that hand full of doubt as if to make sure it was really there, he put down his work again, raised his hand to his neck, and removed a darkened string with a small folded piece of rag tied to it. The shoemaker placed the cloth bundle on his knee, carefully opened it, and inside was a small amount of hair, just a few long golden strands that he had long ago wrapped around his finger.
tr: It didn't take too long. The girl removed her hand from the man's arm and placed it on his shoulder. The shoemaker, after turning around a few times and looking suspiciously at the girl's hand as if to make sure she was still there, set the shoe aside, brought his hand to his collar, and pulled out a tarnished string with a folded piece of cloth tied to the end. He carefully opened it on his knees; inside, there was a very small amount of hair, a few strands of long golden hair that he used to wrap around his finger in the old days.
es: His abstraction lasted very little time. After directing two or three glances at the shoe, as if to make sure it was still on his knee, he resolutely placed it on the bench, brought his hands to his neck, and untied a dirty and blackened cord that surrounded it, from which hung a small cloth bag. Placing the bag on his knee, he carefully opened it and took out two locks of hair, which he examined closely.

en: He took her hair into his hand again, and looked closely at it. “It is the same. How can it be! When was it! How was it!”
vi: He lifted a strand of the girl's hair and examined it carefully. − Exactly the same. How could it be! Since when! How could it be!
tr: Then he held the girl's hair again and looked at it carefully. "The same." How could it be! When was it! How did it happen!"
es: Placing the bag on his knee, he carefully opened it and took out two locks of hair, which he examined closely. —It's the same one!—he murmured. —How is it possible? When did it happen? How did it happen?

en: As the concentrated expression returned to his forehead, he seemed to become conscious that it was in hers too. He turned her full to the light, and looked at her.
vi: As the wrinkles of thought appeared on the shoemaker's forehead, he seemed to recognize that the girl's forehead had the same expression. He turned her completely towards the light to look at her.
tr: The entire intensity of his expression had shifted to the man's forehead, and he noticed that the same expression was on the girl as well. He turned her towards the light and looked again.
es: His forehead lit up more than ever. Turning towards the girl, he took her head in his hands, positioned it so that the light from the window fell fully on her face, and after a long moment of silent contemplation, he said:

en: “She had laid her head upon my shoulder, that night when I was summoned out—she had a fear of my going, though I had none—and when I was brought to the North Tower they found these upon my sleeve. ‘You will leave me them? They can never help me to escape in the body, though they may in the spirit.’ Those were the words I said. I remember them very well.”
vi: − She rested her head on my shoulder that night when I was summoned... she feared this departure, even though I did not... and when I was taken to the North Tower, people saw these strands of hair on my sleeve. “Will you leave them with me? These strands of hair cannot help me escape physically, though they might free my spirit.” Those were the words I said. I still remember very clearly.
tr: "She had rested her head on my shoulder, it was the evening I was summoned – she was afraid I would leave, but I was not afraid at all – and when I was taken to the North Tower, they found these on me. 'Would you leave these with me? They won't help me escape from here, but they will be good for my soul.' That's what I told them. I remember it very well."
es: —That night, the night they called me out, she had rested her head on my shoulder... She feared that I would go out... I didn't feel the slightest apprehension... and when they locked me in the North Tower, they found this hidden in my sleeve... «Will you allow me to keep it?»—I asked them. —They shall not facilitate the escape of my body... although thanks to them, my spirit will frequently pass through the bars». Those were the words I said to them... I remember them as if I had just spoken them.

en: He formed this speech with his lips many times before he could utter it. But when he did find spoken words for it, they came to him coherently, though slowly.
vi: His lips moved for a long time before he could utter a word. But when he finally spoke, he did so very clearly, albeit slowly.
tr: His lips had done quite a bit of preparation to be able to utter these words. But as they slowly spilled from his mouth, they were quite coherent.
es: For a long time, his lips moved before he managed to articulate the words that are transcribed, but when he could speak, he did so perfectly, albeit very slowly.

en: “How was this?—Was it you?”
vi: − How can that be?... Is that her?
tr: "How did this happen? Was it you?"
es: —I don't understand...—he added. — Was it you?

en: Once more, the two spectators started, as he turned upon her with a frightful suddenness. But she sat perfectly still in his grasp, and only said, in a low voice, “I entreat you, good gentlemen, do not come near us, do not speak, do not move!”
vi: Once again, Mr. Lorry and Defarge were startled when the shoemaker suddenly turned to look at the girl, so abruptly it was frightening. But while he held her tightly, Manette remained very still and softly said: − Please, sirs, please do not come near us, do not speak, do not move.
tr: As the shoemaker turned towards the girl, the two men once again rushed forward in a panic. But the young girl, with the man's eyes still on her, continued to sit calmly and said in a low voice, "Please, gentlemen, do not approach, do not say anything, do not move from your place!"
es: The two silent witnesses of the scene advanced alarmed upon observing the abruptness with which the old man turned towards the girl; but she, perfectly calm, said to them in a very low voice: —I beg you, my good sirs, not to come closer, not to speak, not to move.

en: “Hark!” he exclaimed. “Whose voice was that?”
vi: − Listen! - He exclaimed. - Whose voice is that?
tr: "Stop!" the man shouted. "Whose voice was that?"
es: —Shh!—exclaimed the old man. —Who is speaking?

en: His hands released her as he uttered this cry, and went up to his white hair, which they tore in a frenzy. It died out, as everything but his shoemaking did die out of him, and he refolded his little packet and tried to secure it in his breast; but he still looked at her, and gloomily shook his head.
vi: Along with the exclamation, his hands released the girl and frantically tore at his own white hair. This outburst too would pass, like so many things that had faded from his mind except for shoemaking. He folded the small cloth bundle and tried to tie it around his neck as before, but he still looked at the girl without taking his eyes off her and shook his head sadly. −
tr: With this outcry, he removed his hands from the girl and brought them to his disheveled white hair. He had lost her, he had lost everything except his shoemaking skills; he folded his small package again and tucked it safely into his bosom; but his eyes were still on the young girl and he shook his head pensively.
es: He put the curls back in the little bag and wanted to tie the string around his neck again, but without taking his eyes off the young woman and shaking his head with an expression of somber pain.

en: “No, no, no; you are too young, too blooming. It can’t be. See what the prisoner is. These are not the hands she knew, this is not the face she knew, this is not a voice she ever heard. No, no. She was—and He was—before the slow years of the North Tower—ages ago. What is your name, my gentle angel?”
vi: No, no, no; you are too young, too fresh. It cannot be her. Look at the state of this prisoner. This is not the familiar hand, this is not the familiar face, this is not the voice she used to hear. No, no. She was... and he was... before enduring many long years in the North Tower... long ago. What is your name, gentle angel?
tr: "No, no; you are very young, very fresh. You cannot be her. Look at this prisoner. These are not the hands he knows, this is not the face he knows, this is a voice he has never heard. That woman, that man – before all those years in the North Tower – they are long gone. What is your name, beautiful angel?"
es: —No, no, no!—he replied. —It is not possible!... You are too young, too much of a child! You see the effects of being buried in a prison!... These are not the hands she knew, nor this the face she saw, nor this the voice that sounded so sweet in her ears... No, no! She... and he... Many years ago... many eternities... before the slow centuries of the North Tower... Tell me! What is your name, beautiful angel?

en: Hailing his softened tone and manner, his daughter fell upon her knees before him, with her appealing hands upon his breast.
vi: Seeing the shoemaker's tone had softened, his daughter knelt before her father, placing her pleading hands on his chest. −
tr: Upon the softening of the man's tone and demeanor, the young girl knelt down and placed her beautiful hands on her father's chest:
es: The daughter fell to her knees at the feet of the unhappy father, her hands clasped in front of her chest.

en: “O, sir, at another time you shall know my name, and who my mother was, and who my father, and how I never knew their hard, hard history. But I cannot tell you at this time, and I cannot tell you here. All that I may tell you, here and now, is, that I pray to you to touch me and to bless me. Kiss me, kiss me! O my dear, my dear!”
vi: Oh, sir. There will come a time when you will know my name, know who my mother is, know who my father is, and know why I am aware of the harsh, suffering story of my parents. But right now I cannot tell you, and I cannot tell you here. Right now, all I can say is please hold me, bless me. Kiss me, kiss me! Oh, dear sir, dear sir!
tr: "Ah sir, another time you will learn the names of my mother, my father, and myself, and how it is that I never knew their difficult story. But now, especially here, I cannot tell you. The only thing I can tell you here and now is, I beg you, hold me, bless me. Kiss me, kiss me please! For heaven's sake!"
es: —Oh, sir!—he exclaimed. —On another occasion, you will know my name, who my mother was, and who my unfortunate father was, whose painful story never reached my ears! I cannot say it at this moment or in this place. The only thing I can tell you now, right here, is to embrace and bless me! Yes...! Kiss me... kiss me!

en: His cold white head mingled with her radiant hair, which warmed and lighted it as though it were the light of Freedom shining on him.
vi: Your cold white hair mingles with my golden hair, the spring head warming and illuminating the old head like the light of Freedom shining. −
tr: The man's cold white head mingled with the girl's radiant hair, which shone like the "light of freedom" and both warmed and illuminated her.
es: The snow-white hair mingled with the golden hair.

en: “If you hear in my voice—I don’t know that it is so, but I hope it is—if you hear in my voice any resemblance to a voice that once was sweet music in your ears, weep for it, weep for it! If you touch, in touching my hair, anything that recalls a beloved head that lay on your breast when you were young and free, weep for it, weep for it! If, when I hint to you of a Home that is before us, where I will be true to you with all my duty and with all my faithful service, I bring back the remembrance of a Home long desolate, while your poor heart pined away, weep for it, weep for it!”
vi: If you hear my voice... I don't know if it's true, but I hope so... if you hear my voice like someone who once was sweet music to your ears, then please weep, please weep! If you stroke, stroke my hair, and remember a beloved head that once rested on your chest in the days of free youth, then please weep, please weep! If I suggest to you that a family is waiting for us, where I will wholeheartedly fulfill my duty to care for you, if I remind you of a family long desolate while your heart longed, then please weep, please weep!
tr: "If you have likened my voice to the one that once caressed your ear – I don't know if it is so, but I hope it is – let your tears flow! If touching my hair reminded you of the beloved head you rested against your chest in your youthful and free days, let your tears flow! If when I spoke to you about a Home where I could serve you with all my respect and reverence, it reminded you of a Home that dissolved in the old days while your poor heart melted away, let your tears flow!"
es: —If my voice... I don't know if it will be so, but I hope... if my voice awakens in you echoes of another voice that in better years sounded in your ears like delightful music... cry for her... cry for her! If my hair reminds you of a beloved head that happily and joyfully rested on your chest when you were young and free, cry for her, cry for her! If upon seeing yourself in the home that awaits us, memories of another home arise in your mind, deserted and ruined many years ago, another home that fell to pieces while your heart languished and died within the black walls of a dungeon, cry for it... cry for it!

en: She held him closer round the neck, and rocked him on her breast like a child.
vi: The girl hugged the shoemaker tightly around the neck and rocked him like a baby. −
tr: The young girl grabbed the shoemaker by the neck, pressed him against her chest, and rocked him like a child.
es: The young woman, while saying these words, held the old man's white head in her arms and rocked it as if he were a child.

en: “If, when I tell you, dearest dear, that your agony is over, and that I have come here to take you from it, and that we go to England to be at peace and at rest, I cause you to think of your useful life laid waste, and of our native France so wicked to you, weep for it, weep for it! And if, when I shall tell you of my name, and of my father who is living, and of my mother who is dead, you learn that I have to kneel to my honoured father, and implore his pardon for having never for his sake striven all day and lain awake and wept all night, because the love of my poor mother hid his torture from me, weep for it, weep for it! Weep for her, then, and for me! Good gentlemen, thank God! I feel his sacred tears upon my face, and his sobs strike against my heart. O, see! Thank God for us, thank God!”
vi: Oh, dear sir, if I say that your suffering has ended, that I have come here to dispel your sorrow, that we will go to England to live in peace, if I remind you of a precious life that was taken away, remember the cruel homeland of France, then please weep, please weep! And if ever I tell you my name, the name of the living father, the name of the dead mother, then you will understand that I must kneel before that revered father to ask for forgiveness because I did not search for you day by day, mourn for you night by night, because the poor mother hid your suffering out of love for me, then please weep, please weep! Weep for that mother, and for me too! Oh, dear sir, thank God! I have seen your sacred tears fall on my face, and your sobs resonate in my heart. Oh, look! Thank God, thank God!
tr: "If, when I tell you that your suffering has ended, that I have come here to put an end to it, that we will go to England and live in peace and comfort, it reminds you of how your life has been wasted and the terrible things that have happened to you in our homeland France, let your tears flow! When I tell you my name, the name of my living father and my deceased mother, moreover, when you learn that I had to kneel before my honorable father and beg him to forgive me because my poor mother hid the bitter truth about my father from me solely out of her love for me, and therefore I could not cry for her day and night, let your tears flow! Let your tears flow both for him and for me! Ah, dear gentlemen, thank God! I feel his sacred tears on my face, his sobs in my heart. Ah! Thank God, thank you, my God!"
es: —Cry too, dear... dear sir, if when I tell you that your agonies are over forever, that I have come to take you with me to England, where you can enjoy peace and perhaps happiness, I am the cause of you remembering a life that could have been so useful to your fellow men, and that, however, has been wasted! Cry, shed bitter tears over our homeland, over France, which has been so cruel to you! And if when I reveal my name to you, if when I tell you my father's name, who is still alive, and my mother's name, who has died, you know that I will have to fall to my knees at the feet of my beloved father, and that I will need to beg his forgiveness for not having spent every day of my life awake and working to help him, and crying every night, because the love of my unfortunate mother wanted to keep the bitter cup of pain away from my lips, hiding the horrible story from me, cry... cry for her... cry for me too! My good sirs!... Let us thank God! I feel the sacred tears of... this gentleman running down my face, and I feel the sobs of his chest echoing in my heart! Oh!... Thank you... thank you, my God!

en: He had sunk in her arms, and his face dropped on her breast: a sight so touching, yet so terrible in the tremendous wrong and suffering which had gone before it, that the two beholders covered their faces.
vi: He collapsed into the girl's embrace, resting his head on her chest - a touching yet terrifying scene because of the immense injustice and suffering that had occurred before, causing the two men witnessing it to cover their faces, unable to look.
tr: The man was deeply buried in the girl's arms, his face fallen onto her chest; it was such a scene, both poignant and containing the great mistake and pain that had been made, that the two men covered their faces with their hands.
es: The old man had fallen into the girl's arms, with his head resting on her chest. So moving was the scene, and so terrible at the same time, as it was the result of horrendous injustices and tremendous sufferings, that the two witnesses had to cover their faces with their hands.

en: When the quiet of the garret had been long undisturbed, and his heaving breast and shaken form had long yielded to the calm that must follow all storms—emblem to humanity, of the rest and silence into which the storm called Life must hush at last—they came forward to raise the father and daughter from the ground. He had gradually dropped to the floor, and lay there in a lethargy, worn out. She had nestled down with him, that his head might lie upon her arm; and her hair drooping over him curtained him from the light.
vi: When the attic room had been silent for a long time and the sobbing breaths along with the trembling body of the shoemaker had sunk into stillness - the calm after every storm; a symbol of human compassion, of the peace that remains when the storms of life have passed - it was then that Mr. Lorry and Defarge came to help the father and daughter stand up. The shoemaker had slowly collapsed to the floor and lay exhausted in a faint. The girl had sunk down beside him, her arm cradling the shoemaker's head; her hair spread over her father's face like a curtain shielding the source of light.
tr: As the silence of the attic prolonged and the man's swelling heart and trembling body calmed down, like the silence that settles after every storm – this was a symbol of humanity showing that the storm called life eventually calms down, ending in peace and quiet – the men rushed forward to lift the father and daughter from the ground. The shoemaker had slowly collapsed and now lay on the ground in an exhausted state, as if numb. His daughter had also collapsed to the ground with him and had taken her head into her arms; her hair completely blocked the light falling on the man.
es: When tranquility was restored in the attic, and the old man's chest, which for a long while seemed about to burst into pieces, regained the serenity that always follows the most violent storms... which is what happens with humanity, whose storms, which we call life, eventually calm down, giving way to rest and silence; when the old man was calm, the two witnesses approached to lift the father and daughter from the ground. The former had been languishing until he fell to the ground, lacking strength. The daughter fell with him, and remained on the ground, her head resting on his shoulder and her golden hair spread over her eyes.

en: “If, without disturbing him,” she said, raising her hand to Mr. Lorry as he stooped over them, after repeated blowings of his nose, “all could be arranged for our leaving Paris at once, so that, from the very door, he could be taken away—”
vi: − If we don't disturb him, - she said while raising her hand to Mr. Lorry as he, after a few sniffs, was bending down to lift the father and daughter up, - we can arrange everything to leave Paris immediately, take him away from here... −
tr: As Mr. Lorry leaned over them, sniffing repeatedly, the young girl raised her hand and said, "If we can arrange to get him out of Paris without disturbing him, that is, from the doorstep..."
es: —If it were possible—said the girl, reaching out a hand to Lorry—to arrange everything to leave Paris immediately, in such a way that from this very house... —We must keep one important thing in mind—replied Lorry, interrupting the young woman.

en: “But, consider. Is he fit for the journey?” asked Mr. Lorry.
vi: But think about it. Does he have the strength to travel a long distance? Mr. Lorry asked.
tr: "But wait. Is your father suitable for this journey?" asked Mr. Lorry.
es: — Is he ready to undertake the journey?

en: “More fit for that, I think, than to remain in this city, so dreadful to him.”
vi: − I think it's better than staying in this city, which is too terrible for him.
tr: "I think it would be much more appropriate for him to stay here, this place is too terrifying for him."
es: —I believe that the journey, with all its inconveniences, must be more beneficial to him than staying in Paris, where he has suffered so much.

en: “It is true,” said Defarge, who was kneeling to look on and hear. “More than that; Monsieur Manette is, for all reasons, best out of France. Say, shall I hire a carriage and post-horses?”
vi: − That's right, - Defarge said, he was kneeling on the floor looking at everyone and listening to the story. - The most important thing is that Mr. Manette will be safer if he leaves France. So should I go hire a carriage?
tr: Defarge, bending down to hear better, said, "Right." "In any case, leaving France will be good for Monsieur Manette in many ways. What do you think, should I arrange horses with a stagecoach?"
es: —Nothing more certain—interjected Defarge, who had knelt down to see and hear better. —Even disregarding the consideration that the young lady just hinted at, a thousand reasons advise that he leaves France as soon as possible. Do you want me to hire a post chaise with horses?

en: “That’s business,” said Mr. Lorry, resuming on the shortest notice his methodical manners; “and if business is to be done, I had better do it.”
vi: − That's business, - Mr. Lorry returned to his usual professional demeanor, - and business must be done, so it's better if I do it. −
tr: "This is a job in itself," said Mr. Lorry, summarizing the matter in his usual straightforward manner, "and if a job is to be done, I must be the one to do it.""
es: —The business is that—observed Lorry, who needed very little to return to his favorite topic—and when a business needs to be concluded, the sooner it is finished, the better.

en: “Then be so kind,” urged Miss Manette, “as to leave us here. You see how composed he has become, and you cannot be afraid to leave him with me now. Why should you be? If you will lock the door to secure us from interruption, I do not doubt that you will find him, when you come back, as quiet as you leave him. In any case, I will take care of him until you return, and then we will remove him straight.”
vi: Then please let us stay here, - Miss Manette urged. - You see how calm my father is now, I will be fine staying here, sir. Why should you be afraid? If you lock the door so no one disturbs us, I am sure when you return, my father will still be as calm as before. Anyway, I will be here to take care of my father while you are gone, and when you return, we will immediately take him away from here.
tr: "Then, if I may ask," said Miss Manette, "could you leave us alone now? Look how much calmer he is, there's no need for you to be afraid to leave us alone. What could possibly happen? If you lock us in to ensure we are not disturbed, I'm sure you'll find him as quiet as you left him when you return. In any case, I will watch over him until you return, and then we will take him directly to the stable."
es: —In that case—said Miss Manette,—please leave us here. You have seen how calm he has become, which should convince you that you can leave me alone with him without the slightest fear. If you would be so kind as to lock the door when you leave, to protect us from interruptions, I dare to guarantee that when you return, you will find him as calm as you leave him. I will take care of him while you make the preparations. The essential thing is to take him away as soon as possible.

en: Both Mr. Lorry and Defarge were rather disinclined to this course, and in favour of one of them remaining. But, as there were not only carriage and horses to be seen to, but travelling papers; and as time pressed, for the day was drawing to an end, it came at last to their hastily dividing the business that was necessary to be done, and hurrying away to do it.
vi: Neither Mr. Lorry nor Defarge was satisfied with this arrangement and wanted one of them to stay behind. But it wasn't just a matter of horses and carriages; there were also travel documents to consider, and time was running out as the day was coming to an end. In the end, they hastily divided the necessary tasks between them and hurriedly set off.
tr: Neither Mr. Lorry nor Defarge were willing to leave them alone, and they thought it would be good for one of them to stay. However, not only the carriage and horses needed to be arranged, but also the travel documents; moreover, time was running out, the day was ending, so they hurriedly divided the tasks and left.
es: The solution was not much to the liking of Lorry and Defarge, as both would have preferred not to leave the girl alone with the old man, but since it was not only necessary to prepare the post chaise but also to obtain passports, and time was pressing because the day was drawing to a close, it was imperative that they divide the necessary tasks between the two of them, after which they each went their separate ways.

en: Then, as the darkness closed in, the daughter laid her head down on the hard ground close at the father’s side, and watched him. The darkness deepened and deepened, and they both lay quiet, until a light gleamed through the chinks in the wall.
vi: So as the sky gradually darkened, the daughter lay her head on the hard ground beside her father, keeping watch. The darkness grew blacker and blacker, the father and daughter lay still until a light flashed through the cracks in the wall.
tr: Then, when darkness fell, the girl rested her head on the hard ground by her father's side and watched him. The darkness grew and grew, and until a light filtered through the cracks in the wall, father and daughter lay there silently.
es: The shadows of the night found the girl lying on the hard ground, watching over her father.

en: Mr. Lorry and Monsieur Defarge had made all ready for the journey, and had brought with them, besides travelling cloaks and wrappers, bread and meat, wine, and hot coffee. Monsieur Defarge put this provender, and the lamp he carried, on the shoemaker’s bench (there was nothing else in the garret but a pallet bed), and he and Mr. Lorry roused the captive, and assisted him to his feet.
vi: Mr. Lorry and Defarge had arranged everything for the trip, and besides cloaks and warm traveling clothes, they also brought bread, meat, wine, and hot coffee. Defarge placed all these necessary items and the lamp he was holding onto the shoemaker's bench (in the attic room which had no other furniture except a rickety bed). Then he and Mr. Lorry woke the prisoner and helped him stand up.
tr: Mr. Lorry and Monsieur Defarge had made all the preparations for the journey; besides things like cloaks and scarves, they had also taken bread, meat, wine, and hot coffee with them. Monsieur Defarge placed the food he had brought and the lantern on the shoemaker's bench (in the attic, there was no other place besides this grassy cushion), then, together with Mr. Lorry, they woke the prisoner and helped him get up from the ground.
es: Neither she nor the old man changed their posture until Lorry and Defarge entered the attic, who had finished the travel preparations and brought, in addition to blankets and travel coats, bread, cold meat, wine, and hot coffee. Defarge, the bearer of the provisions, placed them on the shoemaker's bench (there were no other pieces of furniture in the attic except for the bench and a mattress), and with Lorry's cooperation, lifted the captive.

en: No human intelligence could have read the mysteries of his mind, in the scared blank wonder of his face. Whether he knew what had happened, whether he recollected what they had said to him, whether he knew that he was free, were questions which no sagacity could have solved. They tried speaking to him; but, he was so confused, and so very slow to answer, that they took fright at his bewilderment, and agreed for the time to tamper with him no more. He had a wild, lost manner of occasionally clasping his head in his hands, that had not been seen in him before; yet, he had some pleasure in the mere sound of his daughter’s voice, and invariably turned to it when she spoke.
vi: Looking at the bewildered, dazed, and fearful expression of the shoemaker, no intellect could comprehend the mysteries within his mind. No one could answer the question of whether he understood what was happening, whether he remembered what he had heard, or whether he knew he had been set free. They tried to start a conversation, but he was so bewildered and responded so slowly that everyone became worried and agreed to leave him alone for the time being. From time to time, he would raise his hands to his head in a manner so foolish and absurd; yet, just hearing Miss Manette's voice would bring him some pleasure, and he would always turn to listen.
tr: No one looking at that fear-stricken, bewildered face could guess what was going through the shoemaker's mind. Did he know what was happening, had he understood what was told to him, did he know he was now free, no one could figure it out. They tried to talk to him; but his mind was so confused and he responded so slowly that they were frightened by his bewildered state and decided not to bother him any further for now. Every now and then, he would take his head in his hands and shake it like a madman, something he had never done before; on the other hand, he really enjoyed hearing his daughter's voice and would immediately turn to look as soon as she spoke.
es: No one would have been able to read in the expressionless apathy of his face the mysteries among which the old man's intelligence probably wandered aimlessly, nor would human insight, no matter how subtle and perceptive, have been able to determine whether he retained any memory of what had happened, if he remembered what he had been told, or if he realized that he was free. They tried to probe him with a barrage of questions; but the responses were so slow and confused that, fearing to disorient him further, they decided to leave him in peace for the time being. The old man's expression was one of senselessness, of ferocity, almost. He frequently pressed his head between his hands, something he had not been seen to do before; however, his face softened as soon as his daughter's voice reached his ears, and he invariably turned his head towards her whenever she spoke to him.

en: In the submissive way of one long accustomed to obey under coercion, he ate and drank what they gave him to eat and drink, and put on the cloak and other wrappings, that they gave him to wear. He readily responded to his daughter’s drawing her arm through his, and took—and kept—her hand in both his own.
vi: Having grown accustomed to submitting to compulsion, he did whatever he was told, ate and drank when told to eat and drink, and wore a cloak or warm clothes when told to wear them. He obediently let Manette take his arm and held the child's hand with both of his old hands.
tr: A man who had been oppressed for a long time and had become accustomed to following orders ate the food given to him, drank the drinks, and wore the cloak and other belongings with an obedient demeanor. When his daughter extended her arm towards him, he immediately responded by taking her hand between his two hands and holding it tightly.
es: With that peculiar submission of those who have long been accustomed to obey the whip, he ate and drank what was given to him, and put on the travel coat that was handed to him. Without resistance, moreover, with evident pleasure, he let his daughter link her arm with his... and not content with that, he took and held her hand between his own.

en: They began to descend; Monsieur Defarge going first with the lamp, Mr. Lorry closing the little procession. They had not traversed many steps of the long main staircase when he stopped, and stared at the roof and round at the walls.
vi: They began to descend the stairs; Mr. Defarge led the way with a lantern, and Mr. Lorry followed at the rear. They had only gone down a few steps when the shoemaker stopped, staring intently at the ceiling and around the walls.
tr: They started descending the stairs, Monsieur Defarge was leading the way with a lantern in hand, and at the very end of this small procession was Mr. Lorry. They had only descended a few of the long steps when the shoemaker stopped and looked at the ceiling and around him.
es: They began to descend. Defarge went ahead, providing light, and Lorry brought up the rear. They had not descended many stairs when the old man stopped and looked attentively upward first, and then around.

en: “You remember the place, my father? You remember coming up here?”
vi: − Do you remember that place, father? Do you remember going up there? −
tr: "Do you remember your arrival here, father? Climbing these steps?"
es: —Do you remember the place, my father? Do you remember when you climbed these stairs?—asked the girl.

en: “What did you say?”
vi: What did you just say?
tr: "What did you say?""
es: —What are you saying?

en: But, before she could repeat the question, he murmured an answer as if she had repeated it.
vi: But before Manette could repeat the question, he answered as if echoing her words: − Remember what?
tr: Even though the girl couldn't repeat her question, he mumbled an answer as if she had.
es: Before the question was repeated, the old man answered, as if it had been asked again.

en: “Remember? No, I don’t remember. It was so very long ago.”
vi: No, I don't remember. It's been too long.
tr: "Remember? No, I don't remember. It was a very long time ago."
es: —Do I remember? No; I don't remember. It's been so long!

en: That he had no recollection whatever of his having been brought from his prison to that house, was apparent to them. They heard him mutter, “One Hundred and Five, North Tower;” and when he looked about him, it evidently was for the strong fortress-walls which had long encompassed him. On their reaching the courtyard he instinctively altered his tread, as being in expectation of a drawbridge; and when there was no drawbridge, and he saw the carriage waiting in the open street, he dropped his daughter’s hand and clasped his head again.
vi: Everyone could clearly see that he did not remember being taken from the prison to this house. They heard him mumbling "One Hundred and Five, North Tower," and when he looked around, it was obvious that he was searching for the walls that had imprisoned him for so long. When he reached the courtyard, he unconsciously changed his pace, as if about to step onto a drawbridge, but there was no drawbridge here, and upon seeing the carriage waiting on the road, he let go of his daughter's hand and started tearing at his hair again.
tr: It was clear that he remembered nothing about being brought from his cell to that house. They heard him mutter, "One Hundred Five, North Tower," and when he looked around, they realized he was seeing the strong castle walls that had surrounded him for many years. When they reached the courtyard, the shoemaker instinctively changed his walk, expecting there to be a drawbridge opening and closing; but there was no bridge, and when he saw the carriage waiting in front of the door, he let go of his daughter's hand and put his head back in his hands.
es: Clearly, it was seen that he retained no memory of having been moved from the prison to the attic. Those who accompanied him heard him murmur "One Hundred and Five, North Tower," and it was undeniable that when he looked around, he believed he saw the thick walls that for so many years had been his tomb. He walked with an altered step as they crossed the courtyard, as if expecting to find the drawbridge; and upon realizing that it did not exist, and seeing the carriage waiting in the street, he let go of his daughter's hand and pressed his head again.

en: No crowd was about the door; no people were discernible at any of the many windows; not even a chance passerby was in the street. An unnatural silence and desertion reigned there. Only one soul was to be seen, and that was Madame Defarge—who leaned against the door-post, knitting, and saw nothing.
vi: There was no one gathered in front of the door; no shadow flitting behind the windows; the streets were completely deserted without a single passerby. An unusual silence and desolation reigned. There was only one person, Madame Defarge - standing by the door, knitting and seeing nothing at all.
tr: There was no one in front of the door; not a single person was looking out from any of the windows, and there wasn't even a single person passing by on the road by chance. There was an unnatural silence and desolation around. Only one person stood out, and that was –leaning against the side of the door, her eyes seeing nothing but the knitting in her hands– Madame Defarge.
es: There were no mobs in front of the door, no heads seen in the windows nor a living soul in the street. Silence and solitude reigned as the only lords. They saw no one except for one person, Madame Defarge... who was knitting and saw nothing.

en: The prisoner had got into a coach, and his daughter had followed him, when Mr. Lorry’s feet were arrested on the step by his asking, miserably, for his shoemaking tools and the unfinished shoes. Madame Defarge immediately called to her husband that she would get them, and went, knitting, out of the lamplight, through the courtyard. She quickly brought them down and handed them in;—and immediately afterwards leaned against the door-post, knitting, and saw nothing.
vi: The prisoner got into the carriage, his daughter followed, and Mr. Lorry was just placing his foot on the step when the poor man pleaded to bring along his shoemaker's bench and the unfinished shoes. Madame Defarge immediately told her husband to let her fetch them, and she left the light, crossed the yard, her hands never ceasing to knit. She quickly brought those items down and handed them to them; then promptly returned to the doorway, her hands still knitting, her eyes seeing nothing.
tr: From the front, the convict, and from behind, the girl had just gotten into the car when Mr. Lorry's foot remained on the step as the man pitifully asked for his shoemaking tools and the unfinished shoes. Madame Defarge immediately called out to her husband, saying she would bring what the man wanted, and went off, knitting as she passed through the lanterns in the courtyard. She quickly brought the items and gave them to the man, then immediately leaned against the side of the door again, continuing her knitting without looking at anything else.
es: The prisoner had already settled himself inside the carriage, his daughter had followed him, and at the moment when Lorry was placing his foot on the step, he was stopped by the voice of the old man who asked for his shoemaker's tools and his unfinished shoes. Madame Defarge immediately said that she would go up to fetch them, and indeed, a second later, she was crossing the courtyard, knitting. She soon reappeared and handed over the requested items, after which she returned to her seat and resumed her knitting... without seeing anything.

en: Defarge got upon the box, and gave the word “To the Barrier!” The postilion cracked his whip, and they clattered away under the feeble over-swinging lamps.
vi: Defarge climbed onto the coachman's seat and shouted, "To the city gates!". The driver cracked his whip and they all clattered along the road under the dim, swaying lanterns above.
tr: Defarge climbed up next to the driver and said, "Take me to the exit gate!" The coach driver cracked his whip and set off under the feeble light of the swaying street lamp on the hill.
es: Defarge mounted the coach box, gave the order "To the Barrier," the postilion cracked the whip, and the post chaise took off flying.

en: Under the over-swinging lamps—swinging ever brighter in the better streets, and ever dimmer in the worse—and by lighted shops, gay crowds, illuminated coffee-houses, and theatre-doors, to one of the city gates. Soldiers with lanterns, at the guard-house there. “Your papers, travellers!” “See here then, Monsieur the Officer,” said Defarge, getting down, and taking him gravely apart, “these are the papers of monsieur inside, with the white head. They were consigned to me, with him, at the—” He dropped his voice, there was a flutter among the military lanterns, and one of them being handed into the coach by an arm in uniform, the eyes connected with the arm looked, not an every day or an every night look, at monsieur with the white head. “It is well. Forward!” from the uniform. “Adieu!” from Defarge. And so, under a short grove of feebler and feebler over-swinging lamps, out under the great grove of stars.
vi: Passing through the swaying streetlights above - brighter in the wealthy streets, and dimmer in the poor streets - passing through the illuminated shops, the bustling crowds, the brightly lit cafes, and the theaters, the carriage arrived at a city gate. There was a guard post and soldiers holding lanterns in their hands. − Where is your pass, traveler? − Your Honor, I have everything here, - Defarge said as he got off the carriage and pulled the guard aside, - here are the documents of the gentleman in the carriage, the one with the silver hair. They entrusted the documents to me, along with the other person, at the place... - He lowered his voice, the military lanterns swayed, and a uniformed arm extended one of them into the carriage, the soldier's eyes scrutinizing the silver-haired head with an unusually inquisitive look. − Alright. Go on! - The guard exclaimed. − Adieu! Goodbye! - Defarge replied. And so, passing through a series of swaying lanterns overhead, growing dimmer and dimmer, the carriage moved out into the desolate plain where only the starlight guided the way.
tr: They arrived at one of the city's exit gates, passing under street lamps that shone brightly on nicer streets and swung with a dimmer light on worse ones, and by illuminated shops, cheerful crowds, bright cafes, and theaters. Soldiers stood at the checkpoint with lanterns in their hands. "Show your documents, travelers!" Defarge went downstairs and pulled the man aside with a serious demeanor, "Here you go, officer," he said, "the documents of the white-haired man inside are here." "They handed these documents to me along with him in the thing..." He lowered his voice, there was a hurried movement among the soldiers with lanterns, and one of them was extended into the carriage by a uniformed arm, and the owner of this uniformed arm's eyes, with an expression far from ordinary, fixed on the white-haired gentleman. "Alright. You may pass!" came the voice from the uniform. "Adieu!" said Defarge. Thus, they proceeded from under the small forest of dimming lights to the vast forest of stars.
es: Crossing under hundreds of hanging lanterns, which shone more brightly in the better streets and with a dimmer, sadder light in the less important ones, in front of profusely illuminated shops, groups of cheerful and lively people, cafés, and theaters, they arrived at one of the city gates, where they were stopped by the soldiers on guard. —Passports, travelers! —Here they are, officer—replied Defarge from the coachman's seat, but immediately jumping to the ground and taking the officer aside. — These are the passports of the gentleman with the white hair, who is inside, which were entrusted to me, along with his person, in... Here Defarge lowered his voice so much that only the officer could hear what he said. A portion of lanterns surrounded the carriage. One of them entered through the door, attached to an arm wearing a military uniform, the eyes of the owner of that arm scrutinized the interior, and especially the old man with the white head, and his lips said. —Alright. Go ahead. Under the immense vault of the eternal luminaries, some of them so distanced from this microscopic world that, if we are to believe what the wise assure us, it is doubtful that their glows have had time to reach us, reigned a gloomy, stormy, and cold night.

en: Beneath that arch of unmoved and eternal lights; some, so remote from this little earth that the learned tell us it is doubtful whether their rays have even yet discovered it, as a point in space where anything is suffered or done: the shadows of the night were broad and black. All through the cold and restless interval, until dawn, they once more whispered in the ears of Mr. Jarvis Lorry—sitting opposite the buried man who had been dug out, and wondering what subtle powers were for ever lost to him, and what were capable of restoration—the old inquiry:
vi: Under that immobile and eternal dome of light, there are stars so far from this small Earth that even the learned are not sure they can see their starlight, a space filled with all past sorrows - the shadows of the vast and dark night. Throughout the long, cold, restless night, Mr. Jarvis Lorry sat in front of the recently unearthed person who had been buried, constantly wondering what delicate abilities the person opposite had permanently lost and what could be restored, while the shadows incessantly whispered the old question in his ear: −
