vi: Cruncher's attention now shifted to the doorman, whom he saw approaching Mr. Lorry with a letter in hand. Mr. Lorry was sitting at a table, among the wigged gentlemen; not far from him was another wigged gentleman - the defense attorney - with a thick stack of papers in front of him; and almost directly opposite this man was yet another wigged gentleman, standing with both hands in his pockets, who, whenever Cruncher looked at him, seemed to be focusing solely on the ceiling. After a few abrupt coughs, a chin rub, and a hand gesture, Jerry managed to catch Mr. Lorry's attention; Mr. Lorry, who had been standing up looking around for him, now nodded in acknowledgment and sat back down.
tr: Mr. Cruncher's attention at this point shifted to the doorman, who admitted Mr. Lorry inside, with his note in hand. Mr. Lorry sat down at a table among the other gentlemen with wigs. He was near a gentleman with a wig who had a pile of papers in front of him, close to the attorney, and directly opposite another gentleman with a wig who, throughout the time Mr. Cruncher was observing, directed all his attention to the ceiling of the court. After Jerry coughed harshly several times, rubbed his chin, and gestured with his hand, he managed to catch the attention of Mr. Lorry, who had stood up to look around. Mr. Lorry quietly nodded his head forward and then sat back down.
es: Mr. Lapa then paid attention to the doorkeeper, whom he saw heading straight towards Mr. Lorry with the letter in his hand. Mr. Lorry was seated at a table among gentlemen suitably bewigged, very close to the defendant's lawyer, who wore an enormous wig and had several bundles of papers under his eyes, and almost opposite another gentleman, no less bewigged than the lawyer, who, when Mr. Lapa saw him, as well as afterwards, had his hands in his pockets, his entire attention focused on the ceiling. With a series of coughing fits, the messenger managed to catch Mr. Lorry's attention, who immediately stood up, nodded, and sat back down.

en: “What’s he got to do with the case?” asked the man he had spoken with.
vi: − What does that man have to do with this case?
tr: The man he just spoke to asked, "What does he have to do with this case?"
es: —What role does that play in the process?—asked Lapa to the individual who had previously asked him that question.

en: “Blest if I know,” said Jerry.
vi: - The person standing next to Jerry asked. − How would I know, - Jerry replied. −
tr: "Honestly, I don't know either," said Jerry.
es: —Hang me if I know.

en: “What have you got to do with it, then, if a person may inquire?”
vi: Then allow me to ask, what do you have to do with this case? −
tr: "What concern is it of yours, if I may ask?""
es: —So... if the question isn't too personal, what role do you play?

en: “Blest if I know that either,” said Jerry.
vi: The same. How would I know, - Jerry said.
tr: "Well, I don't know that either," said Jerry.
es: —May I be torn apart if I know either.

en: The entrance of the Judge, and a consequent great stir and settling down in the court, stopped the dialogue. Presently, the dock became the central point of interest. Two gaolers, who had been standing there, went out, and the prisoner was brought in, and put to the bar.
vi: The appearance of the Chief Justice and the ensuing commotion followed by the immediate calm of the entire court abruptly interrupted the conversation. All attention immediately focused on the dock. The two wardens who had been standing there went out to bring the criminal in for trial.
tr: The conversations were interrupted by the commotion caused by the judge's entrance and the rush to settle in the courtroom. At that moment, everyone's eyes turned to the defendant's stand. The two guards who had been waiting there went out and brought the defendant, placing him in the barred section.
es: The entrance of the judge into the courtroom put an end to the dialogue. From that moment on, all the attention, all the interest of the public was focused on the bar. The jailers, who until that moment had been on either side of the bar, left only to return moments later with the prisoner.

en: Everybody present, except the one wigged gentleman who looked at the ceiling, stared at him. All the human breath in the place, rolled at him, like a sea, or a wind, or a fire. Eager faces strained round pillars and corners, to get a sight of him; spectators in back rows stood up, not to miss a hair of him; people on the floor of the court, laid their hands on the shoulders of the people before them, to help themselves, at anybody’s cost, to a view of him—stood a-tiptoe, got upon ledges, stood upon next to nothing, to see every inch of him. Conspicuous among these latter, like an animated bit of the spiked wall of Newgate, Jerry stood: aiming at the prisoner the beery breath of a whet he had taken as he came along, and discharging it to mingle with the waves of other beer, and gin, and tea, and coffee, and what not, that flowed at him, and already broke upon the great windows behind him in an impure mist and rain.
vi: Except for the gentleman with the wig who was staring at the ceiling, everyone present was intently watching the defendant. Every breath in the courtroom surged towards that person, like waves, like wind, like fire. Eager faces strained their necks around pillars and corners to get a clear view of the criminal; the spectators in the back rows stood up, trying not to miss a single hair; those in the front pressed their hands on the shoulders of the people in front of them to see clearly at all costs - standing on tiptoe, climbing on ledges, stepping on almost everything, to see every pore. Standing out in the crowd ahead was Jerry with hair sticking up like iron spikes on the walls of Newgate Prison; he exhaled beer-laden breaths he had consumed on the way here towards the defendant, his breath mingling with waves of yeast, alcohol, tea, coffee, and various other smells, surging towards the accused, and those foul waves lashed the large windows of the Court with a misty, damp haze.
tr: Everyone in the room fixed their eyes on the man, except for the gentleman with the wig who was lost in watching the ceiling. Their breaths enveloped the man like the sea, wind, or fire. Curious faces stretched out from behind columns and corners to see him; spectators in the back rows stood up to miss nothing; those in the lower part of the room placed their hands on the shoulders of the people in front of them, trying to see the man somehow; some rose on their tiptoes, some climbed onto window sills, and some didn't even know what they were standing on, all to miss no detail about the man. Amidst all this chaos, Jerry stood upright like the emblematic spiked iron wall of Newgate. Meanwhile, the smell of the beer he drank on his way mixed with the waves of beer, gin, tea, and coffee emanating from the breaths of others, reaching the defendant and forming a dirty mist and rain on the large windows behind him.
es: All eyes, except those of the gentleman with the wig, who had his fixed on the ceiling, were fixed on those of the prisoner, all the human breaths in the room directed towards him, like the sea, like fire, like the wind. Clinging to the columns, protruding from the corners, faces reflecting anxiety could be seen, the spectators in the last rows stood up, others rose on tiptoe, and many climbed onto the benches in their eagerness to see everything. Jeremiah Lapa was not among those who showed the least curiosity, standing like an animated piece of the spiked wall of Newgate and shooting at the prisoner waves of breath saturated with beer vapors—he had had a glass on the way—which mixed with those coming from other mouths, saturated with emanations of gin, coffee, and tea.

en: The object of all this staring and blaring, was a young man of about five-and-twenty, well-grown and well-looking, with a sunburnt cheek and a dark eye. His condition was that of a young gentleman. He was plainly dressed in black, or very dark grey, and his hair, which was long and dark, was gathered in a ribbon at the back of his neck; more to be out of his way than for ornament. As an emotion of the mind will express itself through any covering of the body, so the paleness which his situation engendered came through the brown upon his cheek, showing the soul to be stronger than the sun. He was otherwise quite self-possessed, bowed to the Judge, and stood quiet.
vi: The object of all these staring eyes and wheezing breaths was a young man about twenty-five years old, with a well-proportioned and handsome figure, sun-tanned cheeks, and black eyes. His demeanor clearly indicated noble lineage. He wore a simple black outfit, or a very dark gray one, with long black hair tied back at the nape of his neck with a ribbon, more to keep it from covering his face than for style. No matter how much the body is concealed, the spirit still reveals emotions, so his sun-tanned brown cheeks could not hide the pale, sickly hue that emanated from within. But he appeared very calm, bowed to the Judge, and stood still.
tr: The target of all these glances and commotion was a young man around twenty-five years old, well-built, handsome, with tanned skin and brown eyes. He was a perfect gentleman in his demeanor. He wore a simple, black or dark gray outfit, and his long black hair was tied at the nape of his neck with a ribbon, but this was more to keep his hair from falling into his face than for decoration. Just as the mind's emotion expresses itself through whatever covers the body, the pallor caused by the man's condition was due to the brownness on his cheek, thus showing that the soul is stronger than the sun. Otherwise, he was quite a composed man; he had greeted the judge upon entering and was waiting silently.
es: The object of such lively curiosity was a young man of about twenty-five years, handsome, good-looking, with round cheeks and black eyes. He was a gentleman. He was dressed in black, or very dark gray, and his hair, which was long and chestnut, fell over his back, tied with a ribbon. In the same way that the emotions of the human soul filter through the material envelope, so the one engendered by the situation in which he found himself was manifested by a pallor superimposed on the dark and weathered complexion of the accused, demonstrating that his soul was stronger than the sun. He showed himself, however, perfectly in control. With marvelous calm, he bowed to the judge and waited:

en: The sort of interest with which this man was stared and breathed at, was not a sort that elevated humanity. Had he stood in peril of a less horrible sentence—had there been a chance of any one of its savage details being spared—by just so much would he have lost in his fascination. The form that was to be doomed to be so shamefully mangled, was the sight; the immortal creature that was to be so butchered and torn asunder, yielded the sensation. Whatever gloss the various spectators put upon the interest, according to their several arts and powers of self-deceit, the interest was, at the root of it, Ogreish.
vi: The way people stared with wide eyes and breathed heavily while focusing on that young man was not the kind of attention that makes a person more noble. If the defendant were facing a less terrifying sentence - if there were any chance of escaping any barbaric punishment - people certainly wouldn't have paid so much attention. It was the figure destined to suffer a shameful and brutal fate that piqued curiosity; it was the mortal body about to be dissected that caused such a stir. No matter what kind of deceitful mask the audience wears to cover their intentions, depending on their skill and level of self-deception, the root of this interest is the primal desire to consume human flesh.
tr: The reason for all the gazes and attention directed at him was not something that would elevate humanity. If he were standing there only with the danger of receiving a lighter sentence – or even the possibility of being spared from one of the cruel tortures – all the excitement would vanish. The anticipated scene was the shameless punishment of the body condemned to death; the immortal creature that was to be torn apart and shredded had succumbed to this excitement. No matter what the spectators said about their interest, judging by the various methods and deceitful skills they developed, the underlying cause of this interest was Cruelty.
es: Feelings of elevated humanity in the interest that the defendant aroused in the Hall? Not at all! If the sentence that loomed over his head had been less terrifying, if there had been any likelihood that some of its ferocious details would be omitted in its execution, the fascination would have suffered a severe blow. Before the spectators' eyes stood the arrogant body that would very soon be condemned to barbaric mutilations, the creature endowed with an immortal soul about to be torn apart, quartered, and the interest it inspired, no matter what those who felt it might say, was, at its root, in its essence, the interest of the ogre.

en: Silence in the court! Charles Darnay had yesterday pleaded Not Guilty to an indictment denouncing him (with infinite jingle and jangle) for that he was a false traitor to our serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth, prince, our Lord the King, by reason of his having, on divers occasions, and by divers means and ways, assisted Lewis, the French King, in his wars against our said serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth; that was to say, by coming and going, between the dominions of our said serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth, and those of the said French Lewis, and wickedly, falsely, traitorously, and otherwise evil-adverbiously, revealing to the said French Lewis what forces our said serene, illustrious, excellent, and so forth, had in preparation to send to Canada and North America. This much, Jerry, with his head becoming more and more spiky as the law terms bristled it, made out with huge satisfaction, and so arrived circuitously at the understanding that the aforesaid, and over and over again aforesaid, Charles Darnay, stood there before him upon his trial; that the jury were swearing in; and that Mr. Attorney-General was making ready to speak.
vi: Silence requested! Charles Darnay yesterday pleaded not guilty to the charges accusing the defendant of... (a never-ending string of bustling words)... therefore the defendant is guilty of treason against our most majestic, glorious, supreme, etc., King, Emperor, because the defendant, on various occasions and in various ways, aided Louis, King of France, in the war against our aforementioned most majestic, glorious, supreme, etc., Emperor; specifically, by traveling between the territory of our aforementioned most majestic, glorious, supreme, etc., kingdom and the territory of the aforementioned Louis of France, and revealing in a harmful, wrongful, treacherous, and... (many other vile adverbs)... manner to Louis of France that our aforementioned most majestic, glorious, supreme, etc., kingdom was preparing to send an army to Canada and North America... - Jerry, whose hair stood more and more on end as he listened to the legal jargon, was finally relieved to understand; and thus, after so many convoluted words, Jerry knew that it was now time for the aforementioned name, and the repeatedly mentioned name, Charles Darnay, to be tried; that the jury was being sworn in; and that the Attorney General was preparing to speak.
tr: "Silence please! Charles Darnay yesterday denied the accusations (with a thousand noises and uproars) that he had, on various occasions and in various forms and ways, betrayed our noble, honorable, unparalleled sovereign King; and that he had aided King Lewis of France in his war against our noble, honorable, unparalleled sovereign King; in other words, that he had traveled between the lands under the dominion of our noble, honorable, unparalleled sovereign King and those of the said French Lewis, and that he had treacherously, deceitfully, cruelly, and basely provided information to the said French Lewis regarding the forces that our noble, honorable, unparalleled sovereign King would send to Canada and North America, declaring himself innocent." Although the legal terms made Jerry's hair stand on end even more, he was able to make some sense of what was being said, and thus, combining it with the matter that had been discussed over and over again beforehand, he realized that this was the trial of the Charles Darnay standing there; the jury was swearing in, and the gentleman who was the Advocate was beginning his speech.
es: Silence in the Courtroom! —Carlos Darnay, as the accused was called, had denied the previous day the terrible accusation leveled against him. If true, Carlos Darnay was a traitor and disloyal to our serene, august, excellent, etc. etc. King and Lord, for having aided on various occasions and by various means Louis, King of France, in his wars against our serene, august, excellent, etc., etc. King and Lord. He had made frequent trips between the domains of our serene, august, excellent, etc., etc. King and Lord and those of the said King of France, with the purpose of revealing iniquitously, treacherously, disloyally (and many other adverbial qualifiers) to the aforementioned King of France the military forces that our serene, august, excellent, etc. etc. King and Lord had prepared to send to Canada and North America. Such were, in substance, the facts that Jeremiah Lapa had managed to acquire with enormous satisfaction.

en: The accused, who was (and who knew he was) being mentally hanged, beheaded, and quartered, by everybody there, neither flinched from the situation, nor assumed any theatrical air in it. He was quiet and attentive; watched the opening proceedings with a grave interest; and stood with his hands resting on the slab of wood before him, so composedly, that they had not displaced a leaf of the herbs with which it was strewn. The court was all bestrewn with herbs and sprinkled with vinegar, as a precaution against gaol air and gaol fever.
vi: In this situation, the defendant - who was (and he knew he was) being silently hanged, beheaded, and dismembered in the imagination of everyone in the court - remained undaunted and did not show any sign of sorrow. He stood silently and attentively followed the opening procedures of the trial with a serious interest; his two hands resting on the wooden railing of the dock, which had been sprinkled with herbs, so calmly that he did not disturb a single blade of grass. The entire court had been sprinkled with medicinal leaves and vinegar as a preventive measure against the prison's toxic air and fever.
tr: The criminal, who was being hanged, beheaded, and dismembered in the minds of those in the courtroom (and who was also aware of this), neither feared the situation nor adopted a pitiable demeanor. He was silent and attentive; he followed the opening speeches with serious interest and had placed his hands so firmly on the wooden railing in front of him that not a single blade of grass scattered upon it had moved. To counteract the smell and diseases of the prison, grass had been scattered and vinegar had been poured all over the courtroom.
es: The accused, whom everyone present had mentally hanged, beheaded, and quartered in plain sight, neither trembled at the situation nor affected theatrical arrogance. He saw with perfect calm that the judges were taking their oaths and that the Crown prosecutor was preparing to speak. With grave interest, he witnessed the preparations, and with such composure he listened to the proceedings that he did not move even a single leaf of the aromatic herbs sprinkled with vinegar that carpeted the floor, as a hygienic measure against the contagion of prison fever and the foul atmosphere that was breathed there.

en: Over the prisoner’s head there was a mirror, to throw the light down upon him. Crowds of the wicked and the wretched had been reflected in it, and had passed from its surface and this earth’s together. Haunted in a most ghastly manner that abominable place would have been, if the glass could ever have rendered back its reflections, as the ocean is one day to give up its dead. Some passing thought of the infamy and disgrace for which it had been reserved, may have struck the prisoner’s mind. Be that as it may, a change in his position making him conscious of a bar of light across his face, he looked up; and when he saw the glass his face flushed, and his right hand pushed the herbs away.
vi: Above the prisoner's head is a mirror reflecting light downwards. How many wicked and miserable people have left their reflections on that surface, only to vanish from the mirror and from the world. If that glass could recreate every image that has ever been imprinted, just as the ocean waves will one day return every drowned corpse, then surely this disgusting place would be filled with haunting ghosts. Perhaps a fleeting thought about those shameful, infamous reflections had arisen in the criminal's mind. Anyway, a movement to change his posture made him realize a beam of light was cast across his face; he looked up and, seeing his reflection in the mirror, he blushed and his right hand brushed the herbs aside.
tr: A mirror was placed above the defendant's head to reflect the light onto him. Until then, this mirror had reflected many sinners and wretches, and then they had all departed from the surface of the mirror and from the world. If the mirror could send back those images it reflected, just as the ocean casts the dead onto the shore, this vile place would be filled with hideous ghosts. The disgrace and baseness that had occurred in this hall must have also crossed the defendant's mind. Just as he was thinking about these, he noticed the beam of light hitting his face as he slightly moved, looked up at the ceiling, saw the mirror, and his face turned bright red as he pushed the grass aside with his right hand.
es: Above the head of the condemned man, there was a large mirror whose purpose was to concentrate the greatest possible amount of light on his face. Thousands of unfortunate and wicked people had seen their contorted faces reflected on its smooth surface, minutes before a layer of earth concealed them forever. There would be no hell comparable to that abominable Room if the surface of a mirror could return the images it reflects, in the same way that the Ocean returns its dead. Perhaps the condemned man felt the wave of infamy and dishonor that was about to envelop him, or maybe it was chance or a brighter ray of light that moved him to raise his eyes: the fact is that he saw the mirror, and upon seeing it, vivid crimson hues colored his face and his body experienced a violent shudder as if he had just received a powerful electric shock.

en: It happened, that the action turned his face to that side of the court which was on his left. About on a level with his eyes, there sat, in that corner of the Judge’s bench, two persons upon whom his look immediately rested; so immediately, and so much to the changing of his aspect, that all the eyes that were turned upon him, turned to them.
vi: The hand gesture accidentally turned his face to the left. At eye level, sitting in the corner near the judge's seat were two people who immediately caught his attention, and his expression instantly changed, causing all eyes that were fixed on him to turn and look as well.
tr: Then he turned to the left where there was some movement. His eyes immediately caught two people sitting a little further away, in the corner where the Judge's bench was; the demeanor of the defendant had changed so suddenly that all eyes on him immediately turned to where he was looking.
es: When they turned their gaze away from the mirror, they directed it to the left, where it fell upon two people with such intensity that there wasn't a single spectator in the room who didn't turn their eyes towards them.

en: The spectators saw in the two figures, a young lady of little more than twenty, and a gentleman who was evidently her father; a man of a very remarkable appearance in respect of the absolute whiteness of his hair, and a certain indescribable intensity of face: not of an active kind, but pondering and self-communing. When this expression was upon him, he looked as if he were old; but when it was stirred and broken up—as it was now, in a moment, on his speaking to his daughter—he became a handsome man, not past the prime of life.
vi: The audience sees two characters, a young lady just over twenty and a distinguished man clearly her father; his white hair and the indescribably emotional expression on his face immediately draw attention - it is not a focused concentration but a solitary contemplation. That expression makes him appear old, but when it is disturbed and fades away - as it does now while he is talking to his daughter - he looks like a handsome man, still in his prime.
tr: The audience saw two seated individuals, a young lady in her twenties and a gentleman who was clearly her father; the man was immediately noticeable with his snow-white hair and an indescribable intensity of emotion on his face; but it was not a lively face, rather it had a look of someone lost in thought, as if talking to himself. In this state, he appeared to be an old man; but when this expression faded – as it did now, while he was talking to his daughter – he became a handsome man, as if in the prime of his life.
es: The individuals in question were a young lady, approximately twenty years old, and a gentleman, evidently her father. What stood out strikingly in the latter was the snow-white color of his hair and a certain indescribable expression of vehemence, not active, but reflective, intimate. When this expression dominated, he seemed old, but in the moments when it disappeared, for example, when he spoke with his daughter, he was a handsome man who had barely passed the springtime of life.

en: His daughter had one of her hands drawn through his arm, as she sat by him, and the other pressed upon it. She had drawn close to him, in her dread of the scene, and in her pity for the prisoner. Her forehead had been strikingly expressive of an engrossing terror and compassion that saw nothing but the peril of the accused. This had been so very noticeable, so very powerfully and naturally shown, that starers who had had no pity for him were touched by her; and the whisper went about, “Who are they?”
vi: The daughter sat next to him, wrapping one arm around her father's arm, with the other hand holding his arm tightly, clearly terrified of the trial and feeling compassion for the defendant. Her furrowed brow revealed all the horror and empathy she felt for the danger awaiting the other person. These emotions were so vividly, intensely, and naturally expressed that even those who had no sympathy for the convict were moved and whispered to each other: "Who are they?".
tr: The girl was sitting with her arm linked through her father's, and she had placed her other hand on his arm. She had snuggled up to her father, both from the horror of the scene she witnessed and out of pity for the defendant. Her brow was deeply furrowed, influenced by the strange terror surrounding her, the severity of the defendant's situation, and the compassion she felt. This expression was so noticeable, strong, and natural that even the spectators who felt no pity for the defendant were affected by it, and whispers arose: "Who are they?""
es: Her daughter clung to her arm and pressed against her body, driven by the horror that the scene produced in her and the pity that the accused inspired in her, horror and pity so eloquently portrayed on her forehead and in her eyes, that the spectators, unmoved by the sad fate of the accused, could not see the young woman's state without profound pity.

en: Jerry, the messenger, who had made his own observations, in his own manner, and who had been sucking the rust off his fingers in his absorption, stretched his neck to hear who they were. The crowd about him had pressed and passed the inquiry on to the nearest attendant, and from him it had been more slowly pressed and passed back; at last it got to Jerry:
vi: All the while, he both observed and diligently sucked on the rusty, metallic taste on his fingers, the liaison Jerry craned his neck to listen and figure out who the other two people were. The crowd around kept asking each other questions, and the answers were passed on to the nearest person, who would then be asked again, and the answers continued to spread until they finally reached Jerry's ears: −
tr: While making his own observations in his secluded corner and busy sucking the rust off his finger, the messenger Jerry leaned in to hear who these people were. The question from the crowd around him had reached the officer at the other end and then returned at a relatively slow pace, and the information finally reached Jerry:
es: "Who could they be?" they whispered to each other. Jeremías Lapa did not stop asking his neighbor, whose perceptive eyes had not missed the young woman's expression, who those people were; and since everyone had asked the same question, the answer, which was already circulating from mouth to mouth, finally reached his ear.

en: “Witnesses.”
vi: That witness. −
tr: "They were witnesses.""
es: —They are witnesses.

en: “For which side?”
vi: For which side? −
tr: "Whose witnesses are they?"
es: —Of charge?

en: “Against.”
vi: The prosecution.
tr: "They were witnesses against.""
es: —Witnesses against.

en: “Against what side?”
vi: − Prosecuting whom? −
tr: "Against whom?"
es: —Against whom?

en: “The prisoner’s.”
vi: That prisoner.
tr: "The defendant's."
es: —Of the accused.

en: The Judge, whose eyes had gone in the general direction, recalled them, leaned back in his seat, and looked steadily at the man whose life was in his hand, as Mr. Attorney-General rose to spin the rope, grind the axe, and hammer the nails into the scaffold.
vi: The Chief Justice's eyes were drawn in the direction of the crowd's gaze, now returning to the judge's position. He leaned back in his chair, staring intently at the person whose fate he held in his hands, while the Attorney General stood up to tighten the noose, sharpen the axe, and nail the scaffold.
tr: The Judge, whose eyes were turned to where everyone was looking, called them over and leaned back, and as the Prosecutor got up to twist the rope, sharpen the axe, and hammer the nails into the gallows, he fixed his eyes on the man whose life depended on him.
es: The judge, whose gaze had followed the direction taken by all the spectators, turned it away to fix it intently on the unfortunate man whose life was in his hands, at the moment when the Crown prosecutor rose to twist the rope, sharpen the axe, and forge the hammer and nails that would prepare the scaffold.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: 3. Disappointed, the Attorney General had to inform the jury that the defendant before them, despite his young age, was experienced in treacherous schemes that required him to pay with his life.
tr: III
es: III.

en: A Disappointment
vi: 3. Disappointed, the Attorney General had to inform the jury that the defendant before them, despite his young age, was experienced in treacherous schemes that required him to pay with his life.
tr: A Disappointment
es: DISAPPOINTMENT

en: Mr. Attorney-General had to inform the jury, that the prisoner before them, though young in years, was old in the treasonable practices which claimed the forfeit of his life. That this correspondence with the public enemy was not a correspondence of to-day, or of yesterday, or even of last year, or of the year before. That, it was certain the prisoner had, for longer than that, been in the habit of passing and repassing between France and England, on secret business of which he could give no honest account. That, if it were in the nature of traitorous ways to thrive (which happily it never was), the real wickedness and guilt of his business might have remained undiscovered. That Providence, however, had put it into the heart of a person who was beyond fear and beyond reproach, to ferret out the nature of the prisoner’s schemes, and, struck with horror, to disclose them to his Majesty’s Chief Secretary of State and most honourable Privy Council. That, this patriot would be produced before them. That, his position and attitude were, on the whole, sublime. That, he had been the prisoner’s friend, but, at once in an auspicious and an evil hour detecting his infamy, had resolved to immolate the traitor he could no longer cherish in his bosom, on the sacred altar of his country. That, if statues were decreed in Britain, as in ancient Greece and Rome, to public benefactors, this shining citizen would assuredly have had one. That, as they were not so decreed, he probably would not have one. That, Virtue, as had been observed by the poets (in many passages which he well knew the jury would have, word for word, at the tips of their tongues; whereat the jury’s countenances displayed a guilty consciousness that they knew nothing about the passages), was in a manner contagious; more especially the bright virtue known as patriotism, or love of country. That, the lofty example of this immaculate and unimpeachable witness for the Crown, to refer to whom however unworthily was an honour, had communicated itself to the prisoner’s servant, and had engendered in him a holy determination to examine his master’s table-drawers and pockets, and secrete his papers. That, he (Mr. Attorney-General) was prepared to hear some disparagement attempted of this admirable servant; but that, in a general way, he preferred him to his (Mr. Attorney-General’s) brothers and sisters, and honoured him more than his (Mr. Attorney-General’s) father and mother. That, he called with confidence on the jury to come and do likewise. That, the evidence of these two witnesses, coupled with the documents of their discovering that would be produced, would show the prisoner to have been furnished with lists of his Majesty’s forces, and of their disposition and preparation, both by sea and land, and would leave no doubt that he had habitually conveyed such information to a hostile power. That, these lists could not be proved to be in the prisoner’s handwriting; but that it was all the same; that, indeed, it was rather the better for the prosecution, as showing the prisoner to be artful in his precautions. That, the proof would go back five years, and would show the prisoner already engaged in these pernicious missions, within a few weeks before the date of the very first action fought between the British troops and the Americans. That, for these reasons, the jury, being a loyal jury (as he knew they were), and being a responsible jury (as they knew they were), must positively find the prisoner Guilty, and make an end of him, whether they liked it or not. That, they never could lay their heads upon their pillows; that, they never could tolerate the idea of their wives laying their heads upon their pillows; that, they never could endure the notion of their children laying their heads upon their pillows; in short, that there never more could be, for them or theirs, any laying of heads upon pillows at all, unless the prisoner’s head was taken off. That head Mr. Attorney-General concluded by demanding of them, in the name of everything he could think of with a round turn in it, and on the faith of his solemn asseveration that he already considered the prisoner as good as dead and gone.
vi: 3. Disappointed, the Attorney General had to inform the jury that the defendant before them, despite his young age, was experienced in treacherous schemes that required him to pay with his life. That colluding with the enemy nation was not something new today, or yesterday, or even last year or the year before. That, certainly, this defendant, over a longer period, had frequently traveled between France and England to carry out secret activities that he had never honestly disclosed. That, if these treacherous acts had naturally developed (fortunately, this did not happen), the true harm and guilt of his actions might not have been discovered. That, thanks to the Almighty's prompting, a person with a fearless heart, unafraid of hardships, discovered the nature of his schemes, and this person, being too horrified, reported it to the Secretary of State and the esteemed Privy Council. That, this patriot will present himself before the jury. That, the status and character of this person are all noble. That, this person was once a friend of the accused, but at the fortunate yet unfortunate moment, discovered the crimes of the friend he dearly loved, and decided to sacrifice the traitor on the sacred altar of the Fatherland. That, if England, like ancient Greece and Rome, issued decrees to erect statues of the nation's benefactors, this distinguished Citizen would surely be honored. That, since England has no such decree, this person will not have a statue erected. That, morality is inherently contagious; especially the shining virtue of patriotism, or love for the country - a sentiment recorded by poets (in many verses which the Attorney General knows the jury must have memorized word for word; upon hearing this, the faces of the jurors clearly showed a guilty conscience as they did not know a single verse). That, the noble example of this unquestionably pure witness for the Kingdom, whom we are unworthy to honor by name, inspired the servant of the accused and led this servant to the noble resolve of rummaging through the master's pockets and drawers and hiding away many documents. That, he (the Attorney General) is ready to hear slanderous insults against this admirable servant; but that, he cherishes this servant more than his own siblings (of the Attorney General) and respects this servant more than his own parents (of the Attorney General). That, he confidently calls upon the jury to do as he does. That, the evidence from these two witnesses, along with the documents they discovered and are about to present to the court, will show that the accused had obtained lists of the Royal forces, along with deployment plans, both naval and military, and there is no doubt that he regularly transmitted such information to the enemy. That, it cannot be proven that these lists were written by the accused himself; but this does not lessen the severity and actually facilitates the prosecution; that, it shows the accused was cunningly cautious. That, evidence shows that five years ago the accused began these dangerous missions, just a few weeks before the first battle between the British army and the Americans*. That, for these reasons, the jury, being loyal (as he knows they are) and responsible (as they know they are) - must unequivocally find the accused guilty and sentence him to death, whether they want to or not. That, they cannot eat or sleep well; that, they cannot accept the idea of their wives eating or sleeping well; that, they cannot tolerate the thought of their children eating or sleeping well; in short, no one, whether they or their wives or children, can eat or sleep well anymore if the accused is not beheaded. That head, the Attorney General demands the jury to sever, in the name of all that is good and reasonable that he can think of, and with unwavering belief, he solemnly concludes that he considers the accused as good as dead.
tr: The prosecutor had to inform the jury that, although the defendant was young, he was experienced in the matter of treason, which would cost him his life. His relationship with enemies of the state did not belong to today, yesterday, last year, or even the year before. He had been traveling back and forth between France and England for a very long time, and it was very clear that he was involved in secret activities that he could not explain. If treason had engulfed everything (fortunately, this was not the case), the true evil and guilt of his actions might never have come to light. Fortunately, God had given a servant, free from fear and sin, the duty to uncover the conspiracies organized by this defendant and, in horror, to explain all this to His Majesty's assistant and the honorable Privy Council. This patriotic individual was now about to come before them. He was a person of utmost nobility in both position and demeanor. This person was a friend of the defendant, but on a fateful and troublesome day, upon realizing his disgrace, he decided that he could no longer embrace this traitor or harbor him at the sacred altar of his homeland. If statues were erected in England, as in ancient Rome and Greece, for those who had benefited the public, this extraordinary citizen would certainly have had a statue. But since there was no such decision, he probably would not have a statue. As poets have said, Virtue had a contagious nature (he thought many of the jurors knew many poems by heart, line by line; yet the jurors' faces bore a guilty expression indicating they knew nothing about poems); especially what was known as patriotism and love of country was a radiant virtue. This example of purity and perfection, who was to testify on behalf of the King and whom it was an honor to even speak of, had contacted the defendant's servant and inspired in him a sacred determination to rummage through his master's desk drawers and pockets and to hide certain documents. The prosecutor was actually ready to hear derogatory remarks about this commendable servant; but he preferred him over his own brothers and showed him more respect than he did to his own parents. He then invited the jurors to act in the same manner. The evidence presented by these two witnesses and the other documents they had obtained would show how the defendant was equipped with information about Her Majesty's armies, and furthermore, it was an undeniable fact that he had always conveyed information about the structuring and preparations on land and sea to enemy forces. Perhaps it could not be proven that the lists were written in the defendant's handwriting; but this changed nothing; in fact, it was better for the case as it showed how cunning the defendant was in taking precautions. The evidence dated back five years and showed that the defendant had undertaken this harmful duty even then, a few weeks before the first clashes between the British and American armies. For these reasons, the patriotic (he was sure of this) and responsible (he was also sure of this) jurors should definitely declare this defendant Guilty, and whether they were pleased with this situation or not, they should end his life. Unless this defendant's head was cut off, neither the jurors could rest their heads on their pillows in peace, nor could they tolerate their wives resting their heads on their pillows, nor could they bear the thought of their children resting their heads on their pillows; in short, none of them would be able to rest their heads on their pillows in peace and tranquility. The Chief Prosecutor concluded his speech by reiterating his demand for the defendant to be found guilty in the name of everything conceivable; in fact, as a result of all the legal claims he had put forward, the defendant was already dead to him.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated in his report that the accused, though young in years, was so old in treacherous acts and perfidious practices that it was necessary to end his life. " His dealings and continuous correspondence with the public enemy," he said, "do not date from yesterday, nor the day before, nor from last year, nor from two years ago. From a much earlier date, the accused has been making constant trips between England and France, mysterious trips, the purpose of which he himself has not been able to explain to us satisfactorily. Ah! If Heaven, in its high wisdom, had not condemned the machinations of traitors to eternal failure, the criminal acts of this man would have borne their natural fruits, but Providence, which watches in a special way over the fate of our beloved England, inspired a person, in whose heart fear has no entry and in whose conscience malice has no place, with the fortunate thought of uncovering the sinister plans of the accused, and when he achieved his goal, filled with terror, he hurried to reveal them to the first Secretary of State and to the august Privy Council of His Majesty. Soon you will have the opportunity to meet this patriot, whose conduct has been sublime. He had been an intimate friend of the traitor, but as soon as he discovered his infamies, he decided to sacrifice a friendship, which he could no longer keep in his heart, on the sacred altar of patriotism. If England ever erects statues, as Greece and Rome did in honor of those who sacrificed their deepest affections for the sake of the homeland, there is no doubt that this eminent citizen will have his own. Virtue, as countless poets have affirmed, whose names I will not cite because all my listeners have them on the tip of their tongues, is eminently contagious, and above all, the sacred virtue of patriotism, the love of the homeland. It is not surprising, then, that the high and sublime example of the immaculate and impeccable witness I refer to, whose name honors anyone who pronounces it, was contagious to a servant of the same accused, and inspired in him the holy resolution to search the drawers of the tables and the pockets of his master, to seize or take note of his most secret documents. There will be detractors who sink their teeth into the reputation of this admirable servant, slanderers who will expose the peccadilloes of his past life in the public pillory, but even so, I must protest that his present conduct makes him deserving of all my respect, I must say that he deserves more consideration than my own brothers, more consideration than my own parents. I do not doubt, I cannot doubt that those who listen to me will do the same. The statements of the two named witnesses, together with the documents that will be exhibited in due course, demonstrate as clearly as sunlight that the prisoner possessed numerical relations of His Majesty's military forces, explanatory states of their disposition and preparation, and there is no doubt that these relations, these states, he carried, as he has carried so many others, to an enemy power. I confess that it has not been possible to prove that these relations and these states are in the handwriting of the accused, but that does not matter, it means nothing, and in any case, it will be an aggravating circumstance, since it will highlight the cunning malice of the accused. The evidence goes back five years, clearly demonstrating that the prisoner was already then carrying out infamous and pernicious missions, that he was already selling out the homeland weeks before the first battle between English and American forces was fought. All these reasons will necessarily influence the mind of the Jury, if it is a loyal Jury, as I know it is, if it is a responsible Jury, as I consider it to be, to declare the prisoner guilty, and to rid the world of a traitor. Ah, gentlemen of the jury! As long as there is a head on the prisoner's shoulders, it is not possible for your heads to rest peacefully on the pillows of your beds, it is not possible for the heads of your tender wives to rest peacefully on the pillows of their beds, it is not possible for the little heads of your dear children to rest peacefully on the pillows of their beds. The Crown Prosecutor asks you by the most sacred, by what is most dear to you, by the oath you have taken, by the august and excellent King who governs us, by the homeland, which is our mother, to sentence the prisoner to be hanged, beheaded, and quartered."

en: When the Attorney-General ceased, a buzz arose in the court as if a cloud of great blue-flies were swarming about the prisoner, in anticipation of what he was soon to become. When toned down again, the unimpeachable patriot appeared in the witness-box.
vi: When the Attorney General stopped speaking, the entire courtroom buzzed like a swarm of blue flies around the defendant, eagerly awaiting the fate he would face. When the noise subsided, the impeccable patriot appeared at the witness stand.
tr: When the chief prosecutor's speech ended, a murmur broke out in the courtroom; it was as if a swarm of horseflies, sensing what was about to happen, had gathered around the defendant. When the noise subsided, the impeccable patriot had taken his place in the witness stand.
es: When the Crown prosecutor stopped speaking, the courtroom filled with muffled murmurs. It seemed as if the air had filled with swarms of blue flies buzzing around the defendant's head, aware of the state in which they would soon find him. When the buzzing ceased, the impeccable citizen, the sublime patriot cited by the Crown prosecutor, appeared in the witness stand.

en: Mr. Solicitor-General then, following his leader’s lead, examined the patriot: John Barsad, gentleman, by name. The story of his pure soul was exactly what Mr. Attorney-General had described it to be—perhaps, if it had a fault, a little too exactly. Having released his noble bosom of its burden, he would have modestly withdrawn himself, but that the wigged gentleman with the papers before him, sitting not far from Mr. Lorry, begged to ask him a few questions. The wigged gentleman sitting opposite, still looking at the ceiling of the court.
vi: Then the Deputy Attorney General, following the guidance of the Attorney General, questioned the patriot: a gentleman named John Barsad. His self-declaration of a clear conscience was similar to what the Attorney General had described; perhaps the reproachable thing was that it was almost identical to the Attorney General's words. After unburdening his noble heart, he should have humbly withdrawn, but the barrister wearing a wig, holding a stack of papers, sitting in front of him not far from Mr. Lorry, requested to ask a few questions. Meanwhile, the gentleman wearing a wig opposite the barrister continued to look up at the ceiling.
tr: The deputy chief prosecutor, under the leadership of his superior, began to question the patriotic witness; the gentleman's name was John Barsad. This good man's story was exactly as the Chief Prosecutor had told it – in fact, it was too much the same. After the man had unburdened himself of the load he carried in that noble bosom, he was about to withdraw modestly when the wigged man with papers in front of him, sitting just a little beyond Mr. Lorry, wanted to ask him a few questions. The wigged man sitting directly opposite was still looking at the ceiling.
es: The Attorney General, strictly adhering to his chief's instructions, then examined the patriot. His name was John Barsad, and he was a gentleman. The story of his pure and immaculate soul turned out to be the one the Crown prosecutor had succinctly presented in his accusation. After he had answered the questions directed at him, he would have modestly withdrawn, had the gentleman with the enormous wig and bulky bundles of papers, who was seated a short distance from Mr. Lorry, not expressed a desire to ask him some other questions. The second wigged man continued to stare at the ceiling. Here is, in summary, the interrogation to which the great patriot was subjected by the gentleman with the wig:

en: Had he ever been a spy himself? No, he scorned the base insinuation. What did he live upon? His property. Where was his property? He didn’t precisely remember where it was. What was it? No business of anybody’s. Had he inherited it? Yes, he had. From whom? Distant relation. Very distant? Rather. Ever been in prison? Certainly not. Never in a debtors’ prison? Didn’t see what that had to do with it. Never in a debtors’ prison?—Come, once again. Never? Yes. How many times? Two or three times. Not five or six? Perhaps. Of what profession? Gentleman. Ever been kicked? Might have been. Frequently? No. Ever kicked downstairs? Decidedly not; once received a kick on the top of a staircase, and fell downstairs of his own accord. Kicked on that occasion for cheating at dice? Something to that effect was said by the intoxicated liar who committed the assault, but it was not true. Swear it was not true? Positively. Ever live by cheating at play? Never. Ever live by play? Not more than other gentlemen do. Ever borrow money of the prisoner? Yes. Ever pay him? No. Was not this intimacy with the prisoner, in reality a very slight one, forced upon the prisoner in coaches, inns, and packets? No. Sure he saw the prisoner with these lists? Certain. Knew no more about the lists? No. Had not procured them himself, for instance? No. Expect to get anything by this evidence? No. Not in regular government pay and employment, to lay traps? Oh dear no. Or to do anything? Oh dear no. Swear that? Over and over again. No motives but motives of sheer patriotism? None whatever.
vi: Has the witness ever worked as a spy? No, he despises that vile insinuation. How does the witness make a living? From his own assets. Where did the witness's assets come from? The witness does not remember exactly where they came from. What are those assets? Personal matters cannot be disclosed. Did the witness inherit those assets? Yes, he admits. Whose inheritance? Distant relatives. Very distant? Quite distant. Ever been to prison? Definitely not. Ever been imprisoned for debt? I don't understand what that has to do with this. Ever been imprisoned for debt?... There, asking again! Yes or no? Yes. How many times? Two or three times. Not five or six times? Maybe. What is the witness's profession? Noble. Ever been kicked by someone? Probably yes. Frequently? No. Ever been kicked down the stairs? Definitely not; once kicked at the top of the stairs, and the witness rolled down voluntarily. Kicked for cheating at dice, right? The drunk who attacked me said something like that, but it's not true. Dare to swear it's not true? Absolutely. Ever made a living by cheating at gambling? Never. Ever made a living by gambling? Just like everyone else. Ever borrowed money from that defendant? Yes. Paid it back yet? No. Isn't the witness's relationship with the defendant actually very superficial, only due to occasional meetings on carriages, in inns, and on steamboats? No. Are you sure you saw the defendant with these lists? Absolutely sure. Know anything more about these lists? No. Didn't the witness personally try to obtain these documents, right? No. With these exhibits, does the witness hope to get some reward? No. The witness doesn't receive government salary and wasn't hired to harm others, right? Oh heavens, no. Or to do anything else? Oh heavens, no. Dare to swear? Swear a thousand times, no. The witness has no motive other than patriotism, right? No other motive.
tr: Had he ever committed espionage? No, he had grimaced at the suggestion. How did he make a living? With his private properties. Where was his private property? He didn't remember exactly where it was. What was it? It was nobody's business. Had he inherited it from someone? Yes, it was an inheritance. From whom had he inherited it? From a distant relative. Was this relative very distant? A bit. Had he ever been imprisoned? Absolutely not. Had he never been in a debtor's prison? What did this have to do with the case? Had he never been in a debtor's prison? The question came again. Never? Yes, he had been. How many times? Two or three times. Could it be five or six times? Maybe. What was his profession? A gentleman. Had he ever been kicked? Possibly. Often? No. Had he ever been kicked down the stairs? Absolutely not; once he had been kicked at the top of the stairs and had fallen down on his own. Was he kicked for cheating at dice? The drunk who attacked him had said so, but it wasn't true. Could he swear it wasn't true? Of course. Had he ever made a living by cheating at gambling? Never. Had he ever made a living by gambling? As much as other gentlemen played. Had he ever borrowed money from a prisoner? Yes. Had he paid him back? No. Was his relationship with the prisoner, which wasn't that close, limited to forced conversations in the stagecoach, inn, or on the steamboat? No. Was he sure he had seen these lists in the prisoner's possession? He was sure. Did he know anything else about these lists? No. Could he have produced them himself? No. Was there anything he would receive in exchange for this evidence? No. Was he receiving money from the government to set traps? Absolutely not. Or for anything else? Oh, no! Would he swear? Of course. Was his only reason for being there his patriotism? Absolutely.
es: —Have you ever been a spy? —Never—replied the citizen indignantly. —What do you live on? —From my income. —What do those incomes consist of? —I don't have to give explanations about this matter. —Where are your assets located? —I don't remember it precisely. —Have you inherited? —Yes. —Whose? —From a distant relative. —Very far? —Enough. —Have you ever been prosecuted? —Never. —Has he not even been in jail for debts? —I don't know what that has to do with the matter being debated. —Have you been in jail for debts? —Again? —Answer, please. —Yes. —How many times? —Two or three. —Could it be five or six? —Maybe. —Your profession? —Gentleman. —Have you ever been kicked? —Maybe so. —Often? —No. —Have you ever been kicked out of a house? —No. —Haven't they kicked him down the stairs? —I repeat, no. On one occasion, I received a few kicks at the top of a staircase and rolled down it, but it was because I wanted to, by my own will, deliberately. —On the occasion you refer to, weren't you kicked out for cheating, for making tricks in a dice game? —Something like that said the lying drunk who kicked me, but it was false. —Do you swear it was false? —Without the slightest hesitation. —Have you never sought the means to live in the traps of the game? —Never. —Haven't you even lived off gambling? —I have played as all other gentlemen play. —Has the prisoner lent you money? —Yes. —And has he paid for it? —No. —The friendship that has bound him with the prisoner, in reality a light friendship, was it not one of those we usually call obligatory, that is, a friendship cultivated in stagecoaches, inns, and ships? —No. —Have you seen the records and lists in the prisoner's possession? —Yes. —Can you say something more about those lists? —No. —Do you expect your statement to bring you any advantage or benefit? —No. —Not even a fate as a government-hired spy? —No. —Not any other job either? No. —Do you swear? —A thousand and one times. —Does it obey motives other than those of patriotism? —No.

en: The virtuous servant, Roger Cly, swore his way through the case at a great rate. He had taken service with the prisoner, in good faith and simplicity, four years ago. He had asked the prisoner, aboard the Calais packet, if he wanted a handy fellow, and the prisoner had engaged him. He had not asked the prisoner to take the handy fellow as an act of charity—never thought of such a thing. He began to have suspicions of the prisoner, and to keep an eye upon him, soon afterwards. In arranging his clothes, while travelling, he had seen similar lists to these in the prisoner’s pockets, over and over again. He had taken these lists from the drawer of the prisoner’s desk. He had not put them there first. He had seen the prisoner show these identical lists to French gentlemen at Calais, and similar lists to French gentlemen, both at Calais and Boulogne. He loved his country, and couldn’t bear it, and had given information. He had never been suspected of stealing a silver tea-pot; he had been maligned respecting a mustard-pot, but it turned out to be only a plated one. He had known the last witness seven or eight years; that was merely a coincidence. He didn’t call it a particularly curious coincidence; most coincidences were curious. Neither did he call it a curious coincidence that true patriotism was his only motive too. He was a true Briton, and hoped there were many like him.
vi: It was the virtuous servant Roger Cly's turn to take the oath before the interrogation. He had been working for the defendant for four years and knew nothing. He had asked the defendant on the Calais train if the defendant needed a servant, and the defendant had hired him. It was not out of charity that the defendant took him as a servant - there was no such thought. Soon after, he began to suspect the defendant and kept an eye on him. While preparing clothes for the defendant during a trip, he saw lists similar to these in the defendant's pockets many times. He took these lists from the defendant's desk drawer. He did not put those papers in the drawer from the beginning. He saw the defendant show similar lists to many French people in Calais, and show similar lists to many French people in both Calais and Boulogne. He was patriotic and could not accept that, so he went to report it. He had never been suspected of stealing a silver teapot; he had been falsely accused of stealing a mustard pot, but it turned out to be only silver-plated. He had known the previous witness for seven or eight years; it was just a coincidence. He did not consider it a strange coincidence because any coincidence is strange. Nor did he consider it a strange coincidence that his only motive was patriotism. He was a true Englishman and hoped many others were like him.
tr: The virtuous servant Roger Ciy took a long oath on the witness stand. Four years ago, he had started working alongside the defendant with all his goodwill and naivety. On the Calais ship, he had asked the defendant if he needed an assistant, and the defendant had taken him on; it wasn't out of kindness that he wanted to be hired by the defendant, such a thing had never crossed his mind. But later, he started to suspect the defendant and began to watch him. While preparing the defendant's clothes for travel, he constantly saw similar lists in the defendant's pockets. He had also taken these lists from the defendant's desk drawer. It wasn't the first time he had seen them. He had seen the defendant show the same lists to the French in Calais, and similar ones to the French in both Calais and Boulogne. He loved his country, he couldn't tolerate this, so he informed the necessary people. He had never been suspected of stealing a silver teapot; there had been a slander about a mustard pot, but that had also turned out to be a coating. He had known the last witness for seven or eight years; but it was entirely coincidental. It couldn't be called a strange coincidence; coincidences were mostly strange anyway. Moreover, he didn't see his sole motive of patriotism as a strange coincidence. He was a true Briton and hoped that many people were like him.
es: The virtuous servant of the prisoner, Rogerio Cly, was called to testify, and he took his oath with great determination. Four years earlier, he had entered the service of the prisoner, simply and in good faith. On board the ship that serviced Calais, he asked the prisoner if he needed a servant, and the latter accepted him. Very shortly after, the prisoner's behavior seemed suspicious to him, and he resolved to spy on him. During the various trips he made in his company, he saw several times in his master's clothes lists and records similar to those held by the authorities. He was the one who took some of those lists from a drawer in his master's desk. He saw that his master showed other identical lists to a French gentleman in Calais and others to other French gentlemen, both in Calais and in Boulogne. A lover of his country, his conscience rebelled against such dark treacheries and he reported the facts. Regarding his honesty, he assured that it was so impeccable that no one ever dared to accuse him of stealing a silver teapot, for although there were slanderers who once accused him of stealing a butter dish, upon verification, it turned out it was not silver but silver-plated metal. He had known the witness who preceded him in the statement for seven or eight years, but they only ever interacted by coincidence. He did not claim that these were extraordinarily curious coincidences, undoubtedly because it is public and notorious that coincidences are generally so.

en: The blue-flies buzzed again, and Mr. Attorney-General called Mr. Jarvis Lorry.
vi: The entire courtroom was once again filled with the buzzing of bluebottle flies, and the Attorney General called Mr. Jarvis Lorry to testify.
tr: The flies buzzed again and summoned Chief Prosecutor Mr. Jarvis Lorry.
es: The muffled buzzing of the blue flies was heard for the second time, and the Crown prosecutor called Mr. Maurice Lorry.

en: “Mr. Jarvis Lorry, are you a clerk in Tellson’s bank?”
vi: − Mr. Jarvis Lorry, are you an employee of Tellson's Bank? −
tr: "Mr. Jarvis Lorry, you work at Tellson's Bank, don't you?"
es: —Are you an employee of Tellson's Bank, Mr. Maurice Lorry?

en: “I am.”
vi: Yes, I am. −
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “On a certain Friday night in November one thousand seven hundred and seventy-five, did business occasion you to travel between London and Dover by the mail?”
vi: On a Friday in November 1775, did you travel from London to Dover by mail coach for business?
tr: "Did you travel from London to Dover by mail coach for business on a Friday night in November 1775?"
es: —On the night of a Friday in the month of November of the year one thousand seven hundred seventy-five, did you make a journey from London to Dover by the mail coach?

en: “It did.”
vi: − Yes, I did. −
tr: "I went."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Were there any other passengers in the mail?”
vi: Were there any other passengers on the mail coach?
tr: "Was there any other passenger in the car?"
es: —Were there other travelers in the coach?

en: “Two.”
vi: − Two people. −
tr: "There were two more people.""
es: —Yes, sir: two.

en: “Did they alight on the road in the course of the night?”
vi: Did they get off the coach during the night?
tr: "Did these people get off on the road at night?"
es: —Did they leave the coach that night, before reaching Dover?

en: “They did.”
vi: − Yes, they did.
tr: "They got off."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Mr. Lorry, look upon the prisoner. Was he one of those two passengers?”
vi: − Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant over there. Is the defendant one of those two passengers?
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look carefully at the face of the defendant. Was this person one of the two passengers?"
es: —Look at the prisoner, Mr. Lorry, and tell us if he was one of those travelers.

en: “I cannot undertake to say that he was.”
vi: − I cannot answer that question.
tr: "It's very hard to say this."
es: —I can't say that it was.

en: “Does he resemble either of these two passengers?”
vi: − Does the defendant resemble either of those two passengers?
tr: "Does he look like one of those two travelers?""
es: —Does he look like any of your travel companions?

en: “Both were so wrapped up, and the night was so dark, and we were all so reserved, that I cannot undertake to say even that.”
vi: − Both were cloaked, it was pitch dark, and we were all cautious, so I cannot answer even this question.
tr: "Both were tightly wrapped up, it was a very dark night, and everyone was in their own world; it is really hard to say anything.""
es: —The two were so cloaked, the night was so dark, and the three of us kept such secrecy, that it is impossible for me to answer the question.

en: “Mr. Lorry, look again upon the prisoner. Supposing him wrapped up as those two passengers were, is there anything in his bulk and stature to render it unlikely that he was one of them?”
vi: − Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant again. Suppose the defendant were cloaked like those two passengers, based on build and height, does the defendant resemble either of them?
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant's face once more. If you consider the defendant being wrapped up like those two passengers, can you say that in terms of build and stance, he resembles neither of them?"
es: —Examine the prisoner more closely, Mr. Lorry. Picture him cloaked, in the same manner as his travel companions, and tell us if, given his height and build, it is impossible that he was one of the two travelers.

en: “No.”
vi: − No. − Mr. Lorry, would you swear that the defendant is not one of those two passengers?
tr: "No."
es: —It is not impossible.

en: “You will not swear, Mr. Lorry, that he was not one of them?”
vi: − No. − Mr. Lorry, would you swear that the defendant is not one of those two passengers?
tr: "Well, can you swear that you are not one of them, Mr. Lorry?"
es: —Would you not swear that the defendant was none of them?

en: “No.”
vi: − No. −
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: “So at least you say he may have been one of them?”
vi: Then at least you consider it possible that the defendant could be one of those two people, don't you?
tr: "So, you're saying it could be one of those two passengers?"
es: —Then you admit that you could be one of them, don't you?

en: “Yes. Except that I remember them both to have been—like myself—timorous of highwaymen, and the prisoner has not a timorous air.”
vi: − Yes. Only, I remember that both of them... like myself... were afraid of highwaymen, whereas this person does not seem to be afraid at all.
tr: "Yes. Only the other two passengers – just like me – were afraid of highway robbers, whereas this defendant doesn't seem scared at all."
es: —Then you admit that you could be one of them, don't you? —I admit the possibility, but... but I remember perfectly that my two travel companions were... and I was too... terribly afraid of thieves, and it seems to me that the defendant is not one to be easily frightened.

en: “Did you ever see a counterfeit of timidity, Mr. Lorry?”
vi: − Have you ever seen someone pretend to be shy, Mr. Lorry?
tr: "Have you ever witnessed false cowardice, Mr. Lorry?"
es: —And have you never seen fake fear... I mean, people who pretend to feel a fear they don't actually feel?

en: “I certainly have seen that.”
vi: − I'm sure I have.
tr: "Of course I saw it.""
es: —No, sir.

en: “Mr. Lorry, look once more upon the prisoner. Have you seen him, to your certain knowledge, before?”
vi: − Mr. Lorry, please look at the defendant again. Are you sure that you have met the defendant before? − I have met him.
tr: "Mr. Lorry, look at the defendant's face once more. Have you ever seen him before?"
es: —Please identify the defendant again, Mr. Lorry. Do you remember seeing him on any occasion?

en: “I have.”
tr: "Yes, I had seen it.""
es: —Yes.

en: “When?”
vi: When? −
tr: "When?""
es: —When and where?

en: “I was returning from France a few days afterwards, and, at Calais, the prisoner came on board the packet-ship in which I returned, and made the voyage with me.”
vi: It was a few days later, when I returned from France, and in Calais, this person boarded the ship that took me back to the country, and traveled on the same trip with me. −
tr: "A few days later, I was returning from France, and he boarded the steamer I boarded in Calais, and we traveled together."
es: —Upon my return from France, a few days after the stagecoach incident, I found him in Calais aboard the ship on which I was coming back, and we made the journey together.

en: “At what hour did he come on board?”
vi: At what time did the defendant board the ship?
tr: "When did he/she get on the ferry?""
es: —What time did the prisoner board?

en: “At a little after midnight.”
vi: − Shortly after midnight.
tr: "A little past midnight.""
es: —Already late at night.

en: “In the dead of the night. Was he the only passenger who came on board at that untimely hour?”
vi: − Right in the middle of the night. Was the defendant the only passenger who boarded the train at that late hour?
tr: "In the dead of night. Was he the only passenger boarding at that hour?"
es: —Already late at night. He was the only passenger on the boat, except for us, and he arrived at the last minute. —What time could it be?

en: “He happened to be the only one.”
vi: − Coincidentally, this person was the only one.
tr: "It was the only one by chance."
es: —A little past midnight. —And you say you arrived last? —It so happened that I arrived last, yes, sir.

en: “Never mind about ‘happening,’ Mr. Lorry. He was the only passenger who came on board in the dead of the night?”
vi: − Don't worry about the "coincidence," Mr. Lorry. The defendant was the only passenger to board the ship at midnight, correct?
tr: "Forget about the coincidence, Mr. Lorry. He was the only passenger who boarded in the dead of night, wasn't he?"
es: —Let's set aside the "coincidences." He was the only passenger who arrived late at night, wasn't he?

en: “He was.”
vi: − That's right.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Were you travelling alone, Mr. Lorry, or with any companion?”
vi: − At that time, were you traveling alone or with someone, Mr. Lorry? −
tr: "Were you traveling alone, Mr. Lorry, or was there someone with you?""
es: —Were you traveling alone, or accompanied, Mr. Lorry?

en: “With two companions. A gentleman and lady. They are here.”
vi: With two companions. A gentleman and a lady. They are present in the court. −
tr: "There were two people with me. A gentleman and a lady. Now they are here."
es: —With two companions: a gentleman and a young lady. Both are here.

en: “They are here. Had you any conversation with the prisoner?”
vi: They are present in the court. Did you have any conversation with the defendant at that time?
tr: "Yes, yes. Had you spoken with the defendant at that time?"
es: —Indeed: here they are. Did you speak with the prisoner?

en: “Hardly any. The weather was stormy, and the passage long and rough, and I lay on a sofa, almost from shore to shore.”
vi: − Absolutely not. It was stormy, the journey was long and the sea was rough, I mostly lay on the sofa from one shore to the other.
tr: "Not much. The weather was stormy, the journey was long and difficult; I lay down on a seat and slept almost the entire way."
es: —Very little. The weather was stormy, the journey was long and arduous, and I spent it lying on the couch from beach to beach.

en: “Miss Manette!”
vi: − Miss Manette!
tr: "Miss Manette!"
es: —Miss Manette!

en: The young lady, to whom all eyes had been turned before, and were now turned again, stood up where she had sat. Her father rose with her, and kept her hand drawn through his arm.
vi: The girl stood up from her seat, and all eyes that had been on her now turned back to her. Her father stood up as well, still holding her arm.
tr: Everyone turned their eyes again to the young lady they had just looked at, and she also stood up. Her father also stood up with her, still holding her arm.
es: The young lady, towards whom all eyes had previously turned and towards whom they turned again when she was called, stood up. At the same time as she did, her father stood up.

en: “Miss Manette, look upon the prisoner.”
vi: − Miss Manette, look at the defendant.
tr: "Miss Manette, look at the defendant's face."
es: —Examine the prisoner, Miss Manette.

en: To be confronted with such pity, and such earnest youth and beauty, was far more trying to the accused than to be confronted with all the crowd. Standing, as it were, apart with her on the edge of his grave, not all the staring curiosity that looked on, could, for the moment, nerve him to remain quite still. His hurried right hand parcelled out the herbs before him into imaginary beds of flowers in a garden; and his efforts to control and steady his breathing shook the lips from which the colour rushed to his heart. The buzz of the great flies was loud again.
vi: For the prisoner, facing such mercy, such youthful beauty, is far more difficult than facing this entire crowd. Even though he did not flinch while standing close to the grave, challenging all the curious eyes watching him, he still momentarily lost his composure before the girl's gaze. The convict's right hand hastily swept aside the herbs in front of him, turning them into imaginary flower beds; and the effort to keep his breathing steady made his lips tremble, turning pale as if the blood was flowing backward to his heart. The swarm of blue flies buzzed noisily again.
tr: For the defendant, facing this symbol of youth and beauty was much harder than facing the entire crowd. At that moment, the crowd, who had their eyes fixed on him as if waiting at the head of a grave, was not enough to calm him down. He hastily threw the grass in front of him into imaginary flower beds in a garden. While trying to control his breath and calm down, his trembling lips had turned completely white, and all the color had rushed to his heart. The buzzing of the big flies had increased again.
es: A thousand times more painful was it for the accused to find himself facing that young, beautiful girl, who looked at him with longing compassion, than to face the curious gazes of the crowds that filled the room. Without blinking, without a single muscle in his face altering, he endured the terrible accusation of the Crown prosecutor; the statements of the prosecution witnesses did not manage to change his expression, but seeing from the edge of the grave the look, not of curiosity, but of pity, from the girl, all his nerve, which was considerable, was not enough to restrain the agitation in his chest, and in the desperate efforts made to remain calm, his lips turned pale, all the blood flowed back to his heart.

en: “Miss Manette, have you seen the prisoner before?”
vi: − Miss Manette, have you ever met the defendant before? −
tr: "Miss Manette, had you seen the defendant before?"
es: —Did you know the prisoner, Miss Manette?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, I have. −
tr: "Yes, sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Where?”
vi: Where? −
tr: "Where did you see it?"
es: —Where did you meet him?

en: “On board of the packet-ship just now referred to, sir, and on the same occasion.”
vi: On the mail ship just mentioned, sir, and on the same occasion. −
tr: "As mentioned earlier, sir, on the ferry, the same night."
es: —Aboard the ship they mentioned earlier and on the same occasion.

en: “You are the young lady just now referred to?”
vi: You are the lady just mentioned, aren't you?
tr: "So, the lady mentioned earlier is you.""
es: —Are you the young lady mentioned by Mr. Lorry?

en: “O! most unhappily, I am!”
vi: − Oh! Unfortunately, it is indeed me!
tr: "Ah! Unfortunately, it is so, sir!""
es: —Unfortunately, sir, it is I!

en: The plaintive tone of her compassion merged into the less musical voice of the Judge, as he said something fiercely: “Answer the questions put to you, and make no remark upon them.”
vi: Her sorrowful and compassionate voice was drowned out by the harsh and not-so-gentle voice of the Judge: “Answer the question directly without making any comments.” − Miss Manette, did you have any conversation with the defendant on that crossing over the strait?
tr: The young girl's tearful voice full of compassion. When the judge spoke in a stern manner, it got lost within his voice, which was not at all harmonious. "Only answer the questions asked of you and do not make any comments."
es: The tones of compassion that the girl managed to infuse into her voice did not soften that of the judge, who replied with a certain severity: —The witness shall answer the questions asked without making observations or comments...

en: “Miss Manette, had you any conversation with the prisoner on that passage across the Channel?”
tr: "Miss Manette, did you ever share a cabin with the defendant while crossing the English Channel?""
