es: Miss Manette, did you have any conversation with the prisoner during the crossing of the Channel?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, sir. − Please recount it.
tr: "Yes sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Recall it.”
vi: The entire courtroom fell silent when the young woman softly said: −
tr: "Tell me."
es: —Refer her.

en: In the midst of a profound stillness, she faintly began: “When the gentleman came on board—”
vi: When that gentleman boarded the train... −
tr: In the deepening silence, the young girl began to speak in a faint voice: "When the gentleman boarded the ferry-"
es: Amidst an imposing silence, the girl began with a weak voice: —When that gentleman came on board...

en: “Do you mean the prisoner?” inquired the Judge, knitting his brows.
vi: Are you referring to the defendant? - The judge asked, frowning.
tr: The judge frowned and asked, "Are you talking about the defendant?"
es: —Are you referring to the prisoner?—asked the judge, frowning.

en: “Yes, my Lord.”
vi: − Yes, Your Honor. −
tr: "Yes, sir."
es: —Yes, sir.

en: “Then say the prisoner.”
vi: Then we must call him the defendant. −
tr: "Then call him the defendant.""
es: —Well, when you have to name him, call him the prisoner.

en: “When the prisoner came on board, he noticed that my father,” turning her eyes lovingly to him as he stood beside her, “was much fatigued and in a very weak state of health. My father was so reduced that I was afraid to take him out of the air, and I had made a bed for him on the deck near the cabin steps, and I sat on the deck at his side to take care of him. There were no other passengers that night, but we four. The prisoner was so good as to beg permission to advise me how I could shelter my father from the wind and weather, better than I had done. I had not known how to do it well, not understanding how the wind would set when we were out of the harbour. He did it for me. He expressed great gentleness and kindness for my father’s state, and I am sure he felt it. That was the manner of our beginning to speak together.”
vi: When the defendant boarded the ship, he saw my father, - the girl cast a loving glance at the person standing next to her, - too tired and in poor health. My father was so weak that I feared he would have trouble breathing, so I made a bed for him on the deck near the steps leading to the cabin, and I sat on the deck next to him to take care of him. That night there were no other passengers except the four of us. The defendant kindly asked for permission to show me how to shield my father from the wind and rain, better than I could do. I couldn't do it because I didn't know which way the wind would blow when the ship left the port. He helped me with it. He showed great care and kindness towards my father's health, and I truly believe he was sincere. That's how we started talking to each other. −
tr: "When the defendant boarded the ferry, my father," at this moment the girl lovingly turned her eyes towards her father standing next to her, "noticed that he was very exhausted and ill. My father was so weak that I was afraid to move him, and I made him a bed on the deck, next to the stairs leading to the cabins; then I sat down beside him to take care of him. That night, there were no other passengers besides the four of us. The defendant even kindly asked for my permission to suggest what I should do to better protect my father from the wind and cold weather. I didn't know how to do it. I couldn't tell which direction the wind would blow from when we left the port. He helped me. He showed great kindness and concern towards my father, and I'm sure he was sincere while doing it. Thus, we started talking."
es: —When the prisoner came on board, he noticed that my father was very fatigued and in a very delicate state of health. Such was my father's exhaustion that, fearing the lack of air might harm him, I prepared a bed for him on the deck, next to the cabin stairs, and I sat beside him to attend to him. There were only four passengers. The prisoner was so kind that, after asking me to excuse his boldness, he showed me how to place my father sheltered from the air and the damp, something I had not known how to do. He lavished my father with attentions and kindnesses that I cannot forget, and I am sure he did so from the heart. This is how we began to talk.

en: “Let me interrupt you for a moment. Had he come on board alone?”
vi: Let me interrupt you for a moment. Did the defendant board the ship alone?
tr: "Well, I will ask something. Did he board the ferry alone?"
es: —Allow me to interrupt you. Did you arrive alone on board?

en: “No.”
vi: − No. − How many people accompanied him?
tr: "No"
es: —No, sir.

en: “How many were with him?”
vi: − No. − How many people accompanied him?
tr: "How many people were with you?""
es: —How many were accompanying you?

en: “Two French gentlemen.”
vi: − Two French gentlemen. −
tr: "There were two French gentlemen."
es: —Two French gentlemen.

en: “Had they conferred together?”
vi: Did they discuss anything with each other?
tr: "Did they talk?""
es: —What were you discussing with the prisoner?

en: “They had conferred together until the last moment, when it was necessary for the French gentlemen to be landed in their boat.”
vi: − They discussed until the last moment, when the French gentlemen had to leave the ship and board their boat. −
tr: "They talked until the last moment, that is, until the time the French had to return to their boats."
es: —They spoke with the prisoner until the last moment. When the ship was weighing anchor, they bid him farewell and jumped into their boat.

en: “Had any papers been handed about among them, similar to these lists?”
vi: Did they exchange any documents similar to these lists?
tr: "Was there a paper exchange similar to these lists between them?"
es: —Did they exchange among themselves any papers similar to these?

en: “Some papers had been handed about among them, but I don’t know what papers.”
vi: − They exchanged some documents, but I don't know what kind of documents. −
tr: "There was an exchange of papers between them, but I don't know what it was about."
es: —They exchanged some papers, but I don't know how or what they were.

en: “Like these in shape and size?”
vi: Were they similar in shape and size to these documents?
tr: "Were the papers of this size and shape?"
es: —Similar to these in size and shape?

en: “Possibly, but indeed I don’t know, although they stood whispering very near to me: because they stood at the top of the cabin steps to have the light of the lamp that was hanging there; it was a dull lamp, and they spoke very low, and I did not hear what they said, and saw only that they looked at papers.”
vi: − Possibly, but honestly, I don't know, even though they were whispering right next to me; since there was a lamp hanging at the top of the steps leading down to the sleeping quarters, they stood there for better light; the light was very dim, and they spoke very softly, I couldn't hear what they were saying, I only saw them looking at the documents. −
tr: "It might be, but I can't be sure despite their whispering very close to me; they were standing at the top of the stairs leading down to the cabins to take advantage of the light from the hanging lamp; the light was dim and they were speaking very softly, I couldn't hear what they were talking about, I only saw that they were looking at papers.""
es: —It is possible, but I cannot assure it, although I was very close to the place where they were talking. The night was very dark and the prisoner and the French gentlemen positioned themselves at the top of the chamber stairs, under the hanging lantern. They, however, held the conversation in such a low voice that I did not hear a word. I did see, though, that they were reading papers, and nothing more.

en: “Now, to the prisoner’s conversation, Miss Manette.”
vi: Now let's talk about your conversation with the defendant, Miss Manette. −
tr: "Now let's return to your conversation with the defendant, Miss Manette."
es: —Repeat to us the conversation you had with the prisoner, Miss Manette.

en: “The prisoner was as open in his confidence with me—which arose out of my helpless situation—as he was kind, and good, and useful to my father. I hope,” bursting into tears, “I may not repay him by doing him harm to-day.”
vi: The defendant appeared to be straightforward and trustworthy... because in that situation I didn't know what to do... because he was also kind and considerate to me just as he was to my father. I hope that... - the girl burst into tears - ... that today I don't have to repay him with words that harm him.
tr: "The defendant – perhaps due to my helplessness – was very reassuring and very kind, good, and helpful to my father," she said, bursting into tears, and added, "If I say anything that would harm him, I can never repay my debt to him."
es: —The prisoner was very frank with me... he placed great trust in me... he was very kind, very good... he treated my father with tender care... and I wouldn't want—finished the young woman, in a sea of tears—I wouldn't want to repay his favors with statements that might harm him.

en: Buzzing from the blue-flies.
vi: The swarm of green flies buzzed again.
tr: A hum rose from their backs again.
es: The blue horseflies started buzzing again.

en: “Miss Manette, if the prisoner does not perfectly understand that you give the evidence which it is your duty to give—which you must give—and which you cannot escape from giving—with great unwillingness, he is the only person present in that condition. Please to go on.”
vi: − Miss Manette, if the defendant does not fully understand that you were extremely reluctant to provide the evidence that you were obliged to provide, the evidence that you had to provide, and the evidence that you could not avoid providing, then everyone here understands except the defendant. Please continue. −
tr: "Miss Manette, if the defendant does not understand that you are obligated to provide this evidence – that is, you must provide it – and that you cannot escape from this, there is nothing that can be done. Please continue."
es: —Miss Manette—replied the prosecutor,—if the prisoner does not realize that you are giving the testimony that it is your duty to give... that you are obliged to give... that you cannot be excused from giving, against your will and with great reluctance, it must be admitted that he is blind. Please continue.

en: “He told me that he was travelling on business of a delicate and difficult nature, which might get people into trouble, and that he was therefore travelling under an assumed name. He said that this business had, within a few days, taken him to France, and might, at intervals, take him backwards and forwards between France and England for a long time to come.”
vi: He told me that he was doing a delicate and difficult task, one that could cause trouble for many people, so he used a false name when traveling. He said that this task, in a few days, would take him back to France, and that he might have to travel back and forth between France and England many times in the near future. −
tr: "He told me that he was traveling because of a delicate and difficult task that could cause trouble for people, and that's why he was using an alias. He had gone to France for a few days for this task and explained that he might travel back and forth between France and England at intervals for a longer period."
es: —He told me that his journey was motivated by matters of a highly delicate and compromising nature, matters that might possibly cause serious conflicts between different peoples, and for this reason, he was traveling under an assumed name. He told me that these matters had taken him to France a few days earlier, and that probably, for a more or less long period, they would oblige him to make frequent trips between England and France.

en: “Did he say anything about America, Miss Manette? Be particular.”
vi: Did the defendant say anything about America, Miss Manette? Please be specific. −
tr: "Did Miss Manette say anything about America? Think carefully."
es: —Did he speak of America, Miss Manette? Please be kind enough to specify in detail.

en: “He tried to explain to me how that quarrel had arisen, and he said that, so far as he could judge, it was a wrong and foolish one on England’s part. He added, in a jesting way, that perhaps George Washington might gain almost as great a name in history as George the Third. But there was no harm in his way of saying this: it was said laughingly, and to beguile the time.”
vi: He tried to explain to me how the conflict had arisen, and he said that, in his opinion, the British side had been mistaken and foolish. He jokingly added that perhaps George Washington would become as famous in history as King George III. But he said this without any malice; it was just to pass the time with some humor.
tr: "He tried to explain to me how the dispute started and said that what England did was, in his opinion, wrong and foolish. He also jokingly said that George Washington would go down in history as an important name, just like George III. But he said this not with ill intent, but laughingly, for fun. He didn't mean it in a bad way, he said it with a smile, just for amusement."
es: —He tried to explain to me the causes that led to the conflict, and he told me that, in his opinion, the wrong and the injustice were on the side of England. He added, in a humorous tone, that perhaps George Washington was destined to achieve as high a renown in history as George III. But in all this there was not a shadow of malice: he said it laughing and to pass the time.

en: Any strongly marked expression of face on the part of a chief actor in a scene of great interest to whom many eyes are directed, will be unconsciously imitated by the spectators. Her forehead was painfully anxious and intent as she gave this evidence, and, in the pauses when she stopped for the Judge to write it down, watched its effect upon the counsel for and against. Among the lookers-on there was the same expression in all quarters of the court; insomuch, that a great majority of the foreheads there, might have been mirrors reflecting the witness, when the Judge looked up from his notes to glare at that tremendous heresy about George Washington.
vi: Any prominent expression on the face of the main character in an engaging play will be unconsciously mimicked by the audience; the girl's forehead furrowed with concentration and worry to the point of distress as she testified in court, and during the moments she paused for the Judge to take notes, and observed the reactions of the officials on both the defense and prosecution sides. Throughout the courtroom, every curious spectator shared that same expression; to the extent that when the Judge put down his pen and looked up, his face grim due to the highly blasphemous remark about George Washington, the majority of foreheads there became mirrors reflecting the emotions of the girl witness.
tr: In this intriguing scene where all eyes were directed, the audience would unconsciously mimic any stern expression that appeared on the lead actor's face. When he explained this evidence, the young lady's forehead wrinkled with pain and she became attentive, and during the moments when the Judge paused to take notes, he looked at both the defense attorney and the prosecutor to see the impact of his words. The same expression was on the faces of the spectators all around the courtroom; so much so that when the Judge looked up from his notes and stared intently regarding the dreadful misdeed related to George Washington, many of their foreheads were like mirrors reflecting the witness.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: Mr. Attorney-General now signified to my Lord, that he deemed it necessary, as a matter of precaution and form, to call the young lady’s father, Doctor Manette. Who was called accordingly.
vi: The Attorney General now signaled to the Chief Justice, indicating that it was time to question Dr. Manette, the girl's father, in accordance with procedure and as a precaution. This person was called to testify.
tr: The Chief Prosecutor, in all his grandeur, expressed that it was necessary to summon the young lady's father, Doctor Manette, in terms of precaution and procedure. Thus, Mr. Manette was called to the witness stand.
es: The Crown Prosecutor stated that he considered it necessary to question the young lady's father, Dr. Manette.

en: “Doctor Manette, look upon the prisoner. Have you ever seen him before?”
vi: − Dr. Manette, look at the defendant over there. Have you ever met the defendant before?
tr: "Doctor Manette, look at the face of the defendant. Have you ever seen him before?"
es: —Look at the prisoner, Dr. Manette: do you remember seeing him before?

en: “Once. When he called at my lodgings in London. Some three years, or three years and a half ago.”
vi: − Once. When this person visited my house in London. About three or three and a half years ago.
tr: "Once. He had visited my house in London. About three or three and a half years ago."
es: —Only once. It was three or three and a half years ago that he visited me at my house in London.

en: “Can you identify him as your fellow-passenger on board the packet, or speak to his conversation with your daughter?”
vi: − Did you recognize the defendant as the person who was on the same train, or did you see him talking to your daughter?
tr: "Don't you remember the passenger who was traveling next to you on the ferry and talking to your daughter?"
es: —Can you tell us if he was your travel companion during the crossing of the Canal, or repeat the conversation you had with your daughter?

en: “Sir, I can do neither.”
vi: − Your Honor, I was not aware of either of those things.
tr: "I don't remember such a thing, sir.""
es: —Neither one nor the other, sir.

en: “Is there any particular and special reason for your being unable to do either?”
vi: − Is there a specific and special reason why you couldn't recognize both of those things?
tr: "Could there be a specific reason why you can't remember these?""
es: —Are there any particular and special reasons that make it impossible for you to do what is being asked?

en: He answered, in a low voice, “There is.”
vi: − Yes, - he replied softly.
tr: Mr. Manette replied in a low voice, "There is.""
es: —They exist—replied the doctor in a very low voice.

en: “Has it been your misfortune to undergo a long imprisonment, without trial, or even accusation, in your native country, Doctor Manette?”
vi: − Doctor Manette, in France you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, or even without charges, is that correct?
tr: "In your own country, you were imprisoned for a long time without trial, and without even being charged with any crime, weren't you, Doctor Manette?"
es: —Are these the misfortunes of having suffered a long captivity in your homeland, without being condemned, and even without being accused?

en: He answered, in a tone that went to every heart, “A long imprisonment.”
vi: − Imprisoned for a very long time, - his voice answered, moving everyone deeply.
tr: In a tone that tore at everyone's heart, Mr. Manette replied, "For a very long time indeed."
es: With a tone that penetrated to the depths of the hearts of all those present, he replied: —An eternal captivity!

en: “Were you newly released on the occasion in question?”
vi: − When you took that train, you had just been released from prison, hadn't you?
tr: "In the mentioned situation, had you just been released?""
es: —Had you recently regained your freedom when the trip I am referring to took place?

en: “They tell me so.”
vi: − That's what people told me.
tr: "That's what they say."
es: —That's what they tell me.

en: “Have you no remembrance of the occasion?”
tr: "Don't you remember that moment at all?"
es: —Don't you remember?

en: “None. My mind is a blank, from some time—I cannot even say what time—when I employed myself, in my captivity, in making shoes, to the time when I found myself living in London with my dear daughter here. She had become familiar to me, when a gracious God restored my faculties; but, I am quite unable even to say how she had become familiar. I have no remembrance of the process.”
vi: You don't remember anything about that train ride? − No. I had lost my memory for a long time... I don't even know how long... from when I started making shoes in prison, until I found myself in London with my daughter here. I recognized my daughter when God restored my memory; but I still don't know how I came to meet my child again. I don't remember how it happened at all.
tr: "No. My mind has been blank since –I don't even know since when– from the times I started making shoes by myself in prison, to the moment I found myself in London beside my dear daughter, empty. Thank God I remembered my daughter when the Almighty restored my skills; but I am not even in a position to say how I remembered her. I don't remember anything from that period."
es: —I don't remember anything. My brain was a deep night for some time... I can't say how long... from when I was making shoes in my cell until I found myself in London in the company of my dear daughter. I got used to her presence... I don't know how... I have no memory of the process... and finally, the merciful God saw fit to restore my faculties.

en: Mr. Attorney-General sat down, and the father and daughter sat down together.
vi: The Attorney General sat down, and the father and son also sat down at the same time.
tr: The Chief Prosecutor sat down, then the father and bz also took their places.
es: The Crown prosecutor concluded the questioning, and the father and daughter sat down again.

en: A singular circumstance then arose in the case. The object in hand being to show that the prisoner went down, with some fellow-plotter untracked, in the Dover mail on that Friday night in November five years ago, and got out of the mail in the night, as a blind, at a place where he did not remain, but from which he travelled back some dozen miles or more, to a garrison and dockyard, and there collected information; a witness was called to identify him as having been at the precise time required, in the coffee-room of an hotel in that garrison-and-dockyard town, waiting for another person. The prisoner’s counsel was cross-examining this witness with no result, except that he had never seen the prisoner on any other occasion, when the wigged gentleman who had all this time been looking at the ceiling of the court, wrote a word or two on a little piece of paper, screwed it up, and tossed it to him. Opening this piece of paper in the next pause, the counsel looked with great attention and curiosity at the prisoner.
vi: Then a strange situation occurred during the trial. The main objective was to prove that the criminal, along with an unknown accomplice, had taken the Dover mail coach on a Friday night in November five years ago, disembarked during the night to mislead, got off at a place where he did not stay but went back about twelve miles or more to a place with a military base and shipyard, and then gathered information there; a witness was called to confirm that the defendant was present at that exact time, in the dining room of a hotel in the city with the military base and shipyard, waiting to meet another person. The defense attorney was still questioning this witness without any result, except for the witness's admission that he had never met the defendant in any other circumstance, when the gentleman wearing a wig, who had been staring at the ceiling, wrote a few words on a piece of paper, crumpled it up, and tossed it to the attorney. During a pause between two questions, the attorney opened the piece of paper, read it, and then looked at the defendant with great attention and curiosity.
tr: Then, a strange development occurred in the trial. According to the information obtained, the defendant, five years ago. On that Friday night in November, had boarded the Dover Mail with an unidentified accomplice, then disembarked somewhere in the pitch dark of the night, but did not stay there long, had walked ten to fifteen kilometers back to a garrison and dockyard to gather information; but then a witness was called who claimed that at that time, the defendant was waiting for someone else in the tea lounge of a hotel in the town where the mentioned garrison and dockyard were located. The defendant's lawyer had asked this new witness many questions, but received no answer other than that he had never seen the defendant at any other time; just then, the wigged man who had been watching the ceiling of the courtroom until that moment scribbled something on a piece of paper, crumpled it, and threw it to the lawyer. During the first break, the lawyer opened this paper and looked at the defendant with great interest and curiosity.
es: A singular incident occurred at this point. The object of the proceedings, the goal pursued in the process, was to demonstrate that the accused, in the company of another traitorous accomplice whose identity was a mystery until then, travelers, on the night of a Friday in the month of November five years ago, had dismounted during the journey in the mail coach from London to Dover, with the aim of misleading, at a place where they did not intend to stay, from where they retraced twelve or more miles to reach a stronghold with an arsenal, where they gathered the data they were seeking. A witness declared that on the indicated day and time, he had seen the prisoner in the dining room of a hotel in the mentioned stronghold and arsenal, waiting for another person. The defendant's defense attorney was subjecting the witness to an interrogation as rigid as it was skillful, with no other result than ensuring that he had never, neither before nor after the indicated occasion, seen the prisoner, when the bewigged gentleman, who had been staring at the ceiling of the courtroom since the beginning of the trial, wrote two or three words on a small piece of paper, twisted it, and then threw it to the defense attorney. After reading the small piece of paper, the defense attorney looked at the prisoner with extraordinary attention and curiosity.

en: “You say again you are quite sure that it was the prisoner?”
vi: − Do you dare to say again that you are certain this is the defendant?
tr: "Are you sure this person is the defendant?"
es: —Do you say that you have absolute certainty that it was the prisoner?—asked the witness.

en: The witness was quite sure.
vi: The witness is completely certain.
tr: The witness was quite sure.
es: —Absolutely.

en: “Did you ever see anybody very like the prisoner?”
vi: − Have you ever seen anyone who looks very much like the defendant?
tr: "Have you ever seen someone who looks very much like the defendant?"
es: —Have you never seen anyone who resembles the prisoner?

en: Not so like (the witness said) as that he could be mistaken.
vi: Not so much that they could be mistaken for each other, - the witness said.
tr: He had not seen anyone who looked so similar that it would cause confusion (the witness had said exactly this).
es: —To no one who resembles them so much that it could lead to a mistake.

en: “Look well upon that gentleman, my learned friend there,” pointing to him who had tossed the paper over, “and then look well upon the prisoner. How say you? Are they very like each other?”
vi: − Look carefully at that gentleman, he is my colleague, - the lawyer pointed towards the person who threw the piece of paper, - and then look carefully at the defendant. What did he say? Do they look exactly alike?
tr: The man who threw the paper pointed and said, "Look at the gentleman sitting over there, that wise person, and then look at the defendant. What do you say? Don't they look very much alike?"
es: —Take a good look at that gentleman,—he replied, pointing to the one who had just thrown him the note—and then, take a good look at the prisoner. What do you say? Isn't it true that they look quite alike?

en: Allowing for my learned friend’s appearance being careless and slovenly if not debauched, they were sufficiently like each other to surprise, not only the witness, but everybody present, when they were thus brought into comparison. My Lord being prayed to bid my learned friend lay aside his wig, and giving no very gracious consent, the likeness became much more remarkable. My Lord inquired of Mr. Stryver (the prisoner’s counsel), whether they were next to try Mr. Carton (name of my learned friend) for treason? But, Mr. Stryver replied to my Lord, no; but he would ask the witness to tell him whether what happened once, might happen twice; whether he would have been so confident if he had seen this illustration of his rashness sooner, whether he would be so confident, having seen it; and more. The upshot of which, was, to smash this witness like a crockery vessel, and shiver his part of the case to useless lumber.
vi: Except for the careless and sloppy, if not disheveled, appearance of our esteemed colleague, the other two looked so alike that both the witness and everyone in the court were astonished when they recognized the resemblance. After the judge requested our esteemed colleague to remove his wig and he complied with a displeased look, the resemblance became even more strikingly clear. The judge asked Mr. Stryver (the defense attorney) whether they were intending to try Mr. Carton (our esteemed colleague) for treason. Mr. Stryver replied that they were not, but he would ask the witness if he was sure that what had happened once could not happen again; if the witness was certain he had encountered the defendant if he had ever seen such a resemblance before; and now that he had seen it, if he could still be so confident, along with many other questions. The result was that the witness's credibility in court was shattered like a clay pot, and his testimony became a pile of useless fragments.
tr: If we disregard the appearance of our wise friend, which, although not immoral, could be described as disheveled and slovenly, it could be said that when compared to each other, they resembled each other so much that it would astonish not only the witness but everyone present. The judge, upon the prosecutor's request, ordered our wise friend to remove his wig, which made this resemblance even more apparent. The judge asked Mr. Stryver (the defendant's lawyer) whether the other person they were going to try for treason was Mr. Carton (our wise friend). Mr. Stryver told the judge no; but he would ask the witness to tell the judge the likelihood of something happening again once it had happened once; if he had seen his imprudence before, would he still speak so confidently or would he still speak confidently even after seeing it, were among the many questions on his mind. The aim was to crush this witness and nullify his part of the case.
es: However, despite the negligence and untidiness of the gentleman with the little paper, there was a rather remarkable resemblance between him and the prisoner, enough to surprise not only the witness but also everyone present in the courtroom. The president of the tribunal requested the aforementioned gentleman with the little paper to remove his wig, and the resemblance became much more notable. The president asked Mr. Stryver, who was the defense attorney, if they were to prosecute Mr. Carton, the name of the gentleman with the little paper, for the crime of treason, to which the defense attorney replied no, but that he wished to ask the witness if he believed that what had happened once could not happen again, if he would have dared to speak with such certainty and confidence if he had previously seen that palpable example of his temerity, if the sight of a person who so closely resembled the prisoner would not have been a severe blow to his confidence, etc., etc. The result of this incident was to annihilate the witness, destroy the effect of his testimony, and strip all value from his statements.

en: Mr. Cruncher had by this time taken quite a lunch of rust off his fingers in his following of the evidence. He had now to attend while Mr. Stryver fitted the prisoner’s case on the jury, like a compact suit of clothes; showing them how the patriot, Barsad, was a hired spy and traitor, an unblushing trafficker in blood, and one of the greatest scoundrels upon earth since accursed Judas—which he certainly did look rather like. How the virtuous servant, Cly, was his friend and partner, and was worthy to be; how the watchful eyes of those forgers and false swearers had rested on the prisoner as a victim, because some family affairs in France, he being of French extraction, did require his making those passages across the Channel—though what those affairs were, a consideration for others who were near and dear to him, forbade him, even for his life, to disclose. How the evidence that had been warped and wrested from the young lady, whose anguish in giving it they had witnessed, came to nothing, involving the mere little innocent gallantries and politenesses likely to pass between any young gentleman and young lady so thrown together;—with the exception of that reference to George Washington, which was altogether too extravagant and impossible to be regarded in any other light than as a monstrous joke. How it would be a weakness in the government to break down in this attempt to practise for popularity on the lowest national antipathies and fears, and therefore Mr. Attorney-General had made the most of it; how, nevertheless, it rested upon nothing, save that vile and infamous character of evidence too often disfiguring such cases, and of which the State Trials of this country were full. But, there my Lord interposed (with as grave a face as if it had not been true), saying that he could not sit upon that Bench and suffer those allusions.
vi: At this point, Cruncher had thoroughly sucked the rusty, metallic taste from his fingers as a substitute for lunch while following the testimonies. Now he listened to Mr. Stryver refute the incriminating evidence, as if tailoring a suit to fit the jury; the barrister showed them that the patriot Barsad was actually a paid informant and traitor, a shameless human trafficker, and one of the most malicious individuals since Judas Iscariot - who he even resembled. As for the virtuous servant Cly, he was Barsad's friend and accomplice, no better than him; the barrister demonstrated how these two perjurers had targeted the defendant and plotted to frame him; the defendant, being of French origin, had legitimate reasons to travel frequently between the two countries - matters involving his closest and dearest, which he would not disclose even under threat of death. The barrister proved that the testimony of the young lady, who everyone could see was distressed while testifying, had been distorted and coerced into worthless evidence; her statements were merely polite, impartial exchanges that any gentleman or lady might have, except for the wildly inappropriate comment about George Washington, which could only be seen as a crude joke. The barrister argued that it would be a weakness in governance to undermine efforts to win the affection of subjects through fear and hatred sown among the public, which the Attorney General had exploited to the fullest; however, this had no significance other than the fact that the vile and despicable nature of the evidence often discredited such trials, a fact well-documented in our country's State Trials. But at this point, the judge interrupted (with a stern expression as if the barrister had spoken untruths), declaring that he could not accept such insinuations during the trial.
tr: Mr. Cruncher had eaten all the rust off his fingers as if it were lunch while watching the witnesses. Now he was watching with curiosity as Mr. Stryver fitted the defendant's case onto the jury like a well-tailored suit; he was telling them that the so-called patriot Barsad was a secret spy and traitor, and moreover, a shameless blood merchant, and the greatest traitor since the accursed Judas – to whom he indeed bore a resemblance. He explained that the very virtuous servant Cly was his friend and partner and that he deserved such company; that the fraudsters and false witnesses had chosen the defendant as their victim due to family matters in France, after all, he was of French origin and had to cross the Channel frequently – but these family matters, which concerned those close to him, prevented him from explaining all this, even at the cost of his life. The words forcibly taken and distorted from the young lady meant nothing, and everyone had witnessed how much she suffered while saying them; in that environment, such innocent conversation and courtesy between a young gentleman and lady were very natural; meanwhile, those excessive words about George Washington could be nothing but a bad joke. It would appear as a weakness of the state to halt the attempts to apply the lowest levels of national hatred and fears, so the Attorney General had done his best; but it was to no avail, these disgraceful and vile pieces of evidence frequently tainted such cases, and there were many trials like this in the country. But the courts, which were packed to the brim, should not be occupied with such baseless cases. But there the Judge objected (with a stern expression on his face as if what was being said was not true) and said from his bench that he could not allow these insinuations.
es: The result of this incident was to annihilate the witness, destroy the effect of his testimony, and strip all value from his statements. The good Jeremiah Lapa, who was following the course of the trial without missing a word or gesture, had to listen as the defense turned the tables on the prosecutor and the witnesses who had served the Jury, saying that the exalted, the sublime patriot Barsad, was a mercenary spy, a vile traitor, a blood trafficker who knew neither decorum nor shame, the blackest-souled reptile that had existed in the world since the accursed Judas, to whom he bore a physical and moral resemblance, dishonored it with his presence. He asserted that the mirror of a servant, the innocent Cly, was a friend and accomplice of Barsad, and certainly worthy of being so, that the ever-watchful eyes of those miserable forgers and perjurers had resolved to turn the prisoner into a victim of their greed, taking advantage of the fact that he, being of French origin, made frequent trips between England and France for family matters he could not explain, and that the prisoner would not explain, even if his silence cost him his life, because high considerations forbade him. He demonstrated that the statements made by Miss Manette, whose anguish in making them everyone had had the opportunity to appreciate, were of no importance, and were nothing more than innocent gallantries, very natural for a young man who encounters a charming girl on a journey, except for the part concerning George Washington, which in his opinion was so extravagant that it could only be considered a wildly inappropriate joke. He added that Justice would show palpable weakness if it persisted in the idea of pursuing a sterile populism by exploiting low antipathies and national fears that the Crown prosecutor had exploited in his report, which, in truth, had no more foundation than the meanness and vileness of a statement whose bad faith was glaringly obvious, a statement made with the deliberate intention of distorting the facts, a statement that tends to make Justice, to our shame, add a most lamentable error to the endless series of those it has committed. The president, as if what the defender had just expressed was not an exact expression of the truth, interrupted the speaker with a grim face, to say, with a grave demeanor, that it was impossible for him to continue occupying his elevated seat if he was forced to tolerate such unpleasant allusions.

en: Mr. Stryver then called his few witnesses, and Mr. Cruncher had next to attend while Mr. Attorney-General turned the whole suit of clothes Mr. Stryver had fitted on the jury, inside out; showing how Barsad and Cly were even a hundred times better than he had thought them, and the prisoner a hundred times worse. Lastly, came my Lord himself, turning the suit of clothes, now inside out, now outside in, but on the whole decidedly trimming and shaping them into grave-clothes for the prisoner.
vi: Mr. Stryver then called a few more of his witnesses, and afterward Cruncher attentively listened to the Attorney General turn the suit that Mr. Stryver had dressed the jury in inside out; the Attorney General proved that Barsad and Cly were a hundred times better than he had ever imagined, while the defendant was a hundred times worse. Finally, it was the Chief Judge's turn to turn the suit inside out and right side out, but overall he decided to trim it into a shroud for the defendant.
tr: Then Mr. Stryver called a few more witnesses, and while Mr. Cruncher waited, the Attorney General turned the suit that Mr. Stryver had dressed the jury in inside out; that is, he explained that both Barsad and Cly were much better people than the lawyer had thought, and the defendant was a much worse person. Finally, the Judge turned that suit inside out, then right side out, but in the end, he decisively cut it and fashioned a shroud for the defendant.
es: The defense attorney questioned the few exculpatory witnesses, and subsequently, the audience had to admire the efforts made by the Crown prosecutor to turn inside out the case that the former had crafted for the Jury. The most striking part of his speech was to assert a thousand times over that the heroic Barsad and Cly were a thousand times more virtuous than initially stated, and the prisoner a thousand times more criminal. In his final report, the president went over and over the case crafted by the prosecutor and tried to undo the seams of the one presented by the defense attorney, showing a clear tendency to prepare the prisoner's shroud with both.

en: And now, the jury turned to consider, and the great flies swarmed again.
vi: Now it's time for the jury to deliberate and the blue flies swarm and buzz again.
tr: When it came time for the jury members' deliberation, the large flies gathered in the courtroom once again.
es: The Jury withdrew to deliberate, and the large blue flies once again made their unpleasant buzzing heard.

en: Mr. Carton, who had so long sat looking at the ceiling of the court, changed neither his place nor his attitude, even in this excitement. While his learned friend, Mr. Stryver, massing his papers before him, whispered with those who sat near, and from time to time glanced anxiously at the jury; while all the spectators moved more or less, and grouped themselves anew; while even my Lord himself arose from his seat, and slowly paced up and down his platform, not unattended by a suspicion in the minds of the audience that his state was feverish; this one man sat leaning back, with his torn gown half off him, his untidy wig put on just as it had happened to light on his head after its removal, his hands in his pockets, and his eyes on the ceiling as they had been all day. Something especially reckless in his demeanour, not only gave him a disreputable look, but so diminished the strong resemblance he undoubtedly bore to the prisoner (which his momentary earnestness, when they were compared together, had strengthened), that many of the lookers-on, taking note of him now, said to one another they would hardly have thought the two were so alike. Mr. Cruncher made the observation to his next neighbour, and added, “I’d hold half a guinea that he don’t get no law-work to do. Don’t look like the sort of one to get any, do he?”
vi: Right in this bustling scene, lawyer Carton - who had been sitting and staring at the ceiling - did not change his posture or attitude at all. While his colleague Stryver was gathering the papers in front of him and whispering to those nearby, occasionally glancing anxiously at the jury; while everyone attending the trial was moving and forming new groups to some extent; while even the judge left his seat and slowly paced back and forth on the podium, causing the crowd to suspect that he was feeling impatient; only Carton remained leaning back in his chair, his old robe almost slipping off his shoulders, his disheveled wig haphazardly perched on his head as if protesting being removed earlier, his hands in his pockets, and his eyes still fixed on the ceiling. That very disdainful attitude not only made him appear somewhat disreputable but also diminished the undeniable resemblance to the defendant (a resemblance that was quite clear when he temporarily showed a serious demeanor for comparison), to the extent that many trial spectators now remarked to each other that Carton and the defendant did not look much alike. Cruncher made this observation to the person standing next to him and added: −I'd bet half a guinea that this lawyer doesn't get hired much. Doesn't look like the kind of lawyer who has work to do, right?
tr: Mr. Carton, who had been sitting with his eyes fixed on the ceiling of the hall for hours, had neither changed his position nor his demeanor even in this confusion. His wise friend Mr. Stryver, who was gathering the papers in front of him, was whispering to those beside him while occasionally glancing anxiously at the jury; meanwhile, the Judge had risen from his seat and was pacing up and down the podium, causing the audience to suspect he had a fever; the man sitting back with his torn robe half fallen, his disheveled wig crooked after falling off, and his hands in his pockets still had his eyes on the ceiling. The indifference in his manner not only gave him a disreputable air but also diminished his strong resemblance to the defendant (though the resemblance had increased a moment ago with the seriousness that arose when they were compared), so much so that most of the spectators who noticed him were whispering that they didn't look much alike. Mr. Cruncher was also sharing his observations with the man next to him: "I bet this man never wins a case. He doesn't look like the type who can win a case, does he?"
es: The movement, the general murmurs, the anticipation that had taken hold of all the witnesses of the scene, did not cause Mr. Carton, who continued to sit and stare at the ceiling, to change his posture or position. Meanwhile, his friend Mr. Stryver, gathering the papers in front of him, conversed with the people closest to him and from time to time cast anxious glances at the Jury, while all the spectators moved about more or less, sometimes separating, sometimes coming together again, while even the president left his seat to walk around the platform, giving reason for those present to suspect that his state of mind was far from calm, Mr. Carton remained slouched in his seat, with his wig half askew, hands in his pockets, seemingly indifferent to everything and everyone, his eyes fixed on the ceiling as they had been all day. Nevertheless, Mr. Carton noticed more details of the scene unfolding before his eyes than it seemed at first glance. Proof of this is that, when Miss Manette, overwhelmed by so many emotions, fainted into her father's arms, it was Carton who noticed it first and was the first to come to her aid, saying: —Guard!

en: Yet, this Mr. Carton took in more of the details of the scene than he appeared to take in; for now, when Miss Manette’s head dropped upon her father’s breast, he was the first to see it, and to say audibly: “Officer! look to that young lady. Help the gentleman to take her out. Don’t you see she will fall!”
vi: Yet this Carton, despite appearances, was actually observing everything in the court; because at this moment, when Miss Manette collapsed into her father's arms, he was the first to notice and shouted: −Officer?! Take care of the lady. Help the gentleman take her outside. Can't you see she's about to faint?!
tr: Despite his indifferent appearance, Mr. Carton was watching everything in detail, and when Miss Manette's head fell onto her father's chest, he was the first to see it, and as soon as he saw it, he shouted in a voice that everyone could hear, "Hey, attendant! Quick, look after the young lady. Help the gentleman so he can take the lady outside. She's about to faint!"
es: Attend to that young lady... Help the gentleman to get her out of the room... Don't you see she's about to faint?

en: There was much commiseration for her as she was removed, and much sympathy with her father. It had evidently been a great distress to him, to have the days of his imprisonment recalled. He had shown strong internal agitation when he was questioned, and that pondering or brooding look which made him old, had been upon him, like a heavy cloud, ever since. As he passed out, the jury, who had turned back and paused a moment, spoke, through their foreman.
vi: The crowd felt great sympathy for the girl and compassion for the father as she was taken outside. The father was clearly extremely distressed, having to recall the days of his imprisonment. He was deeply moved when questioned, and from that moment on, he looked significantly older, his face perpetually gloomy and contemplative as if shrouded in dark clouds. As he walked out, the jury turned their faces and took a break so that the foreman could speak to the court.
tr: As the girl was being taken outside, a great sense of pity for her and compassion for her father arose in the hall. It was clear that recalling the prison days had disturbed her greatly. During the interrogation, she felt a deep pain inside, and the pensive and thoughtful demeanor that made her look older had settled over her like a heavy cloud. As she was leaving, the jury members returning to their seats remained silent for a moment, then the jury spokesperson spoke.
es: Everyone was moved to compassion upon seeing the young lady being taken out of the room, and there was no one who did not extend all their sympathies to the father. The scene, which could not help but remind him of the endless years of his undeserved imprisonment, deeply affected him. A good proof of this was the intense inner agitation that the interrogation caused him, an agitation that did not go unnoticed by anyone. Moments later, the Jury appeared, and through its president, stated that, not having reached an agreement, they wished to withdraw again.

en: They were not agreed, and wished to retire. My Lord (perhaps with George Washington on his mind) showed some surprise that they were not agreed, but signified his pleasure that they should retire under watch and ward, and retired himself. The trial had lasted all day, and the lamps in the court were now being lighted. It began to be rumoured that the jury would be out a long while. The spectators dropped off to get refreshment, and the prisoner withdrew to the back of the dock, and sat down.
vi: The jury did not have a consensus and wanted to retreat to the deliberation room. The judge (probably still preoccupied with thoughts of George Washington) was somewhat surprised that the jury was not unanimous, but agreed to let them meet in private under supervision, and he himself temporarily withdrew. The trial had lasted all day, and the lights in the court were now being lit. People began to gossip that the jury would deliberate for quite a while. The audience then dispersed for a break, and the defendant retreated to the back of the dock and sat down to await their fate.
tr: They couldn't come to a decision and wanted to reconvene. The judge was surprised when he heard they couldn't come to a decision (perhaps he still had George Washington on his mind), but after expressing that he would be pleased if they locked themselves in a room under supervision and talked, he also withdrew to another room. The trial had lasted all day and the lamps in the hall had been lit. Rumors had started circulating in the hall that the jury members wouldn't come for a long time. The spectators went outside to drink something, and the defendant went behind the section he was in and sat down.
es: Moments later, the Jury appeared, and through its president, stated that, not having reached an agreement, they wished to withdraw again. The president of the Court, whose imagination was filled, if some malicious people are not mistaken, by the portrait of George Washington, expressed some surprise upon learning that the Jury had not reached an agreement, but agreed to let them retire again to deliberate, and, undoubtedly to imitate their conduct, he also withdrew. The hearing had lasted all day and it was necessary to light the lamps in the Courtroom. Rumors circulated that the Jury's deliberations would be long, in view of which, the spectators began to file out to get some refreshments, and the defendant was taken to the most secluded part of the bar, where he took a seat.

en: Mr. Lorry, who had gone out when the young lady and her father went out, now reappeared, and beckoned to Jerry: who, in the slackened interest, could easily get near him.
vi: Mr. Lorry, who had just gone out following the girl and her father, now came back in and signaled to Jerry; the messenger easily reached him as the general curiosity around had subsided.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who had followed the young lady and her father outside, had now returned to the lounge and was signaling to Jerry. Jerry, whose interest in the matter had waned, immediately came over to him.
es: Mr. Lorry, who had gone out accompanying Miss Manette and her father, reappeared again and signaled to Jeremiah Lapa.

en: “Jerry, if you wish to take something to eat, you can. But, keep in the way. You will be sure to hear when the jury come in. Don’t be a moment behind them, for I want you to take the verdict back to the bank. You are the quickest messenger I know, and will get to Temple Bar long before I can.”
vi: − Jerry, if you want to get something to eat, just go. But stay close by. You must pay attention to when the jury returns and follow them immediately without delay, because I need you to deliver the verdict to the bank. You are the fastest messenger I know, and you will definitely reach Temple Bar long before I do.
tr: "Jerry, if you want to get something to eat, go ahead. But don't go too far. Stay within earshot of the jury's arrival. Don't be late even for a second, because I want you to deliver the verdict to the bank immediately. You are the fastest messenger I've ever seen, and I'm sure you'll be at Temple Bar long before me."
es: —If you want to have something, Jeremiah, you can do so, but don't stray too far from here. It's essential that when the Jury enters, you are by my side, as the Bank is eagerly awaiting the news of the verdict. You are the fastest messenger I know and will be able to reach the Temple Court much sooner than I can.

en: Jerry had just enough forehead to knuckle, and he knuckled it in acknowledgment of this communication and a shilling. Mr. Carton came up at the moment, and touched Mr. Lorry on the arm.
vi: Jerry could only raise his finger to tap his forehead, he tapped his forehead to confirm this message and a shilling along with it. At that moment, attorney Carton appeared and took Mr. Lorry's arm: − How is the lady? −
tr: Jerry scratched his narrow forehead after hearing these words and being handed a shilling. At that moment, Mr. Carton came over and touched Mr. Lorry's arm.
es: Lapa made a very graceful bow, I do not know whether it was due to the trust that Mr. Lorry placed in him, or because of the shilling he had just put in his hands. At that point, Mr. Carton left his seat and touched Lorry on the shoulder.

en: “How is the young lady?”
vi: At that moment, attorney Carton appeared and took Mr. Lorry's arm: − How is the lady? −
tr: "How is the little lady?"
es: —How is the young lady?—he asked.

en: “She is greatly distressed; but her father is comforting her, and she feels the better for being out of court.”
vi: She is extremely miserable; but her father is comforting her, and she recovered once she left the court.
tr: "Very sad; but her father is calming her down, she feels a bit better because she has left the courtroom.""
es: —Terribly distressed, but her father tries to console her, and she seems to be better than before leaving the room.

en: “I’ll tell the prisoner so. It won’t do for a respectable bank gentleman like you, to be seen speaking to him publicly, you know.”
vi: − I will inform the prisoner of this. It wouldn't be appropriate for a respectable person from the bank like you to be seen talking openly with him, you know that.
tr: "I will convey this to the defendant. It would not be appropriate for a respectable banker like you to speak with him in front of everyone."
es: —I am going to tell the prisoner. A gentleman as respectable as you should not speak to him in public.

en: Mr. Lorry reddened as if he were conscious of having debated the point in his mind, and Mr. Carton made his way to the outside of the bar. The way out of court lay in that direction, and Jerry followed him, all eyes, ears, and spikes.
vi: Mr. Lorry blushed as if he were also secretly pondering that matter, so Carton made his way towards the outside of the dock. The exit from the court was in that direction, and Jerry followed, wide-eyed, ears strained, hair standing on end.
tr: Mr. Lorry blushed because he had been weighing this in his mind for a while, and Mr. Carton proceeded towards the section where the defendant was. The exit of the court was in that direction, and Jerry, with his upright, attentive demeanor and stiff hair, followed him.
es: Lorry blushed intensely, undoubtedly because he saw that his thoughts at that moment had been read, and Carton started walking towards the bar. It goes without saying that Jeremiah Lapa followed him with all his eyes, with all his ears, and with all the spikes that adorned his scalp.

en: “Mr. Darnay!”
vi: − Mr. Darnay!
tr: "Mr. Darnay!"
es: —Mr. Darnay—called Carton.

en: The prisoner came forward directly.
vi: The defendant stepped forward immediately.
tr: The defendant immediately stepped forward.
es: The prisoner stood up immediately.

en: “You will naturally be anxious to hear of the witness, Miss Manette. She will do very well. You have seen the worst of her agitation.”
vi: − I am sure you are eager to hear news about the witness, Miss Manette. She will be fine. Earlier, you saw her being very emotional.
tr: "Naturally, you are worried about Miss Manette. She will recover though. You saw her at her worst."
es: —It is natural that you wish to have news of the witness Miss Manette. She is better: the worst of her agitation has passed.

en: “I am deeply sorry to have been the cause of it. Could you tell her so for me, with my fervent acknowledgments?”
vi: − I am very sorry for causing this. If you could convey my apologies to her, I would be very grateful.
tr: "I'm very sorry for causing such a thing. Also, please convey my thanks to him."
es: —With all my soul, I regret having been the cause of it. Would you be so kind as to convey it to her on my behalf?

en: “Yes, I could. I will, if you ask it.”
vi: − Alright. I will convey the message, if you wish.
tr: "Of course. If you want, I can convey it."
es: —I will do it, if you wish.

en: Mr. Carton’s manner was so careless as to be almost insolent. He stood, half turned from the prisoner, lounging with his elbow against the bar.
vi: Carton's attitude was so indifferent that it bordered on insolence. He stood there, lazily leaning his elbow on the rail, not bothering to look directly at the defendant.
tr: Mr. Carton had an almost indifferent attitude that bordered on arrogance. He stood there, turned sideways to the defendant, with his elbow resting on the bars of the defendant's box.
es: Carton's attitude was so indifferent that it bordered on insolent. —I desire it very much, and I give you my most cordial thanks—replied the prisoner.

en: “I do ask it. Accept my cordial thanks.”
vi: − Please help me. I sincerely thank you.
tr: "I am requesting from you. Accept my heartfelt thanks."
es: —I desire it very much, and I give you my most cordial thanks—replied the prisoner.

en: “What,” said Carton, still only half turned towards him, “do you expect, Mr. Darnay?”
vi: − Hey, Mr. Darnay, - Carton said without looking directly at the listener, - what sentence are you expecting?
tr: Carton, still turned sideways to the defendant, asked, "What kind of verdict do you think will come out, Mr. Darnay?"
es: —What are you waiting for, Mr. Darnay?—asked Carton, half turned away from his interlocutor.

en: “The worst.”
vi: − The heaviest sentence.
tr: "The worst.""
es: —The worst.

en: “It’s the wisest thing to expect, and the likeliest. But I think their withdrawing is in your favour.”
vi: − Waiting is the wisest choice, and that is the highest possibility. But I think their retreating for a discussion is beneficial for you.
tr: "This is the wisest and most likely thing to happen." "But the fact that they have gone inside to make a decision is in your favor.""
es: —You are doing well, since you expect what will probably happen. However, the new withdrawal of the Jury allows for some hope.

en: Loitering on the way out of court not being allowed, Jerry heard no more: but left them—so like each other in feature, so unlike each other in manner—standing side by side, both reflected in the glass above them.
vi: The court did not allow any further delay, Jerry walked out of the court hearing nothing more; despite the two people - identical in appearance but completely opposite in demeanor - standing next to each other, their reflections mirrored on the ceiling.
tr: It was hard to linger at the exit of the hall, so Jerry didn't hear any more. Leaving them side by side, alone with their reflections in the mirror above – although they looked very similar, their attitudes were completely different – he left.
es: Jeremías Lapa walked away without hearing more. There, beneath the large mirror that reflected both faces, remained the two men, so similar in features and so dissimilar in manners and attitude.

en: An hour and a half limped heavily away in the thief-and-rascal crowded passages below, even though assisted off with mutton pies and ale. The hoarse messenger, uncomfortably seated on a form after taking that refection, had dropped into a doze, when a loud murmur and a rapid tide of people setting up the stairs that led to the court, carried him along with them.
vi: An hour and a half dragged on slowly in the crowded corridors filled with a motley crowd below, regardless of how much beer and lamb pâté had been consumed. The hoarse-voiced messenger sat restlessly on a bench, and after a while of pondering, he fell asleep until the noise and the throng of people surging up the stairs leading into the court woke him up and swept him along.
tr: Even though he passed the time by eating a meat pastry and drinking beer, an hour and a half had been very difficult in the passages teeming with thieves and ruffians. The hoarse-voiced messenger, who was dozing off on something not very comfortable after his meal, found himself caught in the loud buzz and flood of people climbing the stairs leading to the courtroom.
es: An hour and a half more passed slowly, heavily, eternally. The bank messenger, after having his snack, had sat down and fallen asleep on a bench, when he was enveloped by the human tide that clamored as it once again invaded the Hall.

en: “Jerry! Jerry!” Mr. Lorry was already calling at the door when he got there.
vi: − Jerry! Jerry! - Mr. Lorry was standing at the doorway calling loudly as he just arrived. −
tr: When he arrived at the court, Mr. Lorry was calling to him from the door, "Jerry! Jerry!"
es: —Jeremiah... Jeremiah!—shouted Mr. Lorry, trying to get closer to the door.

en: “Here, sir! It’s a fight to get back again. Here I am, sir!”
vi: Yes, I'm here! It took a while to get through the crowd. I'm here, sir!
tr: "I am here, sir! It was very difficult to come. But I came, sir!"
es: —Here I am, sir... but I have to elbow my way through if I want to get back in!

en: Mr. Lorry handed him a paper through the throng. “Quick! Have you got it?”
vi: Mr. Lorry reached through the crowd to hand him a piece of paper. − Hurry up! Did you get it? −
tr: Mr. Lorry handed a paper to the messenger in the crowd. "Quick! Did you get it?"
es: Lorry extended an arm and handed him a paper. —Flying...! Do you have it already?

en: “Yes, sir.”
vi: Yes, I got it.
tr: "Yes, sir!"
es: —Yes, sir.

en: Hastily written on the paper was the word “Acquitted.”
vi: Hastily written on the paper were the words "PARDONED".
tr: In the hastily written note, there were only two words "ACQUITTED."
es: On the paper, there was a single word written: "acquitted".

en: “If you had sent the message, ‘Recalled to Life,’ again,” muttered Jerry, as he turned, “I should have known what you meant, this time.”
vi: − If you text "Resurrection" like last time, - Jerry muttered as he turned away, - then this time I already understand what you mean.
tr: As Jerry was turning, he muttered to himself, "If you had sent a message saying 'Resurrected' again, I would understand what you were talking about this time."
es: —If this time you had written "Resurrected,"—murmured Lapa as he turned around—I would already know what all this means.

en: He had no opportunity of saying, or so much as thinking, anything else, until he was clear of the Old Bailey; for, the crowd came pouring out with a vehemence that nearly took him off his legs, and a loud buzz swept into the street as if the baffled blue-flies were dispersing in search of other carrion.
vi: Jerry had no chance to say or even think anything else until he was out of the Old Bailey Criminal Court; because he had to run at full speed to avoid being knocked over by the crowd pouring out, and the buzzing noise flooding the street was like a swarm of disappointed bluebottles dispersing to find another rotting corpse.
tr: He had no chance to speak, think, or do anything else until he got away from the Old Bailey Court; the crowd was flowing out with such excitement that Jerry's knees buckled, and the bewildered horseflies scattered around with an intense buzz, as if hoping to find another carcass.
es: It was the only thing he could say, or think, or do, until he found himself outside the Old Bailey, as the crowds poured out like an overflowing torrent, sweeping away and dragging along everything in their path. The murmurs were like the loud buzzing of bluebottle flies that disperse in disappointment upon finding themselves deprived of the rotten scraps they expected to find.

en: CHAPTER IV.
vi: 4. Congratulations Pouring into the dim corridors of the court, the last dregs of the human stew that had been boiling all day were now drying up as Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and defense attorney Stryver stood around Charles Darnay - who had just been released - congratulating him on escaping death.
tr: IV
es: IV.

en: Congratulatory
vi: 4. Congratulations Pouring into the dim corridors of the court, the last dregs of the human stew that had been boiling all day were now drying up as Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and defense attorney Stryver stood around Charles Darnay - who had just been released - congratulating him on escaping death.
tr: Congratulations
es: CONGRATULATIONS

en: From the dimly-lighted passages of the court, the last sediment of the human stew that had been boiling there all day, was straining off, when Doctor Manette, Lucie Manette, his daughter, Mr. Lorry, the solicitor for the defence, and its counsel, Mr. Stryver, stood gathered round Mr. Charles Darnay—just released—congratulating him on his escape from death.
vi: 4. Congratulations Pouring into the dim corridors of the court, the last dregs of the human stew that had been boiling all day were now drying up as Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and defense attorney Stryver stood around Charles Darnay - who had just been released - congratulating him on escaping death.
tr: As the last people from the crowd that had been bustling all day streamed out of the courtroom, which was dimly lit, Dr. Manette, his daughter Lucie Manette, Mr. Lorry, and the defense attorney and solicitor Mr. Stryver gathered around Mr. Charles Darnay – the person who had just been acquitted – congratulating him for escaping death.
es: The last remnants of the human stew that had simmered all day in the courtroom were trickling through the dirty and gloomy corridors of the courthouse building, when Doctor Manette, Lucia, his daughter, Mr. Lorry, the defense lawyer, and the defense attorney formed a group around Charles Darnay, who had been released moments before, congratulating and celebrating him for having almost miraculously escaped death.

en: It would have been difficult by a far brighter light, to recognise in Doctor Manette, intellectual of face and upright of bearing, the shoemaker of the garret in Paris. Yet, no one could have looked at him twice, without looking again: even though the opportunity of observation had not extended to the mournful cadence of his low grave voice, and to the abstraction that overclouded him fitfully, without any apparent reason. While one external cause, and that a reference to his long lingering agony, would always—as on the trial—evoke this condition from the depths of his soul, it was also in its nature to arise of itself, and to draw a gloom over him, as incomprehensible to those unacquainted with his story as if they had seen the shadow of the actual Bastille thrown upon him by a summer sun, when the substance was three hundred miles away.
vi: Under a stronger light source, it might be difficult to recognize Dr. Manette with his intelligent face and upright posture as the shoemaker in the attic in Paris. However, anyone who has once looked closely at him cannot help but look again; even if they do not have the opportunity to hear the melancholy tone in his gentle, solemn voice, or see the occasional absent-minded expression that inexplicably appears on his face. Just like during the trial, any external trigger that reminds him of the years of prolonged suffering would cause that gloomy emotion to resurface from the depths of his soul, but that vacant expression often reveals itself, astonishing those who do not know Dr. Manette's past; as if they are seeing the real Bastille casting its dark shadow on his face under the summer sun, while in reality, that place of imprisonment is three hundred miles away from here.
tr: It was difficult to connect the sharp-faced and upright Doctor Manette with the shoemaker in the attic in Paris, even in a brighter light. But no one could look at his face a second time; the opportunity to observe him did not extend to hearing the mournful harmony of his low and gloomy voice or noticing the occasional absent-mindedness that settled over him like a cloud for no reason. There was always a completely different reason deep within his soul that evoked this feeling – as it was during the trial – something related to his long-standing sorrowful state, but sometimes this feeling arose on its own, and then a sadness that those who did not know his story could never understand enveloped him, as if the shadow of the Bastille, three hundred kilometers away, fell upon him even in that summer sun.
es: The light was scarce, but even in the brightness of a summer sun, it would have been very difficult to recognize in the serene and intelligent face and upright body of the doctor the cobbler from the garret in Paris. Nevertheless, it was impossible to see him once without feeling an irresistible itch to examine him again, even if the observer had not had the chance to hear the gloomy rhythm of his deep voice, nor noticed the kind of cloud that overshadowed his countenance for no apparent reason. And it was because he did not need external causes to evoke in his soul, as had happened in the Courtroom during the hearing, painful echoes of his past agonies; these arose spontaneously, and when they did, they enveloped him in something like a funeral veil that could not be seen by those who were unaware of his sad story.

en: Only his daughter had the power of charming this black brooding from his mind. She was the golden thread that united him to a Past beyond his misery, and to a Present beyond his misery: and the sound of her voice, the light of her face, the touch of her hand, had a strong beneficial influence with him almost always. Not absolutely always, for she could recall some occasions on which her power had failed; but they were few and slight, and she believed them over.
vi: Only the daughter has the power to dispel the dark clouds from her father's mind. She is the golden thread that connects him to the past before the calamity, and to the present after escaping captivity; her voice, her radiant face, her comforting hand, always have the supreme power to help him live joyfully. But it is not always so, for she also remembers times when her power failed; however, those instances were rare and not very serious, so she believes they will not happen again.
tr: The only person who could disperse these dark clouds in his mind was his daughter. She was the golden thread that connected him to a Past beyond his suffering and a Present beyond this suffering; the tone of her voice, the light of her face, the touch of her hand always had a wonderful effect on her father. Actually, not always, because there were moments when even his daughter's power was not enough; but these were not too many, moreover, his daughter now believed that these had come to an end.
es: Only his daughter managed to drive away the dark memories that persistently haunted his mind. Lucía was the golden thread that connected him to a past before his miseries and to a present after his sorrows. The sweet music of her voice, the joy reflected in her pretty face, the touch of her hand, almost always had a decisive beneficial influence on him, and I say almost always, because there had been occasions, although not many, when the girl's power had crashed against his sadness. Lucía harbored the sweet hope that those cases would not be repeated.

en: Mr. Darnay had kissed her hand fervently and gratefully, and had turned to Mr. Stryver, whom he warmly thanked. Mr. Stryver, a man of little more than thirty, but looking twenty years older than he was, stout, loud, red, bluff, and free from any drawback of delicacy, had a pushing way of shouldering himself (morally and physically) into companies and conversations, that argued well for his shouldering his way up in life.
vi: Darnay warmly and appreciatively kissed the girl's hand, then turned to barrister Stryver and thanked him profusely. Stryver, though just over thirty, looked as old as fifty, stout, loud, rosy, straightforward, and utterly lacking in tact; he often intruded (both mentally and physically) into groups of people and conversations - this clearly demonstrated his pushy nature in striving to get ahead in life.
tr: After Mr. Darnay kissed Miss Manette's hand with great enthusiasm and gratitude, he turned to Mr. Stryver and thanked him sincerely. Although he was a little over thirty years old, Mr. Stryver, who looked twenty years younger, was a burly, loud-voiced, red-faced, straightforward, and not very courteous man, and the way he forcefully (both mentally and physically) threw himself into various communities and conversations was a sign of how he shouldered life.
es: Darnay had savored the pleasure of kissing the young woman's hand, and after expressing his gratitude with fervent phrases, he turned to his defender, Mr. Stryver, to whom he warmly gave thanks. Stryver, a man who was barely thirty years old, although he looked fifty, robust, stout, red-faced, boastful, and impervious to all kinds of delicate impulses, possessed the secret of adapting himself, morally and physically, to all kinds of companies and conversations, and it was to be supposed that just as he adapted to companies and conversations, he knew how to adapt to the thousand and one trivialities related to life.

en: He still had his wig and gown on, and he said, squaring himself at his late client to that degree that he squeezed the innocent Mr. Lorry clean out of the group: “I am glad to have brought you off with honour, Mr. Darnay. It was an infamous prosecution, grossly infamous; but not the less likely to succeed on that account.”
vi: Still wearing his wig and barrister's gown, Stryver spoke while stepping in front of his new client, pushing Mr. Lorry out of the group: I am very pleased to have the honor of successfully defending you, Mr. Darnay. This was a vile case; extremely vile; but you can't just convict someone at will.
tr: He still had his wig and gown on, and he approached his client in such a way that he ended up pushing poor Mr. Lorry aside. "I am very happy to have saved your honor, Mr. Darnay. It was a tough case, really tough; but your chances of acquittal were not nonexistent."
es: He was still wearing the robe and the wig. When he went to respond to his client, he spun on his heels in a way that excluded the innocent Mr. Lorry from the group, and said: —I infinitely celebrate having gotten you out of the ordeal with honor, Mr. Darnay. You have been the victim of an infamous persecution, brutally infamous, but one that could very well have had the outcome your enemies sought.

en: “You have laid me under an obligation to you for life—in two senses,” said his late client, taking his hand.
vi: − I owe you my life, - the client said while shaking the lawyer's hand.
tr: Holding Mr. Stryver's hand, "I owe you my life – for two reasons," he said.
es: "The obligations I have contracted with you will never expire," replied the young man, warmly shaking the lawyer's hand.

en: “I have done my best for you, Mr. Darnay; and my best is as good as another man’s, I believe.”
vi: − I did my best, Mr. Darnay; and I think anyone would have done their best just like I did.
tr: "I did my best for you, Mr. Darnay, but surely someone else would have tried to do the same.""
es: —I have done for you as much as I could, Mr. Darnay, and I have the presumption to believe that I can do as much as any other man could.

en: It clearly being incumbent on some one to say, “Much better,” Mr. Lorry said it; perhaps not quite disinterestedly, but with the interested object of squeezing himself back again.
vi: Saying that forces someone to praise "No one can compare," it was Mr. Lorry who said that, not entirely impartially but with the intention of rejoining the group.
tr: At this point, it was clear that someone needed to say, "But you did it much better!" and it was Mr. Lorry who said it; it couldn't be said that he was uninterested, but his main goal was to approach the group.
es: The last words required a mandatory response, which any of those in the group could and should give. Mr. Lorry gave it, probably out of interest, that is, to be readmitted into the group. —More, much more than any other man—he said.

en: “You think so?” said Mr. Stryver. “Well! you have been present all day, and you ought to know. You are a man of business, too.”
vi: − Do you think so? - Stryver said. - Well! You've been here all day, you must know well. You are a man of work too. −
