tr: "Is that what you think?" said Mr. Stryver. "Well, you were here all day, you must have understood. After all, you are a businessman too."
es: —Do you really think so?—asked Stryver.—Absolutely. You have witnessed the entire trial, and you have reasons to know what you are saying. Besides, you are a businessman.

en: “And as such,” quoth Mr. Lorry, whom the counsel learned in the law had now shouldered back into the group, just as he had previously shouldered him out of it—“as such I will appeal to Doctor Manette, to break up this conference and order us all to our homes. Miss Lucie looks ill, Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day, we are worn out.”
vi: That's right, - Mr. Lorry, now nudged into the group by the lawyer just as he had been nudged out earlier, - and because of that, I request Dr. Manette to conclude this consultation and for all of us to leave. Miss Lucie doesn't look well, Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day, and we are all exhausted. −
tr: "I say," said Mr. Lorry, whom the lawyer first excluded and then included in the group, "I say, it would be best if Dr. Manette ended this conversation and we all went home. Miss Lucie doesn't look well, Mr. Darnay has had a very difficult day, and we are all tired."
es: —And in that capacity—replied Lorry, whom the lawyer had brought into the group in the same manner as he had previously excluded him—in my capacity as such, I request Dr. Manette to bring this conference to an end, so that we may each retire to our respective homes. Miss Lucie is not feeling well, Mr. Darnay has had a terrible day, and we are all exhausted.

en: “Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry,” said Stryver; “I have a night’s work to do yet. Speak for yourself.”
vi: Please don't speak for others, Mr. Lorry, - Stryver said, - I still have work to do tonight. Please don't speak for others.
tr: "Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry," said Stryver; "I have a lot more work to do. Speak for yourself."
es: —Speak for yourself, Mr. Lorry, speak for yourself—said the lawyer. —I have a night of continuous work ahead of me.

en: “I speak for myself,” answered Mr. Lorry, “and for Mr. Darnay, and for Miss Lucie, and—Miss Lucie, do you not think I may speak for us all?” He asked her the question pointedly, and with a glance at her father.
vi: − I speak for myself, - Mr. Lorry replied, - and for young Darnay, and for Miss Lucie, and... Miss Lucie, do you think I can speak on behalf of all of us? - He asked the girl directly, his eyes glancing at her father again.
tr: "Speaking for myself," said Mr. Lorry, "and even for Mr. Darnay and Miss Lucie, well, I can speak for all of us, can't I, Miss Lucie?" He fixed his eyes on the young girl, while also glancing at her father.
es: —I speak for myself—replied Lorry—and for Mr. Darnay, and for Miss Lucie and... Don't you think, Miss Lucie, that I can speak for all of us?—he asked, addressing the young woman, but looking at the same time at her father.

en: His face had become frozen, as it were, in a very curious look at Darnay: an intent look, deepening into a frown of dislike and distrust, not even unmixed with fear. With this strange expression on him his thoughts had wandered away.
vi: The face of Dr. Manette at that moment had frozen into a very strange look directed at Darnay - a focused look, under furrowed brows that revealed even more clearly a sense of aversion and suspicion, with something fearful about it. With that peculiar expression, his mind had wandered elsewhere.
tr: Adam, however, was frozen, looking at Darnay with curious eyes; it was a determined look, with eyebrows furrowed in hatred and distrust, but devoid of fear. Judging by the expression on his face, a lot of things were going through his mind.
es: The old man's face took on an indefinable expression as he directed an intense look at Darnay. Deep wrinkles appeared on the former's forehead, his lips tightened, and little by little his gaze expressed repugnance, suspicion, and fear.

en: “My father,” said Lucie, softly laying her hand on his.
vi: − Father, - Lucie said softly as she gently took her father's hand.
tr: Lucie gently placed her hand on her father's hand and said, "Father."
es: —My father!—she whispered in his ear, while squeezing his hand.

en: He slowly shook the shadow off, and turned to her.
vi: The gloomy expression gradually faded, the father turned to look at his daughter. −
tr: Adam slowly turned to his daughter, dispelling the shadows in his mind.
es: The old man, whose face gradually lit up, turned towards his daughter.

en: “Shall we go home, my father?”
vi: Shall we go home, father?
tr: "Shall we go home, daddy?""
es: —Shall we go home, my father?—replied the girl.

en: With a long breath, he answered “Yes.”
vi: After a sigh came a "Yes".
tr: Taking a deep breath, "Yes," said the man.
es: The doctor let out a very deep and very prolonged sigh, and replied: —Yes.

en: The friends of the acquitted prisoner had dispersed, under the impression—which he himself had originated—that he would not be released that night. The lights were nearly all extinguished in the passages, the iron gates were being closed with a jar and a rattle, and the dismal place was deserted until to-morrow morning’s interest of gallows, pillory, whipping-post, and branding-iron, should repeople it. Walking between her father and Mr. Darnay, Lucie Manette passed into the open air. A hackney-coach was called, and the father and daughter departed in it.
vi: The friends of the acquitted convict had long dispersed, with the thought - originating from the convict himself - that he would not be exonerated tonight. The lights in the corridors had almost all been extinguished, the iron gates were clanging shut, and this dreadful theater would remain deserted until the next morning when the allure of the gallows, the pillory, the whipping post, and the branding iron would draw the audience again. Walking between her father and Darnay, Lucie Manette stepped out onto the street. A two-horse carriage was called, and the father and daughter boarded it and drove away.
tr: The friends of the acquitted defendant had dispersed early that night because they thought he would not be released – this impression had been created by the defendant himself. Almost all the lamps in the corridors were out, the iron doors were closing with a thousand creaks and clatters, and this gloomy place would remain empty until the next morning, until people filled it with gallows, collars, whipping areas, and branding irons. Lucie Manette walked outside between her father and Mr. Darnay. A carriage had been called, and the father and daughter got into it.
es: The prisoner's friends, whom he had made believe that he would not be released that night, had already dispersed. Almost all the lights that illuminated the narrow corridors of the sinister building, which the next morning would be filled again with people eager for emotions, had been turned off. The defense attorney was the first to leave to go change clothes, and Lucie Manette called a carriage, said goodbye to Mr. Lorry and Darnay, and had herself driven home, accompanying her father.

en: Mr. Stryver had left them in the passages, to shoulder his way back to the robing-room. Another person, who had not joined the group, or interchanged a word with any one of them, but who had been leaning against the wall where its shadow was darkest, had silently strolled out after the rest, and had looked on until the coach drove away. He now stepped up to where Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay stood upon the pavement.
vi: Stryver just left everyone in the hallway to barge back into the dressing room. Another person, who had not joined the group or said a word to anyone and had been leaning against the wall in the darkest corner, now strolled out and stood watching until the carriage disappeared from view. Now he stepped onto the sidewalk where Mr. Lorry and Darnay were standing.
tr: Mr. Stryver had left their side as he was going to the cup room. Another person, who had not joined the group and had not spoken a single word with them but leaned against the darkest corner of the wall, quietly straightened up after resting there for a while and watched until the carriage set off. Then he went over to Mr. Lorry and Mr. Darnay, who were standing on the sidewalk.
es: The defense attorney was the first to leave to go change clothes, and Lucie Manette called a carriage, said goodbye to Mr. Lorry and Darnay, and had herself driven home, accompanying her father. Another person, who had not been part of the group nor exchanged a word with any of its members, detached themselves from the wall against which they had been leaning and, as soon as the carriage was out of sight, silently approached Lorry and Darnay like a shadow, who had remained talking on the sidewalk.

en: “So, Mr. Lorry! Men of business may speak to Mr. Darnay now?”
vi: "Ah, Mr. Lorry! The man of business is now allowed to speak openly with Mr. Darnay, isn't he?"
tr: "Ah Mr. Lorry! So, as a businessman, you can now speak with Mr. Darnay.""
es: —Hello, Mr. Lorry!—he said. —It seems that business men now dare to speak with Darnay, eh?

en: Nobody had made any acknowledgment of Mr. Carton’s part in the day’s proceedings; nobody had known of it. He was unrobed, and was none the better for it in appearance.
vi: No one mentioned Carton's role in today's trial; no one paid any attention to him. Carton had taken off his barrister's robe and looked as disheveled as before.
tr: No one had thanked Mr. Carton for what he did in court that day; there was no one who appreciated its value. He had taken off his robe, but he did not look any better than he did with it on.
es: —It seems that business men now dare to speak with Darnay, eh? What conflicts business causes!

en: “If you knew what a conflict goes on in the business mind, when the business mind is divided between good-natured impulse and business appearances, you would be amused, Mr. Darnay.”
vi: − "Mr. Darnay, if you knew what was wrestling in the mind of a man who only knows work, when that work-focused mind is torn between the urge of kindness and the outward professional demeanor, you would find it very interesting."
tr: "If you knew what contradictions exist in the mind of a businessman torn between goodwill and a sense of duty, you would be very amused, Mr. Darnay."
es: You would laugh, Darnay, if you knew the struggles that business men have to endure between their natural impulses and the demands of their position.

en: Mr. Lorry reddened, and said, warmly, “You have mentioned that before, sir. We men of business, who serve a House, are not our own masters. We have to think of the House more than ourselves.”
vi: Mr. Lorry blushed and said passionately, "You mentioned that earlier, sir." People like us, who work for a company, cannot think only of ourselves. We must think of the company more than ourselves.
tr: Mr. Lorry blushed and said in an excited voice, "You have said this before, sir." We, who work within a company, do not do anything for ourselves. We think of the company more than ourselves.
es: —You made that same remark before, Mr. Carton—replied Lorry, blushing to the whites of his eyes. —We, the businessmen, those who serve a house, are not masters of ourselves. More than in ourselves, we have to think about the house.

en: “I know, I know,” rejoined Mr. Carton, carelessly. “Don’t be nettled, Mr. Lorry. You are as good as another, I have no doubt: better, I dare say.”
vi: − I know, I know, - Carton replied nonchalantly. - Don't be upset, Mr. Lorry, you are as wonderful as everyone else, I am sure of it; I would even dare to say that no one compares to you. −
tr: "I know, I know," said Mr. Carton indifferently. "Don't get upset, Mr. Lorry. I'm sure you are as good as the others; even better.""
es: —I know, I know, Mr. Lorry!—replied Carton carelessly. —I would be sorry if you were upset. I know that you are not worse than the others, and I would even dare to say that you are much better.

en: “And indeed, sir,” pursued Mr. Lorry, not minding him, “I really don’t know what you have to do with the matter. If you’ll excuse me, as very much your elder, for saying so, I really don’t know that it is your business.”
vi: That's right, sir, - Mr. Lorry continued, not bothered by Carton's sarcasm. - Honestly, I don't know what your involvement in this matter is. Please forgive me, as someone much older than you, for saying this, but I truly don't know what role you play in this matter.
tr: Without paying much attention to what Carton said, Mr. Lorry continued, "As a matter of fact, I don't know why you are prolonging this issue." "Sorry, I'm saying this because I'm older than you, but I don't understand why you are meddling so much in this matter.""
es: —To tell the truth, sir, I fail to understand your interference. Forgive me if, taking advantage of my age, I speak to you with perhaps excessive frankness, but I don't see that you have anything to do with our affairs.

en: “Business! Bless you, I have no business,” said Mr. Carton.
vi: − Role! Good Lord, I have no role at all, - Carton said.
tr: "Work? Honestly, I don't understand any job," said Mr. Carton.
es: —Matters! Good heavens, sir! I have no matters.

en: “It is a pity you have not, sir.”
vi: − It's a pity for you, sir.
tr: "It's a pity, sir."
es: —It's a shame that you don't have them.

en: “I think so, too.”
vi: − I think so too. −
tr: "I think so too."
es: —Agreed.

en: “If you had,” pursued Mr. Lorry, “perhaps you would attend to it.”
vi: If you had some work, - Mr. Lorry continued, - perhaps you would devote yourself to it. −
tr: "If you had understood," said Mr. Lorry, "you would be busy with him."
es: —Because if I had them, I would pay them some attention.

en: “Lord love you, no!—I shouldn’t,” said Mr. Carton.
vi: God bless you, oh no... I wouldn't be like that! - Carton said. − Look here, you!
tr: "Oh no, not at all! –Still, I wouldn't have," said Mr. Carton.
es: —No, my friend, no! Rest assured that I would not lend them any!

en: “Well, sir!” cried Mr. Lorry, thoroughly heated by his indifference, “business is a very good thing, and a very respectable thing. And, sir, if business imposes its restraints and its silences and impediments, Mr. Darnay as a young gentleman of generosity knows how to make allowance for that circumstance. Mr. Darnay, good night, God bless you, sir! I hope you have been this day preserved for a prosperous and happy life.—Chair there!”
vi: - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, Carton's indifference made him angry. - Working is a very good and respectable thing. And let me tell you, if work requires us to restrain ourselves, to be silent, to accept, then this kind Mr. Darnay here understands those constraints well. Goodbye Mr. Darnay, God bless you! I hope from today you will have a successful and happy life ahead of you. The carriage has arrived!
tr: Mr. Lorry, who was quite angered by the man's indifference, said, "Look here, sir, doing business is a good thing, a respectable thing. If business brings some restrictions, silences, and obstacles, the noble-hearted young Mr. Darnay knows how to deal with it. Good night, Mr. Darnay, may God protect you! I hope your life will henceforth be filled with prosperity and happiness. There is a cab over there!"
es: —All right, sir!—exclaimed Lorry, filled with indignation at the indifference of his interlocutor. —Say what you will, it is very good and very respectable to have business, and if on certain occasions business imposes silence, restrictions, and impediments, those who, like Mr. Darnay, are generous gentlemen understand it... Mr. Darnay... good night. I congratulate you with all the effusion of my soul and wish you a prosperous and happy life... Coachman!

en: Perhaps a little angry with himself, as well as with the barrister, Mr. Lorry bustled into the chair, and was carried off to Tellson’s. Carton, who smelt of port wine, and did not appear to be quite sober, laughed then, and turned to Darnay:
vi: Perhaps a bit angry with himself as well as with the lawyer, Mr. Lorry hastily got into the one-horse carriage heading back to Tellson's Bank. Still smelling of port wine and seemingly not fully sober, Carton then laughed and turned to Darnay: −
tr: Mr. Lorry, who was a bit angry not only at the lawyer but also at himself, hurriedly got into the cab and went to Tellson's. Carton, who smelled of port wine and did not look very sober, laughed and turned to Darnay:
es: A little uncomfortable with himself, and certainly more with his interlocutor, Mr. Lorry stormed into the carriage and had himself driven to Tellson's Bank. Carton, who smelled of wine and whose strong suit, judging by appearances, was not sobriety, burst into laughter and turned to Darnay.

en: “This is a strange chance that throws you and me together. This must be a strange night to you, standing alone here with your counterpart on these street stones?”
vi: It is indeed strange that you and I happened to meet. Don't you find it odd to stand here tonight alone with someone who looks exactly like you on these cobblestones?
tr: "This is a strange coincidence that brought you and me together. It must be interesting for you to stand here tonight, on these cobblestones, with your colleague."
es: —Strange whims chance has, Mr. Darnay!—exclaimed Carton. —Could you have supposed that tonight you would be here, treading the street stones, in the company of your alter ego?

en: “I hardly seem yet,” returned Charles Darnay, “to belong to this world again.”
vi: − I seem to feel like I don't belong to this world anymore, Charles Darnay replied.
tr: "I don't quite feel like I belong to this world again," replied Charles Darnay.
es: —How could I have supposed it, if even the fact of belonging to this world seems like a dream to me?—replied Darnay.

en: “I don’t wonder at it; it’s not so long since you were pretty far advanced on your way to another. You speak faintly.”
vi: − I'm not surprised; just a moment ago you almost stepped into the other world. − You speak as if you're out of breath and about to faint. −
tr: "I'm not surprised at all; there's a world of difference between how you were this morning and how you are now. You don't have the energy to talk though."
es: —It does not surprise me, after how close it was to the other one. I notice a certain weakness in your voice, Mr. Darnay.

en: “I begin to think I am faint.”
vi: − I think I'm about to faint.
tr: "I actually don't have the energy for anything."
es: —It's just that I'm beginning to believe that I feel weak, Mr. Carton.

en: “Then why the devil don’t you dine? I dined, myself, while those numskulls were deliberating which world you should belong to—this, or some other. Let me show you the nearest tavern to dine well at.”
vi: − So why don't you eat something, for heaven's sake? I already ate, I ate while those idiots were debating which world you belong to... this side or the other side. Let me show you the nearest pub with good food.
tr: "Why haven't you eaten anything yet? While those blockheads were deliberating on which side –this world or the next– they would keep you, I had eaten something. Come, let me show you a good place nearby where you can eat."
es: —Why don't you eat, then? I already ate, while those drones were agreeing on the world in which you would live. I'm going to accompany you to the nearest tavern where you can eat whatever you like.

en: Drawing his arm through his own, he took him down Ludgate-hill to Fleet-street, and so, up a covered way, into a tavern. Here, they were shown into a little room, where Charles Darnay was soon recruiting his strength with a good plain dinner and good wine: while Carton sat opposite to him at the same table, with his separate bottle of port before him, and his fully half-insolent manner upon him.
vi: Linking arms with Darnay, the barrister led him down Ludgate Hill to Fleet Street and from there, through a covered passageway, into a tavern. Upon arrival, they were shown into a small room where Charles Darnay immediately regained his strength with a simple yet delicious dinner accompanied by robust wine; meanwhile, Carton sat across the table with his own bottle of port, his usual nonchalant demeanor once again evident.
tr: Carton pulled Darnay by the arm and they proceeded together from Ludgate Hill towards Fleet Street, then passed through a covered area and arrived at an inn. Here, they were taken to a small room where Charles Darnay could have a nice meal and a good wine to quickly regain his strength; meanwhile, Carton sat at the same table, directly across from Darnay with a separate bottle of port wine in front of him, watching him with a slightly insolent manner.
es: Passing without further ceremonies his arm through Darnay's, Carton started walking towards Fleet Street, soon ending up in a tavern. The attendant accompanied the newcomers to a reserved little room, where Darnay regained his strength. Carton, seated at the same table across from Darnay, had a bottle of wine served to him.

en: “Do you feel, yet, that you belong to this terrestrial scheme again, Mr. Darnay?”
vi: − Now do you feel like you belong to this earthly realm again, Mr. Darnay? −
tr: "Will you be able to feel like you belong to this mortal order again, Mr. Darnay?"
es: —Are you convincing yourself that you still belong to this earthly world, Darnay?—asked Carton.

en: “I am frightfully confused regarding time and place; but I am so far mended as to feel that.”
vi: Still disoriented by time and place; but I have recovered enough to perceive them.
tr: "My concept of time and space has been terribly disrupted; but at least I pulled myself together enough to understand this.""
es: —I can barely grasp the time and place, but I confess that I have almost been convinced of what you say.

en: “It must be an immense satisfaction!”
vi: − That feeling must be wonderful!
tr: "This must be an immense happiness.""
es: —And he must have convinced himself of it with immense satisfaction!—exclaimed Carton with a certain tone of bitterness, filling the glass again, which was certainly one of the largest.—

en: He said it bitterly, and filled up his glass again: which was a large one.
vi: - Carton said bitterly, then poured himself another full glass of wine; a large glass. -
tr: His voice had hardened as he said this, and he refilled his glass; the glass was large.
es: —And he must have convinced himself of it with immense satisfaction!—exclaimed Carton with a certain tone of bitterness, filling the glass again, which was certainly one of the largest.—

en: “As to me, the greatest desire I have, is to forget that I belong to it. It has no good in it for me—except wine like this—nor I for it. So we are not much alike in that particular. Indeed, I begin to think we are not much alike in any particular, you and I.”
vi: As for me, my greatest desire is to forget that I belong to this world. It does me no good... except for fine wine like this... and I am of no use to it. In this respect, you and I are nothing alike. Indeed, I began to think that you and I have nothing in common at all.
tr: "My greatest desire is to forget that I belong to this order. Neither does it do me any good –except for good wines like this– nor do I do it any good. In this respect, we do not resemble each other much. In fact, I have started to think that we do not resemble each other in any respect."
es: As for me, I can say that my greatest desire would be to forget that I am a part of him. Neither does the world have anything good for me... except for wine, nor do I have anything good for the world. In this particular matter, we are quite alike, we resemble each other quite a bit... Of course, I am starting to believe that you and I also resemble each other in everything, don't we?

en: Confused by the emotion of the day, and feeling his being there with this Double of coarse deportment, to be like a dream, Charles Darnay was at a loss how to answer; finally, answered not at all.
vi: Confused by the myriad emotions of the day and feeling as though he were dreaming when faced with the rude-mannered lookalike, Charles Darnay did not know how to respond; in the end, he said nothing.
tr: Charles Darnay, who was confused by the excitement of the day and saw his presence there with this rough-mannered twin as no different from a dream, did not know what to answer; in the end, he said nothing.
es: Carlos Darnay, still under the influence of the day's emotions, took quite a while to respond, simply because he didn't know what answer to give to his interlocutor's extravagant words. When he did, he showed perfect agreement.

en: “Now your dinner is done,” Carton presently said, “why don’t you call a health, Mr. Darnay; why don’t you give your toast?”
vi: After a moment, Carton continued: − Now that you’ve finished dinner, why not drink to your health, Mr. Darnay? Why not raise your glass and toast?
tr: Carton then said, "Well, now that your meal is finished, why don't you toast to his health, Mr. Darnay; come on, raise a glass to his honor.""
es: —Now that you have honored the meal, Mr. Darnay, why don't you raise a glass?

en: “What health? What toast?”
vi: Health for what? Toast for what? −
tr: "To whose health?" "To whose honor?"
es: Why don't you make a toast? —Raise the glass? In honor of whom?

en: “Why, it’s on the tip of your tongue. It ought to be, it must be, I’ll swear it’s there.”
vi: Oh, you know but just don't want to say. It must be so, it definitely must be so, I swear to you.
tr: "Come on, the name is on the tip of your tongue. It must be, I'm sure it's there."
es: —In honor and for the health of the person whose name you have on the tip of your tongue. You must have it, you do have it, I would swear that I am not mistaken.

en: “Miss Manette, then!”
vi: − To Miss Manette then!
tr: "Miss Manette is in that condition!"
es: —I toast, then, to Miss Manette!

en: “Miss Manette, then!”
vi: − To Miss Manette then!
tr: "Miss Manette, is that you?"
es: —To the health of Miss Manette!

en: Looking his companion full in the face while he drank the toast, Carton flung his glass over his shoulder against the wall, where it shivered to pieces; then, rang the bell, and ordered in another.
vi: Looking directly at Darnay who was drinking the toast, Carton threw his own glass over his shoulder, the glass shattered against the wall, and then he rang the bell to call for another glass.
tr: As Darnay drank his wine, Carton, who was watching him intently, threw his glass over his shoulder against the wall, and the glass shattered into pieces; then he rang the bell to ask for more wine.
es: Fixing an insolent gaze on Darnay while downing the contents of his glass, Carton smashed his against the wall after drinking, where it shattered into pieces. He then rang the bell and asked for another.

en: “That’s a fair young lady to hand to a coach in the dark, Mr. Darnay!” he said, filling his new goblet.
vi: − Indeed, a beautiful lady for me to escort her into the carriage at night, Mr. Darnay! - Carton said while filling a new glass.
tr: While filling the cup, "Miss Darnay is such a pleasant young lady that you would want to help her into her car in the dark!"
es: —She is a charming girl, in whose company it would be delightful to take a carriage ride, wouldn't it?—he asked, filling the glass that had just been brought to him with wine.

en: A slight frown and a laconic “Yes,” were the answer.
vi: A brief frown and a curt "Yes!" −
tr: Darnay, slightly furrowing his brows, responded briefly and concisely; "Yes."
es: —Yes—answered Darnay curtly, with a slight frown.

en: “That’s a fair young lady to be pitied by and wept for by! How does it feel? Is it worth being tried for one’s life, to be the object of such sympathy and compassion, Mr. Darnay?”
vi: Indeed, a beautiful lady to have her shed tears of pity for me! How does it feel? Is it worth risking your life in court to become the object of such compassion and sympathy, Mr. Darnay?
tr: "For such a lovely lady to pity a person and shed tears for him! What kind of feeling is this, I wonder? Was it worth being judged to receive such compassion and interest, Mr. Darnay?"
es: —Worthy of compassion and of having true madness done for her. How is she feeling? Indeed, it is worth the risk of being condemned to death in exchange for becoming the object of her sympathies and compassion: what do you say, Darnay?

en: Again Darnay answered not a word.
vi: Darnay still did not respond. −
tr: Darnay did not respond to the gesture.
es: The questioned person remained silent.

en: “She was mightily pleased to have your message, when I gave it her. Not that she showed she was pleased, but I suppose she was.”
vi: The lady was very pleased when she received your message through me. She did not show it, but I think so.
tr: "When I delivered your message, he was incredibly happy. He didn't show it too much, but I understood."
es: —She was extremely pleased to hear the message that you sent her through me. She didn't tell me, but I suppose so.

en: The allusion served as a timely reminder to Darnay that this disagreeable companion had, of his own free will, assisted him in the strait of the day. He turned the dialogue to that point, and thanked him for it.
vi: That insinuation was a timely reminder for Darnay to recall that this unpleasant friend had proactively helped him in today's predicament. He steered the conversation in that direction and thanked Carton for conveying the message.
tr: This reminded Mr. Darnay of how much this grumpy man had voluntarily helped him overcome the difficulties he faced that day. At this point, he changed the subject and thanked him.
es: The allusion was a way of reminding Darnay. He remembered that his unpleasant companion had rendered him a service on that fateful day and thanked him, steering the conversation towards that incident.

en: “I neither want any thanks, nor merit any,” was the careless rejoinder. “It was nothing to do, in the first place; and I don’t know why I did it, in the second. Mr. Darnay, let me ask you a question.”
vi: − I don't need any thanks and don't expect any repayment, - the indifferent reply. - Firstly, this didn't take any effort, and secondly, I don't even understand why I helped. Mr. Darnay, let me ask you a question.
tr: "Do not feel grateful to me nor show respect," he replied indifferently again. "First of all, it's nothing; besides, I don't know why I did it. Mr. Darnay, may I ask you something?"
es: —I neither need your thanks nor deserve them—replied Carton with cold indifference. — Firstly, I didn't know what to do, and secondly, I don't know why I did what I did. Will you allow me to ask you a question, Mr. Darnay?

en: “Willingly, and a small return for your good offices.”
vi: − Gladly, as a small return for your help. −
tr: "Of course, this way I can at least somewhat repay the kindnesses you have done.""
es: —As many as you like, the favors you have done for me give you that right.

en: “Do you think I particularly like you?”
vi: Do you think I have any affection for you?
tr: "Do you think that I love you?"
es: —Do you think I like him?

en: “Really, Mr. Carton,” returned the other, oddly disconcerted, “I have not asked myself the question.”
vi: − Oh, Mr. Carton, - the other replied, strangely confused, - I really haven't asked myself that.
tr: "Really, Mr. Carton," said the other with a strange weariness, "I have never thought of this before."
es: —The truth is... Mr. Carton...—replied Darnay, completely bewildered,—it never occurred to me to ask myself that question.

en: “But ask yourself the question now.”
vi: − Then ask yourself now. −
tr: "Now think about it then."
es: —Do it yourself now.

en: “You have acted as if you do; but I don’t think you do.”
vi: You have acted as if you have some affection; but I don't think so.
tr: "You acted as if you loved, but I don't think you do."
es: —As if I deserved any sympathy from you, you behaved, but if I have to say what I feel, I think I don't deserve it.

en: “I don’t think I do,” said Carton. “I begin to have a very good opinion of your understanding.”
vi: − Neither do I, - Carton said. - I'm starting to appreciate your intellect.
tr: "I think so too," said Carton. "But I admired your understanding."
es: —And I believe the same as you—observed Carton. —I am beginning to form an excellent opinion of your intelligence.

en: “Nevertheless,” pursued Darnay, rising to ring the bell, “there is nothing in that, I hope, to prevent my calling the reckoning, and our parting without ill-blood on either side.”
vi: − However, - Darnay continued, ringing the bell for the waiter, - I hope there's no reason preventing me from calling for the bill and us parting without any animosity. −
tr: "Come on," said Carton as he reached out to ring the bell, "if you don't mind, I'll ask for the bill and let's part as friends.""
es: —Which should not be an obstacle—replied Darnay, ringing the bell—for me to remain deeply grateful to you and for us to part without mutual ill will.

en: Carton rejoining, “Nothing in life!” Darnay rang. “Do you call the whole reckoning?” said Carton. On his answering in the affirmative, “Then bring me another pint of this same wine, drawer, and come and wake me at ten.”
vi: No way! - Carton immediately replied. Darnay rang the bell. - Are you paying for everything? - Carton asked and spoke to the waiter after receiving an affirmative answer. - Then waiter, bring us another bottle of this wine, and wake me up at ten o'clock.
tr: Carton immediately said, "No objection at all!" and Darnay rang the bell. "Will you pay the entire bill?" asked Carton. When Darnay answered affirmatively, he added, "Then bring me another glass of the same wine, waiter, and come wake me up at ten o'clock."
es: —Of course—replied Carton. —Are you saying that you are grateful to me? —I say it, and so it is. —Then, waiter, bring me another pint of this same wine, and wake me up tomorrow at ten.

en: The bill being paid, Charles Darnay rose and wished him good night. Without returning the wish, Carton rose too, with something of a threat of defiance in his manner, and said, “A last word, Mr. Darnay: you think I am drunk?”
vi: After paying, Charles Darnay stood up to say goodbye. Without bothering to return the farewell, Carton also stood up, speaking in a somewhat challenging tone: − One last word, Mr. Darnay.
tr: After Charles Darnay paid the bill, he stood up and wished Carton a good night. Without responding to this wish, Carton also stood up in a defiant and threatening manner and asked, "One last question for you, Mr. Darnay, do you think I'm drunk?"
es: After paying the bill, Darnay stood up, said good night, and headed towards the door. Carton, without responding to the good night, also stood up, looked angrily at the one who was leaving, and said: —Two words, Mr. Darnay, do you think I am drunk?

en: “I think you have been drinking, Mr. Carton.”
vi: Do you think I'm drunk? − I think you've had quite a bit to drink, Mr. Carton.
tr: "It seems you've had quite a bit to drink, Mr. Carton.""
es: —I believe you have drunk a lot, Mr. Carton.

en: “Think? You know I have been drinking.”
vi: − Think? You know very well that I've had a lot to drink.
tr: "Am I drunk? You know I've drunk quite a bit."
es: —Do you just believe it? You know perfectly well that I have been drinking.

en: “Since I must say so, I know it.”
vi: − Because I have to say that, but I know. −
tr: "Yes, I know.""
es: —Since you insist, I will say that, indeed, I know you have been drinking.

en: “Then you shall likewise know why. I am a disappointed drudge, sir. I care for no man on earth, and no man on earth cares for me.”
vi: Then you must also know the reason. I am a lowly servant, sir. I don't care about anyone in the world, and no one in the world cares about me.
tr: "Then let me tell you the reason for this. I am a defeated, heavy laborer. There is no one in this world that I value, and no one values me."
es: —In that case, perhaps you also know why I have been drinking. I am a disillusioned, a disappointed man. I do not care about the fate of any man on earth, nor does any man on earth even remember my existence.

en: “Much to be regretted. You might have used your talents better.”
vi: − That's really unfortunate for you. You should have used your talents better.
tr: "What a pity. You could have used your talents better."
es: —Which remains a misfortune. You should have put your talent to better use.

en: “May be so, Mr. Darnay; may be not. Don’t let your sober face elate you, however; you don’t know what it may come to. Good night!”
vi: − Maybe so, Mr. Darnay; but maybe not. But don't be too quick to rejoice in your composure, you don't know what might come. Goodbye!
tr: "Maybe so, Mr. Darnay, but maybe not. Don't rely too much on your sober, sensible state; one never knows what the days will bring. Good night!"
es: —You may be right, and you may be sadly mistaken. Do not be conceited, however, my friend, for you do not know what the future holds for you... Good night!

en: When he was left alone, this strange being took up a candle, went to a glass that hung against the wall, and surveyed himself minutely in it.
vi: Left alone, this strange man picked up a candle, went to the mirror hanging on the wall, and carefully examined the reflection in the glass.
tr: This strange man, when left alone, took a candle in his hand and went to the mirror hanging on the wall, and carefully examined himself.
es: When he was alone, that singular man took the candlestick, approached a mirror hanging on the wall, and meticulously and thoroughly examined the image reflected on its smooth surface.

en: “Do you particularly like the man?” he muttered, at his own image; “why should you particularly like a man who resembles you? There is nothing in you to like; you know that. Ah, confound you! What a change you have made in yourself! A good reason for taking to a man, that he shows you what you have fallen away from, and what you might have been! Change places with him, and would you have been looked at by those blue eyes as he was, and commiserated by that agitated face as he was? Come on, and have it out in plain words! You hate the fellow.”
vi: − Do you cherish this person? - Carton muttered to his own reflection. - Why would you cherish someone who resembles you? You have nothing worth cherishing; you know that well. Ah, you wretch! You've changed yourself so much! The valid reason to cherish someone is because they show you what you once were, and what you could have become! If you traded places with him, would you look through those blue eyes as he does, would you feel compassion with that expressive face as he does? Come on, speak frankly! You resent that person.
tr: "Do you love this man?" he muttered to himself; "why would a person love a man who resembles himself? There is nothing lovable about you. Oh, come on! What have you changed about yourself in this life? Seeing the things you've lost and what you could have been might be a good reason to love him! Just think for a moment if you switched places with him, would those blue eyes look at you the same way they look at him, and would that sad face ache for you with the same compassion? Come on, just say it openly! You hate him."
es: —Do you find that man likable?—he murmured, as if directing the question to his own reflection. — Why should you find a man who resembles you likable? Do you have anything that could please anyone? You know very well that you don't. I can't understand the reason for the change... Damned be you!... And indeed, the man who tells you what you could have been and what you really are deserves sympathy! Come on!... Say it once and for all, and with honesty! You despise that individual!

en: He resorted to his pint of wine for consolation, drank it all in a few minutes, and fell asleep on his arms, with his hair straggling over the table, and a long winding-sheet in the candle dripping down upon him.
vi: He again resorted to a bottle of wine to drown his sorrows, finishing it within minutes, then resting his head on his arms and falling asleep, his hair sprawled across the table, and candle wax dripping like a shroud over his head.
tr: For solace, his hand went to the wine again, and in a few minutes, having finished it all, accompanied by the dripping long candle, he fell asleep with his hair spread out on the table, collapsed over his arms.
es: As if the wine were a fountain of solace for him, in very few minutes he made the pint of wine pass into his stomach and fell asleep at the same table, his head resting on his arms.

en: CHAPTER V.
vi: He again resorted to a bottle of wine to drown his sorrows, finishing it within minutes, then resting his head on his arms and falling asleep, his hair sprawled across the table, and candle wax dripping like a shroud over his head.
tr: V
es: V.

en: The Jackal
vi: 5. Jackals*
tr: Jackal
es: THE JACKAL

en: Those were drinking days, and most men drank hard. So very great is the improvement Time has brought about in such habits, that a moderate statement of the quantity of wine and punch which one man would swallow in the course of a night, without any detriment to his reputation as a perfect gentleman, would seem, in these days, a ridiculous exaggeration. The learned profession of the law was certainly not behind any other learned profession in its Bacchanalian propensities; neither was Mr. Stryver, already fast shouldering his way to a large and lucrative practice, behind his compeers in this particular, any more than in the drier parts of the legal race.
vi: It was the era of wine, and most men drank heavily. Time has improved this bad habit to the extent that nowadays it would be considered ridiculously exaggerated to mention the average amount of wine and punch a person of that time could consume in one night without damaging the reputation of a noble gentleman. Compared to other high academic professions, the legal profession was no less in terms of its disciples of Bacchus; barrister Stryver was no exception, having aggressively pushed his way into this lucrative field with many clients, he was second to none in both drunkenness and sobriety among his legal peers.
tr: In those days, people drank a lot, and most men drank until they were dead drunk. Time has brought about such great changes in habits that a reasonable explanation of how much wine a man could consume in one night without tarnishing his gentlemanliness would seem like a comical exaggeration today. In these drinking bouts, the legal community was no less than others; of course, Mr. Stryver, as in the most tedious legal competitions, was never behind his peers in this matter either.
es: In those times, universal worship was rendered to the bottle. If I were to specify and detail here the amount of wine and punch that a man could consume in the course of a night, without his reputation as a perfect gentleman suffering the slightest detriment, I would surely be deemed a ridiculous exaggerator by the readers. Men drank a lot, and certainly the luminaries of the forum and the notabilities in any other branch of human knowledge were no exception to the rule, as science has never been a barrier raised between its possessor and the altars of Bacchus. It is therefore not surprising that Mr. Stryver, a lawyer advancing with giant strides in his lucrative profession, rendered as constant worship to the bottle as the driest sponges in the community of pettifoggers.

en: A favourite at the Old Bailey, and eke at the Sessions, Mr. Stryver had begun cautiously to hew away the lower staves of the ladder on which he mounted. Sessions and Old Bailey had now to summon their favourite, specially, to their longing arms; and shouldering itself towards the visage of the Lord Chief Justice in the Court of King’s Bench, the florid countenance of Mr. Stryver might be daily seen, bursting out of the bed of wigs, like a great sunflower pushing its way at the sun from among a rank garden-full of flaring companions.
vi: As a favored individual at the Old Bailey Court as well as the Sessions Court, Stryver had begun cautiously cutting off the lower rungs on the ladder of fame he was climbing. The Old Bailey and Sessions courts now had to summon this favored individual into their eager embrace; daily one could see the flushed face of Stryver, pushing and jostling to catch the eye of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, like a sunflower standing out in a garden full of wigs, competing with other brilliant peers to reach the sun.
tr: Mr. Stryver, the favorite of Old Bailey and the trials, had begun to cautiously cut off the lower rungs of the ladder he was climbing. He was now being called to many trials and to Old Bailey, and they were even eager for his arrival. Every day, with his red face, he appeared before the Chief Justice in the High Court of Justice, and his head, among all those wigged heads, stood out like a giant sunflower reaching for the sun from among thousands of similar, neatly arranged, and brightly shining heads.
es: Favorite at the Old Bailey and indispensable at the court called Sessions, Stryver separated the steps of the ladder with his foot as he left them behind. Every day, in one court or another, Stryver's red face emerged from among a layer of wigs, similar to the sunflower that raises its head above a bed of bright flowers.

en: It had once been noted at the Bar, that while Mr. Stryver was a glib man, and an unscrupulous, and a ready, and a bold, he had not that faculty of extracting the essence from a heap of statements, which is among the most striking and necessary of the advocate’s accomplishments. But, a remarkable improvement came upon him as to this. The more business he got, the greater his power seemed to grow of getting at its pith and marrow; and however late at night he sat carousing with Sydney Carton, he always had his points at his fingers’ ends in the morning.
vi: In the previous bar association, people had noticed that although Stryver was a cunning speaker, regardless of conscience, crafty and bold, he lacked the ability to extract the essence from a pile of reports - the most necessary and admirable skill in the achievements of a barrister. But this had greatly improved. The more cases he handled, the better he seemed to get at digging to the core of the matter; and even if he spent the whole night carousing with Sydney Carton, by morning this barrister still had all the arguments ready to defend in court.
tr: Once, while discussing Baroda, they had mentioned Mr. Stryver as a talkative, unscrupulous, skilled, and brave man, but they had also remarked that he failed to grasp the essence within a multitude of expressions, which was one of the most striking and necessary skills for a lawyer. But he had shown significant improvement in this regard. As he took on more cases, he became stronger in extracting the essence and substance of the matter; even if he stayed up late drinking with Sydney Carton, he would have all his preparations completed by morning.
es: They had observed in the forum that Stryver, at the beginning of his career, although he was a man with a loose tongue, unscrupulous, willing to do anything, bold and insolent, lacked the ability to extract the essence, the core of reports and testimonial evidence, which is so indispensable to any good lawyer, but later on, he made marvelous progress in this particular area. The more he worked, the more easily he reached the heart, the marrow of the matters, it being noteworthy that, even though he had the habit of spending sleepless nights emptying bottles in the company of Carton, the points he had to address the next morning neither faded from his mind nor became obscured.

en: Sydney Carton, idlest and most unpromising of men, was Stryver’s great ally. What the two drank together, between Hilary Term and Michaelmas, might have floated a king’s ship. Stryver never had a case in hand, anywhere, but Carton was there, with his hands in his pockets, staring at the ceiling of the court; they went the same Circuit, and even there they prolonged their usual orgies late into the night, and Carton was rumoured to be seen at broad day, going home stealthily and unsteadily to his lodgings, like a dissipated cat. At last, it began to get about, among such as were interested in the matter, that although Sydney Carton would never be a lion, he was an amazingly good jackal, and that he rendered suit and service to Stryver in that humble capacity.
vi: Sydney Carton - the most idle and useless person - was actually Stryver's right-hand man. The amount of alcohol these two consumed together, if collected from the beginning to the end of the year, would surely be enough to flow like a river. There was no trial, anywhere, of Stryver's without Carton being there, hands in his pockets, eyes glued to the ceiling; they followed the circuit court together, and wherever they went, they extended their usual all-night drinking sessions, and it was rumored that in the morning, Carton could be seen sneaking back to the inn, staggering like a chased cat. Eventually, those who were interested in this matter gradually came to know that although Sydney Carton would never be a lion, he was an extraordinarily skilled jackal, and it was he who prepared all the legal matters for Stryver in that humble role.
tr: The world's most idle and hopeless man, Sydney Carton, was Stryver's friend. The amount of alcohol they consumed between Hilary Term and Michaelmas was enough to float the king's ship; Carton was always present at Stryver's every trial, looking up at the ceiling of the courtroom with his hands in his pockets; they moved in the same circles and even there, they would extend their drinking sessions until midnight, after which it was said that Carton would secretly, in broad daylight, stagger home like a miserable cat. Ultimately, followers began to say that while Sydney Carton might never be a lion, he was a very good jackal, offering help and service to Stryver with this humble title.
es: Sydney Carton, the laziest and most idle specimen of humanity, was Stryver's most powerful ally. On the liquid that the two of them consumed, a three-deck ship could have perfectly floated. Both led the same life, both extended their orgies until dawn, and more than once Carton was seen, with the sun already high, heading with unsteady steps to his home or to the courtroom. There were no shortage of malicious people who claimed that Carton, if he was not and would never become a lion, was instead an excellent tiger, and that, in this capacity, he rendered invaluable services to his friend Stryver.

en: “Ten o’clock, sir,” said the man at the tavern, whom he had charged to wake him—“ten o’clock, sir.”
vi: − Sir, it's ten o'clock, - the voice of the servant whom Carton had entrusted with the task of waking him, - it's ten o'clock, sir. −
tr: The man whom Handa paid to wake him up said, "It is ten o'clock, sir."
es: —Ten o'clock, sir—said the tavern keeper whom Carton had instructed to wake him. —Ten o'clock at night.

en: “What’s the matter?”
vi: What? - Yes, it's ten o'clock. −
tr: "What happened?"
es: —What is happening?

en: “Ten o’clock, sir.”
vi: What? - Yes, it's ten o'clock. −
tr: "It is ten o'clock, sir.""
es: —It's ten o'clock, sir.

en: “What do you mean? Ten o’clock at night?”
vi: What does that mean? Is it ten at night? −
tr: "So what? Is it ten at night?"
es: —And what? Ten o'clock at night?

en: “Yes, sir. Your honour told me to call you.”
vi: Yes, sir. You instructed me to call you, sir. −
tr: "Yes sir. You had asked me to wake you up, remember."
es: —Yes, sir. You asked me to wake you up at that time.

en: “Oh! I remember. Very well, very well.”
vi: Ah! I remember now. Very well, very well.
tr: "Aha! I remember now! Very nice, very nice."
es: —Ah, yes! Now I remember! Alright.

en: After a few dull efforts to get to sleep again, which the man dexterously combated by stirring the fire continuously for five minutes, he got up, tossed his hat on, and walked out. He turned into the Temple, and, having revived himself by twice pacing the pavements of King’s Bench-walk and Paper-buildings, turned into the Stryver chambers.
vi: After a few feeble attempts to continue sleeping but being skillfully awakened by the attendant who kept stoking the fireplace continuously for five minutes, Carton stood up, put his hat on, and went out. He turned towards the Temple area, after circling twice to fully wake up on the sidewalk between King’s Bench Walk and Paper Buildings, he entered the office of barrister Stryver.
tr: Although he tried to fall back asleep, the man's noisy stirring of the fire for five minutes turned it into a skillful struggle, and Carton got up, put on his hat, and went outside. He turned onto the road to Temple, and after pacing twice on the pavement in front of the King's Bench Court and the newspaper buildings, he came to himself and returned to Stryver's office.
es: Not without trying to sleep again, attempts that the innkeeper thwarted by constantly stoking the fire and making noise, Carton finally got up and went out. After he had cleared his head by taking a regular walk, he headed to Stryver's office.

en: The Stryver clerk, who never assisted at these conferences, had gone home, and the Stryver principal opened the door. He had his slippers on, and a loose bed-gown, and his throat was bare for his greater ease. He had that rather wild, strained, seared marking about the eyes, which may be observed in all free livers of his class, from the portrait of Jeffries downward, and which can be traced, under various disguises of Art, through the portraits of every Drinking Age.
vi: Stryver's clerk - who never attended these meetings - had gone home, and Stryver himself opened the door. Stryver was wearing slippers, a loose dressing gown, and had his collar open for comfort. Around his eyes were the clear signs of the tension and ferocity often seen in every indulgent person within the legal profession, from Jeffries* to the present, which one can trace through various portrait paintings disguised as art from the era that worshiped Bacchus.
tr: Stryver's clerk, who never participated in such meetings, had gone home, and Stryver himself opened the door. He was wearing slippers, a loose nightgown, and had loosened his collar for comfort. Around his eyes were wild, tense, and hardened traces that could be seen in all the freely living members of his class, similar to those in the portraits starting from Jeffreys and evolving with every new form of Art, drawn in all ages where there was a penchant for drinking.
es: The official of Stryver, who never attended the conferences he held with Carton, had left, and as a result, it was Stryver himself who had to open the door to the visitor. He was in a robe and slippers, and his eyes shone between two purplish circles similar to those that characterize all who live or have lived a dissipated life.

en: “You are a little late, Memory,” said Stryver.
vi: You're a bit late, Memory Master, - Stryver said.
tr: "You are a bit late, Mr. Memory," said Stryver.
es: —You're a little late, Carton—said Stryver.

en: “About the usual time; it may be a quarter of an hour later.”
vi: − As usual; probably about half an hour late.
tr: "I came as usual, just fifteen minutes late.""
es: —More or less at the usual time, maybe fifteen minutes later.

en: They went into a dingy room lined with books and littered with papers, where there was a blazing fire. A kettle steamed upon the hob, and in the midst of the wreck of papers a table shone, with plenty of wine upon it, and brandy, and rum, and sugar, and lemons.
vi: They walked into a filthy room, filled with books and cluttered with papers, where a fireplace blazed and a kettle steamed on the stove. And amidst that forest of papers, a table laden with wine, spirits, rum with sugar and lemon was revealed.
tr: They entered a filthy room filled with rows of books, papers scattered everywhere, and a burning fireplace. A kettle was steaming on the stove, and on the table amidst the piles of paper resembling a wreck, various kinds of wine, brandy, rum, sugar, and lemon were shining.
es: Both entered the office, a not very large room, crowded with books and papers. A delightful fire was burning in it. On the work table, a teapot was steaming among piles of papers and bottles of rum, brandy, and wine, and among lumps of sugar and lemons.

en: “You have had your bottle, I perceive, Sydney.”
vi: − I'm sure you have already drunk a bottle, Sydney.
tr: "I guess you've knocked back quite a few bottles, Sydney.""
es: —I see that you have already finished your usual bottle, Carton.

en: “Two to-night, I think. I have been dining with the day’s client; or seeing him dine—it’s all one!”
vi: − Two bottles tonight, probably. Earlier I had dinner with the client from today's case; or more precisely, I watched him eat... either way!
tr: "I think I drank two bottles tonight. We had dinner with my client today; or rather, I watched him eat –same thing!"
es: —Tonight there were two. I was eating with my client today... or watching him eat, for that matter, it's the same thing.

en: “That was a rare point, Sydney, that you brought to bear upon the identification. How did you come by it? When did it strike you?”
vi: − Sydney, it's truly extraordinary that you put yourself forward for identification. How did you come up with that idea? When did you recognize the resemblance?
tr: "Drawing attention to your resemblance was a brilliant tactic, Sydney. How did you come up with it? When did you first notice it?"
es: —You gave the matter a truly unique twist, Carton, by drawing my attention to the identification of the defendant. How on earth did such a thing occur to you? —Bah!

en: “I thought he was rather a handsome fellow, and I thought I should have been much the same sort of fellow, if I had had any luck.”
vi: − I think he's quite a handsome guy, and I think I might have turned out like him if I had been lucky.
tr: "I realized he was quite handsome, and I thought if I had a bit of luck, I would resemble this man a little.""
es: I saw that he was a handsome young man, very good-looking, and I thought that I could have been like that, had luck favored me a little more.

en: Mr. Stryver laughed till he shook his precocious paunch.
vi: Stryver laughed, shaking his already portly belly. −
tr: Mr. Stryver laughed heartily, making his already large belly bounce even more.
es: Stryver burst into laughter.

en: “You and your luck, Sydney! Get to work, get to work.”
vi: You're in luck, Sydney! Now, get to work, get to work.
tr: "You and luck, huh Sydney! Come on, let's get to work, let's get to work.""
es: —Luck must be summoned by working, my friend, so... let's get to work!

en: Sullenly enough, the jackal loosened his dress, went into an adjoining room, and came back with a large jug of cold water, a basin, and a towel or two. Steeping the towels in the water, and partially wringing them out, he folded them on his head in a manner hideous to behold, sat down at the table, and said, “Now I am ready!”
vi: With a gloomy face, the Jackal loosened his tie and took off his coat, went to the next room, and returned with a jug of cold water, a basin, and some towels. He dipped a towel into the water, wrung it out slightly, folded the wet towel, and placed it haphazardly on his head, then sat down at the table, saying: − I'm ready! −
tr: The jackal, with a sullen face, unbuttoned his clothes and went to the next room, returning with a large jug of water, a basin, and a few towels. After soaking the towels in the water and wringing them out lightly, he carelessly wrapped one around his head and sat down at the head of the table, saying, "Yes, I'm ready now!"
es: With a more than moderately sullen face, the jackal quickly removed his clothes, entered the adjoining room, and soon came out with a bucket of water, a basin, and one or two towels. He soaked the towels in cold water, wrapped them around his head, sat down in front of the table, and said: —We can begin now.

en: “Not much boiling down to be done to-night, Memory,” said Mr. Stryver, gaily, as he looked among his papers.
vi: There isn't much work tonight, Mr. Memory, - Stryver said cheerfully while looking through the papers. −
tr: "There's not much going on tonight actually, Mr. Memory," said Mr. Stryver, looking at the papers, cheerfully.
es: —We don't have much work tonight, Carton.

en: “How much?”
vi: How many files?
tr: "How many cases are there?"
es: —How much?

en: “Only two sets of them.”
vi: − Only two sets.
tr: "Only two.""
es: —Two protocols.

en: “Give me the worst first.”
vi: − Give me the hardest one. −
tr: "Give the bad news first.""
es: —Give me the worst one first.

en: “There they are, Sydney. Fire away!”
vi: Here you go, Sydney. Do it now!
tr: "Come on, Sydney. Good luck!"
es: —Here are the two... Let's get to work!

en: The lion then composed himself on his back on a sofa on one side of the drinking-table, while the jackal sat at his own paper-bestrewn table proper, on the other side of it, with the bottles and glasses ready to his hand. Both resorted to the drinking-table without stint, but each in a different way; the lion for the most part reclining with his hands in his waistband, looking at the fire, or occasionally flirting with some lighter document; the jackal, with knitted brows and intent face, so deep in his task, that his eyes did not even follow the hand he stretched out for his glass—which often groped about, for a minute or more, before it found the glass for his lips. Two or three times, the matter in hand became so knotty, that the jackal found it imperative on him to get up, and steep his towels anew. From these pilgrimages to the jug and basin, he returned with such eccentricities of damp headgear as no words can describe; which were made the more ludicrous by his anxious gravity.
vi: The Lion then comfortably reclined on a sofa placed on one side of the liquor table, while on the other side, the Jackal sat at a separate table cluttered with papers but still within arm's reach of the bottles and glasses. Both freely used the liquor table, each in their own way; The Lion usually lay on his back, hands hooked into his waistband, eyes gazing at the fireplace or occasionally flipping through a simple file; the Jackal, on the other hand, furrowed his brow, deeply immersed in his work, his eyes not even following his hand as it reached for a glass - the hand often groped around for a minute or more before finding the glass to bring to his lips. Two or three times, when the issue at hand became too difficult, the Jackal was forced to stand up and wet his towel again. After each pilgrimage to the water jug and basin, the Jackal would return with the wet towels draped over his head in an indescribably peculiar manner; looking even more ridiculous with his serious, tense expression.
tr: Then, while the lion leaned back on the sofa next to the liquor table, the jackal went to his own table, which was covered with papers and had wine bottles and glasses right beside it. They both frequently reached for the liquor table but in different styles; the lion usually with his hands resting on his belt, looking at the fire or occasionally shuffling the papers in his hand; the jackal, on the other hand, was so engrossed in his work with a frown and a determined face that his eyes didn't even follow his hand reaching for the glass – thus, he often brought the glass to his lips by feel. Two or three times, the matter at hand became so intricate that the jackal felt the need to get up and put the towels back in the water. He would return from his visits to the pitcher and basin with wet towels wrapped around his head in such a way that it was impossible to describe the oddity, and adding his restless solemnity to this, he looked even more comical.
es: The lion of the forum lounged on a sofa while the jackal took a chair. On the table, placed between the two, there were bottles and glasses. Both of them resorted to them frequently but in different ways: the lion drank, mostly absorbed or at most glancing indifferently at some unimportant document, but the jackal, with such ardor and enthusiasm, devoted himself to his task that his eyes almost never followed the movement of his hands when they reached for the glass, resulting in him groping for one or two minutes more than four times before finding the glass and bringing it to his lips. On two or three occasions, he must have found the matter he was studying so convoluted that he considered it necessary to get up from the chair and dampen the towels again.

en: At length the jackal had got together a compact repast for the lion, and proceeded to offer it to him. The lion took it with care and caution, made his selections from it, and his remarks upon it, and the jackal assisted both. When the repast was fully discussed, the lion put his hands in his waistband again, and lay down to meditate. The jackal then invigorated himself with a bumper for his throttle, and a fresh application to his head, and applied himself to the collection of a second meal; this was administered to the lion in the same manner, and was not disposed of until the clocks struck three in the morning.
vi: Finally, the Jackal gathered a full meal to offer to the Lion. The Lion carefully received it, meticulously selecting the meat from the bones and giving his comments to the Jackal. After the meal was thoroughly savored in that manner, the Lion hooked his hands into his waistband and lay down to ponder. The Jackal then restored his strength with a full glass of wine poured down his throat, a new wet cloth applied to his head, and continued to prepare the second meal; this meal was again offered to the Lion as before, and was only fully digested when the clock struck three in the morning.
tr: In the end, the jackal prepared a hearty meal for the lion and placed it in front of him. After the lion examined it with great care and caution, he made comments by making selections from it, while the jackal assisted him. After the matter was thoroughly discussed, the lion again put his hands on his belt and lay down, lost in thoughts. Then the jackal downed a glass filled to the brim to clear his head and prepared the second meal; this meal was also presented to the lion in the same manner, and when they were done, the clock showed three in the morning.
es: After a while, the jackal managed to prepare an acceptable meal for the lion and proceeded to offer it to him. The lion tried to digest it carefully and with exquisite precautions, separating some delicacies, dispensing with some components, and making judicious observations, which seemed agreeable to the jackal. Having digested the meal, the lion lay down on the sofa, while the jackal, after revitalizing himself again with libations and cold water compresses, dedicated himself to the preparation of the second meal, which was served to the lion in the same manner as the previous one. The clocks were already striking three in the morning.

en: “And now we have done, Sydney, fill a bumper of punch,” said Mr. Stryver.
vi: − Now that the work is done, have a glass of punch, Sydney, - Stryver said.
tr: "Well, now that we've finished, we can have a big glass of punch, can't we, Sydney?" said Mr. Stryver.
es: —Now that we have finished, Carton, we will have a punch.

en: The jackal removed the towels from his head, which had been steaming again, shook himself, yawned, shivered, and complied.
vi: The jackal removed the cloths that had been steaming from its head, stretched, yawned, shivered, and then followed suit.
tr: The Jackal took the steaming towels off his head, gave them a shake, yawned, shivered, and agreed with Stryver.
es: The jackal removed the towels from his head, yawned, stretched, and prepared the punch.

en: “You were very sound, Sydney, in the matter of those crown witnesses to-day. Every question told.”
vi: − Sydney, you were really brilliant in handling the witnesses today. Every question was spot on. −
tr: "You stood very firm in front of those witnesses today, Sydney. With every question you asked."
es: —You were right, Carton, regarding the witnesses this morning: everything went perfectly. —It seems to me that I always have it: will you dare to say otherwise?

en: “I always am sound; am I not?”
vi: Aren't I always brilliant?
tr: "I'm always healthy; isn't that right?""
es: —It seems to me that I always have it: will you dare to say otherwise?

en: “I don’t gainsay it. What has roughened your temper? Put some punch to it and smooth it again.”
vi: − I'm not denying that. What made you so angry? Have another drink to cool down.
tr: "I can't deny this. Why are you upset? Pour some more punch and relax."
es: —No, man, no! You come today with a ruffled temper, my friend. It wouldn't hurt to sprinkle it with a good downpour of punch to soften it.

en: With a deprecatory grunt, the jackal again complied.
vi: Grumbling and making excuses, the Jackal still obeyed.
tr: The Jackal grumbled discontentedly and surrendered again.
es: The jackal responded with a growl, but followed the advice.

en: “The old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School,” said Stryver, nodding his head over him as he reviewed him in the present and the past, “the old seesaw Sydney. Up one minute and down the next; now in spirits and now in despondency!”
vi: − That Sydney Carton fellow back in the days at Shrewsbury, Stryver said while nodding as he compared his friend from the past to the present, - the seesawing Sydney! One moment he's up, the next he's down; sometimes he's enthusiastic, other times he's despondent!
tr: "Sydney Carton, an old student of Shrewsbury School from years ago, huh?" said Stryver, evaluating him both in his current and past state, nodding his head, "Erratic Sydney. One moment good, the next bad; one day cheerful, the next in a slump!"
es: —The good Sydney Carton, lawyer from the Faculty of Zorrilandia, is a kind of swing—observed Stryver.— As soon as he is up, he is down: in a minute he goes from being all fire to being all despair.

en: “Ah!” returned the other, sighing: “yes! The same Sydney, with the same luck. Even then, I did exercises for other boys, and seldom did my own.”
vi: − Ah! - The friend sighed in response. - Yes! That same Sydney, and the same bad luck. Even back then, I used to do homework for my classmates but rarely did my own. −
tr: "Ah!" sighed Carton; "You're right! The same Sydney, the same luck. Even back then, I would do other children's homework and not bother much with my own."
es: —Ah, yes!—replied Carton, letting out a sigh. —Even as a student, I was motivated by the affairs of my classmates, very rarely by my own.

en: “And why not?”
vi: Why not? −
tr: "Why then?"
es: —But why not?

en: “God knows. It was my way, I suppose.”
vi: God only knows, it's probably just my nature.
tr: "Who knows? This is just how I am."
es: —Who knows! By temperament, I suppose.

en: He sat, with his hands in his pockets and his legs stretched out before him, looking at the fire.
vi: He sat with his legs stretched out in front of him, hands in his pockets, eyes fixed on the fireplace.
tr: He sat with his hands in his pockets and watched the fire in the fireplace, stretching his legs forward.
es: He sat down, having said these words, with his hands in his pockets, legs stretched out, and looking at the fire.

en: “Carton,” said his friend, squaring himself at him with a bullying air, as if the fire-grate had been the furnace in which sustained endeavour was forged, and the one delicate thing to be done for the old Sydney Carton of old Shrewsbury School was to shoulder him into it, “your way is, and always was, a lame way. You summon no energy and purpose. Look at me.”
vi: - Carton, if you keep going like this, you won't get anywhere, just like in the past. - Stryver aggressively stood right in front of him with an overbearing attitude, as if the fireplace was a forge of relentless effort and the only thing needed for the old Sydney Carton from Shrewsbury school was to throw him into that fire. - You have no motivation and no purpose. Look at me. -
tr: "Carton," said his friend with a condescending attitude; as if the grill in the fireplace was a hearth fueled by endless efforts and the best thing to do for the years of Sydney Carton who had attended Shrewsbury School was to push him, "you've been on the wrong path from the start. You have neither effort nor purpose. Just look at me."
es: —You cannot deny, Carton—said Stryver to the former student of the Faculty of Foxland,—that your temperament, your way of being, is and has always been flawed. It suffers from a lack of energy, a lack of unity of purpose. Look at me.

en: “Oh, botheration!” returned Sydney, with a lighter and more good-humoured laugh, “don’t you be moral!”
vi: Oh, what a bother! - Sydney replied with a cheerful and somewhat enthusiastic laugh. - You teaching me a lesson! −
tr: "Come on, man!" said Sydney, laughing softly and meekly, "don't lecture me now!"
es: —Sermons at this point?—exclaimed Carton, laughing cynically.

en: “How have I done what I have done?” said Stryver; “how do I do what I do?”
vi: How did I achieve what I have? - Stryver said. - How did I get what I wanted? −
tr: "How did I come to this state?" said Stryver; "How did I obtain what I currently possess?"
es: —Now is when I believe that thing about the preaching devil... —How could I have gotten to where I am? How do I hold the position I hold?

en: “Partly through paying me to help you, I suppose. But it’s not worth your while to apostrophise me, or the air, about it; what you want to do, you do. You were always in the front rank, and I was always behind.”
vi: Partly because you paid me to help you, I suppose. But don't bother calling me like that and don't act superior to me; do whatever you want. You always push to the front, while I always stay behind.
tr: "You obtained some of it by giving me money to help you. But none of it is worth you talking down to me or acting superior; you did what you wanted. You were always in the front rows, while I was always in the back."
es: —Partly, thanks to my cooperation, I suppose. But let's leave these discussions that won't lead us to anything practical. You do whatever you want, you've always been in the forefront, and I, on the other hand, have always been in the background.

en: “I had to get into the front rank; I was not born there, was I?”
vi: − I have to push to the front; I wasn't born into a noble family, was I? − I wasn't there when you were born; but I know you are noble, - Carton said.
tr: "I had to be at the front; after all, I wasn't born there either, right?"
es: "I had to make my own way if I wanted to place myself in the front row, as I don't know that I was born into it," replied Stryver.

en: “I was not present at the ceremony; but my opinion is you were,” said Carton. At this, he laughed again, and they both laughed.
vi: − I have to push to the front; I wasn't born into a noble family, was I? − I wasn't there when you were born; but I know you are noble, - Carton said. With that, he laughed again and Stryver laughed along.
tr: "I wasn't there at your birth, but I think you were definitely born there," said Carton. He laughed again at this remark, and Stryver laughed too.
es: —I did not have the honor of witnessing the ceremony of your birth, but I believe that when you were brought into the world, you were placed among the privileged. The two interlocutors burst into laughter.

en: “Before Shrewsbury, and at Shrewsbury, and ever since Shrewsbury,” pursued Carton, “you have fallen into your rank, and I have fallen into mine. Even when we were fellow-students in the Student-Quarter of Paris, picking up French, and French law, and other French crumbs that we didn’t get much good of, you were always somewhere, and I was always nowhere.”
vi: Carton continued speaking. "Before attending Shrewsbury, while at Shrewsbury, and after leaving Shrewsbury, you were always ahead, while I was always behind." "Even when we were both students in the Latin Quarter in Paris, learning French, studying French law, and other miscellaneous French things of dubious utility, you always stood out, while I remained obscure."
tr: "Before Shrewsbury, in Shrewsbury, and after Shrewsbury," continued Carton, "you were always at the forefront, and I was always behind. During our student days in the student quarter of Paris, where we took lessons in French, French Law, and the French beauties who caused us trouble, you were always getting somewhere, and I was – nowhere."
es: —Before attending Zorrilandia University—replied Carton,—while we were attending, and after we graduated from it, you were in a different league from mine. Even when we were in Paris learning to mumble French and acquiring some notions of French law, and familiarizing ourselves with many other French trivialities that are of no use to us, you were something, while I was always Mr. Nobody.

en: “And whose fault was that?”
vi: − So whose fault is it?
tr: "So whose fault was this?"
es: —Whose fault was it?

en: “Upon my soul, I am not sure that it was not yours. You were always driving and riving and shouldering and passing, to that restless degree that I had no chance for my life but in rust and repose. It’s a gloomy thing, however, to talk about one’s own past, with the day breaking. Turn me in some other direction before I go.”
vi: − Deep down, I also think it's your fault. You are always trying to compete, scramble, and maneuver to get ahead, doing it so continuously that I have no choice but to sit still and waste my intellect. But the sky is about to brighten, and talking about the past is quite boring. Change the subject before I come back. −
tr: "Honestly, I'm not sure it's not yours. While I stood in a corner waiting to rust, you would always strive, struggle, and push things in ways I could never do. But now, at this hour, just before dawn, talking about one's past is a tedious matter. Come on, let's change the subject a bit before you go."
es: —By my life, I won't be the one to claim that it wasn't your fault! You were so lively, you stood out so much, you moved, you stirred in such a way, that I don't know what else I could do but remain shrouded in shadows and condemned to rest... But let's leave this topic, for it is not very pleasant, by my faith, to talk about one's dark past at the break of day.

en: “Well then! Pledge me to the pretty witness,” said Stryver, holding up his glass. “Are you turned in a pleasant direction?”
vi: That’s good! Let’s toast to that beautiful witness, - Stryver said, raising his glass. - Do you agree with this subject?
tr: "Alright, fine! Let's drink to the honor of the beautiful witness then," said Stryver, raising his glass. "Did you like this topic?"
es: —Perfectly—said Stryver, raising the glass. —We will talk about your pretty witness. Don't you think it's a more pleasant topic?

en: Apparently not, for he became gloomy again.
vi: Clearly not, as Carton became melancholy again.
tr: Apparently, he hadn't left, because Carton was bored again.
es: It shouldn't have been, judging by the shadow that darkened his face.

en: “Pretty witness,” he muttered, looking down into his glass. “I have had enough of witnesses to-day and to-night; who’s your pretty witness?”
vi: − Beautiful witness, - he muttered, eyes looking down at his glass of wine. - All day and night I've run into so many witnesses; who is your beautiful witness?
