tr: He looked at his glass, murmuring to himself, "Beautiful witness." "I've dealt with witnesses all day and night; who is this beautiful witness?"
es: —The beautiful witness!—he exclaimed, fixing his eyes on the bottom of the glass. —I have seen many witnesses today... Who are you referring to?

en: “The picturesque doctor’s daughter, Miss Manette.”
vi: − The charming daughter of the doctor, Miss Manette. −
tr: "I'm talking about the interesting doctor's daughter, Miss Manette."
es: —To the precious daughter of the doctor, to Miss Manette.

en: “She pretty?”
vi: Is she beautiful? − Isn't she?
tr: "Is she beautiful?"
es: —Is she pretty?

en: “Is she not?”
vi: Is she beautiful? − Isn't she?
tr: "Isn't it?"
es: —Isn't it, perhaps?

en: “No.”
vi: − No. −
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: “Why, man alive, she was the admiration of the whole Court!”
vi: Oh my goodness, the whole Court admired her!
tr: "What are you saying, man, everyone in the courtroom was impressed by him!"
es: —But man of God!...

en: “Rot the admiration of the whole Court! Who made the Old Bailey a judge of beauty? She was a golden-haired doll!”
vi: − Nonsense, the whole Court admired her! Who turned the Old Bailey into a beauty contest? She's just a blonde doll!
tr: "What do I care about the admiration of those in the courtroom! Is Old Bailey a place to judge beauty? She was just a golden-haired baby!"
es: It has been the admiration of the entire court! —To hell with the court and its admiration! Who made the Old Bailey a judge of beauty? Pretty!... A doll with golden hair!...

en: “Do you know, Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, looking at him with sharp eyes, and slowly drawing a hand across his florid face: “do you know, I rather thought, at the time, that you sympathised with the golden-haired doll, and were quick to see what happened to the golden-haired doll?”
vi: − Do you know, Sydney? - Stryver said, eyes intently looking at Carton and slowly stroking his flushed face. - Do you know, during the trial I thought you had feelings for that blonde doll, so you noticed right away what happened to her.
tr: Mr. Stryver, "You know Sydney," he said, looking sternly and running his hand over his red face, "you know, I thought you liked that golden-haired baby there, how you rushed immediately to see what happened to her."
es: —You know, Carton—asked Stryver, giving his friend a penetrating look and passing his right hand over his red face,—that I'm starting to believe you've sympathized too much with that golden-haired doll, and that your interest quickly noticed what was happening to that golden-haired doll?

en: “Quick to see what happened! If a girl, doll or no doll, swoons within a yard or two of a man’s nose, he can see it without a perspective-glass. I pledge you, but I deny the beauty. And now I’ll have no more drink; I’ll get to bed.”
vi: − Noticed right away what happened! Whether she's a doll or not, if a girl faints right in front of a man, just one or two meters away, he doesn't need a telescope to see it. I'm toasting to your health, not to beauty. No more drinking now, I'm going to sleep.
tr: "Did I run to see what happened? If a lady, baby or not, faints right in front of your eyes, you don't need binoculars to see it. I raise my glass to her honor, but I don't admit that she's beautiful. I'm not drinking anymore; I'm going to sleep."
es: —I warned too soon! It seems to me that if a girl, doll or not, faints two yards from any Christian's nose, they can notice it without looking through a telescope. The topic of conversation doesn't displease me, but I deny the beauty part... I'm not drinking anymore!... I'm going to bed!

en: When his host followed him out on the staircase with a candle, to light him down the stairs, the day was coldly looking in through its grimy windows. When he got out of the house, the air was cold and sad, the dull sky overcast, the river dark and dim, the whole scene like a lifeless desert. And wreaths of dust were spinning round and round before the morning blast, as if the desert-sand had risen far away, and the first spray of it in its advance had begun to overwhelm the city.
vi: When the host escorted Carton to the stairs, holding a candle to light his way down, the cold daylight shone through the dirty windows. When he left the house, the weather was bleak and cold, the clouds hung gray and heavy, the river was dim and gloomy, and the whole scene looked like a dead desert. Dust swirled, swirling like a funeral wreath in the early wind, as if the desert sands had risen in the distance, and the first wave of sand had come to bury the city.
tr: The host, holding a candle, was seeing his guest off down the stairs while the day was coldly peering through the dirty windows. When Carton stepped outside, the air was cold and melancholic, the pale sky was cloudy, the river was dark and dim, and the whole scenery resembled a dead desert. The morning wind was driving clouds of dust before it, swirling them in rings, as if the desert sands from far away had risen, and the first sprinkles from this were already beginning to settle over the entire city.
es: When the owner of the house accompanied Carton to the landing, to light his way with the candle he held in his hand as he descended the stairs, the uncertain glimmers of the new day began to filter through the fogged-up windows. Once he reached the street, the jackal was seen breathing a cold and sad atmosphere, under a sky covered with clouds, bordering a river of dark waters and in places that seemed like the desert of life. Whirlwinds of dust fled, spinning vertiginously before the morning breeze, as if far, far away, the sands of the desert had taken flight and their first clouds threatened to envelop the city.

en: Waste forces within him, and a desert all around, this man stood still on his way across a silent terrace, and saw for a moment, lying in the wilderness before him, a mirage of honourable ambition, self-denial, and perseverance. In the fair city of this vision, there were airy galleries from which the loves and graces looked upon him, gardens in which the fruits of life hung ripening, waters of Hope that sparkled in his sight. A moment, and it was gone. Climbing to a high chamber in a well of houses, he threw himself down in his clothes on a neglected bed, and its pillow was wet with wasted tears.
vi: Inner strength depleted and surrounded by desert, he stopped and stood still on a quiet street, and suddenly saw in the desolate expanse before him the mirage of a lofty aspiration, selfless sacrifice, and steadfast perseverance. In that beautiful illusory city were spacious verandas where love and compassion looked upon him, gardens where the fruits of life ripened, and streams where hope sparkled in the eyes. Just a moment and the illusion vanished. Climbing up to a high room in a crowded building, he threw himself onto the crumpled bed with his clothes still on, and the pillow was soaked with tears of regret.
tr: When this man, filled with burnout within and surrounded by this desert, stood for a moment in front of a silent terrace on his path, he saw the void stretching out before his honorable ambitions, dreams filled with self-sacrifice and determination. In this beautiful dream, loves and beauties in the city were looking at him from joyful balconies, the fruits of life were ripening in the gardens, and the waters of Hope were sparkling brightly before his eyes. Not a minute had passed before it all vanished. Climbing to his room at the top through the houses that seemed to accumulate like in a well, he threw himself onto his messy bed with his clothes still on, and his pillow became soaked with tears flowing in vain.
es: Lacking internal stimuli to ignite his energies, and placed in the center of an endless wasteland, that man stood upright for a few minutes and saw, in the distant reaches of the desolate and sad steppe that stretched out before his gaze, mirages of noble ambition, reflections of selflessness and perseverance. In the enchanted city that emerged before his eyes, there were lofty galleries from where cherubs and graces smiled at him, beautiful gardens where the sweet fruits of life ripened, and waters of hope that leapt with a murmur. The vision faded as quickly as it had appeared. A little later, he climbed the steep stairs to his sad room and fell onto the disheveled clothes of his bed.

en: Sadly, sadly, the sun rose; it rose upon no sadder sight than the man of good abilities and good emotions, incapable of their directed exercise, incapable of his own help and his own happiness, sensible of the blight on him, and resigning himself to let it eat him away.
vi: Sad, sad, the sun rises; the bright sun illuminates a scene no more sorrowful than a person full of talent and good heart who cannot find direction in life, cannot rise to create happiness, aware of the impending adversity yet still letting life wither away.
tr: The sun rose sadly; nothing that the sun shone upon was sadder than this man, who was devoid of the ability to use his talents and beautiful feelings, unable to do anything for his own benefit and happiness, moreover, aware of this dreadful state and, at the cost of being consumed by this dreadful state, giving up on himself.
es: His pillow was soaked with tears when a sickly, sad, melancholic sun rose, though not as much as that man of indisputable talent, of great gifts, and yet, incapable of feeling sweet emotions, incapable of navigating the paths of life, incapable of providing himself with well-being, incapable of savoring a drop of happiness, sensitive only to the eternal night in which he struggled and resigned to never leaving it.

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Sad, sad, the sun rises; the bright sun illuminates a scene no more sorrowful than a person full of talent and good heart who cannot find direction in life, cannot rise to create happiness, aware of the impending adversity yet still letting life wither away.
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: Hundreds of People
vi: 6. Layer upon layer, the quiet house of Dr. Manette lay on a quiet street not far from Soho Square.
tr: Hundreds of People
es: HUNDREDS OF VISITS

en: The quiet lodgings of Doctor Manette were in a quiet street-corner not far from Soho-square. On the afternoon of a certain fine Sunday when the waves of four months had rolled over the trial for treason, and carried it, as to the public interest and memory, far out to sea, Mr. Jarvis Lorry walked along the sunny streets from Clerkenwell where he lived, on his way to dine with the Doctor. After several relapses into business-absorption, Mr. Lorry had become the Doctor’s friend, and the quiet street-corner was the sunny part of his life.
vi: 6. Layer upon layer, the quiet house of Dr. Manette lay on a quiet street not far from Soho Square. On a beautiful Sunday afternoon, when the waves of time had swept away the memories of the treason trial four months ago into the sea of public forgetfulness, Mr. Jarvis Lorry strolled along the sunlit streets from his home in Clerkenwell to Dr. Manette's house for dinner. After several instances of his habitual dedication to work, Mr. Lorry became close to the doctor, and this quiet street became a bright part of his life.
tr: Doctor Manette's Quiet House was at the corner of a quiet street just beyond Soho Square. Four months had passed since the treason trial, and the matter had drifted out of the public's interest and memory into the open seas, when Mr. Lorry, on a beautiful Sunday afternoon, walked along the sunny streets from his home in Clerkenwell to dine with the Doctor. Having come together many times for business, Mr. Lorry and the Doctor had become friends, and that quiet street corner had become a sunny part of his life.
es: Dr. Manette resided in one of the city's quietest streets, not far from Soho Square. On a delightful Sunday afternoon, when the eternal waves of four months had passed over the criminal case for treason, relegating it to oblivion and dragging it out to sea to regions beyond public interest and memory, Mr. Maurice Lorry was striding briskly through the sunlit streets between Clerkenwell, where he lived, and the doctor's house, where he was to dine that evening. It is well for readers to know that Lorry, after several periods of complete withdrawal and total absorption in business, had eventually become an intimate friend of the doctor and saw the quiet street where he lived as the most delightful oasis of his life.

en: On this certain fine Sunday, Mr. Lorry walked towards Soho, early in the afternoon, for three reasons of habit. Firstly, because, on fine Sundays, he often walked out, before dinner, with the Doctor and Lucie; secondly, because, on unfavourable Sundays, he was accustomed to be with them as the family friend, talking, reading, looking out of window, and generally getting through the day; thirdly, because he happened to have his own little shrewd doubts to solve, and knew how the ways of the Doctor’s household pointed to that time as a likely time for solving them.
vi: That beautiful Sunday afternoon, Mr. Lorry took a walk to Soho quite early for three familiar reasons. The first was that on beautiful Sundays, he usually took a walk with the doctor and Lucie before the meal; the second was that on Sundays with bad weather, he was accustomed to visiting like a family member, chatting, reading books, looking out the window, passing the time; the third was that he happened to have some difficult matters to resolve, and he was so familiar with the doctor's family that he knew this time was the best to think.
tr: On this beautiful Sunday, Mr. Lorry had three reasons for making it a habit to walk towards Soho in the afternoon: First, on such lovely Sundays, he would generally go for a walk with the Doctor and Lucie before dinner; Second, on unpleasant Sundays, he had gotten used to spending the whole day with them as a family friend, chatting, reading books, watching outside from the window, in short, spending time with them in this manner; Third, when he had small problems that needed to be resolved in his mind, the Doctor's house was the best place to solve them.
es: Three very important reasons were driving Mr. Lorry, on this delightful Sunday, towards Soho Square in the early afternoon. First: because before lunch, he almost always used to go for a walk accompanying the doctor and his daughter Lucia. Second, because on Sunday afternoons, if it was not very pleasant, he would spend it with them, as a family friend, talking, reading, looking out the window, and constantly moving around, and third, because he wanted to resolve some intricate doubts, and he knew that nowhere was it as likely that he would find the solution as in the doctor's house.

en: A quainter corner than the corner where the Doctor lived, was not to be found in London. There was no way through it, and the front windows of the Doctor’s lodgings commanded a pleasant little vista of street that had a congenial air of retirement on it. There were few buildings then, north of the Oxford-road, and forest-trees flourished, and wild flowers grew, and the hawthorn blossomed, in the now vanished fields. As a consequence, country airs circulated in Soho with vigorous freedom, instead of languishing into the parish like stray paupers without a settlement; and there was many a good south wall, not far off, on which the peaches ripened in their season.
vi: In London, there was no better corner than the corner of Dr. Manette's house. It was a cul-de-sac, and from the front windows of this house, one could overlook a small, peaceful street very suitable for a reclusive lifestyle. At that time, there were still few houses north of Oxford Street, so tall trees grew like a forest, wildflowers bloomed everywhere, and hawthorns blossomed on the vacant lands that no longer exist now. Therefore, the countryside wind freely rushed into Soho vigorously, not sluggishly like a homeless beggar wandering into the parish*; not far to the south, the peach trees with trellises bore ripe fruit every season.
tr: There was no corner in London stranger than the one where the Doctor lived. No road passed through there; the front windows of the Doctor's house overlooked a part of the street that had a pleasant air of seclusion. At that time, there were very few buildings north of Oxford Road, and everywhere was covered with large trees, overgrown wildflowers, and blooming hawthorns; now, none of those fields remain. Later, instead of wandering around like vagrant poor people without a home, this rural air took its freedom and blew freely in Soho; and nearby, there was a beautiful wall where peaches ripened when the season came.
es: There was no more picturesque corner in all of London than the one where the doctor lived. Isolated from the main arteries of the city, there was hardly any traffic, and from the balconies at the front of the house, one could enjoy beautiful views that bore the stamp of tranquility. The buildings were very scarce, and even more so towards the north of Oxford Road, in whose now vanished expansive fields, delightful groves stood, colorful flowers grew spontaneously, saturating the air with fragrant emanations, and lovely buds sprouted from the white hawthorns and the hawthorns. As a result, the air circulated freely around Soho, whose inhabitants were not compelled to breathe the mephitic and poisonous atmosphere of the great centers where the poor suffocate and the rich languish. Near the doctor's balconies, there was more than one pear tree, whose fruits ripened in due time.

en: The summer light struck into the corner brilliantly in the earlier part of the day; but, when the streets grew hot, the corner was in shadow, though not in shadow so remote but that you could see beyond it into a glare of brightness. It was a cool spot, staid but cheerful, a wonderful place for echoes, and a very harbour from the raging streets.
vi: The summer sun shines on this corner of the street from early morning; but as the roads heat up, this corner remains in the shade, not so shaded as to be glaring when looking out into the sunlight. It is a cool, quiet yet cheerful place, a perfect spot for reminiscing; truly a haven away from the storms of the bustling city.
tr: In the early hours of the day, the rays of the summer sun would shine brightly on the corner; but when the streets heated up, a shadow would fall on the corner, though it wasn't a very dense shadow, you could see the brilliance just a bit further away. It was a cool corner, dignified yet cheerful, a wonderful place for the echoing of sounds, like a harbor to escape and take refuge from the angry streets.
es: The rays of the summer sun radiantly penetrated that delightful retreat in the early hours of the day, but when they burned, when they turned the other districts of the city into a scorching oven, the little corner remained enveloped in shadows, although these were not so deep that they couldn't be penetrated by the brilliant glows of a distant sun. It was, in a word, a cool, calm, and tranquil place, yet pleasant, a sheltered harbor against the roar and bustling agitation of the streets.

en: There ought to have been a tranquil bark in such an anchorage, and there was. The Doctor occupied two floors of a large stiff house, where several callings purported to be pursued by day, but whereof little was audible any day, and which was shunned by all of them at night. In a building at the back, attainable by a courtyard where a plane-tree rustled its green leaves, church-organs claimed to be made, and silver to be chased, and likewise gold to be beaten by some mysterious giant who had a golden arm starting out of the wall of the front hall—as if he had beaten himself precious, and menaced a similar conversion of all visitors. Very little of these trades, or of a lonely lodger rumoured to live up-stairs, or of a dim coach-trimming maker asserted to have a counting-house below, was ever heard or seen. Occasionally, a stray workman putting his coat on, traversed the hall, or a stranger peered about there, or a distant clink was heard across the courtyard, or a thump from the golden giant. These, however, were only the exceptions required to prove the rule that the sparrows in the plane-tree behind the house, and the echoes in the corner before it, had their own way from Sunday morning unto Saturday night.
vi: In such a harbor, there must be a ship peacefully anchored, and indeed there was. Dr. Manette's house occupied two floors in a large, solid building, surrounded during the day by many professional establishments that were almost silent, and at night, they all ceased operations. Across a courtyard rustling with the sound of elm leaves was a house with a shop inside that made church organs, silver engravings, and even gold leafing; on the wall of this house, right in front of the main door, instead of a sign, there was a large golden arm symbol, as if some mysterious giant inside had gilded his entire body and thrust his arm out to threaten to turn everyone passing by into precious metals. It was rare to see or hear the people working these trades, or the lodger rumored to live upstairs, or the dark-faced man who upholstered carriage seats and insisted he had a shop on the ground floor. Occasionally, a stray worker in a coat would pass through the hall, or a stranger would appear, occasionally there would be the faint clinking sound from across the courtyard, or the thumping of the golden giant. But these were just exceptions that proved the rule that from Sunday morning to Saturday night, this place was dominated by the birds in the elm trees behind the house and the quiet echoes from the street corner in front.
tr: There must have been a calm ship anchored in such a harbor, and indeed there was. The doctor had settled on the two floors of a large and quiet house; many visitors came and went throughout the day, but they made little noise, and at night, not a sound was heard. It was said that a church organ was being made, silver was being crafted, and gold was being hammered by a mysterious giant figure in a building at the back, reached through a courtyard with a plane tree rustling its green leaves; the man had hung a golden arm on the wall of the entrance hall as if he had forged himself out of gold, thus intimidating the visitors. No one had ever seen or heard of the solitary tenant said to live upstairs, or the thick-headed car decorator who was claimed to have an accounting office downstairs. Occasionally, a stray worker would don his jacket and pace from one corner of the courtyard to the other; sometimes a stranger would be seen, and sometimes there would be a clatter from somewhere beyond the courtyard or thumping sounds from the giant man hammering gold. But these were merely exceptions that emphasized the rule that the sparrows perched on the plane tree behind the house and the echoes heard from the corner dominated this place from Sunday morning to Saturday night.
es: An ideal anchorage was inconceivable without a tranquil boat, and indeed, it had one. The doctor occupied two floors of a rather spacious house, at whose doors many knocked during the night, requesting services to be rendered the following day. At the back of the house, separated from it by a courtyard in the center of which grew a wild banana tree, there was a building where church organs were manufactured, and a mysterious giant chiseled silver and hammered gold, whose powerful arm seemed to emerge from the wall, casting golden flashes, as if the arm itself were made of gold and threatened to turn into gold all those who visited that place. Hardly did these industries make the slightest noise, very rarely was a solitary visitor seen arriving, and even more rarely did a carriage cross those peaceful spots. It was true that from time to time a worker could be seen crossing the courtyard while putting on his jacket, or an unknown person drawn by curiosity, or the distant echo of a hammer blow from the golden giant would strike the ears, but these were the only exceptions, always necessary to prove the rule that this was the corner of echoes, the center of rest and silence, interrupted only by the chirping of sparrows that had their headquarters in the top of the wild banana tree.

en: Doctor Manette received such patients here as his old reputation, and its revival in the floating whispers of his story, brought him. His scientific knowledge, and his vigilance and skill in conducting ingenious experiments, brought him otherwise into moderate request, and he earned as much as he wanted.
vi: This is where Dr. Manette received a few patients who came to him due to his former reputation, which has now been restored thanks to rumors spreading about his imprisonment. His professional knowledge, along with his meticulousness and ability to conduct skillful experiments, also brought him more work, allowing him to make a living.
tr: Doctor Manette had gained many patients thanks to his old fame and the refreshing of this fame through a story passed from mouth to mouth. His scientific equipment and the caution and skill in his successful works also brought other patients to his door, allowing him to earn as much money as he wanted.
es: The doctor Manette received in his house the patients brought to him by his former reputation combined with the floating breezes of the painful history of his life. His scientific knowledge, his practice in the difficult exercise of his profession, and the ingenious experiments he engaged in, gave him a very enviable clientele and he earned more than enough to cover the necessities of life.

en: These things were within Mr. Jarvis Lorry’s knowledge, thoughts, and notice, when he rang the door-bell of the tranquil house in the corner, on the fine Sunday afternoon.
vi: Those understandings, thoughts, and observations occupied Mr. Jarvis Lorry's mind as he rang the doorbell of the quiet house at the corner of the street on this beautiful Sunday afternoon.
tr: Mr. Jarvis Lorry had these thoughts in mind when he knocked on the door of this quiet house on the corner on that beautiful Sunday.
es: All this was perfectly known to the good Mauricio Lorry when he pulled the chain hanging along the door, and set in motion the inhabitants of the quiet house located in the delightful little corner I just described, on a Sunday afternoon.

en: “Doctor Manette at home?”
vi: − Is Dr. Manette home?
tr: "Is Dr. Manette at home?"
es: —Is the doctor at home?

en: Expected home.
vi: He is about to come home. −
tr: He was going to arrive soon.
es: —No, sir.

en: “Miss Lucie at home?”
vi: Is Miss Lucie home?
tr: "Is Miss Lucie at home?"
es: —And Miss Lucía?

en: Expected home.
vi: She is about to come home.
tr: He/She was going to arrive soon.
es: —Neither.

en: “Miss Pross at home?”
vi: − Is Miss Pross home?
tr: "Well, is Miss Pross at home?"
es: —And Miss Pross?

en: Possibly at home, but of a certainty impossible for handmaid to anticipate intentions of Miss Pross, as to admission or denial of the fact.
vi: Probably, but the maid couldn't know Miss Pross's intentions, so she neither denied nor confirmed.
tr: Most likely, she was at home, but he couldn't decide whether Miss Pross would want it to be said that she was at home or not.
es: Probably the latter was at home, but since the maid who opened the door did not know what her intentions were regarding admitting or denying the fact, she also replied that she was not.

en: “As I am at home myself,” said Mr. Lorry, “I’ll go upstairs.”
vi: − Since this is like my home, I will go upstairs, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Well, since I'm here," said Mr. Lorry, "I'll go upstairs and take a look then."
es: —In any case, I'm going up—replied Lorry,—because I consider myself here as at home.

en: Although the Doctor’s daughter had known nothing of the country of her birth, she appeared to have innately derived from it that ability to make much of little means, which is one of its most useful and most agreeable characteristics. Simple as the furniture was, it was set off by so many little adornments, of no value but for their taste and fancy, that its effect was delightful. The disposition of everything in the rooms, from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours, the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as Mr. Lorry stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him, with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this time, whether he approved?
vi: Although the doctor's daughter knew nothing about her native country, she seemed to have inherently inherited from her father's homeland the ability to adapt maximally in minimal conditions - one of the most useful and best characteristics of the French people. The furniture in the house, though simple, was compensated by many small decorations that were not valuable but elegant and beautiful, making them very interesting. The arrangement of everything in the rooms, from the largest to the smallest items; the combination of colors, the subtle contrast and variety thanks to the clever use of inexpensive items, thanks to skillful hands, keen eyes, and aesthetic sense, were so attractive to the eye and revealed the person who created this setting to such an extent that, when Mr. Lorry looked around, it seemed as if even the tables and chairs were silently asking with the same distinctive expression as the wrinkles on Lucie's forehead, which he had become so familiar with: Are you satisfied?
tr: Although the Doctor's daughter knew nothing about the country she was born in, she seemed to have an innate ability to do a lot with the little she had, which was one of the most useful and pleasant characteristics of this country. The furniture was simple, but there were many decorative items around; they were not valuable, but the taste and elegance they reflected left a pleasant impression. The arrangement of the items in the rooms, from the largest to the smallest; the harmony of colors, the delicate variety of small items, and the contrasts they created revealed sensitive hands, tasteful eyes, and a refined appreciation; thus, everything looked very pleasant and also reflected the person who brought them together; so much so that as Mr. Lorry stood looking around, all those tables and chairs seemed to come to life, asking him whether he liked them with their familiar expressions that he had grown accustomed to.
es: Although the doctor's daughter learned nothing in her homeland, it is certain that it initiated her into that rare skill of doing much with scarce means, which was one of her most precious and pleasant characteristics. Modest and simple was the furniture in the house's rooms, and yet, some trinkets, which had no more real value than the exquisite taste with which they were placed, gave them a delightful effect. The arrangement of everything in the house, starting with the largest piece of furniture and ending with the most insignificant object, the combination of colors, and the contrast achieved thanks to trifles by delicate hands, clear-eyed gazes, and impeccable taste, offered such a pleasant ensemble in itself and portrayed its author so graphically, that it seemed as if, with a silent but eloquent language, they asked Mr. Lorry, while he gazed at them in rapture, if they deserved his approval.

en: There were three rooms on a floor, and, the doors by which they communicated being put open that the air might pass freely through them all, Mr. Lorry, smilingly observant of that fanciful resemblance which he detected all around him, walked from one to another. The first was the best room, and in it were Lucie’s birds, and flowers, and books, and desk, and work-table, and box of water-colours; the second was the Doctor’s consulting-room, used also as the dining-room; the third, changingly speckled by the rustle of the plane-tree in the yard, was the Doctor’s bedroom, and there, in a corner, stood the disused shoemaker’s bench and tray of tools, much as it had stood on the fifth floor of the dismal house by the wine-shop, in the suburb of Saint Antoine in Paris.
vi: Each floor of the house had three rooms, with the doors wide open to let the fresh air flow in, and as Mr. Lorry moved from room to room, he enjoyed noticing the similarity between the furniture and the owner that was evident all around. The first room was the most beautiful, containing Lucie's things like a birdcage, vases, books, a writing desk, a sewing table, and a watercolor box; the second room was the doctor's consultation room, which also doubled as the dining room; the third room was the doctor's bedroom, where sunlight spots continuously moved through the rustling plane tree branches outside the yard, and here, in one corner, was the shoemaker's bench and untouched tool tray, just as it was placed on the fifth floor of the eerie house next to the tavern in the outskirts of Saint Antoine in Paris.
tr: There were three rooms on one floor, and the doors connecting them were left open to allow air to pass through easily; Mr. Lorry watched this pleasant harmony surrounding him with a smile and walked from one room to another. The first room was the most beautiful, containing Lucie's birds, flowers, books, easel, desk, and watercolor sets; the second was the Doctor's consultation room, which also served as the dining room; the third room, with its dappled shadows shifting according to the rustling leaves of the plane tree in the courtyard, was the Doctor's bedroom. In one corner of this room stood the shoemaker's bench and tool box, now unused, just as they had stood on the fifth floor of the gloomy house next to the wine shop in a side street of St. Antoine in Paris.
es: The apartment had three main rooms, whose connecting doors were all open, so that the air could circulate through them like lords and masters. Lorry passed from one to another, smiling and pleased. In the first room, which was the best, Lucía had her birds, her books, a writing desk, and a sewing box, as well as a box of colors; the second room was the doctor's consultation room, which also served as a dining room, and the third room, near whose balconies the leaves of the wild plane tree growing in the courtyard whispered, was the doctor's bedroom, in one of whose corners Lorry saw the cobbler's bench and tools, just as they had once been in the attic of the tavern in the San Antonio neighborhood of Paris.

en: “I wonder,” said Mr. Lorry, pausing in his looking about, “that he keeps that reminder of his sufferings about him!”
vi: Staring at that bench, Mr. Lorry muttered to himself: − Why does he keep this? To remember those painful times?
tr: Mr. Lorry paused for a moment and said to himself, "Why does this man keep these items that remind him of his past sufferings?""
es: —It surprises me—murmured Lorry in a clear and intelligible voice—that he keeps these objects which must necessarily remind him of his sufferings and miseries.

en: “And why wonder at that?” was the abrupt inquiry that made him start.
vi: − Understand for what? - The sudden question startled him.
tr: "Why are you surprised?" came a reply, causing Mr. Lorry to startle.
es: —And why should it surprise you?—asked a brusque voice suddenly, causing him to turn around quickly.

en: It proceeded from Miss Pross, the wild red woman, strong of hand, whose acquaintance he had first made at the Royal George Hotel at Dover, and had since improved.
vi: It was the voice of Miss Pross, the strong-willed red-haired woman with powerful arms, whom he had first met at the Royal George Hotel in Dover, and had since become well acquainted with.
tr: This was the crazy Miss Pross with the very strong hands, whom he first met at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and later saw in other settings, with red hair.
es: The voice originated from Miss Pross's throat, who was the same red-faced, strong, and heavy-handed woman with whom Lorry became acquainted at the Hotel George in Dover.

en: “I should have thought—” Mr. Lorry began.
vi: − I thought... - Mr. Lorry began.
tr: "I should have guessed," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —I imagined...—Lorry began to say.

en: “Pooh! You’d have thought!” said Miss Pross; and Mr. Lorry left off.
vi: − Hush! Thought and nonsense! - Miss Pross exclaimed, and Mr. Lorry left his sentence unfinished. - How are you? -
tr: "Amen! He should have guessed!" said Miss Pross, and Mr. Lorry gave up continuing the conversation.
es: —It seemed to her... what?—replied Miss Pross.—Some nonsense, no doubt! Lorry did not answer.

en: “How do you do?” inquired that lady then—sharply, and yet as if to express that she bore him no malice.
vi: She continued, her tone gruff but clearly without any ill will towards him.
tr: "How are you?" the woman asked then – harshly but with an air that seemed to try to show she had no grudge against him.
es: —How are you?—asked the lady then, with a harsh voice, though without malice or intent to offend.

en: “I am pretty well, I thank you,” answered Mr. Lorry, with meekness; “how are you?”
vi: − Thank you, I am very well, - Mr. Lorry replied humbly, - and how are you? −
tr: "Thank you, I am quite well," replied Mr. Lorry in a feeble voice, "How are you?" he asked.
es: —Very well, thank you... and you?

en: “Nothing to boast of,” said Miss Pross.
vi: Fed up with life, - Miss Pross replied.
tr: "There is nothing noteworthy," said Miss Pross.
es: —As discontent as can be.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? − Oh!
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Is it possible?

en: “Ah! indeed!” said Miss Pross. “I am very much put out about my Ladybird.”
vi: Really! - Miss Pross said. - I am quite upset about our dear mistress here.
tr: "Ah! So!" said Miss Pross. "I am very worried about my little bird."
es: —And very possible! What happens with Miss Lucía drives me crazy.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? −
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Is it possible? —But man of God!

en: “For gracious sake say something else besides ‘indeed,’ or you’ll fidget me to death,” said Miss Pross: whose character (dissociated from stature) was shortness.
vi: For heaven's sake, say something other than “really,” it's driving me mad, - Miss Pross, tall in stature but short on patience, exclaimed. −
tr: "For God's sake, say something other than 'really' or I'll go mad," said Miss Pross; her character (unlike her stature) was somewhat stunted.
es: Haven't you learned more than those two words that you keep saying at every turn?

en: “Really, then?” said Mr. Lorry, as an amendment.
vi: Oh, is that so? - Mr. Lorry adjusted.
tr: "Shall I say it correctly then," Mr. Lorry corrected.
es: Is it possible!... A little variation, if you don't want to drive me completely crazy! —Really?—asked Lorry, correcting himself.

en: “Really, is bad enough,” returned Miss Pross, “but better. Yes, I am very much put out.”
vi: − “Is that so,” isn't much better, - Miss Pross replied, - but it's something. Yes, I am quite upset.
tr: "My health is not very good," replied Miss Pross, "but it is still better than the other one. Yes, I am very upset."
es: —It's not the happiest phrase, so to speak, but, in the end, it's better than his eternal "could it be possible." Well, yes, sir; what happens with the young lady drives me crazy.

en: “May I ask the cause?”
vi: − May I ask the reason?
tr: "May I ask the reason then?"
es: —Would it be indiscreet to ask the reason?

en: “I don’t want dozens of people who are not at all worthy of Ladybird, to come here looking after her,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − I don't like a dozen people who don't deserve the dear mistress coming here and gawking at her, - Miss Pross said.
tr: "I don't want dozens of people who are not worthy of her to come here to see her," said Miss Pross.
es: —It gets on my nerves that dozens of people who are not worthy of her come to see her.

en: “Do dozens come for that purpose?”
vi: − A dozen came to look around?
tr: "Are dozens of people coming to see him?"
es: —Dozens?—asked Lorry in amazement.

en: “Hundreds,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Hundreds, actually, - replied Miss Pross.
tr: "Hundreds!" said Miss Pross.
es: —Hundreds—replied Miss Pross, one of whose characteristics, which is often seen in many people, was to exaggerate the original statement if she noticed that someone was questioning it.

en: It was characteristic of this lady (as of some other people before her time and since) that whenever her original proposition was questioned, she exaggerated it.
vi: Like many others before and after, she had the habit of immediately exaggerating her claims when someone doubted them. − What a pity! -
tr: One characteristic of Miss Pross (as with many people before and after her) was that when a word she said was scrutinized, she would exaggerate it.
es: —Hundreds—replied Miss Pross, one of whose characteristics, which is often seen in many people, was to exaggerate the original statement if she noticed that someone was questioning it.

en: “Dear me!” said Mr. Lorry, as the safest remark he could think of.
vi: That was the safest remark Mr. Lorry could think of.
tr: "Phooey!" said Mr. Lorry, this was the safest word that came to his mind.
es: —Good heavens!—exclaimed Lorry, who couldn't think of a more appropriate response.

en: “I have lived with the darling—or the darling has lived with me, and paid me for it; which she certainly should never have done, you may take your affidavit, if I could have afforded to keep either myself or her for nothing—since she was ten years old. And it’s really very hard,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − I have lived with the mistress... - Miss Pross rambled on, - or rather the mistress has lived with me since she was ten and paid me to live; truly, the mistress should never have paid me, I swear to you, if only I could support myself or support the mistress without needing a salary. It's truly a pity!
tr: "I have been living with my little one since he was ten years old, or rather, my little one has been living with me since he was ten and he pays me for it; actually, he shouldn't have to do that, I have tried to manage both myself and him all this time. This is really very hard," said Miss Pross.
es: —Since the young lady was ten years old, I have lived with her... or she has lived with me, and she has paid me, which I would never have allowed, rest assured, if I had found the secret of taking care of myself and her for nothing. Oh! It is truly painful!

en: Not seeing with precision what was very hard, Mr. Lorry shook his head; using that important part of himself as a sort of fairy cloak that would fit anything.
vi: Not exactly understanding what was so pitiable, Mr. Lorry shook his head, using that important body part as a magical mask capable of expressing all emotions.
tr: Even though Mr. Lorry did not fully understand what the difficult thing was, he shook his head from side to side, as if he were using this important part of his body like a kind of magical cloak that fits every situation.
es: Lorry, not clearly seeing what could be painful, limited himself to shaking his head, using that part of his person as the most suitable cover to hide everything. —At all hours, countless people who are not worthy of my treasure, Mr. Lorry, hover around him.

en: “All sorts of people who are not in the least degree worthy of the pet, are always turning up,” said Miss Pross. “When you began it—”
vi: − A whole bunch of people who are not worthy at all of my dear mistress keep showing up, - said Miss Pross. - Ever since you caused the trouble... − I caused the trouble, Miss Pross? −
tr: "There are a lot of people around my beautiful child who are not her equals," said Miss Pross. "When you started this..."
es: No, they are not, not by a long shot! When you started the parade...

en: “I began it, Miss Pross?”
vi: - Ever since you caused the trouble... − I caused the trouble, Miss Pross? −
tr: "Did I start this, Miss Pross?"
es: —Did I start it, Miss Pross?

en: “Didn’t you? Who brought her father to life?”
vi: Who else? Who brought her father back to life? −
tr: "Didn't you start it?" "Who brought his father back to life?""
es: —Of course! Who took his father out of the grave?

en: “Oh! If that was beginning it—” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: Oh! If that trouble was caused by me then... - said Mr. Lorry. −
tr: "Ha! If this is what started it," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —If that was the beginning...

en: “It wasn’t ending it, I suppose? I say, when you began it, it was hard enough; not that I have any fault to find with Doctor Manette, except that he is not worthy of such a daughter, which is no imputation on him, for it was not to be expected that anybody should be, under any circumstances. But it really is doubly and trebly hard to have crowds and multitudes of people turning up after him (I could have forgiven him), to take Ladybird’s affections away from me.”
vi: Then it hasn't ended yet, is that what you mean? I'm telling you, when you caused the trouble, it was already bad enough; I'm not blaming Dr. Manette, it's just that he doesn't deserve to have such a daughter, and it's not his fault either, because in this situation, how could anyone know who deserves what. But it's twice, three times as bad when crowds of people keep coming to see the doctor; well, I can overlook him; just to try to take away my dear mistress.
tr: "This wasn't the end, was it? I mean, when you started this job, it was already hard enough; I'm not saying anything about finding Doctor Manette, of course, but such a daughter is not worthy of him, in my opinion. Still, I'm not blaming her because, under these circumstances, no one can be expected to be guilty. But for people to come to the Doctor in droves (I could forgive her for that) and try to steal my little bird's love from me is unbearable."
es: —I suppose you do not mean to say that was the end of it... I repeat that when the parade began, it was already quite unpleasant. And note that it is not my intention to say that Dr. Manette is to blame, in whom I see no other fault than not being worthy of having a daughter like the one he has, and that is not attributable to him, since there is no person in the world who is worthy of it. I might have been able to forgive the father, but admit that it is horribly painful to see crowds and swarms of people constantly moving around the father and stealing the affection of the daughter from me.

en: Mr. Lorry knew Miss Pross to be very jealous, but he also knew her by this time to be, beneath the service of her eccentricity, one of those unselfish creatures—found only among women—who will, for pure love and admiration, bind themselves willing slaves, to youth when they have lost it, to beauty that they never had, to accomplishments that they were never fortunate enough to gain, to bright hopes that never shone upon their own sombre lives. He knew enough of the world to know that there is nothing in it better than the faithful service of the heart; so rendered and so free from any mercenary taint, he had such an exalted respect for it, that in the retributive arrangements made by his own mind—we all make such arrangements, more or less—he stationed Miss Pross much nearer to the lower Angels than many ladies immeasurably better got up both by Nature and Art, who had balances at Tellson’s.
vi: Mr. Lorry knew that Miss Pross had a very jealous nature, but by now he also understood that beneath this peculiar exterior was a person who was not at all selfish—a trait seen only in women—who, out of love and admiration, would willingly become a slave to the youth she had lost, to the beauty she never had, to the achievements she unfortunately never attained, to the bright hopes that never once shone into her own dreary life. He understood life well enough to know that nothing surpasses the loyal service that comes from the heart, dedicated and free from any self-interest, to the extent that he had to respect Miss Pross, and in the mental hierarchy of respect he silently arranged in his mind—as we all do to some extent—he awarded her a position close to the angels, far above many ladies of superior social standing, education, and with money deposited at Tellson's Bank.
tr: Mr. Lorry knew how jealous Miss Pross could be, but he also knew the self-sacrificing creature that lay beneath all that eccentricity – a type only seen among women; these individuals would attach themselves with pure love and admiration, like slaves, to the youth they had lost, the beauty they never possessed, the skills they were never fortunate enough to acquire, and the bright hopes that would never shine upon their own gloomy lives. Mr. Lorry was worldly enough to know that there was nothing better than this loyal service given from the heart; he knew it was free from any material gain, and he held these individuals in great respect, so much so that in the vengeful plans he concocted in his mind – we all concoct these plans to some extent – he placed Miss Pross in much more favorable positions compared to those ladies who had accounts at Tellson's Bank and were abundantly endowed by both Nature and Art.
es: Lorry knew that Miss Pross was the embodiment of jealousy, but at the same time, he was aware that, aside from her eccentricities, she was at the forefront of those pure beings devoid of all selfishness who, driven by motives of affection and admiration, willingly offer their necks to the chain of slavery, ready to sacrifice themselves for a youth they have lost, a beauty they never possessed, gifts and perfections they never had the fortune to attain, and hopeful dreams that never shed a ray of light on their somber lives. Lorry had a sufficiently perfect understanding of the world to know that nothing compares to the faithful and selfless services that reside in the heart, and consequently, Miss Pross's services earned his highest respect. In the mental classifications he made, for no one fails to make them, in greater or lesser numbers, he placed the red-haired and efficient lady much closer to the last rung of the angels than to many ladies who were incomparably better endowed than she, both by Nature and by Art, and who, in addition, possessed capitals deposited in the vaults of Tellson's Bank.

en: “There never was, nor will be, but one man worthy of Ladybird,” said Miss Pross; “and that was my brother Solomon, if he hadn’t made a mistake in life.”
vi: − Before or after, it has always been the same, there is only one person worthy of the dear mistress, - said Miss Pross. - That is my brother Solomon, if only his life had not made mistakes.
tr: "No one has ever been worthy of my little bird, nor will anyone ever be, except for one person," said Miss Pross; "and that was my brother Solomon, but he made the mistake of his life."
es: —There has never been, nor will there ever be, a man worthy of the young lady—said Miss Pross. —That man was my brother Solomon... if he hadn't had a little slip in life.

en: Here again: Mr. Lorry’s inquiries into Miss Pross’s personal history had established the fact that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who had stripped her of everything she possessed, as a stake to speculate with, and had abandoned her in her poverty for evermore, with no touch of compunction. Miss Pross’s fidelity of belief in Solomon (deducting a mere trifle for this slight mistake) was quite a serious matter with Mr. Lorry, and had its weight in his good opinion of her.
vi: Additionally, Mr. Lorry had investigated Miss Pross's past and confirmed that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who had stripped her of all her assets to fund his speculations, leaving her to live in poverty for the rest of her life without a hint of remorse. Because Miss Pross had unwavering faith in Solomon (considering his small mistakes as trivial matters), Mr. Lorry respected and always thought well of her.
tr: The issue was this: as Mr. Lorry questioned Miss Pross, it became clear that her brother Solomon was a heartless scoundrel who squandered her possessions in gambling and left her in perpetual poverty without any remorse. Mr. Lorry was deeply affected by the strength of Miss Pross's faith in Solomon (seeing his minor mistake as a small flaw), and her value in his eyes increased significantly.
es: An observation: the investigations carried out by Lorry regarding Miss Pross's personal history had resulted in the discovery and verification of the fact that her brother Solomon was a miserable scoundrel who stole everything she owned under the pretext of speculating and trading, then left her abandoned in her misery without a shred of remorse. The high opinion that Miss Pross had of her brother, despite his small slip, was a source of profound admiration for Mr. Lorry and contributed to greatly increasing the respect he felt for her.

en: “As we happen to be alone for the moment, and are both people of business,” he said, when they had got back to the drawing-room and had sat down there in friendly relations, “let me ask you—does the Doctor, in talking with Lucie, never refer to the shoemaking time, yet?”
vi: − Now that it's just you and me, and we are both people of business, - he said as they returned to the living room and sat down for a friendly chat. - I ask you... does the doctor, when talking to Lucie, ever mention the time he spent making shoes?
tr: When they went to the living room and sat down facing each other, Mr. Lorry said, "Now that we are alone and both of us are doing business here, with your permission, I will ask you a question – Doctor, when talking to Lucie, does he ever mention the days he spent making shoes?"
es: —Since we find ourselves alone at this moment, and we are both business people—said Lorry when, moments later, they had both sat down in the parlor,—I will allow myself to ask you a question: In the conversations that the doctor has with his daughter, does he ever refer to the times when he made shoes?

en: “Never.”
vi: − Never. −
tr: "Never.""
es: —Never.

en: “And yet keeps that bench and those tools beside him?”
vi: Does he still keep the bench and tools by his side?
tr: "But he still keeps his old bench and tools."
es: —And yet, he keeps the stool and the tools of the trade in his room.

en: “Ah!” returned Miss Pross, shaking her head. “But I don’t say he don’t refer to it within himself.”
vi: − Oh! - Miss Pross shook her head as she replied. - But I don't mean to say that he doesn't silently remind himself of it. −
tr: "Ah!" said Miss Pross, shaking her head. "I didn't say she had forgotten those days, though."
es: —I have said that he never talks about it with his daughter—replied Miss Pross,—but I will be very careful not to assert that he does not talk to himself about it.

en: “Do you believe that he thinks of it much?”
vi: Do you think he dwells on it a lot?
tr: "Do you think he often thinks about those days?"
es: —Do you think he/she thinks about it often?

en: “I do,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Yes, - Miss Pross replied. −
tr: "I think he's thinking," said Miss Pross.
es: —Yes.

en: “Do you imagine—” Mr. Lorry had begun, when Miss Pross took him up short with:
vi: Do you imagine that... - Mr. Lorry had just started speaking when Miss Pross interrupted him. − Again with the imagination!
tr: Mr. Lorry had just begun to say, "Well, imagine that..." when Miss Pross interrupted him.
es: —Can you imagine?...

en: “Never imagine anything. Have no imagination at all.”
vi: I never imagine anything at all.
tr: "Never dream. Never have an imagination."
es: —I never imagine!—exclaimed Miss Pross, interrupting her interlocutor. —I have no imagination, nor do I need it.

en: “I stand corrected; do you suppose—you go so far as to suppose, sometimes?”
vi: − I was wrong; so do you suppose that... well, surely you must suppose something occasionally?
tr: - "Well, let me correct myself; do you think –you probably have no objection to thinking?"
es: —I will correct myself... Do you suppose... do you sometimes go so far as to suppose?

en: “Now and then,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Occasionally, - said Miss Pross. −
tr: "It can happen from time to time," said Miss Pross.
es: —From time to time, yes.

en: “Do you suppose,” Mr. Lorry went on, with a laughing twinkle in his bright eye, as it looked kindly at her, “that Doctor Manette has any theory of his own, preserved through all those years, relative to the cause of his being so oppressed; perhaps, even to the name of his oppressor?”
vi: Do you suppose, - Mr. Lorry continued, his eyes sparkling with joy as he looked at her appreciatively, - that Dr. Manette knows something about the reason for his oppression, perhaps even the name of his oppressor, and has kept it secret all these years?
tr: Mr. Lorry continued, turning his gaze, which was shining with a cheerful glow, affectionately towards Miss Pross. "Do you think that Dr. Manette has any idea about the reason for the suffering he endured for so many years, or perhaps even knows the name of the tyrant who brought him to this state?"
es: —Well then, do you suppose that Dr. Manette harbors any suspicion... or certainty, that has survived his past miseries, about the cause, the motives of his misfortune? Do you perhaps suppose that he even suspects or knows who his oppressor was?

en: “I don’t suppose anything about it but what Ladybird tells me.”
vi: − I don't suppose anything about this, but my dear mistress has told me the same thing.
tr: "Sanmam, ama yavru kuşumun dediğine göre..."
es: —I don't assume anything more than what the young lady tells me.

en: “And that is—?”
vi: − Meaning...? −
tr: "What is he/she saying?""
es: —And the young lady says...

en: “That she thinks he has.”
vi: Meaning she thinks he knows.
tr: "He thinks his father knows.""
es: —That he believes his father suspects or knows.

en: “Now don’t be angry at my asking all these questions; because I am a mere dull man of business, and you are a woman of business.”
vi: − Don't get angry when I ask these questions; because I am just a clumsy worker, while you are the one who truly knows the job.
tr: "Don't be mad at me for asking these things; after all, I'm a thick-headed businessman, and you're such a businesswoman.""
es: —Don't get upset if I ask you these questions. I am a businessman, quite obtuse, and you are a businesswoman.

en: “Dull?” Miss Pross inquired, with placidity.
vi: − Clumsy? - Miss Pross calmly asked again.
tr: "Thick-headed?" asked Miss Pross calmly.
es: —Obtuse?—inquired Miss Pross.

en: Rather wishing his modest adjective away, Mr. Lorry replied, “No, no, no. Surely not. To return to business:—Is it not remarkable that Doctor Manette, unquestionably innocent of any crime as we are all well assured he is, should never touch upon that question? I will not say with me, though he had business relations with me many years ago, and we are now intimate; I will say with the fair daughter to whom he is so devotedly attached, and who is so devotedly attached to him? Believe me, Miss Pross, I don’t approach the topic with you, out of curiosity, but out of zealous interest.”
vi: − No, no, no, - Mr. Lorry wanted to erase that humble adjective. - Certainly not. Alright, let's get back to work... Are you surprised that Dr. Manette never mentioned it, when it's clear that he didn't commit any crime, as we all surely know? It's not necessary for the doctor to tell me even though he and I have had a working relationship for many years and are now friends; I mean, to tell his beloved daughter whom he loves very much and who also loves him dearly? Trust me, Miss Pross, I bring this up not out of curiosity but out of deep concern for the doctor. −
tr: Mr. Lorry responded, trying to dismiss this modest adjective, "No, no. Of course not. Returning to our matter, don't you find it strange that Doctor Manette, whom we all undoubtedly agree is innocent, has never brought up this subject? Despite having a professional relationship years ago and being quite close now, he hasn't mentioned it to me, let alone to his beautiful daughter, to whom he is deeply attached with mutual affection. Believe me, Miss Pross, the reason I'm bringing this up is not curiosity, but genuine concern."
es: —No, no, no!—replied Lorry. —You are not obtuse at all! But returning to the matter, allow me to ask: isn't it strange, incomprehensible, that Dr. Manette, innocent of any crime as we all know, always avoids touching on that issue with such care? And it's not that I am surprised he doesn't bring it up with me, even though we had frequent business relations years ago and today we share a close friendship, but I am amazed that he doesn't talk about it with his daughter, who loves him so much and whom he adores... Believe me, Miss Pross, it is not curiosity that dictates my words, but the deep affection I feel for the inhabitants of this house.

en: “Well! To the best of my understanding, and bad’s the best, you’ll tell me,” said Miss Pross, softened by the tone of the apology, “he is afraid of the whole subject.”
vi: Well! The thing I know best, though not much, listening to you, - Miss Pross lowered her voice as if to justify, - is that the doctor is afraid of the whole matter.
tr: "Beautiful! As far as I understand, as far as my mind comprehends," said Miss Pross, softened by Mr. Lorry's conciliatory manner of speaking, "the Doctor is afraid of this matter."
es: —Well then, as I believe... and when I believe something, I usually get close to reality, keep that silence that so amazes you because you are afraid to talk about the matter.

en: “Afraid?”
vi: − Afraid? −
tr: "Is he/she/it scared?"
es: —Fear?

en: “It’s plain enough, I should think, why he may be. It’s a dreadful remembrance. Besides that, his loss of himself grew out of it. Not knowing how he lost himself, or how he recovered himself, he may never feel certain of not losing himself again. That alone wouldn’t make the subject pleasant, I should think.”
vi: It's understandable, I think so. It's a terribly horrifying reminder. Moreover, he lost his memory because of it. Not knowing how he lost his memory, nor how he regained it, perhaps he isn't sure that he won't lose it again. Just that alone is already quite unsettling, I think so.
tr: "I think this is a very understandable situation. He has a terrible past. Moreover, he lost his memory because of this. Since he doesn't know how he lost his memory or how he recovered it, one can't even be sure that he won't lose it again. Just this alone is an annoying situation in my opinion."
es: —It is clear as day, and I also find the fear very justified. They are horrifying memories, not only because of what he suffered, but also because in his suffering his intelligence was shipwrecked. Since he does not know how and when he lost it, and how and when he regained it, it is natural that he fears losing it again. As you can understand, this consideration alone would be enough to make talking about the matter unpleasant for him.

en: It was a profounder remark than Mr. Lorry had looked for. “True,” said he, “and fearful to reflect upon. Yet, a doubt lurks in my mind, Miss Pross, whether it is good for Doctor Manette to have that suppression always shut up within him. Indeed, it is this doubt and the uneasiness it sometimes causes me that has led me to our present confidence.”
vi: An insightful comment beyond Mr. Lorry's expectations. He said: − That's right, and afraid to think about the past. But in my heart, I feel worried, Miss Pross, not knowing if it's good for Dr. Manette to always keep things hidden and not speak out. Honestly, it's because of this worry that I often feel uneasy, so now I'm telling you. −
tr: This was a deeper comment than Mr. Lorry had expected. "True," said Mr. Lorry, "it's terrifying even to think about it. Still, I am not at ease, Miss Pross, I am not sure how right it is for Doctor Manette to suppress all these troubles within himself. In fact, the reason I brought up this matter to you is because of this doubt and unease within me."
es: —It's true—replied Lorry, who was satisfied with the deep observation of his interlocutor. —Out of necessity, it must inspire fear in him to speak of his ordeal... However, Miss Pross, I very much doubt that it is good for his peace of mind to keep such dreadful memories buried deep in his heart, and these doubts, and the unease they often cause me, are precisely what have led me to provoke these confidences.

en: “Can’t be helped,” said Miss Pross, shaking her head. “Touch that string, and he instantly changes for the worse. Better leave it alone. In short, must leave it alone, like or no like. Sometimes, he gets up in the dead of the night, and will be heard, by us overhead there, walking up and down, walking up and down, in his room. Ladybird has learnt to know then that his mind is walking up and down, walking up and down, in his old prison. She hurries to him, and they go on together, walking up and down, walking up and down, until he is composed. But he never says a word of the true reason of his restlessness, to her, and she finds it best not to hint at it to him. In silence they go walking up and down together, walking up and down together, till her love and company have brought him to himself.”
vi: That's the way it is, Miss Pross said while shaking her head. - Touching on that matter makes him turn pale and almost sick. It's best to leave it alone. In short, it must be left alone, whether we like it or not. Sometimes in the middle of the night, he wakes up and we hear him upstairs pacing back and forth, back and forth in his room. Her dear mistress knows that her father's mind is pacing back and forth, back and forth in the old prison. She hurriedly runs up, and then the father and daughter pace back and forth, back and forth together until he calms down. But he did not say a word to his daughter about the reason for his unease, and she thought it best not to bring it up with him. The two people kept walking back and forth with each other, walking back and forth with each other, until her love and companionship calmed him down.
tr: Miss Pross, shaking her head from side to side, said, "There is nothing to be done." "The moment you push a little, it gets worse. The best thing is to leave him alone. In short, whether we like it or not, we must leave him alone. Sometimes in the middle of the night, he gets out of bed, and we hear him above us, pacing back and forth, back and forth in his room. My little bird then understands that her father, in his mind, is pacing back and forth, back and forth in his prison cell. She immediately runs to her father's side, and then the two of them continue to walk back and forth in the room together, until her father calms down. But he doesn't say a word to his daughter about the real reason for his restlessness, and his daughter doesn't even touch on the subject. In silence, they go back and forth, back and forth together, until the Doctor regains his composure with his daughter's love and support."
es: —Evil, if it truly is evil, has no remedy—replied Miss Pross, shaking her head. —Touch that string, and the results will be counterproductive; so, it is better to remain silent. How many times, in the late hours of the night, he jumps out of bed and begins to pace agitatedly, up and down, up and down, through his room! Miss knows by now that when this happens, her father's imagination is pacing up and down, up and down, through the dungeon that served as his tomb for so many years. She then runs to her father's room and, standing by his side, paces with him up and down, up and down, until she is convinced he has calmed down. But the doctor never explains the cause of his unrest, and his daughter never asks him. The two of them pace together up and down, up and down, without uttering a word, until the presence of his daughter, and the blind love she has for him, bring the doctor back to himself.

en: Notwithstanding Miss Pross’s denial of her own imagination, there was a perception of the pain of being monotonously haunted by one sad idea, in her repetition of the phrase, walking up and down, which testified to her possessing such a thing.
vi: No matter how much Miss Pross denied her own imagination, the sense of suffering of someone endlessly tormented by a sorrowful event was revealed in the way she repeated the phrase "going back and forth," proving that she was not devoid of imagination.
tr: Although Miss Pross claimed she lacked the ability to imagine, her constant repetition of the words "up and down" revealed that she was in a state of pain that endlessly accompanied a certain sorrowful thought, which actually indicated that she did possess imagination.
es: Miss Pross had denied that she had any imagination, but the evidence that a sad idea haunted her gave the lie to her assertion, evidence highlighted by the repetition of the phrase "up and down," as there was no doubt that it was a fixed idea.

en: The corner has been mentioned as a wonderful corner for echoes; it had begun to echo so resoundingly to the tread of coming feet, that it seemed as though the very mention of that weary pacing to and fro had set it going.
vi: As mentioned above, this street corner is a wonderful place for reminiscing; this place has started to echo with approaching footsteps, as if resonating with the weary rhythm that Miss Pross just described.
tr: It had been mentioned that the sounds echoed wonderfully in the corner where the house was located; now, as if even the words "walking up and down" had started the echo, approaching footsteps were heard.
es: The doctor's house seemed like the house of echoes. At the mention of the doctor's agitated nocturnal walks, the sound of approaching footsteps responded, and to these, the end of the conference.

en: “Here they are!” said Miss Pross, rising to break up the conference; “and now we shall have hundreds of people pretty soon!”
vi: − They're back! - Miss Pross said, standing up to interrupt the conversation. - Now we'll see a hundred people coming right away!
tr: "Here they come!" said Miss Pross, who had stood up to pause their conversation; "soon hundreds of people will crowd in here!"
es: —They are here!—exclaimed Miss Pross, standing up quickly. —It won't be long before people arrive at this house by the hundreds.

en: It was such a curious corner in its acoustical properties, such a peculiar Ear of a place, that as Mr. Lorry stood at the open window, looking for the father and daughter whose steps he heard, he fancied they would never approach. Not only would the echoes die away, as though the steps had gone; but, echoes of other steps that never came would be heard in their stead, and would die away for good when they seemed close at hand. However, father and daughter did at last appear, and Miss Pross was ready at the street door to receive them.
vi: This street corner has a peculiar acoustic feature, like an eardrum amplifying every sound to the point where Mr. Lorry, standing at the open window, heard the footsteps of the father and daughter but couldn't find them, thinking they would never arrive. The echoes not only faded as the footsteps went away but were followed by echoes of other footsteps that never arrived, and just when it seemed the footsteps were near, the echoes would die out forever. But finally, the father and daughter appeared, and Miss Pross was already standing at the front door to welcome them in.
tr: It was a rather peculiar and privileged corner with its acoustic properties. In this place that resembled the inside of an ear, Mr. Lorry stood in front of the open window, looking at the father and daughter whose footsteps he heard, feeling as if they would never reach there. With the fading of the footsteps, not only did the echoes fade away; the echoes of other invisible footsteps came in their place, and as they approached, the others completely disappeared. The father and daughter finally appeared, and Miss Pross immediately ran to the door to greet them.
es: Such marvelous acoustic conditions were gathered in that house that it could very well have been called the ear of the district. Lorry, who was leaning out the window and could perfectly hear the sound of the father and daughter's footsteps, thought they would never arrive. Not only did the echoes of the approaching footsteps reach him, but also many others that faded away just when they seemed closest. Finally, the doctor appeared, giving his arm to his daughter, and they were received at the door of the house by Miss Pross.

en: Miss Pross was a pleasant sight, albeit wild, and red, and grim, taking off her darling’s bonnet when she came up-stairs, and touching it up with the ends of her handkerchief, and blowing the dust off it, and folding her mantle ready for laying by, and smoothing her rich hair with as much pride as she could possibly have taken in her own hair if she had been the vainest and handsomest of women. Her darling was a pleasant sight too, embracing her and thanking her, and protesting against her taking so much trouble for her—which last she only dared to do playfully, or Miss Pross, sorely hurt, would have retired to her own chamber and cried. The Doctor was a pleasant sight too, looking on at them, and telling Miss Pross how she spoilt Lucie, in accents and with eyes that had as much spoiling in them as Miss Pross had, and would have had more if it were possible. Mr. Lorry was a pleasant sight too, beaming at all this in his little wig, and thanking his bachelor stars for having lighted him in his declining years to a Home. But, no Hundreds of people came to see the sights, and Mr. Lorry looked in vain for the fulfilment of Miss Pross’s prediction.
vi: Ms. Pross looked fierce, aggressive, and intense, but she was truly endearing when she removed Lucie's bonnet as her beloved mistress went upstairs, then she dusted the bonnet with a few handkerchiefs, placed Lucie's cloak aside, and brushed Lucie's magnificent hair with utmost pride as if it were her own hair and she were the most beautiful and proud woman in the world. Equally endearing was the sight of Lucie hugging her caretaker to thank her and then playfully protesting that she had gone to too much trouble for her beloved mistress - Lucie only dared to protest in a playful manner, otherwise Ms. Pross would be hurt and retreat to her room to cry. The doctor also seemed pleased as he watched the scene and told Ms. Pross that she spoiled Lucie too much, with a tone and look that were just as indulgent as the caretaker's, and if he could, he would spoil her even more. Mr. Lorry was also pleased, his face brightening under his wig, and he silently thanked his single fate in his later years for leading him to find a family. But not seeing hundreds of people flocking to gawk, Mr. Lorry waited in vain and did not see Ms. Pross's prediction come true.
tr: Although Miss Pross was a crazy, red-haired, surly woman, she looked very pleasant when her dear little one came upstairs, as she took off her hat, dusted it with the corner of her handkerchief, folded her cloak and put it aside, and arranged her thick hair with great pride as if it were her own and as if she were the most arrogant and beautiful woman in the world. Her dear little one also looked very pleasant as she hugged Miss Pross, thanked her, and said she was sorry for causing her so much trouble. The young girl had said her last words half-jokingly, otherwise Miss Pross would have been terribly upset, locked herself in her room, and cried. The doctor also looked very pleasant as he watched them and told Miss Pross how much she spoiled Lucie. However, at that moment, both his speech and his eyes were at least as indulgent as Miss Pross's, and if possible, he would have spoiled her even more. Mr. Lorry, with his small wig on his head, also looked very pleasant as he watched all this with laughing eyes and thanked his fortune for providing a Home that illuminated his world at this advanced age. But not hundreds of people had come to see these beauties, and Mr. Lorry looked around in vain to see if Miss Pross's prediction would come true.
es: It was charming to see Miss Pross, despite her ugliness, her bright red color, and her frowning expression, hurrying to take off her lady's hat as she climbed the stairs; how, to avoid staining it, she wrapped her fingers with a handkerchief, how she tried to remove the dust by blowing on it, how she fluffed her splendid blonde hair with as much pride and satisfaction as she would have done with her own, assuming she had been the most beautiful and vain woman in creation. It was also charming to see the lady hugging her maid, thanking her and protesting against so much attention and work, though protesting with a smile on her lips, for if she did not, Miss Pross, deeply hurt, would have retired to her room to spend the day crying. It was no less charming to see the doctor gazing at them with rapture and to hear him tell Miss Pross that she was spoiling Lucie with so much attention and care, but with such a sweet tone and tender look that it was enough, and even more than enough, to spoil Miss Pross and a hundred more like her, and finally, it was also charming to see Mr. Lorry adjusting his wig and mentally thanking his lucky star that, if it made him a confirmed bachelor, it allowed him to glimpse, in his old age, the pure joys of a home. Everything was charming, but the hundreds of people who were supposed to revolve around Lucie were nowhere to be seen, and Mr. Lorry waited in vain for Miss Pross's prophecy to come true.

en: Dinner-time, and still no Hundreds of people. In the arrangements of the little household, Miss Pross took charge of the lower regions, and always acquitted herself marvellously. Her dinners, of a very modest quality, were so well cooked and so well served, and so neat in their contrivances, half English and half French, that nothing could be better. Miss Pross’s friendship being of the thoroughly practical kind, she had ravaged Soho and the adjacent provinces, in search of impoverished French, who, tempted by shillings and half-crowns, would impart culinary mysteries to her. From these decayed sons and daughters of Gaul, she had acquired such wonderful arts, that the woman and girl who formed the staff of domestics regarded her as quite a Sorceress, or Cinderella’s Godmother: who would send out for a fowl, a rabbit, a vegetable or two from the garden, and change them into anything she pleased.
vi: It's mealtime, yet no groups or classes are arriving. In the organization of this small family, the kitchen work was the responsibility of Miss Pross, and she managed it perfectly single-handedly. Although not luxurious, the meals she cooked were very skillful and beautifully presented, consisting of very delicately prepared dishes, half English and half French, extremely delicious. Very practically, Miss Pross expressed her affection through her cooking skills; she scoured Soho and the surrounding areas in search of poor French immigrants and, with shillings and half-crowns, persuaded them to share their cooking secrets. From these sons and daughters of Gaul, she learned wonderful cooking tips to the extent that the two maids, one old and one young, in the house viewed her as nothing less than a witch or the fairy godmother of Cinderella - who would send them to fetch a chicken, a rabbit, or some vegetables from the garden and transform them into anything at will.
tr: Dinner time had arrived, but there were still hundreds of people missing.
