It is not possible that any of the fortunate mortals who attended the fortnightly reception given by the lord in the year seventeen eighty would question the durability of a system founded on such a solid base as an exquisitely combed, artistically curled, solicitously powdered executioner, adorned with a rich gold-braided frock coat and exquisite silk stockings.

en: Monseigneur having eased his four men of their burdens and taken his chocolate, caused the doors of the Holiest of Holiests to be thrown open, and issued forth. Then, what submission, what cringing and fawning, what servility, what abject humiliation! As to bowing down in body and spirit, nothing in that way was left for Heaven—which may have been one among other reasons why the worshippers of Monseigneur never troubled it.
vi: Having finished his chocolate and relieved of his burden by four servants, the Lord ordered all doors of the most sacred places to be opened and then stepped out. Thus, everyone scrambled to prostrate, scrambled to fawn and flatter; scrambled to grovel; such shameful degradation! With such spiritual and physical subservience, there was no room left for Heaven - perhaps this was one of the reasons why the devotees of the Lord did not bother to think about it.
tr: Monseigneur, after drinking his hot chocolate and relieving his four servants from their distress, stood up and ordered the doors of the holiest of holies room to be opened. What obedience, what flattery, what sycophancy, what lack of pride, and what miserable humiliation it was! When the body and soul bend this much, there was nothing left to reach Heaven – this must have been one reason why those who worshipped Monseigneur did not mind it.
es: Once the lord relieved his four servants of their respective burdens and took the chocolate, he ordered the doors of his sanctuary to be flung wide open and deigned to step outside. What submission, what cringing flattery, what servility, what humiliations, carried to the most inconceivable limits of the abject! Suffice it to say that in all matters concerning idolatry and self-annihilation, those who filled the halls reserved nothing for the heavens. It is true that thoughts of the afterlife concerned the lord's worshippers very little!

en: Bestowing a word of promise here and a smile there, a whisper on one happy slave and a wave of the hand on another, Monseigneur affably passed through his rooms to the remote region of the Circumference of Truth. There, Monseigneur turned, and came back again, and so in due course of time got himself shut up in his sanctuary by the chocolate sprites, and was seen no more.
vi: Dispensing promises here, smiles there, condescendingly whispering to some happy slave, then graciously waving to another sycophant, the Lord cheerfully walked through the outer rooms to the farthest area of the Outer Edge of Truth. Upon reaching here, the Lord turned around and finally retreated to his sanctuary among the chocolate goblins, and no one saw him again.
tr: The Monsignor passed gently through his rooms, making promises to some, smiling at others, whispering something to a happy slave, and waving to another, until he reached the farthest area. He went to the Circle of Truth. At that point, the Monsignor turned around and came back, then shut himself in his temple with the chocolate fairies and was never seen again.
es: Uttering a word here and dropping a hope there, directing a smile at this one and making a hand gesture to that one, the gentleman crossed the halls until he surpassed the limits of the circumference of truth, where he majestically turned on his sacred heels and retraced his steps, to return and enclose himself in his sanctuary.

en: The show being over, the flutter in the air became quite a little storm, and the precious little bells went ringing downstairs. There was soon but one person left of all the crowd, and he, with his hat under his arm and his snuff-box in his hand, slowly passed among the mirrors on his way out.
vi: The show was over, the light breeze had turned into a storm as the precious little bells jingled down the stairs. In no time, the whole group was reduced to one person, and this person, with a hat tucked under their arm and a snuffbox in hand, slowly walked past the mirrors and headed outside.
tr: With the end of the show, the turbulence in the air had turned into a mild storm, and the precious little bells had started ringing downstairs. Soon, only one person remained from that crowd, and he too, with his hat under his arm and a snuffbox in his hand, slowly made his way out among the mirrors.
es: Once the exhibition ended, the whispers that barely touched the air turned into a clamorous storm. The tinkling of the jewels, similar to the incessant ringing of precious little bells, faded away, and very soon only one person remained in sight, a gentleman, who, with his hat under his arm and holding a snuffbox in his hand, amused himself by walking calmly and leisurely, stopping in front of the mirrors he encountered along the way.

en: “I devote you,” said this person, stopping at the last door on his way, and turning in the direction of the sanctuary, “to the Devil!”
vi: This person stopped at the last door on the way out and turned towards the sanctuary, uttering a sentence: − May demons and devils take you away!
tr: Stopping in front of the last door on his way, he looked towards the temple and said, "I consign you to the Devil!"
es: —Take hell with you!—he murmured before leaving, his eyes turned towards the sanctuary door, shaking off the snuff that remained between his fingers.

en: With that, he shook the snuff from his fingers as if he had shaken the dust from his feet, and quietly walked downstairs.
vi: After saying this, he shook off the snuff powder from his fingers as if shaking off the dust from his feet, then quietly descended the stairs.
tr: Then, as if shaking off the dust from his feet, he quietly descended the stairs, shaking the snuff from his fingers.
es: —Take hell with you!—he murmured before leaving, his eyes turned towards the sanctuary door, shaking off the snuff that remained between his fingers.

en: He was a man of about sixty, handsomely dressed, haughty in manner, and with a face like a fine mask. A face of a transparent paleness; every feature in it clearly defined; one set expression on it. The nose, beautifully formed otherwise, was very slightly pinched at the top of each nostril. In those two compressions, or dints, the only little change that the face ever showed, resided. They persisted in changing colour sometimes, and they would be occasionally dilated and contracted by something like a faint pulsation; then, they gave a look of treachery, and cruelty, to the whole countenance. Examined with attention, its capacity of helping such a look was to be found in the line of the mouth, and the lines of the orbits of the eyes, being much too horizontal and thin; still, in the effect of the face made, it was a handsome face, and a remarkable one.
vi: He was around sixty years old, dressed elegantly, with an arrogant demeanor and a face like a finely crafted mask. His face was pale, almost translucent, with well-proportioned and expressive features. Although his nose was delicate, it flared slightly at the nostrils. Only at the flared nostrils did his face reveal any hint of changing emotions. At times, that area would change color, occasionally contracting and expanding as if something was gently pulsing; during those moments, the tip of his nose gave his entire face an air of treachery and cruelty. Upon closer inspection, this expression was accentuated by his overly thin and flat mouth and eyes; nevertheless, the overall impression of his face remained extraordinarily beautiful.
tr: He was a man in his sixties, elegantly dressed, with arrogant manners, and a face that resembled a delicate mask. There was a transparent pallor to his face; all his features were distinct and his expression was stern. His nose had a very beautiful shape, but it was slightly flattened over the nostrils. The only thing that altered the expression on the man's face were these two flattened points, these two depressions. Sometimes they would change color persistently, sometimes they would expand and contract like a faint pulse; then they would impart a treacherous and cruel expression to the entire face. Upon close inspection, it could be seen that the source of this expression was his mouth, which appeared as a line due to being overly horizontal and thin, and his half-closed eyes; yet his face had a pleasant and striking air.
es: He was a man of about sixty years, richly dressed, with haughty gestures and expression, and endowed with a face that, more than a human countenance, seemed like a fine mask. A face of transparent pallor, all its lines, all its features appeared perfectly defined. The nose, artistically shaped, had the peculiarity that its two nostrils showed a very slight contraction towards the upper part. In those two contractions lay, precisely, the only visible alteration in that face. The nostrils sometimes remained contracted, while on some occasions, dilations followed contractions, but in either case, they gave the face an unpleasant expression of cruelty and perfidy. Upon careful examination of that face, it was not difficult to observe that the expression of cruelty was due to the lines of his mouth and the excessively fine and horizontal eye sockets. It cannot be denied, however, that that face was extraordinarily beautiful.

en: Its owner went downstairs into the courtyard, got into his carriage, and drove away. Not many people had talked with him at the reception; he had stood in a little space apart, and Monseigneur might have been warmer in his manner. It appeared, under the circumstances, rather agreeable to him to see the common people dispersed before his horses, and often barely escaping from being run down. His man drove as if he were charging an enemy, and the furious recklessness of the man brought no check into the face, or to the lips, of the master. The complaint had sometimes made itself audible, even in that deaf city and dumb age, that, in the narrow streets without footways, the fierce patrician custom of hard driving endangered and maimed the mere vulgar in a barbarous manner. But, few cared enough for that to think of it a second time, and, in this matter, as in all others, the common wretches were left to get out of their difficulties as they could.
vi: The owner of that face descended the stairs, went out to the yard, got into the carriage, and set off. During the reception, few people talked to him; he stood somewhat aloof, and the Lord's attitude towards him was not warm at all. In this situation, he seemed more interested in the scene of commoners scattering in panic in front of the horses pulling the carriage, often narrowly escaping disaster. His coachman whipped the horses forward as if attacking an enemy, and that reckless, frenzied driving did not cause the owner's face or lips to change color in the slightest. At that time, in this deaf and mute capital, one occasionally heard complaints about the aggressive nobility accustomed to racing their carriages down narrow, sidewalk-less streets, endangering and injuring the common folk without a hint of compassion. But few cared to think twice about it, and in this matter, as in all others, the suffering commoners were left to fend for themselves.
tr: The owner of the face came down and went out into the courtyard, got into his car, and left. Not many people at the reception had spoken to him; he had stood in a corner away from everyone; in fact, the Monsignor could have been warmer towards him. He didn't seem to see anything wrong in people scattering in front of his car and narrowly escaping being run over. The driver was driving the car as if he were chasing an enemy, and this angry indifference of his did not cause any reaction on the face or lips of the gentleman sitting in the back. Even in this deaf city and this mute era, from time to time, complaints were heard in the narrow streets without sidewalks that this harsh driving habit of the wild nobles cruelly endangered and maimed the common people. But very few people paid attention to this situation, and as in many other matters, the miserable populace had to fend for themselves in the face of difficulties.
es: Its owner descended the palace stairs and went out to the vestibule, where his carriage was waiting for him. Few had spoken to him during the reception, and the gentleman could have been more affectionate than he was when he arrived at the place where he remained withdrawn and separated from the groups. Without stopping for a moment, he got into his carriage, and the horses set off at a gallop, scattering the people they encountered along the way. The coachman drove as if he were charging against an enemy army, without his master thinking to curb the coachman's reckless fury, which, far from angering him, seemed rather to please him. Sometimes, very rarely, complaints had been voiced, even in that insensitive city and in that age of ignorance and idiocy, against the barbaric custom of galloping through narrow, sidewalk-less streets, without regard for the unfortunate people who were often run over, but no one deigned to give a second of attention to such trifles, and in this matter, as in many others, the wretched lower class was left free to deal with the difficulty as best they could.

en: With a wild rattle and clatter, and an inhuman abandonment of consideration not easy to be understood in these days, the carriage dashed through streets and swept round corners, with women screaming before it, and men clutching each other and clutching children out of its way. At last, swooping at a street corner by a fountain, one of its wheels came to a sickening little jolt, and there was a loud cry from a number of voices, and the horses reared and plunged.
vi: Racing madly like a lunatic, disregarding all propriety in a brutal manner that people nowadays cannot comprehend, the carriage sped through the streets, dashed around corners, crashed into screaming women, into men grappling with each other, and swiftly pulled children away. Finally, as the carriage charged into a corner by the fountain, one wheel suddenly jerked up in a terrifying manner, followed by the loud cries of many people and the horses rearing up wildly.
tr: With a crazy clatter and a ruthless thoughtlessness that is hard to understand nowadays, the car passed through many streets and turned corners, with women screaming and running away in front of it, and men clinging to both each other and their children as they fled. Finally, as it turned a corner near a fountain, the wheels jolted slightly in an annoying way and screams rose from the crowd, the horses reared up and lunged forward.
es: With deafening noise and inhuman disregard for the most sacred considerations, difficult to comprehend in our days, the carriage flew down the street, bouncing over the cobblestones and turning corners with inconceivable speed, scaring away the women, who screamed in terror, the children, who ran like frightened rabbits, and the men who tried to stick to the walls. At the moment the carriage turned a corner near a fountain, one of the wheels jumped, hundreds of throats let out a scream, and the horses reared and backed up.

en: But for the latter inconvenience, the carriage probably would not have stopped; carriages were often known to drive on, and leave their wounded behind, and why not? But the frightened valet had got down in a hurry, and there were twenty hands at the horses’ bridles.
vi: If the horses do not stop, this carriage will not stop; usually, the carriage just keeps running, leaving the injured person behind, so why should it stop? But the servant hastily got off the carriage and twenty hands held the horse reins tightly.
tr: But a car would not be stopped for such a problem; cars always went on like this and left the injured behind, there was no reason for the opposite. But the frightened servant got out of the car in a hurry; twenty hands had reached for the reins of the horses.
es: It is almost certain that the carriage would have continued its unperturbed, reckless race if it hadn't been for this last inconvenience, as it was what carriages used to do in that happy era, even if they left the street strewn with corpses, why would they do otherwise? But the frightened footman had jumped to the ground and twenty hands grabbed the horses' reins at once.

en: “What has gone wrong?” said Monsieur, calmly looking out.
vi: − What happened? - The official calmly looked outside.
tr: "What's the problem?" asked Monsieur calmly, looking outside.
es: —What's happening?—asked the gentleman, poking his calm face through the door.

en: A tall man in a nightcap had caught up a bundle from among the feet of the horses, and had laid it on the basement of the fountain, and was down in the mud and wet, howling over it like a wild animal.
vi: A tall man wearing a hat had just lifted a bundle wrapped in cloth from under the horses' feet and placed it on the fountain's pedestal, then sat down heavily in the mud, howling like a wild beast.
tr: A tall man with a nightcap on his head had picked up the pile that had fallen between the horses' legs and placed it at the base of the fountain. Now, covered in mud and soaking wet, he was howling like a wild animal.
es: A tall man, with a cap on his head, had taken a bundle from between the horses' legs, which he placed on the base of a fountain, and leaning over it, howled like a wild animal.

en: “Pardon, Monsieur the Marquis!” said a ragged and submissive man, “it is a child.”
vi: − Excuse me, Marquis! - A ragged man said humbly. - Yes, a child. −
tr: "Sorry, Monsieur Marquis!" said a shabbily dressed and obedient man, "it's a child."
es: —Excuse me, Mr. Marquis—said a ragged individual with a humble voice and demeanor,—it's a child.

en: “Why does he make that abominable noise? Is it his child?”
vi: Why is that kid screaming so terribly? Is it his child?
tr: "Why is this man making such disgusting noises?" "Is that his child?""
es: —And why is he making that deafening noise? You say it's a child?

en: “Excuse me, Monsieur the Marquis—it is a pity—yes.”
vi: − Excuse me, Marquis! - It's really unfortunate... yes, that's right.
tr: "Excuse me, Monsieur Marquis –unfortunately– yes."
es: —Excuse me, Mr. Marquis... It is a... shame... yes, that's it.

en: The fountain was a little removed; for the street opened, where it was, into a space some ten or twelve yards square. As the tall man suddenly got up from the ground, and came running at the carriage, Monsieur the Marquis clapped his hand for an instant on his sword-hilt.
vi: The fountain is located a bit away from the road because the road here leads into an open space of about ten or twelve square meters. When the tall man stood up and rushed towards the carriage, the Marquis immediately grasped the hilt of his sword.
tr: The fountain was a little further; the street opened into a small square. When the tall man suddenly got up from the ground and started running towards the carriage, Monsieur Marquis immediately reached for the hilt of his sword.
es: The fountain was a few yards away. The tall man who was leaning over the bundle suddenly straightened up and ran hurriedly towards the carriage, causing the Marquis to place his hand on the hilt of his sword.

en: “Killed!” shrieked the man, in wild desperation, extending both arms at their length above his head, and staring at him. “Dead!”
vi: − It's dead! - This person screamed, in desperate frenzy, raising both arms straight above his head and glaring at the nobleman. - Dead!
tr: Adam, in a terrible desperation, with his hands raised in the air, his eyes fixed on the man, was shouting, "You killed him!" "He's dead!"
es: —Dead!—roared the tall man with signs of savage despair, fixing his eyes on the Marquis and raising both arms. —Murdered!

en: The people closed round, and looked at Monsieur the Marquis. There was nothing revealed by the many eyes that looked at him but watchfulness and eagerness; there was no visible menacing or anger. Neither did the people say anything; after the first cry, they had been silent, and they remained so. The voice of the submissive man who had spoken, was flat and tame in its extreme submission. Monsieur the Marquis ran his eyes over them all, as if they had been mere rats come out of their holes.
vi: The crowd gathered closer, looking at the Marquis. The wide-open eyes revealed nothing more than caution and eagerness; there was no sign of threat or anger. They didn't say a word either; after the initial outcry, everything fell silent and remained so. The voice of the obsequious person who spoke earlier sounded awkward and bland with the utmost servility. The Marquis rolled his eyes at the crowd as if they were a bunch of rats that had just crawled out of their holes.
tr: A crowd of people had gathered around. They were looking at Monsieur Marquis. There was great curiosity and excitement in all their eyes, but not the slightest hint of threat or anger. They weren't saying anything either; after the first shout, they had fallen silent and hadn't made a sound since. The voice of the obedient man speaking to the Marquis had come out in a very monotonous and docile manner, in the most obedient way possible. Monsieur Marquis turned his eyes and looked at them as if they were mice that had come out of their holes.
es: The crowds gathered around the carriage. All eyes were focused on the person of the Marquis, but in them, nothing could be read but anxiety, fear, no anger or threat. Everyone was silent. After the first shout, an imposing silence followed. The voice of the one who had spoken to the magnate remained extremely submissive. The Marquis cast his eyes over the huddled groups, regarding them with the indifference with which he would have looked at a herd of frightened rats.

en: He took out his purse.
vi: He took out his wallet.
tr: He took out his wallet.
es: Without changing his stance, he took out a pocket.

en: “It is extraordinary to me,” said he, “that you people cannot take care of yourselves and your children. One or the other of you is for ever in the way. How do I know what injury you have done my horses. See! Give him that.”
vi: − I am very surprised, - the Marquis said, - your people do not know how to take care of themselves and their children. You keep getting in my way, one after another. I wonder if any of you have injured my horses. Here! Give it to that one.
tr: "How is it," he said, "that you can't take care of yourselves and your children, I just don't understand. Someone always gets in our way. Who knows how much my horses have been harmed? Look! Give that to him."
es: —It surprises me greatly—he said—that you can't even take care of your own children. Frequently, you cross my path in a way that cannot help but be bothersome to me. Don't you realize that your recklessness could harm my horses? Come on!... Give him this!

en: He threw out a gold coin for the valet to pick up, and all the heads craned forward that all the eyes might look down at it as it fell. The tall man called out again with a most unearthly cry, “Dead!”
vi: He tossed a gold coin for the servant to pick up, and all heads turned to watch where the coin would roll. The tall man let out another boundless, mournful scream: "Dead!"
tr: He threw a gold coin to the child, and all heads turned to follow the coin as it fell to the ground. The tall man let out an incredible scream again, "He's dead!"
es: Accompanying the action with the word, he threw a gold coin at the lackey's feet. —Dead... murdered!—the tall man shouted again.

en: He was arrested by the quick arrival of another man, for whom the rest made way. On seeing him, the miserable creature fell upon his shoulder, sobbing and crying, and pointing to the fountain, where some women were stooping over the motionless bundle, and moving gently about it. They were as silent, however, as the men.
vi: He fell silent as the crowd parted for a quick-footed person to approach. Seeing this person, the wretched man buried his head on the newcomer's shoulder and sobbed, pointing towards the fountain, where several women were crouching and gently moving around the motionless bundle of cloth. But they were as silent as the men.
tr: Everyone quickly made way for a man approaching him. The poor man, upon seeing him, rested his head on his shoulder and began to sob uncontrollably, while also pointing to the fountain over which the women were bending motionlessly and moving around with compassion. The women were as silent as the men.
es: Another man arrived at that moment, to whom everyone made way. The one who had just shouted fell into his arms as soon as he saw him, remaining there for a long time, crying and sobbing.

en: “I know all, I know all,” said the last comer. “Be a brave man, my Gaspard! It is better for the poor little plaything to die so, than to live. It has died in a moment without pain. Could it have lived an hour as happily?”
vi: − I know, I know everything, - the newcomer said. - Be brave, Gaspard! It's better that the poor boy died than lived. He died instantly without any pain. Even if he had lived another hour, he wouldn't have been as happy as this.
tr: "I know it all, I know it all," said the last man who arrived. "Be brave, Gaspard! It is better for that poor little child to die than to live. He died in an instant without suffering at all. If he had lived, would he have had a moment of happiness?"
es: —I know everything... I know everything—said the newcomer. —Courage, Gaspar! It is preferable to die as the child did than to live the life that awaited him. He died without pain, without suffering, and on the other hand, had he continued living, those would have relentlessly pursued him.

en: “You are a philosopher, you there,” said the Marquis, smiling. “How do they call you?”
vi: − You there, you truly are a philosopher, - the Marquis said with a smile. - What's your name?
tr: "Hey you, you are a philosopher," said the Marquis with a smile, "What is your name?"" "They call him Defarge.""
es: —You are a philosopher—said the Marquis, smiling. — What is your name?

en: “They call me Defarge.”
vi: − My name is Defarge. −
tr: "They call him Defarge.""
es: —Defarge.

en: “Of what trade?”
vi: What do you do?
tr: "What do you do?"
es: —What is your occupation?

en: “Monsieur the Marquis, vendor of wine.”
vi: − Sir Marquis, I run a tavern. −
tr: "I am selling wine, Monsieur Marquis."
es: —I am a wine seller, Mr. Marquis.

en: “Pick up that, philosopher and vendor of wine,” said the Marquis, throwing him another gold coin, “and spend it as you will. The horses there; are they right?”
vi: Take this, philosopher tavern keeper, - the Marquis said as he threw another gold coin to the man, - spend it as you wish. Are the horses alright?
tr: Throwing another gold coin, "Philosopher and wine seller, here, take this," he said, "and spend it as you wish. How are the horses? Are they well?"
es: —Take this, philosopher and wine seller, and spend it as you please—replied the Marquis, throwing another gold coin at his feet. — Let's see! Are the horses ready?

en: Without deigning to look at the assemblage a second time, Monsieur the Marquis leaned back in his seat, and was just being driven away with the air of a gentleman who had accidentally broke some common thing, and had paid for it, and could afford to pay for it; when his ease was suddenly disturbed by a coin flying into his carriage, and ringing on its floor.
vi: Without bothering to look back at the crowd gathering there for a second time, the Marquis leaned back in his seat; he had just been driven away by carriage with the nonchalance of a gentleman who had accidentally damaged an item, paid for it, and had plenty of money to spare, when a coin flew into the carriage and clattered onto the floor.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, without bothering to look at the crowd once more, leaned back and was leaving with the air of a gentleman who had accidentally broken something ordinary and paid for it, having the means to do so, when his mood was spoiled by the coin tossed into the carriage, which was jingling on the floor.
es: Without deigning to look at the crowds a second time, the Marquis settled back into his seat. The carriage began to move again and its happy occupant had forgotten the incident, as if he had just broken a trinket and paid for it, when his Olympian serenity was disturbed by the violent entry of a gold coin into the interior of the carriage.

en: “Hold!” said Monsieur the Marquis. “Hold the horses! Who threw that?”
vi: − Stop! - The Marquis exclaimed. - Stop the horses! Who threw that?
tr: "Stop!" said Monsieur Marquis. "Stop the horses!" "Who threw this?""
es: —Stop!—shouted the Marquis. —Stop the horses!... Who threw this?

en: He looked to the spot where Defarge the vendor of wine had stood, a moment before; but the wretched father was grovelling on his face on the pavement in that spot, and the figure that stood beside him was the figure of a dark stout woman, knitting.
vi: He looked back to where the innkeeper Defarge had been standing a moment ago, but now in that spot was the wretched father with his face buried in the pavement, and behind him stood a dark-skinned woman knitting. −
tr: The wine seller looked at the spot where Defarge had stood a minute ago, but at that exact spot, the wretched father was now throwing himself to the ground in despair, and right next to him was a dark-haired, stout woman knitting.
es: He looked angrily at the spot where he had just left Defarge, but saw nothing more than the unfortunate father embracing the corpse of his son, and a woman standing, who was looking at him with a frown.

en: “You dogs!” said the Marquis, but smoothly, and with an unchanged front, except as to the spots on his nose: “I would ride over any of you very willingly, and exterminate you from the earth. If I knew which rascal threw at the carriage, and if that brigand were sufficiently near it, he should be crushed under the wheels.”
vi: You dog! - The Marquis said indifferently, his face unchanged except for a point at the tip of his nose. - I am more than willing to run over any of you and wipe you all off the face of this earth. If I knew which scoundrel threw the money into the carriage and if that rascal were nearby, he would be crushed under these wheels.
tr: "You dogs!" said the Marquis, but in a soft tone, with no change in his face except for the spots on his nose. "I would crush you all with great pleasure and send you to the other world. If I knew which scoundrel threw this at the carriage and if he were near this miserable carriage, we would have run over him by now."
es: —Dogs!—murmured the Marquis. —I would gladly run over all of you to rid the world of your disgusting presence! If I knew who the scoundrel was that threw the coin, and had him close enough, by God, I would crush him under the wheels of my carriage!

en: So cowed was their condition, and so long and hard their experience of what such a man could do to them, within the law and beyond it, that not a voice, or a hand, or even an eye was raised. Among the men, not one. But the woman who stood knitting looked up steadily, and looked the Marquis in the face. It was not for his dignity to notice it; his contemptuous eyes passed over her, and over all the other rats; and he leaned back in his seat again, and gave the word “Go on!”
vi: Fully aware of their lowly status and having long known the suffering that a high-ranking official could inflict upon them, regardless of the law, no voice was raised, no hand was lifted, and not even a single glance was directed upwards. Not a single man among them. But the woman knitting continued to stare directly at the Marquis. The dignity of the high official did not allow him to notice this; the Marquis's contemptuous gaze swept past her, past all those rats; then he leaned back in his seat and uttered a word: "Move on!"
tr: People had been so suppressed and had known for so long what such a man could do to them within and beyond the laws and the difficulties of it that no one could raise their voice, hand, or even their eyes. Not a single man among them moved. But the woman who was knitting persistently looked up, and the place she was looking at was the face of the Marquis. The Marquis could not tolerate the fact that he noticed these glances; after casting his disdainful eyes over the woman and the other mice, he leaned back again and said, "Continue!"
es: Such was the fear of the mobs, so great the horror they felt for what men of the Marquis's social class could do to them, within and outside the law, that not a voice, nor a hand, nor a glance was raised. All the men remained silent, their eyes fixed on the ground. Only the woman we referred to earlier dared to fix her angry gaze on the Marquis, who did not even notice her. His lofty gaze passed over her head and over the other rats, and comfortably settled on the plush cushions of his carriage, he ordered the coachman to continue the journey.

en: He was driven on, and other carriages came whirling by in quick succession; the Minister, the State-Projector, the Farmer-General, the Doctor, the Lawyer, the Ecclesiastic, the Grand Opera, the Comedy, the whole Fancy Ball in a bright continuous flow, came whirling by. The rats had crept out of their holes to look on, and they remained looking on for hours; soldiers and police often passing between them and the spectacle, and making a barrier behind which they slunk, and through which they peeped. The father had long ago taken up his bundle and bidden himself away with it, when the women who had tended the bundle while it lay on the base of the fountain, sat there watching the running of the water and the rolling of the Fancy Ball—when the one woman who had stood conspicuous, knitting, still knitted on with the steadfastness of Fate. The water of the fountain ran, the swift river ran, the day ran into evening, so much life in the city ran into death according to rule, time and tide waited for no man, the rats were sleeping close together in their dark holes again, the Fancy Ball was lighted up at supper, all things ran their course.
vi: The carriage moved again and other carriages rushed forward in a convoy behind; the minister's carriage, the advisor's carriage, the tax collector's carriage, the doctor's carriage, the lawyer's carriage, the church's carriage, the theater troupe's carriage, the colorful masquerade procession all rushed past continuously. The rats had crawled out of their holes to watch, and continued to watch for hours; soldiers and police often stood between the rats and the spectacular procession, but the rats still peeked through the gaps in the human fence. The father had long since disappeared with the bundle of cloth; the women who had tended to the bundle while it lay on the fountain's pedestal now sat there watching the water flow and the masquerade procession pass by; all the while, only the knitting woman remained standing, knitting openly, her hands moving swiftly like an unchanging fate. The fountain's water kept flowing; the river kept rushing; the day quickly turned into night, countless lives in this city rushed towards death according to the law, time waited for no one, the rats huddled together to sleep in the dark holes, the masquerade procession became vibrant again at dinner time, everything proceeded as usual.
tr: The car started moving and other cars quickly followed; the Minister, the Planner, the Tax Collector, the Doctor, the Lawyer, the Priest, the Grand Opera and Comedy, and the guests of the Masquerade Ball were shining brightly as they sped along in the cars chasing one another. To see them, the mice had come out of their holes and had been watching for hours; the soldiers and police mingling with the crowd in these cars were secretly observing them from behind the barrier they had formed. The father had already taken his small pile and retreated to a corner; the women who had been bending over and looking at the pile under the fountain were now sitting and watching both the flow of water and the guests coming out of the Masquerade Ball – the only woman knitting with the determination of Fate was still knitting, standing out from everyone else. The water of the fountain was flowing, the water of the river was flowing, the day was turning into night, and many lives in the city were heading towards death as per the order, time and seasons were waiting for no one, the mice had retreated to their dark holes and were sleeping huddled together, while the Masquerade Ball was shining brightly at dinner, everything was flowing in its own course.
es: Through the same place, many other carriages crossed in a frenzied race and rapid succession. The one of the minister, the one of the state arbiters, the one of the general overseer, the one of the doctor, the one of the lawyer, the one of the clergyman. The rats timidly poked their heads out at the entrance of their holes. The father, who had been left without a son, withdrew; the rats retreated to the depths of their holes, and on the base of the fountain, there remained only the woman who had dared to look sternly at the Marquis, rigid as Fate. The water of the fountain flowed murmuring, the waters of the river ran fast and turbulent, the day was running to its end, the life of the city was running to death driven by Time, which waits for no one, the rats were already sleeping in their dark holes, the dance of extravagance continued among lights and dinners, and all things, to put it once and for all, continued their course.

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: The fountain's water kept flowing; the river kept rushing; the day quickly turned into night, countless lives in this city rushed towards death according to the law, time waited for no one, the rats huddled together to sleep in the dark holes, the masquerade procession became vibrant again at dinner time, everything proceeded as usual.
tr: VIII
es: VIII.

en: Monseigneur in the Country
vi: The high official in the countryside
tr: Monseigneur in the Village
es: THE LORD IN THE FIELD

en: A beautiful landscape, with the corn bright in it, but not abundant. Patches of poor rye where corn should have been, patches of poor peas and beans, patches of most coarse vegetable substitutes for wheat. On inanimate nature, as on the men and women who cultivated it, a prevalent tendency towards an appearance of vegetating unwillingly—a dejected disposition to give up, and wither away.
vi: The beautiful scenery was dotted with bright but sparse crops. Many fields that should have been planted with grains were instead planted with poor-quality rye, many fields with various kinds of poor-quality beans, and many fields with the worst kinds of vegetables replacing wheat. Like the men, the women who were farming, these insentient beings all exuded an air of being forced to live, forced to exist - a weary intention of wanting to give up and wither away.
tr: It was a beautiful view, the corn was shining, but there wasn't much of it. In places where there should have been corn, there were barren fields of rye, peas, and beans, and instead of wheat, there were fields of poor vegetables stretching out. This soulless nature had reflected on the people who cultivated it, as if they were planting and harvesting everything reluctantly – they were in a state of indifference, ready to give up and fade away at any moment.
es: A charming landscape, where wheat fields can be seen, although not abundant. Pieces of land sown with rye where wheat could have been grown, pieces sown with beans and peas, pieces sown with vegetables of all kinds, and it is that inanimate nature, harmonizing its tastes with those of humanity, showed a decided tendency towards vegetation that was more apparent than real.

en: Monsieur the Marquis in his travelling carriage (which might have been lighter), conducted by four post-horses and two postilions, fagged up a steep hill. A blush on the countenance of Monsieur the Marquis was no impeachment of his high breeding; it was not from within; it was occasioned by an external circumstance beyond his control—the setting sun.
vi: The Marquis sat in the carriage drawn by four horses with two coachmen laboriously climbing a steep hill (the carriage should have been lighter). The reddish hue on the Marquis's face did not betray his noble lineage; it did not come from within but was due to an external factor beyond his control - the setting sun.
tr: Monsieur the Marquis was climbing a steep hill in a traveling carriage (which could have been lighter) driven by four horses and two drivers. The redness on Monsieur the Marquis's face was not due to anything about himself, that is, not because he doubted his good upbringing, but from an external source beyond his control – the setting sun.
es: The travel carriage of the Marquis, which, by the way, could have been less heavy, drawn by four horses and guided by two postilions, was laboriously climbing a steep hill. The high color of the nobleman's cheeks did not argue against his high lineage. Its origin was not internal, but rather the effect of an unavoidable external circumstance: the sunset.

en: The sunset struck so brilliantly into the travelling carriage when it gained the hill-top, that its occupant was steeped in crimson. “It will die out,” said Monsieur the Marquis, glancing at his hands, “directly.”
vi: The twilight sun shone on the carriage as it rolled up the dazzling hill, so bright that it dyed the people inside the carriage a fiery red. The Marquis glanced at his hands and exclaimed: − The sun will set soon.
tr: As the car approached the top of the hill, the evening sun hit the inside of the car so strongly that the passenger inside turned completely red. "It's about to set," said Monsieur Marquis, looking at his hands, "very soon."
es: The tangential rays of the sun penetrated the travel coach of the Marquis, enveloping him in halos of reddish light. —Soon it will be ready—exclaimed Mr. Marquis, looking at his hands with disgust.

en: In effect, the sun was so low that it dipped at the moment. When the heavy drag had been adjusted to the wheel, and the carriage slid down hill, with a cinderous smell, in a cloud of dust, the red glow departed quickly; the sun and the Marquis going down together, there was no glow left when the drag was taken off.
vi: Indeed, at that moment, the sun was about to set. As the heavy brake was attached to the wheel and the carriage slid down the hill, that fiery red light quickly faded into the smell of scorched sunlight, into the cloud of dust; the sun disappeared at the same time the Marquis descended the hill and the twilight glow extinguished when the brake was removed from the wheel.
tr: Indeed, the sun had descended so low that it set at that very moment. When heavy chocks were placed on the wheels of the carriage and it began to slowly slide downhill in a cloud of ash and dust, the surrounding redness also disappeared; it was as if the sun and Monsieur Marquis had set together, for when the chocks were removed, not a trace of redness remained.
es: Indeed, the sun was so close to its setting that it soon went down. Having reached the top of the hill and with the heavy brakes applied to the wheels, as soon as the carriage began to roll down the slope, enveloped in clouds of dust, the reddish gleams faded: the sun and the Marquis were descending.

en: But, there remained a broken country, bold and open, a little village at the bottom of the hill, a broad sweep and rise beyond it, a church-tower, a windmill, a forest for the chase, and a crag with a fortress on it used as a prison. Round upon all these darkening objects as the night drew on, the Marquis looked, with the air of one who was coming near home.
vi: But there still remains a countryside with rolling hills stretching far, a small village at the foot of the hill, a wide piece of land and a hill behind, a church bell tower, a windmill, a forest for hunting, a cliff with a fortress used as a prison. The marquis glanced around at everything darkening as night fell here, with a contented expression like someone about to return to his home.
tr: At the foot of the hill, in a vast and disordered stretch of countryside, there was a small village; a little beyond this flat area, a church tower, a windmill, a grove for hunting, and a rocky outcrop with a castle used as a prison on its summit were rising. Mr. Marquis looked at all these objects, darkening as night fell, with the air of a man approaching his home.
es: Before the eyes of the Marquis stretched a broken territory, a village at the bottom of the hollow, a plain that ended in a hillock, a bell tower, a windmill, a forest abundant in game, and a fortress perched on the edge of a cliff. The Marquis gazed at all the detailed objects, whose lines began to blur in the shadows of the night, with the expression of someone approaching their home.

en: The village had its one poor street, with its poor brewery, poor tannery, poor tavern, poor stable-yard for relays of post-horses, poor fountain, all usual poor appointments. It had its poor people too. All its people were poor, and many of them were sitting at their doors, shredding spare onions and the like for supper, while many were at the fountain, washing leaves, and grasses, and any such small yieldings of the earth that could be eaten. Expressive signs of what made them poor, were not wanting; the tax for the state, the tax for the church, the tax for the lord, tax local and tax general, were to be paid here and to be paid there, according to solemn inscription in the little village, until the wonder was, that there was any village left unswallowed.
vi: The village had a poor road, with a poor brewery, a poor tannery, a poor inn, a poor relay station for changing carriage horses, a poor fountain, and all the familiar poor amenities. The village also had poor people. All the villagers were poor, many sitting in front of their doors, chopping the rare onions and similar items for dinner, while many others sat around the fountain washing vegetables and any meager produce that could be harvested from the land. Everywhere one looked, the cause of their poverty was evident; taxes for the state, taxes for the church, taxes for the officials, taxes for the local authorities, and taxes for the nation, having to pay here and there, according to the solemn instructions recorded in this small village, to the extent that one must wonder if there is any village not consumed by taxes.
tr: In the village, there was a bad street where everything was bad: a bad brewery, a bad tannery, a bad restaurant, a bad stable where the postal horses were changed, and a bad fountain. The people were also in bad condition. They were all poor, and many of them were sitting in front of their houses, chopping thin onions and similar things for dinner, while some were at the fountain washing the leaves and various herbs they had gathered that were edible. Everywhere bore the poignant traces of the things that impoverished them; according to the magnificent inscription in this small village, taxes to the state, the church, the king, local and general taxes would be paid until there was not a single village left unplundered.
es: The village had a poor street, a poor brewery, a poor tannery, a poor tavern, a poor post relay, and a poor fountain. Since all the services were poor, the inhabitants had to be poor, and indeed they were poor. They all lived in misery, and many were sitting at the doors of their homes, preparing discarded onions and other similar items for their dinner, while others washed vegetables, herbs, and all kinds of edibles that the earth provides at the fountain. It was not necessary to be very astute to discover the causes that reduced them to misery: just reading the solemn inscriptions placed in all visible spots of the village, detailing the taxes to be paid to the State, the Church, and the lord, along with local and general contributions, was more than enough, not only to understand why the inhabitants were poor, but to marvel that hunger and misery had not ended all their lives.

en: Few children were to be seen, and no dogs. As to the men and women, their choice on earth was stated in the prospect—Life on the lowest terms that could sustain it, down in the little village under the mill; or captivity and Death in the dominant prison on the crag.
vi: Rarely saw children and never saw dogs. For those men and women, their choices in life were predetermined - to barely survive at the lowest level in this small village below the mill; or to be imprisoned and die in the towering prison on the cliff.
tr: There were very few children around and no dogs at all. As for the men and women, their two options in this world were clear – either Life in the small village down by the mill, in the most miserable conditions, or captivity and Death in the prison that covered the top of the cliff.
es: Very few children were seen, not a single dog. As for the men and women, the choice the world offered them could not have been clearer: either live in the most miserable way in the village, under the crushing yoke of the lord, or die in the fortress perched on the cliff, destined to be a dungeon.

en: Heralded by a courier in advance, and by the cracking of his postilions’ whips, which twined snake-like about their heads in the evening air, as if he came attended by the Furies, Monsieur the Marquis drew up in his travelling carriage at the posting-house gate. It was hard by the fountain, and the peasants suspended their operations to look at him. He looked at them, and saw in them, without knowing it, the slow sure filing down of misery-worn face and figure, that was to make the meagreness of Frenchmen an English superstition which should survive the truth through the best part of a hundred years.
vi: Announced by a postman and by the cracking sound of the whips from two horsemen, the whip swirling like a snake around the heads of the horses in the evening sky, the Marquis entered the village as if escorted by avenging goddesses. The carriage stopped in front of the post station next to the fountain, and the peasants paused their work to look up at the nobleman. The Marquis looked at them, looked without paying any attention to the slow and certain erosion of hunger on those faces and the wretched, emaciated forms - an image that made the English believe for nearly a hundred years afterward that all French people were as gaunt as that.
tr: The carriage of Monsieur the Marquis, accompanied by a herald going ahead and the driver's whip cracking and curling like a snake in the evening darkness as if Furies had descended upon them, stopped in front of the post office door. The post office was next to the fountain, and the villagers paused their work to look at it. He also looked at the villagers and, without knowing what he saw, he perceived in their pain-filled faces and bodies the weariness and exhaustion that would transform into an English superstition about the frailty of the French over a century.
es: Preceded by a mail coach and accompanied by the cracks of the postillions' whips, which sliced through the air like coiled serpents, the Marquis ordered his carriage to stop in front of the coaching inn's door. Since it was very close to the fountain, the villagers who were there paused their tasks to look at him. He also looked at them and saw how they bowed their heads before him, in the same manner he had bowed his own before the lord, when a road worker happened to join the group.

en: Monsieur the Marquis cast his eyes over the submissive faces that drooped before him, as the like of himself had drooped before Monseigneur of the Court—only the difference was, that these faces drooped merely to suffer and not to propitiate—when a grizzled mender of the roads joined the group.
vi: The marquis cast his eyes down upon the humble faces bowed before him, much like men of his kind would bow before superiors at court - except these faces bowed out of misery, not to seek favor; at that moment, a gray-haired road worker joined the group. −
tr: As a gray-haired road worker mingled with the crowd, Monsieur the Marquis fixed his eyes on the obedient faces bowed before him, just as he bowed before the king – the only difference being that these faces bowed not out of sycophancy but out of pain.
es: He also looked at them and saw how they bowed their heads before him, in the same manner he had bowed his own before the lord, when a road worker happened to join the group.

en: “Bring me hither that fellow!” said the Marquis to the courier.
vi: Bring that man over there to me! - The marquis ordered the station worker.
tr: "Bring that man to me!" said the Marquis to the messenger.
es: —Bring me that individual—said the Marquis to the messenger.

en: The fellow was brought, cap in hand, and the other fellows closed round to look and listen, in the manner of the people at the Paris fountain.
vi: Taking off his hat and holding it in his hand, the man was led forward, and the crowd gathered around to look and listen, just like the people at the fountain in Paris.
tr: The man was brought in with his hat in hand, and the others surrounded him and paid close attention, just like the people at the Paris fountain.
es: The road worker was brought before him, around whom the villagers gathered, eager to listen and see.

en: “I passed you on the road?”
vi: − Did we pass by you on the road?
tr: "Did I pass by you on the road?""
es: —Did I pass you on the way, right?

en: “Monseigneur, it is true. I had the honour of being passed on the road.”
vi: − Yes, sir, we did. I am honored that you passed by me on the road.
tr: "That's right, Monsignor. You honored me by passing by on the road."
es: —It is true, sir, I had the honor of the gentleman passing me on the road.

en: “Coming up the hill, and at the top of the hill, both?”
vi: − Both when the carriage was going uphill and at the top of the hill, right?
tr: "Both while climbing the hill and at the top, right?"
es: —Upon climbing the ramp and at the top of the hill, isn't it true?

en: “Monseigneur, it is true.”
vi: − Yes, sir. −
tr: "Yes, Monsignor.""
es: —Sir, it is true.

en: “What did you look at, so fixedly?”
vi: What did you see that made you stare so intently?
tr: "Why did you stare at me like that then?"
es: —What were you staring at so intently?

en: “Monseigneur, I looked at the man.”
vi: − Sir, I saw a person.
tr: "I looked at the man, Monsignor.""
es: —I was watching the man, sir.

en: He stooped a little, and with his tattered blue cap pointed under the carriage. All his fellows stooped to look under the carriage.
vi: He bent down slightly and pointed the tattered green hat under the car. Everyone around also bent down to look.
tr: The man bent down a little and pointed under the car with his shabby blue hat. Everyone bent down and looked under the car.
es: When he answered, his pointed hat was pointing under the carriage. All the villagers focused their gazes on the same spot.

en: “What man, pig? And why look there?”
vi: − Who, you fool? Why are you looking there?
tr: "What man, you pig?" "Why did you look there?""
es: —What man, you piece of brute?

en: “Pardon, Monseigneur; he swung by the chain of the shoe—the drag.”
vi: − − Please forgive me, sir; he was hanging on the chain of the claw... of the brake, sir.
tr: "Excuse me, Monsignor; the man was hanging onto the chains of the –chock– of the car.""
es: —Excuse me, sir, I mean the man who was hanging from the chain of the winch.

en: “Who?” demanded the traveller.
vi: − − Who? − the official inquired.
tr: "Who?" asked the passenger.
es: —But who?

en: “Monseigneur, the man.”
vi: − − Sir, a person, sir.
tr: "A man, Monsignor.""
es: —The man, sir.

en: “May the Devil carry away these idiots! How do you call the man? You know all the men of this part of the country. Who was he?”
vi: − − Damn these fools! What is his name? You know everyone around here. Who is he?
tr: "May God punish you! What's this man's name? You know everyone around here. Who was this man?"
es: —Let the devil take this mob of idiots! What is that man's name? You know everyone around here: who was that man?

en: “Your clemency, Monseigneur! He was not of this part of the country. Of all the days of my life, I never saw him.”
vi: − Please, sir! He is not from around here. I have never seen him in my life, sir.
tr: "I beg your pardon, Monsignor! He was not from around here. I have never seen him in my life."
es: —Mercy, sir! He was not from this part of the country: I had never seen him in my life.

en: “Swinging by the chain? To be suffocated?”
vi: − Hanging on the chain? Does he want to suffocate?
tr: "He was hanging from the chain, huh? Did he want to choke?"
es: —Suspended from the chain? Hanged?

en: “With your gracious permission, that was the wonder of it, Monseigneur. His head hanging over—like this!”
vi: − With your permission, sir, I was wondering the same thing. His head was tilted back... like this!
tr: "Excuse me, sir, but I thought the same way. His head was hanging down just like that from there!"
es: —With the gentleman's permission, I will say that his head was hanging like this.

en: He turned himself sideways to the carriage, and leaned back, with his face thrown up to the sky, and his head hanging down; then recovered himself, fumbled with his cap, and made a bow.
vi: He turned sideways, leaned against the carriage, tilted his head back, face up to the sky, then returned to a normal position, wringing his hat and bowing respectfully.
tr: Adam went over to the car, lay down on his back, lifted his face to the sky and let his head hang back; then, feeling around, he grabbed the hat he had dropped, stood up, and greeted with a nod.
es: The truck driver approached the rail and positioned himself with his face turned towards the sky and his head hanging down. Then, he returned to a normal posture and made a bow.

en: “What was he like?”
vi: − What does that person look like?
tr: "What was he/she like?""
es: —What did he look like?

en: “Monseigneur, he was whiter than the miller. All covered with dust, white as a spectre, tall as a spectre!”
vi: − Your Honor, he looks even whiter than a flour miller. Dust covers him all over, pale as a ghost, tall as a ghost!
tr: "Monsignor, this man was whiter than the miller. He was covered in dust from head to toe, as white and tall as a ghost!"
es: —Sir, he was whiter than a miller, the dust covered him from head to toe, he was whiter than a specter and taller than a specter.

en: The picture produced an immense sensation in the little crowd; but all eyes, without comparing notes with other eyes, looked at Monsieur the Marquis. Perhaps, to observe whether he had any spectre on his conscience.
vi: That description caused the whole crowd to stir; but all eyes, without being told, turned towards the Marquis. Perhaps to see if there was any ghost in his conscience.
tr: This depiction had created tremendous excitement in the small crowd; all eyes, without straying anywhere else. Were turned towards Monsieur Marquis. Perhaps to see if there was a place for ghosts in his beliefs.
es: The description produced an immense sensation in the audience. Everyone turned their eyes towards the Marquis, perhaps believing that he carried some specter on his conscience.

en: “Truly, you did well,” said the Marquis, felicitously sensible that such vermin were not to ruffle him, “to see a thief accompanying my carriage, and not open that great mouth of yours. Bah! Put him aside, Monsieur Gabelle!”
vi: − Alright, good for you, - the Marquis said, feeling secretly pleased because he knew that a lowly creature like this would never dare to anger him. - You saw a thief following my carriage and didn't even open your mouth. Hmph! Get rid of him, Mr. Gabelle!
tr: "It's good, Aman," said the Marquis, his voice coming out calmly as if to show that such riffraff wouldn't alarm him. "A thief sneaks into my car and you don't open that big mouth of yours to say anything. Shame on you! Pull over, Monsieur Gabelle!"
es: —It cannot be denied that you have behaved like a man!—exclaimed the Marquis. —You see a thief climbing into my carriage, and you don't know how to open that huge mouth you have on your face. Let him go, Mr. Gambelle, let him go!

en: Monsieur Gabelle was the Postmaster, and some other taxing functionary united; he had come out with great obsequiousness to assist at this examination, and had held the examined by the drapery of his arm in an official manner.
vi: Mr. Gabelle was the station master and also collected some other taxes; he had been obsequiously coming out to assist with the questioning, and had importantly grabbed the sleeve of the person being interrogated.
tr: Mr. Gabelle was the postmaster and also dealt with some tax matters; he had rushed to help with the interrogation with great obsequiousness and had formally grabbed the sleeve of the interrogated man's arm.
es: Mr. Gambelle was the head of the post office and other services, and as the scene we are describing unfolded, in his desire to contribute to the successful outcome of the statement, he had grabbed the declarant by the arm.

en: “Bah! Go aside!” said Monsieur Gabelle.
vi: − Hmph! Move aside!
tr: "Come on, step aside!" said Monsieur Gabelle.
es: Mr. Gambelle was the head of the post office and other services, and as the scene we are describing unfolded, in his desire to contribute to the successful outcome of the statement, he had grabbed the declarant by the arm.

en: “Lay hands on this stranger if he seeks to lodge in your village to-night, and be sure that his business is honest, Gabelle.”
vi: - Mr. Gabelle said. − If that stranger tries to stay in this village tonight, arrest him, and make sure he has no malicious intent, Gabelle.
tr: "If this man tries to stay in your village tonight, catch him immediately and find out what he is trying to do, Gabelle.""
es: —Release that scoundrel, Mr. Gambelle, and if the stranger arrives at the village, arrest him and do not set him free until you are sure he is an honest man.

en: “Monseigneur, I am flattered to devote myself to your orders.”
vi: − Your Excellency, it is truly an honor to obey your orders.
tr: "It is an honor for me to carry out your orders, Monseigneur.""
es: —It will be an honor for me to follow the gentleman's orders—replied Gambelle.

en: “Did he run away, fellow?—where is that Accursed?”
vi: − Where did he go, this guy?... Where is that damn guy?
tr: "Where is Adam? Where did that wretch go?"
es: —Did that one escape...? But where has that damn one gone?

en: The accursed was already under the carriage with some half-dozen particular friends, pointing out the chain with his blue cap. Some half-dozen other particular friends promptly hauled him out, and presented him breathless to Monsieur the Marquis.
vi: That damn guy got under the car with five or six familiar people, and was holding up a green hat pointing at the chain. Five or six other familiar people quickly pulled him out and dragged this panting man over. in front of the Marquis.
tr: The unlucky one had crawled under the car with half a dozen friends, pointing at the chain with his blue hat. The other half dozen friends immediately pulled him out and, breathless, brought him before Monsieur Marquis.
es: The damned one had gotten under the carriage, accompanied by half a dozen of his particular friends, to whom he was showing the chain of the gauge. Another half dozen friends immediately dragged him out and took him to the presence of the lord.

en: “Did the man run away, Dolt, when we stopped for the drag?”
vi: − You fool, did that person run away when our carriage stopped to apply the brakes?
tr: "Tell me, you fool, did this man escape when we stopped to remove the block?"
es: —Did that man escape when we stopped to throw the stone?

en: “Monseigneur, he precipitated himself over the hill-side, head first, as a person plunges into the river.”
vi: − Your Honor, at that moment he jumped down the hillside, diving headfirst as if diving into a river. −
tr: "Monsignor, the man threw himself down headfirst from the top of the hill, as if diving into a river.""
es: —He plunged headfirst from the top of the hill, just as if he had thrown himself into the sea.

en: “See to it, Gabelle. Go on!”
vi: Take care of this matter, Gabelle. Let's go!
tr: "Come on, Gabelle. Let's go immediately!"
es: —Make sure to find that out for me, Gambelle... Move out!

en: The half-dozen who were peering at the chain were still among the wheels, like sheep; the wheels turned so suddenly that they were lucky to save their skins and bones; they had very little else to save, or they might not have been so fortunate.
vi: The people were staring at the chain still dragging between the wheels like a flock of sheep; the carriage moved so suddenly that it was sheer luck their skin-and-bone bodies weren't run over; they had nothing but skin and bones, otherwise, they might not have escaped unscathed.
tr: The half-dozen men looking at the chain were still between the wheels like sheep; the wheels turned so suddenly that the men barely saved their lives; in fact, they had very little to save in this life, otherwise, they might not have been so lucky.
es: In front of the wheels, examining the chain, were the half-dozen close friends of the trucker, resembling a flock of sheep. The wheels began to turn so unexpectedly that it was a miracle they managed to save their skins and bones, the only things they could save, fortunately for them.

en: The burst with which the carriage started out of the village and up the rise beyond, was soon checked by the steepness of the hill. Gradually, it subsided to a foot pace, swinging and lumbering upward among the many sweet scents of a summer night. The postilions, with a thousand gossamer gnats circling about them in lieu of the Furies, quietly mended the points to the lashes of their whips; the valet walked by the horses; the courier was audible, trotting on ahead into the dull distance.
vi: The rapid speed of the carriage as it rushed out of the village and up the distant hill was soon hindered by the steep slope. Gradually, the carriage slowed down to a walking pace, swaying and struggling uphill amidst the fragrant summer night. Instead of the avenging goddesses, thousands of mosquitoes swarmed around the two coachmen like a gauze curtain, and the tips of their whips now quietly swatted at the mosquito screen rather than the horses; the servant walked beside the horses; the station hand who had gone ahead was out of sight, only the sound of his footsteps could be heard in the dim distance.
tr: The car, which left the village in a hurry, stalled on the steep hill shortly after. They had slowed down to a walking pace, climbing the hill slowly and clumsily amidst the sweet scents of the summer night. The place of the Furias circling above the drivers was taken by thousands of small gnats that wrapped around their heads like a spider web, which the drivers tried to disperse quietly with the tips of their whips; the servant was walking beside the car; although the messenger trotting ahead was not visible, his voice could be heard.
es: The horses left the village at a gallop, but soon slowed down, as the hill's slope was so steep that they had to climb it at a walk. The road bordered a small cemetery, where a cross with the image of Our Savior could be seen.

en: At the steepest point of the hill there was a little burial-ground, with a Cross and a new large figure of Our Saviour on it; it was a poor figure in wood, done by some inexperienced rustic carver, but he had studied the figure from the life—his own life, maybe—for it was dreadfully spare and thin.
vi: At the very peak of the hill is a small cemetery, with a cross bearing a large statue of Christ the Savior; it is a crude wooden statue carved by some amateur villager, but he had studied the model from real life - perhaps his own life - because the statue is terribly thin and frail.
tr: At the steepest point of the hill, there was a small grave with a Cross and a newly made large statue of Jesus on it; it was a poorly made wooden statue, as if carved by an inexperienced sculptor from the village, but it was so thin and scrawny that it clearly reflected the sculptor's life – perhaps even his own life.
es: It was a wooden image, made by unskilled hands, but the artist had studied from life and surely his model was his own body or that of one of his fellow villagers, as the image was horribly thin and gaunt.

en: To this distressful emblem of a great distress that had long been growing worse, and was not at its worst, a woman was kneeling. She turned her head as the carriage came up to her, rose quickly, and presented herself at the carriage-door.
vi: Before the symbol of suffering of this increasingly worse great pain - and not yet the worst - a woman is kneeling. Turning her head when she hears the sound of a carriage approaching, she hastily stands up and goes to the door.
tr: A woman had knelt before this statue, which was a poignant symbol of these painful days that had been ongoing for a while but were expected to get even worse. When the car approached, she turned her head, immediately stood up, and moved towards the door.
es: At the foot of that sorrowful emblem of immense misfortune, there was a woman kneeling. She turned her head upon hearing the noise of the carriage, quickly stood up, and hurriedly ran towards the coach.

en: “It is you, Monseigneur! Monseigneur, a petition.”
vi: − It's truly you, Your Excellency! Please, Your Excellency, let the heavens shed light on this.
tr: "Ah Monsignor! I have a request from you."
es: —It's the gentleman!—he exclaimed, appearing at the door. —Sir, a favor!

en: With an exclamation of impatience, but with his unchangeable face, Monseigneur looked out.
vi: Letting out an impatient sigh but with an unchanged expression, the official looked out.
tr: Without changing the expression on his face, Monsignor shouted in an impatient tone.
es: The gentleman let out an exclamation of impatience.

en: “How, then! What is it? Always petitions!”
vi: − Again! What is it? Always asking for something!
tr: "What is it! What do you want? You always ask for something anyway!"
es: —What's up? What do you need? Always with requests!

en: “Monseigneur. For the love of the great God! My husband, the forester.”
vi: − Your Excellency. For God's sake, please have mercy! My husband, the woodcutter. −
tr: "Monsignor. For the love of God, help! My husband, the forester."
es: —Sir, for the love of God! My husband... the forest ranger!...

en: “What of your husband, the forester? Always the same with you people. He cannot pay something?”
vi: What happened to your woodcutter husband? You commoners are always like this. Is your husband in debt and unable to pay?
tr: "So what if your husband is a forester? All of you have the same problem. Does he owe someone money?"
es: —What does your husband, the forest ranger, want? These people always ask for the same thing! That he can't pay, huh?

en: “He has paid all, Monseigneur. He is dead.”
vi: − My husband has already paid off all his debts, Your Excellency. My husband has died.
tr: "He had paid all his debts, Monsignor. He died."
es: —He has paid for everything, sir! He is dead!

en: “Well! He is quiet. Can I restore him to you?”
vi: − Good! He is at peace now. Do you want me to bring him back to life? −
tr: "Good then! He has found peace. Should I bring him back to you?"
es: —Better! That way he will rest! Do you think I can return it to you?

en: “Alas, no, Monseigneur! But he lies yonder, under a little heap of poor grass.”
vi: Oh, no, Your Excellency! But my husband lies here, under this mound of withered grass. −
tr: "Oh no, Monsignor! But there, lying under a clump of thin grass."
es: —Alas, sir... I know all too well that it's not true! But he rests over there... under those wretched grasses!...

en: “Well?”
vi: So what?
tr: "Huh?"
es: —And well?

en: “Monseigneur, there are so many little heaps of poor grass?”
vi: − Your Excellency, there are many mounds of withered grass around here but...
tr: "Monsignor, there are so many tufts of thin grass around.""
es: —That there are many stretches of land covered with grass.

en: “Again, well?”
vi: − But why?
tr: "Well, what should I do then?"
es: —Well... so what?

en: She looked an old woman, but was young. Her manner was one of passionate grief; by turns she clasped her veinous and knotted hands together with wild energy, and laid one of them on the carriage-door—tenderly, caressingly, as if it had been a human breast, and could be expected to feel the appealing touch.
vi: She looks like an old woman but she is still fresh. In extreme anguish, she kept twisting her bony, vein-covered hands together violently, then placed one hand on the car door - gently, tenderly, as if that inanimate object were the chest of a person capable of feeling the pleading gesture.
tr: The woman looked old but was young. There was intense pain in her demeanor; she was clasping her veined and battered hands in front of her alternately with a mad strength, and with a tenderness and affection, as if touching a human's chest and as if that person could understand this affectionate touch, she was leaning them against the car door.
es: That woman was young, although she seemed old. Her face reflected immense pain. Sometimes she energetically twisted her calloused hands, and other times she placed them on the carriage door, caressing it tenderly, as if she believed it was a human chest capable of being softened.

en: “Monseigneur, hear me! Monseigneur, hear my petition! My husband died of want; so many die of want; so many more will die of want.”
vi: − Your Honor, please listen to me! Your Honor, please let the heavens see and judge! My husband died of starvation; and many more will die of starvation.
tr: "Monsignor, please listen to me! Please heed my plea! My husband died of poverty; many people are dying of poverty and many more will die because of it."
es: —May the lord have compassion on me! Listen to my plea! My husband has died of hunger... from the same illness that has taken so many others... from the same one that will take all of us in the village to the grave...

en: “Again, well? Can I feed them?”
vi: − And then? Should we feed them?
tr: "So what should I do then? Should I feed them?"
es: —But what are you telling me for? Can I possibly feed all of you?

en: “Monseigneur, the good God knows; but I don’t ask it. My petition is, that a morsel of stone or wood, with my husband’s name, may be placed over him to show where he lies. Otherwise, the place will be quickly forgotten, it will never be found when I am dead of the same malady, I shall be laid under some other heap of poor grass. Monseigneur, they are so many, they increase so fast, there is so much want. Monseigneur! Monseigneur!”
vi: − Your Excellency, with the sacred Lord as my witness, I do not ask you for that. I only ask for a piece of stone or wood with my husband's name to mark his burial place. Otherwise, this place will soon be forgotten, and no one will be able to find the grave once I also die of hunger and lie beneath some withered grass-covered mound. Your Excellency; there are too many dead, increasing rapidly, and there is hunger everywhere. Your Excellency! Please!
tr: "Monsignor, God is my witness to what has happened, but of course, I wouldn't ask such a thing from you. My request from you is a piece of stone or wood, with my husband's name written on it, so that we can place it over where he lies. Otherwise, his place will be forgotten very quickly, and when I die from the same ailment, no one will be able to find this place, and I will probably be lying under another patch of thin grass. Monsignor, so many people are in this state, their numbers are increasing so rapidly, and poverty has engulfed everything. Monsignor! Monsignor!"
es: —Sir... God knows it, but it is not food that I ask for. The only thing I desire is that over the earth that covers my husband's corpse, a piece of wood or stone with his name on it be raised, so that everyone knows where he is buried. If not, soon everyone will forget the place and they won't be able to bury me next to him when I die. Sir!... Sir!...

en: The valet had put her away from the door, the carriage had broken into a brisk trot, the postilions had quickened the pace, she was left far behind, and Monseigneur, again escorted by the Furies, was rapidly diminishing the league or two of distance that remained between him and his chateau.
vi: The servant pushed her away from the carriage door, the horses galloped off, the two coachmen spurred the horses to run faster, leaving the woman behind, while His Excellency - once again escorted by the avenging goddesses - quickly shortened the distance of several miles to his private castle.
tr: The woman from Uşak had moved away from the door, the car had suddenly moved, the drivers drove the car quickly, leaving the woman behind, and the Monsignor, once again accompanied by the Furias, was rapidly closing the distance to his castle.
es: The lackey had separated the poor woman from the carriage, the horses had started a long trot, and the gentleman saw the league or two of distance that still separated him from his château rapidly diminish.

en: The sweet scents of the summer night rose all around him, and rose, as the rain falls, impartially, on the dusty, ragged, and toil-worn group at the fountain not far away; to whom the mender of roads, with the aid of the blue cap without which he was nothing, still enlarged upon his man like a spectre, as long as they could bear it. By degrees, as they could bear no more, they dropped off one by one, and lights twinkled in little casements; which lights, as the casements darkened, and more stars came out, seemed to have shot up into the sky instead of having been extinguished.
vi: The fragrant summer night had enveloped around him, and as carefree as the falling rain, the night also enveloped the filthy, ragged, and weary laborers at the fountain not far away; the road worker, with the accompaniment of his green hat representing his self-worth, was still gossiping about the ghost-like figure hanging onto the vehicle, as long as there was someone to listen. Gradually losing interest, one by one they left, the lights flickering in the small windows; then the lights in the windows also gradually went out, more stars appeared, as if the lights had not been extinguished but had soared up into the glittering sky.
tr: The scents of the summer night had enveloped every corner, and these scents, like rain, without missing a single spot, were also rising over the dusty, shabby-looking, tired group standing by the nearby fountain; the road worker, with the help of his blue hat that he never took off his head, was still describing the ghost-like man to the people, as much as they could tolerate. As they began to tolerate it less and less, those around him dwindled one by one, and the lights flickered on the small window panes; then, as the windows darkened one by one and the number of stars increased, these lights appeared not as if they had gone out, but as if they had been thrown into the sky.
