es: The road was good, and the time spent traveling it was not long. The shadows of a huge building and many very large trees were outlined.

en: The shadow of a large high-roofed house, and of many over-hanging trees, was upon Monsieur the Marquis by that time; and the shadow was exchanged for the light of a flambeau, as his carriage stopped, and the great door of his chateau was opened to him.
vi: The shadow of a vast mansion with high roofs and many sprawling trees was then enveloping the Marquis; and the darkness was replaced by the light of a torch as the carriage came to a stop, then the large gate of the castle opened to welcome him.
tr: The shadows of a large, high-roofed house and a multitude of trees hanging over it had just fallen upon Monsieur Marquis; when his carriage stopped and the large gate of his château opened for him, the shadows were replaced by the light of a torch.
es: It was the château of the Marquis, at whose main door the butler was waiting for him.

en: “Monsieur Charles, whom I expect; is he arrived from England?”
vi: − I'm waiting for Mr. Charles, have you returned from England yet?
tr: "Did the Monsieur Charles I was expecting arrive from England?"
es: —Has Mr. Carlos, whom I am expecting, arrived from England?—he asked.

en: “Monseigneur, not yet.”
vi: − Your Excellency, not yet.
tr: "No, Monsignor, they haven't come yet.""
es: —Not yet, Mr. Marquis—was the response.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: − Your Excellency, not yet.
tr: IX
es: IX.

en: The Gorgon’s Head
vi: 9. Gorgon's Head
tr: Head of Gorgon
es: THE HEAD OF GORGON

en: It was a heavy mass of building, that chateau of Monsieur the Marquis, with a large stone courtyard before it, and two stone sweeps of staircase meeting in a stone terrace before the principal door. A stony business altogether, with heavy stone balustrades, and stone urns, and stone flowers, and stone faces of men, and stone heads of lions, in all directions. As if the Gorgon’s head had surveyed it, when it was finished, two centuries ago.
vi: The Marquis's castle is a magnificent building, in front is a paved courtyard and two curving stone staircases connecting the two ends of the row. Stone patio in front of the main door. A property full of stone, with stone balconies, stone vases, stone flowers, stone human faces, stone lion heads everywhere. It was as if everything had turned to stone before the Gorgon's gaze when the castle was completed two centuries ago.
tr: The Chateau of Monsieur Marquis was a very imposing building, with a wide stone courtyard stretching out in front of it, and two winding stone staircases meeting on the stone terrace in front of the main door. Everything was entirely made of stone, stone balustrades, stone-footed vases and flowers, and everywhere there were stone busts and stone lion heads. It was as if a Gorgon had cast its gaze around when this place was built two hundred years ago.
es: The château of the Marquis was an arrogant building, with thick and solid walls and vast proportions. From its spacious stone courtyard, two wide stone staircases started, which met at the stone terrace, like everything else, that preceded the main door. The sturdy balustrades were made of stone, the vases were made of stone, the flowers were made of stone, the human faces were made of stone, the heads of the lions were made of stone, everything was made of stone. It seemed as if the head of Gorgon had presided, two centuries earlier, over the completion of that immense mass of stone and had devised its finishes and ornamental details.

en: Up the broad flight of shallow steps, Monsieur the Marquis, flambeau preceded, went from his carriage, sufficiently disturbing the darkness to elicit loud remonstrance from an owl in the roof of the great pile of stable building away among the trees. All else was so quiet, that the flambeau carried up the steps, and the other flambeau held at the great door, burnt as if they were in a close room of state, instead of being in the open night-air. Other sound than the owl’s voice there was none, save the falling of a fountain into its stone basin; for, it was one of those dark nights that hold their breath by the hour together, and then heave a long low sigh, and hold their breath again.
vi: The torch leading the way, the Marquis stepped out of the carriage and ascended the low steps; his footsteps disturbed the darkness enough to make an owl perched on the roof of the grand stables, faintly visible behind the trees, hoot loudly in protest. All around was silent, to the extent that the torch being carried up the stairs and another torch planted at the main door burned quietly as if they were in a banquet hall rather than in the middle of the night. Besides the sound of the owl's hoot, no other sound could be heard, except for the water flowing from the fountain into the stone basin; it seemed as if the dark night, after holding its breath for hours, suddenly let out a long, lingering sigh and then held its breath again.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, after getting out of his carriage, ascended the wide and low stone steps accompanied by torches; as the light of the torch pierced the darkness, the loud reproach of the owl perched atop the barn among the trees was heard. Other than that, everything was so quiet that it seemed as if the torch on the steps and the other torch hanging at the main door were burning in a closed room rather than in the open air. Except for the sound of the fountain in the stone pool and the owl, there was not a sound; for it was one of those dark nights when, at every hour, the night held its breath, then let out a deep sigh, and then held its breath again.
es: The torch that preceded the Marquis when, after getting out of his travel carriage, he began the ascent of the spacious stone staircase, shed enough light to provoke the protests of the owl that had its headquarters on the roof of the turret that crowned the stables and rose as if trying to scale the clouds, surrounded by trees of prodigious height. Everything else remained quiet, so quiet that both the torch that preceded the Marquis on the grand staircase and the one that awaited his arrival in front of the honor door burned as if they were in the center of a closed room, and not exposed to the night breezes. Nor was any other noise heard except for the hooting of the owl, with the exception of the sound produced by the water from the fountain as it fell into the basin, for it was one of those nights that hold their breath for entire hours, only to exhale a sigh and remain breathless once again.

en: The great door clanged behind him, and Monsieur the Marquis crossed a hall grim with certain old boar-spears, swords, and knives of the chase; grimmer with certain heavy riding-rods and riding-whips, of which many a peasant, gone to his benefactor Death, had felt the weight when his lord was angry.
vi: The main door slammed shut behind him, the Marquis strode across the eerie, gloomy hall, where old hunting tools like boar spears, swords, and hunting knives were displayed; and even more terrifying with all sorts of horsewhips that many peasants had tasted before being graced by death, due to the lord's wrath.
tr: When the large door slammed shut behind him, Monsieur Marquis passed through a cruel hall containing some old spears, swords, and hunting knives used for boar hunting; it was becoming increasingly cruel due to the various riding crops and whips, who knows how many peasants, who had met merciful Death, had felt their weight on their backs when their master was angry.
es: The door of honor swung on its smooth hinges, and the Marquis entered a gallery whose walls displayed a great variety of ancient armor, and an abundance of darts, spears, swords, and hunting knives, along with a varied assortment of riding crops, whips, and lashes, whose weight more than one peasant had felt when their lord was enraged.

en: Avoiding the larger rooms, which were dark and made fast for the night, Monsieur the Marquis, with his flambeau-bearer going on before, went up the staircase to a door in a corridor. This thrown open, admitted him to his own private apartment of three rooms: his bed-chamber and two others. High vaulted rooms with cool uncarpeted floors, great dogs upon the hearths for the burning of wood in winter time, and all luxuries befitting the state of a marquis in a luxurious age and country. The fashion of the last Louis but one, of the line that was never to break—the fourteenth Louis—was conspicuous in their rich furniture; but, it was diversified by many objects that were illustrations of old pages in the history of France.
vi: Avoiding the large, dark rooms that were locked tonight, the Marquis followed the torchbearer up the stairs to a hallway door. The door opened to welcome him into a private suite with three rooms: a bedroom and two others. The rooms had high vaulted ceilings with cold stone floors without carpets, large grates in the fireplaces for burning wood in the winter, and all the luxuries befitting a Marquis in this era and luxurious country. The furniture was luxurious in the style of the previous Louis generations - King Louis XIV but of a lineage that would surely rule forever*; further diversified by other pieces bearing the marks of various periods in French history.
tr: Monsieur Marquis, without stopping by the larger rooms that were pitch dark, followed his servant carrying a torch up the stairs and arrived at a door in the corridor. This door led to his private suite of three rooms; there was a bedroom and two other rooms here. High vaulted ceilings, beautiful floorings without carpets, the hearth irons on the fireplace base used for burning wood in the winter months, and every kind of luxury were in a style befitting a marquis living in this age and land of luxury. The style of the penultimate member of the dynasty thought to never end – Louis the Fourteenth – was evident in all that rich furniture; but these were also diversified with items seen in the illustrations of the old pages of French history.
es: Without even glancing at the large wings, shrouded in black darkness, the Marquis, always following the torch, arrived in front of a door at the end of the gallery. Once it was opened, he found himself in his rooms, which were three, one of them his bedroom. The rooms with high coffered ceilings, gathered all the luxury, all the refinement that befits a Marquis, who lives in a sumptuous century and in a nation that sacrifices everything to pomp. In the extremely rich furniture, the taste of the penultimate Louis of that sacred dynasty that was meant to be eternal, Louis XIV, predominated, although there were also objects that could pass as illustrations from the ancient pages of French history.

en: A supper-table was laid for two, in the third of the rooms; a round room, in one of the chateau’s four extinguisher-topped towers. A small lofty room, with its window wide open, and the wooden jalousie-blinds closed, so that the dark night only showed in slight horizontal lines of black, alternating with their broad lines of stone colour.
vi: A table was set for two people in the third room; the round room was located in one of the four spire-like towers resembling candle snuffers. The small room had a high ceiling, the windows were wide open but covered with wooden blinds, so only the black night appeared as small horizontal lines interspersed with large gray stripes. −
tr: In the third room, a table for two had been set; it was a round room in one of the four towers of the castle, resembling candle snuffers. The room was small but had a proud atmosphere; its windows were wide open, and the wooden shutters were closed. On such a dark night, only thin black lines and broad stone-colored stripes were visible.
es: In the center of the third room, a round chamber corresponding to one of the four towers flanking the building, there was a dining table set for two people. The room was small, and its window was open, although its shutters were closed.

en: “My nephew,” said the Marquis, glancing at the supper preparation; “they said he was not arrived.”
vi: Set for my nephew, is it? - The Marquis said as he glanced at the table, hearing from the servant that he had not yet arrived.
tr: "My nephew," said the Marquis, looking at the table preparations; "according to what they say, he hasn't arrived yet."
es: —A place setting for my nephew?—murmured the Marquis upon entering. —

en: Nor was he; but, he had been expected with Monseigneur.
vi: The young master hasn't arrived yet, but the official is waiting for him. −
tr: He hadn't come yet; actually, they thought he would come with the Monsignor.
es: And yet, they just told me he hasn't arrived yet.

en: “Ah! It is not probable he will arrive to-night; nevertheless, leave the table as it is. I shall be ready in a quarter of an hour.”
vi: Ah! He might not come tonight; nevertheless, leave the table set. I will have dinner in fifteen minutes.
tr: "Ah! Then it is very unlikely that he will come tonight; still, let's leave the table as it is. I will be ready in fifteen minutes."
es: He had not arrived, indeed, but at the castle, they were expecting him to arrive with the Marquis. —It is unlikely that he will arrive tonight—added the Marquis, addressing the servant in charge of the dining room—but leave the table as it is. In a quarter of an hour, I will sit down to dinner.

en: In a quarter of an hour Monseigneur was ready, and sat down alone to his sumptuous and choice supper. His chair was opposite to the window, and he had taken his soup, and was raising his glass of Bordeaux to his lips, when he put it down.
vi: Fifteen minutes later, the high-ranking official was ready, sitting alone to enjoy a lavish, sumptuous meal. His chair faced the window; after finishing the soup, he lifted the Bordeaux wine glass to his lips but immediately put it down. − What is that? -
tr: The Monsignor was ready within fifteen minutes and sat alone at this magnificent and elegant table. His chair was opposite the window, and just as he had finished his soup and was bringing the Bordeaux wine to his lips, he set the glass down on the table.
es: Indeed: fifteen minutes later, the Marquis took a seat in front of a sumptuous and select dinner. He sat with his back to the window. He had just finished eating the soup and was raising a glass of fine Bordeaux to his lips when he lowered his hand without drinking.

en: “What is that?” he calmly asked, looking with attention at the horizontal lines of black and stone colour.
vi: The marquis calmly asked, his eyes intently observing the alternating gray and black stripes on the curtain.
tr: "What was that?" he asked calmly, focusing his attention on the black and stone-colored horizontal lines.
es: —What is that?—he asked calmly, turning his face towards the lattices.

en: “Monseigneur? That?”
vi: − Your Excellency? What is it?
tr: "Yes, Monsignor? What did you ask?"
es: —What, Monseñor?

en: “Outside the blinds. Open the blinds.”
vi: − Outside the curtain. Draw the curtain aside. The curtain has been drawn.
tr: "A sound came from behind the shutters. Open the shutters."
es: —Get out... Open the shutters.

en: It was done.
tr: The shutters were opened.
es: The order was obeyed immediately.

en: “Well?”
vi: What?
tr: "What's there?"
es: —What's up?

en: “Monseigneur, it is nothing. The trees and the night are all that are here.”
vi: − Your Excellency, there is nothing at all. Here, there are only trees, leaves, and darkness.
tr: "There is nothing, Monsignor. Only trees and darkness."
es: —Nothing, sir: the treetops and the shadows of the night are the only things that can be seen.

en: The servant who spoke, had thrown the blinds wide, had looked out into the vacant darkness, and stood with that blank behind him, looking round for instructions.
vi: The servant spoke after having fully opened the curtain, looked out at the empty dark sky, and turned back to look at the Marquis awaiting orders.
tr: The servant who said this had fully opened the shutters and looked at the vast darkness stretching out in front of him, then pulled back inside and waited for the orders to be given to him.
es: —Nothing, sir: the treetops and the shadows of the night are the only things that can be seen.

en: “Good,” said the imperturbable master. “Close them again.”
vi: − Good, - the master calmly said. - Close it.
tr: "Alright, fine," said the calm gentleman. "Then close the shutters again.""
es: —Alright—said his master, with unshakable calm. —Close it again.

en: That was done too, and the Marquis went on with his supper. He was half way through it, when he again stopped with his glass in his hand, hearing the sound of wheels. It came on briskly, and came up to the front of the chateau.
vi: The curtain had closed, and the Marquis continued his meal. The Marquis, halfway through eating, paused, a glass of wine in hand. There was the sound of a carriage. The sound of the carriage approached quickly and then stopped right in front of the castle.
tr: The shutters were closed again and the Marquis continued his meal. He had just reached the halfway point of his meal when he heard the sound of wheels and put down his glass again. The sounds approached quickly and stopped in front of the chateau.
es: The Marquis turned his attention back to his dinner. He had reached about halfway through it when, for the second time, the glass he was raising to his lips stopped midway. The sound of a carriage rolling at a good pace could be heard approaching the castle.

en: “Ask who is arrived.”
vi: − Ask who is coming.
tr: "Ask who has come.""
es: —Ask who has arrived—said the Marquis to the servant.

en: It was the nephew of Monseigneur. He had been some few leagues behind Monseigneur, early in the afternoon. He had diminished the distance rapidly, but not so rapidly as to come up with Monseigneur on the road. He had heard of Monseigneur, at the posting-houses, as being before him.
vi: He is the grandchild of the high-ranking official. In the early afternoon, he was trailing the high-ranking official by a few miles. The grandchild tried to shorten the distance quickly but couldn't catch up with his uncle on the road. At the relay station, he heard that the high-ranking official had already gone ahead.
tr: He was the nephew of the arriving Monsignor. In the afternoon, he was a little behind the Monsignor on the road. Even though he had quickly closed the gap, it wasn't enough to catch up with the Monsignor. He had learned at the post offices that the Monsignor was a little ahead of him.
es: He was the nephew of the gentleman, to whom at the post house they had indicated that the Marquis would have already arrived at the castle.

en: He was to be told (said Monseigneur) that supper awaited him then and there, and that he was prayed to come to it. In a little while he came. He had been known in England as Charles Darnay.
vi: The servant said that dinner was ready upstairs and the master wanted him to join the meal. A moment later he arrived. In England, everyone called him Charles Darnay.
tr: He was told that the meal was ready and he was expected at the table (the Monsignor had requested this). He came to the table shortly after. In England, he was known as Charles Darnay.
es: —Go and tell him on my behalf that dinner is waiting, and that I beg him to come without delay. Minutes later, the traveler entered the dining room, who was the same young man we have known in England under the name of Charles Darnay.

en: Monseigneur received him in a courtly manner, but they did not shake hands.
vi: The high-ranking official greeted the young man politely, but they did not shake hands.
tr: The Monsignor greeted him kindly, but they did not shake hands.
es: The Marquis received him with exquisite courtesy, but they did not shake hands.

en: “You left Paris yesterday, sir?” he said to Monseigneur, as he took his seat at table.
vi: − Did you leave Paris yesterday, sir? - He asked the Marquis as he sat down at the table.
tr: While sitting at the table, he asked the Monsignor, "Did you leave Paris yesterday, sir?"
es: —Did you leave Paris yesterday?—asked the young man as he sat down at the table.

en: “Yesterday. And you?”
vi: − Yesterday. And you? − I came straight here.
tr: "Yes, I left yesterday. What about you?"
es: —Yesterday, yes; and you?

en: “I come direct.”
vi: And you? − I came straight here.
tr: "I came directly."
es: —I came directly here.

en: “From London?”
vi: − From London? − Yes.
tr: "From London?""
es: —From London?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − You are wasting too much time, - the Marquis said, laughing.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “You have been a long time coming,” said the Marquis, with a smile.
vi: − You are wasting too much time, - the Marquis said, laughing.
tr: "It took you long enough," said the Marquis, laughing.
es: "It took you quite a while to get here," observed the Marquis, smiling.

en: “On the contrary; I come direct.”
vi: − On the contrary, I went straight ahead without stopping.
tr: "On the contrary; I came directly.""
es: —On the contrary, I made the trip very quickly.

en: “Pardon me! I mean, not a long time on the journey; a long time intending the journey.”
vi: − Sorry! I didn't mean the travel time, but the time to decide to set off.
tr: "Sorry about that! I meant to say that it took you a long time to decide to come, not the journey itself."
es: —On the contrary, I made the trip very quickly. —Excuse me, I didn't mean to say that you spent a lot of time on the road, but rather in deciding to make the trip.

en: “I have been detained by”—the nephew stopped a moment in his answer—“various business.”
vi: − I am hindered because... - the nephew responded hesitantly, - ... many things.
tr: "What kept me from coming," –the nephew paused for a moment– "was that some work came up."
es: —Yes... I have been forced to postpone it... various business matters.

en: “Without doubt,” said the polished uncle.
vi: − Indeed, - the uncle said politely.
tr: "Certainly," said the kind uncle.
es: —I suppose so—replied the uncle.

en: So long as a servant was present, no other words passed between them. When coffee had been served and they were alone together, the nephew, looking at the uncle and meeting the eyes of the face that was like a fine mask, opened a conversation.
vi: As long as the servant was present, they did not say another word. When the coffee had been served and only the two of them remained, the nephew looked at his uncle, gazed directly into the eyes of that delicate mask-like face, and began the conversation.
tr: No other conversation took place between them during the time the servant was in the room. After the coffee service, when they were alone, the nephew looked into the uncle's face, which resembled a beautiful mask, and into his eyes, and broached the subject.
es: They exchanged no more words while the servant was present. Once the coffee was served, and uncle and nephew were alone, the latter started the conversation, fixing his eyes on the face of the former, which seemed like a mask.

en: “I have come back, sir, as you anticipate, pursuing the object that took me away. It carried me into great and unexpected peril; but it is a sacred object, and if it had carried me to death I hope it would have sustained me.”
vi: − I have returned, sir, as you know, to continue the purpose that made me leave. That purpose has pushed me into immeasurable danger; but it is a sacred purpose and if I must die for it, I still wish to pursue it to the end.
tr: "As you might guess, sir, I returned to pursue the matter that drove me away from here." "Because of this, I found myself in unexpected, significant trouble, but this is a sacred purpose, and even if it led me to death, I would not abandon this purpose.""
es: —I have returned, uncle, pursuing the same goal that forced me to leave. I have faced immense danger; but the goal is so sacred that even if death had befallen me, my courage would not have faltered.

en: “Not to death,” said the uncle; “it is not necessary to say, to death.”
vi: − Don't say "die," - said the uncle, - there's no need to say "die." − I doubt that, - replied the nephew, - if it pushes me to the point of death, I wonder if you would stop me.
tr: "Taking to death?" said the uncle; "Why is there a need to talk about death now?"
es: —Not death, dear—replied the uncle;—that lady should not even be named.

en: “I doubt, sir,” returned the nephew, “whether, if it had carried me to the utmost brink of death, you would have cared to stop me there.”
vi: − Don't say "die," - said the uncle, - there's no need to say "die." − I doubt that, - replied the nephew, - if it pushes me to the point of death, I wonder if you would stop me.
tr: "If this matter brought me to the brink of death," said the nephew, "I am not sure if you would do anything to save me, sir."
es: —I highly doubt, uncle—replied the nephew,—that you would have extended a hand to me, even seeing me placed on the very edge of death.

en: The deepened marks in the nose, and the lengthening of the fine straight lines in the cruel face, looked ominous as to that; the uncle made a graceful gesture of protest, which was so clearly a slight form of good breeding that it was not reassuring.
vi: The deep lines on the tip of the nose and the fine wrinkles running across that ruthless face looked more ominous than reassuring; the uncle made a polite gesture of protest, but it was clearly just a sign of courtesy rather than reassurance.
tr: Upon this, the deep scars on your uncle's nose and the distinct and straight lines on his cruel face took on a sinister appearance; with a dignified hand gesture that reflected his good upbringing rather than being comforting, he objected.
es: The uncle's nostrils flared and the lines on his face deepened, giving his appearance a more cruel expression; but the Marquis made a graceful gesture of protest, which was not at all reassuring due to its overly palpable effect of the nobleman's refined manners.

en: “Indeed, sir,” pursued the nephew, “for anything I know, you may have expressly worked to give a more suspicious appearance to the suspicious circumstances that surrounded me.”
vi: − Sir, - the nephew continued, - in fact, from what I know, it is possible that you have deliberately arranged things to make my already suspicious circumstances even more suspicious.
tr: "Actually, sir," continued the nephew, "if it were up to me, you would do everything in your power to make my already suspicious situation even more suspicious.."
es: —Speaking frankly—replied the nephew,—if my information is correct, you have done everything possible to give weight to the suspicions arising from the overly suspicious circumstances that surrounded me.

en: “No, no, no,” said the uncle, pleasantly.
vi: − No, no, no, - the uncle said, in a cheerful voice.
tr: "No, no, no," said the uncle sweetly.
es: —No, no, no, no!—replied the uncle, laughing.

en: “But, however that may be,” resumed the nephew, glancing at him with deep distrust, “I know that your diplomacy would stop me by any means, and would know no scruple as to means.”
vi: − But whether or not, - the nephew looked at the Marquis with evident suspicion, - I know your strategy is to stop me by any means, and you won't shy away from any measure. −
tr: Glancing at the Marquis with deep suspicion, the nephew continued, "Even if you don't do it yourself, you will involve your men and, with ruthlessness, somehow stop me.""
es: —We will not discuss that point—continued the nephew, looking at his interlocutor with evident distrust.

en: “My friend, I told you so,” said the uncle, with a fine pulsation in the two marks. “Do me the favour to recall that I told you so, long ago.”
vi: My dear, I already told you, - the uncle said, the two lines on the tip of his nose slightly flaring. - Please remember what I told you, a long time ago.
tr: "Look my dear, I told you," said the uncle, leaving a barely noticeable pause between two sentences. "Please remember what I told you a long time ago."
es: —I am aware that, in exchange for stopping me on the way, you will exhaust all the resources of your special diplomacy, just as I am also aware that in terms of resources, you are not very scrupulous. —My dear nephew, I will allow myself to beg you to try to remember, to keep in mind what I told you a long time ago, a very long time ago.

en: “I recall it.”
vi: − I haven't forgotten. −
tr: "I remember."
es: —I remember it perfectly.

en: “Thank you,” said the Marquis—very sweetly indeed.
vi: Thank you, - the Marquis said, in an exceedingly sweet voice.
tr: "Thank you," said the Marquis, his voice sounding truly sweet.
es: —Thank you very much—replied the Marquis, with a voice that sounded like a musical instrument.

en: His tone lingered in the air, almost like the tone of a musical instrument.
vi: The resonance of that voice kept echoing like a musical note.
tr: His voice resonated in the room like the sound of a musical instrument.
es: —Thank you very much—replied the Marquis, with a voice that sounded like a musical instrument.

en: “In effect, sir,” pursued the nephew, “I believe it to be at once your bad fortune, and my good fortune, that has kept me out of a prison in France here.”
vi: The nephew continued: − Honestly, I believe that it was both your bad luck and my good luck that kept me from being thrown into prison in this land of France.
tr: "If you look at it closely, sir," continued the nephew, "the only reason I haven't ended up in prison here in France is because of your misfortune and my good fortune.""
es: —Indeed, uncle; I firmly believe that I owe it to his bad luck, and to my good star, that I am not currently confined in some prison in France.

en: “I do not quite understand,” returned the uncle, sipping his coffee. “Dare I ask you to explain?”
vi: − "I don't quite understand what you mean," the uncle replied while sipping his coffee. "Can you be more specific?" − "I think that if you hadn't fallen out of favor with the court, and if it weren't for that ominous cloud over the past few years, you would have already thrown me into prison indefinitely with just one order."
tr: "I didn't quite understand what you meant," replied the uncle, sipping his coffee. "Could you speak a bit more clearly?"
es: —I don't quite understand—replied the uncle, taking a sip of coffee. —Would you be so kind as to explain? —With great pleasure.

en: “I believe that if you were not in disgrace with the Court, and had not been overshadowed by that cloud for years past, a letter de cachet would have sent me to some fortress indefinitely.”
vi: "Can you be more specific?" − "I think that if you hadn't fallen out of favor with the court, and if it weren't for that ominous cloud over the past few years, you would have already thrown me into prison indefinitely with just one order."
tr: "If your relationship with the Palace had not soured and this stain had not clung to you for so many years, it would have been a simple matter to throw me into a dungeon with a letter bearing the king's signature.""
es: I mean to say that, had you not fallen into disgrace at court, had you not been under the dark shadow of that cloud that has been enveloping you for some years, I would not have lacked a lettre de cachet that would have opened the doors of a fortress for me indefinitely.

en: “It is possible,” said the uncle, with great calmness. “For the honour of the family, I could even resolve to incommode you to that extent. Pray excuse me!”
vi: − "Quite possible," the uncle said very calmly. "For the honor of the family, I might even decide to take such drastic measures." "I'm sorry! − I understand that, luckily for me, at the reception the day before yesterday, you were still being treated coldly as usual," the nephew noted.
tr: "It's possible," said the uncle with great composure. "I could give you such a trouble for the honor of the family." Sorry, please!"
es: —It is very possible—replied the uncle, with unshakable calm—that the honor of the family might have driven me to bother you to that extent.

en: “I perceive that, happily for me, the Reception of the day before yesterday was, as usual, a cold one,” observed the nephew.
vi: "I'm sorry! − I understand that, luckily for me, at the reception the day before yesterday, you were still being treated coldly as usual," the nephew noted.
tr: "I was in good spirits, but the Reception two days ago was, as usual, quite boring," said the nephew.
es: —Fortunately for me, I observe that at the reception the day before yesterday you encountered the same coldness as always—said the nephew.

en: “I would not say happily, my friend,” returned the uncle, with refined politeness; “I would not be sure of that. A good opportunity for consideration, surrounded by the advantages of solitude, might influence your destiny to far greater advantage than you influence it for yourself. But it is useless to discuss the question. I am, as you say, at a disadvantage. These little instruments of correction, these gentle aids to the power and honour of families, these slight favours that might so incommode you, are only to be obtained now by interest and importunity. They are sought by so many, and they are granted (comparatively) to so few! It used not to be so, but France in all such things is changed for the worse. Our not remote ancestors held the right of life and death over the surrounding vulgar. From this room, many such dogs have been taken out to be hanged; in the next room (my bedroom), one fellow, to our knowledge, was poniarded on the spot for professing some insolent delicacy respecting his daughter—his daughter? We have lost many privileges; a new philosophy has become the mode; and the assertion of our station, in these days, might (I do not go so far as to say would, but might) cause us real inconvenience. All very bad, very bad!”
vi: − "I don't think it's luck, my dear," the uncle replied, his tone still polite and courteous. "I'm not so sure about that." "Prison is also a good opportunity to reflect in suitable solitude, and it might influence your fate even more than if you were to steer your own destiny." "But what's the use of discussing that." "As you said, I am at a disadvantage." "Such small corrective measures, those gentle tools supporting the authority and prestige of the family, those trivial concessions might be very inconvenient for you, requiring interest and pleading." "Many seek it, but very few are granted! It used to be different, but France has changed for the worse." "Not long ago, our ancestors held the power of life and death over the coarse commoners around." "From this very room, many such beasts were dragged out and hanged; in the adjacent room, now my bedroom, one was reportedly stabbed to death on the spot for daring to speak impertinently about his daughter! What was his daughter worth? We've lost many privileges; the new philosophy has become fashionable; in these times, asserting the family's status might, I won't say certainly but might, cause us real difficulties." "Everything is very bad, very bad!
tr: "If I were you, I wouldn't say I'm in good spirits, my dear," replied the uncle with tremendous politeness; "Don't be so sure about that. The chance of a good reputation surrounded by the advantages of solitude can influence your fate much more than what you do on your own. However, there's no point in discussing this matter. As you said, things are against me. These small initiatives that help improve the situation, the elegant aids that contribute to the power and honor of families, these tiny favors that disturb you so much are now only obtained through self-interest and sycophancy. There are many people chasing after these, but (relatively) very few get them! It wasn't like this before, but France has gone very bad in these matters. The generations just before us held the rights to decide the lives and deaths of these insolent people around. Many dogs were taken from this room to be hanged; in the next room [my bedroom], we know a man was stabbed because of the derogatory remarks he made about a girl, yes, about the girl. We've lost many privileges; there's a new philosophy in effect now and making a claim about this situation these days could cause us serious problems (saying it will cause would be too much, so I say could cause]. The situation is bad, very bad!"
es: —Forgive me for saying, my dear nephew, that I, in your place, would not assert that my misfortune at court is a fortune for you. It is very likely that the reflections that solitude in a jail would have suggested to you would have had a more beneficial influence on your future destiny than your actions enjoying freedom. But it is useless to discuss this matter. I find myself, as you say, in a disadvantageous position. Today, only interest or importunities achieve those small instruments of correction, those gentle means to strengthen the power and honor of families, those insignificant favors that could have bothered you so much. So many covet them, and so few (comparatively) obtain them! It was not like this in the past, but things have changed a lot, and they change every day, and it is noteworthy that they go from bad to worse. Our ancestors enjoyed the power of life and death over their vassals and common people. How many of those dogs have left this very room to be hanged immediately! As far as I know, in my bedroom an insolent rogue who dared to utter some tasteless joke about his daughter was stabbed to death... We have lost many privileges; that is the truth. A new philosophy has come into fashion, and I cannot deny that today, if we insisted on defending all our rights, we might encounter serious inconveniences. Things are getting bad, very bad!

en: The Marquis took a gentle little pinch of snuff, and shook his head; as elegantly despondent as he could becomingly be of a country still containing himself, that great means of regeneration.
vi: The Marquis took a pinch of snuff and shook his head elegantly, appearing deeply disappointed with the country that harbored him, a great man capable of restoring the family's status." −
tr: Mark took a pinch of snuff and shook his head from side to side; he was in a state of the most elegant despair about this new development in the country he was still in.
es: The Marquis took a pinch of snuff and shook his head with the expression of someone who regrets that a country disregards such excellent means of regeneration.

en: “We have so asserted our station, both in the old time and in the modern time also,” said the nephew, gloomily, “that I believe our name to be more detested than any name in France.”
vi: "We have asserted our status, both in the past and now," the nephew said sadly, "to the point that I believe our family's prestige in France is more hated than any other."
tr: "We have made our stance so clear since ancient times," said the nephew in a sad voice, "that there is no family more hated than ours in all of France."
es: —In such a way we have asserted our social position, both in past times and in our days—replied the nephew with a somber tone,—that we have managed to make France pronounce our names with aversion and hatred.

en: “Let us hope so,” said the uncle. “Detestation of the high is the involuntary homage of the low.”
vi: − Let's hope so, - the uncle said. - Resentment towards superiors is the involuntary respect of the lowly.
tr: "Let's look at the situation this way," said the uncle. "Hating the upper class is a kind of respect that the lower class shows involuntarily."
es: —Which we should congratulate ourselves for—observed the uncle. —Aversion and hatred are the highest and most involuntary tributes that the small pay to the great.

en: “There is not,” pursued the nephew, in his former tone, “a face I can look at, in all this country round about us, which looks at me with any deference on it but the dark deference of fear and slavery.”
vi: − Throughout this land, - the nephew continued, in the same tone, - I see no face looking at me with any respect, only the dark obedience of fear and servitude. −
tr: My nephew continued in his previous tone, "In these lands," he said, "the ill-fated respect that people will have for us stems solely and exclusively from fear and captivity."
es: —I do not find a single face in this country that looks at us with deference—replied the nephew. —In all of them, I read the respect engendered by fear and slavery.

en: “A compliment,” said the Marquis, “to the grandeur of the family, merited by the manner in which the family has sustained its grandeur. Hah!” And he took another gentle little pinch of snuff, and lightly crossed his legs.
vi: That is precisely the praise of the power of this family, - the Marquis said, - truly worthy of the way our family's power is maintained. Ha! And he took a light pinch of snuff and comfortably crossed his legs.
tr: "This is a compliment befitting the grandeur of our family," said the Marquis, "and it means we have somehow preserved this grandeur. Isn't that so?" Then he took another pinch of snuff and carelessly crossed his legs.
es: "—Which is not without flattery for the family and for the methods employed by the family to sustain its grandeur," said the Marquis, taking another pinch of snuff and crossing one leg over the other.

en: But, when his nephew, leaning an elbow on the table, covered his eyes thoughtfully and dejectedly with his hand, the fine mask looked at him sideways with a stronger concentration of keenness, closeness, and dislike, than was comportable with its wearer’s assumption of indifference.
vi: But when the nephew propped both elbows on the table, covering his contemplative, weary eyes with his hands, that delicate mask glanced at him with a sharp, scrutinizing, and hateful look, completely unlike the indifferent expression it had previously worn.
tr: When the aunt's niece propped her elbows on the table and covered her face with her hands in a pensive manner, the pleasant mask looked at her sideways with a mixture of sharpness, kindness, and intimacy that was much stronger than the indifferent expression worn by its owner.
es: The illustrious man affected a glacial indifference; but when his nephew, with his elbows on the table, covered his eyes with his hands and remained absorbed in his reflections for a considerable amount of time, the Marquis's mask disappeared and he glanced sideways at his nephew with such an expression of rancor that it clashed severely with his initial indifference.

en: “Repression is the only lasting philosophy. The dark deference of fear and slavery, my friend,” observed the Marquis, “will keep the dogs obedient to the whip, as long as this roof,” looking up to it, “shuts out the sky.”
vi: − Repression is the only enduring philosophy, - the Marquis said. - That dark obedience of fear and slavery, young master, will make the beasts obey the whip, as long as this roof, - he looked up, - still covers the sky.
tr: "The only enduring philosophy is oppression. This ill-fated reverence born out of fear and captivity, my dear," said the Marquis, looking at the ceiling, "ensures that as long as our heads are under this roof, the dogs obey the whip."
es: —The only philosophy with lasting effects is repression—observed the Marquis. — That somber respect engendered by fear and slavery, my friend, will make the dogs remain obedient to the whip as long as this roof protects us from the elements.

en: That might not be so long as the Marquis supposed. If a picture of the chateau as it was to be a very few years hence, and of fifty like it as they too were to be a very few years hence, could have been shown to him that night, he might have been at a loss to claim his own from the ghastly, fire-charred, plunder-wrecked rains. As for the roof he vaunted, he might have found that shutting out the sky in a new way—to wit, for ever, from the eyes of the bodies into which its lead was fired, out of the barrels of a hundred thousand muskets.
vi: That might not be as long as the Marquis thinks. If tonight I could show you the image of this castle just a few years later, and the image of fifty other estates like it a few years later, you might not recognize which is the residence among those terrifying ruins, plundered and charred. As for the roof you praise, you would surely see it covering the sky in a different way - that is, with eyes forever darkened as bodies have absorbed countless bullets fired from hundreds of thousands of guns.
tr: This period might not be as long as the Marquis thought. If that night he were shown a picture of the state of this castle a few years later, or even fifty years later that would pass like a few years, he would not believe that this dreadful ruin, burned to ashes and plundered, belonged to him. As for the roof he was so proud of, he could see that it was covered in a completely different way – with people whose eyes eternally spewed fire and hundreds of thousands of rifles from which bullets spread.
es: Perhaps the roof was destined to collapse sooner than the good Marquis believed. If that night they had shown him a picture of what his castle would be like in a few years, and hundreds of castles similar to his, surely no one would have made him believe in the fidelity of the painting.

en: “Meanwhile,” said the Marquis, “I will preserve the honour and repose of the family, if you will not. But you must be fatigued. Shall we terminate our conference for the night?”
vi: − As for now, - the Marquis continued, - I am the protector of the honor and peace of this family, something you do not wish to do. But surely you must be tired. Shall we end the conversation tonight?
tr: "By the way," said the Marquis, "if you won't protect the honor and peace of the family, I will." "But you must be very tired now." "Shall we end our conversation for tonight?""
es: —In the meantime—continued the Marquis,—it is my responsibility to safeguard the honor and peace of our family, whether you want it or not... But now I realize you must be exhausted: shall we end our discussion for tonight?

en: “A moment more.”
vi: − A little longer. −
tr: "One more minute."
es: —One more moment.

en: “An hour, if you please.”
vi: One more hour, if you wish. −
tr: "If you want, we can talk for another hour."
es: —One hour, if that's your preference.

en: “Sir,” said the nephew, “we have done wrong, and are reaping the fruits of wrong.”
vi: Sir, - the nephew said, - we have sown the wind and now we are about to reap the whirlwind.
tr: "Sir," said the nephew, "we made a mistake and now we are reaping the fruits of that mistake.""
es: —We have acted wrongly, uncle, and the fruits of our iniquity are ripening.

en: “We have done wrong?” repeated the Marquis, with an inquiring smile, and delicately pointing, first to his nephew, then to himself.
vi: − Are we sowing the wind? - The Marquis repeated with an inquisitive smile, gently pointing his finger at his nephew and then at himself.
tr: "Did we make a mistake?" repeated the Marquis, with an inquisitive smile, first pointing gently at his nephew and then at himself.
es: —Have we done wrong?—repeated the uncle, smiling.

en: “Our family; our honourable family, whose honour is of so much account to both of us, in such different ways. Even in my father’s time, we did a world of wrong, injuring every human creature who came between us and our pleasure, whatever it was. Why need I speak of my father’s time, when it is equally yours? Can I separate my father’s twin-brother, joint inheritor, and next successor, from himself?”
vi: − Our family, our noble family, that nobility holds great significance for both you and me, but in two vastly different ways. Even during my father's time, we indeed committed many wrongs, harming anyone who stood in the way of our pleasures, whatever those pleasures might be. Why should I speak of my father's time, when it was also your time? Can I separate the twin brother, the co-heir, and the successor that you are from my own father?
tr: "Our family; our honorable family, means completely different things to both of us, it seems. Even in my father's time, we made a lot of mistakes, we harmed many people who came between us and our pleasures. But why am I talking about my father's time, isn't it your time too? Is it possible to distinguish my father from his twin brother, his co-heir, his successor?"
es: —Our family has committed a thousand errors, yes, our honorable family, whose honor is so important to both of us. Even in my father's time, we committed a thousand iniquities, sacrificing without hesitation any human being who stood between us and our pleasures... But why speak of my father's time, when the same happens in yours? Can I, perhaps, establish a separation between my father and his twin brother, his joint heir, his immediate and inevitable successor?

en: “Death has done that!” said the Marquis.
vi: − Death has already done that! - The Marquis said.
tr: "Death did this already!" said the Marquis.
es: —The hand of death called me to succeed it.

en: “And has left me,” answered the nephew, “bound to a system that is frightful to me, responsible for it, but powerless in it; seeking to execute the last request of my dear mother’s lips, and obey the last look of my dear mother’s eyes, which implored me to have mercy and to redress; and tortured by seeking assistance and power in vain.”
vi: − And it has bound me to an institution that I abhor, for which I am responsible but utterly powerless, - the nephew replied. - I must find a way to fulfill the last wish that my beloved mother expressed, following the final gaze of my beloved mother pleading for me to forgive and make amends for the past; and I have suffered in vain seeking help.
tr: "And left me within this terrible system," replied the nephew, "the responsibility is on me but I am powerless; I am trying to fulfill the last wish that fell from my dear mother's lips and to heed the last look in her eyes, as if she were asking me to show mercy and correct the wrongs, but now I am in the agony of searching for support and strength in vain."
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain.

en: “Seeking them from me, my nephew,” said the Marquis, touching him on the breast with his forefinger—they were now standing by the hearth—“you will for ever seek them in vain, be assured.”
vi: − If you ask me for help, - the Marquis said as he lightly poked his nephew's chest with his index finger, the two of them standing by the fireplace at that moment, - then you can be sure that it will forever be hopeless.
tr: "If you are looking for them here, my nephew," said the Marquis, touching his nephew's chest with his index finger – they were now standing by the fireplace – "you can be sure you will be waiting forever."
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain.

en: Every fine straight line in the clear whiteness of his face, was cruelly, craftily, and closely compressed, while he stood looking quietly at his nephew, with his snuff-box in his hand. Once again he touched him on the breast, as though his finger were the fine point of a small sword, with which, in delicate finesse, he ran him through the body, and said,
vi: All the delicate lines on that pale face were brutally and cunningly wrinkled as the Marquis, holding a snuffbox, stood silently watching his nephew. Once again, the Marquis pointed at the chest of the person opposite as if his index finger were a sharp dagger that he would skillfully and cleverly thrust through that body.
tr: Mark stood where he was, silently watching his nephew with a snuffbox in his hand, while every line on his clean white face had deepened cruelly, cunningly, and almost uniformly. Once again, he touched his nephew's chest with his index finger, as if his finger were the sharp tip of a small sword that delicately and skillfully etched a mark on his body, and said: "My dear, I will continue this system I am in until my last breath."'"
es: —And the same hand left me chained to a system that repulses me, that horrifies me, making me responsible for what is beyond my control to prevent; it prevents me from fulfilling the final plea murmured by the lips of my saintly mother, it prevents me from obeying the last, silent, but pathetic order dictated by the beloved eyes of that exemplary lady, who urged me to have pity and compassion, and to never close my ears to the voice of justice; and finally, it tears my soul apart, convincing me that I need a hand to help me and that I seek it in vain. —If you seek it in me, my dear nephew, I assure you that you are wasting your time: you will never find it.

en: “My friend, I will die, perpetuating the system under which I have lived.”
vi: He said: − Dear child, I will protect the institution that I have lived for until death.
tr: Once again, he touched his nephew's chest with his index finger, as if his finger were the sharp tip of a small sword that delicately and skillfully etched a mark on his body, and said: "My dear, I will continue this system I am in until my last breath."'"
es: I have decided to go to the grave perpetuating the system under which I was born and have lived.

en: When he had said it, he took a culminating pinch of snuff, and put his box in his pocket.
vi: After finishing his words, he took one last pleasurable puff of his cigarette and then put the cigarette case back into his pocket.
tr: After saying this, he took one last big pinch of snuff and put the box in his pocket.
es: He took another pinch of snuff, put the little box back in his pocket, and added:

en: “Better to be a rational creature,” he added then, after ringing a small bell on the table, “and accept your natural destiny. But you are lost, Monsieur Charles, I see.”
vi: − It is best to live according to reason, - he added after ringing the small bell on the table to call the servant, - and accept one's predestined fate. But I see you have lost it, young master Charles.
tr: Then, after ringing the small bell on the table, he added, "It is best to be reasonable and accept your drawn fate. However, I see that you have lost this, Monsieur Charles."
es: —It is preferable to listen to the voice of reason and accept the natural destiny... But I observe that you are lost, my dear Carlos.

en: “This property and France are lost to me,” said the nephew, sadly; “I renounce them.”
vi: − I have lost both this inheritance and my France, - the nephew said sadly.
tr: "All this property and France are lost to me," said the nephew sadly, "I have given up on all of them.""
es: —Lost to me are these properties and even France—replied the nephew bitterly.

en: “Are they both yours to renounce? France may be, but is the property? It is scarcely worth mentioning; but, is it yet?”
vi: - I have given up on both. − Neither of them belongs to you, so why give up? France might be possible, but the inheritance? That's not even worth mentioning; but does it belong to you yet?
tr: "Are these yours? It might be France, okay, but this property, wealth? Maybe it's unnecessary to even talk about it, but do you think it's yours?"
es: —I renounce them. —But can you renounce them? I've always believed that to renounce, one must first possess. I don't know if France is yours yet; but the assets of our family... Of course, it's hardly worth talking about; but do you consider them yours?

en: “I had no intention, in the words I used, to claim it yet. If it passed to me from you, to-morrow—”
vi: − I said that without any intention of claiming that right. If I inherit from my uncle tomorrow... − I dare say that is a vain hope.
tr: "I did not intend to make such a claim. But if it passes from you to me, then tomorrow..."
es: —When I spoke as I did, it never occurred to me to allude to the rights I have over them, much less to claim their possession. If tomorrow they were to pass from your hands to mine...

en: “Which I have the vanity to hope is not probable.”
vi: If I inherit from my uncle tomorrow... − I dare say that is a vain hope.
tr: "I hope that such a thing would not be possible."
es: —What I have the vanity to consider very unlikely... —...

en: “—or twenty years hence—”
vi: − ... or twenty years later... −
tr: "Well, what about twenty years from now..."
es: Or twenty years from now...

en: “You do me too much honour,” said the Marquis; “still, I prefer that supposition.”
vi: You honor me too much, - the Marquis said, - but I prefer that hypothesis.
tr: "Ah, how much you have honored me," said the Marquis; "still, I would prefer this assumption to be true.""
es: —You give me too much credit; but I prefer this assumption to the first.

en: “—I would abandon it, and live otherwise and elsewhere. It is little to relinquish. What is it but a wilderness of misery and ruin!”
vi: − ... I would still give it up and live differently, somewhere else. What is there to regret in this place full of suffering and decay.
tr: "I would give up everything and live in a different way and in a different place. Leaving is not that difficult. What meaning do these have amidst all this misery and ruin?"
es: —I would abandon them, to live elsewhere and a different kind of life. It wouldn't be much of an abandonment! After all, a dreadful desert that presents nothing but miseries and ruins!

en: “Hah!” said the Marquis, glancing round the luxurious room.
vi: − Ah! - the Marquis said while looking around the luxurious room.
tr: "Ha!" said the Marquis, glancing around the luxurious room.
es: —Yes?—exclaimed the Marquis, casting his gaze around that sumptuous room.

en: “To the eye it is fair enough, here; but seen in its integrity, under the sky, and by the daylight, it is a crumbling tower of waste, mismanagement, extortion, debt, mortgage, oppression, hunger, nakedness, and suffering.”
vi: − Here it looks beautiful, but in reality, if seen under clear sunlight, it is all just a useless ruin, chaotic, plundered, indebted, mortgaged, oppressed, hungry, naked, and suffering.
tr: "It looks pleasing to the eye here, but when viewed as a whole, under this sky, in the daylight, it is actually a tower where waste, mismanagement, tyranny, debt, mortgage, oppression, hunger, nakedness, and pain are piled up.""
es: —I will not say that the sight does not find some attraction in those; but when studied in their essence, in the light of reason and justice, they are a crumbling tower of extortions, wastefulness, debts, injustices, oppressions, hunger, nakedness, and suffering.

en: “Hah!” said the Marquis again, in a well-satisfied manner.
vi: − Ah! - the Marquis again uttered a sound of satisfaction.
tr: "Ha!" said the Marquis again, with a satisfied demeanor.
es: —Yes?—repeated the Marquis with a tone of satisfaction.

en: “If it ever becomes mine, it shall be put into some hands better qualified to free it slowly (if such a thing is possible) from the weight that drags it down, so that the miserable people who cannot leave it and who have been long wrung to the last point of endurance, may, in another generation, suffer less; but it is not for me. There is a curse on it, and on all this land.”
vi: − If this place were mine, I would entrust it to someone more capable to gradually, if possible, free it from the heavy yoke it has borne for so long, so that the wretched people who cannot leave this land and have been drained of their endurance for generations might suffer less in the future; but this place is not for me. This estate has been cursed, and so has this land. −
tr: "If one day these lands become mine, I would entrust them to skillful hands that would gradually liberate them from the weight that has driven them to collapse (if such a thing is possible), so that the people who cannot leave here and have long been at the end of their endurance, or rather the generations that come after them, would suffer less, but this place is not for me. There is a curse here and over all these lands."
es: —If they come to be mine, I will entrust them to more competent hands than mine so that they can gradually be relieved, if I arrive in time, from the enormous weight that drags them to the precipice, so that the unfortunate ones who are tied to them suffer less in the future. I won't be able to do it; I know. A curse weighs upon them, and not only upon them but also upon the entire nation.

en: “And you?” said the uncle. “Forgive my curiosity; do you, under your new philosophy, graciously intend to live?”
vi: And you? - the uncle said. - May I be a bit curious; with that new philosophy, how do you intend to live? −
tr: "And you?" asked the uncle. "Forgive my curiosity, but is your intention to live according to this new philosophy?"
es: —And you?—asked the uncle. —Pardon my curiosity; do you expect to live off the manna from heaven under the shadow of your newly minted philosophy?

en: “I must do, to live, what others of my countrymen, even with nobility at their backs, may have to do some day—work.”
vi: To live, I must work, like my fellow countrymen, even those of noble birth will one day have to work.
tr: "I will do what my fellow citizens, even the noble ones, will have to do one day to sustain their lives – I will work."
es: —I will have to live on the same thing that so many of my fellow countrymen live on, no matter how many their credentials, no matter how ancient their nobility: work.

en: “In England, for example?”
vi: − In England, for example? − Yes, sir.
tr: "In England, for example?"
es: —In England, for example?

en: “Yes. The family honour, sir, is safe from me in this country. The family name can suffer from me in no other, for I bear it in no other.”
vi: In that country, I will be able to preserve the family's honor. By leaving my homeland, I will not tarnish the family's honor because I will no longer hold any title.
tr: "Yes. There, no harm will come to me for our family's honor, sir. Since I will not bear this name anywhere else, there will be no problem in other countries either."
es: —Yes. The honor of the family can sleep peacefully. I will not tarnish it by working while I am in this country, and I will not be able to tarnish it in another simply because, outside of here, I will not bear the family name.

en: The ringing of the bell had caused the adjoining bed-chamber to be lighted. It now shone brightly, through the door of communication. The Marquis looked that way, and listened for the retreating step of his valet.
vi: The sound of the bell signaled the servant to light the lamp in the adjacent bedroom. Through the connecting door, that room was already brightly lit. The marquis looked towards the bedroom and listened to the retreating footsteps of the servant.
tr: With the ringing of the bell, the lights in the adjacent bedroom turned on. The bright lights of the room reached the place where they were talking. The Marquis looked that way and listened to the receding footsteps of his servant.
es: The Marquis rang a bell. Immediately, the adjacent room lit up. The Marquis waited for the servant who had turned on the lights to leave, and when he heard the footsteps receding, he said, looking at his nephew with a smiling face:

en: “England is very attractive to you, seeing how indifferently you have prospered there,” he observed then, turning his calm face to his nephew with a smile.
vi: − England is indeed very attractive to you, even though you haven't been very successful there, - he remarked, and that indifferent face turned to smile at his nephew. −
tr: Then, turning his cold face towards his nephew with a smile, he said, "England seems very appealing to you, of course things went well there."
es: —England has many attractions for you, although, to be honest, I'm not surprised considering how much you have prospered there.

en: “I have already said, that for my prospering there, I am sensible I may be indebted to you, sir. For the rest, it is my Refuge.”
vi: As I said, to be successful there, I know I will have to be grateful to you, sir. Otherwise, it is my refuge. −
tr: "As I said, I am grateful to you, sir, for things going smoothly. Other than that, it is a Sanctuary for me."
es: —I have already expressed that I believe I owe you all the fortunes and prosperities I found there. In any case, England is my refuge.

en: “They say, those boastful English, that it is the Refuge of many. You know a compatriot who has found a Refuge there? A Doctor?”
vi: Those boastful Englishmen still say that England is a refuge for many people. Do you know a compatriot who also found refuge over there? A doctor? − I know.
tr: "According to what they say, that is, according to the arrogant English, it was a Shelter for many people. Do you know any other citizen who took refuge there? A doctor or someone?"
es: —If we are to believe the vain Englishmen, it is the refuge of many. Do you know of a compatriot of ours who sought refuge there? I am referring to a doctor.

en: “Yes.”
vi: − With his daughter?
tr: "Yes."
es: —I know him.

en: “With a daughter?”
vi: − With his daughter?
tr: "Does he have a daughter?""
es: —Whom does a daughter accompany?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − Yes − Ah, - the Marquis said.
tr: "Var."
es: —Yes.

en: “Yes,” said the Marquis. “You are fatigued. Good night!”
vi: - You must be tired. Goodbye!
tr: "It means," said the Marquis. "You are very tired now. Come on, good night!"
es: —The same one. You're exhausted... Good night.

en: As he bent his head in his most courtly manner, there was a secrecy in his smiling face, and he conveyed an air of mystery to those words, which struck the eyes and ears of his nephew forcibly. At the same time, the thin straight lines of the setting of the eyes, and the thin straight lips, and the markings in the nose, curved with a sarcasm that looked handsomely diabolic.
vi: As he bowed very politely, his smiling face had a hidden look that made his words full of mystery, and both the image and the sound seemed to strike the nephew's eyes and ears. At the same time, the thin lines around his eyelids and his flat thin lips, along with the wrinkles at the tip of his nose, all curved with a mocking expression that made the Marquis look both beautiful and strangely evil.
tr: While bowing his head gracefully, the Marquis had a mysterious expression on his smiling face, which added a mysterious air to his words that did not escape his nephew's eyes and ears. Moreover, his eyes, which were thin and straight lines, along with his thin and straight lips and the mark on his nose, were twisted with a devilish charm of mockery.
es: The smile with which he accompanied the nod of his head that he made to his nephew as a courteous farewell and the tone with which he pronounced the last words, enveloped a mystery that could not help but impress the nephew.

en: “Yes,” repeated the Marquis. “A Doctor with a daughter. Yes. So commences the new philosophy! You are fatigued. Good night!”
vi: − Yes, - the Marquis repeated. - A doctor with his daughter. Yes. Thus begins a new philosophy. You are already tired. Goodbye!
tr: "That's right," repeated the Marquis. "A Doctor with a daughter. Yes. So this is what started your new philosophy! You must be very tired. Well, good night!"
es: —Yes—repeated the Marquis.—A doctor with a daughter... Yes. This is how the new philosophy begins!... Good night.

en: It would have been of as much avail to interrogate any stone face outside the chateau as to interrogate that face of his. The nephew looked at him, in vain, in passing on to the door.
vi: Inquiring that face is no different from inquiring the stone statues outside the castle. The young man looked bewilderedly at the Marquis as he walked out the door.
tr: Questioning the uncle's face was harder than questioning the stone faces in the castle's garden. The nephew looked at the Marquis in vain as he walked out the door.
es: The young man fixed his eyes on her face as if he expected to find in it the explanation of the last words that had hurt his ears. A wasted effort. He would have achieved the same by questioning the faces of the stone statues that were so abundant in the castle.

en: “Good night!” said the uncle. “I look to the pleasure of seeing you again in the morning. Good repose! Light Monsieur my nephew to his chamber there!—And burn Monsieur my nephew in his bed, if you will,” he added to himself, before he rang his little bell again, and summoned his valet to his own bedroom.
vi: − Goodbye! - The uncle said. - I hope to see you again tomorrow morning. Good night! Light the torch to guide the young master back to his room!... Then you can burn my nephew on the bed as well, - he muttered to himself before ringing the small bell again, calling the servant to prepare the private room.
tr: "Good night!" said the uncle. "I am glad we will see each other again tomorrow morning. Rest now! Light the way for the gentleman who will be my nephew so he can go to his room! –and if you can manage it, even closer," he muttered to himself, then rang the small bell again to call the servant to his own room.
es: —Good night!—added the uncle. —The desire to see you tomorrow morning will keep me awake all night... Rest well... Turn on the lights in my dear nephew's bedroom... And roast my dear nephew in bed, if you can!—he added to himself, before ringing the bell again, calling the valet to his room.

en: The valet come and gone, Monsieur the Marquis walked to and fro in his loose chamber-robe, to prepare himself gently for sleep, that hot still night. Rustling about the room, his softly-slippered feet making no noise on the floor, he moved like a refined tiger:—looked like some enchanted marquis of the impenitently wicked sort, in story, whose periodical change into tiger form was either just going off, or just coming on.
vi: The servants came and went, the Marquis donned a loose nightgown and walked back and forth to relax and fall asleep in the stifling, silent night. Only the sound of rustling fabric and the soft footsteps on the floor could be heard, as he walked around the room like a majestic tiger - much like some unruly, cruel Marquis from legend, punished by magic to transform into a tiger and now in the process of changing back into a man or about to become a beast.
tr: The servant had come and gone, and Monsieur Marquis, on that warm, still night, was pacing back and forth in his room in his loose nightgown, slowly preparing himself for sleep. As he walked around the room, his soft slippers made no sound, and he moved like a graceful tiger – he resembled an unashamed, incorrigible, magical marquis, constantly transforming either into a tiger or back from one, just like in fairy tales.
es: The valet answered the call and went out again, leaving the Marquis in his underwear and ready to get into bed. It took him a few minutes to do so. If someone had seen him dressed as he was and wearing slippers, pacing the room with a silent and lively step, similar to that of a royal tiger, they would probably have taken him for the famous enchanted marquis of legend, whose periodic transformations into a feline were either beginning then or ending at that moment.

en: He moved from end to end of his voluptuous bedroom, looking again at the scraps of the day’s journey that came unbidden into his mind; the slow toil up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, the descent, the mill, the prison on the crag, the little village in the hollow, the peasants at the fountain, and the mender of roads with his blue cap pointing out the chain under the carriage. That fountain suggested the Paris fountain, the little bundle lying on the step, the women bending over it, and the tall man with his arms up, crying, “Dead!”
vi: He walked from one end of the magnificent bedroom to the other, recalling in his mind the events of the previous day's journey even though he didn't want to remember; the arduous, slow climb up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, the descent, the mill, the prison on the cliff, the small village in the valley, the commoners by the water fountain, and the road worker with the green hat pointing at the chain under the carriage. That water fountain reminded him of the one in Paris, the small bundle of cloth lying on the pedestal, the women bending over the bundle, and the tall man raising his hands to the sky shouting "Death!". −
tr: Accompanied by a flood of fragmented images from the journey he took that day, he advanced from one end to the other in the opulent bedroom; their arduous climb up the hill at sunset, the setting sun, their descent from the hill, the mill, the prison atop the cliff, the village in the valley, the villagers at the fountain, and the road worker with the blue hat showing the chain under the car. That fountain reminded him of the fountain in Paris, the small heap lying on the steps, the women gathered around it, and the tall man raising his arms and shouting "He's dead!"
es: In the depths of his imagination, while he walked from one end of his voluptuous chamber to the other, the most striking incidents of the journey that had ended that night emerged: he saw himself lazily climbing the steep slope of the hill, contemplating with the eyes of his soul the sunset, the descent of the opposite side of the hill, the mill, the chain of the galga, the prison situated at the edge of the cliff, the village in the hollow, the peasants around the fountain, and the road worker at the moment of pointing with his pointed cap to the chain of his road coach. The village fountain reminded him of the other fountain in Paris, and in it he saw the corpse of the child curled up on the base, the women bent over his little body, and the tall man who, with arms outstretched, shouted: "Dead!"

en: “I am cool now,” said Monsieur the Marquis, “and may go to bed.”
vi: It's cooler now, - the Marquis said, - I should probably go to sleep.
tr: "Oh, I feel a bit refreshed," said Monsieur Marquis, "I can lie down now."
es: —I'm getting cold—murmured Mr. Marqués. —To bed, to bed!

en: So, leaving only one light burning on the large hearth, he let his thin gauze curtains fall around him, and heard the night break its silence with a long sigh as he composed himself to sleep.
vi: Thus, leaving only a single torch burning brightly on the large fireplace, he let down the thin gauze curtains around the bed, and listened as the night broke the silence with a sigh as he drifted into sleep.
tr: She covered the thin canopy surrounding the bed, leaving only the lamp burning on top of the large fireplace, and as she fell asleep, she heard the night break its silence with a deep sigh.
es: He lay down on the bed, let the luxurious curtains fall around him, and prepared to sleep.

en: The stone faces on the outer walls stared blindly at the black night for three heavy hours; for three heavy hours, the horses in the stables rattled at their racks, the dogs barked, and the owl made a noise with very little resemblance in it to the noise conventionally assigned to the owl by men-poets. But it is the obstinate custom of such creatures hardly ever to say what is set down for them.
vi: The stone faces on the outer walls stared blindly into the dark night for three dragging hours; during those dragging three hours, the horses in the stable clattered their mangers, the dogs barked, and the owl hooted a sound that bore little resemblance to the noise poets usually attribute to it. But stubborn creatures like owls never agree to speak according to the descriptions imposed on them.
tr: For three intense hours, the stone faces on the outer walls of the building stared into the dark night with blind eyes; for three intense hours, the horses in the stables neighed, the dogs barked, and the owl hooted, making sounds that bore no resemblance to the traditional sounds depicted by poets. But it is customary for such creatures to behave unexpectedly.
es: For the span of three endless hours, the stone faces of the motionless sentinels placed outside the castle gazed into the darkness of the night; for the span of three endless hours, the restless horses struck the mangers in the stables with their hooves, and the owl emitted a peculiar sound that bore no resemblance to the song that men-poets have attributed to owls.

en: For three heavy hours, the stone faces of the chateau, lion and human, stared blindly at the night. Dead darkness lay on all the landscape, dead darkness added its own hush to the hushing dust on all the roads. The burial-place had got to the pass that its little heaps of poor grass were undistinguishable from one another; the figure on the Cross might have come down, for anything that could be seen of it. In the village, taxers and taxed were fast asleep. Dreaming, perhaps, of banquets, as the starved usually do, and of ease and rest, as the driven slave and the yoked ox may, its lean inhabitants slept soundly, and were fed and freed.
vi: For three dragging hours, the stone faces of the castle, both lion and human, stared blindly into the night. The deadly darkness enveloped the scene, the deadly darkness weighed heavily on the silent dust of the road, adding to the stillness all around. The black night blurred all the withered grass graves in the cemetery, making them indistinguishable; even if the statue of Christ on the cross stepped down, no one would notice. In the village; both the tax collector and the taxpayers were sound asleep. Perhaps the emaciated commoners were dreaming of feasts, as the hungry often dream of food, as the exhausted slave dreams of leisure, as the burdened ox dreams of rest, and in their dreams, all were well-fed and free.
tr: For three intense hours, the stone lions and human faces in the castle stared at the night with blind eyes. Dead darkness covered everywhere, dead darkness had added its own tranquility to the silent dust of the roads. The place where the dead were buried had become so cramped that the mounds covered with sparse grass could no longer be distinguished from one another; for some unknown reason, the figure on the Cross had been taken down by someone. In the village, tax collectors and taxpayers had fallen into a deep sleep. In their dreams, they were probably seeing a feast table, as often happens to those who suffer from hunger, or the kind of comfort and peace that slaves and oxen plowing the fields might see; thus, while the scrawny inhabitants of the region slept soundly, they were filling their bellies and gaining their freedom.
es: Men and stone lions of the castle fixed their pupil-less eyes on the black veils of the night for the span of three mortal hours. Black were the fields, black the forests, black the roads, black like a sea of ink the entire landscape.
