In the village cemetery, it would have been impossible to distinguish one grave from another, and no one could have said whether the cross at whose foot the woman who asked a favor from the Marquis had knelt that afternoon was still standing or had fallen down. In the village, exploiters and exploited slept deeply. Perhaps during sleep, the latter enjoyed sumptuous banquets, as often happens to those who perish from hunger, or tranquility and rest, like oxen accustomed to groaning under the yoke.

en: The fountain in the village flowed unseen and unheard, and the fountain at the chateau dropped unseen and unheard—both melting away, like the minutes that were falling from the spring of Time—through three dark hours. Then, the grey water of both began to be ghostly in the light, and the eyes of the stone faces of the chateau were opened.
vi: The village fountain flows unheard and unseen, the castle fountain drips unnoticed and unheard - both vanish into the night like every second and minute counting the rhythm of time throughout the three hours of darkness. And then, the eerie streams of the two fountains begin to glow mysteriously at dawn, and the stone statue eyes on the castle facade open wide.
tr: The fountain in the village flowed for three intense hours, unseen and unheard by anyone, and likewise, the fountain in the castle dripped unnoticed and unheard – both melted away like minutes flowing in the Fountain of Time. Then, with the dawn of the new day, the gray waters of both began to appear like ghosts, and the eyes of the stone faces in the castle opened.
es: Invisible and silent waters flowed from the village fountain, just like from the castle fountain, disappearing into the distance, like the minutes that continuously slip away from the hand of Time. After three endless hours, the waters began to take on light gray tones, and the eyes of the stone faces of the castle started to light up.

en: Lighter and lighter, until at last the sun touched the tops of the still trees, and poured its radiance over the hill. In the glow, the water of the chateau fountain seemed to turn to blood, and the stone faces crimsoned. The carol of the birds was loud and high, and, on the weather-beaten sill of the great window of the bed-chamber of Monsieur the Marquis, one little bird sang its sweetest song with all its might. At this, the nearest stone face seemed to stare amazed, and, with open mouth and dropped under-jaw, looked awe-stricken.
vi: The sky gradually brightened, brightened, until the sun finally rose to the treetops, quietly spreading its rays across the hills. In the morning glow, the water in the castle's fountain turned blood-red, and the stone statues glowed crimson. The birds' music soared high, and on the large, weather-beaten window ledge of the Marquis's bedroom, a small bird poured all its melody into its song. The song seemed to make the nearby stone statue widen its eyes, open its mouth, and gape in astonishment and fear.
tr: Slowly, the surroundings brightened and finally the sun touched the tops of the motionless trees, pouring its light down from above. In the redness, the water of the castle's fountain had turned the color of blood, and the stone faces had become bright red. Birds were singing cheerful songs loudly, and on the weather-worn sill of Monsieur Marquis's bedroom's large window, a small bird was singing its sweetest song with all its might. The nearest stone face, with its mouth wide open, seemed to be staring at it in astonishment, as if in horror.
es: The sun rose in the East, tinting the treetops and mountain peaks red. Its gleams gave a red hue to the waters that sprang from the castle's fountain and to the stone faces of men and lions. The birds chirped talkatively, one of which, bolder than its companions, exhausted the repertoire of its most beautiful songs perched on the stone windowsill of the Marquis's chamber. The nearest stone sentinel watched the singer with mute astonishment, opened its mouth, and showed signs of the deepest terror.

en: Now, the sun was full up, and movement began in the village. Casement windows opened, crazy doors were unbarred, and people came forth shivering—chilled, as yet, by the new sweet air. Then began the rarely lightened toil of the day among the village population. Some, to the fountain; some, to the fields; men and women here, to dig and delve; men and women there, to see to the poor live stock, and lead the bony cows out, to such pasture as could be found by the roadside. In the church and at the Cross, a kneeling figure or two; attendant on the latter prayers, the led cow, trying for a breakfast among the weeds at its foot.
vi: At this moment, the sun had risen high and the village below began to stir. The wide windows opened, the cracked doors unlatched, and the villagers stepped out onto the streets, shivering in the gentle chill of the new day. Then the villagers' daily tasks, rarely light, began. Some went to the water station; some went to the fields; here, men and women dug; there, women and men tended to the miserable livestock and led the emaciated cows to find the remaining patches of grass along the roadside. In the church under the cross, one or two people knelt, joining in the newly intoned prayers, while the cow they had brought along tried to fill its stomach with the wild grass at its feet.
tr: The sun was now directly overhead and the village had come to life. Window shutters were opened, the bolts of rickety doors were drawn, and people shivered as they poured out into the fresh and crisp –but cold– morning air. Then the villagers' rarely lightened, arduous hustle and bustle began. Some ran to the fountain; some to the fields; on one side, a group of men and women started digging and tilling the soil; on the other side, another group of men and women rushed to tend to the miserable animals and to take the emaciated cows to graze in the meadows they could find along the roadside. A few people were kneeling in the church, praying before the Cross, while the cows outside were searching for breakfast grass at their feet.
es: The gleams of the day star shook off the drowsiness that reigned as an absolute lord in the village. Windows were opened, doors of the houses were unbarred, and people went out shivering into the street to engage in their daily tasks. Some went to the fountain, others to the field; some to plow, others to dig or to graze emaciated livestock. In the church, two or three people remained, pleading with Heaven to preserve the life of some cow or a small number of sheep.

en: The chateau awoke later, as became its quality, but awoke gradually and surely. First, the lonely boar-spears and knives of the chase had been reddened as of old; then, had gleamed trenchant in the morning sunshine; now, doors and windows were thrown open, horses in their stables looked round over their shoulders at the light and freshness pouring in at doorways, leaves sparkled and rustled at iron-grated windows, dogs pulled hard at their chains, and reared impatient to be loosed.
vi: The castle woke up later but gradually, little by little, in accordance with its noble nature. First, the boar-hunting spears and the solitary hunting knives would glint with steel in the early sunlight, glowing red as they once did when bathed in blood; then the main doors and windows would fling open; the horses in the stables would turn their heads to look out at the light and welcome the fresh breeze rushing in through the threshold; the shimmering leaves would rustle before the iron-grilled windows; the dogs would tug fiercely at their chains, eager to be set free.
tr: The castle, in accordance with its nobility, woke up later but gradually and confidently. First, the spears and knives used in boar hunting, which were kept in a separate section, turned red; then they shone sharply under the morning sun; following that, doors and windows were flung wide open, and the horses in the stables turned their heads towards the door to look at the incoming light and fresh air, leaves sparkled and rustled on the iron-barred doors, dogs impatiently jumped, pulling their chains quickly to break free.
es: The castle woke up later, as befitted its high social rank. The sun's rays first tinged the spears, swords, and lances red; later they sparked off the swords, windows began to open, the horses in the stables grew restless, and the dogs shook the chains that held them, barking wildly in demand of freedom.

en: All these trivial incidents belonged to the routine of life, and the return of morning. Surely, not so the ringing of the great bell of the chateau, nor the running up and down the stairs; nor the hurried figures on the terrace; nor the booting and tramping here and there and everywhere, nor the quick saddling of horses and riding away?
vi: All those trivial matters are routine every morning. Of course, except for the loud ringing bell in the castle, except for the sound of footsteps running up and down the stairs, except for the hurried figures on the porch, except for the chaotic sound of shoes stepping everywhere, except for the hasty saddling and the rushing sound of galloping horses.
tr: All these trivial events were part of everyday life and were repeated every morning. But neither the ringing of the castle's big bell, nor the hustle on the stairs, nor the frantic people on the terrace, nor the rising footsteps from around, nor the hurried saddling and riding of the horses could be considered as usual matters, of course.
es: All these were trivial incidents that repeated daily, routine details of ordinary life. But something less trivial, something that was neither routine nor ordinary, was happening that morning in the castle. The great bell was ringing with insistent fury; servants were running from one place to another; many people were crossing the terrace and in the stables, several horses were being saddled with agitation. Why?

en: What winds conveyed this hurry to the grizzled mender of roads, already at work on the hill-top beyond the village, with his day’s dinner (not much to carry) lying in a bundle that it was worth no crow’s while to peck at, on a heap of stones? Had the birds, carrying some grains of it to a distance, dropped one over him as they sow chance seeds? Whether or no, the mender of roads ran, on the sultry morning, as if for his life, down the hill, knee-high in dust, and never stopped till he got to the fountain.
vi: What wind had brought that urgency to the old road worker with gray hair, who had started working on the hilltop behind the village, beside a pile of stones where there was a meager food package so unappealing that no crow bothered to peck at it? Could it be that the birds had carried that urgency away like they carried grains of rice to distant places and had accidentally scattered it upon the road worker's head? Whether or not that was the case, on that sweltering morning, he had run full tilt down the hill, dust reaching up to his knees, and ran straight to the fountain.
tr: What wind had conveyed this rush to the gray-haired road worker, who had already started working, having placed his bundle, which contained food that even a crow wouldn't deign to peck at (there wasn't much), on a pile of stones on the hill beyond the village? Had the birds, while sowing the seeds of fortune, dropped a piece of it on him? For some unknown reason, the road worker, on that stifling morning, as if his life depended on it, ran nonstop down the hill to the fountain, covered in dust and dirt up to his knees.
es: What sudden impulse had seized the road worker, moments before engrossed in his work, up there on the hilltop? Were the birds of the field trying to snatch away the meager lunch he had left on a pile of stones? Why was he running with such fury, downhill, as if his life depended on the speed of his race? Why did he sink his legs up to the knee in the dust, and devour distances without stopping to catch his breath, until he reached the fountain?

en: All the people of the village were at the fountain, standing about in their depressed manner, and whispering low, but showing no other emotions than grim curiosity and surprise. The led cows, hastily brought in and tethered to anything that would hold them, were looking stupidly on, or lying down chewing the cud of nothing particularly repaying their trouble, which they had picked up in their interrupted saunter. Some of the people of the chateau, and some of those of the posting-house, and all the taxing authorities, were armed more or less, and were crowded on the other side of the little street in a purposeless way, that was highly fraught with nothing. Already, the mender of roads had penetrated into the midst of a group of fifty particular friends, and was smiting himself in the breast with his blue cap. What did all this portend, and what portended the swift hoisting-up of Monsieur Gabelle behind a servant on horseback, and the conveying away of the said Gabelle (double-laden though the horse was), at a gallop, like a new version of the German ballad of Leonora?
vi: The entire village had gathered, standing around the fountain in a state of boredom and whispering in low tones, but showing no other emotions than cruel curiosity and surprise. The dumb cows that had been led away earlier were now hastily dragged back and tied to anything that could hold them, standing or lying down chewing on things not worth the effort that they had grazed on during their interrupted wanderings. The castle people and the station people, along with various tax officials, all more or less armed, had gathered into a group on the other side of the small road, bustling about without knowing what to do. The road worker had pushed his way into the middle of a group of about fifty acquaintances and was thumping his chest with his green hat. What misfortune had occurred, what had happened that Mr. Gabelle hurriedly mounted a horse, sitting behind the castle servant, and both galloped away like lovers in the ballad of Leonora?
tr: The entire village had gathered at the fountain, standing there with their spirits low, whispering to each other, but apart from a serious curiosity and astonishment, there was no other emotion on their faces. The cows that had been taken out to graze were hurriedly brought back and tied wherever they could be tied, either staring blankly around or lying down and chewing cud, but there was nothing in their mouths worth the trouble they had gone through from their interrupted stroll. Some people from the chateau, some from the post office, and all the tax collectors had armed themselves to some extent and were gathered on the other side of the small street, waiting aimlessly, which was quite worrisome. The road worker had already plunged into a group of fifty people and was hitting his chest with his blue cap. What did all this signify? Moreover, what did it signify that Monsieur Gabelle was being hastily pulled by a servant on horseback, and that this person, like a new adaptation of the German Lenore ballad, was galloping away (despite the horse being heavily loaded)?
es: Around it, the entire population of the village had gathered, and there they remained with consternation painted on their faces, speaking in very low voices, though without revealing any emotions other than those of somber curiosity and deep surprise. At the mouth of the street, people from the castle, servants from the post house, and all the village authorities, more or less armed, could be seen. The road worker had already penetrated the center of a group, formed by about fifty of his close friends, with whom he spoke with signs of excitement. What did all this mean? Above all, what did the arrival of Mr. Gambelle mean, who, seated on the back of a horse also ridden by a servant from the castle, was approaching the village at full gallop, despite the double load, as if he wanted to represent, slightly modified, the German legend of Leonora?

en: It portended that there was one stone face too many, up at the chateau.
vi: The misfortune was that another stone face had appeared at the castle.
tr: All this indicated that one more stone face had been added to the many in the castle.
es: All this meant that, in the castle, the stone faces had increased by one that night.

en: The Gorgon had surveyed the building again in the night, and had added the one stone face wanting; the stone face for which it had waited through about two hundred years.
vi: The Gorgon in the night glanced over this mansion once more, and added a missing stone face; the stone face that the god had been waiting for two hundred years.
tr: Gorgo had looked at the building again at night and added a stone face to replace the missing one; it was the stone face the building had been waiting for about two hundred years.
es: The Gorgon who presided over the erection of the castle undoubtedly decided to visit his work during the night, noticed that a stone face was missing, the same one they had probably been waiting for for two hundred years, and added it.

en: It lay back on the pillow of Monsieur the Marquis. It was like a fine mask, suddenly startled, made angry, and petrified. Driven home into the heart of the stone figure attached to it, was a knife. Round its hilt was a frill of paper, on which was scrawled:
vi: The stone face lay on the pillow of the Marquis. It resembled a beautiful mask, suddenly startled, angry, then turned to stone. Stabbing through the heart of the stone figure attached to that face was a knife. A piece of crumpled paper was tied around the knife's hilt, scrawled with: “Get to the grave quickly.
tr: This face was now lying on Monsieur Marquis's pillow. After a sudden shock and anger, it was like a beautiful mask turned to stone. There was a knife plunged into the heart of this stone figure. A paper with the following words scribbled on it was wrapped around the hilt:
es: The stone face lay face up on the soft pillow of the Marquis's bed. It seemed like a very fine mask, with an expression that was a little scared or angry. Attached to the head was a man's trunk, also petrified, and embedded in the heart of that trunk was a knife. Around the knife's handle was a paper, on which someone had scribbled the following words:

en: “Drive him fast to his tomb. This, from Jacques.”
vi: A piece of crumpled paper was tied around the knife's hilt, scrawled with: “Get to the grave quickly. - JACQUES” 10.
tr: Take this to his grave immediately! This was written by Jacques
es: “Take him quickly to the grave. On behalf of Santiago.”

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: - JACQUES” 10.
tr: X
es: X.

en: Two Promises
vi: Two promises Months turned into years, and after twelve months, Charles Darnay had settled in England as a senior French teacher well-versed in French literature.
tr: Two Words
es: TWO PROMISES

en: More months, to the number of twelve, had come and gone, and Mr. Charles Darnay was established in England as a higher teacher of the French language who was conversant with French literature. In this age, he would have been a Professor; in that age, he was a Tutor. He read with young men who could find any leisure and interest for the study of a living tongue spoken all over the world, and he cultivated a taste for its stores of knowledge and fancy. He could write of them, besides, in sound English, and render them into sound English. Such masters were not at that time easily found; Princes that had been, and Kings that were to be, were not yet of the Teacher class, and no ruined nobility had dropped out of Tellson’s ledgers, to turn cooks and carpenters. As a tutor, whose attainments made the student’s way unusually pleasant and profitable, and as an elegant translator who brought something to his work besides mere dictionary knowledge, young Mr. Darnay soon became known and encouraged. He was well acquainted, more-over, with the circumstances of his country, and those were of ever-growing interest. So, with great perseverance and untiring industry, he prospered.
vi: Two promises Months turned into years, and after twelve months, Charles Darnay had settled in England as a senior French teacher well-versed in French literature. Nowadays, he would be called a professor; back then, he was referred to as a university tutor*. He taught young men who were interested and keen on learning a globally popular language, nurturing in them an appreciation for the treasure trove of knowledge and the beauty of the French language. Additionally, he could write fluently in English on these subjects and translate works into English very well. Such teachers were not easy to find at that time; the royal family members awaiting succession had not yet been exiled to teach for a living, nor had any nobleman exhausted their accounts at Tellson's Bank to become a cook or carpenter. As a tutor with the goal of making learning interesting and useful for students, and as a talented translator who could bring new meanings to translations beyond the limits of dictionaries, Darnay quickly became famous and was encouraged. Moreover, he was well-informed about current events in France, which were becoming of increasing interest to many people. Thus, through perseverance, he succeeded.
tr: About twelve months had passed, and Mr. Charles Darnay had settled in England as a French teacher specializing in French Literature. If it were this age, he would be a Professor; in that age, he was a private tutor. He worked with young gentlemen who had the time and interest to learn a living language spoken all around the world, and he had developed tastes for knowledge and appreciation in this field. Additionally, he could write beautifully and translate these writings into English in an elegant manner. At that time, finding experts in this field was not easy; the Princes of the past and the Kings of the future were not included in the Teacher class, and no poor noble had emerged from Tellson's ledgers to become a cook or a carpenter. Young Mr. Darnay quickly gained a reputation and attracted attention as a teacher who both entertained and taught useful things to his students with his skills, and as a meticulous translator who added much more than just vocabulary knowledge to translations. Due to the conditions of the country and the growing interest, he became known by many people. Thus, with great determination and unending efforts, he achieved prosperity.
es: Twelve months passed. Carlos Darnay had established himself in England as a teacher of the French language and French literature. Today he would be given the pompous title of professor; at that time he was called a tutor. He taught young people who had time and wished to learn a living language that was spoken all over the world. Teachers like Darnay were not easily found in those times. Princes and kings were far from being able to be among those who could teach, and the ruined nobility did not think of straining their eyes working over the Ledgers of Tellson's Bank, nor of dedicating their skills to the culinary arts or carpentry. The young Darnay soon became known, as he possessed the secret of making his students find his lessons enjoyable as a teacher, and as a translator, he knew how to put something more into his work than just the knowledge derived from grammar and the dictionary. Since, moreover, he managed to assimilate the customs of the country in which he lived, it is not surprising that with some perseverance, he managed to prosper.

en: In London, he had expected neither to walk on pavements of gold, nor to lie on beds of roses; if he had had any such exalted expectation, he would not have prospered. He had expected labour, and he found it, and did it and made the best of it. In this, his prosperity consisted.
vi: In London, he did not expect to walk on streets paved with gold or lie on rose-petal-strewn mattresses; if he had such lofty expectations, he would have already failed. He only wished to work and had found work, had made efforts and never lost heart. His success stemmed from that.
tr: Previously, in London, he had neither hoped to walk on golden pavements nor to lie on beds covered with rose petals; if his ambitions had been so high, he wouldn't have been this successful anyway. He had wanted to do a job, and he found it, did it, and even became the best among those who did it. This was the real wealth.
es: When he moved to London, he did not do so driven by the hope of walking on sidewalks of gold or sleeping on a bed of roses. If he had harbored those hopes, he surely would not have prospered. He expected work, found it, dedicated himself to it with fervor, and made the most of his labor: that was the secret of his prosperity.

en: A certain portion of his time was passed at Cambridge, where he read with undergraduates as a sort of tolerated smuggler who drove a contraband trade in European languages, instead of conveying Greek and Latin through the Custom-house. The rest of his time he passed in London.
vi: Part of his time was spent teaching at Cambridge to students, a school that accepted him as a smuggler of tax-evading European languages rather than a merchant of Greek and Latin antiquities who goes straight through customs. The rest of his time was spent in London.
tr: He spent a portion of his time in Cambridge, where, in his work with students, he was like a kind of smuggler who was tolerated for engaging in the contraband trade of European languages instead of passing Greek and Latin through customs. He spent the rest of his time in London.
es: He spent part of his time in Cambridge, talking with the students and teaching them, almost surreptitiously, European languages, while disregarding Greek and Latin, which were already extensively taught at that educational institution, and the rest of the day he stayed in London. But let's move on to a less unpleasant matter.

en: Now, from the days when it was always summer in Eden, to these days when it is mostly winter in fallen latitudes, the world of a man has invariably gone one way—Charles Darnay’s way—the way of the love of a woman.
vi: And so, from the days that were always summer in the Garden of Eden to the time it turned into the winter of the fallen world, the world of that gentleman followed only one dedicated path, the path of Charles Darnay - the path to a woman's heart.
tr: Men on earth have always walked the same path—from the days of eternal summer in paradise to the winter days in today's sinful lands—on the path of Charles Darnay, in pursuit of a woman's love.
es: From the remote times when humanity enjoyed a perpetual summer, to those we suffer today, in which we have to settle for a no less perpetual winter, the world has invariably followed the same course; the course of Charles Darnay... the course of love for woman.

en: He had loved Lucie Manette from the hour of his danger. He had never heard a sound so sweet and dear as the sound of her compassionate voice; he had never seen a face so tenderly beautiful, as hers when it was confronted with his own on the edge of the grave that had been dug for him. But, he had not yet spoken to her on the subject; the assassination at the deserted chateau far away beyond the heaving water and the long, long, dusty roads—the solid stone chateau which had itself become the mere mist of a dream—had been done a year, and he had never yet, by so much as a single spoken word, disclosed to her the state of his heart.
vi: He had loved Lucie Manette from the moment his life was in danger. Never before had he heard a sound as gentle and lovely as her sympathetic voice; never before had he seen a face as beautiful and kind-hearted as hers when Lucie looked at him standing by the edge of the freshly dug grave. Yet he had never once expressed his feelings; the assassination a year ago at the deserted castle across the stormy sea and the long, dusty miles - the towering stone castle now just a hazy dream - and he still had not, not even once, confessed his heart to Lucie.
tr: Since that hour when his life was in danger, he had loved Lucie Manette. Until he met her at the edge of the grave dug for him, Charles had never heard a voice as sweet and pleasant as Lucie's, nor had he encountered a face as kind and beautiful as hers. But he had not yet said anything to her about it; a year had passed since the murder committed in that desolate stone chateau –which had turned into a mist within a dream– far beyond the rising waters and long dusty roads, yet Charles Darnay had not uttered a single word to Lucie Manette about his feelings.
es: He had fallen in love with Lucie Manette on the day when danger loomed over his head. In his ears, no voice had ever resonated with such harmonious, delicate, tender tones as those she used on that occasion in her compassionate voice, nor had his eyes ever seen a face as enchanting, as angelic as Lucie's, when she saw him at the very edge of the grave that false accusers had opened at his feet. His lips, however, had not revealed the secret of his heart. The murder committed on the other side of the Channel, in a deserted castle, that robust stone castle, dated back a year, and young Darnay had revealed the state of his soul to no one.

en: That he had his reasons for this, he knew full well. It was again a summer day when, lately arrived in London from his college occupation, he turned into the quiet corner in Soho, bent on seeking an opportunity of opening his mind to Doctor Manette. It was the close of the summer day, and he knew Lucie to be out with Miss Pross.
vi: He had a reason to remain silent; he knew all too well. Then, on a summer day when he returned to London after his university teaching duties, Darnay turned into a quiet street in Soho, determined to find an opportunity to express his feelings to Dr. Manette. That day was a late summer day, and he knew Lucie would be out with Miss Pross.
tr: There were clear reasons for this, and he knew them very well. Again on a summer day, in London, late on his return from work at the school, he turned to the quiet corner in Soho with the hope of finding an opportunity to share his thoughts with Doctor Manette. It was a summer evening, and he knew that Lucie had gone out with Miss Pross.
es: That Darnay had his reasons for acting in such a manner, he knew perfectly well; but whether those reasons had disappeared, or whether he could no longer keep the secret locked in his chest, the fact is that one summer day, upon his return from Cambridge, he made his way to the quiet corner of Soho, determined to open his heart to Doctor Manette. The day was drawing to a close, and he knew that Lucie would have gone out with Miss Pross.

en: He found the Doctor reading in his arm-chair at a window. The energy which had at once supported him under his old sufferings and aggravated their sharpness, had been gradually restored to him. He was now a very energetic man indeed, with great firmness of purpose, strength of resolution, and vigour of action. In his recovered energy he was sometimes a little fitful and sudden, as he had at first been in the exercise of his other recovered faculties; but, this had never been frequently observable, and had grown more and more rare.
vi: I saw the doctor reading a book in the armchair by the window. The source of energy, thought to be exhausted from battling through past hardships, has gradually recovered. He is now truly a person full of vitality, with a determined purpose, strong resolve, and enthusiastic activity. That source of energy sometimes suddenly depletes as seen during his initial recovery period; however, such episodes are not frequent and are becoming increasingly rare.
tr: He found the Doctor reading a book in a chair by the window. He was gradually regaining the strength that had supported him during his painful old days and had also intensified those pains. He was now an extremely energetic man, capable of making sound decisions and possessing the determination and strength to implement them. Just as he had initially experienced difficulties with the other skills he had regained, this returning energy sometimes disrupted his balance and routine, but it wasn't too bothersome and its frequency was decreasing day by day.
es: He found the doctor reading by the window. The energies that once sustained him, preventing him from being overwhelmed by the weight of his tortures, had gradually restored him. He was now a man strong in his purposes, energetic in his resolutions, vigorous in his actions. He studied a lot, slept little, endured great fatigue without effort, and was constantly seen content and happy.

en: He studied much, slept little, sustained a great deal of fatigue with ease, and was equably cheerful. To him, now entered Charles Darnay, at sight of whom he laid aside his book and held out his hand.
vi: He reads a lot, sleeps little, is hardworking, and is always cheerful. Seeing Charles Darnay enter, he put the book aside and extended his hand for a handshake.
tr: He works a lot, sleeps little, easily overcomes all that fatigue, and derives great happiness from all of it. Now, seeing Charles Darnay enter the room, he put the book he was reading aside and extended his hand.
es: He studied a lot, slept little, endured great fatigue without effort, and was constantly seen content and happy. Upon seeing Charles Darnay enter his study, he put down the book and extended his right hand to the newcomer.

en: “Charles Darnay! I rejoice to see you. We have been counting on your return these three or four days past. Mr. Stryver and Sydney Carton were both here yesterday, and both made you out to be more than due.”
vi: − Charles Darnay! It's so good to see you. We had figured that you must have returned here three or four days ago. Yesterday, both attorney Stryver and Sydney Carton came here and both said that this time you were away longer than usual.
tr: "Charles Darnay! I am glad to see you. We have been expecting you for three or four days. Yesterday Mr. Stryver and Sydney Carton were here, both of them thought you would come earlier."
es: —Friend Darnay!—he exclaimed. —How much pleasure your visit gives me! For the past three or four days, we have been expecting your return. Yesterday, Mr. Stryver and Mr. Carton were here, and both agreed in saying that you have deprived us of your presence more than necessary.

en: “I am obliged to them for their interest in the matter,” he answered, a little coldly as to them, though very warmly as to the Doctor. “Miss Manette—”
vi: − Thank them for their concern about me, - he replied, somewhat coldly when mentioning the two others, though still courteous to the doctor. - Miss Manette... − Still well, - the doctor interrupted, - and we are all happy that you have returned.
tr: "I am grateful for their concern," she replied, with a somewhat cold demeanor, but this coldness was not directed at the Doctor, but at them. "Miss Manette..."
es: —I sincerely appreciate the interest those gentlemen show me—replied Darnay with some coldness. —And Miss Lucía?

en: “Is well,” said the Doctor, as he stopped short, “and your return will delight us all. She has gone out on some household matters, but will soon be home.”
vi: - Miss Manette... − Still well, - the doctor interrupted, - and we are all happy that you have returned. Lucie has gone out to take care of some household matters, but she will be back soon.
tr: "Good," said the Doctor briefly; "your arrival will make us all happy. He had gone out for some errands related to the house, but he will be back soon."
es: —Alright, thank you very much. Your return will be a source of joy for all of us... She has gone shopping, but she won't take long to return.

en: “Doctor Manette, I knew she was from home. I took the opportunity of her being from home, to beg to speak to you.”
vi: − Dr. Manette, I know she is not at home, so I take this opportunity to speak with you.
tr: "Doctor Manette, I knew that your daughter was not at home. I waited for a moment when she was not at home to be able to talk to you."
es: —I knew that he was out of the house, doctor. Precisely, I took advantage of the occasion of his departure to request a conference with you.

en: There was a blank silence.
vi: Empty silence. − Really? -
tr: There was absolute silence.
es: The doctor fell silent.

en: “Yes?” said the Doctor, with evident constraint. “Bring your chair here, and speak on.”
vi: The doctor clearly tried to stay calm. - Bring a chair over here and we'll talk.
tr: "Well?" said the Doctor with obvious tension. "Pull up a chair and let's talk."
es: —Yes?—he finally asked. —Pull up a chair and we'll talk.

en: He complied as to the chair, but appeared to find the speaking on less easy.
vi: He brought the chair over but found it hard to speak.
tr: Charles immediately pulled the chair: but starting to talk was not that easy.
es: The young man brought a chair without difficulty, but it seems he found it to start the conference.

en: “I have had the happiness, Doctor Manette, of being so intimate here,” so he at length began, “for some year and a half, that I hope the topic on which I am about to touch may not—”
vi: − Doctor, - he said after a while, - I have had the honor of being warmly received here for a year and a half now, so I hope that what I am about to say will not...
tr: "Doctor Manette, for the past one and a half years," he began shortly, "the closeness I have felt from you all has made me very happy, and therefore, the matter I will touch upon shortly..."
es: —I have had the pleasure of frequenting this house so often—he began to say at last—for a year and a half, that I hope the subject I am going to touch upon will not be...

en: He was stayed by the Doctor’s putting out his hand to stop him. When he had kept it so a little while, he said, drawing it back:
vi: The doctor raised his hand to stop him and kept it in front of him for a moment before withdrawing it and saying: − Is it about Lucie? −
tr: When the doctor reached out his hand to stop him, Charles immediately fell silent. After holding his hand like that for a while, he spoke as he pulled it back:
es: The doctor interrupted him by extending a hand.

en: “Is Lucie the topic?”
vi: Yes, it is.
tr: "Is it about Lucie?"
es: —Is Lucía the topic in question?—he asked.

en: “She is.”
vi: − I always find it difficult to talk about Lucie.
tr: "Yes."
es: —It's Lucía.

en: “It is hard for me to speak of her at any time. It is very hard for me to hear her spoken of in that tone of yours, Charles Darnay.”
vi: − I always find it difficult to talk about Lucie. And it is also very hard for me to hear you talk about Lucie in such a manner, Mr. Charles Darnay.
tr: "Talking about him is always difficult for me. Hearing someone mention him in that tone of voice is even harder, Charles Darnay."
es: —It always affects me deeply to talk about Lucía; but it is painful for me to hear you speak of her in the tone that you do, Darnay.

en: “It is a tone of fervent admiration, true homage, and deep love, Doctor Manette!” he said deferentially.
vi: − That is a voice of earnest admiration, sincere respect, and deep affection, Doctor Manette! - Darnay's words were full of reverence.
tr: Darnay said respectfully, "This tone of voice contains great admiration, sincere respect, and deep affection, Doctor Manette!"
es: —It is the tone of fervent admiration, of enthusiastic homage, of the deepest love, doctor—replied Darnay.

en: There was another blank silence before her father rejoined:
vi: A moment of empty silence passed before the father replied: − I trust you.
tr: Before Lucie's father responded, there was absolute silence again.
es: Another pause longer than the previous one.

en: “I believe it. I do you justice; I believe it.”
vi: You are trustworthy, I know.
tr: "I believe. I am sure of your honesty; I believe in you."
es: —I believe it. It is my pleasure to do you justice... I believe it.

en: His constraint was so manifest, and it was so manifest, too, that it originated in an unwillingness to approach the subject, that Charles Darnay hesitated.
vi: The doctor's restraint was evident because he did not want to talk about his daughter, and this attitude was so pronounced that it made Charles Darnay hesitant.
tr: It was so obvious that the Doctor's tension stemmed from his reluctance to discuss this matter that Charles Darnay hesitated.
es: The doctor's displeasure was so visible that Darnay, realizing he had touched on a subject that upset the father, hesitated.

en: “Shall I go on, sir?”
vi: − Can I continue, sir?
tr: "Shall I continue, sir?"
es: —May I continue, sir?—he asked.

en: Another blank.
vi: Another moment of emptiness. −
tr: Another silence.
es: New pause.

en: “Yes, go on.”
vi: Yes, go on. −
tr: "Please, go ahead."
es: —Yes; please continue.

en: “You anticipate what I would say, though you cannot know how earnestly I say it, how earnestly I feel it, without knowing my secret heart, and the hopes and fears and anxieties with which it has long been laden. Dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter fondly, dearly, disinterestedly, devotedly. If ever there were love in the world, I love her. You have loved yourself; let your old love speak for me!”
vi: You must have known what I was going to say, even though you couldn't know how serious I would be, how sincere my feelings are, unless you understood my innermost thoughts, the hopes, fears, and heavy anxieties I've carried for so long. Dr. Manette, I love your daughter passionately, deeply, wholeheartedly, selflessly. If there is love in this world, it is the love I have for her. You have loved before; let your past love speak for me!
tr: "Even if you do not know how sincerely I say these things, how genuine my feelings are, the secret in my heart, and the hopes, fears, and excitements overflowing from this heart, you can guess what I am going to say. Dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter with all my heart, sincerely, without expecting anything in return, and with great devotion. If there is love in the world, it is the feeling I have for your daughter. You have loved once too; let the love you experienced be the interpreter of my feelings!"
es: —Guess what I am going to say, although it is impossible for you to guess with how much fervor I say it and with how much fervor I feel it, for that it would be necessary for your gaze to penetrate to the most intimate depths of my soul, to see there the hopes and fears, the yearnings and anxieties that overwhelm it under their weight. My dear Doctor Manette, I love your daughter with a deep, immense, selfless, fervent love; I love her as very few have loved in the world. You have loved too, doctor: let the love that once quickened the beats of your heart speak for me!

en: The Doctor sat with his face turned away, and his eyes bent on the ground. At the last words, he stretched out his hand again, hurriedly, and cried:
vi: The doctor sat listening, his face turned away, eyes downcast. At the last sentence, he hastily raised his hand and exclaimed: − Don't say that, sir!
tr: The doctor was sitting with his head turned to the other side, his eyes cast down to the ground. As soon as he heard the last words spoken by Charles Darnay, he reached out his hand again and exclaimed:
es: The doctor, who was listening to the young man with his head slightly turned and his eyes fixed on the ground, suddenly extended an arm upon hearing the last words, and exclaimed:

en: “Not that, sir! Let that be! I adjure you, do not recall that!”
vi: At the last sentence, he hastily raised his hand and exclaimed: − Don't say that, sir! Let it go! Please don't bring up the past!
tr: "Please, sir! Don't say that! I beg you, don't mention that topic!"
es: —No...! Don't talk about that!... Don't remind me of it, for heaven's sake!

en: His cry was so like a cry of actual pain, that it rang in Charles Darnay’s ears long after he had ceased. He motioned with the hand he had extended, and it seemed to be an appeal to Darnay to pause. The latter so received it, and remained silent.
vi: Like a cry of real pain, his words ended but the echo still rang in Charles Darnay's ears. The outstretched hand trembled as if pleading with Darnay to stop speaking. The young man understood and remained silent.
tr: There was such great pain in the Doctor's cry that even when he stopped, Charles Darnay's ears rang for a long time. As he moved his outstretched hand, it was as if he was begging Darnay to be silent. Charles comprehended the situation and remained silent for a while.
es: Darnay remained silent.

en: “I ask your pardon,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, after some moments. “I do not doubt your loving Lucie; you may be satisfied of it.”
vi: − I'm sorry, - the doctor whispered after a moment. - I never doubted your love for Lucie; you can trust me.
tr: A few minutes later, "Forgive me," said the Doctor in a soft voice. "I have no doubt that you love Lucie; therefore, you can be at ease."
es: —Forgive me—replied the doctor after a few seconds. —I do not doubt that you love Lucía...

en: He turned towards him in his chair, but did not look at him, or raise his eyes. His chin dropped upon his hand, and his white hair overshadowed his face:
vi: Still sitting in the chair, he turned towards Darnay but did not look at him or raise his head, his hand still supporting his chin, his silver hair covering his face.
tr: The doctor turned to Darnay in his chair, but he still did not look at his face, not lifting his eyes from the ground. His chin had fallen into his hands, and his white hair was shading his face.
es: Without looking at Darnay, without raising his eyes from the ground, with a sad countenance, he asked:

en: “Have you spoken to Lucie?”
vi: − Have you talked to Lucie yet?
tr: "Did you talk to Lucie?"
es: —Have you spoken of your love to Lucía?

en: “No.”
tr: "No."
es: —Never.

en: “Nor written?”
vi: Not yet. − Not even writing letters?
tr: "Well, did you write to him?"
es: —Has he/she written to you?

en: “Never.”
vi: − Not at all.
tr: "No, not at all."
es: —Never.

en: “It would be ungenerous to affect not to know that your self-denial is to be referred to your consideration for her father. Her father thanks you.”
vi: − I would be petty if I pretended not to know that you have tried to avoid expressing your feelings to the daughter out of respect for her father. Thank you.
tr: "It would be unfair not to see that you displayed this dedication thinking of his father. As his father, I thank you."
es: —I would be quite ungrateful if I failed to acknowledge that your selflessness has been greatly influenced by your consideration for the father. The father thanks you.

en: He offered his hand; but his eyes did not go with it.
vi: He extended his hand, but his eyes did not follow.
tr: He reached out his hand, but he was still avoiding eye contact.
es: He offered his right hand to his interlocutor, but his eyes did not follow the movement of his hand.

en: “I know,” said Darnay, respectfully, “how can I fail to know, Doctor Manette, I who have seen you together from day to day, that between you and Miss Manette there is an affection so unusual, so touching, so belonging to the circumstances in which it has been nurtured, that it can have few parallels, even in the tenderness between a father and child. I know, Doctor Manette—how can I fail to know—that, mingled with the affection and duty of a daughter who has become a woman, there is, in her heart, towards you, all the love and reliance of infancy itself. I know that, as in her childhood she had no parent, so she is now devoted to you with all the constancy and fervour of her present years and character, united to the trustfulness and attachment of the early days in which you were lost to her. I know perfectly well that if you had been restored to her from the world beyond this life, you could hardly be invested, in her sight, with a more sacred character than that in which you are always with her. I know that when she is clinging to you, the hands of baby, girl, and woman, all in one, are round your neck. I know that in loving you she sees and loves her mother at her own age, sees and loves you at my age, loves her mother broken-hearted, loves you through your dreadful trial and in your blessed restoration. I have known this, night and day, since I have known you in your home.”
vi: − I know, - Darnay said respectfully, - how could I not know, Dr. Manette, I have seen the two of you together every day, seen how deeply you and Miss Manette love each other, how touching it is, how close you are, and understood the circumstances you both have gone through. Truly, it is rare to see such a father-daughter bond. I know, Doctor... how could I not know,... that besides the love and duty of an adult woman, Lucie also holds for you all the love and reliance of a child. I know that since childhood, Lucie has lived without her parents, so now she gives her father all the deep affection of the present years, along with the trust and attachment she lacked as a child. I know very well that even if you were to return to this world from the other side, in her eyes, you could not be more sacred than you have always been. I know that when she hugs her father tightly, the arms around his neck are those of a child, a young girl, and a grown woman all at once. I know that through the love she has for her father, she sees and loves her young mother, sees and loves her young father, loves the suffering mother, and loves the father who faced terrifying ordeals and was fortunate to survive. I have known this, through many days and nights, since I visited you in this house.
tr: "I know," said Darnay respectfully, "as someone who has spent a long time with you, how could I not know how special and touching the love between you and Miss Manette is, Doctor Manette? This love has developed under such circumstances that the affection between any other father and daughter pales in comparison to yours. I know that this woman, who loves you and feels responsible for you, also carries a love and trust from her infancy in her heart, Doctor Manette –how could I not know this? Of course, I know that, due to her growing up without a mother and father in the past, and now, because of her temperament and the longing and attachment brought by the years she spent apart from you, she has devoted herself to you with great loyalty and enthusiasm. I know very well that even if you were to reunite with her in the afterlife, she would not appear more sacred than she does now. When she embraces you, I know that the hands wrapping around your neck are simultaneously those of a baby, a young girl, and a mother. I also know that, while loving you, she sees and loves her mother at her own age, sees and loves you at my age, loves her mother with a broken heart, loves you with that terrible trial and your joyful return to life. I have seen this every moment since the first day I stepped into this house."
es: —I know—said Darnay with great respect—I know... how could I not know, having seen you most days? I know that between you and Lucie there exists a love so tender, so exceptional, so moving, so in harmony with the circumstances that have presided over its birth and development, that even in the tenderness that binds parents to their weak children, it would be difficult to find precedents. I know, Doctor Manette, that along with the love of a daughter, who is now a woman, all the love of her childhood lives in her heart. I know that, precisely because she was deprived of her father's caresses during her childhood, she has now devoted herself to you with all the constancy, with all the fervor that her years and character give her. I know perfectly well that if you had descended from heaven after your death to accompany your daughter on earth, you could not be more loved, more sacred, or more revered than you are today. I know that when your daughter embraces you, it is the arms of the child, the arms of the maiden, the arms of the woman that tenderly encircle your neck. I know that Lucie, loving you as she does today, loves a mother as young as she is and a father as young as I am; she sees and adores a sorrowful mother, submerged in unfathomable seas of bitterness, and she sees and adores a father buried alive. I know all this, I have been seeing it night and day, for to know it, it has been enough for me to see you in the sacredness of the home.

en: Her father sat silent, with his face bent down. His breathing was a little quickened; but he repressed all other signs of agitation.
vi: The father sat in silence, his head bowed. His breathing was a bit more rapid, but he showed no signs of anger.
tr: Lucie's father sat silently with his face turned downward. His breathing had quickened a bit, but he had suppressed all other signs of excitement.
es: The father continued without changing his attitude, with his head bowed and his eyes downcast. His breathing became a little uneven, but he did not show any other signs of agitation.

en: “Dear Doctor Manette, always knowing this, always seeing her and you with this hallowed light about you, I have forborne, and forborne, as long as it was in the nature of man to do it. I have felt, and do even now feel, that to bring my love—even mine—between you, is to touch your history with something not quite so good as itself. But I love her. Heaven is my witness that I love her!”
vi: − Dear Dr. Manette, because I have always known this, because I have always seen you two together in the glow of that fatherly love, I have tried to restrain myself, and restrained myself to the utmost limits of human strength. I have felt, and even now feel, that if I let my love... even my love... come between you two, it would be like tarnishing that fatherly love with a lesser emotion. But I love her. Heaven bears witness that I love her!
tr: "Dear Doctor Manette, knowing this situation, always seeing this sacred light upon your daughter and you, I have always restrained myself as much as a person can. With my love for her –even with my love– if I were to come between you, I felt, and still feel, that I would add something not as good to what you have experienced. But I love her. God is my witness that I love her!"
es: —And knowing it, Doctor Manette, convinced that to interpose between you a love... my love, is equivalent to introducing into your heaven something that is less sublime than it, I have tried to impose silence on my heart, I have resisted to the utmost limit. I can't anymore!... I love her!... Heaven is my witness that I love her!

en: “I believe it,” answered her father, mournfully. “I have thought so before now. I believe it.”
vi: − I believe it, - the father replied sorrowfully, his voice filled with a sadness that sounded like reproach. - I have thought so before. I believe it. −
tr: The doctor replied in a sorrowful voice, "I believe you." "I had already thought about these things before. I believe you."
es: —I believe it—replied the father with a sorrowful tone. —I had been suspecting it for a long time... I believe it.

en: “But, do not believe,” said Darnay, upon whose ear the mournful voice struck with a reproachful sound, “that if my fortune were so cast as that, being one day so happy as to make her my wife, I must at any time put any separation between her and you, I could or would breathe a word of what I now say. Besides that I should know it to be hopeless, I should know it to be a baseness. If I had any such possibility, even at a remote distance of years, harboured in my thoughts, and hidden in my heart—if it ever had been there—if it ever could be there—I could not now touch this honoured hand.”
vi: But sir, - Darnay said, - please do not think that if I were fortunate enough to have her as my wife, I would separate the fatherly bond between you two; if that were the case, I would not have dared to utter a single word of what I am saying now. Moreover, I know well that it is impossible to separate father and daughter, I know well that doing so would be despicable. If I had such an intention, no matter how distant in time, if it were harbored in my mind, secretly in my heart... if I had such an intention... if I had thought so... then how could I dare to touch this revered hand now.
tr: "But do not think," said Darnay, hearing the reproach in the Doctor's sorrowful voice, "that if one day fate smiles upon me and I attain the happiness of marrying your daughter, I will separate you from each other. What I am saying now will be valid then as well. Even though such a baseness is not possible, I know this. Still, if there were such a possibility, hidden in a corner of my mind and heart, that could emerge years later – impossible, but if there were – I could not shake this honorable hand now."
es: —But I would feel—replied Darnay, who thought he detected a reproach in the doctor's sorrowful tone—I would feel that you also believed that, if my fortune were so immense that one day I could call her my wife, I would try to separate you or utter a single word different from those that are coming out of my mouth at this moment. I fully understand that it would be useless; but in any case, I am not capable of committing such a vile act. If such low thoughts even brushed my mind, I would not be worthy of touching this honorable hand—he added, extending his own to his interlocutor.

en: He laid his own upon it as he spoke.
vi: He placed his hand on his father's hand as emotions surged.
tr: While speaking, she had placed her hand on the Doctor's hand.
es: If such low thoughts even brushed my mind, I would not be worthy of touching this honorable hand—he added, extending his own to his interlocutor.

en: “No, dear Doctor Manette. Like you, a voluntary exile from France; like you, driven from it by its distractions, oppressions, and miseries; like you, striving to live away from it by my own exertions, and trusting in a happier future; I look only to sharing your fortunes, sharing your life and home, and being faithful to you to the death. Not to divide with Lucie her privilege as your child, companion, and friend; but to come in aid of it, and bind her closer to you, if such a thing can be.”
vi: − No, Dr. Manette. Like you, someone who voluntarily left France to live in exile; like you, forced to leave because of many hardships, oppression, and misfortune; like you, having to strive to make a living by one's own efforts and believe in a brighter future; I only want to share your hardships, share life and family with you, and remain loyal to you until death. Not to deprive Lucie of the privileges of being a daughter, a friend, and a companion to you, but to help strengthen the bond between father and daughter even more, if it can be done.
tr: "No, dear Doctor Manette. Like you, I was voluntarily exiled from France; like you, I fled from its madness, oppressions, and sufferings; just like you, I am trying to survive away from there through my own efforts and I believe that happy days await me; my only wish is to share your fate, your life, and your home and to honor you until I die. My aim is not to deprive Lucie, who is both your child, your friend, and your soulmate, of her privileges, but to support her and, if possible, to bind her to you even more."
es: —No, my dear Doctor Manette; like you, I am kept away from France by a self-imposed exile; like you, I have fled from it to avoid seeing its mistakes, its oppressions, its miseries; like you, I have resolved to expatriate myself, live by the work of my hands, and place my hopes in a more prosperous future. My only aspiration is to share your fate, share your life and your home, and be faithful to you until death. I do not aspire to participate in the precious privilege of Lucie as your daughter and loving companion in life; rather, I seek to strengthen that privilege, to bind her more closely to you, assuming that is possible.

en: His touch still lingered on her father’s hand. Answering the touch for a moment, but not coldly, her father rested his hands upon the arms of his chair, and looked up for the first time since the beginning of the conference. A struggle was evidently in his face; a struggle with that occasional look which had a tendency in it to dark doubt and dread.
vi: His hand still lingered on the doctor's hand. He held Darnay's hand for a moment to express his feelings, then rested both his hands on the armrest of the chair, and for the first time since they started talking, he looked up. On his face was a struggle, he was battling the doubts and fears that occasionally arose in his mind. −
tr: Darnay's hand was still on Lucie's father's hand. For a moment, the Doctor responded to this touch in a manner that was not cold, but he immediately placed his hands on the arms of his chair and, for the first time since their conversation began, looked at Darnay's face. The conflict within him was reflected on his face; there was a rare expression of intense doubt and fear on his face.
es: The young man's hand remained on his father's, who had his on the arms of the chair he was sitting in. For the first time since the beginning of the conference, the doctor raised his eyes from the floor. His face reflected the struggle that was taking place within him.

en: “You speak so feelingly and so manfully, Charles Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and will open all my heart—or nearly so. Have you any reason to believe that Lucie loves you?”
vi: You speak very movingly and with great spirit, Charles Darnay, I thank you wholeheartedly, and will also open my heart to you... or almost so. Do you have any reason to believe that Lucie loves you too?
tr: "You speak so sincerely and bravely, Charles Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and now I will open my heart to you completely – or let's say a large part of it. Has there been anything to make you think that Lucie loves you too?"
es: —You speak with such tenderness, and at the same time with such firmness, Carlos Darnay, that I thank you with all my heart, and I am going to reveal to you... almost reveal my own. Do you have reasons to believe that Lucía returns your love?

en: “None. As yet, none.”
vi: − Nothing. So far, there has been none.
tr: "No. Not at all."
es: —None.

en: “Is it the immediate object of this confidence, that you may at once ascertain that, with my knowledge?”
vi: − Is the main purpose of this conversation that you want to use me to find out Lucie's feelings?
tr: "Is the real reason you are opening up to me to get my permission to understand this?""
es: —The immediate purpose of this confidence, is it to ascertain this point right away and with my authorization?

en: “Not even so. I might not have the hopefulness to do it for weeks; I might (mistaken or not mistaken) have that hopefulness to-morrow.”
vi: Absolutely not. It will be many weeks before I dare to hope for that; but I hope, whether right or wrong, that you will allow me to know by tomorrow.
tr: "Not even that. Maybe it won't give me such hope for weeks. But maybe tomorrow I will see this hope (right or wrong)."
es: —Not even that. I don't expect to obtain that happiness for many weeks, although, naturally, I would like to be free of doubt by tomorrow.

en: “Do you seek any guidance from me?”
vi: − Do you need any advice from me?
tr: "So, do you want me to show you the way?"
es: —Are you seeking my advice and guidance?

en: “I ask none, sir. But I have thought it possible that you might have it in your power, if you should deem it right, to give me some.”
vi: − No. But I think you have the right to advise me on something. If you can see it, I will listen. −
tr: "I had no intention of asking such a thing, sir. But upon reflection, if you deem it appropriate, I would like to benefit from your ideas."
es: —Nor have I come with the intention of soliciting your advice and help; but I do believe that, if it is within your power to assist me, and you consider it just, you will provide me with some aid.

en: “Do you seek any promise from me?”
vi: Do you need me to promise something?
tr: "Do you want me to make a promise?""
es: —So, what you are looking for is a promise from me.

en: “I do seek that.”
tr: "I would like to, sir.""
es: —Indeed; that's what I'm looking for.

en: “What is it?”
vi: Yes, it is true. −
tr: "What word?""
es: —What promise is it?

en: “I well understand that, without you, I could have no hope. I well understand that, even if Miss Manette held me at this moment in her innocent heart—do not think I have the presumption to assume so much—I could retain no place in it against her love for her father.”
vi: What? − I know very well that without you, I have no hope. I understand clearly that even if at this moment there is my image in the innocent heart of Miss Manette, please do not think that I am presumptuous in assuming so, then I still mean nothing if her father does not approve.
tr: "I have understood very well that if you are not there, there is no hope at all. If there is one more thing I have understood, it is that even if Miss Manette were to give me a place in her innocent heart right now – but don't think I am claiming such a thing – I wouldn't be able to hold on much against the love she has for her father."
es: —I am quite convinced that, without you, I can expect nothing: I am quite convinced that, even if Lucía loved me as I love her... and do not think that my presumption goes so far as to suppose such a thing, it would be of no use to me if my love were incompatible with the love she owes to her father.

en: “If that be so, do you see what, on the other hand, is involved in it?”
vi: − Let's assume that's the case, but what if the reality is not so?
tr: "Well, do you also know what this means?"
es: —If that is the case, you will be well convinced of...

en: “I understand equally well, that a word from her father in any suitor’s favour, would outweigh herself and all the world. For which reason, Doctor Manette,” said Darnay, modestly but firmly, “I would not ask that word, to save my life.”
vi: − I also understand clearly that a word from the father expressing consent to whoever pursues her will carry more weight than her own private wishes and more than anything else in the world. For that reason, Doctor, - Darnay said humbly but resolutely, - I do not want to ask for that word, even if it means my death.
tr: "I know that a word from her father approving one of the suitors would mean everything to her. Therefore, Doctor Manette," said Darnay humbly but resolutely, "I will not ask such a thing from you."
es: —I am also convinced that a single word spoken by her father in favor of any suitor for her hand would weigh decisively on her mind, and precisely because I am convinced of this, Dr. Manette, I shall not request that word, even if my life depended on it—concluded the young man, with modesty, but with manly determination.

en: “I am sure of it. Charles Darnay, mysteries arise out of close love, as well as out of wide division; in the former case, they are subtle and delicate, and difficult to penetrate. My daughter Lucie is, in this one respect, such a mystery to me; I can make no guess at the state of her heart.”
vi: − I believe you. Charles Darnay, but both the closest and the most distant feelings are full of secrets; in the case of close feelings, they are always delicate, discreet, and hard to discern, in this matter, my daughter Lucie is indeed a mystery; I cannot know whose image is in my daughter's heart.
tr: "I am sure of this. Charles Darnay, secrets arise not only from great conflicts but also from deep affections; in the latter, they are delicate and very fragile, and difficult to unravel. In this regard, my daughter Lucie is a mystery to me; I have no idea where her heart lies."
es: —Of that I am sure, Charles Darnay. Mysteries often arise from deep loves and wide divisions: in the first case, the mysteries are subtle, delicate, and difficult to penetrate. In this respect, Lucie is a mystery to me: I cannot even approximately guess the state of her heart.

en: “May I ask, sir, if you think she is—” As he hesitated, her father supplied the rest.
vi: − May I ask, if you think that she... - Seeing him hesitate, the father understood and continued his words.
tr: "Well sir, could it be that his-" When Darnay couldn't continue, Lucie's father completed the sentence.
es: —Will you allow me to ask, doctor, if she...?

en: “Is sought by any other suitor?”
vi: − Is someone else pursuing you? −
tr: "Does she have another suitor?"
es: —Does she have any other suitors?

en: “It is what I meant to say.”
vi: That's what I meant to say.
tr: "Yes, this is what I wanted to ask.""
es: —That was what I meant to say.

en: Her father considered a little before he answered:
vi: The father pondered for a moment before answering: − You have already seen Mr. Carton coming to this house.
tr: Lucie's father thought for a moment before responding.
es: The father replied after a few moments of reflection:

en: “You have seen Mr. Carton here, yourself. Mr. Stryver is here too, occasionally. If it be at all, it can only be by one of these.”
vi: The father pondered for a moment before answering: − You have already seen Mr. Carton coming to this house. Attorney Stryver occasionally visits as well. If anyone is pursuing my daughter, it can only be one of those two. −
tr: "You had seen Mr. Carton here before. Mr. Stryver also comes occasionally. If there is such a thing, it can only be one of them."
es: —You have seen yourself that Mr. Carton and Mr. Stryver come to this house with some frequency; if anyone aspires to my daughter's hand, it will be one of the two.

en: “Or both,” said Darnay.
vi: Or both, - Darnay said.
tr: "Or both," said Darnay.
es: —Or both—observed Darnay.

en: “I had not thought of both; I should not think either, likely. You want a promise from me. Tell me what it is.”
vi: − I have never considered both; I don't think both have feelings for my daughter. Whatever you want me to promise, just say it.
tr: "I didn't think that both would be interested; I don't really believe it. You were asking for a promise from me. Go ahead, say it."
es: —It hasn't occurred to me that it could be both; moreover, I don't even think it's likely to be either of them. But you have told me that you desire a promise from me: tell me what it is about.

en: “It is, that if Miss Manette should bring to you at any time, on her own part, such a confidence as I have ventured to lay before you, you will bear testimony to what I have said, and to your belief in it. I hope you may be able to think so well of me, as to urge no influence against me. I say nothing more of my stake in this; this is what I ask. The condition on which I ask it, and which you have an undoubted right to require, I will observe immediately.”
vi: − That is, if Miss Manette at some point voluntarily expresses feelings similar to those I have presumptuously revealed to you, please recount what I have said and tell her that you believe in me. I hope you have a favorable opinion of me so that she will not be offended. This is the only thing I dare to ask. To achieve this, I am willing to accept any conditions that you have every right to impose.
tr: "If Miss Manette comes to you one day and opens her heart to you as I just dared to do, please take on my words and tell her that you believe in them. I hope you think well of me and do not influence her negatively. I will not ask anything else from you for my own benefit, that's all. If there is anything you demand in return for this request, I can fulfill it immediately."
es: "The promise I wish to obtain is that, if someday your daughter were to confide in you as I have just done, you would repeat my words to her, adding that you believe in their sincerity." "I believe I deserve a sufficiently good opinion from you to not take a stance against me." "For my part, I will strictly fulfill the condition upon which I base my plea, because you have an indisputable right to its fulfillment."

en: “I give the promise,” said the Doctor, “without any condition. I believe your object to be, purely and truthfully, as you have stated it. I believe your intention is to perpetuate, and not to weaken, the ties between me and my other and far dearer self. If she should ever tell me that you are essential to her perfect happiness, I will give her to you. If there were—Charles Darnay, if there were—”
vi: − I promise you unconditionally, - the doctor said. - I believe that what you say is sincere and noble. I believe your intention is to strengthen, not to sever, the paternal bond that ties me to my most beloved child. If Lucie were to reveal that you are an indispensable happiness, I would give my daughter to you. If... Charles Darnay, if there were...
tr: "I promise," said the Doctor, "and I have no demands. I believe that your purpose, as you say, is pure and sincere. I also believe that your intention is not to weaken the bonds between me and my daughter, who is a part of my very soul, but to eternalize them. If the day comes when she tells me that she has found true happiness with you, I will give her to you. Charles Darnay- if such a thing happens..."
es: —I make the promise you desire, without any condition—replied the doctor. —I firmly believe that your purpose is as you have stated; I believe that you intend to perpetuate, and in no case weaken, the bonds that unite me to the one who is dearer to me than myself. If one day my daughter tells me that you are necessary for her happiness, I will hasten to give her to you. If they existed, Charles Darnay, if they existed...

en: The young man had taken his hand gratefully; their hands were joined as the Doctor spoke:
vi: The young man gratefully grasped the doctor's hand; they shook hands firmly while the father continued: − ... any thought, any reason, any fear, anything, old or new, against the person whom my daughter truly loves... things that person is not directly responsible for,... I will overlook all for my daughter's happiness.
tr: The young man reached out to the Doctor's hand with gratitude; as the Doctor continued to speak, their hands joined.
es: The young man gratefully shook the doctor's hand. —...

en: “—any fancies, any reasons, any apprehensions, anything whatsoever, new or old, against the man she really loved—the direct responsibility thereof not lying on his head—they should all be obliterated for her sake. She is everything to me; more to me than suffering, more to me than wrong, more to me—Well! This is idle talk.”
vi: The young man gratefully grasped the doctor's hand; they shook hands firmly while the father continued: − ... any thought, any reason, any fear, anything, old or new, against the person whom my daughter truly loves... things that person is not directly responsible for,... I will overlook all for my daughter's happiness. Lucie is my everything, more meaningful than any suffering, more meaningful than any injustice I have to endure, more meaningful than... Oh! Saying more would be redundant.
tr: "For my daughter's well-being, it is necessary to stay away from any intention, thought, or concern directed towards the man she truly loves – this man not being directly sommiu. My daughter is my everything; beyond the pains I've endured, beyond the mistakes I've made, far beyond. Anyway! It's all empty talk."
es: Whims, true motives, apprehensions, any other thing, old or recent, against the man whom my daughter truly loved... as long as the responsibility was not personally his... I would forget everything for the love of her. She is everything to me. In the face of her happiness, all the grievances I have received, all the torments that... I am saying what is irrelevant!

en: So strange was the way in which he faded into silence, and so strange his fixed look when he had ceased to speak, that Darnay felt his own hand turn cold in the hand that slowly released and dropped it.
vi: The way the doctor fell into silence was strange, and the way his eyes stared when he stopped speaking was also peculiar, to the extent that Darnay noticed his hand growing cold in the hand that was slowly letting go of his. −
tr: The Doctor's slow descent into silence and the way he fixed his gaze on him after finishing his words were so strange that Darnay felt the hand that the Doctor slowly loosened and released starting to grow cold.
es: The tone the doctor gave to his words was so peculiar, the abrupt interruption so peculiar, the look he directed at his interlocutor so peculiar, that the latter felt the cold penetrate to the depths of his heart.

en: “You said something to me,” said Doctor Manette, breaking into a smile. “What was it you said to me?”
vi: What did you just say to me, - Dr. Manette spoke, a smile forming on his lips. - What did you tell me?
tr: "You had told me something," said Doctor Manette, suddenly smiling. "What was that thing you said?"
es: —Without realizing it, I have diverted the conversation—added the doctor, smiling. — What was it that you were telling me?

en: He was at a loss how to answer, until he remembered having spoken of a condition. Relieved as his mind reverted to that, he answered:
vi: He didn't know how to answer, until he suddenly remembered he had mentioned a condition. Reassured, he replied: − You have trusted me so much that I must reciprocate with all my trust.
tr: Although Darnay did not know how to respond for a moment, he soon remembered the matter. With the relief this brought, he said:
es: Darnay did not know what to answer at first, until he remembered that he had spoken of a condition. Calmer then, he said:

en: “Your confidence in me ought to be returned with full confidence on my part. My present name, though but slightly changed from my mother’s, is not, as you will remember, my own. I wish to tell you what that is, and why I am in England.”
vi: Reassured, he replied: − You have trusted me so much that I must reciprocate with all my trust. My current name, though slightly altered from my mother's name, as you know, is not my real name. I want to tell you my true identity and the reason I am in England.
tr: "I must fully deserve the trust you have in me. As you may recall, my current name, though similar to my mother's maiden name, is not my real name. I would like to tell you what it is and why I am in England."
es: —To your trust, I have the unavoidable duty to respond with mine. My current surname, although it barely differs from my mother's, is not mine, as you know. I wish to tell you what my real surname is, and explain the reasons for my being in England.

en: “Stop!” said the Doctor of Beauvais.
vi: − Don't! - The doctor from Beauvais exclaimed.
tr: "Stop!" said the Doctor from Beauvais.
es: —No! Be quiet!

en: “I wish it, that I may the better deserve your confidence, and have no secret from you.”
vi: − I want it this way, to be more worthy of your trust, I don't want to hide anything from you.
tr: "I wanted there to be nothing I hid from you in order to be worthy of your trust."
es: The doctor brought both hands to his ears and then to Darnay's lips. —I wish so, because I would like to earn your trust and have no secrets from you.

en: “Stop!”
vi: − Don't!
tr: "Stop!"
es: —No!

en: For an instant, the Doctor even had his two hands at his ears; for another instant, even had his two hands laid on Darnay’s lips.
vi: For a moment, the doctor even raised both hands to cover his ears; a moment later, those same hands were placed on Darnay's lips.
tr: The doctor immediately covered his ears with both hands; he even brought his hands to Darnay's lips shortly after.
es: You will tell me when I ask you, but in no way now!
