en: “Tell me when I ask you, not now. If your suit should prosper, if Lucie should love you, you shall tell me on your marriage morning. Do you promise?”
vi: − When I ask, speak; do not speak now. If your pursuit is successful, if Lucie loves you, then you will inform me on the morning of the wedding day. Do you promise me that?
tr: "When I ask you, tell me, not now. If things go well and Lucie loves you, you will tell me this on the morning of the wedding day. Promise?"
es: You will tell me when I ask you, but in no way now! If your aspirations are on the way to being realized, if Lucía reciprocates your love, you will make those revelations to me on the very morning of your wedding. Do you promise me?

en: “Willingly.
vi: − Willingly. −
tr: "Of course.""
es: —With great pleasure.

en: “Give me your hand. She will be home directly, and it is better she should not see us together to-night. Go! God bless you!”
vi: Give me your hand to shake. Lucie is coming back soon, and it is best that Lucie does not see us meeting tonight. Go now! God bless you!
tr: "Give me your hand. Lucie will come soon, and it's better if she doesn't see us together tonight. Now go! God bless you!"
es: —Give me your hand. My daughter will arrive any moment now, and I wouldn't want her to find us together tonight. Go away... and may God bless you!

en: It was dark when Charles Darnay left him, and it was an hour later and darker when Lucie came home; she hurried into the room alone—for Miss Pross had gone straight up-stairs—and was surprised to find his reading-chair empty.
vi: It was already dusk when Darnay left, and it was even darker an hour later when Lucie arrived home; she hurried alone into the living room - for Miss Pross had gone straight upstairs - and was surprised to find her father's armchair empty.
tr: When Charles Darnay left the Doctor's side, it was already dark, and an hour had passed by the time Lucie arrived; the young girl immediately ran into the room alone –since Miss Pross had gone straight upstairs– and was surprised to see that the chair where he always read his book was empty.
es: The night had closed in when Charles Darnay left, and it took Lucia another hour to arrive. She hurried to the room where her father usually stayed, and was quite surprised to find the chair he invariably occupied while reading vacant.

en: “My father!” she called to him. “Father dear!”
vi: − Father! - She called out to the doctor. - Father?
tr: "Dad," she called out. "Daddy!"
es: —Father!—he called. — My dear father!

en: Nothing was said in answer, but she heard a low hammering sound in his bedroom. Passing lightly across the intermediate room, she looked in at his door and came running back frightened, crying to herself, with her blood all chilled, “What shall I do! What shall I do!”
vi: There was no reply, but she heard a faint tapping sound coming from her father's bedroom. Gently moving through the adjacent room, she stood at the doorway and looked in, then ran back in distress, silently lamenting, her heart aching. “What to do? What to do?”
tr: There was no answer, but faint hammering sounds were coming from his father's bedroom. He quietly passed through the room in between and looked into the man's room, and in fear, pale as a ghost, he exclaimed, "Oh, what am I going to do now! What am I going to do!" he shouted, running back in a panic.
es: No one answered; but as repeated hammering sounds reached her ears from her father's bedroom, she ran towards it. She looked through the door and stepped back frightened, crying. —What will I do, my God, what will I do?—he exclaimed.

en: Her uncertainty lasted but a moment; she hurried back, and tapped at his door, and softly called to him. The noise ceased at the sound of her voice, and he presently came out to her, and they walked up and down together for a long time.
vi: She hesitated only briefly before hurriedly returning to knock on the door, and gently called out to her father. The tapping inside stopped immediately when her voice was heard, then the doctor came out to meet Lucie, and the two of them walked together for a long time.
tr: Her hesitation was very brief; she immediately turned back, knocked on her father's door, and called out in a soft tone. Upon the young girl's call, the noise ceased, and soon her father came out to join her; for a long time, they walked together, back and forth.
es: Only a moment did her uncertainties last. She knocked on the door with her knuckles and whispered her father's name. The hammering stopped immediately, her father came out, looked at her silently, and began to pace around the room. Lucía walked by his side.

en: She came down from her bed, to look at him in his sleep that night. He slept heavily, and his tray of shoemaking tools, and his old unfinished work, were all as usual.
vi: That night, she left her bed and went down to her father's room to watch him sleep. His sleep was heavy, and the tray of shoemaking tools along with the half-finished shoe from the old days were laid out exactly as they used to be.
tr: That night, Lucie got out of bed and went to check on her father. The man was sleeping deeply, and his set of shoemaking tools and the unfinished work were exactly where they had been left.
es: The next morning, Lucía entered the doctor's bedroom very early. She found him sleeping deeply. She did not observe any alteration in the shoemaker's bench, nor in the tools, nor in the unfinished shoe.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: 11. The prospect of marriage − Sydney, pour another bowl of punch, - Stryver said to the Jackal that same night, or rather early the next morning.
tr: XI
es: XI.

en: A Companion Picture
vi: 11. The prospect of marriage − Sydney, pour another bowl of punch, - Stryver said to the Jackal that same night, or rather early the next morning.
tr: Portrait of a Friend
es: AMONG COLLEAGUES

en: Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, on that self-same night, or morning, to his jackal; “mix another bowl of punch; I have something to say to you.”
vi: - I have something to discuss with you.
tr: That same night or the morning of that same night, Mr. Stryver said to his jackal, "Sydney, make another bowl of punch. I have something to tell you."
es: —Prepare another punch, Sydney—said the lawyer Stryver that same night, already in the early hours, to his companion the jackal. —I have to make a confession to you.

en: Sydney had been working double tides that night, and the night before, and the night before that, and a good many nights in succession, making a grand clearance among Mr. Stryver’s papers before the setting in of the long vacation. The clearance was effected at last; the Stryver arrears were handsomely fetched up; everything was got rid of until November should come with its fogs atmospheric, and fogs legal, and bring grist to the mill again.
vi: Sydney has been working double shifts tonight, and the night before last, and the night before that, continuously for many nights to arrange Stryver's paperwork before the long holiday begins. Finally, everything was done; Stryver's backlog had been sorted out; there would be no more entanglements until November arrived with its gloomy skies, murky laws, and everything would go smoothly.
tr: Sydney had worked overtime that night, the night before, and the night before that, and many consecutive nights, sitting and dealing with the documents that needed to be organized and sorted before Mr. Stryver went on a long vacation. Finally, the organizing work was done, Stryver's debts were cleared, and they had gotten rid of all the tasks at hand, until both the literal and legal fog enveloped the surroundings in November and the mill started turning again.
es: For several nights before, Sydney had been working diligently to reduce and finish the pile of papers waiting their turn on the desk before going on vacation. Everything was up to date; there was nothing left to do but wait for the arrival of November, abundant in atmospheric fogs and legal fogs.

en: Sydney was none the livelier and none the soberer for so much application. It had taken a deal of extra wet-towelling to pull him through the night; a correspondingly extra quantity of wine had preceded the towelling; and he was in a very damaged condition, as he now pulled his turban off and threw it into the basin in which he had steeped it at intervals for the last six hours.
vi: Sydney was neither more enthusiastic nor more alert after all the hard work. It took several rounds of wet towels on his head to keep him awake through the night; and it also took about the same amount of weeks of drinking before applying the towels; now he looked miserable as he pulled the stack of towels off his head and threw them into the basin he had been dipping them into every so often for the past six hours.
tr: Sydney, despite having so much work, was never lively and sober. To get through the night well, he had to use an extra load of wet towels; because he had consumed just as much wine before the towel phase; now he was in a terrible state, he took off the towel wrapped around his head and threw it into the basin he had been dipping it into and wetting every now and then for the past six hours.
es: Sydney was not a paragon of sobriety and temperance: that night he had to increase by two the number of cold water-soaked towels he usually applied to his head, just as he also doubled the amount of wine consumed prior to applying the towels.

en: “Are you mixing that other bowl of punch?” said Stryver the portly, with his hands in his waistband, glancing round from the sofa where he lay on his back.
vi: − Did you mix another bowl of punch? - Stryver, lying on the sofa with his hands hooked into his waistband, looked around.
tr: The burly Stryver, lying on the couch with his hands on his belt, looked around and called out, "Are you making the punch?"
es: —Are you preparing the other punch?—asked Stryver, from the sofa on which he was lying on his back.

en: “I am.”
vi: − Brewing. −
tr: "I'm preparing.""
es: —Yes.

en: “Now, look here! I am going to tell you something that will rather surprise you, and that perhaps will make you think me not quite as shrewd as you usually do think me. I intend to marry.”
vi: Hey, look here! I'm going to tell you something very surprising, and perhaps it will show you that I'm not as wise as you usually think. I'm planning to get married.
tr: "Look now! I'm going to tell you something that will surprise you a lot, and you might see that I'm not as smart as you think I am. I want to get married."
es: —Listen, then. I'm going to reveal something to you that will surely amaze you, and who knows, it might even make you think I'm much less clever than I appear. I've been thinking about getting married.

en: “Do you?”
vi: − You? − Yes.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —You?

en: “Yes. And not for money. What do you say now?”
vi: And not for money. What do you say to that?
tr: "Yes! But not for the money. What are you saying?"
es: —Yes. It will surprise you even more to know that I am not getting married for money. What do you say?

en: “I don’t feel disposed to say much. Who is she?”
vi: − I have nothing to say. Who is she?
tr: "I don't want to say much." "With whom?"
es: —I don't feel like saying much. Who is she?

en: “Guess.”
vi: − Guess. −
tr: "Guess what.""
es: —Guess it.

en: “Do I know her?”
vi: Do I know her?
tr: "Do I know them?""
es: —Do I know her?

en: “Guess.”
vi: − Guess. − I'm not guessing, it's already five in the morning and my head is boiling.
tr: "Guess.""
es: —Guess it.

en: “I am not going to guess, at five o’clock in the morning, with my brains frying and sputtering in my head. If you want me to guess, you must ask me to dinner.”
vi: − Guess. − I'm not guessing, it's already five in the morning and my head is boiling. If you want me to guess, you have to invite me to dinner. −
tr: "At five in the morning, when my brain is so muddled and scattered, I can't predict anything. If you really want me to guess, we can have dinner together one evening."
es: —It doesn't seem like a good time to start guessing, at five in the morning with my head turned into an erupting volcano. If you want me to guess, invite me to eat.

en: “Well then, I’ll tell you,” said Stryver, coming slowly into a sitting posture. “Sydney, I rather despair of making myself intelligible to you, because you are such an insensible dog.”
vi: Alright, let me tell you, - Stryver said as he slowly shifted to a sitting position. - Sydney, it's a waste of time explaining to you, because you're just an insensitive person. −
tr: "Alright then, I'll tell you," said Stryver as he slowly sat down. "Sydney, I find it difficult to explain myself to you, because you are an insensitive fellow."
es: —Since you don't want to guess, I'll tell you myself—said Stryver, sitting lazily. —Of course, I don't harbor the slightest hope of making myself understood by you, simply because you are and always have been an insensitive dog.

en: “And you,” returned Sydney, busy concocting the punch, “are such a sensitive and poetical spirit—”
vi: And you, - Sydney replied while still busy mixing the punch, - are a sentimental and poetic soul... − Stop it!
tr: While stirring the punch, Sydney turned to him and said, "But you," she said, "are so emotional and poetic."
es: —On the other hand, you have always been and still are a spirit full of sensitivity and poetry—replied Sydney with an ironic tone.

en: “Come!” rejoined Stryver, laughing boastfully, “though I don’t prefer any claim to being the soul of Romance (for I hope I know better), still I am a tenderer sort of fellow than you.”
vi: - Stryver laughed arrogantly, - though I don't like to think of myself as romantic; I hope I'm better than that, but I am a more emotional person than you.
tr: Laughing heartily, "Come on!" Stryver replied, "Although I don't claim to be someone with a romantic soul (but I hope to understand these things better one day), it's certain that I'm more sensitive than you.""
es: —Man!...—exclaimed Stryver, laughing. —I don't aspire to be a sentimental novel hero, but you can't deny that I'm softer than you.

en: “You are a luckier, if you mean that.”
vi: − You mean you're luckier, don't you? −
tr: "You are luckier, if that's what you mean."
es: —You mean luckier.

en: “I don’t mean that. I mean I am a man of more—more—”
vi: That's not what I mean. I mean I'm a person... a person... −
tr: "I didn't mean it like that. What I meant to say is, I am more... more..."
es: —You mean luckier. —No; I meant to say more... more...

en: “Say gallantry, while you are about it,” suggested Carton.
vi: Just say you're more gallant, - Carton suggested. −
tr: "I suppose you mean gentleman," said Carton.
es: —Gallant: Did I get it right this time?

en: “Well! I’ll say gallantry. My meaning is that I am a man,” said Stryver, inflating himself at his friend as he made the punch, “who cares more to be agreeable, who takes more pains to be agreeable, who knows better how to be agreeable, in a woman’s society, than you do.”
vi: Ah! Saying I'm gallant works too, - Stryver boasted to his friend who was mixing the drink. - I mean that with women, I'm someone who values making myself pleasant, someone who strives to be pleasant, someone who knows how to show himself as pleasant more than you.
tr: "Alright, let's say gentleman then. What I really mean is," said Stryver, continuing to puff himself up to his friend who was preparing punch, "I am a man who can make himself accepted by women, who can endure some difficulties to make himself accepted, and who knows better how to make himself accepted."
es: —Well! Let's say gallant! My intention was to say that I am a man who takes care to make myself more pleasant, that I take more interest in making myself more pleasant, that I know the way to make myself more pleasant to women than you do.

en: “Go on,” said Sydney Carton.
vi: − Go on, - Sydney Carton said.
tr: "Go on," said Sydney Carton.
es: —Go ahead—said Sydney Carton.

en: “No; but before I go on,” said Stryver, shaking his head in his bullying way, “I’ll have this out with you. You’ve been at Doctor Manette’s house as much as I have, or more than I have. Why, I have been ashamed of your moroseness there! Your manners have been of that silent and sullen and hangdog kind, that, upon my life and soul, I have been ashamed of you, Sydney!”
vi: − Wait, - Stryver shook his head vigorously, - before I continue, I must finish this story with you. You have visited Dr. Manette's house as often as I have, even more. Oh, I'm really ashamed when you bring that gloomy face there! Your attitude is so silent, sullen, and gloomy that, I swear to you, I'm ashamed of you, Sydney! −
tr: "No; before continuing," said Stryver, shaking his head forcefully from side to side, "let me fully explain this matter to you. You have been at Doctor Manette's house as much as I have, if not more. You can't imagine how embarrassed I was by your sulkiness there! Every time I saw you in that sullen, silent state, I was mortified, Sydney!"
es: —Calm down, my friend—replied Stryver, shaking his head. — Before going any further, I want to state the following: You have visited Doctor Manette's house as often, if not more often than I have, and frankly, I have been embarrassed by your harsh demeanor, the scowl you always wear there. Your manners have been those of a bad-tempered dog and your demeanor so gloomy that I have felt ashamed of you, Sydney.

en: “It should be very beneficial to a man in your practice at the bar, to be ashamed of anything,” returned Sydney; “you ought to be much obliged to me.”
vi: It's good for a lawyer to know shame, - Sydney said, - you should thank me.
tr: "It is extremely beneficial for a man working in Baroda to feel ashamed of such things," replied Sydney, "so you should be grateful to me."
es: —You should be highly grateful to me, Stryver, because men of your profession are not usually ashamed of anything—replied Carton.

en: “You shall not get off in that way,” rejoined Stryver, shouldering the rejoinder at him; “no, Sydney, it’s my duty to tell you—and I tell you to your face to do you good—that you are a devilish ill-conditioned fellow in that sort of society. You are a disagreeable fellow.”
vi: − Don't try to change the subject like that, - Stryver retorted aggressively, speaking as if picking a fight. - No, Sydney, it's my duty to let you know; and I will say it straight to your face to wake you up; that you are an unpleasant and grumpy person towards women. You are despicable.
tr: Stryver responded to his sharp reply, "You won't get away with it like this," he retorted sharply, "no Sydney, it is my duty to tell you this – I'm telling you to your face for your own good – you behave very disgracefully and nonsensically in public. You are a grumpy man."
es: —Don't dodge the issue, Sydney. I consider it my duty to tell you, and I tell it to your face, because I believe I'm doing you a favor, that you lack the qualities to be in society. You are a decidedly unpleasant companion.

en: Sydney drank a bumper of the punch he had made, and laughed.
vi: Sydney drank a full glass of freshly made punch and laughed loudly.
tr: Sydney drank a full glass of the punch she had prepared and laughed heartily.
es: Sydney took a sip of punch and burst out laughing.

en: “Look at me!” said Stryver, squaring himself; “I have less need to make myself agreeable than you have, being more independent in circumstances. Why do I do it?”
vi: − Look at me! - Stryver said, puffing out his chest. - Being this rich and successful, I don't need to do much to be more charming than you. Why do I still try to be charming?
tr: "Look at me for a moment!" said Stryver, gesturing with his hand, "compared to you, I don't need to prove myself at all, I am sufficient on my own in any situation. But why am I doing this?"
es: —Look at me!—replied Stryver, standing up and striking an arrogant pose. —I have less need than you to make myself agreeable, since my position is a thousand times more independent than yours. Why, then, do I always manage to make myself agreeable?

en: “I never saw you do it yet,” muttered Carton.
vi: − I've never seen you do that before, - Carton muttered.
tr: "We have never seen you do anything either," Carton grumbled.
es: —In my life, I have never seen you do it.

en: “I do it because it’s politic; I do it on principle. And look at me! I get on.”
vi: − I do it because it's a strategy; it's my motto. And look at me! I succeed in everything.
tr: "I am doing this politically; I am doing it out of principle. Look at me! How far I've come."
es: —I make myself agreeable because it is required by refined manners and because it is in my blood. I continue. —What you are not continuing, as I see, is the exposition of your matrimonial projects.

en: “You don’t get on with your account of your matrimonial intentions,” answered Carton, with a careless air; “I wish you would keep to that. As to me—will you never understand that I am incorrigible?”
vi: − I haven't finished talking about my marriage plans yet, - Carton said indifferently. - I hope you continue with that topic. As for me... don't you ever understand that I am incorrigible?
tr: With an indifferent attitude, "You haven't made much progress with marriage yet," said Carton; "but don't give up, keep going. As for me, haven't you realized yet that I'm an incorrigible man?"
es: As for the rest, do me the favor of not continuing. Will you never be convinced that I am incorrigible?

en: He asked the question with some appearance of scorn.
vi: The question revealed a tone of contempt.
tr: He had asked this question with a slight hint of disdain.
es: Carton asked this question with a sarcastic tone.

en: “You have no business to be incorrigible,” was his friend’s answer, delivered in no very soothing tone.
vi: − You don't need to act so unmanageable, - Stryver's voice was sharp.
tr: "You can't even be a man who can't be reformed," said his friend in a tone that was far from reassuring.
es: "To be incorrigible, you would need to have business, and I don't know that you have any," replied Stryver, a little annoyed.

en: “I have no business to be, at all, that I know of,” said Sydney Carton. “Who is the lady?”
vi: − I don't need to act at all, I know that, - Sydney Carton replied. - But who is that lady? −
tr: "Nothing will ever come of me anyway," said Sydney Carton. "Who is this lady?"
es: —As far as I know, I don't have them... Who is the lucky one?

en: “Now, don’t let my announcement of the name make you uncomfortable, Sydney,” said Mr. Stryver, preparing him with ostentatious friendliness for the disclosure he was about to make, “because I know you don’t mean half you say; and if you meant it all, it would be of no importance. I make this little preface, because you once mentioned the young lady to me in slighting terms.”
vi: Now, don't get upset when I mention her name, Sydney, Stryver pretended to be friendly before revealing, - because I know you think one thing and say another; and even if you did say what you truly think, it wouldn't matter. I have to preface it a bit because you have previously spoken of that lady to me with disdain.
tr: "But if I tell you her name now, you might get upset, Sydney," said Stryver, as if he were preparing him with a showy sincerity for what he was about to explain, "because I know you don't mean half of what you say, but even if you did, it wouldn't matter. I made such an introduction because you had previously spoken honorably about this young lady."
es: —I would not want the mention of the name to cause you sorrow or displeasure—said Stryver, preparing with friendly circumlocutions the revelation he was about to make. —I know that you do not feel half of what you say, although, to tell the truth, if you felt it all, it would be the same, for it would not matter. I make this preamble because on one occasion you spoke quite lightly of the young lady whose name I am going to pronounce.

en: “I did?”
vi: − Me? − Exactly; and right in this office.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Me?

en: “Certainly; and in these chambers.”
vi: − Me? − Exactly; and right in this office.
tr: "Yes; and right here."
es: —You, yes; and in this very room.

en: Sydney Carton looked at his punch and looked at his complacent friend; drank his punch and looked at his complacent friend.
vi: Sydney Carton looked at the glass of wine and then at his complacent friend; he drained the glass and looked at his friend again. −
tr: Sydney Carton first looked at the punch in his glass, then at his contented friend; then he drank his punch and looked again at his contented friend.
es: Carton treated himself to another glass of punch and looked at his friend.

en: “You made mention of the young lady as a golden-haired doll. The young lady is Miss Manette. If you had been a fellow of any sensitiveness or delicacy of feeling in that kind of way, Sydney, I might have been a little resentful of your employing such a designation; but you are not. You want that sense altogether; therefore I am no more annoyed when I think of the expression, than I should be annoyed by a man’s opinion of a picture of mine, who had no eye for pictures: or of a piece of music of mine, who had no ear for music.”
vi: You once called that lady a blonde doll. That lady is Miss Manette. Sydney, if you had any delicate feelings or emotions towards women, I would have felt uncomfortable with your contempt for her; but you are not that kind of person. You have no feelings at all; so being angry at you for saying that would be like being upset when someone without an eye for art criticizes my paintings, or someone without an ear for music criticizes my compositions.
tr: "You had mentioned this young lady as the golden-haired doll. This young lady is Miss Manette. If you were a man with a bit of sensitivity and kindness, Sydney, I might have been offended by the way you spoke of her, but you are not. You have never had a share of such things; therefore, what you say doesn't bother me more than a person without an eye for beauty commenting on a painting I made or a person without an ear for music commenting on a composition I created."
es: —Referring to the young lady I allude to, you said she was a doll with golden hair. The young lady I refer to is Miss Lucie Manette. If you knew sensitivity, if you were a man of delicate feelings, it would have bothered me that you spoke of her as you did; but since you are neither sensitive nor delicate, I paid no attention to your frivolity. You lack both qualities, and therefore, when your expression comes to my mind, I give it the same importance as I would to the opinion of a blind man who claimed a painting of mine was bad, or to that of a deaf-mute who pretended to find faults in a musical composition of mine.

en: Sydney Carton drank the punch at a great rate; drank it by bumpers, looking at his friend.
vi: Sydney Carton drank quickly; he emptied a full glass, his eyes still on his friend. −
tr: Sydney Carton took a big gulp of his drink; then, looking at his friend, he downed the glass that was filled to the brim.
es: Carton continued frequently visiting the punch bowl.

en: “Now you know all about it, Syd,” said Mr. Stryver. “I don’t care about fortune: she is a charming creature, and I have made up my mind to please myself: on the whole, I think I can afford to please myself. She will have in me a man already pretty well off, and a rapidly rising man, and a man of some distinction: it is a piece of good fortune for her, but she is worthy of good fortune. Are you astonished?”
vi: Now I've told you everything, Sydney, - Stryver continued. - I don't need wealth; she is a lovely person, and I have decided to seek happiness for myself; in general, I think I have enough conditions to be happy. She will have a wealthy husband in me; someone who is advancing quickly, someone with a bit of prestige; for her, having a husband like me is fortunate, but she also deserves to be fortunate. Are you surprised? − Why should I be surprised?
tr: "Now you know everything, Syd," said Mr. Stryver. "I have no interest in money or wealth. She is a magnificent creature and I have decided to be happy; I think I can succeed in being happy. Even in my current state, I am quite wealthy, rapidly rising, and a man with many advantages. This is a great opportunity for her, but I mean, she also deserves this opportunity, of course. Are you surprised?"
es: —You know it all already, Sydney—continued Stryver. —I am marrying that girl, regardless of whether she has a fortune or not. She is a charming creature, and I have resolved to make her happy, and without boasting or immodesty, I believe I can say that I have achieved it. I hold an enviable position, I am prospering and rising quickly, and I am not lacking in distinction. In a word: I am a treasure for her, and I am glad, for she deserves treasures. Are you astonished by what you hear?

en: Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I be astonished?”
vi: - Still drinking, Carton replied. −
tr: Carton, who was still busy drinking punch, said gruffly, "Why should I be surprised?"
es: —Why should it amaze me?—responded Sydney, between sips of punch.

en: “You approve?”
vi: Do you approve?
tr: "So you approve."
es: —Do you approve of it?

en: Carton, still drinking the punch, rejoined, “Why should I not approve?”
vi: Still drinking, Carton replied: − Why wouldn't I approve?
tr: Carton, who was still drinking punch, answered gruffly, "Why shouldn't I approve?"
es: —Why shouldn't I approve it? —Well!

en: “Well!” said his friend Stryver, “you take it more easily than I fancied you would, and are less mercenary on my behalf than I thought you would be; though, to be sure, you know well enough by this time that your ancient chum is a man of a pretty strong will. Yes, Sydney, I have had enough of this style of life, with no other as a change from it; I feel that it is a pleasant thing for a man to have a home when he feels inclined to go to it (when he doesn’t, he can stay away), and I feel that Miss Manette will tell well in any station, and will always do me credit. So I have made up my mind. And now, Sydney, old boy, I want to say a word to you about your prospects. You are in a bad way, you know; you really are in a bad way. You don’t know the value of money, you live hard, you’ll knock up one of these days, and be ill and poor; you really ought to think about a nurse.”
vi: − Very good! - Stryver said to his friend. - You take this news more easily than I thought, and think less about my benefit than I expected; although by now you surely know that your old friend is someone who, once decided, will act. That's right, Sydney, I'm tired of this lifestyle, it's too monotonous; I think it's good for a man to have a family so that if he wants, he can go home; if he doesn't want to, he doesn't have to; I think Miss Manette will please any husband, and will always make me proud. So I've made up my mind. And now, Sydney, my old friend, I want to say a few words to you about your future. You have made mistakes, you have really made mistakes. You don't know the value of money, you live frugally, and one day you will fall into illness and poverty. You need to think about finding someone to take care of you.
tr: "Alright!" said Stryver, "You got over it more easily than I expected and you didn't approach it as opportunistically as I thought, but of course, you know very well how determined your old friend is to get what he wants. Yes Sydney, I'm tired of this same old way of life; I think it's a very nice thing for a man to have a home he can go to when he wants (and escape from when he doesn't), and it seems to me that Miss Manette would be a good wife in any case and would bring me respect. That's how I made my decision. Now Sydney, big boy, I have some things to say about your "situation." You know you're on a bad path, my friend; really on a bad path. You don't know the value of money, you're pushing yourself too hard, one day you won't be able to get up, you'll fall ill and be penniless; you should consider having a woman to take care of you."
es: I see that you are taking it more calmly than I expected, and that, for my sake, you are less mercenary than I thought. It doesn't surprise me, after all, because you know perfectly well that your old schoolmate has always been distinguished by his strength of character. Yes, Sydney, yes; I am tired of the life I lead and the time has come to change it. I have become convinced that it is a delight for a man to have a home, to create a family, if he feels inclined to do so, and I am sure that Miss Manette will always beautify and honor it. I am, therefore, resolved, firmly decided. And now, Sydney, my dear friend, allow me to say a few words about your situation. You are walking down false paths, on the wrong track; you know that as well as I do. You don't understand the value of money, you live a disordered life, you don't think about tomorrow, and in short, your behavior can only lead you to illness and misery. I think you need to find yourself a nurse.

en: The prosperous patronage with which he said it, made him look twice as big as he was, and four times as offensive.
vi: The pompous and boastful manner in Stryver's speech made him doubly arrogant and four times more obnoxious.
tr: Speaking like a well-off boss made him appear twice as big and four times as unpleasant as he actually was.
es: The protective tone with which Stryver spoke accentuated the impertinence of his words and made them doubly offensive.

en: “Now, let me recommend you,” pursued Stryver, “to look it in the face. I have looked it in the face, in my different way; look it in the face, you, in your different way. Marry. Provide somebody to take care of you. Never mind your having no enjoyment of women’s society, nor understanding of it, nor tact for it. Find out somebody. Find out some respectable woman with a little property—somebody in the landlady way, or lodging-letting way—and marry her, against a rainy day. That’s the kind of thing for you. Now think of it, Sydney.”
vi: − Listen to my advice, - Stryver continued, - face the truth. I have faced the truth, in my own way; now you, face the truth, in your own way. Get married. Find someone to take care of you. Don't worry about not liking women, not understanding them, or not being liked by them. Just find someone. Find a respectable woman with some property... a landlady or an innkeeper... and marry her, in case of bad times. That's your future. Think about it, Sydney.
tr: Stryver continued his speech, "Now my advice to you is to open your eyes and look around. I opened my eyes and found my way; you should open your eyes and find your way too. Get married. Find someone to take care of you. It doesn't matter if you get bored among women, don't understand them, or lack refinement. You just find someone. Even if she doesn't have much money – maybe she has a house or a boarding house – let her be a respectable lady and marry her, save yourself. This is what you need. Think about this carefully, Sydney."
es: —Do not be offended that I now recommend you study the matter head-on and without stupid prejudices as I have studied it, although our respective conditions differ greatly. Get married. Find someone to take care of you. It doesn't matter if the company of women is not to your liking; it doesn't matter if you lack intelligence or tact to deal with them. Find a respectable woman who has some assets, and marry her as soon as possible, the only way to prepare yourself in time against the calamities and uncertainties of life. I have finished. Think about it, Sydney.

en: “I’ll think of it,” said Sydney.
vi: Think about it, Sydney.
tr: "I will think about it," said Sydney.
es: —I'll think about it—replied Sydney Carton.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: − Let me think, - Sydney replied.
tr: XII
es: Chapter XII.

en: The Fellow of Delicacy
vi: 12. The elegant gentleman Having wholeheartedly bestowed his fortune upon the doctor's daughter, Stryver decided to inform her of this happy news before he left the city for a long vacation.
tr: The Polite Man
es: THE DELICATE KNIGHT

en: Mr. Stryver having made up his mind to that magnanimous bestowal of good fortune on the Doctor’s daughter, resolved to make her happiness known to her before he left town for the Long Vacation. After some mental debating of the point, he came to the conclusion that it would be as well to get all the preliminaries done with, and they could then arrange at their leisure whether he should give her his hand a week or two before Michaelmas Term, or in the little Christmas vacation between it and Hilary.
vi: 12. The elegant gentleman Having wholeheartedly bestowed his fortune upon the doctor's daughter, Stryver decided to inform her of this happy news before he left the city for a long vacation. After some internal struggle over this matter, he concluded that it would be best to settle the preliminary courtship matters right away and then arrange the wedding as convenient when the court went on its regular recess - either one or two weeks before the end of October or during the Christmas holidays.
tr: Mr. Stryver, who had decided to give a grand gift to the doctor's fortunate daughter, was determined to convey this happy news to her before leaving town for his long vacation. After pondering the matter for a while, he concluded that it would be good to make an attempt, and then they would have time to plan the wedding either a week or two before the Feast of St. Michael on September 29th, or sometime between Christmas and the Feast of St. Hilary of Poitiers on January 13th.
es: Once Mr. Stryver resolved to secure Miss Manette's happiness, nothing was more natural than to let her know as soon as possible the joy that his magnanimity had bestowed upon her. After mentally debating and with due deliberation on such an important matter, he concluded that he should take the preliminary steps right away, before going on vacation, leaving the setting of the wedding date for later, which could take place one or two weeks before Michaelmas, or during the brief Christmas holidays.

en: As to the strength of his case, he had not a doubt about it, but clearly saw his way to the verdict. Argued with the jury on substantial worldly grounds—the only grounds ever worth taking into account—it was a plain case, and had not a weak spot in it. He called himself for the plaintiff, there was no getting over his evidence, the counsel for the defendant threw up his brief, and the jury did not even turn to consider. After trying it, Stryver, C. J., was satisfied that no plainer case could be.
vi: Stryver viewed marriage as a lawsuit that he was sure to win and had already anticipated the court's verdict. If it was necessary to persuade the jury based on material advantages - the only basis worth considering - then this case clearly had no weak points. He imagined himself as the plaintiff's representative, with irrefutable evidence, then the defendant's lawyer throwing away the file, having no grounds for rebuttal, and the jury not even needing to deliberate. After the trial, Stryver, now imagining himself as the Chief Justice, was satisfied that no trial could be clearer.
tr: As for the strength of his case, he had not the slightest doubt, but he could see the path to judgment. This was a clear case argued with the jury on worldly grounds – the only grounds that could be taken seriously – and it had not the slightest weakness. He called himself as the plaintiff, and it was impossible to deal with the evidence. The defendant's lawyer threw the case summary, but the jury did not even turn to look. Lawyer Stryver, C. J. was convinced that there could not be a simpler case than this.
es: That he had already won the lawsuit in advance was so evident that it would have been foolish to doubt it. It was a clear case, without any weak points, one of those lawsuits where it is enough to file the complaint to obtain a favorable judgment. He could even spare himself the trouble of reasoning his request. Why?

en: Accordingly, Mr. Stryver inaugurated the Long Vacation with a formal proposal to take Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens; that failing, to Ranelagh; that unaccountably failing too, it behoved him to present himself in Soho, and there declare his noble mind.
vi: So Stryver began his long vacation by formally inviting Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens, an invitation that was declined; he then invited her to Ranelagh Gardens, which was also inexplicably declined, so he had to personally make his way to Soho to declare his noble intentions there.
tr: Therefore, Mr. Stryver began his long vacation with a formal proposal, inviting Miss Manette to Vauxhall Gardens; when that did not work, he suggested going to Ranelagh Gardens; when that also did not work, he decided it would be appropriate to go to Soho and reveal his noble intention.
es: The jury would rule in his favor without even deliberating: the famous lawyer was more than convinced of this. Consequently, Stryver began his vacation by proposing to Miss Manette to take her to the Vauxhall Gardens.

en: Towards Soho, therefore, Mr. Stryver shouldered his way from the Temple, while the bloom of the Long Vacation’s infancy was still upon it. Anybody who had seen him projecting himself into Soho while he was yet on Saint Dunstan’s side of Temple Bar, bursting in his full-blown way along the pavement, to the jostlement of all weaker people, might have seen how safe and strong he was.
vi: That is why Stryver hurriedly went from the Temple area to Soho just as the holiday was beginning. Anyone who saw him rushing towards Soho while he was still on the Saint Dunstan side of the Temple Bar gate, dashing along the pavement and brushing aside any weaker pedestrians in his path, would see how strong and confident Stryver was.
tr: Thus, Mr. Stryver, with the freshness of the long holiday he had taken, left Temple and headed towards Soho. Those who saw him when he was still on the Saint Dunstan side of Temple Bar, upon seeing him in Soho, could understand how confident and strong he was from his swaggering walk, pushing and shoving poor people aside.
es: After the offer was declined, he invited her to Ranelagh; and since, to his great surprise, this invitation was also not accepted, he resolved to declare the noble aspirations of his soul in the same little house in Soho. One morning, Stryver left the Temple Court and directed his steps towards the peaceful retreat where Dr. Manette lived.

en: His way taking him past Tellson’s, and he both banking at Tellson’s and knowing Mr. Lorry as the intimate friend of the Manettes, it entered Mr. Stryver’s mind to enter the bank, and reveal to Mr. Lorry the brightness of the Soho horizon. So, he pushed open the door with the weak rattle in its throat, stumbled down the two steps, got past the two ancient cashiers, and shouldered himself into the musty back closet where Mr. Lorry sat at great books ruled for figures, with perpendicular iron bars to his window as if that were ruled for figures too, and everything under the clouds were a sum.
vi: On the way past Tellson's Bank, as Stryver had both deposited money there and was acquainted with Mr. Lorry, a close friend of the Manette family, he got the idea to go into the bank to reveal to him the bright prospects on the Soho horizon. So he pushed the creaky door open, rushed down two steps, passed by two ancient tellers, and then barged into the musty room at the back where Mr. Lorry sat with some huge ledgers with columns of figures, by the window with vertical iron bars as if the window frame itself was a ledger sheet and everything under the clouds was money.
tr: As Mr. Stryver, who was passing by Tellson's Bank, thought of stopping by to talk to Mr. Lorry about the shining sun in Soho, since he was both a customer of Tellson's and a close friend of the Manettes, he decided to visit the bank. Thus, with a slight rasp in his throat, he pushed the door open, stumbled down the two steps, passed by the two aged tellers, and threw himself into the musty compartment at the back where Mr. Lorry was seated over the large, lined ledgers kept for accounts; the vertical iron bars on the window stood like the lines separating the figures, and everything else under the sky seemed like their sum total.
es: Since Tellson's Bank was on his way, and knowing the close friendship between Mr. Lorry and the Manettes, it occurred to him to enter the Bank and reveal to him the radiant star that was casting bright rays on the horizon of Soho. He opened the door, which creaked harshly as it turned on its worn hinges, descended the two steps, and soon presented himself in the office where Lorry, bent over his books, was writing endless columns of perfectly aligned numbers.

en: “Halloa!” said Mr. Stryver. “How do you do? I hope you are well!”
vi: − Hello! - Stryver said. - How are you? Hope you're doing well!
tr: "Hello!" said Mr. Stryver. "How are you? Hope all is well."
es: —Hello, Mr. Lorry!—exclaimed Stryver upon entering. —How are you?

en: It was Stryver’s grand peculiarity that he always seemed too big for any place, or space. He was so much too big for Tellson’s, that old clerks in distant corners looked up with looks of remonstrance, as though he squeezed them against the wall. The House itself, magnificently reading the paper quite in the far-off perspective, lowered displeased, as if the Stryver head had been butted into its responsible waistcoat.
vi: Stryver had the outstanding characteristic of always seeming too grand for any space or place. He was so grand for Tellson's that the old employees in the far corners had to look up with disapproving eyes as if they were being squeezed against the wall by him. Even the Boss, who was majestically reading a newspaper in the innermost part, had to lower the paper in annoyance as if Stryver had headbutted him in the stomach.
tr: In every environment he entered, everywhere, Mr. Stryver's most prominent feature was his large stature. He was too bulky for Tellson as well, so much so that the elderly clerks sitting in distant corners raised their heads and looked at him with reproachful eyes as if they were being squeezed against the wall. The Manager, reading his newspaper over there, lifted his head with a stern expression as if Stryver's head was encroaching on his area of responsibility.
es: I suppose as well as always. —Hello, Mr. Stryver!—responded Lorry, shaking the hand that the lawyer extended to him.

en: The discreet Mr. Lorry said, in a sample tone of the voice he would recommend under the circumstances, “How do you do, Mr. Stryver? How do you do, sir?” and shook hands. There was a peculiarity in his manner of shaking hands, always to be seen in any clerk at Tellson’s who shook hands with a customer when the House pervaded the air. He shook in a self-abnegating way, as one who shook for Tellson and Co.
vi: − Hello, Mr. Stryver. How are you? - Mr. Lorry replied cautiously with the exemplary tone he usually used in such circumstances. The way he shook hands was also special, only seen when a Tellson's employee shook hands with a customer in front of the Boss - a handshake that denied personal identity, representing only Tellson and the Corporation.
tr: The prudent Mr. Lorry, in a tone that demonstrated how one should speak in such an environment, said, "How are you, Mr. Stryver? How are you, sir?" and shook his hand. In the handshake, there was the manner of every clerk at Tellson's. When the manager was around, there was a certain demeanor while shaking a customer's hand. It was as if it wasn't him shaking the hand, but the Tellson and Company itself.
es: —Hello, Mr. Stryver!—responded Lorry, shaking the hand that the lawyer extended to him. —Very well, thank you; and you?

en: “Can I do anything for you, Mr. Stryver?” asked Mr. Lorry, in his business character.
vi: − How can I help you, Mr. Stryver? - Mr. Lorry asked in a professional manner. −
tr: "How can I assist you, Mr. Stryver?" asked Mr. Lorry, in his businessman's voice
es: Do you need something from me, Mr. Stryver?

en: “Why, no, thank you; this is a private visit to yourself, Mr. Lorry; I have come for a private word.”
vi: Oh, no, thank you; this is just a personal visit, Mr. Lorry; I have a private matter to discuss with you. −
tr: "No, thank you; this is a personal visit, Mr. Lorry; I have come to talk to you about something private."
es: —No... thank you very much. I have the desire to pay you a private visit, Mr. Lorry; the desire to say a few words to you in private.

en: “Oh indeed!” said Mr. Lorry, bending down his ear, while his eye strayed to the House afar off.
vi: Oh really! - Mr. Lorry leaned his ear towards the guest while his eyes wandered towards the distant Master. −
tr: "Is that so?" said Mr. Lorry, listening intently but his eyes had shifted to the Manager ahead.
es: —Oh, whichever ones you want!—replied Lorry, closing the book and getting ready to listen.

en: “I am going,” said Mr. Stryver, leaning his arms confidentially on the desk: whereupon, although it was a large double one, there appeared to be not half desk enough for him: “I am going to make an offer of myself in marriage to your agreeable little friend, Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry.”
vi: Here I am, - Stryver said confidently, placing both hands on the desk which was twice the size of a normal one but still seemed small before the grand Stryver, - here I am about to propose to your charming little friend, Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry.
tr: "I am going," said Mr. Stryver, confidently leaning his arms on the table; despite it being a large table, he occupied half of it. "I am going to propose marriage to your sweet little friend Miss Manette, Mr. Lorry."
es: —I'm going...—the lawyer began to say, resting his elbows on the table and in a confidential tone,—I'm going to make a marriage proposal to your dear and pleasant little friend Lucía Manette, Mr. Lorry.

en: “Oh dear me!” cried Mr. Lorry, rubbing his chin, and looking at his visitor dubiously.
vi: − Oh dear me! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, rubbing his chin, his eyes looking doubtfully at the guest.
tr: "Good heavens!" shouted Mr. Lorry, rubbing his chin and looking at his visitor with suspicious eyes.
es: —Damn!—exclaimed Lorry, scratching his beard and looking perplexed at the lawyer.

en: “Oh dear me, sir?” repeated Stryver, drawing back. “Oh dear you, sir? What may your meaning be, Mr. Lorry?”
vi: − Why would I die? - Stryver stepped back. - Or would you die? What do you mean, Mr. Lorry? −
tr: "Why, good heavens, sir?" said Stryver, drawing back. "Good heavens, why, sir? What did you mean, Mr. Lorry?"
es: —Demon?—repeated Stryver vividly.—Is that what you come up with to say to me? What does your exclamation mean, Mr. Lorry?

en: “My meaning,” answered the man of business, “is, of course, friendly and appreciative, and that it does you the greatest credit, and—in short, my meaning is everything you could desire. But—really, you know, Mr. Stryver—” Mr. Lorry paused, and shook his head at him in the oddest manner, as if he were compelled against his will to add, internally, “you know there really is so much too much of you!”
vi: What I mean is, - the man of business responded, - of course in a friendly and appreciative manner, I mean it is extremely deserving for you, and... in short, I mean I wish you to achieve all your desires. But... honestly speaking, Mr. Stryver... - Mr. Lorry paused and then shook his head, looking at his guest in a very peculiar way, as if he was forced to speak against his own will, - you know very well that you are exceedingly grand!
tr: "What I mean," the businessman began, "of course it involves friendship and appreciation and is extremely beneficial for you, in short, I mean there's nothing bad about it. But – actually, you know, Mr. Stryver –" Mr. Lorry, as if something had stopped him from continuing, nodded his head in the strangest manner, "you are a bit too, I mean actually, excessively grand."
es: —It is an exclamation... friendly... personal... purely appreciative, that can mean whatever you wish it to mean. The truth is, Mr. Stryver... it seems to me... I find...

en: “Well!” said Stryver, slapping the desk with his contentious hand, opening his eyes wider, and taking a long breath, “if I understand you, Mr. Lorry, I’ll be hanged!”
vi: − Hmph! - Stryver slammed his hand on the table, eyes wide open and took a deep breath. - Mr. Lorry, if I understand what you mean, hang me!
tr: Stryver, striking Mr. Lorry's desk with his rough hand, said "Well then!" and took a deep breath, opening his eyes wide, "it's impossible to understand you either!"
es: —Enough!—replied the lawyer, slamming his hand on the table. —If I understand what you're saying, Mr. Lorry, hang me!

en: Mr. Lorry adjusted his little wig at both ears as a means towards that end, and bit the feather of a pen.
vi: Mr. Lorry adjusted the sides of his wig and bit the tip of his quill pen.
tr: Mr. Lorry adjusted his small wig from both sides of his ears to the back and bit his quill pen.
es: Lorry adjusted his toupee on his head and stood looking at his interlocutor, biting the bristles of his pen.

en: “D—n it all, sir!” said Stryver, staring at him, “am I not eligible?”
vi: − Damn it! - Stryver stared - So I'm not worthy? −
tr: Stryver, fixing his eyes on Mr. Lorry, said, "Damn it! Am I not suitable for her then?"
es: —Do you consider me ineligible?—asked Stryver, staring intently at his interlocutor.

en: “Oh dear yes! Yes. Oh yes, you’re eligible!” said Mr. Lorry. “If you say eligible, you are eligible.”
vi: Oh dear, yes! Yes! Oh, you are very suitable! - Mr. Lorry said. If you are not suitable, then who is.
tr: "Ah of course! Of course you are suitable!" said Mr. Lorry. "If you see yourself as suitable, then you are suitable."
es: —Quite the contrary, Mr. Stryver! Yes... you are eligible.

en: “Am I not prosperous?” asked Stryver.
vi: − So, am I not successful? - Stryver asked again.
tr: "Am I not a successful and wealthy man?" asked Stryver.
es: —Am I not a good match?

en: “Oh! if you come to prosperous, you are prosperous,” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: − Oh! If you are not successful, then who else could be, - Mr. Lorry replied. −
tr: "Ah! If it's about success and wealth, of course you are," said Mr. Lorry,
es: —Good match; yes... why not? —No progress?

en: “And advancing?”
vi: And also advancing further?
tr: "Aren't I steadily rising in my job?"
es: No improvement?

en: “If you come to advancing you know,” said Mr. Lorry, delighted to be able to make another admission, “nobody can doubt that.”
vi: − Advancing further is beyond question, - Mr. Lorry was glad to have another chance to acknowledge, - no one could doubt that. −
tr: "You are certainly rising," said Mr. Lorry, pleased to be able to confirm it once more, "let no one doubt it."
es: —Yes, sir... who doubts it?

en: “Then what on earth is your meaning, Mr. Lorry?” demanded Stryver, perceptibly crestfallen.
vi: So what on earth do you mean, Mr. Lorry? - Stryver asked, clearly puzzled.
tr: "So what do you mean by that, Mr. Lorry?" asked Stryver, with visible distress.
es: —Then, what the hell does his attitude mean?

en: “Well! I—Were you going there now?” asked Mr. Lorry.
vi: − Well! I... Are you planning to go there now? - Mr. Lorry asked.
tr: "Um! Were you- going there now?" asked Mr. Lorry.
es: —Well... I... Tell me: where were you going now?

en: “Straight!” said Stryver, with a plump of his fist on the desk.
vi: − Right away! - Stryver pounded his fist on the table.
tr: "Yes!" said Stryver, banging his fist on the table with a thud.
es: —Straight to the point—replied Stryver, punching the table.

en: “Then I think I wouldn’t, if I was you.”
vi: − Then if I were you, I think I wouldn't go. −
tr: "In that case, if I were you, I wouldn't go."
es: —If I were in your place, I would leave it for a better occasion.

en: “Why?” said Stryver. “Now, I’ll put you in a corner,” forensically shaking a forefinger at him. “You are a man of business and bound to have a reason. State your reason. Why wouldn’t you go?”
vi: Why? - Stryver said. - Now you must tell me the truth. His index finger waved in front of the other person's face as if arguing in court. - You are a man of business, so you must have a reason. You speak up. Why don't you want to go?
tr: "Why?" asked Stryver. Pointing his finger at him as if he were in court, he said, "I will corner you now." "You are a businessman and there must be a reason for what you say. Explain your reason. Why wouldn't you go there?"
es: —Why?—thundered the lawyer. —I am going to press you to the utmost limit. As a businessman, you are obliged to speak with justified reason. Give the reasons: why wouldn't you go?

en: “Because,” said Mr. Lorry, “I wouldn’t go on such an object without having some cause to believe that I should succeed.”
vi: − Because, - Mr. Lorry replied, - I don't want to do it unless there's evidence to believe that I will succeed.
tr: "Because," said Mr. Lorry, "if I had such an intention, I would not go without a reason to believe that I would succeed.""
es: —Because it is a matter that I would never address without having well-founded hopes of achieving the realization of my desire.

en: “D—n me!” cried Stryver, “but this beats everything.”
vi: − Damn it! - Stryver shouted. - I can't understand it at all!
tr: "Damn it!" shouted Stryver, "you really did it."
es: —Wrath of God!—shouted Stryver. —It's a reason that knocks you flat on your back!

en: Mr. Lorry glanced at the distant House, and glanced at the angry Stryver.
vi: Mr. Lorry glanced at the Boss in the distance and then looked at the furious Stryver.
tr: Mr. Lorry first glanced at the distant Manager and then at the angry Stryver.
es: Lorry did not respond.

en: “Here’s a man of business—a man of years—a man of experience—in a Bank,” said Stryver; “and having summed up three leading reasons for complete success, he says there’s no reason at all! Says it with his head on!” Mr. Stryver remarked upon the peculiarity as if it would have been infinitely less remarkable if he had said it with his head off.
vi: − This is a man of work... an elder...  a man full of experience... in the bank, - Stryver said, - and after summarizing the three main reasons for my success, he then said there was no evidence to believe that! And he said it so calmly! - Stryver emphasized the last sentence as if it would be less surprising if Mr. Lorry had said it while out of his mind. −
tr: "A businessman –at this age– a man with this experience –a man working in a bank," said Stryver; "you are given three fundamental reasons for absolute success and you say you have no reason! And you say this with your head held high!" Mr. Lorry had a strange belief, it seems, that if he said these things with his head bowed, they would somehow be less valid, according to Mr. Stryver.
es: —Here is a businessman, a man of years, a man of experience... in a Bank, who after admitting the existence of the three main reasons, each of which is sufficient on its own to ensure success, comes out saying that there is no reason at all. If that isn't the most absurd of absurdities, then let God come and see it!

en: “When I speak of success, I speak of success with the young lady; and when I speak of causes and reasons to make success probable, I speak of causes and reasons that will tell as such with the young lady. The young lady, my good sir,” said Mr. Lorry, mildly tapping the Stryver arm, “the young lady. The young lady goes before all.”
vi: When I talk about success, I mean success with that lady; and when I talk about the reasons for success, I mean the reasons that would be persuasive to that lady. Think about that lady, dear sir, - Mr. Lorry said while gently tapping Stryver's arm, - think about it. The lady's wishes are the most important.
tr: "When I say success, I am talking about the success of reaching the young girl's heart; as for the reasons and justifications that will make this success possible, these are things that only this young lady would know. Only this young lady, dear sir," said Mr. Lorry, lightly tapping Stryver's arm, "This is something the young lady knows. The young lady's thoughts are more important than anything else."
es: —When I referred to success, I was thinking of Miss Manette, and when speaking of causes and reasons on which to base the hopes of seeing the desire fulfilled, I was referring to causes that were truly so for Miss Manette. Yes... my good friend... the young lady, because the young lady is the sole and unappealable judge.

en: “Then you mean to tell me, Mr. Lorry,” said Stryver, squaring his elbows, “that it is your deliberate opinion that the young lady at present in question is a mincing Fool?”
vi: − Mr. Lorry, are you telling me, - Stryver spread his elbows out, - that the young lady we are talking about is a capricious fool?
tr: "Mr. Lorry, what you mean to tell me," said Stryver, placing his elbows, "is the young lady a delicate fool in this matter?""
es: —So, what you want to tell me, Mr. Lorry, is that the young lady, in your opinion, is a finicky fool.

en: “Not exactly so. I mean to tell you, Mr. Stryver,” said Mr. Lorry, reddening, “that I will hear no disrespectful word of that young lady from any lips; and that if I knew any man—which I hope I do not—whose taste was so coarse, and whose temper was so overbearing, that he could not restrain himself from speaking disrespectfully of that young lady at this desk, not even Tellson’s should prevent my giving him a piece of my mind.”
vi: − Not quite, Mr. Stryver, - Mr. Lorry blushed. - I want to tell you that I do not want to hear anyone uttering disrespectful words about that young lady; if I know anyone; I hope there is none; whose rude behavior and arrogant nature lead them to speak disrespectfully about that young lady right at my desk, then not even Tellson's Bank will stop me from giving them a good scolding.
tr: "Of course not." "What I want to tell you, Mr. Stryver," said Mr. Lorry, with a flushed face, "is that I will not allow anyone to speak disrespectfully about this young lady; if someone were to – and I hope no one does – lose control of their vulgarity and audacity and attempt to speak disrespectfully about her at this table, not even Tellson could prevent me from putting them in their place.""
es: —So, what you want to tell me, Mr. Lorry, is that the young lady, in your opinion, is a finicky fool. —You interpret me in a hurtful way, Mr. Stryver—replied Lorry, red with anger.— What I meant to say, and what I am saying, is that I will not tolerate any tongue uttering a disrespectful word about Miss Manette, and that if I knew of any man... which I want to believe does not exist, any man of such coarse taste and impetuous temperament, who dared to speak with little respect of Miss Manette, the consideration of being at Tellson's Bank would not be enough for me to leave his rudeness unpunished.

en: The necessity of being angry in a suppressed tone had put Mr. Stryver’s blood-vessels into a dangerous state when it was his turn to be angry; Mr. Lorry’s veins, methodical as their courses could usually be, were in no better state now it was his turn.
vi: The act of being angry but forced to speak in a restrained tone had caused Stryver's blood vessels to swell dangerously when he got heated; Mr. Lorry's blood vessels, normally not visible, now bulged when it was his turn. −
tr: When it was his turn to get angry, the necessity of suppressing his anger had put Mr. Stryver's veins at risk; although Mr. Lorry's veins generally pulsed regularly, they were not in very good condition because it was his turn to get angry.
es: The need to contain within his chest the anger that struggled to explode had put Stryver in a dangerous state of mind; as for Lorry, despite having accustomed his blood to not be disturbed by anything or anyone, he found himself in a state of mind as dangerous as that of the lawyer.

en: “That is what I mean to tell you, sir,” said Mr. Lorry. “Pray let there be no mistake about it.”
vi: That's what I mean, sir, - Mr. Lorry said. - Please do not misunderstand me.
tr: "These were the things I wanted to say, sir," said Mr. Lorry. "Please, let there be no mistake."
es: —You know what I wanted to tell you, sir—replied Lorry. —I would greatly appreciate it if you don't forget it.

en: Mr. Stryver sucked the end of a ruler for a little while, and then stood hitting a tune out of his teeth with it, which probably gave him the toothache. He broke the awkward silence by saying:
vi: Stryver put the end of the ruler in his mouth, sucked on it for a while, then tapped the end of the ruler against his teeth in a rhythm that probably made him ache. Stryver broke the silence: "I find this strange, Mr. Lorry."
tr: After Mr. Stryver chewed on the end of a ruler for a while, he made noises by tapping his teeth, but this must have hurt his teeth as he stopped. Breaking the strange silence, he said:
es: There followed a moment of silence, during which Stryver sucked on the end of a small iron square he had taken from the table. Finally, he broke the truly painful silence by saying:

en: “This is something new to me, Mr. Lorry. You deliberately advise me not to go up to Soho and offer myself—myself, Stryver of the King’s Bench bar?”
vi: Stryver broke the silence: "I find this strange, Mr. Lorry." "You deliberately advise me not to go to Soho to propose; I, Stryver of the High Court Bar."
tr: "I never expected this Mr. Lorry. Are you now advising me – Stryver of the King's Bench – not to go to Soho and not to make an offer?"
es: —What you are telling me, Mr. Lorry, is so new, so inconceivable, that I cannot quite understand it, despite the clarity of your words. Are you truly advising me not to go to Soho and offer my hand... the hand of the famous lawyer Stryver, to the daughter of Doctor Manette?

en: “Do you ask me for my advice, Mr. Stryver?”
vi: − Do you want to hear my advice, Mr. Stryver? −
tr: "Do you want my advice, Mr. Stryver?"
es: —Are you asking me for honesty, Mr. Stryver?

en: “Yes, I do.”
vi: Yes, I want to hear it. −
tr: "Yes, I do."
es: —Yes.

en: “Very good. Then I give it, and you have repeated it correctly.”
vi: Very well. Then you have just heard what I said, and you have just repeated it exactly. −
tr: "Very good. Then let me tell you, and you should follow these exactly."
es: —Perfectly. You have repeated word for word and letter for letter what I must reply.

en: “And all I can say of it is,” laughed Stryver with a vexed laugh, “that this—ha, ha!—beats everything past, present, and to come.”
vi: Then all I can say is... ha ha, - Stryver laughed irritably, - this matter is really... ha ha... incomprehensible, both past, present, and future.
tr: "All I will say," said Stryver, laughing in an offended manner, "is that your words –ha ha!– erase the entire past, present, and future.""
es: Do not present yourself in Soho, nor offer your hand... the hand of the brilliant lawyer Stryver, to the daughter of Doctor Manette. —And I reply that this... ha, ha, ha, ha!

en: “Now understand me,” pursued Mr. Lorry. “As a man of business, I am not justified in saying anything about this matter, for, as a man of business, I know nothing of it. But, as an old fellow, who has carried Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and of her father too, and who has a great affection for them both, I have spoken. The confidence is not of my seeking, recollect. Now, you think I may not be right?”
vi: − Now listen to me, - Mr. Lorry continued. - As a man of business, I have no right to say anything about this private matter; as a man of business, I don't know how to speak about this matter. But I speak as an old man who once held Miss Manette in his arms when she was a child, as a trusted friend of both Miss Manette and her father, and as someone who deeply loves both of them. It was you who came here to ask for my opinion, remember that. Now you think I'm wrong, huh? −
tr: "Don't misunderstand me," continued Mr. Lorry. "As a businessman, I cannot be certain of the accuracy of what I say on this matter, after all, I am a businessman and I do not understand much about these subjects. However, I told you these things as an old man who has carried Miss Manette in his arms, been a reliable friend to her and her father, and loves both of them very much. Remember that I was not the one who brought up this matter. Am I wrong now?"
es: beats all the past, present, and future nonsense hands down. —Let's dot the i's and cross the t's—added Lorry;—as a businessman, I can say nothing about the matter we are debating, because as a businessman, I know nothing: but as an old friend of the house, as a man who has rocked Miss Manette in his arms, who is the trusted friend of Miss Manette and her father, as a man who loves them both dearly, I can speak, and as such, I have spoken. Now then: do you think I could be wrong?

en: “Not I!” said Stryver, whistling. “I can’t undertake to find third parties in common sense; I can only find it for myself. I suppose sense in certain quarters; you suppose mincing bread-and-butter nonsense. It’s new to me, but you are right, I dare say.”
vi: Not at all! - Stryver hissed. - I can't understand other people's common sense; I only understand my own logic. I believe I'm right on some issues, while you believe in nonsensical rubbish. Strangely enough, but you're right, I'm sure of it.
tr: "You are right!" said Stryver, vaguely. "When it comes to common sense, I value my own opinions more than those of third parties. I had thought some people were reasonable, but you say this delicate fool is a complete idiot. This was something I did not expect, but I suppose you are right."
es: —Not even in your dreams! Common sense is a rare plant that grows in few places. I have never hoped to find it outside of myself. I supposed that perhaps it existed where, apparently, according to you, only folly finds fertile ground. I am disappointed, I confess, as I expected something else; but I believe you are right.

en: “What I suppose, Mr. Stryver, I claim to characterise for myself—And understand me, sir,” said Mr. Lorry, quickly flushing again, “I will not—not even at Tellson’s—have it characterised for me by any gentleman breathing.”
vi: − I believe in what I think is right, Mr. Stryver... please understand, - Mr. Lorry blushed again, I do not allow... even here at Tellson's... anyone to speak for me. −
tr: "Mr. Stryver, what I think is a part of my personality. Please understand me, sir," said Mr. Lorry, suddenly turning bright red again, "I cannot accept anyone –even within Tellson's– interpreting my thoughts in this manner."
es: —I have neither spoken of fertilized or unfertilized grounds for folly to grow in, nor will I tolerate... inside or outside Tellson's Bank, anyone born offending people whose name can only be pronounced on one's knees!—shouted Lorry, growing furious again.

en: “There! I beg your pardon!” said Stryver.
vi: Oh! I apologize to you! - Stryver exclaimed.
tr: "So be it! I apologize!" said Stryver.
es: —I have neither spoken of fertilized or unfertilized grounds for folly to grow in, nor will I tolerate... inside or outside Tellson's Bank, anyone born offending people whose name can only be pronounced on one's knees!—shouted Lorry, growing furious again. —Don't trouble yourself: I beg you to forgive phrases said without the intention of bothering anyone.

en: “Granted. Thank you. Well, Mr. Stryver, I was about to say:—it might be painful to you to find yourself mistaken, it might be painful to Doctor Manette to have the task of being explicit with you, it might be very painful to Miss Manette to have the task of being explicit with you. You know the terms upon which I have the honour and happiness to stand with the family. If you please, committing you in no way, representing you in no way, I will undertake to correct my advice by the exercise of a little new observation and judgment expressly brought to bear upon it. If you should then be dissatisfied with it, you can but test its soundness for yourself; if, on the other hand, you should be satisfied with it, and it should be what it now is, it may spare all sides what is best spared. What do you say?”
vi: − I forgive you. Thank you. Now, Mr. Stryver, what I mean to say is... it might be distressing for you if you find yourself mistaken, it might be distressing for Dr. Manette to have to speak frankly with you, it might be very distressing for Miss Manette to have to speak frankly with you. I have the honor and good fortune to be close to that family, you know. If you allow, I will try to observe and consider more clearly to give better advice without harming your intention to propose, or having to speak for you. Then if you are not satisfied with my advice, you can investigate yourself; on the other hand, if you are satisfied when what I say turns out to be true as I just said, then both sides can avoid unpleasantness. What do you think?
tr: "Accepted. Thank you. So, Mr. Stryver, what I meant to say was this: Seeing that you were mistaken might upset you, having to tell you some things plainly might upset Doctor Manette, and speaking frankly might also be very distressing for Miss Manette. You know under what circumstances I had the honor and happiness of being with them. If you wish, without involving your name at all, I can try to observe a bit more and come to a judgment in order to review my advice. If you are not satisfied with the result, you can question its validity yourself, but if you are satisfied and reach the point where we are now, everyone will go their own way. What do you say?"
es: —Forgiven, and thank you. What I meant to say was the following: it would be painful for you to suffer a disappointment, it would be painful for Dr. Manette to find himself in the position of having to be explicit with you, and it would be very painful for Miss Lucía to find herself in the harsh necessity of speaking frankly to you. You know that I have the honor and the happiness of being a good friend of the family. Well then: if you want me, without representing you in any way, without involving you in anything at all, to make new observations that confirm or modify the impressions I have today, I offer myself for that right away. If the result of my new observations does not satisfy you, you will be free to personally verify their foundation; otherwise, we will have at least managed to avoid unpleasant scenes and situations. What do you think of my plan?

en: “How long would you keep me in town?”
vi: − How long do I have to stay in this city waiting for you? −
tr: "How long do I need to stay in the city?"
es: —How long would it take you to answer me?

en: “Oh! It is only a question of a few hours. I could go to Soho in the evening, and come to your chambers afterwards.”
vi: Oh! Just a few hours. This afternoon I can go to Soho and then to your office. −
tr: "Ah! Just a few hours of work. In the evening, I'll go to Soho, and then I'll come to you."
es: —Oh! It's a matter of a few hours! This afternoon I can go to Soho, and from there go straight to your house.

en: “Then I say yes,” said Stryver: “I won’t go up there now, I am not so hot upon it as that comes to; I say yes, and I shall expect you to look in to-night. Good morning.”
vi: Then I agree, - Stryver said. - Now I won't go there anymore, I'm not in a hurry to go there right away; I agree, and I will wait for you to come by this evening. Goodbye.
tr: "Alright then," said Stryver. "I won't go now, it's not that urgent; I accept and I am expecting you this evening. Good day."
es: —If that's the case, it seems fine to me. I will wait for you tonight... Good morning!

en: Then Mr. Stryver turned and burst out of the Bank, causing such a concussion of air on his passage through, that to stand up against it bowing behind the two counters, required the utmost remaining strength of the two ancient clerks. Those venerable and feeble persons were always seen by the public in the act of bowing, and were popularly believed, when they had bowed a customer out, still to keep on bowing in the empty office until they bowed another customer in.
vi: So Stryver turned his back and dashed out of the bank, stirring up such a strong gust of wind behind him that the two old clerks bowing behind the two counters had to muster all their strength just to stay upright. People always saw those weak, venerable gentlemen bowing down, and everyone believed that once they bowed to see a client out, they would remain bent over like that in the empty bank until they had to welcome another client in.
tr: Then, as Mr. Stryver turned around and left the bank, he created such a dramatic atmosphere that the two elderly clerks standing behind the counters, who were greeting him, made every effort not to topple over. These very esteemed frail individuals were always seen in a state of greeting, even to the extent that, according to common belief, when they bid farewell to someone, they would remain in that state until they welcomed a new customer, even if the office was empty.
es: The gentleman Stryver left the Bank building with a tempest of anger in his chest. He had enough insight to understand that the banker would not have expressed his opinions on the matter so clearly if he had not had such a solid foundation to support them, which amounted to a moral certainty.

en: The barrister was keen enough to divine that the banker would not have gone so far in his expression of opinion on any less solid ground than moral certainty. Unprepared as he was for the large pill he had to swallow, he got it down. “And now,” said Mr. Stryver, shaking his forensic forefinger at the Temple in general, when it was down, “my way out of this, is, to put you all in the wrong.”
vi: This lawyer was shrewd enough to understand that the old man in the bank would never reveal so much unless he had a solid basis for believing what he said. Those unexpected words were indeed a bitter pill too large for him to swallow, but he tried to swallow it. Once he had swallowed it, Stryver waved his index finger as if arguing before the court with the entire Temple Bar and silently threatened, "Now, the way out of this is to prove you are all wrong."
tr: The lawyer was smart enough to know that the banker, besides his sharp instincts, could not express his thoughts to this extent without solid grounds. He was caught off guard by the big pill he had to swallow and he swallowed it. "Now," said Mr. Stryver at Temple Bar, waving his finger around as if he were in court, "the only way to settle this is to prove that you are wrong."
es: He had enough insight to understand that the banker would not have expressed his opinions on the matter so clearly if he had not had such a solid foundation to support them, which amounted to a moral certainty. He was far from thinking, when he entered the Bank, that such a bitter pill awaited him; but he had no choice but to swallow it. —You have put yourself in an awkward situation, Stryver—he said to himself;—you have made a fool of yourself... Now's the time for your forensic talent to get out of this mess!

en: It was a bit of the art of an Old Bailey tactician, in which he found great relief. “You shall not put me in the wrong, young lady,” said Mr. Stryver; “I’ll do that for you.”
vi: That was a little trick of courtroom tactics at the Old Bailey that often saved him during arguments. Stryver reassured himself, "You won't prove me wrong, miss, I will prove you wrong."
