tr: Kurnaz Old Bailey tactics were now easing his troubles. "You will show me that I am not mistaken, young lady," said Mr. Stryver; "I will make you do it."
es: It was clearly visible that the pill had gotten stuck in his throat and that the eminent lawyer was looking for a way to spit it out. —Ah, my dear miss!—he murmured after a few moments. —I will not be the one to bear the ridicule!... You will have the pleasure of keeping the fruit of the cucurbit family that you have reserved for me!

en: Accordingly, when Mr. Lorry called that night as late as ten o’clock, Mr. Stryver, among a quantity of books and papers littered out for the purpose, seemed to have nothing less on his mind than the subject of the morning. He even showed surprise when he saw Mr. Lorry, and was altogether in an absent and preoccupied state.
vi: Therefore, when Mr. Lorry arrived at the office at ten o'clock in the evening, Stryver was sitting amidst a clutter of books and papers, seemingly no longer concerned with the morning's events. He even appeared surprised to see Mr. Lorry and greeted him with the distracted air of someone busy.
tr: Therefore, when Mr. Lorry knocked on his door at the late hour of around ten at night, Mr. Stryver, amidst the books and papers he had deliberately scattered around, seemed as if the morning's matter had completely slipped his mind. Upon seeing Mr. Lorry, he showed a sign of surprise, appearing distracted and busy.
es: Indeed: that night, when Lorry arrived at the lawyer's house, he found him among stacks of papers and piles of books purposely placed on his desk, absorbed in his work and completely oblivious to the matter discussed that morning. He even seemed surprised to see Lorry.

en: “Well!” said that good-natured emissary, after a full half-hour of bootless attempts to bring him round to the question. “I have been to Soho.”
vi: "Well!" - The kindly marriage messenger, after half an hour of unsuccessfully steering the conversation to this matter, had to remind him. - "I went to Soho."
tr: "Well!" said the kind-hearted envoy, after waiting in vain for an hour for him to bring up the subject. "I went to Soho today." "Did you go to Soho?"
es: —I have been in Soho—said the emissary, after more than half an hour spent in vain attempts to broach the subject.

en: “To Soho?” repeated Mr. Stryver, coldly. “Oh, to be sure! What am I thinking of!”
vi: − To Soho? - Stryver asked nonchalantly. - Oh, of course! Where was my mind? −
tr: Mr. Stryver repeated coldly. "Oh, of course! What am I saying!"
es: —In Soho?—repeated Stryver with glacial indifference. —Ah... yes! What a head I have!

en: “And I have no doubt,” said Mr. Lorry, “that I was right in the conversation we had. My opinion is confirmed, and I reiterate my advice.”
vi: And I am certain, - Mr. Lorry said, - that I was right when we talked this morning. My opinion has been confirmed, and I repeat that advice. −
tr: "Regarding the truth of what we have discussed," said Mr. Lorry, "I have no doubt left. My opinion has been confirmed, and I reiterate my advice to you."
es: Would you believe that I didn't remember such a thing? —I no longer have the slightest doubt that the advice I gave you was extremely accurate. My impressions have been fully confirmed.

en: “I assure you,” returned Mr. Stryver, in the friendliest way, “that I am sorry for it on your account, and sorry for it on the poor father’s account. I know this must always be a sore subject with the family; let us say no more about it.”
vi: Rest assured, - Stryver replied, in a friendly tone, - I feel sorry for you and for that poor father. I understand this must be very awkward for that family; let's not talk about this anymore.
tr: "Believe me," replied Mr. Stryver, in his most friendly manner, "I felt sorry for you, and for your poor father as well. I know that this matter will always be a sad situation for this family; it's best to close this subject."
es: —Believe me, I truly regret it very much for you—replied Stryver with perfect calm,—and no less truly for the poor father. It is an incident that the family will always remember with sorrow, and that... But let's not talk about it.

en: “I don’t understand you,” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: − I don't understand your point, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "I don't understand you," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —I confess that I do not understand.

en: “I dare say not,” rejoined Stryver, nodding his head in a smoothing and final way; “no matter, no matter.”
vi: − Probably not, - Stryver nodded with a comfortable and decisive air, not important, not important.
tr: "Never mind," replied Stryver, in a soothing and decisive manner; "it doesn't matter, it doesn't matter."
es: —I believe it; but it doesn't matter... it doesn't matter.

en: “But it does matter,” Mr. Lorry urged.
vi: − But this matter is indeed important, - Mr. Lorry emphasized.
tr: "Don't say that, it's an important matter," insisted Mr. Lorry.
es: —On the contrary—replied Lorry,—it matters, and I would like it to be explained.

en: “No it doesn’t; I assure you it doesn’t. Having supposed that there was sense where there is no sense, and a laudable ambition where there is not a laudable ambition, I am well out of my mistake, and no harm is done. Young women have committed similar follies often before, and have repented them in poverty and obscurity often before. In an unselfish aspect, I am sorry that the thing is dropped, because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view; in a selfish aspect, I am glad that the thing has dropped, because it would have been a bad thing for me in a worldly point of view—it is hardly necessary to say I could have gained nothing by it. There is no harm at all done. I have not proposed to the young lady, and, between ourselves, I am by no means certain, on reflection, that I ever should have committed myself to that extent. Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the mincing vanities and giddinesses of empty-headed girls; you must not expect to do it, or you will always be disappointed. Now, pray say no more about it. I tell you, I regret it on account of others, but I am satisfied on my own account. And I am really very much obliged to you for allowing me to sound you, and for giving me your advice; you know the young lady better than I do; you were right, it never would have done.”
vi: − Not at all; I assure you, not at all. After mistakenly believing there was reason where there was none, and mistakenly believing there was noble aspiration where there was none, I realized my error and suffered no harm. Young ladies often make similar foolish mistakes and often regret them when they find themselves in poverty and obscurity. For the person in question, I regret that this did not come to pass, because if it had, it would have been a misfortune for me, from a material gain perspective; but for myself, I am glad it did not come to pass, because if it had, it would have been a misfortune for me, from a material gain perspective... needless to say, I would have gained nothing. No harm has occurred. I have not proposed to that lady, and just between you and me, looking back, I am not even sure if I need to get married that much. Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the whimsical, capricious, and inconsistent nature of empty-headed girls; do not dream of it if you do not wish to be disappointed. Now, please don't talk about that anymore. I've already said it, I feel sorry for them but happy for myself. And I am very grateful that you allowed me to ask for advice and counseled me; you understand that lady better than I do; you were right, this marriage will never happen.
tr: "No, it's not important; believe me, it's not. I was mistaken in thinking that where there is no logic, there is logic, and where there is no enthusiasm, there is praiseworthy enthusiasm, but it's okay, it's not a problem. Other young ladies I knew before had done such foolish things, and then they regretted it in misery and poverty. If I think without being selfish, I am saddened that it didn't happen, because it would have been bad for me financially; if I look at it selfishly, again it would have been bad for me financially – I would have gained nothing from this. So, I have no loss. I made no offer to the young lady, and between us, thinking about it, I'm not even sure it was a good decision to bring it to that point. Mr. Lorry, you cannot control the delicate pride and frivolity of empty-headed girls; one should not have such an expectation, otherwise, you will always be disappointed. Now please, let's not talk about this any further. As I said, I felt sorry for them but I am pleased for myself. I am grateful to you for listening to me and advising me; after all, you know the young lady better than I do; you were right, this wouldn't have worked."
es: —I repeat, it doesn't matter. I thought I saw common sense and laudable ambition where neither exists. I was mistaken, I am cured of my error, and the matter is concluded. Fortunately, my error is one that does not cause harm to the one who was its victim. There are many young ladies who have committed similar follies, which they have come to regret when it was already too late, when they found themselves plunged into ruin and misery... Poor things!... I do not blame them! Indeed, they are worthy of compassion! Youth is so thoughtless!... Seeing what happened from a point of view free of all selfishness, I regret it, because it would have been a good deal for her, and if I look at it through the prism of my selfishness, I cannot help but celebrate a failure that saves me from making a disastrous deal. You will understand, without me having to say it, that I, far from gaining, was losing, and not a little. Of course, so far it has done me no harm. I have not offered my hand to that young lady, and here between us, speaking frankly, I never thought of making such an offer. Follow my advice, Mr. Lorry: never try to fight against the frivolities and follies of those flighty little heads if you don't want to reap disappointments in abundance... No... do me the favor! Let's leave this conversation. I repeat that I regret what happened for others but I am glad for what concerns me. I will never thank you enough for the advice you gave me. You know that young lady much better than I do... You were right... I was about to make a blunder although I surely would not have gone through with it.

en: Mr. Lorry was so taken aback, that he looked quite stupidly at Mr. Stryver shouldering him towards the door, with an appearance of showering generosity, forbearance, and goodwill, on his erring head. “Make the best of it, my dear sir,” said Stryver; “say no more about it; thank you again for allowing me to sound you; good night!”
vi: Mr. Lorry was so astonished that he stared blankly as Stryver aggressively pushed him towards the door, the barrister's face appearing to bestow upon the misguided man all his goodwill, patience, and tolerance. − Manage on your own, dear sir, - Stryver said. - Don't mention this again; thank you once more for letting me ask your opinion; goodbye!
tr: Mr. Lorry was so surprised that he stared blankly at Mr. Stryver, who had escorted him to the door with a shower of insincere thoughts disguised as great generosity, tolerance, and goodwill. "Let it be for the best for us, sir," said Stryver; "let's not talk about this anymore; thank you again for listening to me; good night!"
es: Such was Lorry's bewilderment and astonishment that he could think of nothing else but to stare stupidly at his interlocutor, whose face reflected generosity, nobility, and good intentions. —Believe me, my dear friend!—repeated Stryver as he accompanied Lorry to the door,—follow my advice. Thank you very much...

en: Mr. Lorry was out in the night, before he knew where he was. Mr. Stryver was lying back on his sofa, winking at his ceiling.
vi: Before he could understand anything, Mr. Lorry was thrown out into the night. Stryver lay down on the sofa, winking at the ceiling.
tr: Mr. Lorry found himself in the darkness of the night before he could understand what was happening. Mr. Stryver, on the other hand, was lying on his couch, winking at the ceiling.
es: Good night! Lorry found himself in the street before he realized what was happening to him. Stryver lay on his back on the sofa, staring at the ceiling.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: Stryver lay down on the sofa, winking at the ceiling.
tr: Thirteen
es: Chapter XIII.

en: The Fellow of No Delicacy
vi: 13. The rude fellow If Sydney Carton shone anywhere, he certainly never shone at Dr. Manette's house.
tr: Rude Man
es: THE INDELICATE SUBJECT

en: If Sydney Carton ever shone anywhere, he certainly never shone in the house of Doctor Manette. He had been there often, during a whole year, and had always been the same moody and morose lounger there. When he cared to talk, he talked well; but, the cloud of caring for nothing, which overshadowed him with such a fatal darkness, was very rarely pierced by the light within him.
vi: 13. The rude fellow If Sydney Carton shone anywhere, he certainly never shone at Dr. Manette's house. He had been visiting for a whole year and always brought a gloomy, sullen, and bored face there. Whenever he wanted to talk, he spoke very well; but the indifferent look, like a cloud enveloping him in sorrowful darkness, was rarely pierced by the light in his heart.
tr: Although Sydney Carton shone in other environments, he definitely did not shine in Doctor Manette's house. For a year, he had frequently visited their home but always sat idly by with his grumpy demeanor and sullen face. When he deigned to speak, he spoke well, but the light within him could rarely pierce through the deadly darkness of his indifferent attitude.
es: If ever, or anywhere, Sydney Carton shone, it certainly was not in the abode of Mr. Manette. He visited it quite frequently for an entire year, and he was always sad, taciturn, pensive. And it was not that he lacked oratory skills, no; he knew how to speak perfectly well when he set his mind to it; but the cloud that enveloped him was so dense that the luminous flashes of his intelligence very rarely managed to pierce through it.

en: And yet he did care something for the streets that environed that house, and for the senseless stones that made their pavements. Many a night he vaguely and unhappily wandered there, when wine had brought no transitory gladness to him; many a dreary daybreak revealed his solitary figure lingering there, and still lingering there when the first beams of the sun brought into strong relief, removed beauties of architecture in spires of churches and lofty buildings, as perhaps the quiet time brought some sense of better things, else forgotten and unattainable, into his mind. Of late, the neglected bed in the Temple Court had known him more scantily than ever; and often when he had thrown himself upon it no longer than a few minutes, he had got up again, and haunted that neighbourhood.
vi: However, he needed something from the neighborhood surrounding that house, the lifeless paving stones of the sidewalk there. Many nights he wandered there, suffering and aimless, when alcohol brought him no fleeting joy; many bleak dawns also saw his lonely figure lingering there, hesitating to leave as the first rays of sunlight highlighted the architectural beauty of the church spires and high-rise buildings, just as this quiet moment made his mind perceive the better things that had been forgotten or were out of reach. Recently, the crumpled bed in Temple Court rarely lulled him to sleep; often he would throw himself onto the bed only to get up a few minutes later and wander to that neighborhood.
tr: He even loved the meaningless stones that formed the streets and sidewalks surrounding his house. On most nights when the wine couldn't give him temporary happiness, he would wander those streets, head clouded, miserably; as dawn broke with all its gloom, his lonely silhouette would appear, and when the first rays of the sun illuminated the beauties of the distant church towers and majestic buildings, he would still be wandering there, as if these silent hours evoked in his mind the feeling that good things, otherwise unthought of and unattainable, would happen. Recently, he had been visiting his bed in Temple less frequently; most of the time when he did throw himself into bed, it didn't last long, and he would get up and go back to that neighborhood.
es: That the streets near the mentioned house, and even the insensible stones of the sidewalks, exerted a mysterious attraction on him, could not be questioned. More than one night he could have been found wandering like a lost soul in those places, especially when the wine failed to infiltrate his chest with a fictitious and transitory joy. More than one early morning, the pale glows of the dawning aurora revealed, not far from the doctor's house, the contours of a figure, which if it was not Sydney Carton himself, bore a notable resemblance to him. More than one morning, the first rays of the sun, while highlighting the architectural beauties of the church bell towers and the most notable buildings, brought discouragement to the chest of the solitary night wanderer, making him see that there are things that man, with all his good will, cannot achieve. For some time before, the disordered bed that Carton had in the Temple Court rarely deserved the honor of being used by its owner, and it is noteworthy that, even when this happened by exception, Carton would get up after a few minutes to continue his wanderings.

en: On a day in August, when Mr. Stryver (after notifying to his jackal that “he had thought better of that marrying matter”) had carried his delicacy into Devonshire, and when the sight and scent of flowers in the City streets had some waifs of goodness in them for the worst, of health for the sickliest, and of youth for the oldest, Sydney’s feet still trod those stones. From being irresolute and purposeless, his feet became animated by an intention, and, in the working out of that intention, they took him to the Doctor’s door.
vi: One August day, when Stryver was graciously allowed to go on vacation in Devonshire (after informing his friend the Jackal that "he had reconsidered and decided not to pursue marriage anymore"), when the scenery and the scent of flowers on the streets bestowed a bit of goodness to the most unfortunate, a bit of health to the sickest, and a bit of youth to the oldest, Sydney's steps wandered on the sidewalk. From hesitant and aimless, his steps gradually quickened with a newly formed intention, and to carry it out, his steps led him to the doctor's house.
tr: On a day in August, when Mr. Stryver (after informing his jackal that he now thought differently about marriage) carried his gentle presence to Devonshire, and the appearance and scent of the flowers in the city's streets began to bring goodness to the wicked, healing to the sick, and youth to the old, Sydney was still busy pacing the roads. His indecision and clueless state had ended, and with the purposes that gave him vitality and the thought of implementing them, he found himself at the Doctor's door.
es: One day in the month of August, when Mr. Stryver, after informing his friend that "more careful reflections had led him to abandon his matrimonial plans," had transferred to Devonshire the treasures of finesse and delicacy inherent to his person, one of those August days when the wicked find in the chalice of flowers rich springs of goodness, the sick find health, and the old and worn-out find youth, Carton, a slave to his habit, wandered like a lost soul through the streets. He walked irresolutely and aimlessly; but suddenly his eyes lit up; his feet were animated by the breath of the intention that sprang in his mind, and those feet, faithful and submissive slaves to the latter, carried him straight to the door of Dr. Manette.

en: He was shown up-stairs, and found Lucie at her work, alone. She had never been quite at her ease with him, and received him with some little embarrassment as he seated himself near her table. But, looking up at his face in the interchange of the first few common-places, she observed a change in it.
vi: You were invited upstairs and saw Lucie alone with her needlework. She had never felt comfortable interacting with Sydney, greeting him with a bit of awkwardness as he sat down near the sewing table. But just after looking up and saying the first few polite words, she immediately noticed his face change.
tr: When they sent him upstairs, he found Lucie working alone. The young girl had never been very comfortable around him, so when Sydney sat down next to the table, she greeted him a bit shyly. However, after the usual pleasantries, the young girl noticed some changes in him.
es: Lucía, whom he found alone and absorbed in her tasks, received him with some unease, and it is even more than likely that if she could have had her way, she would have refused to receive him, for Carton's manner always inspired a certain feeling of mistrust in her. However, as the first phrases were exchanged between them, she noticed something in the expression on her visitor's face that first reassured her, and then stirred compassion in her heart.

en: “I fear you are not well, Mr. Carton!”
vi: − I fear you are not well, Mr. Carton!
tr: "I didn't see you very well, Mr. Carton!"
es: "Do you feel unwell, Mr. Carton?" she asked.

en: “No. But the life I lead, Miss Manette, is not conducive to health. What is to be expected of, or by, such profligates?”
vi: − Indeed. But Miss Manette, living as I do, how could I be well? What is there to hope for in this wasted life?
tr: "I am not well. For the life I lead does not suit my health, Miss Manette. What can be expected from a libertine like me?"
es: "Do you feel unwell, Mr. Carton?" she asked. —I am not well, it is true: but the life I lead, Miss Manette, is not the best way to enjoy good health. What can we libertines expect!

en: “Is it not—forgive me; I have begun the question on my lips—a pity to live no better life?”
vi: − Isn't it... forgive me for saying so,... isn't it a pity to live like this? −
tr: "I'm sorry, but –I can't help but ask– isn't it a sad situation that you can't live a better life?"
es: —And isn't it a pity?... I beg you to forgive me; but since, without realizing it, the beginning of the question slipped from my lips, I will finish it, although making it clear that nothing could be further from my mind than the intention to offend you. Isn't it a pity that you don't try to live a more orderly life?

en: “God knows it is a shame!”
vi: By God, life is truly miserable! −
tr: "Truly a painful situation.""
es: —It's something more than pity! God knows very well that it's a shame!

en: “Then why not change it?”
vi: Then why not change it?
tr: "Then why don't you change this?"
es: —So, why doesn't he correct himself?

en: Looking gently at him again, she was surprised and saddened to see that there were tears in his eyes. There were tears in his voice too, as he answered:
vi: Looking at him gently, she was both surprised and saddened to see tears in the young man's eyes. His voice was also choked as he replied: −
tr: The young girl looked meekly at Sydney and was surprised and saddened when she saw the tears streaming from her eyes. As she replied, Sydney's voice was also filled with tears:
es: Lucía, who looked directly at her interlocutor when she asked the question, saw, with a mix of surprise and sorrow, that Carton's eyes were filled with tears. Tears also flowed in his voice when he replied:

en: “It is too late for that. I shall never be better than I am. I shall sink lower, and be worse.”
vi: It's too late. I will never get better. I will only become more and more degraded, worse and worse.
tr: "It's too late now. I can never have a better life. I will only sink lower and get worse."
es: Tears also flowed in his voice when he replied: —It's no longer time... I will never be better than I am today... on the contrary... I will get worse... I will descend more and more...

en: He leaned an elbow on her table, and covered his eyes with his hand. The table trembled in the silence that followed.
vi: He propped one elbow on the table, raising his hand to cover his eyes. The tabletop trembled in the ensuing silence.
tr: He had his elbows resting on the girl's table, covering his eyes with his hand. In the ensuing silence, the table was trembling.
es: Resting his elbows on the table, he covered his eyes with his hands. The table trembled during the painful silence that followed.

en: She had never seen him softened, and was much distressed. He knew her to be so, without looking at her, and said:
vi: She had never seen him so weak and miserable. Without even looking, she knew she felt sorry for him.
tr: The young girl had never seen him so weak and sorrowful before. Without looking at the girl, Sydney knew how she might be feeling and said:
es: The table trembled during the painful silence that followed. —Forgive me, Miss Manette—replied Carton.

en: “Pray forgive me, Miss Manette. I break down before the knowledge of what I want to say to you. Will you hear me?”
vi: Sydney said: − Please forgive me, Miss Manette. I am distressed because of what I want to confess to you. Would you be willing to listen to me?
tr: "Please forgive me, Miss Manette. I broke down before I could say more to you. Do you want to listen to me?"
es: —Forgive me, Miss Manette—replied Carton. —I carry a secret that weighs heavily on me and that I wish to reveal to you: would you be so kind as to deign to listen to me?

en: “If it will do you any good, Mr. Carton, if it would make you happier, it would make me very glad!”
vi: −If it helps you feel better, Mr. Carton, if it makes you happier, I would very much like to hear it!
tr: "If it will be of any benefit to you, Mr. Carton, if it will make you happy, then I will be pleased as well.""
es: "If listening to you will be beneficial for you, Mr. Carton, if it will provide you with a contentment that you apparently do not have now, speak, for in listening to you I will have special pleasure."

en: “God bless you for your sweet compassion!”
vi: −You are so kind, may God bless you!
tr: "How compassionate you are. May God protect you!"
es: —God will undoubtedly reward you for the compassion with which you treat me.

en: He unshaded his face after a little while, and spoke steadily.
vi: After a moment, he removed his hand from his face and spoke, his voice now calm: −Don't be afraid of what I say.
tr: He calmly started to speak after removing his hand from his face.
es: Carton calmed down somewhat, removed his hands from his eyes, and replied with a firm tone:

en: “Don’t be afraid to hear me. Don’t shrink from anything I say. I am like one who died young. All my life might have been.”
vi: Please don't be concerned about what I say. I am like someone who has died young. My whole life may have been wasted.
tr: "What I have to say should not worry you. Do not be afraid. I am like someone who died young. It has been this way all my life."
es: —Do not be alarmed by my words nor be frightened if I tell you that I have already lived what I was meant to live, that I am like someone who has died very young. Nothing remains in me capable of bearing fruit... I am barren for good.

en: “No, Mr. Carton. I am sure that the best part of it might still be; I am sure that you might be much, much worthier of yourself.”
vi: −No, Mr. Carton. I am sure the best is yet to come; I am sure you will be prouder, more confident in yourself.
tr: "No, Mr. Carton. I am sure there are much better days ahead for you; I am sure you will reach much better places."
es: —No, Mr. Carton, no! You are young, there are still sediments of goodness in your soul. I am sure that, with a little bit of goodwill, you can become very worthy of yourself...

en: “Say of you, Miss Manette, and although I know better—although in the mystery of my own wretched heart I know better—I shall never forget it!”
vi: − You are very kind, Miss Manette, but I know myself better; although from the depths of this sorrowful heart I know it is not true; but I will never forget your kind words!
tr: "Thank you Miss Manette, even though I know that what I said is true –even though my poor heart is a mystery, I know this– I will never forget what you said!"
es: —Tell me how I can make myself worthy of your pity, at least, miss, and although I know you are mistaken, although I read in the depths of my shipwrecked heart the deception in which you find yourself, I will never forget it.

en: She was pale and trembling. He came to her relief with a fixed despair of himself which made the interview unlike any other that could have been holden.
vi: Lucie turned pale and trembled. Sydney tried to reassure her, but his attitude of desperate self-deprecation only made the conversation more peculiar.
tr: The young girl's color had faded, and she was trembling. The man was so helpless that he didn't know what to say in front of her.
es: A dense paleness covered the girl's cheeks: her hands trembled. —If a miracle of God, assuming that divine omnipotence could reach so far, had made it possible for you, Miss Lucía, to reciprocate the love of the man who at this moment stands before your eyes, the love of this degraded, lost, libertine, drunken being, this repugnant remnant of humanity... which is nothing else but what I am... you know it very well, the happiness that would flood my soul, as great as it would be, would not prevent me from seeing that the union of our destinies would drag you down to the depths of my miseries, would plunge you into the abysses of pain and late repentance, would envelop you in waves of dishonor.

en: “If it had been possible, Miss Manette, that you could have returned the love of the man you see before yourself—flung away, wasted, drunken, poor creature of misuse as you know him to be—he would have been conscious this day and hour, in spite of his happiness, that he would bring you to misery, bring you to sorrow and repentance, blight you, disgrace you, pull you down with him. I know very well that you can have no tenderness for me; I ask for none; I am even thankful that it cannot be.”
vi: − Miss Manette, suppose that you reciprocate the love of the man standing before you; a worthless, degenerate, drunken, poor, and misguided man whom you already know; then right today, right at this moment, he knows well that instead of bringing you happiness, he will bring you hardship and poverty, bring you sorrow and regret, will ruin you, will disgrace you, will drag you down to the bottom with him. I know well that you have no feelings for me and I do not ask for that; in fact, I am even more grateful that it cannot happen. −
tr: "Miss Manette, even if it were possible for you to reciprocate the love of this man before you – the self-ruined, wasted, drunken, and worthless wretch – despite all your happiness, you would be aware every moment, every minute, that he brings you suffering, pain, and regret, that he disappoints you, ruins your life, and drags you down with him. I know very well that you cannot harbor any love for me in your heart; I do not ask for such a thing; in fact, I am grateful that such a thing cannot be."
es: —If a miracle of God, assuming that divine omnipotence could reach so far, had made it possible for you, Miss Lucía, to reciprocate the love of the man who at this moment stands before your eyes, the love of this degraded, lost, libertine, drunken being, this repugnant remnant of humanity... which is nothing else but what I am... you know it very well, the happiness that would flood my soul, as great as it would be, would not prevent me from seeing that the union of our destinies would drag you down to the depths of my miseries, would plunge you into the abysses of pain and late repentance, would envelop you in waves of dishonor. I am firmly convinced of this; as convinced as I am that your heart cannot hold any tenderness for me. I do not expect it, I do not ask for it! Moreover: I thank Heaven that has made it impossible!

en: “Without it, can I not save you, Mr. Carton? Can I not recall you—forgive me again!—to a better course? Can I in no way repay your confidence? I know this is a confidence,” she modestly said, after a little hesitation, and in earnest tears, “I know you would say this to no one else. Can I turn it to no good account for yourself, Mr. Carton?”
vi: But even without that, can’t you help me, Mr. Carton? Can’t you help me return... forgive me once more!... return to a better path? Is there no way you can repay my trust? You know I trust you, - she said humbly after a moment of hesitation, with sincere tears in her eyes. - You know I would not say this to anyone else. Is it possible that you can't turn that trust into something good for me, Mr. Carton?
tr: After hesitating for a moment, Miss Manette said, "Even if there isn't such a thing, can't I help you, Mr. Carton? Can't I –forgive me but– lead you to a better life? Isn't there a way to restore your confidence in yourself? I know this is all about believing," she added humbly and with sincere tears, "I know you won't tell anyone about this. Can't I turn this situation to your advantage, Mr. Carton?"
es: —Couldn't I save you, Mr. Carton, without those affections you refer to? Couldn't I?... Forgive me again! Couldn't I show you a better path, guide you on straighter paths? Must it be impossible for me to repay in some way the trust you place in me? Because I know it is a trust—added Lucie modestly, though with some hesitation—a trust that you would not place in anyone else, and that you place in me. Couldn't we turn that trust to your benefit, Mr. Carton?

en: He shook his head.
vi: He shook his head.
tr: Sydney shook her head from side to side.
es: —No, Miss Lucía—replied Carton, shaking his head with an expression of bitter sadness.

en: “To none. No, Miss Manette, to none. If you will hear me through a very little more, all you can ever do for me is done. I wish you to know that you have been the last dream of my soul. In my degradation I have not been so degraded but that the sight of you with your father, and of this home made such a home by you, has stirred old shadows that I thought had died out of me. Since I knew you, I have been troubled by a remorse that I thought would never reproach me again, and have heard whispers from old voices impelling me upward, that I thought were silent for ever. I have had unformed ideas of striving afresh, beginning anew, shaking off sloth and sensuality, and fighting out the abandoned fight. A dream, all a dream, that ends in nothing, and leaves the sleeper where he lay down, but I wish you to know that you inspired it.”
vi: − No way, Miss Manette, no way. If you are willing to listen to me a little more, you have already helped me as much as you could. I want you to understand that you have been the last hope of my life. No matter how lowly I am, I am not so blind as to not see you and your father together, to see this house become a home thanks to your hands, which has rekindled in me many things I thought were forgotten forever. Since knowing you, I have been tormented by a regret that I thought had long been exhausted, I have heard whispers that I thought had forever fallen silent, reminding me to turn back from my wayward path. I have vaguely thought about trying to change, to start my life over, to abandon my degenerate and stagnant life, and to continue the struggle for existence. A dream, just a dream, leads nowhere, and it leaves the dreamer lying there, but I want you to understand that it was you who stirred those thoughts in me. −
tr: "No, Miss Manette. There is no way. If you listen to me a little more, you will have done the best you can. I want you to know that you were the last dream I saw. Seeing your father and this home with you in it, revives the dreams I thought were dead and pulls me further down. Since I met you, I have been feeling a guilt I thought had left me, and I hear those old whispers that I thought had silenced forever, trying to pull me up. There are vague thoughts in my mind calling me to start everything anew, to turn over a new leaf, to shake off the laziness and sensitivity, and to return to the struggle I had abandoned. This is a dream with no end, leaving the dreamer where they lie, all of these are dreams, but I want you to know that you are the one who inspires these dreams."
es: —Impossible. If you would be so kind as to listen to me for a few more moments, you will have done for me all that you can do. I want you to know that it has been the last dream of my soul: I want you to know that your image and that of your father, the sight of this home, which is such thanks to you, have reached the deep abyss of my degradation and stirred there shadows that I believed dead forever: I want you to know that, since I have known you, I feel the sting of remorse that I thought lifeless and ineffective, and whispers of ancient voices that I believed forever silenced sound in my ears. I have even come to seriously think about starting, about engaging in new struggles, about inaugurating a new life, about running with new courage to the arena so long abandoned!... Chimeras... illusions, dreams that can lead to nothing practical! But chimeras, dreams, and illusions evoked by you, inspired by you!

en: “Will nothing of it remain? O Mr. Carton, think again! Try again!”
vi: Are those things all over? Oh Mr. Carton, please reconsider! Try harder! −
tr: "Does it really lead nowhere? Oh Mr. Carton, please think a little more! Give it a try!"
es: —But those illusions, those dreams, they must have left something in your soul... Oh Mr. Carton! Seek... ponder... try!

en: “No, Miss Manette; all through it, I have known myself to be quite undeserving. And yet I have had the weakness, and have still the weakness, to wish you to know with what a sudden mastery you kindled me, heap of ashes that I am, into fire—a fire, however, inseparable in its nature from myself, quickening nothing, lighting nothing, doing no service, idly burning away.”
vi: No, Miss Manette, I have long known that I am completely unworthy. I know I am so weak and cannot improve, but I want you to know that you suddenly have the power to ignite the ashes that are me into a flame... but that flame cannot escape my nature, it cannot drive anything, it cannot illuminate anything, it cannot help anything, and it will gradually die out.
tr: "No, Miss Manette; I know that I am a man who deserves nothing. Perhaps it was a weakness to tell you how you brought me back to life, how you suddenly turned me, who was no different from a heap of ashes, into a burning fire, truly a weakness, but such a fire that, although it has penetrated me, it moves nothing, illuminates nothing, serves no purpose, it just burns inwardly."
es: —It's useless: I would be wasting my time, and besides, I don't deserve to live. And yet, to give you an idea of the inconceivable extremes to which human aberrations can go, I will confess that I have had the weakness, and still have the frankness, to wish that you know the prodigious speed with which I have been transformed, from a heap of extinguished and frozen ashes, into a living fire... although a fire entirely similar to my corrupted nature, a fire that animates nothing, that illuminates nothing, that serves no purpose, a fire that is lost.

en: “Since it is my misfortune, Mr. Carton, to have made you more unhappy than you were before you knew me—”
vi: − Mr. Carton, it is truly unfortunate that I have made you feel more unhappy than before you met me...
tr: "Mr. Carton, it is such a misfortune for me that you have become even more unhappy after getting to know me...""
es: —Since I have had the misfortune of making you more unfortunate than you were before you met me...

en: “Don’t say that, Miss Manette, for you would have reclaimed me, if anything could. You will not be the cause of my becoming worse.”
vi: − Don't say that, Miss Manette, if I can still be saved, it is only you who can do it. You are not the cause of my worsening. −
tr: "Don't say that, Miss Manette, if there is anything in this world that can do me good, it is you. You cannot be the cause of my worsening."
es: —Don't say that, Miss Lucía; if I were capable of redemption, you would have redeemed me; if my misfortunes could have an end, you would have put an end to them. It is not you, it could not have been you who caused my misfortune to be greater.

en: “Since the state of your mind that you describe, is, at all events, attributable to some influence of mine—this is what I mean, if I can make it plain—can I use no influence to serve you? Have I no power for good, with you, at all?”
vi: Because your influence, as you mentioned, has somewhat affected my mood... I don't know if you understand what I mean... is there nothing you can do to help me? Is there nothing you can do to bring some goodness into my life?
tr: "If I had such an influence on the state of mind you described – I mean, what I want to say is – can't I use this influence for your benefit? Do I have no power at all to positively affect your life?"
es: —I meant to say that, if the current state of his soul is due to my influences, wouldn't there be a way to channel those influences in a way that would be beneficial to him? Can't I do any good for him?

en: “The utmost good that I am capable of now, Miss Manette, I have come here to realise. Let me carry through the rest of my misdirected life, the remembrance that I opened my heart to you, last of all the world; and that there was something left in me at this time which you could deplore and pity.”
vi: − Miss Manette, the best thing I can do now is what I have done right here. Let me live out this misguided life while always remembering today, the day I opened my heart to you, the only person in the world, and the day I realized I still have some worth deserving of your compassion.
tr: "The best thing that could happen to me, Miss Manette, is to be here right now. Let me live with the memory of the day I opened my heart to you for the rest of my misguided life, and let the thing you pity and grieve over now live with me forever."
es: —The greatest, the only one I could desire, has already been provided to me. Will you allow me to keep the memory that you were the last person to whom I opened my heart during the rest of my disordered life, and the belief that there is something in it that has deserved your compassionate pity, and with that, you do me the greatest good I could dream of.

en: “Which I entreated you to believe, again and again, most fervently, with all my heart, was capable of better things, Mr. Carton!”
vi: − I wholeheartedly and earnestly ask you to believe, and always believe, that you can make your life better, Mr. Carton! −
tr: "The thing I have pleaded for with all my heart and soul, Mr. Carton, could have led to very beautiful things in your life!"
es: —With all my soul, I would like to convince you, Mr. Carton, that with a little bit of effort and another bit of goodwill, you would achieve better things.

en: “Entreat me to believe it no more, Miss Manette. I have proved myself, and I know better. I distress you; I draw fast to an end. Will you let me believe, when I recall this day, that the last confidence of my life was reposed in your pure and innocent breast, and that it lies there alone, and will be shared by no one?”
vi: Please do not expect me to believe that, Miss Manette. I understand myself better than anyone else. I have caused you worry, so I will conclude this conversation quickly. I only hope you will allow me to believe that in the future, when you recall today, the final confidences I entrusted to your pure and innocent soul will remain secret, known to no one else, will you? −
tr: "Please tell me to stop believing in this, Miss Manette! It's clear what I am, I know myself well. I will upset you; I am rapidly progressing down a bad path. If we return to what I was saying, could I ask you to keep this last secret of my life hidden in your pure and innocent heart and not to reveal it to anyone?"
es: —Her excellent heart deceives her, Miss Lucía. Believe me: I have put myself to the test, and the result has been deplorable: I am incapable of redemption. I know that I am causing you sorrow, and I will finish. I have entrusted the sweetest secret of my life to a pure and innocent heart. When the memory of this day arises in my mind, will I be allowed to harbor the comforting belief that this heart has received it and keeps it, resolved not to confide it to anyone else?

en: “If that will be a consolation to you, yes.”
vi: Yes, if that helps you find peace.
tr: "If this will be a consolation for you, yes."
es: —If that belief is a comfort to you, hold on to it.

en: “Not even by the dearest one ever to be known to you?”
vi: − Even your dearest loved ones are not to know?
tr: "Even to the person who is most valuable to you, right?"
es: —Do you promise not to reveal it to anyone, not even to the person dearest to you today or who may be in the future?

en: “Mr. Carton,” she answered, after an agitated pause, “the secret is yours, not mine; and I promise to respect it.”
vi: − Mr. Carton, - the girl replied after a moment of confused silence, - the secret is yours, not mine, and I promise to keep it. −
tr: After an uneasy silence, the young girl replied, "Mr. Carton, this secret is yours, not mine; I promise to keep it.""
es: —Mr. Carton—replied Lucie with agitation,—the secret is not mine, but yours: rest assured that I will know how to respect it.

en: “Thank you. And again, God bless you.”
vi: Thank you. Once again, God bless you.
tr: "Thank you. God bless you."
es: —Thank you very much... and God bless you!

en: He put her hand to his lips, and moved towards the door.
vi: He kissed her hand in farewell, then walked to the door.
tr: Carton brought the young girl's hand to his lips and walked towards the door.
es: Carton took the hand that Lucía extended to him, brought it to his lips, and began to walk towards the door.

en: “Be under no apprehension, Miss Manette, of my ever resuming this conversation by so much as a passing word. I will never refer to it again. If I were dead, that could not be surer than it is henceforth. In the hour of my death, I shall hold sacred the one good remembrance—and shall thank and bless you for it—that my last avowal of myself was made to you, and that my name, and faults, and miseries were gently carried in your heart. May it otherwise be light and happy!”
vi: − Please don't worry, Miss Manette, I will never bring this up again, not even a word. I will not mention it again, from now on. This promise is more certain than my own death. I will carry this sacred memory with me when I die... and I will be grateful to you, I will bless you... the one with the gentle heart who accepted my final confession, accepted my honor, my faults, and my suffering. May you always be happy and serene!
tr: "Do not worry Miss Manette, I will not bring up this matter again. This issue is closed here. Consider me dead. Know that, on my deathbed, I will remember this sacred moment –and I will always be grateful to you for it– for I will have made my final confession to you and you will carry my name, my mistakes, and my pains in your heart. Aside from this, I hope your heart will always be at ease and happy!"
es: —Count on it, Miss Lucía, that I will never refer to the conversation we just had. If I were to drop dead this instant, the secret would not be better kept, as far as I am concerned. A pure heart, an innocent heart is the holy ark where from today my name, my mistakes, my miseries, my final confession are kept... Ah!

en: He was so unlike what he had ever shown himself to be, and it was so sad to think how much he had thrown away, and how much he every day kept down and perverted, that Lucie Manette wept mournfully for him as he stood looking back at her.
vi: Sydney Carton behaved nothing like he used to, how sad it is to think of the life he has squandered, the many wasted and debauched days. Lucie Manette couldn't hold back a sorrowful cry as he looked back. −
tr: Carton was so different from the way he had been before, and it was so painful to see how much he had consumed his life, despised himself, and hindered himself, that as he stood speaking with his back turned, Lucie Manette began to cry sorrowfully.
es: At the hour of my death, it will be an ineffable comfort for me to embrace this thought, which will be my sacred companion for the rest of my life!

en: “Be comforted!” he said, “I am not worth such feeling, Miss Manette. An hour or two hence, and the low companions and low habits that I scorn but yield to, will render me less worth such tears as those, than any wretch who creeps along the streets. Be comforted! But, within myself, I shall always be, towards you, what I am now, though outwardly I shall be what you have heretofore seen me. The last supplication but one I make to you, is, that you will believe this of me.”
vi: Please be calm! - He said. - I am not worthy of your tears, Miss Manette. In just one or two hours, when my lowly friends and despicable but irresistible vices welcome me back, I will be even less deserving of these tears, worse than the wretched people on the streets. Please be calm! But in my heart, I will always be the person I am now to you, even though outwardly I will still be the man you have always seen. The last thing I earnestly ask of you is to believe my words.
tr: "Calm down!" said Carton, "your tears are not worth it, Miss Manette. Even in a couple of hours, no matter how angry I get, because of my wretched friends and habits that I cannot resist, I will become worse than the desperate people wandering these streets, and I will not be worth your tears at all. Calm down! Inside, my feelings towards you will always remain the same, but from the outside, I will appear just as you have always seen me. My last request from you is to believe me on this matter."
es: Abundant tears ran down the cheeks of Lucía Manette. —Don't cry, Miss Lucía, for I don't deserve anyone, much less an angel like you, to shed tears for me. Within one or two hours, vile friendships and vicious habits, which I despise but to which I succumb, will make me an object less worthy of those tears than the last human wreck dragging its miseries through the streets. I want, however, to make it clear that, if outwardly I will continue to be what I have been up to now, for you, my inner self will be what it is now. My penultimate plea is to ask you to believe me.

en: “I will, Mr. Carton.”
vi: − I believe you, Mr. Carton.
tr: "I believe, Mr. Carton.""
es: —I believe you, Mr. Carton, I believe you.

en: “My last supplication of all, is this; and with it, I will relieve you of a visitor with whom I well know you have nothing in unison, and between whom and you there is an impassable space. It is useless to say it, I know, but it rises out of my soul. For you, and for any dear to you, I would do anything. If my career were of that better kind that there was any opportunity or capacity of sacrifice in it, I would embrace any sacrifice for you and for those dear to you. Try to hold me in your mind, at some quiet times, as ardent and sincere in this one thing. The time will come, the time will not be long in coming, when new ties will be formed about you—ties that will bind you yet more tenderly and strongly to the home you so adorn—the dearest ties that will ever grace and gladden you. O Miss Manette, when the little picture of a happy father’s face looks up in yours, when you see your own bright beauty springing up anew at your feet, think now and then that there is a man who would give his life, to keep a life you love beside you!”
vi: − I only request this one thing, and now I will free you from a guest whom I know very well is not compatible with you, between him and you there is an infinite distance. It is meaningless to say, I know, but these words come from the bottom of my heart. I am willing to do everything for you, and for anyone you love. If on the road of life I still have any chance or ability to sacrifice for you and for your loved ones, I will sacrifice without hesitation. Please remember me, in some peaceful moments, and believe these sincere and earnest words. The time will come, not long from now, when the bond of marriage will connect you with someone... the bond will gently and firmly bind you to the home that you will embellish... the beloved bond will bring you many blessings and joys. Oh Miss Manette, when the shadow of happiness of the father is the little boy looking up at you, when your lovely face is doubled for the little girl growing up beside you, please occasionally remember that there is someone willing to trade his life to protect another life that you love!
tr: "I actually have one last request, and after that, I will rid you of this visitor with whom you have no common ground and between whom there is an insurmountable chasm. I know it's unnecessary to say this, but I can't help myself. There is nothing I wouldn't do for you and your loved ones, Miss Manette. If I had a better job and consequently an opportunity or situation to make a sacrifice for you or your loved ones, I would do it without hesitation. When you are alone, remember me with this vitality and sincerity. The day will come, and that day is very near, when you will form new bonds in your life, bonds that will bring you closer to your beloved home more sincerely and strongly, and these pleasant bonds will honor and make you happy forever. Ah Miss Manette, as a happy father looks sweetly at you and the little ones carrying your bright beauty grow at your feet, know both now and then that there is a man ready to give his life to ensure your happiness remains unspoiled!"
es: —I am going to make my final plea to you, and then I will free you from the presence of a visitor in whose degraded soul your angelic one cannot find a single harmonious chord, and from whom you are separated by a bottomless and boundless abyss. I know that saying it is useless; but it springs from my soul and I cannot keep it silent. For you, and for anyone you care about, I will do everything. To sacrifice a lost existence is no merit, I know; but if Providence were to give me the opportunity to sacrifice it, for you and for the people you care about, I would gladly do so. Try to retain in your memory what I am saying. The day will come, and it will not be long, when you will form new bonds, new bonds that will tie you very closely to the man who has the fortune to deserve you, the most tender, the sweetest, the most beautiful bonds that can bring joy to human existence. Oh, Miss Lucia! In the midst of the happiness that awaits you, when the happy face of your father is joined by that of another man who looks into your eyes, remember sometimes that in the world there lives a being ready to give his life at any moment in exchange for preserving the life of the mortal you love! The last favor I ask of you is not to forget my offer... Goodbye... goodbye!...

en: He said, “Farewell!” said a last “God bless you!” and left her.
vi: He says “Goodbye!” and utters for the last time “God bless you!” then leaves.
tr: "Goodbye!" he said finally, "God bless you!" and left the young girl's side.
es: May God bless you!

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: 14.The honest businessman
es: Chapter XIV.

en: The Honest Tradesman
vi: 14.The honest businessman
tr: Honest Tradesman
es: THE HONORABLE MINSTREL

en: To the eyes of Mr. Jeremiah Cruncher, sitting on his stool in Fleet-street with his grisly urchin beside him, a vast number and variety of objects in movement were every day presented. Who could sit upon anything in Fleet-street during the busy hours of the day, and not be dazed and deafened by two immense processions, one ever tending westward with the sun, the other ever tending eastward from the sun, both ever tending to the plains beyond the range of red and purple where the sun goes down!
vi: The traffic was like water, the clothes like wedges passing daily before Jeremiah Cruncher, who was sitting on a stool on Fleet Street with the hideous little boy beside him. If not for those two, who could sit on Fleet Street during the busy hours of the day without being dazzled and deafened by the two processions, one following the sun westward, one fleeing the sun eastward, both endlessly heading towards the distant fields beyond the multicolored sunset!
tr: Every day, a variety of people passed in front of Mr. Jeremiah Cruncher, who sat on his stool with his mischievous son on Fleet Street. Who wouldn't be bewildered by the sight of two immense caravans, one heading west with the sun and the other east, towards the plains beyond the reds and purples formed where the sun sets, while sitting on Fleet Street during these busy hours of the day?
es: Many and very varied objects paraded before the eyes of Jeremías Lapa during the hours he spent daily sitting on his rustic bench on Fleet Street, accompanied by his unattractive offspring. Anyone who spent the liveliest hours of the day on Fleet Street, sitting on a bench or a chair, on a stone or on the hard ground, would inevitably end the day dazed and deafened, due to the two immense, endless processions that, despite following opposite directions, one from East to West, the other from West to East, inevitably walked towards the same end, towards the world that the red and purple rays of the sun never visit.

en: With his straw in his mouth, Mr. Cruncher sat watching the two streams, like the heathen rustic who has for several centuries been on duty watching one stream—saving that Jerry had no expectation of their ever running dry. Nor would it have been an expectation of a hopeful kind, since a small part of his income was derived from the pilotage of timid women (mostly of a full habit and past the middle term of life) from Tellson’s side of the tides to the opposite shore. Brief as such companionship was in every separate instance, Mr. Cruncher never failed to become so interested in the lady as to express a strong desire to have the honour of drinking her very good health. And it was from the gifts bestowed upon him towards the execution of this benevolent purpose, that he recruited his finances, as just now observed.
vi: With a straw in his mouth, Cruncher sat watching the two streams of movement as if he were the ferryman god for centuries tasked with guarding the river of the underworld - only he did not wish for this flow to dry up. If it dried up, what would be worth hoping for, because a small part of his income came from leading timid women (most of whom were encumbered by their clothing and had long passed their prime) from Tellson's side across the traffic to the other side. Each time he accompanied them, no matter how brief, Cruncher managed to befriend the ladies to express his desire for the honor of toasting their health. And the small sums of money the ladies gave him when he performed this charitable purpose were an additional source of income, and that is why he sat there observing.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, with a straw in his mouth, was watching these two currents like a boatman observing the flow of the river that has surrounded hell for centuries, but Jerry never believed that these currents would ever dry up. He hoped they wouldn't either, as a small portion of his income came from ferrying delicate ladies (mostly well-dressed, middle-aged ones) across to the other side on behalf of Tellson. In these brief acquaintances, Mr. Cruncher would always show great interest in the ladies and felt a tremendous desire to reach the honor of toasting to their health. Thus, he earned a part of his income, as he did now, from the money given as a reward for this benevolence.
es: The good Lapa, chewing the obligatory straw, watched the course of the two gigantic streams, similar to that gentle rustic who spent several centuries contemplating the course of a river, with the only difference between the two being that the latter feared the river would dry up, while Jeremiah was certain that the course of those streams would never be interrupted. It is true that this certainty was for Lapa a source of cheerful hopes, since a large part of his income was earned by serving as a guide for women who wished to cross the street. Although, as a general rule, the ladies who sought his services were well into the decline of life, and on the other hand, the relationships established during the brief crossing were necessarily short-lived, such an impression did the fiery Jeremiah have of the fair sex that he never rendered such a service without expressing a fervent desire to be granted the honor of drinking to the health of his companion.

en: Time was, when a poet sat upon a stool in a public place, and mused in the sight of men. Mr. Cruncher, sitting on a stool in a public place, but not being a poet, mused as little as possible, and looked about him.
vi: There was a time when poets often sat dreamily on benches, watching people pass by in public places. Also sitting on a bench in a public place but not a poet, Cruncher looked around, the less daydreaming, the better.
tr: In the past, a poet used to sit on a stool in places where there were a lot of people and get lost in thoughts while watching the passersby. Mr. Cruncher, who was sitting on a stool in the crowd, however, was not a poet and wasn't thinking much; he was just looking around.
es: There were times when poets would sit on a bench in the most public places to think, and meditate, and reflect in plain view of people. Jeremías Lapa also sat on a bench in a public place; but since he was not a poet, he thought, reflected, and meditated as little as possible, and instead, he looked around a lot.

en: It fell out that he was thus engaged in a season when crowds were few, and belated women few, and when his affairs in general were so unprosperous as to awaken a strong suspicion in his breast that Mrs. Cruncher must have been “flopping” in some pointed manner, when an unusual concourse pouring down Fleet-street westward, attracted his attention. Looking that way, Mr. Cruncher made out that some kind of funeral was coming along, and that there was popular objection to this funeral, which engendered uproar.
vi: It turned out that he was encountering a time when the streets were not crowded, devoid of slow-moving ladies, and when business was not thriving, he began to suspect that his wife Cruncher at home must be "sitting around" cursing him; just at that moment, he saw an unusual crowd pouring down Fleet Street heading west. Straining his eyes to look, Cruncher recognized a funeral procession approaching, followed by a noisy crowd.
tr: However, it was now a season when the crowd and elderly women were not abundant, and business was generally going so poorly that a strong suspicion arose within Mr. Cruncher that Mrs. Cruncher had sighed, just at that moment an unusual crowd flowing from the west towards Fleet Street caught his attention. After looking for a while, Mr. Cruncher decided that it was a funeral crowd; a large number of people protesting the funeral had caused a great commotion.
es: He was going through one of those distressing moments when street traffic was sparse, and even sparser were the women who wished to cross it, one of those moments when his business looked so disheartening that our hero began to suspect that his wife might be kneeling and praying in some corner, when his attention was caught by an unusual torrent of people, surging down Fleet Street, following the very course of the sun, that is, towards the West. Upon examining the torrent, Lapa saw that it was a funeral procession which undoubtedly was not to the people's liking, as they were objecting to its passage.

en: “Young Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, turning to his offspring, “it’s a buryin’.”
vi: − Jerry, my boy, - Cruncher turned to his son, - there's a funeral.
tr: "Look Jerry," said Mr. Cruncher, turning to his son, "the funeral is coming."
es: —It's a burial, son—said Jeremías to his offspring.

en: “Hooroar, father!” cried Young Jerry.
vi: − Hooray, father! - young Jerry shouted.
tr: "Way to go, Dad!" shouted little Jerry.
es: "Long live... father!" shouted Lapa's son, doing four kicks in the air.

en: The young gentleman uttered this exultant sound with mysterious significance. The elder gentleman took the cry so ill, that he watched his opportunity, and smote the young gentleman on the ear.
vi: The son uttered those words of joy with an air of mysterious importance. The father, irritated by this, waited for a moment when no one was paying attention and then gave the son a slap.
tr: There was a mysterious situation in the cheerful shout that came from the little gentleman. The older gentleman, however, did not like this shout very much; when he found the opportunity, he gave the little gentleman a slap on the ear.
es: The little gentleman imbued his cry of joy with a mysterious significance that displeased the father to such an extent that he watched closely and soon seized the opportunity to grab his offspring by the ear.

en: “What d’ye mean? What are you hooroaring at? What do you want to conwey to your own father, you young Rip? This boy is a getting too many for me!” said Mr. Cruncher, surveying him. “Him and his hooroars! Don’t let me hear no more of you, or you shall feel some more of me. D’ye hear?”
vi: − What kind of nonsense are you up to? What are you cheering for? Are you mocking your father, you little rascal? I can't stand you anymore! Cruncher stared at his son. - You dare to cheer? If I hear that again, you'll get another slap. Do you hear me?
tr: "What's going on? Why are you shouting? Are you trying to say something to your father, you scoundrel? This child is getting too much now!" said Mr. Cruncher, eyeing him. "As if he himself wasn't enough, he's also shouting 'long live'! Don't make a sound again or I'll come down on you. Did you hear me?"
es: —What is that?—shouted Jeremiah's father. — What does that cheer mean? Is that the respect you have for your father? This boy is a rascal, a scoundrel, as scoundrelly as his cheers! Don't let me hear you again, if you don't want to feel my wrath! Do you understand?

en: “I warn’t doing no harm,” Young Jerry protested, rubbing his cheek.
vi: − I didn't do anything wrong, - young Jerry protested while rubbing his cheek. −
tr: "I didn't say anything bad," Little Jerry protested, rubbing his cheek.
es: —Was I hurting anyone?—exclaimed the boy in protest, rubbing his ear.

en: “Drop it then,” said Mr. Cruncher; “I won’t have none of your no harms. Get a top of that there seat, and look at the crowd.”
vi: Shut up, - Cruncher said, - I don't care if you did something wrong or not. Go sit in that chair and watch people.
tr: "Cut it short," said Mr. Cruncher; "Keep your words to yourself. Get up on that stool and look at that rudeness."
es: —Was I hurting anyone?—exclaimed the boy in protest, rubbing his ear. —What you weren't doing was right!—replied Lapa.—Get up on this bench and look at the crowds.

en: His son obeyed, and the crowd approached; they were bawling and hissing round a dingy hearse and dingy mourning coach, in which mourning coach there was only one mourner, dressed in the dingy trappings that were considered essential to the dignity of the position. The position appeared by no means to please him, however, with an increasing rabble surrounding the coach, deriding him, making grimaces at him, and incessantly groaning and calling out: “Yah! Spies! Tst! Yaha! Spies!” with many compliments too numerous and forcible to repeat.
vi: The son obeyed and the crowd moved forward; the throng shouted and screamed around a dark hearse and a dark funeral carriage, on which there was only one person, dressed in the somber attire essential for this solemn role. But the funeral conductor was not at all pleased with this role as the crowd around the carriage grew increasingly chaotic, mocking him, frowning at him, and incessantly jeering, “Hey! Spy! Hiss! Hey hey! Spy!” along with countless other unbearably harsh praises that cannot be recounted.
tr: The child listened to his father's words, the crowd had approached; they were shouting and booing around a pale-colored hearse and again a pale-colored mourning carriage; inside the mourning carriage, there was a single mourner dressed in pale-colored clothes due to the gravity of his position. He was not at all pleased with his situation, because the noisy crowd surrounding the carriage was mocking him, making faces, and continuously groaning, "Boo! Spies! Boo! Spies!" along with many other unrepeatable, unspeakable insults.
es: The son obeyed. The crowds came shouting wildly and jumping around a dirty and old death cart, followed by a hearse just as dirty, old, and tarnished as the cart, occupied by a single representative of mourning, who displayed the funeral attire that she considered indispensable to the dignity of her position. It did not seem, however, that her position was very desirable, as the mobs jumped around the carriage shouting until deafening her, making faces and contortions, mocking her respectable person, and hurling unpleasant apostrophes to her ear.

en: Funerals had at all times a remarkable attraction for Mr. Cruncher; he always pricked up his senses, and became excited, when a funeral passed Tellson’s. Naturally, therefore, a funeral with this uncommon attendance excited him greatly, and he asked of the first man who ran against him:
vi: Funerals always had a great attraction for Cruncher; he would always strain his eyes and ears and become excited whenever a funeral passed by Tellson's. So a funeral with an unusually large number of attendees made him extremely happy, and he immediately asked the first person who came by: −What's this, my friend?
tr: Funerals had always piqued Mr. Cruncher's interest; whenever a funeral passed by Tellson's, he would watch it with full attention and get excited. Therefore, naturally, this unusual group accompanying the funeral had quite excited him, and he immediately asked the man running in front:
es: Funerals were always a special source of excitement for Jeremías Lapa; it is not surprising, then, that on this occasion, involving a funeral with such a noisy entourage, it drove him to the point of asking the first person he encountered:

en: “What is it, brother? What’s it about?”
vi: What's going on?
tr: "Brother, what is this? What's happening?"
es: —What's up, brother? What's that?

en: “I don’t know,” said the man. “Spies! Yaha! Tst! Spies!”
vi: −I have no idea, - the other person said.- Spy! Hey hey! Hiss! Dirty spy!
tr: "I don't know either," said the man. "Spies! Boo! Spies!"
es: —I don't know—replied the questioned one without stopping. Spies!... Spies!

en: He asked another man. “Who is it?”
vi: Cruncher asked another person: − Who died? − I don't know, - this person replied the same way but cupped his hands around his mouth to form a megaphone and shouted enthusiastically and strangely fervently, - Dirty spy!
tr: He asked another man. "Who is this?"
es: —Who is the dead person?—he asked another.

en: “I don’t know,” returned the man, clapping his hands to his mouth nevertheless, and vociferating in a surprising heat and with the greatest ardour, “Spies! Yaha! Tst, tst! Spi—ies!”
vi: Cruncher asked another person: − Who died? − I don't know, - this person replied the same way but cupped his hands around his mouth to form a megaphone and shouted enthusiastically and strangely fervently, - Dirty spy! Hey hey! Hiss, hiss! Spiiii... y!
tr: "I don't know!" said the man, but he had brought his hand to his mouth and was shouting with incredible enthusiasm and tremendous zeal: "Spies! Boo! Boo! Spies!"
es: —I don't know—he also replied, placing his hands in front of his mouth like a megaphone, and shouting with redoubled fury:—Spies! Spies!

en: At length, a person better informed on the merits of the case, tumbled against him, and from this person he learned that the funeral was the funeral of one Roger Cly.
vi: It was only after a while that Cruncher met someone who knew the true situation and found out that this funeral was for a certain Roger Cly.
tr: Finally, a man who knew more about this matter came across him, and from this man, he learned that the funeral was for someone named Roger Cly.
es: Lapa finally stumbled upon a person better informed about the case, thanks to whom he was able to find out that it was the burial of an individual named Rogerio Cly.

en: “Was he a spy?” asked Mr. Cruncher.
vi: −This guy was a spy? - Cruncher asked.
tr: "What is the case?" asked Mr. Cruncher.
es: —Was he a spy?—asked Lapa.

en: “Old Bailey spy,” returned his informant. “Yaha! Tst! Yah! Old Bailey Spi—i—ies!”
vi: −A spy at the Old Bailey, - the knowledgeable person informed him. − Hey hey! Hiss! Hey! The spy at the Old Baiiiii... ley! − Ah, that's right!
tr: "Old Bailey spy!" said the source of the news. "Boo! Boo! Old Bailey spies!"
es: —Spy of the Old Bailey—replied the informant. —Spy... yes... spy of the Old Bailey!

en: “Why, to be sure!” exclaimed Jerry, recalling the Trial at which he had assisted. “I’ve seen him. Dead, is he?”
vi: - Jerry exclaimed as he remembered the trial he had attended before.- I've met this guy before. He's dead now?
tr: Remembering the trial he himself had attended, Jerry shouted, "Ah, of course!" "I had seen him." "He's dead, isn't he?"
es: —Damn!—exclaimed Lapa, recalling the sight he had witnessed in the past. —I know him. Is he dead?

en: “Dead as mutton,” returned the other, “and can’t be too dead. Have ’em out, there! Spies! Pull ’em out, there! Spies!”
vi: −Dead as a doornail, - the other person replied, - stone cold dead. Drag them out here! Dirty spy! Tear them apart! Dirty spy!
tr: "A corpse, a corpse," the other replied, "saying he died is an understatement. Get them out! Spies! Get them out! Spies!"
es: —Dead like my grandmother! And he should be even more dead!... Get out!... Spy!... Throw him in here!

en: The idea was so acceptable in the prevalent absence of any idea, that the crowd caught it up with eagerness, and loudly repeating the suggestion to have ’em out, and to pull ’em out, mobbed the two vehicles so closely that they came to a stop. On the crowd’s opening the coach doors, the one mourner scuffled out by himself and was in their hands for a moment; but he was so alert, and made such good use of his time, that in another moment he was scouring away up a bye-street, after shedding his cloak, hat, long hatband, white pocket-handkerchief, and other symbolical tears.
vi: This idea was too easily accepted when no one could think of anything else, so the crowd eagerly seized upon it, shouting and repeating the suggestion to drag and tear apart, while crowding so tightly that the two carriages couldn't move an inch. When the crowd managed to open the funeral carriage door, the only person in mourning attire frantically jumped out and was caught for a moment; but he was too quick and knew how to take advantage of the situation, so in just a flash, he had escaped into an alley after shedding his coat, hat, long mourning band, white handkerchief in his pocket, and even the symbolic tears.
tr: In an environment where there were no other ideas, this idea was so reasonable that the crowd eagerly jumped on it, and while they kept reiterating their suggestions to get them out of the car, shouting loudly, the two vehicles got so close to each other that they had to stop. As someone from the crowd opened the car door, the only mourning passenger quickly threw himself out and found himself amidst the crowd, but he was so alert and agile that he threw off his cloak, hat, hatband, white handkerchief, and other symbols of mourning, and fled straight into the side streets.
es: Such a brilliant idea had to be inevitably accepted by those crowds, and so it was, indeed. Everyone eagerly seized upon the cry and repeated it a thousand times, as they drew so close to the hearse and the funeral carriage that they forced them to stop. In the blink of an eye, they seized the representative of the mourning; but he, who was anything but clumsy, so admirably knew how to make use of the time that in another blink of an eye he gave the crowds the slip by dashing down a side alley, not without leaving in their hands his cape, his hat, the veil that covered him to his knees, the obligatory white handkerchief, and other symbolic tears.

en: These, the people tore to pieces and scattered far and wide with great enjoyment, while the tradesmen hurriedly shut up their shops; for a crowd in those times stopped at nothing, and was a monster much dreaded. They had already got the length of opening the hearse to take the coffin out, when some brighter genius proposed instead, its being escorted to its destination amidst general rejoicing. Practical suggestions being much needed, this suggestion, too, was received with acclamation, and the coach was immediately filled with eight inside and a dozen out, while as many people got on the roof of the hearse as could by any exercise of ingenuity stick upon it. Among the first of these volunteers was Jerry Cruncher himself, who modestly concealed his spiky head from the observation of Tellson’s, in the further corner of the mourning coach.
vi: These mourning clothes were joyfully torn to pieces and scattered everywhere by the crowd while the merchants hastily closed their shops; for at that time the crowd would not hesitate before anything and was as terrifying as a monstrous tyrant. The crowd was so frenzied that they opened the hearse, intending to pull the coffin out, when a genius, smarter than the rest, came up with the idea to leave it as it was and all together escort the hearse to its final destination to celebrate the funeral. Any practical idea was necessary, so everyone eagerly accepted this suggestion, and the hearse immediately became packed with eight people inside, a dozen clinging outside; while the hearse itself carried about the same number of people on its roof and a group skillfully clinging around in every possible way. Among the first volunteers was Jerry Cruncher, who timidly hid his bristly head in the farthest corner of the hearse so that the people from Tellson's Bank would not see him.
tr: While those around were tearing all these items into pieces with great pleasure and scattering them around, the shopkeepers hastily pulled down their shutters; in such times, such a mob knew no bounds and could turn into a terrifying monster. The crowd had gone so far as to open the car door and take out the coffin, but a bright-minded person suggested that instead of removing it from the car, they should accompany it cheerfully to its destination. Due to the need for practical suggestions, this proposal was also met with applause, and suddenly eight men filled the inside of the car, a dozen clung to the outside, and meanwhile, a large number swarmed onto the roof of the car with great skill. Among those leading the way was Jerry Cruncher, who had curled up in a corner inside the mourning car and was humbly hiding his spiky hair to avoid being seen by those from Tellson's.
