es: The town entertained itself by tearing and scattering to the four winds the indicated objects and garments, demonstrating wild joy, while the merchants hurriedly closed the doors of their establishments, as the mob, in those happy times, was a highly dangerous monster, capable of devouring everything once it opened its jaws. They had already opened the doors of the hearse to take out the coffin, when another genius proposed escorting it to its destination amidst general rejoicing. The proposal, like all those that are eminently practical, deserved to be approved by acclamation, and immediately eight individuals stormed the coach while another six climbed onto the roof of the hearse. One of the first volunteers was Jeremías Lapa, who, in his modesty, hid himself and his head in a corner of the coach.

en: The officiating undertakers made some protest against these changes in the ceremonies; but, the river being alarmingly near, and several voices remarking on the efficacy of cold immersion in bringing refractory members of the profession to reason, the protest was faint and brief. The remodelled procession started, with a chimney-sweep driving the hearse—advised by the regular driver, who was perched beside him, under close inspection, for the purpose—and with a pieman, also attended by his cabinet minister, driving the mourning coach. A bear-leader, a popular street character of the time, was impressed as an additional ornament, before the cavalcade had gone far down the Strand; and his bear, who was black and very mangy, gave quite an Undertaking air to that part of the procession in which he walked.
vi: The official employees of the funeral home opposed the change in funeral rites; but the river was alarmingly close, and many in the crowd noted that using cold water would effectively calm any stubborn employee, so the funeral home staff only weakly and briefly protested. The funeral continued with the new rites, a chimney sweep took control of the hearse - under the guidance of the actual driver who was precariously perched beside him to closely supervise - while a street vendor, also with an assistant advisor, drove the funeral carriage. A bear trainer, a popular street character of the time, was also enlisted as an additional decoration before the procession reached Strand Street; and his mangy black bear was the only one in the procession with a truly mournful face.
tr: The funeral attendants initially protested a bit about this change in the ceremony, but the river was quite close, and when some of them started making remarks that dipping the stubborn attendants into the cold water would bring them to their senses, the objections ceased. The transformed procession set off with the chimney sweep as the driver – the actual driver sat next to him, carefully watching and guiding him; the mourning coach was driven by a minister and a pie seller. Before the cavalry regiment even reached the Strand, a bear handler, a street character much loved at the time, joined them, adding color to the procession; as for his very dirty black bear, it gave the procession a truly funereal atmosphere as it walked along.
es: The funeral home employees protested against that alteration of the ceremony; but the distance to the river was alarmingly short, and several voices had already advocated the effectiveness of a cold immersion to bring the recalcitrant funeral employees to their senses, and as a result, the protests were weak and brief. The procession continued once it was reformed. A chimney sweep guided the hearse, advised by a professional coachman sitting next to him, and the driving of the car was handled by a baker, assisted in turn by a responsible minister. A Hungarian with his bear, a very popular street type at that time, joined the procession; the bear, being black and very thin, perfectly harmonized with the funereal character of the procession of which it was a part.

en: Thus, with beer-drinking, pipe-smoking, song-roaring, and infinite caricaturing of woe, the disorderly procession went its way, recruiting at every step, and all the shops shutting up before it. Its destination was the old church of Saint Pancras, far off in the fields. It got there in course of time; insisted on pouring into the burial-ground; finally, accomplished the interment of the deceased Roger Cly in its own way, and highly to its own satisfaction.
vi: So, while drinking beer, smoking cigarettes, singing loudly, and making all sorts of sorrowful and mocking gestures, the chaotic crowd kept moving forward, constantly drawing more people to join, and wherever they went, all the shops would shut their doors tightly. The destination was the old Saint Pancras church, far out in the countryside. The crowd eventually arrived, all pouring into the cemetery; and finally, they completed the burial of the late Roger Cly in the manner they wanted, and everyone was satisfied.
tr: Thus, the boisterous procession advanced, drinking beers, puffing on pipes, singing songs, accompanied by an endless imitation of sorrow, and constantly adding new members to their ranks; everyone who saw them closed their shops. The place they were headed to was the old St Pancras Church, far away in the middle of the fields. After a while, they reached their destination and all flowed into the cemetery like a flood; finally, they managed to bury the late Roger Cly in their own way and to their own satisfaction.
es: In this manner, the disordered procession continued, growing at every step and forcing all the shops on the streets it passed through to close. The end of the journey was the old church of San Pancracio, located outside the city, where it arrived in due time. The burial of Rogerio Cly's corpse was carried out according to an extravagant ceremony, much to the satisfaction of the large accompanying crowd.

en: The dead man disposed of, and the crowd being under the necessity of providing some other entertainment for itself, another brighter genius (or perhaps the same) conceived the humour of impeaching casual passers-by, as Old Bailey spies, and wreaking vengeance on them. Chase was given to some scores of inoffensive persons who had never been near the Old Bailey in their lives, in the realisation of this fancy, and they were roughly hustled and maltreated. The transition to the sport of window-breaking, and thence to the plundering of public-houses, was easy and natural. At last, after several hours, when sundry summer-houses had been pulled down, and some area-railings had been torn up, to arm the more belligerent spirits, a rumour got about that the Guards were coming. Before this rumour, the crowd gradually melted away, and perhaps the Guards came, and perhaps they never came, and this was the usual progress of a mob.
vi: The dead had been buried, and the crowd now needed new entertainment for themselves. A brilliant mind (or perhaps the same person from earlier) came up with the fun idea of accusing random passersby of being spies at the Old Bailey and venting their hatred on them. Dozens of innocent people who had never set foot near the Old Bailey in their lives were chased, knocked down, and assaulted. From this game, it was an easy and natural step to move on to breaking windows and then to looting pubs. Eventually, hours later, when many summer houses had been torn down and many fences had been broken to make weapons for the more aggressive ones, a rumor spread that the guards were coming. Upon hearing this news, the crowd gradually dispersed, and whether the guards came or never came, this was the usual course of events for a frenzied mob.
tr: The dead had been buried, and the crowd was in a rush to find a new amusement when another genius (perhaps the same man) came up with the witty idea of accusing passersby of being Old Bailey spies and taking revenge on them. To bring this idea to life, they grabbed hold of a bunch of innocent people who had never even passed near Old Bailey in their entire lives and harassed them by pushing and shoving. Naturally, from there, they moved on to the game of breaking windows and looting houses. Eventually, a few hours later, after some summer houses had been demolished and fences torn down, rumors spread that soldiers were coming to support the warrior spirits. Even before the rumor spread, the crowd had gradually dispersed; the soldiers may or may not have come, but this was what happened in all stampedes.
es: Once the deceased was buried, the author of the previous humorous proposition, or perhaps another genius, as they are never lacking in crowds, conceived and proposed the diabolical idea, unanimously approved, of accusing passersby of being spies from the Old Bailey and calling for vengeance against all those whom chance brought to those places. Dozens of innocent unfortunates who had never in their lives been within a thousand yards of the despised court were pursued like wild beasts, harassed, and mercilessly beaten. The transition from this game to breaking windows, knocking down doors and windows, and looting inns and taverns could not have been simpler, more natural, or more logical. After several hours of looting, when several country houses had been stormed, many shops ransacked, and numerous iron fences destroyed, providing weapons to the most belligerent characters, word spread that the guards were coming. The mere news was enough to disperse the mobs before the guards arrived, who perhaps did not even think of approaching the scene of the events.

en: Mr. Cruncher did not assist at the closing sports, but had remained behind in the churchyard, to confer and condole with the undertakers. The place had a soothing influence on him. He procured a pipe from a neighbouring public-house, and smoked it, looking in at the railings and maturely considering the spot.
vi: Cruncher did not participate in the post-funeral entertainments but stayed in the cemetery to chat and comfort the undertaker's staff. This place made him feel at ease. He got a pipe from a nearby pub and smoked while observing the surrounding fence, carefully examining the location.
tr: Mr. Cruncher had not attended the closing celebration; he had stayed behind in the cemetery in the churchyard, talking to the funeral staff. This place had a calming effect on him. He had found a pipe in one of the nearby pubs, and was smoking it while looking at the fences and thinking about the commotion that had taken place.
es: Jeremías Lapa did not take part in the recent disturbances; he preferred to remain in the cemetery, conversing with the funeral home employees and engaging in somber reflections. The realm of death always exerted a calming influence on him. Sitting on a grave, smoking a pipe he had acquired from the nearby tavern with philosophical calm, he meditated, his eyes fixed on the gate.

en: “Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, apostrophising himself in his usual way, “you see that there Cly that day, and you see with your own eyes that he was a young ’un and a straight made ’un.”
vi: "Jerry," Cruncher muttered to himself out of habit. "That day you saw that guy Cly already. You saw with your own eyes that he was a young and decent man."
tr: Mr. Cruncher said to himself, as usual, "Jerry! That day you saw Cly with your own eyes, and you saw that he was young and strong.""
es: You see, Jeremías, what the world is like! —Lapa said to himself. —Not long ago you saw with your own eyes that Cly, young, robust, brimming with life, and now...

en: Having smoked his pipe out, and ruminated a little longer, he turned himself about, that he might appear, before the hour of closing, on his station at Tellson’s. Whether his meditations on mortality had touched his liver, or whether his general health had been previously at all amiss, or whether he desired to show a little attention to an eminent man, is not so much to the purpose, as that he made a short call upon his medical adviser—a distinguished surgeon—on his way back.
vi: After finishing his pipe and pondering a bit more, he also returned to make sure he was at the old spot before Tellson's closed. It was unclear whether his thoughts about death had affected his internal organs or his general health had been unstable recently, or if he just wanted to show some care to a reputable person, but either way, on the way back he stopped by the doctor's house - a renowned surgeon.
tr: After smoking his pipe and drifting into thoughts for a while, it occurred to him that he needed to take his place at Tellson's before closing time. Whether the thoughts about mortality he had been pondering had affected his liver, his health had been deteriorating for some time, or he simply wanted to show interest in an important personage, it was unknown, but on his way back, he paid a brief visit to the family doctor – a distinguished surgeon.
es: After smoking his pipe, and after a considerable amount of time spent in deep meditations and sad reflections, he got up and started back to the city, intending to be at his post before the Bank's closing time. It has not been entirely possible to clarify whether his meditations had a pernicious influence on his liver, or if his health had already been deteriorating beforehand, or if his visit had no other purpose than to bestow an honor upon the person he visited: whatever the cause, the fact was that, on the way, he stopped for a few minutes at his doctor's house... the eminent veterinarian of the city.

en: Young Jerry relieved his father with dutiful interest, and reported No job in his absence. The bank closed, the ancient clerks came out, the usual watch was set, and Mr. Cruncher and his son went home to tea.
vi: Jerry, the child, sat in his father's place out of duty, reporting that during his father's absence, there was no work at all. The bank closed, the old decrepit clerks left, the night watchman arrived, and Cruncher and his son went home for tea.
tr: Little Jerry had taken responsibility and reassured his father, saying that nothing had happened in his absence. The bank closed, the old clerks left, the clock was set as usual, and Mr. Cruncher and his son went home to have tea.
es: The son expressed to the father with great interest that nothing had happened during his absence. The Bank closed the day's operations, the employees left, and Lapa, accompanied by his son, headed home.

en: “Now, I tell you where it is!” said Mr. Cruncher to his wife, on entering. “If, as a honest tradesman, my wenturs goes wrong to-night, I shall make sure that you’ve been praying again me, and I shall work you for it just the same as if I seen you do it.”
vi: − “Hey, let me tell you something!” - Cruncher said to his wife as soon as he walked in. - “I am an honest worker. If my work tonight fails, it’s definitely because you cursed me. Even if I don't see you doing anything, I will still give you a beating as usual.”
tr: When he came inside, "Look, let me tell you something now!" said Mr. Cruncher to his wife. "As an honest tradesman, if my business goes wrong again tonight, I will be sure that you have cursed me and I will punish you as if I had seen it with my own eyes."
es: —Today you will know who I am—he said to his wife as soon as he crossed the threshold of the house. —If tonight I am in a bad mood like an honest tradesman, it will be proof that you have spent the day praying against me, and you will know what's what, just as if I had seen you dragged across the floor with my own eyes.

en: The dejected Mrs. Cruncher shook her head.
vi: Mrs. Cruncher dejectedly shook her head.
tr: Mr. Cruncher nodded his head forward sadly.
es: His rib moved its head.

en: “Why, you’re at it afore my face!” said Mr. Cruncher, with signs of angry apprehension.
vi: "Ah, you dare to do that in front of me!" - Cruncher exclaimed, his voice both angry and worried.
tr: "Why are you looking at my face like that?" shouted Mr. Cruncher, furious with rage.
es: —What! Do you dare to do it right under my nose?—he replied with an angry tone.

en: “I am saying nothing.”
vi: − "I didn't say anything." − "Hmph, then don't think anything in your head."
tr: "I didn't say anything.""
es: —If I don't say anything!

en: “Well, then; don’t meditate nothing. You might as well flop as meditate. You may as well go again me one way as another. Drop it altogether.”
vi: − "I didn't say anything." − "Hmph, then don't think anything in your head." "If you're not sitting there praying, then you're plotting something." "One way or another, you're cursing me." "Stop it all, you hear.
tr: "Don't say good; don't even think about it. Whether you kneel down and pray or just think about it, it all leads to the same outcome. Don't do anything."
es: —I already know; but you think! Thinking is just as bad as talking! You can ruin me just the same by praying as by meditating! I don't want you to do either!

en: “Yes, Jerry.”
vi: − Yes, sir."
tr: "Okay Jerry."
es: —Alright, Jeremías.

en: “Yes, Jerry,” repeated Mr. Cruncher sitting down to tea. “Ah! It is yes, Jerry. That’s about it. You may say yes, Jerry.”
vi: − Yes, - Cruncher kept repeating as he sat down at the table for tea. Well! Yes. Alright. Allow her to say "yes."
tr: "Alright Jerry," repeated Mr. Cruncher as he sat down for tea. "Oh! Again 'Alright Jerry'. Don't you know anything else? Alright Jerry, alright Jerry."
es: —Alright, Jeremías. —Yes!... Alright, Jeremías... Perfectly, Jeremías... Agreed, Jeremías... Whatever you say, Jeremías...

en: Mr. Cruncher had no particular meaning in these sulky corroborations, but made use of them, as people not unfrequently do, to express general ironical dissatisfaction.
vi: Cruncher's grumblings didn't have any clear meaning, but he kept talking anyway, just like everyone else does when they generally express sarcastic discontent.
tr: The words Mr. Cruncher kept repeating grumpily did not convey a specific meaning but rather expressed a sarcastic dissatisfaction, much like many people often do.
es: You think you can fool me with those words of agreement, don't you?

en: “You and your yes, Jerry,” said Mr. Cruncher, taking a bite out of his bread-and-butter, and seeming to help it down with a large invisible oyster out of his saucer. “Ah! I think so. I believe you.”
vi: − Just say yes, - Cruncher said, biting into a buttered bread and swallowing quickly as if gulping down a large invisible oyster just shucked. - Ah! That works too. I trust you. −
tr: "You and your 'All right, Jerry,'" said Mr. Cruncher, taking a bite of his buttered bread as if he were swallowing it with the help of an invisible oyster taken from a saucer. "Ah! I think so too. I believe you."
es: You think you can fool me with those words of agreement, don't you? Well, you are completely mistaken!

en: “You are going out to-night?” asked his decent wife, when he took another bite.
vi: Are you going out tonight? - The wife kindly asked as the husband took another bite.
tr: As Mr. Cruncher took a second bite of his bread, his polite wife asked, "Are you going out tonight?"
es: —Are you planning to go out tonight?—asked the woman.

en: “Yes, I am.”
vi: − I am. −
tr: "Yes, I will go out."
es: —Yes; I plan to go out.

en: “May I go with you, father?” asked his son, briskly.
vi: Can I come with you, Dad? - The son eagerly suggested.
tr: His son immediately blurted out, "Can I come with you too, Dad?"
es: —May I accompany you, father?—asked his child.

en: “No, you mayn’t. I’m a going—as your mother knows—a fishing. That’s where I’m going to. Going a fishing.”
vi: - No, that's not possible. I have to go... your mother knows it already,... go fishing. I have to go there. Go fishing. −
tr: "No, you cannot come. As your mother knows, I am going fishing. Yes, that's right. I am going fishing."
es: —You won't be able to accompany me. Tonight I am going... your mother already knows... I am going fishing; fishing; that's it.

en: “Your fishing-rod gets rayther rusty; don’t it, father?”
vi: Isn't your fishing rod a bit rusty, Dad? − Never mind that.
tr: "But didn't your fishing rod rust, dad?""
es: —Every day the fish are getting smarter, aren't they, father?

en: “Never you mind.”
tr: "It's none of your business."
es: —It's none of your business.

en: “Shall you bring any fish home, father?”
vi: Will you bring fish home, Dad? − If I don't bring any home, you'll go hungry tomorrow, - the father replied while shaking his head.
tr: "Will you bring fish, Dad?"
es: —Will he bring fish? —If I don't bring it, there will be a general uproar at home tomorrow—replied Lapa, shaking his head.

en: “If I don’t, you’ll have short commons, to-morrow,” returned that gentleman, shaking his head; “that’s questions enough for you; I ain’t a going out, till you’ve been long abed.”
vi: - Enough questions; as long as you haven't gone to bed and fallen asleep, I won't go anywhere.
tr: "If I don't bring it, there will be nothing to eat tomorrow," said the man, shaking his head; "come on, that's enough questions; I'll go after you fall asleep."
es: —And enough with the questions, kid. I won't leave until you have gone to bed.

en: He devoted himself during the remainder of the evening to keeping a most vigilant watch on Mrs. Cruncher, and sullenly holding her in conversation that she might be prevented from meditating any petitions to his disadvantage. With this view, he urged his son to hold her in conversation also, and led the unfortunate woman a hard life by dwelling on any causes of complaint he could bring against her, rather than he would leave her for a moment to her own reflections. The devoutest person could have rendered no greater homage to the efficacy of an honest prayer than he did in this distrust of his wife. It was as if a professed unbeliever in ghosts should be frightened by a ghost story.
vi: For the rest of the evening, Cruncher did nothing but keep a very close watch on his wife, constantly engaging her in conversation to prevent her from plotting or praying for any misfortune to befall him. Therefore, Cruncher urged his son to talk to his mother as well, tormenting the poor woman with all sorts of complaints and grievances, not allowing her a single moment of peace to think privately. Even the most devout person who believes in the efficacy of sincere prayers could not match Cruncher's belief that his wife only wished ill upon her husband. It's no different from someone who claims not to believe in ghosts but gets scared out of their wits when hearing ghost stories.
tr: Jerry did not take his eyes off Mrs. Cruncher for the rest of the evening and kept talking to her harshly so that she wouldn't start cursing him. With this thought, he also forced his son to keep his mother engaged in conversation and subjected the poor woman to countless complaints to prevent her from being alone and lost in her thoughts. Even the most devout person would not regard the effect of a sincere prayer as much as he did; he was so suspicious of his own blood. It was like someone who claimed not to believe in ghosts being scared by a ghost story.
es: The rest of the evening he devoted to watching his wife and forcing her to talk constantly in order to prevent her from praying or meditating against him. With the same objective in mind, he also forced his son to chat endlessly with his mother, much to her displeasure, as she did not have a single second to devote to her reflections. The most devout person could not have paid a more eloquent tribute to the efficacy of an honest prayer. His fear of his wife's prayers was as if a person who swore up and down that they did not believe in ghosts or apparitions were horrified upon hearing ghost and apparition stories.

en: “And mind you!” said Mr. Cruncher. “No games to-morrow! If I, as a honest tradesman, succeed in providing a jinte of meat or two, none of your not touching of it, and sticking to bread. If I, as a honest tradesman, am able to provide a little beer, none of your declaring on water. When you go to Rome, do as Rome does. Rome will be a ugly customer to you, if you don’t. I’m your Rome, you know.”
vi: − Remember that! - Cruncher said. - Don't try any tricks tomorrow! If this honest man here manages to bring back some meat, don't you dare refuse to eat it and just swallow plain bread. This honest guy here, if he brings back some beer, don't just pretend to drink plain water. When in Rome, do as the Romans do. If you don't follow the customs, the host will kick you out of the house. I am the host here, got it!
tr: "Look at me!" said Mr. Cruncher. "I don't want any trouble tomorrow! If I manage to bring home a few pieces of meat as an honest tradesman, there's no skipping that and just eating bread. If I can also bring home some beer as an honest tradesman, there's no saying you'll just drink water. When in Rome, do as the Romans do. If you don't do this, Rome will treat you like a bad customer. I'm your Rome, don't you forget it."
es: —It's a big deal that your prayers are a constant threat to our stomachs!—said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: Then he began grumbling again:
vi: Then he started grumbling again: − Food and drinks are served right to your mouth and you still complain!
tr: Then he started muttering again:
es: —It's a big deal that your prayers are a constant threat to our stomachs!—said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time.

en: “With your flying into the face of your own wittles and drink! I don’t know how scarce you mayn’t make the wittles and drink here, by your flopping tricks and your unfeeling conduct. Look at your boy: he is your’n, ain’t he? He’s as thin as a lath. Do you call yourself a mother, and not know that a mother’s first duty is to blow her boy out?”
vi: I don't understand why I have to work so hard to get food and drinks, just because of your nonsense of sitting around praying and living immorally. Look at your son! Is he your son or not? He's so skinny. You call yourself a mother but don't know that the first duty of a mother is to fatten up her child?
tr: "You are depriving your own bread and water! Because of your kneeling and praying and those merciless behaviors, no food or drink has entered the house. Look at your son. Look! This child is yours, isn't he? He has become skin and bones. Do you now call yourself a mother? Don't you know that a mother's first duty is to feed her child?"
es: —It's a big deal that your prayers are a constant threat to our stomachs!—said Lapa.—Your unnatural behavior would starve your husband and your son if I weren't watching over them all the time. Look at your son...! Because I believe he is your son, right? He's thinner than a rapier... You, who have the audacity to call yourself his mother, don't you know that the first, the most sacred duty of a mother is to make her son gain weight?

en: This touched Young Jerry on a tender place; who adjured his mother to perform her first duty, and, whatever else she did or neglected, above all things to lay especial stress on the discharge of that maternal function so affectingly and delicately indicated by his other parent.
vi: That statement hit Jerry Jr.'s sore spot, so he begged his mother to fulfill this first duty, and regardless of whether she fulfilled any other duties, the most important thing was to show motherly love in a truly touching and delicious way as his father had said.
tr: These words had touched Little Jerry; he called for his mother to fulfill her first duty, as the matter of fulfilling the maternal duty, which his father had expressed in an impressive and gentle manner, had created a much greater impact on the child than anything else the woman had done or neglected.
es: These words moved the son so deeply that he implored his mother to fulfill, above all else, the maternal role with the same delicacy indicated by his father.

en: Thus the evening wore away with the Cruncher family, until Young Jerry was ordered to bed, and his mother, laid under similar injunctions, obeyed them. Mr. Cruncher beguiled the earlier watches of the night with solitary pipes, and did not start upon his excursion until nearly one o’clock. Towards that small and ghostly hour, he rose up from his chair, took a key out of his pocket, opened a locked cupboard, and brought forth a sack, a crowbar of convenient size, a rope and chain, and other fishing tackle of that nature. Disposing these articles about him in skilful manner, he bestowed a parting defiance on Mrs. Cruncher, extinguished the light, and went out.
vi: The evening passed with the Cruncher family like that, until young Jerry was made to go to bed and his mother had to follow the same order. Cruncher sat alone, smoking a few pipes to pass the time, waiting until nearly one o'clock in the morning to set off. At that dark, late hour, he got up from his chair, took a key out of his pocket, opened a cupboard, and pulled out a sack, a large crowbar, ropes with chains, and other tools needed for this special fishing trip. After skillfully tucking, wrapping, wearing, and hooking all those items around himself, Cruncher gave his wife a grumbling farewell, extinguished the light, and left.
tr: Little Jerry was sent to bed, and his mother was sent to sleep with a similar pacifier, thus ending the evening for the Cruncher family. Mr. Cruncher spent the early hours of the night smoking his pipe alone and waited for the clock to strike one to go for his walk. As the first and eerie hour of the day approached, he got up from his chair, took a key out of his pocket, opened a locked cabinet, and took out a sack, a crowbar of appropriate size, a rope, a chain, and other fishing equipment. After carefully placing these items in the sack, he gave Mrs. Cruncher one last scornful look, turned off the light, and went outside.
es: Thus the evening slipped away in the peaceful home of the Lapas, until mother and son were ordered to go to bed. The head of the family passed the hours of the night smoking solitary pipes until a little past midnight, when he got up to go out. Before that, however, he took from a cupboard, whose key he kept in his pocket, a sack, a rather thick iron bar, some ropes, a chain, and other similar fishing tools, which, once placed and arranged conveniently, he turned off the light and left.

en: Young Jerry, who had only made a feint of undressing when he went to bed, was not long after his father. Under cover of the darkness he followed out of the room, followed down the stairs, followed down the court, followed out into the streets. He was in no uneasiness concerning his getting into the house again, for it was full of lodgers, and the door stood ajar all night.
vi: Little Jerry, who had been pretending to change clothes and lie down on the bed, immediately got up and followed. Hidden in the darkness, he followed his father out of the room, down the stairs, into the yard, and then onto the street. Returning to this house was not difficult for him because the house was full of tenants and the door was ajar all night.
tr: Little Jerry, who just pretended to undress when he went to his room, went outside right after his father. He quietly left the room in the darkness that enveloped everything, went down the stairs, into the courtyard, and from there to the street. He had no worry about how to return home because there were plenty of tenants in the building and the door would stay ajar all night.
es: Minutes later, the curious child followed his father, having had the foresight to lie down dressed on the bed when he received the order to retire. Under the cover of night, he left his room, descended the stairs stealthily, and ventured through the deserted streets. As for returning to his father's house, he had no fear, for he knew very well that the door remained open all night.

en: Impelled by a laudable ambition to study the art and mystery of his father’s honest calling, Young Jerry, keeping as close to house fronts, walls, and doorways, as his eyes were close to one another, held his honoured parent in view. The honoured parent steering Northward, had not gone far, when he was joined by another disciple of Izaak Walton, and the two trudged on together.
vi: Driven by the commendable aspiration to learn the honest craft secrets of his father, young Jerry kept close to the house fronts, walls, and doorways as he walked, his eyes always closely following his esteemed father. As for the esteemed father, he had just headed a short distance north when he encountered another night fisherman, and the two proceeded together.
tr: With admirable determination, Little Jerry, trying to learn the intricacies and mysteries of his father's honorable work, followed him with his eyes on his honorable father, passing through door frames, wall edges, and door cracks. The honorable father, heading north, had not gone far when another disciple of Izaak Walton joined him, and they continued their arduous walk together.
es: Driven by the very commendable desire to learn the arts and mysteries of the nocturnal occupations of his honorable father, the boy, sticking to the walls of the houses, immersing himself in the doorways, tried not to lose sight of the hardworking author of his days for an instant. The latter took a northern direction, and he had not gone very far when he encountered a new disciple of Isaac Walton, in whose company he continued the journey.

en: Within half an hour from the first starting, they were beyond the winking lamps, and the more than winking watchmen, and were out upon a lonely road. Another fisherman was picked up here—and that so silently, that if Young Jerry had been superstitious, he might have supposed the second follower of the gentle craft to have, all of a sudden, split himself into two.
vi: After half an hour, they passed through the area with flickering streetlights and the watchmen who had already fallen asleep, and then reached a deserted road. Here, they picked up another fisherman - so silently that if Jerry were superstitious, he would have thought that the fisherman they had just met had suddenly split into two.
tr: Half an hour after setting out, they passed the flickering street lamps and the even more flickering watchmen, and reached a deserted road. Here, another fisherman joined them – the man had joined them so quietly that if Little Jerry had been a superstitious person, he might have thought that the second follower of the delicate task had suddenly split into two.
es: Half an hour later, they both walked without a word along a lonely path, where neither the gaze of the street lamps nor that of the night watchmen could reach. Another fisherman joined them on the path, but with such discretion and silence that if the boy had been superstitious, he surely would have believed that the man who first joined his father had suddenly and miraculously split into two.

en: The three went on, and Young Jerry went on, until the three stopped under a bank overhanging the road. Upon the top of the bank was a low brick wall, surmounted by an iron railing. In the shadow of bank and wall the three turned out of the road, and up a blind lane, of which the wall—there, risen to some eight or ten feet high—formed one side. Crouching down in a corner, peeping up the lane, the next object that Young Jerry saw, was the form of his honoured parent, pretty well defined against a watery and clouded moon, nimbly scaling an iron gate. He was soon over, and then the second fisherman got over, and then the third. They all dropped softly on the ground within the gate, and lay there a little—listening perhaps. Then, they moved away on their hands and knees.
vi: The three men continued walking and Jerry followed them until the three fishermen stopped under a bank that jutted out close to the road. On the bank was a low brick wall with an iron fence. In the darkness of the bank and the fence, the three men left the main road and turned into a dead-end alley beside the fence - which was up to three meters high in some places. Crouching in a dark corner, looking into the alley, young Jerry immediately saw the silhouette of his esteemed father clearly illuminated in the dim moonlight, swiftly climbing up the iron gate. His father climbed over quickly, followed by the second fisherman, then the third. All three quietly jumped down to the ground inside the gate and lay still for a while - perhaps listening. Then they crawled away on their hands and knees.
tr: The trio continued on their way and Jerry followed these three men until they stopped under an earthen embankment on the road. There was a low brick wall with iron railings on top of the embankment. The trio, in the shadow of the embankment and the wall, turned into a narrow dead-end road; the wall still extended along one side of the road – two and a half to three meters high. The next thing Jerry, crouched in a corner and watching this narrow road, saw was the figure of his honest father, very clearly visible in front of the pale and cloud-covered moon, hurriedly testing the weight of an iron gate. Soon after, his father jumped over it, followed by the second fisherman, and then the third fisherman jumped over. They all made a soft landing over the gate and lay on the ground for a while – probably listening to their surroundings. Then they proceeded on their hands and knees.
es: The three continued their march followed by Lapa's son, until they halted at the foot of an embankment whose slope rose above the path. On top of the slope, there ran a low brick wall, crowned by an iron fence. The men slid like ghosts along the slope, trying to take cover in its shadow, until they reached an indentation that gave access to a sort of alley, one side of which, formed by the brick wall, was about ten feet high. In the whitish light of the moon, the boy could see that the honest tradesman to whom he owed his existence was climbing the iron fence with unparalleled agility. He was immediately followed by the second fisherman, and then by the third. The three reached the ground inside the fence, where they remained for a few minutes, lying on the ground... probably listening. Then they advanced, crawling on their hands and knees.

en: It was now Young Jerry’s turn to approach the gate: which he did, holding his breath. Crouching down again in a corner there, and looking in, he made out the three fishermen creeping through some rank grass! and all the gravestones in the churchyard—it was a large churchyard that they were in—looking on like ghosts in white, while the church tower itself looked on like the ghost of a monstrous giant. They did not creep far, before they stopped and stood upright. And then they began to fish.
vi: Now it's Jerry's turn to sneak to the gate; he holds his breath and tiptoes forward. Retreating into the dark corner and looking in, it noticed the shadows of three people fishing, crawling through the dense grass, surrounded by tombstones - they were in a vast cemetery - the white tombstones like ghosts while the church tower rose high like the shadow of a giant monster. The three people crawled a short distance and then stood up. And they began their night fishing.
tr: Now it was Little Jerry's turn to jump from the door. He jumped, holding his breath. When he crouched in a corner again and looked at them, he saw the three fishermen crawling among the thick grass and all those tombstones in the churchyard – it was a big yard – the tombstones looked like ghosts in white, and the church tower looked like the ghost of a terrible giant. Soon they stopped crawling, stood up, and began to fish.
es: The boy approached the gate, holding his breath. From a corner where he crouched, he saw the three fishermen crawling like snakes through the tall grass that covered the ground... and among many crosses and tombstones. They were in a cemetery, and they looked like dreadful ghosts being watched by an even more dreadful, more monstrous ghost: the tower of the nearby church, a terrifying giant tasked with guarding the peace of the dead. They did not advance much further. The boy soon noticed that they straightened up and began to fish.

en: They fished with a spade, at first. Presently the honoured parent appeared to be adjusting some instrument like a great corkscrew. Whatever tools they worked with, they worked hard, until the awful striking of the church clock so terrified Young Jerry, that he made off, with his hair as stiff as his father’s.
vi: At first, they fished with a shovel. Then Jerry's venerable father seemed to be adjusting a tool that looked like a gigantic corkscrew. Whatever tool they used, they worked hard until the church clock bell struck a terrifying chime, causing young Jerry to flee in fright, his hair standing on end just like his father's.
tr: They started fishing with a garden spade. Then the honorable father continued with a tool that resembled a large corkscrew. No matter what tool they used, they were working hard, but the church clock struck so terribly that it scared Little Jerry so much that, with his hair standing up like his father's, he didn't know how to run away.
es: They first fished with a hoe. Shortly after, the honorable Lapa prepared an instrument similar to an enormous corkscrew. Whatever fishing tools they used, they handled them with unusual fervor. The spikes that crowned the boy's head acquired the steely hardness of his father's when the giant guardian of the city of the dead let out slow, resonant, grave, terrifying, the two o'clock in the morning.

en: But, his long-cherished desire to know more about these matters, not only stopped him in his running away, but lured him back again. They were still fishing perseveringly, when he peeped in at the gate for the second time; but, now they seemed to have got a bite. There was a screwing and complaining sound down below, and their bent figures were strained, as if by a weight. By slow degrees the weight broke away the earth upon it, and came to the surface. Young Jerry very well knew what it would be; but, when he saw it, and saw his honoured parent about to wrench it open, he was so frightened, being new to the sight, that he made off again, and never stopped until he had run a mile or more.
vi: However, the long-held desire to understand not only prevented it from running away but also pulled it back. The three others were still persistently fishing at night when little Jerry peeked through the gate again; but this time, it seemed there were fish biting. From the dug hole came creaking and rumbling sounds, and the three figures above were straining as if something very heavy was pulling them down. Bit by bit, that heavy object was pulled up from the surrounding soil and emerged to the surface. Little Jerry already knew what it was, but when he first saw it with his own eyes, and saw his esteemed father about to pry it out, he was so terrified that he ran away, this time running nonstop for several kilometers.
tr: But the desire to learn what was happening inside him, which he had been carrying for a while, soon stopped him and even made him turn back. When he hid by the door for the second time and watched them, they were still fishing with determination, but this time it seemed like something had been caught on the line. Sounds of struggling and whining came from below, and the bodies of the men, bent forward, tensed as if something was pulling them down. Slowly, the weight slipped out of the soil and surfaced. Little Jerry had understood what was going to come out, but when he saw it, moreover, when he saw that his honorable father was about to pull and open it, he was so terrified by this sight he was not used to that he started running without looking back, and only after running a mile or two did he stop.
es: The boy embarked on a reckless escape; but his desire to know was so great that not only did he stop after a short distance, but it also prompted him to return to the gate. He saw that the three men continued fishing, and assumed they had caught something upon observing that the fishermen seemed bent over and as if doubled, making efforts aimed at pulling out a very heavy fish. Indeed, it was so: little by little they were hoisting the fish until it surfaced. The shape of the fish was unmistakable; but when the boy saw that his father was about to open it, he was seized by such panic that he took off in a frantic run, not stopping or slowing down until he had covered more than a mile of ground.

en: He would not have stopped then, for anything less necessary than breath, it being a spectral sort of race that he ran, and one highly desirable to get to the end of. He had a strong idea that the coffin he had seen was running after him; and, pictured as hopping on behind him, bolt upright, upon its narrow end, always on the point of overtaking him and hopping on at his side—perhaps taking his arm—it was a pursuer to shun. It was an inconsistent and ubiquitous fiend too, for, while it was making the whole night behind him dreadful, he darted out into the roadway to avoid dark alleys, fearful of its coming hopping out of them like a dropsical boy’s kite without tail and wings. It hid in doorways too, rubbing its horrible shoulders against doors, and drawing them up to its ears, as if it were laughing. It got into shadows on the road, and lay cunningly on its back to trip him up. All this time it was incessantly hopping on behind and gaining on him, so that when the boy got to his own door he had reason for being half dead. And even then it would not leave him, but followed him upstairs with a bump on every stair, scrambled into bed with him, and bumped down, dead and heavy, on his breast when he fell asleep.
vi: At that moment, he ran as fast as he could, only stopping to catch his breath, as if it were a ghostly race with the ultimate desire to reach the finish line. The boy was convinced that the coffin he had just seen was chasing after him; and he imagined that terrifying thing standing on one end, jumping onto his back, about to catch up and grab him - perhaps it would seize his arm - and he had to run for his life. The ghostly coffin appeared and disappeared, present everywhere, so when the entire darkness behind him turned into horror, the boy had to dash into the middle of the road to avoid the dark alleys, fearing that ghost would leap out from there like a kite with its wings and tail cut off. The ghost also hid at the doorways, rubbing its ghastly shoulders against the doors, then hunching its shoulders and tucking its neck as if laughing loudly. The ghost hid in the darkness on the road, lying on its back waiting to trip him. And there was always a ghost jumping right behind, chasing closely, so that even when the boy reached his house, he still hadn't recovered his wits. Even then, the ghost didn't let go but followed the boy upstairs, pounding on the steps, jumping onto the bed with him, and ramming its head into his chest, pushing him into a deep, exhausted sleep.
tr: Even if he didn't need to catch his breath, he wouldn't stop; it was as if he was racing against ghosts, and his only desire was for this race to end. He had a strong belief that the coffin he had just seen was chasing him; it seemed to be hopping and bouncing after him, upright on its narrow side, and at any moment it could catch up to him and hop right beside him – maybe it would grab him by the arm – the chase never ended. It was like a demon whose actions were unclear and whose emergence was unpredictable, and as it had made the night he left behind utterly terrifying, Little Jerry burst out from the dark side streets onto the main road and fled from it in terror, like a skinny child's tailless and wingless kite, leaping away in fright. The demon also hid in door cracks, rubbing its terrifying shoulders against the doors and pulling them up to its ears as if it were laughing. It blended into the other shadows on the road. It cunningly lay on its back on the ground to trip Little Jerry. All this time, it never stopped hopping behind the child and didn't leave him alone; when he finally reached the door of their house, Little Jerry was exhausted. But even then, the demon hadn't left him alone; it had followed him up the stairs with thudding steps, entered the bed with him, and when the child fell asleep, it settled heavily on his chest.
es: Not even then would he have stopped if he hadn't run out of breath, for he wasn't fleeing from images conjured by fear, but from specters that were haunting him terribly. The coffin he had seen was right on his heels, jumping over the stones and dirt of the path in a perpendicular position and on its narrowest end, determined to catch up to him and place itself by his side... perhaps to cling to his arm. That diabolical coffin must have been a marvel of incongruity and ubiquity, for it would leap among the black rows of trees lining the path as soon as it would fly over the thick treetops, like a kite without a tail or wings. It also hid in the doorways, against which it rubbed its horrible ribs, producing a sound similar to hollow laughter. It constantly gained ground on the boy in that fantastic race. When the pursued reached the door of his house, he was half-dead with fear. Not even after taking refuge inside did he find himself free from the relentless pursuit of the coffin, which climbed the stairs after him, jumping over the steps, and lay down in his bed, and climbed onto his chest when sleep or terror overcame the unfortunate curious one.

en: From his oppressed slumber, Young Jerry in his closet was awakened after daybreak and before sunrise, by the presence of his father in the family room. Something had gone wrong with him; at least, so Young Jerry inferred, from the circumstance of his holding Mrs. Cruncher by the ears, and knocking the back of her head against the head-board of the bed.
vi: The sky had just begun to brighten, dawn had not yet broken when little Jerry, lying in the room, woke up from his heavy sleep because of the sound of his father in the outer room. His father must have encountered something unpleasant; at least, little Jerry could deduce that much when he saw Cruncher grabbing his wife's ears and banging her head against the headboard.
tr: Little Jerry in his small room was awakened from this troubled sleep at dawn, before the sun had risen, by the sounds coming from his father and mother's bedroom. Seeing his father holding Ms. Cruncher by the ears and banging the back of her head against the bedpost, it seemed things had gone wrong for his father; at least, that's what Little Jerry thought.
es: The presence of Jeremías Lapa in the boy's narrow room ended his restless sleep before the first rays of the sun appeared over the earth. Fortune must have been unkind to him that night; at least, that is what his son inferred from the fact that he had his wife by the ears and was shaking her without consideration.

en: “I told you I would,” said Mr. Cruncher, “and I did.”
vi: − I told you already, - Cruncher said, - I said I would do it.
tr: "I told you, I would do it," said Mr. Cruncher, "and I did.""
es: —I offered it to you, and I'm fulfilling it!—said Jeremiah.

en: “Jerry, Jerry, Jerry!” his wife implored.
vi: - Jerry, Jerry, Jerry! - His wife pleaded.
tr: "Jerry, Jerry, Jerry!" his wife pleaded.
es: —For God's sake, Jeremiah!—exclaimed his wife with a pleading tone.

en: “You oppose yourself to the profit of the business,” said Jerry, “and me and my partners suffer. You was to honour and obey; why the devil don’t you?”
vi: − When there's profit in business, you don't accept it, - Jerry said, you keep cursing me and my friends with bad luck. I tell you but you don't listen to me, don't respect me, why is that?
tr: "We didn't gain anything because of you," said Jerry, "you are also causing trouble in our partnership. You should have just stayed put, why didn't you listen to me?"
es: —You insist on ruining my business, without considering that you are harming me and my associates. Your obligation is to obey: why don't you do it?

en: “I try to be a good wife, Jerry,” the poor woman protested, with tears.
vi: − I'm just trying to be a good wife, Jerry, - the miserable woman cried and argued back.
tr: The poor woman, in tears, protested, "I'm trying to be a good wife, Jerry."
es: —I strive to be an honorable woman! —replied the unfortunate one, shedding tears.

en: “Is it being a good wife to oppose your husband’s business? Is it honouring your husband to dishonour his business? Is it obeying your husband to disobey him on the wital subject of his business?”
vi: − You say you're being a good wife but curse your husband with bad luck in business? You say you respect your husband but sabotage his work? You say you listen to your husband but why don't you listen to the important things?
tr: "Are you being a good wife by ruining your husband's work? Will you honor him by sabotaging his work? Are you obeying your husband by not following what he says about his important work?"
es: —And do you think that honesty consists of ruining your husband's business? Do you think you honor your husband by dishonoring his affairs?

en: “You hadn’t taken to the dreadful business then, Jerry.”
vi: − When I said that, you weren't doing this terrible job, Jerry.
tr: "Back then, you weren't doing this terrible job, Jerry.""
es: —You shouldn't engage in such horrible businesses, Jeremiah!

en: “It’s enough for you,” retorted Mr. Cruncher, “to be the wife of a honest tradesman, and not to occupy your female mind with calculations when he took to his trade or when he didn’t. A honouring and obeying wife would let his trade alone altogether. Call yourself a religious woman? If you’re a religious woman, give me a irreligious one! You have no more nat’ral sense of duty than the bed of this here Thames river has of a pile, and similarly it must be knocked into you.”
vi: − Having a husband who works honestly is fortunate for you, Cruncher retorted, - but whether the husband works or doesn't work is not something for you women to calculate. Being a wife who respects her husband, listens to her husband, means letting him work in peace. You think you're pious? If you're pious, I'd rather marry an impious woman! Your sense of responsibility is no better than a stake driven into the bottom of the Thames out there; I have to hammer it into your head like that stake for you to understand.
tr: "It's enough that you're the wife of an honest tradesman," retorted Mr. Cruncher, "so don't stick your nose into these matters with that woman's mind of yours. A woman who respects her husband and obeys him does not interfere in his affairs. Do you now call yourself pious? If you are a pious woman, go find me an impious one! Your sense of duty is not even as much as that stake in the Thames River; that stake should be driven into you instead."
es: —It should be enough for you to be the wife of an honest tradesman and not to let your narrow feminine understanding entertain calculations or judgments about the nature of the business your husband does or does not do. The woman who is honest and obedient does not meddle in what is the exclusive concern of her husband. And you call yourself religious? You call yourself honest? If you are religious, if you are honest, give me irreligious and dishonorable women! The altercation, which was being held in a low voice, came to an end when Jeremiah, removing his mud-covered boots, lay down on the ground, face up with his hands placed under his head as a pillow.

en: The altercation was conducted in a low tone of voice, and terminated in the honest tradesman’s kicking off his clay-soiled boots, and lying down at his length on the floor. After taking a timid peep at him lying on his back, with his rusty hands under his head for a pillow, his son lay down too, and fell asleep again.
vi: The argument happened quietly and ended with the honest worker kicking off his clay-covered boots from his feet and lying down on the floor. After a moment of timidly glancing at his father lying on his back, with rust-stained hands under his head as a pillow, the son also lay down to continue sleeping.
tr: This argument had taken place in a low voice and ended after the honest shopkeeper kicked off his muddy boots and lay down full length on the ground. After casting a timid glance at his father, who was lying on his back with his rusty hands under his head as a pillow, his son also lay down beside him and fell back asleep.
es: The altercation, which was being held in a low voice, came to an end when Jeremiah, removing his mud-covered boots, lay down on the ground, face up with his hands placed under his head as a pillow. The son, in his desire to imitate the father, lay back down on the bed, soon falling asleep.

en: There was no fish for breakfast, and not much of anything else. Mr. Cruncher was out of spirits, and out of temper, and kept an iron pot-lid by him as a projectile for the correction of Mrs. Cruncher, in case he should observe any symptoms of her saying Grace. He was brushed and washed at the usual hour, and set off with his son to pursue his ostensible calling.
vi: That morning's breakfast had no fish, and there was nothing else either. Cruncher was disheartened and irritable, holding the tin lid as if it were a missile ready to be launched to punish his wife if he saw any sign on her face that she was secretly praying. He brushed his teeth and washed his face at the usual time, then continued with his son to go about their daytime pretense work.
tr: There was no fish for breakfast, and there were very few other foods as well. Mr. Cruncher was both grumpy and angry, and he had an iron pot lid with him to throw at Mrs. Cruncher if he noticed any sign of her saying a prayer of thanks. After washing his face and combing his hair at the usual time, he set off with his son towards his ostensible duty.
es: After lunch, which did not include any fish dishes, and one could say no other delicacies either, Mr. Jeremiah, who, by the way, was angrier than ever, well-groomed and washed, went out with his son and took the road to Tellson's Bank.

en: Young Jerry, walking with the stool under his arm at his father’s side along sunny and crowded Fleet-street, was a very different Young Jerry from him of the previous night, running home through darkness and solitude from his grim pursuer. His cunning was fresh with the day, and his qualms were gone with the night—in which particulars it is not improbable that he had compeers in Fleet-street and the City of London, that fine morning.
vi: Carrying the stool under his arm, walking beside his father on the bustling, sunlit Fleet Street, young Jerry this morning was completely different from the young Jerry who had run home alone in the dark last night, chased by a ghostly coffin. The boy's fear had dissipated with the night, and the new day had returned to him his familiar mischievous look - and many of the people jostling on Fleet Street and in the city of London on that beautiful morning felt the same way as the little boy.
tr: On the sunny and crowded Fleet Street, Little Jerry, walking beside his father with his stool under his arm, was very different from the Little Jerry who had fled from his cruel pursuer in the darkness and desolation of the previous night. His spirits had been refreshed by the dawn of the new day, and his worries had ended with the night – after all, it was not unexpected to have his peers on Fleet Street and in the city of London on such a beautiful morning.
es: The young scion of the honorable tradesman who was walking beside him on Fleet Street was no longer the same person who the previous night had fled in terror along solitary paths from his terrible pursuer. With the light of day, he regained his usual boldness, and his qualms and scruples ended with the night... in whose particulars it is more than likely that he had many companions on the lively Fleet Street.

en: “Father,” said Young Jerry, as they walked along: taking care to keep at arm’s length and to have the stool well between them: “what’s a Resurrection-Man?”
vi: Father, - young Jerry said as they walked, carefully keeping a stride's distance from his father and using the stool as a barrier, - what kind of job is body-snatching, father?
tr: "Dad," said Little Jerry as they walked –he was trying to keep an arm's length distance and to hold the stool between himself and his father– "who is the one that brings a man out of the grave?"
es: —Father—said the boy during the journey,—what is a gravedigger?

en: Mr. Cruncher came to a stop on the pavement before he answered, “How should I know?”
vi: Cruncher paused for a moment on the sidewalk before answering: − How should I know?
tr: Mr. Cruncher paused on the sidewalk for a moment before answering, "How should I know?"
es: The good Lapa could not answer such an unexpected question without first standing as if nailed to the spot. —How should I know!—he finally replied.

en: “I thought you knowed everything, father,” said the artless boy.
vi: − I thought you knew everything, father, - the boy said honestly.
tr: "I used to think you knew everything, dad," said the child innocently.
es: —I thought you knew everything, Father—replied the candid boy.

en: “Hem! Well,” returned Mr. Cruncher, going on again, and lifting off his hat to give his spikes free play, “he’s a tradesman.”
vi: − Huh! Fine! - Cruncher continued walking, speaking as he took off his hat to let his spiky hair free, - it's a business trade. −
tr: "Hmm! Well," replied Mr. Cruncher, continuing to walk and taking off his hat to free his spiky hair, "he is a tradesman."
es: —Hmm! Well... look!—said Jeremías Lapa, after taking off his hat and scratching his forehead. —A gravedigger is an honest craftsman, a tradesman.

en: “What’s his goods, father?” asked the brisk Young Jerry.
vi: What do you sell, dad? - Young Jerry quickly asked.
tr: "Well, what does he sell, dad?" asked the curious Little Jerry.
es: —What line of business are you in?

en: “His goods,” said Mr. Cruncher, after turning it over in his mind, “is a branch of Scientific goods.”
vi: − They are items... - Cruncher pondered for a moment before answering, - ... of a scientific nature*.
tr: "The things he sells," said Mr. Cruncher, after weighing what he was going to say in his mind, "are used in some scientific studies."
es: —He trades... in scientific goods of a special nature.

en: “Persons’ bodies, ain’t it, father?” asked the lively boy.
vi: − A dead body, right dad? - The kid cheerfully asked.
tr: "Human bodies, you mean, dad?" the child asked excitedly this time.
es: —On human corpses; right, father?

en: “I believe it is something of that sort,” said Mr. Cruncher.
vi: − I think it's something like that, - Cruncher replied.
tr: "I suppose something like that," said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —I think you're not entirely off track, son.

en: “Oh, father, I should so like to be a Resurrection-Man when I’m quite growed up!”
vi: − Oh, dad, I want to grow up to be a body snatcher like you!
tr: "Oh dad, when I grow up, I want to be a grave robber too then!"
es: —Oh father! I would like to be a gravedigger when I become a man! The proposition filled the father with noble pride.

en: Mr. Cruncher was soothed, but shook his head in a dubious and moral way. “It depends upon how you dewelop your talents. Be careful to dewelop your talents, and never to say no more than you can help to nobody, and there’s no telling at the present time what you may not come to be fit for.” As Young Jerry, thus encouraged, went on a few yards in advance, to plant the stool in the shadow of the Bar, Mr. Cruncher added to himself: “Jerry, you honest tradesman, there’s hopes wot that boy will yet be a blessing to you, and a recompense to you for his mother!”
vi: Cruncher felt happy inside, but still shook his head, showing a sense of morality and doubt. − It depends on how skilled you are. You must practice to become skilled, and never tell anyone what doesn't need to be said; for now, it's impossible to say if you can do that job. Hearing that, little Jerry eagerly ran a few steps ahead of his father, placing the stool in the shade of the Temple Bar gate.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was relieved but shook his head from side to side in an undecided and virtuous manner. "It depends on how you develop your skills. Strive to improve your skills and don't promise people more than you can deliver; we can't know yet what will be suitable for you." Encouraged by these words, when Jerry stepped a few paces ahead of his father to place the stool in the shadow of Temple Bar, Mr. Cruncher said to himself, "Honest tradesman Jerry, you'll see, this child will be a great blessing for you and will make up for his mother's shortcomings!"
es: However, shaking his head as if in doubt, he replied: —It will depend on the heights your talents can reach. Try to encourage their development, to which the example I set will powerfully contribute. Today it is premature to talk about what you will do or not do in the future. Moments later, while the boy was going to place the bench in the shade of the Temple Court building, Jeremías Lapa murmured to himself: —Friend Jeremías, honorable craftsman; you can harbor well-founded hopes that your son will, in time, become a treasure that will compensate for your misfortune of having an unnatural wife.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: Hearing that, little Jerry eagerly ran a few steps ahead of his father, placing the stool in the shade of the Temple Bar gate.
tr: XV
es: Chapter XV.

en: Knitting
vi: Cruncher followed behind, thinking to himself: "Jerry, an honest worker like you might just find this little one bringing luck, making up for his mother!"
tr: Knitting
es: KNITTING

en: There had been earlier drinking than usual in the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge. As early as six o’clock in the morning, sallow faces peeping through its barred windows had descried other faces within, bending over measures of wine. Monsieur Defarge sold a very thin wine at the best of times, but it would seem to have been an unusually thin wine that he sold at this time. A sour wine, moreover, or a souring, for its influence on the mood of those who drank it was to make them gloomy. No vivacious Bacchanalian flame leaped out of the pressed grape of Monsieur Defarge: but, a smouldering fire that burnt in the dark, lay hidden in the dregs of it.
vi: 15. The wine shop of Defarge had customers drinking earlier than usual. It's only six in the morning, and the haggard faces standing outside the barred windows looking in already see other faces inside bent over their glasses. Mr. Defarge sells very weak wine even at his best, but now the wine he sells is even weaker. Weak and sour, just looking at the gloomy faces of the drinkers tells you what the wine is like. The pressed grapes of Monsieur Defarge yield no passionate fervor for the drinkers, only a faint warmth hidden in the dregs.
tr: Drinking had started earlier than usual at Monsieur Defarge's wine shop. At six in the morning, pale faces peering through the barred windows saw other faces bent over wine glasses inside. Even in the best of times, Monsieur Defarge always sold wine diluted with water, but lately, the wine he sold was even more diluted. It was a sour wine, moreover, it soured its surroundings, because it affected the mood of those who drank it, making them melancholic. The sparks of Bacchic joy that sprang from Monsieur Defarge's pressed grapes were not bright flames, but a fire smoldering in the dark, hidden in the pulp of the grapes.
es: That day, at Mr. Defarge's tavern, the libations had begun earlier than usual. When at six in the morning, pale faces approached the bars of the grates that protected the windows, they saw other pale faces bent over their respective wine cups. As a general rule, the wine sold at Defarge's tavern had received the healthy waters of baptism, but the wine that these early Bacchic drinkers were consuming on this occasion must have been sour, or at least had the property of souring the temperament of those who drank it. The juice of the grapes contained in Defarge's barrels did not ignite cheerful Bacchic flames, but a latent fire, a fire that burned without coming to the surface.

en: This had been the third morning in succession, on which there had been early drinking at the wine-shop of Monsieur Defarge. It had begun on Monday, and here was Wednesday come. There had been more of early brooding than drinking; for, many men had listened and whispered and slunk about there from the time of the opening of the door, who could not have laid a piece of money on the counter to save their souls. These were to the full as interested in the place, however, as if they could have commanded whole barrels of wine; and they glided from seat to seat, and from corner to corner, swallowing talk in lieu of drink, with greedy looks.
vi: This is the third consecutive day that Mr. Defarge's wine shop has had customers since early morning. It started on Monday, and now it's already Wednesday. The guests came there more to ponder than to drink; since the shop opened, many people have come to listen, whisper, and linger without spending a single penny at the counter to save their souls. But in the shop, they acted extremely eager as if they could easily buy up all the barrels; and they glided from one spot to another, from corner to corner, their faces greedily absorbing words instead of wine.
tr: For three consecutive days, early drinking had started at Monsieur Defarge's place. This situation had begun on Monday, and today was Wednesday. In fact, people were more deep in thought than drinking; many didn't have a penny to pay the bill, yet as soon as the shop opened, they would slip inside, listen to the conversations, and whisper among themselves. All they cared about was finding out what was happening, but they would wander from table to table, corner to corner, with an attitude as if they could buy all the wine barrels in the shop, greedily sipping the conversations instead of the wine.
es: Three mornings had already passed since the sacrifices to Bacchus began very early in Defarge's tavern. They started on Monday and now it was Wednesday. It is true that there was more talking and listening than drinking, for there was no shortage of early risers who entered the establishment as soon as the door opened, and for whom it would have been impossible to place a coin on the counter, even if their soul's salvation depended on it. Nevertheless, they showed the same contentment as if they had been served entire barrels of wine; you could see them moving from one bench to another, shifting from one corner to another, eagerly swallowing paragraphs of conversation instead of savoring sips of wine.

en: Notwithstanding an unusual flow of company, the master of the wine-shop was not visible. He was not missed; for, nobody who crossed the threshold looked for him, nobody asked for him, nobody wondered to see only Madame Defarge in her seat, presiding over the distribution of wine, with a bowl of battered small coins before her, as much defaced and beaten out of their original impress as the small coinage of humanity from whose ragged pockets they had come.
vi: The guests were more numerous than usual, yet the owner was nowhere to be seen. No one paid attention to the owner's absence because those who entered the tavern were not looking for him, did not need to meet him, and no one was surprised to see only Mrs. Defarge sitting at the counter overseeing the sale of liquor; in front of her was a bowl containing chipped coins, the embossed faces on the coins worn down and unrecognizable from countless times rubbing against tattered pockets.
tr: Despite this unusual crowd, the owner of the wine shop was nowhere to be seen. Not that his absence was felt; no one entering through the door was looking for him or asking about him, and no one was pondering why only –sitting with a bowl containing money as tattered, worn, and frayed as the pockets they came from, managing the distribution of the wine– Madame Defarge was there.
es: Although the crowd was larger than usual, the innkeeper had not considered it necessary to make himself visible. The patrons should not have given importance to Defarge's absence, since no one asked about him, no one showed a desire to see him, no one was surprised to see Mrs. Defarge alone, sitting behind the counter, overseeing the distribution of wine and collecting counterfeit coins, from which the images and crests stamped by the die had disappeared. They were coins worthy of the ragged pockets from which they had come.

en: A suspended interest and a prevalent absence of mind, were perhaps observed by the spies who looked in at the wine-shop, as they looked in at every place, high and low, from the king’s palace to the criminal’s gaol. Games at cards languished, players at dominoes musingly built towers with them, drinkers drew figures on the tables with spilt drops of wine, Madame Defarge herself picked out the pattern on her sleeve with her toothpick, and saw and heard something inaudible and invisible a long way off.
vi: If any spy were to look into this tavern - as is their habit of prying everywhere, regardless of the place's status, from the royal palace to the dungeon - they would see an atmosphere of boredom and lethargy enveloping the inside. The card games dragged on wearily, the domino players contemplatively built towers with the pieces, the drinkers dipped their fingers into spilled drops of liquor to doodle on the table, while Madame Defarge herself poked at her sleeve with the tip of a toothpick, her face distant as if she were hearing and seeing something silent and invisible.
tr: From the king's palace to the prisoners' dungeon, spies scattered everywhere probably observed a general distraction with suspended curiosity when they looked at this wine shop. The card players had become sluggish, the domino players were building towers out of the pieces in deep thought, the wine drinkers were drawing shapes on their tables with spilled wine drops, and Madam Defarge, while fiddling with the patterns on her knitting with a toothpick, occasionally gazed into the distance as if she had seen or heard something.
es: Boredom, absolute lack of interest, and an excess of annoyance were the only things that the spies, who undoubtedly watched from the street as they watched all places, high and low, from the king's palace to the criminal's cell, would have noticed in the tavern. The playing cards languished, the domino players built castles with the tiles, the drinkers drew faces on the tables with the drops of wine that fell from the cups, and Mrs. Defarge followed the patterns on her sleeve with a toothpick, as if she heard something that did not strike her eardrums and saw things that did not impress her retina.

en: Thus, Saint Antoine in this vinous feature of his, until midday. It was high noontide, when two dusty men passed through his streets and under his swinging lamps: of whom, one was Monsieur Defarge: the other a mender of roads in a blue cap. All adust and athirst, the two entered the wine-shop. Their arrival had lighted a kind of fire in the breast of Saint Antoine, fast spreading as they came along, which stirred and flickered in flames of faces at most doors and windows. Yet, no one had followed them, and no man spoke when they entered the wine-shop, though the eyes of every man there were turned upon them.
vi: The Saint Antoine district at the tavern remained the same until noon. When the sun was at its peak, two dusty travelers passed through the streets, under the hanging lamps; one was Mr. Defarge, the other was a road worker wearing a green hat. Dirty and thirsty, the two entered the tavern. Their appearance was like lighting a fire right in the heart of Saint Antoine; wherever they went, the fire spread, flickering on the faces standing at the entrances and windows. However, no one followed, no one said anything when the two entered the tavern, although everyone's eyes were on them.
tr: St. Antoine's drunken state continued until noon. When two men passed through these streets and under their swinging lamps, covered in dust and dirt, the sun was directly overhead. One was Monsieur Defarge, the other was a road worker with a blue cap. Covered in dust from head to toe and parched with thirst, they rushed into the wine shop. Their arrival had set St. Antoine's heart ablaze, spreading as they walked, igniting and trembling the faces of people at the doors and windows. Yet no one followed them, and when they entered the wine shop, no one said a word to them, but all eyes were on them.
es: Until noon, the characteristics of San Antonio in its wine-like aspect did not change at all. Shortly after twelve, two men covered in dust arrived, one of whom was Mr. Defarge, and the other a road worker, both with stern and thirsty expressions, who entered the tavern. Their arrival ignited in the heart of San Antonio burning sparks that, spreading outside the tavern, soon turned into flames, and these in turn into human faces that filled all the doors and windows of the neighborhood. No one followed the dusty travelers, no one addressed a single word to them, but everyone fixed their eyes on them.

en: “Good day, gentlemen!” said Monsieur Defarge.
vi: − Hello, everyone! - Defarge spoke up.
tr: "Hello gentlemen!" said Monsieur Defarge.
es: —Good morning!—answered a large chorus.

en: It may have been a signal for loosening the general tongue. It elicited an answering chorus of “Good day!”
vi: Perhaps it is a sign for every tongue to start working. Everyone simultaneously opened their mouths and said, "Hello!".
tr: It was as if this was a signal given to loosen the tongues of the people. In response, they all opened up and said in unison, "Hello!"
es: —Good morning!—answered a large chorus.

en: “It is bad weather, gentlemen,” said Defarge, shaking his head.
vi: − Today is a bad day, ladies and gentlemen, - Defarge said while shaking his head.
tr: "The weather is very bad, gentlemen!" said Defarge, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —Bad weather, gentlemen—replied Defarge, shaking his head.

en: Upon which, every man looked at his neighbour, and then all cast down their eyes and sat silent. Except one man, who got up and went out.
vi: Hearing that, everyone looked at each other and then all lowered their heads and sat silently. Except for one person who stood up and went outside.
tr: Upon this, everyone looked at the person next to them, then lowered their eyes and sat quietly. But one of them had stood up and gone outside.
es: Each of those present looked at their neighbor, and then, everyone lowered their eyes to the ground and remained silent. Only one, as an exception, got up from their seat and left.

en: “My wife,” said Defarge aloud, addressing Madame Defarge: “I have travelled certain leagues with this good mender of roads, called Jacques. I met him—by accident—a day and half’s journey out of Paris. He is a good child, this mender of roads, called Jacques. Give him to drink, my wife!”
vi: − Hey darling, - Defarge said loudly to Madame Defarge, - I traveled a stretch with this respectable road mender named Jacques. I met him, just by chance, when I was a day and a half out of Paris. This fellow is charming, this road mender named Jacques. Give him a drink, darling!
