tr: Defarge called out loudly, "Madam," to Madam Defarge: "Look, I have traveled to many places with this kind-hearted road worker named Jacques. I met him –by chance– in a place one and a half days away from Paris. His name is Jacques, this road worker is a good boy. Give him a drink, madam!"
es: —My dear wife—continued Defarge,—I have traveled a portion of leagues in the company of this good walker, whose name is Santiago. I found him... by chance, a day and a half from Paris. He is a good boy and his name is Santiago... Give him a drink, dear!

en: A second man got up and went out. Madame Defarge set wine before the mender of roads called Jacques, who doffed his blue cap to the company, and drank. In the breast of his blouse he carried some coarse dark bread; he ate of this between whiles, and sat munching and drinking near Madame Defarge’s counter. A third man got up and went out.
vi: Another person stood up and went outside. Madame Defarge placed a glass of wine in front of Jacques the road mender, he lifted his green cap to greet everyone and then drank. In his chest pocket, he had some pieces of black bread; from time to time, he nibbled on a piece and sat at Madame Defarge's counter, drinking wine and nibbling. Another person stood up and went outside.
tr: A man got up and went outside. Madame Defarge took off her blue hat, greeted the crowd, and placed the wine in front of Jacques, the road worker, who drank it. The man had taken out a black bread with grains from his coat; he occasionally took a bite from it, eating and drinking noisily next to Madame Defarge's counter. At that moment, a third man got up and left the shop.
es: Another man stood up and left the tavern. Mrs. Defarge served a glass of wine to the good road worker, who greeted her by taking off the blue cap that covered his head, and drank. He took a piece of rough, black bread from his bosom, sat down next to the counter, and began to eat and drink. Another patron, the third one, stood up and left the tavern.

en: Defarge refreshed himself with a draught of wine—but, he took less than was given to the stranger, as being himself a man to whom it was no rarity—and stood waiting until the countryman had made his breakfast. He looked at no one present, and no one now looked at him; not even Madame Defarge, who had taken up her knitting, and was at work.
vi: Defarge also quenched his thirst with a freshly poured glass of wine - but his glass was less than the guest's while wine was something he never lacked - and just stood waiting until the peasant finished his breakfast. Defarge didn't look at anyone around and no one looked at him; even Madame Defarge, who was engrossed in her usual knitting work.
tr: Defarge took a sip of his wine—his wine was less than the man he brought with him, but after all, he always had it at hand—and refreshed himself, waiting for the peasant to finish his breakfast. The man was not looking at anyone there, and no one was looking at him now; not even Madam Defarge, who lifted her knitting and tended to the shop.
es: Defarge served himself another glass of wine, smaller than the one served to the road-mender, and waited for him to finish his refreshment. He neither looked at any of those present, nor did any of those present look back at him. Madame Defarge had taken the knitting in her hands and worked without looking up and without speaking.

en: “Have you finished your repast, friend?” he asked, in due season.
vi: Finished eating, my friend? - After a while, Defarge finally spoke.
tr: "Have you finished your meal, my friend?" asked Defarge, when the time came.
es: —Have you finished lunch already?—asked the innkeeper to the laborer after noticing that he wasn't eating.

en: “Yes, thank you.”
vi: − Alright, thank you.
tr: "Yes, thank you.""
es: —Yes; thank you very much.

en: “Come, then! You shall see the apartment that I told you you could occupy. It will suit you to a marvel.”
vi: − Let's go then! You will see the room where you will stay as I mentioned. It will definitely suit your taste very much.
tr: "Then come on! Let me show you the apartment I said you could stay in. It's just the right place for you."
es: —Yes; thank you very much. —Then, let's go: I will show you the room I mentioned you would occupy, and which I certainly assure you will be to your liking.

en: Out of the wine-shop into the street, out of the street into a courtyard, out of the courtyard up a steep staircase, out of the staircase into a garret—formerly the garret where a white-haired man sat on a low bench, stooping forward and very busy, making shoes.
vi: From the tavern to the street, from the street to the inner courtyard, from the courtyard up the steep stairs, from the stairs to the attic - where once lived the old man with silver hair, hunched over his workbench, diligently making shoes.
tr: From the wine shop to the street, from the street to a courtyard, from the courtyard to a steep staircase, and from the staircase to an attic – an attic where an old man with thin white hair was busy making shoes at a low workbench, his back hunched – they went.
es: From the shop, they went out to the street, from the street they entered a courtyard, in the courtyard they took a staircase, and at the end of the staircase they found an attic... which was once the dwelling of a man with hair as white as snow, who spent his days sitting on a stool and making shoes.

en: No white-haired man was there now; but, the three men were there who had gone out of the wine-shop singly. And between them and the white-haired man afar off, was the one small link, that they had once looked in at him through the chinks in the wall.
vi: Now, that silver-haired person is no longer there; but the three people who are there now are the ones who had just left the tavern one by one. And between them and the silver-haired person who has gone far away, there is a small connection: they had once stood outside secretly watching that person through the cracks in the wall.
tr: There was no longer the white-haired man, but the three men who came out of the wine shop one by one were still there. However, there was a small connection between themselves and the white-haired man in the distance, which was that they had once watched him through the cracks in the wall.
es: The one with hair as white as snow was not in the attic, but the three men who had previously left the tavern one by one were.

en: Defarge closed the door carefully, and spoke in a subdued voice:
vi: Defarge carefully closed the door and then lowered his voice: − Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three!
tr: Defarge carefully closed the door and began to speak in a low voice.
es: Defarge carefully closed the door of the garret, and said in a low voice:

en: “Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three! This is the witness encountered by appointment, by me, Jacques Four. He will tell you all. Speak, Jacques Five!”
vi: Defarge carefully closed the door and then lowered his voice: − Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three! This is the witness that I, Jacques Four, have arranged to meet. He will tell you everything. Speak, Jacques Five!
tr: "Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Three! Here is the witness found by me, Jacques Four. He will tell you everything now. Speak up, Jacques Five!"
es: —Santiago First, Santiago Second, Santiago Third! I present to you the witness found by me, Santiago Fourth. He will tell you everything. You may speak, Santiago Fifth.

en: The mender of roads, blue cap in hand, wiped his swarthy forehead with it, and said, “Where shall I commence, monsieur?”
vi: The road mender, holding his green cap in his hand, wiped his dark forehead, his voice uneasy: − Where should I start, sir?
tr: The road worker, wiping his sunburned forehead with the blue hat in his hand,.said, "Where should I start, monsieur?"
es: The road worker, after drying his sweaty forehead with the blue cap he held in his hand, asked: —Where do I start?

en: “Commence,” was Monsieur Defarge’s not unreasonable reply, “at the commencement.”
vi: − Start from the beginning, - Defarge's reply was not without reason. −
tr: Mr. Defarge's response was not at all unreasonable, "From the beginning."
es: —You can start at the beginning—replied Defarge very logically.

en: “I saw him then, messieurs,” began the mender of roads, “a year ago this running summer, underneath the carriage of the Marquis, hanging by the chain. Behold the manner of it. I leaving my work on the road, the sun going to bed, the carriage of the Marquis slowly ascending the hill, he hanging by the chain—like this.”
vi: Well then, gentlemen, - the road mender began, - last year around this time in the summer, I saw that man hanging under the Marquis's carriage, clinging to the chain. This is how it happened. At that time, I had finished my work and was about to go home, the sun was about to set, the Marquis's carriage was slowly going up the hill, and the man was hanging onto the chain... like this.
tr: "When I saw him last summer, gentlemen," the road worker began, "he was hanging from a chain under the Marquis's carriage. Picture it in your mind. My work on the road was finished, I was leaving, the sun was returning to its bed, and as the Marquis's carriage was slowly climbing the hill, he was hanging from a chain – just like this."
es: —I saw him, gentlemen—began the road worker,—it was a year ago this summer, under the carriage of the Marquis, hanging from the chain. I had just finished my task, the sun was setting on the horizon, the Marquis's carriage was laboriously climbing the hill, and he was hanging from the chain like this.

en: Again the mender of roads went through the whole performance; in which he ought to have been perfect by that time, seeing that it had been the infallible resource and indispensable entertainment of his village during a whole year.
vi: The village storyteller used gestures to recount old tales, and by now he had mastered this performance, realizing it was an indispensable source of joy that had continuously delighted the villagers throughout the past year.
tr: The road worker reenacted the incident; since his performance had become the village's sole absolute source and inevitable entertainment throughout the entire year, he had now perfected it.
es: The speaker graphically depicted a scene that he had represented thousands of times in the village over an entire year.

en: Jacques One struck in, and asked if he had ever seen the man before?
vi: Jacques Một interrupted and asked the road worker if he had ever seen the person under the car before.
tr: Jacques Bir; intervened and asked him if he had seen this man before.
es: Santiago Primero took the floor to ask the traveler if he had seen the man hanging from the chain before.

en: “Never,” answered the mender of roads, recovering his perpendicular.
vi: − Never, - the road worker said as he straightened up again.
tr: "I've never seen it," replied the road worker, as he returned to an upright position.
es: —Never—replied the one being questioned, regaining an upright position.

en: Jacques Three demanded how he afterwards recognised him then?
vi: Jacques One asked how the road mender could later identify the man? −
tr: Jacques Three then asked how he could recognize him later.
es: —Never—replied the one being questioned, regaining an upright position. Santiago Tercero asked how he had been able to recognize him later, having not seen him until that day.

en: “By his tall figure,” said the mender of roads, softly, and with his finger at his nose. “When Monsieur the Marquis demands that evening, ‘Say, what is he like?’ I make response, ‘Tall as a spectre.’”
vi: By his tall stature, - the road mender whispered, picking his nose with one finger. - When the Marquis asked that evening “Hey, what did that guy look like?” I answered “Tall as a ghost!”. −
tr: "From his tall height," said the road worker in a soft tone, placing his finger on his nose. "When Monsieur Marquis asked me that evening, 'What does this man look like?' I said, 'He is tall like a ghost.'"
es: —I recognized him by his tall stature—said the road worker, placing the index finger of his right hand on his nose. —When that night the Marquis asked what signs he had, I replied: "He is tall like a specter."

en: “You should have said, short as a dwarf,” returned Jacques Two.
vi: You should have said short like a dwarf, - Jacques Two retorted. −
tr: "I think you should have said as short as a dwarf," said Jacques Two.
es: —You should have said "small as a dwarf," observed Santiago Segundo.

en: “But what did I know? The deed was not then accomplished, neither did he confide in me. Observe! Under those circumstances even, I do not offer my testimony. Monsieur the Marquis indicates me with his finger, standing near our little fountain, and says, ‘To me! Bring that rascal!’ My faith, messieurs, I offer nothing.”
vi: But how could I have known at that time! At that time, the incident hadn't happened yet, and the man hadn't confided in me. See! But even in that situation, I didn't confess anything. The Marquis pointed at me while standing near the fountain in my village and said “Bring that brat to me for questioning!”. Honestly, gentlemen, I didn't reveal anything. −
tr: "But how could I have known? The action was not yet complete, and he didn't trust me anyway. Just think! Even in that situation, I didn't say much. Monsieur Marquis stood by our little fountain, pointed at me with his finger, and said, 'Bring me that scoundrel!' Honestly, gentlemen, I didn't go and say anything."
es: —And what did I know? The feat had not been committed, nor had he confided in me. But keep in mind that, even under those circumstances, I declared nothing, said nothing. A good proof of this is that the Marquis, pointing at me with his finger, shouted: "Bring me that scoundrel!" No, no, gentlemen! I said nothing!

en: “He is right there, Jacques,” murmured Defarge, to him who had interrupted. “Go on!”
vi: He's right, Jacques, - Defarge whispered to the one who had interrupted. - Continue! − Alright! -
tr: "You're right, Jacques," murmured Defarge to the person who interrupted. "Alright, go on!"
es: —You are right, Santiago—said Defarge. —Continue.

en: “Good!” said the mender of roads, with an air of mystery. “The tall man is lost, and he is sought—how many months? Nine, ten, eleven?”
vi: The road mender said with a secretive air. - That tall man disappeared, and they hunted for... how many months? Nine, ten, eleven months?
tr: "Good!" said the road worker with a mysterious air. "Then the tall man disappears, they look for him – how many months pass? Nine, ten, maybe eleven?"
es: —Well then—continued the road worker with an air of mystery.—The tall man has gone missing and they are looking for him... since when? Since nine, ten, eleven months?

en: “No matter, the number,” said Defarge. “He is well hidden, but at last he is unluckily found. Go on!”
vi: − The number of months doesn't matter, - Defarge said. - He hid well, but unfortunately, he was eventually exposed. Continue! −
tr: "Forget the number;" said Defarge. "It's well hidden but unfortunately, it gets found in the end. Continue!"
es: —The number of months is the least relevant thing—replied Defarge. —He was well hidden, but in the end, they unfortunately found him. Continue.

en: “I am again at work upon the hill-side, and the sun is again about to go to bed. I am collecting my tools to descend to my cottage down in the village below, where it is already dark, when I raise my eyes, and see coming over the hill six soldiers. In the midst of them is a tall man with his arms bound—tied to his sides—like this!”
vi: Then I was working on the hillside again, and the sun was about to set. I was packing up my tools to go down the hill to my home in the village below, it was already dusk, when I looked up and saw six soldiers coming from the other side of the hill. In the midst of those soldiers was a tall man, his hands tied... tightly bound to his sides... like this!
tr: "One day, I am working on the hill again and the sun is about to set. I am gathering my tools to return to my house in the village below, it has already darkened down there, then I lift my head and see six soldiers coming down the hill. Right in the middle of them is a tall man with his arms tied – they tied them from the side like this!"
es: —Once again I am working on the hillside and the sun is also setting behind the Western mountains, just like the previous time. I gather my tools to go down to the village, where night has already fallen, when, as I lift my eyes, I see six soldiers appear at the top of the hill. In the midst of the soldiers, I see a man with his arms tied to his sides... in this manner.

en: With the aid of his indispensable cap, he represented a man with his elbows bound fast at his hips, with cords that were knotted behind him.
vi: With the prop of his inseparable hat, he mimicked the actions of a person whose elbows were tightly bound to his waist, with the rope knotted tightly behind his back.
tr: He portrayed a man whose elbows were tightly bound to his hips, accompanied by the hat he never let go of, with knots tied at the back.
es: With the help of his indispensable blue hat, the speaker admirably represents a man whose elbows are tied to his waist.

en: “I stand aside, messieurs, by my heap of stones, to see the soldiers and their prisoner pass (for it is a solitary road, that, where any spectacle is well worth looking at), and at first, as they approach, I see no more than that they are six soldiers with a tall man bound, and that they are almost black to my sight—except on the side of the sun going to bed, where they have a red edge, messieurs. Also, I see that their long shadows are on the hollow ridge on the opposite side of the road, and are on the hill above it, and are like the shadows of giants. Also, I see that they are covered with dust, and that the dust moves with them as they come, tramp, tramp! But when they advance quite near to me, I recognise the tall man, and he recognises me. Ah, but he would be well content to precipitate himself over the hill-side once again, as on the evening when he and I first encountered, close to the same spot!”
vi: − I stood to the side, gentlemen, next to the pile of rocks, watching some soldiers and prisoners pass by; since this road is deserted, anything that happens is worth watching. At first, when they arrived, I only saw six soldiers with a tall prisoner who was tied up, almost completely black so you couldn't see his face; except for the side facing the setting sun which was glowing red. Then I saw their shadows stretch long on the other side of the road, and on the hillside above, like the shadows of giants. Then I saw them covered in dust, wherever they went, dust rose up in a cloud! But when they got really close, I recognized the tall man, and he recognized me. Well, he must have been very eager to throw himself down that hillside and escape again, just like the afternoon when I first saw him, also near that spot!
tr: "Then, gentlemen, I move to the side, over by the piles of stones, so I can see the soldiers and the prisoner passing by (after all, it's a deserted road, there's nothing worth looking at) as they approach, I see nothing but six soldiers and a tall man with his arms tied, and they are all pitch black –but those on the side where the sun is setting seem to be outlined with a red line, gentlemen. Also, I see their long shadows cast on the ditch on the other side of the road and the hill above it, you would think that the shadows of giants had fallen." "And they are all covered in dust, and as they march with a steady rhythm, the dust moves along with them!" "But when they get close enough, I recognize the tall man, and he recognizes me. Ah, just like the evening we first met, in the same places, how wonderful it would be if he threw himself down the hill again!""
es: —I step aside, gentlemen, positioning myself next to a pile, to watch the soldiers and their prisoner pass by, as it is a military road where nothing passes that is not worth watching, and when they approached, at first, I saw nothing but six soldiers escorting a bound man, a tall man, and that both soldiers and prisoner appeared black, except for the part facing the sunset, where I noticed some reddish lines. I also observed that the shadows cast by their bodies crossed the road in its entirety, as if they were the shadows of giants. I also saw that they were covered in dust, and that they raised clouds of dust as they marched. When they passed in front of me, I recognized the tall man they had as a prisoner, and he recognized me as well. Ah! I well know that the prisoner would have thrown himself headfirst down the hillside as he did the afternoon I first saw him in the same place!

en: He described it as if he were there, and it was evident that he saw it vividly; perhaps he had not seen much in his life.
vi: He described it as if he were present at the scene, clearly he had seen it vividly; perhaps in his life, he rarely encountered such an event.
tr: He was describing it as if he had gone there again, and it was clear that he was reliving the events; perhaps he hadn't seen much in his life until now.
es: Next, he gave a detailed and vivid description of the scene he had just mentioned.

en: “I do not show the soldiers that I recognise the tall man; he does not show the soldiers that he recognises me; we do it, and we know it, with our eyes. ‘Come on!’ says the chief of that company, pointing to the village, ‘bring him fast to his tomb!’ and they bring him faster. I follow. His arms are swelled because of being bound so tight, his wooden shoes are large and clumsy, and he is lame. Because he is lame, and consequently slow, they drive him with their guns—like this!”
vi: − I didn't let the soldiers know that I recognized the tall man; he also didn't let the soldiers know that he recognized me; both sides acted the same, both sides understood each other, just a glance was enough. “Move on!” then the commanding soldier pointed down to the village and said, “hurry to your grave!” then urged the prisoner to move faster. I followed. His arms were swollen because they were tied too tightly, the large and cumbersome wooden shoes, and he was limping. Because he was limping, he was slow, and the soldiers kept prodding him with their guns... like this!
tr: "I never let the soldiers know that I recognize the tall man; he doesn't let on that he recognizes me either, but we understand each other through our eyes, we see this. The soldier in charge points to the village and says, 'Come on! Take him to his grave immediately!' and the men speed up. I'm following them too. They've tied him up so tightly that his arms are swollen, his wooden shoes are huge and clumsy, and as if that weren't enough, he's also limping. Of course, he walks slowly because he's limping, and the soldiers are pushing him with their rifles – exactly like that!"
es: —Neither did I let the soldiers understand that I had recognized the prisoner, nor did the prisoner let the soldiers see that he had recognized me. Instead, we conveyed it to each other through the language of the eyes. “Alive, alive!” said the leader of the soldiers.—“Let’s take him quickly to the pit!”; and indeed, they quickened their pace. I followed them. The prisoner’s arms were swollen due to the brutal pressure of the ropes, and since his clogs were too big and very heavy, he walked with a limp. One who limps cannot walk quickly, and since the soldiers wanted to make the journey swiftly, they drove the prisoner in this manner.

en: He imitated the action of a man’s being impelled forward by the butt-ends of muskets.
vi: He mimicked the action of someone being pushed forward by the butt of a musket.
tr: He portrayed a man being pushed with a rifle butt.
es: The road worker imitated the movements of the man who is forced to walk with rifle butts.

en: “As they descend the hill like madmen running a race, he falls. They laugh and pick him up again. His face is bleeding and covered with dust, but he cannot touch it; thereupon they laugh again. They bring him into the village; all the village runs to look; they take him past the mill, and up to the prison; all the village sees the prison gate open in the darkness of the night, and swallow him—like this!”
vi: − Then when the whole group ran down the hill as if chased by ghosts, he tripped and fell, and the soldiers laughed loudly as they pulled him up. His face was bleeding, covered in dirt, but he couldn't raise his hand to wipe it; seeing this, the soldiers laughed even louder. They took him into the village; the whole village came out to watch; they took him past the mill and then up to the prison; all the villagers saw the prison gate open in the darkness and swallow the prisoner... just like this!
tr: "As they race down the hill like madmen competing with each other, the man falls to the ground. The soldiers laugh and pick him up from the ground. The man's face is bleeding and covered in dirt, but he can't touch his face; so they laugh again. They bring him to the village; the whole village runs to see him; they walk him past the mill and onto the road leading to the prison; all the villagers witness the prison door opening and swallowing the man in the darkness of the night – just like that!"
es: —The prisoner fell flat on his face while they ran down the slope like madmen. The soldiers burst out laughing and lifted him up. His face was bleeding and covered in dirt, but the poor man couldn't bring his hands to it, which, seen by the soldiers, led to more laughter. They took him to the village, which came out en masse to see him, and from the village to the mill, and from the mill to the dungeon. The entire village saw how the dungeon door opened and swallowed the prisoner in this manner:

en: He opened his mouth as wide as he could, and shut it with a sounding snap of his teeth. Observant of his unwillingness to mar the effect by opening it again, Defarge said, “Go on, Jacques.”
vi: The man tried to open his mouth as wide as possible and then snapped it shut, making his teeth clatter together with a loud sound. Seeing that the man didn't want to open his mouth quickly to prolong the suspense, Defarge said: − Go on, Jacques.
tr: He opened his mouth as wide as he could and made a harsh sound by clashing his teeth together. Realizing that he did not want to open his mouth again to avoid ruining the effect he had created, Defarge said, "Go on, Jacques."
es: The road worker opened an enormous mouth, and closed it with a clatter produced by his teeth clashing violently. He wanted to represent the scene with such verisimilitude that he continued with his mouth closed until Defarge, after a long wait, said: —Go ahead, Santiago.

en: “All the village,” pursued the mender of roads, on tiptoe and in a low voice, “withdraws; all the village whispers by the fountain; all the village sleeps; all the village dreams of that unhappy one, within the locks and bars of the prison on the crag, and never to come out of it, except to perish. In the morning, with my tools upon my shoulder, eating my morsel of black bread as I go, I make a circuit by the prison, on my way to my work. There I see him, high up, behind the bars of a lofty iron cage, bloody and dusty as last night, looking through. He has no hand free, to wave to me; I dare not call to him; he regards me like a dead man.”
vi: − The whole village returned, - the road worker continued, in a sneaky manner, whispering, - the whole village murmured by the fountain; the whole village went to sleep; the whole village dreamed of that unfortunate person being locked behind bars, padlocked in a prison on the cliff, and never leaving that place, unless dead. In the morning, with my tools on my shoulder, quickly eating a few pieces of black bread, I left, I passed by that prison on my way to work. When I got there, I saw him, way up there, behind the bars of a high iron cage, still covered in dust and blood like the night before, looking out. He was still tied up so he couldn't wave; I didn't dare call out; he looked at me as if he were already dead.
tr: Standing on his tiptoes and speaking in a low voice, "The whole village," the road worker continued, "is retreating and whispering by the fountain; then they all go to sleep; the whole village sees the same unhappy person in their dreams, imprisoned behind the locked doors and iron bars on the rocks, the prisoner who will only leave here as a corpse." In the morning, with my tools on my shoulder, eating a piece of dark bread, I go to work, circling around the prison on my way. There, high up, I see him behind the bars of a majestic iron cage, his face covered in blood and dust just like the previous night, looking out. Since his hands are tied, he can't wave; and I don't dare call out to him; at that moment, he is no different from a dead man."
es: —The entire village withdraws,—continued the traveler, lowering his voice and standing on his tiptoes,—the entire village gathers around the fountain and speaks; the entire village retreats to their beds; the entire village dreams of that unfortunate one, who is found between walls and irons, locked in the dungeon that rises at the edge of the cliff, from which he will only emerge to die. The next morning, I throw my tools over my shoulders, take a piece of black bread, and taking a detour, pass by the prison before heading to work. There I see him, behind the sturdy bars of that iron cage, covered in blood and dust, just as he was the night before. He cannot extend a hand to me, because none have been left free; I do not dare to call out to him nor does he dare to speak to me; his appearance is that of a dead man.

en: Defarge and the three glanced darkly at one another. The looks of all of them were dark, repressed, and revengeful, as they listened to the countryman’s story; the manner of all of them, while it was secret, was authoritative too. They had the air of a rough tribunal; Jacques One and Two sitting on the old pallet-bed, each with his chin resting on his hand, and his eyes intent on the road-mender; Jacques Three, equally intent, on one knee behind them, with his agitated hand always gliding over the network of fine nerves about his mouth and nose; Defarge standing between them and the narrator, whom he had stationed in the light of the window, by turns looking from him to them, and from them to him.
vi: Defarge and the three others looked at each other sadly, their faces gloomy, restrained, and full of hatred as they listened to the peasant recount the story; though they did not show it, each person's demeanor was full of authority. They looked like ruthless judges; Jacques One and Two sat on the rickety bed, both resting their chins on their hands, eyes intently watching the road mender; Jacques Three knelt on one knee beside them, also watching intently, his restless hand rubbing the sensitive skin around his nose and mouth; Defarge stood between the three Jacques and the storyteller, while the storyteller blocked the light from the window, constantly looking from Defarge to the three others and then from the three others back to Defarge.
tr: Defarge and the three men exchanged subtle glances. While listening to the peasant's story, their expressions were filled with gloom, anger, and hatred; there was both a mysterious and stern air about them all. The room was dominated by a heavy courtroom atmosphere; Jacques One and Jacques Two were sitting on an old bench, hands on their chins, listening intently to the road worker; Jacques Three, who was just as attentive, was kneeling right behind them, nervously and constantly rubbing around his mouth and nose; standing in the light reflected from the window between these three men and the storyteller, Defarge kept looking back and forth between the men and the road worker.
es: Both Defarge and the three listeners exchange grim looks, looks that breathe hatred and vengeance, as they listen to the story from the lips of the traveler. The attitude of the three, although reserved, is authoritative, as if they constituted a very severe tribunal. The First and Second Santiagos are seated on the old mattress, their respective chins resting on their hands and their eyes fixed on the narrator. The Third Santiago has one knee on the ground and continuously passes his nervous hand over his mouth and nose, while Defarge, standing between the group formed by the three Santiagos and the narrator, sometimes looks at the latter, sometimes turns his severe face towards the former.

en: “Go on, Jacques,” said Defarge.
vi: − Continue, Jacques, - Defarge said.
tr: "Continue, Jacques," said Defarge.
es: —Go ahead, Santiago—says Defarge.

en: “He remains up there in his iron cage some days. The village looks at him by stealth, for it is afraid. But it always looks up, from a distance, at the prison on the crag; and in the evening, when the work of the day is achieved and it assembles to gossip at the fountain, all faces are turned towards the prison. Formerly, they were turned towards the posting-house; now, they are turned towards the prison. They whisper at the fountain, that although condemned to death he will not be executed; they say that petitions have been presented in Paris, showing that he was enraged and made mad by the death of his child; they say that a petition has been presented to the King himself. What do I know? It is possible. Perhaps yes, perhaps no.”
vi: − He stayed in that iron cage for several days. The whole village secretly watched because they were afraid. But they always stood far away, looking up at the prison on the cliff; then in the evening, when the day's work was done, everyone gathered to gossip at the fountain, all facing the prison. Before, everyone looked towards the post station; but at that time, they all looked up at the prison. They whispered to each other by the fountain that even if he was sentenced to death, he wouldn't be executed; they said a petition had been submitted in Paris, saying he went mad with grief over his child's death; they said the petition had been presented to the King himself. How do I know this! Maybe it's true. Maybe it is, maybe it isn't.
tr: "They kept the prisoner in the iron cage for a while. The villagers are secretly watching him because they are afraid of him. But from a distance, they constantly watch this prison on top of the cliffs, and when all the work is done and they gather at the fountain to gossip, they all turn their faces towards the prison. Previously, they always turned their faces towards the post office, but now they all face the prison. At the fountain, they whisper that although the man was sentenced to death, he will not be executed; they say a petition was sent to Paris for his pardon, explaining that the man went mad and lost control of himself after his child's death; another petition was personally submitted to the King. Who knows? It's possible. Maybe it's true, maybe it's not."
es: —In that iron cage, they have him locked up for a number of days. The village sees him, but cautiously, for they are afraid. During the day, they watch the prison from afar, and at night, when the day's work is done and they gather by the fountain, all faces turn towards the jail. Before, the object of the entire village's gaze was the post house: today it is the prison. In the conversations that the village holds by the fountain, they say that even if he were sentenced to death, the sentence would not be carried out; they say that petitions have been presented in Paris demonstrating that the unfortunate man went mad and did not know what he was doing as a result of his son's tragic death; they say that a petition has been presented to the King himself... Who knows? It could be! I do not claim either yes or no.

en: “Listen then, Jacques,” Number One of that name sternly interposed. “Know that a petition was presented to the King and Queen. All here, yourself excepted, saw the King take it, in his carriage in the street, sitting beside the Queen. It is Defarge whom you see here, who, at the hazard of his life, darted out before the horses, with the petition in his hand.”
vi: − Listen here, Jacques, - interrupted the cold one, Number One. There really was a petition presented to the King and Queen. Except for you, everyone here saw the King receive the petition, right in his carriage while traveling through the streets, with the Queen sitting beside him. It was Defarge standing here who risked his life to rush out and present that petition. −
tr: Number one, "Listen then Jacques," he objected harshly. "Know this. A petition was presented to the King and Queen. Everyone here except you saw the King receive this petition, he was in his carriage on the street, sitting next to the Queen. The one you see before you now, with the petition in hand, risking his life by throwing himself in front of the horses, was Defarge."
es: —Listen carefully, Santiago!—interrupted Santiago Primero with a harsh tone. — Know that a petition has been presented to the King and Queen. Everyone here, except for you, knows that the King took it in his hands while he was riding in a carriage down the street, seated next to the Queen. Defarge, whom you are seeing, risked his life to stand in front of the horses holding the petition in his hand.

en: “And once again listen, Jacques!” said the kneeling Number Three: his fingers ever wandering over and over those fine nerves, with a strikingly greedy air, as if he hungered for something—that was neither food nor drink; “the guard, horse and foot, surrounded the petitioner, and struck him blows. You hear?”
vi: That's not all, Jacques! - said Number Three, who was kneeling; his hands constantly rubbing around a sensitive area as if hungrily craving something that wasn't food or drink. - The mounted and foot guards surrounded the petitioner and beat him up. Do you hear clearly?
tr: "Listen to this too, Jacques!" said Jacques Three, who was kneeling: His fingers were incessantly, insatiably wandering over his face, as if craving something – but it was neither food nor drink; "the petitioner was surrounded by guards, horses, and infantry, and they started beating him up. Do you understand?"
es: —Listen to me now, Santiago!—interjected Santiago Tercero, always with one knee on the ground and waving his nervous fingers.—The escort, both on foot and on horseback, fell upon the supplicant and bruised him with blows! Do you understand?

en: “I hear, messieurs.”
vi: − Yes, clearly, sirs. −
tr: "I understand, gentlemen."
es: —I understand, gentlemen.

en: “Go on then,” said Defarge.
vi: Then continue, - Defarge said.
tr: "Then go on," said Defarge.
es: —Go ahead, then—said Defarge.

en: “Again; on the other hand, they whisper at the fountain,” resumed the countryman, “that he is brought down into our country to be executed on the spot, and that he will very certainly be executed. They even whisper that because he has slain Monseigneur, and because Monseigneur was the father of his tenants—serfs—what you will—he will be executed as a parricide. One old man says at the fountain, that his right hand, armed with the knife, will be burnt off before his face; that, into wounds which will be made in his arms, his breast, and his legs, there will be poured boiling oil, melted lead, hot resin, wax, and sulphur; finally, that he will be torn limb from limb by four strong horses. That old man says, all this was actually done to a prisoner who made an attempt on the life of the late King, Louis Fifteen. But how do I know if he lies? I am not a scholar.”
vi: − Alright, and furthermore, - the peasant continued, - they are whispering that he was taken down to my countryside to be executed on the spot, he will definitely be executed. They are also gossiping that because he killed a high official, and since the high official is considered the parent of the tenants... or serfs... whatever you call it... he will be executed as a parricide. An old man at the fountain said that his right hand, the hand that held the knife, will be burned right in front of him; then both arms will be cut off, both legs cut off, his chest will be opened; then boiling oil, molten lead, hot resin, melted wax, and sulfur will be poured into the wounds; finally, he will be quartered by horses. That old man said that there was indeed a prisoner who suffered this punishment for attempting to assassinate the late king, Louis XV. But whether he was telling the truth or not, I don't know. I never went to school. −
tr: "On the other hand, according to the whispers at the fountain," continued the villager, "he was brought here to be executed on the spot and will definitely be executed. They are even whispering that he will be executed as a patricide because he murdered the Monsignor, and since the Monsignor was the father of the peasants – the slaves – well, what can you do. According to an old man at the fountain, the convict's right hand, the one that held the knife, will be burned before his eyes; hot oil, molten lead, hot resin, wax, and sulfur will be poured into the wounds opened on his arm, chest, and legs; and finally, his arms and legs will be pulled in four different directions by four strong horses. Then the same old man says that all of this was exactly applied to a convict who attempted to kill the late King, Louis XV. But I am just repeating what he said. I don't know."
es: —There are also people who claim that he has been brought to our country to be executed here, and that he will inevitably be executed. They also say that, since he killed the lord, and the lord is the father of his vassals, he will be executed as a parricide. An old man says that they will burn his right hand alive, armed with a knife; that in the wounds they will open on his arms, chest, and legs, they will pour boiling oil, molten lead, burning resin, wax, and sulfur, and finally, that tied to the tails of four horses, he will be torn apart. The same old man claims that this is what they did to a criminal who attempted against the life of our late King Louis XV. Could it be true? Could it be false? I don't know: I am not wise.

en: “Listen once again then, Jacques!” said the man with the restless hand and the craving air. “The name of that prisoner was Damiens, and it was all done in open day, in the open streets of this city of Paris; and nothing was more noticed in the vast concourse that saw it done, than the crowd of ladies of quality and fashion, who were full of eager attention to the last—to the last, Jacques, prolonged until nightfall, when he had lost two legs and an arm, and still breathed! And it was done—why, how old are you?”
vi: Then listen here, Jacques! - Said the man with restless hands and a hungry look. - That prisoner’s name was Damiens, and all those tortures were carried out in broad daylight, right in the streets of Paris; among the dense crowd that came to watch the execution, the most notable were the elegant and wealthy ladies; they eagerly and attentively watched until the very end... until the very end, do you hear, Jacques! That means until midnight, when the prisoner had already had both legs and one arm cut off, and was still breathing! This happened when... oh, how old are you? −
tr: "Then listen once more, Jacques!" said the greedy man with his hands fidgeting. "The name of that prisoner was Damiens, all of this happened in the streets of Paris, in broad daylight, and nothing was more interesting in that huge crowd than the eagerness of those elegant and fancy ladies to witness the prisoner's final moments – the final moments, Jacques, the final moments lasted until evening, even when both his legs and one arm were torn off, the man was still breathing! They did it all exactly – how old are you?"
es: —Listen again, Santiago!—exclaimed the third of this name.— The convict you speak of was named Damiens, and the program you just described was carried out in broad daylight and on the streets of Paris. Regarding the impression it made on those who witnessed it, I will only tell you, Santiago, that the multitude of ladies of the highest nobility who came to witness the execution did not want to miss any detail; they watched it with rapture until the end... until the end, Santiago, which did not come until nightfall, hours after the unfortunate man had lost two legs and an arm... and he was still breathing! That happened... But tell me, how old are you?

en: “Thirty-five,” said the mender of roads, who looked sixty.
vi: Thirty-five, - the road worker said, looking as old as sixty.
tr: "Thirty-five," said the road worker who looked sixty years old.
es: —Thirty-five—replied the road worker, who looked sixty.

en: “It was done when you were more than ten years old; you might have seen it.”
vi: − So, at that time you were just over ten years old; you could have witnessed this incident.
tr: "So this happened when you were around ten years old; you might have seen it.""
es: —Thirty-five—replied the road worker, who looked sixty.

en: “Enough!” said Defarge, with grim impatience. “Long live the Devil! Go on.”
vi: − Enough! - Defarge's voice was hot and fierce. - Long live the devil! Continue.
tr: "Enough!" said Defarge, with a grumpy impatience. "May God not punish you! Go on, continue."
es: —Too many!—murmured Defarge impatiently.

en: “Well! Some whisper this, some whisper that; they speak of nothing else; even the fountain appears to fall to that tune. At length, on Sunday night when all the village is asleep, come soldiers, winding down from the prison, and their guns ring on the stones of the little street. Workmen dig, workmen hammer, soldiers laugh and sing; in the morning, by the fountain, there is raised a gallows forty feet high, poisoning the water.”
vi: − Alright! Some people rumored this, others rumored that; everyone was talking about the prisoner; even the fountain seemed to be discussing it. Finally, on a Sunday night when the whole village was asleep; soldiers appeared, a winding procession from the prison down, the clanking of weapons echoing on the village's stone streets. Laborers digging, laborers hammering, soldiers laughing and singing; by morning, next to the fountain stood a gallows fifteen meters high, contaminating the entire water source.
tr: "Alright! Some say one thing; some say another, but everyone is talking about this; it's as if even the fountain is flowing in the same tone. After a while, on Sunday night when the whole village is asleep, the soldiers come; they descend the prison road, and their weapons clink on the stones of the narrow street. Workers are digging; workers are hammering nails; soldiers are singing and laughing; in the morning, next to the fountain, a ten-meter-high gallows, which pours its poison into the water, rises."
es: —Continue. —They talk about nothing else in the village: even the fountain seems to have learned the same refrain. Finally, on a Sunday night, the soldiers arrive and head to the prison. Workers digging, workers hammering, soldiers laughing out loud, and when day breaks, a forty-foot-high gallows stands next to the fountain, whose shadow poisons the waters.

en: The mender of roads looked through rather than at the low ceiling, and pointed as if he saw the gallows somewhere in the sky.
vi: The road worker looked up at the low ceiling, but his gaze seemed to pierce through the roof, directed towards some gallows in the sky.
tr: When the road worker turned his eyes to the low ceiling, he saw much more beyond it and pointed to the sky as if he had seen a gallows.
es: Workers digging, workers hammering, soldiers laughing out loud, and when day breaks, a forty-foot-high gallows stands next to the fountain, whose shadow poisons the waters.

en: “All work is stopped, all assemble there, nobody leads the cows out, the cows are there with the rest. At midday, the roll of drums. Soldiers have marched into the prison in the night, and he is in the midst of many soldiers. He is bound as before, and in his mouth there is a gag—tied so, with a tight string, making him look almost as if he laughed.” He suggested it, by creasing his face with his two thumbs, from the corners of his mouth to his ears. “On the top of the gallows is fixed the knife, blade upwards, with its point in the air. He is hanged there forty feet high—and is left hanging, poisoning the water.”
vi: − Everything came to a halt; everyone gathered there, no one led the cattle to graze, the cattle stood together with the people in one place. By noon, a drum was heard. The soldiers had entered the prison during the night and now were bringing the prisoner out. He was still tied up as before, his mouth stuffed with a rag... tightly bound with a taut rope, making him look like he was grinning. - The man recalled that image by grimacing, pulling his mouth wide with his thumbs to his ears. - At the top of the gallows, a knife was stuck, its sharp blade pointing upwards. He was hung up fifteen meters high... and dangled there, contaminating the water reservoir below.
tr: "All work stops, everyone gathers at the fountain, no one takes the cows to graze, they are there with the villagers. At exactly noon, the drums thunder. The soldiers went to the dungeon at night and brought the prisoner, now he stands in the midst of a bunch of soldiers. They tied the man as before, and there is a gag in his mouth – they tied his mouth so tightly that he looks like he is smiling." He tried to demonstrate this by pulling his face with his thumbs from the corners of his mouth to his ears. "They placed the knife on top of the gallows, with the sharp side facing up, the tip pointing to the sky. They hanged him at a height of ten meters – by poisoning the water, he remained hanging there."
es: Everyone stops working, everyone gathers there, the cows don't go out to the field because they don't want to miss the spectacle either. At noon, the drums thunder. The soldiers, who went to the prison the night before, return with him in the middle. The convict is tied up, they have put a gag in his mouth secured with a rope in such a way that it looks like he is smiling. At the top of the gallows, they have placed a knife with its point facing up. The convict is hanged forty feet high, and his corpse remains swinging... poisoning the fountain's waters with its shadow.

en: They looked at one another, as he used his blue cap to wipe his face, on which the perspiration had started afresh while he recalled the spectacle.
vi: They looked at each other, and the villager wiped his sweat-covered face with a blue hat as he recounted the scene. −
tr: The road worker had started sweating again at the sight before his eyes and used his blue hat to wipe his face while the others looked at each other.
es: The listeners exchanged somber looks, while the narrator wiped the sweat from his face with the blue cap.

en: “It is frightful, messieurs. How can the women and the children draw water! Who can gossip of an evening, under that shadow! Under it, have I said? When I left the village, Monday evening as the sun was going to bed, and looked back from the hill, the shadow struck across the church, across the mill, across the prison—seemed to strike across the earth, messieurs, to where the sky rests upon it!”
vi: It was terrible, gentlemen. How can women and children fetch water to use! Who dares to chat under that shadow anymore! The shadow of the gallows, do you hear me clearly, gentlemen? When I left the village, on Monday evening at sunset, and stood on the hill looking back, the shadow of the hanged man fell over the church, over the mill, over the prison... it seemed to stretch across the ground, gentlemen, all the way to the horizon!
tr: "Very terrible, gentlemen. How will women and children get water from there now! Who will gossip under that shadow in the evening! Under it, didn't I say? On Monday evening, as the sun was about to set, when I left the village, when I turned around while climbing the hill, that shadow was still swaying in front of the church, the mill, and the prison – gentlemen, it seemed to cover everywhere under this sky, the entire earth!"
es: —It's horrifying, gentlemen!—he replied. —How are the women and children supposed to drink water from the fountain? Who is the daring one that dares to speak during the night under that shadow? Under the shadow, I said? When I left the village on Monday afternoon, almost at sunset, I turned my head from the top of the hill and saw that the shadow covered the church, covered the mill, covered the prison on the cliff, covered all the land, gentlemen, that has the blue sky as its roof!

en: The hungry man gnawed one of his fingers as he looked at the other three, and his finger quivered with the craving that was on him.
vi: Hungry Jacques gnawed at his fingers as he looked at the other three, his fingertips trembling with ravenous desire. −
tr: The hungry man had started to gnaw on one of his fingers while looking at the other three, and his finger trembled under the effect of his hunger.
es: The listener who was kneeling on the ground seemed to be hungry for something... that was neither food nor drink.

en: “That’s all, messieurs. I left at sunset (as I had been warned to do), and I walked on, that night and half next day, until I met (as I was warned I should) this comrade. With him, I came on, now riding and now walking, through the rest of yesterday and through last night. And here you see me!”
vi: That's it, gentlemen. I left at dusk, as advised, and kept going, all that night and the next day, until I met this friend, just as I was told. I traveled with him, sometimes by carriage, sometimes on foot, until the end of yesterday and all through last night. Now I am here!
tr: "So it is, gentlemen. I left there at sunset (as I was asked) and walked through that night and until noon the next day, until I met this friend (as I was told). Then, for the rest of the day and all through the night, we came here together, partly walking and partly on horseback. And now, here I am before you!"
es: —I have finished, gentlemen. I left the village moments before sunset, as I just mentioned, and walked all night and half of the following day, until I found, as I also mentioned, this comrade. In his company, I arrived here, sometimes on foot, sometimes on horseback, traveling all the rest of yesterday and all of last night. I have spoken.

en: After a gloomy silence, the first Jacques said, “Good! You have acted and recounted faithfully. Will you wait for us a little, outside the door?”
vi: After a sorrowful silence, Jacques One spoke: − Alright! You did the right thing and have recounted truthfully. Could you wait for us outside the door for a moment?
tr: After a boring silence, Jacques Bir said, "Great! You described and explained everything with all your sincerity. Would you wait for us outside the door for a bit now?" he said.
es: —Alright—said Santiago Primero, after an imposing silence. — You have acted and narrated faithfully. Would you like to wait for us briefly outside, on the stairs?

en: “Very willingly,” said the mender of roads. Whom Defarge escorted to the top of the stairs, and, leaving seated there, returned.
vi: − Willingly, - the road worker said. Defarge led him to the top of the stairs, left him there, and then returned.
tr: "With pleasure," said the road worker. After accompanying him to the top of the ladder and seating him, Defarge turned back.
es: —With great pleasure—replied the road worker. Defarge accompanied him to the staircase, left him sitting on the last step, and went back into the attic.

en: The three had risen, and their heads were together when he came back to the garret.
vi: The three people stood up, huddling together to discuss as Defarge returned to the attic room.
tr: When Defarge returned to the attic, all three of them had stood up and were talking with their heads together.
es: The three Jacques had stood up and formed a very tight group.

en: “How say you, Jacques?” demanded Number One. “To be registered?”
vi: − What about him, Jacques? - Number One asked. - Should we add him to the list?
tr: "What do you say, Jacques?" asked number one. "Should it be recorded?"
es: —What do you say, Santiago?—asked the number one of this name. —Shall we record it in our register?

en: “To be registered, as doomed to destruction,” returned Defarge.
vi: − Add him to the list, and he will be eliminated, - Defarge replied.
tr: "Let it be recorded as doomed to destruction," replied Defarge.
es: —Register him as condemned to destruction! —replied Defarge.

en: “Magnificent!” croaked the man with the craving.
vi: − Excellent! - Number Three groaned hungrily.
tr: "Magnificent!" shouted the greedy man in a hoarse voice.
es: —Magnificent!—exclaimed Santiago Tercero.

en: “The chateau, and all the race?” inquired the first.
vi: − That castle and the entire family? - Number One asked. −
tr: "The castle and his entire family?" asked number one.
es: —The castle and the entire lineage?—replied the first one.

en: “The chateau and all the race,” returned Defarge. “Extermination.”
vi: That castle and the entire family, - Defarge replied. - Exterminate them all. − Excellent! -
tr: "The château and all its family," replied Defarge. "Let them all be exterminated!"
es: —Yes; the castle and the entire race!—roared Defarge—Complete extermination!

en: The hungry man repeated, in a rapturous croak, “Magnificent!” and began gnawing another finger.
vi: The glutton repeated with a delighted groan and began to gnaw on another finger.
tr: The hungry man shouted enthusiastically again, "Magnificent!" and started gnawing on another finger.
es: —Sublime!—shouted the third Santiago.

en: “Are you sure,” asked Jacques Two, of Defarge, “that no embarrassment can arise from our manner of keeping the register? Without doubt it is safe, for no one beyond ourselves can decipher it; but shall we always be able to decipher it—or, I ought to say, will she?”
vi: Jacques Hai asked Defarge: "Are you sure that keeping this list won't cause any trouble? Surely the list is safe because no one but us can decode it; but can we always guarantee that we can decode it ourselves..." or, should I say, can she guarantee it?"
tr: "Are you sure that our record-keeping habit won't get us into trouble?" Jacques asked Defarge Twice, "there is no danger for now because no one else can decipher this code, but will we always be able to decipher it – or rather, will your wife be able to decipher it?""
es: —Are you certain that the system we've agreed upon for the registry won't cause us any trouble? —Santiago Primero asked Defarge.—That it is secure, there is no doubt, since, except for us, no one is capable of deciphering it: but will we always be able to decipher it... or rather, will she be able to?...

en: “Jacques,” returned Defarge, drawing himself up, “if madame my wife undertook to keep the register in her memory alone, she would not lose a word of it—not a syllable of it. Knitted, in her own stitches and her own symbols, it will always be as plain to her as the sun. Confide in Madame Defarge. It would be easier for the weakest poltroon that lives, to erase himself from existence, than to erase one letter of his name or crimes from the knitted register of Madame Defarge.”
vi: "Jacques," Defarge replied, straightening up, "if my wife is solely responsible for remembering this list, she will remember it perfectly... not missing a single word." She has knitted that list into her stitches and unique symbols, she can look at it and know without missing a single name. Trust Madame Defarge. A great coward would find it easier to commit suicide than to erase a name, erase a crime from Madame Defarge's knitted list of extermination.
tr: "Jacques," said Defarge, straightening up, "if my wife has committed this record to memory, she will not forget a single word – not even a syllable. It is all woven with stitches and symbols according to her own method, it is as clear as day to her. Trust Madame Defarge. Feeble cowards can easily be erased from this world, but not a single name or crime can be erased from the records woven by Madame Defarge."
es: —Santiago—replied Defarge, standing up,—if my wife insists on keeping the entire record in her memory, rest assured that not a single word, not a single syllable of what it contains will be lost. With knitting needles, she is capable of writing everything clearer than the sun. Trust my wife. The most cowardly poltroon, the most attached to the world who lives or has lived under the sky's cover, would find it easier to take his own life than to remove a single letter from the record written stitch by stitch by my lady.

en: There was a murmur of confidence and approval, and then the man who hungered, asked: “Is this rustic to be sent back soon? I hope so. He is very simple; is he not a little dangerous?”
vi: There were murmurs of agreement and approval, then the hungry Number Three asked: − Are we going to kick that country bumpkin out? I hope so. He's not very smart, isn't that dangerous? −
tr: The men murmured among themselves in a manner that showed their trust and approval, and the greedy man said: "Will this peasant be sent back immediately? I hope so. He is a very simple man; isn't this a bit of a dangerous situation?"
es: Murmurs of approval greeted Defarge's words. —What do we do with that rustic?—asked Santiago Tercero. —Do we fire him? It seems excessively simple to me: won't it be dangerous for us?

en: “He knows nothing,” said Defarge; “at least nothing more than would easily elevate himself to a gallows of the same height. I charge myself with him; let him remain with me; I will take care of him, and set him on his road. He wishes to see the fine world—the King, the Queen, and Court; let him see them on Sunday.”
vi: He doesn't know anything, - Defarge said, - and even if he manages to reveal something, he will be hanged as well. Leave him to me; just let him stay with me; I will take care of him and send him on his own path. He wants to see this beautiful world... see the King, see the Queen, and see the Court; this Sunday I will show him all those things. −
tr: "He knows nothing," said Defarge; "at least he is unaware of the things that would get him hanged from the same height of a gallows. I take responsibility; let him stay with me; I will take care of him, then he can go his own way. He wants to see the world of the nobles –the King, the Queen, the Palace; let him see them all on Sunday."
es: —He knows nothing—replied Defarge,—and the little he could say would only serve to get him to a scaffold as high as the one he was just describing to us. I'll take care of him; leave him to me. In due time, I'll let him go. It seems he wishes to see the King, the Queen, the magnates, and the lords of the court: we will allow him to satisfy his desire on Sunday.

en: “What?” exclaimed the hungry man, staring. “Is it a good sign, that he wishes to see Royalty and Nobility?”
vi: What? - the hungry Number Three exclaimed, eyes wide open. - What is trustworthy about someone who desires to see royalty and nobility?
tr: "What?" shouted the hungry man, staring intently. "Is it a good thing that he wants to see the royal family and the nobles?"
es: —What!—exclaimed Santiago Tercero. —Don't you think it's a bad sign that he wants to see the royalty and the nobility?

en: “Jacques,” said Defarge; “judiciously show a cat milk, if you wish her to thirst for it. Judiciously show a dog his natural prey, if you wish him to bring it down one day.”
vi: − Jacques, - Defarge said, - it is wise to let the cat see the milk if you want the cat to crave it. It is wise to let the dog recognize the prey if you want the dog to hunt for you someday.
tr: "Jacques," said Defarge; "if you want a cat to be eager to drink milk, show it the milk from a reasonable distance. If you show a dog its prey from a reasonable distance, one day it might catch it and bring it to you."
es: —Santiago—replied Defarge,—show the cat the milk if you want to excite its thirst; show the mastiff its natural prey if you want it to fall upon it and tear it apart in due time.

en: Nothing more was said, and the mender of roads, being found already dozing on the topmost stair, was advised to lay himself down on the pallet-bed and take some rest. He needed no persuasion, and was soon asleep.
vi: No one said anything more, and they saw the road worker had fallen asleep at the top of the stairs, so they told him to go lie down on the rickety bed inside the attic room. Without needing any persuasion, he fell asleep immediately after that.
tr: Nothing else was discussed, and they advised the road worker, whom they found dozing at the top of the stairs, to lie down on the couch and rest a bit. There was no need for insistence; the man soon fell asleep.
es: Nothing more was said at that time. The road worker, whom they found nodding off on the landing, was invited to lie down on the mattress. He did not need to be asked twice, and moments later, he was sleeping like a log.

en: Worse quarters than Defarge’s wine-shop, could easily have been found in Paris for a provincial slave of that degree. Saving for a mysterious dread of madame by which he was constantly haunted, his life was very new and agreeable. But, madame sat all day at her counter, so expressly unconscious of him, and so particularly determined not to perceive that his being there had any connection with anything below the surface, that he shook in his wooden shoes whenever his eye lighted on her. For, he contended with himself that it was impossible to foresee what that lady might pretend next; and he felt assured that if she should take it into her brightly ornamented head to pretend that she had seen him do a murder and afterwards flay the victim, she would infallibly go through with it until the play was played out.
vi: For a country bumpkin like this road worker, there was no better place in Paris than Defarge's tavern. Except for the inexplicable fear of Madame Defarge that always haunted him, he found living here both novel and comfortable. But Madame Defarge sat at the bar all day, seemingly paying no attention to him and clearly determined not to consider him involved in any secret plots, so cold that every time he saw her, his legs would turn to jelly. Because deep down, he was certain that he could never predict what she intended to do; and he was convinced that if Madame Defarge's fancifully adorned head suddenly imagined that he had murdered and skinned someone, she would undoubtedly believe it to be true to the end.
tr: For a provincial slave in his position, there were far worse places in Paris than Defarge's tavern. Aside from the mysterious fear he often felt in the presence of Madame Defarge, his new life was quite pleasant. But Madame seemed so unaware of his existence as she sat behind that counter all day, and so clearly showed that his presence meant nothing, that every time their eyes met, the peasant trembled in his wooden shoes. Moreover, he thought it was impossible to guess what was going through the woman's mind, and if she ever considered that he had committed a murder and then robbed the victim, she would certainly not leave him alone until the show was complete.
es: Worse lodging than what Defarge's tavern offered could not have been found in Paris by an unfortunate like the wayfarer. If we disregard the mysterious fear that the tavern keeper's wife inspired in him, a fear that constantly haunted him, he led a life that could not be more pleasant. But the fact is that the tavern keeper's wife spent the entire day sitting behind the counter, so indifferent to his presence, so determined not to acknowledge the presence of a stranger in the house, that he wandered around bewildered and suspicious. It is not surprising, then, that when Sunday arrived and he learned that the innkeeper's wife would join her husband to accompany him to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the plan, although his tongue said otherwise.

en: Therefore, when Sunday came, the mender of roads was not enchanted (though he said he was) to find that madame was to accompany monsieur and himself to Versailles. It was additionally disconcerting to have madame knitting all the way there, in a public conveyance; it was additionally disconcerting yet, to have madame in the crowd in the afternoon, still with her knitting in her hands as the crowd waited to see the carriage of the King and Queen.
vi: Therefore, when Sunday came, the road worker did not like (although he said otherwise) seeing the mistress go with the master and him to the Palace of Versailles. It was quite embarrassing that the mistress kept knitting all the way, on the public carriage; and even more embarrassing when at noon, amidst the crowd, she continued to knit while everyone was eagerly waiting to see the King and Queen's carriage. −
tr: Therefore, when Sunday came and he learned that Madam Defarge would be accompanying the road worker Monsieur to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the situation (though, of course, he told them otherwise). It was extremely annoying that Madam knitted throughout the journey on public transport; even more annoying was that she still carried her knitting among the crowd gathered to see the King and Queen's carriage in the afternoon.
es: It is not surprising, then, that when Sunday arrived and he learned that the innkeeper's wife would join her husband to accompany him to Versailles, he was not at all pleased with the plan, although his tongue said otherwise. His bewilderment increased when the innkeeper's wife did not stop knitting during the journey, and his bewilderment turned into horrible confusion that afternoon when, while waiting for the Queen to pass by, he had to remain next to the innkeeper's wife, whose hands were handling the knitting needles with true fervor.

en: “You work hard, madame,” said a man near her.
vi: You work so diligently, - a man standing next to her said.
tr: "You work very hard, madam," said the man next to her.
es: —Do you work a lot, ma'am?—said a man who passed by her side.

en: “Yes,” answered Madame Defarge; “I have a good deal to do.”
vi: − Yes, - Madame Defarge replied - I still have many things to knit. −
tr: "Indeed," said Madam Defarge; "I have more work to do."
es: —Yes—replied Madame Defarge,—I have much to do.

en: “What do you make, madame?”
vi: What are you knitting?
tr: "What are you doing, madam?"
es: —And what do you do, ma'am?

en: “Many things.”
vi: − All sorts of things. −
tr: "A lot."
es: —Many things.

en: “For instance—”
vi: For example... −
tr: "For example..."
es: —For example...

en: “For instance,” returned Madame Defarge, composedly, “shrouds.”
vi: For example, - Madame Defarge calmly replied, - shrouds.
tr: "For example," said Madam Defarge calmly, "shrouds."
es: —For example—replied the innkeeper with the same calm as before—shrouds.

en: The man moved a little further away, as soon as he could, and the mender of roads fanned himself with his blue cap: feeling it mightily close and oppressive. If he needed a King and Queen to restore him, he was fortunate in having his remedy at hand; for, soon the large-faced King and the fair-faced Queen came in their golden coach, attended by the shining Bull’s Eye of their Court, a glittering multitude of laughing ladies and fine lords; and in jewels and silks and powder and splendour and elegantly spurning figures and handsomely disdainful faces of both sexes, the mender of roads bathed himself, so much to his temporary intoxication, that he cried Long live the King, Long live the Queen, Long live everybody and everything! as if he had never heard of ubiquitous Jacques in his time. Then, there were gardens, courtyards, terraces, fountains, green banks, more King and Queen, more Bull’s Eye, more lords and ladies, more Long live they all! until he absolutely wept with sentiment. During the whole of this scene, which lasted some three hours, he had plenty of shouting and weeping and sentimental company, and throughout Defarge held him by the collar, as if to restrain him from flying at the objects of his brief devotion and tearing them to pieces.
vi: The man quickly moved away, and the road worker raised his green hat to fan himself, feeling extremely suffocated standing next to the lady of the house. If he needed the King and Queen to save him, he was lucky not to have to wait long; the King with his firm jaw and the beautiful Queen appeared in a golden carriage, accompanied by their elegant and trusted courtiers, a splendid procession of joyful ladies and handsome nobles; the men and women adorned in silk, jewels, powdered faces, and painted lips, with their haughty manners and disdainful expressions, captivated the road worker so much that he shouted, "Long live the King! Long live the Queen! Long live everyone and everything!" As if he had never known anyone else named Jacques in his life. Afterwards, he was shown many gardens, courtyards, towers, fountains, and green hills, and again he saw the King and Queen, the courtiers and nobles with the ladies, and once more he shouted, "Long live everyone!" To the point where he burst into tears from emotion. Throughout the three-hour-long admiration, he also encountered many people who were moved to tears, and Defarge always held tightly to his collar as if fearing he would rush at those he momentarily worshipped and tear them apart.
tr: Adam distanced himself from the woman at the first opportunity and the road worker waved his blue hat like a fan in his hand. The place was excessively crowded and suffocating. If he needed a King and Queen to find himself again, he was very lucky because the solution came to him; for soon the big-faced King and the clean-faced Queen arrived in their gilded carriage, accompanied by the dazzling group of the palace favorites with sparkling eyes, smiling ladies, and elegant lords; ladies and gentlemen in jewels, silks, and powders, bodies that disregarded everyone with all their splendor and grace, and well-groomed and arrogant faces; the road worker was so captivated and lost in all this that he started shouting, "Long live the King, Long live the Queen, Long live everyone and everything!" as if he was unaware of the Jacques who popped up everywhere at any moment in those days. Then gardens, courtyards, terraces, fountains, trees, flowers, and again the King and Queen, again the palace favorites, lords, and ladies; more Long live, and finally, unable to bear all this emotional intensity, he burst into tears. During this scene, which lasted about three hours, the road worker shouted a lot, cried, and showed accompanying emotional reactions, and throughout this time, Defarge held him tightly by the collar so that he wouldn't jump on the crowd he was declaring his loyalty to and tear them apart.
es: The stranger moved away as soon as he could. The poor road worker felt such a strange oppression in his chest that he had to fan himself with his cap. If for his complete recovery he needed the presence of two crowned heads, it must be admitted that he could not complain about his luck, since moments later, a king with large jaws and a queen with a beautiful face appeared, comfortably seated in a golden carriage. With the sovereigns came the best, the most notable of their court. The poor road worker, upon seeing that charming army of smiling ladies and brilliant gentlemen, all covered in silks and lace, blondes and rich velvets, gold braid and dazzling jewelry, felt such waves of enthusiasm in his chest that, shouting at the top of his lungs, he cheered for the King and the Queen, the ladies and gentlemen, and even the carriages and the horses that pulled them. And he saw beautiful gardens and charming groves, and magnificent terraces and marvelous fountains, and he found the King and the Queen again, and cheered, until he was hoarse, for everything created, and his enthusiasm grew, and the enthusiasm gave birth to sympathy in his soul, and the sympathy to tenderness, and this, finding the limits of his chest too narrow, overflowed in torrents through his eyes in the form of tears. During the scene, which lasted three hours, during which he shouted until he was hoarse and cried until he exhausted the source of his tears, Defarge had to hold him by the neck with one hand to prevent him from, in his thoughtless enthusiasm, falling upon the objects of his fleeting devotion and destroying them with his big hands.

en: “Bravo!” said Defarge, clapping him on the back when it was over, like a patron; “you are a good boy!”
vi: − Bravo! - Defarge patted his back like a superior when it was over. Well done!
tr: When everything was over, "Bravo!" said Defarge, patting the man on the back like a boss, "You are a good man!"
es: —Bravo!—exclaimed Defarge when the parade ended. —You are a good boy.

en: The mender of roads was now coming to himself, and was mistrustful of having made a mistake in his late demonstrations; but no.
vi: The road worker now snapped back to reality and worried if he had done anything wrong in his recent expressions; but no.
tr: The road worker was coming to himself. He had started to come to himself now and was wondering if he had done anything wrong in his earlier performance, but there was no problem.
es: The truck driver, who was beginning to come to his senses, feared he had made a blunder, but soon calmed down.

en: “You are the fellow we want,” said Defarge, in his ear; “you make these fools believe that it will last for ever. Then, they are the more insolent, and it is the nearer ended.”
vi: − You are exactly the person we need, - Defarge whispered in his ear, - you make those fools believe they will last forever. Therefore, the more arrogant they are, the sooner they will perish. − There! -
tr: "You are the man we are looking for," said Defarge into the man's ear; "these fools think this grandeur will last forever. Then they become more arrogant and get closer and closer to the end."
es: —You are the man we need—Defarge said to him, pressing his lips to his ears. — You will make those fools believe that their madness will last forever; their insolence will grow, and they themselves will hasten their end.

en: “Hey!” cried the mender of roads, reflectively; “that’s true.”
vi: The road laborer exclaimed, looking pensive. -
tr: "Yaa!" shouted the road worker; "very true!"
es: —Quiet!—exclaimed the road worker. —Well, it's true!

en: “These fools know nothing. While they despise your breath, and would stop it for ever and ever, in you or in a hundred like you rather than in one of their own horses or dogs, they only know what your breath tells them. Let it deceive them, then, a little longer; it cannot deceive them too much.”
vi: That's right. − Those fools don't know anything. Even though they despise our lives and are ready to sacrifice your life or the lives of hundreds like you rather than give up their horses and dogs, they only know what you reveal to them. Keep deceiving them like that, a little longer; no matter how much you deceive them, it's worth it.
tr: "These fools know nothing. They can't stand your breathing, if it were possible, they would forever stop the breath of you and hundreds like you for one of their own horses or dogs, all they know is what your breath tells them. Let them believe this a little longer; it won't take much time anyway."
es: —They are idiots and blind.
