They deeply despise you; they would watch your death and that of a thousand more like you with indifference; moreover, they would sacrifice those thousand lives without remorse in exchange for saving just one of their horses or dogs, and yet, they are puffed up by your screams. Let's deceive them for some more time, for no matter how great the deception is, it will never be as great as they deserve.

en: Madame Defarge looked superciliously at the client, and nodded in confirmation.
vi: Madame Defarge nodded in agreement and disdainfully looked at the country visitor.
tr: Madam Defarge looked at the customer with a proud demeanor and then nodded in approval.
es: Mrs. Defarge looked at the road-mender and made approving gestures.

en: “As to you,” said she, “you would shout and shed tears for anything, if it made a show and a noise. Say! Would you not?”
vi: She said to him: − As for you, you can shout, cry, whatever you want, as long as you make a big show of it. Speak! Can you do it?
tr: "As for you," said the madam, "you cry and shout for all kinds of show and pomp. Isn't that right? Speak!"
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “Truly, madame, I think so. For the moment.”
vi: − Honestly, I think I can, ma'am. For the time being, I can. −
tr: "That's right, madam, I think so. For the moment, it seems that way."
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “If you were shown a great heap of dolls, and were set upon them to pluck them to pieces and despoil them for your own advantage, you would pick out the richest and gayest. Say! Would you not?”
vi: If you see a pile of dolls and are told to freely destroy and tear them apart, you will choose the most expensive and splendid one. Speak! Isn't that right?
tr: "If they showed you a huge pile of babies and asked you to tear them apart and plunder them for your own benefit, you would go and choose the richest and sweetest one. Isn't that right? Tell me!" "Yes madam, that's correct.""
es: —Tell me, my friend: if they placed a huge pile of beautiful dolls in front of you and told you that you could destroy and strip the ones you fancied, isn't it true that you would choose the richest, the most beautiful ones?

en: “Truly yes, madame.”
vi: − Honestly, it is, ma'am.
tr: "Yes madam, that's correct.""
es: —It is true, madam.

en: “Yes. And if you were shown a flock of birds, unable to fly, and were set upon them to strip them of their feathers for your own advantage, you would set upon the birds of the finest feathers; would you not?”
vi: − Alright. And if you see a flock of birds that cannot fly and are told to freely pluck their feathers, you will choose the one with the most beautiful feathers; isn't that right?
tr: "Yes madam, that's correct."" "Yes, and if they showed you a flock of birds that couldn't fly and asked you to pluck their feathers for your own benefit, you would go and choose the ones with the most beautiful feathers; isn't that right?"
es: —Very well. And if they showed you a flock of birds with beautiful plumage, unable to take flight, and gave you permission to pluck their feathers for your own benefit, wouldn't you start with the ones that had the most beautiful feathers?

en: “It is true, madame.”
vi: − That's right, ma'am. −
tr: "Yes, that's correct, madam.""
es: —That's right, ma'am.

en: “You have seen both dolls and birds to-day,” said Madame Defarge, with a wave of her hand towards the place where they had last been apparent; “now, go home!”
vi: Today you have seen both dolls and birds, - Madame Defarge gestured towards the direction the court had just passed.
tr: "Today you saw both the babies and the birds," said Madam Defarge, extending her hand toward the area where they were last seen; "now, go home!"
es: —Well, you just saw the pile of beautiful dolls and the flock of brightly colored birds: now, let's go home.

en: CHAPTER XVI.
vi: - Now, go back to the countryside.
es: Chapter XVI.

en: Still Knitting
vi: 16. Still knitting, Madame Defarge and her husband leisurely returned to the heart of Saint Antoine, while a green speck of a hat trudged through the darkness, piercing the dust, traveling long distances along the roadside, slowly heading straight towards the Marquis' castle, where he now lay in his grave listening to the rustling leaves.
tr: Continue Knitting
es: MORE STITCHES PER INCH

en: Madame Defarge and monsieur her husband returned amicably to the bosom of Saint Antoine, while a speck in a blue cap toiled through the darkness, and through the dust, and down the weary miles of avenue by the wayside, slowly tending towards that point of the compass where the chateau of Monsieur the Marquis, now in his grave, listened to the whispering trees. Such ample leisure had the stone faces, now, for listening to the trees and to the fountain, that the few village scarecrows who, in their quest for herbs to eat and fragments of dead stick to burn, strayed within sight of the great stone courtyard and terrace staircase, had it borne in upon their starved fancy that the expression of the faces was altered. A rumour just lived in the village—had a faint and bare existence there, as its people had—that when the knife struck home, the faces changed, from faces of pride to faces of anger and pain; also, that when that dangling figure was hauled up forty feet above the fountain, they changed again, and bore a cruel look of being avenged, which they would henceforth bear for ever. In the stone face over the great window of the bed-chamber where the murder was done, two fine dints were pointed out in the sculptured nose, which everybody recognised, and which nobody had seen of old; and on the scarce occasions when two or three ragged peasants emerged from the crowd to take a hurried peep at Monsieur the Marquis petrified, a skinny finger would not have pointed to it for a minute, before they all started away among the moss and leaves, like the more fortunate hares who could find a living there.
vi: 16. Still knitting, Madame Defarge and her husband leisurely returned to the heart of Saint Antoine, while a green speck of a hat trudged through the darkness, piercing the dust, traveling long distances along the roadside, slowly heading straight towards the Marquis' castle, where he now lay in his grave listening to the rustling leaves. The stone statues now leisurely listened to the sounds of trees and flowing water, to the point that some ragged villagers - wandering into the stone castle courtyard and the wide-porched staircase in search of vegetables to eat and firewood to burn - in their hunger-induced delirium thought the faces of those statues had changed. There was a rumor whispered among the villagers - a rumor that refused to die just like the people here - that when the knife struck its mark, the faces of the statues changed from haughty to angry and pained; and when the culprit's body was hoisted twelve meters above the fountain, the faces of the statues changed once more to the brutal look of the avenged, and they have kept that look ever since. On the stone statue's face at the large window of the bedroom where the murder occurred, two small indentations on the nose could be clearly seen, which no one had noticed before; occasionally, a few ragged villagers would break away from the crowd to sneak a peek at the stony face of the Marquis, their bony fingers hastily pointing out those wrinkles for a moment, before all of them would leave to scavenge for something edible among the moss and leaves like a pack of hares, though hares were luckier not to be as hungry as the people.
tr: As Madam Defarge and her husband returned peacefully to the center of St. Antoine, they advanced through the darkness at a point with a blue hat, covering tiresome kilometers on dusty roads; they slowly headed towards the region where the château of Monsieur the Marquis, now lying in his grave, listened to the whispering rustle of the trees. They now had plenty of time to listen to the trees and the fountain with their stone faces, and when a handful of peasants, resembling scarecrows, reached the wide stone courtyard and the steps of the terrace while searching for grass to eat and twigs to burn, their hunger-stricken minds realized that the expressions on these faces had changed. According to a new rumor in the village – rumors as pale and feeble as the villagers themselves – when the knife was plunged, these faces also changed, turning from proud faces into ones filled with pain and anger; moreover, as the hanged body swung and changed direction ten meters above the fountain, the expressions changed again, adopting the cruel gaze of someone who had taken revenge, and they would remain that way forever. Two small indentations had appeared on the nose carved into the stone face above the large window of the bedroom where the murder was committed, everyone had noticed them, although no one had seen them before; occasionally, two or three ragged peasants would break away from the crowd to steal a glance at the petrified Monsieur the Marquis, and as soon as one of them extended a skinny finger towards it, they would all scurry away like wild rabbits through the moss and leaves, fleeing to places where they could feel at ease.
es: While Mrs. Defarge and her husband were returning in friendly company to the center of San Antonio, a blue cap was advancing, piercing the darkness and wrapped in thick clouds of dust along the roads leading to the place where the castle of the Marquis, at that time sleeping the eternal sleep, listened to the whispering conversations of the trees. The stone faces had plenty of time to listen to the conversations held by the trees and the fountain, and they took such interest in it that the skeletons that populated the village and roamed the vicinity of the castle in search of some herbs to quell their hunger and some logs to feed the fire of their cold homes, if they happened to see the courtyard, double staircase, and terrace of the castle, they allowed their famished imagination to entertain the idea that the expression of the stone faces had undergone a profound alteration. The wretched villagers assured that the expression of pride and disdain of the stone guardians of the castle turned into an expression of pain and anger when the knife struck the House, and they assured that from the moment the body of the murderer swung forty feet above the ground, the expression of pain and anger of those stone faces was replaced by one that breathed fierce vengeance, which would endure in them until the end of time. The stone face that watched over the large window of the bedroom where the murder had been committed appeared one day with two fine nicks on its nose; and if ever, from among a group of ragged villagers, two or three stood out to approach the petrified Marquis, not a minute of contemplation would pass without them fleeing scared like hares pursued by agile greyhounds.

en: Chateau and hut, stone face and dangling figure, the red stain on the stone floor, and the pure water in the village well—thousands of acres of land—a whole province of France—all France itself—lay under the night sky, concentrated into a faint hair-breadth line. So does a whole world, with all its greatnesses and littlenesses, lie in a twinkling star. And as mere human knowledge can split a ray of light and analyse the manner of its composition, so, sublimer intelligences may read in the feeble shining of this earth of ours, every thought and act, every vice and virtue, of every responsible creature on it.
vi: Castles and straw huts, stone statues and dangling corpses of the condemned, red bloodstains on marble floors and clear water in village wells - thousands of acres - an entire province of France - the whole of France - submerged under the starry sky, all reduced to a fleeting strip of land. The entire world is the same, with all its grand and trivial matters hidden under the twinkling stars. Just as only the human intellect can separate light and analyze the spectrum clearly, only extraordinary minds can perceive, within the hazy light that envelops this world, all thoughts and actions, all sins and virtues for which everyone on earth is accountable.
tr: The castle and the hut, the stone face and the swinging body, the red stain on the stone floor, the pristine water in the village well – thousands of acres of land – all the countryside of France – the entirety of France – stretched out as a thin line under the dark sky. Even the whole world, with all its grandeur and smallness, was lying within a twinkling star. As if the ordinary human mind could dissect a beam of light and analyze its composition, thus the superior intellects could read the thoughts, behaviors, every kind of immorality, and virtue of every creature on our dimly shining world.
es: Castle and huts, stone faces and flesh-and-blood faces, castle courtyard slabs stained red and pure waters enclosed in the village well, thousands of hectares of land... an entire province of France... all of France, sleep under the immense bluish vault, as if they were an imperceptible point, an atom lost in the immensity. The world is nothing else, with all its greatness and insignificance, in relation to the brilliant star that twinkles above. The wise men of the earth break, divide, decompose a ray of light and analyze its components; and in the same way, another intelligence more sublime than the human reads the weak glimmers that emanate from this earth we inhabit, and analyzes all thoughts and all actions, all vices and all virtues of the creatures endowed with intelligence.

en: The Defarges, husband and wife, came lumbering under the starlight, in their public vehicle, to that gate of Paris whereunto their journey naturally tended. There was the usual stoppage at the barrier guardhouse, and the usual lanterns came glancing forth for the usual examination and inquiry. Monsieur Defarge alighted; knowing one or two of the soldiery there, and one of the police. The latter he was intimate with, and affectionately embraced.
vi: The Defarges sat on the creaky public carriage under the starlight, following the familiar route towards the gates of Paris. The carriage had to stop at the checkpoint as usual, and the usual lanterns came out to inspect the faces. Mr. Defarge got off the carriage; he knew one or two of the guards here, along with a policeman. He was very close with the policeman, and the two embraced warmly.
tr: The Defarges, husband and wife, slowly made their way under the stars in their carriage and arrived at one of the gates of Paris, the point they aimed to reach. They were routinely stopped in front of the security barrier, and the usual lanterns were brightly shone on them for a general inspection and questioning. Monsieur Defarge got out of the carriage; he knew a couple of the soldiers and police officers there. He was familiar with the second one, and they embraced warmly.
es: The public carriage in which the Defarges, husband and wife, made their return journey stopped at the gate of the city closest to their home, where the usual lanterns soon appeared, tasked with conducting the customary examinations and investigations. Defarge jumped out of the carriage upon seeing two or three soldiers and a policeman he knew; the latter, with whom he had close ties of friendship, embraced him.

en: When Saint Antoine had again enfolded the Defarges in his dusky wings, and they, having finally alighted near the Saint’s boundaries, were picking their way on foot through the black mud and offal of his streets, Madame Defarge spoke to her husband:
vi: After the Defarge couple got off the carriage for the last time at the boundary of the area known as Saint Antoine, the saint once again enveloped them in his dark wings; as they groped their way through the black mud and filth of the alleys, Madame Defarge asked her husband: − Tell me, what did Jacques the policeman say to you?
tr: St Antoine had once again embraced the Defarges with its dim wings, and as they finally got off the carriage near St Antoine and struggled to walk through the streets filled with pitch-black mud and filth, Madame Defarge said to her husband:
es: Arriving at the boundaries of the district placed under the protection of the wings of Saint Anthony, the Defarges left the carriage and walked to their house on foot, through dark and muddy streets. On the way, Mrs. Defarge asked her husband:

en: “Say then, my friend; what did Jacques of the police tell thee?”
tr: "Tell me, my friend; what did Officer Jacques say to you?"
es: —What did Santiago the police officer tell you?

en: “Very little to-night, but all he knows. There is another spy commissioned for our quarter. There may be many more, for all that he can say, but he knows of one.”
vi: He said everything he had, but there was little news tonight. There is another spy hired to investigate our area. There may be more, but according to what he knows, there is only one.
tr: "He didn't say much tonight, but he told everything he knew. They have placed another spy in our region. There might be many more, but he only knew about one."
es: —Everything he knows, even though it is very little. They have appointed another spy for our neighborhood: maybe it's not the only one, but that one only knows about one.

en: “Eh well!” said Madame Defarge, raising her eyebrows with a cool business air. “It is necessary to register him. How do they call that man?”
vi: − Ah, I see! - Madame Defarge raised her eyebrows, looking indifferent. Then we need to add him to the list. Who is he?
tr: "Well, good!" said Madam Defarge, adopting a serious business air and raising her eyebrows. "We need to record that too. What's his name?"
es: —Alright—replied the innkeeper with her usual calm. —It will have to be noted in the register. What is that man's name?

en: “He is English.”
vi: − He is an Englishman.
tr: "He is an Englishman."
es: —It's English.

en: “So much the better. His name?”
vi: − Even better. What's his name?
tr: "Better." "What's his name?"
es: —Even better! Your name?

en: “Barsad,” said Defarge, making it French by pronunciation. But, he had been so careful to get it accurately, that he then spelt it with perfect correctness.
vi: − Barsad, - Defarge pronounced the name with a French accent. But he listened very carefully to be able to write it down accurately when he got home.
tr: "Barsad," said Defarge, pronouncing it as if it were French. But he had been so careful to understand the name correctly that he made no mistake when writing it.
es: —Barsad. —Barsad. —Perfect!

en: “Barsad,” repeated madame. “Good. Christian name?”
vi: − Barsad, - she repeated. - Good. And his given name?
tr: "Barsad," repeated the madam. "Good. What is his first name?"
es: —Perfect! What is your first name?

en: “John.”
vi: − John. − John Barsad, - she repeated, after muttering to herself.
tr: "John."
es: —Juan.

en: “John Barsad,” repeated madame, after murmuring it once to herself. “Good. His appearance; is it known?”
vi: − John. − John Barsad, - she repeated, after muttering to herself. - Good. And his appearance, do you know?
tr: After Madam muttered this to herself once, she repeated, "John Barsad." "Good. And his appearance; do we know it?"
es: —Juan Barsad... Juan Barsad—repeated the innkeeper. —Very well. Your address?

en: “Age, about forty years; height, about five feet nine; black hair; complexion dark; generally, rather handsome visage; eyes dark, face thin, long, and sallow; nose aquiline, but not straight, having a peculiar inclination towards the left cheek; expression, therefore, sinister.”
vi: − Age, around forty; height, about one meter seventy-five; black hair; dark skin; overall quite handsome; black eyes, thin, long face, sallow complexion; hooked nose rather than straight, slightly bent towards the left cheek, giving his face a sinister look.
tr: "Approximately in his forties, 1.75 meters tall, black-haired, dark-skinned, with a face that could be considered pleasant; dark eyes, a thin, long, pale face, a nose like a beak, but not straight, crooked to the left; this has given his face a rather sinister expression."
es: —About forty years old, around five feet nine inches tall, black hair, sallow complexion, black eyes, thin, aquiline nose, but not straight: it has the peculiarity of being slightly twisted to the left, which naturally gives him a sinister expression.

en: “Eh my faith. It is a portrait!” said madame, laughing. “He shall be registered to-morrow.”
vi: − Unbelievable. Just like a portrait! - The wife said while laughing. - Tomorrow he will be put on the list.
tr: "God bless you. You practically painted the man's portrait!" said the lady, laughing. "It will be recorded immediately tomorrow."
es: —It's a perfect likeness, upon my word!—exclaimed Madame Defarge, laughing. —I will record it tomorrow.

en: They turned into the wine-shop, which was closed (for it was midnight), and where Madame Defarge immediately took her post at her desk, counted the small moneys that had been taken during her absence, examined the stock, went through the entries in the book, made other entries of her own, checked the serving man in every possible way, and finally dismissed him to bed. Then she turned out the contents of the bowl of money for the second time, and began knotting them up in her handkerchief, in a chain of separate knots, for safe keeping through the night. All this while, Defarge, with his pipe in his mouth, walked up and down, complacently admiring, but never interfering; in which condition, indeed, as to the business and his domestic affairs, he walked up and down through life.
vi: They entered the tavern that had stopped selling (because it was already midnight), Mrs. Defarge immediately took her seat at the counter, counted the meager earnings collected while she was away, checked the inventory, reviewed the income and expense entries in the ledger, made additional entries herself, interrogated the assistant bartender thoroughly before letting him go to sleep. After that, she poured all the money from the bowl onto the table again, wrapped the coins in a handkerchief, tying each bundle separately to store them overnight. During that time, Defarge, with a pipe in his mouth, walked back and forth, pleased and admiringly watching his wife work but never interfering; indeed, in both business and family matters, he had spent his whole life just walking back and forth like that.
tr: They returned to the closed (because it was night) wine shop, and Madam Defarge immediately took her place at the counter, counted the coins that had accumulated in her absence, checked the supplies, examined the ledger they kept, took other notes herself, and after thoroughly inspecting the wine distributor in every possible way, sent him to bed. Then she once again turned the money bowl upside down and, to keep it safe at night, placed the money in her handkerchief, tying several knots one after the other. Meanwhile, Monsieur Defarge, with his pipe in his mouth, walked up and down the shop with an indifferent admiration, but never interfered with his wife; in fact, this was true both in his business and family matters, he walked up and down in life.
es: Upon arriving at the tavern, which they found closed—it was past midnight—Mrs. Defarge took a seat behind the counter and devoted her attention to examining the day's accounts. She began by pouring out the jar in which the proceeds of the sales were kept onto the counter, counted the money, measured the inventory, read the entries and exits recorded in the designated book, corrected the entries, made some new ones and discussed others, and after thoroughly scrutinizing and pressuring the individual in charge of the establishment in a thousand ways, she sent him to bed. Next, she made several equal piles from the coins taken out of the jar, which she tied into her handkerchief, soon turning it into a rosary of knots. Meanwhile, Defarge walked around the establishment, smoking his pipe and admiring with satisfaction his wife's prudent and wise domestic economy, though without interfering in it.

en: The night was hot, and the shop, close shut and surrounded by so foul a neighbourhood, was ill-smelling. Monsieur Defarge’s olfactory sense was by no means delicate, but the stock of wine smelt much stronger than it ever tasted, and so did the stock of rum and brandy and aniseed. He whiffed the compound of scents away, as he put down his smoked-out pipe.
vi: The night was sultry and the tavern reeked because the doors were closed and it was surrounded by a foul-smelling area. Defarge's sense of smell was not particularly sensitive, but the smell of wine in the cask seemed stronger than usual, and so did the barrels of rum, brandy, and anise liquor. He waved away that mixture of smells with a final puff of his pipe before putting it down.
tr: It was a hot night, and the tightly shut shop in an already stinking neighborhood reeked horribly. Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not very sensitive, but the smell of the wines in stock was many times sharper to his nose than their taste; likewise, the rum, cognac, and anise stock had a heavy odor. As he set aside his extinguished pipe, he puffed in disdain at this mixture of smells.
es: Since the shop was narrow, and the ceiling was low, and the night was extremely hot with all the windows and doors closed, the atmosphere was extraordinarily stale. Mr. Defarge's sense of smell was not a marvel of delicacy, but even so, the vapors of the wine, combined with those of the rum and the brandy, bothered him to such an extent that he tried to keep them away from his nose by snorting and fanning himself with his hands.

en: “You are fatigued,” said madame, raising her glance as she knotted the money. “There are only the usual odours.”
vi: − I'm tired, - the wife said, tying the money, looking up. The smell of alcohol is just normal.
tr: "You seem very tired," said the madam, looking at her husband while tying a knot in the handkerchief. "It smells like always."
es: —You are tired, my friend—said his wife, giving him a look while tying up the money.— The smell you breathe here is the same as every day.

en: “I am a little tired,” her husband acknowledged.
vi: − I'm a bit tired, - the husband admitted.
tr: "I am a bit tired, yes," admitted her husband.
es: —Indeed; I am tired—replied Defarge.

en: “You are a little depressed, too,” said madame, whose quick eyes had never been so intent on the accounts, but they had had a ray or two for him. “Oh, the men, the men!”
vi: − I'm also a bit discouraged, - the wife, who was sharp-eyed but not so focused on money matters that she didn't notice her husband. - Oh, you men are something else!
tr: "You seem a bit bored," said the madam; although her hurried eyes were intensely focused on the account, she couldn't help but glance at her husband from time to time. "Ah, these men, men!"
es: —And a little depressed and disheartened—replied the innkeeper's wife, whose piercing eyes, although focused on the accounts, spared one or two glances to examine her husband. —Ah... men!...

en: “But my dear!” began Defarge.
vi: − But darling! - Defarge began.
tr: "But my dear!" Defarge began to say.
es: —But...

en: “But my dear!” repeated madame, nodding firmly; “but my dear! You are faint of heart to-night, my dear!”
vi: − But darling! - The wife echoed, shaking her head vigorously. - But darling! Tonight you're disheartened, darling! −
tr: "But my dear!" repeated the lady, shaking her head resolutely; "but my dear! You are so spiritless tonight, darling!"
es: —No buts about it—replied the lady with firmness. —I repeat, tonight you are disheartened.

en: “Well, then,” said Defarge, as if a thought were wrung out of his breast, “it is a long time.”
vi: Yes, indeed, - Defarge said as if his wife had understood his innermost feelings, - it has been a long time. −
tr: "Actually," said Defarge, as if an idea had been torn from his chest, "it took a very long time."
es: —It takes so long!—exclaimed Defarge.

en: “It is a long time,” repeated his wife; “and when is it not a long time? Vengeance and retribution require a long time; it is the rule.”
vi: It has been a long time, - the wife repeated, - when has it ever been quick? Revenge and punishment are long-term matters, they have to be.
tr: His wife repeated, "It took too long; when did it not take long? Revenge and retaliation take a long time; that's how it is."
es: —Does it take so much time?... And what is it that doesn't require time? Revenge and justice have always required it!

en: “It does not take a long time to strike a man with Lightning,” said Defarge.
vi: − Lightning striking someone doesn't take much time, - Defarge said.
tr: "A lightning strike doesn't last very long, though," said Defarge.
es: —The lightning does not take long to strike a man—observed Defarge.

en: “How long,” demanded madame, composedly, “does it take to make and store the lightning? Tell me.”
vi: − How long does it take to create a lightning bolt? - The wife calmly asked.
tr: "Tell me," said the madam calmly, "How long does it take to produce and gather lightning?"
es: —And how long does it take for the necessary electricity to accumulate for the lightning to strike? Tell me, if you know!

en: Defarge raised his head thoughtfully, as if there were something in that too.
vi: Defarge looked up thoughtfully, perhaps his wife's words had some truth to them.
tr: Defarge, as if he had something on his mind, raised his head thoughtfully.
es: Defarge raised his head, but did not reply.

en: “It does not take a long time,” said madame, “for an earthquake to swallow a town. Eh well! Tell me how long it takes to prepare the earthquake?”
vi: His wife continued: − An earthquake burying a city doesn't take much time. That's right! So how long does it take to create an earthquake, tell me?
tr: "It doesn't take long for an earthquake to swallow a city," said the madam. "But how long does it take to prepare for that earthquake, you tell me that?""
es: —It takes little time for an earthquake to turn a city to dust. Well then, how much time is needed to prepare an earthquake?

en: “A long time, I suppose,” said Defarge.
vi: − A long time, probably, - Defarge said. −
tr: "It will probably take a long time," said Defarge.
es: —A lot, I suppose—replied Defarge.

en: “But when it is ready, it takes place, and grinds to pieces everything before it. In the meantime, it is always preparing, though it is not seen or heard. That is your consolation. Keep it.”
vi: But once it's ready, it happens, and crushes everything in its path. Meanwhile, it always accumulates, even if no one sees or hears it. Just stay assured. Don't lose heart.
tr: "But when it is ready and comes to life, it will shatter everything in its path. Even if we hear or see nothing, it is constantly preparing right now. Take comfort in this. Do not forget it."
es: —But when it is ready, when it happens, the city bursts, is pulverized, reduced to impalpable atoms. Console yourself! The earthquake is preparing itself even though no one sees it, even though no one hears it.

en: She tied a knot with flashing eyes, as if it throttled a foe.
vi: The wife tied another string of money, her eyes glaring as if she were strangling an enemy.
tr: With eyes gleaming as if he were strangling an enemy, he tied another knot.
es: With flashing eyes, he tied another knot; it seemed as if he were strangling an enemy.

en: “I tell thee,” said madame, extending her right hand, for emphasis, “that although it is a long time on the road, it is on the road and coming. I tell thee it never retreats, and never stops. I tell thee it is always advancing. Look around and consider the lives of all the world that we know, consider the faces of all the world that we know, consider the rage and discontent to which the Jacquerie addresses itself with more and more of certainty every hour. Can such things last? Bah! I mock you.”
vi: − I've told myself, - the wife spread her right hand to emphasize her words - revenge, even if it takes a long time, will eventually come. I already said, it never turns back, it never stops. I already said, it always moves forward. Look around and think about the lives of the many people you know, think about the faces of the many people you know, think about the rage and dissatisfaction that the Jacques brothers are expressing more and more intensely, day by day, hour by hour. Will those things last forever? Pfft! You are really funny.
tr: "Let me tell you this much," he said, extending his right hand to emphasize what he was about to say, "the journey may have been long, but that journey is coming to an end now. I'm telling you, it will never retreat and it will never stop. I'm telling you, it will always move forward. Take a look around and think of all the faces you know, think of all those Jacques' growing anger and discontent with each passing day. How much longer will this continue? Hah! Don't worry about it anymore."
es: —I assure you—he added, extending his right hand as if to give greater expression to his words—that no matter how late it may be, it is on its way, it is approaching by the moment. I assure you that it always advances, it does not retreat, it does not stop. Look around you and scrutinize the lives of all the people you know, observe the faces of the entire world, and you will see that the discontent, the rage that roars in the chest of the exploited increases day by day, hour by hour. And do you think that this state of affairs can last? Bah! You are naive!

en: “My brave wife,” returned Defarge, standing before her with his head a little bent, and his hands clasped at his back, like a docile and attentive pupil before his catechist, “I do not question all this. But it has lasted a long time, and it is possible—you know well, my wife, it is possible—that it may not come, during our lives.”
vi: − My brave wife, - Defarge replied, standing in front of his wife, head slightly bowed, hands clasped behind his back, looking like a diligent student attentively facing his catechism teacher, - I have no doubt about that. But this has gone on for too long, and it could be... you know, it could be... that we might not see it happen even until we die. −
tr: "My brave wife," said Defarge, with his head tilted to the side in front of his wife, his hands tied behind his back, like a well-behaved and good child being questioned by a religious teacher, "I am not questioning these things. But it took a very long time and maybe we won't live to see it – you know, my dear wife, this is possible."
es: —My dear little wife—replied Defarge, standing up in front of his wife, lowering his head and with his hands behind his back, resembling a docile schoolboy in front of his teacher,—I do not doubt it... The irritation exists: but it has been around for so long, that it is very possible... that it will not erupt in time for us to witness the cataclysm.

en: “Eh well! How then?” demanded madame, tying another knot, as if there were another enemy strangled.
vi: Well then! So what? - His wife asked while tying another string of money, adding another enemy strangled.
tr: "Hey! What does this mean now?" asked the madam, tying another knot as if she were strangling another enemy.
es: —And what?—replied the woman. —Even if that were the case, so what?

en: “Well!” said Defarge, with a half complaining and half apologetic shrug. “We shall not see the triumph.”
vi: − Well! - Defarge shrugged, half complaining, half regretting. - Then we will not see the victory, that's what.
tr: "Well!" said Defarge, shrugging his shoulders with a manner that was partly complaining, partly apologetic. "We may not see the victory."
es: —Well... we wouldn't have the joy of savoring the triumph.

en: “We shall have helped it,” returned madame, with her extended hand in strong action. “Nothing that we do, is done in vain. I believe, with all my soul, that we shall see the triumph. But even if not, even if I knew certainly not, show me the neck of an aristocrat and tyrant, and still I would—”
vi: − We have no choice, - the wife replied, extending her hand emphatically. - What we are doing is not useless at all. I believe, with all my soul, that we will see victory. But even if we don't see it, even if I am certain we won't, just give me the neck of a tyrannical noble and I will...
tr: "But we will be helping her," replied the madam, extending her hands with a determined gesture. "Nothing we do is in vain. I wholeheartedly believe that we will see the victory. But even if we won't see those days, even if we have no hope left, show me the throat of a cruel ruler or noble, and I will still..."
es: —But indeed, the fact of having contributed to it—said the innkeeper energetically. —Nothing we do will be in vain. I believe with all my soul that we will see the triumph; but even if I knew for certain that I would not have that joy, as long as there exists the neck of an aristocrat or a tyrant, I will not stop...

en: Then madame, with her teeth set, tied a very terrible knot indeed.
vi: Speaking of that, she gritted her teeth and clenched a string of money as if she wanted to tear someone apart. − There!
tr: Then, Madam clenched her teeth and tied another tight knot with all her might.
es: —Calm... calm!—exclaimed Defarge, whose face turned crimson as if he had been accused of being a coward.

en: “Hold!” cried Defarge, reddening a little as if he felt charged with cowardice; “I too, my dear, will stop at nothing.”
vi: - Defarge exclaimed, his face slightly red as if he felt accused of cowardice. - Me too, my dear, I will not stop at anything.
tr: Feeling accused of cowardice and blushing slightly, Defarge said to his wife, "Hold on, dear! I am not afraid of anything either."

en: “Yes! But it is your weakness that you sometimes need to see your victim and your opportunity, to sustain you. Sustain yourself without that. When the time comes, let loose a tiger and a devil; but wait for the time with the tiger and the devil chained—not shown—yet always ready.”
vi: − Right! But your weakness is that sometimes you need to see the prey and the opportunity to maintain your determination to the end. You must be resolute without needing to do so. When the time comes, unleash the tiger and the devil within; but for now, chain them up and wait... do not reveal them... but always be ready.
tr: "Correct! But your weakness is feeling the need to see your victim and the opportunity in your hand in order to continue on your path. Continue on your path without these. When the time comes, you will reveal the tiger and the devil within you; but for now, keep the tiger and the devil chained inside you –don't show them to anyone– yet always keep them ready."
es: Nor will I, my dear, retreat for anything or anyone. —I know; but you are weak despite everything, and you are, because to keep your courage from faltering you need to see your victim at your feet. Try not to falter, even if it seems that the victim is far away. When the time comes, unleash the tigers and demons you keep locked inside your chest, but in the meantime, keep them chained... hidden, but always ready.

en: Madame enforced the conclusion of this piece of advice by striking her little counter with her chain of money as if she knocked its brains out, and then gathering the heavy handkerchief under her arm in a serene manner, and observing that it was time to go to bed.
vi: The wife emphasized the final sentence of her advice by slamming a string of coins onto the bar counter as if she wanted to smash someone's brains out, then casually tucked the string of coins under her arm and told her husband it was time to go to bed.
tr: Madam, to increase the impact of her words, slammed her handkerchief full of money on the counter as if she were scattering her brains, then very calmly tucked the now heavier handkerchief under her arm and said it was time to go to bed.
es: The good innkeeper finished her advice by slamming a blow on the counter with the handkerchief turned into a heavy rosary; then she lifted it, and with unshakable calm indicated that it was already time to go to bed.

en: Next noontide saw the admirable woman in her usual place in the wine-shop, knitting away assiduously. A rose lay beside her, and if she now and then glanced at the flower, it was with no infraction of her usual preoccupied air. There were a few customers, drinking or not drinking, standing or seated, sprinkled about. The day was very hot, and heaps of flies, who were extending their inquisitive and adventurous perquisitions into all the glutinous little glasses near madame, fell dead at the bottom. Their decease made no impression on the other flies out promenading, who looked at them in the coolest manner (as if they themselves were elephants, or something as far removed), until they met the same fate. Curious to consider how heedless flies are!—perhaps they thought as much at Court that sunny summer day.
vi: The next noon, that respectable woman sat in her usual spot in the tavern, diligently knitting. And if she occasionally glanced at the rose placed beside her, the flower did not affect her familiar busy expression. The tavern had a few scattered patrons, some drinking, some not. It was very hot, and the curious, daring flies that ventured into the small sticky glasses near her all fell to the bottom, dead. Their deaths did not stir the slightest sympathy from the other flies outside, who indifferently watched their kind (as if they were elephants or some distant species), until they met the same fate. How peculiar those indifferent flies were! - Perhaps the courtiers in the blazing summer sun were just as calm and unfeeling.
tr: The next day at noon, this admirable woman was once again knitting with great determination in her usual spot at the wine shop. There was a rose beside her, and although she occasionally glanced at the flower, her usual demeanor never changed. A few customers, some drinking, some not, some standing, some sitting, were scattered around the shop. It was a very hot day; swarms of flies, which had extended their curious and adventurous searches to the sticky little glasses next to the lady, had fallen to the bottoms of the glasses one by one and died. The other flies buzzing around did not seem at all affected by their deaths; they just looked at them with the utmost composure (as if they themselves were elephants or some other equally unrelated animal) until they shared the same fate. How carefree flies are! –perhaps on that hot summer day, they could think no more than the Palace people.
es: The next morning, he found that admirable woman in her usual spot, knitting with true fervor. Beside her, there was a rose to which she occasionally turned her eyes. Some patrons, standing or sitting, were drinking and chatting. The day was very hot, and the swarms of flies, which carried their audacity to the extreme of investigating the contents of the glasses near the lady, soon fell dead at the bottom. Their unfortunate fate did not make the slightest impression on the other flies, who watched them unflinchingly and indifferently until the same misfortune befell them. How stupid flies are!

en: A figure entering at the door threw a shadow on Madame Defarge which she felt to be a new one. She laid down her knitting, and began to pin her rose in her head-dress, before she looked at the figure.
vi: A person stepped across the threshold, casting a shadow on Madame Defarge's wine counter, and she immediately knew it was a stranger. Putting down her knitting, she pinned a rose to her headscarf and looked at the newcomer.
tr: Then, a person who entered cast his shadow over Madam Defarge; it was a type completely unfamiliar to the madam. Madam put aside her knitting and pinned her rose to the edge of her bonnet before attending to the man.
es: Mrs. Defarge saw the shadow of a person entering the tavern and understood that it was a new customer. Before looking at the person's face, she placed the knitting on the counter and pinned the rose in her hair.

en: It was curious. The moment Madame Defarge took up the rose, the customers ceased talking, and began gradually to drop out of the wine-shop.
vi: How strange. As soon as Mrs. Defarge picked up the flower, the guests inside immediately stopped chatting and one by one left the tavern.
tr: It was a strange situation. With Madam Defarge raising her rose, the customers had stopped talking and started leaving the shop one by one.
es: The scene that followed could not have been more curious: as soon as the innkeeper's fingers touched the rose, conversations in the establishment ceased and all the patrons began to go out into the street.

en: “Good day, madame,” said the new-comer.
vi: − Hello, madam, - the stranger spoke.
tr: "Good day, madam," said the stranger.
es: —Good morning, ma'am—said the newcomer.

en: “Good day, monsieur.”
vi: − Hello, sir.
tr: "Good day, monsieur.""
es: —Good morning, sir—replied Mrs. Defarge, taking up her knitting again.—Ah!—she added to herself.

en: She said it aloud, but added to herself, as she resumed her knitting: “Hah! Good day, age about forty, height about five feet nine, black hair, generally rather handsome visage, complexion dark, eyes dark, thin, long and sallow face, aquiline nose but not straight, having a peculiar inclination towards the left cheek which imparts a sinister expression! Good day, one and all!”
vi: She said loudly, then continued knitting while muttering to herself: “Ah! Hello, about forty years old, approximately one meter seventy-five, black hair, overall quite handsome face, dark skin, black eyes, thin, long face, sallow complexion, hooked nose rather than straight, especially slightly crooked towards the left cheek, making the face look somewhat sinister! Hello, everyone!” −
tr: She said this out loud, but when she took her knitting back in hand, she muttered to herself: "Ha! Good days, at forty years old, 1.75 meters tall, black hair, dark skin, generally a face that could be called pleasant; dark eyes, thin, long, pale face, nose like a beak but not straight, crooked to the left; this gave her a rather untrustworthy expression! Good day to you all!"
es: —Good morning, sir—replied Mrs. Defarge, taking up her knitting again.—Ah!—she added to herself. —About forty years old, around five feet nine inches tall, black hair, sallow complexion, black eyes, thin, aquiline nose, but not straight, with the particularity of being slightly twisted to the left, which naturally gives a sinister expression... Truly a good day!

en: “Have the goodness to give me a little glass of old cognac, and a mouthful of cool fresh water, madame.”
vi: Please give me a small glass of aged cognac, and a glass of cool water, madam.
tr: "Could you please give me a small glass of old cognac and a large glass of cold water, madam?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to give me a small glass of old cognac and a sip of fresh water, ma'am?

en: Madame complied with a polite air.
vi: She politely serves the guests.
tr: The lady graciously fulfilled the man's request.
es: The barmaid served what the customer ordered.

en: “Marvellous cognac this, madame!”
vi: − This cognac is excellent, madam!
tr: "This is a magnificent cognac, madam!""
es: —Delicious cognac, madam!

en: It was the first time it had ever been so complimented, and Madame Defarge knew enough of its antecedents to know better. She said, however, that the cognac was flattered, and took up her knitting. The visitor watched her fingers for a few moments, and took the opportunity of observing the place in general.
vi: It was the first time someone had praised it like that, and Mrs. Defarge, knowing the origin of this cognac, did not believe it. Nevertheless, she thanked him for the compliment and continued knitting. The guest watched the nimble fingers of the innkeeper for a while and then took this opportunity to observe the surroundings.
tr: The cognac had never been praised so highly before, and Madam Defarge knew well the state of the previous ones. Nevertheless, she told the man that he had praised the cognac too much and resumed her knitting. After watching the woman's fingers for a few minutes, the stranger glanced around.
es: As it was the first time she had heard her cognac praised, it is not surprising that the innkeeper suspected that the praise was due to reasons that perhaps were not precisely the quality of the liquor. She gave thanks, however, and continued knitting. The stranger remained for a few moments observing Mrs. Defarge's hands, and in passing, taking note of the establishment.

en: “You knit with great skill, madame.”
vi: − You knit so well.
tr: "How beautifully you knit, madam.""
es: —You knit with marvelous speed—he said.

en: “I am accustomed to it.”
vi: − I'm used to it. −
tr: "I'm used to it now."
es: —The habit... I am very accustomed to this work.

en: “A pretty pattern too!”
vi: The patterns are also beautiful!
tr: "What a beautiful pattern it is!""
es: —And with a perfection that enchants.

en: “You think so?” said madame, looking at him with a smile.
vi: − You think so? - She smiled at the guest.
tr: "Do you think so?" said the madam, looking at him with a smile on her face.
es: —Do you think so?

en: “Decidedly. May one ask what it is for?”
vi: − Certainly. May I ask what you are knitting for?
tr: "Absolutely. May I ask what you are knitting?"
es: —With all my soul... And tell me: that stocking is...?

en: “Pastime,” said madame, still looking at him with a smile while her fingers moved nimbly.
vi: − Just for fun, - she said, her eyes still looking, her mouth still smiling, her fingers still moving swiftly.
tr: "I'm just keeping myself busy," said the woman, her fingers moving quickly, still with a smile on her face, looking at him.
es: —Pastime... a means of distraction—replied the innkeeper, looking at her interlocutor with a smile on her lips.

en: “Not for use?”
vi: − So it's for nothing? −
tr: "So, you're not knitting anything specific?"
es: —Aren't you going to make use of it?

en: “That depends. I may find a use for it one day. If I do—Well,” said madame, drawing a breath and nodding her head with a stern kind of coquetry, “I’ll use it!”
vi: It depends. Who knows, one day it might be needed. If it is needed... Well, - she took a breath and shook her head as if both flirting and showing seriousness, - then I'll use it!
tr: "It depends on the situation." "One day it might be useful." "If I finish it..." "well," said the madam, sighing and shaking her head with a cruel flirtation, "I'll use it!""
es: —According to. Perhaps the day will come when I use them—said the innkeeper with a certain coquettishness. —Surely I will use them... if I make them well.

en: It was remarkable; but, the taste of Saint Antoine seemed to be decidedly opposed to a rose on the head-dress of Madame Defarge. Two men had entered separately, and had been about to order drink, when, catching sight of that novelty, they faltered, made a pretence of looking about as if for some friend who was not there, and went away. Nor, of those who had been there when this visitor entered, was there one left. They had all dropped off. The spy had kept his eyes open, but had been able to detect no sign. They had lounged away in a poverty-stricken, purposeless, accidental manner, quite natural and unimpeachable.
vi: The noteworthy thing is that the preferences of the people in the Saint Antoine district seemed to be clearly at odds with the rose on Madame Defarge's headscarf. Two people had entered the shop one after the other, intending to order a drink, but upon seeing that decoration, they hesitated, pretended to look around as if searching for a friend who wasn't there, and then left. Those who were present in the shop when this stranger entered had all left, leaving no one behind. Disappeared without a trace. The spy had observed carefully but saw no signs. Everyone was listlessly wandering in the same manner of destitution, aimlessly, unintentionally, completely naturally, and without any suspicion.
tr: It was a remarkable situation. The taste of St. Antoine seemed to be in direct contrast with the rose on Madame Defarge's cap. Two men had entered separately, and just as they were about to order their drinks, their eyes caught this change, causing them to hesitate, and then they left, pretending not to look at a friend who wasn't there. In fact, when this stranger entered, only one person remained from those who were already there. Everyone else had left. The spy had kept his eyes wide open but had found nothing. People had left the shop in a manner that aroused no suspicion, sluggishly, in their miserable, aimless, and random states.
es: As curious as it may seem, the fact is that the taste of Saint Anthony showed a decided opposition to Mrs. Defarge displaying a rose in her hairstyle. Two men entered separately, approached the counter with the clear intention of ordering something to drink, and no sooner did they see the rose, they hesitated, looked around as if searching for a friend, whom they did not find, and immediately left. Of all those who were in the establishment when the one conversing with the landlady entered, not a single one remained: they had all left. The spy, for readers will have understood by now that the individual in question was a spy, had not managed to catch any signals, even though he had been looking with a hundred eyes since he entered.

en: “John,” thought madame, checking off her work as her fingers knitted, and her eyes looked at the stranger. “Stay long enough, and I shall knit ‘barsad’ before you go.”
vi: “John,” the shop owner thought to herself, her fingers weaving this name into the list, then looked at the stranger. “Stay a little longer and I will have time to weave in your surname Barsad as well.” −
tr: Her fingers knitting furiously and her eyes on the stranger, while working her patterns, the lady thought to herself, "JOHN." "Stay a little longer so that I can knit 'BARSAD' before you leave.""
es: —Juan!—thought Mrs. Defarge, knitting and keeping her eyes on the customer. —If you stay here much longer, I will write Barsad right under your nose.

en: “You have a husband, madame?”
vi: Do you have a husband?
tr: "Are you married, madam?""
es: —Are you married, ma'am?

en: “I have.”
vi: − Yes. − Children? −
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Children?”
vi: No children.
tr: "Do you have children?"
es: —With children?

en: “No children.”
vi: No children.
tr: "No."
es: —Without children.

en: “Business seems bad?”
vi: − Business seems difficult?
tr: "Things are probably going badly?"
es: —And business, is it going well?

en: “Business is very bad; the people are so poor.”
vi: − Business is very difficult; the people are too poor. −
tr: "Things are bad; people are very poor.""
es: —Business is very bad. People are so poor!...

en: “Ah, the unfortunate, miserable people! So oppressed, too—as you say.”
vi: Oh, the miserable, unfortunate people! And they are so oppressed too... as you said.
tr: "Oh unfortunate and miserable people! Moreover, there is so much pressure on them – as you said."
es: —Ah, yes! Poor and unfortunate! And even shamefully oppressed!... as you say.

en: “As you say,” madame retorted, correcting him, and deftly knitting an extra something into his name that boded him no good.
vi: − "You said it yourself," she retorted, corrected, and swiftly added some symbol that was anything but nice to this name.
tr: "As you said," the lady immediately corrected, and skillfully wove something ominous next to the man's name.
es: —As you say—corrected the barmaid, moving her fingers more quickly and adding something to the surname Barsad.

en: “Pardon me; certainly it was I who said so, but you naturally think so. Of course.”
vi: − Excuse me, it was indeed I who spoke, not her, but of course, she thinks the same way. Of course.
tr: "Ah, pardon; I was the one who said that, of course, but you must be thinking the same thing." "Certainly.""
es: —Excuse me: it's true that I was the one who said it, but I have no doubt that you think it. It can't be anything else.

en: “I think?” returned madame, in a high voice. “I and my husband have enough to do to keep this wine-shop open, without thinking. All we think, here, is how to live. That is the subject we think of, and it gives us, from morning to night, enough to think about, without embarrassing our heads concerning others. I think for others? No, no.”
vi: − I think so? - She responded in a high voice. - My husband and I are already too busy running this tavern. We don't think about anything else. Here, we only think about how to survive. That's what we think about, and that's enough to keep us busy from morning till night, with no time to think about anything else. Me thinking about something else? No way.
tr: "Is that so?" replied the madam loudly. "We have no time to think from trying to keep this wine shop running with my husband. The only thing we think about here is how we will live. That's our whole concern, so our minds are occupied with many things day and night, we have no state to think about others. How are other people doing? There's nothing to be done."
es: —Do I think about it?—replied the innkeeper. —Our establishment causes my husband and me too many headaches for us to afford the luxury of thinking. The only thing we think about is making sure we have what we need to live. This is the goal of all our musings, which provides a very broad field for all our thoughts. Me think for others? Not in my lifetime!

en: The spy, who was there to pick up any crumbs he could find or make, did not allow his baffled state to express itself in his sinister face; but, stood with an air of gossiping gallantry, leaning his elbow on Madame Defarge’s little counter, and occasionally sipping his cognac.
vi: Coming here to gather any bit of information he could get, the spy did not let his bewilderment show on his sinister face but stood there pretending to chat casually, with both elbows resting on Madame Defarge's wine counter, occasionally sipping a bit of cognac.
tr: The spy, who was there to gather the smallest crumb of information he could find, had managed not to let his astonishment show on his sinister face, but as he leaned his elbow on Madame Defarge's small counter and sipped his cognac little by little, he still stood there with the air of a gossiping hero.
es: The spy, who had entered determined to gather whatever he could, was very careful not to let his sinister face show his disappointment. On the contrary, he continued leaning on his elbows over the counter, directing the occasional compliment to the barmaid and taking a sip of cognac from time to time.

en: “A bad business this, madame, of Gaspard’s execution. Ah! the poor Gaspard!” With a sigh of great compassion.
vi: − It was really terrible, ma'am, the execution of Gaspard. Oh! Poor Gaspard! - Sighed very sympathetically. − Really? -
tr: "This is very bad, madam, I mean Gaspard's execution. Oh! Poor Gaspard!" she said, sighing deeply with sorrow.
es: —The execution of Gaspard has been a judicial brutality, madam. Poor Gaspard!—she exclaimed, letting out a sigh. —We do not agree—replied the innkeeper coldly.

en: “My faith!” returned madame, coolly and lightly, “if people use knives for such purposes, they have to pay for it. He knew beforehand what the price of his luxury was; he has paid the price.”
vi: The innkeeper's wife nonchalantly. - Whoever uses a knife for such things must pay the price. He knew the price of that luxury beforehand and has paid it.
tr: "Peace!" said the madam with a calm and carefree demeanor, "if people use knives for such purposes, they must bear the consequences. He knew what this behavior would cost and he paid for it."
es: —It is only fair that those who allow their knives to be used as Gaspard used his, should pay for it. He knew perfectly well the price at which such luxuries are paid, and he has paid it: nothing more natural.

en: “I believe,” said the spy, dropping his soft voice to a tone that invited confidence, and expressing an injured revolutionary susceptibility in every muscle of his wicked face: “I believe there is much compassion and anger in this neighbourhood, touching the poor fellow? Between ourselves.”
vi: − I heard that... - the spy lowered his voice to a whisper as if to suggest a secret, every muscle on his fierce face showing the suspicion of a wounded revolutionary - I heard that the people here are very sympathetic and angry about that unfortunate person. Just telling you, ma'am.
tr: The spy, "If you ask me," he said, giving his voice a softness that evoked confidence and adding a revolutionary sensitivity to every nerve of his mischievous face; "If you ask me, the people in this neighborhood are filled with great compassion and anger because of this poor man. Let's keep it between us."
es: —I believe—added the spy, lowering his voice and as if inviting his interlocutor to enter the realm of confidences, while giving his sinister face a resolutely revolutionary expression,—I believe that this whole neighborhood sympathizes with the fate of the unfortunate man and roars with fury against those who have sacrificed him. Just between the two of us, I find it justified.

en: “Is there?” asked madame, vacantly.
vi: − Really? - the shop owner asked absentmindedly.
tr: "Is that so?" said the madam, with empty eyes.
es: —But does that fury exist?

en: “Is there not?”
vi: − Isn't that so?
tr: "Isn't that so?"
es: —Haven't you noticed?

en: “—Here is my husband!” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − ... My house is there! - Mrs. Defarge said.
tr: "..." "Here comes my husband!" said Madam Defarge.
es: —Here is my husband—said Mrs. Defarge.

en: As the keeper of the wine-shop entered at the door, the spy saluted him by touching his hat, and saying, with an engaging smile, “Good day, Jacques!” Defarge stopped short, and stared at him.
vi: The shop owner had just passed through the door when the spy lifted his hat in greeting and said with a deliberate smile, "Hello, Jacques!" Defarge stood still, glaring at him.
tr: When the owner of the wine shop walked in through the door, the spy touched his hat and greeted him, smiling sympathetically, "Good day, Jacques!" he said. Defarge stayed where he was and fixed his eyes on the man.
es: No sooner had the innkeeper entered the establishment, the spy greeted him by touching his hat and saying with an insinuating smile: —Good morning, Santiago. Defarge stood rooted to the ground, his eyes fixed on the spy.

en: “Good day, Jacques!” the spy repeated; with not quite so much confidence, or quite so easy a smile under the stare.
vi: − Hello, Jacques! - He repeated, no longer entirely confident, and the smile became awkward under that intense stare.
tr: "Good day, Jacques!" repeated the spy, but under these gazes, the confidence in his voice and the smile on his face had weakened.
es: —You are mistaken, my good sir.

en: “You deceive yourself, monsieur,” returned the keeper of the wine-shop. “You mistake me for another. That is not my name. I am Ernest Defarge.”
vi: − You are mistaken, sir, - the innkeeper replied. - You are mistaking me for someone else. That is not my name. I am Ernest Defarge.
tr: "There is a mistake, monsieur," replied the owner of the wine shop. "You must have confused me with someone else. I am not Jacques. My name is Ernest Defarge."
es: — You are confusing me with someone else. My name is not Santiago: I am Ernesto Defarge.

en: “It is all the same,” said the spy, airily, but discomfited too: “good day!”
vi: − It's all the same, - the spy said cheerfully, but also awkwardly.
tr: "What difference does it make," said the spy in a flippant manner but was annoyed, "still, have a good day!"
es: —It's the same—replied the spy with a smile on his lips, although unable to completely hide his annoyance.—The name is the least of it.

en: “Good day!” answered Defarge, drily.
vi: - Hello! − Hello! - Defarge coldly replied.
tr: "Good day!" said Defarge emotionlessly.
es: Good morning. —Good morning—replied Defarge curtly.

en: “I was saying to madame, with whom I had the pleasure of chatting when you entered, that they tell me there is—and no wonder!—much sympathy and anger in Saint Antoine, touching the unhappy fate of poor Gaspard.”
vi: − I was just telling her, I had the honor of conversing with your wife when you came in, talking about how the people of Saint Antoine are very sympathetic and angry... and rightly so!... About the unfortunate fate of poor Gaspard.
tr: "When you came in, I was telling the lady with whom I had the pleasure of conversing that St. Antoine was seething with pain and anger due to the poor fate of unfortunate Gaspard – and rightly so!"
es: —I was telling the lady, with whom I have had the honor of chatting for a while, that, according to what I am told, there reigns in the neighborhood... and it does not surprise me... as much sympathy for the unfortunate Gaspard as there is irritation against those who have inhumanely sacrificed him.

en: “No one has told me so,” said Defarge, shaking his head. “I know nothing of it.”
vi: − I haven't heard anyone say that, - Defarge shook his head. - I don't know anything about this.
tr: "I have never heard of such a thing," said Defarge, shaking his head from side to side. "I have no idea.""
es: —I have heard no one say such a thing—replied Defarge. —I don't know a word.

en: Having said it, he passed behind the little counter, and stood with his hand on the back of his wife’s chair, looking over that barrier at the person to whom they were both opposed, and whom either of them would have shot with the greatest satisfaction.
vi: After speaking, he walked around behind the bar, stood with his hand on the back of his wife's chair, and looked at the person sitting on the other side of the barrier facing both of them, the person whom both he and his wife would gleefully shoot dead if they could.
tr: After saying this, Defarge went behind the small counter and stood there with his hand on the back of his wife's chair, both of them scrutinizing the man standing directly in front of them, whom they would drown in a spoonful of water if they could.
es: Having said this, he went behind the counter and positioned himself behind his wife. From the opposite side of the fragile barrier, the couple observed the individual whom they would have shot with the greatest pleasure.

en: The spy, well used to his business, did not change his unconscious attitude, but drained his little glass of cognac, took a sip of fresh water, and asked for another glass of cognac. Madame Defarge poured it out for him, took to her knitting again, and hummed a little song over it.
vi: Accustomed to the job, the detective pretended not to know, continued to drink the small glass of cognac, sipped a bit of cool water, then ordered another glass of cognac. Mrs. Defarge poured wine for him, then picked up her knitting and continued, knitting while softly humming a song.
tr: The spy, who had now mastered his craft, still acted as if he was unaware of anything; he had finished his glass of cognac, taken a sip of water, and asked for another glass of cognac. Madam Defarge filled the man's glass, took up her knitting again, and started to hum a song.
es: The spy, skilled in his trade, did not change his attitude of indifference. He finished the contents of the small glass that had been served to him, took a sip of fresh water, and ordered the second glass of cognac. Mrs. Defarge served it to him, after which she continued knitting with great fervor and humming a tune.

en: “You seem to know this quarter well; that is to say, better than I do?” observed Defarge.
vi: − It seems you know this area well; that is, even better than I do? - Defarge said.
tr: "It seems you know this area even better than I do, huh?" said Defarge.
es: —It seems that you know the neighborhood well—observed Defarge;—I mean, you know it better than I do.

en: “Not at all, but I hope to know it better. I am so profoundly interested in its miserable inhabitants.”
vi: − No, but I want to know more. I am deeply concerned about the miserable residents here.
tr: "No, not really, but I want to learn better. I have a deep interest in the wretched inhabitants of these parts."
es: —No, my friend. I know it very little, but I hope to get to know it well. Its wretched inhabitants awaken a deep interest in me.

en: “Hah!” muttered Defarge.
vi: − Hmph! - Defarge muttered. −
tr: "Hmph!" grumbled Defarge.
es: —Ah!—exclaimed Defarge.

en: “The pleasure of conversing with you, Monsieur Defarge, recalls to me,” pursued the spy, “that I have the honour of cherishing some interesting associations with your name.”
vi: Thanks to the honor of speaking with you, Mr. Defarge, I remember this matter, - the spy continued - the matter is that I also have the honor of knowing some interesting things related to you.
tr: "Monsieur Defarge, the happiness of speaking with you has given me the honor of recalling some individuals associated with your name," the spy continued.
es: "The pleasure of conversing with you, Mr. Defarge," continued the spy, "reminds me that I have had the honor of becoming familiar with incidents in which you have taken an active part."

en: “Indeed!” said Defarge, with much indifference.
vi: − Really? - Defarge responded more indifferently. −
tr: "Is that so!" said Defarge, with a rather indifferent attitude.
es: —Really!—said Defarge indifferently.

en: “Yes, indeed. When Doctor Manette was released, you, his old domestic, had the charge of him, I know. He was delivered to you. You see I am informed of the circumstances?”
vi: Yes, really. When Dr. Manette was released from prison, it was you, his former servant, who took care of him, I know this. He was entrusted to you. I know this well, you see? −
tr: "Yes, yes. When Doctor Manette was released, I know that you took care of him as his former servant. They brought him to you. As you can see, I am aware of what happened."
es: —Nothing more certain. When Doctor Manette was released, you, who were once his servant, took charge of him. He was entrusted to you. So you see, I am well aware of the matter.

en: “Such is the fact, certainly,” said Defarge. He had had it conveyed to him, in an accidental touch of his wife’s elbow as she knitted and warbled, that he would do best to answer, but always with brevity.
vi: That is correct, - Defarge said. While knitting and humming, his wife casually nudged him with her elbow, implying that he should answer, but as briefly as possible.
tr: "That's right!" said Defarge. His wife, while knitting, had accidentally nudged him with her elbow and murmured like a song that it would be good to give a quick answer without prolonging the conversation.
es: —It's true: you are right—he replied. Accidentally, his wife's elbow, which continued to move the needles with great activity, brushed against his, and in the brushing, despite being accidental, Defarge saw an indication that he should answer the spy's questions, but briefly.

en: “It was to you,” said the spy, “that his daughter came; and it was from your care that his daughter took him, accompanied by a neat brown monsieur; how is he called?—in a little wig—Lorry—of the bank of Tellson and Company—over to England.”
vi: − You were the one Dr. Manette's daughter came to find, - the spy said, - and she took her father away from your place, accompanied by a gentleman in a fine brown coat; what was his name again?... wearing a small wig... Lorry... from Tellson's Bank and Company... went to England.
tr: "The girl had come to you," said the spy, "and she had taken her away from you, accompanied by a gentleman in a neat brown suit; what was his name? –he had a small wig on his head –Lorry from Tellson and Company– from England."
es: —The doctor's daughter presented herself to you—continued the spy. —She came in the company of a gentleman... what was his name?... A gentleman who wore a wig... Ah, yes! Lorry... His name was Lorry... from Tellson's Bank and Company... She came in the company of Mr. Lorry, took charge of her father's person, and took him to England.

en: “Such is the fact,” repeated Defarge.
vi: − That's right, - Defarge repeated. −
tr: "It is true," repeated Defarge.
es: —That is how it was, indeed—repeated Defarge.

en: “Very interesting remembrances!” said the spy. “I have known Doctor Manette and his daughter, in England.”
vi: Very good memories! - The spy said. - I know Dr. Manette and his daughter in England.
tr: "Very interesting things have stayed in my mind!" said the spy. "I had met Doctor Manette and his daughter in England."
es: —One always remembers such incidents with pleasure—replied the spy. —I have met Dr. Manette and his daughter in England.

en: “Yes?” said Defarge.
vi: − Really? - Defarge said.
tr: "Is that so?" said Defarge.
es: —Yes?—asked Defarge.

en: “You don’t hear much about them now?” said the spy.
vi: − Haven't you heard any news about them lately?
tr: "Don't you receive news from them anymore?" said the spy.
es: —Do you receive news from him frequently?—asked the spy.

en: “No,” said Defarge.
vi: − No. −
tr: "No," said Defarge.
es: —No—responded Defarge.

en: “In effect,” madame struck in, looking up from her work and her little song, “we never hear about them. We received the news of their safe arrival, and perhaps another letter, or perhaps two; but, since then, they have gradually taken their road in life—we, ours—and we have held no correspondence.”
vi: In fact, - Madame Defarge paused her knitting, stopped singing, and looked up to interject, - we haven't heard anything about them anymore. We heard that they arrived safely, and received one or two letters; but since then, we've gone our separate ways... they and us... we no longer have any contact. −
tr: "Actually," Madam Defarge interjected, lifting her head from her work and pausing her song, "we can no longer hear from them. We had heard that they arrived safely, then we received one or two more letters, but after that, they went their way, we went ours, and our connection was completely severed.
es: —It's been a very long time since we've heard from them—interjected the innkeeper's wife. —We received news that they had arrived safely, and some time later a letter... maybe two; but then, they continued on their way, we on ours, and our correspondence has completely ceased.

en: “Perfectly so, madame,” replied the spy. “She is going to be married.”
vi: That's right, madam, - the spy responded. - That girl is about to get married. −
tr: "You are right, madam," replied the spy. "The doctor's daughter is going to get married soon."
es: —That's what usually happens—observed the spy.—The daughter is ready to get married.

en: “Going?” echoed madame. “She was pretty enough to have been married long ago. You English are cold, it seems to me.”
vi: About to? - The landlady said. - A girl as pretty as her should have been married long ago. You English people seem quite cold. −
tr: "Is she going to get married?" repeated the madam. "She was such a lovely girl that I thought she must have already gotten married." "I think you English people are quite cold too.""
es: —Is she about to get married?—repeated Madame Defarge. —She is quite beautiful enough to have been married long ago. Of course, you English are blocks of ice instead of men!

en: “Oh! You know I am English.”
vi: Oh! You know I'm English.
tr: "Aaa! How do you know that I am English?""
es: —Ah! Who told you that I am English?

en: “I perceive your tongue is,” returned madame; “and what the tongue is, I suppose the man is.”
vi: − From the voice, I can tell, - the shop owner replied, - and I think the voice reflects the person.
tr: "I understood your language," replied the madam, "and to me, a person is what their language is."
es: —I see that your language is English, and I have always believed that a man is of the same nationality as his language.

en: He did not take the identification as a compliment; but he made the best of it, and turned it off with a laugh. After sipping his cognac to the end, he added:
vi: That guy didn't take this recognition as a compliment; but he skillfully managed with a fake laugh. After finishing his glass of cognac, he continued: − Yes, Miss Manette is getting married.
tr: Although Casus did not see this observation as a compliment. he did not show that he was upset and brushed it off with a laugh. Then he downed the cognac and said:
es: Discovering his nationality did not amuse the spy at all, although he took great care to keep his discontent deep in his chest. He let out a laugh, finished the contents of his glass, and replied:

en: “Yes, Miss Manette is going to be married. But not to an Englishman; to one who, like herself, is French by birth. And speaking of Gaspard (ah, poor Gaspard! It was cruel, cruel!), it is a curious thing that she is going to marry the nephew of Monsieur the Marquis, for whom Gaspard was exalted to that height of so many feet; in other words, the present Marquis. But he lives unknown in England, he is no Marquis there; he is Mr. Charles Darnay. D’Aulnais is the name of his mother’s family.”
vi: After finishing his glass of cognac, he continued: − Yes, Miss Manette is getting married. But she is not marrying an Englishman; she is marrying someone like her, of French origin. Speaking of Gaspard; (Oh dear, poor Gaspard! So cruel, so cruel!) the strange thing is that she is about to marry the nephew of the Marquis, the very person for whom Gaspard was hanged high up; in other words; Miss Manette's fiancé is the current Marquis. But he lives in hiding in England, where he is no Marquis at all; he is Charles Darnay. Called by the name D’Aulnais on his mother's side.
tr: "Yes, Miss Manette is getting married. But not to an Englishman; to someone who, like her, is French by birth. Speaking of Gaspard (oh poor Gaspard! What a great cruelty, it was terrible!) how strange it is that Miss Manette is going to marry Monsieur Marquis's nephew, that is, the person who caused Gaspard to hang so many meters above; in other words, the new Marquis, Mr. Charles Darnay – his mother's maiden name was also D'Aulnais."
es: —Well yes, Miss Manette is about to get married, but not to an Englishman, rather to a man who, like her, was born in France. Speaking of Gaspard!... Poor Gaspard!... It was cruelty... an act of ferocity!... Well then, the man Miss Manette is going to marry is the nephew of the Marquis because of whom Gaspard danced at a height of forty feet above the ground; or rather: the current Marquis. He lives in England under an assumed name, without flaunting the title of Marquis. He calls himself Charles Darnay; you know that his mother's surname was D'Aulnais.

en: Madame Defarge knitted steadily, but the intelligence had a palpable effect upon her husband. Do what he would, behind the little counter, as to the striking of a light and the lighting of his pipe, he was troubled, and his hand was not trustworthy. The spy would have been no spy if he had failed to see it, or to record it in his mind.
vi: Madame Defarge continued knitting as usual, but this news visibly affected her husband.
