Behind the wine counter, Defarge struck a match and lit his pipe, his hands trembling with everything he did, showing his agitation. That spy wouldn't be worthy of being called a spy if he didn't notice or pay attention to those signs.
tr: Madam Defarge was still knitting resolutely, but the news she had received had a visible effect on her husband. It was evident from his every move that he was struggling as he lit his pipe behind the small counter, his hands trembling. If the spy had missed this or failed to note it in his mind, he wouldn't be called a spy.
es: Mrs. Defarge had neither eyes nor hands, nor faculties for anything other than the knitting she was doing, but the news had a palpable effect on her husband. His face reflected intense turmoil, despite his efforts to control himself, his hands trembled, and his inner agitation seeped through every pore of his body. The spy would not have been worthy of his position if he had not noticed this and committed it to memory.

en: Having made, at least, this one hit, whatever it might prove to be worth, and no customers coming in to help him to any other, Mr. Barsad paid for what he had drunk, and took his leave: taking occasion to say, in a genteel manner, before he departed, that he looked forward to the pleasure of seeing Monsieur and Madame Defarge again. For some minutes after he had emerged into the outer presence of Saint Antoine, the husband and wife remained exactly as he had left them, lest he should come back.
vi: At least he won a point, though its value was uncertain, and with no customers entering the shop for him to gather more information, Barsad paid for his drink and left; on his way out, he courteously expressed his desire to have the honor of meeting Mr. and Mrs. Defarge again. He had been outside Saint Antoine for a few minutes, yet the couple remained in their positions, fearing he might return.
tr: Although it was not very clear what Defarge's state proved, at least the spy had managed to hit him from somewhere, and since there were no other customers around to come to his aid with another piece of evidence, Mr. Barsad paid for his drinks and left the shop. Before leaving, he created an opportunity and in a polite manner. He did not forget to mention that he would be happy to see Monsieur and Madame Defarge again and that he was looking forward to it. Even after the spy had moved far away from St. Antoine, the couple waited in the same position for a while, in case he might return.
es: Having obtained that result, although without knowing if it could be of any use to him, Mr. Barsad, seeing that no customers were arriving whose conversations might have provided him with valuable information, paid for what he had taken and left, not without expressing, with great politeness, that he would have the pleasure of frequently visiting the establishment. Minutes later, when the spy had left the area protected by Saint Anthony, husband and wife continued exactly as if the spy had not left the shop, undoubtedly fearing that he might retrace his steps.

en: “Can it be true,” said Defarge, in a low voice, looking down at his wife as he stood smoking with his hand on the back of her chair: “what he has said of Ma’amselle Manette?”
vi: − Is it true? - Defarge asked in a low voice, looking down at his wife while he stood smoking, one hand resting on the back of her chair. − What he said about Miss Manette, is it true?
tr: "I wonder," said Defarge in a low voice, standing behind his wife's chair, looking at her while puffing on his pipe, "could what the man said about Mademoiselle Manette be true?"
es: —Could it be true what that man said about Miss Manette?—asked Defarge in a low voice.

en: “As he has said it,” returned madame, lifting her eyebrows a little, “it is probably false. But it may be true.”
vi: − That's what he said, - his wife replied, her eyebrows slightly raised, - it might not be true. But it might be true.
tr: "According to what he said," said the madam, raising her eyebrows slightly, "it is probably wrong. But it could also be right."
es: —It is probably a lie; but I do not deny that it could be true—replied the woman. —Yes, it is...

en: “If it is—” Defarge began, and stopped.
vi: − If... - Defarge started to speak but then fell silent.
tr: "If it's true," Defarge started to say, but fell silent.
es: Defarge did not finish his thought.

en: “If it is?” repeated his wife.
vi: − "If what?" - The wife asked.
tr: "What if it's true?" his wife repeated. "..."
es: —What?—asked the woman.

en: “—And if it does come, while we live to see it triumph—I hope, for her sake, Destiny will keep her husband out of France.”
tr: If it is true and we can see the victory – for the girl's sake, I hope Fate keeps her husband away from France."
es: —Yes, it is... and given that things come in a way that we can see the triumph... for her, I will wish that Destiny keeps her husband far from France.

en: “Her husband’s destiny,” said Madame Defarge, with her usual composure, “will take him where he is to go, and will lead him to the end that is to end him. That is all I know.”
vi: "If it happens, when we are still alive to see the victory... I hope that, for her sake, fate will keep her husband away from France." − "Her husband's fate," - Madame Defarge said in her usual indifferent tone, - "will take him where he must go, to the end he must meet." "That's all I know." −
tr: "Whatever her husband's fate is," said Madame Defarge with her usual calmness, "it will take him to where he is destined to go, that is, to the end that will finish him." That's all I know."
es: —The fate of your husband will take him where he must go—responded the innkeeper with glacial calm—and it will lead him to the end that is destined for him. That is all I can tell you.

en: “But it is very strange—now, at least, is it not very strange”—said Defarge, rather pleading with his wife to induce her to admit it, “that, after all our sympathy for Monsieur her father, and herself, her husband’s name should be proscribed under your hand at this moment, by the side of that infernal dog’s who has just left us?”
vi: "But it's so strange... well, how could it not be strange..." - Defarge almost pleaded with his wife to admit, - "think about it, after all the affection we have for the doctor, for his daughter, now under your knitting needles, her husband's name lies next to the name of that scoundrel who just left?" −
tr: Defarge, "But this is very strange – I mean, at least for now, isn't it very strange?" he said to his wife, almost as if begging for her to agree with him, "look, while feeling so much sympathy for her father and herself, you will now trap her future husband's name, the one who just left the shop, in your knitting next to that wretched dog?"
es: —But you will deny that it is very... strange... I say strange for lack of a better word... don't you find it strange that with all the sympathy we have always had for her father, and even for her herself, you are now condemning her husband with your own hand, based solely on what that hellhound who just left said?

en: “Stranger things than that will happen when it does come,” answered madame. “I have them both here, of a certainty; and they are both here for their merits; that is enough.”
vi: "When it happens, there will be even stranger things," - his wife replied. − "I have recorded both names in the list, it's done; both deserve it; that is enough."
tr: "When the day we've been waiting for comes, we will see even stranger things," replied the madam. "I wrote both of them here, they will stay forever, and they both deserved this; that's enough.""
es: —Stranger things than that will happen when the day comes—replied Madame Defarge. —I have both of them here; make no mistake; and they will be treated according to their merits. This should suffice for you.

en: She rolled up her knitting when she had said those words, and presently took the rose out of the handkerchief that was wound about her head. Either Saint Antoine had an instinctive sense that the objectionable decoration was gone, or Saint Antoine was on the watch for its disappearance; howbeit, the Saint took courage to lounge in, very shortly afterwards, and the wine-shop recovered its habitual aspect.
vi: She had packed up her knitting as she said those words, then removed the rose from her headscarf. Either the people of Saint Antoine intuitively knew that the offensive ornament had disappeared, or they had been waiting for the moment the rose was removed; in any case, the people of this area then shuffled back in, restoring the old vitality to the wine shop.
tr: After saying these words, she gathered her knitting and immediately removed the rose from the side of her head. The people of St. Antoine either instinctively felt that this troublesome ornament had been removed or had witnessed its disappearance firsthand; whatever the case, the neighborhood residents suddenly rushed in, and the wine shop returned to its usual state.
es: Having said these words, she picked up the stocking and removed the rose that adorned her head. Whether it was that Saint Anthony instinctively knew the hour, the precise moment when the innkeeper would make that innocent flower disappear which seemed to displease him so much, or whether he was watching for the moment of its disappearance, the fact is that the Saint did not take long to appear, and that, within a few seconds, the establishment had regained its usual animation.

en: In the evening, at which season of all others Saint Antoine turned himself inside out, and sat on door-steps and window-ledges, and came to the corners of vile streets and courts, for a breath of air, Madame Defarge with her work in her hand was accustomed to pass from place to place and from group to group: a Missionary—there were many like her—such as the world will do well never to breed again. All the women knitted. They knitted worthless things; but, the mechanical work was a mechanical substitute for eating and drinking; the hands moved for the jaws and the digestive apparatus: if the bony fingers had been still, the stomachs would have been more famine-pinched.
vi: In the afternoon, during this season, it is the time when everyone in Saint Antoine shows their faces on the streets, sits on doorsteps or window sills, gathers at street corners or dirty courtyards to catch the breeze. Madame Defarge, with her knitting in hand, is accustomed to moving from place to place, meeting one group after another - she is like a missionary (there are many like her); the kind of person whose absence would make the world a better place. All the women knit. They knit useless things; but this manual labor serves as a mechanical substitute for eating; the hands work in place of the mouth and digestive organs - if those bony fingers were to remain still, the stomachs would growl more from hunger.
tr: In the evening, the people of St. Antoine once again took to the streets to get some fresh air, sitting on doorsteps and window sills, and emerging into the miserable street corners and courtyards. Madame Defarge, with her work in hand, was accustomed to wandering from one group to another. A woman who was a Missionary – there were many like her – was knitting furiously. All the women were knitting. They were knitting unnecessary things, but this mechanical work served as a substitute for eating and drinking; instead of jaws and digestive systems, their hands were working; if their skinny fingers were to stop, their stomachs would shrink even more.
es: When night fell, during the times of the year when the inhabitants of San Antonio would sit at their doorsteps or gather in streets and courtyards seeking fresh air to breathe, Mrs. Defarge, with her work in hand, would usually go from door to door and from group to group... a kind of missionary like so many others. All the women would knit, undoubtedly so that this mechanical work would substitute for the jaws, which were forcibly idle most of the time. Since the jaws and the digestive system could not move, the hands would move. If the idleness had extended to the fingers, the stomachs would have felt the rigors of hunger more.

en: But, as the fingers went, the eyes went, and the thoughts. And as Madame Defarge moved on from group to group, all three went quicker and fiercer among every little knot of women that she had spoken with, and left behind.
vi: Like nimble fingers; nimble eyes, and nimble thoughts as well. As Madame Defarge moved from one group to another, all three of these things operated more quickly and fiercely among the groups of women she had spoken to and then left.
tr: As the fingers worked, the eyes also worked, and of course, so did the minds. As Madame Defarge moved from one group to another, this trio became increasingly faster and more determined in each small group of women that Madame spoke to and left behind.
es: As the fingers moved, so did the eyes and thoughts; and as Madame Defarge went from door to door and from group to group, the fingers of the women she encountered worked with redoubled fervor, their eyes looked with greater fierceness, and the activity of their thoughts increased a hundredfold.

en: Her husband smoked at his door, looking after her with admiration. “A great woman,” said he, “a strong woman, a grand woman, a frightfully grand woman!”
vi: The husband stood smoking at the doorway, admiring his wife. “How rare are skillful women,” he thought to himself, “a strong, formidable, incredibly talented woman!”
tr: Her husband was smoking a cigarette in front of the door, looking at his wife with admiration. " What an amazing woman," he said, "a strong, great, incredibly great woman this is!" he was saying.
es: Her husband smoked by the door of the tavern, watching his life's companion with admiration. —A great woman... a strong woman... a sublime woman!—he murmured.

en: Darkness closed around, and then came the ringing of church bells and the distant beating of the military drums in the Palace Courtyard, as the women sat knitting, knitting. Darkness encompassed them. Another darkness was closing in as surely, when the church bells, then ringing pleasantly in many an airy steeple over France, should be melted into thundering cannon; when the military drums should be beating to drown a wretched voice, that night all potent as the voice of Power and Plenty, Freedom and Life. So much was closing in about the women who sat knitting, knitting, that they their very selves were closing in around a structure yet unbuilt, where they were to sit knitting, knitting, counting dropping heads.
vi: Darkness gradually fell, then the church bells tolled and from afar came the rhythmic drumming of the Royal Guard as the women sat knitting, still knitting. Darkness enveloped them. Another night was surely approaching when the cheerful church bells that now rang from high towers across France would be melted down and cast into terrifying cannons; when the drumbeats that usually drowned out the cries of the wretched would roar in that night with the shouts of Power and Plenty, of Freedom and Life. Layer upon layer of darkness covered the women who sat knitting, still knitting, their hearts harboring dreams of seeing themselves gathered around a high platform yet to be erected, where they sat knitting, knitting, counting, counting each head as it fell.
tr: Darkness had enveloped the surroundings, and while the women sat knitting furiously, the church bells rang and the distant sounds of the soldiers' drums in the Palace courtyard could be heard. The darkness had settled heavily upon them. As the church bells rang – these bells that sweetly chimed from the towers rising over France would later blend with the sound of thundering cannons – another darkness was approaching with sure steps; the military drums that needed to be played to drown out the wretched voices would beat that night for "Power and Abundance, Freedom and Life." The women who ceaselessly knitted as they sat were very close to their destination, now surrounding an unfinished structure where they would sit knitting and counting the heads being executed.
es: Night fell; the church bells rang and the distant sound of drums echoed: the women continued knitting. Another darker night was approaching, another night in which the church bells, which now rang joyfully, would give their bronze to be melted into thundering cannons, in which the drum rolls would thunder through the air to drown out the voice of a condemned man... omnipotent that night, with the omnipotence granted by power and abundance, freedom and life. The veils of the night enveloped the women who were knitting, just as they would soon envelop that other building, not yet constructed, where they would sit, also knitting but watching and counting at the same time the heads that fell one after another.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Layer upon layer of darkness covered the women who sat knitting, still knitting, their hearts harboring dreams of seeing themselves gathered around a high platform yet to be erected, where they sat knitting, knitting, counting, counting each head as it fell.
tr: XVII
es: XVII.

en: One Night
vi: 17. That night
tr: One Night
es: ONE NIGHT

en: Never did the sun go down with a brighter glory on the quiet corner in Soho, than one memorable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat under the plane-tree together. Never did the moon rise with a milder radiance over great London, than on that night when it found them still seated under the tree, and shone upon their faces through its leaves.
vi: The sun had never set more gloriously on the quiet corner of Soho than on that memorable evening when the doctor and his daughter sat together under the plane tree. The moon had never risen more gently over the vast city of London than on that night when the father and daughter still sat there, and the moonlight pierced through the leaves to illuminate their faces.
tr: The sun had never set with such a bright halo in that quiet corner of Soho as it did on that unforgettable evening when the Doctor and his daughter sat together under the plane tree. While the father and daughter sat under the tree, the moon, which shone on their faces through the leaves, had never risen over the vast London with such a sweet brightness as it did that evening.
es: Neither the tranquil refuge of Soho ever admired such a beautiful sunset as the memorable evening when Doctor Manette and his daughter watched it while sitting under the leafy plane tree that stood in the courtyard of the house, nor did the moon ever rise so radiant and splendid over the city of London as the night that found them sitting under the tree and bathed their faces and heads with a serene light filtered through the leaves.

en: Lucie was to be married to-morrow. She had reserved this last evening for her father, and they sat alone under the plane-tree.
vi: Lucie will get married tomorrow. She spent this last evening with her father, and it was just the two of them under the tree.
tr: Lude was going to get married the next day. She had reserved the last evening for her father, and they were sitting together under the sycamore tree.
es: Lucía was to be married the next day, and she wanted to dedicate her last night as a single woman to her father: it was due to this circumstance that she was sitting under the plane tree in the company of the author of her days.

en: “You are happy, my dear father?”
vi: Are you happy, dear father? −
tr: "Are you happy, daddy?"
es: —Are you happy, dear father?

en: “Quite, my child.”
vi: Of course, my little girl.
tr: "Yes, my child.""
es: —Completely, my daughter.

en: They had said little, though they had been there a long time. When it was yet light enough to work and read, she had neither engaged herself in her usual work, nor had she read to him. She had employed herself in both ways, at his side under the tree, many and many a time; but, this time was not quite like any other, and nothing could make it so.
vi: The father and daughter sat for a long time but said little. The sky still had enough light for work and reading, but she was not as busy as usual and did not read to her father. Usually, when she was with her father under this tree, she would work or read, but this time was completely different; nothing could change today.
tr: Although they had been there for a while, they had spoken very little. Even when there was still enough light to work or read something, Lucie had neither devoted herself to her task nor read a book to her father. She had often idled like this before, under the tree, beside her father, but this evening was not like the others, it couldn't be.
es: Although they had been at the mentioned place for some hours before, they had spoken very little. On other days, when the girl sat under the tree in the company of her father, she worked or read; but on this occasion, even during the time when she had enough light to work or read, she did neither. The circumstances had changed, and when these change, the routine is interrupted.

en: “And I am very happy to-night, dear father. I am deeply happy in the love that Heaven has so blessed—my love for Charles, and Charles’s love for me. But, if my life were not to be still consecrated to you, or if my marriage were so arranged as that it would part us, even by the length of a few of these streets, I should be more unhappy and self-reproachful now than I can tell you. Even as it is—”
vi: − And tonight, I am also very happy, dear father. I am immensely happy in the love that God has blessed; the love I have for Charles and the love Charles has for me. But if my life no longer included honoring you, or if this marriage arrangement was set to separate us, even if only by a few streets, I would now be indescribably sad and regretful. Even if...
tr: "I am very happy tonight, Daddy. This love –my love for Charles and Charles's love for me– makes me deeply happy. But if I still couldn't dedicate my life to you or if my marriage, even if just a few streets away, would separate me from you, you can't imagine how unhappy I would be, how bad I would feel. Actually, even right now-"
es: —I am also happy, very happy tonight, my father. The love that Heaven has blessed makes me happy... my love for Carlos and Carlos's love for me. However, if I could not continue dedicating my life to you, if my marriage imposed the obligation to separate from you, even if only the width of the street separated our houses, far from considering myself happy, I would feel miserable. Even so...

en: Even as it was, she could not command her voice.
vi: No matter how she tried to hide it, Lucie would always choke up and leave the sentence unfinished.
tr: At that moment, the young girl couldn't control her voice.
es: Even so, the emotion eventually completely overwhelmed her.

en: In the sad moonlight, she clasped him by the neck, and laid her face upon his breast. In the moonlight which is always sad, as the light of the sun itself is—as the light called human life is—at its coming and its going.
vi: Under the sorrowful moonlight, she wrapped her arms around Mr. Manette's neck, resting her head on her father's chest. The moonlight was always sorrowful, sorrowful like the sunlight - brilliant then fading away - like the ephemeral nature of human life.
tr: In the melancholy moonlight, the young girl hugged her father's neck and rested her head on his chest. The moonlight, which always disappeared with the emergence of daylight – that light which calls people to life – was always melancholic anyway.
es: In the melancholic light of the moon, she threw her arms around her father's neck and rested her head on his chest. The light of the moon, which is always sad, just as the light of the sun is sad... just as the light we call human life is sad, which shines today and is extinguished tomorrow, illuminated a simply moving scene.

en: “Dearest dear! Can you tell me, this last time, that you feel quite, quite sure, no new affections of mine, and no new duties of mine, will ever interpose between us? I know it well, but do you know it? In your own heart, do you feel quite certain?”
vi: − Dear father! Can you tell me one last time, are you completely sure that no new feelings or new responsibilities of mine could ever separate our father-daughter bond? I am certain of it, but what about you? Deep down, are you completely convinced of that?
tr: "Dear father! Would you tell me once more that you are sure the new loves and new duties entering my life will never come between us? I am sure of this, but do you think the same? Do you believe this wholeheartedly?"
es: —Dear Father! Are you convinced... firmly convinced, that new loves of mine, new duties of mine, will never come between us? I am; but what about you? Does this certainty take root in the depths of your heart?

en: Her father answered, with a cheerful firmness of conviction he could scarcely have assumed, “Quite sure, my darling! More than that,” he added, as he tenderly kissed her: “my future is far brighter, Lucie, seen through your marriage, than it could have been—nay, than it ever was—without it.”
vi: The father responded with a cheerfully confident voice that could not be feigned: − Absolutely certain, my dear! Moreover, Lucie, - he added while affectionately kissing his daughter, - seeing you settled in marriage makes my future even brighter... oh, even more so than if this marriage hadn't happened.
tr: Her father replied with a sincere certainty to persuade his daughter, "Of course I'm sure, my dear! Moreover," he added while kissing his daughter affectionately, "with your marriage, my future will be much brighter, Lucie – more than ever before."
es: —Completely, absolutely convinced!—replied the father with a tone of firm conviction. —Even more so, my daughter!—he added, kissing her.— My future appears brighter in my eyes when seen through your marriage than it would if you remained single.

en: “If I could hope that, my father!—”
vi: − I only hope that is truly the case, father! −
tr: "Oh, I hope it will be like that, daddy!""
es: —If I could believe you, my father...!

en: “Believe it, love! Indeed it is so. Consider how natural and how plain it is, my dear, that it should be so. You, devoted and young, cannot fully appreciate the anxiety I have felt that your life should not be wasted—”
vi: Trust me, my dear! It truly is. Think about it; it is so clear and natural. You are burdened with me and still young, you cannot fully understand my long-standing worry of not wanting your life to be wasted...
tr: "Believe me, my dear! This is the truth. Think about how natural and right this situation is, this is how it should be. You can't understand how much it upsets me to think that you, with your youthful and self-sacrificing nature, would waste your life..."
es: —Well, believe it, my darling, because it is so. Think that nothing could be more natural or logical. If you knew the anxiety that a father feels about the future of a beloved daughter...! If you could appreciate how great my desires are to prevent contingencies that might make you unhappy...!

en: She moved her hand towards his lips, but he took it in his, and repeated the word.
vi: Lucie raised her hand to her father's lips to stop him, but the doctor took his daughter's hand and repeated.
tr: The girl brought her hand to her father's lips, but he pulled her hand away and repeated his words.
es: The girl wanted to seal her father's lips with her hand, but he stopped her by taking hold of her hand, and continued thus:

en: “—wasted, my child—should not be wasted, struck aside from the natural order of things—for my sake. Your unselfishness cannot entirely comprehend how much my mind has gone on this; but, only ask yourself, how could my happiness be perfect, while yours was incomplete?”
vi: − ... Wasteful, my dear... it must not be wasteful, it must not go against the natural order... just for me. You are not selfish, so you cannot fully understand how much I have worried about this; but ask yourself; how can my happiness be complete if you are at a disadvantage?
tr: "... you must not waste your life, my child – you must not go against the laws of nature and waste your own life for my sake. You are so self-sacrificing towards me that you cannot fully understand what goes through my mind, but think about it, how can my happiness be complete when yours is lacking?"
es: —Unfortunate, my daughter, yes; torn from the natural order of things... because of me. Your selflessness, your lack of selfishness, it is not possible for you to understand how much that point has troubled me; but if you ask yourself how my happiness can be complete while yours is incomplete, perhaps you will understand my words.

en: “If I had never seen Charles, my father, I should have been quite happy with you.”
vi: − If I had never met Charles, father, I would be completely happy without him.
tr: "If I hadn't known Charles, I would have lived quite happily with you, father."
es: —If I had never seen Carlos, my father, you alone would have been enough to make my happiness complete.

en: He smiled at her unconscious admission that she would have been unhappy without Charles, having seen him; and replied:
vi: The father smiled at his daughter's unintended confession, surely Lucie would be very sad without that young man in her life.
tr: The doctor smiled and responded with a confession, made unwittingly by his daughter, that revealed she could not be happy without Charles:
es: The father couldn't help but smile at that unconscious confession that his daughter would be unhappy without Carlos after having seen him, and he replied:

en: “My child, you did see him, and it is Charles. If it had not been Charles, it would have been another. Or, if it had been no other, I should have been the cause, and then the dark part of my life would have cast its shadow beyond myself, and would have fallen on you.”
vi: He replied: − My dear, you have met Charles, and you have had Charles. If you hadn't met Charles, you would have met another young man. And if you didn't meet anyone else, it would be my fault, and thus the dark part of my life not only causes me suffering but also brings sorrow to you.
tr: "My dear, the one you encountered was Charles. If it hadn't been Charles, it would have been someone else. On the other hand, if it hadn't been someone else, it would have been something that originated from me, and then the shadow of the dark part of my life would have surpassed me and fallen upon you."
es: —My daughter; you saw a man, and that man was Carlos; if it hadn't been Carlos, it would have been someone else; and if it hadn't been someone else, rest assured that the cause would have been me, in which case, the unfortunate period of my life would not only have enveloped me in its dark shadows, but also someone else, and that someone would have been you.

en: It was the first time, except at the trial, of her ever hearing him refer to the period of his suffering. It gave her a strange and new sensation while his words were in her ears; and she remembered it long afterwards.
vi: Except for the previous court appearance, today was the first time the girl heard her father mention that painful time. Her father's words echoed in her ears, making her extraordinarily emotional, and that feeling would remain deeply etched in her heart forever.
tr: For the first time since the trial, Lucie was hearing him speak of those painful days. Her father's words had stirred a strange and new feeling within her, and this feeling lingered in her mind for a long time.
es: It was the first time, after the hearing of Darnay's case, that the doctor alluded to his misfortune. —Look at it!—exclaimed Doctor de Beauvais, extending his arm towards the moon and giving his words a tone that his daughter could not forget for a long time.

en: “See!” said the Doctor of Beauvais, raising his hand towards the moon. “I have looked at her from my prison-window, when I could not bear her light. I have looked at her when it has been such torture to me to think of her shining upon what I had lost, that I have beaten my head against my prison-walls. I have looked at her, in a state so dull and lethargic, that I have thought of nothing but the number of horizontal lines I could draw across her at the full, and the number of perpendicular lines with which I could intersect them.” He added in his inward and pondering manner, as he looked at the moon, “It was twenty either way, I remember, and the twentieth was difficult to squeeze in.”
vi: − Look! - The doctor in Beauvais pointed to the moon. - I looked at the moon from the prison window when I couldn't bear its light. I looked at the moon with a heart aching, thinking about how its light was also shining on everything I had lost, hurting so much that I banged my head against the prison wall. I looked at the moon in a state of despair, so despondent that I thought of nothing else but how many lines I would have to draw to slash and erase the full moon's face. - He looked at the moon and added, with a pensive, contemplative look. - Twenty lines, both horizontal and vertical, I remember, and it was very difficult to fit in the twentieth line.
tr: The Doctor from Beauvais said, "Look!" pointing at the moon. "Even though I couldn't bear its light, I would always look at it from the window of my dungeon. Thinking that it shone over what I had lost would hurt me so much inside that I would bang my head against the walls of the dungeon as I looked. While staring with numb and lifeless eyes, I wouldn't think of anything else, only calculating the number of horizontal lines I could draw over it and the number of vertical lines that would intersect with them." While gazing at the moon, lost in deep thoughts, he added, "I remember twenty horizontal, twenty vertical, and fitting the twentieth was difficult."
es: —Look at it!—exclaimed Doctor de Beauvais, extending his arm towards the moon and giving his words a tone that his daughter could not forget for a long time. —I have seen it many times from the narrow window of my dungeon, when its light hurt me. I have gazed at it many times when it caused me such dreadful tortures to think that it shone upon the beings I had lost, that I would have gladly thrown myself headfirst against the walls of my prison. I have gazed at it while being in such a state of stupor and imbecility, that I could think of nothing else but the number of horizontal lines I could draw on its surface during the full moon, and the number of perpendiculars with which I could intersect the former. I remember calculating that twenty of each kind could fit—he added pensively—and the twentieth one fit with difficulty.

en: The strange thrill with which she heard him go back to that time, deepened as he dwelt upon it; but, there was nothing to shock her in the manner of his reference. He only seemed to contrast his present cheerfulness and felicity with the dire endurance that was over.
vi: The strange feeling when hearing her father recount the old days surged in Lucie as the doctor spoke; but he spoke without any intention of making his daughter sad. It seemed he only wanted to compare the current happiness and joy with the extreme suffering of the past.
tr: As he reminisced about the old days, his father's strange excitement also deepened, but there was nothing surprising about him talking about these things. It was as if he was comparing his current happiness and joy with his dreadful patience in the past.
es: I remember calculating that twenty of each kind could fit—he added pensively—and the twentieth one fit with difficulty.

en: “I have looked at her, speculating thousands of times upon the unborn child from whom I had been rent. Whether it was alive. Whether it had been born alive, or the poor mother’s shock had killed it. Whether it was a son who would some day avenge his father. (There was a time in my imprisonment, when my desire for vengeance was unbearable.) Whether it was a son who would never know his father’s story; who might even live to weigh the possibility of his father’s having disappeared of his own will and act. Whether it was a daughter who would grow to be a woman.”
vi: − I have looked at the moon, countless times thinking of the unborn child from whom I was separated. I don't know if it is still alive. I don't know if it was born healthy or if the mother's suffering took the life of the fetus. I don't know if it is a boy who will one day avenge me. Many times in prison, I craved revenge unbearably. Not sure if it is a boy who is completely unaware of his father's story, or if he even thinks that disappearing from his life was his father's voluntary choice. Not sure if it is a girl who will later become a woman.
tr: "While looking at the moon, I thought of my unborn child thousands of times. Had it been born, I wondered? Had it been born healthy, or had it died from its poor mother's sorrow? Or was it a boy who would one day avenge his father? (During the days I was in prison, my desire for revenge had become unbearable.) A boy who would never know his father's story; or perhaps he would even think that his father had disappeared of his own will and volition. Or it was a girl who would grow up to be a beautiful woman."
es: I have gazed at it thinking millions of times about the son from whom I was violently torn before he was born... I wondered if he had been born alive, if he was living, if the mother's pain had killed them both. I wondered if, in the case of being a boy, he would avenge his father, for while I was buried alive, there were times when an intolerable desire for vengeance dominated me; I wondered if he would ever come to know the sad story of his father's days, if perhaps he believed that his father had disappeared freely and voluntarily. I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence.

en: She drew closer to him, and kissed his cheek and his hand.
vi: Lucie nestled close to her father, then kissed Dr. Manette's cheeks and hands.
tr: Lucie approached her father and kissed his cheek and hand.
es: I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence.

en: “I have pictured my daughter, to myself, as perfectly forgetful of me—rather, altogether ignorant of me, and unconscious of me. I have cast up the years of her age, year after year. I have seen her married to a man who knew nothing of my fate. I have altogether perished from the remembrance of the living, and in the next generation my place was a blank.”
vi: − I once imagined that my daughter had completely forgotten her father... or rather, knew nothing about me, didn't care about me. Year after year, I counted my daughter's ages. I imagined my daughter had married someone who knew nothing about my fate. And I faded away in the memories of the living, until the next generation no longer remembered me.
tr: "I always thought to myself that my daughter had completely forgotten me – even imagined that she was entirely unaware of me, that she never knew me. I kept calculating her age every year. I envisioned her marrying a man who knew nothing of my fate. I had been completely erased from the memories of the living and had no place in the next generation."
es: I wondered if, being a daughter, she would grow up to be a woman, and I imagined her completely forgetting me, ignorant of my existence. In my imagination, I saw her grow, live year after year; I saw her married to a man who was unaware of my sad fate. I considered myself dead to the world of the living, and I saw the generation following mine in which I did not appear.

en: “My father! Even to hear that you had such thoughts of a daughter who never existed, strikes to my heart as if I had been that child.”
vi: − Father! Even though I heard you say it was just imagination, my heart aches as if I were the daughter in your imagination! −
tr: "Daddy! The fact that you have thought about these things for a girl who doesn't exist, it burns my heart as if I were that child.""
es: —My father!—exclaimed the young woman, kissing her father with passion. — That daughter to whom your thoughts referred has never existed, but, nevertheless, it almost hurts me as much to hear you speak as you do as if that daughter were me.

en: “You, Lucie? It is out of the Consolation and restoration you have brought to me, that these remembrances arise, and pass between us and the moon on this last night.—What did I say just now?”
vi: Me, Lucie? If it weren't for you comforting and restoring my mind, there wouldn't be this last night to remember old times and talk under the moon... − Where was I just now? −
tr: "Lucie, all these memories came alive after you comforted and healed me, and on this last night, they came between me and the moon. –What was I saying?"
es: —You, Lucía? Quite the opposite! Precisely those memories arise from the joy, from the comforts you have brought me, and since they are pleasant memories, I take pleasure in recalling them by the light of the moon on our last night... What was I saying?

en: “She knew nothing of you. She cared nothing for you.”
vi: That imagined daughter knew nothing about her father, didn't care about him. −
tr: "He knew nothing about you. He had no idea about you."
es: —That your daughter knew nothing about you... that she didn't remember you.

en: “So! But on other moonlight nights, when the sadness and the silence have touched me in a different way—have affected me with something as like a sorrowful sense of peace, as any emotion that had pain for its foundations could—I have imagined her as coming to me in my cell, and leading me out into the freedom beyond the fortress. I have seen her image in the moonlight often, as I now see you; except that I never held her in my arms; it stood between the little grated window and the door. But, you understand that that was not the child I am speaking of?”
vi: Ah! But there were many other moonlit nights, when sorrow and silence evoked a different mood... a mood of serene melancholy as if all painful feelings had reached their limit... I saw my daughter coming to the prison to meet her father, taking him out of captivity back to freedom. Under the moonlight, I often saw the face of that daughter clearly, as clearly as I see you now; only I could never hold her in my arms; she just stood between the small barred window and the door. But you must understand that you are not the daughter I am talking about, right? −
tr: "Correct! But on other nights when the moon shone, when sadness and silence affected me differently –like every emotion that is fundamentally the most painful, it affected me with a feeling similar to sorrowful peace– I would imagine her coming to my cell and taking me to freedom beyond the prison walls. Just as I see you now, I would often see her in the moonlight, but I could never hold her in my arms; she would stand between the small window with iron bars and the door. But you understand that the child I mentioned is not her, right?"
es: —That your daughter knew nothing about you... that she didn't remember you. —It's true; but on other nights, when my sadness and the silence that surrounded me gave my emotions a different direction, when they produced in me something like a painful sensation of peace... like an emotion whose foundation was pain... I imagined my daughter entering my cell, taking me out of the fortress where I was imprisoned, and granting me freedom. Many, many times I have seen her image in the moonlight, just as I see yours at this moment. There was, however, a difference, and that is, I could never hold her in my arms, I always saw her cold, motionless, rigid in the center of the cell, in the space between the bars and the door... You understand that you were not the girl I speak of.

en: “The figure was not; the—the—image; the fancy?”
vi: That shadow... that illusion... wasn't it just imagination? −
tr: "Was that image a symbol, a dream?""
es: —It wasn't; that's true... but your imagination made you believe...

en: “No. That was another thing. It stood before my disturbed sense of sight, but it never moved. The phantom that my mind pursued, was another and more real child. Of her outward appearance I know no more than that she was like her mother. The other had that likeness too—as you have—but was not the same. Can you follow me, Lucie? Hardly, I think? I doubt you must have been a solitary prisoner to understand these perplexed distinctions.”
vi: No. This is different. It stood before my dazed eyes, but never faded away. The image in my imagination was of another daughter and more real. I knew nothing about her appearance except that she resembled her mother. And the illusion before me also had that resemblance... like you... but wasn't you. Do you understand what I mean, Lucie? Probably not? I'm afraid you would have to live in solitary confinement to understand those difficult-to-explain differences.
tr: "No. This was something else. It stood in my line of sight in a disturbing way but didn't move at all. The silhouette my mind was chasing was very different, a much more real child. About its appearance, I know nothing except that it resembled its mother. The other one also looked like it – just like you – but it wasn't the same. Can you follow what I'm saying, Lucie? It's a bit difficult, isn't it? Maybe you had to be left alone in a dungeon to understand these complex distinctions."
es: —No; none of that. My visual organ, disturbed, is clear, I saw her motionless, and yet, the ghost that my intellectual faculties pursued was the ghost of another girl, different and more real. Of her external appearance, I only know that the image my eyes saw resembled her mother... and the other, the ghost... also resembled her... like you resemble her... but it was a different resemblance. Do you understand me, Lucia? No, right? I highly doubt that anyone who has not spent long centuries confined and separated from their loved ones can understand the subtle distinctions of a prisoner.

en: His collected and calm manner could not prevent her blood from running cold, as he thus tried to anatomise his old condition.
vi: Mr. Manette's calm and composed demeanor could not prevent Lucie from feeling a chill as her father tried to analyze his past emotions.
tr: The doctor's composed and calm demeanor, adopted in an effort to return to the old days, was enough to chill his daughter's blood.
es: Although the father's calm was perfect, the young woman felt ice running through her veins when she heard him dissect the state of mind he found himself in during times, fortunately past.

en: “In that more peaceful state, I have imagined her, in the moonlight, coming to me and taking me out to show me that the home of her married life was full of her loving remembrance of her lost father. My picture was in her room, and I was in her prayers. Her life was active, cheerful, useful; but my poor history pervaded it all.”
vi: − In quieter moments, I see under the moonlight, that girl comes and takes me outside, visiting her family home, a place full of loving memories of her deceased father. In her room, she has a picture of me hanging, and in her prayers, she always mentions my name. Her life is full of energy, joy, and usefulness; but permeating through that life is still the sad story of mine. −
tr: "In relatively peaceful moments, I would imagine her coming to me in the moonlight and dream that she would take me to her nest to show me that it was filled with the loving memories of her deceased father. My picture would be in her room and she would pray for me. She was full of life, cheerful, and beautiful, but my pitiful story had permeated everywhere."
es: —I imagined her coming to my dungeon by the light of the moon to tell me that her blessed married home was full of sweet memories of her father lost forever. In her study, my portrait occupied a prominent place and I was the one who inspired her prayers. Her life was active, happy, useful; but it was filled, saturated with my sad story.

en: “I was that child, my father, I was not half so good, but in my love that was I.”
vi: That girl is me, father, even though I am not half as good as she is, I love you just as much.
tr: "Here I am, that child, my father. My life wasn't that good, but I loved you just the same."
es: —That daughter was me, my father. I was not, by any means, as good as you imagined, but my tender affection was not exaggerated by your fantasy.

en: “And she showed me her children,” said the Doctor of Beauvais, “and they had heard of me, and had been taught to pity me. When they passed a prison of the State, they kept far from its frowning walls, and looked up at its bars, and spoke in whispers. She could never deliver me; I imagined that she always brought me back after showing me such things. But then, blessed with the relief of tears, I fell upon my knees, and blessed her.”
vi: − Then she lets me meet her children, - the doctor from Beauvais said, - and they all know about me, they are all taught to feel compassion for me. When they pass by the national prison, they shy away from the threatening walls, look up at the high barred windows, and whisper. That girl cannot free me; I see her always bringing me back to the dungeon after showing me so many things. But at those times, I have shed tears of joy, I have knelt down to bless her.
tr: "Then he would show me his children," said the Doctor from Beauvais, "they knew about me and had taught me to pity them. When they passed by a prison, they were kept away from its frowning walls and would look at the iron bars and whisper among themselves. My daughter could not set me free, but after showing me all this, I imagined she would take me back to my cell. Then I would relax and burst into tears, kneeling down to pray for her."
es: —He also taught his children, to whom he often spoke of me. All of them had learned to pity me. When they passed near one of those tombs called state prisons, they would avert their eyes from its grim walls, look fearfully at its bars, and speak in very low voices. My daughter could not give me freedom; but even so, it was enough for her to show me the things I have just mentioned, for consoling tears to run down my cheeks and for me to fall to my knees blessing her.

en: “I am that child, I hope, my father. O my dear, my dear, will you bless me as fervently to-morrow?”
vi: − I am that girl, I wish to be so, father. Oh father, father, will you bless me so dearly tomorrow?
tr: "I am that child, father, oh I hope so, my dear father." "Oh my dear father, my beloved father, will you pray for me with the same enthusiasm again tomorrow?""
es: —I am that daughter, yes, I am. Oh, my father! Will you bless me tomorrow with the same fervor?

en: “Lucie, I recall these old troubles in the reason that I have to-night for loving you better than words can tell, and thanking God for my great happiness. My thoughts, when they were wildest, never rose near the happiness that I have known with you, and that we have before us.”
vi: − Lucie, the reason I recount the painful past is because tonight I love you immensely, and thank God for giving me this happiness. My imaginations back then, no matter how fanciful, could never bring me the happiness like the days we spent together and what is to come.
tr: "Lucie, the reason I am telling you all these old troubles now is because I love you more than words can express and I thank God for giving me such great happiness. Even in the moments when I indulged in the most impossible dreams, I could not have imagined the happiness I feel now by your side and the beautiful days that lie ahead of us."
es: —I remember those ancient tortures, dear Lucía, because it highlights more and more the joy that overwhelms me tonight. Never did my hopes, not even when they were most excessive, manage to represent to me a happiness as great as the one I have experienced since being by your side, as the one I hope to savor in the future.

en: He embraced her, solemnly commended her to Heaven, and humbly thanked Heaven for having bestowed her on him. By-and-bye, they went into the house.
vi: Mr. Manette embraced his daughter, prayed for God's blessing on Lucie, and thanked God for giving him a beloved child. Then the father and daughter went into the house.
tr: The doctor hugged his daughter, solemnly entrusted her to God, and humbly thanked for being granted his daughter. A little later, they entered the house.
es: He then embraced his daughter, solemnly blessed her, and fervently thanked God who had granted her to him. Shortly after, they entered the house embraced.

en: There was no one bidden to the marriage but Mr. Lorry; there was even to be no bridesmaid but the gaunt Miss Pross. The marriage was to make no change in their place of residence; they had been able to extend it, by taking to themselves the upper rooms formerly belonging to the apocryphal invisible lodger, and they desired nothing more.
vi: The only person invited to the wedding was Mr. Lorry; there wasn't even a bridesmaid, only the haggard Miss Pross. This wedding did not change the residence; the house simply gained more people, Charles and Lucie would move up to the rooms on the upper floor which previously belonged to unseen, ephemeral lodgers, and the newlyweds desired nothing more than that.
tr: There was no one invited to the wedding except Mr. Lorry; there wasn't even a bridesmaid other than the unpleasant Miss Pross. There would be no change in the place where they lived after the marriage; they had only expanded the house a bit, incorporating the rooms on the upper floor that previously belonged to the invisible imaginary tenant, and felt no need to do anything else.
es: No guests would attend the wedding ceremony, nor would any alterations be made to the doctor's residence because of the marriage. They had limited themselves to expanding it a bit by taking the upper floor that until then had been occupied by an invisible tenant, which fulfilled their wishes.

en: Doctor Manette was very cheerful at the little supper. They were only three at table, and Miss Pross made the third. He regretted that Charles was not there; was more than half disposed to object to the loving little plot that kept him away; and drank to him affectionately.
vi: Dr. Manette was very cheerful during dinner. The dinner table had only three people, with Miss Pross being the third. He regretted that Charles was not there, inwardly opposing the trivial sentimental scheme that had caused his son-in-law's absence, and he raised his glass in silent sympathy for Charles.
tr: Dr. Manette was very cheerful at dinner. There were only three people at the table; the third person was Miss Pross, after all. The Doctor was saddened by Charles's absence; he was almost going to oppose the loving little game that kept his almost-son-in-law away that day, and with these affectionate feelings, he raised his glass in his honor.
es: Dr. Manette was very cheerful and lively during dinner. Three people sat at the table, the third being Miss Pross. The doctor regretted that they had not invited Charles Darnay; he even felt tempted to scold those who had concocted the plot to keep him away, and he drank to his health.

en: So, the time came for him to bid Lucie good night, and they separated. But, in the stillness of the third hour of the morning, Lucie came downstairs again, and stole into his room; not free from unshaped fears, beforehand.
vi: It was time to retreat to their rooms and say goodnight. But in the stillness of the night at three in the morning, Lucie went downstairs again, sneaking into her father's room, her heart still uneasy with vague fears from before.
tr: Then it was time for the Doctor to say goodnight to Lucie, and everyone retired to their rooms. But in the silence of the later hours of the night, Lucie came back downstairs and secretly entered her father's room; she had a multitude of fears she couldn't define.
es: It was already very late when he said goodnight to Lucía and retired to his room. At three in the morning, the young woman, not entirely free from fears and premonitions, got up and quietly entered her father's bedroom.

en: All things, however, were in their places; all was quiet; and he lay asleep, his white hair picturesque on the untroubled pillow, and his hands lying quiet on the coverlet. She put her needless candle in the shadow at a distance, crept up to his bed, and put her lips to his; then, leaned over him, and looked at him.
vi: But everything remained in place; all around was calm; and the father was fast asleep, his silver hair spread like a painting on the soft pillow, and his hands lay still under the blanket. She placed the cumbersome candle into the distant shadow, tiptoed to her father's bed, kissed his lips, and then kept looking down at him for a long time.
tr: However, everything was in its place; not a sound was heard and her father was sleeping soundly, his snow-white hair was worth watching on his comfortable pillow and his hands were lying still on the bedspread. The young girl placed the unnecessary candlestick somewhere away and, snuggling up to her father, planted a kiss on his lips; then she leaned over and looked at him.
es: Everything was in its place, everything in order, everything calm. The doctor slept peacefully, his long white hair falling over the pillow and his hands resting naturally on the quilt. The girl left the candlestick in a corner, approached the bed, and touched her father's withered lips with her fresh ones. Then she gazed at him intensely.

en: Into his handsome face, the bitter waters of captivity had worn; but, he covered up their tracks with a determination so strong, that he held the mastery of them even in his sleep. A more remarkable face in its quiet, resolute, and guarded struggle with an unseen assailant, was not to be beheld in all the wide dominions of sleep, that night.
vi: On that beautiful face, the bitterness of the days of captivity had faded, but the doctor had covered all traces of the past with such a strong determination that even in his sleep he did not allow them to be revealed. That night, throughout the vast and endless realm, it was impossible to find a face more serene, more resolute, and more quietly determined in the struggle against the invisible attacker.
tr: The man's pleasant face had been worn down by the bitter waters of captivity, but the doctor had covered these marks with such strong determination that he managed to conceal them even in his sleep. That night, if all the faces in the realm of sleep were examined, none could be found as silent, as determined, and as cautious as his, in his struggle against an invisible aggressor.
es: The bitter waters of captivity had left their marks on his perfect face; but so firm, so energetic was the resolution of that father, that even while sleeping he managed to conceal them. In the vast realms of sleep, surely there was no other face that night as guarded against the gaze of any unexpected visitor as that of Doctor Manette.

en: She timidly laid her hand on his dear breast, and put up a prayer that she might ever be as true to him as her love aspired to be, and as his sorrows deserved. Then, she withdrew her hand, and kissed his lips once more, and went away. So, the sunrise came, and the shadows of the leaves of the plane-tree moved upon his face, as softly as her lips had moved in praying for him.
vi: Lucie timidly placed her hand on his chest and prayed for the strength to be truly filial, worthy of the suffering her father had endured. Then she withdrew her hand, kissed her father's lips once more, and left the room. Thus, dawn arrived, and the shadows of the weeping willow leaves danced on his face, gently like Lucie's lips whispering a prayer.
tr: Lucie timidly placed her hand on her father's chest and prayed to always be able to stay by his side, after all the love she felt for him and all the suffering the man had endured. Then she withdrew her hand and, after kissing him on the lips once more, she left. The sun had now risen, and the shadows of the plane tree's leaves played softly on the man's face, as gently as his daughter's lips moved while she prayed for him.
es: Timidly, she placed a hand on that beloved chest and fervently asked God to grant her the ability to always be as faithful to him as his paternal love and past sufferings deserved. She then withdrew her hand, kissed that adored mouth once more, and left the bedroom. When the sun was born, the shadows cast by the banana leaves on her face did not move with as much gentleness as Lucia's lips did when she directed her prayer to Heaven.

en: CHAPTER XVIII.
vi: Thus, dawn arrived, and the shadows of the weeping willow leaves danced on his face, gently like Lucie's lips whispering a prayer.
tr: XVIII
es: XVIII.

en: Nine Days
vi: 18.Nine days of radiant sunshine on the wedding day, three people were ready in front of the doctor's closed room, where Mr. Manette was talking to Charles Darnay inside.
tr: Nine Days
es: NINE DAYS Nature displayed all its splendor on the wedding day.

en: The marriage-day was shining brightly, and they were ready outside the closed door of the Doctor’s room, where he was speaking with Charles Darnay. They were ready to go to church; the beautiful bride, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross—to whom the event, through a gradual process of reconcilement to the inevitable, would have been one of absolute bliss, but for the yet lingering consideration that her brother Solomon should have been the bridegroom.
vi: 18.Nine days of radiant sunshine on the wedding day, three people were ready in front of the doctor's closed room, where Mr. Manette was talking to Charles Darnay inside. They were preparing to go to the church: the beautiful bride, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross - for her, this marriage must have been the utmost joy if not for the lingering thought that her brother Solomon should have been the groom, but gradually she had to accept this inevitable fact.
tr: On the wedding day, the weather was sparkling, and everyone was waiting in front of the closed door of the room where the Doctor was talking to Charles Darnay. They were all ready to go to the church; that is, the beautiful bride, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross – Miss Pross, who had gradually accustomed herself to this inevitable event, was happy indeed, but she still couldn't get rid of the thought that the groom should have been her own brother Solomon.
es: All those who were to attend the ceremony were already in place, waiting for the doctor to come out of his room, where he was talking with Charles Darnay. Next to the indicated room's door were the bride, radiant with beauty, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross... for whom the event, thanks to a gradual process of reconciliation with the inevitable, would have been a source of infinite happiness, if not for the slightly painful consideration that the groom should not be Charles Darnay but her brother Solomon.

en: “And so,” said Mr. Lorry, who could not sufficiently admire the bride, and who had been moving round her to take in every point of her quiet, pretty dress; “and so it was for this, my sweet Lucie, that I brought you across the Channel, such a baby! Lord bless me! How little I thought what I was doing! How lightly I valued the obligation I was conferring on my friend Mr. Charles!”
vi: −There it is! - Mr. Lorry could never tire of admiring the bride, bustling around her, scrutinizing every detail of the beautiful, simple wedding dress. - There it is! I carried you across the sea just for this day, dear Lucie, since you were a baby. God bless me! At that time, I didn't think of anything! I didn't know that one day I would have the important duty of entrusting you to Charles!
tr: "Do you see?" said Mr. Lorry, who couldn't stop praising the bride, as he circled around her lovely, simple wedding dress; "Sweet Lucie, so I brought you across the Channel for this, oh how beautiful you are! Thank God! I didn't realize I was doing something so important! I didn't understand the significance of the task I entrusted to my friend Charles so well!"
es: —The truth is that I made a great deal!—exclaimed Lorry, who couldn't stop admiring the bride. —Just think about accompanying her on her journey across the Channel for this! My goodness, and how little I thought about what I was doing! And how little value I placed on the service I rendered to my good friend Charles Darnay on that occasion!

en: “You didn’t mean it,” remarked the matter-of-fact Miss Pross, “and therefore how could you know it? Nonsense!”
vi: −This marriage wasn't your idea, - Miss Pross said plainly, - so how could you have known back then? Nonsense! − Really?
tr: "You had no such intention," said the straightforward Miss Pross, "how could you have known? Nonsense!"
es: —I don't know how you could give it more or less value than it deserved if you didn't remotely dream of what was going to happen!—observed Miss Pross.—Nonsense!

en: “Really? Well; but don’t cry,” said the gentle Mr. Lorry.
vi: Ah; but don't cry, will you? - Mr. Lorry said kindly.
tr: "Is that so? Alright, but don't cry," said the gentle Mr. Lorry.
es: —Really? Perhaps you are right... But don't cry—replied Lorry.

en: “I am not crying,” said Miss Pross; “you are.”
vi: − I'm not crying, - Miss Pross replied.- You are the one crying. − Me, Miss Pross? -
tr: "I am not crying," said Miss Pross; "it is you who are crying." "Am I my Pross?"
es: —I am not crying; you are the one who is crying—replied Miss Pross.

en: “I, my Pross?” (By this time, Mr. Lorry dared to be pleasant with her, on occasion.)
vi: By now, Mr. Lorry dared to tease her whenever he had the chance. −Who else?
tr: (Mr. Lorry had now found the courage to address her more intimately, given the situation.)
es: —Me, Pross of my sins?—asked Lorry, who now dared to joke with his interlocutor every now and then.

en: “You were, just now; I saw you do it, and I don’t wonder at it. Such a present of plate as you have made ’em, is enough to bring tears into anybody’s eyes. There’s not a fork or a spoon in the collection,” said Miss Pross, “that I didn’t cry over, last night after the box came, till I couldn’t see it.”
vi: I saw it with my own eyes, and it's no surprise to me. Your silverware set is a gift that would bring tears to anyone's eyes, - Miss Pross said. When the gift box arrived last night, every fork and spoon made me cry until my eyes were blurred.
tr: "Yes, you were crying just a moment ago, I saw you and I wasn't surprised at all. You gave them such a beautiful dinner set that anyone who sees it would be moved to tears. Every fork and spoon in this set," said Miss Pross, "brought me to tears, I cried so much after the box arrived last night that I couldn't see."
es: —You, yes. You are crying at this moment, I have seen it, and it is foolish to deny it to me. Besides, it does not surprise me. A gift like the one you have given to the young lady is enough to bring tears to the eyes of a stone statue. What a silver service! I was crying last night over each of the forks, over each of the spoons in the collection from the moment the case arrived until I could see it opened.

en: “I am highly gratified,” said Mr. Lorry, “though, upon my honour, I had no intention of rendering those trifling articles of remembrance invisible to any one. Dear me! This is an occasion that makes a man speculate on all he has lost. Dear, dear, dear! To think that there might have been a Mrs. Lorry, any time these fifty years almost!”
vi: − So I am very satisfied, - said Mr. Lorry, - although I swear on my honor, I never intended to make anyone cry their eyes out over those small gifts. Good Lord! This is an occasion for a man to reflect on all that he has lost. Heavens, heavens, heavens! Just think, in nearly fifty years there could have been a Mrs. Lorry by now! −
tr: "I am very happy," said Mr. Lorry, "but it was not my intention to blind your eyes with these insignificant objects that I gave as a memento." Ah, yes! In such situations, one realizes all the things they have lost. Ahh, ah! Now, by my side, there could have been a wife of fifty years, a Mrs. Lorry!"
es: —What fills me with immense pride, although I swear on my honor that it was not my intention for that small memento to cause anyone suffering. Devil, devil! Here is an occasion that forces a man to think with sorrow about what he has lost! When I remember that fifty years ago there could have been a Mrs. Lorry in the world...!

en: “Not at all!” From Miss Pross.
vi: Not at all! - Miss Pross's voice.
tr: "It couldn't be!" came a response from Miss Pross.
es: —I deny it!—replied Miss Pross. —What!

en: “You think there never might have been a Mrs. Lorry?” asked the gentleman of that name.
vi: − Do you think there could never have been a Mrs. Lorry? Mr. Lorry asked.
tr: "Do you think that there could never be a Ms. Lorry in my life?""
es: Do you think it was impossible for there to have been a Mrs. Lorry?

en: “Pooh!” rejoined Miss Pross; “you were a bachelor in your cradle.”
vi: − Pshaw! - Miss Pross retorted. - You've been a bachelor since you were in the cradle.
tr: "Hmph!" said Miss Pross; "you are a born bachelor."
es: —Get out of the way! You've been single since you were rocked in your cradle!

en: “Well!” observed Mr. Lorry, beamingly adjusting his little wig, “that seems probable, too.”
vi: − Well! - Mr. Lorry cheerfully said while adjusting his small wig, that could be true.
tr: "Eee!" said Mr. Lorry, his eyes laughing as he adjusted his small wig, "you might be right."
es: —I think it very likely—replied Lorry, adjusting his wig.

en: “And you were cut out for a bachelor,” pursued Miss Pross, “before you were put in your cradle.”
vi: − And fate destined you to be a bachelor for life even before you were born, - Miss Pross insisted.
tr: "It was determined that you would remain single while you were still lying in your cradle," added Miss Pross.
es: —And before they put him in the cradle, they cut him out to be a lifelong bachelor.

en: “Then, I think,” said Mr. Lorry, “that I was very unhandsomely dealt with, and that I ought to have had a voice in the selection of my pattern. Enough! Now, my dear Lucie,” drawing his arm soothingly round her waist, “I hear them moving in the next room, and Miss Pross and I, as two formal folks of business, are anxious not to lose the final opportunity of saying something to you that you wish to hear. You leave your good father, my dear, in hands as earnest and as loving as your own; he shall be taken every conceivable care of; during the next fortnight, while you are in Warwickshire and thereabouts, even Tellson’s shall go to the wall (comparatively speaking) before him. And when, at the fortnight’s end, he comes to join you and your beloved husband, on your other fortnight’s trip in Wales, you shall say that we have sent him to you in the best health and in the happiest frame. Now, I hear Somebody’s step coming to the door. Let me kiss my dear girl with an old-fashioned bachelor blessing, before Somebody comes to claim his own.”
vi: − Then it must be, - Mr. Lorry said, - I must be unlucky, I should have had a say in choosing my lifestyle. That's enough! Now, my dear Lucie, - the old man gently wrapped his arm around the girl's waist, - I hear them coming and going in the next room, so Miss Pross and I, as the two people officially in charge, want to take this last opportunity to tell you some things you want to know. My dear, you have entrusted your benevolent father to people who are decent and care for him as much as you do; we will take good care of your father for the next fortnight while you and your husband go to Warwickshire and around there, even putting aside, or nearly so, the work at Tellson's Bank to look after your father. Then after the fortnight, your father will go with you and your husband to Wales for another fortnight, and you will see that we will return your father to you in the healthiest and happiest state. There, I hear the footsteps of Someone coming to the door already. Let me kiss you, my dear, and give you the blessings of this old-fashioned bachelor before Someone comes to take you away.
tr: "Then I think there is a mistake in this matter, I should have been given a say in my own life. Anyway! Now, dear Lucie," said Mr. Lorry, gently wrapping his arm around Lucie's waist. "I can hear their voices from inside, and Miss Pross and I, as knowledgeable individuals, do not want to miss the opportunity to tell you the things you want to hear. You are leaving your dear father in hands as sincere and compassionate as yours, my beautiful girl; he will be very well taken care of; for the next two weeks, while you are in Warwickshire and its surroundings, even Tellson's is of no importance (compared to him). At the end of these two weeks, when your father comes to you and your dear husband for the other two weeks you will spend in Wales, you will see how healthy and happy we have sent him to you. It seems someone is approaching the door. Before someone else comes and kisses her, let me kiss my dear girl."
es: —In which case, they did very wrong, for they should have listened to my vote before choosing the patron... I hear the sound of footsteps in the next room, my dear Lucía—he added, wrapping his arm around the bride's waist—and Miss Pross, and I, as formal and business-like people that we are, suspend our dispute, because we do not want to waste the opportunity that presents itself to say a few things to you that you will not dislike hearing. You are going to leave your father, dear girl, in hands as loving and eager to serve him as yours, in hands that will go out of their way to attend to and care for him during the two weeks that the happy newlyweds are to spend in Warwickshire and its surroundings. Even Tellson's Bank will metaphorically step back to give way to you. And when, after the fifteen days, you accompany your dear husband on the trip to Wales, which is to last another fifteen days, you will have to admit that we return him to you happier and more content than when you left him with us... But someone is approaching the door, and this pretty young lady will allow a hardened bachelor to kiss her before that someone arrives and claims what is his.

en: For a moment, he held the fair face from him to look at the well-remembered expression on the forehead, and then laid the bright golden hair against his little brown wig, with a genuine tenderness and delicacy which, if such things be old-fashioned, were as old as Adam.
vi: He placed his two hands on Lucie's beautiful face for a long time, observing the expressions on the forehead he remembered so well, then gently pressed her golden hair against his small brown wig with affection and tenderness. This sincere gesture, though old-fashioned, has been a way to express love since the dawn of humanity.
tr: To look at that familiar expression on her forehead, he held her beautiful face in his hands for a moment, then, with a tenderness and delicacy as old as Adam and Eve, he rested her golden hair against his own small brown wig.
es: The excellent Lorry spent a good while contemplating that beautiful face, then separated the silky golden curls, which mingled with his chestnut wig, and placed his lips on the smooth forehead with the delicacy with which Adam's contemporaries did these things.

en: The door of the Doctor’s room opened, and he came out with Charles Darnay. He was so deadly pale—which had not been the case when they went in together—that no vestige of colour was to be seen in his face. But, in the composure of his manner he was unaltered, except that to the shrewd glance of Mr. Lorry it disclosed some shadowy indication that the old air of avoidance and dread had lately passed over him, like a cold wind.
vi: The doctor's office door was wide open, he and Charles Darnay walked out. The doctor's face was pale as if there was no blood left - when the two went into the room, his complexion was not like that. But his calm demeanor remained unchanged, only Mr. Lorry's sharp eyes noticed a sign of gloom as if a cold wind had just blown through, making the doctor seem somewhat fearful and evasive like before.
tr: The door of the Doctor's room opened and the Doctor and Charles Darnay came out. The Doctor's face was so pale – it hadn't been like that when he went in – that there wasn't the slightest hint of color, yet although his demeanor was the same, Mr. Lorry's keen eye did not miss that the feeling of avoiding and fearing everything that used to envelop the Doctor had passed like a faint cold breeze.
es: The door of the doctor's room opened, and he came out followed by Charles Darnay. A deadly pallor covered the face of the former, in which no traces of color remained, a pallor that did not exist when he was locked in his room with Darnay. His attitude, however, his expression, remained unchanged, although Lorry's keen eye discovered a certain somber indication that revealed the passage over his soul of the breath of repulsion and hatred that at other times, like a fleeting gust of cold wind, had struck him.

en: He gave his arm to his daughter, and took her down-stairs to the chariot which Mr. Lorry had hired in honour of the day. The rest followed in another carriage, and soon, in a neighbouring church, where no strange eyes looked on, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married.
vi: Mr. Manette offered his arm to his daughter, then led her downstairs to the carriage that Mr. Lorry had hired for this grand day. The others followed in another carriage, and soon after, at a nearby church, where no strangers were peeking, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily wed.
tr: The doctor took his daughter by the arm and led her down the stairs to the carriage that Mr. Lorry had hired in honor of the day. The others followed them in another carriage, and a little later, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were happily married in a nearby church, away from prying eyes.
es: He gave his arm to his daughter and accompanied her to the carriage that Lorry, in consideration of the solemnity of the day, had rented. The other people settled in another carriage, and minutes later, Charles Darnay and Lucie Manette were united with sweet and indissoluble bonds in the nearby church.

en: Besides the glancing tears that shone among the smiles of the little group when it was done, some diamonds, very bright and sparkling, glanced on the bride’s hand, which were newly released from the dark obscurity of one of Mr. Lorry’s pockets. They returned home to breakfast, and all went well, and in due course the golden hair that had mingled with the poor shoemaker’s white locks in the Paris garret, were mingled with them again in the morning sunlight, on the threshold of the door at parting.
vi: Beyond the tear-filled eyes reflecting the smiles of everyone at the end of the wedding ceremony, on the bride's hand was the radiant, sparkling light of several diamonds that had just emerged from the dark pocket of Mr. Lorry. They went home for breakfast, and everything went well, then came the moment when the golden hair that had once mingled with the silver locks of the poor shoemaker in the attic in Paris now once again mingled with the silver head at the doorstep during the farewell.
