tr: When the wedding ended, alongside the sparkling tears among the smiling faces of the small gathering, the diamonds that had just emerged from the dark mystery of Mr. Lorry's pocket were also shining brightly in the bride's hand. They returned home for breakfast; everything went well and just as the golden hair had mingled with the curls of the poor shoemaker's white hair in the attic in Paris, now, as they were saying goodbye at the doorstep, it mingled in the morning sunlight.
es: In addition to the transparent tears that shone among smiles during the ceremony, some brilliant diamonds of the clearest waters sparkled in the bride's hand, which moments before had been freed from the darkness of one of Mr. Lorry's pockets, where they had been confined. The newlyweds returned to the house, followed by the small circle of guests, had lunch, and later, the beautiful golden hair that once mingled its strands with the white locks of the poor shoemaker who ardently made shoes in an attic in Paris, came together again with the same, bathed in the morning sun's rays, on the doorstep at the moment of farewell.

en: It was a hard parting, though it was not for long. But her father cheered her, and said at last, gently disengaging himself from her enfolding arms, “Take her, Charles! She is yours!”
vi: It was a difficult farewell even though the separation would not be long. But the father encouraged his daughter and finally gently separated from her tight embrace, he exclaimed: − Charles, take Lucie away! Lucie is your wife now!
tr: Although it wouldn't be a long separation, it was a difficult farewell. But her father had managed to cheer her up, and finally, as he gently extricated himself from her embracing arms, he said, "Come on, take her Charles! My daughter is yours now!"
es: It was a painful separation, although its duration was to be short. The father encouraged his daughter, gently detached himself from her loving arms, and said with a lively expression: —Take it, Carlos! It's yours!

en: And her agitated hand waved to them from a chaise window, and she was gone.
vi: And the daughter's anxious hand waved goodbye to everyone through the carriage window, then she departed.
tr: Lucie waved excitedly to them from the car window, and then the car disappeared from sight.
es: One minute later, through the window of a departing stagecoach, a hand waving a handkerchief emerged; it was Lucía's hand.

en: The corner being out of the way of the idle and curious, and the preparations having been very simple and few, the Doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross, were left quite alone. It was when they turned into the welcome shade of the cool old hall, that Mr. Lorry observed a great change to have come over the Doctor; as if the golden arm uplifted there, had struck him a poisoned blow.
vi: The secluded street corner frequented by curious idlers, the preparation for this wedding was very simple and neat, on the road only the doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross remained. When the three of them returned to the shadow of the old, cold hall, Mr. Lorry noticed that Mr. Manette's expression had changed completely, as if the golden arm symbol mounted on the high wall had just dealt the doctor a vicious blow.
tr: Due to the house being in a corner away from idle types and the curious, and because the wedding preparations were simple and minimal, Doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross were left alone as the car departed. When they entered the shadow of the cool, old hall, Mr. Lorry noticed the significant change in the Doctor; it was as if the golden arm standing there had suddenly delivered a poisonous punch to him.
es: As the little corner of Soho was shielded from curious eyes and away from places frequented by idlers, and on the other hand, the preparations had been simple and unpretentious, once the newlyweds had left, the doctor, Mr. Lorry, and Miss Pross were completely alone. When the three of them re-entered the living room, it was then that Lorry noticed the terrible change that had just occurred in the doctor: it seemed as if the arm of the golden giant had struck him with a poisoned blow.

en: He had naturally repressed much, and some revulsion might have been expected in him when the occasion for repression was gone. But, it was the old scared lost look that troubled Mr. Lorry; and through his absent manner of clasping his head and drearily wandering away into his own room when they got up-stairs, Mr. Lorry was reminded of Defarge the wine-shop keeper, and the starlight ride.
vi: The doctor, of course, had to suppress his emotions a great deal, and if sudden changes were revealed when he had the chance to let go, it would not be surprising. But Mr. Lorry became worried because Mr. Manette again bore the distraught expression of his previous suffering; when they went upstairs, the way the doctor absentmindedly ruffled his hair and entered his private room like a lost soul reminded Mr. Lorry of the innkeeper Defarge and the journey under the starlight.
tr: The doctor had naturally suppressed many emotions within himself, and it was not at all surprising that there was a sudden change in him with the disappearance of the source of pressure; on the other hand, what really worried Mr. Lorry was the old fearful, lost expression on the man's face. Moreover, when they went upstairs, the doctor absentmindedly took his head in his hands and wandered around his room sorrowfully, which reminded Mr. Lorry of Defarge, the owner of the wine shop, and their progress along the star-lit road.
es: It was natural that the violent efforts he necessarily had to make to keep his emotion locked within his chest would be followed by a similarly violent reaction as soon as the cause, the occasion for those efforts, disappeared. It was not, then, the reaction, it was not the flattening, that alarmed Mr. Lorry, but the derangement with which the doctor put his hands on his head, the gloomy monotony with which he began to pace as soon as he entered the room, and those symptoms alarmed him because they reminded him of the attic of Defarge's tavern and the condition in which he found the doctor there.

en: “I think,” he whispered to Miss Pross, after anxious consideration, “I think we had best not speak to him just now, or at all disturb him. I must look in at Tellson’s; so I will go there at once and come back presently. Then, we will take him a ride into the country, and dine there, and all will be well.”
vi: − Probably... - after a moment of anxious thought, he whispered to Miss Pross. - Perhaps right now we should not say anything to the doctor, or bother him. I have to stop by Tellson to check on some work; I'll go right away and be back soon. Then, we will take a carriage to take the doctor on a countryside trip and have a meal there, and everything will be fine.
tr: After thinking uneasily, Mr. Lorry whispered to Miss Pross, "I think," he said, "I think we shouldn't talk to him now, or even disturb him at all. I need to go to Tellson's; I'll just go and come back quickly. Then we can take him for a walk in the countryside, have a meal somewhere around there, it will do us all good."
es: —I believe—he said in a very low voice to Miss Pross—that we should not speak to him at this moment nor distract him in any way. I am going to take a look at the Bank, from where I will return in a moment. Upon my return, I will take him to the countryside, where we will eat after taking a good walk, and I hope that in this way we will be able to dispel the dark thoughts that seem to hover over his soul.

en: It was easier for Mr. Lorry to look in at Tellson’s, than to look out of Tellson’s. He was detained two hours. When he came back, he ascended the old staircase alone, having asked no question of the servant; going thus into the Doctor’s rooms, he was stopped by a low sound of knocking.
vi: Mr. Lorry found it easier to visit Tellson's than to leave it. He was kept there for two whole hours. When he returned, he went up the old staircase alone, without asking the servants anything, and went straight to the doctor's room. The faint sound of a knock made him stop.
tr: For Mr. Lorry, going to Tellson's was easier than returning from Tellson's. They kept him at the bank for two hours. When he returned, without asking the servant anything, he climbed the old stairs alone and just as he was about to enter the Doctor's room, he was stopped by the low sounds coming from inside.
es: Nothing was easier for Lorry than entering the Bank; but nothing was more difficult than leaving it. The quick look he intended to take lasted two hours. When he returned to the house in Soho and went up the stairs, without asking the servant who came to open the door for him, as he was about to enter the doctor's room, which he was heading straight for, he stood as if nailed to the floor.

en: “Good God!” he said, with a start. “What’s that?”
vi: − My God! - He was startled. - What's the matter?
tr: "Good heavens!" he said, startled. "What is this?"
es: Inside the room, loud and repeated blows could be heard. —Good God!—he exclaimed, stepping back a pace—What is that?

en: Miss Pross, with a terrified face, was at his ear. “O me, O me! All is lost!” cried she, wringing her hands. “What is to be told to Ladybird? He doesn’t know me, and is making shoes!”
vi: − Oh heavens, oh heavens! It's all ruined! - Miss Pross, her face horrified, wringing her hands, whispered into his ear. - How will we explain this to our dear mistress? He doesn't recognize me, and just keeps making shoes!
tr: Miss Pross was right beside him with a horrified look on her face. "Oh, oh! We are ruined!" she was crying out, rubbing her hands. "What are we going to tell my little bird now? The man did not recognize me, he is sitting and making shoes!"
es: Miss Pross, with terror painted on her face, murmured in his ear: —What a misfortune...! Poor us...! Everything is lost, everything! What do we tell the young lady? Who will tell her? Oh...!—he added, wringing his hands—She doesn't know me, Mr. Lorry, and she is making shoes!

en: Mr. Lorry said what he could to calm her, and went himself into the Doctor’s room. The bench was turned towards the light, as it had been when he had seen the shoemaker at his work before, and his head was bent down, and he was very busy.
vi: Mr. Lorry said a few comforting words to her and then went straight into the doctor's room. The old bench was facing the light source as he had seen before, and the shoemaker was diligently, busily working.
tr: After Mr. Lorry had said everything he could to calm the woman, he entered the Doctor's room alone. The shoemaking bench was turned towards the light just as he had seen it before, and the man was bent forward, working diligently.
es: Lorry tried to calm her, though in vain, and entered the doctor's room. He had moved the stool close to the window, just as he had it placed in the attic in Paris, and was working fervently, his head bent over the shoe.

en: “Doctor Manette. My dear friend, Doctor Manette!”
vi: − Doctor Manette. My friend, Doctor Manette!
tr: "Doctor Manette! My dear friend." "Doctor Manette!"
es: —Doctor Manette!—shouted Lorry.— My dear friend... my good Doctor Manette...!

en: The Doctor looked at him for a moment—half inquiringly, half as if he were angry at being spoken to—and bent over his work again.
vi: The doctor looked at him for a moment - half questioning, half angry at being disturbed - then bent down to continue his work.
tr: The doctor briefly lifted his head and looked at him – with eyes that were half inquisitive, half annoyed at being disturbed – before bending back over the work in front of him.
es: The doctor raised his head, looked at the person who called him with an expression of both surprise and anger, undoubtedly displeased that they dared to address him... and continued his task.

en: He had laid aside his coat and waistcoat; his shirt was open at the throat, as it used to be when he did that work; and even the old haggard, faded surface of face had come back to him. He worked hard—impatiently—as if in some sense of having been interrupted.
vi: Mr. Manette had taken off his coat and vest; his shirt was open at the collar just like in the old days; and even the haggard, worn-out look of those times had returned. He worked diligently - seemingly anxious - as if the work had been delayed for a long time.
tr: He had set aside his jacket and vest; the collar of his shirt was open, just like in the old days when he did this job; his face had once again taken on that pale, wild look. He was working feverishly –impatiently– as if someone might come and interrupt him.
es: He had stripped off his frock coat and waistcoat, wore his shirt unbuttoned and his chest bare, exactly as when they found him in the attic of the tavern. His face had even regained the old gaunt and somber look from the years of his misfortune, and he worked with extraordinary fervor, with impatience, like someone finishing an urgent task and not wanting to be interrupted.

en: Mr. Lorry glanced at the work in his hand, and observed that it was a shoe of the old size and shape. He took up another that was lying by him, and asked what it was.
vi: Mr. Lorry glanced at the shoe in the doctor's hand and recognized it as the one that had been left unfinished some time ago. He picked up the other shoe lying next to Mr. Manette and asked about the type of shoe.
tr: When Mr. Lorry looked at the work in the doctor's hand, he saw that it was something of old style and measures. He took the other shoe standing next to the man and asked what it was.
es: Lorry looked at the shoe the doctor was stitching and saw that it was very old-fashioned. He didn't dare to take it from his hands; but he picked up another one that was at the shoemaker's feet, and asked him what it was.

en: “A young lady’s walking shoe,” he muttered, without looking up. “It ought to have been finished long ago. Let it be.”
vi: − The young lady's walking shoes, - the doctor mumbled, not looking up. - They should have been done a long time ago. Leave them there. −
tr: Without lifting his head from his work, the doctor murmured, "Walking shoes for a young girl." "It should have been finished already. But anyway."
es: —Walking shoe for a young lady—replied the doctor without raising his eyes. —I should have finished it a long time ago. Leave me alone.

en: “But, Doctor Manette. Look at me!”
vi: Oh, Doctor Manette. Look at me!
tr: "But Doctor Manette. Look at me, please!"
es: —But for God's sake, Dr. Manette!—exclaimed Lorry. —Look at me!

en: He obeyed, in the old mechanically submissive manner, without pausing in his work.
vi: The doctor complied in a mechanical, submissive manner as before, his hands not stopping their work.
tr: The doctor, with his old mechanical obedient manner, complied without interrupting his work.
es: The doctor obeyed with the old mechanical submission, but without interrupting his work.

en: “You know me, my dear friend? Think again. This is not your proper occupation. Think, dear friend!”
vi: − You know me, friend? Think again. This job is not your profession. There was no way to make Dr. Manette say another word.
tr: "Do you remember me, dear friend? Please think. This is not your real job. Dear friend, please think again!"
es: —Don't you recognize me yet, my dear friend? Come to your senses, Doctor Manette! Your profession is not that of a shoemaker... it never has been. It was a wasted effort to try to get a single word out of him.

en: Nothing would induce him to speak more. He looked up, for an instant at a time, when he was requested to do so; but, no persuasion would extract a word from him. He worked, and worked, and worked, in silence, and words fell on him as they would have fallen on an echoless wall, or on the air. The only ray of hope that Mr. Lorry could discover, was, that he sometimes furtively looked up without being asked. In that, there seemed a faint expression of curiosity or perplexity—as though he were trying to reconcile some doubts in his mind.
vi: There was no way to make Dr. Manette say another word. He would look up for a moment whenever asked to, but no matter how much he was questioned, he wouldn't utter a sound. He just kept working, working, working in silence, and Mr. Lorry's words seemed to fall into the void or bounce off a wall with no echo. The only glimmer of hope Mr. Lorry could see was that the doctor would occasionally glance up even when no one asked him to. At those moments, the doctor's eyes seemed to be tinged with curiosity or confusion, just like Mr. Manette trying to unravel the doubts in his mind.
tr: Nothing could make him talk any more. When asked, he would lift his head and look for a moment; but no matter how much effort was made to persuade him, not a single word would come out of his mouth. The Doctor worked silently and incessantly, and the words rained down on him as if they had fallen on a wall or into the air without an echo. The only glimmer of hope Mr. Lorry could see was the Doctor occasionally, even though he was not asked to, secretly lifting his head and looking. In such moments, there was a faint expression of curiosity and bewilderment on his face; as if his mind was occupied with doubts he was trying to dispel.
es: He would momentarily lift his head when Lorry told him to, but all the pleas and entreaties were in vain: he did not speak. He worked, sewed with true fervor, and the words directed at him slid over his ears, as they would slide over a cold steel wall. A single ray of hope shone among the shadows of despair that enveloped Lorry, and it was that sometimes, the doctor would look at him furtively without being told to. The ray of hope was weak, as it had no more foundation than the fact that his friend's glances seemed to indicate curiosity, perplexity of mind, something like a symptom that the doctor was trying to harmonize, reconcile certain doubts that had arisen in his soul.

en: Two things at once impressed themselves on Mr. Lorry, as important above all others; the first, that this must be kept secret from Lucie; the second, that it must be kept secret from all who knew him. In conjunction with Miss Pross, he took immediate steps towards the latter precaution, by giving out that the Doctor was not well, and required a few days of complete rest. In aid of the kind deception to be practised on his daughter, Miss Pross was to write, describing his having been called away professionally, and referring to an imaginary letter of two or three hurried lines in his own hand, represented to have been addressed to her by the same post.
vi: Mr. Lorry immediately noted two most important things; first, not to let Lucie know about this; second, to keep it secret from those who knew the doctor. Together with Miss Pross, he proceeded with the second important thing first, by spreading the news that the doctor was unwell and needed complete rest for a few days. As for Lucie, Miss Pross, out of kindness, had to deceive her; she wrote a letter saying that the doctor had some business that required him to be away and in the letter, she fabricated a story about receiving a few hurried lines from the doctor informing them.
tr: Suddenly, two things came to Mr. Lorry's mind, more important than anything else; first, this incident must be kept from Lucie; second, this incident must be kept from everyone who knew the Doctor. By putting their heads together, Miss Pross and Mr. Lorry took an urgent measure against the second group by saying that the Doctor was not feeling well and needed to rest for a few days. As for the deception to be applied to his daughter, Miss Pross would write a letter to Lucie explaining that her father had been called away for work, and even a few imaginary lines supposedly written hastily by her father would be included in the same post.
es: Lorry opined that it was necessary to adopt two important resolutions, apart from others of lesser importance: the first, to prevent Lucie from learning about the misfortune, and the second, to prevent this from reaching the ears of any of the people who knew the doctor. In agreement with Miss Pross, he immediately took the necessary precautionary measures to achieve the second result, which consisted of stating that the doctor was indisposed, and that his state of health required a few days of rest and absolute isolation. To deceive his daughter, Miss Pross was to write a letter informing her that her father had had to leave for professional matters, and commenting on a letter received by mail and written by the doctor in a hurry, in which he merely stated that his absence would be brief.

en: These measures, advisable to be taken in any case, Mr. Lorry took in the hope of his coming to himself. If that should happen soon, he kept another course in reserve; which was, to have a certain opinion that he thought the best, on the Doctor’s case.
vi: Mr. Lorry was forced to use both of these methods in the hope that the doctor would soon regain his senses. In that case, he had another contingency plan; that is, to seek some advice which he thought would be best for Dr. Manette's condition.
tr: Mr. Lorry had taken these sensible measures in the hope that the Doctor would come to his senses. If this happened soon, there was another plan in place; Mr. Lorry thought this would be the best for the Doctor.
es: These measures were, so to speak, of a general nature, and Lorry adopted them in case the doctor's unfortunate crisis soon disappeared. In case this solution did not take long, he considered it necessary, or at least very convenient, to follow a plan from which he promised great results for the future, a plan that consisted of forming a well-founded and motivated opinion about his friend's state of mind.

en: In the hope of his recovery, and of resort to this third course being thereby rendered practicable, Mr. Lorry resolved to watch him attentively, with as little appearance as possible of doing so. He therefore made arrangements to absent himself from Tellson’s for the first time in his life, and took his post by the window in the same room.
vi: Hoping the doctor would recover quickly and thus make the third way more convenient, Mr. Lorry decided to observe Mr. Manette very carefully but as discreetly as possible. For the first time in his life, he arranged to take a temporary leave from Tellson's and kept watch by the window in the doctor's room.
tr: With hopes for the Doctor's recovery and eagerness to implement his third plan in the village, Mr. Lorry decided not to take his eyes off him; while doing so, he needed to remain inconspicuous. Therefore, for the first time in his life, he took leave from Tellson's and positioned himself in the same room as the Doctor, in front of the window.
es: In case this solution did not take long, he considered it necessary, or at least very convenient, to follow a plan from which he promised great results for the future, a plan that consisted of forming a well-founded and motivated opinion about his friend's state of mind.

en: He was not long in discovering that it was worse than useless to speak to him, since, on being pressed, he became worried. He abandoned that attempt on the first day, and resolved merely to keep himself always before him, as a silent protest against the delusion into which he had fallen, or was falling. He remained, therefore, in his seat near the window, reading and writing, and expressing in as many pleasant and natural ways as he could think of, that it was a free place.
vi: He immediately saw that trying to start a conversation with Mr. Manette would only make things worse, as the more he was pressed, the more confused the doctor became. Mr. Lorry abandoned this idea on the very first day and decided to just sit quietly in front of Mr. Manette, at a slight distance, in silence as a way to counteract the doctor's delusions or to prevent them from worsening. Therefore, he just sat by the window, reading or writing something, trying his best to appear comfortable and natural, as if in this room anyone could freely do whatever they wanted.
tr: It didn't take long for Mr. Lorry to realize that talking to the Doctor was of no use, and in fact, made the situation worse, because the more he was pressed, the more anxious the Doctor became. Mr. Lorry gave up on this attempt on the very first day and decided to keep his distance from him, as if silently protesting, in order to save him from the delusion he had fallen into or was falling into. Thus, Mr. Lorry spent the whole day sitting in the chair by the window, reading books, writing and drawing, and trying to show him in every pleasant and natural way he could think of that this was a free place.
es: Very soon he had to convince himself that talking to him was not only perfectly useless but also harmful, since when he pressed him with questions or observations, he would upset and excite him more and more. Consequently, he gave up talking to him and resolved not to leave him alone for a moment, to become a silent protest against the deception into which he had fallen or was falling. To this end, and in his desire to carry out the noble mission he had imposed on himself while enveloping it in the utmost secrecy, for the first time in his life he took the necessary measures to remain indefinitely absent from the Bank, and took possession of an armchair placed next to the window of the doctor's room, where he spent his time reading or writing.

en: Doctor Manette took what was given him to eat and drink, and worked on, that first day, until it was too dark to see—worked on, half an hour after Mr. Lorry could not have seen, for his life, to read or write. When he put his tools aside as useless, until morning, Mr. Lorry rose and said to him:
vi: On the first day, whatever food and drink was given to him, Dr. Manette ate and drank and kept diligently making shoes until there was no more light - it had gotten so dark that Mr. Lorry couldn't read or write anything, yet Mr. Manette continued working for another half hour before putting away his tools to continue the next morning. At that point, Mr. Lorry stood up and said: −
tr: Dr. Manette ate and drank what was given to him, and on that first day, he worked until he could no longer see – Mr. Lorry, despite his efforts, had stopped reading and writing half an hour earlier because he could no longer see. When the doctor set aside his tools to resume in the morning, Mr. Lorry stood up and said:
es: The doctor Manette ate and drank what was served to him, and worked on the first day until he ran out of light, it being noteworthy that, when he had to leave his task, it had already been a good half hour since Lorry had had to put aside the book he was reading, simply because he could no longer see the letters. Lorry stood up when he saw that the doctor was putting away his tools, and asked him:

en: “Will you go out?”
vi: Do you want to go outside?
tr: "Shall we go outside?"
es: —Do you want to go out?

en: He looked down at the floor on either side of him in the old manner, looked up in the old manner, and repeated in the old low voice:
vi: The doctor bowed his head, looking at the floor on both sides as he used to, then looked up as he used to, and softly repeated in the same old voice: − Go outside? −
tr: The doctor looked down to the ground and to his sides with his usual demeanor, then he raised his head with his usual demeanor and finally repeated in his usual low voice:
es: The doctor fixed his eyes on the ground, moved them from one place to another as in times past, and finally raising them, he said:

en: “Out?”
vi: The doctor bowed his head, looking at the floor on both sides as he used to, then looked up as he used to, and softly repeated in the same old voice: − Go outside? −
tr: "Outside?'
es: —Going out?

en: “Yes; for a walk with me. Why not?”
vi: Yes, take a walk with me. Why not?
tr: "Yes, let's go for a walk together. Shall we?"
es: —Yes... Come take a walk with me: why not?

en: He made no effort to say why not, and said not a word more. But, Mr. Lorry thought he saw, as he leaned forward on his bench in the dusk, with his elbows on his knees and his head in his hands, that he was in some misty way asking himself, “Why not?” The sagacity of the man of business perceived an advantage here, and determined to hold it.
vi: The doctor didn't bother to reply, nor did he say anything further. But Mr. Lorry seemed to see the doctor - while hunched over on the bench in the dark, elbows on his knees, head buried in his hands - vaguely muttering the question “Why not?”. With the sharpness of a professional, Mr. Lorry recognized the favorable condition, and he decided to maintain it as such.
tr: The doctor made no effort to respond and did not say another word. But Mr. Lorry, while the Doctor was leaning over his workbench in the evening darkness with his elbows on his knees and his head in his hands, thought he heard him faintly ask himself, "Is it possible?" The businessman’s common sense had derived something useful from this and did not want to overlook it.
es: He did not attempt to explain why not, nor did he part his lips again; but Lorry, while watching him with a penetrating gaze, bending his body, with his elbows resting on his knees and his head on the palms of his hands, believed that the unfortunate man was asking himself: "Why not?" The sagacity of the businessman saw an advantage in this and resolved to make the most of it.

en: Miss Pross and he divided the night into two watches, and observed him at intervals from the adjoining room. He paced up and down for a long time before he lay down; but, when he did finally lay himself down, he fell asleep. In the morning, he was up betimes, and went straight to his bench and to work.
vi: Miss Pross and he took turns during the night in the adjacent room to watch over the doctor. Mr. Manette paced back and forth for a long time before lying down on the bed, but once he lay down, he slept soundly. In the morning, he got up early and went straight to the bench to continue making shoes.
tr: Miss Pross and Mr. Lorry, dividing the night into shifts, periodically checked on the Doctor from the adjacent room. Before going to bed, the Doctor paced up and down the room for a long time, and as soon as he finally laid his head on the pillow, he fell asleep immediately. In the morning, he got up without delay and started working at his bench.
es: During the nights, they watched over the sick person from the adjoining room, sometimes Mr. Lorry, sometimes Miss Pross, for which they had established two shifts, corresponding to the two halves into which they divided the watch duty. The doctor usually spent some time pacing in his room before retiring to bed; but when he lay down, he slept deeply and enjoyed a peaceful sleep. Come morning, as soon as he got up, he went straight to his bench and began to work.

en: On this second day, Mr. Lorry saluted him cheerfully by his name, and spoke to him on topics that had been of late familiar to them. He returned no reply, but it was evident that he heard what was said, and that he thought about it, however confusedly. This encouraged Mr. Lorry to have Miss Pross in with her work, several times during the day; at those times, they quietly spoke of Lucie, and of her father then present, precisely in the usual manner, and as if there were nothing amiss. This was done without any demonstrative accompaniment, not long enough, or often enough to harass him; and it lightened Mr. Lorry’s friendly heart to believe that he looked up oftener, and that he appeared to be stirred by some perception of inconsistencies surrounding him.
vi: On the second day, Mr. Lorry cheerfully greeted the doctor by name and talked about the topics that the two had recently been discussing. Mr. Manette did not respond, but it was clear that he heard what Mr. Lorry said and was thinking about those matters, despite his disturbed mind. That encouraged Mr. Lorry to call Miss Pross in to help several times a day; during those times, they calmly talked about Lucie, about the father who was present, as if nothing had happened. They tried to appear as if they were having natural conversations, not too long, and not too often to avoid disturbing the doctor; and Mr. Lorry's friendly heart lit up when he saw that the doctor was looking up more often, showing some attention to the unusual things around him.
tr: On the second day, Mr. Lorry cheerfully greeted the Doctor and talked about the topics they had become familiar with recently. He always spoke of these subjects. Even though he did not respond, it was clear that the Doctor heard what was being said and, no matter how complex, pondered over them. This situation encouraged Mr. Lorry to involve Miss Pross at certain times of the day; during such times, the two of them would put their heads together and talk quietly about Lucie, her father, and the day's affairs as if nothing was amiss, with their usual demeanor. During this time, they did not act overly exaggerated, did not prolong the conversation, nor did they speak so frequently as to disturb the Doctor; the fact that the Doctor began to lift his head more often and seemed affected by the inconsistencies around him somewhat eased Mr. Lorry's warm heart.
es: On the second day of the crisis, Lorry greeted the doctor by calling him by his name, and then began to talk to him about matters that were very familiar to both of them. The doctor did not respond, but it was evident that he heard what was being said to him and that he was thinking about it, albeit in a confused manner. This encouraged Lorry, who asked Miss Pross to come in and keep him company several times during the day, in order to constantly talk about Lucia and her father, who was present at the conversations, naturally and as if nothing had happened. The results were not very successful, but neither were they so fruitless as to discourage Lorry from continuing the plan, as it managed, if nothing else, to dispel, even if only for brief moments, the state of indifference in which he was immersed.

en: When it fell dark again, Mr. Lorry asked him as before:
vi: When night fell again, Mr. Lorry asked as he did yesterday: − Dear Doctor, do you want to go outside?
tr: When darkness fell again, Mr. Lorry asked the Doctor as before:
es: When the night of this second day closed, Lorry repeated his question from the previous day:

en: “Dear Doctor, will you go out?”
vi: When night fell again, Mr. Lorry asked as he did yesterday: − Dear Doctor, do you want to go outside?
tr: "Dear Doctor, shall we go outside?"
es: —My dear doctor, do you want to go out?

en: As before, he repeated, “Out?”
vi: Just like yesterday, Mr. Manette repeated: − Go outside? −
tr: The doctor repeated as before; "Outside?""
es: And as on the previous day, the respondent answered:

en: “Yes; for a walk with me. Why not?”
vi: Yes, take a walk with me. Why not?
tr: "Yes, let's go for a walk together. Shall we?"
es: —Go out?

en: This time, Mr. Lorry feigned to go out when he could extract no answer from him, and, after remaining absent for an hour, returned. In the meanwhile, the Doctor had removed to the seat in the window, and had sat there looking down at the plane-tree; but, on Mr. Lorry’s return, he slipped away to his bench.
vi: This time, Mr. Lorry pretended to leave when he saw the doctor say nothing, and stayed away for about an hour before returning. During that time, Dr. Manette had moved to sit by the window and looked down at the plane tree; but seeing Mr. Lorry return, he quietly went back to the shoemaker's bench.
tr: When Mr. Lorry received no response from him, he pretended to leave and disappeared for an hour before returning. During this time, the Doctor had moved to the window and was sitting, looking at the sycamore tree; but with Mr. Lorry's return, he immediately went back to his workbench.
es: Lorry feigned an absence upon not being able to obtain another response, returning after an hour. While Lorry was away, the doctor removed the stool that was next to the window and sat in a chair, from where he was contemplating the plane tree in the courtyard; but as soon as Lorry entered the room, he returned to sit on the stool.

en: The time went very slowly on, and Mr. Lorry’s hope darkened, and his heart grew heavier again, and grew yet heavier and heavier every day. The third day came and went, the fourth, the fifth. Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, nine days.
vi: Time passed very slowly, and Mr. Lorry's hope gradually became more fragile, his heart growing heavier and heavier, each heavy day followed by an even heavier one. The third day ended and the fourth day came, then the fifth. Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, nine days.
tr: Time was flowing very slowly and Mr. Lorry's hopes had faded, his heart had become heavy again, and with each passing day it grew heavier and heavier. The third day came and went, then the fourth, and then the fifth day. Five days, six days, seven days, eight days, and nine days.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away.

en: With a hope ever darkening, and with a heart always growing heavier and heavier, Mr. Lorry passed through this anxious time. The secret was well kept, and Lucie was unconscious and happy; but he could not fail to observe that the shoemaker, whose hand had been a little out at first, was growing dreadfully skilful, and that he had never been so intent on his work, and that his hands had never been so nimble and expert, as in the dusk of the ninth evening.
vi: Hope dwindled more and more, and his heart grew heavier with worry; Mr. Lorry had spent nine days like this. This secret remained hidden, Lucie was still blissfully unaware; but he could not help but notice the shoemaker, whose hands, initially somewhat forgetful of their craft, had become increasingly skillful to a frightening degree.
tr: With his hopes gradually fading and his heart growing heavier with each passing day, Mr. Lorry went through difficult times. The secret was well kept and Lucie was unaware and happy; but Mr. Lorry couldn't help but notice that the shoemaker's hands, which were slow at first, were becoming more skilled, never working with such enthusiasm before, and never moving as deftly and skillfully as they did in the twilight of this ninth day.
es: Days passed, and the hopes that Lorry had conceived were gradually fading away. It was true that the misfortune had not left the doctor's room; it was true that it was a secret to everyone, that Lucía did not remotely suspect it and was happy and content; but the good banker could not help but see, with deep sorrow, that the shoemaker, whose hand was clumsy in the first days, was acquiring a marvelous skill, that the doctor was taking more and more pleasure in the trade, and that his hands never worked with as much fervor and dexterity as when night spread its black mantle over the ninth day after the misfortune.

en: CHAPTER XIX.
vi: Never had he made shoes with such focus, and never had his hands been so swift and adept, in the twilight of the ninth day.
tr: Nineteen
es: 19th.

en: An Opinion
vi: 19. Consultation
tr: An Idea
es: AN OPINION

en: Worn out by anxious watching, Mr. Lorry fell asleep at his post. On the tenth morning of his suspense, he was startled by the shining of the sun into the room where a heavy slumber had overtaken him when it was dark night.
vi: Exhausted from worrying and watching, Mr. Lorry fell asleep in the next room. On the tense tenth morning, he was awakened by the sunlight streaming into the room where sleep had overtaken him in the dark night.
tr: Mr. Lorry, exhausted from anxious watching, had fallen asleep at his post. On the tenth morning of this uncertain situation, Mr. Lorry woke up with a start as daylight streamed in; he must have fallen asleep under the weight that had settled on him in the pitch darkness of the night.
es: With his energies exhausted by long and anxious hours of incessant watchfulness, Mr. Lorry fell asleep at his post of honor. A ray as indiscreet as it was bright from the morning sun came to shake the heavy sleep that had overcome him the previous night, which was the tenth in the series of watchful nights.

en: He rubbed his eyes and roused himself; but he doubted, when he had done so, whether he was not still asleep. For, going to the door of the Doctor’s room and looking in, he perceived that the shoemaker’s bench and tools were put aside again, and that the Doctor himself sat reading at the window. He was in his usual morning dress, and his face (which Mr. Lorry could distinctly see), though still very pale, was calmly studious and attentive.
vi: He rubbed his eyes and stood up; but even so, he wasn't sure he was fully awake. Because when he stepped to the doctor's room door and looked in, he saw the shoemaker's bench and tools had been put away, and the doctor was sitting properly reading a book by the window. He was dressed in his usual morning attire, and his face (Mr. Lorry saw clearly) though still pale, was calm and focused.
tr: He rubbed his eyes and shook himself; but even while doing all this, he still wasn't sure if he was awake or not. Because when he went to the Doctor's room and looked inside, he saw that the cobbler's bench and tools had been put aside again and the Doctor was reading a book in front of the window. He was wearing his usual morning attire, and although his face (as Mr. Lorry could clearly see) was still pale, it was adorned with a calm interest and attention.
es: With a nervous hand, he rubbed his eyes, stood up, and ran to the entrance of the doctor's bedroom. There he stopped abruptly, wondering if he was asleep or awake. Reasons? He had plenty: the stool, with the rest of the shoemaker's tools, was in a corner, and the doctor was calmly reading, lounging in an armchair by the window. He was wearing a morning suit, and his face, which Lorry could see perfectly, though a little pale, reflected absolute calm and placidity.

en: Even when he had satisfied himself that he was awake, Mr. Lorry felt giddily uncertain for some few moments whether the late shoemaking might not be a disturbed dream of his own; for, did not his eyes show him his friend before him in his accustomed clothing and aspect, and employed as usual; and was there any sign within their range, that the change of which he had so strong an impression had actually happened?
vi: Even when he was sure he was truly awake, Mr. Lorry still felt dizzy for a moment, confused about whether the shoe-making episode last night was a disturbing dream if he hadn't seen his friend in familiar attire and manner, doing his usual work; so, had all the signs of change that had worried him for the past nine days really happened?
tr: Although Mr. Lorry convinced himself that he was now awake, in his dazed state, he couldn't decide for a moment whether this recent shoemaking matter was a bothersome illusion created in his mind; after all, his friend was sitting right in front of him in his usual attire and appearance, engaged in his usual occupation, showing not the slightest sign of any change or discomfort.
es: A few pinches administered with a firm hand convinced Mr. Lorry that he was not asleep: this point was perfectly clarified and elucidated. But if he was awake then, hadn't he spent the previous days sleeping? The shoemaker, who had caused him so many headaches, could he not have been a dreamed character, a product of a prolonged nightmare? Was there any other explanation for the fact that he was now seeing, with his own perfectly awake eyes, his friend, dressed as usual, calm as usual, and reading as usual?

en: It was but the inquiry of his first confusion and astonishment, the answer being obvious. If the impression were not produced by a real corresponding and sufficient cause, how came he, Jarvis Lorry, there? How came he to have fallen asleep, in his clothes, on the sofa in Doctor Manette’s consulting-room, and to be debating these points outside the Doctor’s bedroom door in the early morning?
vi: But that was only a question in the first moments of confusion and astonishment, and the answer was already too clear. If his worries had no real and justifiable cause, then why was he, Jarvis Lorry, here? Why had he fallen asleep, without changing clothes, on the sofa in Dr. Manette's clinic, and from early morning stood pondering various thoughts at the door of the doctor's bedroom?
tr: After the initial mental confusion and astonishment, everything was becoming a bit clearer. If these events weren't real and didn't have a valid reason, what was Jarvis Lorry doing there? Why had he fallen asleep on the couch in Dr. Manette's clinic, fully clothed, and why was he pondering these matters in front of the Doctor's bedroom door at this early hour of the morning?
es: And yet, if it hadn't been for his great confusion and lethargy, this last hypothesis would have fallen apart. If the unfortunate change caused by such a profound impression had been dreamed and not real, what was the banker from the famous Tellson doing in the quiet house in Soho? How had he just found himself asleep, dressed and shod, on the couch in Dr. Manette's consultation room? Why were these doubts assailing him at such an early hour of the morning and precisely at the entrance to the doctor's bedroom?

en: Within a few minutes, Miss Pross stood whispering at his side. If he had had any particle of doubt left, her talk would of necessity have resolved it; but he was by that time clear-headed, and had none. He advised that they should let the time go by until the regular breakfast-hour, and should then meet the Doctor as if nothing unusual had occurred. If he appeared to be in his customary state of mind, Mr. Lorry would then cautiously proceed to seek direction and guidance from the opinion he had been, in his anxiety, so anxious to obtain.
vi: A few minutes later, Miss Pross was standing next to him, whispering. If he had any lingering doubts, her words would surely dispel them all; but by then, he was fully awake and no longer had any doubts. He advised Miss Pross to wait until the usual breakfast time and then meet the doctor as if nothing unusual had happened. If the doctor was in his usual familiar state of mind, Mr. Lorry would then cautiously seek the advice and guidance that he had been eagerly wanting to know during the past days of worry.
tr: Within a few minutes, Miss Pross came to him and was whispering something. If there had still been a shred of doubt left in him, Miss Pross's words would have surely dispelled it; but by that time, Mr. Lorry's mind had cleared, and he had no doubts left. He suggested waiting until the usual breakfast hour, and then meeting with the Doctor as if nothing had happened. If the Doctor was in his usual natural state, Mr. Lorry, without letting his guard down, would ask him to give as much advice and wisdom as he could muster amidst all the troubles.
es: Minutes later, Miss Pross was whispering some words in his ear. If any trace of doubt had remained in his mind, the words that struck his ears would have dispelled it, but none remained: his head was clear and the doubts had disappeared. Given the new state of affairs, Lorry advised doing nothing until lunchtime, and then visiting the doctor as if nothing had happened. If his friend remained calm and in control, Lorry would cautiously and cleverly question him, trying to obtain something from him that could guide and direct him in the future.

en: Miss Pross, submitting herself to his judgment, the scheme was worked out with care. Having abundance of time for his usual methodical toilette, Mr. Lorry presented himself at the breakfast-hour in his usual white linen, and with his usual neat leg. The Doctor was summoned in the usual way, and came to breakfast.
vi: Following his judgment, Miss Pross carefully did as instructed. After taking his usual leisurely time for meticulous grooming, Mr. Lorry appeared at breakfast time in his familiar white linen suit and snug-fitting stockings. Dr. Manette was invited to breakfast as usual, and he went to the dining room.
tr: The plan was carefully executed with Miss Pross, who had entrusted herself to Mr. Lorry's prudence. Mr. Lorry, who had plenty of time to dress according to his usual routine, took his place at breakfast in his white linen shirt and his usual silk stockings that showed off his well-shaped legs. The doctor was called to breakfast as usual, and he also attended.
es: The plan, which earned Miss Pross's approval, was executed with diligent care. Lorry, who had plenty of time to spruce up, appeared at lunchtime neat and impeccable. The doctor was called as usual, and as usual, lunch was served.

en: So far as it was possible to comprehend him without overstepping those delicate and gradual approaches which Mr. Lorry felt to be the only safe advance, he at first supposed that his daughter’s marriage had taken place yesterday. An incidental allusion, purposely thrown out, to the day of the week, and the day of the month, set him thinking and counting, and evidently made him uneasy. In all other respects, however, he was so composedly himself, that Mr. Lorry determined to have the aid he sought. And that aid was his own.
vi: If we follow the cautious methods exactly - Mr. Lorry saw it as the only safe way - it is understandable why Dr. Manette initially thought that his daughter's wedding had only taken place yesterday. The seemingly random but actually intentional hints about the day, date, and month made the doctor count and recount and think, clearly indicating that he was not at ease. Otherwise, he was extremely calm, to the point that Mr. Lorry decided there was no need to go far to seek anyone's guidance. Dr. Manette himself would indicate what needed to be done.
tr: Mr. Lorry thought that they could only make solid progress if they approached her gently and gradually, and from what they could understand in this way, the Doctor believed that his daughter's wedding had been the day before. A topic mentioned in passing, but actually brought up intentionally to reveal the current day and month, had made the Doctor think, calculate in his mind, and visibly unsettled him. On the other hand, he was so composed in every other aspect that Mr. Lorry was determined to find the remedy he sought. The remedy was the Doctor himself.
es: From the conversation, initiated and followed by Lorry with exquisite caution and tact, he inferred that the doctor believed his daughter's marriage had taken place the day before. Proceeding methodically in his explorations, he casually dropped a reference to the day of the week and month they were in, a reference that visibly confused the doctor, but since in all other respects he reflected an evident serenity of judgment, Lorry resolved to seek the help he desired, and he expected that help from the doctor himself.

en: Therefore, when the breakfast was done and cleared away, and he and the Doctor were left together, Mr. Lorry said, feelingly:
vi: Therefore, when breakfast was over, the table cleared, and only the two of them remained, Mr. Lorry asked the doctor, his voice emotional: − Dear Mr. Manette, I very much wish to ask your opinion on a strange case that I am deeply concerned about; that is, it is very strange to me, but to someone knowledgeable like you, it might not be as much.
tr: Thus, after breakfast was finished and the table was cleared, when Mr. Lorry and the Doctor were left alone, Mr. Lorry said to his friend in a compassionate voice:
es: Consequently, after lunch was finished and the table cleared, Lorry said with signs of keen interest:

en: “My dear Manette, I am anxious to have your opinion, in confidence, on a very curious case in which I am deeply interested; that is to say, it is very curious to me; perhaps, to your better information it may be less so.”
vi: Therefore, when breakfast was over, the table cleared, and only the two of them remained, Mr. Lorry asked the doctor, his voice emotional: − Dear Mr. Manette, I very much wish to ask your opinion on a strange case that I am deeply concerned about; that is, it is very strange to me, but to someone knowledgeable like you, it might not be as much.
tr: "My friend Manette, let's keep this between us, but I am eager to get your opinions on a very strange matter that deeply concerns me; I mean, it seems very strange to me, but perhaps it won't seem as strange to you since you are more knowledgeable than I am.""
es: —My dear Manette, I wish for you to give me your opinion on a case that interests me extraordinarily, a very curious case... I mean, very curious to me, as perhaps you may find it natural and logical.

en: Glancing at his hands, which were discoloured by his late work, the Doctor looked troubled, and listened attentively. He had already glanced at his hands more than once.
vi: Glancing at his pale hands, whitened from the recent shoemaking, the doctor appeared confused but continued to listen attentively. He had glanced at his hands more than once.
tr: Doctor, who glanced at his hands that had changed color due to his recent busyness, seemed annoyed, but he listened to Mr. Lorry attentively. He had looked at his hands enough a moment ago.
es: The doctor listened with keen attention and looked with a troubled expression at his hands, calloused from the work of the last ten days. He had already looked at them frequently before.

en: “Doctor Manette,” said Mr. Lorry, touching him affectionately on the arm, “the case is the case of a particularly dear friend of mine. Pray give your mind to it, and advise me well for his sake—and above all, for his daughter’s—his daughter’s, my dear Manette.”
vi: − Doctor Manette, - Mr. Lorry said as he affectionately took the doctor's arm, - this is the case of a very dear friend of mine. Please be considerate and guide that person... and above all, for that person's daughter... that person's daughter, Mr. Manette. −
tr: "Doctor Manette," said Mr. Lorry, touching his friend's arm affectionately, "this is a matter concerning a very close friend of mine. Please listen very carefully to what I have to say and give me some advice on his behalf –more importantly, for the sake of his daughter– yes, his daughter, my dear friend."
es: —The case in question affects, my dear Manette—replied Lorry—a friend of mine, whom I care for very much. This is why I earnestly ask you to examine it with genuine interest and advise me for the good of my friend... and above all, for the good of his daughter... my friend's daughter, my dear Manette.

en: “If I understand,” said the Doctor, in a subdued tone, “some mental shock—?”
vi: As I understand, - the doctor whispered, - it is a form of mental trauma...? − Correct! − Please be clear, - said the doctor.
tr: "As far as I understand," said the Doctor in a low voice, "this must be a mental shock?"
es: —If I understand correctly—replied the doctor in a very low voice,—it is a mental shock...

en: “Yes!”
vi: As I understand, - the doctor whispered, - it is a form of mental trauma...? − Correct! − Please be clear, - said the doctor.
tr: "Correct!"
es: —That's it!

en: “Be explicit,” said the Doctor. “Spare no detail.”
vi: - Do not hide anything.
tr: "Explain clearly," said the Doctor. "Do not skip any details."
es: —Speak to me clearly and without omitting any details—said the doctor.

en: Mr. Lorry saw that they understood one another, and proceeded.
vi: Mr. Lorry saw that they understood each other and continued.
tr: Seeing that they understood each other, Mr. Lorry continued speaking.
es: Lorry understood that they had come to an understanding, and continued like this:

en: “My dear Manette, it is the case of an old and a prolonged shock, of great acuteness and severity to the affections, the feelings, the—the—as you express it—the mind. The mind. It is the case of a shock under which the sufferer was borne down, one cannot say for how long, because I believe he cannot calculate the time himself, and there are no other means of getting at it. It is the case of a shock from which the sufferer recovered, by a process that he cannot trace himself—as I once heard him publicly relate in a striking manner. It is the case of a shock from which he has recovered, so completely, as to be a highly intelligent man, capable of close application of mind, and great exertion of body, and of constantly making fresh additions to his stock of knowledge, which was already very large. But, unfortunately, there has been,” he paused and took a deep breath—“a slight relapse.”
vi: "Dear Mr. Manette, this is a case of long-term injury, very severe and seriously affecting emotions, affecting... affecting... as you said,... the mind." The mind. This is a case of injury that this person has endured for an unknown length of time, because I think that even this person cannot calculate the time, and there is no way to calculate it. This is a case of injury that this person has overcome, through a recovery process that even this person does not fully understand... as I have heard this person recount very movingly in public. This is a case of injury from which this person has fully recovered, to the extent of returning to their highly intellectual former self, capable of employing both mental and physical efforts, and continuously adding new knowledge to an already profound understanding. But unfortunately, recently... - Mr. Lorry paused to catch his breath, - ... there was a slight relapse. −
tr: "Dear Manette, this is an old and long-standing type of shock and emotions, feelings, eeh –as you said– it affects the mind to a very large and intense extent. The mind. This is such a shock that, when it comes, it takes its victim to a completely different realm, how long it stays is unknown, because I think the person cannot understand how much time has passed and there is no other way to understand it. The patient comes out of this shock state in a way that he himself cannot explain –once he demonstrated this strikingly in front of everyone. When he comes out of this shock, he completely returns to his old self, that is, he becomes a man who is extremely intelligent, competent in terms of mental functions, physically tremendously active, and constantly in pursuit of refreshing his already vast knowledge. But unfortunately" –he paused and took a deep breath– "his ailment relapsed."
es: —My dear Manette, it is a terrible shock, very old and lasting several years, a cruel, brutal shock, of affections, of feelings, of... faculties, of the mind... that's it: of the mind. How long the shock that overwhelmed and crushed the unfortunate person who was its victim lasted, is something I cannot specify, for only my friend could tell us, and he was not in a condition to calculate the time. The one who suffered the shock managed to recover from its effects thanks to a process that he himself cannot explain... as I heard him say in public on an occasion when he gave a moving account of his misfortunes. I say that he has recovered from the effects of the mental upheaval so completely, that today he is a man of very clear intelligence, a man who can engage in deep intellectual pursuits, with a vigorous soul and a strong body, a man who multiplies his knowledge every day, and recounts that he already possessed a rich store of it before. Unfortunately... he has had... a small relapse.

en: The Doctor, in a low voice, asked, “Of how long duration?”
vi: How long did it last? - The doctor asked softly.
tr: The doctor asked in a low voice, "How long did it last?"
es: The doctor asked eagerly: —How long?

en: “Nine days and nights.”
vi: − Nine days and nights. −
tr: "Nine days, nine nights."
es: —It lasted nine days and nights.

en: “How did it show itself? I infer,” glancing at his hands again, “in the resumption of some old pursuit connected with the shock?”
vi: How did it manifest? − I guess, - the doctor looked at his hands again, - he resumed the old work related to that injury?
tr: "How did it manifest itself then? I wonder," meanwhile the Doctor glanced at his hands again, "did he return to an old habit connected to this shock?"
es: —In what way did it manifest?—asked the doctor, looking at his hands again. —Perhaps by returning to some old occupation related to his mental disturbance?

en: “That is the fact.”
vi: − That's correct. −
tr: "That's exactly what happened."
es: —Indeed.

en: “Now, did you ever see him,” asked the Doctor, distinctly and collectedly, though in the same low voice, “engaged in that pursuit originally?”
vi: So, have you ever seen, - the doctor asked, his voice clear and calm, though still soft, - this person doing that work before?
tr: "Well, have you ever seen him," he said, speaking slowly and calmly, "engaged in that task before?"
es: —Another thing: Did you ever have the opportunity to see him engaged in that occupation during his original illness prior to the relapse?—asked the doctor very calmly, albeit always in a very low voice.

en: “Once.”
vi: − Once. −
tr: "I had seen it once."
es: —Only once.

en: “And when the relapse fell on him, was he in most respects—or in all respects—as he was then?”
vi: And during the relapse, did this person resemble their former self in many aspects... or completely in every way?
tr: "Well, when the illness recurred, was it in some ways – or in every way – like what you saw?""
es: —After his relapse, did you find him the same as before in almost everything... or in everything?

en: “I think in all respects.”
vi: − I think completely.
tr: "I think it was the same in every aspect."
es: —I think in everything.

en: “You spoke of his daughter. Does his daughter know of the relapse?”
vi: − He mentioned his daughter. Does his daughter know about the recurrence?
tr: "You mentioned your daughter. Does she know that this condition has recurred?"
es: —You mentioned earlier about a daughter of your friend: has the daughter heard about her father's relapse?

en: “No. It has been kept from her, and I hope will always be kept from her. It is known only to myself, and to one other who may be trusted.”
vi: − No. This matter is kept secret, and I hope she will never find out. Only I know, along with one other trustworthy person.
tr: "No. This situation was hidden from him, and I hope it will always be kept hidden. Only I know this, and one other trustworthy person."
es: —No: the relapse has remained surrounded by the strictest secrecy, and I don't think the daughter will ever come to suspect it. Only two people know about it: myself, and another person of absolute trust.

en: The Doctor grasped his hand, and murmured, “That was very kind. That was very thoughtful!” Mr. Lorry grasped his hand in return, and neither of the two spoke for a little while.
vi: The doctor tightly grasped Mr. Lorry's hand and whispered: − This is truly precious. So considerate! Mr. Lorry squeezed the doctor's hand in return, and both remained silent for a long time before Mr. Lorry carefully and affectionately chose his words: −
tr: The doctor tightly held Mr. Lorry's hand and murmured, "You are very kind. This is a very thoughtful gesture!" he said. Mr. Lorry also held his hand tightly in response, and they remained silent for a while.
es: —Delicate and generous foresight, my friend!—exclaimed the doctor, shaking Lorry's hand effusively. The two interlocutors remained silent for a few moments.

en: “Now, my dear Manette,” said Mr. Lorry, at length, in his most considerate and most affectionate way, “I am a mere man of business, and unfit to cope with such intricate and difficult matters. I do not possess the kind of information necessary; I do not possess the kind of intelligence; I want guiding. There is no man in this world on whom I could so rely for right guidance, as on you. Tell me, how does this relapse come about? Is there danger of another? Could a repetition of it be prevented? How should a repetition of it be treated? How does it come about at all? What can I do for my friend? No man ever can have been more desirous in his heart to serve a friend, than I am to serve mine, if I knew how.
vi: You see, Mr. Manette, I'm just a businessman, I don't know how to handle such difficult and complicated matters. I don't have the appropriate knowledge nor am I deeply educated; I need guidance. There is no one in this world whom I wholeheartedly hope to guide me as much as you. Please tell me why it has recurred? Is there a risk of it happening again? Is there any way to prevent a recurrence? If it recurs, how should it be treated? What is the cause of this situation? What can I do for my friend? No one has ever wanted to help a friend as much as I want to help mine, if only I knew how.
tr: "Now dear Manette," said Mr. Lorry a little later, in his most gentle and compassionate manner, "I am just a businessman and I am not very good at solving such intricate and difficult matters. I don't have much knowledge; my mind doesn't grasp these things, I am asking you to guide me. I can't trust anyone else as much as I trust you on this matter. There is no one in the world whose knowledge I can trust as much as yours on this matter. Can you tell me how this ailment recurs? Is there a risk of it happening again? Can its recurrence be prevented? If it recurs, how should it be treated? Why does such a thing happen? What can I do for my friend? There is probably no one as eager as I am to help his friend, but if only I knew what to do.
es: —I am a businessman, my dear Manette—said Lorry, breaking the silence and speaking with tones of deep affection,—and, therefore, a layman in such convoluted and difficult matters. I lack the data to guide me, I lack the intelligence, the knowledge to lead me, I lack a person to advise me. In this world, there is no man in whom I can place my trust or who can dispel my doubts, except for you. Tell me, what was the cause of the relapse? Is there a danger of another occurring? Assuming that the danger exists, are there means to prevent it? What are these means? What can I do to benefit my friend? There has never been a man in the world who so eagerly wished to serve a friend as I do mine, if I knew how; but I don't know what to do if the case repeats itself.

en: “But I don’t know how to originate, in such a case. If your sagacity, knowledge, and experience, could put me on the right track, I might be able to do so much; unenlightened and undirected, I can do so little. Pray discuss it with me; pray enable me to see it a little more clearly, and teach me how to be a little more useful.”
vi: But in this matter, I am powerless. If your profound intellect and experience could guide me, I could be of much more help; but groping blindly like this, I am utterly useless. Please discuss with me, help me understand better, and show me how to be more useful.
tr: I don't know what to do in such a situation. If you guide me with your intelligence, knowledge, and experience, I can do something; but without knowing the way, I can't do much. Please explain to me, help me see the situation more clearly, and guide me so I can help him."
es: There has never been a man in the world who so eagerly wished to serve a friend as I do mine, if I knew how; but I don't know what to do if the case repeats itself. If your sagacity, your knowledge, your experience, can show me the right path, I believe without immodesty that I could do much: without guidance, without external help, all my good intentions will flounder in the dark sea of my ignorance. Please, give me some explanations, enlighten me a little and show me how to be useful to my friend.

en: Doctor Manette sat meditating after these earnest words were spoken, and Mr. Lorry did not press him.
vi: Hearing those earnest words, Dr. Manette sat in deep thought for a while, and Mr. Lorry did not press him.
tr: After these heartfelt words, Doctor Manette fell into deep thought, and Mr. Lorry did not press him further.
es: Dr. Manette lowered his head and immersed himself in deep thoughts. Lorry waited calmly.

en: “I think it probable,” said the Doctor, breaking silence with an effort, “that the relapse you have described, my dear friend, was not quite unforeseen by its subject.”
vi: − I think that, - the doctor struggled to break the silence, - my friend, the recurrence as you describe it is not entirely unforeseen by the person.
tr: "If you ask me, my dear friend," said the Doctor, forcing himself to break the silence, "the discomfort you described was not something the patient did not expect."
es: —It seems very likely to me—said the doctor after a while—that the relapse you have just described to me was foreseen by the one who was your victim.

en: “Was it dreaded by him?” Mr. Lorry ventured to ask.
vi: − Does this person fear a relapse? - Mr. Lorry boldly asked.
tr: Mr. Lorry dared to ask, "Well, was he afraid of it?"
es: —Perhaps foreseen and feared?—Lorry dared to ask.

en: “Very much.” He said it with an involuntary shudder.
vi: − Very much so, - the doctor involuntarily shuddered.
tr: "A lot indeed." The doctor shuddered involuntarily.
es: —Perhaps foreseen and feared?—Lorry dared to ask. —Temida, yes—exclaimed the doctor, involuntarily shuddering.

en: “You have no idea how such an apprehension weighs on the sufferer’s mind, and how difficult—how almost impossible—it is, for him to force himself to utter a word upon the topic that oppresses him.”
vi: - You cannot imagine how this fear constantly weighs on this person's mind, and how difficult it is... almost impossible... for this person to force themselves to speak about the heavy burden in their heart.
tr: "You cannot know how much of a burden such a concern creates on the patient and how difficult –almost impossible– it is to force oneself to talk about a subject that upsets them so much."
es: —It is impossible for you to form an approximate idea of the enormous weight with which that fear weighs upon the patient's chest... nor of the near impossibility in which he finds himself to speak a word about the matter that oppresses him.

en: “Would he,” asked Mr. Lorry, “be sensibly relieved if he could prevail upon himself to impart that secret brooding to any one, when it is on him?”
vi: − If one were to confide that secret burden to someone when being tormented by it, - Mr. Lorry asked, - would this person feel relieved?
tr: "Well, I wonder," said Mr. Lorry, "if, when this happened to him, he could have shared this secret with someone, wouldn't he have felt a bit relieved?""
es: —And wouldn't that oppression ease—asked Lorry—if he decided to confide in someone the secret that apparently torments him?

en: “I think so. But it is, as I have told you, next to impossible. I even believe it—in some cases—to be quite impossible.”
vi: − I also think so. But as I have said, it is almost impossible. I even believe that... in some cases... it is completely unfeasible.
tr: "They were probably comfortable. But as I said, this is an almost impossible situation. In fact – in some cases – I think this is quite impossible."
es: —I believe so; but it is, as I just said, almost impossible. It even seems to me... that it is absolutely impossible.

en: “Now,” said Mr. Lorry, gently laying his hand on the Doctor’s arm again, after a short silence on both sides, “to what would you refer this attack?”
vi: − Then, - Mr. Lorry gently placed his hand on the doctor's arm after a moment of silence between them, - in your opinion, what caused the relapse?
tr: After a brief silence, "Well," said Mr. Lorry, gently placing his hand on the Doctor's arm again, "what do you attribute this crisis to?"
es: Another pause ensued, which Lorry gently ended by asking: —To what do you attribute the relapse?

en: “I believe,” returned Doctor Manette, “that there had been a strong and extraordinary revival of the train of thought and remembrance that was the first cause of the malady. Some intense associations of a most distressing nature were vividly recalled, I think. It is probable that there had long been a dread lurking in his mind, that those associations would be recalled—say, under certain circumstances—say, on a particular occasion. He tried to prepare himself in vain; perhaps the effort to prepare himself made him less able to bear it.”
vi: − I believe that something extraordinarily powerful happened, awakening a stream of thoughts and memories about the original cause of the mental trauma. Then this person clearly recalled many extremely painful related events all at once, I think. Perhaps for a long time, deep down, this person had feared remembering such related events... for example, in such a situation... for example, on such an occasion. This person had tried to prepare for it but in vain; perhaps the very effort to mentally prepare made this person even less able to withstand that fear. −
tr: "I think," said Doctor Manette, "this was an extraordinary situation that made him intensely relive the initial cause of this ailment in his mind. I believe a series of powerful associations that caused him immense suffering formed in his mind. Perhaps there were fears within him for some time that these associations would be revived – in certain situations – for some reason. He tried in vain to prepare himself for these; perhaps all this preparation and effort weakened him."
es: —In my opinion—replied Doctor Manette,—there has been a vigorous awakening of memories that were the determining cause of the initial illness, ideas associated with past tortures have been revived by the breath of some recent event. It is very likely that in the patient's mind there had been accumulating for some time the fear of this vigorous awakening of painful memories... due to certain circumstances... due to a specific event... In this case, the patient tried to take preventive measures... he surely would have taken them, but in vain. Who knows if the very efforts made to resist the blow incapacitated him to endure it!

en: “Would he remember what took place in the relapse?” asked Mr. Lorry, with natural hesitation.
vi: When experiencing such a relapse, does this person remember what happened? - Mr. Lorry asked with a noticeably hesitant voice.
tr: "Well, does he remember what he experienced during this illness?" asked Mr. Lorry with a natural hesitation.
es: —Do you think my friend remembers what he has done during the relapse?—asked Lorry, after hesitating for a few seconds.

en: The Doctor looked desolately round the room, shook his head, and answered, in a low voice, “Not at all.”
vi: Dr. Manette looked around the room, shook his head, and then softly replied: − I don't remember anything at all. −
tr: After the doctor sadly glanced around the room, he shook his head from side to side and replied in a low voice, "No, nothing.""
es: The doctor cast sad glances around, shook his head, and replied in a voice lower than ever: —Absolutely nothing!

en: “Now, as to the future,” hinted Mr. Lorry.
vi: What about later on? - Mr. Lorry prompted.
tr: "Then let's talk a little about the future," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Let's move on now to the forecast... to the future.

en: “As to the future,” said the Doctor, recovering firmness, “I should have great hope. As it pleased Heaven in its mercy to restore him so soon, I should have great hope. He, yielding under the pressure of a complicated something, long dreaded and long vaguely foreseen and contended against, and recovering after the cloud had burst and passed, I should hope that the worst was over.”
vi: − Later on, I think there is much hope, - the doctor regained his assertive tone. - The merciful God has allowed this person to recover so quickly, so I have much hope. This person had succumbed to the pressure of a complex matter that he had long feared, anticipated, and wanted to resist; and now that the relapse is over, I hope the worst is behind us. −
tr: "From the future," said the Doctor, gathering his strength again, "I am quite hopeful. If he got over this last crisis so quickly, one should not lose hope in God. If he has been crushed under the pressure of a complex event he has been waiting for in fear and uncertainty for a long time, tried to overcome it, and was able to recover after the dark clouds dispersed, the future cannot be worse."
es: —The future—replied the doctor energetically—fills me with great hopes. These hopes are based on the short duration of the relapse, thanks to Heaven. If we consider that the patient, after being struck down by the weight of something feared for a long time, something vaguely anticipated, something against which he vainly tried to protect himself, has recovered once the storm has passed, there are ample reasons to believe that the worst is over.

en: “Well, well! That’s good comfort. I am thankful!” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: Very good, very good! Truly a relief. I am grateful to you! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed. − I am grateful to you! -
tr: "Very good!" "I am really relieved." "Thank you very much!" said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Very well...! Very well! Your words reassure me... Thank you!—exclaimed Lorry.

en: “I am thankful!” repeated the Doctor, bending his head with reverence.
vi: The doctor echoed, bowing respectfully.
tr: "Thank you very much!" repeated the Doctor, bowing his head respectfully.
es: —Thank you!—repeated the doctor, bowing his head.

en: “There are two other points,” said Mr. Lorry, “on which I am anxious to be instructed. I may go on?”
vi: − There are two more issues I hope to be guided on, - Mr. Lorry said. - May I continue speaking? −
tr: "There are only two more issues," said Mr. Lorry, "for which I need your opinion. Shall I explain?"
es: —There are still two points on which I would like you to instruct me. May I continue?

en: “You cannot do your friend a better service.” The Doctor gave him his hand.
vi: The more you speak, the better it is for your friend, - the doctor extended his hand. −
tr: "You cannot do a greater kindness for your friend than this." The doctor extended his hand to Mr. Lorry.
es: —It is the greatest favor you can do for your friend—replied the doctor, extending his hand to him.

en: “To the first, then. He is of a studious habit, and unusually energetic; he applies himself with great ardour to the acquisition of professional knowledge, to the conducting of experiments, to many things. Now, does he do too much?”
vi: Then the first issue. This person is exceptionally eager to learn and has extraordinary determination; this person is extremely enthusiastic about acquiring professional knowledge, conducting experiments, and many other tasks. So, is this person overexerting their mind?
tr: "So, the first issue is this: My friend is inherently extremely hardworking and incredibly energetic; he makes great efforts to increase his knowledge, constantly reads, conducts experiments, and never remains idle. Could it be that working this much has been too much for him?"
es: —First: my friend is studious by temperament and possesses uncommon energy. He ardently pursues the acquisition of new professional knowledge, conducts laborious experiments, and engages in countless activities that demand intense mental effort. Tell me: don't you think he works excessively?

en: “I think not. It may be the character of his mind, to be always in singular need of occupation. That may be, in part, natural to it; in part, the result of affliction. The less it was occupied with healthy things, the more it would be in danger of turning in the unhealthy direction. He may have observed himself, and made the discovery.”
