vi: − I think not. It could be that this person's mind is naturally like that, always busy. It could be partly due to their nature and partly as a consequence of past hardships. The less occupied the mind is with healthy matters, the more it risks weakening again. Perhaps this person has observed themselves and discovered that. −
tr: "I don't think so. He's already used to keeping his mind occupied with things. This could be partly his nature, and partly the result of the troubles he's experienced. As long as he engages with healthy things, the risk of veering into an unhealthy direction decreases. He might have arrived at this finding through self-observation."
es: —I don't think so. Perhaps the nature of his intelligence demands continuous mental work, whether the nature in question is innate and natural, or artificially modified, so to speak, as a consequence of sorrows and afflictions. The less he occupies himself with intellectual matters, the greater the danger that his thoughts will take harmful directions. It is likely that he himself, after observing himself carefully, has made the discovery to which I am referring.

en: “You are sure that he is not under too great a strain?”
vi: Are you certain that this person is not overly stressed?
tr: "So, you are sure that he didn't push himself too hard?"
es: —Do you have any assurance that my friend's mental work is not excessive?

en: “I think I am quite sure of it.”
vi: − I believe I am completely certain.
tr: "If you ask me, that's the way it is."
es: —I have it; yes.

en: “My dear Manette, if he were overworked now—”
vi: − Mr. Manette, if this person is now overworking... − Mr. Lorry, I don't think that's the case.
tr: "Well, dear Manette, if he overexerts himself now...""
es: —But if he were overcome by excessive work...

en: “My dear Lorry, I doubt if that could easily be. There has been a violent stress in one direction, and it needs a counterweight.”
vi: If the mind is under extreme pressure on one side, the other side must counteract to balance it. −
tr: "Dear Lorry, I don't think so. For a while now, there has been a serious problem in his life, and now he needs to be occupied with other things."
es: —I highly doubt that such a thing will happen, my dear Lorry. When there is a violent tendency in a certain direction, it becomes indispensable to counterbalance it in some way, or otherwise, the equilibrium is broken.

en: “Excuse me, as a persistent man of business. Assuming for a moment, that he was overworked; it would show itself in some renewal of this disorder?”
vi: Excuse me, I am a person who only knows work. Let's assume this person has overworked; in that case, would this mental disorder recur? − I don't think so, - Dr. Manette asserted confidently.
tr: "I'm sorry, I'm just a bit of a persistent businessman. If we assume that he overexerts himself, do you think this ailment will reappear?"
es: —Excuse my insistence, my dear Manette, as it is known that we businessmen are persistent. Assuming that the relapse we regret was the result of intense mental pressure, is there no danger of it happening again?

en: “I do not think so. I do not think,” said Doctor Manette with the firmness of self-conviction, “that anything but the one train of association would renew it. I think that, henceforth, nothing but some extraordinary jarring of that chord could renew it. After what has happened, and after his recovery, I find it difficult to imagine any such violent sounding of that string again. I trust, and I almost believe, that the circumstances likely to renew it are exhausted.”
vi: Let's assume this person has overworked; in that case, would this mental disorder recur? − I don't think so, - Dr. Manette asserted confidently. - I believe that only a single stream of association could cause a recurrence. But from now on, I think that stream of association would have to be extraordinarily powerful to recur. After what has happened, and with this person having recovered, I find it hard to imagine what could cause such an extreme impact. I believe, and I can say with certainty, that there is no longer a risk of recurrence.
tr: "Madam. For such a reason," said Doctor Manette, in a confident manner, "I don't believe his ailment will reappear. In my opinion, the only thing that could trigger a relapse from now on would be a shocking experience. After all that has happened and following his recovery, I find it very unlikely that this dreadful affliction will seize him again. I believe that the circumstances which could cause this ailment to recur have now been eliminated."
es: —I don't believe it... I can't believe it—replied Dr. Manette with a tone of deep conviction. — Only the exacerbation of a certain class of memories could provoke another relapse, only the violent vibration of the very string that caused the first one could be the cause of others. Now then: after what has happened, I consider it almost impossible for new exacerbations of the memories I refer to, impossible for new vibrations of the sick string. I believe... I almost dare to assure that the circumstances that could lead to new setbacks have disappeared forever.

en: He spoke with the diffidence of a man who knew how slight a thing would overset the delicate organisation of the mind, and yet with the confidence of a man who had slowly won his assurance out of personal endurance and distress. It was not for his friend to abate that confidence. He professed himself more relieved and encouraged than he really was, and approached his second and last point. He felt it to be the most difficult of all; but, remembering his old Sunday morning conversation with Miss Pross, and remembering what he had seen in the last nine days, he knew that he must face it.
vi: Dr. Manette spoke with the hesitation of someone who understands how fragile the structure of the mind can be, but still with the determination of someone who has gradually regained self-control through suffering and personal endurance. His friend had no right to undermine that confidence. Mr. Lorry had to feign being reassured, more cheerful, and moved on to discuss the second and final issue. He found this the most difficult point to address; but recalling the conversation from the previous Sunday with Miss Pross and remembering what he had witnessed over the past nine days, he knew he could not avoid it.
tr: Dr. Manette had spoken with the timidity of a man aware that the slightest thing could upset the delicate structure of the mind; on the other hand, there was also a self-confidence in his demeanor that had developed over time with the sufferings he had endured and the patience he had shown. This confidence would not be shaken by his friend. Mr. Lorry felt much more relieved, encouraged by the Doctor's words, and moved on to the second matter. He sensed that this would be very difficult; but thinking about the conversation he had with Miss Pross on a Sunday morning and what he had seen over the past nine days, he realized he needed to confront this situation.
es: The doctor spoke with the timidity of someone who knows how little it takes to disturb the delicate organization of intelligence, and at the same time with the confidence of one who, tempered in the bitter waters of tribulations, has acquired that strength which is capable of impassively resisting the hurricanes of life. It would not be his friend who tried to combat that confidence. On the contrary, he showed himself more hopeful and convinced than he actually was, and proceeded to address the second point. This was much more difficult and thorny than the first: Lorry was very persuaded of this; but he recalled the conversation he had with Miss Pross on Sunday, took into account the painful scenes he had witnessed in the last nine days, and understood that he had a duty to face it.

en: “The occupation resumed under the influence of this passing affliction so happily recovered from,” said Mr. Lorry, clearing his throat, “we will call—Blacksmith’s work, Blacksmith’s work. We will say, to put a case and for the sake of illustration, that he had been used, in his bad time, to work at a little forge. We will say that he was unexpectedly found at his forge again. Is it not a pity that he should keep it by him?”
vi: − Due to the impact of the temporary relapse that fortunately passed, Mr. Lorry cleared his throat, - this person continued to do the work they used to do, let's call it... blacksmithing, yes, blacksmithing. To illustrate the issue, let's assume that this person worked with a small forge during the time of hardship. Let's assume that we unexpectedly saw this person working with that forge as before. Isn't it pitiful that this person keeps that small forge close by?
tr: "During this temporary ailment that my friend has managed to get through quite well," said Mr. Lorry, clearing his throat, "we can say that he was engaged in blacksmithing, yes, blacksmithing. To make the situation more concrete, let's say that in his old bad days, he worked in a small blacksmith's forge. Now, at completely unexpected moments, he thinks he is back in his forge. Isn't it very painful for him to live through it this way?"
es: —During his relapse, fortunately now past, he devoted himself... to the trade of... locksmith—said Lorry, with evident hesitation. —Yes; that's it: to the trade of locksmith. As an example to clarify the concepts, we will say that my friend, during the time of his mental imbalance, used to work in a forge. We will add that, due to circumstances that need not be detailed, he has found that forge again. Don't you think it's a shame that he keeps it by his side?

en: The Doctor shaded his forehead with his hand, and beat his foot nervously on the ground.
vi: The doctor raised his hand to cover his forehead, his foot tapping restlessly on the floor.
tr: The doctor raised his hand to his forehead and stomped his foot angrily.
es: The doctor ran his hand across his forehead.

en: “He has always kept it by him,” said Mr. Lorry, with an anxious look at his friend. “Now, would it not be better that he should let it go?”
vi: Mr. Lorry continued speaking, his eyes anxiously watching his friend: − This person always keeps that forge. Wouldn't it be better for him to discard that thing?
tr: Mr. Lorry, "He always kept the hearth," he said, looking at his friend with worried eyes. "Wouldn't it be better for him to get rid of it from the house?"
es: —He has it constantly in his sight—replied Lorry, looking anxiously at his friend. — Don't you think it would be better if he didn't see what must inevitably remind him of painful times?

en: Still, the Doctor, with shaded forehead, beat his foot nervously on the ground.
vi: The doctor still had his hand covering his forehead, his foot still tapping restlessly on the floor.
tr: The doctor was still tapping his foot nervously, with his hands on his forehead.
es: The doctor tapped the floor with a nervous foot.

en: “You do not find it easy to advise me?” said Mr. Lorry. “I quite understand it to be a nice question. And yet I think—” And there he shook his head, and stopped.
vi: − Do you find it difficult to explain this to me? - Mr. Lorry said. - I know this is a delicate question. But I think that... At this point, he shook his head and fell silent.
tr: "It seems difficult to give advice," said Mr. Lorry. "I think that would be a very appropriate decision. But I guess..." he trailed off, shaking his head from side to side.
es: —Do you find the advice I ask of you so difficult?—insisted Lorry. —It seems to me the solution is very simple, however, I believe that... —You must understand—replied Doctor Manette, turning to his interlocutor—that it is extremely difficult to explain, adhering to the inflexible rules of logic, the intimate operations of the mind of the poor man to whom you refer.

en: “You see,” said Doctor Manette, turning to him after an uneasy pause, “it is very hard to explain, consistently, the innermost workings of this poor man’s mind. He once yearned so frightfully for that occupation, and it was so welcome when it came; no doubt it relieved his pain so much, by substituting the perplexity of the fingers for the perplexity of the brain, and by substituting, as he became more practised, the ingenuity of the hands, for the ingenuity of the mental torture; that he has never been able to bear the thought of putting it quite out of his reach. Even now, when I believe he is more hopeful of himself than he has ever been, and even speaks of himself with a kind of confidence, the idea that he might need that old employment, and not find it, gives him a sudden sense of terror, like that which one may fancy strikes to the heart of a lost child.”
vi: − You see, - Dr. Manette turned to look at his friend after a moment of confused silence, - it is indeed difficult to thoroughly explain what goes on in the mind of this poor soul. This person had a terrible longing to do that work, and was very happy to do it; surely it helped him alleviate his suffering a great deal by replacing the complex activity of the mind with the complex activity of the hands; and in doing so, he became more and more proficient, the dexterity of his hands helped him forget the torment in his mind to the extent that he couldn't bear the thought of being separated from that work. Even now, when I see that he is more hopeful about himself than ever before, he even speaks about himself with confidence, but the thought of needing the old work and not having it suddenly terrifies him, like the fear in the heart of a child who has once been lost from their mother.
tr: After a disturbing short silence, Doctor Manette turned to Mr. Lorry and said, "Now look," he said, "it is very difficult to fully explain what is going through this poor man's mind. Once upon a time, he very earnestly wanted to find a job to occupy himself and was very happy when he found it; clearly, this job greatly alleviated his pain at the time; the confusion of his mind was replaced by the confusion of his fingers, and with this change, as he became more skilled, the dexterity of his fingers replaced the skill of self-tormenting; therefore, he never thought of parting with it. Even now, although your friend is more hopeful and confident than ever, he panics with a feeling similar to that of a lost child, thinking that if one day he feels the need to return to this old occupation and cannot find it."
es: —You must understand—replied Doctor Manette, turning to his interlocutor—that it is extremely difficult to explain, adhering to the inflexible rules of logic, the intimate operations of the mind of the poor man to whom you refer. In the past, he so fervently requested to dedicate himself to that trade, that when what he longed for was granted to him, he thanked Heaven from the depths of his soul. It is undeniable that, upon finding a means that allowed him to substitute the perplexity of his fingers for the perplexity of his brain, and with the dexterity of his hands the operations of his tortured mind when he acquired some practice in the trade, his torments were greatly alleviated, in which case, it is natural that he shows resistance to parting from what did him so much good. Even today, although I believe there is not the slightest danger of new relapses, even if his friend shares this confidence of mine, the idea that there could come a day when he might need the forge, and not find it, I believe would cause him a pain only comparable to that of a father threatened with being separated from his child.

en: He looked like his illustration, as he raised his eyes to Mr. Lorry’s face.
vi: He truly looked like a lost child when he looked up straight into Mr. Lorry's eyes.
tr: The moment the doctor lifted his head and looked at Mr. Lorry's face, he resembled the person he had described.
es: —We do not agree—replied Lorry.

en: “But may not—mind! I ask for information, as a plodding man of business who only deals with such material objects as guineas, shillings, and bank-notes—may not the retention of the thing involve the retention of the idea? If the thing were gone, my dear Manette, might not the fear go with it? In short, is it not a concession to the misgiving, to keep the forge?”
vi: − But how could it be... Please, sir! I need guidance, because a slow-witted person like me only knows how to deal with tangible things like coins, currency, paper money... If you keep those tools, won't you forever be haunted by that fear? If those things are no longer there, Mr. Manette, wouldn't that fear disappear as well? In short, keeping that forge means constant worry and suffering, right?
tr: "But –damn! As a businessman who has been dealing with material things, guineas, shillings, banknotes, and such for years, I may have asked you many questions, but– I am saying, doesn't keeping this object with you all the time keep the idea constantly in your mind? If dear Manette had thrown this thing away, wouldn't the fear have gone away with it? In short, doesn't preserving this blacksmith's forge mean the same as surrendering to fears?"
es: —We do not agree—replied Lorry. —I know I am not an authority on the matter, for as a businessman, my intelligence extinguishes when I do not apply it to things as material as pounds sterling, shillings, and banknotes; but even so, I ask: does the preservation of the forge not tend to perpetuate the idea? If the forge were to disappear, my dear Manette, would not the fear disappear with it? In a word: is it not a concession made to fear to preserve the forge?

en: There was another silence.
vi: Another moment of silence. −
tr: There was another silence.
es: —You must also understand—replied the doctor after another moment of silence and with a trembling voice—that this is about an old colleague.

en: “You see, too,” said the Doctor, tremulously, “it is such an old companion.”
vi: You see, - the doctor's voice trembled, - it's like an old friend. −
tr: "As you can appreciate," said the Doctor with a trembling voice, "this is a very old friend."
es: —You must also understand—replied the doctor after another moment of silence and with a trembling voice—that this is about an old colleague.

en: “I would not keep it,” said Mr. Lorry, shaking his head; for he gained in firmness as he saw the Doctor disquieted. “I would recommend him to sacrifice it. I only want your authority. I am sure it does no good. Come! Give me your authority, like a dear good man. For his daughter’s sake, my dear Manette!”
vi: If it were me, I wouldn't keep it, - Mr. Lorry shook his head; the more anxious the doctor became, the more confident he felt. - I would advise this person to give it up. I just need your permission. I'm sure keeping it is of no use. Come on! Allow me, as a kind person. For the sake of this person's daughter, Mr. Manette!
tr: Shaking his head from side to side, "If it were me, I wouldn't keep him by my side," said Mr. Lorry; he had gathered his strength upon seeing the Doctor's concern. "I will advise him to sacrifice this friend. I only seek your approval for this. That hearth is of no use to him anymore. Come on, my dear friend, please give me this authority. For the sake of your daughter, dear Manette!"
es: —An old companion whom I would distance from my side!—replied Lorry with great firmness, for it is worth noting that he was gaining it as the doctor was losing it. —An old companion whom I would sacrifice without a shred of remorse! I only need your authorization. Keeping it is harmful; I am sure of it. Grant me the permission I seek, my dear Manette... You are good... you have a good heart... grant it to me for the sake of the peace of my poor friend's daughter...!

en: Very strange to see what a struggle there was within him!
vi: How strange it was to witness the doctor's inner turmoil!
tr: The doctor was clearly fighting a great battle within himself!
es: The struggle that took place in the doctor's chest between conflicting thoughts was fierce, terrible, and frightening.

en: “In her name, then, let it be done; I sanction it. But, I would not take it away while he was present. Let it be removed when he is not there; let him miss his old companion after an absence.”
vi: − Then for the sake of that girl, do it; I give my permission. But if it were me, I wouldn't do it in front of this person. Dispose of those things when he is absent; let him remember his old friend after he has gone far away.
tr: "Then, for my daughter's sake, let it be done; I find it appropriate. But I advise against removing it while she is around. It would be better to get rid of it when she is not here; let her miss her old friend after not seeing it for a while."
es: After a while, he said: —In deference to his friend's daughter, I grant the authorization he asks for. I sanction the sacrifice of the forge; but it should not be done in front of his friend. Take advantage of a moment of absence and spare him the pain of witnessing the destruction of what was his sole companion in past times.

en: Mr. Lorry readily engaged for that, and the conference was ended. They passed the day in the country, and the Doctor was quite restored. On the three following days he remained perfectly well, and on the fourteenth day he went away to join Lucie and her husband. The precaution that had been taken to account for his silence, Mr. Lorry had previously explained to him, and he had written to Lucie in accordance with it, and she had no suspicions.
vi: Mr. Lorry agreed immediately and the consultation ended. They spent the whole day enjoying the countryside, and the doctor had fully recovered. For the next three days, he remained as healthy as usual, and on the fourteenth day, he set off to meet Lucie and her husband. Mr. Lorry had previously explained to Mr. Manette how they had fabricated a story to explain the doctor's absence, and Mr. Manette had used that excuse to write to Lucie, so she suspected nothing.
tr: Mr. Lorry gladly accepted immediately, and the matter was closed. They spent the day in the countryside, and the Doctor recovered quite a bit. He was also very well during the following three days, and on the fourteenth day, he set out to join his daughter Lucie and son-in-law. Mr. Lorry had previously explained to him the precaution they had taken during the Doctor's silent period, and the Doctor had written something to Lucie accordingly, so she suspected nothing.
es: With true joy, Lorry accepted the solution, and the conference was concluded. They spent the day in the countryside, which was enough to restore the doctor. During the next three days, he went about his normal life, and on the fourteenth day of his daughter's absence, he went to join her and her husband.

en: On the night of the day on which he left the house, Mr. Lorry went into his room with a chopper, saw, chisel, and hammer, attended by Miss Pross carrying a light. There, with closed doors, and in a mysterious and guilty manner, Mr. Lorry hacked the shoemaker’s bench to pieces, while Miss Pross held the candle as if she were assisting at a murder—for which, indeed, in her grimness, she was no unsuitable figure. The burning of the body (previously reduced to pieces convenient for the purpose) was commenced without delay in the kitchen fire; and the tools, shoes, and leather, were buried in the garden. So wicked do destruction and secrecy appear to honest minds, that Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, while engaged in the commission of their deed and in the removal of its traces, almost felt, and almost looked, like accomplices in a horrible crime.
vi: The night the doctor left home, Mr. Lorry entered the doctor's room carrying an axe, saw, chisel, and hammer, with Miss Pross assisting by holding a lamp. In the room, behind closed doors, with an air of mystery and guilt, Mr. Lorry smashed the shoemaker's bench to pieces while Miss Pross held the candle, illuminating the scene as if they were participating in a murder - judging by her fierce expression, Miss Pross indeed seemed fitting for this conspiracy. The remains were chopped up for easier burning, and the incineration began immediately in the kitchen stove; the tools, shoes, and leather pieces were buried in the garden. For honest souls, this secretive destruction was truly cruel, so Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, busy carrying out the act and erasing all traces, both inwardly and outwardly resembled accomplices in a heinous crime.
tr: The night the doctor left the house, Mr. Lorry, with an axe, saw, chisel, and hammer in hand, accompanied by Miss Pross holding a lantern, went to his friend's room. There, behind closed doors, while Mr. Lorry, with a mysterious and guilty demeanor, was smashing the shoemaker's bench to pieces, Miss Pross, as if she were an accomplice to a murder – which suited her stern appearance quite well – held the light for him. Without any delay, the bench (broken into pieces as intended) was burned in the kitchen fire, and all the tools, shoes, and leather pieces were buried in the garden. As Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross carried out their actions and erased the traces of them, there was such a dreadful sense of destruction and secrecy that both felt and indeed looked like accomplices to a terrible murder.
es: As soon as night fell on the day the doctor left his house, he entered the bedroom of our good friend Lorry, armed with a butcher's knife, a saw, a chisel, and a hammer. Miss Pross followed him in, holding a candlestick in her hand. Behind closed doors, in the mystery of the night, resembling someone committing a criminal act, Mr. Lorry smashed the shoemaker's bench to pieces, while Miss Pross held the light as if witnessing the commission of a murder. In the kitchen, the sinful bench, previously reduced to splinters, was then incinerated, and subsequently, the tools and implements of the trade, shoes, soles, and leather, received an honorable burial in the garden adjacent to the house. Both Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, while executing the feat and making the traces disappear, considered themselves, and almost appeared to be, accomplices in a horrendous crime.

en: CHAPTER XX.
vi: For honest souls, this secretive destruction was truly cruel, so Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, busy carrying out the act and erasing all traces, both inwardly and outwardly resembled accomplices in a heinous crime.
tr: XX
es: XX.

en: A Plea
vi: For honest souls, this secretive destruction was truly cruel, so Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross, busy carrying out the act and erasing all traces, both inwardly and outwardly resembled accomplices in a heinous crime.
tr: A Request
es: A PLEA

en: When the newly-married pair came home, the first person who appeared, to offer his congratulations, was Sydney Carton. They had not been at home many hours, when he presented himself. He was not improved in habits, or in looks, or in manner; but there was a certain rugged air of fidelity about him, which was new to the observation of Charles Darnay.
vi: When the newlyweds returned, the first person to congratulate them was Sydney Carton. He arrived a few hours after they had come home. His clothes, appearance, and demeanor were no better, but Carton had a certain firmness and reliability that Charles Darnay had never seen before.
tr: When the newlywed couple returned home, the first person to come and congratulate them was Sydney Carton. When Carton arrived, Lucie and Charles had not been home for long. There was no improvement in Carton's habits, appearance, or manners; but he had acquired an air of a strong, loyal friend that Charles Darnay had just begun to notice.
es: The first person who showed up at Doctor Manette's house after the newlyweds returned from their honeymoon was Sydney Carton. His attire, his manners, his gestures, his expression, could be said to be the same as always; but over the hard exterior, despite being extraordinarily rough, there was a certain air of fidelity that did not go unnoticed by the scrutinizing gaze of Charles Darnay.

en: He watched his opportunity of taking Darnay aside into a window, and of speaking to him when no one overheard.
vi: Waiting for a convenient moment, he pulled Darnay to the window, speaking privately so that no one could hear.
tr: Carton was waiting for an opportunity to pull Darnay to the window and talk to him at a moment when no one would hear.
es: Carton took advantage of the first opportunity that presented itself to take Darnay to the recess of a window, where he spoke to him without their conversation reaching the ears of any of those present.

en: “Mr. Darnay,” said Carton, “I wish we might be friends.”
vi: − Mr. Darnay, - said Carton, - I hope we can be friends.
tr: "Mr. Darnay," said Carton, "I hope to be friends with you."
es: —I wish that we could be friends, Mr. Darnay—Carton began saying.

en: “We are already friends, I hope.”
vi: − We already are friends, I hope. −
tr: "Aren't we already like that?"
es: —I think we already are—replied Darnay.

en: “You are good enough to say so, as a fashion of speech; but, I don’t mean any fashion of speech. Indeed, when I say I wish we might be friends, I scarcely mean quite that, either.”
vi: It's very kind and polite of you to say so; but my intention has nothing to do with politeness. Honestly, when I say I hope we can be friends, I don't mean it out of politeness either.
tr: "You are kind and gracious enough to say this; but there is no need for courtesy now. When I said I hoped to be friends, I didn't exactly mean that."
es: —I appreciate you saying that, even if your words are plainly dictated by politeness. But I was not referring to that conventional friendship. When I tell you that I wish for us to be friends, I am alluding to another kind of friendship.

en: Charles Darnay—as was natural—asked him, in all good-humour and good-fellowship, what he did mean?
vi: Charles Darnay naturally had to ask again, very cheerfully and affectionately, what Carton meant.
tr: Charles Darnay –as usual– asked with a cheerful and affectionate manner what she meant.
es: Carlos Darnay begged him to explain himself.

en: “Upon my life,” said Carton, smiling, “I find that easier to comprehend in my own mind, than to convey to yours. However, let me try. You remember a certain famous occasion when I was more drunk than—than usual?”
vi: − I swear, - Carton said with a laugh, - it's easy to understand myself but hard to make others understand my meaning. But I will try to explain. Do you remember that time when I was more... more drunk than usual?
tr: "Throughout my life," said Carton, smiling, "I have struggled to express what was on my mind. But if you allow me, I will try to explain. You remember that infamous evening when I was more drunk than ever, don't you?"
es: —By my life, I find it easier to understand the idea myself than to make it understandable to others! —replied Carton. —I will try, however. Do you remember that memorable occasion when I was more drunk than usual?

en: “I remember a certain famous occasion when you forced me to confess that you had been drinking.”
vi: − I still remember the time when you forced me to admit that you were too drunk.
tr: "I remember that famous evening when you forced me to say that you drank too much."
es: —I remember the memorable occasion when you forced me to declare that I had been drinking.

en: “I remember it too. The curse of those occasions is heavy upon me, for I always remember them. I hope it may be taken into account one day, when all days are at an end for me! Don’t be alarmed; I am not going to preach.”
vi: − I remember too. That time still haunts me because I can never forget it. I hope that on the final day of judgment, my regret will be considered! Don't panic, I'm not preaching.
tr: "I remember too. The curse of such nights weighs heavily on me, and I always remember. I hope they take this into account when I reach the end of my life! Don't worry; I won't bore you."
es: —I haven't forgotten it either. The curse that weighs on those occasions leaves such lasting traces on me that it can be said I never forget them. I harbor the hope that a day will come, the one that puts an end to my days on earth, when I will make amends for that occasion... Don't be alarmed, it is not my intention to preach.

en: “I am not at all alarmed. Earnestness in you, is anything but alarming to me.”
vi: − I'm not panicking. With someone as sincere as you, why would I panic? −
tr: "I definitely did not panic. The only thing that makes me anxious is your sincerity."
es: —I'm not alarmed! Your seriousness can never alarm me.

en: “Ah!” said Carton, with a careless wave of his hand, as if he waved that away. “On the drunken occasion in question (one of a large number, as you know), I was insufferable about liking you, and not liking you. I wish you would forget it.”
vi: Ah! - Carton nonchalantly waved his hand as if to dismiss Darnay's words. - That drunken time; one of many such times, you know; I was rude when I talked about whether I liked or hated you. I hope you can forget it.
tr: "Ah!" said Carton, waving his hand indifferently as if dismissing the matter. "When it comes to talking about whether I love you in my drunken state (as you know, there are plenty of examples like this), I was unbearable. I hope you can forget it."
es: —Well then: regarding the drunkenness in question... one of my countless drunken episodes, I was unbearably impertinent, talking to you about whether I found you likable or unlikable: I beg you to forget it and to consider my words as unsaid.

en: “I forgot it long ago.”
vi: − I've forgotten it long ago.
tr: "I already forgot.""
es: —I forgot them a long time ago.

en: “Fashion of speech again! But, Mr. Darnay, oblivion is not so easy to me, as you represent it to be to you. I have by no means forgotten it, and a light answer does not help me to forget it.”
vi: − Again with the polite talk! But Darnay, I'm not as easy to forget as you are. I have no way to forget, and a casual remark can't help me forget. −
tr: "How dare you speak like this! But Mr. Darnay, I cannot forget some things as easily as you do. I can never forget my state that evening, and even your dismissive response does not help me forget it.'
es: —Once again, your words are inspired by compliments and social conventions! I must say, Mr. Darnay, that I do not forget as easily as you pretend to forget. I have not forgotten her, and I assure you that a light and indifferent response on your part will not help me forget her.

en: “If it was a light answer,” returned Darnay, “I beg your forgiveness for it. I had no other object than to turn a slight thing, which, to my surprise, seems to trouble you too much, aside. I declare to you, on the faith of a gentleman, that I have long dismissed it from my mind. Good Heaven, what was there to dismiss! Have I had nothing more important to remember, in the great service you rendered me that day?”
vi: If it was a casual remark, then I apologize, - Darnay replied. - I answered like that because I thought it wasn't important, but I'm surprised that it bothers you so much and that you want to let it go. I tell you, on my honor as a gentleman, that I have forgotten it long ago. For God's sake, what does it matter! Don't I have anything more important to remember, when it was you who saved me that day? −
tr: "If I made you think that I took this lightly," replied Darnay, "please forgive me. My only intention was to set aside a small matter that has caused you surprising distress. I swear on my honor that this incident had long been erased from my mind. Though, what was there to erase anyway! If I have anything to remember, it should be the great kindness you showed me that day."
es: —If my response has been flippant, I beg you to forgive me—replied Darnay.— My intention was to remove all importance from what, to my considerable surprise, concerns you too much. I declare to you, on my word of honor, that I forgot the conversation of the night to which you refer a long time ago, and I understand that by forgetting it, I did not gain any merit. For what, had you not rendered me that very day a service that no moderately grateful heart can or should forget?

en: “As to the great service,” said Carton, “I am bound to avow to you, when you speak of it in that way, that it was mere professional claptrap, I don’t know that I cared what became of you, when I rendered it.—Mind! I say when I rendered it; I am speaking of the past.”
vi: That rescue, - Carton said - since you put it that way, I have to confess to you, at that time I did it just as a professional trick, I did it regardless of the consequences you would face... Remember! I'm talking about my feelings back then; I'm talking about the past.
tr: "When you mention great kindness now," said Carton, "I must confess that they were all professional tall tales. At that time, I didn't really care what would happen to you. –But look, I am saying at that time; I mean, I am talking about the past."
es: —You put me in the position of telling you—replied Carton—that the great service you speak of was simply what we might call a professional prank, one of those tricks we lawyers often resort to in order to gain popularity. A good proof of this is that, when I rendered it, I was completely indifferent to your fate. Note that I said when I rendered it; that is, I am speaking of past events.

en: “You make light of the obligation,” returned Darnay, “but I will not quarrel with your light answer.”
vi: − You are underestimating that favor again, - Darnay replied, - but I don't want to argue with your baseless words.
tr: "Now you are underestimating my debt of gratitude to you," said Darnay, "but I will not argue about your underestimation of this situation.""
es: —You insist on belittling my obligation, and yet, I, less finicky than you, am not offended by the lightness of your response.

en: “Genuine truth, Mr. Darnay, trust me! I have gone aside from my purpose; I was speaking about our being friends. Now, you know me; you know I am incapable of all the higher and better flights of men. If you doubt it, ask Stryver, and he’ll tell you so.”
vi: − It's the absolute truth, Mr. Darnay, believe me! I digressed; I was talking about our friends. There, you know me, you know I don't have the talent to rise higher or be better like everyone else. If you still doubt, just ask Stryver and he will tell you this.
tr: "This is the truth, Mr. Darnay, believe me! Look, I have strayed away from the main topic I wanted to tell you; I was talking about being friends with you. Now, you know me; you know that I can't soar high like other men. If you have any doubts about this, ask Stryver, he will tell you."
es: —It is the naked truth, Mr. Darnay, the naked truth. But I have strayed from the object I was pursuing. I was speaking of my desires for us to be friends. As you already know me, there is no need for me to tell you that my friendship can honor no one. If you have any doubts, ask Stryver.

en: “I prefer to form my own opinion, without the aid of his.”
vi: − I prefer to have my own opinion, without needing to consult him.
tr: "I prefer to give my opinion on this matter without his help.""
es: —I prefer to form an opinion without their assistance.

en: “Well! At any rate you know me as a dissolute dog, who has never done any good, and never will.”
vi: − Fine! Anyway, you know I'm a wastrel, incapable of doing anything good and never will be.
tr: "Good! In the end, you know me as a worthless person who is good for nothing and will never be.""
es: —Very well. Therefore, you already know that I am a dissolute dog, incapable of anything good, now and always.

en: “I don’t know that you ‘never will.’”
vi: − I don't know about your "never ever" situation.
tr: "Will it never be useful, or not, I don't know.""
es: —We do not agree, my friend.

en: “But I do, and you must take my word for it. Well! If you could endure to have such a worthless fellow, and a fellow of such indifferent reputation, coming and going at odd times, I should ask that I might be permitted to come and go as a privileged person here; that I might be regarded as an useless (and I would add, if it were not for the resemblance I detected between you and me, an unornamental) piece of furniture, tolerated for its old service, and taken no notice of. I doubt if I should abuse the permission. It is a hundred to one if I should avail myself of it four times in a year. It would satisfy me, I dare say, to know that I had it.”
vi: − But I know, and you must believe me. Well! If you can tolerate someone like me, who has a bad reputation and occasionally visits this place, then I would like to come here as someone granted favor; you can consider me as a discarded piece of furniture, kept because of its past usefulness, and no one bothers to notice. And I want to add that if it weren't for the fact that I discovered we look alike, I would just be a discarded thing. I will not abuse your permission. I bet one hundred to one that I will only come here four times a year at most. If permitted, I dare say I would want nothing more. −
tr: "But I know, and you should believe me. Well, if you are going to accept a worthless, ill-reputed man like me into your home at odd times, at least allow me to come and go as a privileged man; see me as a useless piece of furniture with no special features if you want (of course, I must add that this has nothing to do with the similarity between you and me); like an old item kept for the sake of old times, which has been discarded. If you grant me this permission, I don't think I would misuse it. I would probably only visit four or five times a year anyway. But knowing that I have such a right would make me feel good."
es: —I assure you, and you must believe me. I continue. If you find yourself strong enough to tolerate the presence in this house of a person who is worthless, and who moreover enjoys a questionable reputation, I will ask you as a special favor to allow me to come here or leave, without adhering to hours or rules, seeing in me nothing more than a useless piece of furniture and... I would gladly add abnormal, if it weren't for the physical resemblance between the two of us... a useless piece of furniture, reserved for rare services and one that you wouldn't even notice. I highly doubt that I will abuse the permission, if you grant it to me. There is a hundred to one chance that I will not use your indulgence more than four times a year. It would be a satisfaction for me to know that I am abusing it.

en: “Will you try?”
vi: Will you come? −
tr: "Would you really do this?"
es: —Will you do your best to take advantage?

en: “That is another way of saying that I am placed on the footing I have indicated. I thank you, Darnay. I may use that freedom with your name?”
vi: That is a subtle way of saying my request has been granted. Thank you very much, Darnay. May I call you by your first name to be more familiar?
tr: "From what you say, I infer that I have a place here. Thank you, Darnay. Well, may I address you by your name while exercising this right?"
es: —We shall see. Do you authorize me to take the liberty I am requesting, Darnay?

en: “I think so, Carton, by this time.”
vi: − I think so too, Carton, from now on.
tr: "Of course, Carton, as you wish.""
es: —Authorized, Carton.

en: They shook hands upon it, and Sydney turned away. Within a minute afterwards, he was, to all outward appearance, as unsubstantial as ever.
vi: They shook hands and Sydney turned on his heel. Just a minute later, he once again looked completely disheveled as usual.
tr: Upon this, they shook hands and Sydney left. A few minutes had passed when he once again adopted that indifferent attitude towards the outside world.
es: They shook hands and then Carton walked away. A minute later, Carton was his usual extravagant self.

en: When he was gone, and in the course of an evening passed with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and Mr. Lorry, Charles Darnay made some mention of this conversation in general terms, and spoke of Sydney Carton as a problem of carelessness and recklessness. He spoke of him, in short, not bitterly or meaning to bear hard upon him, but as anybody might who saw him as he showed himself.
vi: After the guest had left, in the afternoon sitting with Miss Pross, the doctor, and Mr. Lorry, Charles Darnay briefly mentioned this conversation and remarked on Sydney Carton as a matter of carelessness and defiance. He spoke briefly, without implying any harshness or criticism towards his friend, only mentioning the things that everyone had already seen Sydney reveal.
tr: After Carton left, Charles Darnay was sitting and talking with Miss Pross, the Doctor, and Mr. Lorry in the evening. He mentioned, in general terms, the conversation he had with Sydney Carton and noted that Sydney Carton's problem was not caring about or valuing anything. There was no hostile or accusatory tone when he spoke about him; it was as if he was merely conveying something that anyone who looked at him could see.
es: That night, in the conversations that followed dinner, in which Miss Pross, the doctor, Lorry, and the married couple took part, Sydney Carton was incidentally and generally discussed, portraying him as a living problem of indifference and recklessness. Darnay said a few phrases about him which, although they could not be considered harsh or offensive, reflected a certain disdain.

en: He had no idea that this could dwell in the thoughts of his fair young wife; but, when he afterwards joined her in their own rooms, he found her waiting for him with the old pretty lifting of the forehead strongly marked.
vi: He did not expect that those words would be remembered by his beautiful young wife; but later, when he returned to their private room and met Lucie, he saw her waiting with the familiar charming wrinkle clearly imprinted on her forehead. −
tr: He had never thought that these words would occupy his beautiful wife's mind; but later, when he went to their room to be with his wife, he found her waiting for him with her forehead distinctly tensed as before.
es: Little did he think that he had hurt the feelings of his beautiful wife. When later, after the gathering had ended, he found her in their room, he couldn't help but notice a certain worry in her.

en: “We are thoughtful to-night!” said Darnay, drawing his arm about her.
vi: Do we have something to worry about tonight? - Darnay said as he wrapped his arms around her.
tr: "We seem to be a bit pensive tonight!" said Darnay, embracing his wife with his arms.
es: —I find you thoughtful tonight—said Carlos, passing his arm around her waist...

en: “Yes, dearest Charles,” with her hands on his breast, and the inquiring and attentive expression fixed upon him; “we are rather thoughtful to-night, for we have something on our mind to-night.”
vi: − That's right, Charles, - With her hand placed on her husband's chest, Lucie looked at him intently, questioning. - We have something to worry about tonight, because we have something to be concerned about tonight.
tr: With her hands on her husband's chest, "Yes, dear Charles," said Lucie, her eyes fixed on her husband with a questioning and attentive expression; "we are quite thoughtful tonight, because we have some things on our minds tonight."
es: —I am, my dear Carlos—replied Lucía, looking him straight in the eye,—I am thoughtful tonight because there is something on my mind that is bothering me.

en: “What is it, my Lucie?”
vi: − What is it, Lucie? −
tr: "What are they, my dear Lucie?""
es: —And what is it, my Lucía?

en: “Will you promise not to press one question on me, if I beg you not to ask it?”
vi: You have to promise not to press me on things I don't want to answer, okay?
tr: "I will tell you, but please promise me that you won't ask me anything about this, okay?"
es: —Do you give me your word not to let your curiosity go beyond what I desire?

en: “Will I promise? What will I not promise to my Love?”
vi: − Promise? Is there anything I wouldn't promise you, my love?
tr: "Should I give my word? If my beloved asks, how could I not give my word?"
es: —And what is it that I will not promise to my love?

en: What, indeed, with his hand putting aside the golden hair from the cheek, and his other hand against the heart that beat for him!
vi: Truly, what wouldn't I promise when one hand brushes away the golden lock falling on your cheek and the other rests on your chest where the heart that belongs to me beats!
tr: How could it be thought otherwise, with one hand on his heart that beat for her, while his golden hair, falling over his wife's cheek, was brushed aside with the other!
es: —I believe, Carlos, that poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you have shown him tonight.

en: “I think, Charles, poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you expressed for him to-night.”
vi: − Charles, I think Mr. Carton deserves more attention and respect than what you said about him tonight.
tr: "Charles, I think Mr. Carton deserves more attention and respect than what you said about him tonight.""
es: —I believe, Carlos, that poor Mr. Carton deserves more consideration and respect than you have shown him tonight.

en: “Indeed, my own? Why so?”
vi: − Really, my love? Why do you say that?
tr: "What did I say?" "Why then?""
es: —Really? And why?

en: “That is what you are not to ask me. But I think—I know—he does.”
vi: − That's not something you should ask. But I think... I know... he deserves it. −
tr: "Please don't ask me this! But I think – I know – they deserve this."
es: —That is precisely what you should not ask me. Just think... that I know for a fact that they deserve it.

en: “If you know it, it is enough. What would you have me do, my Life?”
vi: If you know that, it's enough. So what do you want me to do, my love?
tr: "If you know, that's enough for me! So, what do you want me to do, my dear?"
es: —If you are certain, there's nothing more to discuss. What do you want me to do, my love?

en: “I would ask you, dearest, to be very generous with him always, and very lenient on his faults when he is not by. I would ask you to believe that he has a heart he very, very seldom reveals, and that there are deep wounds in it. My dear, I have seen it bleeding.”
vi: − My love, I want you to always be generous with him, forgiving his mistakes when he's not around. I want you to believe that he is someone whose heart is almost always closed, and deeply scarred. My love, I have seen that heart bleed.
tr: "My love, I will always ask you to treat him very well and to be tolerant of his mistakes. Believe me, he has a deeply wounded heart and he very rarely opens it to people. I have witnessed that heart bleeding, my love."
es: —The only thing I wish is that you always treat him with great generosity, and that you try to excuse his flaws when someone brings them to public attention in his absence. I also ask you to believe that in his chest beats a heart that very, very rarely reveals itself, a heart covered with very deep wounds. Believe me, my dear, for I assure you that I have seen it bleeding.

en: “It is a painful reflection to me,” said Charles Darnay, quite astounded, “that I should have done him any wrong. I never thought this of him.”
vi: − I am truly heartbroken to know that I have treated him so poorly, Charles Darnay exclaimed in astonishment. - I never thought he was that sensitive. −
tr: "If I have behaved rudely," said Charles, in a bewildered state, "I am very sorry for that. I had never thought of it that way for him."
es: —He believes that I deeply regret having made him the object of my inconsiderations—said Darnay, still astonished by his wife's words. —It was not my intention to treat him unfairly.

en: “My husband, it is so. I fear he is not to be reclaimed; there is scarcely a hope that anything in his character or fortunes is reparable now. But, I am sure that he is capable of good things, gentle things, even magnanimous things.”
vi: That's right, my love. I'm afraid he cannot change; there is no hope of improving his character or fate. But I believe he is capable of many kind, good, even noble deeds.
tr: "But this is the situation, my dear husband. I don't think he will ever recover; I have no hope that either his personality or his fate will improve anymore. But I am sure he can do good things, beautiful things, even noble things."
es: —Well, you didn't do him justice, my dear Carlos. I fear it must be impossible to make him change, that neither his character nor his special way of being are susceptible to modification; but I assure you he is a man capable of good deeds, even magnanimous actions.

en: She looked so beautiful in the purity of her faith in this lost man, that her husband could have looked at her as she was for hours.
vi: The pure faith given to that failure made Lucie so radiantly beautiful that her husband could silently gaze at her for hours.
tr: Lucie looked so beautiful with the purity of her faith in this lost man that her husband could gaze at this face for hours.
es: Lucía was so beautiful, her lovely face so radiant with the purest light of faith in a man deemed irredeemable by all, that her husband, unable to find words to respond, stood there entranced, gazing at her.

en: “And, O my dearest Love!” she urged, clinging nearer to him, laying her head upon his breast, and raising her eyes to his, “remember how strong we are in our happiness, and how weak he is in his misery!”
vi: − My dear! - Lucie nestled close to him, resting her head on his chest, looking up. - Please remember how happy we are while he is so miserable!
tr: Snuggling up to her husband, resting her head on his chest, and fixing her eyes on his, Lucie continued, "And there's this, my love! Don't forget that we draw strength from our happiness, while he becomes even weaker from the pain he endures!"
es: —Please me, my love!—exclaimed Lucía, letting her little head fall on her husband's chest and raising her eyes to him. —Reflect on how immense our happiness is, and how much he is to be pitied in his misery!

en: The supplication touched him home. “I will always remember it, dear Heart! I will remember it as long as I live.”
vi: That plea moved Darnay deeply. − I will always remember that, my love! I will remember it for the rest of my life.
tr: Charles was deeply affected by his wife's request. "I will never forget this, my dear! I will remember it for the rest of my life."
es: The plea hit the mark. —I will never forget it, my little heart! I will remember it as long as I live!

en: He bent over the golden head, and put the rosy lips to his, and folded her in his arms. If one forlorn wanderer then pacing the dark streets, could have heard her innocent disclosure, and could have seen the drops of pity kissed away by her husband from the soft blue eyes so loving of that husband, he might have cried to the night—and the words would not have parted from his lips for the first time—
vi: He bent down to her blonde hair, kissed Lucie's rosy lips, and wrapped his arms around her. If any suffering wanderer counting their steps through the night streets heard her innocent confession, saw the tears of compassion welling up in her blue eyes, which her husband dried with kisses, that person would surely cry out to the night for the first time - words that would never escape our lips: − God bless her for having compassion on me!
tr: Charles leaned in towards her golden hair and planted a kiss on her rose lips, then hugged her tightly. If the wretched vagabond wandering the dark streets had seen her innocent words and the merciful tears flowing from her soft, loving blue eyes being wiped away by her husband's kisses, he would have cried all night – and once again these words would have escaped his lips:
es: He leaned over that head adorned with rich golden attire, brought his lips close to Lucía's rose-like ones, and embraced her tightly. If the nocturnal wanderer who at that moment walked absorbed through the lonely streets near the little corner of Soho, had been able to hear that plea dictated by the purest compassion, if he had been given to see some very clear pearls drunk by a loving husband in some blue and clean eyes like the sky, he would have exclaimed with rapture:

en: “God bless her for her sweet compassion!”
vi: If any suffering wanderer counting their steps through the night streets heard her innocent confession, saw the tears of compassion welling up in her blue eyes, which her husband dried with kisses, that person would surely cry out to the night for the first time - words that would never escape our lips: − God bless her for having compassion on me!
tr: "God, protect that compassionate, beautiful heart!"
es: —May God bless her beautiful soul!

en: CHAPTER XXI.
vi: 21. The echoing footsteps A strange corner of the street echoed, as mentioned earlier, the corner with the doctor's house.
tr: 21st
es: XXI.

en: Echoing Footsteps
vi: 21. The echoing footsteps A strange corner of the street echoed, as mentioned earlier, the corner with the doctor's house.
tr: Echoing Footsteps
es: STEPS THAT RESONATE

en: A wonderful corner for echoes, it has been remarked, that corner where the Doctor lived. Ever busily winding the golden thread which bound her husband, and her father, and herself, and her old directress and companion, in a life of quiet bliss, Lucie sat in the still house in the tranquilly resounding corner, listening to the echoing footsteps of years.
vi: 21. The echoing footsteps A strange corner of the street echoed, as mentioned earlier, the corner with the doctor's house. Always busy with the golden thread entwining her husband, father, herself, and the old nanny who was also a companion, and a peaceful life, Lucie sat in the quiet house on that silent, echoing corner, listening to the footsteps of the years reverberating.
tr: The corner where the Doctor lived was a corner that echoed perfectly. Lucie sat in the tranquil house in the echoing corner, continuously winding the golden thread that silently and peacefully connected her husband, her father, herself, her old nanny, and her friend into a happy life, listening to the echoing footsteps of the years.
es: The most admirable corner to gather the echoes was the one where Dr. Manette lived. Lucía, always engaged in the pleasant task of twisting the golden thread that connected her to her husband, her father, herself, and her former director and companion, savored a life of uninterrupted happiness in that peaceful center of tranquility, listening to the echo of the footsteps of time.

en: At first, there were times, though she was a perfectly happy young wife, when her work would slowly fall from her hands, and her eyes would be dimmed. For, there was something coming in the echoes, something light, afar off, and scarcely audible yet, that stirred her heart too much. Fluttering hopes and doubts—hopes, of a love as yet unknown to her: doubts, of her remaining upon earth, to enjoy that new delight—divided her breast. Among the echoes then, there would arise the sound of footsteps at her own early grave; and thoughts of the husband who would be left so desolate, and who would mourn for her so much, swelled to her eyes, and broke like waves.
vi: At first, even though she was a young wife full of happiness, there were moments when she let go of her work, her eyes tinged with sadness. Because in those echoes, she felt that something was going to happen, something faint, distant, and vague that stirred her heart. Her heart wavered between hope and doubt - the hope of a new and strange love; the doubt of not knowing how long she would remain in this world to enjoy that love. Amidst those echoes, there were moments when the sound of her early steps towards the grave resounded; and thinking of the husband left alone mourning his wife, she couldn't hold back the flowing tears.
tr: Although she was an extremely happy young wife at first, there were times when she felt the work slipping away from her and her eyes grew dull. There was something coming towards her with echoes, something vague, from afar, barely audible, but enough to make her heart race. Hopes and doubts fluttered inside her – hopes of a love she had not yet known, and doubts that she would not be able to savor this new delight in the remaining days – always constricting her chest. Amidst the echoing sounds, she could hear the footsteps rising at her grave; then, when she thought of her devastated husband and how he would mourn for her, tears flowed like a flood.
es: Sometimes, especially at the beginning, even when she considered herself completely happy, her hands would drop the golden thread she was twisting onto her knees, and the pure blue of her eyes would cloud over: it was because among the echoes that resonated far in the distance, she thought she perceived something very light, very subtle, barely perceptible yet, and which, nevertheless, caused her a certain feeling of unease. Then, her heart would be equally filled with soothing hopes and tormenting doubts: hopes of knowing a love she did not yet know and fears of not living long enough to savor the purest joys of that love. Among the echoes that on those occasions struck her ears, were the sounds of her own footsteps walking towards the grave; and thinking of the loneliness in which she would leave her husband, of the sharp pain her death would cause him, tears would come to her eyes and overflow down her cheeks.

en: That time passed, and her little Lucie lay on her bosom. Then, among the advancing echoes, there was the tread of her tiny feet and the sound of her prattling words. Let greater echoes resound as they would, the young mother at the cradle side could always hear those coming. They came, and the shady house was sunny with a child’s laugh, and the Divine friend of children, to whom in her trouble she had confided hers, seemed to take her child in his arms, as He took the child of old, and made it a sacred joy to her.
vi: Time passed, and now she had little Lucie in her arms. Then, amidst the echoes approaching, there were the tiny footsteps and the babbling of a child. Ignoring the loud reverberations, the young mother by the cradle only heard those waves of happiness. Then the awaited echoes arrived as well, and this cool, shaded house burst into the laughter of children; and God, the friend of children, the supreme being to whom she had entrusted her worries, seemed to have taken her child - just as He had welcomed the Holy Infant - and transformed it into a spiritual joy for the young mother.
tr: Time passed and her little daughter Lucie was born. Then, among these approaching echoes, her daughter's tiny steps and chirping sounds mingled. Yet, the young mother beside the cradle always heard the approaching great echoes. As the sounds continued to approach, the dim house was illuminated with the child's laughter, and in the young mother's troubled days, the divine friend of children seemed to have taken her baby into its arms and made her a source of sacred joy.
es: Those times have passed. In her arms now played an angel, named Lucía, like her; and then, dominating all the echoes of the advancing steps, always stood out those of tiny little feet mixed with silver sounds emitted by a tongue that begins to babble. The world could be deafened by the most thunderous echoes: the young mother, sitting by the cradle, only heard the soothing music of her little daughter's half-formed words. The divine friend of children, to whom all mothers usually entrust the care of their children, had taken Lucía's child in his arms and turned him into an inexhaustible source of joy for her!

en: Ever busily winding the golden thread that bound them all together, weaving the service of her happy influence through the tissue of all their lives, and making it predominate nowhere, Lucie heard in the echoes of years none but friendly and soothing sounds. Her husband’s step was strong and prosperous among them; her father’s firm and equal. Lo, Miss Pross, in harness of string, awakening the echoes, as an unruly charger, whip-corrected, snorting and pawing the earth under the plane-tree in the garden!
vi: Always busy with the golden thread that entwines everyone together, weaving her efforts to build happiness into their lives without ever revealing herself, Lucie hears in the echoes of time the soothing, affectionate reverberations. Among them are the steady and successful footsteps of her husband, and the stable and healthy footsteps of her father. There, under the linden tree in the garden, Miss Pross, like an untamed warhorse that has been bridled and tamed with a whip, is snorting, stamping, and stirring up even more reverberations!
tr: The golden thread that tirelessly connected them all was weaving Lucie's happiness into the lives of others, prioritizing it above everything else, so that Lucie heard warm and comforting sounds in the echoes of the years. Among these, her husband's footsteps were strong and intense; her father's were steady and calm. As for Miss Pross, she amplified the echoes like an unruly cavalry horse in its harness, snorting through her nose and pawing the ground under the plane tree in the garden when whipped!
es: Lucía was always busy twisting the golden thread that bound the happy members of that family, always contributing to the fabric of everyone's lives with the weave of her beneficial influence, while carefully avoiding letting it dominate; in the echoes of the footsteps of the years, she heard nothing but friendly steps. Among them, her husband's steps stood out for being strong and prosperous; her father's were firm and always the same, and Miss Pross's were impetuous and violent, an echo that awakened a thousand echoes, similar to the harsh neighing and stamping of a horse being punished.

en: Even when there were sounds of sorrow among the rest, they were not harsh nor cruel. Even when golden hair, like her own, lay in a halo on a pillow round the worn face of a little boy, and he said, with a radiant smile, “Dear papa and mamma, I am very sorry to leave you both, and to leave my pretty sister; but I am called, and I must go!” those were not tears all of agony that wetted his young mother’s cheek, as the spirit departed from her embrace that had been entrusted to it. Suffer them and forbid them not. They see my Father’s face. O Father, blessed words!
vi: Even when the echoes are of sorrow and pain, those reverberations are neither cruel nor harsh. Even when the golden hair like Lucie's, shining with a halo around the head of the son lying on the pillow about to depart, and the boy says with a radiant smile, “Papa and maman, I am very sorry to leave you and my pretty sister; but God has called and I must go!” the tears soaking the mother's cheeks are still not the utmost agony as the little soul leaves the arms entrusted by God. Painful but accepting. They will meet again before God. Oh, hallowed be Thy name!
tr: Even in times of sorrowful voices, they were neither hurtful nor rude. When the weary face of a little boy with golden hair similar to Lucie's was surrounded by a halo of light on the pillow, and with a radiant smile on his face, he said, "Dear mother and father, I am very sad to leave you and my sweet sister; but they are calling me, I must go!" even then, the tears wetting his young mother's cheeks were not tears of pain, but the soul entrusted to her had been taken away. Feel sorrow for him but do not hinder him. He will meet God. God bless him!
es: Not even on the rare occasions when echoes of joy were mixed with echoes of pain, was the latter cruel or lacerating. When on the pillow of a little bed fell in disarray the curls of a blonde hair, similar to Lucia's, framing the emaciated and transparent face of a child, who, smiling sweetly, said: "I am very sorry to leave my daddy and my mommy; I am also very sorry to part from my dear little sister; but they are calling me from above and I must answer the call," the tears that flooded the mother's cheeks were not tears of agony; for the fact that an angel leaves the covering that served as its dress should not tear them from her eyes. To the gentle fluttering of an angel's wings were joined the echoes born on earth, resulting in a murmur that was not entirely earthly, as it was animated by a breath from the heavens.

en: Thus, the rustling of an Angel’s wings got blended with the other echoes, and they were not wholly of earth, but had in them that breath of Heaven. Sighs of the winds that blew over a little garden-tomb were mingled with them also, and both were audible to Lucie, in a hushed murmur—like the breathing of a summer sea asleep upon a sandy shore—as the little Lucie, comically studious at the task of the morning, or dressing a doll at her mother’s footstool, chattered in the tongues of the Two Cities that were blended in her life.
vi: Thus, the rustling of the Angel's wings blended with other echoes, reverberations not entirely earthly but imbued with the breath of Heaven. Whispering softly in the mother's ear, the sigh of the wind blowing over the small grave in the garden also carries the sound of little Lucie diligently and amusingly performing her morning duties, or dressing her doll on her mother's footstool, chattering in the language of both cities that are her homelands.
tr: Thus, to the other echoes was added the fluttering of an angel's wings, and these were not earthly echoes, but ones that carried the breath of heaven. Then the sighs of the winds blowing over the small grave in the garden joined them, and both came to Lucie's ear with a calm murmur, like the breeze of the sea that had fallen asleep on a beach in summer – meanwhile, little Lucie would be eagerly engaging in her morning activities or dressing her doll while chattering away in the language of the Two Cities that had intertwined with her life, at her mother's knee.
es: To the gentle fluttering of an angel's wings were joined the echoes born on earth, resulting in a murmur that was not entirely earthly, as it was animated by a breath from the heavens. Also mingled with those faint sighs of the wind that kiss the flowers of the cemetery were sighs that Lucía's ear picked up, believing they were the breathing of a summer sea that sleeps upon a flat sandy beach while her little daughter, studying with comical seriousness the lessons of the morning, or engrossed in the task of dressing her dolls, chatted, mixing words from the two cities that had combined in her life.

en: The Echoes rarely answered to the actual tread of Sydney Carton. Some half-dozen times a year, at most, he claimed his privilege of coming in uninvited, and would sit among them through the evening, as he had once done often. He never came there heated with wine. And one other thing regarding him was whispered in the echoes, which has been whispered by all true echoes for ages and ages.
vi: Those echoes rarely truly reflected the footsteps of Sydney Carton. About six times a year at most, he exercised the privilege of visiting this house without prior invitation, often spending the entire evening with everyone as he used to. He never came when he reeked of alcohol. And there was one more thing related to Carton that silently echoed, something that throughout the ages every true reverberation quietly continued.
tr: The echoes rarely responded to the footsteps of Sydney Carton. Carton exercised his right to visit uninvited at most five or six times a year, and as he once frequently did, he would spend the entire evening with them. He never went there while intoxicated. There was one more thing whispered about Carton among the echoes, and this had been whispered by all honest echoes for years.
es: Very rarely did the echoes respond to the real steps of Sydney Carton. Half a dozen times a year, at most, he exercised his privilege of showing up at the doctor's house uninvited and taking part in the evening gathering as he had so often done in the past. He never showed up drunk or even half-drunk. But if the echoes of his steps rarely sounded in the little corner of Soho, it was very common to hear the brief and beautiful story that they whispered about him.

en: No man ever really loved a woman, lost her, and knew her with a blameless though an unchanged mind, when she was a wife and a mother, but her children had a strange sympathy with him—an instinctive delicacy of pity for him. What fine hidden sensibilities are touched in such a case, no echoes tell; but it is so, and it was so here. Carton was the first stranger to whom little Lucie held out her chubby arms, and he kept his place with her as she grew. The little boy had spoken of him, almost at the last. “Poor Carton! Kiss him for me!”
vi: The man who truly loves a woman, even if his love is unrequited but remains devoted without resentment, when she becomes a wife and a mother, none of her children will lack extraordinary feelings for him - a subtle compassion instinctively directed towards him. What hidden emotions resonate in such situations? There is no echo to reveal these occurrences, and it is the same with Carton. He was the first stranger to whom little Lucie extended her chubby hands, and he held a place in her life. As for the little boy who passed away, even near the end, he still said, "Poor Carton! Kiss him for me!"
tr: No man could love a woman this much, and even if he lost her, he couldn't remain so innocently and stubbornly attached to her, knowing that she was now a wife and mother, to the extent that even Lucie's children felt a strange sympathy for Carton – perhaps they pitied him with an instinctive sensitivity. No echo could tell what secret emotions created this; but it was so, it was very obvious. The first stranger to whom little Lucie extended her chubby arms was Carton, and he was always by her side as she grew up. Even the little boy, while taking his last breath, was murmuring his name. "Poor Carton! Kiss him for me!"
es: There has never existed a man madly in love with a woman, who has seen and treated her with pure eyes and immaculate thought after she has become a wife and mother. As if her tender little children understood her silent pain, they showed him a singular sympathy... something like a delicate instinct of compassion towards him. The echoes do not speak when these sensitivities, which have their seat in the deepest recesses of the soul, vibrate, but although silent, they whisper. Carton was the first stranger to the house to whom little Lucía extended her chubby arms, and the child, moments before taking his flight to heaven, exclaimed: "Poor Carton! I wish they would give him a kiss for me!"

en: Mr. Stryver shouldered his way through the law, like some great engine forcing itself through turbid water, and dragged his useful friend in his wake, like a boat towed astern. As the boat so favoured is usually in a rough plight, and mostly under water, so, Sydney had a swamped life of it. But, easy and strong custom, unhappily so much easier and stronger in him than any stimulating sense of desert or disgrace, made it the life he was to lead; and he no more thought of emerging from his state of lion’s jackal, than any real jackal may be supposed to think of rising to be a lion. Stryver was rich; had married a florid widow with property and three boys, who had nothing particularly shining about them but the straight hair of their dumpling heads.
vi: Stryver continued to aggressively push forward in the legal field, like a large engine-powered ship cutting through murky waters, dragging his steadfast friend behind like a small boat. As the boats being towed are often those that have met with severe misfortune and mostly end up sinking, Sydney remained submerged in that life. But Sydney's weakness and deeply ingrained habits, unfortunately, were too weak and too deeply ingrained for him to have any desire to abandon them or feel ashamed; he chose that way of life, no longer thinking about escaping the state of being a Jackal to a Lion—unlike a true wild dog that might dream of becoming a mighty lion. Stryver, already wealthy, married a flamboyant widow with assets and three children, three of whom had nothing particularly remarkable except for their straight hair on their round heads.
tr: Mr. Stryver, like a large boat trying to make its way through muddy water, was forging ahead on the path of law, dragging his useful friend in his wake like a dinghy at the stern of the boat. These privileged dinghies generally encounter difficulties, often bobbing up and down in the water, and thus Sydney was living such a sunken life. The indifferent and powerful state within him, even if not pleased, was so much easier and stronger than any kind of unpleasantness and disgrace that Carton could not deviate from the path he was on, and never considered giving up being the jackal to the lion, whereas it was expected that all true jackals would hope to become lions one day. Stryver, on the other hand, had become wealthy; he had married a vigorous widow with a lot of property and three sons, who had no brilliance other than the straight hair shining on their dull heads.
es: Stryver penetrated the domains of law each day with greater vigor, like a powerful ship plowing through turbulent seas, and in his wake, Carton could be seen like a barge being towed. The barge thus favored by the ship that took it in tow faces serious dangers, generally navigates with difficulty, and is almost always waterlogged. Carton also navigated the seas of life, lurching and exposed to capsizing at any moment. However, a deeply ingrained and firm habit, more ingrained and firmer in his heart than any of the stimulants we commonly call the perception of abandonment of misfortune, indicated the course he should follow, and Carton followed it, without ever thinking of leaving the lamentable state he found himself in, without having more aspirations to renounce his role as a jackal to a lion than a flesh-and-blood jackal has ever had to elevate itself to the category of a lion. Stryver was rich. He had married a widow who owned magnificent properties and was the mother of three children, none of whom had been endowed by the hand of nature with exceptional gifts, although they were distinguished by the thick mass of bristly spines that adorned their heads.

en: These three young gentlemen, Mr. Stryver, exuding patronage of the most offensive quality from every pore, had walked before him like three sheep to the quiet corner in Soho, and had offered as pupils to Lucie’s husband: delicately saying “Halloa! here are three lumps of bread-and-cheese towards your matrimonial picnic, Darnay!” The polite rejection of the three lumps of bread-and-cheese had quite bloated Mr. Stryver with indignation, which he afterwards turned to account in the training of the young gentlemen, by directing them to beware of the pride of Beggars, like that tutor-fellow. He was also in the habit of declaiming to Mrs. Stryver, over his full-bodied wine, on the arts Mrs. Darnay had once put in practice to “catch” him, and on the diamond-cut-diamond arts in himself, madam, which had rendered him “not to be caught.” Some of his King’s Bench familiars, who were occasionally parties to the full-bodied wine and the lie, excused him for the latter by saying that he had told it so often, that he believed it himself—which is surely such an incorrigible aggravation of an originally bad offence, as to justify any such offender’s being carried off to some suitably retired spot, and there hanged out of the way.
