vi: From every pore exuded the most obnoxious air of superiority, Stryver had once made these three sons walk ahead of him like three sheep to the quiet corner of Soho, and he had suggested to Lucie's husband to take them as his students. Stryver had said very tactfully: "Hey friend! Here are three pieces of cheese bread I bring to your marriage adventure, Darnay!" The fact that these three pieces of cheese bread were politely declined made Stryver unbearably angry, but later it became a useful lesson for him to teach these three sons to beware of the pride of beggars, just like that fellow countryman tutor. When his belly was full of wine, Stryver would also often speak eloquently about Lucie, about the tricks she had used to "trap" him, and about his own counter-tricks to "avoid being trapped". Stryver's colleagues at the Supreme Court would occasionally gather to drink their fill and listen to those tall tales, but no one believed them; they overlooked the fabrications because they thought Stryver repeated them so often that he himself came to believe them - if anyone said this and Stryver heard it, the fault of that person would only become more grievous and irredeemable, with the only recourse being to drag the offender to some suitable secluded spot and hang them to death as deserved.
tr: Mr. Stryver, in his most unpleasantly domineering manner, herded these three young gentlemen like sheep to the corner in Soho and, after handing them over to Lucie's husband as students, said, "Hello! Their flesh is yours, their bones are mine. If you want to use these three pieces of flesh while going on a family picnic, Darnay!" The polite refusal of this offer of three pieces of flesh drove Mr. Stryver mad, and he decided to educate the young gentlemen himself. He first advised them to steer clear of the arrogance of Beggars, like this private tutor. On nights when he drank too much, he would sit across from Mr. Stryver and loudly recount the traps Ms. Darnay had set to "catch" him and the magnificent tactics he had used to avoid being "caught." His colleagues from the bar who attended these boozy and boastful gatherings would tolerate him, noting that Stryver had begun to believe his own lies – it was such an incorrigible situation that everyone avoided him as much as possible.
es: Stryver, exuding protection from every pore of his body, had presented these three little gentlemen in the peaceful house in Soho, and offered them as disciples to Lucie's husband. With unparalleled delicacy, said the brilliant lawyer when making the presentation: —I have the pleasure of contributing these three pieces of bread to your wedding lunch, Darnay. With very courteous words, Darnay declined those three pieces of bread, raising such a tempest of indignation in Stryver's noble chest, that from then on he made a special effort to ensure that in the souls of the little gentlemen in question, the idea of treating beggars like that famished teacher, whose only patrimony was pride, would be born and deeply rooted with the utmost disdain. He also had the good habit of enumerating and explaining to his wife the arts that Lucie Manette once used to "catch" him, and the diamond wall he opposed to her artifices, thanks to which he was an "uncatchable" fish for that fisherwoman. Some of his colleagues, who used to be his companions in his bacchanalian excesses, excused him by saying that he had repeated the lie in question so many times that he himself already believed it as a matter of faith... which, far from excusing an offense, aggravates it enough to justify the offended party taking the offender to a secluded and convenient place, and nicely and without annoying procedures, leaving him hanging from any tree with a noose.

en: These were among the echoes to which Lucie, sometimes pensive, sometimes amused and laughing, listened in the echoing corner, until her little daughter was six years old. How near to her heart the echoes of her child’s tread came, and those of her own dear father’s, always active and self-possessed, and those of her dear husband’s, need not be told. Nor, how the lightest echo of their united home, directed by herself with such a wise and elegant thrift that it was more abundant than any waste, was music to her. Nor, how there were echoes all about her, sweet in her ears, of the many times her father had told her that he found her more devoted to him married (if that could be) than single, and of the many times her husband had said to her that no cares and duties seemed to divide her love for him or her help to him, and asked her “What is the magic secret, my darling, of your being everything to all of us, as if there were only one of us, yet never seeming to be hurried, or to have too much to do?”
vi: Those were the echoes that Lucie, sometimes sad, sometimes joyful, heard at the corner of this echoing street until her little daughter turned six years old. Oh, how affectionate were the echoes of the child's footsteps, along with the father's - always brisk and calm - and needless to say, the footsteps of the loving husband. It goes without saying that every gentle echo in this close-knit family, thanks to Lucie's skillful and clever management making everything prosperous, was sweet music to her ears. It also goes without saying how soothing were the echoes around Lucie when countless times Mr. Manette told her that although his daughter was married (if that were indeed the case), she was even more devoted to her father than when she was single, and when countless times Darnay told her that it seemed her filial piety did not divide the love or support she gave to her husband, he asked her: "My dear, what magic do you possess that you manage everything for everyone as if the whole family were just one person, yet you never seem hurried or busy?"
tr: All these were among the echoes that Lucie sometimes listened to thoughtfully, sometimes with cheerful laughter, in her corner until her little girl turned six. There is no need to mention how the pitter-patter of her child's footsteps, the always lively and confident steps of her father, and the footsteps of her beloved husband warmed her heart. Moreover, every little echo in their peaceful home, which Lucie managed with great delicacy and thrift, where nothing was wasted, sounded like a beautiful melody to the young woman's ears. Especially when her father told her that he felt even more connected to her after she got married, and her husband said that none of her attentions and duties diminished her love and support for him, and asked her, "How do you manage to be everything to all of us? You attend to all our needs but never seem rushed or act as if you have too much to do?" these words sweetly echoed in Lucie's ears.
es: Such were, among others, the echoes that Lucía, sometimes pensive and other times amused and even laughing out loud, heard from the peaceful corner of Soho. The girl turned six years old. The echoes of her steps along the paths of life resonated deep in her mother's heart, mingled with the equally delightful steps of the doctor, always calm and always active, and with those of her husband, always tender and always in love. In Lucía's ears, the gentle echoes of that home, managed by herself, sounded like divine music, a home where opulence did not reign, but abundance did. The echoes of what her father so often said, namely, that he found her more affectionate, if possible, married than when she was single, also sounded with exquisite sweetness.

en: But, there were other echoes, from a distance, that rumbled menacingly in the corner all through this space of time. And it was now, about little Lucie’s sixth birthday, that they began to have an awful sound, as of a great storm in France with a dreadful sea rising.
vi: But there were other echoes from afar that roared and threatened this corner of the street during that time. Now, as little Lucie turned six, those echoes began to resonate fearfully like the terrifying stormy seas echoing from France.
tr: But all this time, there were also voices echoing in the distance and rumbling menacingly in the corner. During these days when little Lucie's birthday was being celebrated, these voices began to emerge terribly, as if a great storm had broken out in France and the seas had risen tremendously.
es: Other echoes were also sounding, in the distance, yes, but not so far as to be unheard, echoes that roared menacingly over the quiet corner. It was around the date of Lucita's sixth birthday when its thunderous voice rose to the clouds, a voice like a terrible storm unleashed in France.

en: On a night in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine, Mr. Lorry came in late, from Tellson’s, and sat himself down by Lucie and her husband in the dark window. It was a hot, wild night, and they were all three reminded of the old Sunday night when they had looked at the lightning from the same place.
vi: On an evening in mid-July 1789, Mr. Lorry from Tellson's Bank came by late and sat down beside Lucie and her husband by the darkened window. That night was hot and thunderous, and all three of them remembered a past Sunday night when they also sat here watching the lightning tear through the sky.
tr: One night in mid-July of the year 1789, Mr. Lorry came from Tellson's late and sat down beside Lucie and her husband in front of the dark window. It was a hot and sultry night, and all three of them remembered that past Sunday night when they had watched the lightning strike in the same place.
es: One night in the month of July in the year seventeen eighty-nine, Lorry appeared and took a seat by the window between Lucía and her husband. It was a stormy night with a scorching breath that reminded the three of that other night when they were watching the lightning from that same window.

en: “I began to think,” said Mr. Lorry, pushing his brown wig back, “that I should have to pass the night at Tellson’s. We have been so full of business all day, that we have not known what to do first, or which way to turn. There is such an uneasiness in Paris, that we have actually a run of confidence upon us! Our customers over there, seem not to be able to confide their property to us fast enough. There is positively a mania among some of them for sending it to England.”
vi: Mr. Lorry said while pushing back his brown wig: − I'm beginning to think about having to sleep over at Tellson's. The work there is so overwhelming that no one knows what to do first or how to manage it. There is such great unrest in Paris that people are rushing to deposit money into this bank! Clients over there are entrusting their assets to Tellson's so massively that it can't handle it. Clearly, many of them have gone mad trying to transfer their wealth to England.
tr: "I suppose," said Mr. Lorry, pushing his brown wig back, "I will have to spend the night at Tellson's. We had so much work all day that we didn't know where to start or how to do it. Paris is in a tremendous state of unrest, and all the clients are flocking to us! Our clients there are bewildered about how to transfer their assets to us. Some of them are struggling like mad to send them to England."
es: —I am beginning to think—said Lorry, pushing his wig back to his nape—that I must have spent the whole night at the Bank. Today, such an unbridled storm of business has rained down upon us that we haven't known where to start or where to finish. Distrust is spreading in Paris to such an extent that confidence is coming to us like a rushing torrent. Our clients there can't wait to entrust us with their goods and properties. Nothing, nothing! It's a true mania of sending everything to England that has suddenly seized them!

en: “That has a bad look,” said Darnay—
vi: − That's worrisome - Darnay said.
tr: "This is not at all pleasant," said Darnay.
es: —What in my opinion is a very bad sign—observed Darnay.

en: “A bad look, you say, my dear Darnay? Yes, but we don’t know what reason there is in it. People are so unreasonable! Some of us at Tellson’s are getting old, and we really can’t be troubled out of the ordinary course without due occasion.”
vi: − You said it's worrisome, didn't you, Darnay? That's right, but I don't know why. People are so unreasonable! Many of us at Tellson are already old, and we really can't be bothered with unusual matters without a good reason.
tr: "Isn't it quite unpleasant, dear Darnay?" "Yes, but we don't know the reason for it." "People are acting irrationally!" "Some of the people at Tellson's have aged like me, so we can't just change the bank's operations for no reason.""
es: —A bad sign, my dear Darnay? Perhaps, if it obeyed justified reasons; but the world is so irrational! The only positive thing so far is that they are overwhelming us with work, surely without reason, without consideration that at Tellson's Bank there are many of us who are already old.

en: “Still,” said Darnay, “you know how gloomy and threatening the sky is.”
vi: − Anyway, you know the situation is worryingly unstable, Darnay said.
tr: "That's true," said Darnay, "you can see how gloomy and dark the weather is."
es: —However—objected Darnay,—you know perfectly well that there is a closure on the horizon, that the clouds have been condensing for a long time, threatening a storm.

en: “I know that, to be sure,” assented Mr. Lorry, trying to persuade himself that his sweet temper was soured, and that he grumbled, “but I am determined to be peevish after my long day’s botheration. Where is Manette?”
vi: − Of course, - Mr. Lorry agreed, trying to convince himself that he was just in a bad mood and merely complaining to get it over with. - But after a long troublesome day, I'm irritated and want to grumble. Where is Mr. Manette? −
tr: "Of course I see," Mr. Lorry immediately conceded, trying to convince himself that he was no longer in his usual calm state and was complaining. "But after such a terrible and long day, I'm also quite annoyed now. Where is Manette?"
es: —I know... of course I know—replied Lorry, trying to persuade himself of the need to appear a little grumpy and discontented;—so much so, that I come resolved to quarrel with anyone to make up for the fatigues of this devilish day. Where is Manette?

en: “Here he is,” said the Doctor, entering the dark room at the moment.
vi: Here I am, - said the doctor, entering the dark living room at that very moment.
tr: At that moment, the Doctor who entered the dark room called out, "I'm here."
es: —Here is a piece—replied the doctor, entering the room at that moment.

en: “I am quite glad you are at home; for these hurries and forebodings by which I have been surrounded all day long, have made me nervous without reason. You are not going out, I hope?”
vi: − I'm so glad you're home; because all these busy and worrying matters have surrounded me all day, making me unreasonably angry. Surely you haven't gone out for a walk, have you?
tr: "I am very glad that you are home; because my nerves have been unnecessarily frayed all day by the hustle and premonitions surrounding me. I hope you are not going out."
es: —I'm glad you're home, as today's rush and premonitions have made me nervous for no reason or cause. I suppose you don't plan on going out, do you?

en: “No; I am going to play backgammon with you, if you like,” said the Doctor.
vi: − No, I was thinking of playing chess with you, if you like, - the doctor said.
tr: "No; if you want, we can play backgammon together," said the Doctor.
es: —No; if you want, we can play a game of backgammon.

en: “I don’t think I do like, if I may speak my mind. I am not fit to be pitted against you to-night. Is the teaboard still there, Lucie? I can’t see.”
vi: − I think I don't like it, to be frank. I can't compete with you tonight. Is there still tea, Lucie? I don't see any. −
tr: "To tell the truth, I don't really want to, I guess. I don't have the strength to argue with you tonight. Is the tea tray still here, Lucie? I couldn't see it."
es: —I prefer not to play, as tonight I am not in the mood to contend with you. Is the board here, Lucía? You have this room in darkness and, since I am not a cat, I see nothing.

en: “Of course, it has been kept for you.”
vi: Of course there is, I saved some for you. −
tr: "Of course, I waited for you.""
es: —Here it is, waiting for you.

en: “Thank ye, my dear. The precious child is safe in bed?”
vi: Thank you, my dear. And my little darling is already in a warm, cozy bed, right? −
tr: "Thank you, my dear. Did the sweet girl go to bed?"
es: —Thank you very much, dear. Is the precious one in her little bed?

en: “And sleeping soundly.”
vi: And she is sleeping soundly.
tr: "Yes, sleeping soundly.""
es: —Sleeping like a log.

en: “That’s right; all safe and well! I don’t know why anything should be otherwise than safe and well here, thank God; but I have been so put out all day, and I am not as young as I was! My tea, my dear! Thank ye. Now, come and take your place in the circle, and let us sit quiet, and hear the echoes about which you have your theory.”
vi: − Good; everything is peaceful! I see no reason why this place shouldn't be peaceful, thank God; but I'm exhausted today, not as strong as I used to be! Here's the tea, you're so thoughtful! Thank you. Now, come sit around this table with us, let's sit quietly and listen to the echoes that you hypothesized about.
tr: "I'm fine, everything is alright! Although, thank God, everything is always alright here of course; but today my nerves are very frayed, well, I'm not as young as I used to be anymore! Oh, is that my tea, dear! Thank you. Now you come join us too, and let's all sit quietly together and listen to those echoes you've been creating various theories about."
es: —Very well... very well! The truth is that I don't know why everything shouldn't go very well here... thank God! But of course: they have worn me out so much today... And then, I'm not as young as you all are... as I was thirty years ago...! My little cup of tea... That's right, Lucía... Thank you! Now, make some room for me, I will sit in the circle, and I will try to listen to those echoes about which you have very peculiar theories.

en: “Not a theory; it was a fancy.”
vi: − What hypothesis; it's just imagination.
tr: "It wasn't actually a theory; just an idea."
es: —They are not theories, but whims of my imagination.

en: “A fancy, then, my wise pet,” said Mr. Lorry, patting her hand. “They are very numerous and very loud, though, are they not? Only hear them!”
vi: − Well, imagination, my dear, - Mr. Lorry said while gently patting Lucie's hand. - These echoes are very many and very loud, aren't they? Just listen and you'll see!
tr: "Well, let it be a thought then, my clever girl," said Mr. Lorry, gently tapping Lucie's hand with affection. "How loud and high their voices are, aren't they? Just listen!"
es: —Perfectly, dear; we will call them whims—replied Lorry. They are numerous, varied, and thunderous, aren't they? Of course! You just have to pay attention!

en: Headlong, mad, and dangerous footsteps to force their way into anybody’s life, footsteps not easily made clean again if once stained red, the footsteps raging in Saint Antoine afar off, as the little circle sat in the dark London window.
vi: Footsteps rushing in, mad, dangerous, intruding into anyone's life, footsteps not easily washed clean once stained with blood, the furious footsteps in distant Saint Antoine, while everyone sits around the dark window in London.
tr: As this small community sat in front of a dark window in London, hurried, frantic, and dangerous steps advanced with great determination as if they would destroy anything in their path, and once these steps approaching from beyond St. Antoine were stained with madness and fury, they could not be easily cleansed.
es: Hurried steps, hard steps, dangerous steps that violently penetrate someone's vital center, and once they have been stained red, they are difficult to clean, echoed in the distance, in the San Antonio neighborhood of Paris, and their resounding echoes reached the quiet corner of Soho in London.

en: Saint Antoine had been, that morning, a vast dusky mass of scarecrows heaving to and fro, with frequent gleams of light above the billowy heads, where steel blades and bayonets shone in the sun. A tremendous roar arose from the throat of Saint Antoine, and a forest of naked arms struggled in the air like shrivelled branches of trees in a winter wind: all the fingers convulsively clutching at every weapon or semblance of a weapon that was thrown up from the depths below, no matter how far off.
vi: That same morning in Saint Antoine, a forest of ragged, dark-skinned people like scarecrows was bustling about, and the sunlight reflecting off this wave of heads glinted with the steel of bayonets and swords. A terrifying roar had erupted from the throat of Saint Antoine, and a sea of bare arms rose to the sky like withered branches in the winter wind, every finger fiercely gripping any weapon or anything that could be used as a weapon from any depth.
tr: That morning, St. Antoine was like a vast and dark sea of railings swaying back and forth, and the light of steel swords and bayonets glistening under the sun occasionally struck the tops of the heads moving up and down. Then a tremendous roar rose from the narrow passage of St. Antoine; a forest of bare arms, like tree branches dried by winter winds, were raised to the sky. All fingers, no matter how far they had been thrown from, were striving to grab whatever weapon or weapon-like object was hurled at them.
es: That morning, San Antonio had been a field covered by a vast and stern mass of shirtless people who moved impatiently, adorned with steel sabers and bayonets on whose cold surfaces the sun's rays broke. The jaws of San Antonio let out tremendous screams while an immense forest of bare arms waved in the air, resembling branches of trees whipped by a terrible gale. There was no hand that did not wield some weapon or semblance of a weapon; there was no window that did not throw instruments of slaughter to the mobs.

en: Who gave them out, whence they last came, where they began, through what agency they crookedly quivered and jerked, scores at a time, over the heads of the crowd, like a kind of lightning, no eye in the throng could have told; but, muskets were being distributed—so were cartridges, powder, and ball, bars of iron and wood, knives, axes, pikes, every weapon that distracted ingenuity could discover or devise. People who could lay hold of nothing else, set themselves with bleeding hands to force stones and bricks out of their places in walls. Every pulse and heart in Saint Antoine was on high-fever strain and at high-fever heat. Every living creature there held life as of no account, and was demented with a passionate readiness to sacrifice it.
vi: Who distributed the weapons, where they came from, through what intermediaries, no one in that sea of people knew; they only saw the weapons, in waves, twenty at a time, being thrown out and then suddenly raised above the crowd like lightning; not only muskets - there were also ammunition, gunpowder, lead bullets, iron bars, wooden sticks, knives, axes, pickaxes, every kind of weapon that a frenzied mind could find or create. Those who couldn't grab anything to use as a weapon used their bloody hands to pry bricks and stones from the walls. Every pulse and heartbeat in Saint Antoine was throbbing, burning hot. Everyone here regarded their lives as nothing, and were madly ready to sacrifice them.
tr: Who was giving these weapons, where were they coming from, how had everything started, how had all these crooked and trembling weapons, standing like a lightning bolt above the crowd, reached them, there was no one among them who could answer these questions; on the other hand, rifles were being distributed continuously – and of course cartridges, gunpowder, cannonballs, iron rods, clubs, knives, axes, spears, and every kind of weapon imaginable and useful were being passed from hand to hand. Those who were not closing anything were busy tearing stones and bricks from the walls with bloody hands. Every heart and pulse in St. Antoine was beating wildly. Every living being there was disregarding their life, madly eager to sacrifice themselves with ambitious impatience.
es: Where they came from, who provided them, where the rain of those elements of destruction that crossed over their heads like brilliant rays began, no one could have said; but it is certain that invisible hands distributed muskets, cartridges, gunpowder, bullets, iron bars, wooden beams, knives, axes, spears, pikes. Those who could not procure anything else, drove their bloodied fingers into the joints of the stones or bricks and tore blocks or cobblestones from the walls. There was no pulse in San Antonio that did not beat erratically, no heart that did not crave blood, no living being that valued life in any way, nor any person who did not cry out to sacrifice it.

en: As a whirlpool of boiling waters has a centre point, so, all this raging circled round Defarge’s wine-shop, and every human drop in the caldron had a tendency to be sucked towards the vortex where Defarge himself, already begrimed with gunpowder and sweat, issued orders, issued arms, thrust this man back, dragged this man forward, disarmed one to arm another, laboured and strove in the thickest of the uproar.
vi: Just as all boiling, swirling waters converge towards the center, all the fierce upheavals here revolve around Defarge's tavern, and everyone immersed in this cauldron of fire is drawn into the most furious vortex, where Defarge himself, smeared with sweat and gunpowder, is exerting himself to give orders, distribute weapons, push one person back, pull another forward, and take guns from one to give to another.
tr: Just as every boiling whirlpool has a center, the center of this frothing crowd was Defarge's wine shop, and every drop boiling in the cauldron was eager to be drawn into the vortex where Defarge was already steeped in gunpowder and sweat, issuing commands, distributing weapons, pushing one person and pulling another, taking a weapon from one and giving it to another, and toiling amidst all this intense chaos.
es: Just as all whirlpools of boiling waters have their central point, so that choppy sea roared around Defarge's tavern, all the human drops falling into the cauldron showed a determined tendency to approach the vortex where Defarge himself, already blackened by gunpowder and sweat, dictated orders, handed out weapons, forced this man to retreat and dragged that one towards him, disarmed one to arm another with his weapons, and worked and moved and multiplied in the center of the storm.

en: “Keep near to me, Jacques Three,” cried Defarge; “and do you, Jacques One and Two, separate and put yourselves at the head of as many of these patriots as you can. Where is my wife?”
vi: − Stand close to me, Jacques Three, - Defarge shouted, - and you, Jacques One and Two, split up and lead those patriots, as many as possible. Have you seen my wife? −
tr: "Stand close to me, Jacques Three," shouted Defarge; "and you, Jacques One and Jacques Two, go immediately and take command of as many patriots as you can. Where is my wife?"
es: —Don't leave my side, Santiago Tercero!—roared Defarge.—You, Santiago Primero and Santiago Segundo, lead other groups of patriots! Where is my wife?

en: “Eh, well! Here you see me!” said madame, composed as ever, but not knitting to-day. Madame’s resolute right hand was occupied with an axe, in place of the usual softer implements, and in her girdle were a pistol and a cruel knife.
vi: Here! I’m here! - her voice was as calm as ever, but today she was not knitting. Instead of holding her usual soft tools, her right hand was gripping an axe, and tucked into her belt were a pistol and a formidable knife. −
tr: "Well, here I am!" said the madam with her usual calmness, but today she wasn't knitting. In the madam's determined right hand, instead of her usual and relatively soft tools, there was an axe, and on her belt, there was a gun and a terrifying knife.
es: —Here I am!—replied Madame Defarge, as composed as ever, but without knitting. The sweet lady wielded an axe instead of needles, and at her waist she displayed two unique ornaments: a pistol and a long knife.

en: “Where do you go, my wife?”
vi: Where are you planning to go? −
tr: "Where are you going?""
es: —Where are you, my little woman?—asked Defarge.

en: “I go,” said madame, “with you at present. You shall see me at the head of women, by-and-bye.”
vi: Right now, I’m going with you, - she said. - You will soon see me leading the women.
tr: "I will come with you," said the lady, "and later you will see me leading the women.""
es: —At this moment with you: in an instant, at the head of the women—replied the innkeeper.

en: “Come, then!” cried Defarge, in a resounding voice. “Patriots and friends, we are ready! The Bastille!”
vi: − Then let's go! - Defarge shouted loudly, his voice booming. - Patriots and friends, get ready! The Bastille!
tr: "Then let's go!" shouted Defarge, with his ringing voice. "Patriots, my friends, we are ready now! To the Bastille!"
es: —Forward, then!—shouted Defarge with a thunderous voice. —Patriots...! My friends...! To the Bastille!

en: With a roar that sounded as if all the breath in France had been shaped into the detested word, the living sea rose, wave on wave, depth on depth, and overflowed the city to that point. Alarm-bells ringing, drums beating, the sea raging and thundering on its new beach, the attack began.
vi: With a roar as if every breath in France had crystallized into that dreadful name, the sea of people surged, wave after wave, layer after layer, flooding into the city and heading towards that place. The alarm bells rang out, drums beat incessantly, the raging sea roared, crashing waves onto a new shore, the attack began.
tr: As if all the breaths in France had uttered this disgusting word, a great noise erupted, and the living sea surged wave upon wave, piling on top of each other and furiously carrying the entire city to that point. As the bells rang, the drums beat, and the sea swelled with rage, pounding its new shore, the attack began.
es: As if this last hateful word had given shape to all the breaths of France, a terrifying roar tore through the air, that living sea swelled, its depths churned, its waves rose and engulfed the entire city. All the alarm bells rang, all the drums thundered, the sea bellowed and roared, and the attack began.

en: Deep ditches, double drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great towers, cannon, muskets, fire and smoke. Through the fire and through the smoke—in the fire and in the smoke, for the sea cast him up against a cannon, and on the instant he became a cannonier—Defarge of the wine-shop worked like a manful soldier, Two fierce hours.
vi: Crossing deep moats, rushing over suspension bridges, overcoming massive stone walls, surging towards eight large towers, cannons and muskets exchanging fire, fire and smoke enveloping everything. Through the smoke and fire - in the thick haze of smoke and fire, the sea of people lifted Defarge onto the cannon and he immediately became a gunner. The innkeeper fired continuously like a valiant warrior. For two hours straight.
tr: Deep trenches, two suspension bridges, huge stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, rifles, fire, and smoke. The owner of the wine shop, Defarge, fought bravely like a valiant soldier for two fierce hours amidst all that fire and smoke – the sea had carried him through the fire and smoke to the cannon, and as soon as he took charge, he became an artilleryman.
es: Deep moats, double drawbridges, massive stone walls, eight huge towers, cannons, muskets, fire and smoke... No matter! Amid seas of fire and clouds of thick smoke... floating through the smoke and riding on the fire, for the sea threw him against a cannon and immediately turned him into a terrible artilleryman..., Defarge, the tavern keeper, worked like an infernal soldier for two hours.

en: Deep ditch, single drawbridge, massive stone walls, eight great towers, cannon, muskets, fire and smoke. One drawbridge down! “Work, comrades all, work! Work, Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques One Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Five-and-Twenty Thousand; in the name of all the Angels or the Devils—which you prefer—work!” Thus Defarge of the wine-shop, still at his gun, which had long grown hot.
vi: Deep trenches, suspension bridges, massive stone walls, heading towards eight large towers, cannons, muskets, smoke and fire. One suspension bridge has been blown up! − Take action, all of you, take action! Take action, Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques One Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Twenty-Five Thousand; in the name of all Angels and Demons... Any demon or god will do... Take action! - Tavern owner Defarge kept firing, the cannon had heated up. − Follow me, sisters! -
tr: A deep trench, a suspension bridge, huge stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, rifles, fire, and smoke. One of the bridges came down! "Come on, friends, come on! Come on Jacques One, Jacques Two, Jacques Thousand, Jacques Two Thousand, Jacques Twenty-five Thousand; all Angels and Demons –whichever you choose– come on!" The wine shop owner Defarge never left the side of the cannon that had become quite hot.
es: A wide and deep moat, a single drawbridge, robust stone walls, eight large towers, cannons, muskets, fire and smoke... A drawbridge falls... «Forward, comrades, forward! Forward, Santiago First! Forward, Santiago Second! Forward, Santiago Thousand, forward, Santiago Two Thousand, Santiago Five Thousand, Santiago Twenty Thousand...! By all the angels in Heaven... by all the demons in hell... as you wish... forward!» Such are the cries that come from the throat of the innkeeper, turned hours before into a terrible gunner, the innkeeper, who gives no rest to his already reddened cannon!

en: “To me, women!” cried madame his wife. “What! We can kill as well as the men when the place is taken!” And to her, with a shrill thirsty cry, trooping women variously armed, but all armed alike in hunger and revenge.
vi: His wife shouted. - Come on! We women are just as good at killing as men when it comes to it! - And answering her was a deafening, ravenous scream from a forest of women armed with various weapons but all sharing the same hunger and hatred.
tr: "Come closer, women!" his wife shouted. "What are you saying? After the Bastille is taken, can we kill like men too?" Though their hands were filled with various weapons, driven by hunger and revenge, the women, who were the only weapon, screamed with their shrill voices and all their might.
es: “All the women, to me!”—his wife was shouting in the meantime. “Well, why not...! Can't we kill just like they do, once the town falls into our hands?” And towards her ran herds of women, hoarse, bellowing, armed with different weapons, but all animated by the same spirit: the spirit of vengeance!

en: Cannon, muskets, fire and smoke; but, still the deep ditch, the single drawbridge, the massive stone walls, and the eight great towers. Slight displacements of the raging sea, made by the falling wounded. Flashing weapons, blazing torches, smoking waggonloads of wet straw, hard work at neighbouring barricades in all directions, shrieks, volleys, execrations, bravery without stint, boom smash and rattle, and the furious sounding of the living sea; but, still the deep ditch, and the single drawbridge, and the massive stone walls, and the eight great towers, and still Defarge of the wine-shop at his gun, grown doubly hot by the service of Four fierce hours.
vi: Artillery, fire tubes, smoke and flames; but still not past the deep moat, the hanging bridge, the massive stone walls, and not yet to the eight large towers. The raging sea transformed by the waves of fallen casualties. Weapons gleaming, torches blazing brightly, convoys of carts carrying wet straw, layers upon layers of people from all directions rushing towards the nearby obstacles, shouts, gunfire, curses, death as light as a feather, thunderous destruction, the sea of people roaring and crashing forward; but still not past the deep moat, the hanging bridge, the massive stone walls, and not yet to the eight large towers, and the tavern keeper Defarge still beside the cannon, hot from four hours of fierce firepower.
tr: Cannon, rifle, fire and smoke; but still, there were deep trenches, a solitary suspension bridge, massive stone walls, and eight large towers before them. Those who were wounded and fell to the ground caused small shifts in the swelling sea. Exploding weapons, burning torches, carts loaded with wet straw emitting smoke, frantic activity in every direction from nearby trenches, screams, volleys of gunfire, curses, relentless courage, the hum, the clamor, and the angry sound of the living sea; but still, there were deep trenches, a solitary suspension bridge, massive stone walls, eight large towers, and the wine shop owner Defarge still at the cannon, thoroughly enraged after four fierce hours.
es: Cannons, muskets, fire, and smoke; but there remained a deep moat, a drawbridge, robust stone walls, and eight large towers. The wounded who fell left some gaps in the boiling sea. Weapons gleam, torches burn, carts loaded with dampened straw emit clouds of smoke, barricades spring up everywhere, fierce howls resound, repeated volleys thunder through the space, dreadful curses pierce the ears, everyone displays bravery, the living sea roars with redoubled fury... and still there remains the deep moat, and the drawbridge, and the robust stone walls, and the eight large towers, and Defarge, the innkeeper, continues at the cannon, heated to a white-hot glow as a result of four uninterrupted hours of service!

en: A white flag from within the fortress, and a parley—this dimly perceptible through the raging storm, nothing audible in it—suddenly the sea rose immeasurably wider and higher, and swept Defarge of the wine-shop over the lowered drawbridge, past the massive stone outer walls, in among the eight great towers surrendered!
vi: A white flag was raised from within the fortress, then negotiations - a vague affair in this frenzied storm, no one could hear anything - suddenly the sea of people surged higher and higher, wider and wider, and swept the innkeeper Defarge onto a lowered drawbridge, crossing the massive outer stone walls, and into the midst of the eight towers that had just fallen!
tr: After the white flag was raised at the castle and the negotiations began – but in this furious storm, nothing could be seen or heard properly – the sea suddenly swelled and foamed incredibly, and hurled Defarge over the drawbridge, delivering him among the eight large towers over the massive stone walls!
es: Within the fortress, a white flag appears... the waves roar more than ever, they swell, rise to the clouds, and drag Defarge the innkeeper, throwing him beyond the drawbridge, beyond the sturdy stone walls, among the eight great towers.

en: So resistless was the force of the ocean bearing him on, that even to draw his breath or turn his head was as impracticable as if he had been struggling in the surf at the South Sea, until he was landed in the outer courtyard of the Bastille. There, against an angle of a wall, he made a struggle to look about him. Jacques Three was nearly at his side; Madame Defarge, still heading some of her women, was visible in the inner distance, and her knife was in her hand. Everywhere was tumult, exultation, deafening and maniacal bewilderment, astounding noise, yet furious dumb-show.
vi: That sea of people pushed him forward irresistibly, he couldn't even catch his breath or look back, as if he were struggling in the fierce waves of the Southern Sea, until he was driven to the forecourt of the Bastille prison. There, leaning against the corner of the wall, he strained to look around. Jacques Three was nearby; the silhouette of Madame Defarge, still commanding her group of women, appeared far inside, a knife gleaming in her hand. Everywhere was chaotic, jubilant, with deafening madness, no one could hear anyone else and everyone gestured wildly like a brutal pantomime.
tr: The power of the ocean that hurled him there was so irresistible that, until he reached the outer courtyard of the Bastille, it was impossible to breathe or turn his head as if he were struggling with the waves in the South Sea. When he arrived, he tried to look around at the base of the wall. Jacques Three was right beside him; Madame Defarge, who still led the women, was within sight with a knife in her hand. Everywhere there was. chaos, joy, deafening and mad frenzy, astonishing noise, and despite everything, an angry pantomime.
es: The force of the ocean that dragged him was so irresistible that even taking a breath, even turning his head, was as impracticable for him as if he were struggling against the undertow of the South Sea, until he found himself in the inner courtyard of the Bastille. There, leaning against an angle of the wall, he tried to look around. Next to him was Santiago Tercero, and a short distance away he saw his wife, leading the women and brandishing a knife. Everything was tumult, all joy, deafening and maniacal astonishment, noises, furious drum rolls.

en: “The Prisoners!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Prisoners!"
es: —The prisoners!

en: “The Records!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Records!"
es: —The records!

en: “The secret cells!”
vi: − Prisoner! − Files! − Secret cell!
tr: "Secret cells!"
es: —The records!

en: “The instruments of torture!”
vi: − Torture instruments!
tr: "Torture devices!"
es: —The instruments of torture!

en: “The Prisoners!”
vi: − Prisoner!
tr: "Prisoners!"
es: —The prisoners!

en: Of all these cries, and ten thousand incoherences, “The Prisoners!” was the cry most taken up by the sea that rushed in, as if there were an eternity of people, as well as of time and space. When the foremost billows rolled past, bearing the prison officers with them, and threatening them all with instant death if any secret nook remained undisclosed, Defarge laid his strong hand on the breast of one of these men—a man with a grey head, who had a lighted torch in his hand—separated him from the rest, and got him between himself and the wall.
vi: Among those shouts and the countless indistinct clamors, "Prisoner!" was the loudest roar carried by the sea of people, echoing, continuing seemingly endlessly. When the first waves of people surged through, dragging along the prison officials, threatening to kill them immediately if they did not reveal any secret corners, Defarge forcefully grabbed the neck of a jailer - a gray-haired man holding a burning torch - pulled him out, pushed him against the wall, and then stood blocking his way.
tr: Amidst all these screams and tens of thousands of contradictions, the most heard scream in the sea that flowed inside like a human flood as infinite as time and space was "Prisoners!" When the foremost waves dragged the guards in front of them and threatened them with death to ensure that no hidden corner remained unopened, Defarge placed his hand on the chest of one of these men – a gray-haired man holding a torch – and separated him from the others, pinning him between the wall and himself.
es: Of all these shouts, and of ten thousand incoherencies of the sort, the one most repeated by that raging sea was "The prisoners!". When the first waves penetrated, dragging the officers of the fortress ahead of them and threatening them with immediate death if they left a single hiding place unrevealed, Defarge grabbed one of them with his powerful claw, a gray-haired man who was holding a lit torch, separated him from the others, and said to him:

en: “Show me the North Tower!” said Defarge. “Quick!”
vi: − Show the way to the North Tower! - Defarge said. - Hurry up! − I will show you right away if you go with me, - the man replied.
tr: "Show me the North Tower!" said Defarge. "Quick!"
es: —Show me the North Tower... quickly!

en: “I will faithfully,” replied the man, “if you will come with me. But there is no one there.”
vi: - But there is no one there.
tr: "Of course, I'll show you," the man replied, "come with me. But there's no one there."
es: —I will do it with great pleasure, if you want—replied the man—but there is no one in there.

en: “What is the meaning of One Hundred and Five, North Tower?” asked Defarge. “Quick!”
vi: − One Hundred and Five, what does the North Tower mean? - Defarge asked. - Speak quickly. −
tr: "What is the meaning of the One Hundred and Five North Tower?" asked Defarge. "Quickly, tell me!"
es: —What does One Hundred and Five, North Tower mean?—asked Defarge—Answer... quickly!

en: “The meaning, monsieur?”
vi: What do you mean, sir? −
tr: "Did you ask for the meaning, monsieur?"
es: —What does it mean, sir?

en: “Does it mean a captive, or a place of captivity? Or do you mean that I shall strike you dead?”
vi: Is it a prisoner or a cell? Or do you want me to punch you to death!
tr: "Is this a prisoner or a cell? Or does it mean I can kill you right here and now?"
es: —Does it mean a captive or a dungeon to imprison captives? Answer!

en: “Kill him!” croaked Jacques Three, who had come close up.
vi: − Kill him! - Jacques Three screamed, he had just approached.
tr: Jacques Three, who approached them, shouted in a hoarse voice, "Kill him!"
es: Do you want me to kill you like a dog? "Kill him!" shouted Santiago Tercero.

en: “Monsieur, it is a cell.”
vi: − Sir, it is a cell.
tr: "Monsieur, that is a cell."
es: —It's a cell, sir.

en: “Show it me!”
vi: − Take me there! −
tr: "Show me that place!"
es: —Show it to me.

en: “Pass this way, then.”
vi: Then go this way.
tr: "Let's go this way then."
es: —This way, sir.

en: Jacques Three, with his usual craving on him, and evidently disappointed by the dialogue taking a turn that did not seem to promise bloodshed, held by Defarge’s arm as he held by the turnkey’s. Their three heads had been close together during this brief discourse, and it had been as much as they could do to hear one another, even then: so tremendous was the noise of the living ocean, in its irruption into the Fortress, and its inundation of the courts and passages and staircases. All around outside, too, it beat the walls with a deep, hoarse roar, from which, occasionally, some partial shouts of tumult broke and leaped into the air like spray.
vi: With the familiar habit of hunger, Jacques Three was clearly disappointed when the conversation turned in a direction that did not promise bloodshed, so he grabbed Defarge's arm and the prison guard's arm. The three heads huddled closely together in a brief exchange, and even then they could barely hear each other, the deafening roar of the crowd around them surging into the fortress, flooding the courtyards, passageways, and staircases. All around, the roar of the crowd echoed, and from time to time, a chaotic scream erupted like a wave crashing into the sky.
tr: With his usual greedy demeanor and disappointed by the dialogue between the man and Defarge progressing towards a point where no blood would be shed, Jacques Three had grabbed Defarge's arm, and Defarge had grabbed the guard's arm. During this brief conversation. The three heads were closely huddled together, but even in that state, they could barely hear each other. As the living ocean invaded the Bastille and surged through its courtyards, corridors, and stairways, it made a tremendous noise. Outside, the ocean was pounding the walls with a deep, muffled roar, and the screams rising from this chaos were scattering in the air.
es: Santiago Tercero, insatiable hydropic as always, evidently disappointed to see that the dialogue was taking a turn that reduced the chances of bloodshed, clung to Defarge's arm at the same time that Defarge clung to the jailer's arm. During the brief dialogue transcribed above, the heads of the three men were close together, and even so, they could barely hear each other; such was the tremendous roar produced by that living ocean as it penetrated the fortress and flooded the rooms, cells, corridors, and staircases. The shouting outside was no less, where from time to time thunderclaps that foretold turmoil erupted, and lightning bolts crossed the heated atmosphere like immeasurable whips wielded by titans.

en: Through gloomy vaults where the light of day had never shone, past hideous doors of dark dens and cages, down cavernous flights of steps, and again up steep rugged ascents of stone and brick, more like dry waterfalls than staircases, Defarge, the turnkey, and Jacques Three, linked hand and arm, went with all the speed they could make. Here and there, especially at first, the inundation started on them and swept by; but when they had done descending, and were winding and climbing up a tower, they were alone. Hemmed in here by the massive thickness of walls and arches, the storm within the fortress and without was only audible to them in a dull, subdued way, as if the noise out of which they had come had almost destroyed their sense of hearing.
vi: Passing through the dark dungeons that had never seen daylight, crossing the prison doors, the grimy, horrifying cells, descending the cave-like steps, then ascending the jagged, steep stone steps more like dry waterfall cliffs than stairs, Defarge, the jailer, and Jacques Three, holding each other's hands tightly, tried to move as quickly as possible. From time to time, especially at the beginning, the sea of people surged forward, sweeping them along; but when they finished descending and continued up a spiral staircase to a high tower, only the three of them remained. Here, surrounded by thick walls and arches, the storm inside and outside the fortress was just a faint sound, unlike the noise they had just escaped that had nearly destroyed their hearing ability.
tr: Defarge, the guard, and Jacques Three, arm in arm, hurried along at full speed, passing by the gloomy cellars where daylight had never once entered, and the disgusting doors of dark dungeons, descending steps that resembled caves, and climbing steep slopes of stone and brick that resembled dried-up waterfalls. In many places, especially in the first places they passed, they too were swept away by the flood, but as their descent ended and they spiraled up the tower, they were left alone. Now, surrounded by the imposing thick walls and arches, the sound of the storm both inside and outside the castle came very muffled and deep, as if all that noise would destroy their sense of hearing.
es: Defarge, the jailer, and Santiago Tercero, holding each other by the arms, hurried through dark corridors never visited by daylight, passed by terrifying doors of gloomy and damp dungeons, descended through cavernous stairways, and then climbed rough stone and brick steps, more akin to dry waterfalls than to stairs. From time to time, especially at the beginning, the flood blocked their way or swept them along; but after a while, once they entered a spiral staircase and began to ascend a tower, they were left alone. The walls that isolated them from the world were so thick that their ears, as if shattered by the previous furious roars, could barely perceive muffled sounds.

en: The turnkey stopped at a low door, put a key in a clashing lock, swung the door slowly open, and said, as they all bent their heads and passed in:
vi: The jailer stopped at a low door, inserted the creaking key into the lock, slowly opened the door, and said as all three bowed their heads to enter: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower!
tr: The guard stood in front of a low door, inserted the key into the lock with a clatter, slowly opened the door, and as they all bowed their heads and entered, he said:
es: The jailer stopped in front of a very low door, took out a key, opened it, and said while bending his body to be able to enter:

en: “One hundred and five, North Tower!”
vi: The jailer stopped at a low door, inserted the creaking key into the lock, slowly opened the door, and said as all three bowed their heads to enter: − One Hundred and Five, North Tower!
tr: "Here is One Hundred and Five, North Tower!"
es: —One Hundred Five, North Tower.

en: There was a small, heavily-grated, unglazed window high in the wall, with a stone screen before it, so that the sky could be only seen by stooping low and looking up. There was a small chimney, heavily barred across, a few feet within. There was a heap of old feathery wood-ashes on the hearth. There was a stool, and table, and a straw bed. There were the four blackened walls, and a rusted iron ring in one of them.
vi: Inside, there was a window without glass, densely barred, high up on the wall, and the door was blocked by a stone slab, so one had to crouch down and look up to see a piece of the sky. A few steps away was a small chimney, also densely barred. On the hearth was a pile of long-burned wood ashes. A stool, a table, a straw bed. Four blackened walls, and on one wall was a rusty iron ring. −
tr: On top of the wall, there was a small window with thick iron bars and no glass, with a stone partition in front of it, so one had to crouch down to the ground and look up to see the sky. A little further away, there was a small chimney covered with thick grates. Inside, there was a stool, a table, and a straw bed. All four walls were pitch black, and on one of them, a ring was hanging.
es: They found themselves in a square formed by four blackened walls. In one of them, there was a rusty iron ring, and in another, at the height of the vaulted ceiling, a small window defended by thick iron bars and arranged in such a way that it barely allowed a very narrow line of blue sky to be seen. Piles of ashes covered the floor, and its furniture consisted of a bench, a table, and a straw mattress. —Pass the torch slowly along the walls so that I can see—said Defarge to the jailer.

en: “Pass that torch slowly along these walls, that I may see them,” said Defarge to the turnkey.
vi: Slowly pass the torch along these walls so I can have a look, - Defarge said to the jailer.
tr: "Hold the torch up to these walls so I can see," Defarge said to the guard.
es: —Pass the torch slowly along the walls so that I can see—said Defarge to the jailer.

en: The man obeyed, and Defarge followed the light closely with his eyes.
vi: This person listened, and Defarge attentively followed the beam of light.
tr: Adam followed what was said. Defarge also carefully followed the light with his eyes.
es: The man obeyed. Defarge was examining the walls with a penetrating gaze.

en: “Stop!—Look here, Jacques!”
vi: − Stop!...
tr: "Stop! – Look over there, Jacques!"
es: —Stop...! Look, Santiago!

en: “A. M.!” croaked Jacques Three, as he read greedily.
vi: Look here, Jacques! − “A. M.”! - Jacques Three said, almost groaning as he read those initials eagerly.
tr: "Stop! – Look over there, Jacques!" As Jacques was reading with a greedy attitude, he shouted in a muffled voice, "A. M!"
es: —A. M.—roared Santiago Tercero with a longing expression.

en: “Alexandre Manette,” said Defarge in his ear, following the letters with his swart forefinger, deeply engrained with gunpowder. “And here he wrote ‘a poor physician.’ And it was he, without doubt, who scratched a calendar on this stone. What is that in your hand? A crowbar? Give it me!”
vi: − “Alexandre Manette,” Defarge said softly, tracing the letters with his dark, gunpowder-stained index finger. - And here he carved the words “poor doctor”. And surely it was he, no one else, who carved the tally marks on this stone. What are you holding? A crowbar? Give it to me!
tr: Defarge, running his dark finger stained with gunpowder over the letters, said into his friend's ear, "Alexandre Manette." "Look, he also wrote 'A poor doctor' here."" He was definitely the one who drew the calendar on this stone. What is that in your hand? A shackle? Give it to me!"
es: —Alejandro Manette—whispered Defarge in his ear, placing the tip of his index finger on the initials. —Here he has written "poor doctor." No doubt about it! He was the one who engraved his epitaph here! What do you have in your hand? An iron bar? Give it to me!

en: He had still the linstock of his gun in his own hand. He made a sudden exchange of the two instruments, and turning on the worm-eaten stool and table, beat them to pieces in a few blows.
vi: Defarge still held the cannon fire starter in his hand. He immediately swapped tools with Jacques Three and turned to smash the worm-eaten stool and table with a few heavy blows.
tr: Defarge still had the rifle in his hand. He quickly handed it to Jacques, took the crowbar, and shattered the worm-eaten stool and table with a few blows.
es: Defarge, who still held the cannon's firebrand in his hand, exchanged it for the iron bar that Santiago Tercero handed to him and, in less time than it takes to tell, smashed the bench and the table to pieces.

en: “Hold the light higher!” he said, wrathfully, to the turnkey. “Look among those fragments with care, Jacques. And see! Here is my knife,” throwing it to him; “rip open that bed, and search the straw. Hold the light higher, you!”
vi: − Hold the torch a bit higher! - He said angrily to the jailer, then turned to Jacques. - Search thoroughly in that pile of wood scraps, Jacques. Here! Take my knife! - He tossed the knife to his friend. - Slash the bed open, search in the straw mattress. Hold the torch higher, you!
tr: Defarge said angrily to the guard, "Hold the light a little higher!" "Look carefully between those pieces, Jacques! Take my knife," he said, throwing it to him; "tear open the bed, look inside the straw. You, lift that light a little higher too!"
es: —Raise the light!—he shouted furiously at the jailer. — And you, Santiago, take my knife,—he added, throwing it to him—tear that mattress, and search through the straw...! Raise the light!

en: With a menacing look at the turnkey he crawled upon the hearth, and, peering up the chimney, struck and prised at its sides with the crowbar, and worked at the iron grating across it. In a few minutes, some mortar and dust came dropping down, which he averted his face to avoid; and in it, and in the old wood-ashes, and in a crevice in the chimney into which his weapon had slipped or wrought itself, he groped with a cautious touch.
vi: After glaring at the jailer, Defarge crawled on the fireplace floor, carefully looking up the chimney, using a crowbar to tap, pry at the fireplace walls, and attempt to dislodge the iron bars crisscrossing the chimney hole. A few minutes later, plaster and dust fell down, he turned his face away; then carefully groped and searched through the old ashes and wood debris, in the chimney nook where the crowbar had reached.
tr: After looking at the guard menacingly, he bent over the stove and looked up the chimney, then struck its edges with the iron poker in his hand and tried to remove the iron grate on top. A few minutes later, when plaster and dust started falling from above, he turned his head to the side; amidst all this dust and old ashes, he cautiously felt around with his weapon inside a crack in the chimney.
es: After casting a threatening look at the jailer, Defarge, while Santiago Tercero carried out his order, dug with the iron bar between the joints of the pavement slabs, stirred the ashes, and tried to move the stones of the walls.

en: “Nothing in the wood, and nothing in the straw, Jacques?”
vi: − Is there nothing in that pile of straw and wood, Jacques? −
tr: "Isn't there something in the ashes or the straw, Jacques?"
es: —Haven't you found anything, Santiago?—he asked after a while.

en: “Nothing.”
vi: There's nothing. −
tr: "Nothing."
es: —Nothing.

en: “Let us collect them together, in the middle of the cell. So! Light them, you!”
vi: Gather it all in the middle of the room. Done! Burn it, you!
tr: "Let's gather these in the middle of the cell. Now, burn them!" .
es: —We are going to make a pile with the straw and the chips... Like this! Light the fire, jailer!

en: The turnkey fired the little pile, which blazed high and hot. Stooping again to come out at the low-arched door, they left it burning, and retraced their way to the courtyard; seeming to recover their sense of hearing as they came down, until they were in the raging flood once more.
vi: The jailer set the torch to the pile, and the straw and wood blazed up. Bending down again to pass through the low archway, all three left the fire burning, retracing their steps back to the yard; as they descended, their hearing seemed to recover, until they were once again in the sea of frenzied people.
tr: With the guard's ignition, the small pile burned brightly. Leaving the fire burning, they bent down again and exited through the low-arched door, following the path to the courtyard; as they descended, their sense of hearing improved; until they found themselves once again in the midst of the angry human flood.
es: The jailer immediately obeyed the order. The three men left the dungeon, leaving the combustible materials burning, and returned once again to the courtyard, where the disorder was as dreadful, if not more so, than before.

en: They found it surging and tossing, in quest of Defarge himself. Saint Antoine was clamorous to have its wine-shop keeper foremost in the guard upon the governor who had defended the Bastille and shot the people. Otherwise, the governor would not be marched to the Hotel de Ville for judgment. Otherwise, the governor would escape, and the people’s blood (suddenly of some value, after many years of worthlessness) be unavenged.
vi: The sea of people was still surging, fervently searching for Defarge. The people of Saint Antoine were clamoring for the tavern owner to lead the group guarding the chief officer, who had fired upon the populace to protect the Bastille prison. If not, they would not be able to bring the officer to the City Hall for trial. If not, the officer would escape and those who had shed blood would not be avenged (after so many years of worthlessness, the blood of commoners suddenly had some value).
tr: People were running around excitedly, looking for Defarge. St. Antoine was clamoring to unleash the wine shop owner upon the governor who defended the Bastille and fired upon the people. Otherwise, the governor would not be taken to the Town Hall for trial. Otherwise, the governor would escape, and the blood of the people (which had suddenly become valuable after years of being worthless) would be left unavenged.
es: The mob was frantically, madly searching for Defarge; they wanted the tavern keeper to be the head of the guard in charge of watching over the governor who had defended the Bastille and fired upon the people. How else would the governor be taken to the Hôtel de Ville to be judged? How else would they prevent him from escaping, leaving the blood of the people unavenged, which had suddenly gained some value after so many years of being worth nothing?

en: In the howling universe of passion and contention that seemed to encompass this grim old officer conspicuous in his grey coat and red decoration, there was but one quite steady figure, and that was a woman’s. “See, there is my husband!” she cried, pointing him out. “See Defarge!” She stood immovable close to the grim old officer, and remained immovable close to him; remained immovable close to him through the streets, as Defarge and the rest bore him along; remained immovable close to him when he was got near his destination, and began to be struck at from behind; remained immovable close to him when the long-gathering rain of stabs and blows fell heavy; was so close to him when he dropped dead under it, that, suddenly animated, she put her foot upon his neck, and with her cruel knife—long ready—hewed off his head.
vi: Amidst the sea of humanity howling and arguing aggressively as if wanting to drown the old official in a gray coat adorned with a red medal, there was only one person who remained completely calm, and that was a woman. − Look, there's my husband! - She shouted, pointing. - Defarge, there! She stood close to the fierce old official; and continued to stay close; she stayed close to him as the crowd moved through the streets while Defarge and the mob led him away; still close when he neared his destination and was struck from behind; still close when he endured a long-accumulated rain of punches and kicks; still close when he collapsed under the blows, and then suddenly she became very animated, stomped on his neck, and drew a very long, brutal knife to sever his head.
tr: With his eye-catching gray jacket and red insignia, surrounded by the crowd groaning with passion and ambition, there was only one person who remained calm among them, and that was a woman. "Here comes my husband!" she shouted, pointing at Defarge. "Look at Defarge!" The woman stood motionless right next to the stern-faced old official, even as Defarge and the rest of the crowd dragged the man through the streets, pushed him from behind as they approached their intended spot, and as knives and fists rained down on the man, the woman remained motionless, always close to the man, and when the man finally collapsed lifelessly to the ground, she was right beside him and suddenly moved, placing her foot on the man's neck and with the cruel knife she had been holding for a long time, severed the man's head from his body.
es: Among the countless mobs that roared with rage and moved restlessly around the stern figure of the elderly official, whose gray overcoat with red trimmings made him more visible, there was only one calm and serene person, and that person was a woman. —There is my husband—she said, extending an arm towards Defarge. She stood motionless beside the governor when her husband appeared, and she continued motionless without separating from his person. By his side, she remained rigid and calm while Defarge and his men led him through the streets, and she did not separate when they were about to reach their destination, nor when the mobs began to strike him from behind, nor when the tips of innumerable knives tore into his flesh, nor when, riddled with wounds, he fell dead on the street stones. She was so close to him that upon seeing him fall, suddenly animated, she placed her foot on the neck of the dead man and with her sharp knife cut off his head.

en: The hour was come, when Saint Antoine was to execute his horrible idea of hoisting up men for lamps to show what he could be and do. Saint Antoine’s blood was up, and the blood of tyranny and domination by the iron hand was down—down on the steps of the Hotel de Ville where the governor’s body lay—down on the sole of the shoe of Madame Defarge where she had trodden on the body to steady it for mutilation. “Lower the lamp yonder!” cried Saint Antoine, after glaring round for a new means of death; “here is one of his soldiers to be left on guard!” The swinging sentinel was posted, and the sea rushed on.
vi: It was time for the people of Saint Antoine to carry out the terrifying idea of hanging people on lampposts to show who they were and what they could do. The blood of the people of Saint Antoine had boiled, and the blood of the cruel and iron-fisted regime had flowed - on the steps of the Town Hall where the body of the governor lay - under the heel of Madame Defarge as she stepped on the body to steady herself while she beheaded him. − Down with the lamppost over there! - The people of Saint Antoine shouted after glaring around to find more people to execute. - There's another one of the governor's guards here! - The guard was hanged and dangled, and the sea of people surged forward, surged forward.
tr: It was time to implement the horrific idea of hanging people instead of lamps, to show what St. Antoine was and what he could do. Blood had rushed to St. Antoine's head, and the blood of iron-handed tyranny and domination had been spilled – it was flowing down from the steps of the Town Hall, from where the governor's body lay – and from the sole of Madam Defarge's shoe, which she had planted on the man's body to behead him. After looking around to see if there were any other men to kill, St. Antoine shouted, "Lower the lamp over here! Let's put one of his soldiers on guard!" As the guard swung from the lamp post, the sea surged again.
es: Very soon the time would come when San Antonio would lower the lanterns that illuminated his brutalities and replace them with the corpses of aristocrats. The blood of San Antonio grew fervent as that of the iron hand of tyranny cooled... as it ran down the steps leading to the doors of the Hôtel de Ville, that of the governor, as the sole of Madame Defarge's shoe was stained red from pressing the neck of the unfortunate man whom she made the object of horrible mutilation. —Lower that lantern!—roared San Antonio, after turning his bloodshot eyes around. —Do you want a sentinel? Here you have one! He is a soldier of our enemies! And there remained the sentinel, swaying gloomily, while the mob moved away roaring.

en: The sea of black and threatening waters, and of destructive upheaving of wave against wave, whose depths were yet unfathomed and whose forces were yet unknown. The remorseless sea of turbulently swaying shapes, voices of vengeance, and faces hardened in the furnaces of suffering until the touch of pity could make no mark on them.
vi: The sea is vast and threatening, dark and ominous; the sea rises with wave after wave of destruction; the sea is unfathomably deep; the sea is immensely powerful. The sea is cruel, surging with waves that make people sway, roaring with the call for revenge, forging ruthless faces in the furnace of suffering until every trace of compassion is completely eradicated.
tr: The depth of this terrifying dark water and the destructive waves crashing over each other is beyond comprehension, and its power is unknown. The merciless sea, with all its cruelty, was tossing bodies, voices of revenge, and faces hardened by pain, devoid of any trace of mercy.
es: It was a sea of black and threatening waters, a sea whose waves carried destruction in each of their movements, a sea of unfathomable depth, a sea whose forces no one knew. A sea shielded against the sting of remorse, a sea of turbulent agitations, of cries for vengeance, of hearts hardened in the furnaces of suffering, upon whose diamond-like surface pity slid without leaving the slightest trace.

en: But, in the ocean of faces where every fierce and furious expression was in vivid life, there were two groups of faces—each seven in number—so fixedly contrasting with the rest, that never did sea roll which bore more memorable wrecks with it. Seven faces of prisoners, suddenly released by the storm that had burst their tomb, were carried high overhead: all scared, all lost, all wondering and amazed, as if the Last Day were come, and those who rejoiced around them were lost spirits. Other seven faces there were, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-seen eyes awaited the Last Day. Impassive faces, yet with a suspended—not an abolished—expression on them; faces, rather, in a fearful pause, as having yet to raise the dropped lids of the eyes, and bear witness with the bloodless lips, “Thou Didst It!”
vi: But amidst the sea of faces brimming with vigorous anger and savagery, there were two groups entirely different from the crowd - each group consisting of seven faces - so distinct that the surging waves carrying more and more drifting fragments of memories could not submerge them. The seven faces belong to seven prisoners, unexpectedly freed by the storm that shattered their prison, now being hoisted above the crowd; all are terrified, all are lost, all are bewildered as if the Day of Final Judgment has arrived and the rejoicing crowd are the souls of the dead. Another seven faces, held higher, are seven severed heads, their eyelids half-closed over eyes staring blankly, awaiting the Day of Judgment. The faces are motionless, frozen in a condensed emotion; the faces turned to stone amidst the horror, not yet able to open their eyes wide to witness the pale lips screaming “MURDERERS!”.
tr: But within this torrent of people filled with furious and angry expressions, there were two groups of seven people each who, unlike the others, were in a more devastated state than anyone else swept away by this crowd. The seven prisoners, suddenly freed by the storm that scattered their graves, were now being carried on hands; all of them were frightened, as if they had fallen into a void, bewildered by what had happened to them, as if Judgment Day had come and the people surrounding them were lost souls. The other seven faces being carried a little higher up were lifeless, their eyelids drooped, their eyes half-open, waiting for Judgment Day. These were indifferent faces, yet they bore an expression that was postponed but never altered; after a fearful wait, their drooped eyelids would open with effort and those lifeless lips would testify, "YOU DID THIS!"
es: But in that ocean of faces, a living reflection of all furies, of all violences, two groups of faces could be observed, each formed by seven faces that stood out from the boiling human waves that carried them, shipwreck remnants like none that have ever floated on any sea. Above the heads of the crowds, seven faces of prisoners could be seen, unexpectedly pulled from their graves by the human storm that visited them, seven frightened, stunned, bewildered faces, as if they were being taken to execution on the shoulders of rejoicing demons; and another seven faces, carried higher, seven dead faces, whose drooping eyelids and half-closed eyes awaited the arrival of Judgment Day; impassive faces whose life did not seem extinguished, but suspended, faces that seemed as if they were about to raise their eyelids again and open their blood-covered lips to say: "You murdered me!"

en: Seven prisoners released, seven gory heads on pikes, the keys of the accursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some discovered letters and other memorials of prisoners of old time, long dead of broken hearts,—such, and such—like, the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid-July, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-nine. Now, Heaven defeat the fancy of Lucie Darnay, and keep these feet far out of her life! For, they are headlong, mad, and dangerous; and in the years so long after the breaking of the cask at Defarge’s wine-shop door, they are not easily purified when once stained red.
vi: Seven prisoners set free, seven heads displayed on sharp stakes, the keys to the cursed fortress of eight towers, several letters found, and many other memories of prisoners long dead from suffering - so many things like that - all echoed in the footsteps of the people of Saint Antoine marching through the streets of Paris in mid-July 1789. At this moment, may Lucie Darnay's imagination be blocked so that those footsteps stay far from her life! For those are advancing, frenzied, dangerous footsteps; because many years after the day the wine cask burst outside Defarge's wine shop, those footsteps are not easily washed clean once stained with blood.
tr: The seven released prisoners, the seven bloody heads on the tips of spears, the keys to the cursed castle with its eight sturdy towers, some letters and belongings left by former prisoners, the broken hearts that died years ago –and a lot of similar things– walked through the streets of Paris in mid-July of the year 1789, accompanied by the thunderous footsteps of St. Antoine. May Lucie Darnay's predictions not come true, and may these distant footsteps remain far from them! The crowd sees nothing because they are like madmen, dangerous, and it is not at all easy to clean the streets stained red again years after the wine barrel broke in front of Defarge's shop.
es: Seven prisoners freed, seven bloody heads carried as horrible trophies on the spikes of pikes, the keys of the cursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some letters, a few memorials of ancient prisoners who had died of sorrow many years before... and something else of the sort, paraded through the streets of Paris amidst a very numerous escort, one day in mid-July of the year seventeen eighty-nine. May Heaven keep the echo of the steps of the aforementioned escort away from the life of Lucie Darnay! For they are echoes of hurried steps, of hard steps, of dangerous steps that violently penetrate the vital core of someone, echoes produced by feet that years before were stained red as a result of a barrel breaking near the door of Defarge's tavern, and when those feet are stained red, they are hardly ever cleaned.

en: CHAPTER XXII.
vi: For those are advancing, frenzied, dangerous footsteps; because many years after the day the wine cask burst outside Defarge's wine shop, those footsteps are not easily washed clean once stained with blood.
tr: XXII
es: XXII.

en: The Sea Still Rises
vi: The sea still roars, Saint Antoine gaunt has had only one victorious week to temporarily soothe the bitterness of gnawing bread crumbs with the sweetness of brotherly hugs and cheers, as Madame Defarge sits at the wine counter as usual, overseeing the customers.
tr: The Sea is Still Rising
es: THE TIDE RISES

en: Haggard Saint Antoine had had only one exultant week, in which to soften his modicum of hard and bitter bread to such extent as he could, with the relish of fraternal embraces and congratulations, when Madame Defarge sat at her counter, as usual, presiding over the customers. Madame Defarge wore no rose in her head, for the great brotherhood of Spies had become, even in one short week, extremely chary of trusting themselves to the saint’s mercies. The lamps across his streets had a portentously elastic swing with them.
vi: The sea still roars, Saint Antoine gaunt has had only one victorious week to temporarily soothe the bitterness of gnawing bread crumbs with the sweetness of brotherly hugs and cheers, as Madame Defarge sits at the wine counter as usual, overseeing the customers. Madame Defarge does not wear a rose in her hair because in just one short week, the numerous spies have been extremely reluctant to entrust their lives to the mercy of Saint Antoine. The street lamps at the intersections in the area named after this saint always sway ominously on their posts like a dark omen.
tr: Madam Defarge was sitting behind her counter as usual, scrutinizing the customers, while the weary St. Antoine was so joyful from a week of embracing and congratulating each other like brothers that he could soften the little bread he had. There was no rose in Madam Defarge's hair, because even in that short week, the spies were strangely cautious about leaving themselves to the mercy of the saints. The street lamps were swinging ominously.
es: For only a week had the terrible San Antonio sweetened the harshness of the hard and bitter bread he put in his mouth, for only a week had he had the satisfaction of doing whatever he pleased and of alternating his outbursts with fraternal hugs and cordial congratulations. Madame Defarge presided over her patrons from her usual spot. She no longer wore a rose in her hair, for the great brotherhood of spies had become so circumspect in the brief span of seven days that not even by a miracle could one find someone willing to entrust themselves to the tender care of the Saint.
