The street lamps of those streets exerted a wondrous influence over them.

en: Madame Defarge, with her arms folded, sat in the morning light and heat, contemplating the wine-shop and the street. In both, there were several knots of loungers, squalid and miserable, but now with a manifest sense of power enthroned on their distress. The raggedest nightcap, awry on the wretchedest head, had this crooked significance in it: “I know how hard it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to support life in myself; but do you know how easy it has grown for me, the wearer of this, to destroy life in you?” Every lean bare arm, that had been without work before, had this work always ready for it now, that it could strike. The fingers of the knitting women were vicious, with the experience that they could tear. There was a change in the appearance of Saint Antoine; the image had been hammering into this for hundreds of years, and the last finishing blows had told mightily on the expression.
vi: Mrs. Defarge sat with her arms crossed in the hot morning sunlight, silently watching the tavern and the street. Both inside and outside, many groups of idle people gathered, dirty and miserable, but their dire circumstances now granted them a palpable sense of power. The most tattered nightcaps, askew on the most unfortunate heads, seemed to convey a sinister meaning: "I know it is increasingly difficult for me, the wearer of this cap, to sustain myself; but do you know it is becoming easier for me, the wearer of this cap, to destroy your life?" All the skinny, bony arms that had long been without work now always had the task of brandishing fists. The fingers of the women who had been knitting malevolently for so long knew they could tear flesh and skin apart. The appearance of the Saint Antoine district has completely changed; this image has been carved out over hundreds of years, and the final finishing blows have been struck to shape that face.
tr: Madame Defarge, with her arms crossed, was thoughtfully looking at the wine shop and the road under the morning sun. On both, there were groups of idle people in filthy and miserable conditions, but now a clear power seemed to have settled over all their troubles. From the most wretched nightcap, worn on the most miserable head, this could be read: "I, who wear this cap, know how hard it is to sustain my life, but do you know how easy it is for me, who wears this cap, to take your life?" Every skinny and bare arm that previously had no work was now ready to do this at any moment. The fingers of the women knitting were in a terrible state from the experiences they had lived through before. The face of St. Antoine had changed; this image had been ingrained in it for centuries, and with the final strong blow, its expression had changed completely.
es: With arms crossed, Mrs. Defarge watched the street from behind the counter, while also keeping an eye on her establishment. Neither in the street nor in the establishment were there any shortages of well-nourished groups of loafers, scrawny and ragged, but with faces that reflected the power they had enthroned over their miseries. Even the dirtiest and most tattered cap, scowling from atop the head it half-covered, seemed to say: "I know how hard you made life for me: but do you know how easy it has become for me to take away the comfortable and happy life you lead?" All the bare arms that had previously lacked work now had it in abundance and perpetuity: to wound, to kill. The fingers of the women, previously occupied with knitting, had taken to other tasks since they realized they knew how to tear. Saint Anthony had undergone a radical transformation: the image, after hundreds of years of tranquility, was now in motion and delivering terrifying blows.

en: Madame Defarge sat observing it, with such suppressed approval as was to be desired in the leader of the Saint Antoine women. One of her sisterhood knitted beside her. The short, rather plump wife of a starved grocer, and the mother of two children withal, this lieutenant had already earned the complimentary name of The Vengeance.
vi: Ms. Defarge sat observing the neighborhood with a satisfaction carefully concealed to fit her role as the leader of the Saint Antoine women's group. A fellow sister sat knitting beside her. She was the short, somewhat plump wife of the starving grocer, and also the mother of two children. This deputy leader was praised with the nickname Goddess of Vengeance.
tr: Madame Defarge was sitting, watching her surroundings with the secret satisfaction expected from the leader of the women of St Antoine. One of her friends was also knitting beside her. This short, plump woman, who was the wife of a skin-and-bones grocer and mother of two children, was named Vengeance because she was Madame Defarge's right hand.
es: All this was observed by Madame Defarge from behind the counter of her establishment with the complacency of the leader of the women of Saint Antoine. One of her sisters was knitting beside her. She was a short and somewhat plump woman, married to a shopkeeper and mother of two children to boot, who had earned the glorious nickname of "The Vengeance."

en: “Hark!” said The Vengeance. “Listen, then! Who comes?”
vi: "Look!" - the Goddess of Vengeance said. - "Listen! Who is coming?"
tr: "Listen!" said Revenge. "Listen, look! Who is coming?"
es: She was a short and somewhat plump woman, married to a shopkeeper and mother of two children to boot, who had earned the glorious nickname of "The Vengeance." —Attention!—exclaimed La Venganza—Who goes there?

en: As if a train of powder laid from the outermost bound of Saint Antoine Quarter to the wine-shop door, had been suddenly fired, a fast-spreading murmur came rushing along.
vi: Like a trail of gunpowder suddenly ignited from the outermost part of Saint Antoine running towards the tavern door, a murmur surged closer and closer.
tr: A series of gunpowder-like, powerful hums spread from the borders of the St. Antoine district towards the door of the wine shop, as if ignited.
es: As if they had set fire to a trail of gunpowder that extended from the borders of San Antonio's domains to Defarge's tavern, thus rumors reached the shop, born far away, and spread with dizzying speed in all directions.

en: “It is Defarge,” said madame. “Silence, patriots!”
vi: − That's Defarge, - she said. - Silence, patriots!
tr: "Here is Defarge," said madam. "Silence, friends!"
es: —It's Defarge!—said the tavern keeper. —Silence, patriots!

en: Defarge came in breathless, pulled off a red cap he wore, and looked around him! “Listen, everywhere!” said madame again. “Listen to him!” Defarge stood, panting, against a background of eager eyes and open mouths, formed outside the door; all those within the wine-shop had sprung to their feet.
vi: Defarge ran in, panting, snatched the red cap off his head, and looked around. − Listen, everyone! - Her voice again. - Listen to what he says! Defarge stood panting, with eager eyes and gaping mouths behind him at the door; everyone in the tavern stood up abruptly.
tr: Defarge arrived out of breath, took off the red cap on his head, and looked around! "Everyone be quiet!" said madam again. "Listen to him!" Defarge was standing breathlessly in front of the eager eyes and open mouths gathered at the door; everyone in the wine shop had jumped to their feet.
es: Defarge entered, panting, out of breath; he tore the red cap from his head that adorned it, and cast quick glances around him. —Attention everyone!—shouted the innkeeper. —Listen to him! Defarge had remained on the threshold, contemplating the sea of open eyes and even more open mouths that filled the street. The people inside the tavern stood up. —Speak, Defarge!

en: “Say then, my husband. What is it?”
vi: - Speak, my dear. What is it?
tr: "Tell me, my dear husband. What happened?"
es: —replied the tavern keeper. —What's happening?

en: “News from the other world!”
vi: − News from the dead! −
tr: "There is news from the other world!"
es: —News from the other world!

en: “How, then?” cried madame, contemptuously. “The other world?”
vi: How can that be? - She exclaimed, her voice scornful. - The dead?
tr: "What do you mean?" shouted the madam, with a disdainful tone. "The other world?"
es: —Really?—asked his wife, putting a strong sarcastic tone in her words. —From the other world?

en: “Does everybody here recall old Foulon, who told the famished people that they might eat grass, and who died, and went to Hell?”
vi: − Does anyone here remember old Foulon*, who said that starving people could eat grass to fill their bellies, and who was believed to be dead and gone to the underworld?
tr: "Does everyone here remember old Foulon, who suggested that starving people eat grass and then went on to meet his end in hell?""
es: —Do you all remember that individual named Foulon, who told the starving people to eat grass, and to try to die quickly and go to hell?

en: “Everybody!” from all throats.
vi: − Remember! - Every throat shouted.
tr: They all shouted together, "We remember."
es: —Yes...!—shouted the mobs in unison.

en: “The news is of him. He is among us!”
vi: − There is news about him. He is alive and here! − Alive and here! -
tr: "The news is about him. He is among us!"
es: —My news refers to him. We have him among us.

en: “Among us!” from the universal throat again. “And dead?”
vi: Those same throats shouted in unison. -
tr: "Is he among us?" they shouted all together again. "Wasn't he dead?"
es: —Among us!—they all roared. —Dead?

en: “Not dead! He feared us so much—and with reason—that he caused himself to be represented as dead, and had a grand mock-funeral. But they have found him alive, hiding in the country, and have brought him in. I have seen him but now, on his way to the Hotel de Ville, a prisoner. I have said that he had reason to fear us. Say all! Had he reason?”
vi: And dead? − Not dead! He was so afraid of us... and rightly so... that he pretended to be dead and held a fake funeral. But people found him alive, hiding in the countryside, and brought him back here. I just saw him, the prisoner, being escorted to the Town Hall. I said that this old man is afraid of us, and that's true. Everyone, speak up! Isn't that right?
tr: "He didn't die! He was so scared of us –and not without reason– that he spread the news of his death and arranged a grand funeral for himself. But they found him hiding in a rural area and brought him back. I had seen him, but now he is being taken to the City Hall as a prisoner. I said he was right to be afraid of us. Tell me! Is he right or not?"
es: —No; he is alive. Such was the terror he had of us... and rightly so, that he pretended to be dead and ordered a grand funeral for himself. But he has been found alive, hiding in the countryside, and they have brought him here. I just saw him this moment while they were taking him prisoner to the Hôtel de Ville. I said that he feared us with reason... Tell me...! Did he fear us with reason?

en: Wretched old sinner of more than threescore years and ten, if he had never known it yet, he would have known it in his heart of hearts if he could have heard the answering cry.
vi: If that unfortunate old criminal, over seventy years old, had never known it before, he would now remember it deeply if he heard the unanimous shout in response from everyone.
tr: If this miserable sinner, who had reached the age of seventy, had heard these cries, even if he had not yet found the answer, he would certainly have felt it deep in his heart.
es: The blood of that ancient sinner would have frozen if the fierce cry that came from the monster's jaws had reached his ears.

en: A moment of profound silence followed. Defarge and his wife looked steadfastly at one another. The Vengeance stooped, and the jar of a drum was heard as she moved it at her feet behind the counter.
vi: A moment of profound silence followed. Defarge and his wife looked directly at each other. The Goddess of Revenge bent down, and a sound like a loud drum was the noise of her feet stomping hard behind the wine counter.
tr: Then there was a silence that penetrated deep into the soul. Defarge and his wife looked at each other resolutely. Revenge was leaning behind the counter, moving the drum at his feet.
es: A few moments of deep silence followed. Defarge and his wife stared at each other with a terrifying intensity; La Vengeance remained motionless, and a drum rolled in the distance while behind the counter there was a sound like moving feet.

en: “Patriots!” said Defarge, in a determined voice, “are we ready?”
vi: − O patriots! - Defarge shouted resolutely. Ready?
tr: "Comrades!" cried Defarge in a determined voice. "Are we ready?"
es: —Patriots!—shouted Defarge with a resolute voice. —Are we ready?

en: Instantly Madame Defarge’s knife was in her girdle; the drum was beating in the streets, as if it and a drummer had flown together by magic; and The Vengeance, uttering terrific shrieks, and flinging her arms about her head like all the forty Furies at once, was tearing from house to house, rousing the women.
vi: Immediately, Madame Defarge's knife was tucked into her back; the footsteps thundered on the road as if some miracle had granted the crowd a drummer to march along; the Goddess of Vengeance screamed a terrifying cry, raising her hands above her head as if summoning all forty avenging deities at once, running from house to house to incite the women.
tr: Madame Defarge immediately tucked her knife into her belt; the drum was thundering in the streets, as if the drummer and his drum had magically vanished, and Vengeance, with terrifying screams and her arms raised like the Furies, was going door to door rousing the women.
es: Immediately, the long knife appeared at the waist of the innkeeper, drums rolled through the streets, as if they and those who struck their patches had sprung up by magical arts, and La Venganza, letting out ferocious screams, with her hair loose and waving her arms above her head, resembling not one, but all forty Furies together, ran from house to house inciting the women.

en: The men were terrible, in the bloody-minded anger with which they looked from windows, caught up what arms they had, and came pouring down into the streets; but, the women were a sight to chill the boldest. From such household occupations as their bare poverty yielded, from their children, from their aged and their sick crouching on the bare ground famished and naked, they ran out with streaming hair, urging one another, and themselves, to madness with the wildest cries and actions. Villain Foulon taken, my sister! Old Foulon taken, my mother! Miscreant Foulon taken, my daughter! Then, a score of others ran into the midst of these, beating their breasts, tearing their hair, and screaming, Foulon alive! Foulon who told the starving people they might eat grass! Foulon who told my old father that he might eat grass, when I had no bread to give him! Foulon who told my baby it might suck grass, when these breasts were dry with want! O mother of God, this Foulon! O Heaven our suffering! Hear me, my dead baby and my withered father: I swear on my knees, on these stones, to avenge you on Foulon! Husbands, and brothers, and young men, Give us the blood of Foulon, Give us the head of Foulon, Give us the heart of Foulon, Give us the body and soul of Foulon, Rend Foulon to pieces, and dig him into the ground, that grass may grow from him! With these cries, numbers of the women, lashed into blind frenzy, whirled about, striking and tearing at their own friends until they dropped into a passionate swoon, and were only saved by the men belonging to them from being trampled under foot.
vi: The men, terrifying and seething with rage, stood at the windows looking out, grabbing any weapon they could find, and rushed down to the street; but it was the women who presented a sight that made even the bravest shudder. Leaving behind their household chores in poverty, abandoning their children, the elderly, and the sick, who were crawling in hunger on the bare ground, the women let their hair down and ran out, urging each other and themselves to join the frenzy with the wildest screams and actions. The thug Foulon has been caught, sisters! Foulon has been caught, mother! The scoundrel Foulon has been caught, daughter! Then dozens and dozens of women ran into the crowd, beating their chests, tearing their hair, screaming, Foulon is still alive! Foulon told the starving people to eat grass! Foulon told my old father to eat grass when I had no bread for him! Foulon told my nursing infant to eat grass when my breasts ran dry with no milk to feed him! Oh Mother Mary, this Foulon! Oh God, why is this suffering so great! Listen to me, oh my dead child! Listen to me, oh my withered old father! I kneel on these stones and swear to kill Foulon to avenge you, my child, my father! Husband, brother, give me Foulon's blood! Cut off Foulon's head for me! Tear out Foulon's heart for me! Give me Foulon's body and soul! Dismember Foulon and bury him so the grass grows green on his grave! Screaming like that, wave after wave of women, driven to blind madness, kept spinning, hitting, and tearing at each other until they collapsed unconscious from the frenzy, only to be saved from trampling by their husbands, fathers, and brothers.
tr: Men were terrifying as they looked out from the windows with their cruel rage, armed with whatever weapons they could find, mingling with the flood of people in the streets, but the state of the women was enough to freeze the blood of even the bravest person. Leaving behind all the work in their barely subsisting homes, their children, their elderly, and their starving, ailing loved ones who were languishing in desolate places, they threw themselves into the streets with their hair flowing, inciting both each other and themselves with wild screams and behaviors. Foulon the murderer has been caught, my brother! Foulon the murderer has been caught, my mother! Foulon the tyrant has been caught, my daughter! Then a group joined them, beating their chests, tearing their hair, and shouting, Foulon is alive! Foulon, who told the starving people to eat grass! Foulon, who told my old father, to whom I couldn't give a piece of bread, to eat grass! Foulon, who told the baby that couldn't suckle from its mother's dry breast to suck on grass! Oh, this Foulon! My God, what pains we have suffered! Hear me, my dead baby and my withering father! I swear on this stone and soil that I will take revenge on Foulon for you! Husbands, brothers, and young men, bring us Foulon's blood! Bring us Foulon's head! Bring us Foulon's heart, bring us Foulon's body and soul, tear Foulon apart and bury him so that grass grows on him! A multitude of women, screaming like mad, attacked everything around them, whirling about, hitting their friends and tearing their clothes until they fainted from rage, and only their men could save them from being trampled underfoot.
es: Terrible was the expression of the men who, thirsty for blood, stuck their heads out of the windows; even more terrible was that of those who, wielding the most deadly weapons they could get their hands on, came out of the doors of the houses and spread furiously through the streets; but the expression of the women was enough to freeze the blood of the most fearless man. Abandoning the domestic tasks imposed by their misery, leaving their old and their children, naked and starving, lying on the hard ground, they went out into the street, their hair loose, trampling over each other, howling like maddened beasts and acting as such. —Die, Foulon, who stole my sister! —Death to the villain Foulon, who robbed my mother! —Die, scoundrel Foulon, who stole my daughter from me! Others, in large groups, penetrated among those who had previously shouted and, striking their chests fiercely and tearing at their hair, they vociferated: —Foulon alive! He who told the starving people to eat grass must not live! The demon who told me to give grass to my mother when bread was lacking cannot live! The monster who told me to give grass to suck on, when my breasts, dried up from hunger, could not provide the milk needed to live, will not live! —Holy Virgin!—others exclaimed. —Listen to me, my son, from the other world to which the inhuman Foulon took you! Listen to me, my father, who died of hunger because of him! By your bones, by your soul, I swear to avenge you on the person of Foulon! —Husbands... give us the blood of Foulon! Young fathers, give us the head of Foulon! Brothers, give us the heart of Foulon! Young patriots, give us the body and soul of Foulon, tear apart the miserable corpse of Foulon, bury it, so that it may fertilize the land and grass may grow over his remains, the grass he advised us to eat! These and other no less terrifying screams drove many women to frenzy, who, after running with insane fury, howling like beasts, and hitting and scratching their own friends, rolled on the ground with their eyes out of their sockets and their mouths foaming. Thanks to their relatives or friends lifting them up, they did not die crushed under the thousands of beastly feet.

en: Nevertheless, not a moment was lost; not a moment! This Foulon was at the Hotel de Ville, and might be loosed. Never, if Saint Antoine knew his own sufferings, insults, and wrongs! Armed men and women flocked out of the Quarter so fast, and drew even these last dregs after them with such a force of suction, that within a quarter of an hour there was not a human creature in Saint Antoine’s bosom but a few old crones and the wailing children.
vi: However, the group did not delay at all; not even for a moment! This Fouton is at City Hall and could escape. No way, if the people of Saint Antoine knew clearly the suffering, humiliation, and wrongs they had to endure! A group of men and women, armed with weapons, quickly rushed out of this area, with a powerful force that swept up everyone to the last person, surging so rapidly that within fifteen minutes, there was no one left in the heart of Saint Antoine except for a few elderly and crying children.
tr: Still, no time had been wasted! This man called Foulon was at the City Hall and could be released. However, St Antoine, who had suffered so much pain, insult, and injustice, would never allow this! Armed men and women swiftly left the neighborhood in droves, and they pulled the remaining stragglers towards them with such force that within fifteen minutes, there was no one left in the heart of St Antoine except for a few old women and wailing children.
es: Not a moment was lost. Foulon was at the Hôtel de Ville where he might be set free... Would San Antonio tolerate such mockery? Never, if he had not lost the notion of his dignity, the memory of his sufferings, of his insults, of his injustices! A flood of armed men and disheveled women soon overflowed the district's boundaries, dragging with it every human creature raised on the dry breasts of San Antonio, with the exception of a few decrepit old men and some children unable to walk.

en: No. They were all by that time choking the Hall of Examination where this old man, ugly and wicked, was, and overflowing into the adjacent open space and streets. The Defarges, husband and wife, The Vengeance, and Jacques Three, were in the first press, and at no great distance from him in the Hall.
vi: No. By that time, everyone was already crowded into the City Hall, now turned into the Court - where that vile, evil old man was present - or spilling out into the nearby open spaces and streets. The Defarges, both husband and wife, the Goddess of Vengeance, and Jacques Three, were among the first to push in, standing not far from Foulon. −
tr: No one. At that moment, they had all crowded into the interrogation room where this old, ugly, and treacherous man was, and they had even spilled into the adjacent courtyard and streets. The Defarges, husband and wife, Revenge, and Jacques Three were always at the forefront, and in the room, they were standing just a little away from Foulon.
es: A flood of armed men and disheveled women soon overflowed the district's boundaries, dragging with it every human creature raised on the dry breasts of San Antonio, with the exception of a few decrepit old men and some children unable to walk. The mobs have already entered the room where they are taking the old man's statement, who may have been ruthless, but at that moment was deserving of compassion. In a prominent place, in the front row, a short distance from the prisoner, are the Defarges, husband and wife, La Vengeance, and Jacques Three.

en: “See!” cried madame, pointing with her knife. “See the old villain bound with ropes. That was well done to tie a bunch of grass upon his back. Ha, ha! That was well done. Let him eat it now!” Madame put her knife under her arm, and clapped her hands as at a play.
vi: There! - Madame Defarge shouted, brandishing her knife. - Look at that wicked old man tied up with rope. They've tied a bundle of grass to his back too, how wonderful. Ha ha! Wonderful indeed. Make him eat grass! - She tucked the knife under her arm, clapping as if watching a play.
tr: Pointing with her knife, "Look at that!" shouted the madam. "Look, they've tied up the old man with ropes. It's a good idea to tie a bunch of grass to his back. Ha ha! They had a very clever idea. Now let him eat it!" The madam had tucked her knife under her arm and was clapping her hands as if she were in a play.
es: —Look at him!—shouts the innkeeper, pointing at him with the tip of the knife. — There you have the old villain tied up with ropes! It wouldn't be a bad idea to tie a bundle of grass to his back! Ha, ha, ha, ha! It's the best we can do... force him to eat grass! The innkeeper placed her knife under her arm and applauded herself.

en: The people immediately behind Madame Defarge, explaining the cause of her satisfaction to those behind them, and those again explaining to others, and those to others, the neighbouring streets resounded with the clapping of hands. Similarly, during two or three hours of drawl, and the winnowing of many bushels of words, Madame Defarge’s frequent expressions of impatience were taken up, with marvellous quickness, at a distance: the more readily, because certain men who had by some wonderful exercise of agility climbed up the external architecture to look in from the windows, knew Madame Defarge well, and acted as a telegraph between her and the crowd outside the building.
vi: The people standing right behind Madame Defarge explained the reason for her satisfaction to those behind them, and these people would explain to others, and so on; thus, the nearby streets also echoed with applause. For two or three hours straight, along with the whispered explanations, Madame Defarge's frequently anxious expression was quickly mimicked and spread - the image even traveled faster than the words - because many strong and agile people had climbed up the outside beams to look in through the windows. They knew Madame Defarge well and took on the task of conveying her reactions to the crowd outside.
tr: The people standing right behind Madam Defarge explained to those behind them why the woman was so delighted, then they explained to those behind them, and they to those behind them, until all the surrounding streets echoed with applause. Thus, during the two to three hours of interrogation and while the words spilled from the man's mouth were being sifted, even the people far away were instantly informed of every expression that appeared on Madam Defarge's impatient face. One reason for this rapid dissemination was that some agile men who knew Madam Defarge well climbed the building from the outside to look in through the window and acted as telegraphs between the madam and the crowd outside.
es: As the people who were positioned behind Madame Defarge hurried to explain to those following them the cause of her satisfaction, and the explanation spread from ear to ear like wildfire, soon deafening applause resounded in the hall, in the street, and in the nearby squares. In the same way, all the expressions of impatience uttered by Madame Defarge over two or three hours were transmitted with astonishing speed over great distances. It is not surprising: men endowed with exceptional agility climbed the facade of the building, taking advantage of the architectural adornments that covered it, until they perched on the windowsills, from where they could perfectly see and hear Madame Defarge and acted as a telegraph between her and the crowd roaring outside.

en: At length the sun rose so high that it struck a kindly ray as of hope or protection, directly down upon the old prisoner’s head. The favour was too much to bear; in an instant the barrier of dust and chaff that had stood surprisingly long, went to the winds, and Saint Antoine had got him!
vi: The sun had finally risen high enough to shine directly down on the old criminal's head like a ray of hope or protection. That grace was too much; in a flash, the dusty and rickety fence that had stood for so long without collapsing, now flew apart - the people of Saint Antoine rushed in to seize the prisoner.
tr: After a while, the sun rose higher as if to give hope or to protect, and its soft light fell directly on the old prisoner. This was too much; in the blink of an eye, that long barrier of straw dust mingled with the wind and St. Antoine seized the man!
es: The sun rose so high that it finally cast a cheerful ray of confidence or protection over the old man's head. Clouds of dust rose in the distance; the sound of furious galloping horses was carried by the air in its waves; but Saint Anthony was awake, Saint Anthony was vigilant, and his keen eyes saw the clouds of dust, and his sensitive ears heard the thunder of the horses' hooves.

en: It was known directly, to the furthest confines of the crowd. Defarge had but sprung over a railing and a table, and folded the miserable wretch in a deadly embrace—Madame Defarge had but followed and turned her hand in one of the ropes with which he was tied—The Vengeance and Jacques Three were not yet up with them, and the men at the windows had not yet swooped into the Hall, like birds of prey from their high perches—when the cry seemed to go up, all over the city, “Bring him out! Bring him to the lamp!”
vi: Even from the farthest corner of the crowd, everyone immediately knew what was happening. Defarge jumped over a fence and a table, tightly gripping the wretched unfortunate in a deadly embrace - Madame Defarge, closely following her husband, immediately seized the rope binding the prisoner - The Goddess of Vengeance and Jacques Three had not yet arrived, the crowd clinging to the windows like perched birds had not yet managed to get inside - when it seemed the entire city echoed with the shout: "Bring him out! Bring him to the lamppost!"
tr: Even those at the very back of the crowd were instantly informed of the situation. Defarge leaped over the railing and the table that stood between him and the man, and pounced on the lowly scoundrel – Madame Defarge followed her husband and grabbed one of the ropes the man was tied with – Revenge and Jacques Three did not follow them, and the men perched at the windows like birds did not rush into the hall yet; then from outside came the cries, "Bring him out! Bring him to the lamp!"
es: Clouds of dust rose in the distance; the sound of furious galloping horses was carried by the air in its waves; but Saint Anthony was awake, Saint Anthony was vigilant, and his keen eyes saw the clouds of dust, and his sensitive ears heard the thunder of the horses' hooves. Defarge leaped over the balustrade and the table, and embraced the unfortunate old man in a deadly grip. The tavern keeper followed her husband like a faithful wife, and grabbed one of the ropes that bound the prisoner. Before La Vengeance and Santiago Third had time to join them, before the men perched in the windows could jump into the room, the entire city seemed to shout with hundreds of thousands of mouths: —It's ours...! To the lantern!

en: Down, and up, and head foremost on the steps of the building; now, on his knees; now, on his feet; now, on his back; dragged, and struck at, and stifled by the bunches of grass and straw that were thrust into his face by hundreds of hands; torn, bruised, panting, bleeding, yet always entreating and beseeching for mercy; now full of vehement agony of action, with a small clear space about him as the people drew one another back that they might see; now, a log of dead wood drawn through a forest of legs; he was hauled to the nearest street corner where one of the fatal lamps swung, and there Madame Defarge let him go—as a cat might have done to a mouse—and silently and composedly looked at him while they made ready, and while he besought her: the women passionately screeching at him all the time, and the men sternly calling out to have him killed with grass in his mouth. Once, he went aloft, and the rope broke, and they caught him shrieking; twice, he went aloft, and the rope broke, and they caught him shrieking; then, the rope was merciful, and held him, and his head was soon upon a pike, with grass enough in the mouth for all Saint Antoine to dance at the sight of.
vi: Falling down, being pulled up, head thrust down on the steps of the City Hall; then, kneeling; then, standing up; then, falling backward; being dragged away, being punched and kicked, suffocating from the handfuls of grass and straw thrust into his face by hundreds of hands; clothes torn, flesh bruised, suffocating, bleeding, but never ceasing to plead, to beg for mercy; then struggling fiercely in agony within the cramped space as waves of people pushed closer to look; then like a dead log being dragged through a forest of human legs; the criminal was dragged to the nearest street corner where a fateful street lamp hung, and there Madame Defarge let him go - like a cat playing with a mouse - then silently, coldly watched the victim while everyone prepared. And while the prisoner begged her, the women continued to scream madly at him, the men aggressively shouted to stuff grass into his mouth and then kill him. The first time, the rope broke when he was hanged, and the crowd caught him as he screamed falling down; the second time, the rope broke again when he was hanged, and the crowd caught him again as he screamed falling down; and on the third time, the merciless rope held tight, and soon after his head was displayed on a pike, grass stuffed in his mouth for all of Saint Antoine to see and dance in celebration.
tr: They dragged the man down the stairs of the building; sometimes on his knees, sometimes standing, sometimes pulling him on his back, they pushed him, and when hundreds of hands pressed grass and straw into his face, he felt like he was suffocating; his clothes were torn, he was covered in wounds and bruises, he was struggling to breathe, and he was bleeding all over; yet he did not stop begging and pleading for mercy; during this passionate and painful act, people made space by pulling each other back to see him; he was like a dry log in a forest of hundreds of legs; they dragged the man to the nearest corner where one of the deadly lamps was hanging; Madam here –like a cat releasing a mouse– let him go and watched him with a calm demeanor while the crowd made their preparations, and he begged and pleaded with Madam. Meanwhile, the women were constantly screaming shrilly, and the men were shouting that they would kill him by stuffing his mouth harshly. At one point, they pulled the man up, but the rope broke and they caught him as he fell to the ground screaming; then they pulled him up again, the rope broke again, and they caught him again as he fell screaming; finally, the rope held him painfully, and soon his head, with enough grass in his mouth to make all of St. Antoine dance before him, was on the end of a stake.
es: Knocked to the ground and lifted back up, forced to descend dragging that fatal ladder, sometimes headfirst, other times on his knees, now face down and now on his back, brutally beaten and wounded, suffocated by the bundles of grass and straw that hundreds of hands violently shoved into his mouth, shattered, crushed, losing blood in torrents, the wretched man did not cease for an instant to beg for mercy. His agonies increased when the beasts closest to him stepped aside so that no one would be deprived of the pleasure of watching him, and they reached their ultimate limit when he saw that they tied him by the feet to a log and carried him to the nearby corner, where there was a lantern. There, Madame Defarge released him, like a cat playing with a mouse, and looked at him with terrifying calmness without uttering a word, while the men completed their preparations, unaffected by the pleas the unfortunate man directed at her. They hoisted him up, and the rope broke... The same thing happened twice, until finally, a rope, more compassionate than the men, held and put an end to his sufferings. Moments later, Saint Anthony danced around a head, impaled on a pike, from whose mouth bundles of grass and straw protruded.

en: Nor was this the end of the day’s bad work, for Saint Antoine so shouted and danced his angry blood up, that it boiled again, on hearing when the day closed in that the son-in-law of the despatched, another of the people’s enemies and insulters, was coming into Paris under a guard five hundred strong, in cavalry alone. Saint Antoine wrote his crimes on flaring sheets of paper, seized him—would have torn him out of the breast of an army to bear Foulon company—set his head and heart on pikes, and carried the three spoils of the day, in Wolf-procession through the streets.
vi: The brutal work of that day was not yet over, for the people of Saint Antoine, having shouted, danced, and boiled with hatred, were once again seething with resentment at the end of the day upon hearing the news that the son-in-law of the slain man - another enemy and offender of the people - was coming to Paris with five hundred escort soldiers, all cavalry. The people of Saint Antoine recorded this man's crimes on fluttering papers, then captured him alive - surely they must have attacked the entire army to capture him and subject him to the same fate as Foulon - beheading him and displaying his heart on a sharp stake, and the whole wolf-like crowd paraded all three trophies through the streets.
tr: But the day's bad deeds were not yet over, for when the wretched man's despicable son-in-law, another enemy of the people, arrived in Paris with five hundred soldiers, St. Antoine screamed and went so berserk that the place was in turmoil again. St. Antoine had written his crimes on gilded papers, they caught him quickly –they could have dragged him out of the heart of an army to accompany Foulon– they impaled his head and heart on stakes and paraded through the streets with the day's three trophies in hand.
es: The day did not end there. San Antonio shouted so much, danced so much, that his burning blood ignited again at dusk, upon learning that a son-in-law of the old man who had fallen under his wrath, another of the enemies and offenders of the people, was arriving in Paris with an escort of five hundred mounted men. San Antonio wrote the account of their crimes on sheets of paper stained with blood, attacked the escort... and minutes later paraded through the streets in a joyful procession carrying the trophies of the day impaled on pikes: two heads and a heart!

en: Not before dark night did the men and women come back to the children, wailing and breadless. Then, the miserable bakers’ shops were beset by long files of them, patiently waiting to buy bad bread; and while they waited with stomachs faint and empty, they beguiled the time by embracing one another on the triumphs of the day, and achieving them again in gossip. Gradually, these strings of ragged people shortened and frayed away; and then poor lights began to shine in high windows, and slender fires were made in the streets, at which neighbours cooked in common, afterwards supping at their doors.
vi: It wasn't until late at night that the group of men and women returned to their crying, hungry children. As a result, the unfortunate bakeries were once again surrounded by long lines of people patiently waiting to buy moldy loaves of bread; while waiting with their empty, shrunken stomachs, they passed the time by embracing each other to celebrate their recent achievements and reminiscing about the day's events. Gradually, the ragged lines of people shortened and thinned out, then dim lights began to shine in the high windows, and flickering fires were lit on the streets, with neighboring households gathering to cook together, and afterward, they sat right on the doorsteps, slurping their soup.
tr: When the women and men returned to their whining hungry children, it was already quite dark. Then long queues formed in front of the wretched bakeries, and people waited patiently to get dry bread; while waiting with empty and growling stomachs, they spent their time embracing each other in a drunkenness of victory and gossiping. Gradually, the queues of people in tattered clothes shortened and disappeared, and dim lights began to flicker one by one in the high windows; small fires were also lit in the streets, and neighbors cooked their meals together on these fires and then ate them in front of their doors.
es: Until night fell, those men and women did not think about the elderly or the children they had left in their homes, abandoned and without bread. The miserable bakeries were besieged by endless lines of people waiting for their turn to buy a miserable crust of bad bread, and while they waited with empty stomachs, they celebrated their triumphs by hugging each other and chatting incessantly. Gradually, the lines shortened and finally disappeared: then some dim lights shone inside the houses, and some bonfires were lit in the streets where the poorest cooked together the slop that they later ate in their respective homes.

en: Scanty and insufficient suppers those, and innocent of meat, as of most other sauce to wretched bread. Yet, human fellowship infused some nourishment into the flinty viands, and struck some sparks of cheerfulness out of them. Fathers and mothers who had had their full share in the worst of the day, played gently with their meagre children; and lovers, with such a world around them and before them, loved and hoped.
vi: The dinner was meager, scanty, without meat and also without any sauce for the miserable piece of bread. But friendship had mixed in a bit of nourishing flavor into the dry food, sparking a bit of cheerful laughter. The fathers and mothers who had spent the whole day participating in those dreadful tasks were now gently playing with their skinny children; and the lovers - amidst the surrounding world waiting to embrace them - loved each other and hoped for tomorrow.
tr: The only accompaniment to these meager and inadequate meals, which contained no trace of meat, was dry bread. On the other hand, these poor foods, enriched by friendship, had awakened a sense of joy within people. Parents, who had taken their share of this bad day, played sweetly with their skinny children; lovers, on the other hand, filled with love and hope as they looked at their surroundings and the life stretching out before them.
es: Those dinners were poor and insufficient, pure of meat and free of sauces and seasoning, and yet, the eyes of those who ate such unappetizing dishes sparkled with joy. Fathers and mothers who had taken an active part in the day played happily with their emaciated children, and the lovers, despite the overcast sky, loved and hoped.

en: It was almost morning, when Defarge’s wine-shop parted with its last knot of customers, and Monsieur Defarge said to madame his wife, in husky tones, while fastening the door:
vi: Near dawn, when Defarge's tavern bid farewell to its last guests, Mr. Defarge said to his wife in a hoarse voice as he closed the doors: −
tr: When the last customers at Defarge's wine shop had left, it was almost dawn, and as Monsieur Defarge was locking the door, he whispered softly to Madame:
es: The day was very near when the patrons of Defarge's tavern left, and as he was closing the door, he said to his wife:

en: “At last it is come, my dear!”
vi: At last, the day has come, my dear!
tr: "The day we've been waiting for has finally come, my dear wife!" he said.
es: —At last, it arrived, dear.

en: “Eh well!” returned madame. “Almost.”
vi: − Indeed! - She replied. - It's coming soon.
tr: "Eh!" replied the madam. "Almost."
es: —Yes... almost—replied the lady.

en: Saint Antoine slept, the Defarges slept: even The Vengeance slept with her starved grocer, and the drum was at rest. The drum’s was the only voice in Saint Antoine that blood and hurry had not changed. The Vengeance, as custodian of the drum, could have wakened him up and had the same speech out of him as before the Bastille fell, or old Foulon was seized; not so with the hoarse tones of the men and women in Saint Antoine’s bosom.
vi: Saint Antoine sleeps; the Defarges sleep; even the Goddess of Vengeance sleeps beside her starved husband, and the drum has fallen silent. That drum was the only sound in Saint Antoine that bloodshed and beheadings could not alter. The Goddess of Vengeance, the guardian of that battle drum, might awaken and beat the drum again to rally the people as before the fall of the Bastille, or before old Foulon was seized; but the hoarse voices of all the men and women in the heart of Saint Antoine have been changed forever.
tr: St. Antoine fell asleep, the Defarges fell asleep. Revenge also fell asleep with her husband writhing in hunger, and the drum took a rest. In St. Antoine, the only sound that blood and turmoil couldn't change was the drum's. If she wanted, Revenge, who preserved it, could wake it up and make it produce the sounds from before the fall of the Bastille or before old Foulon was captured; but the same couldn't be said for the low-voiced people in the heart of St. Antoine.
es: Saint Anthony slept, Defarge slept, even La Vengeance slept next to her famished grocer, and the drums also slept. They were the only voice of Saint Anthony that did not change, that always sounded the same. If La Vengeance, who was in charge of them, had awakened them, it is quite certain that they would have delivered the same speech they gave when the Bastille fell, the same one they gave when Foulon was beheaded.

en: CHAPTER XXIII.
vi: The Goddess of Vengeance, the guardian of that battle drum, might awaken and beat the drum again to rally the people as before the fall of the Bastille, or before old Foulon was seized; but the hoarse voices of all the men and women in the heart of Saint Antoine have been changed forever.
tr: XXIII
es: XXIII.

en: Fire Rises
vi: 23. Burning
tr: Tension is Rising
es: THE FIRE IS GAINING INTENSITY

en: There was a change on the village where the fountain fell, and where the mender of roads went forth daily to hammer out of the stones on the highway such morsels of bread as might serve for patches to hold his poor ignorant soul and his poor reduced body together. The prison on the crag was not so dominant as of yore; there were soldiers to guard it, but not many; there were officers to guard the soldiers, but not one of them knew what his men would do—beyond this: that it would probably not be what he was ordered.
vi: It was no longer the same in the village with the fountain, where the road mender went out daily to the highway, hammering stones to earn enough bread to keep his pitiful, bewildered soul from leaving his emaciated body. The prison on the cliff was no longer as formidable as before; there were still guards but fewer; there were still officers commanding those guards but no one knew what their troops could accomplish - only that these troops might very well disobey their orders.
tr: There was a change in the village where the fountain flowed, and the road worker eked out his living from the stones on the roads for the sake of carrying and holding together his poor ignorant soul and his poor skinny body. The prison on top of the rocks was not as popular as it used to be; there were soldiers guarding it now, but they were few in number, and there were officers protecting these soldiers, but not a single one of them knew what their men would do – moreover, this was probably not something that would be ordered to them.
es: Important changes have occurred in the village from which the road worker would leave every day to wrest from the stones that covered the roads the crust of bread that kept his ignorant soul tied to his emaciated body. The prison of the cut was no longer as formidable as before. Soldiers guarded it, but they were few in number; officers guarded the soldiers, but they did not know what the soldiers would do, for if they knew anything, it was... that they would be very careful not to do what they were ordered.

en: Far and wide lay a ruined country, yielding nothing but desolation. Every green leaf, every blade of grass and blade of grain, was as shrivelled and poor as the miserable people. Everything was bowed down, dejected, oppressed, and broken. Habitations, fences, domesticated animals, men, women, children, and the soil that bore them—all worn out.
vi: Everywhere, the entire countryside was desolate, with nothing but scenes of desolation. Each green leaf, each blade of grass, each stalk of rice was pitifully withered like these impoverished people. Everything was bent, sorrowful, stifling, and hopeless. Houses, fences, livestock, men, women, children, and even the land that sustained them - all were exhausted.
tr: In the distance, a ruined country stretched over a vast area, and the only thing it promised was sorrow. Every green leaf, every blade of grass and piece of grain had withered and shriveled just as much as those poor people. Everything was drooping, joyless, devastated, and ruined. Houses, fences, domestic animals, men, women, children, and the land that gave them life – all were exhausted.
es: The entire territory that could be seen was a desolate steppe. The grass that covered the roads and fields, the plants that germinated there, were as poor and stunted as the people themselves. Bent plants, toppled, crushed... men with hunched backs, disheartened men, oppressed... misery in the homes, misery in the garden fences, misery in the domestic animals, misery in the men, in the women, in the children, misery in the ground on which they all set their feet.

en: Monseigneur (often a most worthy individual gentleman) was a national blessing, gave a chivalrous tone to things, was a polite example of luxurious and shining life, and a great deal more to equal purpose; nevertheless, Monseigneur as a class had, somehow or other, brought things to this. Strange that Creation, designed expressly for Monseigneur, should be so soon wrung dry and squeezed out! There must be something short-sighted in the eternal arrangements, surely! Thus it was, however; and the last drop of blood having been extracted from the flints, and the last screw of the rack having been turned so often that its purchase crumbled, and it now turned and turned with nothing to bite, Monseigneur began to run away from a phenomenon so low and unaccountable.
vi: The blessing of the nation is the high-ranking officials (considered individually, they are often the most elite nobles), they create a chivalrous appearance for everything, are the elegant epitome of luxurious and splendid life, and bring so much meaning to similar matters. However, it is these high-ranking officials, in one way or another, who have caused this situation. It is indeed strange how the world, seemingly reserved for the grand officials, has been drained and exhausted so quickly! There must be some shortsightedness in the way things are permanently arranged! But it is true, and when even the solid rock has been drained to the last drop of blood, when the torture device has been twisted to its final turn and tightening further would strip the screw, when no more pressure can be applied, the high-ranking officials begin to flee from this both dreadful and incomprehensible disaster.
tr: The Monsignor (who is mostly quite a distinguished gentleman) was a blessing for the country, giving events a chivalrous air; he was a fine example of a luxurious and glittering life and many situations akin to it; yet somehow, along with his class, he had brought the matter to this point. How strange it is that the "order" established especially for those like the Monsignor would soon collapse! Apparently, they couldn't see that this order wouldn't last forever! Indeed, as the last drop of blood stained the stones, and the pulley system of the torture rack began to spin uselessly from the constant turning of the last screw, the Monsignor decided to flee from these vile and incomprehensible matters.
es: The gentleman, almost always a most dignified knight considered as an individual, was a national blessing, gave tone to things, and constituted by himself an eloquent example of a brilliant and lavish life; but the gentleman, considered as an institution, as a class, had created that deplorable state of affairs. Strange phenomenon that the world, brought out of nothing for the gentleman's pleasure and enjoyment, was so soon squeezed dry and without a drop of juice! And yet, it was so. The gentleman, finding no longer a drop of blood to suck, seeing nothing to bite into, began to turn his back on a phenomenon as low as it was inexplicable.

en: But, this was not the change on the village, and on many a village like it. For scores of years gone by, Monseigneur had squeezed it and wrung it, and had seldom graced it with his presence except for the pleasures of the chase—now, found in hunting the people; now, found in hunting the beasts, for whose preservation Monseigneur made edifying spaces of barbarous and barren wilderness. No. The change consisted in the appearance of strange faces of low caste, rather than in the disappearance of the high caste, chiselled, and otherwise beautified and beautifying features of Monseigneur.
vi: But that is not the change in this village, and many villages like it. For decades, the high-ranking officials have drained this place dry but rarely showed their faces unless they were excited to go hunting - sometimes hunting people, sometimes hunting animals, and turning the barren, savage lands into exclusive hunting grounds for themselves. No, the change lies in the unfamiliar faces of the commoners appearing, not in the refined, elegant appearances of the high and mighty, whose embellished facades are disappearing.
tr: But in the village and many other villages, nothing had changed. The Monsignor had oppressed and exploited the village for many years, rarely making an appearance except during hunting seasons – sometimes hunting humans, sometimes animals, and he would ruthlessly clear barren lands to preserve them. No. The change was not so much in the absence of the upper class, symbolized by the blessed and blessing face of the Monsignor, but in the emergence of the strange faces of the lower class.
es: But the important changes that occurred in the village and in many other similar villages did not precisely lie in that. Dozens of years ago, the lord squeezed and wrung the people without it occurring to him to honor them with his gracious presence more than very few times, and even then, it was to indulge in the pleasures of the hunt... whether it was of men or animals. No. The change consisted more in the appearance of lowly faces than in the disappearance of the faces of the upper class.

en: For, in these times, as the mender of roads worked, solitary, in the dust, not often troubling himself to reflect that dust he was and to dust he must return, being for the most part too much occupied in thinking how little he had for supper and how much more he would eat if he had it—in these times, as he raised his eyes from his lonely labour, and viewed the prospect, he would see some rough figure approaching on foot, the like of which was once a rarity in those parts, but was now a frequent presence. As it advanced, the mender of roads would discern without surprise, that it was a shaggy-haired man, of almost barbarian aspect, tall, in wooden shoes that were clumsy even to the eyes of a mender of roads, grim, rough, swart, steeped in the mud and dust of many highways, dank with the marshy moisture of many low grounds, sprinkled with the thorns and leaves and moss of many byways through woods.
vi: Therefore, at that time, when working alone in the dust, the road worker seldom thought about his dusty fate of returning to dust, but mainly worried about how many meals he could earn and, if possible, how many meals he could eat - at that time, when he lifted his eyes from his solitary work to look into the distance, he often saw a rustic figure walking towards him, a type of traveler that was once rare in this area but was now becoming more common. As the figure became clearer, the road worker would recognize without much surprise that it was a person with disheveled hair, a somewhat savage face, tall and large, wearing crude wooden shoes that even the road workers like him found clumsy, with an aggressive, rough, dark appearance, covered in dust from miles of travel, soaked in mud from marshy lands, and full of thorns and moss from cutting through forest shortcuts.
tr: Meanwhile, the road worker, lost in thought about how little food he had left and how long he could last if he ate it, far from the thought that he came from the earth and would one day return to it, working alone amidst the dust and dirt, looked up and saw a rough-looking man approaching him, the kind that used to be rare in the area but now was frequently encountered. When the man got closer, the road worker noticed that he was tall, wild-looking, and disheveled, and he wasn't surprised at all. But what did catch his eye were the man's wooden shoes, covered in dust and dirt, caked in mud, soaked in low-lying wet areas, and smeared with thorns, grass, and mold from the secluded paths in the groves, which even to a grim, rough, and sunburnt road worker like himself seemed misshapen.
es: At the time we refer to, when the solitary road worker labored turning the soil, without thinking that it was dust and to dust it would return, for his thoughts almost always revolved around how little he would find to eat for dinner at home, and how much he would eat if he had it, in those times, if he lifted his eyes from the ground and looked along the road, it was not impossible that they would encounter men of rough appearance, very rare before in those places and very frequent now. As those men approached the road worker, he saw that they were generally individuals with coarse bristles and an almost barbaric appearance, tall, wearing clogs, with a fierce look, covered in mud and dust, like someone who has walked many roads.

en: Such a man came upon him, like a ghost, at noon in the July weather, as he sat on his heap of stones under a bank, taking such shelter as he could get from a shower of hail.
vi: A figure like that appeared like a phantom at midday in July, when the road worker was sitting on a pile of rocks under an embankment, trying to avoid a sudden hailstorm.
tr: The road worker sat on a pile of stones under a ledge he had taken refuge under to escape the downpour, watching this man approach like a ghost in the middle of the day in July.
es: One of these specimens appeared suddenly to the road worker, one day in the month of July around noon, while he was sitting sheltered by a wall, to protect himself from the hail that the clouds were sending in abundance.

en: The man looked at him, looked at the village in the hollow, at the mill, and at the prison on the crag. When he had identified these objects in what benighted mind he had, he said, in a dialect that was just intelligible:
vi: The other man looked at him, looked down at the village in the valley, looked at the mill, then looked at the prison on the cliff. After identifying those targets in his dark mind, he spoke in an almost incomprehensible dialect: − How's the situation, Jacques?
tr: Adam looked at the road worker, then at the village in the pit, the mill, and the prison on the rocks. After placing these locations somewhere in his ignorant mind, he said with a barely understandable accent:
es: The stranger looked at him, then let his eyes wander over the village that slept in the hollow, over the mill and the prison that stood on the cliff, and when he had identified all those objects, he asked, in a dialect that was barely intelligible:

en: “How goes it, Jacques?”
tr: "How's it going, Jacques?"
es: —How are you, Santiago?

en: “All well, Jacques.”
vi: All good, Jacques.
tr: "Everything is fine, Jacques.""
es: —Very well, Santiago.

en: “Touch then!”
vi: − Understood!
tr: "Give me your hand then!"
es: —High five!

en: They joined hands, and the man sat down on the heap of stones.
vi: The two men shook hands, and he sat down on the pile of rocks. −
tr: They shook hands and he also sat on that pile of stones.
es: The two interlocutors exchanged a handshake.

en: “No dinner?”
vi: Not having lunch? −
tr: "Do you have food?"
es: —Is there no food?

en: “Nothing but supper now,” said the mender of roads, with a hungry face.
vi: Now we only have dinner, - the road worker said, his face showing hunger.
tr: "There are only a few bites to snack on," said the road worker, with a hungry face.
es: —Just dinner—replied the truck driver with a hungry look.

en: “It is the fashion,” growled the man. “I meet no dinner anywhere.”
vi: − It's the same everywhere, - the other person grumbled. - Everywhere you go, you have to skip lunch.
tr: "That's the custom!" the man grumbled. "I couldn't find a meal anywhere I went."
es: —It's the fashion—grumbled the stranger. —I can't find anyone who eats.

en: He took out a blackened pipe, filled it, lighted it with flint and steel, pulled at it until it was in a bright glow: then, suddenly held it from him and dropped something into it from between his finger and thumb, that blazed and went out in a puff of smoke.
vi: He took out a darkened pipe, packed it with tobacco, lit it with a flint and steel, and puffed away until the tobacco glowed red; then he removed the pipe from his mouth, pinched some kind of powder between his thumb and forefinger and dropped it in, the pipe flared up and then extinguished, leaving a wisp of smoke.
tr: Adam took out a darkened pipe and filled it, then lit it with a flint stone. He drew on it until a bright redness formed at the tip, then suddenly pulled it from his mouth and threw a bright object, which he held between his fingers and extinguished as soon as it fell.
es: Then he took out a blackened pipe, filled it, and lit it, and then dropped something he had between his thumb and index finger onto it.

en: “Touch then.” It was the turn of the mender of roads to say it this time, after observing these operations. They again joined hands.
vi: − Understood! - Now it's the turn of the road worker to speak after observing that action. The two shook hands again.
tr: "Shake hands then!" After observing all these procedures, it was the road worker's turn to say this phrase. They shook hands again.
es: A flame and a small cloud of smoke emerged from the pipe. —High five!—exclaimed the road worker, after attentively observing the aforementioned operations. The interlocutors exchanged the second handshake.

en: “To-night?” said the mender of roads.
vi: − Tonight? - The road guide asked. − Tonight? -
tr: "Tonight?" asked the road worker.
es: —Tonight?—asked the truck driver.

en: “To-night,” said the man, putting the pipe in his mouth.
vi: The traveler said while bringing the pipe to his lips.
tr: "Tonight!" said the man, bringing the pipe to his mouth.
es: —Tonight—replied the stranger, bringing the pipe to his mouth.

en: “Where?”
tr: "Where?"
es: —Where?

en: “Here.”
vi: Where? − Here.
tr: "Here."
es: —Here.

en: He and the mender of roads sat on the heap of stones looking silently at one another, with the hail driving in between them like a pigmy charge of bayonets, until the sky began to clear over the village.
vi: Y and the road worker sat silently on the pile of stones, looking at each other while the hail shot sharp drops like bayonets into the space between them, until the sky over the village began to clear.
tr: The road worker and Adam sat silently on the pile of stones, looking at each other while hailstones rained down like bullets and the clouds over the village dispersed.
es: Both remained seated on the pile of stones, looking at each other, until the hail stopped and the sky cleared.

en: “Show me!” said the traveller then, moving to the brow of the hill.
vi: − Show me the way! - The traveler said and then went up the hill. − There! -
tr: Then the traveler advanced towards the slope of the hill and said, "Show me!"
es: —Instruct me—said the traveler then, addressing the crest of the hill.

en: “See!” returned the mender of roads, with extended finger. “You go down here, and straight through the street, and past the fountain—”
vi: The road worker replied, extending a finger. - You go down here, cross the street, pass the fountain... − Forget about those! -
tr: The road worker said, "Did you see that?" pointing his finger. "Go down from there and walk straight when you reach the road, then pass the fountain."
es: —Look—replied the traveler, with his arm extended,—go down to the hollow, enter through the street, you will pass the fountain...

en: “To the Devil with all that!” interrupted the other, rolling his eye over the landscape. “I go through no streets and past no fountains. Well?”
vi: The other interrupted, glancing around the scene. - I'm not crossing any street or passing any fountain. What?
tr: "For God's sake, stop!" the man interrupted, pointing to the scenery with his eyes. "I don't walk on such roads or pass by fountains. Got it?"
es: —To hell with the street and the fountain!—exclaimed the stranger impatiently. —I neither want to enter any street nor pass by any fountains.

en: “Well! About two leagues beyond the summit of that hill above the village.”
vi: − Fine! Then about two miles over the hill behind the village.
tr: "Alright then! Walk for two hours beyond the peak of that hill above the village.""
es: —I neither want to enter any street nor pass by any fountains. —About two leagues beyond the summit of the hill that rises above the village.

en: “Good. When do you cease to work?”
vi: − Good. When will you be done? −
tr: "Good! When will your work be finished?"
es: —Current. When do you leave work?

en: “At sunset.”
vi: At sunset. −
tr: "As the sun sets."
es: —At sunset.

en: “Will you wake me, before departing? I have walked two nights without resting. Let me finish my pipe, and I shall sleep like a child. Will you wake me?”
vi: Wake me up before you leave, okay? I've been walking for two days without rest. Let me finish this pipe and then I'll sleep soundly. Remember to wake me up.
tr: "Will you wake me up before you leave? I've been walking non-stop for two nights. Let me finish my pipe and sleep here like a child. Will you wake me up?"
es: —Will you wake me up before you leave? It's been two nights and days that I've been traveling without rest or sleep. I'll finish smoking this pipe and sleep like a blessed one... Will you wake me up?

en: “Surely.”
vi: − Certainly.
tr: "Of course.""
es: —With great pleasure.

en: The wayfarer smoked his pipe out, put it in his breast, slipped off his great wooden shoes, and lay down on his back on the heap of stones. He was fast asleep directly.
vi: The traveler finished smoking, put the pipe into his chest, took off his clunky wooden shoes, and then lay down on the pile of rocks. He fell asleep immediately.
tr: The traveler extinguished his pipe, tucked it into his bosom, and, removing his large wooden shoes, lay down on his back on the pile of stones. He fell asleep as soon as he lay down.
es: The wanderer smoked his pipe, put it away in his chest, took off his clogs, and lay down on his back on the pile of stones. Seconds later, he was sleeping deeply.

en: As the road-mender plied his dusty labour, and the hail-clouds, rolling away, revealed bright bars and streaks of sky which were responded to by silver gleams upon the landscape, the little man (who wore a red cap now, in place of his blue one) seemed fascinated by the figure on the heap of stones. His eyes were so often turned towards it, that he used his tools mechanically, and, one would have said, to very poor account. The bronze face, the shaggy black hair and beard, the coarse woollen red cap, the rough medley dress of home-spun stuff and hairy skins of beasts, the powerful frame attenuated by spare living, and the sullen and desperate compression of the lips in sleep, inspired the mender of roads with awe. The traveller had travelled far, and his feet were footsore, and his ankles chafed and bleeding; his great shoes, stuffed with leaves and grass, had been heavy to drag over the many long leagues, and his clothes were chafed into holes, as he himself was into sores. Stooping down beside him, the road-mender tried to get a peep at secret weapons in his breast or where not; but, in vain, for he slept with his arms crossed upon him, and set as resolutely as his lips. Fortified towns with their stockades, guard-houses, gates, trenches, and drawbridges, seemed to the mender of roads, to be so much air as against this figure. And when he lifted his eyes from it to the horizon and looked around, he saw in his small fancy similar figures, stopped by no obstacle, tending to centres all over France.
vi: While the road worker was diligently engaged in his dusty work, the black clouds gradually dispersed, revealing patches of sky through which silver sunlight pierced, casting long streaks of light on the scenery below. The short road worker (now wearing a red hat instead of a blue one) seemed to be drawn to the person lying on the pile of rocks. He kept glancing in that direction, thus only working mechanically and, I must say, perfunctorily. As for the traveler - with a sunburned face, a tangled mess of black hair and beard, a coarse red woolen hat, a ragged assortment of self-woven fabrics and furry animal skins, a strong build that had weakened from lack of food, lips tightly pressed in despair and irritation in his sleep - he inspired awe in the road worker. The traveler had journeyed many miles, his feet swollen, ankles blistered and bleeding, his bulky shoes stuffed with grass and leaves were too heavy to drag along the long road, his clothes torn and full of holes, and his body covered in sores. Stooping beside him, the road worker tried to see if there were any hidden weapons on the traveler; but in vain, for the man slept with his arms firmly crossed over his chest, as resolute as his tightly pressed lips. Fortresses with high walls, deep moats, watchtowers, barred gates, and drawbridges seemed meaningless to the road worker as he looked at this sleeping figure. And when he looked up and around the horizon, in his mind he imagined similar figures, unstoppable, heading towards the cities across France.
tr: When the road worker returned to his dusty job and the clouds dispersed in the sky, making way for bright rays that cast silvery glimmers on the scenery, the small man (now wearing a red hat instead of his blue one) seemed mesmerized by the man lying on this pile of stones. His eyes frequently drifted to the man, and he used his tools almost absentmindedly, even a bit clumsily. The man's bronze face, his tangled hair and beard, his red woolen hat, his handmade outfit pieced together from various cheap fabrics and hides, his strong body thinned from a life of scarcity, and his lips tightly shut in a sullen and hopeless manner as he slept, evoked a mixture of respect and fear in the road worker. It was evident that the traveler had come from a very long distance; his feet were swollen and covered in wounds. It must have been difficult to drag those large shoes filled with leaves and grass for so many hours, and just as he was battered, his clothes were also torn and tattered. The road worker bent over the man to see if he was hiding a weapon in his bosom, but it was in vain, for the man had his arms tightly crossed over his chest, just like his lips. The road worker thought that cities protected by embankments, watchtowers, gates, ditches, and drawbridges were nothing for a figure of this stature. When he lifted his eyes from the man and looked at the horizon, he vaguely saw that such unstoppable men covered all of France.
es: A strange fascination was exerted by the traveler's figure lying on the pile of stones over the road worker, whose cap was no longer blue, as before, but red. Engaged in his rough task, he so frequently turned his eyes towards the sleeper that it can be said he handled his tools in a mechanical manner and with scant results. The bronzed face, the tousled black hair and thick beard of the same color, the red cap made of coarse wool, the rough cloth suit, the robust constitution slightly diminished by deprivations, and the rigid and violent compression of the traveler's lips, filled the road worker with fear. The unknown man must have traveled great distances, judging by his blistered feet and his chafed and bleeding ankles. The road worker tried to see if the sleeper was carrying weapons or not, but in vain, as the sleeper's arms, crossed over his chest, prevented it. Fortresses, walled enclosures, deep ditches, and drawbridges must have been minor obstacles for men like him; and when the road worker, taking his eyes off him, raised them and looked around, he believed he saw with his imagination men like him who, blind to obstacles, ran determinedly from the periphery towards the center of France.

en: The man slept on, indifferent to showers of hail and intervals of brightness, to sunshine on his face and shadow, to the paltering lumps of dull ice on his body and the diamonds into which the sun changed them, until the sun was low in the west, and the sky was glowing. Then, the mender of roads having got his tools together and all things ready to go down into the village, roused him.
vi: The other man still slept, indifferent to the alternating sun and rain, to the light and darkness that took turns covering his face, to the opaque hailstones scattering on his body that glistened like diamonds when the sun shone on them, sleeping until the sun dipped down in the west and the entire sky turned red. At that moment, the road worker had finished packing up his tools and everything, ready to head back to the village, and then he woke the other man.
tr: Adam, the torrential rain, the intermittently shining sun, the sun that would appear and disappear on his face, the hailstones that would patter on his body and then turn into diamonds under the effect of the sun, without paying any heed to them, continued to sleep until the sun lowered in the west and the sky turned crimson. After a while, when the road worker was ready to gather his tools and descend to the village, he woke him up.
es: The stranger continued sleeping, indifferent to the hailstorms that fell from time to time, indifferent to the kisses of the burning sun, and indifferent to the shadows. He did not wake up, he did not move until, with the setting of the day's star, the road worker woke him up, after gathering all his tools to begin the return to the village.

en: “Good!” said the sleeper, rising on his elbow. “Two leagues beyond the summit of the hill?”
vi: − Good! - The traveler propped himself up on his elbow. - Two miles over the hill past the village? − Around that.
tr: "Alright!" said the sleeping man, straightening up on his elbow. "Two hours away from the top of the hill, right?"
es: —Very well—said the stranger, sitting up. — You say two leagues beyond the crest of the hill that overlooks the village?

en: “About.”
vi: − Around that.
tr: "More or less."
es: —More or less.

en: “About. Good!”
vi: Good!
tr: "More or less. Alright!"
es: —More or less... Alright.

en: The mender of roads went home, with the dust going on before him according to the set of the wind, and was soon at the fountain, squeezing himself in among the lean kine brought there to drink, and appearing even to whisper to them in his whispering to all the village. When the village had taken its poor supper, it did not creep to bed, as it usually did, but came out of doors again, and remained there. A curious contagion of whispering was upon it, and also, when it gathered together at the fountain in the dark, another curious contagion of looking expectantly at the sky in one direction only. Monsieur Gabelle, chief functionary of the place, became uneasy; went out on his house-top alone, and looked in that direction too; glanced down from behind his chimneys at the darkening faces by the fountain below, and sent word to the sacristan who kept the keys of the church, that there might be need to ring the tocsin by-and-bye.
vi: The road worker headed back, the dust on the road ahead swirling with the wind, and soon he reached the water fountain, squeezing in among the bony cows being led to drink, and it seemed he was whispering secrets for both the village and the cows to hear. When the villagers had finished their modest dinner, they did not climb into bed as usual but instead sat in front of their houses, staying there. The peculiar habit of whispering into each other's ears had infected the entire village, and when they gathered around the fountain in the dark, they caught another peculiar habit of looking in one direction, waiting for something in the sky. Mr. Gabelle, the station commander here, became anxious; he also climbed onto the roof alone to look in that direction, then looked down at the dark faces behind the chimney below and sent a message to the church keyholder that the alarm bell might need to be rung soon.
tr: The road worker, pushing the dust and dirt ahead of him with the blowing wind, moved towards the house and, shortly after reaching the fountain, mingled with the skinny cows brought to drink water, pretended to whisper to them, and whispered something to the whole village. After the villagers had a snack with the intention of dinner, they did not go to bed as usual but came out to their doorsteps again and waited. The strange whisper had spread everywhere, and when the villagers gathered at the fountain in the dark, everyone looked in the same direction in the sky with hopeful eyes, as if it had spread from one to another. Monsieur Gabelle, who was responsible for that region, was alarmed; he climbed to the roof of his house alone and also looked in that direction; he glanced at the increasingly darkening faces at the fountain below from behind the chimneys and soon sent word to the sexton, who kept the church keys, thinking that the bell might need to be rung.
es: The truck driver returned home, following the cloud of dust raised by his feet and pushed by the wind blowing at his back, and soon found himself by the fountain among tightly packed herds of skinny cows brought there to drink.
