en: “I know the fellow.”
tr: "I know that man."
es: —I know that gentleman. —By all the devils together!...

en: “Do you, by Jupiter?” said Stryver. “I am sorry for it.”
vi: You do, by God? - Stryver said. - I feel sorry for you.
tr: "Really?" said Stryver. "I'm sorry to hear that.""
es: Do you know him? I feel it in my soul.

en: “Why?”
vi: − Why? − Why, Darnay?
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why?

en: “Why, Mr. Darnay? D’ye hear what he did? Don’t ask, why, in these times.”
vi: − Why? − Why, Darnay? Haven't you heard about the things he's done? Don't ask why in these times. −
tr: "Why, Mr. Darnay? Haven't you heard what he has done? In such a time, is it appropriate to ask why?"
es: —Are you asking why, Darnay? But haven't you heard what he has done? —I've heard it, yes; but I ask you why you feel that I know you.

en: “But I do ask why?”
vi: But I want to ask why? −
tr: "But I am asking.""
es: —I've heard it, yes; but I ask you why you feel that I know you.

en: “Then I tell you again, Mr. Darnay, I am sorry for it. I am sorry to hear you putting any such extraordinary questions. Here is a fellow, who, infected by the most pestilent and blasphemous code of devilry that ever was known, abandoned his property to the vilest scum of the earth that ever did murder by wholesale, and you ask me why I am sorry that a man who instructs youth knows him? Well, but I’ll answer you. I am sorry because I believe there is contamination in such a scoundrel. That’s why.”
vi: Then I'll say it again, Mr. Darnay, I feel sorry for you. I am sorry to hear you raise such strange questions. This is a person who has been infected with the most harmful and blasphemous rules ever, who has given up his property to the most despicable scum of the earth who only know how to commit mass murder, yet you still ask why I am sorry that a children's teacher like you knows such a person? Alright, I will tell you. I am sorry because I believe that kind of scoundrel also spreads widely. That is the reason.
tr: "Then let me say it again, Mr. Darnay, I am sorry that you know this man. I am also sorry that you ask me such strange questions. This man has conformed to the most miserable and vile devilries ever, left his property to the world's most despicable scum who commit mass murder, and a gentleman like you asks me why I am sorry. But I will still explain. I am sorry because such vile ideas are contagious. That's how it is."
es: —In that case, I will repeat to you, Mr. Darnay, that I regret that you know that unworthy man, and that I am sorry you do not understand why I feel this way. It greatly distresses me to hear the inconceivable questions you ask. We are told here of a subject corrupted by the most pestilent and impious of rottenness, of an individual the vilest that has ever existed in the world, who abandons his goods to the scum of the earth, to the scoundrels whose creed is murder and theft, and you ask me why I regret that a man who dedicates himself to teaching youth knows him? Do you insist on knowing? Well, I will tell you! I regret it because I believe that wretches like the one in question contaminate those who know them. And you know it.

en: Mindful of the secret, Darnay with great difficulty checked himself, and said: “You may not understand the gentleman.”
vi: Remembering the secret, Darnay tried his best to stay calm, he said: − Perhaps you do not know this gentleman. −
tr: Darnay, keeping his secret in mind and making a great effort not to reveal it, said: "Perhaps you misunderstood this gentleman.""
es: Darnay, containing himself with difficulty, replied: —Perhaps you do not understand the gentleman to whom you are referring.

en: “I understand how to put you in a corner, Mr. Darnay,” said Bully Stryver, “and I’ll do it. If this fellow is a gentleman, I don’t understand him. You may tell him so, with my compliments. You may also tell him, from me, that after abandoning his worldly goods and position to this butcherly mob, I wonder he is not at the head of them. But, no, gentlemen,” said Stryver, looking all round, and snapping his fingers, “I know something of human nature, and I tell you that you’ll never find a fellow like this fellow, trusting himself to the mercies of such precious protégés. No, gentlemen; he’ll always show ’em a clean pair of heels very early in the scuffle, and sneak away.”
vi: But I know how to corner you, Mr. Darnay, Stryver said in a bullying tone, - and I will do just that. And if that person is indeed a gentleman, then I do not know him. You can tell him that, along with my regards. You can also tell him that, I say this myself, after abandoning his wealth and status to that crowd of butchers, I don't understand why he doesn't just lead them. But no, gentlemen, - Stryver said, looking around and snapping his fingers, - I know a little about human nature, and I tell you that you will never see a person like him entrust himself to the mercy of such a precious group of followers. No, gentlemen, he will always run for his life at the first sign of trouble, and disappear.
tr: "I understand how to corner you, Mr. Darnay," said Zorba Stryver, "and I will corner you. If he is a gentleman, I couldn't understand it. You can convey this to him with my respects. Please ask him for me why, after leaving all his property and reputation to that bloodthirsty mob, he didn't stay at the forefront. But no, gentlemen," said Stryver, looking around and snapping his fingers, "I understand a bit about human nature, and believe me, men like him do not sacrifice themselves in life for those very precious men they favor. No, gentlemen; these people show up at the very beginning of the hustle and bustle with their shiny shoes, and then they vanish."
es: —But I know very well how to put you between a rock and a hard place, and I am going to do it—shouted Stryver. —If that individual is a gentleman, I certainly do not understand him; you can tell him that from me, and give him my regards in passing. You can also add on my behalf that after abandoning the patrimonial goods to the rabble, I am greatly astonished that he has not put himself at the head of the thieves and murderers... But no, gentlemen, no; I, who know a little about human nature, dare to assure you that you will never find a subject like that who entrusts himself to the tender care of your humble protégés. No, gentlemen, no; if he shows anything of himself to those people, it will be, in any case, a pair of heels, and even then, only for the time it takes to put distance between them.

en: With those words, and a final snap of his fingers, Mr. Stryver shouldered himself into Fleet-street, amidst the general approbation of his hearers. Mr. Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the desk, in the general departure from the Bank.
vi: Finishing his words and snapping his fingers one last time, Stryver stormed out onto Fleet Street to the applause of the crowd gathered around listening. At the desk, only Lorry and Charles Darnay remained as everyone else left the bank.
tr: Mr. Stryver, after snapping his fingers one last time following these words, headed towards Fleet Street amidst the admiring glances of those listening to his speech. Everyone had left, and Mr. Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone at the table.
es: Having said these words, which earned the unanimous approval of his listeners, he went out onto Fleet Street. Seconds later, Lorry and Charles Darnay were left alone in the office.

en: “Will you take charge of the letter?” said Mr. Lorry. “You know where to deliver it?”
vi: − Will you take care of this letter? - Mr. Lorry asked. - Do you know where to deliver it? − I know.
tr: "Will you take care of the letter?" said Mr. Lorry. "Do you know where to take it?"
es: "Since you know the person to whom the letter is addressed," said Lorry, "would you take charge of delivering it to them?"

en: “I do.”
tr: "I know."
es: —With great pleasure.

en: “Will you undertake to explain, that we suppose it to have been addressed here, on the chance of our knowing where to forward it, and that it has been here some time?”
vi: Then please explain that the letter was sent to this address because it was assumed we would know who to forward it to, and that it has been here for quite a while?
tr: "Can you explain to him that we assumed this letter was sent here, thinking we knew where it was to be delivered, and that it has been here for a while?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to explain to him that it was undoubtedly sent here because they believed we knew him, and that, not knowing who he was or where he was, the letter has been held up for some time?

en: “I will do so. Do you start for Paris from here?”
vi: − I will say so. Are you leaving for Paris from here? −
tr: "Okay, I'll tell you. Are you departing for Paris from here?"
es: —I will do so. When are you leaving for Paris?

en: “From here, at eight.”
vi: From here, at eight o'clock.
tr: "Yes, at eight o'clock.""
es: —At eight, I leave from right here.

en: “I will come back, to see you off.”
vi: − I will come back to see you off.
tr: "I will come again to see you off.""
es: —I will return to say goodbye to him.

en: Very ill at ease with himself, and with Stryver and most other men, Darnay made the best of his way into the quiet of the Temple, opened the letter, and read it. These were its contents:
vi: Very frustrated with himself, with Stryver, and with others, Darnay tried to find a quiet place in the Temple Bar area, opened the letter, and read it. Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: Extremely uncomfortable with himself, Stryver, and the other men, Darnay withdrew to a quiet corner of the Temple, opened the letter, and read it. It contained the following:
es: Discontented with himself, and even more so with Stryver and his compatriots, Darnay left the Bank building and, as soon as he reached a corner where he believed he was out of sight of prying eyes, he opened the letter, which was written in the following terms:

en: “Prison of the Abbaye, Paris.
vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: Abbaye Prison, Paris
es: "Abbey Prison, Paris."

en: “June 21, 1792. “Monsieur Heretofore The Marquis.
vi: Letter written: Abbaye Prison, Paris, June 21, 1792 TO THE FORMER MARQUIS
tr: June 21, 1792 The Former Marquis of France, Monsieur,
es: "June 21, 1792." Mr. Marquis:

en: “After having long been in danger of my life at the hands of the village, I have been seized, with great violence and indignity, and brought a long journey on foot to Paris. On the road I have suffered a great deal. Nor is that all; my house has been destroyed—razed to the ground.
vi: After a long period of life-threatening danger in the hands of the villagers, I was forcibly and humiliatingly captured, having to walk a long distance to Paris. On the way, I endured countless hardships. But it's not over yet; the tiles of my house have been destroyed - razed to the ground.
tr: After being captured, I was brought to Paris on foot following the terrible days I spent in the hands of the villagers under great violence and insult. I suffered greatly during this long journey. As if that wasn't enough, they also destroyed my home – they razed it to the ground.
es: »After running for a long time in imminent danger of losing my life at the hands of the villagers, I have been captured, subjected to a thousand violences and outrages, and finally taken to Paris, which I was forced to travel to on foot. The bitterness I endured on the way is not to be recounted here; and that is not all; my house has been destroyed... razed to the ground.

en: “The crime for which I am imprisoned, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, and for which I shall be summoned before the tribunal, and shall lose my life (without your so generous help), is, they tell me, treason against the majesty of the people, in that I have acted against them for an emigrant. It is in vain I represent that I have acted for them, and not against, according to your commands. It is in vain I represent that, before the sequestration of emigrant property, I had remitted the imposts they had ceased to pay; that I had collected no rent; that I had had recourse to no process. The only response is, that I have acted for an emigrant, and where is that emigrant?
vi: The crime for which I am imprisoned, dear Marquis, and for which I will be tried and will lose my life (without your chivalrous assistance), is the crime of treason against the glorious people, as they say, by acting on behalf of an exile against them. I have wasted my efforts trying to convince them that I was helping them, not acting against them, in accordance with your orders. I wasted my efforts trying to convince them that, before confiscating the property of the exile, I had paid all the taxes they had not paid; that I did not collect any rent; that I did not pursue any debts. They still insisted that I was acting on behalf of an exile and were determined to know where that exile was.
tr: The former Marquis of France, Monsieur, the crime that caused my arrest and my imminent appearance before the judge, and (if deprived of your generous help) will cost me my life, they say, is that I betrayed the vast majority of the people and turned them against me because of a refugee. It does no good to say that I acted not against them, but for them, according to your orders. It also does no good to explain that before the confiscation of refugee properties, I forgave tax debts, did not collect rent, and took no action. The only thing they tell me is, you worked for a refugee, and where is that refugee.
es: "The crime of which I am accused, the one that has me buried in jail, Mr. Marquis, the crime for which I will appear before the Court and which will cost me my head (if you do not lend me your generous assistance) is, according to them, that of treason against the majesty of the people, whom they claim I have sold out to protect an emigrant." "In vain have I made it clear to them that, far from acting against them, I have acted in their favor, adhering to your instructions, Mr. Marquis; in vain have I argued that prior to the confiscation of the emigrants' properties, I had forgiven the taxes that the people stopped paying, that I did not collect the rents, that I did not resort to the courts." "To all my representations they reply that I acted in favor of an emigrant, and I ask myself: where is that emigrant?"

en: “Ah! most gracious Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, where is that emigrant? I cry in my sleep where is he? I demand of Heaven, will he not come to deliver me? No answer. Ah Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, I send my desolate cry across the sea, hoping it may perhaps reach your ears through the great bank of Tilson known at Paris!
vi: Oh! Dear most benevolent lord, formerly the Marquis, where is that exiled man? I weep in my sleep asking where he is? I ask the heavens if he will come to rescue me? There is no reply. Oh dear lord, formerly the Marquis, I send my forlorn cries across the sea, hoping they might reach your ears through the renowned and prestigious Tilson* bank in Paris!
tr: Ah! Former Marquis of France, dear Monsieur, where do you think this refugee is? Even in my sleep, I mutter about where he might be. I pray to God to send him to me. But it is of no use. Ah, Former Marquis of France, Monsieur, in the hope that something might reach your ears through Tellson's Bank in Paris, I send my desperate cries across the seas!
es: "Ah, my good Lord Marquis!" "Where is that emigrant?" "I ask while I sleep; where is he?" "I turn my eyes to the heavens, and ask them; will he come to save me?" "They do not answer me." "Ah, Lord Marquis!" "I send my cry of anguish across the seas, in case God wills it to reach his ears through the mediation of the great Tellson's Bank, so well known in Paris."

en: “For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity, of the honour of your noble name, I supplicate you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, to succour and release me. My fault is, that I have been true to you. Oh Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, I pray you be you true to me!
vi: For the love of God, justice, generosity, and the honor of your noble lineage, I earnestly beseech you, dear lord, formerly the Marquis, to help and liberate me. My fault is my loyalty to you. Oh dear lord, formerly the Marquis, I pray that you will not forsake me.
tr: For the love of God, in the name of justice, and for the greatness and honor of your noble name, I beg you to save me, Monsieur the Former Marquis of France. My only fault was being loyal to you. Oh Monsieur the Former Marquis of France, I beg you to be loyal to me as well!
es: "For the love of God, for fairness, for justice, for generosity, for the immaculate honor of your noble surname, Mr. Marquis, I beg you to come to my aid and save me from the death that threatens me." "My only crime is having been faithful to you... Oh Mr. Marquis!" "I trust that you will reciprocate my loyalty."

en: “From this prison here of horror, whence I every hour tend nearer and nearer to destruction, I send you, Monsieur heretofore the Marquis, the assurance of my dolorous and unhappy service.
vi: From this horrifying prison, where with each passing hour I draw closer to death, I send to you, formerly the Marquis, my sorrowful and unfortunate loyalty.
tr: Former Marquis of France, Monsieur, I send you my sorrowful and unhappy service from this fear-filled dungeon, where each passing day brings me closer to death.
es: "From this dungeon where all horrors have their seat, from this antechamber of death, I send you, Mr. Marquis, the expression of my painful loyalty, together with the offering of my unfortunate services."

en: “Your afflicted,
vi: From this horrifying prison, where with each passing hour I draw closer to death, I send to you, formerly the Marquis, my sorrowful and unfortunate loyalty.
tr: Your loyal servant
es: "Your afflicted servant,"

en: “Gabelle.”
vi: Dear suffering, GABELLE
tr: Salt tax
es: "Gabelle."

en: The latent uneasiness in Darnay’s mind was roused to vigourous life by this letter. The peril of an old servant and a good one, whose only crime was fidelity to himself and his family, stared him so reproachfully in the face, that, as he walked to and fro in the Temple considering what to do, he almost hid his face from the passersby.
vi: The letter stirred up the persistent discomfort in Darnay's mind. An old, kind servant was in danger just because of his loyalty to him and his family, which reproached him so harshly that Darnay almost wanted to hide his face from passersby out of shame as he walked around the Temple area pondering what to do.
tr: Darnay, who was already uneasy, became even more worried with this letter. This old and good servant, whose only crime was being loyal to him and his family, had looked at Darnay with such a reproachful expression due to the danger he was in that Darnay, not knowing what to do, had walked back and forth in Temple, almost hiding his face from passersby.
es: The reading of the letter that remains copied infiltrated into Darnay's latent unease a vigorous torrent of life. The danger looming over the head of an old servant, certainly one of the best, who had committed no other crime than being loyal to him and his family, was for Darnay like a whip received full in the face. The shame rose to his face with such force that while he walked aimlessly without knowing what resolution to adopt, he didn't even dare to look at the passersby.

en: He knew very well, that in his horror of the deed which had culminated the bad deeds and bad reputation of the old family house, in his resentful suspicions of his uncle, and in the aversion with which his conscience regarded the crumbling fabric that he was supposed to uphold, he had acted imperfectly. He knew very well, that in his love for Lucie, his renunciation of his social place, though by no means new to his own mind, had been hurried and incomplete. He knew that he ought to have systematically worked it out and supervised it, and that he had meant to do it, and that it had never been done.
vi: He knew very well that he had acted negligently in the horror of the events that had pushed the infamy and vile actions of this ancient family to the extreme, in the suspicion and resentment towards his uncle, in the disgust he felt for the crumbling pillars of the society he should have supported. He knew very well that it was because of his love for Lucie that he had hastily and carelessly abandoned his social status, even though this intention had been harbored in his heart for a long time. He knew that he should have resolved it in proper order and overseen the matter; he had the means to do so but did not follow through.
tr: The fear created in him by the evil deeds of his old family and their bad reputation, the hurtful suspicions he harbored towards his uncle, and the dissatisfaction awakened in his conscience by the scattered pieces he needed to gather made him aware that he was not behaving as he should. He was also fully aware that his renunciation of his social status for his love for Lucie, although not a new thought in his mind, was rushed and incomplete. He knew that he needed to handle and manage this matter systematically, but it hadn't happened.
es: He knew very well that, driven by the horror of the deed that put a fitting end to the misdeeds and the terrible reputation of his ancient family, prompted by the suspicions his uncle had inspired in him and by the aversion with which his conscience viewed the ruinous factory that, according to his lineage, he was duty-bound to sustain and strengthen, he had acted in an imperfect manner. He knew very well that by yielding to the love he felt for Lucía, by renouncing the position he was supposed to occupy in society, he had rushed into things, he had acted with reprehensible recklessness. He knew very well that his resolution should have been carried out personally, as he knew he had intended to do so, and that, nevertheless, he did not do it.

en: The happiness of his own chosen English home, the necessity of being always actively employed, the swift changes and troubles of the time which had followed on one another so fast, that the events of this week annihilated the immature plans of last week, and the events of the week following made all new again; he knew very well, that to the force of these circumstances he had yielded:—not without disquiet, but still without continuous and accumulating resistance. That he had watched the times for a time of action, and that they had shifted and struggled until the time had gone by, and the nobility were trooping from France by every highway and byway, and their property was in course of confiscation and destruction, and their very names were blotting out, was as well known to himself as it could be to any new authority in France that might impeach him for it.
vi: He knew very well that, for his own happiness, he had chosen England as his home, needing a stable job amidst the rapid and chaotic upheavals of the times, with events succeeding each other so quickly that last week's work was unfinished before this week's tasks ended it, and next week's issues were already poised to arise; all of this swept him along with the circumstances - it wasn't that Darnay didn't blame himself, but he couldn't resist the relentless and overwhelming cycle. Indeed, he was still waiting for an opportunity to act, but the timing kept shifting and delaying until it was too late; now the nobility was fleeing France on every road, properties were being confiscated and destroyed, even identities were being erased; Darnay himself knew this as well as any new government in France, who could very well punish him.
tr: His own family happiness, the necessity of being constantly occupied with work, all the changes and troubles were following one another at such a great speed that the events of this week were obliterating the undeveloped plans of the previous week, everything was being planned anew for the next week, and Darnay felt the weight of all these developments that he let flow over him; he was not without anxiety, but he also did not have a constant and steadily increasing resistance. He was observing the developing events, changes, and struggles from where he stood each passing day; Darnay knew as well as the new authority in France, which was least likely to accuse him, that the nobles in France were fleeing by any means they could find, their properties were being confiscated and destroyed, and their names were being erased one by one.
es: The happiness of the home that had been created in London, the need to lead an active life, the continuous upheavals of the time, so abrupt and so rapid that plans not well matured the previous week fell apart the following week under the overwhelming force of new events, were weighty circumstances to which he yielded; he knew it very well; but it was also not hidden from him that, if he yielded to the force of circumstances with reluctance, he did not attempt to oppose them with continuous and formal resistance. His conscience told him that he wished to act and that several times he had been lurking for the opportunity; but it added that just as many times he let the opportunity pass, while the nobility fled from France by all roads and paths, while their properties were confiscated and destroyed, and even the names of those who had until then been favored by fortune were erased from the book of life.

en: But, he had oppressed no man, he had imprisoned no man; he was so far from having harshly exacted payment of his dues, that he had relinquished them of his own will, thrown himself on a world with no favour in it, won his own private place there, and earned his own bread. Monsieur Gabelle had held the impoverished and involved estate on written instructions, to spare the people, to give them what little there was to give—such fuel as the heavy creditors would let them have in the winter, and such produce as could be saved from the same grip in the summer—and no doubt he had put the fact in plea and proof, for his own safety, so that it could not but appear now.
vi: But he did not oppress anyone, he did not imprison anyone; he did not even demand to enjoy a status befitting his position but voluntarily gave up all his titles, renounced all privileges to dive into life, find a place for himself, and make a living on his own. According to the directive written by his own hand, Mr. Gabelle managed that depleted estate, exempting the people from taxes, sharing with them whatever could be shared - a bit of dry wood in the winter that the usurers could not seize, a few vegetables in the summer that the sharks could not take - and surely Gabelle had brought this up to plead and prove, for his own safety, hence the current situation.
tr: He had never oppressed anyone, never had anyone arrested; he had not collected taxes from the people by force, and when giving away his possessions, he did so willingly. He had thrown himself into a world where he had no privileges, achieved something through his own efforts, and earned his own bread. Mr. Gabelle had managed the land in accordance with written orders, distributing the basic necessities to people little by little – firewood in winter as much as the cruel creditors allowed, and in summer, crops to the extent they could wrest from them – and of course, Gabelle, albeit late, had presented this situation as evidence in his defense to save his life.
es: But on the other hand, he had oppressed no one, he had sent no one to jail. Far from having trampled on anyone to collect his rents, he had freely and spontaneously abandoned his property, sought refuge in a foreign nation, and earned the bread he put in his mouth through his own effort. Mr. Gabelle had administered an impoverished estate according to written instructions that directed him to treat the people well, to give them what little could be given... firewood to keep warm in winter and some fruits to help them through the summer, as the creditors allowed nothing else... and surely he would have cited these facts in his defense. These were public facts, facts that could easily be proven; and if the facts in question justified the administrator before the people, it goes without saying that they were a patent of friendship with the people in favor of the one who issued the orders that he followed.

en: This favoured the desperate resolution Charles Darnay had begun to make, that he would go to Paris.
vi: Thus, the reckless decision that Charles Darnay was contemplating became even more compelling: he wanted to go to Paris.
tr: This situation had cemented Charles Darnay's desperate decision to go to Paris.
es: These considerations strengthened the resolution to make the trip to Paris that Darnay had almost adopted prior to receiving Gabelle's letter.

en: Yes. Like the mariner in the old story, the winds and streams had driven him within the influence of the Loadstone Rock, and it was drawing him to itself, and he must go. Everything that arose before his mind drifted him on, faster and faster, more and more steadily, to the terrible attraction. His latent uneasiness had been, that bad aims were being worked out in his own unhappy land by bad instruments, and that he who could not fail to know that he was better than they, was not there, trying to do something to stay bloodshed, and assert the claims of mercy and humanity. With this uneasiness half stifled, and half reproaching him, he had been brought to the pointed comparison of himself with the brave old gentleman in whom duty was so strong; upon that comparison (injurious to himself) had instantly followed the sneers of Monseigneur, which had stung him bitterly, and those of Stryver, which above all were coarse and galling, for old reasons. Upon those, had followed Gabelle’s letter: the appeal of an innocent prisoner, in danger of death, to his justice, honour, and good name.
vi: Yes. Like the sailor in the old tale, the storms have driven him into the magnetic field of the Magnetic Mountain, he is being drawn in, and he must go. Every thought that appeared in his mind pulled him, faster and faster, more and more surely, towards that terrible gravitational pull. The long-standing simmering discomfort was precisely the fact that his unfortunate country was being used by bad means to achieve bad ends, something he knew better than anyone: he himself was not there to try to prevent some of this bloodshed and to speak out for tolerance and humanity. Half suppressed, half reproachful, that discomfort made Darnay bitterly compare himself to the old, conscientious man at the bank; then immediately after, he bitterly thought of the mocking words of the nobles who had insulted him, the words of Stryver, full of spite and insolence due to old grudges. And finally, he thought of Gabelle's letter: an innocent prisoner, close to death, pleading for justice, honor, and his reputation.
tr: Here. Just like the sailor in the old story, he was being drifted towards the Magnet Stone Cliff by winds and currents, and Paris was drawing him in the same way, and he had to go. Everything that came to his mind was dragging him towards this terrible center of attraction with greater speed and even more stability. While the sorrowful lands had fallen into the hands of ill-intentioned people, his mere sitting there made Darnay very uneasy, and he could do nothing to stop the flowing blood, only hoping for mercy and humanity. Under the influence of this uneasiness that both suffocated and saddened him, he found himself comparing with the brave and old gentleman with a strong sense of duty; immediately after this touching comparison (which was quite humiliating for him), he remembered Monsignor's sarcastic and mocking words and Stryver's rude and hurtful remarks regarding old matters. As if these were not enough, he then thought of Gabelle's letter; an innocent prisoner in mortal danger was seeking help from his justice, honor, and high name.
es: Yes. Similar to the sailor from the ancient legend, the winds and currents had dragged him until they placed his ship within the radius of influence of the Magnetic Mountain, and it attracted him with an increasingly irresistible force. All the thoughts that germinated in his mind impelled him, pushed him towards the center of that terrible attraction. His initial impatience obeyed the thought that his unfortunate homeland, guided by bad instruments, pursued bad objectives and was running headlong into the abyss, while he, who perhaps could have given a better direction to the national aspirations, remained in London without intervening, without attempting something that would put an end to the brutal effusion of blood, something that would secure the rights to mercy, to humanity, unknown at the time. When those remorseful feelings were already stirring in his soul, the conduct of the elderly Lorry came to multiply their strength a hundredfold, as he, obedient to the voice of duty, hastened to face the tremendous risks involved in a journey to France under those circumstances, and if that were not enough, there came the comments of the gentlemen, comments that deeply wounded him, and those of Stryver, a thousand times harsher than those of the others. All this was followed by the letter from Gabelle, the letter of an innocent prisoner who, coming to the edge of the grave, made a desperate appeal to his justice, to his honor, and to his name.

en: His resolution was made. He must go to Paris.
vi: His mind was made up. He had to go to Paris.
tr: He had made his decision. He had to go to Paris.
es: It didn't take long to decide; he would go to Paris.

en: Yes. The Loadstone Rock was drawing him, and he must sail on, until he struck. He knew of no rock; he saw hardly any danger. The intention with which he had done what he had done, even although he had left it incomplete, presented it before him in an aspect that would be gratefully acknowledged in France on his presenting himself to assert it. Then, that glorious vision of doing good, which is so often the sanguine mirage of so many good minds, arose before him, and he even saw himself in the illusion with some influence to guide this raging Revolution that was running so fearfully wild.
vi: Yes. The Magnetic Rock was drawing him in, and he had to rush towards it, until he faced it head-on. He did not see the danger; he did not know the risk. He only thought about completing what had been left unfinished, believing that once he returned to France, merely presenting that intention would be happily accepted. Then, in Darnay's mind, appeared the glorious prospect of noble deeds, the optimistic illusion often seen in kind-hearted people; he even imagined himself having the power to lead the fierce Revolution that was raging savagely and brutally.
tr: Yes. The Magnetic Stone Cliff was pulling Darnay towards itself, and he had to keep going until he crashed into the cliffs. Darnay was unaware of the rock; he saw no danger in this. Even if he left what he intended to do unfinished, when he went to France and explained it, it would be met with great appreciation. Then the splendid image of this good deed appeared before him like an optimistic mirage belonging to many noble minds, and he even imagined that it had the power to influence this furious revolution advancing with a terrible madness.
es: Yes. The Magnetized Mountain was pulling him, and there was no other choice but to steer the bow of his skiff towards it. He was unaware that there were reefs in the seas he was about to sail, nor did he believe that the voyage would pose any dangers to him. The intention that guided him to act as he had, even if his work had remained incomplete, seemed to him more than sufficient to earn him the gratitude of France, as soon as he set foot on its soil and asserted the rights that supported him. Before his eyes rose the glorious vision of having acted rightly, and he even began to harbor illusions that he would have some influence in steering that horrendous revolution, which had risen with such uncontrollable fury, threatening to destroy everything in existence.

en: As he walked to and fro with his resolution made, he considered that neither Lucie nor her father must know of it until he was gone. Lucie should be spared the pain of separation; and her father, always reluctant to turn his thoughts towards the dangerous ground of old, should come to the knowledge of the step, as a step taken, and not in the balance of suspense and doubt. How much of the incompleteness of his situation was referable to her father, through the painful anxiety to avoid reviving old associations of France in his mind, he did not discuss with himself. But, that circumstance too, had had its influence in his course.
vi: While coming and going with his resolved intention, he was determined not to let either Lucie or her father know about this until the very last moment. He had to spare Lucie the sorrow of parting; to spare her father from the anxiety and worry—the doctor did not want to recall the dangerous homeland, so when he found out, it would already be done. His difficult situation was very similar to Dr. Manette's, although he did not discuss it with him to avoid bringing up old connections from the time in France. But that very situation also influenced Darnay's decision.
tr: With this decision in mind, while walking up and down the street, he decided that neither Lucie nor Doctor Manette should be aware of it until he left. Lucie should not experience the pain of separation, and her father, who was always ready to return to the dangerous old days, should see it not as a cause for worry and suspicion but as a step taken. Since he avoided with sorrowful anxiety evoking the old days in France in the Doctor's mind, it was debatable how appropriate it would be to talk to him about the void inside. But this was a matter in itself.
es: Having made his decision, he believed that neither Lucie nor Doctor Manette should know about it until he had put it into practice. As for Lucie, it was only natural to spare her the pain of separation, and as for her father, whose aversion to thinking about the places where he had endured so much suffering in past years was so strong, it was also best not to speak to him about the plan, but rather about its execution, the only way to avoid causing him painful doubts.

en: He walked to and fro, with thoughts very busy, until it was time to return to Tellson’s and take leave of Mr. Lorry. As soon as he arrived in Paris he would present himself to this old friend, but he must say nothing of his intention now.
vi: He kept pacing back and forth, busy with his thoughts, until it was time to return to Tellson's Bank to see Mr. Lorry off. Upon arriving in Paris, he would immediately seek out this old friend, but for now, he was not to speak of his intentions.
tr: He continued to walk back and forth, his mind occupied with these thoughts, until it was time to return to Tellson's and bid farewell to Mr. Lorry. He would go to his old friend as soon as he arrived in Paris, but for now, he should not mention this intention to him.
es: Such were the thoughts that agitated him until it was time to say goodbye to Lorry. He would not confide his intentions to him either. He would know them in Paris when they were already accomplished, when he paid him a visit, and this visit, he would make as soon as he arrived in the capital of France.

en: A carriage with post-horses was ready at the Bank door, and Jerry was booted and equipped.
vi: A stagecoach from the post station was already waiting in front of the bank, and Jerry was neatly prepared.
tr: A horse-drawn mail coach was waiting in front of the bank, and Jerry, fully equipped with boots on his feet, was ready.
es: In front of the door of Tellson's Bank, a stagecoach was waiting. Next to the carriage door, Jeremiah Lorry stood guard.

en: “I have delivered that letter,” said Charles Darnay to Mr. Lorry. “I would not consent to your being charged with any written answer, but perhaps you will take a verbal one?”
vi: − I have delivered that letter, - Charles Darnay said to Mr. Lorry. I do not wish to deliver you a written reply, but surely you can relay a verbal message?
tr: "I delivered the letter," said Charles Darnay to Mr. Lorry. "I didn't want to put you in a difficult position by giving a written response, but can we send a message verbally?"
es: —I have delivered the letter to the gentleman to whom it was addressed—said Darnay to Lorry. —I did not want to bring a written reply that might cause you trouble; but I accepted a verbal response, trusting that you will have no objection to conveying it.

en: “That I will, and readily,” said Mr. Lorry, “if it is not dangerous.”
vi: − I am willing, - Mr. Lorry said, - if it is not dangerous.
tr: "If it's not something dangerous, of course," said Mr. Lorry, "gladly.""
es: "With great pleasure, as long as it is not too dangerous," replied Lorry.

en: “Not at all. Though it is to a prisoner in the Abbaye.”
vi: − Not at all. Although this message is sent to a prisoner in the Abbaye prison.
tr: "It's definitely not dangerous. Although it's going to a prisoner in Abbaye."
es: "With great pleasure, as long as it is not too dangerous," replied Lorry. —It is not, although it must be received by a man who is imprisoned in the Abbey.

en: “What is his name?” said Mr. Lorry, with his open pocket-book in his hand.
vi: − What is that person's name? - Mr. Lorry asked, holding an open notebook.
tr: "What is his name?" asked Mr. Lorry, opening his small notebook.
es: —What is his name?—asked Lorry, taking a little notebook out of his pocket.

en: “Gabelle.”
vi: − Gabelle. − Gabelle.
tr: "Gabelle.""
es: —Gabelle.

en: “Gabelle. And what is the message to the unfortunate Gabelle in prison?”
vi: − Gabelle. − Gabelle. Any message for the unfortunate prisoner Gabelle? − Just say "he has received the letter and will come." −
tr: "Gabelle." "So, what message shall we send to this unfortunate prisoner in jail?""
es: —Gabelle. And what should I say to the unfortunate prisoner Gabelle?

en: “Simply, ‘that he has received the letter, and will come.’”
vi: Any message for the unfortunate prisoner Gabelle? − Just say "he has received the letter and will come." −
tr: "In short, you say, 'he read the letter, he will come.'"
es: —Simply these words: "He has received the letter and will come."

en: “Any time mentioned?”
vi: Is there a specific time? −
tr: "Will we specify the time?"
es: —Without saying when?

en: “He will start upon his journey to-morrow night.”
vi: He will depart tomorrow night.
tr: "He will set out tomorrow night.""
es: —He will embark on the journey tomorrow night.

en: “Any person mentioned?”
vi: − Is there anyone in particular? −
tr: "So, are we going to name someone?""
es: —Should I not mention any names?

en: “No.”
vi: No.
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: He helped Mr. Lorry to wrap himself in a number of coats and cloaks, and went out with him from the warm atmosphere of the old Bank, into the misty air of Fleet-street. “My love to Lucie, and to little Lucie,” said Mr. Lorry at parting, “and take precious care of them till I come back.” Charles Darnay shook his head and doubtfully smiled, as the carriage rolled away.
vi: He helped Mr. Lorry wrap himself in a bundle of coats and cloaks, and together they left the warm atmosphere of the old bank, stepping into the foggy streets of Fleet. − Send my regards to Lucie and little Lucie, - Mr. Lorry said at parting, - take good care of them until I return. - Charles Darnay shook his head and smiled doubtfully as the carriage rolled away.
tr: After helping Mr. Lorry wrap himself in layers of cardigans and cloaks, they stepped together from the warm air of the old bank into the misty air of Fleet Street. As Mr. Lorry departed, he said, "Please give my regards to Lucie and little Lucie, and take good care of them until I return." As the carriage moved away, Charles Darnay nodded with a doubtful smile.
es: After helping Lorry bundle up in two or three layers, under which he was already wearing two or three coats, he went out accompanying him to Fleet Street. —Give my love to both Lucías—said Lorry at the moment the stagecoach departed. —Take good care of them until I return. Carlos Darnay nodded, smiled with an ambiguous expression, and stood watching the carriage as it moved away at the horses' long trot.

en: That night—it was the fourteenth of August—he sat up late, and wrote two fervent letters; one was to Lucie, explaining the strong obligation he was under to go to Paris, and showing her, at length, the reasons that he had, for feeling confident that he could become involved in no personal danger there; the other was to the Doctor, confiding Lucie and their dear child to his care, and dwelling on the same topics with the strongest assurances. To both, he wrote that he would despatch letters in proof of his safety, immediately after his arrival.
vi: That night - August 14th - he stayed up late, writing two heartfelt letters; one addressed to Lucie explaining the legitimate duty that compelled him to go to Paris and finally informing her of the reasons why he was confident he would not encounter any danger there; the other addressed to Dr. Manette, entrusting Lucie and their beloved child to his care, and also discussing the aforementioned matters with the strongest conviction. To both, he wrote that he would send a letter immediately upon arrival to prove that he was still safe.
tr: That night –on the fourteenth of August– he stayed up late and wrote two letters fervently; one was to Lucie, in which he explained at length the necessity of going to Paris, why it was essential, and how confident he was that nothing would happen to him there; the other letter was to Doctor Manette, entrusting Lucie and her dear little girls to him, and emphasizing the matters mentioned in the other letter. He wrote to both that he would send letters proving his well-being as soon as he arrived there.
es: That night, it was the fourteenth of August, Charles Darnay went to bed very late, as he first had to write two letters; one addressed to Lucie, in which he explained the unavoidable duty he had to go to Paris and detailed extensively the reasons that, in his opinion, removed all kinds of risks from his person, and another to the doctor, to whom he entrusted the care of Lucie and her little daughter. To both, he promised to write again as soon as he reached the end of his journey.

en: It was a hard day, that day of being among them, with the first reservation of their joint lives on his mind. It was a hard matter to preserve the innocent deceit of which they were profoundly unsuspicious. But, an affectionate glance at his wife, so happy and busy, made him resolute not to tell her what impended (he had been half moved to do it, so strange it was to him to act in anything without her quiet aid), and the day passed quickly. Early in the evening he embraced her, and her scarcely less dear namesake, pretending that he would return by-and-bye (an imaginary engagement took him out, and he had secreted a valise of clothes ready), and so he emerged into the heavy mist of the heavy streets, with a heavier heart.
vi: The next day was a day of suffering, a day spent among loved ones but for the first time, he had something to hide from them in his mind. It was really hard to maintain a carefree appearance while they had no suspicion that he was deceiving them. But just a loving glance towards his wife, who was happy and busy, was enough to make him determined not to reveal what was going to happen (he almost decided to tell her, because for him, the feeling of doing something without his wife's silent support was indeed too unfamiliar), and the day passed quickly. In the evening, he hugged his wife and beloved daughter, pretending that he would return home soon (he excused himself with an appointment and had secretly prepared his belongings), and then he left, immersed in the heavy mist, the heavy streets, and an even heavier heart.
tr: It had been difficult for Charles to spend that day with them, with the thought that they would be separated for the first time in his mind. Hiding this innocent lie, which they had no suspicion of, was an exhausting situation. On the other hand, the affectionate look he directed at his happy and occupied wife further strengthened his decision not to tell her what awaited them (otherwise, he would have almost opened up to her, it was very strange to act without her calm support) and thus the day passed quickly. In the evening, he hugged Lucie and her equally precious namesake, and saying he would return before it got too late (supposedly he had some work to do and his suitcase with clothes in it was hidden in a corner), he merged into the heavy and foggy air of the street with a heavy heart.
es: It was a day of trial for Darnay, the one he had to spend with his beloved family while keeping a secret deep in his heart that no one could suspect; but a loving glance directed at his wife, so cheerful, so confident, strengthened his resolve not to tell her anything, and the day passed without incident. At dusk, he embraced her, telling her that an unforeseen matter required him to leave, but that his absence would be very brief, and he left.

en: The unseen force was drawing him fast to itself, now, and all the tides and winds were setting straight and strong towards it. He left his two letters with a trusty porter, to be delivered half an hour before midnight, and no sooner; took horse for Dover; and began his journey. “For the love of Heaven, of justice, of generosity, of the honour of your noble name!” was the poor prisoner’s cry with which he strengthened his sinking heart, as he left all that was dear on earth behind him, and floated away for the Loadstone Rock.
vi: That invisible attraction is pulling him swiftly towards it, right now, and all the waves and winds are pushing him forward. Darnay had given two letters to a trusted messenger to deliver to the house half an hour after midnight, no sooner; he mounted his horse to Dover and began his journey. “For the love of God, justice, mercy, and the honor of your noble lineage!”
tr: An invisible force was now swiftly pulling him towards itself, and all the currents and winds were supporting this with all their might. He left both letters with a reliable messenger to be delivered exactly half an hour before midnight and started his journey by mounting his horse to head to Dover. As he was being drawn towards the Magnet Stone Rock, leaving the most valuable things in the world behind, his shattered heart found strength in the poor prisoner's words, "For the love of God, for the sake of justice, and for the greatness and honor of your noble name!"
es: He had already secretly taken a trunk with the necessary clothes out of the house. He entrusted the two letters to a servant worthy of all trust, with orders to deliver them at midnight, not a minute before, took a horse, and set out on the journey to Dover. He felt faint; but the desperate cry of the poor prisoner who appealed to his justice, his honor, his generosity, gave him strength to leave behind what was most dear to him in the world and to steer his ship towards the Magnetic Mountain that was drawing him in.

en: The end of the second book.
vi: The cry of that poor prisoner had made his sorrowful heart even more resolute, and he left behind all his dearest loved ones, to rush into the Magnetic Rock.
tr: Third Chapter
es: THIRD BOOK

en: Book the Third—the Track of a Storm
vi: Part three GONE WITH THE STORM 1. Solitary Confinement
tr: The Path of the Storm
es: THE COURSE OF THE STORM

en: CHAPTER I.
vi: Part three GONE WITH THE STORM 1. Solitary Confinement
tr: I
es: I.

en: In Secret
vi: Part three GONE WITH THE STORM 1. Solitary Confinement
tr: Secret
es: IN SECRET

en: The traveller fared slowly on his way, who fared towards Paris from England in the autumn of the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-two. More than enough of bad roads, bad equipages, and bad horses, he would have encountered to delay him, though the fallen and unfortunate King of France had been upon his throne in all his glory; but, the changed times were fraught with other obstacles than these. Every town-gate and village taxing-house had its band of citizen-patriots, with their national muskets in a most explosive state of readiness, who stopped all comers and goers, cross-questioned them, inspected their papers, looked for their names in lists of their own, turned them back, or sent them on, or stopped them and laid them in hold, as their capricious judgment or fancy deemed best for the dawning Republic One and Indivisible, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death.
vi: The traveler took a long time to traverse the distance from England to Paris in the autumn of 1792. So many bad roads, poor carriages, and exhausted horses ready to hinder the journey even though the unfortunate king of France was still reigning gloriously on the throne; but changing times brought forth many more obstacles. Every city gate and village toll station had groups of patriotic Citizens armed with muskets ready to fire, stopping everyone passing through, questioning, checking papers, cross-referencing names with their lists, turning people back, letting them through, or detaining and arresting them, depending on their judgment or whims, which they deemed best for the early days of the United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death.
tr: In the autumn of 1792, the traveler who set out from England to go to France progressed slowly on his way. Even if the unfortunate King of France had been sitting on his throne in all his splendor, he would have been delayed in reaching his destination due to all those bad roads, poor equipment, and bad horses, but the changing times harbored other obstacles as well. At the entrance of each village and in front of the tax office, a group of patriots, with rifles ready to fire in their hands, stopped passersby, subjected them to cross-examination, examined their documents, checked their names against their own lists, and in the name of the approaching "Republic and Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death," they either sent them back, allowed them to continue on their way, or stopped and arrested them, whichever they deemed most appropriate at the moment.
es: Little by little, the traveler shortened the distance that separated him from Paris. We are in the autumn of the year seventeen ninety-two. He would not have lacked detestable roads, terrible carriages, and horses afflicted by old age that hindered his progress, even if the dethroned king of France had continued to occupy his throne and reign amidst splendors of glory; but aside from those obstacles, the alteration of the times had accumulated a thousand more. All the city gates, all the town entrances, were manned by bands of patriotic citizens, armed with national muskets ready to fire on their own, who stopped everyone entering or leaving, to subject them to strict interrogations, meticulously examine their documents, see if their names appeared on the lists they had, and either allow them to continue their journey or arrest them, as their whim advised, for the good of the newly born One and Indivisible Republic, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death.

en: A very few French leagues of his journey were accomplished, when Charles Darnay began to perceive that for him along these country roads there was no hope of return until he should have been declared a good citizen at Paris. Whatever might befall now, he must on to his journey’s end. Not a mean village closed upon him, not a common barrier dropped across the road behind him, but he knew it to be another iron door in the series that was barred between him and England. The universal watchfulness so encompassed him, that if he had been taken in a net, or were being forwarded to his destination in a cage, he could not have felt his freedom more completely gone.
vi: Only a few miles into his journey on French soil, Charles Darnay began to realize that there was no hope of returning as long as he was not recognized as a good Citizen in Paris. Now, no matter what happened, he had to see the journey through to the end. No sorrowful village had yet slammed its gates on him, no public barrier had yet blocked the road behind him, but he knew that yet another difficult threshold had been added to the long series of obstacles standing between him and England. Wherever he went, he was closely watched as if he had fallen into a trap or was being transported in a cage to his destination; he could not have imagined losing his freedom so completely.
tr: Charles Darnay realized that very shortly after arriving on French soil, it was impossible to return from these roads until he was declared a good citizen in Paris. Whatever happened to him, he had to go to the end of the road. No village had turned him back, no barrier had been set in his way yet, but it felt to him as if there was a tightly bolted iron gate stretching between himself and England. He was in such great anxiety that even if he had been caught in a net or was being taken to his destination in a cage, he could not have felt his freedom being taken away as much as he did.
es: Charles Darnay had traveled very few leagues of French territory when he began to realize the impossibility he would face in treading those eternal roads again, unless he was first declared a good citizen of Paris. But he could no longer turn back; whatever fate destiny had in store for him, he had no choice but to continue the journey to the end. Behind him, he left an open road, free of barriers and ditches, but nonetheless, he knew that between England and himself stood obstacles a thousand times more insurmountable than the strongest iron gates. Such was the universal vigilance surrounding him, that if he had been traveling within the meshes of a thick steel net, or well confined inside a cage, he would not have considered his freedom more lost.

en: This universal watchfulness not only stopped him on the highway twenty times in a stage, but retarded his progress twenty times in a day, by riding after him and taking him back, riding before him and stopping him by anticipation, riding with him and keeping him in charge. He had been days upon his journey in France alone, when he went to bed tired out, in a little town on the high road, still a long way from Paris.
vi: The constant surveillance not only blocked his way on the highway twenty times in one stretch but also delayed his journey twenty times a day. People rode horses to catch him and make him turn back, rushed ahead to intercept him, rode alongside him, and guarded him closely. For several days, he had been wandering alone in France, and when night fell, he was exhausted on the bed in a small town inn by the main road, with Paris still far away.
tr: This great unease not only made him stop twenty times a day on the road, but also delayed him twenty times from his path; sometimes a rider would come from behind and turn him back from his path; sometimes he would suddenly become suspicious while going ahead and stop him; sometimes he would go alongside him, not taking his eyes off him. When he threw himself into bed in a small town on his way, still very far from Paris, in an utterly exhausted state, days had passed since his solitary journey in France had begun.
es: That universal surveillance not only forced him to stop twenty times a day on the main roads, at the post relays, but also hindered and delayed his progress just as many times each day, sometimes catching up with him and ordering him to turn back, sometimes accompanying him and preventing him from advancing as quickly as he desired. He had been traveling through French territory for several days when one night he went to bed early in an inn in a small, insignificant town, located quite far from Paris.

en: Nothing but the production of the afflicted Gabelle’s letter from his prison of the Abbaye would have got him on so far. His difficulty at the guard-house in this small place had been such, that he felt his journey to have come to a crisis. And he was, therefore, as little surprised as a man could be, to find himself awakened at the small inn to which he had been remitted until morning, in the middle of the night.
vi: If he had not presented the letter from the wretched Gabelle sent from the Abbaye prison, he would not have been able to get this far. The guard post of this small town had harassed him to the point that he felt this journey had reached a perilous stage. Therefore, he was not surprised when he found himself being awakened in the middle of the night at the inn where he had rented a room to wait until morning.
tr: Nothing but the sorrowful letter from Gabelle in the Abbaye Prison could have brought him this far. They had cornered him so much at the police station in this small place that he had the feeling his journey would end here. Therefore, he was not at all surprised when someone came to the small inn where he was staying in the middle of the night and woke him up.
es: To the letter that Gabelle sent him from the Abbey prison, he owed having come so far, but upon reaching the town we are talking about, he was met with so many difficulties at the gates that he understood the crisis was very near. Therefore, it did not surprise him much to be awakened in the middle of the night in the bed of the inn where he had lain down with the intention of sleeping until the next morning.

en: Awakened by a timid local functionary and three armed patriots in rough red caps and with pipes in their mouths, who sat down on the bed.
vi: Awakened by a shy local official and three armed patriots wearing tattered red hats, pipes in their mouths, sitting by his bed.
tr: Darnay had been awakened by a timid official and three armed citizens, who were sitting on the bed with pipes in their mouths and coarse red caps on their heads.
es: Upon waking, their eyes met a local official, of a timid temperament, and three patriots armed to the teeth, wearing bright red caps and smoking enormous pipes. The three with the caps took a seat on his bed.

en: “Emigrant,” said the functionary, “I am going to send you on to Paris, under an escort.”
vi: − Exile, - the official said, - I will send you to Paris, with an escort.
tr: "Refugee!" said the officer, "I will send you to Paris with an escort."
es: —Emigrant—said the official,—I have decided to send you to Paris with an escort.

en: “Citizen, I desire nothing more than to get to Paris, though I could dispense with the escort.”
vi: − Citizen, I want nothing more than to get to Paris, although I think I don't need an escort.
tr: "Citizen, I already want nothing more than to go to Paris, but there is no need for an escort."
es: —Citizen, my greatest desire is to reach Paris, but I can perfectly do without the escort.

en: “Silence!” growled a red-cap, striking at the coverlet with the butt-end of his musket. “Peace, aristocrat!”
vi: − Silence! - A red hat just snapped while striking the blanket with the butt of a musket. - Do not argue, nobleman!
tr: "Wait a minute!" grumbled the man with the red cap, hitting the bedspread with the tip of his rifle. "Calm down, aristocrat!"
es: —Silence!—shouted a red cap, striking the bed with the butt of the musket. —Shut up, aristocrat!

en: “It is as the good patriot says,” observed the timid functionary. “You are an aristocrat, and must have an escort—and must pay for it.”
vi: − Just as this Distinguished Citizen said, - the timid official indicated. You are a nobleman, so you must have an escort... and you must pay for the escort.
tr: "As your patriotic friend said," said the timid official, "you are an aristocrat and you will pay for the escort."
es: —This good patriot is right—said the official timidly. — You are an aristocrat, and therefore, you must make the journey under the supervision of an escort.

en: “I have no choice,” said Charles Darnay.
vi: − I have no other choice, - Charles Darnay said.
tr: "I guess I have no other choice," said Charles Darnay. "Luck?
es: —The choice is not in my hands—replied Charles Darnay.

en: “Choice! Listen to him!” cried the same scowling red-cap. “As if it was not a favour to be protected from the lamp-iron!”
vi: − Choice! Listen to him talk! - That same grumpy red hat shouted loudly. - Acting as if me protecting him from being hanged on the lamppost is taking away his privilege.
tr: Look at this!" shouted the same frowning, red-capped officer. "We save the man from being hung on a lamppost, and look at what he says!"
es: —Election!—exclaimed one of the red caps. — Have you ever seen such a thing? As if we weren't doing him a favor by sparing him from adorning a lamppost hook from this moment on!

en: “It is always as the good patriot says,” observed the functionary. “Rise and dress yourself, emigrant.”
vi: − This patriotic citizen always speaks the truth, - the official said. Get up and change your clothes, exile.
tr: "As your patriotic friend said," said the officer. "Get up and get dressed, refugee."
es: —The observation of the good patriot couldn't be more accurate—interjected the official. — Get up and get dressed, emigrant.

en: Darnay complied, and was taken back to the guard-house, where other patriots in rough red caps were smoking, drinking, and sleeping, by a watch-fire. Here he paid a heavy price for his escort, and hence he started with it on the wet, wet roads at three o’clock in the morning.
vi: Darnay complied and was taken back to the guard post, where other patriots wearing tattered red caps were smoking, drinking, and sleeping by the fire. Here he had to pay a large sum for the escort, and began to be taken along the muddy roads at three o'clock in the morning.
tr: Darnay carried out what was told to him and was taken back to the military post where other patriots with rough red caps were smoking pipes, drinking, and sleeping by the signal fire. After paying his escorts a substantial amount of money here, they set off together through the wet streets at three in the morning.
es: Darnay obeyed, who was immediately taken to the guardhouse, where he found many patriots wearing their corresponding red caps, some smoking and others drinking by the warmth of the fire. After being forced to pay a large sum for an escort he had not requested, he set out on the journey at three in the morning.

en: The escort were two mounted patriots in red caps and tri-coloured cockades, armed with national muskets and sabres, who rode one on either side of him.
vi: The escort group consisted of two patriots wearing red hats adorned with the tricolor emblem, carrying guard muskets and curved swords, riding horses on either side of Darnay.
tr: Two escorts with red caps and badges, on their horses, advanced on either side of Darnay with their rifles and cavalry swords in hand.
es: The escort consisted of two mounted patriots, who rode at their sides, with red caps adorned with tricolor cockades, and they were armed with muskets and national sabers.

en: The escorted governed his own horse, but a loose line was attached to his bridle, the end of which one of the patriots kept girded round his wrist. In this state they set forth with the sharp rain driving in their faces: clattering at a heavy dragoon trot over the uneven town pavement, and out upon the mire-deep roads. In this state they traversed without change, except of horses and pace, all the mire-deep leagues that lay between them and the capital.
vi: The escorted person rode a horse alone, but a slack rope was tied to his reins, with the other end wrapped around the wrists of the two patriots. Thus, they set off in the face-stinging rain, the horses clattering like heavy cavalry on the town's rough cobblestone streets, and proceeded to the main muddy roads. In this manner, they sped along the distant roads, only pausing to change horses or adjust their pace, traveling straight through the muddy miles to the capital.
tr: Although the escorted man managed his own horse, a rope was tied to its reins, and one of the citizens had wrapped the other end of the rope around his own wrist. In this state, they advanced accompanied by the harsh rain hitting their faces; they moved slowly and clumsily on the rugged pavements, trudging through the mud. In this state, without changing anything except their horses and speed, they zigzagged along the muddy roads leading to the capital.
es: The escorted man handled his horse, but there was a rope tied to the bridle of the horse, the other end of which was tied to one of the patriots' wrists. In this manner, they made the journey, enduring a freezing drizzle that the wind blew against their faces, at a heavy trot, along uneven paths interspersed with extensive mudflats. Without making any changes during the journey other than switching horses, they finally reached the capital.

en: They travelled in the night, halting an hour or two after daybreak, and lying by until the twilight fell. The escort were so wretchedly clothed, that they twisted straw round their bare legs, and thatched their ragged shoulders to keep the wet off. Apart from the personal discomfort of being so attended, and apart from such considerations of present danger as arose from one of the patriots being chronically drunk, and carrying his musket very recklessly, Charles Darnay did not allow the restraint that was laid upon him to awaken any serious fears in his breast; for, he reasoned with himself that it could have no reference to the merits of an individual case that was not yet stated, and of representations, confirmable by the prisoner in the Abbaye, that were not yet made.
vi: They traveled all night, stopping only an hour or two after dawn, and rested until dusk. The two escorts were so poorly dressed that they wrapped straw around their bare feet and covered their tattered shoulders with straw to keep the rain off. Apart from his personal discomfort at being taken away and the constant worry about the ever-present danger posed by a perpetually drunken patriot carelessly wielding a musket, Charles Darnay felt no fear of being treated as a prisoner; for he believed that this general situation had nothing to do with his specific case, and it would end as soon as he explained his reason for returning to France, which would be confirmed by the prisoner at Abbaye prison.
tr: They traveled throughout the night and took a break a couple of hours after dawn, resting until dusk fell. The escorts' clothing was so shabby that the men had wrapped straw around their bare legs and covered their tattered shoulders with the same straw to protect themselves from the rain. Despite the discomfort of being followed so closely and the danger posed by one of the escorts carelessly carrying a rifle while constantly drinking, Charles Darnay tried to keep his heart light and not let the pressure weigh him down; for it was pointless to fear an unopened case and the kind of statements that a prisoner in the Abbaye could approve of.
es: They traveled during the night, stopping an hour or two before daybreak, and sleeping until the twilight of the afternoon. The escort dressed in such extreme poverty that to cover their bare legs, they had to resort to straw, with which they padded them. Apart from the inconveniences of the journey, the annoyance of being escorted, and the inherent dangers of depending on patriots who were chronically drunk and armed with muskets that fired on their own, Charles Darnay could dismiss all kinds of fears, since it was to be expected that, as soon as he referred to his merits, which would be confirmed by the prisoner of the Abbey, they would hasten to treat him as a man friendly to the people.

en: But when they came to the town of Beauvais—which they did at eventide, when the streets were filled with people—he could not conceal from himself that the aspect of affairs was very alarming. An ominous crowd gathered to see him dismount of the posting-yard, and many voices called out loudly, “Down with the emigrant!”
vi: But when they arrived in the city of Beauvais in the afternoon, when the streets were crowded, he could not hide his anxiety about the very troubling situation. A threatening crowd gathered to watch him dismount at the station yard, and many voices shouted: "Down with the exiles!"
tr: When they arrived in the town of Beauvais – at a time in the evening when the streets were teeming with people – it was not at all difficult to see that the situation was grave. The crowd gathered in the post yard to see his arrival was shouting in unison, "Let the refugee come down!"
es: However, when they arrived in the city of Beauvais at dusk, and consequently, when the streets were filled with people, he could not help but understand that things were taking on an alarming turn. In the courtyard of the inn, many groups gathered who, initially looking at him with a frown, eventually began to shout: —Death to the emigrant!

en: He stopped in the act of swinging himself out of his saddle, and, resuming it as his safest place, said:
vi: Just as he swung his leg over the saddle but before he could step down, he stopped abruptly and continued to sit on the horse for safety, he said: − Exile, my friends!
tr: Just as he was about to dismount from the saddle, he decided that for now the saddle was the safest place and gave up dismounting, saying, "Here is the refugee in front of you, friends!
es: Darnay stopped at the moment he was about to dismount, and from the saddle, he replied:

en: “Emigrant, my friends! Do you not see me here, in France, of my own will?”
vi: Just as he swung his leg over the saddle but before he could step down, he stopped abruptly and continued to sit on the horse for safety, he said: − Exile, my friends! Don't you see that I am here voluntarily, in this France of ours? −
tr: Just as he was about to dismount from the saddle, he decided that for now the saddle was the safest place and gave up dismounting, saying, "Here is the refugee in front of you, friends! Didn't I come to France of my own free will?" he said.
es: —Emigrated? No, my friends. Don't you see me here, my friends, in France, by my own free will?

en: “You are a cursed emigrant,” cried a farrier, making at him in a furious manner through the press, hammer in hand; “and you are a cursed aristocrat!”
vi: You are a cursed exile, - a blacksmith shouted angrily as he pushed through the crowd, holding a hammer, - and you are a cursed noble!
tr: With a hammer in his hand, "You are a damned refugee," a blacksmith shouted angrily from within the crowd; "and also a damned aristocrat!"
es: —You are a damned emigrant and a scoundrel aristocrat!—shouted a blacksmith, lunging at him with a hammer raised high.

en: The postmaster interposed himself between this man and the rider’s bridle (at which he was evidently making), and soothingly said, “Let him be; let him be! He will be judged at Paris.”
vi: The station master stood between him and Darnay's saddle (clearly the blacksmith's target), then spoke to calm things down: − Leave him be; leave him be! Paris will judge him. − Judge! -
tr: The postmaster, stepping in between this man and the rider's saddle (clearly he was making these at the time), said in a calming manner, "Let it go, let it go! He will be judged in Paris anyway."
es: The manager of the post house intervened between the furious blacksmith and the rider, and as someone who wishes to avoid an unpleasant scene, said: —Leave him, friends, leave him! He will be judged in Paris.

en: “Judged!” repeated the farrier, swinging his hammer. “Ay! and condemned as a traitor.” At this the crowd roared approval.
vi: The blacksmith repeated as he swung the hammer. Ah! And condemn him for treason. - Hearing this, the crowd roared in agreement.
tr: "He will be judged, of course!" repeated the blacksmith, waving his hammer. "Of course! He will be convicted as a traitor." Upon this, the crowd approved with a loud murmur.
es: —They will judge!—repeated the blacksmith, brandishing the hammer. —They will condemn him as a traitor. The mobs let out fierce roars of approval.

en: Checking the postmaster, who was for turning his horse’s head to the yard (the drunken patriot sat composedly in his saddle looking on, with the line round his wrist), Darnay said, as soon as he could make his voice heard:
vi: Darnay stopped the station master - he was turning Darnay's horse into the yard (while the drunken patriot sat calmly in the saddle, looking around with the rope wrapped around his wrist) - as soon as the commotion subsided, he spoke immediately: − Friends, you are mistaken or you do not fully understand.
tr: Darnay, turning his horse's head towards the courtyard, said to the postmaster (while the drunken patriot, with a rope wrapped around his wrist, sat calmly in his saddle, observing the surroundings) at the first moment he could make himself heard:
es: Darnay, as soon as he could be heard, exclaimed:

en: “Friends, you deceive yourselves, or you are deceived. I am not a traitor.”
vi: Darnay stopped the station master - he was turning Darnay's horse into the yard (while the drunken patriot sat calmly in the saddle, looking around with the rope wrapped around his wrist) - as soon as the commotion subsided, he spoke immediately: − Friends, you are mistaken or you do not fully understand. I am not a traitor. −
tr: "Friends, either you are deceiving yourselves or someone is deceiving you. I am not a traitor."
es: —You are mistaken, my friends, you are mistaken. I am not a traitor.

en: “He lies!” cried the smith. “He is a traitor since the decree. His life is forfeit to the people. His cursed life is not his own!”
vi: He lies! - The craftsman shouted. - He has been a traitor ever since the decree. His life belongs to the people. His cursed life is no longer his own!
tr: "He's lying!" shouted the blacksmith. "Since that new law was passed, he's been a traitor. His life is in the hands of the people. His damn life is no longer his own!"
es: —You lie!—roared the blacksmith. —According to the decree, he is a traitor!... His life belongs to the people... his cursed existence is not his own!

en: At the instant when Darnay saw a rush in the eyes of the crowd, which another instant would have brought upon him, the postmaster turned his horse into the yard, the escort rode in close upon his horse’s flanks, and the postmaster shut and barred the crazy double gates. The farrier struck a blow upon them with his hammer, and the crowd groaned; but, no more was done.
vi: Just as Darnay saw the crowd's eyes boiling with hatred and knew they would soon rush at him, the station master had already pulled the horse into the yard, with two escorts closely following on either side, and the station master securely closed and locked the heavy gates. The blacksmith struck the gate with a hammer, and the crowd grumbled angrily; but that was all. −
tr: As soon as Darnay saw the aggressive urgency in the eyes of the crowd, he understood that it would be directed at him; at that moment, the postmaster turned Darnay's horse towards the courtyard, the escorts immediately closed in on the horse, and the postmaster tightly shut the doors. When the blacksmith struck the door hard with his hammer, the crowd murmured, but nothing else happened.
