es: In the gazes of the mobs, Carlos Darnay read one of those ferocious assaults whose outcome is always a man torn to pieces. Such a fate would have befallen him if it had not been for the post house manager, who forced the horse to enter the courtyard. The escort followed our friend, and the manager immediately closed and bolted the door. The blacksmith struck the door with the hammer blows he could not deliver to the head of the emigrant; the mobs roared in indignation, but nothing more happened.

en: “What is this decree that the smith spoke of?” Darnay asked the postmaster, when he had thanked him, and stood beside him in the yard.
vi: Which decree is that craftsman talking about? - Darnay asked the station master as he stood in the yard beside him and thanked him.
tr: After thanking the postmaster, while they were standing in the courtyard, Darnay asked, "Which law was the blacksmith talking about?"
es: —What decree is that which the blacksmith mentioned?—asked Darnay to the owner of the inn, after thanking him for his fortunate mediation.

en: “Truly, a decree for selling the property of emigrants.”
vi: − Yes, the decree for the confiscation of the property of exiles.
tr: "A law regarding the sale of refugees' properties."
es: —It is the decree that orders the sale at public auction of the assets of the emigrants—replied the person questioned.

en: “When passed?”
vi: − When was it passed? −
tr: "When did it come out?"
es: —When was it enacted?

en: “On the fourteenth.”
vi: On the fourteenth.
tr: "On the fourteenth.""
es: —The fourteenth day.

en: “The day I left England!”
vi: − The day I left England! −
tr: "The day I left England!""
es: —The same day I left England.

en: “Everybody says it is but one of several, and that there will be others—if there are not already—banishing all emigrants, and condemning all to death who return. That is what he meant when he said your life was not your own.”
vi: Everyone says that, but it is just one of many decrees, there will be many more decrees... if there aren't already, decrees banning exiles from returning and punishing those who do with death. That's why that man said your life is no longer your own. −
tr: "According to what they said, this was just one of them; even if not now, other laws will be enacted later to get rid of the refugees and to prosecute those who return. When he said that life depended on us, this is what he meant."
es: —Everyone claims that it is nothing more than the first of the series, already drafted... or that will be drafted shortly, which banish the emigrants and condemn to death those who return to set foot on French territory. That's what the blacksmith meant when he said that your life was not yours, but the people's.

en: “But there are no such decrees yet?”
vi: But there hasn't been such a decree yet, right? −
tr: "But these laws haven't come out yet!""
es: —But I suppose such decrees have not yet been promulgated, have they?

en: “What do I know!” said the postmaster, shrugging his shoulders; “there may be, or there will be. It is all the same. What would you have?”
vi: How would I know! - The station master said, shrugging. - There might be, or there certainly will be. Either way, it's the same. Which one do you want?
tr: "I don't know," said the postmaster, shrugging his shoulders; "maybe it has been sent out or maybe it will be sent out. It's all the same in the end. What difference does it make?"
es: —I can't be sure—replied the postmaster, shrugging his shoulders. — They may not have been promulgated yet, or maybe they have; but it doesn't matter.

en: They rested on some straw in a loft until the middle of the night, and then rode forward again when all the town was asleep. Among the many wild changes observable on familiar things which made this wild ride unreal, not the least was the seeming rarity of sleep. After long and lonely spurring over dreary roads, they would come to a cluster of poor cottages, not steeped in darkness, but all glittering with lights, and would find the people, in a ghostly manner in the dead of the night, circling hand in hand round a shrivelled tree of Liberty, or all drawn up together singing a Liberty song. Happily, however, there was sleep in Beauvais that night to help them out of it and they passed on once more into solitude and loneliness: jingling through the untimely cold and wet, among impoverished fields that had yielded no fruits of the earth that year, diversified by the blackened remains of burnt houses, and by the sudden emergence from ambuscade, and sharp reining up across their way, of patriot patrols on the watch on all the roads.
vi: They lay down on the straw mattress in the attic until midnight, then rode on when the whole city was asleep. One of the most striking and strange changes that made this journey even more bizarre was that people seemed to sleep very little. After long, lonely stretches of hoofbeats on desolate roads, they often encountered a cluster of shabby cottages not shrouded in darkness but brightly lit, and often found many people gathering in the middle of the night like ghosts, holding hands around a withered Tree of Liberty, or all coming together to sing a Victory song. But fortunately, the people of Beauvais were sound asleep that night, so they were able to leave in solitude; the clinking of horse hooves echoed through the cold and damp, across the exhausted fields that year yielded no crops, punctuated by the charred remnants of burned houses, and by the sudden ambushes of patriotic patrols monitoring every road, cutting across their journey.
tr: They rested on the hay in an attic until midnight and set out again when the whole town was asleep. One of the things that made this mad journey surreal and one of the biggest changes they observed was that everyone was now sleeping less. After traveling for a long time on gloomy and deserted roads, they would reach clusters of poor cottages, far from the darkness, with their lamps shining brightly, and here they would encounter people wandering around like ghosts in the dead of night, circling hand in hand around the shriveled tree of liberty, or standing tall together singing songs of freedom. But fortunately, Beauvais was asleep that night, so things went well for them, and they once again merged into solitude and desolation; sometimes passing through barren fields that had not yielded crops that year and were varied with the black remnants of burned houses, accompanied by the untimely cold and rain, and sometimes pulling on the reins in front of patriotic patrols who suddenly appeared from their hiding places, ambushing all the roads.
es: Darnay rested until midnight lying on a pile of straw, leaving the city when its inhabitants were deep in sleep. Among the many radical changes in customs that Darnay could observe during his eventful journey, changes that gave it a strong fantastical color, not the least was the lack of sleep among the patriots. Often, after a long and heavy walk along solitary paths, they would arrive late at night to a village whose inhabitants, instead of sleeping peacefully, danced fantastic dances around a Liberty tree, or sang hymns to Liberty. Fortunately, however, that night Beauvais deemed it convenient to rest, thanks to which the travelers were able to continue their journey along deserted roads, covered with mud and water, skirting uncultivated fields that had produced no harvest that year, among burned-down hamlets, and with the risk of unexpectedly receiving a gunshot fired by any of the countless patriots swarming everywhere.

en: Daylight at last found them before the wall of Paris. The barrier was closed and strongly guarded when they rode up to it.
vi: The dawn light finally saw them before the gates of Paris. The barriers were tightly closed and heavily guarded as they rode up. −
tr: Daylight finally caught them at the gates of Paris. The barrier was closed, and as they moved in that direction, there was no getting past the guard.
es: Near the walls of Paris they were, when they received the greeting of the first lights of the day. At the barrier, they found a strong guard.

en: “Where are the papers of this prisoner?” demanded a resolute-looking man in authority, who was summoned out by the guard.
vi: Where are the papers for this prisoner? - The voice of a stern-faced man, who seemed to be the commander, asked as he was called over by the guards.
tr: The stern-looking official called outside by the guard asked, "Where are the prisoner's papers?"
es: "Where are the prisoner's documents?" asked a resolute-looking man, called by the sentinel, in an authoritative tone.

en: Naturally struck by the disagreeable word, Charles Darnay requested the speaker to take notice that he was a free traveller and French citizen, in charge of an escort which the disturbed state of the country had imposed upon him, and which he had paid for.
vi: Completely taken aback by that unpleasant address, Charles Darnay requested the speaker to note that he was a free traveler and a French citizen, that the country's unrest necessitated him to have an escort, and that he had paid to hire this escort group. −
tr: Charles Darnay, who was naturally disturbed by this unpleasant word, explained to this person that he was a free traveler and a French citizen, and that he had hired his companions due to the country's chaotic situation.
es: Carlos Darnay, disgusted upon hearing such an unpleasant word, replied that he was not a prisoner, but a traveler who arrived freely and voluntarily, a French citizen, entrusted to the custody of an escort that the disturbed state of the country made necessary, and that he had paid for out of his own pocket.

en: “Where,” repeated the same personage, without taking any heed of him whatever, “are the papers of this prisoner?”
vi: Where? - The other character repeated, paying no heed to him. - Where are this prisoner's papers?
tr: The same person, without paying attention to what he heard, asked again, "Where are the prisoner's papers?"
es: —Where are this prisoner's documents?—repeated the same individual, without paying the slightest attention to Darnay or his words.

en: The drunken patriot had them in his cap, and produced them. Casting his eyes over Gabelle’s letter, the same personage in authority showed some disorder and surprise, and looked at Darnay with a close attention.
vi: Storing the papers in his hat, the drunken patriot fished them out and presented them. Glancing over Gabelle's letter, the authoritative figure was slightly confused, surprised, and looked at Darnay intently.
tr: The drunken companion took out the papers from inside his hat and handed them over. The official who glanced at Gabelle's letter, confused and astonished, scrutinized Darnay with great attention.
es: The patriot of the perpetual drunkenness took them out of his hat, where he carried them, handing them over to the person who asked for them. Gabelle's letter caused some confusion and not a little surprise in him, while also capturing his attention, which he focused on Darnay.

en: He left escort and escorted without saying a word, however, and went into the guard-room; meanwhile, they sat upon their horses outside the gate. Looking about him while in this state of suspense, Charles Darnay observed that the gate was held by a mixed guard of soldiers and patriots, the latter far outnumbering the former; and that while ingress into the city for peasants’ carts bringing in supplies, and for similar traffic and traffickers, was easy enough, egress, even for the homeliest people, was very difficult. A numerous medley of men and women, not to mention beasts and vehicles of various sorts, was waiting to issue forth; but, the previous identification was so strict, that they filtered through the barrier very slowly. Some of these people knew their turn for examination to be so far off, that they lay down on the ground to sleep or smoke, while others talked together, or loitered about. The red cap and tri-colour cockade were universal, both among men and women.
vi: Without saying a word, he went straight into the guard post, leaving both the escort and the escorted sitting on their horses outside the city gate. While looking around waiting, Charles Darnay saw that the place was guarded by a mixed force of soldiers and patriots, the latter far outnumbering the former; while entering the capital seemed quite easy for the peasant produce carts and other vehicles, leaving this place was very difficult, even for the simplest country folk. A chaotic multitude of people, both men and women, not to mention various animals and vehicles, were waiting to pass through; but due to the extremely strict paper checks, the whole crowd moved very slowly through the barriers. Some people, knowing their turn was far off, lay down on the ground to sleep or smoke, while others chatted or wandered around. Everywhere you look, you see the red hat and the tricolor badge, on the heads of both men and women.
tr: Without saying a single word, the man left them and entered the police station alone; meanwhile, Darnay and his companions waited in front of the door, on their horses. During this tense wait, Charles Darnay looked around and saw that the entrance was held by soldiers and patriotic citizens, the number of citizens was greater than that of the soldiers, and while it was easy for peasants and similar types bringing supplies with carts to enter the city, exiting was very difficult even for the most ordinary citizen. Men and women of all kinds, a multitude of animals, and various types of vehicles were waiting to exit; but the previous identity check was so strict that they had progressed very slowly from the barrier. While some, seeing that they had a long wait ahead, lay down to sleep or smoke tobacco, others chatted with each other or loitered around. The red cap and the tricolor rosette were very popular among both women and men.
es: Without saying a word, he left the escort and the escorted and entered the guardhouse, leaving the travelers on horseback in front of the door. Carlos Darnay, meanwhile, was able to observe that the guard was made up of soldiers and patriots, more of the latter than the former, and that, while the carts bringing provisions to the city or those engaged in any kind of trade encountered no difficulties entering, they faced very great difficulties when trying to leave, even if they were the humblest of people. Men and women, pack and draft animals, and carts and coaches of all kinds waited to be allowed to leave; but the law regarding prior identification was enforced so rigidly that although hundreds reached the barrier, they exited one by one and at long intervals. Those who knew it would be a long time before their turn came waited lying in the street, where they slept or smoked, while others engaged in lively conversations or passed the time walking around. The red caps and tricolor cockades were mandatory attire that everyone wore, regardless of age or gender.

en: When he had sat in his saddle some half-hour, taking note of these things, Darnay found himself confronted by the same man in authority, who directed the guard to open the barrier. Then he delivered to the escort, drunk and sober, a receipt for the escorted, and requested him to dismount. He did so, and the two patriots, leading his tired horse, turned and rode away without entering the city.
vi: When Darnay had been sitting on his horse for about half an hour, observing this scene, the authoritative figure from earlier appeared before him again, ordering the guards to open the barrier. He then handed a receipt to the two escorts, one drunk and one sober, and instructed Darnay to dismount. He complied, and the two patriots led away his weary horse, turning their backs and riding off without entering the city.
tr: Darnay, who had been sitting on his horse's saddle for about half an hour observing the surroundings, found the same official in front of him again, the man was telling the guards to open the barrier. Then, one drunk and the other sober, the escorts gave a receipt for the person they were accompanying and asked Darnay to dismount. Darnay did as he was told, and the two citizens took his tired horse with them and returned the way they had come without entering the city.
es: The wait for Charles Darnay would last half an hour, during which time he was able to make the observations that are noted, when the same character, apparently the chief of the barrier guard, came out again, who, after giving the escort a receipt for the person escorted, ordered him to dismount. Darnay obeyed, and the men who had accompanied him there took charge of his horse and left without entering the city.

en: He accompanied his conductor into a guard-room, smelling of common wine and tobacco, where certain soldiers and patriots, asleep and awake, drunk and sober, and in various neutral states between sleeping and waking, drunkenness and sobriety, were standing and lying about. The light in the guard-house, half derived from the waning oil-lamps of the night, and half from the overcast day, was in a correspondingly uncertain condition. Some registers were lying open on a desk, and an officer of a coarse, dark aspect, presided over these.
vi: He followed that guide into the guard station reeking of cheap liquor and tobacco, where it was full of soldiers and patriots lying and sitting, some sleeping, some awake, some drunk, some sober, and in various states between wakefulness and sleep, between sobriety and drunkenness. The light in the guard station, partly cast from the oil lamps lit since the night, and partly from the dim daylight, continuously flickered and swayed. A pile of books lay open on the desk, and a dark-skinned, coarse officer was seated at the table.
tr: Darnay, along with the official, went to the police station, which reeked of cheap wine and tobacco, where some soldiers and citizens were sleeping and waking, sitting or lying down, transitioning between sleep and wakefulness, and between drunkenness and sobriety. The light, partly from the gas lamp left on overnight and partly from the enclosed atmosphere, reflected an equally ambiguous situation. Some record books were open on one of the tables, and a rough-looking, sullen clerk was bent over them.
es: The head of the guard led Darnay to the guardhouse, which reeked of cheap wine and tobacco, where there were several groups of soldiers and patriots, some asleep and others awake, the latter drunk and the former sober, and some on the borders of wakefulness and sleep, and of sobriety and drunkenness. Two oil lamps cast a very questionable light over the guardhouse, on one of whose walls there was a table, upon which some records could be seen. A coarse-looking officer, seated in front of the table, was in charge of the records.

en: “Citizen Defarge,” said he to Darnay’s conductor, as he took a slip of paper to write on. “Is this the emigrant Evrémonde?”
vi: − Citizen Defarge, - he said to the person who had brought Darnay in, while taking out a piece of paper to make notes. - Is this the exiled Evrémonde? −
tr: Taking a paper to write something about the man, "Citizen Defarge," said the official who brought Darnay. "Is this the refugee Evremonde?""
es: —Citizen Defarge—said the character who had introduced Darnay, while taking a sheet of paper—Is this the emigrant Evrémonde?

en: “This is the man.”
vi: This is the man. −
tr: "Yes, it's him."
es: —This is it.

en: “Your age, Evrémonde?”
vi: How old are you, Evrémonde? −
tr: "How old are you, Evremonde?"
es: —How old are you, Evrémonde?

en: “Thirty-seven.”
vi: Thirty-seven.
tr: "Thirty-seven."
es: —Thirty-seven.

en: “Married, Evrémonde?”
vi: − Do you have a family, Evrémonde?
tr: "Are you married, Evremonde?"
es: —Married, Evrémonde?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − Yes. −
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Where married?”
vi: Where did you get married?
tr: "Where is your house?"
es: —Where?

en: “In England.”
vi: − In England.
tr: "In England."
es: —In England.

en: “Without doubt. Where is your wife, Evrémonde?”
vi: − Surely so. Where is your wife, Evrémonde? −
tr: "Without a doubt. Where is your wife, Evremonde?"
es: —I believe it. Where is your wife, Evrémonde?

en: “In England.”
vi: In England.
tr: "In England."
es: —In England.

en: “Without doubt. You are consigned, Evrémonde, to the prison of La Force.”
vi: − Certainly. Evrémonde, you are assigned to La Force prison.
tr: "No doubt. You have been sent to La Force Prison, Evremonde."
es: —I believe so too. You are consigned, Evrémonde, to the prison of La Force.

en: “Just Heaven!” exclaimed Darnay. “Under what law, and for what offence?”
vi: − My God! - exclaimed Darnay. - By what law, and for what crime?
tr: "My God, how is this possible!" cried Darnay. "According to which law, for what crime?"
es: —God in Heaven!—exclaimed Darnay—By virtue of what law, and for what crime or offense?

en: The officer looked up from his slip of paper for a moment.
vi: The officer lifted his eyes from the paper and looked up for a moment.
tr: The attendant lifted his head from the paper he was filling out and looked up for a moment.
es: After a few seconds of silent contemplation, the official replied:

en: “We have new laws, Evrémonde, and new offences, since you were here.” He said it with a hard smile, and went on writing.
vi: - We have had many new laws, Evrémonde, and many new crimes, since the last time you were here. - He said with a malicious smile, then continued writing.
tr: "Since you left here, we have new laws, Evremonde, and of course, new crimes." As he said this, there was a rough smile on his face, and he continued writing.
es: —Since you left France, Evrémonde, we have been governed by new laws, and what pertains to crimes and offenses has changed profoundly. "I beg you to bear in mind, citizen, that I have come voluntarily, yielding to the written plea on that paper before your eyes," replied Darnay.

en: “I entreat you to observe that I have come here voluntarily, in response to that written appeal of a fellow-countryman which lies before you. I demand no more than the opportunity to do so without delay. Is not that my right?”
vi: − I would like to draw your attention to the fact that I have come here voluntarily, in response to the request of a compatriot written in the letter that is lying in front of you. I just want to have the opportunity to fulfill that request without delay. Don't I have that right?
tr: "I would like to state that I have come here of my own accord to help the citizen whose request is written on the paper in front of you. I hope you will give me this opportunity without delay. Do I not have this right?"
es: "I beg you to bear in mind, citizen, that I have come voluntarily, yielding to the written plea on that paper before your eyes," replied Darnay. "I ask for nothing more than the opportunity to do what a fellow countryman of mine requests. Am I not within my rights?"

en: “Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde,” was the stolid reply. The officer wrote until he had finished, read over to himself what he had written, sanded it, and handed it to Defarge, with the words “In secret.”
vi: − An exile has no rights at all, Evrémonde, - came the indifferent reply. The officer wrote until he was finished, read over what he had written, sprinkled sand to dry the ink, and then handed the paper to Defarge, with a word: "Solitary confinement."
tr: The official replied emotionlessly, "Refugees have no rights, Evremonde!" He finished his writing, read it once more to himself, then sealed it and handed it to Defarge, saying "Secret."
es: "Emigrants have no rights, Evrémonde," was the stolid reply of the official. After giving Darnay a sinister smile, he wrote a few lines, folded the paper, and handed it to Defarge, saying: —Secret.

en: Defarge motioned with the paper to the prisoner that he must accompany him. The prisoner obeyed, and a guard of two armed patriots attended them.
vi: Defarge waved the paper as a signal for the prisoner to go with him. The prisoner obeyed, and two armed patriotic Citizens escorted him.
tr: Defarge signaled the prisoner to come with the paper in his hand. The prisoner complied, and two armed patriotic citizens joined them.
es: Defarge indicated to the prisoner to follow him. The prisoner obeyed, accompanied by two armed patriots who positioned themselves to his right and left.

en: “Is it you,” said Defarge, in a low voice, as they went down the guardhouse steps and turned into Paris, “who married the daughter of Doctor Manette, once a prisoner in the Bastille that is no more?”
vi: − Is it true that you... - Defarge asked in a low voice as they descended the guardhouse steps and entered Paris, - ... are the husband of Dr. Manette's daughter, who was once a prisoner in the Bastille? −
tr: As they descended the steps of the station and headed towards Paris, Defarge asked Darnay in a low voice, "Are you the one who married the daughter of Doctor Manette, who once lay in the Bastille?"
es: As they left the guardhouse to enter Paris, Defarge asked the prisoner in a low voice: —Are you the one who married the daughter of Dr. Manette, once a prisoner in the now non-existent Bastille?

en: “Yes,” replied Darnay, looking at him with surprise.
vi: Yes, - Darnay replied, looking at the questioner in surprise.
tr: "Yes!" replied Darnay, looking at her in astonishment.
es: —Yes—replied Darnay, looking at him with surprise.

en: “My name is Defarge, and I keep a wine-shop in the Quarter Saint Antoine. Possibly you have heard of me.”
vi: − I am Defarge, the owner of the wine shop in the Saint Antoine district. You must have heard of me. −
tr: "My name is Defarge and I have a wine shop in St Antoine Square. You have probably heard of me before."
es: —My name is Defarge and I own a tavern in the San Antonio neighborhood. You may know me by reputation.

en: “My wife came to your house to reclaim her father? Yes!”
vi: Did my wife come to your house to bring her father back? Yes!
tr: "My wife had come to your house to pick up her father, right?" "Of course!"
es: —My wife went to your house to claim her father... Yes, yes!

en: The word “wife” seemed to serve as a gloomy reminder to Defarge, to say with sudden impatience, “In the name of that sharp female newly-born, and called La Guillotine, why did you come to France?”
vi: The word "wife" seemed to be a dark reminder to Defarge, causing him to suddenly become agitated. − In the name of the newly born sharp lady named La Guillotine*, I ask why you returned to France? −
tr: When Defarge heard the word "wife," he suddenly became tense and impatiently asked, "For the love of the newly born stern lady Guillotine, answer; why did you come to France?"
es: It seems that the word "woman" awakened somber memories in Defarge, for he said with brusque impatience: —Do you want to tell me, in the name of that newly born woman called Guillotine, why on earth you have come to France?

en: “You heard me say why, a minute ago. Do you not believe it is the truth?”
vi: You heard me give the reason just now. Do you not believe that is the truth?
tr: "You just heard why I came. Don't you believe what I said is true?"
es: —Not a minute ago you heard me explain what was the cause of my trip. Do you think I didn't tell the truth?

en: “A bad truth for you,” said Defarge, speaking with knitted brows, and looking straight before him.
vi: − A harsh truth for you, - Defarge said, frowning, looking straight ahead. −
tr: "A fact to your detriment," said Defarge, looking straight ahead with furrowed brows.
es: —True, it couldn't be more fatal for you—replied Defarge, furrowing his brow and looking intently at his interlocutor.

en: “Indeed I am lost here. All here is so unprecedented, so changed, so sudden and unfair, that I am absolutely lost. Will you render me a little help?”
vi: Honestly, I am bewildered to be back here. Everything here is too strange, too changed, too sudden and unjust, to understand anything at all. Can you help me a little?
tr: "I was taken aback here. Everything has changed so unexpectedly, mercilessly, and quickly that I was taken aback. Can't you help me a little?"
es: —It is true that I find myself lost here. I see everything so disrupted, so different from what it used to be, so unpleasant, that I confess I don't even know where to turn my eyes. Would you do me a small favor?

en: “None.” Defarge spoke, always looking straight before him.
vi: − No. - Defarge said, still looking straight ahead.
tr: "No." Defarge was speaking while looking straight ahead.
es: —Absolutely none—replied Defarge, with a gaze as if lost in space.

en: “Will you answer me a single question?”
vi: − Can you answer just one question for me?
tr: "If I ask you something, can you answer?"
es: —You don't want to answer a question for me, not even one?

en: “Perhaps. According to its nature. You can say what it is.”
vi: − Maybe. It depends on the nature of the question. Just say it straight out. −
tr: "It could be. It depends on the question you're going to ask. What is the matter?"
es: —We'll see... Depending on how it is. You can do it.

en: “In this prison that I am going to so unjustly, shall I have some free communication with the world outside?”
vi: In the prison where I will be unjustly detained, will I have any freedom to communicate with the outside world? −
tr: "In this prison where I have been so unjustly taken, will I be able to communicate freely with the outside?""
es: —In the prison where I am so unjustly confined, will I be able to communicate freely with the outside world?

en: “You will see.”
vi: You will find out.
tr: "You will see."
es: —You will see it yourself.

en: “I am not to be buried there, prejudged, and without any means of presenting my case?”
vi: − Will I be buried there for life, will I be judged, is there any way to justify myself? −
tr: "I won't be locked up there without a trial or a chance to explain my situation, will I?"
es: —Do you intend to bury me in it, without judging me, without condemning me, without giving me the means to justify and defend myself?

en: “You will see. But, what then? Other people have been similarly buried in worse prisons, before now.”
vi: You will know soon. But what if there is? Many people have already been buried for life in prison before. −
tr: "You will see. But then what will happen? Many people in similar situations before you were imprisoned in much worse dungeons."
es: —You'll see for yourself... But if that were the case, so what? Many others as good as you have found themselves buried in worse prisons.

en: “But never by me, Citizen Defarge.”
vi: But it wasn't caused by me, Citizen Defarge.
tr: "But such a thing wouldn't happen to me, right Citizen Defarge?"
es: —But not because of me, citizen Defarge.

en: Defarge glanced darkly at him for answer, and walked on in a steady and set silence. The deeper he sank into this silence, the fainter hope there was—or so Darnay thought—of his softening in any slight degree. He, therefore, made haste to say:
vi: Defarge responded with a dark look and continued walking, silent and speechless. The more sullen and silent he became, Darnay thought, the less hope he had that Defarge would soften even a little. Darnay hastily continued: − There is something extremely important to me; you know, Citizen, even better than I do about its importance; I need to inform Mr. Lorry of Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman currently in Paris, of a simple matter, without any commentary, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.
tr: Defarge looked at him mysteriously as if he were about to say something, and then sank into a long and stern silence. As the silence prolonged, the possibility of the man softening was diminishing – or so Darnay thought. Therefore, he hastily said:
es: The somber expression on Defarge's face became extraordinarily pronounced upon hearing the response, after which he continued walking in silence. As his taciturnity increased, the hopes that Darnay initially had of softening the man dissipated. —For me, it is of exceptional importance, as you know as well as I do, citizen Defarge, to inform Mr. Lorry, from Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman who is currently in Paris, of the simple fact, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force.

en: “It is of the utmost importance to me (you know, Citizen, even better than I, of how much importance), that I should be able to communicate to Mr. Lorry of Tellson’s Bank, an English gentleman who is now in Paris, the simple fact, without comment, that I have been thrown into the prison of La Force. Will you cause that to be done for me?”
vi: Darnay hastily continued: − There is something extremely important to me; you know, Citizen, even better than I do about its importance; I need to inform Mr. Lorry of Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman currently in Paris, of a simple matter, without any commentary, that I have been imprisoned in La Force. Can you help me with that?
tr: "Considering the fact that I will be confined to La Force Prison, it is extremely important for me to be able to speak with the English gentleman Mr. Lorry, who works at Tellson's Bank and is currently in Paris. Can you arrange this for me?"
es: —For me, it is of exceptional importance, as you know as well as I do, citizen Defarge, to inform Mr. Lorry, from Tellson's Bank, an English gentleman who is currently in Paris, of the simple fact, without any comment, that I have been imprisoned in La Force. Would you do me the favor of making him aware of this?

en: “I will do,” Defarge doggedly rejoined, “nothing for you. My duty is to my country and the People. I am the sworn servant of both, against you. I will do nothing for you.”
vi: − I will do nothing for you, - Defarge insisted. My duty is to serve my country and my people. I have sworn to oppose people like you for those two reasons. I will do nothing for you.
tr: "For you," said Defarge and continued resolutely, "there is nothing I can do. My obligation is to my country and my people. I am their sworn servant against you. I can do nothing for you."
es: —I will do absolutely nothing in your favor—replied Defarge. —I owe myself to my country and the people. I have sworn to serve both against you. Expect nothing from me.

en: Charles Darnay felt it hopeless to entreat him further, and his pride was touched besides. As they walked on in silence, he could not but see how used the people were to the spectacle of prisoners passing along the streets. The very children scarcely noticed him. A few passers turned their heads, and a few shook their fingers at him as an aristocrat; otherwise, that a man in good clothes should be going to prison, was no more remarkable than that a labourer in working clothes should be going to work. In one narrow, dark, and dirty street through which they passed, an excited orator, mounted on a stool, was addressing an excited audience on the crimes against the people, of the king and the royal family. The few words that he caught from this man’s lips, first made it known to Charles Darnay that the king was in prison, and that the foreign ambassadors had one and all left Paris. On the road (except at Beauvais) he had heard absolutely nothing. The escort and the universal watchfulness had completely isolated him.
vi: Charles Darnay found that making another request would be futile, moreover, his pride would be hurt. As they walked quietly, he couldn't help but notice that the people had become too accustomed to the sight of prisoners being escorted through the streets. Even children didn't bother to pay attention to him. A few people passing by turned to look, a few others gestured at him as if he were a nobleman; besides that, a well-dressed person going to prison was no more remarkable than a laborer in shabby clothes going to work. In a narrow, dark, filthy street they passed through, an enthusiastic orator stood on a stool, speaking to an eager crowd about the crimes against the people committed by the king and the royal family. Now, hearing a few words from this person, Charles Darnay learned that the king had been imprisoned and all foreign envoys had left Paris, leaving no one behind. On the way (except when in Beauvais), he hadn't heard any news. The escort and the surveillance everywhere had completely isolated him.
tr: Darnay felt that there was no point in pleading any further, moreover, his pride was hurt. As he proceeded in silence, he saw how familiar the public was with prisoners passing by. Except for a few children, no one noticed him. Two or three passersby turned their heads to look, and a few, thinking he was an aristocrat, pointed their fingers and shook them; after all, a well-dressed man being taken to prison had become as normal as a worker going to his job in his work clothes. In a narrow, dark, and dirty street they passed, an excited speaker standing on a stool was telling an enthusiastic crowd about the crimes the king and the royal family had committed against the people. As far as Charles Darnay could catch from this man's lips, the king was in prison and all the foreign ambassadors had left Paris. He had heard nothing on the road (except outside Beauvais). His escorts and his great anxiety must have isolated him from everything.
es: Darnay fell silent, both because he considered all chances of obtaining even the slightest favor from that man to be definitively lost, and because his wounded pride led him to view his pleas as humiliations. He couldn't help but notice, as he silently walked through the streets, how accustomed the people were to the sight of prisoners passing by. Not even the children paid attention to him. Some passersby turned their heads and pointed at him, indicating that he was an aristocrat, and nothing more. Indeed, seeing a well-dressed man being taken to prison was as common and natural as seeing a worker heading to his job with his tools in hand. In a narrow, dark, and dirty alley they had to cross, they encountered a highly agitated street orator, delivering fervent speeches to an equally agitated audience, extolling the crimes committed against the sovereign people by the King, the royal family, and the nobles. From the few words that reached Darnay's ears, he was able to infer that the King had been imprisoned and that foreign ambassadors had left Paris en masse, news of which he was entirely unaware, as during his journey, the individuals escorting him, along with the universal surveillance, had kept him in such absolute isolation that he had heard nothing.

en: That he had fallen among far greater dangers than those which had developed themselves when he left England, he of course knew now. That perils had thickened about him fast, and might thicken faster and faster yet, he of course knew now. He could not but admit to himself that he might not have made this journey, if he could have foreseen the events of a few days. And yet his misgivings were not so dark as, imagined by the light of this later time, they would appear. Troubled as the future was, it was the unknown future, and in its obscurity there was ignorant hope. The horrible massacre, days and nights long, which, within a few rounds of the clock, was to set a great mark of blood upon the blessed garnering time of harvest, was as far out of his knowledge as if it had been a hundred thousand years away. The “sharp female newly-born, and called La Guillotine,” was hardly known to him, or to the generality of people, by name. The frightful deeds that were to be soon done, were probably unimagined at that time in the brains of the doers. How could they have a place in the shadowy conceptions of a gentle mind?
vi: Now, of course, he knew that he had fallen into dangers far greater than those that had arisen since he left England. Now, of course, he knew that those dangers were quickly closing in on him and the situation had become increasingly urgent. He had to admit to himself that if he had known about these developments a few days earlier, he would not have taken that trip. However, looking back more clearly later, it would be evident that Darnay's worries were not as dark as he had imagined. Even if the future is uncertain, it remains an unknown future, and it is precisely because of this ambiguity that we still have hope. In his understanding, there was no sign of the horrific massacre that lasted many days and nights, a massacre that, after just a few turns of the clock's hands, had stained an entire season of fortunate achievements with blood; that image was as distant as if it had been a hundred thousand years ago. Neither he nor the French populace knew anything about "the newly born sharp lady named La Guillotine." The terrible things that will be done perhaps even at this moment cannot be imagined even by those who will carry them out. So how can a gentle mind possibly envision such things in its own obscure perception?
tr: He knew now that he was in much greater dangers than those he was in when he left England. He also knew now that the threat was rapidly increasing and would continue to increase. If he had known what he would experience in the last few days, he might never have embarked on this journey. Still, his anxieties were not as dark as they seemed; there was a faint light, it seemed. The future was as uncertain as it was troubled, and within all this uncertainty, there was an ignorant hope. The massacre that would begin in a few hours and last for days and nights would stain the sacred harvest time with blood, but to Darnay, it felt like something that would happen a hundred thousand years later. "The newly born harsh lady guillotine" was not yet well-known by name. The terrible actions that would soon take place perhaps had not yet formed in the minds of those who would carry them out. How could all these fit into the vague concepts within a polite mind?
es: As is natural, he understood that the dangers threatening him were infinitely greater and infinitely more numerous than he had supposed when leaving England; he understood that the dangers were multiplying at an alarming rate and that they would multiply even more; he could not help but confess to himself that the idea of making the journey would never have crossed his mind had he foreseen the events that had unfolded in recent days. And yet, his fears, when examined in the light of the most recent incidents, were not as great as they seem they should have been. No matter how nebulous the future appeared to him, it was an unknown future that, in its very obscurity, held a certain hope. As unaware as those who lived thousands of years before him, he was to the horrible massacres that, continuing day after day, night after night, would drown the always blessed harvest season in torrents of blood. He barely knew by name the "newly born woman called Guillotine," just as the general populace barely knew her by name, for in those days, even those who had brought her into the world could not have imagined the dreadful deeds that would soon envelop her in an immense bloody aura.

en: Of unjust treatment in detention and hardship, and in cruel separation from his wife and child, he foreshadowed the likelihood, or the certainty; but, beyond this, he dreaded nothing distinctly. With this on his mind, which was enough to carry into a dreary prison courtyard, he arrived at the prison of La Force.
vi: He had anticipated the possibility, or certainty, of being unjustly mistreated in harsh captivity, suffering the pain of separation from his wife and children; but beyond those things, he had no specific fears. With that mindset, he stepped into the gloomy courtyard of La Force prison - he had arrived.
tr: While cruelly separated from his wife and child, he could foresee the unjust treatment he would endure in custody and the difficulties he would face, he was even certain of it; but beyond that, there was nothing specific he feared. His mind filled with these thoughts, enough to fill a gloomy prison courtyard, they arrived at La Force Prison.
es: He suspected that he would be the victim of an arbitrary arrest, that he would be treated with irritating injustice, that he would have to endure deprivations and hardships, of which the least would not be being separated from his beloved wife and his idolized daughter; he suspected all of this; moreover, he considered it undeniable; but beyond that, he feared nothing. Such were the reflections that overwhelmed him when he arrived at the prison called La Force.

en: A man with a bloated face opened the strong wicket, to whom Defarge presented “The Emigrant Evrémonde.”
vi: A fat-faced man opened a small hatch in the iron gate for Defarge to hand over the "Exiled Evrémonde." −
tr: A man with a swollen face opened the heavy door, and Defarge introduced Darnay by saying, "Refugee Evremonde."
es: A man with a fierce face opened the wicket. —The emigrant Evrémonde—said Defarge, introducing the prisoner.

en: “What the Devil! How many more of them!” exclaimed the man with the bloated face.
vi: Oh my God! How many more people! - The fat-faced man exclaimed.
tr: "May God punish them! Will they never end?" shouted the fat-faced man.
es: —Crowned demons! But is this procession never going to end?—exclaimed the one with the fierce face.

en: Defarge took his receipt without noticing the exclamation, and withdrew, with his two fellow-patriots.
vi: Ignoring the complaints, Defarge took the confirmation paper and withdrew, along with his two patriotic Citizens. −
tr: Defarge took the receipt without paying attention to the man's shouting and returned with his two guards.
es: Defarge took the receipt that the jailer handed him, without paying attention to his exclamation, and withdrew along with the two patriots.

en: “What the Devil, I say again!” exclaimed the gaoler, left with his wife. “How many more!”
vi: Heavens! I must speak! - The jailer exclaimed again when he was alone with his wife. - How many more! −
tr: The guard who remained with his wife shouted again, "May God punish them!" "Will these never end?"
es: —Thunder and lightning!—grumbled the jailer, now alone with his wife.— This is a river that always flows!

en: The gaoler’s wife, being provided with no answer to the question, merely replied, “One must have patience, my dear!” Three turnkeys who entered responsive to a bell she rang, echoed the sentiment, and one added, “For the love of Liberty;” which sounded in that place like an inappropriate conclusion.
vi: We must be patient, dear! - Unable to give a precise answer, the jailer's wife responded thus and rang the bell to call in three wardens. They also agreed with her and one person added, "For the love of Freedom," that sentence echoed in this place like a paradoxical conclusion.
tr: His wife, who had no answer to this question, simply said, "You need to be patient, dear!" The three guards who came upon hearing the woman's bell were of the same opinion, and one of them, although it wasn't quite appropriate for the situation, added, "For the love of freedom!"
es: The jailer's wife, who probably did not have the appropriate response in her repository of replies for the previous exclamation, simply answered: —You have to be patient, my friend. The sounds of a bell that the woman rang evoked three jailers, who said in unison: —Long live Freedom! The choir did not seem the most appropriate to be sung in a place like that, but greater anomalies are seen in the world.

en: The prison of La Force was a gloomy prison, dark and filthy, and with a horrible smell of foul sleep in it. Extraordinary how soon the noisome flavour of imprisoned sleep, becomes manifest in all such places that are ill cared for!
vi: La Force Prison is a gloomy, dark, and filthy place, reeking of the stench of death. The overpowering smell of death manifests so quickly and terribly in any place that is not well cared for! − Solitary confinement again! -
tr: The dark and filthy La Force Prison was a gloomy prison, and inside there was a disgusting smell caused by heavy sleep. How quickly the disgusting smell of sleep, which was not properly attended to, would permeate such places where detainees were held!
es: La Force prison was a gloomy, repugnant, and filthy building, where one could breathe the foul atmosphere of death. It is truly astonishing how quickly the sense of smell detects the odor of flesh stored in places like that, especially when they are not suitable for the purpose and, in addition, are neglected.

en: “In secret, too,” grumbled the gaoler, looking at the written paper. “As if I was not already full to bursting!”
vi: The jailer grumbled, looking at the paper. - As if it isn't crowded enough here already!
tr: The guard grumbled, looking at the paper, "And it's supposed to be secret!" "I'm already looking for a reason to explode!"
es: —And also secret!—murmured the warden while reading the paper.— As if I weren't already so full of them that one of these days I'll explode!

en: He stuck the paper on a file, in an ill-humour, and Charles Darnay awaited his further pleasure for half an hour: sometimes, pacing to and fro in the strong arched room: sometimes, resting on a stone seat: in either case detained to be imprinted on the memory of the chief and his subordinates.
vi: He placed the paper in the file, irritated, and Charles Darnay waited patiently for another half hour; sometimes he paced back and forth in the sturdy vaulted room, sometimes he sat on the stone bench - long enough for the jailer and his subordinates to remember him. −
tr: Adam grumpily put the paper into a file, and Charles Darnay waited for about half an hour for him to regain his mood; sometimes walking up and down in the room filled with sharp belts, sometimes resting on a heavy stone; in any case, he was etched into the memory of the man standing over him and those beside him.
es: With signs of very bad temper, he skewered the paper with a spike that pierced many others, and began to pace around the vaulted room without paying the slightest attention to the prisoner, whom he kept waiting for more than half an hour.

en: “Come!” said the chief, at length taking up his keys, “come with me, emigrant.”
vi: Let's go! - Finally, the jailer picked up the bunch of keys. - Follow me, exile.
tr: "Come!" called the guard at the head, while taking out his key, "come with me, refugee."
es: "Follow me, emigrant," he finally said, taking the keys.

en: Through the dismal prison twilight, his new charge accompanied him by corridor and staircase, many doors clanging and locking behind them, until they came into a large, low, vaulted chamber, crowded with prisoners of both sexes. The women were seated at a long table, reading and writing, knitting, sewing, and embroidering; the men were for the most part standing behind their chairs, or lingering up and down the room.
vi: In the dim twilight of the prison, the newcomer who received Darnay led him through corridors and staircases, with many doors clicking open and shut, locking behind them, until they reached a low-ceilinged, vaulted room crowded with both male and female prisoners. The women sat at a long table, reading, writing, knitting, and embroidering; most of the men stood leaning against the backs of chairs or paced back and forth in the room.
tr: In the gloomy dim light of the prison, they walked through corridors and stairs accompanied by the new warden, many doors opened and locked behind them, and finally, they arrived at a large, low-ceilinged, domed hall filled with a multitude of inmates, both men and women. The women were seated at the head of a long table, some reading and writing, some knitting, and some sewing and embroidering; many of the men were either leaning back in their chairs or wandering up and down the hall.
es: The warden led the new inmate through a corridor and a staircase, and after several minutes, and not without opening many doors during the walk and closing them again after passing through, they arrived at a large, low-ceilinged, vaulted room, crowded with prisoners of both sexes. The women were sitting around a table, reading or writing, knitting, sewing, or embroidering, while the men, for the most part, were standing behind the chairs occupied by the women, except for a few who were amusing themselves by walking around.

en: In the instinctive association of prisoners with shameful crime and disgrace, the new-comer recoiled from this company. But the crowning unreality of his long unreal ride, was, their all at once rising to receive him, with every refinement of manner known to the time, and with all the engaging graces and courtesies of life.
vi: The newcomer instinctively wanted to retreat and avoid encountering this group of shameful and sinful prisoners. But the surreal, dreamlike feeling he had throughout his long journey reached its peak when all those prisoners immediately stood up to welcome him with the most elegant, refined, and graceful manners of the contemporary nobility.
tr: The newly arrived prisoner instinctively recoiled and stepped back upon seeing the inmates he associated with disgraceful crimes and scandals. But the most surreal part of this long and unreal journey was that they all stood up at that moment to greet him with the most polite manners of the time and all the elegance and grace that beautify life.
es: So gloomy was the room, so somber the expression of the people crowded there, so pronounced the yellowness that privations and misery had created on their faces, that Carlos Darnay believed he was among a large collection of the dead.

en: So strangely clouded were these refinements by the prison manners and gloom, so spectral did they become in the inappropriate squalor and misery through which they were seen, that Charles Darnay seemed to stand in a company of the dead. Ghosts all! The ghost of beauty, the ghost of stateliness, the ghost of elegance, the ghost of pride, the ghost of frivolity, the ghost of wit, the ghost of youth, the ghost of age, all waiting their dismissal from the desolate shore, all turning on him eyes that were changed by the death they had died in coming there.
vi: Those subtle gestures were so tragic in the desolate scene of this prison, so eerie when displayed in this wretched, filthy, ironic place, that Charles Darnay felt as if he were standing before a group of corpses. All ghosts! Ghosts of beauty, ghosts of dignity, ghosts of grace, ghosts of pride, ghosts of vanity, ghosts of cunning, ghosts of youth, ghosts of old age, all waiting to leave this desolate shore, all fixing their eyes on him, eyes transformed by the torment of death as they buried their lives in this prison.
tr: The style and gloom of the prison had so strangely overshadowed these subtleties, and the prisoners had fallen into such bizarre states, resembling ghosts amidst all this inappropriate filth and misery, that Charles Darnay felt as if he were among a community of the dead. They all seemed like ghosts! The ghost of beauty, the ghost of splendor, the ghost of grace, the ghost of pride, the ghost of frivolity, the ghost of intelligence, the ghosts of youth and old age, all were waiting for the day they would escape from this desolate shore, and all had turned their dead eyes, which had died upon entering the prison, towards him.
es: So gloomy was the room, so somber the expression of the people crowded there, so pronounced the yellowness that privations and misery had created on their faces, that Carlos Darnay believed he was among a large collection of the dead. There were only ghosts there. Ghosts of beauty, ghosts of elegance, ghosts of haughtiness, ghosts of pride, ghosts of frivolity, ghosts of talent, ghosts of youth, ghosts of old age, all of them waiting for the hour to leave the inhospitable shore of the world, all of them fixing their eyes on the newcomer, eyes that death had altered as soon as they entered the antechamber of its domains.

en: It struck him motionless. The gaoler standing at his side, and the other gaolers moving about, who would have been well enough as to appearance in the ordinary exercise of their functions, looked so extravagantly coarse contrasted with sorrowing mothers and blooming daughters who were there—with the apparitions of the coquette, the young beauty, and the mature woman delicately bred—that the inversion of all experience and likelihood which the scene of shadows presented, was heightened to its utmost. Surely, ghosts all. Surely, the long unreal ride some progress of disease that had brought him to these gloomy shades!
vi: He stood stunned and silent. The warden stood next to him and the other wardens around, who in their normal daily work might not have looked so bad, but compared to the grieving mothers, the young girls in their prime in this prison, these ghostly figures with their graceful appearances, youthful beauty, and mature elegance of noblewomen - they looked strangely coarse, contrasting to the point that this dark scene became extremely eerie. Yes, all ghosts. Yes, a long, illusory journey, the miserable miles, had brought him to meet these sorrowful ghosts! −
tr: Charles Darnay was frozen in place at the sight. The guard was beside him, others were wandering around, and although they appeared normal with their usual busyness, they stood so crudely next to the sorrowful mothers and young girls in the prime of their lives – all those fancy women, beautiful young women, and well-mannered mature women ghosts – that the contrast created by every kind of experience and possibility represented by these silhouettes was at its extremes. They must all have been ghosts. At the end of this long, surreal, and afflicted road, these gloomy figures had appeared before him!
es: Darnay remained motionless, rigid, due to his astonishment. The appearance of the warden, who stood beside him, no less than that of the jailers who moved from one place to another, undoubtedly in full exercise of their high functions, was so rough, so brutal, so ferocious, especially when compared to that of the distressed mothers and the beautiful daughters stored there, with the coquetry and distinction typical of well-born young women and the refined manners of the high-ranking lady, that Darnay had to reinforce his belief that he had been confined in the mansion of specters.

en: “In the name of the assembled companions in misfortune,” said a gentleman of courtly appearance and address, coming forward, “I have the honour of giving you welcome to La Force, and of condoling with you on the calamity that has brought you among us. May it soon terminate happily! It would be an impertinence elsewhere, but it is not so here, to ask your name and condition?”
vi: In the name of the friends met in misfortune, - a person of noble appearance and gentle speech approached, - I am honored to welcome you to La Force, and to sympathize with the misfortune that has brought you to us. May it soon have a happy ending! Elsewhere it might be impolite to ask, but here it is not, may I know your name and status?
tr: A distinguished-looking gentleman approached and said, "On behalf of this unfortunate community, I am honored to welcome you to La Force and to share in whatever misfortune has brought you among us. We hope that your sufferings will come to an end as soon as possible. In any other place, it would certainly be inappropriate to ask, but given the circumstances here, may we know your name and situation?"
es: "—In my own name and on behalf of all the unfortunate companions gathered here," said a gentleman with courtly manners, stepping forward, "I have the honor of welcoming you to La Force, and to lament with you the calamity that brings you here." "May it be of brief duration and end with happiness!" "Now then, expressing our wishes would be an unforgivable impertinence anywhere else, but not here." "We take the liberty of asking your name and status."

en: Charles Darnay roused himself, and gave the required information, in words as suitable as he could find.
vi: Charles Darnay awoke and answered with the words he found most appropriate.
tr: Charles Darnay composed himself and introduced himself with the most appropriate words he could find.
es: Darnay hastened to comply with the wishes expressed by the gentleman.

en: “But I hope,” said the gentleman, following the chief gaoler with his eyes, who moved across the room, “that you are not in secret?”
vi: − But I hope, - the nobleman said while glancing at the chief warden walking across the room, - you are not in solitary confinement?
tr: "But I hope," said the polite gentleman, watching the chief warden roaming the room with his eyes, "you are not one of the secret ones.""
es: —I suppose you are not here "in secret"—replied the gentleman, following with his gaze the warden who was crossing the room at that moment.

en: “I do not understand the meaning of the term, but I have heard them say so.”
vi: − I don't fully understand the meaning of that word but I heard them say so. −
tr: "I don't know what this statement means, but I heard them say it like this.""
es: —Two or three times I have heard that password mentioned in reference to me, but I do not know what it could mean.

en: “Ah, what a pity! We so much regret it! But take courage; several members of our society have been in secret, at first, and it has lasted but a short time.” Then he added, raising his voice, “I grieve to inform the society—in secret.”
vi: Ah, how pitiful! We are very sorry! But be brave; many people in our circle have been in solitary confinement, at first, but only for a short period. − Then he raised his voice and spoke to everyone. − It is with great sorrow that I must inform you all... solitary confinement. −
tr: "Ah, what a pity!" "We are very sorry about this!" "But don't lose your courage; many people here were secretive when they first arrived, but this situation didn't last long." Then, raising his voice, he added, "I'm sorry to say this, but – it was secretive.""
es: —Oh, what a pity! We truly regret it... But do not be discouraged. Many have come here "in secret" and then their situation has changed. Then he added, raising his voice: —With deep regret, I inform my colleagues that... in secret.

en: There was a murmur of commiseration as Charles Darnay crossed the room to a grated door where the gaoler awaited him, and many voices—among which, the soft and compassionate voices of women were conspicuous—gave him good wishes and encouragement. He turned at the grated door, to render the thanks of his heart; it closed under the gaoler’s hand; and the apparitions vanished from his sight forever.
vi: The murmuring voices of concern rose as Charles Darnay walked through the room to the barred door where the jailer was waiting for him, many blessings and encouragements were directed at him - among which the most distinct was the sympathetic, gentle voice of a woman. At the barred door, he turned to express his gratitude; the door closed under the jailer's hand; and those shadows disappeared forever.
tr: As Charles Darnay crossed the room and advanced towards the barred door where the guard awaited him, murmurs of compassion rose from the crowd, many of which – the most distinct being from women with soft and affectionate voices – encouraged him with well-wishes. When Darnay reached the barred door, he turned to offer them his thanks; the guard closed the iron door, and the phantoms vanished from his sight forever.
es: As Charles Darnay approached the door defended with a thick grate, next to which the jailer awaited him, strong murmurs of commiseration arose, mixed with phrases of pity from the women, who strove to encourage him. Having reached the mentioned door, Charles turned and thanked those he was leaving from the bottom of his heart. The door was closed by the hand of the jailer, and the spectral apparitions faded away forever.

en: The wicket opened on a stone staircase, leading upward. When they had ascended forty steps (the prisoner of half an hour already counted them), the gaoler opened a low black door, and they passed into a solitary cell. It struck cold and damp, but was not dark.
vi: That doorway led to a stone staircase, ascending upwards. When they had climbed about forty steps (the prisoner, having been confined for half an hour, had counted the steps), the jailer opened a low, black door, and they entered the confinement cell. Cold, damp, but not dark. −
tr: The door opened to a stone staircase leading upwards. After climbing forty steps together (the half-hour prisoner had counted each step), the guard opened a low black door and they entered an empty cell. It was cold and damp but not dark.
es: The door gave access to a spiral staircase, which Darnay ascended following his guide. After climbing forty steps, carefully counted by the prisoner of half an hour, the jailer opened a low and very black door and entered a solitary cell. It was very cold, smelled of mold, but it was not dark.

en: “Yours,” said the gaoler.
vi: It's yours, - the jailer said.
tr: "This is yours," said the guard.
es: —Yours—said the warden.

en: “Why am I confined alone?”
vi: − Why am I being kept in solitary confinement? −
tr: "Why are they keeping me alone?"
es: —Why are they locking me up alone?

en: “How do I know!”
vi: How should I know?
tr: "How should I know?""
es: —That is what I don't know.

en: “I can buy pen, ink, and paper?”
tr: "Can I get a pen, ink, and paper?"
es: —I suppose I will be allowed to buy paper, pen, and ink?

en: “Such are not my orders. You will be visited, and can ask then. At present, you may buy your food, and nothing more.”
vi: Can I buy pens, paper, and ink? − I don't know if you can. Someone will come to see you, and you can ask them then. For now, you can only buy food, and nothing else.
tr: "I was not given such an order. You can ask when they come to see you. For now, you can only get food."
es: —For the moment, no. They will visit you... I don't know when, and then you can request that favor. You can buy food, but nothing else.

en: There were in the cell, a chair, a table, and a straw mattress. As the gaoler made a general inspection of these objects, and of the four walls, before going out, a wandering fancy wandered through the mind of the prisoner leaning against the wall opposite to him, that this gaoler was so unwholesomely bloated, both in face and person, as to look like a man who had been drowned and filled with water. When the gaoler was gone, he thought in the same wandering way, “Now am I left, as if I were dead.” Stopping then, to look down at the mattress, he turned from it with a sick feeling, and thought, “And here in these crawling creatures is the first condition of the body after death.”
vi: In the cell, there was a chair, a table, and a straw mattress. While the guard was checking these items and the four walls before leaving, a vague delusion passed through the mind of the prisoner standing against the opposite wall: this guard was swelling up in a sickly manner, both his face and body, like a drowned man bloated with water. After the guard left, he also thought vaguely, "Now it's just me, as if I were already dead." Cutting through his thoughts, he looked down at the mattress and turned away in disgust, "Looking at the bugs crawling here is the first stage of a corpse's decay."
tr: There was a table, a chair, and a straw-filled mattress in the cell. Before the guard left, while inspecting these items and the walls of the cell, a flood of thoughts passed through Darnay's distracted mind as he leaned against the wall directly opposite the guard; the guard's face and body were so unhealthily swollen that he looked like a drowned man filled with water. When the guard left, in the same distraction, he thought, "I have been abandoned as if I were dead." Then he stopped and looked at the mattress, turned his head away in disgust, and thought, "and the first thing my body encountered after death were the creatures crawling over there."
es: In the cell, there was a chair, a table, and a straw mattress. The warden, after subjecting the cell's furniture to a meticulous inspection, left, leaving Darnay alone. —I can say that I am dead and buried—murmured the unfortunate one. —

en: “Five paces by four and a half, five paces by four and a half, five paces by four and a half.” The prisoner walked to and fro in his cell, counting its measurement, and the roar of the city arose like muffled drums with a wild swell of voices added to them. “He made shoes, he made shoes, he made shoes.” The prisoner counted the measurement again, and paced faster, to draw his mind with him from that latter repetition. “The ghosts that vanished when the wicket closed. There was one among them, the appearance of a lady dressed in black, who was leaning in the embrasure of a window, and she had a light shining upon her golden hair, and she looked like  * Let us ride on again, for God’s sake, through the illuminated villages with the people all awake!  * He made shoes, he made shoes, he made shoes.  * Five paces by four and a half.” With such scraps tossing and rolling upward from the depths of his mind, the prisoner walked faster and faster, obstinately counting and counting; and the roar of the city changed to this extent—that it still rolled in like muffled drums, but with the wail of voices that he knew, in the swell that rose above them.
vi: "One side five steps, one side four and a half, one side five steps, one side four and a half, one side five steps, one side four and a half." The prisoner walked back and forth in the cell, counting the length, and the roar of the city below echoed up like a muffled drum accompanied by a chaotic wave of human voices. "He makes shoes, he makes shoes, he makes shoes." The prisoner counted the length again, quickening his pace, to drive that thought from his mind. "The ghosts disappear when that door closes." Among them was a lady in black leaning against the window, and she had bright blonde hair, and she looked like... Let's rush on, dear God, through the lit houses and the sleepless people!... He makes shoes, he makes shoes, he makes shoes... One side five steps, one side four and a half." With these fragmented thoughts raging inside, the prisoner walked faster, faster, stubbornly counting his steps; and the roar of the city changed its tone... it still drummed like a muffled beat but the rising chaotic wave of human voices became the lamentations of his dear brothers.
tr: "Five and a half steps, five and a half steps, five and a half steps." The prisoner was pacing up and down in the cell, measuring the room, and the city's hum, mixed with the maddening sounds, was increasing like the muffled sounds of drums. "Those shoes would do, those shoes would do, those shoes would do." The prisoner measured the room again and, as if trying to keep his mind away from these words, took his steps faster this time. "The ghosts that disappear when the door closes. Among them was one, a woman in a black dress leaning against the window sill with golden hair illuminated by the light, as if a... For God's sake, let's keep going, let's pass through the bright villages where everyone is awake!.. Those shoes would do, shoes would do, shoes would do... Five and a half steps." With these thoughts coming from the deepest parts of his mind and struggling, the prisoner kept counting his steps faster and faster; the city's hum also kept increasing in the same way –the well-known screams accompanying the muffled drum sounds were relentless.
es: Five steps by four and a half... five steps by four and a half—he repeated mechanically, pacing the cell in all directions and counting at the same time. The noise of the city reached his ears transformed into a kind of muffled drumbeat mixed with shrill human voices. —Five steps by four and a half... Made shoes... five steps by four and a half... made shoes... shoes... The prisoner quickened his pace and tried to count, in order to drive away the thought of the one making shoes, which threatened to become a fixed idea. —The specters vanished as soon as I crossed the gate's door—he kept thinking. —I saw among them a lady dressed in black, who was leaning on the windowsill. The light shone fully on her golden hair, and she seemed to... My God... My God!... Will I ever walk again through the villages visited by the sunlight, through the villages where people awaken? Making shoes... making shoes... making shoes... Five steps by four and a half... five steps by four and a half... The prisoner walked with increasing speed, always absorbed in the same thoughts, always counting, always having before his mind's eye the vision of the shoemaker, while the din of the city continued to sound in his ears like a muffled drumroll mixed with cries from voices he knew and loved, with heart-wrenching wails emitted by throats that until then had barely given voice to sounds other than those reflecting the joy of the heart.

en: CHAPTER II.
vi: With these fragmented thoughts raging inside, the prisoner walked faster, faster, stubbornly counting his steps; and the roar of the city changed its tone... it still drummed like a muffled beat but the rising chaotic wave of human voices became the lamentations of his dear brothers.
tr: II
es: II.

en: The Grindstone
vi: With these fragmented thoughts raging inside, the prisoner walked faster, faster, stubbornly counting his steps; and the roar of the city changed its tone... it still drummed like a muffled beat but the rising chaotic wave of human voices became the lamentations of his dear brothers.
tr: Whetstone
es: THE WHETSTONE

en: Tellson’s Bank, established in the Saint Germain Quarter of Paris, was in a wing of a large house, approached by a courtyard and shut off from the street by a high wall and a strong gate. The house belonged to a great nobleman who had lived in it until he made a flight from the troubles, in his own cook’s dress, and got across the borders. A mere beast of the chase flying from hunters, he was still in his metempsychosis no other than the same Monseigneur, the preparation of whose chocolate for whose lips had once occupied three strong men besides the cook in question.
vi: 2. The grinding wheel The Tellson Bank in Paris was located in the Saint Germain area in the wing of a large mansion, deep at the end of a courtyard, separated from the street by a high wall and a sturdy gate. This house belonged to a great nobleman before he fled from danger, disguised in the clothes of his cook, and crossed the border. Just a beast pursued by hunters, but in a previous life, he was the Lord who, every morning, had to have three servants along with the aforementioned cook lift the chocolate cup to his lips.
tr: Tellson Bank in the Saint Germain area of Paris was located in a wing of a large building separated from the street by a high wall and a sturdy gate, with a courtyard in front of it. The building belonged to a significant nobleman who, when troubles arose, donned his cook's attire, greased his heels, and successfully crossed the border. This cunning individual, who managed to escape from the hunters and whose soul migration had yet to occur, was none other than the Monsignor who once needed three strong men in addition to his cook to bring his cocoa to his lips.
es: The Tellson Bank, established in the Saint Germain district of Paris, occupied a wing of an immense building, preceded by a garden separated from the street by a fairly high wall and a very solid gate. The building was the property of one of the most powerful nobles in the kingdom, who had lived in it until the disturbances of the time forced him to flee, disguised in his cook's attire, and cross the border. Although in reality he was reduced to the condition of a game piece that managed to evade the attacks of the beaters and hunters, he was still the same lord, whose important operation of preparing chocolate and bringing it to his glorious lips required the efforts of three servants, apart from those of the cook.

en: Monseigneur gone, and the three strong men absolving themselves from the sin of having drawn his high wages, by being more than ready and willing to cut his throat on the altar of the dawning Republic one and indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, Monseigneur’s house had been first sequestrated, and then confiscated. For, all things moved so fast, and decree followed decree with that fierce precipitation, that now upon the third night of the autumn month of September, patriot emissaries of the law were in possession of Monseigneur’s house, and had marked it with the tri-colour, and were drinking brandy in its state apartments.
vi: The lord had departed, and the three servants had absolved themselves of the crime of receiving high wages from the noble by eagerly deciding to slit their former master's throat to offer a sacrifice on the altar of the nascent Unified Republic of Indivisible Freedom, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, when the mansion of this high official was confiscated and nationalized. The situation developed too rapidly, one decree following another in a frantic and urgent manner, so on the third night of September in the autumn, the patriotic delegation of the new government took over the lord's mansion, marked it with the tricolor flag, and drank brandy in the luxurious rooms inside.
tr: The Monsignor had fled, and the three powerful men who sinned while drawing high salaries from him had exonerated themselves at the altar of the newborn "Republic One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death," eager and impatient to slit his throat, had seized the Monsignor's house and confiscated all his property. Events were progressing so rapidly, and laws were being passed in such a frenzied rush one after another, that by the third night of September, the patriotic representatives of the laws had taken over the Monsignor's house, painted everything in three colors, and were drinking brandy in his rooms.
es: The master had left; his servants absolved themselves of the horrendous sin of having received his wages by showing themselves perfectly willing to slit his throat on the brand-new altar of the One and Indivisible Republic, of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death, and the master's sumptuous property was first seized and then confiscated. Things were done with such dizzying speed, and the decrees followed one another with such fierce haste, that by the third night of September, patriotic emissaries of the law had taken possession of the house in question, purified it by raising the tricolor flag over it, and were smoking and getting nicely drunk in its luxurious rooms.

en: A place of business in London like Tellson’s place of business in Paris, would soon have driven the House out of its mind and into the Gazette. For, what would staid British responsibility and respectability have said to orange-trees in boxes in a Bank courtyard, and even to a Cupid over the counter? Yet such things were. Tellson’s had whitewashed the Cupid, but he was still to be seen on the ceiling, in the coolest linen, aiming (as he very often does) at money from morning to night. Bankruptcy must inevitably have come of this young Pagan, in Lombard-street, London, and also of a curtained alcove in the rear of the immortal boy, and also of a looking-glass let into the wall, and also of clerks not at all old, who danced in public on the slightest provocation. Yet, a French Tellson’s could get on with these things exceedingly well, and, as long as the times held together, no man had taken fright at them, and drawn out his money.
