vi: A place of business in London like Tellson's in Paris would quickly drive the Owner mad and declare bankruptcy in the Gazette. How would these calm, responsible, and respectable Englishmen converse with the potted orange trees in front of the bank, and with the statue of Cupid on the counter? But Tellson's in Paris was like that. The staff here had painted the statue of Cupid white, but one could still see it hanging from the ceiling, dressed in a flimsy cloth, aiming its bow at money from morning till night (often the target of love). In Lombard Street, London, if one saw this little deity, saw the alcove draped behind it, saw the mirror mounted on the wall, and saw all the young employees easily losing their temper with customers, it would only lead to bankruptcy. Yet at Tellson's in France, none of these things mattered, the bank thrived nonetheless, as long as the situation remained under control and no one panicked and withdrew all their money.
tr: If Tellson's London branch had been no different from its Paris branch, it would soon have driven the manager insane and caused the bank's bankruptcy. Who knows what the dignified and respectable Englishmen, symbols of sobriety and respectability, would say when they saw the orange trees planted in wooden boxes in the bank's courtyard and Cupid behind the counter? But such things were happening. Although Tellson had plastered over Cupid, he could still be seen on the ceiling in his light attire, aiming at money from morning till night, as he often did. This young pagan must have inevitably brought bankruptcy to London, to Lombard Street, and of course, the partitioned area behind this immortal child, the mirror set into the wall, and the not-so-old clerks who would come out and dance among the people at the slightest provocation. Tellson in France could handle such things quite well, and as long as things were going smoothly, no one had been frightened enough to withdraw their money.
es: If the Tellson House in London had resembled the Tellson House in Paris, the Londoners would surely have soon seen it listed among the bankrupt entities deserving to appear in the Gazette. What would the staunch English respectability have said if, in the lobby of a Bank, they had found abundant pots planted with orange trees and... horror! the figure of a Cupid presiding over the cash register? And yet, as inconceivable as it may seem, such was the case at the Tellson Bank in Paris. True, Tellson had whitewashed the Cupid on the wall with several coats of lime, but the one on the ceiling remained, scantily clad, gazing anxiously at the cash register (as it usually does) from dawn until nightfall. The most tremendous bankruptcy would have been the fatal and inevitable consequence of the presence of that pleasant pagan on Lombard Street in London, if it had not already been enough to cause it, a half-hidden alcove among rich curtains, in front of which stood the mischievous child, the immense mirror left on the wall, and the employees themselves, not as old as one would desire, who had no qualms about dancing in public with little encouragement. It is true that a French Tellson could afford all that and even more, without scandalizing anyone, without any capitalist even dreaming of withdrawing their capitals for such insignificant reasons.

en: What money would be drawn out of Tellson’s henceforth, and what would lie there, lost and forgotten; what plate and jewels would tarnish in Tellson’s hiding-places, while the depositors rusted in prisons, and when they should have violently perished; how many accounts with Tellson’s never to be balanced in this world, must be carried over into the next; no man could have said, that night, any more than Mr. Jarvis Lorry could, though he thought heavily of these questions. He sat by a newly-lighted wood fire (the blighted and unfruitful year was prematurely cold), and on his honest and courageous face there was a deeper shade than the pendent lamp could throw, or any object in the room distortedly reflect—a shade of horror.
vi: From now on, how much money will be withdrawn from Tellson, how much will remain there, lost and forgotten; how many treasures of gold and silver will tarnish in Tellson's vaults while their owners, having deposited them, rot in prison or will one day die a gruesome death; how many Tellson accounts will never be settled in this world and must be transferred to the next? No one could answer, that night, not even Mr. Jarvis Lorry, although he himself was pondering those questions. He sat by the newly lit fireplace (this withering year turned cold early), on his brave and honest face a shadow of darkness that neither the hanging lamp nor any distorted reflection in this room could dispel—the darkness of horror.
tr: From now on, what money would be withdrawn from Tellson's and what money would lie there, lost and forgotten; while their owners rotted in prisons and were violently punished and destroyed, what gold and jewels would tarnish in Tellson's vaults; how many accounts at Tellson's would remain open in this world and be left to be settled in the next; that night, there was no one who could answer these questions, immersed in deep thoughts, other than Mr. Jarvis Lorry. The honest and brave face of Mr. Lorry, sitting by the newly lit fireplace (amidst all the chaos and scarcity, winter had also come early), was covered by a shadow deeper than anything the hanging lamp or anything else in the room could reflect – the shadow of terror.
es: How much money would henceforth come out of the coffers of the Tellson House in Paris, how much would remain there lost and forgotten, how much silver, how many jewels would lose their immaculate shine in the establishment's secret chambers, while their owners lost it in the dungeons or on the scaffold, how many current accounts of the Bank would remain unsettled in this world and pass to the next, is what no mortal could have said, what not even approximately managed to conjecture that night the very same Maurice Lorry, despite having repeated these questions hundreds of times. Sitting by the fireplace where some logs were crackling and burning (that barren and unproductive year had brought forward the cold season), his face, a reflection of honesty, showed shadows that were not cast by the hanging lamp from the ceiling nor by any of the objects in the room.

en: He occupied rooms in the Bank, in his fidelity to the House of which he had grown to be a part, like strong root-ivy. It chanced that they derived a kind of security from the patriotic occupation of the main building, but the true-hearted old gentleman never calculated about that. All such circumstances were indifferent to him, so that he did his duty. On the opposite side of the courtyard, under a colonnade, was extensive standing—for carriages—where, indeed, some carriages of Monseigneur yet stood. Against two of the pillars were fastened two great flaring flambeaux, and in the light of these, standing out in the open air, was a large grindstone: a roughly mounted thing which appeared to have hurriedly been brought there from some neighbouring smithy, or other workshop. Rising and looking out of window at these harmless objects, Mr. Lorry shivered, and retired to his seat by the fire. He had opened, not only the glass window, but the lattice blind outside it, and he had closed both again, and he shivered through his frame.
vi: Dedicated to the headquarters that had become an intimate part of his life, he stayed permanently at this bank. It was also by chance that the Tellson Bank in Paris was safely protected by a group of patriots who had occupied the main building, but this honest old man never calculated that. He was indifferent to all circumstances, only knowing to perform his duty. At the other end of the yard, under the columns, there was a long area reserved for carriages, and in fact, a few carriages from the old Lord were still there. Two large torches were tightly tied to two columns, and under the torchlight, one could see a large grindstone wheel exposed to the sky, hastily brought here as if from a nearby blacksmith or workshop. Standing up to look at those harmless objects outside the window, Mr. Lorry involuntarily shuddered and turned back to sit by the fireplace. He had opened not only the glass window but also the outer shutters, then he had to go back and close both layers of doors and shivered all over.
tr: Mr. Lorry, like a well-rooted ivy, was staying in one of the rooms at the bank due to his long-standing loyalty to the company he had served for years. In this way, they were providing a kind of security against the patriotic occupation of the main building; but the kind-hearted old gentleman never gave it a thought. He minded his own business and never concerned himself with such matters. At the bottom of the courtyard, under the columns, there was a wide area for carriages – even the carriages of Monseigneur were parked there. On two of the columns, there were lanterns with flickering flames, and outside, in their light, a large grindstone was noticeable: it seemed to have been hastily brought from a nearby blacksmith or another workshop and roughly placed there. Standing up and looking out the window at these harmless things, Mr. Lorry shivered and returned to his chair by the fireplace. He had opened not only the window but also the latticed shutter outside; he closed both again and shivered as he sat down once more.
es: Lorry occupied rooms in the Bank building, to which his proven loyalty to the house, of which he was an integral part, gave him indisputable right. Many believed that the patriotic occupation of almost the entire building was a guarantee of security for the establishment, although the loyal Lorry never shared such a belief. Whatever happened in Paris was indifferent to him, for the only thing that aroused his interest was the fulfillment of his duty. At the back of the garden, under a roof supported by graceful columns, there was a coach house, in which some of the master's carriages remained. Attached to two columns were two lit torches, and at the base, placed in such a way as to receive their light, was a sharpening stone, mounted haphazardly, which had undoubtedly been brought from some nearby blacksmith or carpenter's shop. Lorry, who got up from his seat and looked out the window, withdrew with a shudder upon seeing that harmless object.

en: From the streets beyond the high wall and the strong gate, there came the usual night hum of the city, with now and then an indescribable ring in it, weird and unearthly, as if some unwonted sounds of a terrible nature were going up to Heaven.
vi: From beyond the high wall and sturdy gate came the usual murmur of the capital city's night, occasionally accompanied by an indescribable, strange, and extraordinary sound, like eerie noises from the terrifying depths soaring into the sky.
tr: The usual nighttime hum of the city was coming from the streets behind the high wall and the large gate, occasionally accompanied by an indescribable ringing; it was strange and hair-raising, as if the unusual sounds of a dreadful nature were rising to the sky.
es: Even in the room where Lorry worked, the muffled murmur of the streets could be heard, occasionally joined by noises that seemed to come from a fantastical world, unheard-of noises so terrible that they rose from the earth to the sky.

en: “Thank God,” said Mr. Lorry, clasping his hands, “that no one near and dear to me is in this dreadful town to-night. May He have mercy on all who are in danger!”
vi: − Thank God, - Mr. Lorry said, clasping his hands, - it's fortunate that none of my loved ones are in this dreadful city tonight. May He have mercy on those in peril!
tr: "Thank God," said Mr. Lorry, clasping his hands, "no one close to me, no one I love, is in this terrible city tonight. May God protect everyone who is in danger!"
es: —Thank God—said Lorry, clasping his hands,—I have no loved ones by my side on this dreadful night. May the Almighty look with compassionate eyes upon all those who are in danger!

en: Soon afterwards, the bell at the great gate sounded, and he thought, “They have come back!” and sat listening. But, there was no loud irruption into the courtyard, as he had expected, and he heard the gate clash again, and all was quiet.
vi: Immediately after, there was a bell at the main gate and he thought to himself, "They have returned!" and sat still, listening intently. But there was no noisy crowd disturbing the courtyard as he had imagined; instead, he heard the gate slam shut, and then all was silent.
tr: Soon after, the big doorbell rang and Mr. Lorry, thinking "They have come!" perked up his ears from where he was sitting. However, there was no grand invasion in the courtyard as he had imagined; then he heard the thud of the door again and the place fell into silence.
es: He had barely spoken these words when the gate bell rang. —No doubt they are coming back—thought Lorry. He remained seated and listening; but as he did not hear the sound of footsteps in the vestibule, as he expected, nor the gate being closed again, vague fears regarding the Bank assailed good Lorry.

en: The nervousness and dread that were upon him inspired that vague uneasiness respecting the Bank, which a great change would naturally awaken, with such feelings roused. It was well guarded, and he got up to go among the trusty people who were watching it, when his door suddenly opened, and two figures rushed in, at sight of which he fell back in amazement.
vi: That restless fear only made his heart more tense and uneasy about the safety of the bank; with any important establishment, such worries naturally arise. The bank was well-protected. He stood up, intending to meet the trusted individuals guarding the place when the door suddenly burst open, two figures rushed in, and he was stunned when he saw them.
tr: Mr. Lorry's inner unease and fear had revealed his vague anxiety about the bank, but it was natural for such a great change to evoke this feeling when his emotions were so heightened. The bank was well protected, and just as Mr. Lorry stood up to go to the reliable men guarding it, the door suddenly opened, and he stepped back in great astonishment upon seeing two people burst in.
es: He calmed himself, however, convinced that it was well guarded by men of absolute trust. He was about to resume his tasks when the door of his room suddenly opened and two people appeared on the threshold, at whose sight Lorry recoiled, seized by the most violent astonishment he had ever experienced in his life.

en: Lucie and her father! Lucie with her arms stretched out to him, and with that old look of earnestness so concentrated and intensified, that it seemed as though it had been stamped upon her face expressly to give force and power to it in this one passage of her life.
vi: Lucie and her father! Lucie stretched out her arms towards him, and on her forehead was a look of concentration and worry, as if that expression had channeled all her strength into this moment in life.
tr: It was Lucie and her father who had arrived! Lucie was coming towards him with her arms open, bearing that old intense and severe seriousness on her face as if it were sealed there to give him strength and power in this period of his life.
es: Lucía and her father; Lucía, who extended her hands to him with a pleading gesture and looked at him with an expression of someone who has their entire life concentrated in their eyes.

en: “What is this?” cried Mr. Lorry, breathless and confused. “What is the matter? Lucie! Manette! What has happened? What has brought you here? What is it?”
vi: − What is this? - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, bewildered and breathless. What's going on? Lucie! Manette! What happened? Why did you both have to come here? What's the matter?
tr: "What happened?" shouted Mr. Lorry, breathless and confused. "What's going on? Lucie! Manette! Has something happened? What brought you here? What happened?"
es: Lucía and her father; Lucía, who extended her hands to him with a pleading gesture and looked at him with an expression of someone who has their entire life concentrated in their eyes. —Lucie... Manette!... What is this?—exclaimed Lorry, with indescribable astonishment—What is happening? What is going on? What brings you here?

en: With the look fixed upon him, in her paleness and wildness, she panted out in his arms, imploringly, “O my dear friend! My husband!”
vi: Her eyes still fixed on him, her face pale and frightened, Lucie rushed into his arms, her voice choked with urgency. − Oh sir!
tr: With her pale face and all her anxiety, Lucie, who was embraced by Mr. Lorry, fixed her gaze on Mr. Lorry and, in a breathless, pleading voice, said, "Oh my dear life companion! My husband!" she moaned.
es: Lucía, pale as a corpse, fell sobbing into the arms of the elderly friend from her childhood. —Oh... dear friend! My husband...

en: “Your husband, Lucie?”
vi: My husband! − Your husband, Lucie? − Charles.
tr: "Your husband, Lucie?"
es: —Your husband, Lucía?

en: “Charles.”
vi: − How is Charles?
tr: "Charles."
es: —Carlos.

en: “What of Charles?”
vi: − How is Charles?
tr: "What happened to Charles?"
es: —What about Carlos?

en: “Here.
vi: − Here. − Here, in Paris? −
tr: "He's here!"
es: —Here... in Paris.

en: “Here, in Paris?”
vi: − Here. − Here, in Paris? −
tr: "In Paris?""
es: —In Paris?

en: “Has been here some days—three or four—I don’t know how many—I can’t collect my thoughts. An errand of generosity brought him here unknown to us; he was stopped at the barrier, and sent to prison.”
vi: He has been here for a few days... three or four days... I don't remember exactly... I can't think clearly. Some noble cause brought my husband here without letting anyone at home know; he was stopped at the city gate and imprisoned.
tr: "He has been here for a while –three or four days –I don't know exactly how many days– I can't gather my thoughts. For some unknown reason, he seems to have come to help someone; then he was stopped at the city entrance and thrown into prison."
es: —He has been here for a few days... three or four... I don't know how many... It is impossible for me to put my thoughts in order... A generous idea, unknown to us, brought him here; he was detained at the barrier and taken to jail.

en: The old man uttered an irrepressible cry. Almost at the same moment, the bell of the great gate rang again, and a loud noise of feet and voices came pouring into the courtyard.
vi: The old man couldn't suppress a cry. Almost simultaneously, the bell outside the gate rang again, and the sound of footsteps and loud voices filled the yard.
tr: The old man couldn't hold himself back and let out a scream. Almost at the same time, the big doorbell rang again and a crowd of people rushed into the courtyard with shouts and commotion.
es: The old man let out a cry of fright. Almost at the same time, the gate bell rang and voices mixed with the sound of footsteps were heard in the garden.

en: “What is that noise?” said the Doctor, turning towards the window.
vi: −What is that noise? - Dr. Manette asked as he turned to the window.
tr: "What is that noise?" said the Doctor, turning to the window.
es: —What noise is that?—asked the doctor, turning to the window.

en: “Don’t look!” cried Mr. Lorry. “Don’t look out! Manette, for your life, don’t touch the blind!”
vi: − Don't look! - Mr. Lorry shouted. - Don't look out! Manette, for your life, don't open the door!
tr: "Don't look!" shouted Mr. Lorry. "Don't look outside! Manette, for the love of your life, don't touch the shutter!"
es: —Don't look out! Don't look outside!... For heaven's sake, Manette, for your life... don't touch the blind!

en: The Doctor turned, with his hand upon the fastening of the window, and said, with a cool, bold smile:
vi: The doctor turned back, his hand on the window latch, and said with a calm, brave smile: −My dear friend, I once lived an interesting time in this capital.
tr: The doctor, with his hand on the window handle, turned and said with a bold smile:
es: The doctor turned, without removing his hand from the window latch, and with a cold and daring smile, he replied.

en: “My dear friend, I have a charmed life in this city. I have been a Bastille prisoner. There is no patriot in Paris—in Paris? In France—who, knowing me to have been a prisoner in the Bastille, would touch me, except to overwhelm me with embraces, or carry me in triumph. My old pain has given me a power that has brought us through the barrier, and gained us news of Charles there, and brought us here. I knew it would be so; I knew I could help Charles out of all danger; I told Lucie so.—What is that noise?” His hand was again upon the window.
vi: The doctor turned back, his hand on the window latch, and said with a calm, brave smile: −My dear friend, I once lived an interesting time in this capital. I was once a prisoner of the Bastille. No patriot in Paris... in Paris? No, in all of France... would touch me once they knew I was a prisoner of the Bastille, unless they rushed to embrace me or lift me up in joy. My past suffering has now become a power that helps us overcome all barriers, and it has brought us news of Charles in France, and led us here. I knew the situation had to be like this; I knew I could help Charles escape danger; I told Lucie so... What is that noise? - His hand again placed on the window latch.
tr: "My dear friend, I have a good life in this city. I am a man who has served time in the Bastille Prison. In Paris – is it just Paris? There is no patriot in all of France who, knowing I was imprisoned in the Bastille, would not embrace me and hold me in high regard. My old pain gave me such strength that we were able to cross that barricade and get inside, and thanks to this, we learned about Charles's situation and were able to come here. I knew it would be like this; I knew I could save Charles from all dangers; I even told Lucie. –What is that noise?" His hand had gone to the window again.
es: —My dear friend, in this city, my life is sacred. I have been a prisoner of the Bastille. There is not a patriot in Paris... what am I saying in Paris? in all of France!... There is not a patriot in all of France who, knowing that I have been a prisoner of the Bastille, would dare to touch me, except to crush me with hugs or to carry me in triumph through the streets. My past tortures have given me enough influence to get here without encountering obstacles at the barriers and to obtain news about Charles. I knew it would be so, I knew it would be easy for me to free Charles from the dangers that threaten him, and I assured Lucia of this... But what is that noise?—he finished, turning towards the window.

en: “Don’t look!” cried Mr. Lorry, absolutely desperate. “No, Lucie, my dear, nor you!” He got his arm round her, and held her. “Don’t be so terrified, my love. I solemnly swear to you that I know of no harm having happened to Charles; that I had no suspicion even of his being in this fatal place. What prison is he in?”
vi: −Don't look out! - Mr. Lorry cried out, completely desperate. -Don't, Lucie, my dear, you too! - He wrapped his arms tightly around the girl. Don't be too alarmed, my dear. I swear to you that I had no knowledge of any danger coming to Charles; I didn't even know he was in this deadly place. Which prison is he in?
tr: "Don't look!" shouted Mr. Lorry, having completely lost hope. "No Lucie, you don't look either, my dear!" He pulled Lucie back, wrapping his arms around her. "Don't be afraid, my child! I swear that nothing has happened to Charles; I even doubt that he is in this dreadful place. Which prison have they taken him to?"
es: —Don't look!—shouted Lorry with a desperate tone—You neither, Lucia, my dear Lucia!—he added, wrapping his arm around her waist. —But don't be afraid... don't be scared. I swear I don't know that anything bad has happened to Charles... I didn't even suspect that fate had brought him to this city. Which prison is he in?

en: “La Force!”
vi: − La Force! − La Force!
tr: "The Force!"
es: —At the Force.

en: “La Force! Lucie, my child, if ever you were brave and serviceable in your life—and you were always both—you will compose yourself now, to do exactly as I bid you; for more depends upon it than you can think, or I can say. There is no help for you in any action on your part to-night; you cannot possibly stir out. I say this, because what I must bid you to do for Charles’s sake, is the hardest thing to do of all. You must instantly be obedient, still, and quiet. You must let me put you in a room at the back here. You must leave your father and me alone for two minutes, and as there are Life and Death in the world you must not delay.”
vi: − La Force! − La Force! Lucie, my dear, if you are brave and know how to help everyone... as you always have been... then now you must be calm, and do exactly what I say; because everything depends on it, more than you think or I can say. Tonight, whatever you do will be useless; you cannot go out into the street. I say this because, for Charles's sake, what I ask of you is the hardest thing to do. You must obey me, sit still and be calm. Let me take you to a room in the back to rest for a while. You must let your father and me discuss privately for a few minutes, this is a matter of life and death, you must not delay.
tr: "The Force? Lucie my dear, if you have been brave and skillful in your life – which you always have been – now you must pull yourself together and do exactly what I tell you; because everything depends on this and neither can I explain it nor can you guess it. There is nothing you can do for him tonight; you must absolutely not move from your place. I am saying this because what I want you to do for Charles is the hardest part. You must calm down as soon as possible, listen to us and stay quiet, let me place you in one of the back rooms. Leave your father and me alone for a few minutes, you know this is a matter of life and death, it cannot be delayed."
es: —La Force. If you have ever been brave, Lucía, my dear, if you have ever considered yourself strong enough to do something useful, today more than ever you must summon all your courage and all your effort to follow to the letter what I am going to tell you, because I assure you that much more depends on it than you can imagine, much more than I could tell you. What I am going to beg you to do for your Carlos is the hardest, the most difficult thing to conceive, because I am precisely going to ask you to calm down, to do nothing, to obey me, to allow me to take you to a secluded room in this house and to remain calm in it, leaving your father and me alone for a few minutes.

en: “I will be submissive to you. I see in your face that you know I can do nothing else than this. I know you are true.”
vi: −You will listen to him. Looking at him, you know you can't do anything else. You know he is right.
tr: "I will do whatever you say. It seems you understand that I can't do anything else for you. If you say so, then it is so."
es: For your dear Carlos, for the death that roams free in this unfortunate city today, I am sure you will obey me! —I submissively obey your wishes, because I see in your face that I can neither do nor should do anything else, and that your words are inspired by my best interest. Lorry kissed Lucía and immediately accompanied her to her room, where he left her, locking the door with a key as he exited.

en: The old man kissed her, and hurried her into his room, and turned the key; then, came hurrying back to the Doctor, and opened the window and partly opened the blind, and put his hand upon the Doctor’s arm, and looked out with him into the courtyard.
vi: The old man kissed the girl, hurriedly took her into his room and locked the door, then hastily returned to the doctor. While opening the window and slightly drawing the curtain, he held Mr. Manette's arm, and they both looked out into the yard.
tr: The old man hurriedly took Lucie to her room, kissed her, and locked the door behind her; then he hurried back to the Doctor, opened the window, drew the shutters, placed his hand on the Doctor's arm, and they looked out into the courtyard together.
es: He hurried back to join the doctor, opened the window that faced the garden, placed his right hand on his friend's shoulder, and leaned out, indicating that his friend should do the same.

en: Looked out upon a throng of men and women: not enough in number, or near enough, to fill the courtyard: not more than forty or fifty in all. The people in possession of the house had let them in at the gate, and they had rushed in to work at the grindstone; it had evidently been set up there for their purpose, as in a convenient and retired spot.
vi: Looking out at a crowd of men and women: not so crowded as to overflow the courtyard: about forty or fifty people at most. The people who took over this mansion opened the gate for them to enter, and they rushed to the grindstone to get it working; clearly, that object was placed here with a purpose, in a convenient and discreet location.
tr: Below, there was a commotion involving both men and women, but their numbers were not enough to fill the courtyard; there were at most forty or fifty people. The owners of the building had opened the door for them, and they had rushed straight to the whetstone to get to work; apparently, they had placed it in a suitable and quiet corner for their own purposes.
es: Before his eyes, there was a compact group of men and women, not many, that is, not enough, by far, to fill the garden, as there wouldn't be more than forty or fifty. The people who occupied the house had granted them entry so they could use the sharpening stone, installed there for public service, no doubt.

en: But, such awful workers, and such awful work!
vi: But the people were truly terrifying, and their actions were truly horrifying!
tr: But the workers and their jobs were so terrible!
es: It seems that a sharpening stone should have nothing special about it, much less that it should attract sharpeners; but it chills the blood to think of those horrible sharpeners, both because of their appearance and the nature of their work, or rather, the objective of the work they performed.

en: The grindstone had a double handle, and, turning at it madly were two men, whose faces, as their long hair flapped back when the whirlings of the grindstone brought their faces up, were more horrible and cruel than the visages of the wildest savages in their most barbarous disguise. False eyebrows and false moustaches were stuck upon them, and their hideous countenances were all bloody and sweaty, and all awry with howling, and all staring and glaring with beastly excitement and want of sleep. As these ruffians turned and turned, their matted locks now flung forward over their eyes, now flung backward over their necks, some women held wine to their mouths that they might drink; and what with dropping blood, and what with dropping wine, and what with the stream of sparks struck out of the stone, all their wicked atmosphere seemed gore and fire. The eye could not detect one creature in the group free from the smear of blood. Shouldering one another to get next at the sharpening-stone, were men stripped to the waist, with the stain all over their limbs and bodies; men in all sorts of rags, with the stain upon those rags; men devilishly set off with spoils of women’s lace and silk and ribbon, with the stain dyeing those trifles through and through. Hatchets, knives, bayonets, swords, all brought to be sharpened, were all red with it. Some of the hacked swords were tied to the wrists of those who carried them, with strips of linen and fragments of dress: ligatures various in kind, but all deep of the one colour. And as the frantic wielders of these weapons snatched them from the stream of sparks and tore away into the streets, the same red hue was red in their frenzied eyes;—eyes which any unbrutalised beholder would have given twenty years of life, to petrify with a well-directed gun.
vi: The grindstone had two hand cranks, being frantically turned by two men; the fierce spinning threw their long hair back, exposing two faces more brutal and terrifying than the most savage-looking barbarians. False eyebrows and mustaches were affixed to their grotesque faces, drenched in sweat and blood, their entire faces contorted from shouting, from eyes blazing with animalistic eagerness, and from lack of sleep. While these two scoundrels turned the wheel incessantly, their matted hair sometimes flung forward covering their eyes, sometimes flung back covering their necks, women raised cups of wine to their lips; the wine was as red as blood, the sparks flying from the grindstone added to the scene, making the entire vicious space seem filled with blood and fire. Look as closely as you might, you couldn't find a single person among them not stained with blood. Clustered around the grindstone were half-naked men, their limbs and bodies smeared with blood; men dressed in rags, those rags also bloodstained; fierce men wearing lace, silk, and ribbons stolen from women, those trinkets too dyed in blood. Axes, knives, bayonets, swords, all waiting to be sharpened, were all stained red. Many large swords were tightly bound to the wielders' wrists with strips of cloth torn from clothing; all sorts of bindings, all soaked in blood. And as the chaotic armed mob grabbed weapons from the shower of sparks and rushed into the street, their crazed eyes also burned with that same red hue - the eyes of wild beasts that anyone with a shred of humanity would be willing to sacrifice twenty years of their life to shoot dead on the spot.
tr: The grindstone had two handles, and the faces of the two men who were wildly turning them rose with each turn of the grindstone, causing their long hair to fly in the air, and in this state, they looked more terrifying and cruel than the faces of the most frenzied and savage barbarians. The faces to which the false eyebrows and mustaches were attached were drenched in sweat and blood, and under the influence of all that howling, they were all convulsed; their eyes sparkled with a mad excitement and sleeplessness. As the men kept turning with all their brutality, their matted hair fell in front of their eyes, and they constantly threw it back, while some of the women held wine to their mouths in case they wanted it; with the effect of the flowing wine, blood, and sparks from the stone, the ominous atmosphere that surrounded everything had coagulated and ignited. There was not a single person whose face was not smeared with blood. Half-naked men were trying to reach the grindstone by shouldering each other; their hands and arms were stained all over; their clothes, resembling rags, were stained all over; they were men loaded with lacy, silky, and ribboned spoils they had collected from women, which were finely stained with blood. They had brought a lot of small axes, knives, bayonets, and swords to make them sharper, and they were all covered in blood. Some of these sharp swords were tied to the wrists of those carrying them with linen strips and scraps of clothing. Although the things they tied varied, they were all shades of a single color. As the frenzied carriers of these weapons took them from the sparks and carried them to the streets, the same red had covered their mad eyes; the eyes looked so crazed that anyone who had not turned cruel would give twenty years of their life for the weapon aimed at them to freeze in place.
es: Two men, whose faces were more horrible and cruel in expression than the fiercest savages when they display their most barbaric garments and paints, were turning the stone. False eyebrows and false mustaches adorned repugnant faces, all splattered with blood, faces contorted with rage and frenzy. While those heartless men turned the stone over and over, some women brought vessels full of wine to their lips. The scene could not have been more nauseating or more ferocious. Blood, wine, and fire were the constitutive elements of the scene; blood that covered the faces and hands of all the monsters present, wine that dripped from their fetid mouths, and fire that sparked brightly from the sharpening stone. Pushing and shoving each other in their eagerness to sharpen their instruments of slaughter as quickly as possible, there were men naked from the waist up, their arms, necks, faces, and bodies stained with blood; men covered in rags, with the rags stained with blood; men adorned with women's clothing, with lace, ribbons, and silks, and the silks, ribbons, and lace stained with blood. Axes, knives, bayonets, sabers, swords, all the instruments they were sharpening were stained with blood. Some carried swords or axes tied to their wrists with strips of cloth or pieces of dresses; the bindings varied, but not the color, all were red.

en: All this was seen in a moment, as the vision of a drowning man, or of any human creature at any very great pass, could see a world if it were there. They drew back from the window, and the Doctor looked for explanation in his friend’s ashy face.
vi: That scene appeared only for a moment, like the ephemeral world in the final gaze of a drowning person or anyone in a perilous situation. The two men stepped back from the window, and the doctor searched for an answer on the pale, ashen face of his friend.
tr: Just as a drowning man or someone swiftly passing to the other world can see the world in that final moment, what happened in the courtyard occurred in just such a moment. They withdrew from the window, and the Doctor looked at his friend's ashen face, waiting for an explanation.
es: Lorry and the doctor recoiled as soon as their eyes met the repugnant scene.

en: “They are,” Mr. Lorry whispered the words, glancing fearfully round at the locked room, “murdering the prisoners. If you are sure of what you say; if you really have the power you think you have—as I believe you have—make yourself known to these devils, and get taken to La Force. It may be too late, I don’t know, but let it not be a minute later!”
vi: Mr. Lorry whispered while fearfully glancing at the tightly locked door: − They are going to kill the prisoners. If you are certain of what you are saying; if you truly have the power you believe you possess... though I believe you do... please introduce yourself to those devils, and ask them to take you to La Force prison. It might already be too late, I am not sure, but we cannot hesitate any longer!
tr: "They are," said Mr. Lorry in a whispering voice, looking at the locked room with eyes full of fear, "killing the prisoners. If you are sure of what you just said; if you truly possess the power you think you do – and I believe you do – introduce yourself to these devils and go to La Force. Maybe it is already too late, I don't know, but we must not waste any time!"
es: —They are murdering the prisoners—said Lorry, answering the unspoken question that the doctor had just directed at him. —If you are sure of what you say, if you really possess the influence you believe you have, and which I also believe you have, reveal yourself to those demons and have them take you to La Force. It may already be too late, who knows; but in any case, do not waste a single second.

en: Doctor Manette pressed his hand, hastened bareheaded out of the room, and was in the courtyard when Mr. Lorry regained the blind.
vi: Dr. Manette squeezed Mr. Lorry's hand, hurriedly left the room with his head uncovered, and headed into the courtyard while Mr. Lorry drew the curtain back to look outside.
tr: Dr. Manette, after shaking his friend's hand, quickly went outside without taking his hat, and by the time Mr. Lorry turned back to the window, he had already reached the courtyard.
es: Dr. Manette shook his friend's hand and, without saying a word, without even covering himself, went down to the garden.

en: His streaming white hair, his remarkable face, and the impetuous confidence of his manner, as he put the weapons aside like water, carried him in an instant to the heart of the concourse at the stone. For a few moments there was a pause, and a hurry, and a murmur, and the unintelligible sound of his voice; and then Mr. Lorry saw him, surrounded by all, and in the midst of a line of twenty men long, all linked shoulder to shoulder, and hand to shoulder, hurried out with cries of—“Live the Bastille prisoner! Help for the Bastille prisoner’s kindred in La Force! Room for the Bastille prisoner in front there! Save the prisoner Evrémonde at La Force!” and a thousand answering shouts.
vi: The long white hair, the bright face, the fiercely confident demeanor of Mr. Manette as he brushed aside the weapons of those people like a ship cutting through water, brought him straight into the heart of the crowd gathered around the grinding wheel. The crowd paused for a moment, then hurried, then murmured, then the indistinct voice of the doctor; then Mr. Lorry saw Mr. Manette, surrounded by the crowd, standing amidst a group of about twenty people, all shoulder to shoulder, hastily moving out while shouting “Long live the prisoner of the Bastille! Save the relatives of the prisoner of the Bastille who are imprisoned in La Force! Make way for the prisoner of the Bastille! Save the prisoner Evrémonde in La Force!” and a thousand voices echoed in response.
tr: His flowing white hair, striking face, and the hurried confidence in his demeanor carried him through the weapons as if parting water, bringing him instantly to the very center of the crowd. After a few minutes of silence, there was some movement, murmurs; then his incomprehensible voice was heard and at that moment Mr. Lorry saw the Doctor. He was surrounded; standing in the midst of twenty men, shoulder to shoulder, hands on each other's shoulders, shouting in agitation. "Long live the prisoners of the Bastille! Let's help the prisoner in La Force who is a relative of those in the Bastille! Make way for the Bastille prisoner in the front lines! Let's save Evremonde, the prisoner in La Force!" and thousands responded.
es: Her hair white as snow, her face, which could not help but draw attention, the decisiveness with which she pushed away the weapons of that mob of monsters, opened the way for her to the center of the gathering, to the very sharpening stone. Lorry observed that everyone fell silent, that in the midst of a solemn silence the old man's voice rose vibrantly, that everyone listened attentively, that everyone looked at the speaker with the deepest respect; and after a few minutes, he saw that more than twenty men formed a compact group, surrounding the doctor and, enthroning him on their shoulders, they went out into the street shouting with delirious enthusiasm: —Long live the prisoner of the Bastille! —We want the relative of the one from the Bastille imprisoned in La Force! —Make way for the prisoner of the Bastille! —Freedom for the prisoner Evrémonde, confined in La Force!

en: He closed the lattice again with a fluttering heart, closed the window and the curtain, hastened to Lucie, and told her that her father was assisted by the people, and gone in search of her husband. He found her child and Miss Pross with her; but, it never occurred to him to be surprised by their appearance until a long time afterwards, when he sat watching them in such quiet as the night knew.
vi: He closed the shutters, his heart pounding, then closed the outer window and drew the curtains, hurriedly going to Lucie to inform her that the townspeople had helped to search for Charles. Lucie was not alone but accompanied by her little girl and Miss Pross; however, it was only much later that Mr. Lorry, sitting and watching them in the familiar stillness of the night, realized this with surprise.
tr: Mr. Lorry, his heart fluttering, closed the cage again, shut the window and the curtains, and hurriedly went to Lucie, telling her that her father had gone with others to look for her husband. He found Lucie with her child and Miss Pross; but for a long time, that is, until he sat down and watched them in the silence of the night, it did not even occur to him to be surprised that they were there.
es: Lorry closed the window very hopefully, and hurried to join Lucie, to whom he reported that her father, aided by the townspeople, had gone to look for her husband. With Lucie was her daughter and Miss Pross, but such was the confusion of good Lorry that he wasn't even surprised to find them there until much later.

en: Lucie had, by that time, fallen into a stupor on the floor at his feet, clinging to his hand. Miss Pross had laid the child down on his own bed, and her head had gradually fallen on the pillow beside her pretty charge. O the long, long night, with the moans of the poor wife! And O the long, long night, with no return of her father and no tidings!
vi: Lucie had by then fallen asleep on the floor at Mr. Lorry's feet, one hand still clutching his. Miss Pross had earlier placed the child on his bed, her head slowly sinking onto the pillow next to this charming responsibility. Oh, how the night dragged on with the sighs of the poor wife! Oh, how the night dragged on with no news of the father who had not returned!
tr: At that moment, Lucie, in a state of unconsciousness, was sitting on the ground by Mr. Lorry's knee, holding tightly to his hand. Miss Pross had laid the child on Mr. Lorry's bed, and before long, her own head had fallen onto the pillow right next to her sweet responsibility. The night, oh what a long night it was, accompanied by the poor woman's moans! Oh, throughout that long, very long night, neither had her father returned home, nor had any news arrived!
es: The night was horrible. Lucía, in a state of stupor, was sitting on the floor wringing her hands, and Miss Pross, after putting the child to bed, succumbed to the sleep that besieged her and fell asleep with her head bent over the child's little bed. Horrible night, during which Lorry had to listen to the constant sobs of the unfortunate Lucía! Horrible night, eternal night, night of anguish, night of anxiety, night spent waiting for the arrival of a father who did not come, the arrival of news of a husband placed at the edge of the grave, and the news did not come!

en: Twice more in the darkness the bell at the great gate sounded, and the irruption was repeated, and the grindstone whirled and spluttered. “What is it?” cried Lucie, affrighted. “Hush! The soldiers’ swords are sharpened there,” said Mr. Lorry. “The place is national property now, and used as a kind of armoury, my love.”
vi: Twice more in the dark night, the gate bell rang and a crowd surged in, and the grindstone wheel hissed and spun furiously. − What is happening? - Lucie cried out in fear. − Shh! The soldiers' swords are sharpened here, - Mr. Lorry said. - This place is now national property, and it is used as an armory, my dear.
tr: In the darkness, the bell of the large door rang twice more and people poured in again in droves, and the grindstone spun furiously, scattering sparks. "What is this?" cried Lucie, in horror. "Stay calm! The soldiers' swords are being sharpened there!" said Mr. Lorry. "This place now belongs to the people, my dear, and is being used as a sort of armory."
es: Twice more the gate bell rang violently, twice more the intrusion was repeated, twice more they set the grindstone in motion. Lucía was frightened. —What is that?—he asked. —Silence!—responded Lorry. —It is the soldiers sharpening their swords. The house is now national property, my dear.

en: Twice more in all; but, the last spell of work was feeble and fitful. Soon afterwards the day began to dawn, and he softly detached himself from the clasping hand, and cautiously looked out again. A man, so besmeared that he might have been a sorely wounded soldier creeping back to consciousness on a field of slain, was rising from the pavement by the side of the grindstone, and looking about him with a vacant air. Shortly, this worn-out murderer descried in the imperfect light one of the carriages of Monseigneur, and, staggering to that gorgeous vehicle, climbed in at the door, and shut himself up to take his rest on its dainty cushions.
vi: Then two more times like that; but the last time there were fewer people and it was brief. Right after that, dawn broke and Mr. Lorry gently separated the girl's hand that was tightly holding his, carefully walked to the window and looked out. A man, covered in blood like a severely wounded soldier just regaining consciousness on a massacre battlefield, stood up from the roadside near the grindstone wheel and looked around with a dazed expression. Immediately after that, in the dim light, this exhausted murderer saw a Lord's carriage and staggered towards it, opened the door, climbed in, and closed the door to sleep on the luxurious cushioned benches.
tr: The number of those who came this time was twice that of the previous ones; but by the end of this last mission, they had begun to weaken. Soon after, as dawn began to break, Mr. Lorry gently separated his hand from the one clinging to him and cautiously looked out the window. Standing on the pavement where the grindstone was, a man with a blank expression looked around; his clothes were so dirty that he resembled a wounded soldier crawling back to consciousness from a massacre site. The exhausted villain soon noticed one of Monseigneur's carriages in the dim light, staggered towards the magnificent carriage, climbed the steps, and closed the door to rest on the elegant cushions.
es: The new day dawned. Lorry managed to free himself from Lucia's clenched hands and looked out the window. Next to the sharpening stone, a man, covered in blood from head to toe, resembling a wounded soldier regaining consciousness on the battlefield, was rising from the ground where he had been lying and looking around with a dazed expression. That killer, tired of killing, saw the lord's magnificent carriages, walked unsteadily to one of them, opened the door, and locked himself inside, ready to rest from the night's exertions on the plush cushions.

en: The great grindstone, Earth, had turned when Mr. Lorry looked out again, and the sun was red on the courtyard. But, the lesser grindstone stood alone there in the calm morning air, with a red upon it that the sun had never given, and would never take away.
vi: The Earth, the great wheel, had completed its turn when Mr. Lorry looked out once more and the sun dyed the outer yard red. But the smaller grindstone wheel still stood solitary there in the tranquil morning, stained red with a color not bestowed by the sunlight, and would never fade.
tr: When Mr. Lorry looked out the window again, the great grindstone called the world was turning, and the sun was painting the courtyard red. But the smaller grindstone, in the morning coolness, stood alone with a redness that the sun never gave and would never take back.
es: That killer, tired of killing, saw the lord's magnificent carriages, walked unsteadily to one of them, opened the door, and locked himself inside, ready to rest from the night's exertions on the plush cushions.

en: CHAPTER III.
vi: 3. Darkness
tr: III
es: III.

en: The Shadow
vi: 3. Darkness
tr: Shadow
es: THE SHADOW

en: One of the first considerations which arose in the business mind of Mr. Lorry when business hours came round, was this:—that he had no right to imperil Tellson’s by sheltering the wife of an emigrant prisoner under the Bank roof. His own possessions, safety, life, he would have hazarded for Lucie and her child, without a moment’s demur; but the great trust he held was not his own, and as to that business charge he was a strict man of business.
vi: One of the first considerations that arose in Mr. Lorry's professional mind as the work hour approached was the thought: he had no right to endanger Tellson's Bank by sheltering the wife of an exiled prisoner within its walls. He was ready to sacrifice his property and personal safety for Lucie and her little girl without hesitation; but the work entrusted to him was not his own, and with that responsibility, he resolutely placed his duty above all else.
tr: When the working hour arrived, the first thought that occupied Mr. Lorry's work-focused mind was this: Did he have the right to endanger Tellson's by sheltering the wife of a refugee prisoner under the bank's roof? For Lucie and her child, he would unhesitatingly give all his property, even his life, but this great responsibility was not something that belonged solely to him, and when it came to work, he was a serious businessman.
es: One of the first reflections that Mr. Lorry's practical understanding suggested to him, as soon as the hour to commence the Bank's operations struck the next day, was that he had no right to create difficulties and attract dangers to Tellson's Bank by providing shelter in the building to the wife of an imprisoned emigrant. Without a second of hesitation, with joy, with all his soul, he would have sacrificed everything he possessed, including his freedom and his life, on the altar of the affection he felt for Lucie and her daughter; but the great banking establishment was not his, and when it came to business, Lorry was rigid, inflexible.

en: At first, his mind reverted to Defarge, and he thought of finding out the wine-shop again and taking counsel with its master in reference to the safest dwelling-place in the distracted state of the city. But, the same consideration that suggested him, repudiated him; he lived in the most violent Quarter, and doubtless was influential there, and deep in its dangerous workings.
vi: At first, his mind thought of Defarge and considered going to that tavern again to ask the innkeeper to introduce him to the safest refuge in the city's madness. But that very consideration made him abandon the idea; Defarge was living right in the most brutal area, certainly had influence there, and was surely deeply involved in the current dangerous situation.
tr: At first, he thought of Defarge and considered finding the wine shop again to get advice from the owner on where the safest place in this wayward city might be. But then he gave up on this idea; Defarge lived in the most dreadful area and was certainly an influential person there; he might even be at the forefront of these dangerous affairs.
es: As a consequence of his musings, he thought of Defarge, and the thought was followed by the decision to go to the tavern and ask its owner to indicate a safe refuge for Lucie, if there was one in that troubled city, a refuge that could very well be, if Defarge agreed, the same garret where Dr. Manette had lived in the past. However, he dismissed this plan almost as soon as he conceived it, considering that the tavern was located in the most dangerous neighborhood of the city and that Defarge, undoubtedly an influential person among the inhabitants of that violent region, would be fully involved in the enterprises that were being forged and matured there.

en: Noon coming, and the Doctor not returning, and every minute’s delay tending to compromise Tellson’s, Mr. Lorry advised with Lucie. She said that her father had spoken of hiring a lodging for a short term, in that Quarter, near the Banking-house. As there was no business objection to this, and as he foresaw that even if it were all well with Charles, and he were to be released, he could not hope to leave the city, Mr. Lorry went out in quest of such a lodging, and found a suitable one, high up in a removed by-street where the closed blinds in all the other windows of a high melancholy square of buildings marked deserted homes.
vi: By noon, the doctor still hadn't returned, and each minute of delay made things more difficult for Tellson's Bank, so Mr. Lorry had no choice but to discuss it with Lucie. Lucie said that her father intended to rent a short-term lodging in an area near the bank. Since renting a house did not harm the company, and he anticipated that even if everything went well and Charles was released, he would still hope to leave the capital, Mr. Lorry went out to find a lodging, found a suitable place, on a high floor, in a secluded small street, where all the windows were tightly curtained, indicating that these were abandoned houses.
tr: Noon was approaching, the Doctor still hadn't returned, and with each passing minute, he was putting Tellson in a bit more danger. Mr. Lorry had had a tête-à-tête with Lucie. Lucie mentioned that her father had talked about renting a house in that area, near the bank, for a short period. From a business perspective, it wasn't a matter to object to, and as far as he could see, even if everything went well for Charles and he was released, there was no hope of leaving the city immediately; Mr. Lorry went out to find a house for them and found a suitable place in a gloomy building in a secluded side street on the hills, where the closed shutters indicated that no one was living inside.
es: As it was nearing twelve in the morning and the doctor had not yet appeared, with each passing minute increasing the predicament in which he had placed Tellson's Bank, Lorry decided to hold a consultation with Lucie. She mentioned that her father had spoken to her about renting a room in that very district, not far from the Bank. Seeing that the doctor's plan was not in opposition to the Bank's affairs, and foreseeing that even if Charles's situation was resolved favorably, and even if through the doctor's intervention and influence he was released, it would still be impossible for him to escape the city, Lorry immediately went out to find a suitable room and found one on an isolated street surrounded by uninhabited buildings.

en: To this lodging he at once removed Lucie and her child, and Miss Pross: giving them what comfort he could, and much more than he had himself. He left Jerry with them, as a figure to fill a doorway that would bear considerable knocking on the head, and returned to his own occupations. A disturbed and doleful mind he brought to bear upon them, and slowly and heavily the day lagged on with him.
vi: He immediately took Lucie and her mother, along with Miss Pross, to their lodging; providing them with all the comforts possible, even more comfortably than he arranged for himself. He left Jerry with them as an obstacle blocking the doorway and willing to take a punch to the head, then returned to his work. He worked with a heart full of anxiety and suffering, and the long day passed slowly and heavily.
tr: He first placed Lucie, her daughter, and Miss Pross in this small place; he tried to make them as comfortable as possible, even giving them comforts that he himself did not have. He placed Jerry, with his door-sized bulk and thick head capable of withstanding any blow, next to them and returned to his work. But he was always uneasy and unhappy inside, and thus the day slowly, gradually came to an end.
es: Without losing a moment, he moved Lucía, her daughter, and Miss Pross to the mentioned room, giving them as much comfort as he could, which was more than he himself had. He left Jeremiah Lapa with them and went back to immerse himself in his tasks. He spent the rest of the day sad, worried, and suspicious, until it was time to close the establishment.

en: It wore itself out, and wore him out with it, until the Bank closed. He was again alone in his room of the previous night, considering what to do next, when he heard a foot upon the stair. In a few moments, a man stood in his presence, who, with a keenly observant look at him, addressed him by his name.
vi: The long, dragging days wore down time, and wore him down, until the bank closed. He was alone again in the room like the night before, contemplating what to do when he heard footsteps ascending the steps. A moment later, someone stood before him, sharp eyes observing, calling his name directly.
tr: When the day ended and the bank closed, Mr. Lorry was also exhausted. When he heard a footstep on the stairs, he was alone in his room again, just like the previous night, thinking about what to do next. Soon, a man appeared before him and, after scrutinizing him intently, addressed him by name.
es: He spent the rest of the day sad, worried, and suspicious, until it was time to close the establishment. Then he retired to his room, as he had the day before, and was thinking about the resolutions he should adopt when he heard the sound of footsteps on the stairs. Seconds later, a man appeared before him who, looking at him with a penetrating gaze, addressed him by his name.

en: “Your servant,” said Mr. Lorry. “Do you know me?”
vi: − At your service, sir, - said Mr. Lorry. - Do you know me?
tr: "Please," said Mr. Lorry. "Do you recognize me?"
es: —At your service, Mr. Lorry. Do you know me?

en: He was a strongly made man with dark curling hair, from forty-five to fifty years of age. For answer he repeated, without any change of emphasis, the words:
vi: He was a burly man, with curly black hair, around forty-five to fifty years old. Instead of answering, he repeated the man's words without any expression: −
tr: He was a man with curly black hair, around forty-five to fifty years old, with a strong appearance. Without changing the emphasis, he repeated Mr. Lorry's words:
es: He was an individual of solid build, with naturally curly black hair, and about forty-five years old. —Do you know me?—he repeated.

en: “Do you know me?”
vi: Do you know me?
tr: "Do you know me?"
es: —Do you know me?—he repeated.

en: “I have seen you somewhere.”
vi: − I have met you somewhere before.
tr: "I think we have met before."
es: —I have seen you somewhere.

en: “Perhaps at my wine-shop?”
vi: − Perhaps at my tavern?
tr: "Maybe we had met at my wine shop."
es: —In my wine shop, perhaps?

en: Much interested and agitated, Mr. Lorry said: “You come from Doctor Manette?”
vi: − With a look of concern and emotion, Mr. Lorry said: − Did Mr. Manette send you here?
tr: Mr. Lorry, both concerned and anxious, then said: "Are you coming from Dr. Manette's side?"
es: More interested than ever, and not a little agitated, Lorry asked:

en: “Yes. I come from Doctor Manette.”
vi: − Yes, Mr. Manette sent me here. −
tr: "Yes, I am coming from Doctor Manette's side.""
es: —Are you coming on behalf of Dr. Manette? —Yes; I come on behalf of Doctor Manette.

en: “And what says he? What does he send me?”
vi: And what did he say? − Did he leave any message for me?
tr: "What does he say? What message did he send me?"
es: —And what does it say? Is he sending me something?

en: Defarge gave into his anxious hand, an open scrap of paper. It bore the words in the Doctor’s writing:
vi: − Defarge handed an open piece of paper to the anxious hand. The letter was written in the doctor's handwriting: Charles is safe, but I cannot safely leave this place yet.
tr: Defarge handed a piece of paper to the worried Mr. Lorry. On the paper, in the Doctor's handwriting, the following was written:
es: Defarge placed in the eagerly outstretched hand of Lorry a piece of paper, which contained the following words, written in the doctor's own hand:

en: “Charles is safe, but I cannot safely leave this place yet. I have obtained the favour that the bearer has a short note from Charles to his wife. Let the bearer see his wife.”
vi: The letter was written in the doctor's handwriting: Charles is safe, but I cannot safely leave this place yet. I have arranged for the bearer of this letter to deliver a short note from Charles to his wife. Let the bearer of this letter meet Charles's wife.
tr: Charles is safe, but I still cannot leave here safely. I asked the person bringing you this note to allow Charles to send a small note to his wife as well. Please arrange for this person to meet with Lucie.
es: "Carlos is without news, but I cannot abandon the place where I am. I have managed to get the bearer of this to carry two lines from Carlos to his wife. Make sure the bearer meets with my daughter."

en: It was dated from La Force, within an hour.
vi: The letter is dated and timed from La Force prison, an hour ago.
tr: The note had been written an hour ago at La Force.
es: The letter was dated in La Force an hour earlier.

en: “Will you accompany me,” said Mr. Lorry, joyfully relieved after reading this note aloud, “to where his wife resides?”
vi: − Are you willing to accompany me to this man's wife's residence? - Mr. Lorry felt relieved and at ease after reading the letter.
tr: After reading the note aloud, Mr. Lorry relaxed and asked in a cheerful voice, "Would you accompany me to where his wife lives?"
es: —Would you be so kind as to accompany me to the house where Carlos's wife resides?—asked Lorry, without hiding the joy that the reading of the note had produced in him.

en: “Yes,” returned Defarge.
vi: − Alright, - Defarge replied.
tr: "Thank you," replied Defarge.
es: —Yes—replied Defarge.

en: Scarcely noticing as yet, in what a curiously reserved and mechanical way Defarge spoke, Mr. Lorry put on his hat and they went down into the courtyard. There, they found two women; one, knitting.
vi: Not paying any attention to the fact that Defarge's way of speaking was very cautious and unusually mechanical, Mr. Lorry put on his hat and the two of them went down to the yard. There, they met two women; one of them was knitting.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who had not quite noticed how quietly and mechanically Defarge spoke, put on his hat and they went down to the courtyard together. There were two women standing there; one of them was knitting.
es: Without stopping, you lie in the reserved and curiously mechanical tone with which Defarge spoke, Lorry put on his hat and went down with his visitor to the garden, where they found two women, one of them knitting.

en: “Madame Defarge, surely!” said Mr. Lorry, who had left her in exactly the same attitude some seventeen years ago.
vi: − Madame Defarge, indeed! - Mr. Lorry said, seventeen years ago when he left Paris he had met her exactly like this. −
tr: Mr. Lorry, who had left her exactly like this seventeen years ago, said, "Madame Defarge, of course!"
es: —Mrs. Defarge?—asked Lorry, who had left her occupied with the same thing seventeen years earlier.

en: “It is she,” observed her husband.
vi: That's right, - her husband said.
tr: "Yes, that's him," said her husband.
es: —The same one—replied the husband.

en: “Does Madame go with us?” inquired Mr. Lorry, seeing that she moved as they moved.
vi: − Is she coming with us? - Mr. Lorry asked when he saw her step aside.
tr: When he saw the woman start walking with them, Mr. Lorry asked, "Is the lady going to come with us too?"
es: —Is your wife coming with us?—asked Lorry, noticing that the women were starting to walk.

en: “Yes. That she may be able to recognise the faces and know the persons. It is for their safety.”
vi: − Yes. So that she can recognize faces, recognize people. For their safety.
tr: "Yes. It can recognize faces and identify people this way. This is necessary for their safety."
es: —Yes. He comes to recognize faces and get to know people. It's a measure that benefits the doctor's daughter.

en: Beginning to be struck by Defarge’s manner, Mr. Lorry looked dubiously at him, and led the way. Both the women followed; the second woman being The Vengeance.
vi: Beginning to be surprised by Defarge's attitude, Mr. Lorry looked at him suspiciously and then led the way. The two women followed behind; the second woman was the Goddess of Revenge.
tr: Mr. Lorry, who was starting to be disturbed by Defarge's demeanor, looked suspiciously and continued walking. Two women were following them; the second woman was Vengeance.
es: Lorry, to whom Defarge's attitude and words began to seem strange, gave him a suspicious look and continued walking. The two women followed, one of whom was called The Vengeance.

en: They passed through the intervening streets as quickly as they might, ascended the staircase of the new domicile, were admitted by Jerry, and found Lucie weeping, alone. She was thrown into a transport by the tidings Mr. Lorry gave her of her husband, and clasped the hand that delivered his note—little thinking what it had been doing near him in the night, and might, but for a chance, have done to him.
vi: They quickly passed through the separating streets, up the stairs to the new residence, were let in by Jerry, and found Lucie crying alone. She was overjoyed when Mr. Lorry brought news of Charles, and she tightly grasped the hand of the person who had given her the letter from her husband - not thinking at all that this very hand had killed a prisoner the night before, and perhaps, if given the chance, would have killed her husband as well.
tr: They hurried through the streets as quickly as possible, climbed the steps of the new house, were greeted by Jerry, and upon entering, found Lucie sobbing alone. The young woman, revived by the news brought by Mr. Lorry from her husband, tightly grasped the hand that delivered the note – a hand that had no idea what it had done near her husband that night or what it had done until now.
es: They crossed the nearby streets as quickly as possible, climbed the stairs to Lucía's residence, Jeremías opened the door for them, and they found Carlos's wife alone and crying. The news about her husband that Lorry gave her filled her with joy, and she warmly shook the hand that handed her the brief words written by her Carlos... without thinking about what that hand had been doing the previous night very close to her husband's person, nor what it might have done with him had a fortunate coincidence not prevented it.

en: “Dearest,—Take courage. I am well, and your father has influence around me. You cannot answer this. Kiss our child for me.”
vi: My love - Be brave. I am still well, and your father can influence the people here. This letter is not to be replied to. Kiss our child for me.
tr: My darling, Don't worry. I'm fine, your father has strong influence here. You won't be able to reply to this letter. Kiss our child for me.
es: "Courage, my dear. I am well, and your father has influence over those around me. You cannot reply to me. Kiss our angel for me."

en: That was all the writing. It was so much, however, to her who received it, that she turned from Defarge to his wife, and kissed one of the hands that knitted. It was a passionate, loving, thankful, womanly action, but the hand made no response—dropped cold and heavy, and took to its knitting again.
vi: That is all. But it was immensely meaningful to the recipient, to the point that she turned from Defarge to his wife and kissed a hand holding a knitting needle. It was a warm, loving, appreciative gesture from a woman, but the other hand did not respond - it coldly withdrew and continued knitting.
tr: That was all. But it meant so much to the person to whom the note was sent that Luice, after turning to Defarge, kissed one of her knitting hands. This was a very emotional, loving, grateful, and womanly gesture, but the knitting hand did not respond – it fell coldly and heavily, and resumed its knitting.
es: Nothing else was written on the note. It was, however, so much for the unfortunate woman who had just received it, that in her gratitude she turned to Madame Defarge and kissed with effusion the hands that were knitting. It was an act of a passionate, loving, grateful wife; but the hand that was the object of this act did not respond. It withdrew from her lips heavy, cold as ice, and continued knitting.

en: There was something in its touch that gave Lucie a check. She stopped in the act of putting the note in her bosom, and, with her hands yet at her neck, looked terrified at Madame Defarge. Madame Defarge met the lifted eyebrows and forehead with a cold, impassive stare.
vi: The collision felt strange, leaving Lucie numb. The letter, not yet raised to her chest, halted abruptly, her hands flailing, and she looked at the woman in horror. Madame Defarge only raised an eyebrow and furrowed her brow, her gaze cold and indifferent.
tr: With this attitude, Lucie came to her senses. She stopped just as she was about to tuck the note into her bosom and looked at Madam Defarge with fear-filled eyes, her hands at her neck. Madam Defarge scrutinized Lucie's raised eyebrows and forehead with a cold and indifferent expression.
es: Lucía found something in that hand that shook her. At the very moment she brought her right hand to her chest to store the received note, her eyes, fixed on the face of the innkeeper, reflected infinite terror. Mrs. Defarge responded to her gaze with another that overflowed with impassivity, ice.

en: “My dear,” said Mr. Lorry, striking in to explain; “there are frequent risings in the streets; and, although it is not likely they will ever trouble you, Madame Defarge wishes to see those whom she has the power to protect at such times, to the end that she may know them—that she may identify them. I believe,” said Mr. Lorry, rather halting in his reassuring words, as the stony manner of all the three impressed itself upon him more and more, “I state the case, Citizen Defarge?”
vi: − My child, - Mr. Lorry tried to explain, - there are frequent riots on the streets now, although it may not affect you, Mrs. Defarge wants to meet those she can protect in this situation, to know their faces, to identify them if needed. Am I right, Citizen Defarge? Mr. Lorry was quite cautious in his reassurances as the increasingly cold demeanor of the three others made him more and more suspicious.
tr: "Look dear," Mr. Lorry began, "there are frequent uprisings in the streets; although they probably won't bother you, Madam Defarge likes to see and recognize the people she can protect in such times – so she can remember them later. Isn't that right, Citizen Defarge?" said Mr. Lorry, as the cruel demeanor of the three increased, Mr. Lorry's reassuring voice began to sound hesitant.
es: —My dear Lucía—said Lorry, trying to explain the presence of the women,—disturbances in the streets are very frequent, and although it is unlikely that anyone will bother you, Mrs. Defarge has come with the purpose of seeing the people whom she can extend her protection to, as it is convenient for her to know them well in order to be able to identify them at any given moment. I believe, citizen Defarge—he finished without daring to lavish further words of comfort,—that I have stated the truth of the matter, haven't I?

en: Defarge looked gloomily at his wife, and gave no other answer than a gruff sound of acquiescence.
vi: Defarge looked gloomily at his wife, responding only with a curt sound of agreement.
tr: Defarge, with a stern face, looked at his wife and then grumbled in agreement without any other reaction.
es: Defarge directed a somber look at his wife and limited himself to expressing his agreement with a grunt.

en: “You had better, Lucie,” said Mr. Lorry, doing all he could to propitiate, by tone and manner, “have the dear child here, and our good Pross. Our good Pross, Defarge, is an English lady, and knows no French.”
vi: − It’s best if you bring the girl out here, and Miss Pross as well, - Mr. Lorry tried his best to calm the situation, both in tone and manner. Defarge, our kind Miss Pross is English and doesn’t speak French.
tr: Mr. Lorry said, "Come on, dear Lucie," trying to comfort Lucie as much as he could with both his tone and manner, "bring your sweet daughter and our good Pross here. Defarge, our good Pross is an Englishwoman and does not know a single word of French."
es: —I believe, Lucía, that it would be advisable for the girl and Miss Pross to leave—replied Lorry. —Our excellent Pross, Defarge, is an English lady who does not understand French at all.

en: The lady in question, whose rooted conviction that she was more than a match for any foreigner, was not to be shaken by distress and, danger, appeared with folded arms, and observed in English to The Vengeance, whom her eyes first encountered, “Well, I am sure, Boldface! I hope you are pretty well!” She also bestowed a British cough on Madame Defarge; but, neither of the two took much heed of her.
vi: Firmly believing she is not inferior to any foreigner, Miss Pross was undaunted by any danger; she stepped out, arms crossed, and upon meeting the Goddess of Retribution, she immediately exclaimed, “Ah, surely a brazen face! Hope you’re well!” She also spat an English phrase towards Mrs. Defarge; but neither of the other two paid any attention. −
tr: The woman in question, perhaps due to her strong belief that no stranger would harm her, felt neither distress nor fear; she had her arms crossed and said in English to the first person she noticed, Revenge, "Hey, you ugly thing! Hope you're doing well!" Then she coughed towards Madam Defarge; however, neither of the women paid any attention to her.
es: The lady in question, in whose chest the belief that she was more than capable of putting any foreigner in their place was deeply rooted, and who had not lost her peace of mind despite the disturbances and anarchy reigning in Paris, appeared with her arms crossed, and cast a quintessentially English look at La Venganza, whose eyes met hers from the very first moment. —Hello, you cheeky thing!—he said in English. —I'm glad to see you well. He also directed one or two words to Mrs. Defarge; but neither she nor the other found it convenient to reply.

en: “Is that his child?” said Madame Defarge, stopping in her work for the first time, and pointing her knitting-needle at little Lucie as if it were the finger of Fate.
vi: Is that his child? - Mrs. Defarge, now stopping her work, pointed her knitting needle like a finger of Fate towards little Lucie.
tr: Madam Defarge, for the first time pausing her work and pointing her knitting needle at little Lucie as if it were the finger of fate, asked, "Is this her child?"
es: —Is that the girl?—asked Madame Defarge, pausing her work for the first time and pointing at Lucie with her knitting needle as if it were the finger of Fate.

en: “Yes, madame,” answered Mr. Lorry; “this is our poor prisoner’s darling daughter, and only child.”
vi: − Yes, ma'am, - Mr. Lorry replied, - this is the beloved daughter of that poor prisoner, and she is his only child.
tr: "Yes madam," replied Mr. Lorry; "this poor prisoner's beloved daughter, his only child.""
es: —Yes, ma'am—replied Lorry. —She is the beloved and only daughter of our poor prisoner.

en: The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed to fall so threatening and dark on the child, that her mother instinctively kneeled on the ground beside her, and held her to her breast. The shadow attendant on Madame Defarge and her party seemed then to fall, threatening and dark, on both the mother and the child.
vi: The darkness associated with Madame Defarge and her two followers seemed to envelop the child with a sinister and threatening aura, causing the mother to instinctively kneel beside her child and hold the child tightly in her arms. The darkness of Madame Defarge and her two followers seemed to cast a sinister and threatening shadow over both mother and child.
tr: The shadow cast by Madam Defarge and her companion over the child was so threatening and terrifying that the mother instinctively knelt beside her child and hugged him tightly. This time, the threatening and terrifying shadow of Madam Defarge and her companion fell upon both the mother and the child.
