vi: − Hello, Citizen.
tr: "Good day to you too, citizen!"
es: —Good afternoon, citizen.

en: This mode of address was now prescribed by decree. It had been established voluntarily some time ago, among the more thorough patriots; but, was now law for everybody.
vi: That form of address is now mandatory by law. It started voluntarily some time ago among the more enthusiastic patriots; but then it became a general rule.
tr: It had now been decided that people would address each other in this manner. A while ago, this phrase had spontaneously emerged among fervent patriots, but now it was a law that everyone had to follow.
es: It was the prescribed greeting, nothing less than by a decree. It had been implemented some time before by the most fervent patriots, but by the time we refer to, it was mandatory for everyone.

en: “Walking here again, citizeness?”
vi: − Here again, Citizeness? −
tr: "Gene buralarda mı dolaşıyorsun yurttaş?"
es: —Taking a walk around here, citizen?

en: “You see me, citizen!”
vi: As you can see, Citizen!
tr: "As you can see, citizen!"
es: —You are already seeing it, citizen.

en: The wood-sawyer, who was a little man with a redundancy of gesture (he had once been a mender of roads), cast a glance at the prison, pointed at the prison, and putting his ten fingers before his face to represent bars, peeped through them jocosely.
vi: The sawyer was a short man accustomed to exaggerated gestures (he used to be a road worker). He glanced towards the prison, pointed, then held up his ten fingers in front of his face as if they were bars, and humorously pretended to peer through them.
tr: The small and overly gesticulative sawyer (who was once a road worker) glanced at the prison, pointed at it, and in a comical manner, brought his ten fingers in front of his face like bars, pretending to look through them.
es: The sawyer, who in earlier times had been a road worker, raised his eyes, extended his arm in the direction of the prison, brought both hands to his face placing his fingers in a way that represented bars, looked through them, and let out a significant laugh.

en: “But it’s not my business,” said he. And went on sawing his wood.
vi: − But that's not my business, - he said. And continued sawing wood.
tr: "Whatever, it's none of my business," he said. Then he continued chopping the wood.
es: —It's not my business—he said,—and continued sawing.

en: Next day he was looking out for her, and accosted her the moment she appeared.
vi: The next day, he waited for Lucie and started talking to her as soon as she arrived. −
tr: The next day, he waited for Lucie and approached her as soon as she arrived.
es: The next day, it seemed that the sawyer was waiting for Lucía, as he approached her as soon as she appeared in the alley.

en: “What? Walking here again, citizeness?”
vi: What? Walking again, Citizeness?
tr: "Huh? Are you wandering around here again, citizen?"
es: —Out for a walk here again, citizen?

en: “Yes, citizen.”
vi: − Yes, Citizen. − Ah!
tr: "Yes, citizen."
es: —Yes, citizen.

en: “Ah! A child too! Your mother, is it not, my little citizeness?”
vi: Another child! This is your mother, little Citizeness? −
tr: "Ah! You've brought a child too! This is your mother, isn't it, little citizen?"
es: —Ah! And with a little girl? Your mom, little citizen, isn't that right?

en: “Do I say yes, mamma?” whispered little Lucie, drawing close to her.
vi: Can I speak, mother? - Little Lucie whispered, clinging to her mother.
tr: Little Lucie snuggled up to her mother and whispered, "Should I say yes, mom?"
es: —Should I say yes, mom?—asked the girl in a low voice, approaching her mother.

en: “Yes, dearest.”
vi: − Yes, my dear.
tr: "Yes, my dear.""
es: —Yes, dear, yes.

en: “Yes, citizen.”
vi: − Yes, Citizen. −
tr: "Yes, citizen.""
es: —Yes, citizen—replied Lucita.

en: “Ah! But it’s not my business. My work is my business. See my saw! I call it my Little Guillotine. La, la, la; La, la, la! And off his head comes!”
vi: Ah! But that's not my business. My business is to work. Look at my saw! I call it Little Guillotine. La, la, la; La, la, la! And his head falls!
tr: "Ah! But it doesn't concern me. I'll mind my own business. Have you seen my saw? I call it my little guillotine. La, la, la; la, la, la! There goes the man's head!"
es: —Ah! It's not my business. The only thing that interests me is working... Look at my saw, citizen... I call it my dear Guillotine... La, la, la, la, la... and a head falls.

en: The billet fell as he spoke, and he threw it into a basket.
vi: A short piece of wood fell while he was talking and sawing, then he threw the piece of wood into the basket.
tr: While Adam was talking, the log fell to the ground, and he picked it up and threw it into the basket.
es: Indeed; while he was speaking, the piece of wood fell, and the sawyer put it into a basket.

en: “I call myself the Samson of the firewood guillotine. See here again! Loo, loo, loo; Loo, loo, loo! And off her head comes! Now, a child. Tickle, tickle; Pickle, pickle! And off its head comes. All the family!”
vi: − I call myself the Samson of the wood guillotine. Look here too! Loo, loo, loo; Loo, loo, loo! And her head falls! Now it's the child's turn. Swish, swish; Swish, swish! And its head falls. The whole family!
tr: "I call myself the Samson of the wood guillotine. Look now, again! Loo, loo, loo; loo, loo, loo! There goes the woman's head too! Now a child. Come on, giddy giddy; biddy biddy! There goes his head too. We've taken care of the whole family!"
es: —I give myself the name of Samson, the Fuel Guillotine. I handle my device, and a head falls... Now a woman's head falls... are you watching, citizen? It's the girl's turn... whack! Goodbye, little head! I finished with the whole family.

en: Lucie shuddered as he threw two more billets into his basket, but it was impossible to be there while the wood-sawyer was at work, and not be in his sight. Thenceforth, to secure his good will, she always spoke to him first, and often gave him drink-money, which he readily received.
vi: Lucie shuddered as he threw two more pieces of wood into the basket, but she couldn't avoid the sawyer while he was working. Since then, to avoid his ill will, she always initiated conversations with him first, and often sent him some money for drinks, which he readily accepted.
tr: Lucie shuddered when the man threw two logs into the basket; but it was impossible to be there and not be seen by the sawyer while he was at work. Since that day, Lucie would first chat with him every time she went there to ensure he wouldn't cause any harm, and she often gave him money for drinks; he would accept it without any hesitation.
es: Lucía found it repugnant to watch the logs being sawed and could not see the act of placing them in the basket without feeling a shudder, but it was impossible for her to stay in that place during the sawyer's working hours without him seeing her. Henceforth, in order to win his sympathies, not only did she take the initiative to speak to him, but she also gave him some coins for a drink, which he accepted without hesitation.

en: He was an inquisitive fellow, and sometimes when she had quite forgotten him in gazing at the prison roof and grates, and in lifting her heart up to her husband, she would come to herself to find him looking at her, with his knee on his bench and his saw stopped in its work. “But it’s not my business!” he would generally say at those times, and would briskly fall to his sawing again.
vi: He was a curious man, and often Lucie would forget about him as she gazed intently at the roof and the iron-barred windows of the prison, her heart focused on her husband. Then she would suddenly realize that he was watching her, kneeling on the workbench but his saw had stopped working. "But that's none of my business!" he would often say at those moments, then hastily return to his sawing.
tr: The sawyer was a curious man; sometimes, when Lucie would forget him and, with her eyes lost in the prison's roof and bars, open her heart to her husband, she would suddenly come to herself and find the man, with his saw halted in his hand, his knee braced against his stool, watching her. At such times, he would again, saying "This doesn't concern me!" desperately continue to cut the wood.
es: The sawyer was an extremely curious individual. Many times, when Lucía, forgetting his presence, would remain for a long time with her gaze fixed on the prison bars and her heart set on her husband, upon realizing her imprudence, she would lower her gaze and see the sawyer looking at her with a smile, his knee on the bench and holding the saw, but not working. When this happened, as a general rule, he would say, "it's none of my business," and resume his work without further comment.

en: In all weathers, in the snow and frost of winter, in the bitter winds of spring, in the hot sunshine of summer, in the rains of autumn, and again in the snow and frost of winter, Lucie passed two hours of every day at this place; and every day on leaving it, she kissed the prison wall. Her husband saw her (so she learned from her father) it might be once in five or six times: it might be twice or thrice running: it might be, not for a week or a fortnight together. It was enough that he could and did see her when the chances served, and on that possibility she would have waited out the day, seven days a week.
vi: In all weather conditions, whether it was the freezing snow of winter or the cold winds of spring, the scorching heat of summer or the drizzling rain of autumn, and then again the freezing snow of winter, Lucie would stand there for two hours every day; every day when she left, she would send a kiss towards the prison wall. About five or six times, Charles would see her once (she heard her father say so); sometimes two or three times in a row; sometimes it would take one or two weeks before he could see her. As long as her husband had the chance to see her, that was enough, and for that chance, she was willing to stand there all day, seven days a week.
tr: In all kinds of weather, in snow, in winter, in the harsh winds of spring, under the scorching sun of summer, in the autumn rains, and then again in snow, in winter, Lucie stood and waited in the same place for two hours every day, and every day, as she left, she kissed the wall of the prison. Her husband (according to what she learned from her father) sometimes saw her only once in five or six attempts, sometimes he saw her two or three days in a row, and sometimes he didn't see her at all for one or two weeks. But the possibility of her husband seeing her and sometimes actually seeing her was enough for her, and for this reason, she could stand there like that seven days a week.
es: At all times, whether during the snows and ice of winter or enduring the furious gales of spring, whether under the scorching summer sun or the torrential autumn rains, not a single day did Lucía fail to spend two hours in that place, not a single day did she fail to kiss, upon leaving, the walls of the prison. Her husband saw her (Lucía knew this through her father) once for every five or six times she went out, sometimes two or three consecutive days, although it also happened that he was deprived of that joy for an entire week. Lucía was satisfied with him seeing her as many times as he had the opportunity to reach the window, and in exchange for not disappointing him even once, she would have gone out not for a day, not for a week; but for entire years.

en: These occupations brought her round to the December month, wherein her father walked among the terrors with a steady head. On a lightly-snowing afternoon she arrived at the usual corner. It was a day of some wild rejoicing, and a festival. She had seen the houses, as she came along, decorated with little pikes, and with little red caps stuck upon them; also, with tricoloured ribbons; also, with the standard inscription (tricoloured letters were the favourite), Republic One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
vi: She kept coming to that corner regularly until December, while her father calmly walked through the scene of horror. On a lightly snowy afternoon, she came to her usual spot again. That day was a chaotic celebration. On her way there, she saw many houses decorated with small spears, topped with tiny red hats; there were also tricolor ribbons and the familiar slogan reading "The Indivisible Unified Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!" - the letters also bore the three favored colors.
tr: As Lucie kept going back and forth and her father continued to march forward with his head held high amidst all that horror, December arrived. As the snow lightly fell, Lucie reached her usual corner. The people were celebrating with wild joy. On her way, she had seen houses decorated with small spears topped with little red hats; and also standard writing adorned with tricolored ribbons (the most popular were the tricolored letters): "The Republic is One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death!"
es: December arrived. Her father continued walking among dreadful horrors, always with a firm step, always with a solid head. One cold and rainy afternoon, Lucía arrived at the usual little corner. It was a day of general rejoicing. She had seen the houses adorned with an abundance of hats pierced by small spears, and decorated with tricolor ribbons and with the inscription, also tricolor (tricolor letters were very fashionable): "One and Indivisible Republic. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death."

en: The miserable shop of the wood-sawyer was so small, that its whole surface furnished very indifferent space for this legend. He had got somebody to scrawl it up for him, however, who had squeezed Death in with most inappropriate difficulty. On his house-top, he displayed pike and cap, as a good citizen must, and in a window he had stationed his saw inscribed as his “Little Sainte Guillotine”—for the great sharp female was by that time popularly canonised. His shop was shut and he was not there, which was a relief to Lucie, and left her quite alone.
vi: The shabby shop of the sawyer was so small that there wasn't enough space to write the entire slogan. He had asked someone to hastily write that phrase on the door, and this person had a hard time fitting in the last word "Death". On the roof, he erected a spear with a hat on it as every good Citizen should do, and in the window, he displayed his saw with the words "Little Saint Guillotine" - because by that time, the sharp lady had been canonized by the people. His shop was closed and he had gone somewhere; seeing this, Lucie felt relieved to be standing alone.
tr: The wretched shop of the sawyer was so small that its facade was not enough to bear this inscription. But then he had found someone who could barely squeeze the word death into it. As a duty of being a good citizen, he had placed a spear and a hat on top of the shop and had put his saw, which he called "Little Saint Guillotine," in one of the windows – after all, this sharp lady was now known by everyone at that time. The shop was closed, and the sawyer was not there; thus, Lucie was left alone and took a deep breath.
es: So miserable and cramped was the sawyer's workshop that its entire surface was almost insufficient for the copied inscription. The house was topped with its corresponding spear equipped with its indispensable red cap, as befitted any citizen who considered himself good, and in a window, he had placed his saw, under which the following inscription could be read: "The Holy Guillotine." The workshop was closed, the sawyer was absent, and Lucía could savor the pleasure of being completely alone. However, the sawyer was not very far away.

en: But, he was not far off, for presently she heard a troubled movement and a shouting coming along, which filled her with fear. A moment afterwards, and a throng of people came pouring round the corner by the prison wall, in the midst of whom was the wood-sawyer hand in hand with The Vengeance. There could not be fewer than five hundred people, and they were dancing like five thousand demons. There was no other music than their own singing. They danced to the popular Revolution song, keeping a ferocious time that was like a gnashing of teeth in unison. Men and women danced together, women danced together, men danced together, as hazard had brought them together. At first, they were a mere storm of coarse red caps and coarse woollen rags; but, as they filled the place, and stopped to dance about Lucie, some ghastly apparition of a dance-figure gone raving mad arose among them. They advanced, retreated, struck at one another’s hands, clutched at one another’s heads, spun round alone, caught one another and spun round in pairs, until many of them dropped. While those were down, the rest linked hand in hand, and all spun round together: then the ring broke, and in separate rings of two and four they turned and turned until they all stopped at once, began again, struck, clutched, and tore, and then reversed the spin, and all spun round another way. Suddenly they stopped again, paused, struck out the time afresh, formed into lines the width of the public way, and, with their heads low down and their hands high up, swooped screaming off. No fight could have been half so terrible as this dance. It was so emphatically a fallen sport—a something, once innocent, delivered over to all devilry—a healthy pastime changed into a means of angering the blood, bewildering the senses, and steeling the heart. Such grace as was visible in it, made it the uglier, showing how warped and perverted all things good by nature were become. The maidenly bosom bared to this, the pretty almost-child’s head thus distracted, the delicate foot mincing in this slough of blood and dirt, were types of the disjointed time.
vi: But he was not far away, because immediately afterward Lucie was terrified when she heard the noisy footsteps and the shouts of people approaching. Shortly after, a crowd of people passed by the corner near the prison, with the sawyer holding the hand of the Goddess of Revenge in the middle. The crowd, which must have been up to five hundred people, danced enthusiastically like five thousand demons. There was no other music than their singing. They danced to their favorite Revolutionary song, keeping a fierce rhythm as if they were collectively grinding their teeth. Men danced with women; women danced with each other; men danced with each other; they danced with anyone they could pair up with randomly. At first, they were just a whirlwind of tattered red hats and ragged coats; but as they flooded this corner and began to dance around Lucie, some went mad like horrifying ghosts. They moved forward, backward, clapped each other's hands, grabbed each other's heads, spun alone, seized anyone, and twirled together until many pairs collapsed. Those who did not fall held hands in a circle and spun, then the circle broke into smaller circles of two or four people, and these circles kept spinning, kept spinning until all suddenly stopped, started again, clapped, grabbed, separated, then reversed the spin, all spinning in the opposite direction. Suddenly, they stopped, rested, started again, forming lines that took up the entire width of the street, then, heads bowed low, hands raised high, they ran off while screaming. No battle scene was half as terrifying as this dance. It was entirely a corrupt amusement - an innocent game turned malevolent - a healthy pastime turned into something that stirred up angry blood, paralyzed consciousness, and froze the heart. If any movements reveal a bit of beauty, the horror increases even more as everything that was once good now becomes distorted and lost. The maiden's bare breasts exposed to the dance, or the innocent pretty head frantically moving to the rhythm, the nimble feet tiptoeing high in this blood-soaked mud, these are the epitomes of a chaotic era.
tr: But the sawyer was not far away, soon there was some commotion and Luice heard approaching shouts; she was filled with great fear. Before long, a large group of people, with Vengeance and the Sawyer in the very middle, hand in hand, flowed like a torrent from the corner of the prison wall. There were roughly five hundred people, and they danced as if they were five thousand demons. There was no music other than the songs they sang themselves. They danced to the popular song of the Revolution, keeping a cruel tempo that resembled the grinding of teeth. Men and women danced together; sometimes only women, sometimes only men, as if this calamity had brought them together. At first, they were a storm of rough red caps and coarse woolen clothes; but when they filled the street and stopped to dance around Lucie, the spirit of a terrible creature that danced in a frenzy awoke within them all. They moved forward and backward, slapped each other's hands, then grabbed each other by the heads and spun alone, then held onto each other again and spun in pairs until many of them collapsed to the ground. While they were on the ground, the others held hands and spun in a circle together; then the circle broke up again, and after spinning in pairs and fours, they all stopped together, then started again, slapped each other again, grabbed each other by the heads and broke up, then turned in the opposite direction, and then all began to turn in different directions. Suddenly they stopped again, waited, and as if turning back time, lined up along the road in rows and advanced with their heads down and fists in the air, shouting. No fight could be as terrifying as this dance. It was such a strange thing – once innocent but now containing devilry – a healthy amusement that had turned into an event that ignited people's blood, upset their emotions, and hardened their hearts. The visible measure of finesse it contained made this dance even uglier, showing how everything good could be twisted and corrupted. The bare flanks of young girls, the wildly swaying beautiful heads almost childlike in age, and the delicate feet advancing through this swamp of blood and filth were all part of this maddened moment.
es: Lucía's wait lasted only a few minutes when loud shouts echoed in the street, filling her with terror. Seconds later, compact crowds turned the corner of the prison, with the sawyer in the center holding hands with La Venganza. There would be no fewer than five hundred people, dancing as if they were five hundred thousand demons. Nor did they have music, for their devilish dances were sufficiently accompanied by the hoarse and discordant shouting from their throats. They sang the popular hymn of the Revolution, accompanied by a fierce clashing of teeth. They danced a fierce dance, which we will not describe, for it suffices to say that the prevailing savagery had turned an innocent distraction into an effective means of igniting the blood, dulling the senses, and hardening the heart.

en: This was the Carmagnole. As it passed, leaving Lucie frightened and bewildered in the doorway of the wood-sawyer’s house, the feathery snow fell as quietly and lay as white and soft, as if it had never been.
vi: It was the Carmagnole dance. As the crowd passed by, leaving Lucie terrified and trembling in front of the woodcutter's house, the gentle snowflakes fell softly, covering the ground as if nothing had happened. −
tr: It was the Carmagnole dance. When the crowd left Lucie at the door of the woodcutter's hut, frightened and bewildered, snowflakes began to fall gently like feathers, covering the ground whiter and softer than ever before.
es: It was the Carmagnole. Lucía, horrified, frozen with fear, had taken refuge in the doorway of the sawyer, covering her face with her hands.

en: “O my father!” for he stood before her when she lifted up the eyes she had momentarily darkened with her hand; “such a cruel, bad sight.”
vi: Oh! Father! - She lowered her hands from her face and saw her father standing in front of her. - The scene is truly horrifying, brutal!
tr: "Ah, daddy!" said Lucie, lifting her eyes, which she had momentarily covered with her hands, and seeing her father in front of her, "what a terrible, what an awful sight it was!"
es: —Oh my father!—she exclaimed as she separated her hands and unexpectedly found herself facing the doctor. — What a cruel, so repugnant spectacle!

en: “I know, my dear, I know. I have seen it many times. Don’t be frightened! Not one of them would harm you.”
vi: − I know, my dear, I know. I have seen it many times. Do not panic! No one will harm you.
tr: "I know, my dear, I know. I've seen these before. Don't be afraid! None of them can harm you."
es: —I know, my dear, I know. I have witnessed it many times. Don't be afraid, no one will harm you in the slightest.

en: “I am not frightened for myself, my father. But when I think of my husband, and the mercies of these people—”
vi: − I am not afraid for myself, father. But when I think of my husband, who is at the mercy of these people... − Soon, no one will have power over Charles's life and death.
tr: "I am not afraid for myself, daddy. But when I think about my husband and how he is at the mercy of these people..."
es: —I am not afraid for myself, my father; but when I think of my husband and the outbursts of those people...

en: “We will set him above their mercies very soon. I left him climbing to the window, and I came to tell you. There is no one here to see. You may kiss your hand towards that highest shelving roof.”
vi: But when I think of my husband, who is at the mercy of these people... − Soon, no one will have power over Charles's life and death. When your father came out here, your husband was going up to that window, and your father came to tell you. There is no one else watching here. You can send a kiss towards the highest sloping roof.
tr: "We will rescue him from their mercy very soon. As I was coming, he was also going to the window, I came to tell you this. There is no one around to see now. You can blow a kiss to the window on the top floor."
es: —Soon we will protect you from his outbursts. I left him climbing to the window and came to tell you. Since today there is no one around here who can see you, it doesn't matter if you send a kiss with your hand to the highest part of the roof, to the very eaves.

en: “I do so, father, and I send him my Soul with it!”
vi: − I will do it right away, father, and send my soul as well!
tr: "Okay, Dad, and with this kiss, I will also send my soul to him now."
es: —I will send it, my father, and with the kiss, I will send my entire soul.

en: “You cannot see him, my poor dear?”
vi: − You cannot see Charles, can you, my poor daughter. −
tr: "But you can't see him, can you, my poor little one?""
es: —You can't see him, my poor daughter; can you?

en: “No, father,” said Lucie, yearning and weeping as she kissed her hand, “no.”
vi: No, father, - Lucie said, crying with longing as she sent a kiss through the wind, - I cannot see him.
tr: "No, father!" said Lucie, kissing his hand and sending a longing kiss while crying, "No!"
es: —No, my father, I can't—replied Lucía, crying.

en: A footstep in the snow. Madame Defarge. “I salute you, citizeness,” from the Doctor. “I salute you, citizen.” This in passing. Nothing more. Madame Defarge gone, like a shadow over the white road.
vi: Footsteps on the snow. Madame Defarge. − Hello, Citizeness, - said the doctor. − Hello, Citizen. - The greeting passed, that was all. Madame Defarge left, like a shadow on the white snow.
tr: Then, a footstep was heard in the snow. The one approaching was Madame Defarge. "Greetings, citizen," said the Doctor. "Greetings, citizen," she replied. They said nothing else. Madame Defarge moved forward like a shadow on the white path and disappeared from sight.
es: Some footsteps were heard, and Madame Defarge appeared. —Greetings, citizen—said the doctor. —Greetings, citizen—replied the innkeeper, continuing on her way without stopping.

en: “Give me your arm, my love. Pass from here with an air of cheerfulness and courage, for his sake. That was well done;” they had left the spot; “it shall not be in vain. Charles is summoned for to-morrow.”
vi: − Now I'll take you home, my dear. Be cheerful and brave for Charles and leave this place. Well done, - the father and daughter left that corner. - It won't be in vain. Tomorrow, Charles will be called to trial.
tr: "Come into my arms, my dear. For his sake, pass through here with a cheerful and brave demeanor now. Well done," they had started walking; "and this cheerfulness is not in vain. Charles will appear in court again tomorrow."
es: —Give me your arm, my dear. Leave here, but pretend to be cheerful, even though I know you cannot feel it... That's it, very good. Tomorrow, Carlos will appear before his judges.

en: “For to-morrow!”
vi: − Tomorrow! −
tr: "Tomorrow!"
es: —Tomorrow!

en: “There is no time to lose. I am well prepared, but there are precautions to be taken, that could not be taken until he was actually summoned before the Tribunal. He has not received the notice yet, but I know that he will presently be summoned for to-morrow, and removed to the Conciergerie; I have timely information. You are not afraid?”
vi: There's no time to hesitate anymore. I've prepared thoroughly, but many things need to be guarded against; we must be cautious until Charles actually goes to court. Your husband hasn't received the notice yet, but I know that tomorrow Charles will be transferred to the Conciergerie prison awaiting trial; I have timely information. You're not afraid, are you?
tr: "We have no time to lose. I am well prepared, but there are precautions we need to take; these precautions could not be taken without him being formally summoned to court. The decision has not yet been communicated to him, but I am sure he will be brought to court tomorrow and sent to the Conciergerie Prison; I received the news just in time. You're not afraid, are you?"
es: —We cannot waste time. I have everything admirably arranged, but there is a need to take precautions that cannot be finalized until the very moment Carlos appears before the Tribunal. He has not yet received the summons, but I know for a fact that he will be summoned for tomorrow and that he will be transferred to the Consulate. As you can see, I receive the news in a timely manner. I suppose you won't be scared, right?

en: She could scarcely answer, “I trust in you.”
vi: − I trust you, - Lucie couldn't speak.
tr: Lucie could barely say, "I trust you."
es: The unfortunate woman could barely stammer. —I trust you. —You can trust, in the certainty of not being disappointed.

en: “Do so, implicitly. Your suspense is nearly ended, my darling; he shall be restored to you within a few hours; I have encompassed him with every protection. I must see Lorry.”
vi: − You must trust father completely. Your long wait is almost over; in just a few hours, Charles will be back with you; I have done everything to protect your husband. Now I must go meet Mr. Lorry.
tr: "You must trust. All your worries will soon come to an end, my dear; a few hours after the trial, you will be reunited with your beloved; I have ensured his safety in every way. Now I need to see Lorry."
es: Your agonies are coming to an end, my love. Within a few hours, you will have him in your arms. I have surrounded him with all imaginable protections. I need to see Lorry...

en: He stopped. There was a heavy lumbering of wheels within hearing. They both knew too well what it meant. One. Two. Three. Three tumbrils faring away with their dread loads over the hushing snow.
vi: He stopped walking. The sound of a creaking wheel echoed faintly. Both father and son understood all too well the meaning of that sound. One. Two. Three. Three carts laden with the dreadful tribute for La Guillotine were crossing the snow, which lay silent and terrifying.
tr: He stopped. The sound of a slowly approaching car was heard. They both knew very well what this meant. One. Two. The three cars carrying the prisoners to the guillotine were moving over the calm snow with their dreadful loads.
es: The doctor was interrupted. In the nearby street, there was a heavy noise of carts. One... two... three... Three carts loaded with condemned men being taken to their execution.

en: “I must see Lorry,” the Doctor repeated, turning her another way.
vi: − We must meet Lorry, - the doctor repeated, then led Lucie in another direction.
tr: "I need to see Lorry," he repeated.
es: —I need to see Lorry—repeated the doctor, turning his head to the other side to avoid seeing the funeral procession.

en: The staunch old gentleman was still in his trust; had never left it. He and his books were in frequent requisition as to property confiscated and made national. What he could save for the owners, he saved. No better man living to hold fast by what Tellson’s had in keeping, and to hold his peace.
vi: The faithful old man continued to maintain the work entrusted to him; he never left the bank. He and his books were always needed when it came to matters of confiscated and nationalized property. He did everything he could to preserve the assets for the owners. No one in this world could be more trustworthy than Mr. Lorry in protecting the assets entrusted to Tellson's Bank and keeping silent.
tr: This sturdy old man was still the person he trusted the most; this situation had never changed. He was frequently consulted, along with his records, for properties that had been confiscated and become state property. He also protected the property owners as much as he could. No one could protect what Tellson had as well as he did and do it with such composure.
es: The good Lorry remained motionless in the Bank building. Both he and the books were frequently requisitioned as confiscated property and converted into national assets, which did not prevent him from saving as much as possible through sheer determination and self-sacrifice.

en: A murky red and yellow sky, and a rising mist from the Seine, denoted the approach of darkness. It was almost dark when they arrived at the Bank. The stately residence of Monseigneur was altogether blighted and deserted. Above a heap of dust and ashes in the court, ran the letters: National Property. Republic One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
vi: The sky turned a gloomy red-yellow, a mist rising from the Seine River, signaling the advance of the dark night. It was already dark when the father and son arrived at the bank. The once magnificent mansion of the Lord was now completely ruined and desolate. Above a pile of ashes in the yard was a banner with the words: The United Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!
tr: The yellow tinged with red and the murky sky, along with the mist rising from the Seine River, heralded the evening. By the time they reached the bank, it was almost dark. The grand residence of the Monsignor was now in a state of ruin and abandonment. On the piles of dust and ash in the courtyard, these words were written: "National Property. The Republic is One and Indivisible. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death!"
es: It was getting dark when the father and daughter arrived at the Bank. The sumptuous residence of the gentleman remained deserted. On the garden gate there was an inscription that read: "National Property. One and Indivisible Republic. Liberty, Equality, Fraternity or Death."

en: Who could that be with Mr. Lorry—the owner of the riding-coat upon the chair—who must not be seen? From whom newly arrived, did he come out, agitated and surprised, to take his favourite in his arms? To whom did he appear to repeat her faltering words, when, raising his voice and turning his head towards the door of the room from which he had issued, he said: “Removed to the Conciergerie, and summoned for to-morrow?”
vi: Who is with Mr. Lorry? The owner of the coat draped over the chair, whose face is unseen? Who is the person Mr. Lorry paused his conversation to go outside, anxious and astonished, to embrace his beloved niece Lucie? Who is the person Mr. Lorry raised his voice to, towards the door just exited, repeating the words he had just heard Lucie hesitantly say?
tr: I wonder who was next to Mr. Lorry – the one with the riding jacket on the chair – and who was the person that was not supposed to be seen? In a nervous and bewildered state, who had this person, who emerged to embrace their loved one, just come from? Raising his voice and turning his head towards the door he entered, to whom could he have repeated Lucie's trembling words, "Sent to the Conciergerie and to be tried tomorrow?"
es: What had become of Mr. Lorry, who was not in his office? Whom had he just dismissed when he came out, agitated and surprised, to embrace his beloved little friend? To whom did he repeat the words that had just been addressed to him in a faltering voice, saying from the door he was crossing: "Transferred to the Conciergerie and summoned for tomorrow?"

en: CHAPTER VI.
vi: Mr. Lorry exclaimed: − Transferred to the Conciergerie prison tomorrow awaiting trial?
tr: VI
es: VI.

en: Triumph
vi: Mr. Lorry exclaimed: − Transferred to the Conciergerie prison tomorrow awaiting trial?
tr: Victory
es: TRIUMPH

en: The dread tribunal of five Judges, Public Prosecutor, and determined Jury, sat every day. Their lists went forth every evening, and were read out by the gaolers of the various prisons to their prisoners. The standard gaoler-joke was, “Come out and listen to the Evening Paper, you inside there!”
vi: The formidable Court of five judges, a prosecutor, and a jury deciding daily trials. The trial list was issued every evening and read to the prisoners by the wardens of various prisons. The familiar joke of the wardens was: “Come out and hear the evening news, folks inside!”.
tr: The terrifying court panel, consisting of five judges, a prosecutor, and a determined jury, convened every day. The lists were sent to various prisons every evening and were read to the prisoners by the guards there. "Inmates, come closer and listen to the evening newspaper!" was a joke made by many guards.
es: Without exaggeration, it can be said that the formidable Tribunal of the Five not only operated every day but was also in permanent session. The lists of prisoners who were to appear before the Tribunal the following day were delivered every afternoon to the wardens of the prisons, who, in turn, read them to those concerned. In prison jargon, these lists were called "Nightly Journals."

en: “Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay!”
vi: −Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay!
tr: "Charles Evremonde, that is, Darnay!"
es: "Carlos Evrémonde, alias Darnay."

en: So at last began the Evening Paper at La Force.
vi: Thus, the evening news reading had begun at La Force prison.
tr: Thus, the evening newspaper session finally began at La Force.
es: Such was the name that headed the "Evening Journal" corresponding to La Force.

en: When a name was called, its owner stepped apart into a spot reserved for those who were announced as being thus fatally recorded. Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, had reason to know the usage; he had seen hundreds pass away so.
vi: When a name was called, the person would step out to a designated spot for those whose fate was to be decided. Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, understood this well because he had seen hundreds of people go to their deaths in that manner.
tr: The people whose names were called would move to the place reserved for prisoners awaiting death. Charles Evremonde, that is, Darnay, knew what this meant; for hundreds had gone this way before.
es: As soon as the name was pronounced, the interested party separated from the group of his unfortunate companions and took his place in the spot designated for those called. Since Charles Darnay had witnessed that scene hundreds of times, it goes without saying that he had plenty of reasons to be familiar with the custom.

en: His bloated gaoler, who wore spectacles to read with, glanced over them to assure himself that he had taken his place, and went through the list, making a similar short pause at each name. There were twenty-three names, but only twenty were responded to; for one of the prisoners so summoned had died in gaol and been forgotten, and two had already been guillotined and forgotten. The list was read, in the vaulted chamber where Darnay had seen the associated prisoners on the night of his arrival. Every one of those had perished in the massacre; every human creature he had since cared for and parted with, had died on the scaffold.
vi: The fat prison guard wearing glasses to read the list glanced over the prisoners to make sure Darnay had stepped out, then continued reading, pausing after each name to glance up like that. The list had twenty-three names but only twenty people stepped out; because one prisoner on the list had died in prison and no one remembered, plus two had gone to the guillotine and no one remembered. The list was finished, in the vaulted room where Darnay first met the prisoners of his class on the night he was brought here. All those people had lost their lives in the massacre, none remained, every person since that day whom he had cared for and then bid farewell had died on the scaffold.
tr: The chubby-faced guard, who had put on glasses to read the names, looked up to make sure the person he called was in place, then returned to his list and repeated the same process for each name. There were twenty-three names on the list, but only twenty people responded, because one of those called had died and been forgotten in his cell, and two others had already been executed by guillotine and forgotten. The list was being read in the domed hall where Charles Darnay had first encountered the other prisoners on the night he arrived at the prison. All those prisoners had been wiped out in the massacre; everyone Darnay had grown close to and then parted from since his arrival had died on the gallows.
es: The chubby warden gave him a look through the dirty lenses of his spectacles, without which he could not read, to make sure he had moved to the place he was supposed to occupy, and having confirmed this, he continued reading the list, making a similar pause after each name. Twenty-three were named, but since one of them had died in jail, and the Holy Guillotine had beheaded two others, although no one remembered them, only twenty answered the call. The list was read in the same vaulted room where Charles found so many prisoners gathered the night he entered the jail. All of them had been torn apart by the mobs on the day of the general massacre, and those who entered later left again to take their passage to the other world on the scaffold.

en: There were hurried words of farewell and kindness, but the parting was soon over. It was the incident of every day, and the society of La Force were engaged in the preparation of some games of forfeits and a little concert, for that evening. They crowded to the grates and shed tears there; but, twenty places in the projected entertainments had to be refilled, and the time was, at best, short to the lock-up hour, when the common rooms and corridors would be delivered over to the great dogs who kept watch there through the night. The prisoners were far from insensible or unfeeling; their ways arose out of the condition of the time. Similarly, though with a subtle difference, a species of fervour or intoxication, known, without doubt, to have led some persons to brave the guillotine unnecessarily, and to die by it, was not mere boastfulness, but a wild infection of the wildly shaken public mind. In seasons of pestilence, some of us will have a secret attraction to the disease—a terrible passing inclination to die of it. And all of us have like wonders hidden in our breasts, only needing circumstances to evoke them.
vi: The hurried and tender farewells echoed, but the parting quickly came to an end. It was a daily occurrence, and the prisoners at La Force that night were busy preparing for some reward and punishment games along with a small concert. They huddled together and shed tears at the barred windows, watching the number of people being called away; but the planned amusements were short by twenty people who needed to be replaced, and time was pressing, nearly time to return to the cells, the hour when the common rooms and corridors would be entrusted to large guard dogs for the night. The prisoners were not insensitive or indifferent; it was this prison environment that made them behave that way. This same environment also gave rise to another more puzzling phenomenon: the wild attitudes that surely led many to face the guillotine unnecessarily and lose their lives unjustly - it was not arrogance but a kind of epidemic that seemed to have spread from the madness of the populace. In times of epidemic, many of us also silently suffer from this condition - a most dreadful temporary tendency to want to die from the epidemic. We all harbor strange desires within us, just waiting for the right conditions to erupt.
tr: After the hasty farewell words and good wishes they exchanged, they quickly parted ways. This was a daily occurrence, and then the La Force community plunged into preparations for the evening's games to be held for the losses of the day, and a small concert. They gathered in front of the bars and wept; but the twenty people who left for the evening's entertainment needed to be replaced, and there was little time left until the doors were locked; the large dogs were handed over to guard the common rooms and corridors throughout the night. The prisoners were not insensitive or callous; they were merely acting in the manner required by the times. Similarly, albeit with a subtle difference, a kind of exhilaration or intoxication undoubtedly gave some of them unnecessary courage as they went to the guillotine, and because of this, dying was not only something to be proud of but also like a dreadful infection spreading from the frenzied minds of the public. Like the desire some had to contract the disease during the plague – strangely, they wanted to die from it. In fact, there are such oddities hidden within all of us, waiting for certain conditions to emerge.
es: Some farewell and encouraging phrases were exchanged between those who were leaving and those who were staying, not many, as aside from being an incident that repeated every day, the society of La Force had planned for that night the celebration of some games, and they needed to make the most of the time to finalize the program. Those who stayed accompanied those who were leaving to the exit gate of the room, shed some tears, and turned back, as it was necessary to fill the twenty gaps left vacant by the absentees if they did not want to forgo the evening's entertainments, and this had to be done before the hour of silence, when the establishment's vigilance was entrusted to armies of ferocious mastiffs that filled the corridors and adjoining rooms. And it is not that the prisoners were insensitive or hard-hearted; but in their character, in their way of being, the condition of the era inevitably had an influence. Just as those saw their unfortunate companions leave almost impassively, there were many who, intoxicated, undoubtedly yielding to a kind of fervor that is barely understood today but was very natural at that time, challenged the people without any need and spontaneously ran in search of the caresses of the guillotine, without their act being influenced much or little by boastfulness, but by the general infection consequent to the brutal shaking of the public soul. In times of pestilence, one sees people who are mysteriously attracted to the contagion, people who would wish to die from it. And it is that we all carry within the depths of our souls dormant oddities that need only the concurrence of certain circumstances to awaken.

en: The passage to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night in its vermin-haunted cells was long and cold. Next day, fifteen prisoners were put to the bar before Charles Darnay’s name was called. All the fifteen were condemned, and the trials of the whole occupied an hour and a half.
vi: The road to the Conciergerie prison is short and dark; the night in the cold, rat-infested cells drags on endlessly. The next day, fifteen prisoners were brought to trial before Charles Darnay was called. All fifteen were convicted, and the trials lasted a full hour and a half.
tr: The road to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night spent in its vermin-filled cells, however, was long and cold. The next day, fifteen prisoners were tried before Charles Darnay's name was called. All of them were found guilty, and their trial lasted an hour and a half.
es: Short and dark was the passage from La Force to the Conciergerie, long and cold the nights spent in the pestilential cells of the latter. Fifteen prisoners appeared before the Tribunal the next morning, before Charles Darnay was called to appear. The hearings of the fifteen lasted an hour and a half, and all fifteen were condemned to death.

en: “Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay,” was at length arraigned.
vi: − Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - it is finally his turn.
tr: After a while, they called him to the stand, saying, "Charles Evremonde, who goes by the name Darnay."
es: “Charles Evrémonde, alias Darnay,” they finally called.

en: His judges sat upon the Bench in feathered hats; but the rough red cap and tricoloured cockade was the head-dress otherwise prevailing. Looking at the Jury and the turbulent audience, he might have thought that the usual order of things was reversed, and that the felons were trying the honest men. The lowest, cruelest, and worst populace of a city, never without its quantity of low, cruel, and bad, were the directing spirits of the scene: noisily commenting, applauding, disapproving, anticipating, and precipitating the result, without a check. Of the men, the greater part were armed in various ways; of the women, some wore knives, some daggers, some ate and drank as they looked on, many knitted. Among these last, was one, with a spare piece of knitting under her arm as she worked. She was in a front row, by the side of a man whom he had never seen since his arrival at the Barrier, but whom he directly remembered as Defarge. He noticed that she once or twice whispered in his ear, and that she seemed to be his wife; but, what he most noticed in the two figures was, that although they were posted as close to himself as they could be, they never looked towards him. They seemed to be waiting for something with a dogged determination, and they looked at the Jury, but at nothing else. Under the President sat Doctor Manette, in his usual quiet dress. As well as the prisoner could see, he and Mr. Lorry were the only men there, unconnected with the Tribunal, who wore their usual clothes, and had not assumed the coarse garb of the Carmagnole.
vi: The judges sat on the bench wearing hats adorned with feathers; but the courtroom was filled with tattered red hats bearing the tricolor emblem. Looking at the jury and the chaotic crowd, Darnay felt as if the normal order had been overturned, with criminals now judging the honest people. The lowest, most vicious, and most vile class of a city teeming with the lowest, most vicious, and most vile people, was conducting the trial: commenting, applauding, objecting, anticipating, and urging the outcome, noisily and incessantly. The men mostly carried various weapons; the women, some held knives, some held swords, others ate and drank while watching the trial, and many were knitting. Among those knitting was one who never stopped with a distinctive pattern. The woman sat in the front row, next to a man whose face Darnay had not seen since he arrived at the gates of Paris, but he clearly remembered the man as Defarge. He noticed that a few times the woman whispered into Defarge's ear and seemed to be his wife; but what he noticed most about these two was that although they sat very close to him, they never looked in his direction. It seemed they were waiting for something very persistently, and they did not take their eyes off the jury. Sitting below the Judge was Dr. Manette, in his usual simple attire. Darnay clearly saw that, apart from the officials, Mr. Manette and Mr. Lorry were the only ones there dressed in ordinary clothes, not in the Carmagnole dance attire.
tr: The jurors were sitting with furry hats; but many others had coarse red hats and tricolor rosettes. When Charles Darnay looked at the jury and the noisy crowd, he perhaps thought that everything had turned upside down and that criminals were judging honest people. The lowest, most cruel, and most vile segment of the city, with their not at all low and vile numbers, was directing the spirit of the hall; they were loudly expressing opinions, applauding, opposing, speculating, and making the jury decide in an instant. Most of the men had various kinds of weapons; the women were carrying knives or daggers, and while some were following the trial by eating and drinking, many were knitting. Among those knitting was a woman who, besides her knitting, had an empty bottle tucked under her arm. She was in the front row, next to Defarge, whom Charles had not seen since the first day he reached the barrier but recognized immediately upon seeing. He saw the woman whispering something into the man's ear a few times and thought she was his wife; but what caught his attention the most while looking at these two was that, despite standing so close to him, they never looked at him. It was as if they were waiting for something with stubborn determination and never took their eyes off the jury for even a moment. In front of the president, in his usual plain attire, sat Doctor Manette. As far as the prisoner could see, there were only himself and Mr. Lorry, who had not donned the coarse carmagnole outfits but were in their usual clothes and had no connection with the court.
es: The judges wore hats adorned with feathers, but aside from them, the entire audience wore red woolen caps with their corresponding tricolor cockades. A mere glance at the Tribunal was enough to suspect that the natural order of things had been inverted and that criminals were judging honorable men. The sentences were inspired by the vilest, most cruel, most criminal mob in the city, and they inspired them by injecting immense amounts of baseness, cruelty, and wickedness into their inspirations, sometimes commenting loudly, sometimes applauding, sometimes anticipating and precipitating the outcome of the deliberations. All the men filling the room were armed to the teeth; all the women carried knives and daggers, some were eating, others drinking, others knitting. Among the latter, there was one who stood out for her industriousness. She was seated in one of the front rows next to a man whom Charles had not seen since the day he arrived at the Barrier of Paris, but who reminded him of Defarge. He observed that the woman spoke two or three times in a very low voice to her neighbor, which led him to suppose that she was his wife, but what most powerfully caught his attention was that despite being as close as possible to him, they did not look at him even once. They frequently turned their eyes to the judges, as if expecting something, but nothing more. Near the President of the Tribunal sat Doctor Manette, calm as always and dressed as always. The prisoner noticed that only the doctor and Mr. Lorry, seated next to him, were dressed as usual and did not display the coarse attire of the Carmagnole.

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, was accused by the public prosecutor as an emigrant, whose life was forfeit to the Republic, under the decree which banished all emigrants on pain of Death. It was nothing that the decree bore date since his return to France. There he was, and there was the decree; he had been taken in France, and his head was demanded.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, was accused by the prosecutor of being an exiled nobleman, condemned to death by the Republic, according to the decree that sentenced all exiled nobles to death. He disregarded the fact that the decree was issued after Darnay had already returned to France. He was in France, the decree was in effect; he was arrested in France, and he must lose his head. −
tr: Charles Evremonde, that is Darnay, was accused of being an émigré by the prosecutor and, based on the law that condemned all émigrés to death, he too had to pay the price of the Republic with his life. It did not matter that the law had been enacted after he had returned to France. He was before them now, and the law was before them as well; Evremonde had come to France secretly and his head was demanded.
es: Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay, was accused by the public prosecutor of being an emigrant whose life was forfeit to the Republic according to the decree that proscribed all emigrants under penalty of death. The fact that the decree in question had been promulgated when the accused was already in France was a trivial circumstance that did not deserve consideration. The decree existed, they had the accused in front of them who had been arrested within the borders of France, and the Republic demanded his head.

en: “Take off his head!” cried the audience. “An enemy to the Republic!”
vi: Off with his head! - The crowd shouted. - Enemy of the Republic!
tr: "Off with his head!" shouted the people, "He's an enemy of the Republic!"
es: —Let his head roll!—roared the crowd—Death to that enemy of the Republic!

en: The President rang his bell to silence those cries, and asked the prisoner whether it was not true that he had lived many years in England?
vi: The judge rang the bell to silence the crowd and asked the prisoner if it was true that he had lived in England for many years.
tr: The chairman rang his bell to silence the shouting and asked the prisoner if it was true that he had been living in England for a long time.
es: The President rang the bell to silence those shouts and asked the accused if it was not true that he had resided in England for many years.

en: Undoubtedly it was.
vi: It was certainly true.
tr: Undoubtedly, it was so.
es: Darnay answered affirmatively.

en: Was he not an emigrant then? What did he call himself?
vi: So, you are not an exiled noble, are you? Then what do you call yourself?
tr: Wasn't he a refugee then? What did he call himself?
es: —And you say you're not an emigrant? What name do you give yourself, then?

en: Not an emigrant, he hoped, within the sense and spirit of the law.
vi: Not an exiled noble, Charles Darnay hopes, in the sense and spirit of this law.
tr: He did not consider himself a refugee in the sense contained in the law.
es: —I do not consider myself an emigrant according to the letter and spirit of the law.

en: Why not? the President desired to know.
vi: Why not? The judge wants to know.
tr: Why was he thinking this way? The president wanted to know.
es: —Why not? That is what I wish to know.

en: Because he had voluntarily relinquished a title that was distasteful to him, and a station that was distasteful to him, and had left his country—he submitted before the word emigrant in the present acceptation by the Tribunal was in use—to live by his own industry in England, rather than on the industry of the overladen people of France.
vi: Because Charles voluntarily renounced the title he despised, the status he hated, and left the country - before the term "exile" was used to refer to the nobility in the sense that this court accepts - to labor for his livelihood in England rather than living off the labor of the oppressed people in France.
tr: Because he had willingly given up a title he never liked and a position he never liked, he had left his country – he accepted the current refugee definition of the court – but in France, instead of living off others, he wanted to make a name for himself in England through his own efforts.
es: —Because I freely and willingly renounced a title that was not to my liking and a social position that displeased me, and I left my homeland to live off my work in England rather than off rents collected from the people of France, burdened under the weight of so many taxes and levies.

en: What proof had he of this?
vi: Does he have any evidence of this?
tr: How was he going to prove this?
es: —How do you prove the accuracy of your statements?

en: He handed in the names of two witnesses; Theophile Gabelle, and Alexandre Manette.
vi: He names two witnesses: Theophile Gabelle, and Alexandre Manette.
tr: He gave the names of two witnesses: Theophile Gabelle and Alexandre Manette.
es: —With the testimony of Théophile Gabelle and Alexandre Manette.

en: But he had married in England? the President reminded him.
vi: But you got married in England? The judge reminded.
tr: But didn't she get married in England? The president immediately reminded.
es: —But you got married in England—objected the President.

en: True, but not an English woman.
vi: Yes, but not to an English woman.
tr: It was true, but not with an Englishman.
es: —True; but not with an English woman.

en: A citizeness of France?
vi: A female French citizen?
tr: Was he/she a French citizen?
es: —With a citizen of France?

en: Yes. By birth.
vi: Yes. Born in France.
tr: Yes. By birth.
es: —Yes.

en: Her name and family?
vi: Her name and her family's name?
tr: What was their name, who was their family?
es: —Your last name and family?

en: “Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette, the good physician who sits there.”
vi: Lucie Manette, the only daughter of Dr. Manette, the esteemed doctor present in the court.
tr: "Lucie Manette, the only daughter of the kind-hearted Doctor Manette sitting over there.""
es: —Lucie Manette, only daughter of Doctor Manette, the excellent physician present here.

en: This answer had a happy effect upon the audience. Cries in exaltation of the well-known good physician rent the hall. So capriciously were the people moved, that tears immediately rolled down several ferocious countenances which had been glaring at the prisoner a moment before, as if with impatience to pluck him out into the streets and kill him.
vi: This answer made the crowd quite cheerful. The entire courtroom echoed with shouts of praise for the famous doctor. These people were so impulsive that some who just moments ago were glaring aggressively at the prisoner as if they wanted to drag him out and kill him, were now immediately in tears.
tr: This response had a positive effect on the public. When they heard the name of the well-known, kind-hearted doctor, the people in the hall shouted with enthusiasm. People's emotions were so fickle that, just a minute ago, the savage faces that were looking at the convict with the thought of dragging him out and killing him were now shedding tears.
es: This response produced an effect in the audience that is impossible to describe with words. The hall trembled under the cries of delirious enthusiasm that the mere mention of Doctor Manette's name elicited. So capricious were the movements of the people that many eyes, which a second before had been watching the accused with ferocity as if their impatience to have him delivered to them to tear him apart was overflowing, immediately filled with tears.

en: On these few steps of his dangerous way, Charles Darnay had set his foot according to Doctor Manette’s reiterated instructions. The same cautious counsel directed every step that lay before him, and had prepared every inch of his road.
vi: Charles Darnay took the steps on this dangerous path exactly according to the repeated instructions of Dr. Manette. The doctor had also meticulously guided the upcoming steps, and he had been thoroughly prepared.
tr: Charles Darnay took his first steps on this dangerous path. He had taken them in accordance with the advice that Doctor Manette had repeatedly given him. Every step ahead of him had been determined by this cautious advisor, who had calculated every inch of the path he would take.
es: Carlos Darnay, in his statements, had followed the doctor's instructions to the letter.

en: The President asked, why had he returned to France when he did, and not sooner?
vi: The judge asked why he returned to France at that time and not earlier?
tr: The chairman asked him why he returned to France on the date he was arrested instead of earlier.
es: —Why did the accused return to France when he did, and not earlier?—asked the President.

en: He had not returned sooner, he replied, simply because he had no means of living in France, save those he had resigned; whereas, in England, he lived by giving instruction in the French language and literature. He had returned when he did, on the pressing and written entreaty of a French citizen, who represented that his life was endangered by his absence. He had come back, to save a citizen’s life, and to bear his testimony, at whatever personal hazard, to the truth. Was that criminal in the eyes of the Republic?
vi: He replied that he did not return earlier simply because he had no means of livelihood in France, unless he relied on what he had given up; whereas in England, he lived by teaching French language and literature. He returned at that time because of the urgent plea of a French Citizen, who had said that his life would be in danger due to his absence. He returned to save this person's life, and to face the truth, regardless of any risks to himself. Was this a crime against the Republic?
tr: He hadn't returned before; because in France, apart from those things he had abandoned, he had nothing to sustain himself with; whereas in England, he made a living by teaching French language and literature. He had returned here at the persistent and written request of a French citizen who claimed that his life was in danger due to his absence. He had come to save a citizen's life and to testify for him, to tell the truth, no matter the cost. Could this have been a crime committed against the Republic?
es: —I did not return earlier—answered Carlos—simply because in France I had no other means of livelihood than the assets I had renounced, whereas in England I earned enough for my subsistence by giving lessons in French and French literature. If I returned when I did, it was in response to a written plea from a French citizen, who informed me that my absence was very seriously compromising his life. I returned to save the life of the citizen in question, and to declare the truth without regard to dangers or inconveniences. What crime does the Republic see in this?

en: The populace cried enthusiastically, “No!” and the President rang his bell to quiet them. Which it did not, for they continued to cry “No!” until they left off, of their own will.
vi: "No!" The crowd enthusiastically shouted, and the judge's ringing of the bell to silence them was in vain. The crowd kept shouting "No!" until they stopped on their own.
tr: The crowd shouted enthusiastically, "No!" and the President rang his bell to silence them. But it didn't work, because they were still shouting "No!", then suddenly the voices stopped on their own.
es: The mob shouted, drunk with enthusiasm: —None... none!

en: The President required the name of that citizen. The accused explained that the citizen was his first witness. He also referred with confidence to the citizen’s letter, which had been taken from him at the Barrier, but which he did not doubt would be found among the papers then before the President.
vi: The judge asked for the name of that Citizen. The convict explained that the Citizen was the first witness he had mentioned. He also confidently referred to the letter from that Citizen, which had been taken from him at the gates of Paris, but he was certain it could be found in the files before the judge.
tr: The President wanted to learn the name of this citizen. The defendant said that the person in question was his first witness. Then, confidently, he spoke about the letter that had been taken from him at the barrier but should now be among the papers in front of the President.
es: The President rang the bell, but he could not impose silence until the audience grew tired of shouting. —What was the name of the citizen to whom the defendant refers?—asked the President. —Teófilo Gabelle, present here. The letter I have mentioned, which, although it was taken from me at the Barrier, I have no doubt will be among the documents the President has on the table, confirms my statements.

en: The Doctor had taken care that it should be there—had assured him that it would be there—and at this stage of the proceedings it was produced and read. Citizen Gabelle was called to confirm it, and did so. Citizen Gabelle hinted, with infinite delicacy and politeness, that in the pressure of business imposed on the Tribunal by the multitude of enemies of the Republic with which it had to deal, he had been slightly overlooked in his prison of the Abbaye—in fact, had rather passed out of the Tribunal’s patriotic remembrance—until three days ago; when he had been summoned before it, and had been set at liberty on the Jury’s declaring themselves satisfied that the accusation against him was answered, as to himself, by the surrender of the citizen Evrémonde, called Darnay.
vi: Dr. Manette had arranged for the letter to be there - he assured Charles that it would be there - and at this point, the letter was taken out and read. Citizen Gabelle was called out to verify, and he confirmed that truth. Citizen Gabelle very delicately and politely implied that under the pressure of work that this Court had to handle with countless enemies of the Republic, he had almost been forgotten in the Abbaye prison - in fact, the patriotic Court had completely forgotten him - until three days ago; when he was called out for trial and the jury decided to release him upon finding no grounds for charges because Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, had surrendered himself.
tr: The doctor – as he had previously promised Darnay – had ensured that the letter was there, and when it came time for the trial records, it was produced and read. Citizen Gabelle was called to verify its authenticity, and he confirmed it. Then Citizen Gabelle subtly and politely implied that the court had forgotten him in the Abbaye Prison due to the abundance of enemies of the Republic it had to deal with – in fact, he had been completely erased from the court's patriotic memory – and this situation had come to light three days before his trial, and with the surrender of Citizen Evremonde, that is, Darnay, the jury declared that the charge against Gabelle had been dropped and he was released.
es: The doctor had taken good care to ensure that the letter in question was on the table. The President found it effortlessly and read it aloud. Next, Gabelle was called to confirm the statements of the accused and to declare himself the author of the letter, which he did with great precision and a tone of truth. Citizen Gabelle delicately and tactfully suggested that the Tribunal, short on time due to the countless enemies of the Republic demanding all its attention, had left him in the Abbey prison until three days prior, an insignificant and very natural oversight; and that, when he appeared before the Tribunal, he was declared innocent and set free, having satisfactorily dispelled the accusations against him.

en: Doctor Manette was next questioned. His high personal popularity, and the clearness of his answers, made a great impression; but, as he proceeded, as he showed that the Accused was his first friend on his release from his long imprisonment; that, the accused had remained in England, always faithful and devoted to his daughter and himself in their exile; that, so far from being in favour with the Aristocrat government there, he had actually been tried for his life by it, as the foe of England and friend of the United States—as he brought these circumstances into view, with the greatest discretion and with the straightforward force of truth and earnestness, the Jury and the populace became one. At last, when he appealed by name to Monsieur Lorry, an English gentleman then and there present, who, like himself, had been a witness on that English trial and could corroborate his account of it, the Jury declared that they had heard enough, and that they were ready with their votes if the President were content to receive them.
vi: The next person to be questioned was Dr. Manette. His personal credibility and clear answers made a strong impression; however, he continued to testify that the defendant was his first friend when he was freed after a long period of imprisonment; that the defendant had stayed in England, always faithful and devoted to him and his daughter during their exile; that, not only was he not favored by the aristocratic government in England, but this defendant had actually been sentenced to death there for the crime of opposing England and sympathizing with the United States. As he presented these circumstances, with utmost caution and sincere, straightforward persuasiveness, the jury and the crowd watching the trial unanimously expressed their agreement. Finally, when he mentioned Mr. Lorry, an English gentleman currently present in court, who, like him, had been a witness in the trial of this defendant in England and could corroborate his testimony, the jury declared that they had heard enough and were ready to vote if the Judge agreed.
tr: The next person to be questioned was Doctor Manette. His beloved personality and the clarity of his answers had a great impact on the people; but when he continued speaking and said that the first friend he made after being freed from his long imprisonment was this defendant, and when he stated that during the defendant's years of exile in England, he had always been loyal and devoted to his daughter and himself, that he had no connection with the aristocratic government there, and that he was even judged for being an enemy of England and a friend of America – when he revealed all these details with all his common sense, reality, and sincerity, the jury agreed with the public. Finally, when Doctor Manette said that the English gentleman named Mr. Lorry, who was present there, had testified just like him in the court in England and could confirm what he had just said, the jury stated that this was sufficient and that they could announce their decision if it was also suitable for the President.
es: The next person to be questioned was Dr. Manette. His great personal popularity and the clarity and precision of his answers created an indescribable impression on the audience; but when he demonstrated that the accused was the one who most effectively contributed to freeing him from his eternal captivity, when he stated that the accused remained in England, surrounding not only his daughter but also himself with tender care and devoted affection, affection and care that made their exile sweet, when he added that far from being a supporter and defender of the aristocratic government of the country where he lived, he was prosecuted and almost condemned to death as an enemy of England and a friend of the United States. After he made a clear and eloquent exposition of all these circumstances, the Tribunal and the audience identified with him. So much so, that when he invoked the testimony of Mr. Lorry, an English gentleman present there, a witness, like him, of the trial held in England against Darnay, and ready to corroborate all his statements, the judges replied that they were satisfied with what they had heard, and that they would gladly vote if the President was willing to receive the votes.

en: At every vote (the Jurymen voted aloud and individually), the populace set up a shout of applause. All the voices were in the prisoner’s favour, and the President declared him free.
vi: Each verdict was loudly announced by each juror, and the crowd in the courtroom cheered and clapped. All the verdicts were favorable for the prisoner, and the Judge declared that Charles Darnay was free.
tr: In each vote, the Jury members were announcing their votes one by one, out loud, and the crowd was applauding with great enthusiasm. They had all voted in favor of the defendant, and the President announced that he was acquitted.
es: As the judges voted (doing so individually and aloud), the audience burst into frenzied applause. Unanimously, they declared the prisoner innocent, and as a result, the President declared him free.

en: Then, began one of those extraordinary scenes with which the populace sometimes gratified their fickleness, or their better impulses towards generosity and mercy, or which they regarded as some set-off against their swollen account of cruel rage. No man can decide now to which of these motives such extraordinary scenes were referable; it is probable, to a blending of all the three, with the second predominating. No sooner was the acquittal pronounced, than tears were shed as freely as blood at another time, and such fraternal embraces were bestowed upon the prisoner by as many of both sexes as could rush at him, that after his long and unwholesome confinement he was in danger of fainting from exhaustion; none the less because he knew very well, that the very same people, carried by another current, would have rushed at him with the very same intensity, to rend him to pieces and strew him over the streets.
vi: Then began a strange spectacle of the people in the court, similar to when the crowd sometimes wants to satisfy its own inconsistency or indulge in feelings of kindness and generosity, or perhaps it is a way for them to make amends for a past full of violent rage. At this moment, no one could determine what motive this strange spectacle stemmed from; it could be a combination of all three motives, but the feelings of kindness and generosity were more overwhelming. As soon as the acquittal order was issued, tears flowed abundantly like blood at other times, with both men and women rushing to Charles, embracing him with such fervent affection that he felt faint from exhaustion after a long period of miserable imprisonment; however, he knew very well that these same people, driven by the tides of the times, would also rush at him with the same fervor to tear him apart and throw his remains into the street.
tr: Then one of those strange scenes began to unfold, revealing how fickle a crowd can be, or how impulses can turn into generosity and compassion, or how a swelling cruel rage can come to an end. No one could say which of these strange scenes was the main reason; perhaps it was a mixture of all of them, especially the second one. Not long after the blood had been shed, the courtroom was flooded with tears due to the acquittal, and so many men and women ran to him at once, embracing him with brotherly feelings, that Darnay, after that tedious and long imprisonment, felt he might collapse from exhaustion; on the other hand, he knew very well that the same crowd, if swept by a different current, would have rushed at him with the same intensity to tear him to pieces and scatter him in the streets.
