es: Then followed one of those extraordinary scenes that highlight the fickleness of the mob, or the impulses towards generosity and pity, dormant in the depths of their soul, or what they consider to be a demonstration that they are not carried away by the explosive force of cruel rage. It is impossible to determine which of these three motives decisively influenced the extraordinary scenes that followed; probably all three influenced, with the second one predominating. The fact is that, as soon as the acquittal was pronounced, tears flowed as abundantly as blood had on other occasions, and the prisoner received so many and such tight embraces from everyone, regardless of gender, that he was in real danger of his prolonged captivity ending in a full-blown suffocation; it is noteworthy that these embraces were given by the same people who, driven by a different current, would have pounced on him with the same intensity to tear him apart with their nails and drag his palpitating remains through the streets.

en: His removal, to make way for other accused persons who were to be tried, rescued him from these caresses for the moment. Five were to be tried together, next, as enemies of the Republic, forasmuch as they had not assisted it by word or deed. So quick was the Tribunal to compensate itself and the nation for a chance lost, that these five came down to him before he left the place, condemned to die within twenty-four hours. The first of them told him so, with the customary prison sign of Death—a raised finger—and they all added in words, “Long live the Republic!”
vi: He temporarily escaped from those tight embraces as he had to make way for other defendants to be tried. After that, five people were tried for the same crime of being enemies of the Republic, because they did not support it by word or deed. Having missed the opportunity to execute Charles Darnay, the court compensated itself and the nation with another opportunity that came so quickly that before he left the court, the five new defendants had been sentenced to death within twenty-four hours. The first in this group let him know by raising one finger - the familiar prison sign for death - and all five exclaimed, "Long live the Republic!".
tr: When they took Darnay out to make room for the other prisoners to be tried, he was freed from all those embraces. The next five people were to be tried collectively as enemies of the Republic, for they had neither supported the Republic in word nor in deed. The court, as if eager to quickly make up for the gap and this national loss, decided that these five men, who were brought in before Darnay even left the hall, would be executed within twenty-four hours. The foremost prisoner conveyed this decision to Darnay with the death sign that had become customary in the prisons – by raising his finger – and they all shouted together, "Long live the Republic!"
es: Thanks to having to leave the room to make way for other defendants awaiting sentencing, he was able to escape for the moment from that overwhelming torrent of caresses. Next, five accused individuals appeared together, who were charged with being enemies of the Republic, not because they had worked against it, but because they had done nothing, neither in word nor deed, in its favor. The Tribunal hurried to compensate the nation for the freedom granted to one accused, so much so that he had not yet left the room when the death sentence already weighed upon the five unfortunate ones, to be executed within twenty-four hours. The first of the condemned indicated to Darnay the fate that awaited him by raising a finger, a symbol of death among the prisoners, and his companions shouted in unison with a sarcastic tone: —Long live the Republic!

en: The five had had, it is true, no audience to lengthen their proceedings, for when he and Doctor Manette emerged from the gate, there was a great crowd about it, in which there seemed to be every face he had seen in Court—except two, for which he looked in vain. On his coming out, the concourse made at him anew, weeping, embracing, and shouting, all by turns and all together, until the very tide of the river on the bank of which the mad scene was acted, seemed to run mad, like the people on the shore.
vi: In reality, there were no more spectators left to prolong the judgment, because when Charles and Dr. Manette exited the gate, they saw a dense crowd that seemed to include every face he had seen in the court - except for two faces he kept searching for but couldn't find. Seeing him come out, the crowd showered him with tears, embraces, and shouts, individually or in unison, to the point that the waters of the river next to the court seemed to go mad just like the people on the shore.
tr: In truth, these five people no longer had any spectators to prolong their trials, because the moment Darnay and Doctor Manette stepped out the door, a huge crowd accompanied them, and they were all the types seen in the courtroom – except for the two people Darnay had looked for in vain. As soon as they stepped outside, the crowd, with tearful eyes and shouting, surrounded them again, until the waters of the river, where this mad scene took place, swelled and overflowed, they pounced on them sometimes one by one, sometimes in groups.
es: It is true that Darnay did not have more time to listen to the explanations that the condemned could or wished to give him, for no sooner had he stepped out into the street in the company of Doctor Manette than he found himself surrounded by a dense crowd, in which he saw almost all the faces he had seen before in the courtroom, with the exception of two, which he searched for in vain with his eyes. Once again, he was enveloped by the furious whirlwind that had earlier nearly suffocated him, as they kissed him, embraced him, cried, shouted, and gave themselves over to other outbursts more fitting for madmen than for sane people.

en: They put him into a great chair they had among them, and which they had taken either out of the Court itself, or one of its rooms or passages. Over the chair they had thrown a red flag, and to the back of it they had bound a pike with a red cap on its top. In this car of triumph, not even the Doctor’s entreaties could prevent his being carried to his home on men’s shoulders, with a confused sea of red caps heaving about him, and casting up to sight from the stormy deep such wrecks of faces, that he more than once misdoubted his mind being in confusion, and that he was in the tumbril on his way to the Guillotine.
vi: They placed him on a large armchair in the midst of the crowd, the chair they had taken from the courtroom, or from a room or hallway of the court. On the chair, they had draped a red flag, and behind the chair, they had tied a spear with a red cap on it. Despite the doctor's pleas, the crowd still carried Charles shoulder-high on this triumphal chair, surrounded by a chaotic sea of red caps surging like wild waves, throwing into his view drifting faces, making him several times feel as if he too had lost his mind and was being taken on a cart to meet La Guillotine.
tr: They seated Darnay on a rather large chair that must have been found either in the courtroom, one of the rooms of the courthouse, or one of its corridors. They had draped a red flag over the chair and tied a spear with a red cap at its end to the back of it. While he was on this triumphal chariot, not even the Doctor's pleas could prevent him from being carried on shoulders all the way to his home, and when he saw those excited faces rising from the depths and reaching a crescendo in the sea of red caps swirling around him, Darnay's mind became confused and disoriented, and he felt as though he were in an execution cart on the way to the guillotine.
es: They forcefully sat him down in a large armchair that they had either taken from the Tribunal's hall or from one of the nearby houses. They adorned the armchair with a red flag and a spear whose iron tip displayed a red cap. All the doctor's pleas were not enough to prevent him from being triumphantly carried to his house, seated in that armchair which, borne on shoulders, resembled a throne placed upon a turbulent sea of red caps.

en: In wild dreamlike procession, embracing whom they met and pointing him out, they carried him on. Reddening the snowy streets with the prevailing Republican colour, in winding and tramping through them, as they had reddened them below the snow with a deeper dye, they carried him thus into the courtyard of the building where he lived. Her father had gone on before, to prepare her, and when her husband stood upon his feet, she dropped insensible in his arms.
vi: In that nightmarish procession, the crowd carried Charles and embraced anyone they met on the way, pointing towards him. The snow-covered streets were filled with the red of the Republic, as if stained with blood, as the winding procession marched on, carrying Darnay all the way to the courtyard of the family house. Dr. Manette had gone ahead to inform Lucie, and when her husband stepped down to stand on the ground, she fainted in his arms.
tr: They continued this dreamlike wild procession, hugging everyone they encountered and showing them Darnay. They wound their way through those snowy streets, which they had previously painted a deep red, and this time carried him to the courtyard of the house where he lived, painting everything in the color of the Republic. His father had gone to the house earlier to prepare his daughter, and when Lucie saw her husband in front of her, she let herself fall into his arms.
es: Getting ahead of that wild procession, which embraced everyone it encountered on the way, the doctor arrived at his house in order to properly prepare his daughter. Nevertheless, when Carlos was able to descend from his improvised throne and opened his arms to his beloved wife, she fainted in them.

en: As he held her to his heart and turned her beautiful head between his face and the brawling crowd, so that his tears and her lips might come together unseen, a few of the people fell to dancing. Instantly, all the rest fell to dancing, and the courtyard overflowed with the Carmagnole. Then, they elevated into the vacant chair a young woman from the crowd to be carried as the Goddess of Liberty, and then swelling and overflowing out into the adjacent streets, and along the river’s bank, and over the bridge, the Carmagnole absorbed them every one and whirled them away.
vi: While Charles held his wife tightly in his arms and turned her face towards him so that no one could see his tears and their lips met, a few people in the crowd began to dance. Immediately, the remaining people also started dancing, and the courtyard was filled with the Carmagnole dance. Then, they placed a girl from the crowd on an empty chair to carry her like a Goddess of Liberty, and the throng surged into the nearby streets, along the riverbank, across the bridge, and the Carmagnole dance captivated everyone, sweeping them away like a whirlwind.
tr: When Darnay pressed his wife to his heart and turned her beautiful head so that their lips, joined by his own tears, would not be seen by the crowd, a group of people began to dance. Then the others also started to dance, and the courtyard was suddenly filled with the enthusiasm of the carmagnole. Later, they seated a young woman from the crowd on the empty chair as the "goddess of liberty" and carried her through the streets with the same enthusiasm, flowing from there to the riverbank, and then to the bridge, spinning everyone they encountered into the carmagnole.
es: While Darnay held Lucie, supporting her against his chest, her head bent so that the crowd would not see the copious tears running down her cheeks, some of those who had carried him in triumph began to dance, the others caught on, and seconds later an unrestrained Carmagnole was improvised in the courtyard of the house. Later, they installed a young woman on the vacant chair, proclaiming her the Goddess of Liberty, carrying her on their shoulders through the adjacent streets, amidst deafening shouts and discordant songs.

en: After grasping the Doctor’s hand, as he stood victorious and proud before him; after grasping the hand of Mr. Lorry, who came panting in breathless from his struggle against the waterspout of the Carmagnole; after kissing little Lucie, who was lifted up to clasp her arms round his neck; and after embracing the ever zealous and faithful Pross who lifted her; he took his wife in his arms, and carried her up to their rooms.
vi: After tightly holding Dr. Manette's hand while he stood proudly and triumphantly beside him; after tightly holding Mr. Lorry's hand as he breathlessly ran up, escaping the flood of the Carmagnole; after kissing little Lucie who was lifted high to embrace her father's neck; and after hugging the loyal and eager Miss Pross who was holding little Lucie; Charles held Lucie in his arms and guided his wife upstairs.
tr: After shaking hands firmly with Mr. Lorry, who was breathless from the struggle to resist the cannagnole flood, and standing before him with a triumphant and proud demeanor, Charles Darnay kissed little Lucie, who had been lifted up to hug him, embraced the sturdy and loyal Miss Pross who had lifted her, and then carried his wife in his arms to their rooms.
es: Carlos, after embracing the doctor, whose face bore the look of a victor, after hugging Mr. Lorry, who, panting and breathless, managed to reach him by swimming against the immense wave that danced the Carmagnole, after kissing Lucita, whom he lifted from the ground so she could wrap her little arms around his neck, after hugging the faithful Pross, lifted Lucía in his arms and carried her to her rooms.

en: “Lucie! My own! I am safe.”
vi: − Lucie! My love! I am safe.
tr: "Lucie! My darling! I am free now.""
es: —Lucía... my Lucía... Free... Free!... —Oh my dear Carlos! Allow me, kneeling, to give thanks to God with the same fervor with which I prayed for you!

en: “O dearest Charles, let me thank God for this on my knees as I have prayed to Him.”
vi: − Oh dear Charles, let me kneel down to thank God as I have been praying for a long time.
tr: "Ah Charles, my love, after all my pleading, now I will kneel and give thanks to God.""
es: Lucía fell to her knees.

en: They all reverently bowed their heads and hearts. When she was again in his arms, he said to her:
vi: They sincerely bowed their heads in prayer. When Lucie had returned to his arms, Charles said to her: "It's all thanks to your father, my love."
tr: They all bowed their heads with respect and placed their hands on their hearts. When Darnay took Lucie into his arms again, he said to her;
es: All those present bowed their heads reverently and prayed from the depths of their hearts. When, the prayer finished, Lucía returned to his arms, Carlos said.

en: “And now speak to your father, dearest. No other man in all this France could have done what he has done for me.”
vi: When Lucie had returned to his arms, Charles said to her: "It's all thanks to your father, my love." Throughout all of France, no one could do what your father has done for me.
tr: "Now pray for your father, my love. No one in France would do what he did for me," she said.
es: —Now thank your father, my little woman! No man in France could have done as much for me as he has!

en: She laid her head upon her father’s breast, as she had laid his poor head on her own breast, long, long ago. He was happy in the return he had made her, he was recompensed for his suffering, he was proud of his strength. “You must not be weak, my darling,” he remonstrated; “don’t tremble so. I have saved him.”
vi: She rested her head on her father's chest, just like in the old days, long ago when she had held him in her arms. Dr. Manette was very happy to repay what Lucie had done for him; all the past sufferings were now compensated, and he was proud of his strength: − Don't be so weak, my dear, - he gently chided, - don't tremble like that. I have saved Charles.
tr: Long ago, just as she had rested her poor father's head on her chest, this time Lucie rested her head on her father's chest. The doctor was happy that he could do this for his daughter; he had paid the price for his suffering and was proud of the strength he possessed. "Pull yourself together now, my dear," he said, as if reproaching her; "what is there to be so afraid of? I saved him, didn't I."
es: Lucía rested her head on her father's chest, just as she had done many years before. The doctor considered himself happy to be able to repay in some way the selfless affection shown by his daughter, deemed all his sufferings worthwhile, and felt a noble pride when thinking of his strength. —Be strong in prosperity as you were in the storm, my daughter. Do not tremble... Do not cry. I have saved him.

en: CHAPTER VII.
vi: I have saved Charles.
tr: VII
es: VII.

en: A Knock at the Door
vi: 7. The sound of knocking "I have saved Charles."
tr: The Door is Knocking
es: UNEXPECTED VISIT

en: I have saved him.” It was not another of the dreams in which he had often come back; he was really here. And yet his wife trembled, and a vague but heavy fear was upon her.
vi: 7. The sound of knocking "I have saved Charles." It was not another dream like the ones Charles often had of being free; he was truly here. Yet Lucie still trembled in a vague but heavy fear.
tr: "I saved him, that's it." This wasn't one of the dreams he often had; Charles was really beside them. His wife, however, was still trembling and had a vague but intense fear inside her.
es: UNEXPECTED VISIT It was not a dream like so many other times; there was Carlos, and yet, his wife trembled, seized by a vague but intense terror.

en: All the air round was so thick and dark, the people were so passionately revengeful and fitful, the innocent were so constantly put to death on vague suspicion and black malice, it was so impossible to forget that many as blameless as her husband and as dear to others as he was to her, every day shared the fate from which he had been clutched, that her heart could not be as lightened of its load as she felt it ought to be. The shadows of the wintry afternoon were beginning to fall, and even now the dreadful carts were rolling through the streets. Her mind pursued them, looking for him among the Condemned; and then she clung closer to his real presence and trembled more.
vi: The atmosphere around them was dark and dense, with the populace bloodthirsty for revenge and impulsive, causing innocent people to constantly lose their lives due to baseless suspicions and dark malice. How could Lucie forget that so many innocent people like her husband, loved by so many dear ones, faced the same fragile fate as Charles every day? With that thought, how could her heart ease this fear? The winter evening darkness had begun to fall, and even now, the terrifying carriages were still rolling through the streets. Her mind thought of the people sitting in those carriages, imagining her husband among the convicted; she nestled closer to her present husband and trembled even more.
tr: The weather was so foggy and dark, people were so filled with intense hatred and fickleness, innocent people were being sent to death so frequently due to a small suspicion or sheer malice, and it was so impossible to forget that every day many men, who were as innocent as their husbands and as valuable to their wives as their husbands, were experiencing the same fate as their husbands, that Lucie's heart could not lighten as much as she had hoped. The shadows of the winter noon had begun to fall, and even now those dreadful carts were rumbling through the streets. Her mind drifted there, and her eyes searched for her husband among the convicts; then she clung to the body right next to her and shivered a little more.
es: The atmosphere was so black and corrupted, the people were so brutally vengeful and cruel, the innocent who had the misfortune to inspire any suspicion, however vague, or to awaken malice, were taken to the slaughterhouse with such terrible regularity, it was so impossible to forget how many, as free of guilt as her husband, and as idolized by their loved ones as Charles was by Lucie, fell to the blows that Dr. Manette's son-in-law had managed to evade, that the heart of his afflicted wife could not free itself from the horrible weight that oppressed it. The shadows of the winter evening twilight began to envelop the city, and the fateful carts of death continued to roll through the streets. With her imagination, Lucie followed them, the eyes of her soul searched for her husband among the condemned, and seeing him with her fleshly eyes by her side, she clung to him and trembled more than ever.

en: Her father, cheering her, showed a compassionate superiority to this woman’s weakness, which was wonderful to see. No garret, no shoemaking, no One Hundred and Five, North Tower, now! He had accomplished the task he had set himself, his promise was redeemed, he had saved Charles. Let them all lean upon him.
vi: Her father, while encouraging his daughter, displayed a hidden strength far more powerful than Lucie's weakness - a truly wonderful image. No more the attic in the Saint Antoine district, no more the meticulous shoemaking, no more the One Hundred and Five North Tower cell! He had completed the self-imposed task, kept his promise, and saved Charles. Everyone relied on him.
tr: His father, who was trying to cheer him up, showed such a loving strength in response to this woman's weakness that it was wonderful to see. Now there was neither the attic, nor the shoemaking, nor the One Hundred and Five North Tower! He had accomplished the task he had set his mind to, kept his promise, and saved Charles. They could now trust him in every matter.
es: Her father, striving to calm her, laughing at her fears, showed signs of an admirable compassionate superiority, of a manly fortitude that contrasted with the womanly weakness of his daughter. The attic, the shoemaker's bench, the old man who spent his days sewing shoes, the One Hundred Five, North Tower, were past events of which no traces remained. He had successfully completed the endeavor he had undertaken with manly courage, he had fulfilled his promise, Carlos was free, why fear? The doctor had more than enough strength to serve as a robust support for all those who felt their own waning.

en: Their housekeeping was of a very frugal kind: not only because that was the safest way of life, involving the least offence to the people, but because they were not rich, and Charles, throughout his imprisonment, had had to pay heavily for his bad food, and for his guard, and towards the living of the poorer prisoners. Partly on this account, and partly to avoid a domestic spy, they kept no servant; the citizen and citizeness who acted as porters at the courtyard gate, rendered them occasional service; and Jerry (almost wholly transferred to them by Mr. Lorry) had become their daily retainer, and had his bed there every night.
vi: They lived very frugally; not only because it was the safest way of life, causing the least discomfort to the people around them, but also because they were not wealthy; and Charles, during his imprisonment, had to spend a lot of money on terrible meals, on guards, and on poorer fellow prisoners. Partly because of this, and partly to avoid harboring spies in the house, they had no servants; they only occasionally asked the male and female Citizens guarding the outer courtyard for a bit of help; Jerry (Mr. Lorry had almost entirely entrusted him to the Manette family) became their daily attendant and stayed there every night.
tr: They managed the house in a very frugal manner; not because it was the safest way to live or because it prevented them from despising people, but because they had no money, and during Charles's imprisonment, he had spent a lot of money on the bad food given to him, for his guard, and for other poorer prisoners. Both for this reason and to avoid having a spy in the house, they did not hire a servant; only the citizens, one woman and one man, who were occasionally on duty at the gate of the courtyard, served them; Jerry (whom Mr. Lorry had completely put at their disposal) took care of their daily chores and stayed with them at night.
es: The furnishings of their house could not be more modest; not only because prudence advised it so, to avoid hurting the poverty of the people, but also because they were not rich, for Carlos, during the extended period of his captivity, had to pay an exorbitant price for food, the allowances of his guards, and a proportional part to cover the expenses of prisoners poorer than himself. Due in part to the aforementioned reasons, and in part to avoid the danger of being spied on within their own home, they had no servants. The citizen and the citizeness in charge of the porter’s lodge provided the necessary services to the family if circumstances required it, apart from Jeremiah, who had been almost entirely given to them by the good Lorry, and was at their disposal during the day and slept in the house at night.

en: It was an ordinance of the Republic One and Indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, that on the door or doorpost of every house, the name of every inmate must be legibly inscribed in letters of a certain size, at a certain convenient height from the ground. Mr. Jerry Cruncher’s name, therefore, duly embellished the doorpost down below; and, as the afternoon shadows deepened, the owner of that name himself appeared, from overlooking a painter whom Doctor Manette had employed to add to the list the name of Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay.
vi: According to the regulations of the Unified Indivisible Republic of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death, the name of every person living inside must be clearly written on the door or doorpost of every house in a certain font size, at a certain convenient distance from the ground. Therefore, Jerry Cruncher's name was duly inscribed on the doorpost of his house; and as dusk fell, the owner of that name appeared, keeping an eye on the painter whom Dr. Manette had hired to add to that list the name of Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay.
tr: "The Republic is One and Indivisible. According to the decree of 'Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death,' the name of the residents of each house had to be engraved on the door or side of the house, in letters of a certain size, at a certain height from the ground, and in a legible manner. Thus, the name of Mr. Jerry Cruncher also adorned the bottom of the list as required, and when the shadows began to lengthen in the afternoon, the owner of this name appeared, observing the painter whom Doctor Manette had assigned the task of adding the name Charles Evremonde, also known as Darnay, to the list.
es: The Republic One and Indivisible of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death had decreed that above the doors of all houses, at a specified height, there should be a large signboard on which the names of all the inhabitants of the house would be inscribed in letters of a specified size. As a result, among the names inscribed on the signboard placed on the door of the doctor's residence was that of Jeremiah Lapa, and on the occasion referred to in this story, not only the name but also the owner of the name was standing by the door, watching the painter called by Doctor Manette to add the name of Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, to the signboard.

en: In the universal fear and distrust that darkened the time, all the usual harmless ways of life were changed. In the Doctor’s little household, as in very many others, the articles of daily consumption that were wanted were purchased every evening, in small quantities and at various small shops. To avoid attracting notice, and to give as little occasion as possible for talk and envy, was the general desire.
vi: In the fear and suspicion that enveloped that dark era, all harmless and normal ways of living changed. In the doctor's family, as in every other household, essential daily items were bought in the evening, in small quantities from various shops. Everyone wanted to avoid drawing attention, the less opportunity for others to envy and gossip, the better.
tr: In the universal fear and insecurity that darkened the era, all harmless lifestyles had changed. In the doctor's small house, as in many other houses, all the necessities for the next day were bought in small amounts from various small shops every evening. The important thing was not to attract attention, to avoid gossip and jealousy.
es: The atmosphere of terror and distrust in which people lived had profoundly altered even the most innocent and harmless habits of life. In the doctor's house, as in almost all the others, essential and daily consumption items were bought every afternoon in small quantities and from different small shops. It was the way to avoid attracting attention and to provide the least possible occasion for gossip and envy.

en: For some months past, Miss Pross and Mr. Cruncher had discharged the office of purveyors; the former carrying the money; the latter, the basket. Every afternoon at about the time when the public lamps were lighted, they fared forth on this duty, and made and brought home such purchases as were needful. Although Miss Pross, through her long association with a French family, might have known as much of their language as of her own, if she had had a mind, she had no mind in that direction; consequently she knew no more of that “nonsense” (as she was pleased to call it) than Mr. Cruncher did. So her manner of marketing was to plump a noun-substantive at the head of a shopkeeper without any introduction in the nature of an article, and, if it happened not to be the name of the thing she wanted, to look round for that thing, lay hold of it, and hold on by it until the bargain was concluded. She always made a bargain for it, by holding up, as a statement of its just price, one finger less than the merchant held up, whatever his number might be.
vi: For the past few months, Miss Pross and Cruncher have been entrusted with shopping; Miss Pross carries the money; Cruncher carries the basket. Every afternoon when the streetlights are lit, they go out to perform their duty and bring home such essential goods. Although Miss Pross has been in a French family for a long time, she could have been as proficient in French as in English if she wanted to learn; but she had no such intention, so in the end, regarding that "gibberish" language (as she often called it), she was no better than Cruncher. Therefore, her way of shopping was to throw the name of the item at the shopkeeper's head, regardless of the masculine or feminine article that should precede it, and if it was not the name of the item she needed, she would look around for it, grab it, and hold onto it until the price was settled. She always bargained by holding up a few fingers to indicate her price, always one finger less than the number of fingers the shopkeeper indicated, regardless of the actual price.
tr: For a few months, Miss Pross and Mr. Cruncher had been buying the provisions; Miss Pross carried the money, and the other carried the basket. Every evening when the street lamps were lit, they would set out to perform this duty, and after purchasing the necessary provisions, they would bring them home. Although Miss Pross had been with a French family for a long time, she couldn't speak French at all; yet, if she had a bit of sense, she could speak it as if it were her native language; after all, (in her own words) she knew no more about this "nonsense" than Mr. Cruncher did. Therefore, upon entering the shop, she had developed a way of shopping where she would say the first word that came to mind without knowing what it meant; if that thing wasn't what she wanted, she would look around with this item in her hand and not put it down until the bargaining was over. She would always negotiate while holding this item, and regardless of the price, she would always indicate one finger less than the price the merchant indicated with his fingers.
es: For several months prior, Miss Pross and Jeremiah Lapa had been in charge of the shopping; the latter carried the basket, the former the money. Every evening, when the streetlights were lit, both would go out and bring back the necessary consumables for the following day. Although Miss Pross, given the many years she had lived with a French family, seemed like she should speak French with as much correctness and fluency as English, she knew exactly as much as Jeremiah Lapa, who didn't know a single word, and that was either she lacked the talent or she didn't want to apply it to nonsense (as she called it) like that. As a result, her commercial system consisted of firing a noun point-blank as soon as she faced the shopkeeper, and if the noun didn't match the item she needed, as was almost always the case, she would look around, grab the item, and not let go until the deal was closed. As for the price, it was understood without difficulty by raising one finger less than the shopkeeper, regardless of the number of fingers he raised.

en: “Now, Mr. Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose eyes were red with felicity; “if you are ready, I am.”
vi: − "Mr. Cruncher," said Miss Pross, her eyes red from tears of joy, "if you are ready, then I am done."
tr: Miss Pross, her eyes red with happiness, said, "Well Mr. Cruncher, if you're ready, let's go.""
es: —Mr. Lapa—said Miss Pross, whose eyes sparkled with happiness,—I am ready; and you?

en: Jerry hoarsely professed himself at Miss Pross’s service. He had worn all his rust off long ago, but nothing would file his spiky head down.
vi: Jerry hoarsely declared his willingness to serve Miss Pross. He had long since rid his fingers of the smell of rust, but nothing could tame his bristling hair.
tr: Jerry joined Miss Pross in a hoarse voice. The rust color on his hands had long gone, but nothing could blunt his spiky hair.
es: Jeremiah replied that he was at Miss Pross's service.

en: “There’s all manner of things wanted,” said Miss Pross, “and we shall have a precious time of it. We want wine, among the rest. Nice toasts these Redheads will be drinking, wherever we buy it.”
vi: − We need to buy so many things, - Miss Pross said, - and we have so little time. We also need to buy wine. Everywhere we buy wine, we encounter Red Caps toasting.
tr: "We have a lot of things to get," said Miss Pross, "it will take quite some time. We also need to get some wine. No matter where we get it from, these red-capped people are toasting everywhere."
es: —Today we are in need of everything,—observed Miss Pross,—and among other things, wine. A tough time awaits us. Wherever we buy it, we are bound to find plenty of red caps toasting like the damned.

en: “It will be much the same to your knowledge, miss, I should think,” retorted Jerry, “whether they drink your health or the Old Un’s.”
vi: − As for you, I think it doesn't matter what we drink to celebrate, - Jerry retorted, - whether they toast to you or to an old brain.
tr: Jerry immediately responded, "Whether they drink to your health or the old man's, I think it all comes down to the same thing for you, Miss."
es: —They don't break their heads too much to come up with their toasts—observed Jeremías. —I always hear them toast for the same thing; for the One.

en: “Who’s he?” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Which old man? - Miss Pross asked. −
tr: "Who is the old man?" said Miss Pross.
es: —And who is that one? —Who knows.

en: Mr. Cruncher, with some diffidence, explained himself as meaning “Old Nick’s.”
vi: The Satan himself, - Cruncher stammered in explanation.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, somewhat hesitantly, said, "Old Nick."
es: Unless they are referring to Noah... the one who planted the first vineyard...

en: “Ha!” said Miss Pross, “it doesn’t need an interpreter to explain the meaning of these creatures. They have but one, and it’s Midnight Murder, and Mischief.”
vi: − Ah! - Miss Pross said. - But with that lot, no explanation is needed to understand. They are nothing but darkness, murder, and destruction.
tr: Miss Pross said, "Haa! There is no need to explain what these men are up to. They have only one occupation, which is to kill people and cause trouble at midnight."
es: —Ah... I see! You don't have to be very wise to understand who those wretches are toasting to. They are toasting to the Killer... to the Evil One.

en: “Hush, dear! Pray, pray, be cautious!” cried Lucie.
vi: − Shh, sister! Mind your words! - Lucie exclaimed. −
tr: "Shh! Please, please be careful, dear!" Lucie shouted.
es: —Careful, my friend!—interjected Lucía—Caution, please, a lot of caution!

en: “Yes, yes, yes, I’ll be cautious,” said Miss Pross; “but I may say among ourselves, that I do hope there will be no oniony and tobaccoey smotherings in the form of embracings all round, going on in the streets. Now, Ladybird, never you stir from that fire till I come back! Take care of the dear husband you have recovered, and don’t move your pretty head from his shoulder as you have it now, till you see me again! May I ask a question, Doctor Manette, before I go?”
vi: Yes, yes, yes, I will be careful, - Miss Pross said, - but we can speak privately that I hope not to see those people reeking of onions and tobacco hugging each other all over the streets anymore. Now, dear mistress, you must sit by the fireplace without moving and wait for me to return! Take care of your husband who has just come back, and keep your beautiful head steady on your neck, not moving like it is now, and wait for me to return! Doctor Manette, may I ask you a question before I go? − I think you may ask freely. -
tr: "Alright, alright, I'll be careful," said Miss Pross; "between you and me, I hope we don't run into any types on the road whose breath smells like onions and tobacco. Now my little bird, don't get up from this fire until I return, okay? Take good care of your husband until I come back and keep that beautiful head of yours, just like now, resting on his shoulder! Before I leave, may I ask you something, Mr. Manette?"
es: —Yes, yes, yes! I will be very prudent; but it seems to me that among us I can say that it is not very pleasant to receive sighs that reek of onions, liquor, and tobacco, mixed with hugs, on those streets. I am going out; but do not move from beside the fire until I return, my dear young lady. Take care of the husband you have recovered and fear nothing. May I ask a question before leaving, Doctor?

en: “I think you may take that liberty,” the Doctor answered, smiling.
vi: The doctor replied with a smile.
tr: The Doctor replied with a smile, "Of course, it's your right."
es: —I think you can take that liberty—replied the doctor with a humorous tone.

en: “For gracious sake, don’t talk about Liberty; we have quite enough of that,” said Miss Pross.
vi: − Oh heavens, don't mention the word freedom; we are tired of hearing it, - said Miss Pross.
tr: "For God's sake, don't talk to me about justice; I hear enough about it already," said Miss Pross.
es: —For all the saints in Heaven, do not speak of freedom, doctor. I am fed up with freedom—exclaimed Pross.

en: “Hush, dear! Again?” Lucie remonstrated.
vi: − Shh, there she goes again! - Lucie scolded.
tr: Luice, "Hush! Again, my dear?" she reproached.
es: —For God's sake, dear; again?—said Lucía.

en: “Well, my sweet,” said Miss Pross, nodding her head emphatically, “the short and the long of it is, that I am a subject of His Most Gracious Majesty King George the Third;” Miss Pross curtseyed at the name; “and as such, my maxim is, Confound their politics, Frustrate their knavish tricks, On him our hopes we fix, God save the King!”
vi: − All right, dear, - said Miss Pross, nodding emphatically, - in short, I am a British subject of His Gracious Majesty King George the Third, - she curtsied as she mentioned the king's name, - and therefore, my motto is "Crush the plotting, thwart the scheming, hope of the people, God save the King*".
tr: Miss Pross nodded her head vigorously forward, "Alright darling," she said, "in short, I am loyal to His Majesty King George III." Miss Pross had curtsied as she mentioned the king's name, "and as I always say, may their policies fail, their deceitful schemes collapse, and subsequently may we achieve our hopes, God save the King!"
es: —Well, miss—replied Pross, shaking her head solemnly;—if you want me to say what I feel, I will declare that I, as a subject of His Gracious Majesty King George III, laugh at those ragamuffins. My maxim is: "Cursed be their politics by God; may God thwart their criminal purposes; in God I trust, and long live the King."

en: Mr. Cruncher, in an access of loyalty, growlingly repeated the words after Miss Pross, like somebody at church.
vi: To show his loyalty, Cruncher also growled and repeated those words after Miss Pross, as if he were in church.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, with a faithful demeanor and a gruff voice, as if he were in church, repeated Miss Pross's words.
es: Lapa, in a burst of loyalty to his sovereign, repeated the cheer in a stentorian voice.

en: “I am glad you have so much of the Englishman in you, though I wish you had never taken that cold in your voice,” said Miss Pross, approvingly. “But the question, Doctor Manette. Is there”—it was the good creature’s way to affect to make light of anything that was a great anxiety with them all, and to come at it in this chance manner—“is there any prospect yet, of our getting out of this place?”
vi: − I am glad that you still have plenty of English blood in you, although I hope you haven't caught such a cold that you are hoarse, - Miss Pross said with satisfaction. - But the question is, Dr. Manette, is... - This kind-hearted person always has a way of addressing things casually as if they were nothing, even when everyone else considers them very serious, - ... do we have any prospects of leaving this place yet?
tr: "I'm glad you're a true Englishwoman, but of course, I wish you hadn't caught a cold and lost your voice," said Miss Pross approvingly. "But Doctor Manette, my question to you is this. Is there" –she was trying to shed a light of hope on a matter that worried everyone– "is there any chance of us getting out of here?"
es: —I celebrate that you are a true Englishman, Mr. Lapa,—said Miss Pross with an approving tone,—although it would have been desirable if you hadn't put so much energy into your shout. But let's get to the question, Doctor; haven't you yet found a way to leave this damned city forever?

en: “I fear not yet. It would be dangerous for Charles yet.”
vi: − I'm afraid not, it's still dangerous for Charles. − Oh my!
tr: "Unfortunately, there is no more. This could still be dangerous for Charles."
es: But let's get to the question, Doctor; haven't you yet found a way to leave this damned city forever? —No, for now; going out under these circumstances would be dangerous for Carlos.

en: “Heigh-ho-hum!” said Miss Pross, cheerfully repressing a sigh as she glanced at her darling’s golden hair in the light of the fire, “then we must have patience and wait: that’s all. We must hold up our heads and fight low, as my brother Solomon used to say. Now, Mr. Cruncher!—Don’t you move, Ladybird!”
vi: - Miss Pross cheerfully suppressed a sigh while glancing at her beloved mistress's golden hair by the fireplace. - Then we just have to be patient and wait, that's all. We have to hold our heads high and endure, as my brother Solomon often says. Let's go, Mr. Cruncher!... And you, my dear mistress, don't fidget!
tr: Miss Pross, looking at the golden hair of her sweet child shining in the fireplace, sighed deeply and said, "Well, what can we do!" "Then there's nothing to do but to be patient and wait, as my brother Solomon said, we will hold our heads high and fight." "Come on, Mr. Cruncher! –You stay right where you are, my little bird!""
es: —What can you do!—exclaimed Miss Pross, holding back a sigh and looking at Lucie. —We will have patience and wait... Courage, and let the storm rage over the neighbor's head, as my brother Solomon used to say. Let's go now, Mr. Lorry... Don't move, miss.

en: They went out, leaving Lucie, and her husband, her father, and the child, by a bright fire. Mr. Lorry was expected back presently from the Banking House. Miss Pross had lighted the lamp, but had put it aside in a corner, that they might enjoy the fire-light undisturbed. Little Lucie sat by her grandfather with her hands clasped through his arm: and he, in a tone not rising much above a whisper, began to tell her a story of a great and powerful Fairy who had opened a prison-wall and let out a captive who had once done the Fairy a service. All was subdued and quiet, and Lucie was more at ease than she had been.
vi: The two left, leaving Lucie, her husband, her father, and the child by the bright fireplace. The whole family was expecting Mr. Lorry to visit soon after finishing his work at the bank. Miss Pross had lit the lamp but placed it in the corner so they could enjoy the firelight undisturbed. Little Lucie sat beside her grandfather, her small hands holding his arm; and Dr. Manette, in an almost whispering voice, began to tell her the story of a wonderful fairy who broke through the prison walls to rescue a prisoner who had once helped her. All around was quiet and peaceful, and Lucie felt more at ease than ever. − What is that? -
tr: They left Lucie, her husband, her father, and her child by the bright fire and went out. Mr. Lorry would arrive from the bank shortly. Miss Pross had lit the lamp, but she had placed it in a distant corner so they could enjoy the fireplace. Little Lucie sat next to her grandfather and held his arm tightly, and her grandfather began to tell, in a whispering voice, the story of a great and powerful fairy who had done him a favor beforehand by opening the wall of a prison and freeing a prisoner. A sense of tranquility enveloped everything, and Lucie felt much more at ease.
es: The Pross and Lapa left, leaving Lucía, her husband, the doctor, and Lucita sitting by the warmth of the fire. They were expecting Mr. Lorry to arrive at any moment. Miss Pross had lit a light, but she placed it in a corner so that the family could exclusively enjoy the faint light radiating from the fireplace. Lucita, sitting on her grandfather's knee, was listening to the story of a great and powerful fairy who once broke the strong walls of a dungeon to free a captive who had once rendered a service to the fairy.

en: “What is that?” she cried, all at once.
vi: She suddenly exclaimed.
tr: "What was that?" he suddenly shouted.
es: —What is that? —Lucía suddenly exclaimed.

en: “My dear!” said her father, stopping in his story, and laying his hand on hers, “command yourself. What a disordered state you are in! The least thing—nothing—startles you! You, your father’s daughter!”
vi: − My dear! - Her father said, pausing his story and holding Lucie's hand, Calm down. Why are you so startled! Even the smallest things... things that mean nothing... can make you jump! You, my daughter! −
tr: The father paused his story, took his daughter's hand, and said, "Calm down, my dear. How tense you are! Such things –nothing– should not scare you! You are your father's daughter!"
es: —My dear!—replied the doctor, pausing the story—Calm yourself. Your nervous disorder is extraordinary. The most insignificant thing... even without any reason... alarms you. You have me... your father, my daughter.

en: “I thought, my father,” said Lucie, excusing herself, with a pale face and in a faltering voice, “that I heard strange feet upon the stairs.”
vi: Father, I think that... - Lucie, pale-faced, stammered in defense, - ... I heard strange footsteps coming up the stairs.
tr: Lucie, with a pale face and a trembling voice, as if apologizing, said, "I thought I heard a footstep on the stairs, father."
es: —I thought I heard the sound of footsteps on the stairs—Lucía stammered.

en: “My love, the staircase is as still as Death.”
vi: − My dear, the stairs are as silent as a sheet.
tr: "My dear, the stairs are as silent as a dead person."
es: —Silly girl...! The staircase is as silent as a tomb.

en: As he said the word, a blow was struck upon the door.
vi: He had just finished speaking when there was a loud knock on the door.
tr: As soon as the doctor said this, a knock was heard at the door.
es: As the last word left his lips, there was a knock at the door.

en: “Oh father, father. What can this be! Hide Charles. Save him!”
vi: − Oh my God, father. What is happening! Hide Charles. Save him! −
tr: "Oh father, father. Who could this be! Hide Charles, save him!"
es: —Oh, father... my father! What could it be? Let Carlos hide...! Save him!

en: “My child,” said the Doctor, rising, and laying his hand upon her shoulder, “I have saved him. What weakness is this, my dear! Let me go to the door.”
vi: My child, - the doctor said as he stood up, placing his hand on Lucie's shoulder, I have already saved Charles. Why so weak, my dear! Let me go open the door and see.
tr: When the doctor stood up and placed his hand on his daughter's shoulder, he said, "My dear, I have already saved him." What is this weakness, my child! Let me go and check that door."
es: —Dear daughter!—replied the doctor, standing up and placing his hand on Lucía's shoulder. —I have already saved him. I don't understand your weakness... I'm going to open the door.

en: He took the lamp in his hand, crossed the two intervening outer rooms, and opened it. A rude clattering of feet over the floor, and four rough men in red caps, armed with sabres and pistols, entered the room.
vi: He held the lamp in his hand, crossed the two outer rooms that separated them, and opened the main door. The sound of heavy footsteps pounded on the floor, and four ruffians wearing red hats, armed with swords and pistols, entered the inner room.
tr: He took the lamp in his hand, passed through the two rooms in between, and opened the door. In front of the door, there were feet making clattering noises, and four rough men wearing red hats, armed with swords and pistols, rushed in immediately.
es: He took the candlestick in his hand, crossed the two intermediate rooms, and opened the door. Four men of wild appearance, covered with red caps and armed with sabers and pistols, entered the reception area, from where they proceeded to the room where the family was.

en: “The Citizen Evrémonde, called Darnay,” said the first.
vi: − Citizen Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, - the first one spoke. −
tr: "Where is the citizen Evremonde known as Darnay?" said the one in front.
es: "Citizen Evrémonde?" asked the one who entered first.

en: “Who seeks him?” answered Darnay.
vi: Who are you looking for? - Darnay responded.
tr: "Who is looking for him?" replied Darnay.
es: —Who is looking for him?—asked Darnay.

en: “I seek him. We seek him. I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you before the Tribunal to-day. You are again the prisoner of the Republic.”
vi: − I am looking for you. We are looking for you. I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you in court today. You are now once again a prisoner of the Republic.
tr: "I am searching. We are searching. I know you, Evremonde; I saw you before the court today. We are arresting you again in the name of the Republic."
es: —I... we will look for him. I know you, Evrémonde; I saw you yesterday in the Tribunal room. You are once again a prisoner of the Republic.

en: The four surrounded him, where he stood with his wife and child clinging to him.
vi: The four strangers surrounded the spot where Charles stood with his wife and child clinging to him. −
tr: All four of them immediately surrounded Darnay, who was tightly held by his wife and child.
es: The four men surrounded the group formed by Darnay, his wife, and their little daughter, who had embraced him.

en: “Tell me how and why am I again a prisoner?”
vi: Tell me why and how I am a prisoner? −
tr: "Can you tell me how and why I am being arrested again?"
es: —How and why am I a prisoner again?

en: “It is enough that you return straight to the Conciergerie, and will know to-morrow. You are summoned for to-morrow.”
vi: You only need to know that you must return to the Conciergerie prison immediately, and tomorrow it will be clear. Tomorrow you will be tried again.
tr: "You need to go straight to the Conciergerie, you will learn there. You will appear in court tomorrow."
es: —Come with us to the Consulate, and tomorrow you will be able to satisfy your curiosity. Tomorrow you must appear before the Court.

en: Doctor Manette, whom this visitation had so turned into stone, that he stood with the lamp in his hand, as if he were a statue made to hold it, moved after these words were spoken, put the lamp down, and confronting the speaker, and taking him, not ungently, by the loose front of his red woollen shirt, said:
vi: Dr. Manette was stunned by this visit, standing like a statue with the lamp in his hand. The words he just heard awakened him, he put down the lamp and faced the speaker, gently grasping the edge of this man's red coat: −
tr: Dr. Manette was so petrified by this visit that he stood holding the lamp as if he were a statue made to hold it, and upon hearing these words, he moved and placed the lamp on the ground; then he stood in front of the person who had spoken, and without being rude, he grabbed the loose collar of his red woolen shirt and said:
es: Dr. Manette, whom the unexpected visit had left in a perfectly astonished state, to the point of seeming like a statue with a candlestick in hand, shook off his stupor after hearing the last words, placed the candlestick on the mantelpiece, faced the one who was leading the conversation, and, grabbing him by the collar of his shirt, red like his cap, said:

en: “You know him, you have said. Do you know me?”
vi: You say you know this person. Do you know me?
tr: "You said you knew him. Do you know me then?"
es: —You said you know him; do you know me as well?

en: “Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor.”
vi: − Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor. −
tr: "Yes, I know you, Citizen Doctor."
es: —Yes; I know you, citizen doctor.

en: “We all know you, Citizen Doctor,” said the other three.
vi: We all know you, Citizen Doctor, - the other three also said.
tr: "We all know you, Citizen Doctor," said the other three as well.
es: —We all know you, citizen doctor—added the remaining three.

en: He looked abstractedly from one to another, and said, in a lower voice, after a pause:
vi: Mr. Manette looked dazedly from one person to another, then after a moment of silence, he softly asked: −
tr: After the doctor thoughtfully scrutinized them, he said in a low voice:
es: The old man let his gaze wander over the faces of the four men, and after a pause, he replied, lowering his voice:

en: “Will you answer his question to me then? How does this happen?”
vi: So, will you answer this question for me? How did this happen?
tr: "So, will you give me the answer to his question? How did this happen?"
es: —Do you want to answer me the question he asked you? Why does it catch on again?

en: “Citizen Doctor,” said the first, reluctantly, “he has been denounced to the Section of Saint Antoine. This citizen,” pointing out the second who had entered, “is from Saint Antoine.”
vi: − Citizen doctor, - the first person reluctantly said, - this person has been accused by the Saint Antoine district. This citizen is from Saint Antoine, - he pointed to the second person in the group.
tr: The man in front reluctantly said, "Citizen Doctor, this man has been denounced to the St Antoine district. This citizen," he said, pointing to the second man who had entered, "is from St Antoine."
es: —Citizen doctor,—replied the first speaker with evident repugnance,—he has been denounced by the San Antonio Section... to which this citizen belongs—he added, pointing with his hand to the individual who was beside him.

en: The citizen here indicated nodded his head, and added:
vi: The person who was addressed nodded and added: − He was accused by Saint Antoine.
tr: The indicated citizen nodded and added:
es: The mentioned citizen made an affirmative nod and said:

en: “He is accused by Saint Antoine.”
tr: "Found guilty by St Antoine.""
es: —He has been accused by San Antonio.

en: “Of what?” asked the Doctor.
vi: For what crime? - The doctor asked.
tr: "Why?" asked the Doctor.
es: —Of what?

en: “Citizen Doctor,” said the first, with his former reluctance, “ask no more. If the Republic demands sacrifices from you, without doubt you as a good patriot will be happy to make them. The Republic goes before all. The People is supreme. Evrémonde, we are pressed.”
vi: − Citizen doctor, - the first person said, still in that reluctant tone, - please don't ask anymore. If the Republic requires you to sacrifice, then surely you will be willing to sacrifice, if you are a good Citizen. The Republic is above all. The People are supreme. Evrémonde, let's go immediately.
tr: The man in front said reluctantly, "Citizen Doctor, don't ask any more questions. If the Republic asks you to make a sacrifice, a good citizen fulfills it without hesitation and with pleasure. The Republic comes before everything. The people are noble. Evremonde, our time is running out."
es: "Citizen doctor," replied the first, "ask no more questions." "If the Republic demands sacrifices from you, you, as the good patriot that you are, will consider yourself happy to make them." "Above all and before all, the Republic." "The People are sovereign." "Evrémonde, we are in a hurry."

en: “One word,” the Doctor entreated. “Will you tell me who denounced him?”
vi: − Just one word, - the doctor insisted. - Please tell me who accused this person? −
tr: "One minute," insisted the Doctor. "Can you tell me who reported him?"
es: —One more word—objected the doctor. —Do you want to tell me who reported him?

en: “It is against rule,” answered the first; “but you can ask Him of Saint Antoine here.”
vi: It's against the law to say, - the first person replied, - but you can ask the people from the Saint Antoine area here.
tr: The man in front replied, "This is against the rules," he said, "but you can ask Citizen St. Antoine about it."
es: —I would be neglecting my duty...

en: The Doctor turned his eyes upon that man. Who moved uneasily on his feet, rubbed his beard a little, and at length said:
vi: The doctor turned to look at the person. He stood restlessly, fidgeting with his beard for a moment before saying: − Well!
tr: The doctor turned his eyes towards the man. After the man fidgeted nervously and lightly stroked his beard, he said:
es: Tomorrow you can ask Saint Anthony. The doctor then directed a look at another of the men, who moved with a certain expression of discomfort, rubbed his beard, and said:

en: “Well! Truly it is against rule. But he is denounced—and gravely—by the Citizen and Citizeness Defarge. And by one other.”
vi: He stood restlessly, fidgeting with his beard for a moment before saying: − Well! That is indeed against the law. But this person has been accused... and heavily charged... by Citizen Defarge, both male and female. And by another person.
tr: "Hey! This is really against the rules. But –personally– He was denounced by Citizen Defarge and his wife. There was another one."
es: —Well! It is true that we cannot say it without failing in our duty; but I have no objection to stating that he has been accused... indeed of great crimes, by Citizen and Citizeness Defarge... and also, by another person. —Who is this other person?

en: “What other?”
vi: − Who is it? −
tr: "Who is that?"
es: —Who is this other person?

en: “Do you ask, Citizen Doctor?”
vi: Are you still asking, Citizen Doctor? −
tr: "Do you really want to know this, Citizen Doctor?"
es: —Are you asking that, citizen doctor?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: “Then,” said he of Saint Antoine, with a strange look, “you will be answered to-morrow. Now, I am dumb!”
vi: − Then you will have an answer tomorrow, - the man from Saint Antoine said with a strange expression. -
tr: With a strange expression on his face, the man from St. Antoine said, "Then you will learn the answer to this question tomorrow. Now I am mute!"
es: —You'll know tomorrow—replied the one from San Antonio with a strange intonation. —Now, I am mute!

en: CHAPTER VIII.
vi: For now, I will say no more!
tr: VIII
es: VIII.

en: A Hand at Cards
vi: 8. Whether it was a cheerful game or a new disaster at home, Miss Pross weaved through the narrow streets and crossed the river via Pont-Neuf, calculating the essential items she needed to buy in her mind.
tr: Cards in Hand
es: AN ORIGINAL GAME

en: Happily unconscious of the new calamity at home, Miss Pross threaded her way along the narrow streets and crossed the river by the bridge of the Pont-Neuf, reckoning in her mind the number of indispensable purchases she had to make. Mr. Cruncher, with the basket, walked at her side. They both looked to the right and to the left into most of the shops they passed, had a wary eye for all gregarious assemblages of people, and turned out of their road to avoid any very excited group of talkers. It was a raw evening, and the misty river, blurred to the eye with blazing lights and to the ear with harsh noises, showed where the barges were stationed in which the smiths worked, making guns for the Army of the Republic. Woe to the man who played tricks with that Army, or got undeserved promotion in it! Better for him that his beard had never grown, for the National Razor shaved him close.
vi: 8. Whether it was a cheerful game or a new disaster at home, Miss Pross weaved through the narrow streets and crossed the river via Pont-Neuf, calculating the essential items she needed to buy in her mind. Cruncher walked beside her, carrying the basket. The two of them kept glancing left and right past the shops, their eyes wary of any gathered crowds, and avoiding any groups of people speaking excitedly. That evening was freezing and the river was foggy, the dazzling lights and the deafening sounds indicating the positions of the barges that had been turned into workshops where workers were making guns for the Republic's army. Woe to anyone who dares to mock that army, or whose value does not match their rank within it! That person had better not grow a beard because the National Razor will cut their throat.
tr: Miss Pross, unaware of the new disaster at home, happily passed through the narrow streets and crossed the Pont-Neuf Bridge with a list of things she needed to get in her mind. Mr. Cruncher was walking beside her with a basket in his hand. They looked to the right and left of the shops they passed, cautiously examined every kind of crowded group huddled together, and if they saw them talking heatedly, they changed their route. It was a cold and damp evening, and the barges where blacksmiths working for the Republic Army were making weapons blurred their eyes with bright lights and made their ears ring with loud noises on the misty river. The situation was dire for those playing tricks on the Army or those who were unjustly promoted here! "The National Razor" would give them a deep shave, so it was better if their beards didn't grow.
es: Immersed in the blissful ignorance of the new misfortune that had befallen the family, Miss Pross left behind a portion of narrow alleyways and crossed the river by the New Bridge, mentally reviewing the number of purchases she had to make. Walking beside her was Lapa, carrying the basket. Both of them, although seemingly only focused on examining the shops open to the right and left of the streets they traversed, were on the lookout for groups of patriots, especially if they were very numerous, and frequently changed their route to avoid encountering those who spoke with excessive animation. It was a cold and damp afternoon. The points of light that dotted the gray layer covering the river indicated the places where barges converted into workshops by those manufacturing weapons for the Republic's army were anchored. Woe to the mortal who dared to mock that army! Woe to the one who held a rank in that army that they did not deserve! They would have been better off if their beard had never grown, for the National Barber's Razor would shave it off as a blessing.

en: Having purchased a few small articles of grocery, and a measure of oil for the lamp, Miss Pross bethought herself of the wine they wanted. After peeping into several wine-shops, she stopped at the sign of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, not far from the National Palace, once (and twice) the Tuileries, where the aspect of things rather took her fancy. It had a quieter look than any other place of the same description they had passed, and, though red with patriotic caps, was not so red as the rest. Sounding Mr. Cruncher, and finding him of her opinion, Miss Pross resorted to the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, attended by her cavalier.
vi: After buying some miscellaneous food items and a little lamp oil, Ms. Pross suddenly remembered that she needed to buy some wine. After looking into a few wine shops, she stopped in front of the sign "The Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity" not far from the National Palace - formerly the Tuileries Palace - which seemed to suit her taste. This shop is less noisy than other similar shops they had passed by, and although there were patriotic red hats, they were not as bright red as in other places. Asking Cruncher for his opinion and seeing that he agreed, Miss Pross and her knight entered the shop Brutus de l’Antiquité.
tr: After buying a few small grocery items and some oil for the lamp, Miss Pross remembered that they wanted wine. After glancing at a few wine shops, she stopped in front of a place near the National Palace, formerly the Tuileries, which had a sign that read "Good Republican of Antiquity Brutus"; its exterior had caught her interest. It appeared calmer compared to similar places they had passed by, and although there were patriots with red hats inside, it wasn't as red as the others. After checking with Mr. Cruncher and seeing that they were of the same mind, she entered the Good Republican Brutus's shop with her escort.
es: After buying a portion of food items and a quantity of oil for the lamp, Miss Pross thought about acquiring the wine she needed. She scorned a number of taverns and finally favored one, placed under the patronage of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, situated a short distance from the National Palace, formerly the Tuileries, an establishment quieter than any of its counterparts found up to that point, in which it was true that many red caps were seen, but they were less abundant than in the others. After consulting Lapa, and seeing that he was of the same opinion, Miss Pross entered the temple of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, accompanied by her gentleman.

en: Slightly observant of the smoky lights; of the people, pipe in mouth, playing with limp cards and yellow dominoes; of the one bare-breasted, bare-armed, soot-begrimed workman reading a journal aloud, and of the others listening to him; of the weapons worn, or laid aside to be resumed; of the two or three customers fallen forward asleep, who in the popular high-shouldered shaggy black spencer looked, in that attitude, like slumbering bears or dogs; the two outlandish customers approached the counter, and showed what they wanted.
vi: These two strangers went straight to the counter, signaling that they wanted to buy what they needed; paying no attention to the dim light; to the people with pipes in their mouths playing limp cards and yellowed dominoes; to a half-naked worker, covered in soot, reading a newspaper aloud while others listened; to the weapons worn or placed beside them, ready; to the two or three customers in short black high-shouldered coats, common at the time, sleeping on the tables like bears or dogs.
tr: The inside was a bit smoky; men playing with worn-out playing cards and domino tiles, with pipes in their mouths; a worker, covered in soot, with one chest and arm bare, reading a newspaper loudly, surrounded by people listening to him; two or three customers, resembling bears or dogs, dozing off, with their weapons either strapped on or set aside, lounging in their padded black coats; while these two foreign customers approached the counter and pointed out what they wanted.
es: Without paying much attention to the dim lights, to the men with pipes in their mouths playing with grimy cards or yellowed dominoes, to the laborer who, with his shirt sleeves rolled up to his shoulders and his chest bare, loudly read a newspaper to a group of people listening with their mouths open, to the weapons that filled the tables or hung from the drinkers' waists, nor to the three or four patrons who were sleeping off their drunkenness, sprawled face down on the floor, and who, more than men, looked like lying bears or mastiffs, the two buyers approached the counter and asked for what they needed.

en: As their wine was measuring out, a man parted from another man in a corner, and rose to depart. In going, he had to face Miss Pross. No sooner did he face her, than Miss Pross uttered a scream, and clapped her hands.
vi: While the two people were waiting for the wine to be poured, a customer in the corner said goodbye to his friend, stood up, and walked out, facing Ms. Pross. As soon as she saw him, Ms. Pross clapped her hands and shouted.
tr: While the wines were being filled, a man in a corner stood up after saying goodbye to another man. As he was leaving, he came face to face with Miss Pross, who, upon seeing him, let out a scream and clapped her hands.
es: While the innkeeper measured the wine, a man, who was talking with another in a corner of the establishment, stood up and began to walk. To get out to the street, he had to pass by Miss Pross, which is nothing unusual, but what was unusual was that, as soon as he bumped into her, a piercing scream tore through the air followed by a semi-fainting of the lady.

en: In a moment, the whole company were on their feet. That somebody was assassinated by somebody vindicating a difference of opinion was the likeliest occurrence. Everybody looked to see somebody fall, but only saw a man and a woman standing staring at each other; the man with all the outward aspect of a Frenchman and a thorough Republican; the woman, evidently English.
vi: Immediately, everyone in the tavern stood up abruptly. Everyone thought that someone had killed someone else due to a disagreement, as often seen. Everyone looked to see if anyone had fallen, but they only saw a man and a woman staring at each other; the man appeared to be entirely French, while the woman was clearly English.
tr: Suddenly, everyone jumped to their feet. It was a common occurrence for someone to be killed as a result of a disagreement. Everyone looked to see who had fallen, but they only saw a man and a woman standing and looking at each other; the man appeared to be a Frenchman and a staunch Republican, while the woman was evidently English.
es: All the people in the tavern stood up. It was so common to see people being killed outright for such a justified reason as defending any opinion, that everyone looked to see who was the mortal falling lifeless to the ground, but to their general astonishment, the only thing they saw was a couple, a man and a woman, staring at each other with extraordinary intensity, and the man seemed French, and a red republican, and the woman was undoubtedly English.

en: What was said in this disappointing anti-climax, by the disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, except that it was something very voluble and loud, would have been as so much Hebrew or Chaldean to Miss Pross and her protector, though they had been all ears. But, they had no ears for anything in their surprise. For, it must be recorded, that not only was Miss Pross lost in amazement and agitation, but, Mr. Cruncher—though it seemed on his own separate and individual account—was in a state of the greatest wonder.
vi: The disappointment was palpable, causing all the regulars in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern to loudly argue and chatter, but even if Miss Pross and her protector tried to listen, it was like ducks hearing thunder, they understood nothing. But in their astonishment, the two heard nothing. Because it must be said, not only was Miss Pross stunned and emotional, but Cruncher was also extremely surprised - for his own personal reasons.
tr: After this disappointment, the words spoken loudly and fluently by the disciples of the Ancient Good Republican Brutus, no matter how much they listened, were no different from Hebrew or Chaldean for Miss Pross and her protector. But they were in no state to listen to anyone out of astonishment anyway. For Miss Pross had become blind to her surroundings due to the amazement and worry she had fallen into, and Mr. Cruncher – in his own way and measures – was engulfed in tremendous curiosity.
es: The picturesque phrases with which the good disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity expressed their disillusionment sounded in the ears of Miss Pross and her companion as if they had been spoken in Hebrew or Chaldean. They only understood that they were shouted, as their surprise allowed them no more. We speak in the plural because, if Miss Pross was surprised, Jeremiah Lapa was on the verge of falling to the ground under the violent blow of his stupefaction.

en: “What is the matter?” said the man who had caused Miss Pross to scream; speaking in a vexed, abrupt voice (though in a low tone), and in English.
vi: What’s going on? - The person who had made Miss Pross scream lowered their voice and spoke hurriedly and irritably in English.
tr: The man who caused Miss Pross to scream asked in a nervous and rude manner (but in a low voice) and in English, "What happened?"
es: —What is it?—asked the man who was the cause of Miss Pross's scream. The two words had been spoken in English, with a brusque and threatening accent and a very low tone of voice.

en: “Oh, Solomon, dear Solomon!” cried Miss Pross, clapping her hands again. “After not setting eyes upon you or hearing of you for so long a time, do I find you here!”
vi: − Oh Solomon, my dear Solomon! - Miss Pross exclaimed while clapping her hands. So many years you've been missing, and now I see you here!
tr: Miss Pross clapped her hands again, shouting, "Oh Solomon, dear Solomon!" "I haven't seen your face or heard your voice for so long, I can't believe you're standing before me now!"
es: —Oh Solomon... Dear Solomon!—exclaimed Miss Pross, clasping her hands. —At last I find you, after so many years of absence, after so many years without news of you!

en: “Don’t call me Solomon. Do you want to be the death of me?” asked the man, in a furtive, frightened way.
vi: − Don't call me Solomon. Do you want me to die or what? - The man said, looking furtive and scared. − Oh my, oh my!
tr: Adam said, "Don't call me Solomon. Do you want me to die?" he asked in a voice full of fear and evasion.
es: —Don't call me Solomon. Are you seeking my death, wretched woman?—asked the man, casting frightened glances around.

en: “Brother, brother!” cried Miss Pross, bursting into tears. “Have I ever been so hard with you that you ask me such a cruel question?”
vi: - Miss Pross burst into tears. - Have I ever treated you badly that you ask me such a cruel question? −
tr: "My brother, my brother!" Miss Pross cried out, bursting into tears. "Have I ever done you any harm that you ask me such a cruel question?"
es: —Brother... my brother!—exclaimed Miss Pross, in a flood of tears—Have I behaved so badly towards you that you ask me such a cruel question?

en: “Then hold your meddlesome tongue,” said Solomon, “and come out, if you want to speak to me. Pay for your wine, and come out. Who’s this man?”
vi: Then stop wagging your tongue, - Solomon said. - Go outside if you want to talk to me. Pay for your drink, then go outside. Who is this man?
tr: "Then hold that busybody tongue of yours now," said Solomon, "if you want to talk to me, come outside. Pay for your wine and come outside. Who is this man?"
es: —Well, put that devilish tongue of yours in your pocket!—grumbled Salomón. —If you want to tell me something, let's go outside. Pay for the wine and let's go... Who is that man?

en: Miss Pross, shaking her loving and dejected head at her by no means affectionate brother, said through her tears, “Mr. Cruncher.”
vi: Miss Pross shook her head in despair at her brother's indifference to sibling affection, and said through her tears: − Mr. Cruncher. − Tell him to go out immediately, - Solomon replied.
tr: Miss Pross, shaking her loving and sorrowful head at her not-at-all affectionate brother, said tearfully, "Mr. Cruncher."
es: —It is Mr. Lapa—answered Miss Pross with dismay.

en: “Let him come out too,” said Solomon. “Does he think me a ghost?”
vi: - Does he think I'm a ghost or something?
tr: Solomon said, "Let him come." "Why is he looking at me as if I'm a ghost?""
es: —Well, let him come out too... But what is that? Does that person take me for a ghost?

en: Apparently, Mr. Cruncher did, to judge from his looks. He said not a word, however, and Miss Pross, exploring the depths of her reticule through her tears with great difficulty paid for her wine. As she did so, Solomon turned to the followers of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity, and offered a few words of explanation in the French language, which caused them all to relapse into their former places and pursuits.
vi: Judging by Cruncher's expression, it certainly seemed so. But Cruncher didn't say a word, and Miss Pross, trying to hold back her tears, fumbled in her pocket to pay for the drink. Meanwhile, Solomon turned to the other patrons in the Brutus de l’Antiquité tavern and offered some explanations in French, which made everyone return to their previous positions and concerns.
tr: Judging by his looks, Mr. Cruncher seemed to have truly mistaken him for a ghost. Not a single word came out of his mouth, but Miss Pross, in tears, barely managed to rummage through the bottom of her bag to pay for the wine. After Miss Pross paid the money, Solomon turned to the patrons of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity and made an announcement in French, after which everyone sat down and returned to their occupations.
es: The question was very much in place, for Lapa was indeed looking at him as one looks at a specter. However, he did not part his lips, and Miss Pross, shedding tears, paid for the wine. Meanwhile, Solomon addressed the disciples of the Good Republican Brutus of Antiquity and gave them, in French, some explanations that were enough for all of them to return to their respective posts.

en: “Now,” said Solomon, stopping at the dark street corner, “what do you want?”
vi: − Alright, - Solomon spoke as he stopped at a dark corner of the street, - what do you want now? −
tr: Solomon, "Tell me," he said, standing on a dark street corner, "what do you want?"
es: —Let's see—said Solomon, once he reached a dark corner of the street—What is it that you want from me?

en: “How dreadfully unkind in a brother nothing has ever turned my love away from!” cried Miss Pross, “to give me such a greeting, and show me no affection.”
vi: You love me, yet you treat me so terribly! - Sister Pross cried. - No greeting, no affection. −
