tr: Miss Pross, still teary-eyed, said, "Is this how one greets a sister who loves them so much, speaking to her so rudely, so badly?"
es: —It is horrifying to meet a beloved brother who shows not the slightest sign of affection to the sister who was always tender and loving towards him!

en: “There. Confound it! There,” said Solomon, making a dab at Miss Pross’s lips with his own. “Now are you content?”
vi: There. Damn it! There, - Solomon said as he quickly brushed his lips against Sister Pross's lips. - Are you satisfied now?
tr: "Alright, alright!" "Here you go," said Solomon and planted a small kiss on his sister's lips. "Are you happy now?"
es: —Bah! Nonsense!—exclaimed Solomon, brushing Miss Pross's forehead with his lips—Are you happy now?

en: Miss Pross only shook her head and wept in silence.
vi: Sister Pross just shook her head and cried silently.
tr: Miss Pross silently cried, only nodding her head.
es: Miss Pross shook her head and burst into tears again.

en: “If you expect me to be surprised,” said her brother Solomon, “I am not surprised; I knew you were here; I know of most people who are here. If you really don’t want to endanger my existence—which I half believe you do—go your ways as soon as possible, and let me go mine. I am busy. I am an official.”
vi: − If you think I'm surprised, I'm not surprised at all, - the younger brother said. - I know you're here; I know most people are here. If you truly don't want my life to be in danger, which you might actually want, then I'll go my way, and you go yours, the sooner the better. I'm busy. I'm now an official. −
tr: "If you expect me to be surprised," said his brother Solomon, "I am not surprised at all; I knew you were here, I know most of the people here. If you don't want to put my life in danger – which I think is what you're doing – you should go your own way as soon as possible, and I'll go mine. I have a lot of work to do. I am on duty."
es: —If you think that you have surprised me, you are completely mistaken; I was not surprised to find you. I knew you were in Paris, so it's good for you to know that there are very few people in Paris who live without me knowing about it. If you don't want to put my existence in grave danger... I'm tempted to believe that this is your intention... continue on your way as soon as possible, and let me continue on mine. I have many occupations... I am a public official.

en: “My English brother Solomon,” mourned Miss Pross, casting up her tear-fraught eyes, “that had the makings in him of one of the best and greatest of men in his native country, an official among foreigners, and such foreigners! I would almost sooner have seen the dear boy lying in his—”
vi: My English brother Solomon, - Miss Pross lamented while raising her tearful eyes to the sky, - who had the qualities to become someone important in our homeland, is now an official for foreigners, and such foreigners at that! I'd rather see my beloved brother lying dead in... − See! - The brother shouted, interrupting.
tr: Miss Pross lifted her tearful eyes and lamented, "My English brother Solomon, who could have been one of the best and foremost men of his own country, has become an officer serving foreigners, and such foreigners at that! To see you like this..."
es: —My brother Solomon, English by birth and soul, my brother Solomon, who in his homeland could have been one of the greatest men, a public official in a country that is not his own, depending on men who are not English... and what men, Good heavens! I would have preferred to find you dead in his...!

en: “I said so!” cried her brother, interrupting. “I knew it. You want to be the death of me. I shall be rendered Suspected, by my own sister. Just as I am getting on!”
vi: I'd rather see my beloved brother lying dead in... − See! - The brother shouted, interrupting. - I knew it. You just want me dead. My own sister is making me a suspect. Right when I'm advancing!
tr: His brother interrupted him, shouting, "I know, I know!" "It's obvious. You'd prefer me dead. I'll be suspected because of my own brother. And just when I had everything under control!"
es: —I believe it!... I supposed it!... I knew it for sure!—exclaimed her brother, interrupting her. — What you want is my death. My tender, my loving sister will make them list me among the suspects... That is to say; she is already doing it.

en: “The gracious and merciful Heavens forbid!” cried Miss Pross. “Far rather would I never see you again, dear Solomon, though I have ever loved you truly, and ever shall. Say but one affectionate word to me, and tell me there is nothing angry or estranged between us, and I will detain you no longer.”
vi: − Oh my God! - Miss Pross exclaimed. - I'd rather never see you again, Solomon, even though I always love you and always will. Just say a kind word to me, and say there's no anger or coldness between us, and I won't hold you back anymore.
tr: "May the Almighty God undo it if He has written it!" cried Miss Pross. "Dear Solomon, even though I love you with all my heart, it is better that I never see you again than to be the cause of your death. But tell me one nice thing so that I know there is no resentment or anger between us! Then I will get out of your way."
es: —God forbid!—cried Miss Pross.—I have loved you much, Solomon, I love you much; but I would have preferred never to see you again, than to find you as I find you. Tell me a word of affection, tell me that you do not hate me, that hatred does not separate us, and I will leave without detaining you a second longer.

en: Good Miss Pross! As if the estrangement between them had come of any culpability of hers. As if Mr. Lorry had not known it for a fact, years ago, in the quiet corner in Soho, that this precious brother had spent her money and left her!
vi: Poor Miss Pross! As if the coldness between the siblings was her fault. As if Mr. Lorry hadn't known the truth, that many years ago, in the quiet corner of Soho, this precious brother had spent all her money and then disappeared!
tr: Kind-hearted Miss Pross! She acted as if she were the reason for the coldness between them. As if Mr. Lorry didn't know the fact that years ago this dear brother had squandered all of Miss Pross's money and fled from the quiet corner in Soho!
es: Tell me a word of affection, tell me that you do not hate me, that hatred does not separate us, and I will leave without detaining you a second longer. Solomon was uttering the requested word of affection, providing evidence of a condescension that surely would not have existed had their respective positions been reversed, when unexpectedly Jeremiah Lapa interjected into the conversation, placing a paw on the affectionate brother's shoulder and saying in a hoarse voice:

en: He was saying the affectionate word, however, with a far more grudging condescension and patronage than he could have shown if their relative merits and positions had been reversed (which is invariably the case, all the world over), when Mr. Cruncher, touching him on the shoulder, hoarsely and unexpectedly interposed with the following singular question:
vi: Solomon was speaking some affectionate words, but with a condescending and superior tone, as if the value and relative positions between the siblings had reversed (a common occurrence in this world), when Cruncher patted him on the shoulder and, in a hoarse voice, interrupted with an unexpected question: − Hey!
tr: Finally, Solomon uttered a few words of affection, but he did so with a spiteful condescension that was excessive, even though familial values and roles had been reversed (yet this was the case everywhere in the world), and at that moment, Mr. Cruncher, unexpectedly intervening, touched Solomon's shoulder and said to him in a gruff voice;
es: Solomon was uttering the requested word of affection, providing evidence of a condescension that surely would not have existed had their respective positions been reversed, when unexpectedly Jeremiah Lapa interjected into the conversation, placing a paw on the affectionate brother's shoulder and saying in a hoarse voice:

en: “I say! Might I ask the favour? As to whether your name is John Solomon, or Solomon John?”
vi: May I ask you something? Is your name John Solomon, or Solomon John?
tr: "Hey, can I ask you something? Is your name John Solomon or Solomon John?"
es: —It seems to me that I will also be allowed to ask a question. Would you tell me if your name is Juan Salomón or Salomón Juan?

en: The official turned towards him with sudden distrust. He had not previously uttered a word.
vi: The man turned to look at Cruncher with sudden suspicion. Cruncher hadn't uttered a word until now.
tr: The officer turned to him with sudden suspicion. Not a single word had come out of his mouth before.
es: The public official, in response, turned towards the person breaking their silence to ask a question that unsettled him, and stood staring at him intently with visible suspicion. —I am waiting—replied Lapa.—Have you suddenly become mute?

en: “Come!” said Mr. Cruncher. “Speak out, you know.” (Which, by the way, was more than he could do himself.) “John Solomon, or Solomon John? She calls you Solomon, and she must know, being your sister. And I know you’re John, you know. Which of the two goes first? And regarding that name of Pross, likewise. That warn’t your name over the water.”
vi: − Hey! Speak clearly, - Cruncher continued. With this hoarse voice, even Cruncher couldn't speak clearly. – Are you John Solomon, or Solomon John? This lady calls you Solomon, so she must know, she's your sister after all. But I know you as John. Which one is the surname, which one is the first name? And then there's the surname Pross. That's not your surname in England. −
tr: "Come on!" said Mr. Cruncher. "Speak up, have you lost your tongue?" (He couldn't do more on his own anyway.) "Is it John Solomon or Solomon John? He calls you Solomon and since he is your brother, he must know it correctly. But I know your name as John. Which of these two names comes first now? The same goes for the name Pross. You weren't using this name on the other side, were you?"
es: —I am waiting—replied Lapa.—Have you suddenly become mute? Juan Salomón or Salomón Juan? Which one is it? The young lady calls you Salomón, and it is to be assumed that she knows your name well, since she is your sister, as I see. But the fact is that I know you as Juan. Which of the two names is the real one? I say the same about the last name. In England, you were not called Pross.

en: “What do you mean?”
vi: What do you mean?
tr: "What do you mean?"
es: —But what are you saying?

en: “Well, I don’t know all I mean, for I can’t call to mind what your name was, over the water.”
vi: − Well, I'm not exactly sure, because I can't remember your surname from back then.
tr: "Honestly, I don't know what I mean either, because I can't remember which name you used in England.""
es: —I don't even know it very well myself, for I confess that I don't remember the last name you had on the opposite shore of the Canal.

en: “No?”
tr: "Don't you really remember?"
es: —Have you forgotten?

en: “No. But I’ll swear it was a name of two syllables.”
vi: Can't you? − No. But I swear it was a two-syllable surname.
tr: "I don't remember. But I'm sure it was a two-syllable name."
es: —Have you forgotten? —Yes; but I would swear it was a two-syllable surname.

en: “Indeed?”
vi: − Really? − Really.
tr: "Is that so?"
es: —Really!

en: “Yes. T’other one’s was one syllable. I know you. You was a spy—witness at the Bailey. What, in the name of the Father of Lies, own father to yourself, was you called at that time?”
vi: And the name has only one syllable. I know you. You were a spy back then... a witness at the Bailey Court. What was your surname back then, tell me?
tr: "It is so. The other was a single syllable. I know you. You are the spy witness in Bailey. In the name of the god of liars, who is probably your father, what was your name back then?"
es: —Really. Pross has only one syllable; the other had two... In the name of the Father of Lies, who is undoubtedly your father, could you tell me what your name was when you practiced the honorable profession of informer at the Old Bailey?

en: “Barsad,” said another voice, striking in.
vi: − Barsad, - another voice interrupted. − That's right!
tr: "Barsad," someone interrupted.
es: —Barsad!—answered another voice, joining the conversation.

en: “That’s the name for a thousand pound!” cried Jerry.
vi: I bet a thousand pounds! - Jerry shouted.
tr: "This is the name of the thousand-pound man!" shouted Jerry.
es: The one who had just spoken was our old friend Sydney Carton.

en: The speaker who struck in, was Sydney Carton. He had his hands behind him under the skirts of his riding-coat, and he stood at Mr. Cruncher’s elbow as negligently as he might have stood at the Old Bailey itself.
vi: The person who just spoke was Sydney Carton. He was standing next to Cruncher, with his hands hidden behind his back under the cloak of a traveler's coat, looking as nonchalant as when he stood at the Old Bailey Criminal Court.
tr: The man who joined the conversation was Sydney Carton. He stood with his hands clasped behind his rider's jacket, right next to Mr. Cruncher's elbow, with an indifferent attitude as if he were in the Old Bailey court.
es: The one who had just spoken was our old friend Sydney Carton. With both hands placed behind his back under the tails of his coat, he had positioned himself next to Lapa, affecting the same nonchalance with which he used to attend the sessions at the Old Bailey.

en: “Don’t be alarmed, my dear Miss Pross. I arrived at Mr. Lorry’s, to his surprise, yesterday evening; we agreed that I would not present myself elsewhere until all was well, or unless I could be useful; I present myself here, to beg a little talk with your brother. I wish you had a better employed brother than Mr. Barsad. I wish for your sake Mr. Barsad was not a Sheep of the Prisons.”
vi: − Don't panic, dear Miss Pross. I went to see Mr. Lorry last night, much to his surprise; we agreed that I would not let anyone else know of my presence unless I was needed; I am here to have a word with your younger sister. I hope your sister has a better job than Mr. Barsad did before, and for your sake, I also hope Mr. Barsad is not a "sheep" of the prison.
tr: "Don't be afraid, dear Miss Pross. I went to see Mr. Lorry last evening, he was very surprised; we decided that it would be best for me to stay out of sight until everything is settled or until I can be of some help; I came here to have a short conversation with your brother. I wish your brother had a better job than Mr. Barsad. I felt sorry on your behalf that your brother is a jailbird."
es: —Do not be alarmed, Miss Pross—he replied.— Yesterday afternoon I presented myself at Mr. Lorry's residence, much to the surprise of this gentleman, who was far from expecting my visit. We both agreed that I would not be seen anywhere until the matter was definitively and satisfactorily resolved, or until my presence was necessary. Adhering to the agreement, I have come here because it is essential that I exchange a few words with your brother. I very much regret that you are the sister of such an untrustworthy individual; I very much regret that you have for a brother a hangman's blackbird.

en: Sheep was a cant word of the time for a spy, under the gaolers. The spy, who was pale, turned paler, and asked him how he dared—
vi: "Sheep" was the slang term used by jailers at that time to refer to informers. The spy, whose face had already turned pale, asked Carton how he dared... − I will tell you, - Sydney said.
tr: Kuzu, in those times, was a slang term used by guards for spies. The pale-faced spy's face turned even paler, and he asked with what courage he spoke to him like that.
es: This was the name by which spies were usually referred to. —How dare you—asked the spy, pale as a corpse—to tell me...?

en: “I’ll tell you,” said Sydney. “I lighted on you, Mr. Barsad, coming out of the prison of the Conciergerie while I was contemplating the walls, an hour or more ago. You have a face to be remembered, and I remember faces well. Made curious by seeing you in that connection, and having a reason, to which you are no stranger, for associating you with the misfortunes of a friend now very unfortunate, I walked in your direction. I walked into the wine-shop here, close after you, and sat near you. I had no difficulty in deducing from your unreserved conversation, and the rumour openly going about among your admirers, the nature of your calling. And gradually, what I had done at random, seemed to shape itself into a purpose, Mr. Barsad.”
vi: The spy, whose face had already turned pale, asked Carton how he dared... − I will tell you, - Sydney said. - Mr. Barsad, I saw you coming out of the Conciergerie prison while I was looking at those walls more than an hour ago. You have a memorable face, and I am good at remembering faces. Curious to see you there, and not unfamiliar with you, I had reason to connect you with the misfortune of my currently very unfortunate friend, so I followed you. I followed you closely into this tavern and sat next to you. From your loose words and the public rumors of your admirers there, it was not difficult for me to deduce the nature of your work. And gradually, my impulsive following of you also gained a specific purpose, Mr. Barsad. − What is the purpose? -
tr: "I will tell you," said Sydney. "Mr. Barsad, about an hour ago, while I was lost in thought by the walls of the Conciergerie Prison, I saw you coming out of there. You have an unforgettable face, and I do not forget a face I have seen. I was indeed surprised to see you there, and as you know, I thought you might have something to do with the misfortunes that have befallen our extremely unfortunate friend, so I followed you. I entered this wine shop right behind you and sat next to you. It was not at all difficult to understand what kind of work you do from your frank conversations and the rumors circulating among your admirers. Then, what I started by chance turned into a specific purpose, Mr. Barsad."
es: —I will explain myself, so that you see I am not speaking nonsense—replied Carton. — Half an hour ago, I was contemplating the walls of the Conciergerie when I saw you coming out of its doors. Among other qualities, some good, some bad, I have the ability to remember faces well, and you can count that yours is one that is hard to forget. I was surprised to see you in that place, and since, on the other hand, I have my reasons to associate your person with the misfortunes of a friend, who is now more unfortunate than ever, the idea occurred to me to follow you. Trailing closely behind you, I entered the tavern and sat next to you. From your conversation, and from the murmurs of admiration you elicited from your listeners, it was not difficult for me to infer what your profession is. What I initially did by chance gradually became a determined objective, Mr. Barsad.

en: “What purpose?” the spy asked.
vi: The spy asked.
tr: "What is the purpose?" asked the spy.
es: —And that objective?...—asked the spy.

en: “It would be troublesome, and might be dangerous, to explain in the street. Could you favour me, in confidence, with some minutes of your company—at the office of Tellson’s Bank, for instance?”
vi: − It will be troublesome and possibly dangerous if we explain it out here on the street. Please, sir, could we talk privately for a few minutes... in the office of Tellson's Bank, for example? −
tr: "It wouldn't be appropriate to explain this in the middle of the street; it could be dangerous. For instance, could we talk for a few minutes, privately, at Tellson's Bank?"
es: —It would be bothersome, and even dangerous, to explain it on the street. Would you be so kind as to accompany me for a few minutes... to Tellson's Bank, for example?

en: “Under a threat?”
vi: Is that a threat? −
tr: "Is this a threat?"
es: —Under threat?

en: “Oh! Did I say that?”
vi: Oh! Did I say anything like that?
tr: "Ah! Did I ever say such a thing?"
es: —Bah! Did I talk about threats?

en: “Then, why should I go there?”
vi: − Then why should I go there?
tr: "Then why should I go?""
es: —So, why on earth would I go there?

en: “Really, Mr. Barsad, I can’t say, if you can’t.”
vi: − Honestly, Mr. Barsad, I cannot explain the reason unless you go there.
tr: "Honestly, Mr. Barsad, I cannot say that.""
es: —Frankly, Mr. Barsad; I can't say.

en: “Do you mean that you won’t say, sir?” the spy irresolutely asked.
vi: − So you mean you won't speak, right? - The spy hesitated. −
tr: "So, are you not going to tell me even then, sir?" the spy asked hesitantly.
es: —Can't you, or won't you, sir?—asked the spy with a certain hesitation.

en: “You apprehend me very clearly, Mr. Barsad. I won’t.”
vi: You understand me very well, Mr. Barsad. I won't speak.
tr: "You have understood me very well, Mr. Barsad. Yes, I will not tell you!"
es: —You interpret me wonderfully well; I do not want to.

en: Carton’s negligent recklessness of manner came powerfully in aid of his quickness and skill, in such a business as he had in his secret mind, and with such a man as he had to do with. His practised eye saw it, and made the most of it.
vi: Carton's indifferent and nonchalant attitude greatly aided his quick wit and skillfulness with the schemes he had in mind and with the person he needed to deal with. His experienced eye recognized this and he took full advantage of it.
tr: In contrast to the man's irritability and resourcefulness, Carton's indifferent and reckless demeanor was sufficient both for what he had in mind and to deal with this man. His experienced eyes had seen this situation and acknowledged it.
es: The tone of glacial indifference with which Carton spoke was a very powerful auxiliary to his prodigious skill. His lynx-like vision noticed it from the first moment, and it is said that he took full advantage of it.

en: “Now, I told you so,” said the spy, casting a reproachful look at his sister; “if any trouble comes of this, it’s your doing.”
vi: − Hey, I already told you, - the spy cast a reproachful glance towards the sister, - if there's any trouble with this, it's all your fault.
tr: Throwing a reproachful look at his sister, the spy said, "I'm telling you, if anything bad happens to me, it's your fault.""
es: —Remember what I tell you and never forget it!—exclaimed Barsad, directing a furious look of reproach at his sister. —It will be your doing if something bad happens to me.

en: “Come, come, Mr. Barsad!” exclaimed Sydney. “Don’t be ungrateful. But for my great respect for your sister, I might not have led up so pleasantly to a little proposal that I wish to make for our mutual satisfaction. Do you go with me to the Bank?”
vi: − Stop, stop, Mr. Barsad! - Sydney exclaimed. - Don't be ungrateful. If it weren't for my utmost respect for your sister, I would have comfortably made the small proposal that I want both sides to be satisfied with. Will you come with me to the bank?
tr: "Come, come Mr. Barsad!" shouted Sydney. "Don't be ungrateful. If I didn't have so much respect for your sister, I wouldn't be able to talk so comfortably about my little proposal, which I think would satisfy both of us. Are you coming to the bank with me now?"
es: "Come on, come on, Mr. Barsad!" said Carton. "Don't be ungrateful." "Be thankful for the respect your sister inspires in me and the kindness with which I am making you a proposition that should leave us all satisfied." "Will you accompany me to the Bank?" —Yes; I will accompany you.

en: “I’ll hear what you have got to say. Yes, I’ll go with you.”
vi: − I will listen to what you need to say. Alright, I'll go with you.
tr: "I was curious about what you wanted to say. Yes, I am coming with you."
es: I am ready to hear what you wish to tell me. —First of all, we will escort your sister to the corner of the house where she lives.

en: “I propose that we first conduct your sister safely to the corner of her own street. Let me take your arm, Miss Pross. This is not a good city, at this time, for you to be out in, unprotected; and as your escort knows Mr. Barsad, I will invite him to Mr. Lorry’s with us. Are we ready? Come then!”
vi: − I suggest that first we safely escort your sister to the corner of her street. Let me take your arm, Miss Pross. This city is not safe, and at this hour, letting you walk on the street without protection; and the person accompanying you knows Mr. Barsad so I invite him to come with us to Mr. Lorry's place, are we ready? Let's go!
tr: "First of all, I suggest taking your sister safely to the corner of her own street. Take my arm, Miss Pross. It is not good for you to be outside unprotected at this time, in this city; moreover, since your companion knows Mr. Barsad, I also invite him to join Mr. Lorry. Is everyone ready? Then let's go!"
es: —First of all, we will escort your sister to the corner of the house where she lives. Please accept my arm, Miss Pross. Given the circumstances the city is going through, you should not go alone and unprotected, and since the man accompanying you knows Mr. Barsad, I take the liberty of inviting him to come with us to Mr. Lorry's residence. Are we ready? Yes? Then let's go.

en: Miss Pross recalled soon afterwards, and to the end of her life remembered, that as she pressed her hands on Sydney’s arm and looked up in his face, imploring him to do no hurt to Solomon, there was a braced purpose in the arm and a kind of inspiration in the eyes, which not only contradicted his light manner, but changed and raised the man. She was too much occupied then with fears for the brother who so little deserved her affection, and with Sydney’s friendly reassurances, adequately to heed what she observed.
vi: Afterwards, Miss Pross would remember and remember for the rest of her life that, when she held Sydney's arm and looked up at his face, pleading with him not to harm Solomon, what she felt was the resolute strength in his arm and the fervor in his eyes, which not only contrasted with his usual indifferent demeanor but also added to his admirable nature. But at that moment, Miss Pross was too worried about her brother who was unworthy of her love, combined with Sydney's sincere reassurances, so she didn't pay much attention to that feeling.
tr: When Miss Pross, holding onto Sydney's arm and looking at his face, pleaded with him not to harm Solomon, she would remember very shortly and even for the rest of her life, the determined strength in his arm and the inspiration in his eyes that not only contradicted his indifferent demeanor but also transformed and elevated him. Miss Pross was very afraid for her brother, who was not at all deserving of her love, and it could not be said that she heeded Sydney's friendly advice.
es: Later, Miss Pross remembered, and never forgot in her life, that when she clung to Carton's arm and looked into his face to make a silent but eloquent plea on behalf of her brother, she noticed in the strength of his arm and in the expression of his eyes something that not only contradicted Carton's lightness of tone and manner, but also transformed and elevated the man. If at the moment it did not catch her attention, it was because she was too preoccupied with the fears inspired by the fate of a brother so undeserving of her affection to make observations.

en: They left her at the corner of the street, and Carton led the way to Mr. Lorry’s, which was within a few minutes’ walk. John Barsad, or Solomon Pross, walked at his side.
vi: They left Miss Pross at the corner of her street, then Carton led the way to Mr. Lorry's place, a few minutes' walk away. John Barsad, or Solomon Pross, walked beside him.
tr: They left Miss Pross at the corner of her street, and Carton headed towards Mr. Lorry's place, which was a few minutes' walk away. John Barsad or Solomon Pross was also walking alongside him.
es: After bidding farewell to Miss Pross in the vicinity of the doctor's house, Carton, walking between Barsad and Jeremiah Cruncher, headed towards the building of Tellson's Bank, which was very close by.

en: Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner, and was sitting before a cheery little log or two of fire—perhaps looking into their blaze for the picture of that younger elderly gentleman from Tellson’s, who had looked into the red coals at the Royal George at Dover, now a good many years ago. He turned his head as they entered, and showed the surprise with which he saw a stranger.
vi: Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner and was sitting in front of a small crackling fireplace - perhaps seeing in the flames an image of himself many years ago: a distinguished gentleman from Tellson's Bank gazing at the glowing embers in the fireplace of the Royal George Hotel in Dover. Hearing footsteps approaching, he turned around and was surprised to see a stranger.
tr: Mr. Lorry had just finished his dinner and was sitting in front of a few pieces of wood burning in the fireplace – perhaps seeing in the glow of the fire the young clerk of Tellson's watching the embers at the Royal George Hotel in Dover years ago. As they entered, Mr. Lorry turned his head towards them and was surprised to see a stranger with them.
es: Lorry, who had just finished eating and was sitting by the warmth of the fire, turned his head upon hearing the footsteps of his visitors, and could not help but show a gesture of surprise when he saw an unfamiliar face.

en: “Miss Pross’s brother, sir,” said Sydney. “Mr. Barsad.”
vi: − Miss Pross's brother, sir, - Sydney said. - Mr. Barsad. − Barsad? -
tr: "Sir, this gentleman is Miss Pross's brother," said Sydney, "Mr. Barsad.""
es: "I present to you Miss Pross's brother," said Carton, "Mr. Barsad."

en: “Barsad?” repeated the old gentleman, “Barsad? I have an association with the name—and with the face.”
vi: The distinguished gentleman repeated, - Barsad? I do remember that name... and the face.
tr: The old man repeated, "Barsad?" "Barsad? I remember this name from somewhere – and the face too."
es: —Barsad?—repeated Lorry. —Barsad? I seem to remember that surname... and the face of the one who bears it.

en: “I told you you had a remarkable face, Mr. Barsad,” observed Carton, coolly. “Pray sit down.”
vi: − I told you that you have a memorable face, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said nonchalantly. - Please, have a seat.
tr: Carton said with an insolent manner, "I told you that you have an unforgettable face, Mr. Barsad." "Please sit down."
es: —Didn't I tell you before that you have a face that is hard to forget, Mr. Barsad?—asked Carton coldly. —Do me the favor of sitting down.

en: As he took a chair himself, he supplied the link that Mr. Lorry wanted, by saying to him with a frown, “Witness at that trial.” Mr. Lorry immediately remembered, and regarded his new visitor with an undisguised look of abhorrence.
vi: He also sat down and reminded Mr. Lorry with a word accompanied by a raised eyebrow: − The witness at the trial years ago. Mr. Lorry immediately remembered and looked at the new guest with undisguised disgust.
tr: As Carton pulled up a chair for himself, he frowned and gave Mr. Lorry the answer he wanted, "The witness at the trial." Mr. Lorry immediately remembered the man and scrutinized his new visitor with evident disdain.
es: Carton, at the same time as he brought a chair closer, provided Lorry with the link he had been searching for to connect the chain of his memories. —Witness of that case—said Carton simply. It was enough for Lorry to remember, and also for him to look at Barsad with visible disgust.

en: “Mr. Barsad has been recognised by Miss Pross as the affectionate brother you have heard of,” said Sydney, “and has acknowledged the relationship. I pass to worse news. Darnay has been arrested again.”
vi: Sydney continued: "Miss Pross recognized Mr. Barsad as her beloved brother that you have heard about, and he confirmed this relationship." Now for worse news. Darnay has been arrested again.
tr: "Mr. Barsad is Miss Pross's dear brother, you must have heard," said Sydney, "and he himself confirmed this relationship. Now I move on to the bad news. Darnay has been arrested again."
es: —Miss Pross has recognized in Mr. Barsad the affectionate brother she has so often heard you speak of—observed Carton. —Barsad has not denied the relationship... But let's move on to worse news; Darnay has been imprisoned again.

en: Struck with consternation, the old gentleman exclaimed, “What do you tell me! I left him safe and free within these two hours, and am about to return to him!”
vi: Shaken, the old man exclaimed: − How can that be! Just two hours ago when I said goodbye, Darnay was still safe and free, I was planning to meet him again! −
tr: The old man, frozen by this news, exclaimed, "What are you saying? Just two hours ago, when I left him, he was safe and free, and I was about to go to him now!"
es: —What are you telling me!—exclaimed Lorry, deeply dismayed. —It hasn't been two hours since I left him at his house free and happy, and I was just about to go see him.

en: “Arrested for all that. When was it done, Mr. Barsad?”
vi: He has been arrested again anyway. When was he arrested, Mr. Barsad? −
tr: "How did they arrest him? When did this happen, Mr. Barsad?"
es: —Well, he is imprisoned. When did they arrest him, Barsad?

en: “Just now, if at all.”
vi: Right now, if not already.
tr: "I think just now."
es: —In any case, it must have been just a moment ago.

en: “Mr. Barsad is the best authority possible, sir,” said Sydney, “and I have it from Mr. Barsad’s communication to a friend and brother Sheep over a bottle of wine, that the arrest has taken place. He left the messengers at the gate, and saw them admitted by the porter. There is no earthly doubt that he is retaken.”
vi: − Mr. Barsad knows best, - Sydney said, - I heard Mr. Barsad telling another "sheep" friend in the tavern that they had gone to arrest Darnay. Barsad went with the escort team to Darnay's house gate and saw them go inside. His re-arrest is absolutely certain.
tr: "Mr. Barsad is the most knowledgeable person on this matter, sir," said Sydney, "I heard about this issue, that is, Darnay's arrest, while Mr. Barsad was drinking wine and talking with a friend and another fellow brother. He left the messengers at the door, then saw them coming in. There is no doubt that he has been arrested again."
es: —Barsad is a reliable source of information in this matter—observed Carton. —I heard the news from his lips when he was telling it, between glasses of brandy, to a friend of his, an informer like him. It seems that he accompanied those in charge of arresting him up to the door of the doctor's house, leaving when he saw that the doorman was letting them in. Therefore, doubt is impossible.

en: Mr. Lorry’s business eye read in the speaker’s face that it was loss of time to dwell upon the point. Confused, but sensible that something might depend on his presence of mind, he commanded himself, and was silently attentive.
vi: Through Sydney's expression, Mr. Lorry's keen eye immediately understood that there was no need to waste time doubting anymore. Though confused, he still understood that it was necessary to keep a clear mind, so he calmed himself and listened attentively.
tr: Mr. Lorry's businesslike eyes read on the speaker's face that dwelling further on this subject would be a waste of time. He was bewildered but aware that he needed to gather his thoughts, so he composed himself and listened quietly.
es: Lorry understood that the misfortune was real. In his mind, he felt the harsh struggle of a thousand confused and contradictory ideas, but he realized how crucial it was not to lose his presence of mind and, with titanic efforts, he controlled himself, regained his composure, and remained silent and attentive.

en: “Now, I trust,” said Sydney to him, “that the name and influence of Doctor Manette may stand him in as good stead to-morrow—you said he would be before the Tribunal again to-morrow, Mr. Barsad?—”
vi: Sydney continued: − At this moment, I believe that the name and prestige of Dr. Manette could be very useful for Darnay tomorrow... Mr. Barsad, you said that Darnay will be retried tomorrow, didn't you? −
tr: "If you ask me," Sydney said to him, "Doctor Manette's name and reputation might be useful again tomorrow –you mentioned that he would appear in court again tomorrow, didn't you Mr. Barsad?"
es: —It is to be hoped... I have that confidence—replied Carton—that the doctor's name and his influence on the masses will be so effective tomorrow... Did you not say, Barsad, that he is to appear before the Tribunal tomorrow?

en: “Yes; I believe so.”
vi: Yes, I believe so. − ...
tr: "Yes, I think so.""
es: —Yes; I think the appearance will be tomorrow.

en: “—In as good stead to-morrow as to-day. But it may not be so. I own to you, I am shaken, Mr. Lorry, by Doctor Manette’s not having had the power to prevent this arrest.”
vi: It could be very useful for Darnay tomorrow as well as today. But it's not certain. Mr. Lorry, to be honest, I was also surprised that Dr. Manette was unable to prevent this arrest.
tr: "It might work, of course. But it might not work either. To tell the truth, Mr. Lorry, I am very worried that Doctor Manette's influence cannot prevent this arrest."
es: —... As effective tomorrow, and as decisive, as today; but it is not impossible that the opposite may occur. I will confess, Mr. Lorry, that the fact that the doctor has not been able to prevent the imprisonment inspires me with great fears.

en: “He may not have known of it beforehand,” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: − Perhaps he didn't know beforehand, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Maybe he didn't know about this," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Perhaps he didn't even suspect the possibility of danger—replied Lorry.

en: “But that very circumstance would be alarming, when we remember how identified he is with his son-in-law.”
vi: − But this situation is truly alarming when we know how attached he has been to his son-in-law.
tr: "That's the worst part, after all, everyone knows how much he is identified with his son-in-law."
es: —What, in my opinion, would be a highly alarming circumstance, given how closely he is identified with his son-in-law.

en: “That’s true,” Mr. Lorry acknowledged, with his troubled hand at his chin, and his troubled eyes on Carton.
vi: − That's right, - Mr. Lorry admitted, his hand anxiously stroking his chin, his eyes anxiously looking at Carton.
tr: With his nervous hands on his chin and his nervous eyes again on Carton, Mr. Lorry accepted, saying, "You are right."
es: —It's true—replied Lorry, resting his chin on the palm of his hand and looking at Carton with a downcast expression.

en: “In short,” said Sydney, “this is a desperate time, when desperate games are played for desperate stakes. Let the Doctor play the winning game; I will play the losing one. No man’s life here is worth purchase. Any one carried home by the people to-day, may be condemned tomorrow. Now, the stake I have resolved to play for, in case of the worst, is a friend in the Conciergerie. And the friend I purpose to myself to win, is Mr. Barsad.”
vi: − In short, - Sydney said, - this is a time of desperation, so we must play desperate games with desperate stakes. Let the doctor play the winning hand, and I will play the losing one. There is no life here worth anything anymore. Anyone who is celebrated by the people today may be condemned tomorrow. Now the stake I am determined to win, in the worst case, is a friend in the Conciergerie prison. And the friend I want to win is Mr. Barsad.
tr: "In short," said Sydney, "this is a desperate time where desperate games are played for desperate stakes. Let the Doctor play to win, I will play to lose. In this environment, no one's life has any value. Today, a man carried home on shoulders can be condemned to death the next day. Now, as a last resort, I will put forward a friend from the Conciergerie as a trump card. The person I am determined to win over is Mr. Barsad."
es: —In short—continued Carton:—when a desperate game is played and desperate bets are placed, one must also resort to desperate measures. Let the doctor play with the winning cards, while I will handle the losing ones. Let the doctor engage in the game aimed at getting his son-in-law out of the Consistory; meanwhile, I will play another independent game with the goal of putting a friend into the Consistory. The friend I intend to put in, Mr. Barsad, is you.

en: “You need have good cards, sir,” said the spy.
vi: − You need good cards, sir, - the spy said.
tr: "For that, you need to have very good cards, sir," replied the spy.
es: —You will need to gather very good cards to win that game, replied the spy.

en: “I’ll run them over. I’ll see what I hold,—Mr. Lorry, you know what a brute I am; I wish you’d give me a little brandy.”
vi: − You need good cards, sir, - the spy said. − Let me see what cards I have... Mr. Lorry, you know how rough I am; I wish you would give me some strong liquor.
tr: "I will reveal it soon. First, let me fully see what I have. Mr. Lorry, you know what a miserable man I am. Could you give me some brandy?"
es: "I have already gathered them, and I am going to lay them face up... but you know, Mr. Lorry, how clumsy I am if I don't spur my wits with a few drinks." "If you could give me a little brandy, I would appreciate it."

en: It was put before him, and he drank off a glassful—drank off another glassful—pushed the bottle thoughtfully away.
vi: The wine was brought out and he drank a full glass - another full glass - then pensively pushed the bottle aside.
tr: They placed the brandy in front of him, and he drank it in one gulp – then another – then pushed the bottle aside thoughtfully.
es: He was served the liquor, of which he took two consecutive glasses.

en: “Mr. Barsad,” he went on, in the tone of one who really was looking over a hand at cards: “Sheep of the prisons, emissary of Republican committees, now turnkey, now prisoner, always spy and secret informer, so much the more valuable here for being English that an Englishman is less open to suspicion of subornation in those characters than a Frenchman, represents himself to his employers under a false name. That’s a very good card. Mr. Barsad, now in the employ of the republican French government, was formerly in the employ of the aristocratic English government, the enemy of France and freedom. That’s an excellent card. Inference clear as day in this region of suspicion, that Mr. Barsad, still in the pay of the aristocratic English government, is the spy of Pitt, the treacherous foe of the Republic crouching in its bosom, the English traitor and agent of all mischief so much spoken of and so difficult to find. That’s a card not to be beaten. Have you followed my hand, Mr. Barsad?”
vi: − Mr. Barsad, - he continued in a tone as if he were examining the cards in his hand - sheep of the prisons, emissary of the Republican committees, sometimes a jailer, sometimes a prisoner, always a spy and informant, even more valuable for being English because the English are generally less suspected of being easily bribed than the French, you represent your recruiter under a false name. That is a very good card. Mr. Barsad, currently working for the French Republic government, previously worked for the British aristocratic government, enemy of France and freedom. That is an excellent card. In an age of suspicion like this country, it is easy to infer that Mr. Barsad is still on the payroll of the British aristocratic government, spying for Pitt*, the treacherous enemy of the Republic lurking within France, the dangerous English spy and traitor often mentioned but hard to detect. That is the trump card. Have you seen my cards, Mr. Barsad? − I don't understand your game, - the spy replied, somewhat uneasy.
tr: As if he really had cards in his hand and was looking at them, he continued his speech, "Mr. Barsad, the prison lamb, spy of the Republican committees, sometimes a guard, sometimes a prisoner, but always a spy and informant, much more valuable here because he is English, as he does not arouse much suspicion in inciting perjury compared to a Frenchman and introduces himself to his superiors with a pseudonym. This is a very good card. Mr. Barsad, who is currently working on behalf of the Republican French government, previously worked on behalf of the aristocratic English government, which was an enemy of France and freedom. This is an excellent card. In all this atmosphere of suspicion, it is as clear as day that Mr. Barsad, who still works on behalf of the aristocratic English government, is Pitt's spy, an enemy traitor nestled in the heart of the Republic, and the ever-mentioned but never-found English traitor and representative of all kinds of treachery. This trump card can never be beaten. Could you see the cards I have, Mr. Barsad?"
es: —Mr. Barsad—he said, setting the bottle aside and speaking as if he held a collection of cards in his hand,—executioner's blackbird, emissary of the republican committees, today a jailer, yesterday a prisoner, always a spy and secret informer, whose value here increases considerably due to the circumstance of being English, and therefore less exposed to suspicion than any Frenchman, presents himself to the very ones he serves under a false name; this triumph is of the first order. Mr. Barsad, today in the pay of the French revolutionary government, served, not long ago, the aristocratic English government, sworn enemy of France and its liberties; it seems to me that I have just shown another card that is hard to beat. If we now enter the realm of suspicions and deductions, we will find one, clear as daylight, a suspicion that I will express with the following words: Mr. Barsad, salaried informer of the aristocratic English government, is at the same time an agent of Pitt, a cunning enemy who will strike the Republic at its heart, a treacherous Englishman, agent, instrument, author of all those indignities that everyone talks about and no one is able to prove. This is a triumph that almost assures the game. Are you following my game, Mr. Barsad?

en: “Not to understand your play,” returned the spy, somewhat uneasily.
vi: Have you seen my cards, Mr. Barsad? − I don't understand your game, - the spy replied, somewhat uneasy.
tr: A bit uneasy, the spy replied, "I can't say that I understand your game."
es: —I am beginning to understand the importance of the letters, but I still don't know how you plan to play them—replied the spy, visibly uneasy.

en: “I play my Ace, Denunciation of Mr. Barsad to the nearest Section Committee. Look over your hand, Mr. Barsad, and see what you have. Don’t hurry.”
vi: − I will play the ace of denouncing Mr. Barsad to the nearest District Committee. Review your cards, Mr. Barsad, see what you have. Don't rush.
tr: "I am playing Asım, the nearest regional committee has been informed by Mr. Barsad. You also take a look at your hand, Mr. Barsad, what do you see? But don't rush."
es: —I begin by playing the next trump card: A denunciation against the so-called Barsad before the nearest district Committee. Look at your cards, Barsad, and play... without haste, no one is rushing us.

en: He drew the bottle near, poured out another glassful of brandy, and drank it off. He saw that the spy was fearful of his drinking himself into a fit state for the immediate denunciation of him. Seeing it, he poured out and drank another glassful.
vi: He pulled the bottle of wine closer, filled another glass, and drank it all. He saw that the spy was afraid he would get drunk and wanted to expose him immediately. He poured himself another full glass of wine.
tr: Carton pulled the bottle and filled another glass with cognac, drinking it in one gulp. The spy saw that Carton was afraid he would report him immediately, that he would drink it in one gulp like that. Noticing this, Carton filled another one and downed it.
es: He took the bottle again, poured himself another glass, drank it with unperturbed calmness, and waited. He saw that the spy feared that the libations would result in an immediate denunciation, and, no doubt to increase the fear, he poured and downed the fourth glass.

en: “Look over your hand carefully, Mr. Barsad. Take time.”
vi: − “Look at your cards carefully, Mr. Barsad.” “Take your time.
tr: "Look carefully at your hand, Mr. Barsad. Think carefully."
es: —Take all the time you need, Barsad, lest you lose the game on the first move.

en: It was a poorer hand than he suspected. Mr. Barsad saw losing cards in it that Sydney Carton knew nothing of. Thrown out of his honourable employment in England, through too much unsuccessful hard swearing there—not because he was not wanted there; our English reasons for vaunting our superiority to secrecy and spies are of very modern date—he knew that he had crossed the Channel, and accepted service in France: first, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among his own countrymen there: gradually, as a tempter and an eavesdropper among the natives. He knew that under the overthrown government he had been a spy upon Saint Antoine and Defarge’s wine-shop; had received from the watchful police such heads of information concerning Doctor Manette’s imprisonment, release, and history, as should serve him for an introduction to familiar conversation with the Defarges; and tried them on Madame Defarge, and had broken down with them signally. He always remembered with fear and trembling, that that terrible woman had knitted when he talked with her, and had looked ominously at him as her fingers moved. He had since seen her, in the Section of Saint Antoine, over and over again produce her knitted registers, and denounce people whose lives the guillotine then surely swallowed up. He knew, as every one employed as he was did, that he was never safe; that flight was impossible; that he was tied fast under the shadow of the axe; and that in spite of his utmost tergiversation and treachery in furtherance of the reigning terror, a word might bring it down upon him. Once denounced, and on such grave grounds as had just now been suggested to his mind, he foresaw that the dreadful woman of whose unrelenting character he had seen many proofs, would produce against him that fatal register, and would quash his last chance of life. Besides that all secret men are men soon terrified, here were surely cards enough of one black suit, to justify the holder in growing rather livid as he turned them over.
vi: The cards are weaker than he thought.” Barsad saw the losing cards that Sydney Carton was unaware of. Having been expelled from his prestigious job in England after too many unsuccessful false testimonies—not because he was no longer needed there; England at that time, as now, boasted of its superiority in scheming and spying—he knew he had voluntarily crossed the English Channel to take up work in France; initially, he baited and eavesdropped on the expatriates there, then gradually baited and eavesdropped on the locals. He knew that under the overthrown regime, he had been a spy in the Saint Antoine area and at Defarge’s wine shop; he had once been provided with information by the keen-nosed police about Dr. Manette's imprisonment, release, and his background. He had used that information to strike up an acquaintance with the Defarges and tried to exploit Madame Defarge but failed miserably. He always trembled with fear remembering that while he was striking up a conversation, that dreadful woman had looked at him in a terrifying way while her fingers deftly knitted. Since then, he had encountered her many times in the Saint Antoine district, always holding out a list knitted into the fabric and denouncing many people, who would surely meet their fate at the guillotine. He knew, just like many others recruited for this kind of work, that his life would never be safe; escape was impossible; he would always be under the shadow of death; and despite having switched sides to serve this reigning terror, a single word could put him in danger. Once accused, with the serious crimes he just reviewed in his mind, he foresaw that the dreadful woman with the cruel personality he had witnessed many times would surely bring out that deadly list to accuse him and extinguish his last chance of survival. Furthermore, all those who live secret lives are easily panicked, and the cards in his hand were unlucky enough to prove the increasingly livid look on his face due to anger.
tr: Barsad's hand was worse than he had anticipated. Mr. Barsad saw that he was losing the cards in this hand, about which Sydney Carton knew nothing, one by one. He had been dismissed from his honorable job in England—not because he was unwanted there, but because our pride in secrecy and espionage coincides with recent times—due to too much perjury, and he had crossed the Channel to accept the job in France. At first, he had engaged in incitement and spying among his own citizens, and then gradually tried the same activities among the French. Carton knew that he had been spying in the St. Antoine district and in Defarge's wine shop under the orders of the overthrown government; to establish dialogue with the Defarges, he had gathered information about Dr. Manette's imprisonment, release, and life from vigilant police officers, then used this information against Madame Defarge but had achieved nothing. He shuddered with fear, recalling how the dreadful woman always knitted while talking to him and how she glared at him menacingly as her fingers moved. He had seen her many times later in St. Antoine, the woman constantly reading the names she knitted into her work, and the lives of these people she denounced soon ended at the guillotine. As everyone involved in these matters knew, he was never safe; escape was impossible; he was tightly bound under the shadow of the blade, and despite all the treachery and betrayal he had committed to contribute to the surrounding savagery, a single word could cause that blade to fall on his head. With things in this state, once a denunciation was made, that dreadful woman, whose ruthlessness he had witnessed many times, could bring out her deadly records and ruin his life. Moreover, men involved in such secret affairs are quickly terrified, and there were cards in this hand that, when revealed, would inevitably cause the holder to turn pale.
es: Barsad was a weaker adversary than Carton had supposed. To tell the truth, he had very bad cards in his game, and he knew it, although Carton did not. He knew, for example, that, dismissed from his honorable position in England as a result of unforgivable blunders committed in the exercise of it, he crossed the Channel and offered his services in France, where they were accepted, at first, to tempt and extract information from his compatriots, and later, to tempt and extract information from the French. He knew that, during the overthrown government, he was in charge of monitoring the Saint Antoine district and Defarge's tavern; that he received from the police the necessary data about the captivity, freedom, and history of Dr. Manette, thanks to which he believed he would manage to become a confidential friend of the Defarges, although he soon had to convince himself that, on some occasions, those who seek wool come back shorn. He always remembered with terror that that terrible tavern keeper had been knitting while he tried to extract information from her, and he would tremble every time he recalled that she looked at him with a somber expression while her fingers moved swiftly. He had seen her countless times since then in the Saint Antoine district, armed with her knitting records and denouncing people whose heads were soon severed by the guillotine. He knew, as all those who hold jobs like his do, that the storm raged over his head at all hours; that his head was in danger, that escape was impossible, that with each moment he brought his neck closer to the blade, and that, despite the services rendered to the cause of the reigning terror, a single word was enough to send him to the scaffold. No sooner had he been denounced, with all or part of the grave charges just insinuated against him, than he understood that that formidable woman, of whose implacable character he had seen ample proof, would exhibit the fatal record that would dispel the last possibility of salvation. Add to this the law, proven a thousand times, that all informers, all secret informers, are cowards by temperament, men who are easily frightened, and one can understand the state of mind in which Barsad was left.

en: “You scarcely seem to like your hand,” said Sydney, with the greatest composure. “Do you play?”
vi: − It seems you don't like your cards, - Sydney said very calmly. - Are you going to play?
tr: "It seems you are not very satisfied with your own hand," said Sydney with great composure. "Shall we continue the game?"
es: —It seems that your letters are not much to their liking—said Carton with his usual calm. —Don't you play?

en: “I think, sir,” said the spy, in the meanest manner, as he turned to Mr. Lorry, “I may appeal to a gentleman of your years and benevolence, to put it to this other gentleman, so much your junior, whether he can under any circumstances reconcile it to his station to play that Ace of which he has spoken. I admit that I am a spy, and that it is considered a discreditable station—though it must be filled by somebody; but this gentleman is no spy, and why should he so demean himself as to make himself one?”
vi: − I think, sir, - the cringing and humble spy turned to Mr. Lorry, - I beg this venerable and generous gentleman to speak to this other gentleman, who is much younger than you, and ask him not to demean himself by playing the trump card he mentioned. I confess I am a spy, and this is a profession considered to be dishonorable... though someone has to do this work; but this gentleman is not a spy, why should he demean himself like us spies?
tr: "I think it's ongoing, sir," said the spy, turning to Mr. Lorry, "It would actually be good to get the opinion of an experienced and helpful gentleman like yourself. Can this gentleman, who is much younger than you, really play the card he mentioned?" "I admit that I am a spy and that it is a disgraceful situation – but someone has to do it; however, why does this gentleman lower himself by pretending to be a spy when he is not one?""
es: —I believe, sir—responded Barsad, turning towards Lorry and speaking with fawning humility,—that I find myself in the position of requesting from a gentleman of your years and benevolence the favor of asking this other gentleman, much younger than you, to refrain from playing the card he just mentioned to me. I confess that I am a spy, and I acknowledge that the profession honors no one, although you will admit that someone has to perform it; but this gentleman is not a spy, this gentleman is not an informer; and since he is not one now, what need is there for him to be one in the future?

en: “I play my Ace, Mr. Barsad,” said Carton, taking the answer on himself, and looking at his watch, “without any scruple, in a very few minutes.”
vi: − I play my ace, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said without waiting for Mr. Lorry to reply, and looking at the clock, - without hesitation, in just a few minutes.
tr: "I will play the ace I have, Mr. Barsad," said Carton, who took the remark personally, and looking at his watch, he added, "without any hesitation, in a little while."
es: —I will play my card, Mr. Barsad—said Carton, without waiting for Lorry to reply,—without the slightest scruple and within five minutes.

en: “I should have hoped, gentlemen both,” said the spy, always striving to hook Mr. Lorry into the discussion, “that your respect for my sister—”
vi: − Gentlemen, - the spy always tried to involve Mr. Lorry in the conversation, - I was hoping that out of respect for my sister... −
tr: The spy, trying to draw Mr. Lorry into the conversation, replied, "Out of respect for my sister from two such courteous gentlemen like yourselves..."
es: —I had harbored the hope, gentlemen, that, out of consideration for my sister...

en: “I could not better testify my respect for your sister than by finally relieving her of her brother,” said Sydney Carton.
vi: The best way for me to show respect for your sister is to finally relieve her of her brother, - Sydney Carton said.
tr: "I cannot better prove my respect for your sister than by finally freeing her from her brother," said Sydney Carton.
es: "The greatest favor we can do for your sister is to free her forever from a brother like you," replied Carton.

en: “You think not, sir?”
vi: − Is there no other way, sir?
tr: "So, this is what you think, sir?"
es: —Do you believe so, sir?

en: “I have thoroughly made up my mind about it.”
vi: − I've made up my mind.
tr: "My decision on this matter is final."
es: —I am absolutely convinced of it.

en: The smooth manner of the spy, curiously in dissonance with his ostentatiously rough dress, and probably with his usual demeanour, received such a check from the inscrutability of Carton,—who was a mystery to wiser and honester men than he,—that it faltered here and failed him. While he was at a loss, Carton said, resuming his former air of contemplating cards:
vi: A strange contrast to his ragged exterior, and perhaps to his usual behavior, the polite demeanor of the spy had lost its effect in the face of Carton's enigmatic attitude - a man who was a mystery even to those more intelligent and virtuous than Barsad. While he was still bewildered, Carton continued in the tone of someone considering his hand of cards: −
tr: Barsad was so affected by the spy's calm demeanor, which was completely at odds with his flashy yet coarse clothing, and perhaps by his ordinary behavior, that he was left bewildered, not knowing what to do. This mysteriousness of Carton – which was an enigma even for men much wiser and more honest than him – left Barsad in a state of confusion. While he was in this state of not knowing what to say, Carton, adopting the manner of a man arranging his cards, said:
es: The spy, with all his humility, which so greatly contrasted with his terrorist attire and probably with his ordinary manner of being, received such a harsh blow from the inscrutability of Carton, who had always been a mystery to men more honest and clever than he, that he wavered, trembled, and gave himself up for lost. While disconcerted, stupefied, he remained silent, not knowing how to get out of the predicament, Carton replied:

en: “And indeed, now I think again, I have a strong impression that I have another good card here, not yet enumerated. That friend and fellow-Sheep, who spoke of himself as pasturing in the country prisons; who was he?”
vi: And indeed, now that I think about it, I realize I have an even better card that I haven't mentioned yet. That fellow... who claims to be a sheep grazing in this country's prison; who is he?
tr: "Actually, now that I think about it again, I realized I had one more good card in my hand, which I hadn't noticed before. You know, that guy and his prison lamb friend who said he grazed in many prisons; who was that?"
es: —I am examining my letters again, and I find one, as good as the ones listed, that I had not mentioned. Who is that colleague of yours, who spoke as if he had spent his entire life grazing in prisons?

en: “French. You don’t know him,” said the spy, quickly.
vi: − A Frenchman. You wouldn't know him, - the spy quickly replied.
tr: "The French one. You wouldn't know him," the spy quickly replied.
es: —He is a Frenchman; you do not know him—replied the spy quickly.

en: “French, eh?” repeated Carton, musing, and not appearing to notice him at all, though he echoed his word. “Well; he may be.”
vi: − The Frenchman? - Carton repeated, looking pensive, as if he wasn't paying attention to Barsad but was speaking to himself. - Ah, it could be him.
tr: "French, huh!" Carton repeated, lost in thought and seemingly unaware of her, yet he had echoed the exact word she had said. "Well, it could be, of course."
es: —French, eh?—exclaimed Carton, as if he wasn't thinking about what he was saying—could be.

en: “Is, I assure you,” said the spy; “though it’s not important.”
vi: − It's him, I assure you, - the spy said, - though this matter is not important.
tr: "Yes, you can be sure," said the spy; "but it doesn't matter."
es: —It is... I assure you... although that is the least of it—said the spy.

en: “Though it’s not important,” repeated Carton, in the same mechanical way—“though it’s not important—No, it’s not important. No. Yet I know the face.”
vi: − Even though this matter is not important, - Carton repeated mechanically as before, -... even though this matter is not important... No, not important. No. But I remember that face.
tr: "But it doesn't matter," repeated Carton in the same mechanical manner –"but it doesn't matter– No, it doesn't matter at all. It doesn't. But I know it."
es: —Although that is the least of it...—repeated Carton mechanically—although that is the least of it... Yes... it is the least of it... But the fact is that I know that face.

en: “I think not. I am sure not. It can’t be,” said the spy.
vi: − I think not. I'm sure not. Impossible, - the spy said.
tr: "Sanmam. I'm not sure about this. It can't be," said the spy.
es: —I don't think so... Of course, I assure you that no... It's not possible...

en: “It-can’t-be,” muttered Sydney Carton, retrospectively, and idling his glass (which fortunately was a small one) again. “Can’t-be. Spoke good French. Yet like a foreigner, I thought?”
vi: − Im...pos...sible, - Sydney Carton murmured as if reminiscing, his hand fondling the wine glass (fortunately, it was a small glass). - Im...pos...sible. Speaks French well. But still with a foreign accent, right?
tr: "Un-be-liev-able," murmured Sydney Carton, in the same manner as before, and refilled his glass (fortunately, this time it was a small one). "Un-be-liev-able. His French was good. But it sounded foreign to me."
es: —It's not possible...—murmured Carton, filling his cup for the fifth time, which fortunately was small. —It's not possible... He speaks French correctly... but with a slightly foreign accent...

en: “Provincial,” said the spy.
vi: − Provincial accent, - the detective said.
tr: "Provincial," said the spy.
es: —Provincial accent—explained the spy.

en: “No. Foreign!” cried Carton, striking his open hand on the table, as a light broke clearly on his mind. “Cly! Disguised, but the same man. We had that man before us at the Old Bailey.”
vi: − No. Foreign! - Carton exclaimed, slamming the table as he suddenly remembered. - Cly! Disguised, but still the same person. We saw him standing in front of us at the Old Bailey Court.
tr: Carton, as if a lightning bolt had struck his mind, slammed his hand on the table and said, "No. It was a stranger!" he shouted. "Cly! He had hidden his face, but it was the same man. He was standing right in front of us at Old Bailey."
es: —No! Foreign accent!—replied Carton, slamming his fist on the table. —It's Cly! Disguised, disfigured, but the very same Cly! I've had him in my sight many times at the Old Bailey.

en: “Now, there you are hasty, sir,” said Barsad, with a smile that gave his aquiline nose an extra inclination to one side; “there you really give me an advantage over you. Cly (who I will unreservedly admit, at this distance of time, was a partner of mine) has been dead several years. I attended him in his last illness. He was buried in London, at the church of Saint Pancras-in-the-Fields. His unpopularity with the blackguard multitude at the moment prevented my following his remains, but I helped to lay him in his coffin.”
vi: − There, you have concluded hastily, sir, - Barsad said with a smile that made his hooked nose seem to bend to one side, - in this matter, you have given me the advantage. Cly, whom I admit without hesitation was my friend in the past; but he has been dead for many years. I took care of him when he was sick and dying. He was buried in London in the Saint Pancras churchyard. At that time, the common people hated him so much that I couldn't attend his funeral, but I personally helped place him in the coffin.
tr: With a smile that made the curve of his nose more pronounced to one side, "Now you have rushed a bit, sir," said Barsad, "you have given me an advantage." Of course, I admit that he was once my partner, but Cly has been dead for a long time. I was even with him during his illness. He was buried in the garden of Saint Pancras Church in London. Since he was not a man much favored among that blasphemous crowd, I couldn't attend his funeral, but I helped put him in the coffin."
es: —You get worked up easily, sir—said Barsad with a smile that accentuated the tilt of his aquiline nose,—which gives me an advantage over you. Cly, my colleague from another time, I have no hesitation in confessing, died a number of years ago. I took care of him myself during his final illness. He was buried in London, in the cemetery of the parish of St. Pancras. I did not accompany him to the cemetery, because I feared the crowds, as my friend and colleague had the misfortune of becoming extraordinarily unpopular; but I helped those who placed him in the coffin.

en: Here, Mr. Lorry became aware, from where he sat, of a most remarkable goblin shadow on the wall. Tracing it to its source, he discovered it to be caused by a sudden extraordinary rising and stiffening of all the risen and stiff hair on Mr. Cruncher’s head.
vi: At that moment, from where he was sitting, Mr. Lorry suddenly noticed the shadow of a goblin standing out on the wall. Tracing where the shadow came from, he realized that the unusually upright shadow was actually Cruncher's head with his hair standing on end. −
tr: Meanwhile, Mr. Lorry, from where he was sitting, noticed a shadow on the wall that distinctly resembled that of a goblin. Upon looking carefully, he realized that it was formed by Mr. Cruncher's hair standing even more upright than usual.
es: Suddenly, Lorry saw the shadow of a goblin or something similar projected on the wall. He turned his head looking for the source of the projection, and with indescribable surprise, noticed that it was on the head of Jeremiah Lapa, whose hair, resembling steel spikes, had stood on end.

en: “Let us be reasonable,” said the spy, “and let us be fair. To show you how mistaken you are, and what an unfounded assumption yours is, I will lay before you a certificate of Cly’s burial, which I happened to have carried in my pocket-book,” with a hurried hand he produced and opened it, “ever since. There it is. Oh, look at it, look at it! You may take it in your hand; it’s no forgery.”
vi: We must be judicious and fair, - said the spy. To prove that you are mistaken and your assumption is baseless, I will show you Cly's burial certificate that I happen to have in my notebook for a long time, - his hand hastily pulled out the notebook and opened it. Here it is. Ah, take a look, take a look! You can pick it up and see; it's not a forgery.
tr: "We need to be reasonable," said the spy, "and fair. To show you how wrong you are and how unfounded these claims are, I will show you Cly's burial certificate, which I carry in my notebook," he said, taking it out and opening it with hurried hands, "luckily, it has been with me since then. Here it is. Go ahead, look, read it! You can take it; it's not fake."
es: "—Come to your senses, sir, and do not be deceived by suspicions that have no rational basis," replied the spy." —To demonstrate to you how mistaken you are, and the lack of any basis for your assumption, I am going to present you with a proper death certificate for Cly, a certificate that I always carry in my pocket." "Take it," he added, offering his interlocutor a folded paper." —Read it, read it... take it in your hands, examine it carefully... it is not fake, no, but authentic and very authentic!"

en: Here, Mr. Lorry perceived the reflection on the wall to elongate, and Mr. Cruncher rose and stepped forward. His hair could not have been more violently on end, if it had been that moment dressed by the Cow with the crumpled horn in the house that Jack built.
vi: At this moment, Mr. Lorry again saw the shadow on the wall lengthen, and Cruncher stood up and walked over. His hair now stood up like a spiked club, each strand stiff and fierce as if anger wanted to shoot out of his head.
tr: Mr. Lorry now noticed that the reflection on the wall had lengthened; Mr. Cruncher had gotten up and was approaching them. In this house that Jack built, even if he had horns of a cow on his head, his hair could not look this wild.
es: Lorry observed that the shadow cast on the wall was lengthening. It was because Lapa had risen from his seat and was approaching the spy, beside whom he positioned himself without being seen or heard by him.

en: Unseen by the spy, Mr. Cruncher stood at his side, and touched him on the shoulder like a ghostly bailiff.
vi: The spy did not see Cruncher standing next to him.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, standing over the unsuspecting spy like a ghostly bailiff, touched his shoulder.
es: It was because Lapa had risen from his seat and was approaching the spy, beside whom he positioned himself without being seen or heard by him.

en: “That there Roger Cly, master,” said Mr. Cruncher, with a taciturn and iron-bound visage. “So you put him in his coffin?”
vi: Like a ghostly law enforcer, Cruncher grabbed Barsad's shoulder and said: "So it turns out that Roger Cly." "Hey you, did you put him in the coffin yourself?" − "Who else but me." − "Then who took him out of the coffin?" − "What do you mean?" - Barsad leaned back in his chair, stammering.
tr: "So, Roger Cly, your master, is dead," said Mr. Cruncher, with a silent and steely expression. "Did you put him in the coffin?"
es: Placing his right hand on Barsad's shoulder, he asked: —So it was you who put Rogerio Cly inside the coffin?

en: “I did.”
vi: "Hey you, did you put him in the coffin yourself?" − "Who else but me." − "Then who took him out of the coffin?" − "What do you mean?" - Barsad leaned back in his chair, stammering.
tr: "Yes."
es: —I went; yes.

en: “Who took him out of it?”
vi: "Hey you, did you put him in the coffin yourself?" − "Who else but me." − "Then who took him out of the coffin?" − "What do you mean?" - Barsad leaned back in his chair, stammering.
tr: "Well, then who took him out of there?"
es: —And who got him out of it?

en: Barsad leaned back in his chair, and stammered, “What do you mean?”
vi: "Hey you, did you put him in the coffin yourself?" − "Who else but me." − "Then who took him out of the coffin?" − "What do you mean?" - Barsad leaned back in his chair, stammering.
tr: Barsad leaned back in his chair and stammered, "What do you mean?"
es: Barsad, leaning back in his chair, stammered: —What do your words mean?

en: “I mean,” said Mr. Cruncher, “that he warn’t never in it. No! Not he! I’ll have my head took off, if he was ever in it.”
vi: − "I mean," - Cruncher said, - "that he was never in the coffin." No! Absolutely not! If he's in there, you can cut off my head.
tr: "So," said Mr. Cruncher, "he actually never got into that coffin. No! He wasn't! If he did, they can cut off my head."
es: —It means—Lapa replied—that Cly's corpse was never inside the coffin. No... and no! Off with my head if it was!

en: The spy looked round at the two gentlemen; they both looked in unspeakable astonishment at Jerry.
vi: The spy darted his eyes at the two noble people, who were also looking at Jerry in astonishment, unable to utter a word.
tr: Casus looked at the two gentlemen beside him; both were staring at Jerry in a bewildered state.
es: The spy alternately looked at the two gentlemen, who, in turn, gazed with infinite astonishment at Lapa.

en: “I tell you,” said Jerry, “that you buried paving-stones and earth in that there coffin. Don’t go and tell me that you buried Cly. It was a take in. Me and two more knows it.”
vi: Jerry continued: "I'm telling you, in that coffin, you buried nothing but dirt and rocks." Don't tell me you buried Cly. That's a scam. Two others and I have known for a long time."
tr: "In that coffin," said Jerry, "you had only put cobblestones and dirt. Don't tell me you buried Cly. This was a trick. Two other people and I know this."
es: —And I add—replied Jeremías Lapa—that you buried street cobblestones and dirt inside that coffin. Don't come here with nonsense or with pretensions of making me believe that they buried Cly, because I, and two other men, know very well what was inside the coffin.

en: “How do you know it?”
vi: How do you know?
tr: "How do you know?"
es: —But how do you know?

en: “What’s that to you? Ecod!” growled Mr. Cruncher, “it’s you I have got a old grudge again, is it, with your shameful impositions upon tradesmen! I’d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a guinea.”
vi: "That's irrelevant." Cruncher growled. "By God! You are my old grudge, for daring to pull such a humiliating scam on an honest man! If I could strangle you to death, I would do it even if it cost me half a Guinea."
tr: "What's it to you? Oh my God!" muttered Mr. Cruncher, "I already have an old grudge against you for those miserable taxes you collect from all the tradesmen!" "I'll strangle you right here for half a guinea."
es: —And what business is it of yours? —Lapa growled. —I have despised you for a long time, yes, sir, because even in matters as serious as death, you dare to deceive honest workers who only aspire to work. Know this, my good sir, for less than half a guinea, I would grab you by the neck and strangle you!

en: Sydney Carton, who, with Mr. Lorry, had been lost in amazement at this turn of the business, here requested Mr. Cruncher to moderate and explain himself.
vi: Sydney Carton and Mr. Lorry were both astonished by this turn of events. Upon hearing this, both of them asked Cruncher to calm down and explain clearly. −
tr: Sydney Carton, who was as bewildered by the turn of events as Mr. Lorry, at this point asked Mr. Cruncher to calm down and explain the situation.
es: Both Carton and Lorry, whose astonishment had reached its peak, begged Jeremiah Lapa to moderate himself and to explain to them what was an enigma of impossible solution.

en: “At another time, sir,” he returned, evasively, “the present time is ill-conwenient for explainin’. What I stand to, is, that he knows well wot that there Cly was never in that there coffin. Let him say he was, in so much as a word of one syllable, and I’ll either catch hold of his throat and choke him for half a guinea;” Mr. Cruncher dwelt upon this as quite a liberal offer; “or I’ll out and announce him.”
vi: Another time, sir, - he replied evasively, - it's not convenient to explain now. And I dare say that this fellow knows full well that Cly was never in that coffin. If he dares to say that again, just hearing it once more, I'd willingly pay half a guinea to strangle him on the spot, - Cruncher continued with that generous offer, - or I will go out and denounce him.
tr: "Another time, sir," Mr. Cruncher replied evasively, "this is not the right time to explain." "What I mean to say is that he knows very well that Cly is not in that coffin." "If he says otherwise, I'll either strangle him on the spot," Mr. Cruncher offered this quite generously, "or I'll go and report him immediately.""
