es: —Another day I will do it, sir—replied Lapa, not inclined to give the explanations that were asked of him,—for this is not a suitable occasion to enter into explanations. What I want to make clear is that that individual knows very well that Cly never intended to be locked in that coffin. Let that liar dare to repeat it, and I will strangle him with my claws or run off to denounce him.

en: “Humph! I see one thing,” said Carton. “I hold another card, Mr. Barsad. Impossible, here in raging Paris, with Suspicion filling the air, for you to outlive denunciation, when you are in communication with another aristocratic spy of the same antecedents as yourself, who, moreover, has the mystery about him of having feigned death and come to life again! A plot in the prisons, of the foreigner against the Republic. A strong card—a certain Guillotine card! Do you play?”
vi: − Hmm! I see another opportunity, - Carton said. - I have another card to play, Mr. Barsad. In this mad Paris, where everyone suspects everyone else, you cannot escape being denounced while you are in contact with another aristocratic spy of the same background as you, who also has the secret of faking his death and coming back to life! A conspiracy in the prison, by foreigners wanting to oppose the Republic. The sure-winning card... the Guillotine card! Will you play?
tr: "Hmm! There is just one thing," said Carton. "I have one more card in my hand, Mr. Barsad. In this agitated Paris, where suspicion is everywhere, it is quite a mysterious situation for you to have a connection with an aristocratic spy with a similar past as yours, and for this person to come back to life after a fake death. It is hardly possible for you to stay away from being informed! A foreigner playing a game against the Republic in the prisons. A strong card – definitely a guillotine card! Shall we continue the game?"
es: —Hmm!—grumbled Carton. —I encounter another triumph, Barsad. Here in Paris, where the atmosphere is filled with suspicion, it is quite certain that one who, like you, maintains close relations with another aristocratic spy of your same ilk, who bears the mystery of having pretended to be dead and buried only to resurrect against all divine and human laws, does not escape alive from a denunciation. Machinations against the Republic concocted by foreigners whom the Republic has on its payroll... Bad, bad! It is a very great triumph... the triumph of the Guillotine, Barsad. Are you not playing? —No! I don't play!

en: “No!” returned the spy. “I throw up. I confess that we were so unpopular with the outrageous mob, that I only got away from England at the risk of being ducked to death, and that Cly was so ferreted up and down, that he never would have got away at all but for that sham. Though how this man knows it was a sham, is a wonder of wonders to me.”
vi: − No! - The spy replied. - I give up. I confess that the brutal crowd hates both of us so much that I had no choice but to risk drowning to escape from England, and Cly was being hunted everywhere, so if he didn't fake his death, he couldn't have escaped. As for how this man knew about the faked death, I have no idea.
tr: "No!" said the spy. "Alright, I'll tell you. In that maddened crowd, we had so little space that I risked death and fled from England; as for Cly, he was so trapped that if we hadn't turned that cabinet, he would never have escaped. But what I'm curious about is how this man learned that it was a game."
es: —replied the spy. —I surrender! I confess that we had become so unpopular with the vile rabble, that I managed to escape from England where I was at risk of being hanged, and Cly was so compromised that if he didn't die, it's certain that he wouldn't have been able to get out even by air. What amazes me, what stuns me, what drives me crazy, is that this man knows that Cly wasn't buried.

en: “Never you trouble your head about this man,” retorted the contentious Mr. Cruncher; “you’ll have trouble enough with giving your attention to that gentleman. And look here! Once more!”—Mr. Cruncher could not be restrained from making rather an ostentatious parade of his liberality—“I’d catch hold of your throat and choke you for half a guinea.”
vi: − You guys don't waste your time with this one anymore, - Cruncher often argued back. - You guys don't need to waste your time paying attention to him. Look here! Just one more time! - Cruncher couldn't help but propose his boastful exchange, - I'd give up half a guinea to strangle you to death right now.
tr: The combative Mr. Cruncher replied harshly, "Don't waste your thoughts on that man, you'll already have enough trouble dealing with this gentleman." One more thing! I'm telling you again!" –Mr. Cruncher once again flaunted his generosity– "I'll choke and strangle you!"
es: What amazes me, what stuns me, what drives me crazy, is that this man knows that Cly wasn't buried. How did he find out? —Don't get worked up, my good sir—replied Lapa—You'd do well to pay attention to what these gentlemen are telling you. But don't forget that for less than half a guinea, I'll strangle you with my own hands.

en: The Sheep of the prisons turned from him to Sydney Carton, and said, with more decision, “It has come to a point. I go on duty soon, and can’t overstay my time. You told me you had a proposal; what is it? Now, it is of no use asking too much of me. Ask me to do anything in my office, putting my head in great extra danger, and I had better trust my life to the chances of a refusal than the chances of consent. In short, I should make that choice. You talk of desperation. We are all desperate here. Remember! I may denounce you if I think proper, and I can swear my way through stone walls, and so can others. Now, what do you want with me?”
vi: The prison sheep glanced from Cruncher to Sydney Carton, then spoke more decisively: − It's time to lay it all out. My shift is about to start and I can't stay too long. You said you had a proposal; what is it? Look, demanding too much from me won't do any good. Forcing me to do anything in my position that risks my neck, I'd rather risk refusing than agreeing. In short, the choice is mine. You mentioned desperation. We are all desperate here. Remember that! I can also denounce you if I see fit, and I can lie under oath as well as anyone. Now, what do you want from me? −
tr: The prison turnkey then turned to Sydney Carton and said more resolutely, "We are at a certain point now. Soon I will return to my work, I can't stay here any longer. You said you had a proposal for me; what is it? Don't ask me for something I can't do. If you ask for something that would put my head in danger, of course, I can't agree to that. In short, I must make this choice. You are talking to me about despair. We are all desperate here. Remember! If we think about it, I can also report you and swear falsely to get out of those stone walls, as can others. Now tell me, what do you want from me?"
es: The executioner's blackbird turned to Carton and spoke with a decisiveness he had not shown until that moment: —I go on duty very soon, and I cannot afford to linger any longer. You told me you wanted to make me a proposition; would you be so kind as to state it? I will start by telling you not to ask me for great things, not to demand anything that conflicts with my position, nothing that puts my head at greater risk than it already is, for I prefer to risk my life on the contingencies of a refusal rather than on those of consent. You spoke earlier of a desperate venture; we are all desperate now; for my part, I confess that I am as desperate as anyone. Another thing; without the slightest scruple, I will betray you if I see it suits me, for when the house collapses, one seeks an exit among the heaps of ruins. Having made these warnings, which you should not lose sight of, tell me what you want from me.

en: “Not very much. You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?”
vi: Not much. You're the jailer at the Conciergerie, right?
tr: "It's not much. You are a guard at the Conciergerie, aren't you?"
es: —Very little. Aren't you the jailer of the Ministry?

en: “I tell you once for all, there is no such thing as an escape possible,” said the spy, firmly.
vi: − I'm telling you outright, there's no chance of escape from there, - the spy asserted.
tr: "I'm telling you for the first and last time, it's impossible to escape from there," said the spy with a firm attitude.
es: —Instead of answering your question, I will tell you that there is no possible escape—replied the spy with determination.

en: “Why need you tell me what I have not asked? You are a turnkey at the Conciergerie?”
vi: − Why are you talking about something I didn't ask? Are you the jailer at the Conciergerie?
tr: "Why are you telling me something I didn't ask you about? Are you a guard at the Conciergerie?"
es: —And I demand that you answer what I just asked. —I am sometimes.

en: “I am sometimes.”
vi: − Sometimes I do that job. −
tr: "Yes, sometimes."
es: —I am sometimes.

en: “You can be when you choose?”
vi: Can you do that job when you need to?
tr: "Can you do this whenever you want?"
es: —Can he be when he wants to?

en: “I can pass in and out when I choose.”
vi: − I can come and go whenever I want.
tr: "I can come and go as I please.""
es: —I can enter and leave the Concierge's office whenever I want.

en: Sydney Carton filled another glass with brandy, poured it slowly out upon the hearth, and watched it as it dropped. It being all spent, he said, rising:
vi: Sydney Carton poured another glass of strong liquor, then slowly poured it onto the fireplace floor, watching the liquid drip until it was empty, then stood up and said: −
tr: Sydney Carton filled another glass of cognac, then slowly poured it onto the base of the fireplace and watched it spill. When it was all over, he stood up and said:
es: Carton filled another small glass of liquor, poured it drop by drop on the ground, and after a few moments of reflection said:

en: “So far, we have spoken before these two, because it was as well that the merits of the cards should not rest solely between you and me. Come into the dark room here, and let us have one final word alone.”
vi: We have been talking in front of these two people because they also need to know that the value of these cards is not just between you and me. Go into that dark room and we will have a final word with each other.
tr: "Up until now, we have spoken in front of these two people because the value of our cards needed to be known by others as well. Now, come to that dark room so we can talk alone about my final words."
es: —Up to this point, we have spoken in the presence of these two gentlemen because it was convenient for me that someone, besides the two of us, should be aware of the value of the letters I have, but what remains is something that should stay between you and me. Accompany me to that room, where we will exchange the few remaining words.

en: CHAPTER IX.
vi: Go into that dark room and we will have a final word with each other.
tr: IX
es: IX.

en: The Game Made
vi: 9. Betting While Sydney Carton and the prison sheep were in the dark room next door, talking so quietly that no sound could be heard, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry with a wary and suspicious expression.
tr: The Game Begins
es: THE GAME IS ON

en: While Sydney Carton and the Sheep of the prisons were in the adjoining dark room, speaking so low that not a sound was heard, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry in considerable doubt and mistrust. That honest tradesman’s manner of receiving the look, did not inspire confidence; he changed the leg on which he rested, as often as if he had fifty of those limbs, and were trying them all; he examined his finger-nails with a very questionable closeness of attention; and whenever Mr. Lorry’s eye caught his, he was taken with that peculiar kind of short cough requiring the hollow of a hand before it, which is seldom, if ever, known to be an infirmity attendant on perfect openness of character.
vi: 9. Betting While Sydney Carton and the prison sheep were in the dark room next door, talking so quietly that no sound could be heard, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry with a wary and suspicious expression. The way the "honest businessman" reacted to Mr. Lorry's gaze only increased the suspicion; Jerry stood restlessly as if he had fifty feet and was continuously trying to balance his body on each one; he scrutinized his fingernails with suspiciously intense focus; whenever he caught Mr. Lorry's eye, he would cough to bring his palm up to cover his mouth in a polite gesture but only added to the impression of concealment and dishonesty.
tr: While Sydney Carton and the prison lamb were talking in the dark room next door, in a voice so low that no one could hear, Mr. Lorry looked at Jerry with evident suspicion and distrust. The response of this honest tradesman to these looks was not very reassuring either; he was frequently shifting his legs as if he had forty of them and was trying each one; he was examining his nails with quite a suspicious interest, and whenever he made eye contact with Mr. Lorry, he would cover his mouth with his hand as if struck by a strange coughing fit, which could not be seen as a very honest behavior.
es: While Sydney Carton and the executioner's blackbird, locked in the adjoining room, conferred in such low voices that not the slightest sound filtered through the door's cracks, Lorry watched Jeremiah Lapa with manifest suspicion and deep distrust. It should be noted that the effect produced by the good banker's persistent gaze on the honest craftsman was not the most suitable for dispelling apprehensions; he shifted the leg on which the weight of his body rested as frequently as if he had fifty limbs and wished to test the sturdiness of each; he examined his nails with such scrupulous attention that it aroused suspicion, and whenever his eyes met Lorry's scrutinizing ones, he was seized by a fit of coughing that forced him to bring his hand to his mouth, a symptom that rarely, if ever, accompanies perfect frankness of character.

en: “Jerry,” said Mr. Lorry. “Come here.”
vi: − Jerry, - Mr. Lorry said. - Come here.
tr: "Jerry," said Mr. Lorry. "Come here.""
es: —Jeremiah!—exclaimed Lorry suddenly. —Come here!

en: Mr. Cruncher came forward sideways, with one of his shoulders in advance of him.
vi: Cruncher shrugged his shoulders forward, walking sideways towards him. −
tr: Mr. Cruncher came over, standing with one shoulder forward.
es: Lapa approached walking in the manner of a crab, that is, sideways.

en: “What have you been, besides a messenger?”
vi: What did you do before when you were both a messenger for the company and something else?
tr: "What do you do besides carrying news?"
es: —What jobs have you had besides being a bank messenger?

en: After some cogitation, accompanied with an intent look at his patron, Mr. Cruncher conceived the luminous idea of replying, “Agicultooral character.”
vi: After a moment of pondering, accompanied by a stare towards his boss, Cruncher came up with a creative answer: − Worked as a digger.
tr: After thinking for a bit and looking carefully at his boss, Mr. Cruncher finally came up with the brilliant idea to say, "I am engaged in farming."
es: After a rather thorough meditation, and after seeking an illuminating idea in the fixed gaze of his superior, Lapa replied:

en: “My mind misgives me much,” said Mr. Lorry, angrily shaking a forefinger at him, “that you have used the respectable and great house of Tellson’s as a blind, and that you have had an unlawful occupation of an infamous description. If you have, don’t expect me to befriend you when you get back to England. If you have, don’t expect me to keep your secret. Tellson’s shall not be imposed upon.”
vi: − I am very suspicious, - Mr. Lorry angrily waved his index finger in front of Cruncher, - you dared to use the name and reputation of Tellson's to cover up your vile illegal activities. If so, don't expect me to remain friendly with you when we return to England. If so, don't expect me to stay silent about your actions. Don't think you can take advantage of Tellson's anymore.
tr: "This matter has upset me," said Mr. Lorry, shaking his index finger at him angrily, "because you have engaged in disgraceful illegal activities hiding behind the respectable and grand bank of Tellson. Don't think that I will help you when you return to England. Don't ever think that I will keep this secret. Tellson can never be misused in such a way."
es: —I have been a farmer. —I harbor well-founded fears—replied Lorry, moving his hand with a fierce gesture—that you have been an errand man for the respectable Tellson's Bank to mislead, to have a screen that covered other occupations contrary to the Law, occupations simply infamous. If so, do not expect any consideration from me as soon as we reach England; if so, do not expect me to keep the secret either. Tellson must know it, and they will know it.

en: “I hope, sir,” pleaded the abashed Mr. Cruncher, “that a gentleman like yourself wot I’ve had the honour of odd jobbing till I’m grey at it, would think twice about harming of me, even if it wos so—I don’t say it is, but even if it wos. And which it is to be took into account that if it wos, it wouldn’t, even then, be all o’ one side. There’d be two sides to it. There might be medical doctors at the present hour, a picking up their guineas where a honest tradesman don’t pick up his fardens—fardens! no, nor yet his half fardens—half fardens! no, nor yet his quarter—a banking away like smoke at Tellson’s, and a cocking their medical eyes at that tradesman on the sly, a going in and going out to their own carriages—ah! equally like smoke, if not more so. Well, that ’ud be imposing, too, on Tellson’s. For you cannot sarse the goose and not the gander. And here’s Mrs. Cruncher, or leastways wos in the Old England times, and would be to-morrow, if cause given, a floppin’ again the business to that degree as is ruinating—stark ruinating! Whereas them medical doctors’ wives don’t flop—catch ’em at it! Or, if they flop, their floppings goes in favour of more patients, and how can you rightly have one without t’other? Then, wot with undertakers, and wot with parish clerks, and wot with sextons, and wot with private watchmen (all awaricious and all in it), a man wouldn’t get much by it, even if it wos so. And wot little a man did get, would never prosper with him, Mr. Lorry. He’d never have no good of it; he’d want all along to be out of the line, if he, could see his way out, being once in—even if it wos so.”
vi: − Sir, - Cruncher pleaded nervously, - a noble person like you, whom I have been fortunate to do small tasks for until now, please don't harm me hastily, even if it is true... I'm not saying you are right, but let's suppose it is. And you must think that even if you are right, it's not just me. It's due to both sides. At this moment, there are doctors making a lot of money while an honest worker finds it very difficult to earn a few pennies... Pennies! No, not even half a penny... Half a penny! No, earning a quarter of a penny is already hard... Those doctors just borrow carriages to go to Tellson's as fast as smoke or even faster, secretly winking at the worker... Well, that's also taking advantage of Tellson's, sir. You can't treat people differently based on their appearance. And then there's my wife, Mrs. Cruncher, not now but at least back in England and probably in the future too, she just sits down and curses, so I can't do any business... always unlucky! At that time, the wives of those doctors didn't curse their husbands... they took everything! And if they did sit down, they cursed so that many people would get sick, so their husbands would have more work, is it wrong for me but right for them? Then there's the bribes to the undertakers, the parish overseers, the grave diggers, the cemetery keepers, all of them are equally greedy, so how much is left for the worker, even if it is true. If you earn a little, it's not enough to get by, Mr. Lorry. It's not enjoyable work, sir; anyone who falls into that job just wants to leave if they have the chance to change... the job you mentioned.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, whose face turned red with shame, began to plead, "I hope, sir," he said, "that a gentleman like you, whom I have had the honor of working for until my hair turned gray, would think twice before harming me, even if I did such a thing, not that I am saying I did, but if I had." And if I had done it, there would be an explanation for it. One must look at it from both sides. Right now, while doctors are filling their pockets with guineas, an honest tradesman might be shooting at a penny –not a single penny going into his pocket! Nothing at all, not even half a penny –penniless men! No, not even a quarter penny –while those men are slipping in and out of Tellson's like they are looting from a fire, giving the honest tradesman a sidelong glance as they pass by, getting into their carriages, getting out of their carriages –ah! just like looting from a fire. Aren't they using Tellson's too? These things should not be overlooked. I have a wife, I mean I had one when I was in England, and I hope I will have one in the future, a woman who prays morning and night, to the point of being tiresome –and what prayers! But they, they don't even compare to the doctors' wives –have you ever seen them? Or if they do pray, it's for more patients to come, so how can you fully understand one side without looking at the other? Then even if that were the case, among all those undertakers, church clerks, gravediggers, and private guards (by the way, they are all greedy and all involved in it), what falls to men like us? So even if a person deals with such things, he doesn't get much out of it, Mr. Lorry. He sees no benefit; and once he gets involved, if he could foresee it, he would always want to get out of this path –I mean, if I had done it, that's how it would be."
es: —I cannot believe, sir,—replied Lapa humbly—that a gentleman like you, a gentleman in whose service I have grown old, would decide to cause me such considerable harm without thinking it over very well first..., even if what you suspect were true. I am not saying that it is; but if it were, I would always trust that you would not treat me so badly. Assuming that it were what you fear, even then the matter would have to be studied from two points of view, since it does not have just one, but two. There are doctors in medicine, and not a few, who find gold guineas where an honest tradesman finds nothing but miserable pennies... Not even pennies! Half pennies... And not even half pennies; quarter pennies... and that's generous. And what do you say about those who enter and leave Tellson's Bank, passing by the honest tradesman who is sitting by the door on an old stool, while they ride in luxurious carriages? Isn't it a sight to awaken the most dormant appetite? Add to all that the presence in England of a Mrs. Lapa who spends day and night on her knees praying to ruin all her husband's business, while the wives of the doctors and those who ride in luxurious carriages pray for the prosperity of their respective households. Another thing; if what you suspect were true, which I am not saying it is, do you think I would become very rich by taking the leftovers from the undertakers, what the sacristans didn't want, what the cemetery watchmen scorned? No, Mr. Lorry, no! It's a lost trade; believe me.

en: “Ugh!” cried Mr. Lorry, rather relenting, nevertheless, “I am shocked at the sight of you.”
vi: − Oh! - Mr. Lorry exclaimed, his tone somewhat softened. - You are truly dreadful.
tr: "Off!" shouted Mr. Lorry, though he had softened a bit. "I am amazed as I look at you."
es: —Ugh!—exclaimed Lorry—You horrify me!

en: “Now, what I would humbly offer to you, sir,” pursued Mr. Cruncher, “even if it wos so, which I don’t say it is—”
vi: − Therefore, sir, I beg you, - Cruncher still tried to say, - that matter, I will not speak of it...
tr: "Now sir, the thing that I will presumptuously propose to you," continued Mr. Cruncher, "even if there were such a thing, which I am not saying there is..."
es: —The offer that I humbly dare to make to you, even if what you suspect were true, which I am not saying it is, is...

en: “Don’t prevaricate,” said Mr. Lorry.
vi: − Don't beat around the bush, - Mr. Lorry said.
tr: "Don't drag it out," said Mr. Lorry.
es: —Don't come with lies!

en: “No, I will not, sir,” returned Mr. Crunches as if nothing were further from his thoughts or practice—“which I don’t say it is—wot I would humbly offer to you, sir, would be this. Upon that there stool, at that there Bar, sets that there boy of mine, brought up and growed up to be a man, wot will errand you, message you, general-light-job you, till your heels is where your head is, if such should be your wishes. If it wos so, which I still don’t say it is (for I will not prewaricate to you, sir), let that there boy keep his father’s place, and take care of his mother; don’t blow upon that boy’s father—do not do it, sir—and let that father go into the line of the reg’lar diggin’, and make amends for what he would have undug—if it wos so—by diggin’ of ’em in with a will, and with conwictions respectin’ the futur’ keepin’ of ’em safe. That, Mr. Lorry,” said Mr. Cruncher, wiping his forehead with his arm, as an announcement that he had arrived at the peroration of his discourse, “is wot I would respectfully offer to you, sir. A man don’t see all this here a goin’ on dreadful round him, in the way of Subjects without heads, dear me, plentiful enough fur to bring the price down to porterage and hardly that, without havin’ his serious thoughts of things. And these here would be mine, if it wos so, entreatin’ of you fur to bear in mind that wot I said just now, I up and said in the good cause when I might have kep’ it back.”
vi: − No, I will not do it anymore, sir, - Cruncher spoke according to his thoughts and habits. - I will not mention... the matter I am begging you for. Sitting on that chair, at the Temple gate, is my son, whom I have raised to adulthood, he will run errands for you, carry messages for you, do everything you command until death, if you wish. That matter, I will not mention, because I will not beat around the bush with you anymore, sir, please let the boy take his father's place, take care of his mother, please do not accuse his father... do not do that, please... and let his father go to work digging graves properly to make up for what he should not have dug... that matter, and I will do the burial work properly, decently from now on. So, Mr. Lorry, - Cruncher said while wiping his forehead, as a way to declare that he had reached the end of his speech, - that is what I respectfully present to you. With so many terrible things happening around like this, anyone who sees it must think carefully, oh my, just seeing how many citizens have lost their heads is enough to know that the wages for porters have dropped drastically. And I also ask you to remember the recent matter, that matter, those things I said earlier to expose that guy, I helped Mr. Carton when I could have said nothing at all. −
tr: "No, I'm not prolonging it," replied Mr. Cruncher as if he were just about to express exactly what was on his mind or his proposal –"I'm not saying that –but if that's the case, what I would presumptuously offer you, sir, is this: Over there on the stool, you know the boy sitting by the Bar, that's my son, he's hardworking, he's good, if you want, he can do your errands, carry letters, handle your daily small tasks. If that's the case, which I still say it isn't (because I don't want to prolong the matter, sir), let that boy take his father's place and look after his mother; have pity on that boy's father –don't do it, sir– and let his father become an ordinary gravedigger and give up grave robbing –if this is true– and with this wish and belief, he would honor and protect the future of the dead, how wonderful. That's my offer to you, Mr. Lorry," said Mr. Cruncher, wiping his forehead with his arm as if to indicate he had reached the end of his speech, "that was my offer, sir. People don't ever think about the terrible things happening around them, just look, citizens with their heads chopped off, oh there are so many of them, porters are everywhere. That's what I would have to say, if the situation were as you said, I would beg you not to forget what I said and I would do it all for a good cause, otherwise, I might not have said any of this at all."
es: —No, sir; I will speak truthfully. The humble offer I wish to make is the following: on the bench placed on the sidewalk of the Tribunal, my son, who is almost a man, will sit, run errands, keep watch, and strive to perform the duties that I have carried out until now, if you so wish. If what you fear were true, which I am not saying it is, nor that it isn't, because I do not want to lie to you, give my son his father's position and let him take care of his mother at the same time, and meanwhile, let the father be free to dig the earth as he pleases. That is, Mr. Lorry—added Lapa, wiping the sweat from his forehead with the back of his hand,—what I wish to offer you.

en: “That at least is true,” said Mr. Lorry. “Say no more now. It may be that I shall yet stand your friend, if you deserve it, and repent in action—not in words. I want no more words.”
vi: At least this is true, - Mr. Lorry said. - Now don't say anything more. Maybe I would still be close to you, if you were worthy, and repented through actions... not words. I don't want to hear another word.
tr: "At least this is true," said Mr. Lorry. "Don't say anything else anymore. If this is what you deserve and you show your remorse through your actions – not just words – I might be able to help you. Don't say anything else anymore."
es: —Quiet, Jeremías! Quiet, and don't say another word! Who knows if I will decide to treat you as I have until now, if with actions, not words, you show me your repentance. Words, I do not want them; they do not convince me.

en: Mr. Cruncher knuckled his forehead, as Sydney Carton and the spy returned from the dark room. “Adieu, Mr. Barsad,” said the former; “our arrangement thus made, you have nothing to fear from me.”
vi: Cruncher tapped his forehead as Sydney Carton and the spy emerged from the dark room. − Goodbye, Mr. Barsad, - Carton said. - Since we have an agreement, you have no reason to fear me anymore.
tr: Mr. Cruncher was rubbing his forehead with his fingers when Sydney Carton and the spy came from the dark room. "Adieu Mr. Barsad," said Carton; "now that we have an agreement, you have no reason to fear me."
es: Carton and Barsad left at that moment. —Goodbye, Barsad—said the first;—we have an understanding. Have no fear of me.

en: He sat down in a chair on the hearth, over against Mr. Lorry. When they were alone, Mr. Lorry asked him what he had done?
vi: He sat down in the chair by the fireplace, facing Mr. Lorry as before. When only they were left, Mr. Lorry asked him what he had done? −
tr: She sat in a chair next to the fireplace, directly across from Mr. Lorry. When they were alone, Mr. Lorry asked her what she was doing.
es: He took a seat next to Lorry, who asked him.

en: “Not much. If it should go ill with the prisoner, I have ensured access to him, once.”
vi: Not much. If something unfortunate happened to Darnay, I had ensured a way to see him once in prison.
tr: "There isn't much. If the prisoner gets into trouble, I said I would make sure he is reached."
es: —What have they done? —Not much; if the prisoner's fate becomes uncertain, they will allow me to visit him; nothing more.

en: Mr. Lorry’s countenance fell.
vi: Mr. Lorry's face darkened.
tr: Mr. Lorry's face fell.
es: Lorry's discouragement deepened.

en: “It is all I could do,” said Carton. “To propose too much, would be to put this man’s head under the axe, and, as he himself said, nothing worse could happen to him if he were denounced. It was obviously the weakness of the position. There is no help for it.”
vi: "That's all I can do," said Carton. "An excessive demand would lead this person to the guillotine, and as he himself has said, if he were to be denounced, he would die just the same." Clearly, this is a weak point in my position. There's no other choice.
tr: "This is all I can do," said Carton. "Asking for more would mean putting the man's head under the guillotine, and as he said, being reported would be his end. That's what makes it difficult. There's nothing to be done."
es: —I can do no more—replied Carton. —Asking too much would be equivalent to sending that man to the guillotine, and, as he very well said, no greater misfortune could befall him even if we betrayed him. Let us be thankful for the precariousness of his position, for otherwise, we would have achieved nothing. —But reaching him, in the event that he is condemned, is not saving him—objected Lorry.

en: “But access to him,” said Mr. Lorry, “if it should go ill before the Tribunal, will not save him.”
vi: − But the matter of meeting Darnay, - Mr. Lorry said, - if something unfortunate happens in court, it wouldn't save him either.
tr: "But if things go wrong before the trial," said Mr. Lorry, "reaching him won't be enough to save him.""
es: —But reaching him, in the event that he is condemned, is not saving him—objected Lorry.

en: “I never said it would.”
vi: − I never said that.
tr: "I didn't say we could save it either."
es: —I never said I would save him—replied Carton.

en: Mr. Lorry’s eyes gradually sought the fire; his sympathy with his darling, and the heavy disappointment of his second arrest, gradually weakened them; he was an old man now, overborne with anxiety of late, and his tears fell.
vi: Mr. Lorry's eyes slowly turned towards the fire; the love he had for Lucie and the deep despair when Darnay was arrested again had left his eyes vacant; he was now an old man, recently having endured excessive worries, and tears streamed down his cheeks. −
tr: Mr. Lorry's gaze slowly drifted towards the fire; his love for the one and only Lucie and the heavy disappointment brought by this second arrest had weakened him; now he was an old man, crushed under the weight of recent troubles, drowned in tears.
es: Lorry's eyes gradually sought the fire burning in the fireplace. The pain caused by the second imprisonment of the husband of the girl he loved so much drained all his energy. He was no longer a young man, despite his many years; he was an old man crushed by anxiety. The tears stored in his chest rose to his eyes and rolled silently down his wrinkled cheeks.

en: “You are a good man and a true friend,” said Carton, in an altered voice. “Forgive me if I notice that you are affected. I could not see my father weep, and sit by, careless. And I could not respect your sorrow more, if you were my father. You are free from that misfortune, however.”
vi: You are a kind-hearted person and a true friend, - Carton said, changing his tone. - Please forgive me for seeing you so moved. If you were my father, I could not sit by and watch my father cry without concern. I respect your suffering as if it were my own father's. But fortunately for you, I am not your son.
tr: "You are a good man and a true friend," said Carton, in a different tone of voice. "Forgive me for giving you such bad news. If I saw my father crying, I couldn't sit idly by, and if you were my father, I couldn't show more respect to your sorrow than I do now. But fortunately, you have not had the misfortune of being my father."
es: —You have a great heart and are a loyal friend to your friends—said Carton with a disturbed voice. —Forgive me if I have been the bearer of news that has affected you so painfully. It would be impossible for me to see my father cry and remain calm, and I swear to you that I respect your pain no less than I would respect my father's. So much respect, so much interest, so much feeling was in the tone and expression of the words that are transcribed, that Lorry, who had not had the opportunity to appreciate the good side of Carton, experienced one of the greatest surprises of his life.

en: Though he said the last words, with a slip into his usual manner, there was a true feeling and respect both in his tone and in his touch, that Mr. Lorry, who had never seen the better side of him, was wholly unprepared for. He gave him his hand, and Carton gently pressed it.
vi: Even though he spoke the last sentence with the same indifferent attitude as before, his tone and emotions were still full of affection and respect to such an extent that Mr. Lorry was completely surprised because he had never seen him express himself like that. He extended his hand to Carton, who gently took it.
tr: Despite saying his final words in his usual manner, there was a sincere feeling and respect both in his tone of voice and in his touch, and Mr. Lorry, who had never seen this good side of him before, was completely caught off guard. He extended his hand to him, and Carton gently shook it.
es: So much respect, so much interest, so much feeling was in the tone and expression of the words that are transcribed, that Lorry, who had not had the opportunity to appreciate the good side of Carton, experienced one of the greatest surprises of his life. He silently extended a hand to his interlocutor, who shook it warmly.

en: “To return to poor Darnay,” said Carton. “Don’t tell Her of this interview, or this arrangement. It would not enable Her to go to see him. She might think it was contrived, in case of the worse, to convey to him the means of anticipating the sentence.”
vi: − Back to poor Darnay, - Carton said. - Please do not let Lucie know about this exchange, or this agreement. She must not be allowed to see Darnay. She might think that this is a plan to, in the worst-case scenario, give him a means to commit suicide before being taken to the guillotine.
tr: "Returning to poor Darnay," said Carton. "Do not mention this meeting or this arrangement to his wife. This will not enable her to see her husband. She might think that this plan, at worst, was made to bring the necessary things for him to carry out his own execution."
es: —Returning to poor Darnay—replied Carton,—I will say that it is not convenient for you to speak to your wife about the conference we just had, nor about what I have obtained from the spy. She could not reach the dungeon, and if she knew that I was going, she might think that my intention was to provide her husband with the means to advance the execution of the sentence.

en: Mr. Lorry had not thought of that, and he looked quickly at Carton to see if it were in his mind. It seemed to be; he returned the look, and evidently understood it.
vi: Mr. Lorry did not think of that at all, and quickly glanced at Carton to see if he really thought so. It seemed true; he returned Mr. Lorry's look and clearly understood the meaning. −
tr: Mr. Lorry had never thought of this and quickly looked at Carton to see if such a thing had occurred to him. It seemed it had; this was plainly evident from Carton's expression.
es: Lorry had not thought of it, who upon hearing the previous words, quickly turned his eyes towards Carton, as if to ascertain whether what he did not want Lucía to think was precisely what he had in mind.

en: “She might think a thousand things,” Carton said, “and any of them would only add to her trouble. Don’t speak of me to her. As I said to you when I first came, I had better not see her. I can put my hand out, to do any little helpful work for her that my hand can find to do, without that. You are going to her, I hope? She must be very desolate to-night.”
vi: She can imagine a thousand things, - Carton said, - and each one would only make her more miserable. Do not tell her about me. As I told you when I first came here, it is best that I do not meet her. I can still do anything useful for Lucie within my capacity without having to meet her. You are going to Lucie's house, aren't you? I hope so. Tonight she must be in great despair.
tr: "Thousands of things might come to Lucie's mind," said Carton, "and each one of them would only increase her distress. Do not mention me to her. As I said when I first came, it is better if I do not see her. I can do everything I can without seeing her. You are going to her now, aren't you? She must be in a wretched state tonight."
es: —Perhaps she would think that—added Carton,—and she might suspect a thousand other things, each of which would be an added torture to those already besieging her. Do not even speak to her about me. As I told you upon arriving in Paris, I will not see her; it is best that I do not see her. Whatever I can do for her, I will do better by not seeing her. Are you going to visit her now? Go as soon as possible, yes, for tonight she must be in despair.

en: “I am going now, directly.”
vi: − I am going now, right away.
tr: "Now I will go directly to him.""
es: —I'm going right now.

en: “I am glad of that. She has such a strong attachment to you and reliance on you. How does she look?”
vi: − Then I am very glad. She is extremely attached to and trusts you. How does she look now, I wonder?
tr: "I'm glad to hear that. He is very attached to you and trusts you. How does he look?"
es: —Which makes me very happy. He loves you very much and has limitless confidence in you. How is he now?

en: “Anxious and unhappy, but very beautiful.”
vi: − Worried and distressed, but very beautiful.
tr: "Anxious and unhappy, but very beautiful."
es: —Swimming in a dreadful sea of anxieties, but beautiful as always.

en: “Ah!”
vi: − Ah!
tr: "Ahh!"
es: —Ah!

en: It was a long, grieving sound, like a sigh—almost like a sob. It attracted Mr. Lorry’s eyes to Carton’s face, which was turned to the fire. A light, or a shade (the old gentleman could not have said which), passed from it as swiftly as a change will sweep over a hill-side on a wild bright day, and he lifted his foot to put back one of the little flaming logs, which was tumbling forward. He wore the white riding-coat and top-boots, then in vogue, and the light of the fire touching their light surfaces made him look very pale, with his long brown hair, all untrimmed, hanging loose about him. His indifference to fire was sufficiently remarkable to elicit a word of remonstrance from Mr. Lorry; his boot was still upon the hot embers of the flaming log, when it had broken under the weight of his foot.
vi: A prolonged, sorrowful sound, like a sigh - almost like a sob. The utterance made Mr. Lorry attentively look at Carton's face, which was turned towards the firelight. The light, or the shadow (the old man couldn't determine), was swiftly passing over Carton's face like patches of light and dark sweeping quickly over a hillside on a bright sunny day, and he lifted a foot to push a small burning log, causing it to tumble into the fireplace. He wore a white coat and high boots, the fashionable style: the firelight reflected on his light-colored attire made him appear even more pale under his long, disheveled brown hair. His indifference to the fire was enough to prompt Mr. Lorry to utter a reminder; his boot was still placed on the burning log's red embers as it crumbled under the weight of his foot.
tr: It was a long and sorrowful sound, like a sigh – almost like a sob. Mr. Lorry turned his eyes to Carton, whose face was turned toward the fire, at the sound. On a bright sunny day, a light or shadow passed quickly over Carton's face, like a broken coin rolling downhill, and he extended his foot to push back a burning log that had rolled forward. He was wearing a white riding jacket, which was fashionable at the time, and long boots, and the light from the fire reflecting off his clothes made him look quite pale, while his long, disheveled brown hair was untied. Carton was so indifferent to the fire that Mr. Lorry couldn't help but warn him; for when the burning log broke under the weight of his foot, Carton's booted foot was still standing on its hot embers.
es: It was a deep, long exclamation, similar to a groan, to a stifled sob. Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: “I forgot it,” he said.
vi: − I forgot, - he said.
tr: "I forgot," said Carton.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: Mr. Lorry’s eyes were again attracted to his face. Taking note of the wasted air which clouded the naturally handsome features, and having the expression of prisoners’ faces fresh in his mind, he was strongly reminded of that expression.
vi: Mr. Lorry's eyes looked up at his face again. Noticing the weariness covering the once delicate features of Carton, he immediately recalled the face of the prisoner still vividly imprinted in his mind. −
tr: Mr. Lorry's eyes again drifted to the young man's face. He noticed the air of wasted potential that overshadowed his naturally handsome features and the expression on his face reminded him of the expressions on the faces of the prisoners he had recently seen.
es: Lorry's eyes turned towards Carton's quickly enough to catch, while the latter's were fixed on the fire in the fireplace, the fleeting passage of either a light or a shadow; the elderly gentleman would not have dared to specify which it was.

en: “And your duties here have drawn to an end, sir?” said Carton, turning to him.
vi: Is your work here almost finished? - Carton said, turning to look at him. −
tr: Turning to him, Carton asked, "Have you finished your duties here, sir?"
es: —Have you already finished the task that brought you here?—asked Carton after a few brief seconds.

en: “Yes. As I was telling you last night when Lucie came in so unexpectedly, I have at length done all that I can do here. I hoped to have left them in perfect safety, and then to have quitted Paris. I have my Leave to Pass. I was ready to go.”
vi: It's done. As I was telling you last night when Lucie came here unexpectedly, I have finally completed the necessary tasks here. I hope they will stay here in complete safety, then I will bid farewell to Paris. I have a pass. I am ready to leave.
tr: "Yes. As I explained last night when Lucie arrived unexpectedly, I did everything I could here. I was hoping to leave Paris, leaving them here safely. I have my exit document. I was ready to go."
es: —Yes. As I was telling you last night, when Lucía arrived so unexpectedly, I have done everything that could be done. I only hoped to see you safe from danger and happy before leaving Paris. I was planning to leave very soon; but...

en: They were both silent.
vi: Both were silent.
tr: They were both silent.
es: Both remained silent.

en: “Yours is a long life to look back upon, sir?” said Carton, wistfully.
vi: − You have a whole long life to look back on, don't you? - Carton said, thoughtfully.
tr: "You are a person who has seen and experienced a lot, aren't you, sir?" said Carton thoughtfully.
es: —Long is the book of his life, Mr. Lorry, isn't it?—asked Carton, undoubtedly just to say something.

en: “I am in my seventy-eighth year.”
vi: − I am already seventy-eight years old.
tr: "I am seventy-eight years old.""
es: —I have turned seventy-eight years old.

en: “You have been useful all your life; steadily and constantly occupied; trusted, respected, and looked up to?”
vi: − You have had a useful life, always stable and busy; trusted; respected; and admired. −
tr: "Throughout your life, you have always done useful things; you have always worked; you have become a person whom everyone trusts, respects, and values, right?"
es: —Seventy-eight well-spent years; seventy-eight years during which he has been useful to his fellow men and respected by them; eh?

en: “I have been a man of business, ever since I have been a man. Indeed, I may say that I was a man of business when a boy.”
vi: Since I became an adult, I have only known business. − Indeed, I can say I have been in business since I was young. −
tr: "I have been a businessman for as long as I can remember. I can say that I was involved in the business world even as a child."
es: —Almost since I can remember, I have been involved in business; without exaggeration, I can say that, since I was a boy, I have been a businessman.

en: “See what a place you fill at seventy-eight. How many people will miss you when you leave it empty!”
vi: Look at you at seventy-eight, and the company still needs you so much. How many people will remember you when you are gone!
tr: "Do you see, at seventy-eight years old, how much space you occupy in this world. There will be many people who will look for you in your absence."
es: —His diligence has earned him an enviable position. How many will miss him when he leaves that position vacant!

en: “A solitary old bachelor,” answered Mr. Lorry, shaking his head. “There is nobody to weep for me.”
vi: − A lonely old bachelor, - Mr. Lorry replied, shaking his head. No one will mourn me. −
tr: "I am an old man with no one," replied Mr. Lorry, shaking his head from side to side. "There is no one to mourn for me.""
es: "Don't believe it," replied Lorry, shaking his head. "Who would shed a tear for the memory of an old and lonely bachelor like me?"

en: “How can you say that? Wouldn’t She weep for you? Wouldn’t her child?”
vi: How can you say that? Won't Lucie mourn you? And her children too? −
tr: "How can you say this? Doesn't Lucie cry for you? Doesn't her child cry too?"
es: —Don't say that! Won't she cry for you? Won't your daughter cry?

en: “Yes, yes, thank God. I didn’t quite mean what I said.”
vi: Yes, yes, thank God. That's not exactly what I meant.
tr: "Yes, yes, thank God they exist. That's not exactly what I meant."
es: —Yes... yes... They will cry... Thank God! Excuse me; I didn't know what I was saying.

en: “It is a thing to thank God for; is it not?”
vi: − That is something to be thankful to God for, isn't it? −
tr: "This is something to be thankful to God for, isn't it?"
es: —It is a comfort that well deserves to be thanked to God for; isn't it true?

en: “Surely, surely.”
vi: It certainly is. −
tr: "Of course.""
es: —A lot, yes... agreed.

en: “If you could say, with truth, to your own solitary heart, to-night, ‘I have secured to myself the love and attachment, the gratitude or respect, of no human creature; I have won myself a tender place in no regard; I have done nothing good or serviceable to be remembered by!’ your seventy-eight years would be seventy-eight heavy curses; would they not?”
vi: If tonight, you could honestly say to your own lonely heart, "no one has ever loved, cherished, been grateful to, or respected me; no one has shown me any affection; I haven't done anything good or useful for anyone to remember me by!", if that were the case, then your seventy-eight years of life would be seventy-eight curses, wouldn't they?
tr: "If tonight you could turn to your lonely heart and honestly say, 'In this life, I have neither gained anyone's love, nor loyalty, nor gratitude, nor respect; I have not secured a compassionate place in any way; I have not done any good or been of any benefit to anyone that would be remembered!' this seventy-eight years would weigh upon you like a heavy curse; wouldn't it?"
es: —If tonight you could truthfully say the following words to yourself: "I have not managed to earn anyone's affection, esteem, gratitude, or respect; I have not succeeded in awakening echoes of sympathy in any human heart, I have done nothing good, nothing useful to my fellow men, nothing worthy of being remembered," your seventy-eight years of age would be seventy-eight thousand years of remorse; isn't that true?

en: “You say truly, Mr. Carton; I think they would be.”
vi: − That's right, Mr. Carton; I think so.
tr: "You are right, Mr. Carton; it would probably be so."
es: —You are right, Carton; I think I would never get tired of cursing them.

en: Sydney turned his eyes again upon the fire, and, after a silence of a few moments, said:
vi: Sydney turned his eyes towards the fireplace, and after a moment of silence, he said: − I want to ask you...
tr: Sydney turned her eyes back to the fire and after a few minutes of silence, she said:
es: Carton fixed his gaze on the fire once again, remained thoughtful for a long time, and finally said:

en: “I should like to ask you:—Does your childhood seem far off? Do the days when you sat at your mother’s knee, seem days of very long ago?”
vi: Your childhood must be a distant memory, right? The time when you sat on your mother's lap must be a blur?
tr: "What I want to ask you is this: Does it feel like your childhood is far behind you? Do the days when you sat on your mother's lap seem very distant?"
es: —I would like to ask you another question; when you remember your childhood, do you find it too distant? Does it seem to you that a lot of time has passed since the happy days when you sat on your sweet mother's knees?

en: Responding to his softened manner, Mr. Lorry answered:
vi: In response to his sudden softness, Mr. Lorry replied: − Twenty years ago, yes; but not at this age.
tr: Mr. Lorry replied to Carton's emotional state as follows:
es: Lorry, with a tone of voice made uncertain by the effect of the emotion that overwhelmed him, replied:

en: “Twenty years back, yes; at this time of my life, no. For, as I draw closer and closer to the end, I travel in the circle, nearer and nearer to the beginning. It seems to be one of the kind smoothings and preparings of the way. My heart is touched now, by many remembrances that had long fallen asleep, of my pretty young mother (and I so old!), and by many associations of the days when what we call the World was not so real with me, and my faults were not confirmed in me.”
vi: In response to his sudden softness, Mr. Lorry replied: − Twenty years ago, yes; but not at this age. Because, as I get closer and closer to the final moment, I have completed the cycle, getting closer and closer to the starting point. It seems that this is how we slowly prepare for the end. Now, my heart is stirred by many long-forgotten memories of my beautiful young mother; because I am now too old!... And about many things related to that time, the time when the reality we call this world did not yet exist for us, and the mistakes within us had not yet become habits.
tr: "Twenty years ago it seemed that way, yes; but at this stage of my life, no. Because I am getting closer to the end with each passing day, I am progressing towards the beginning by turning in a circle. It seems like a good method found to prepare ourselves for that long journey in a soft and calm manner. The revival of many memories that have been dormant for a long time makes my heart ache, many memories of my young and beautiful mother (while I am so old!) and of those days when the thing called the world had a completely different meaning for me and my mistakes did not matter."
es: —Twenty years ago, yes; today, no. What happens to me is like someone traveling in a circle; they start by moving away from the starting point, but as they reach the end, they get closer and closer to the beginning. Often today, tender memories long dormant awaken in my heart, often I see my saintly mother, so young, so beautiful... my mother very young and I very old... often I remember incidents from life that occurred when the world was not as real to me as it is today, nor had faults taken root in me.

en: “I understand the feeling!” exclaimed Carton, with a bright flush. “And you are the better for it?”
vi: − I understand that feeling! - Carton exclaimed, his face glowing with excitement. - And does that make you feel better? −
tr: "I can understand this feeling!" shouted Carton with sudden enthusiasm. "Well, do these make you feel any better?"
es: —I understand—exclaimed Carton, blushing deeply. —And those memories, far from leaving a bitter taste, will be pleasant for you, right?

en: “I hope so.”
vi: We hope so.
tr: "I guess.""
es: —Indeed; they give me a feeling of sweet sorrow.

en: Carton terminated the conversation here, by rising to help him on with his outer coat; “But you,” said Mr. Lorry, reverting to the theme, “you are young.”
vi: Carton ended the conversation by standing up to help the old man put on his coat. − Like you, you are still young, - Mr. Lorry returned to that topic.
tr: Carton stood up to help Mr. Lorry put on his coat, ending the conversation, "But you," said the old man, returning to the subject again, "you are still young."
es: Carton helped his interlocutor put on the overcoat.

en: “Yes,” said Carton. “I am not old, but my young way was never the way to age. Enough of me.”
vi: − Yes, - Carton replied. - I am not old, but my youth is not the kind to be peacefully enjoyed in old age. That's enough about me. −
tr: "True," said Carton. "I am not old, but the path I am on is not a good one for aging. Anyway, let's forget about me."
es: —You, on the other hand, are very young—replied Lorry, returning to the same topic. —Yes... I am not old; but my youthful paths were never the ones that lead to old age.

en: “And of me, I am sure,” said Mr. Lorry. “Are you going out?”
vi: The same goes for me, no need to say more, - Mr. Lorry replied. - Are you going out?
tr: "Then let's forget about me as well," said Mr. Lorry. "Are you leaving?"
es: —Are you going out?—asked Lorry.

en: “I’ll walk with you to her gate. You know my vagabond and restless habits. If I should prowl about the streets a long time, don’t be uneasy; I shall reappear in the morning. You go to the Court to-morrow?”
vi: − I will take you to Miss Lucie's gate. You know my habit of wandering restlessly. If I wander the streets for a long time, don't worry; I will reappear in the morning. Will you be going to the courthouse tomorrow? −
tr: "I will accompany you to Lucie's door. You know how aimless and restless I am. If I wander the streets too much, don't worry; I'll be in front of you again in the morning. Are you going to the trial tomorrow?"
es: —I will accompany you to the door of your house. You already know my restless nature and my wandering habits, so if I spend many hours roaming aimlessly through those streets without returning home, rest assured, I will reappear if not today, then tomorrow. Do you plan to attend the trial hearing tomorrow?

en: “Yes, unhappily.”
vi: Yes, unfortunately.
tr: "Yes, unfortunately.""
es: —With great pain in my soul, I will have to attend.

en: “I shall be there, but only as one of the crowd. My Spy will find a place for me. Take my arm, sir.”
vi: − I will also be there, but just standing in the crowd. My spy will find a spot for me. Take my arm, sir.
tr: "I will be there too, but only as one of the crowd. My spy will find me a place. Take my arm, sir."
es: —I will be there, but among the audience. My spy will find me a seat... Would you like to take my arm?

en: Mr. Lorry did so, and they went down-stairs and out in the streets. A few minutes brought them to Mr. Lorry’s destination. Carton left him there; but lingered at a little distance, and turned back to the gate again when it was shut, and touched it. He had heard of her going to the prison every day. “She came out here,” he said, looking about him, “turned this way, must have trod on these stones often. Let me follow in her steps.”
vi: Mr. Lorry complied, and they went downstairs and out into the street. In just a few minutes, they reached Mr. Lorry's destination. Carton left him there; but lingered a bit further away, then returned when the gate had closed and touched the gate. He had heard about her daily visits to the prison. − She had come out from here, - he said, looking around, - turned this way, and must have often walked on these paving stones. Let us follow her footsteps.
tr: Mr. Lorry did as Carton said, and the two of them went down the stairs and out into the street. A few minutes later, they arrived at the place where Mr. Lorry was going. Carton left him there; but after lingering a bit nearby, he returned and touched the door when it closed. He had heard that Lucie went to the prison every day. "She must have come out from here," he said, looking around, "then turned and walked over these stones. Let me follow her steps."
es: Arm in arm, they went down the stairs and out into the street. Minutes later, they arrived in front of Dr. Manette's house, where they parted ways. Lorry entered the house, and Carton walked away but only for a short time, as moments later, he returned to stand by the closed door. —She goes out this way every day—Carton said to himself;—she takes that direction... How many times must she have stepped on those stones!... I will follow her steps!

en: It was ten o’clock at night when he stood before the prison of La Force, where she had stood hundreds of times. A little wood-sawyer, having closed his shop, was smoking his pipe at his shop-door.
vi: It was ten o'clock at night when he arrived in front of La Force prison, where she had stood hundreds of times. The short carpenter had just closed his shop and was standing in the doorway smoking a pipe.
tr: When Carton arrived at La Force Prison, where Lucie had stood in front of hundreds of times, it was ten o'clock at night. A small, slight woodcutter had closed his shop and was smoking his pipe in front of his door.
es: The city clocks were striking ten at night when Carton ended his walk in front of the grim walls of La Force prison. A wood sawyer, after closing his workshop, was calmly smoking his pipe in front of his establishment.

en: “Good night, citizen,” said Sydney Carton, pausing in going by; for, the man eyed him inquisitively.
vi: "Hello, Citizen," Sydney Carton greeted, pausing on his way; because the man was looking at him inquisitively.
tr: When he saw the man looking at him with curious eyes, he stopped and said, "Good evening, citizen," said Sydney Carton.
es: —Good evening, citizen—said Carton, noticing that the sawyer was giving him inquisitive looks.

en: “Good night, citizen.”
vi: "Hello, Citizen," Sydney Carton greeted, pausing on his way; because the man was looking at him inquisitively.
tr: "Good night, citizen."
es: —Good evening, citizen.

en: “How goes the Republic?”
vi: − Hello, Citizen. − How is the Republic? −
tr: "How is the Republic going?"
es: —How is the Republic doing?

en: “You mean the Guillotine. Not ill. Sixty-three to-day. We shall mount to a hundred soon. Samson and his men complain sometimes, of being exhausted. Ha, ha, ha! He is so droll, that Samson. Such a Barber!”
vi: Do you mean the guillotine? − Still in good health. Today sixty-three lives, soon it will quickly rise to one hundred. Sometimes Samson and his men also complain of exhaustion. Ha, ha, ha! He is very humorous, that Samson. A real barber! −
tr: "I guess you meant guillotine. Not bad. Sixty-three people went today. Soon we'll reach a hundred. Samson and his men sometimes complain of fatigue. Ha, ha, ha! What a strange man that Samson is. A true barber!"
es: —I suppose you are referring to the Guillotine... It's not doing badly. Today sixty-three; we won't take long to reach a hundred per day. Sansón and his assistants complain that the work is excessive, that their strength is running out... Ha, ha, ha! How funny good Sansón is! Have you ever seen a busier barber in your life?

en: “Do you often go to see him—”
vi: Do you often see him...
tr: "Do you go to see him often?"
es: —Do you see him often...?

en: “Shave? Always. Every day. What a barber! You have seen him at work?”
vi: − Shaving? I see it all the time. Every day. A real skilled barber! Have you seen him work?
tr: "Shaving? Always. Every day. What a barber! Have you ever seen him at work?"
es: —Shaving? Every day... What a barber! Have you ever seen him in action?

en: “Never.”
vi: − Never. −
tr: "No, I have never seen it."
es: —Never.

en: “Go and see him when he has a good batch. Figure this to yourself, citizen; he shaved the sixty-three to-day, in less than two pipes! Less than two pipes. Word of honour!”
vi: Go watch when he has to shave a whole crowd. Imagine this, Citizen; today he shaved sixty-three people in the time it takes to smoke two pipes! Not even finished smoking two pipes. That's the honest truth!
tr: "When you have a group in your hand, you must go and see it. Imagine, citizen; while I finished two pipes, the man beheaded sixty-three people today! I'm saying without smoking two pipes. I swear on my honor!"
es: —Well, don't forget to go see him when he has work to do. It's a delight to watch him work... Just imagine, citizen; today, sixty-three in less than two hours... In less than two hours, word of honor!

en: As the grinning little man held out the pipe he was smoking, to explain how he timed the executioner, Carton was so sensible of a rising desire to strike the life out of him, that he turned away.
vi: While the short, grinning man extended his pipe to explain how he measured the executioner's time, Carton turned away to suppress the rising urge to beat the man to death.
tr: As the grinning little man showed the pipe he was smoking to demonstrate how the executioner measured his speed, Carton felt such an unbearable urge to kill him right then and there that he turned around and walked away immediately.
es: Carton was so repulsed by the relish with which the sawyer described the executioner's tasks that he turned his back to avoid strangling him, as was his most fervent desire.

en: “But you are not English,” said the wood-sawyer, “though you wear English dress?”
vi: − But you're not English, - the woodcutter said, - even though you're dressed in English style?
tr: "Even if you wear English clothes," said the sawyer, "you're not English, are you?"
es: —But you are not English, even though you dress like an Englishman, right?—asked the sawyer.

en: “Yes,” said Carton, pausing again, and answering over his shoulder.
vi: − Indeed I am, - Carton said, stopping again, answering over his shoulder.
tr: Carton stopped again and replied over his shoulder, "I am an Englishman."
es: —I am English—replied Carton, turning his head.

en: “You speak like a Frenchman.”
vi: − You speak French like a Frenchman.
tr: "You speak like a French person."
es: —Well, you speak like a true Frenchman.

en: “I am an old student here.”
vi: − I used to study here before.
tr: "I used to be a student here."
es: —I was a student here.

en: “Aha, a perfect Frenchman! Good night, Englishman.”
vi: − A ha, just like a Frenchman! Goodbye, Mr. Englishman.
tr: "Ah, you are just like a Frenchman! Good night, Englishman.""
es: —Ah...! Almost French, then. Good night, Englishman.

en: “Good night, citizen.”
vi: − Goodbye, Citizen. −
tr: "Good night, citizen."
es: —Good evening, citizen.

en: “But go and see that droll dog,” the little man persisted, calling after him. “And take a pipe with you!”
vi: But remember to go see that barber clown, - the small guy insisted on calling after. - And remember to bring the pipe!
tr: Shouting after him, "But go and see that strange fellow," insisted the little man. "Don't forget to take a pipe with you!"
es: —Don't forget to go see our friend Samson. Carton moved away, but he had not gone far from the sawyer's workshop when he stopped under a streetlamp and wrote a few words with a pencil on a piece of paper.

en: Sydney had not gone far out of sight, when he stopped in the middle of the street under a glimmering lamp, and wrote with his pencil on a scrap of paper. Then, traversing with the decided step of one who remembered the way well, several dark and dirty streets—much dirtier than usual, for the best public thoroughfares remained uncleansed in those times of terror—he stopped at a chemist’s shop, which the owner was closing with his own hands. A small, dim, crooked shop, kept in a tortuous, up-hill thoroughfare, by a small, dim, crooked man.
vi: Sydney hadn't gone far before he stopped right in the middle of the street under a flickering lamp and took out a pencil to write on a piece of paper. Then, with the determined steps of someone familiar with the way, he crossed many dark and filthy streets - filthier than usual because even the busiest main streets were not cleaned during this time of terror. He stopped in front of a pharmacy, where the owner himself was closing up. A small, dim, dark pharmacy, located on a winding road leading uphill, owned by a small, dim, dark man.
tr: Sydney had not gone far when he stopped under a dim street lamp and wrote something on a small piece of paper with his pen. Then, with the steps of someone who knew the way well, he zigzagged through many dark and dirty streets –the streets were much dirtier than usual, because even the busiest avenues had not been cleaned during the Reign of Terror– and stopped in front of a pharmacy, whose owner was about to close the shop with his own hands. The owner of this tiny, obscure, and crooked shop on a winding and busy slope was a tiny, obscure, and crooked man.
es: Carton moved away, but he had not gone far from the sawyer's workshop when he stopped under a streetlamp and wrote a few words with a pencil on a piece of paper. Then, crossing a number of dark and dirty streets with the determined step of someone who knows exactly where they are going, he stopped in front of a drugstore, whose door the druggist was closing at that moment.

en: Giving this citizen, too, good night, as he confronted him at his counter, he laid the scrap of paper before him. “Whew!” the chemist whistled softly, as he read it. “Hi! hi! hi!”
vi: After greeting this Citizen, he went straight to the pharmacy counter and placed a note in front of him. "Phew!" - The pharmacist whistled softly when he read the note. "Oh dear! Oh dear!
tr: He placed the small piece of paper in front of the citizen at the cardboard counter, saying good night to him as well. When the pharmacist read this, he said, "Wow!" and let out a soft whistle: "Whew! Whew! Whew!"
es: After bidding goodnight to the druggist, whose appearance was as dirty and repugnant as the shop itself, he placed on the counter the piece of paper on which he had written with a pencil a short while ago. —Damn!—exclaimed the druggist. —Hee, hee, hee!

en: Sydney Carton took no heed, and the chemist said:
vi: Oh dear!" - Seeing that Sydney Carton was not interested, he continued to ask.
tr: Sydney Carton paid no attention to him, the pharmacist asked:
es: —Hee, hee, hee!

en: “For you, citizen?”
vi: "For you, Citizen?" − "For me." − "You must be careful to keep the items separate, Citizen."
tr: "Are these for you, citizen?"
es: Is it for you, citizen?

en: “For me.”
vi: "For you, Citizen?" − "For me." − "You must be careful to keep the items separate, Citizen."
tr: "For me."
es: —For me.

en: “You will be careful to keep them separate, citizen? You know the consequences of mixing them?”
vi: "For you, Citizen?" − "For me." − "You must be careful to keep the items separate, Citizen." "Do you know the consequences if they mix together?" − "I know well."
tr: "Put these in separate places, will you, citizen? You know what happens if you mix them up, right?"
es: —Will you be careful to keep them separate, citizen? Do you know the consequences of mixing them?

en: “Perfectly.”
vi: "Do you know the consequences if they mix together?" − "I know well."
tr: "I know very well.""
es: —Perfectly.

en: Certain small packets were made and given to him. He put them, one by one, in the breast of his inner coat, counted out the money for them, and deliberately left the shop. “There is nothing more to do,” said he, glancing upward at the moon, “until to-morrow. I can’t sleep.”
vi: The small packages were prepared and then handed to him. Carton placed each package into the pocket of his inner coat, counted the payment, and leisurely walked out. − Now there's nothing left to do until tomorrow, - he looked up at the moon and said to himself. - I can't sleep.
tr: The pharmacist prepared the requested items in small packages and gave them to Carton. He then placed them one by one into the inner pocket of his coat, paid, and walked out with confident steps. "Until tomorrow," he said, looking up at the moon, "there is nothing else to do. I can't sleep either."
es: The druggist prepared some papers, which Carton put in the inner pocket of his frock coat. He paid the amount, and without further words, went out to the street. —For tonight, I have nothing left to do—he murmured, raising his head. —Tomorrow we will continue... It is impossible for me to sleep.

en: It was not a reckless manner, the manner in which he said these words aloud under the fast-sailing clouds, nor was it more expressive of negligence than defiance. It was the settled manner of a tired man, who had wandered and struggled and got lost, but who at length struck into his road and saw its end.
vi: It was not an attitude of defiance or a display of recklessness, but a challenge when he uttered those words under the swiftly moving clouds. It was the determination of a weary soul, one who had wandered, struggled, and erred but had finally found the right path and the ultimate destination.
tr: While saying these things under the swiftly drifting clouds, Carton had neither a careless attitude nor a defiant manner. He had more the calmness of a weary man who had wandered the roads, overcome many hardships, lost his way but ultimately found it, and now saw the end of it.
es: The tone with which Carton pronounced the previous words reflected neither indifference nor bewilderment, nor was there despair or defiance in them; his accent resonated with the resolution of a man who, after many years of traveling down twisted paths without a fixed direction or destination, finally enters one whose end is known to him.

en: Long ago, when he had been famous among his earliest competitors as a youth of great promise, he had followed his father to the grave. His mother had died, years before. These solemn words, which had been read at his father’s grave, arose in his mind as he went down the dark streets, among the heavy shadows, with the moon and the clouds sailing on high above him. “I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die.”
vi: In the old days, when he was famous as a promising young man among his competitive peers, his father passed away. His mother had died many years before that. The solemn words he had heard read when standing before his father's grave now resurfaced in his mind as he walked through the dark alleys, submerged in thick darkness, with the moon and drifting clouds high above. "The Lord said: I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me will live, even though they have died. And whoever lives by believing in me will never die."
tr: Years ago, as a young man full of great promise, he had walked behind his father's coffin to the cemetery, standing out among his rivals. His mother had died many years before his father. With the moon and drifting clouds overhead, passing through heavy shadows as he moved along the dark streets, Carton recalled the sacred words spoken at his father's grave: "I am the resurrection and the life, said the Lord; whoever believes in me, even if he dies, shall live, and whoever lives and believes in me shall never die."
es: Many years ago, when he stood out among the talented young people, among the students who promised great things, he accompanied his father to the cemetery. His mother had passed away much earlier. Well then; those solemn words that the priest read over the grave of the one who gave him life, words forgotten amidst the disorder of a licentious life, emerged powerfully in his memory as he walked through the sad and lonely streets tonight, under a sky covered with dark clouds. "I am the resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, even if he dies, will live; and he who lives and believes in Me, will never die."

en: In a city dominated by the axe, alone at night, with natural sorrow rising in him for the sixty-three who had been that day put to death, and for to-morrow’s victims then awaiting their doom in the prisons, and still of to-morrow’s and to-morrow’s, the chain of association that brought the words home, like a rusty old ship’s anchor from the deep, might have been easily found. He did not seek it, but repeated them and went on.
vi: In a dreadful city under the shadow of the guillotine, he wandered alone in the sorrowful night for the sixty-three people who had been executed today, and for the victims of tomorrow who were currently awaiting their fate in the prisons, for the victims of the days to come, this chain of thoughts made it easy for him to recall the holy words of the past, like finding the anchor of an old rusty ship that had sunk to the depths. He repeated those words and continued on.
tr: In a city ruled by the guillotine, alone at night, with the pain of sixty-three people sent to death that day and the agony of the victims in prisons waiting to be executed tomorrow, the next day, or the day after, weighing heavily on his heart, successive associations brought forth these words from the past, like the emergence of the rusty anchor of an old ship from the depths. He hadn't actually searched for them, but he found himself constantly repeating these words.
es: It would not have been difficult to find the mysterious force that evoked those memories from the depths of his soul, similar to the chain that pulls the rusted anchor from the depths of the silt, long embedded there, by simply noticing that he was walking alone and at night, through the streets of a city under the law of the guillotine, painfully recalling the sixty-three heads that had rolled that day, and thinking of the wretches who would die on the scaffold the next day, and the day after, and the day after that. However, he did not attempt to seek it; he merely repeated over and over the words that have been copied, and continued walking.

en: With a solemn interest in the lighted windows where the people were going to rest, forgetful through a few calm hours of the horrors surrounding them; in the towers of the churches, where no prayers were said, for the popular revulsion had even travelled that length of self-destruction from years of priestly impostors, plunderers, and profligates; in the distant burial-places, reserved, as they wrote upon the gates, for Eternal Sleep; in the abounding gaols; and in the streets along which the sixties rolled to a death which had become so common and material, that no sorrowful story of a haunting Spirit ever arose among the people out of all the working of the Guillotine; with a solemn interest in the whole life and death of the city settling down to its short nightly pause in fury; Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again for the lighter streets.
