vi: He attentively looked at the lit windows where people were about to go to sleep for a few hours of peace to forget the surrounding horrors; he looked at the church towers where no prayers echoed anymore because so many years of imposture, usurpation, and degradation under the guise of the clergy had made the people lose their faith; he looked at the distant cemeteries reserved for the Eternal Sleep, as the inscriptions on the gates read; he looked at the overcrowded prisons; he looked at the roads where groups of sixty people at a time were taken to their deaths, a sight that had become so commonplace and familiar that people were indifferent to all the sorrowful tales of the souls who perished under the guillotine. Thinking of all the living and the dead in the city who were temporarily suspending their wrath for a moment each night, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine once more, heading towards the brighter streets.
tr: Sydney Carton looked with a dignified curiosity at the people visible in the lit windows, who would soon retire to rest and forget the surrounding horrors for a few tranquil hours; then at the towers of churches where no prayers were read anymore, and from which everyone fled due to their reaction to the charlatans, looters, and immoral people who had been masquerading as priests for years; at the distant cemeteries with signs reading "for eternal sleep" at their gates; at the prisons and the streets where people, having grown accustomed to groups of sixty being taken to their deaths by cart, could no longer conjure up any tragic ghost stories in front of the guillotine; and with the same dignified curiosity that gave his anger a brief respite every night, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine again to reach the brighter avenues of the city whose life and death he observed.
es: Focusing all his interest on the illuminated windows corresponding to rooms where people were preparing to rest, eager to forget during the brief hours of nighttime calm the horrors that surrounded them during the day, in the church towers, where divine services were no longer held, as popular revulsion had made priests the main target of their wrath, accusing them of being impostors, libertines, and thieves; in those sacred places, destined, according to the inscriptions placed above the doors, for eternal rest; in the dungeons, overflowing with prisoners, and in the streets, where people ran to meet a death already considered, by force of habit, so common and natural that even those in charge of handling the guillotine did not have their dreams disturbed by spectral apparitions; in short, with all his attention focused on the life of that city rushing headlong to death, Sydney Carton crossed the Seine looking for better-lit and more lively streets.

en: Few coaches were abroad, for riders in coaches were liable to be suspected, and gentility hid its head in red nightcaps, and put on heavy shoes, and trudged. But, the theatres were all well filled, and the people poured cheerfully out as he passed, and went chatting home. At one of the theatre doors, there was a little girl with a mother, looking for a way across the street through the mud. He carried the child over, and before the timid arm was loosed from his neck asked her for a kiss.
vi: Few horse-drawn carriages were seen on the road because passengers in such carriages were easily suspected; those with status hid their faces under red hats, wore coarse shoes, and trudged along on foot. But the theaters were crowded; as he passed by, people were spilling out of the doors, cheerful and chatting on their way home. In front of a theater, a little girl stood with her mother, trying to navigate through the mud to cross the street. He helped carry the child across, and before the timid arms of the little one let go of his neck, Carton asked the girl for a kiss.
tr: There weren't many cars around, because those who rode in cars aroused a lot of suspicion; therefore, nobility had hidden its head under red caps, put on clumsy shoes, and was progressing slowly and awkwardly. On the other hand, all the theaters were full, and as Carton passed by one of them, people cheerfully came out and went home chatting. In front of one of the theater doors, a mother and her daughter were standing, thinking about how to cross the muddy road. Carton picked up the child and carried her across, and before that timid arm let go of his neck, she asked for a kiss from him.
es: There were very few cars to be seen, for those who could afford the luxury of having them, knowing that using them was as much as requesting to be inscribed in the Book of Suspects, preferred to walk on foot, wearing red caps and the most ordinary shoes. The theaters, however, were full, and they began to empty at the hour when Carton strolled through the central streets where they were located. Next to the door of a theater, from which compact masses of cheerful people were emerging, singing as they headed to their homes, Carton saw a little girl, holding her mother's hand, looking for a spot that would allow her to cross the street without getting knee-deep in the mud. Carton took the little girl in his arms, carried her to the opposite sidewalk, and before the timid little angel let go of the arms that encircled his neck, he asked her to give him a kiss.

en: “I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die.”
vi: “Jesus said to her, 'I am the resurrection and the life. The one who believes in me will live, even though they die; and whoever lives by believing in me will never die.'”
tr: "I am the resurrection and the life," said God, "whoever believes in me, even if they die, will still live, and whoever lives and believes in me will never die."
es: “I am the resurrection and the life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, he shall live; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die.”

en: Now, that the streets were quiet, and the night wore on, the words were in the echoes of his feet, and were in the air. Perfectly calm and steady, he sometimes repeated them to himself as he walked; but, he heard them always.
vi: At this moment, as the streets were silent and the night was late, those words echoed in his footsteps and in the surrounding space. Completely calm and resolute, he sometimes repeated those words on his way; but the prayer always resonated within him.
tr: Since the streets had become completely silent and the night had fallen with all its darkness, the words seemed to echo at his feet and then spread into the air. Carton was walking on one hand, and on the other, he was repeating these words in an extremely calm manner and at regular intervals; but these words never left his ear.
es: Later in the night, when the tranquility in the streets was complete and the silence absolute, it seemed to him that the sound of his own footsteps modulated those sentences, which the breeze brought wrapped in its subtle whispers. Master of himself, calm, resolute, he frequently repeated them with his lips; but they always sounded in his ears.

en: The night wore out, and, as he stood upon the bridge listening to the water as it splashed the river-walls of the Island of Paris, where the picturesque confusion of houses and cathedral shone bright in the light of the moon, the day came coldly, looking like a dead face out of the sky. Then, the night, with the moon and the stars, turned pale and died, and for a little while it seemed as if Creation were delivered over to Death’s dominion.
vi: The night gradually waned, as he stood on the bridge listening to the river lapping against the embankment around Ile de la Cité, where a picturesque jumble of houses and churches gleamed under the moonlight, the cold dawn emerging like the face of a corpse on the horizon. Then the night and the stars faded and disappeared, and for a moment it seemed as if all things had entered the realm of death.
tr: Sydney Carton stood on the bridge, listening to the waters hitting the river walls on the Paris island, where the dazzling chaos of houses and the cathedral shone brightly in the moonlight, as the night was about to end, the day came cold like a dead face looking from the sky. Then the night, along with the moon and stars, faded away; it was as if death had taken over the entire universe for a while.
es: And the night continued advancing while Carton, leaning over the parapet of the bridge, listened to the murmuring kisses of the river against the walls of the Island of Paris, and contemplated the picturesque confusion of buildings wrapped in gray shadows, over which the dome of the cathedral, bathed in the whitish light of the moon, rose arrogantly. The day came. The night, with the moon and the stars, paled and died, and for a few minutes, it seemed that all of creation fell under the yellowish scepter of Death.

en: But, the glorious sun, rising, seemed to strike those words, that burden of the night, straight and warm to his heart in its long bright rays. And looking along them, with reverently shaded eyes, a bridge of light appeared to span the air between him and the sun, while the river sparkled under it.
vi: But the glorious sun is rising, its rays spreading wide as if shattering the oppression of the night, as if repeating those holy words that warm his heart. With a respectful hand shielding his eyes, he looks straight into the dawn sunlight; a bridge of light seems to connect him with the sun while the river below sparkles with the morning light.
tr: When the sun rose with all its grandeur today, it seemed to have cast aside all those words and the night's troubles, warming the heart of Sydney with its bright lights. When she shielded her eyes and looked at them, it was as if a bridge of light formed between her and the sun, and the river below sparkled brilliantly.
es: The river's current, rapid, impetuous, deep, seemed to him like a loving friend.

en: The strong tide, so swift, so deep, and certain, was like a congenial friend, in the morning stillness. He walked by the stream, far from the houses, and in the light and warmth of the sun fell asleep on the bank. When he awoke and was afoot again, he lingered there yet a little longer, watching an eddy that turned and turned purposeless, until the stream absorbed it, and carried it on to the sea.—“Like me.”
vi: The water flowed swiftly, deeply, and unchangingly, like a kindred spirit in the tranquil morning. He strolled along the river, gradually distancing himself from the residential area, and in the warm sunlight, he fell asleep by the water's edge. Upon waking and continuing his walk, he lingered there a bit longer, watching a whirlpool spinning aimlessly until the river carried it out to sea.
tr: The powerful current in the river, which was exceedingly fast, deep, and distinct, had become like a companion to him in the morning silence. Sydney, far from the houses, fell asleep on the riverbank under the sunlight and warmth after walking along this current for a while. When he woke up and got up, he lingered there a bit more, watching a whirlpool that was aimlessly turning, until the current swallowed it and carried it to the sea.
es: The river's current, rapid, impetuous, deep, seemed to him like a loving friend. He started walking along its banks, moving away from the city's bustle. He fell asleep on the shore; when he woke up, he continued walking for a few more minutes, his eyes fixed on a whirlpool spinning vertiginously, until the current swallowed him and dragged him to the sea.

en: A trading-boat, with a sail of the softened colour of a dead leaf, then glided into his view, floated by him, and died away. As its silent track in the water disappeared, the prayer that had broken up out of his heart for a merciful consideration of all his poor blindnesses and errors, ended in the words, “I am the resurrection and the life.”
vi: - "Just like me." A merchant ship with sails the color of dead leaves came into view, drifted past, and faded away. As the silent waters behind the ship disappeared, so did the prayer - still echoing in his heart, asking for divine mercy for all his blind mistakes - end with the words: "I am the resurrection and the life."
tr: –"Just like me!" Then, a boat with a sail faded like a dead leaf came into view, and after gliding in front for a while, it disappeared from sight. When the boat's traces on the water vanished, the prayer that sprang from Sydney's heart for the forgiveness of his own negligence and mistakes ended with these words, "I am the resurrection, I am the life.""
es: He fell asleep on the shore; when he woke up, he continued walking for a few more minutes, his eyes fixed on a whirlpool spinning vertiginously, until the current swallowed him and dragged him to the sea. —Like me!—murmured Carton.

en: Mr. Lorry was already out when he got back, and it was easy to surmise where the good old man was gone. Sydney Carton drank nothing but a little coffee, ate some bread, and, having washed and changed to refresh himself, went out to the place of trial.
vi: Mr. Lorry was absent when he returned home; it was not difficult to guess where this kind-hearted old man had gone. Sydney Carton only drank a little coffee, ate some bread, then bathed and changed clothes for comfort, and went to the courthouse.
tr: When he returned, Mr. Lorry had left, and it was not at all difficult to guess where this kind-hearted man had gone. Sydney Carton drank a little coffee, ate some bread, and after washing up and putting on clean clothes, he went to the courthouse.
es: When he arrived home, Lorry had already left. Carton did not ask where he had gone, as with little effort of imagination he could guess it.

en: The court was all astir and a-buzz, when the black sheep—whom many fell away from in dread—pressed him into an obscure corner among the crowd. Mr. Lorry was there, and Doctor Manette was there. She was there, sitting beside her father.
vi: In the court, there was a commotion and noise as the black sheep - the people whom many commoners feared and avoided - cornered him in a hidden spot within the crowd. Mr. Lorry was there, and Dr. Manette was there. She was also there, sitting next to her father.
tr: The black sheep, which many people avoided out of fear, had seated Sydney in a secluded corner amidst the crowd, filling the courtroom with great excitement and murmurs. Mr. Lorry and Doctor Manette were there. Lucie was also sitting right next to her father.
es: He had a small cup of coffee, washed and got ready, and went without delay to the Tribunal. There he found Lorry, there he found Dr. Manette, there he found her, sitting next to her father.

en: When her husband was brought in, she turned a look upon him, so sustaining, so encouraging, so full of admiring love and pitying tenderness, yet so courageous for his sake, that it called the healthy blood into his face, brightened his glance, and animated his heart. If there had been any eyes to notice the influence of her look, on Sydney Carton, it would have been seen to be the same influence exactly.
vi: When Darnay was brought in for trial, to reassure him, she sent her husband a look full of sympathy and encouragement, full of loving admiration and tender sorrow, but also full of courage that made Darnay's face flush, his eyes shine, and his heart beat faster. If anyone had noticed how her presence affected Sydney Carton, they would have seen that he shared the same exhilaration as Darnay.
tr: When her husband was brought in, Lucie looked at him with such supportive, encouraging, deep love and pain-laden compassion that color instantly returned to Charles's face, his eyes sparkled, and his heart skipped a beat. If at that moment someone had observed the effect of Lucie's gaze on Sydney Carton, they would have seen that it was exactly the same as Charles's reaction.
es: When Charles Darnay appeared, Lucie directed a look at him so encouraging, so full of boundless love and tender compassion, that it brought blood to the prisoner's cheeks, brightened his gaze, and lifted his heart. If anyone had had their eyes on Sydney Carton, they would have noticed that the look, although not directed at him, had the same effect on him as it did on the prisoner.

en: Before that unjust Tribunal, there was little or no order of procedure, ensuring to any accused person any reasonable hearing. There could have been no such Revolution, if all laws, forms, and ceremonies, had not first been so monstrously abused, that the suicidal vengeance of the Revolution was to scatter them all to the winds.
vi: In that unjust court, there was almost no procedural order to ensure that anyone accused was given a fair trial. Such a Revolution would never have occurred if all the laws, procedures, and rituals had not been brutally trampled upon from the beginning, to the extent that the Revolution now discarded all legalities to exact a mad revenge akin to suicide.
tr: In the unjust court, there was no reasonable method or rule that allowed the defendants to speak. In any case, if all the laws, methods, and protocols had not been so monstrously abused, there would not have been such a revolution, yet the death-thirsty revolution, driven by feelings of vengeance, had swept them all away into the wind.
es: Before that unjust tribunal, which had begun by banishing order in its proceedings, it was perfectly useless for any accused person to attempt to be heard; it would not have been worth bringing the Revolution to not simultaneously scatter all the laws, regulations, and ceremonies to the four winds, to not abolish once and for all the social order that the world had so monstrously abused, to not deny the accused the right to justify themselves.

en: Every eye was turned to the jury. The same determined patriots and good republicans as yesterday and the day before, and to-morrow and the day after. Eager and prominent among them, one man with a craving face, and his fingers perpetually hovering about his lips, whose appearance gave great satisfaction to the spectators. A life-thirsting, cannibal-looking, bloody-minded juryman, the Jacques Three of St. Antoine. The whole jury, as a jury of dogs empannelled to try the deer.
vi: Everyone was looking towards the jury. It was the same resolute patriots and reputable republicans as yesterday and the day before, and as it would be tomorrow and the day after. The most eager and noticeable among them was a man with a greedy face and fingers constantly hovering around his mouth; his presence made the trial spectators extremely delighted. The bloodthirsty juror, looking as if he wanted to devour someone alive, was none other than Jacques Three of the Saint Antoine district. The entire jury was like a pack of hounds gathered to judge a fallen deer.
tr: All eyes turned to the jury. They were all the same determined patriots and good republicans as yesterday, the day before, tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow. Among them, one man with a greedy expression, impatient and with fingers constantly roaming over his lips, stood out immediately, and the audience was immensely pleased with his demeanor. This bloodthirsty, cannibalistic-looking, and cruel jury member was Jacques Three from St. Antoine. The entire jury stood like dogs gathered to judge a deer.
es: The Jury was from the very first moments the focus of all eyes. It was composed of the same resolute patriots, the same excellent republicans who formed it the day before, the same who would form it the next day. Among them stood out a man with a repulsive face, a fierce cannibal in every sense of the word, an individual who drank blood, bathed in blood, and breathed blood. It was Santiago Tercero, the one we met in the San Antonio neighborhood. The others resembled a pack of dogs eager to tear apart the prey.

en: Every eye then turned to the five judges and the public prosecutor. No favourable leaning in that quarter to-day. A fell, uncompromising, murderous business-meaning there. Every eye then sought some other eye in the crowd, and gleamed at it approvingly; and heads nodded at one another, before bending forward with a strained attention.
vi: Everyone then turned towards the five magistrates and the prosecutor. Today, no one in this group seemed tolerant; everyone appeared ruthless, steely, and cruel. Then the crowd looked at each other, eyes showing approval, heads nodding in satisfaction, and then they craned their necks forward, focusing on the trial.
tr: All eyes turned to the five judges and the prosecutor. There was no positive atmosphere in that part today. Instead, something cruel, savage, and deadly was brewing there. Then they looked around at the thousands in the crowd, their eyes gleaming as if in approval, and nodded to each other before leaning forward tensely and giving their attention.
es: All eyes were fixed on the five jurors and the public prosecutor, who spoke, more or less, in the following terms:

en: Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay. Released yesterday. Reaccused and retaken yesterday. Indictment delivered to him last night. Suspected and Denounced enemy of the Republic, Aristocrat, one of a family of tyrants, one of a race proscribed, for that they had used their abolished privileges to the infamous oppression of the people. Charles Evrémonde, called Darnay, in right of such proscription, absolutely Dead in Law.
vi: Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay. Released yesterday. Denounced again and re-arrested yesterday. The indictment was served to him yesterday. The accused is condemned as an enemy of the Republic, a member of the aristocracy, belonging to a tyrannical lineage, of the type to be eradicated, for having exploited their privileges to brutally oppress the common people. Charles Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, according to that eradication law, is certain to face the death penalty.
tr: Charles Evremonde, known as Darnay, was released yesterday. On the same day, he was found guilty again and imprisoned. The indictment was delivered to him last night. He was accused and denounced as an enemy of the Republic and an aristocrat. He comes from a family of a cruel ruler, exiled due to the oppressions they inflicted on people despite their abolished privileges. Charles Evremonde, known as Darnay, is legally dead because of this exile decree.
es: —Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay. Yesterday he was released, and on the same day he was accused again and re-arrested. Last night he was informed of the charges brought against him. He is charged with being an enemy of the Republic, an aristocrat, a member of a family of tyrants, a member of a proscribed race, who abused his privileges, now happily abolished, oppressing the people in the most villainous manner. Carlos Evrémonde, also called Darnay, guilty of the mentioned crimes, is a dead man in the eyes of the Law.

en: To this effect, in as few or fewer words, the Public Prosecutor.
vi: With just a few brief words, the prosecutor had finished the indictment.
tr: What the prosecutor said was basically this.
es: His head rightfully belongs to the executioner.

en: The President asked, was the Accused openly denounced or secretly?
vi: The judge asked the defendant whether the accusation was public or secret?
tr: The president asked whether the defendant was reported openly or secretly.
es: —Is the accusation against the defendant public or secret?—asked the president.

en: “Openly, President.”
vi: − Public, Your Honor. −
tr: "Openly, Mr. President."
es: —Is the accusation against the defendant public or secret?—asked the president.

en: “By whom?”
vi: By whom? −
tr: "Who did it?""
es: —Who made it?

en: “Three voices. Ernest Defarge, wine-vendor of St. Antoine.”
vi: Three people. Ernest Defarge, a wine seller in Saint Antoine.
tr: "Three people. Ernest Defarge, the wine-seller from St Antoine."
es: —Three people. Ernesto Defarge, innkeeper of San Antonio.

en: “Good.”
vi: − Alright.
tr: "Beautiful."
es: —Very well.

en: “Thérèse Defarge, his wife.”
vi: - Thérèse Defarge, his wife.
tr: "Therese Defarge, his wife.""
es: —Teresa Defarge, wife of the aforementioned.

en: “Good.”
vi: - Okay.
tr: "Beautiful."
es: —Perfectly.

en: “Alexandre Manette, physician.”
vi: − Alexandre Manette, doctor.
tr: "And also Alexandre Manette, doctor.""
es: —Alejandro Manette, doctor.

en: A great uproar took place in the court, and in the midst of it, Doctor Manette was seen, pale and trembling, standing where he had been seated.
vi: The entire courtroom was in an uproar, and in the midst of the crowd, Dr. Manette, pale and trembling, stood up from where he had been sitting all this time.
tr: A great commotion erupted in the salon, and in the midst of all this chaos, Doctor Manette, trembling with a pale face, suddenly stood up from where he was seated.
es: This last name raised a storm of deafening shouts in the room. In the midst of the tumult, the doctor was seen to rise, pale as a corpse and trembling like a leaf.

en: “President, I indignantly protest to you that this is a forgery and a fraud. You know the accused to be the husband of my daughter. My daughter, and those dear to her, are far dearer to me than my life. Who and where is the false conspirator who says that I denounce the husband of my child!”
vi: − Your Honor, I vehemently protest that this is a forgery and a deceit. You know well that the defendant is my daughter's husband. My daughter and those dear to her are more important than my own life. Who and where is this schemer who dares to say that I denounced my son-in-law!
tr: "Mr. President, this is unacceptable, I object to this fraud and deceit. You know that the accused person is my daughter's husband. My daughter and her loved ones are more precious to me than my own life. Who is this deceitful conspirator saying that I reported my own child's husband, where is this person?"
es: —President—he shouted,—I indignantly protest against the vile lie that has just been uttered here. I could not have denounced my daughter's husband, and the Court knows very well that the accused is my son-in-law. My daughter, and the people who are dear to her, are worth a thousand times more to me than my own life. Where is the impostor who dares to claim that I have denounced my daughter's husband? Where is the false patriot who dares to lie so shamelessly?

en: “Citizen Manette, be tranquil. To fail in submission to the authority of the Tribunal would be to put yourself out of Law. As to what is dearer to you than life, nothing can be so dear to a good citizen as the Republic.”
vi: − Citizen Manette, please calm down. Not complying with the authority of the Court means you are violating the law. As for what is more important than one's own life, for a good Citizen, nothing is more important than the Republic itself.
tr: "Citizen Manette, calm down. If you disobey the authority of the court, you will also be acting unlawfully. As for the people you mentioned being more precious than your life, for a good citizen, nothing can be more precious than the Republic."
es: —Calm yourself, citizen Manette. To disrespect the authority of the Tribunal would be tantamount to stepping outside the Law. You have said that there is something worth a thousand times more than your life; and I do not know that for a good patriot there is anything worth as much as the Republic.

en: Loud acclamations hailed this rebuke. The President rang his bell, and with warmth resumed.
vi: The rebuke was met with loud applause. The judge rang the bell and eagerly continued: −
tr: After the president's scolding, a thunderous applause erupted. The president rang his bell and continued his speech with the same enthusiasm.
es: Frenzied applause rewarded the president's reply. He, after imposing silence with the force of bell rings, continued passionately:

en: “If the Republic should demand of you the sacrifice of your child herself, you would have no duty but to sacrifice her. Listen to what is to follow. In the meanwhile, be silent!”
vi: If the Republic demands that we sacrifice our own children, then it is our duty to make that sacrifice. Let the court proceed. For now, silence!
tr: "If the Republic asks you to sacrifice your child, the only thing you should do is to sacrifice them. Now be silent and listen carefully to what I have to say!"
es: —If the Republic demanded the sacrifice of your own daughter, your duty would be to sacrifice her. Let's continue, and silence.

en: Frantic acclamations were again raised. Doctor Manette sat down, with his eyes looking around, and his lips trembling; his daughter drew closer to him. The craving man on the jury rubbed his hands together, and restored the usual hand to his mouth.
vi: The crowd once again erupted in wild applause. Dr. Manette sat down, looking around, his lips trembling; his daughter clung closely to him. The bloodthirsty juror rubbed his hands together, then habitually brought one hand to his mouth.
tr: The people in the salon applauded wildly again. Dr. Manette sat down, looking around and with trembling lips; his daughter snuggled closely next to him. The greedy man on the jury rubbed his hands and, as usual, brought his hand to his mouth.
es: The doctor Manette collapsed into the chair. His lips trembled, and his eyes looked around in terror. The cannibal-faced jury rubbed their hands with visible relish.

en: Defarge was produced, when the court was quiet enough to admit of his being heard, and rapidly expounded the story of the imprisonment, and of his having been a mere boy in the Doctor’s service, and of the release, and of the state of the prisoner when released and delivered to him. This short examination followed, for the court was quick with its work.
vi: Defarge was called out. When the noise in the court had subsided, he quickly recounted the story of Dr. Manette's imprisonment, how he had served the doctor since he was young, the doctor's release from prison, and his condition when he was entrusted to him. Then came the brief examination because the court worked very quickly: − You played a role in the storming of the Bastille, didn't you, Citizen? − I think so.
tr: When the sounds in the courtroom died down and he was sure his voice could be heard, Defarge spoke up and recounted the Doctor's imprisonment, how he was a small child working alongside him at the time of his incarceration, then the prisoner's release, and the state he was in when he was freed and brought to him.
es: Once silence was restored, Defarge presented himself, who gave a succinct account of the doctor's captivity and release; he stated that he had been his servant, and described the condition in which the captive was found when he was handed over. After the story was finished, the Tribunal addressed him with the following questions:

en: “You did good service at the taking of the Bastille, citizen?”
vi: Then came the brief examination because the court worked very quickly: − You played a role in the storming of the Bastille, didn't you, Citizen? − I think so.
tr: "You played a significant role in the capture of the Bastille, didn't you, citizen?"
es: —Did you render good services in the storming of the Bastille, citizen?

en: “I believe so.”
vi: At this point, from the crowd came the excited shout of a woman: −
tr: "I think so."
es: —I believe so.

en: Here, an excited woman screeched from the crowd: “You were one of the best patriots there. Why not say so? You were a cannonier that day there, and you were among the first to enter the accursed fortress when it fell. Patriots, I speak the truth!”
vi: You are one of the most patriotic people there. Why don't you tell the whole story? You were the one who fired the cannon that day, and you were in the first group to enter that cursed fortress when it fell. Dear patriots, I speak the truth!
tr: At that moment, a woman in the crowd shouted in a shrill voice; "You were one of the most patriotic people there. Why don't you tell us? You were the artilleryman there that day, and when that damned fortress fell, you were among the first to enter. Patriots, that's the truth!"
es: —You were one of the best patriots!—shouted a woman, overcome with enthusiasm—Why not say it like that? That day you were an artilleryman, you fought with fury, and you were the first to enter the damned fortress after it fell into the hands of the people. Patriots... believe me, because I tell the truth!

en: It was The Vengeance who, amidst the warm commendations of the audience, thus assisted the proceedings. The President rang his bell; but, The Vengeance, warming with encouragement, shrieked, “I defy that bell!” wherein she was likewise much commended.
vi: It was the Goddess of Revenge, in the enthusiastic cheers of the crowd, manipulating the trial. The judge rang the bell; but the Goddess of Revenge, still excited, shouted: − I challenge that bell! - And the crowd cheered in response.
tr: The person trying to steer the case with the enthusiastic approval of the audience was İntikam. The chairman rang the bell; but İntikam, further encouraged by those in the hall, shouted even more fervently, "That bell doesn't work on me!" and the crowd once again applauded wildly.
es: The one who had just spoken was La Venganza. The applause from the crowd was deafening. The President rang the bell, but La Venganza, incited by the mobs, howled: —I don't feel like being quiet! I laugh at the bell and at whoever rings it! Finally, he fell silent when his strength was exhausted.

en: “Inform the Tribunal of what you did that day within the Bastille, citizen.”
vi: − Present to the court what you did that day in the Bastille, Citizen.
tr: "Then tell the court what you did at the Bastille that day, citizen."
es: —Report to the Tribunal what you did inside the Bastille, citizen.

en: “I knew,” said Defarge, looking down at his wife, who stood at the bottom of the steps on which he was raised, looking steadily up at him; “I knew that this prisoner, of whom I speak, had been confined in a cell known as One Hundred and Five, North Tower. I knew it from himself. He knew himself by no other name than One Hundred and Five, North Tower, when he made shoes under my care. As I serve my gun that day, I resolve, when the place shall fall, to examine that cell. It falls. I mount to the cell, with a fellow-citizen who is one of the Jury, directed by a gaoler. I examine it, very closely. In a hole in the chimney, where a stone has been worked out and replaced, I find a written paper. This is that written paper. I have made it my business to examine some specimens of the writing of Doctor Manette. This is the writing of Doctor Manette. I confide this paper, in the writing of Doctor Manette, to the hands of the President.”
vi: − I knew beforehand, - Defarge said, looking at his wife, who was standing at the bottom of the steps leading up to where he stood, her eyes looking up at her husband. I knew that the prisoner I spoke of was locked in Cell One Hundred and Five, North Tower, when he made shoes under my protection. When I fired the cannon that day, I decided that when the place fell, I would go examine that cell. The Bastille fell. I went up to that cell with a Citizen who is now on this jury, led by a guard. I examined it very carefully. In a hole in the chimney, where a stone had been pried out and replaced, I found a bundle of handwritten papers. This is that bundle of handwritten papers. I took the time to examine some samples of Dr. Manette's handwriting. It is indeed his handwriting. I respectfully hand over that bundle of papers, written in Dr. Manette's own handwriting, to the Chief Justice. −
tr: Defarge, sitting at the foot of the witness stand, looked towards his wife who was staring at him unblinkingly, and said, "The prisoner in question. I knew he was held in a cell known as One Hundred and Five, North Tower. He had told me this himself. During the days when he was making shoes and I was looking after him, if you asked his name, he would say One Hundred and Five, North Tower. On that day, when the cannon was fired, I decided to examine that cell when the Bastille fell. Then it fell. Accompanied by a guard and a citizen friend who is now on the Jury, we went up to the cell. I examined the cell thoroughly. One of the stones of the chimney had been removed and then replaced, and here I found a paper with something written on it. This is that paper. Later, I found and examined some writing samples of Doctor Manette. This was his writing. I am handing this paper containing Doctor Manette's writing to the President."
es: —I knew—replied Defarge, looking at his wife who was staring at him from a short distance with her eyes—that the captive I speak of had been buried in a cell they called One Hundred and Five, North Tower. The secret was revealed to me by him, for while he stayed in my house, making shoes, he did not know that he had any other name than One Hundred and Five, North Tower. On the day of the storming of the Bastille, while I was firing my cannon, I decided to inspect the cell in question as soon as the fortress fell into our hands. It fell; and I immediately went up to the mentioned dungeon, along with a companion who is on the jury, and a jailer who took charge of guiding us. I inspected it very carefully, and in a hole in the wall, concealed behind a stone that had been removed and replaced, I found a written paper. This is the written paper. I have examined several writings of Doctor Manette, and the handwriting on this paper is in Doctor Manette's own hand. I hand this paper, written in Doctor Manette's own hand, to the President.

en: “Let it be read.”
vi: For the court to read aloud.
tr: "Let the text be read."
es: —Let it be read.

en: In a dead silence and stillness—the prisoner under trial looking lovingly at his wife, his wife only looking from him to look with solicitude at her father, Doctor Manette keeping his eyes fixed on the reader, Madame Defarge never taking hers from the prisoner, Defarge never taking his from his feasting wife, and all the other eyes there intent upon the Doctor, who saw none of them—the paper was read, as follows.
vi: The courtroom was as silent as a grave - the prisoner looked lovingly at his wife, who only took her eyes off her husband to anxiously look at her father. Dr. Manette stared intently at the person holding the stack of papers, Madame Defarge never took her eyes off the prisoner, Defarge only saw the wife gloating, and all other eyes were on the doctor, who paid no attention to anyone.
tr: Everyone held their breath, and while not a sound was heard in the hall, the defendant looked at his wife with loving eyes, and she only took her worried eyes off him to look at her father. While Doctor Manette's eyes were fixed on the person who would read the paper. Madame Defarge did not take her eyes off the defendant, Monsieur Defarge did not take his eyes off his wife whose face was beaming, and all other eyes were turned to the Doctor who saw none of this – the paper began to be read.
es: The document, read in the midst of a sepulchral silence, while the convict looked lovingly at his wife, and she looked now at him, now at her father, and Dr. Manette did not take his eyes off the reader, and Mrs. Defarge fixed hers insistently on the prisoner, and Defarge did not take his eyes off his wife, and everyone in the room watched the doctor who saw no one, said thus:

en: CHAPTER X.
vi: The paper was read aloud.
tr: X
es: X.

en: The Substance of the Shadow
vi: 10. The Essence of Darkness I, Alexandre Manette, an unfortunate doctor, born in Beauvais, later living in Paris, write this sorrowful testament in the dismal Bastille prison, in the last month of the year 1767.
tr: The Shadow's Form
es: THE SUBSTANCE OF THE SHADOW

en: I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate physician, native of Beauvais, and afterwards resident in Paris, write this melancholy paper in my doleful cell in the Bastille, during the last month of the year, 1767. I write it at stolen intervals, under every difficulty. I design to secrete it in the wall of the chimney, where I have slowly and laboriously made a place of concealment for it. Some pitying hand may find it there, when I and my sorrows are dust.
vi: 10. The Essence of Darkness I, Alexandre Manette, an unfortunate doctor, born in Beauvais, later living in Paris, write this sorrowful testament in the dismal Bastille prison, in the last month of the year 1767. I secretly write it piece by piece under extremely harsh conditions. I intentionally hide it in the wall cavity of the chimney, where I painstakingly created a hiding place over a long period. A compassionate hand might find it there when I and my sufferings have turned to dust.
tr: Ben, Alexandre Manette, born in Beauvais, the unfortunate doctor who lived in Paris, am writing this sorrowful note in the gloomy cell of the Bastille in the last month of the year 1767. I am writing this note in stolen intervals, under very difficult conditions. To hide it, I have slowly and laboriously prepared a place in the wall of the chimney. Perhaps a compassionate hand will find it one day when I and my sufferings have turned to dust.
es: "I, Alejandro Manette, unfortunate doctor, native of Beauvais, and resident of Paris, write this painful document in my horrendous cell in the Bastille in the last month of the year 1767." "I write it taking advantage of moments that I steal from vigilance and overcoming immense difficulties." "My purpose is to hide it inside the wall of my tomb, where through hard work I have managed to open a hole." "Perhaps some merciful hand will find it when I and my misfortunes have passed into the world of oblivion."

en: “These words are formed by the rusty iron point with which I write with difficulty in scrapings of soot and charcoal from the chimney, mixed with blood, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity. Hope has quite departed from my breast. I know from terrible warnings I have noted in myself that my reason will not long remain unimpaired, but I solemnly declare that I am at this time in the possession of my right mind—that my memory is exact and circumstantial—and that I write the truth as I shall answer for these my last recorded words, whether they be ever read by men or not, at the Eternal Judgment-seat.
vi: These lines were written with a rusty sharp iron dipped in soot scraped from the chimney, mixed with blood, in the last month of the tenth year of my imprisonment. My heart was completely in despair. Through the terrible signs that I had noticed in myself, I knew that my sanity would not remain intact for much longer, but I swear that right now, I am completely lucid - my memory is still accurate and detailed - and I swear to write down the exact truth as if these were my last words, whether or not this testament is read by anyone on the Day of Final Judgment.
tr: I am writing these words in the last month of my ten-year imprisonment, with great difficulty, by mixing soot and coal dust that I scraped from the chimney with blood and using a rusty iron tip to write. There is no hope left inside me anymore. From the symptoms that have recently emerged, I understand that losing my sanity is near, but I swear that right now my mind is fully intact – my memory is strong, even the details are vivid in my mind – and I am ready to account for all these recorded last words to humanity and to God on Judgment Day.
es: "I trace these lines with the rust I have scraped from the moldy bars of the grille mixed with blood from my veins, in the last month of the tenth year of my captivity." "In my chest, there is not a single atom of hope left." "Terrible phenomena that I have observed in myself announce that very soon reason will also abandon me, but I solemnly declare that at this moment I am in full possession of my mental faculties... that my memory is exact and detailed, that I write the truth, and that I am ready to vouch for the veracity of my words, whether they are read by men someday or condemned to eternal secrecy, before the Eternal Judge whose gaze reads into the depths of hearts."

en: “One cloudy moonlight night, in the third week of December (I think the twenty-second of the month) in the year 1757, I was walking on a retired part of the quay by the Seine for the refreshment of the frosty air, at an hour’s distance from my place of residence in the Street of the School of Medicine, when a carriage came along behind me, driven very fast. As I stood aside to let that carriage pass, apprehensive that it might otherwise run me down, a head was put out at the window, and a voice called to the driver to stop.
vi: On a moonlit night covered with clouds, during the third week of December (I remember it was the 22nd of the month) in the year 1757, I was strolling along a deserted section of the Seine riverbank to enjoy the cool air, an hour's walk from my home on École de Médecine street, when a carriage came speeding from behind. As I cautiously stepped aside to avoid being run over, a head popped out of the carriage window and a voice shouted at the coachman to stop the horses.
tr: In the third week of December in the year 1757 (I believe it was the twenty-second), on a moonlit and cloudy night, in the freezing weather, I had gone for a walk to get some fresh air on a deserted quay an hour's distance from my home on the street of the Faculty of Medicine, by the banks of the Seine River, when I heard the sound of a rapidly approaching carriage from behind. As I stepped aside to give way so that it wouldn't run me over, a head leaned out of the carriage window and told the driver to stop.
es: One night during the fourth week of December (I believe it was the twenty-second of the month) in the year 1757, I found myself walking in a secluded area of the promenade that borders the Seine, an hour's distance from my home, located on the street of the Faculty of Medicine, when I saw a carriage approaching from behind, drawn by two horses, at a gallop. As I stepped aside to let the carriage pass and avoid being run over, a head appeared in the window, and a voice commanded the coachman to stop.

en: “The carriage stopped as soon as the driver could rein in his horses, and the same voice called to me by my name. I answered. The carriage was then so far in advance of me that two gentlemen had time to open the door and alight before I came up with it.
vi: The carriage came to a halt as soon as the coachman pulled the reins, and that same voice called me by name. I responded. The carriage had stopped far ahead, so the two gentlemen had time to open the door and step down before I arrived.
tr: The moment the driver managed to pull on the reins of his horse, the carriage stopped, and the same person called out to me by name. I responded in kind. The carriage had stopped a bit ahead of me, so by the time I reached them, the two gentlemen had already opened the carriage door and stepped out.
es: "The carriage came to a halt as soon as the coachman could rein in the horses, and the same voice that had given the order to stop called me by my name." "The carriage did not stop in front of me, but at a distance sufficient for two gentlemen to have time to open the door and jump onto the path before I arrived, responding to the call."

en: “I observed that they were both wrapped in cloaks, and appeared to conceal themselves. As they stood side by side near the carriage door, I also observed that they both looked of about my own age, or rather younger, and that they were greatly alike, in stature, manner, voice, and (as far as I could see) face too.
vi: I saw that both were wrapped tightly in cloaks, seemingly concealing their identities. When they stood next to each other near the car door, I also noticed that both were about my age, or slightly younger, and very similar in terms of build, demeanor, voice, and (as far as I could tell) even their faces.
tr: I noticed that both of them were wrapped in cloaks, as if hiding from something. When they stood side by side next to the carriage door, I saw that they were both around my age, perhaps a bit younger, and that they resembled each other greatly in height, build, demeanor, voice, and (as far as I could see) facial features.
es: "I observed that both were perfectly cloaked in their capes and that they tried to conceal their faces." "When I reached their side and found them standing on either side of the door, I also noticed that both seemed to be of my age, perhaps younger, and that they resembled each other greatly in height, movements, voice, and (from the little I could see) even in their faces."

en: “‘You are Doctor Manette?’ said one.
vi: − Are you Doctor Manette? - Someone asked.
tr: "Are you Doctor Manette?" said one.
es: "—Are you Dr. Manette?—one of them asked me.

en: “I am.”
vi: − I am.
tr: "Yes, it's me."
es: "—I am— I replied.

en: “‘Doctor Manette, formerly of Beauvais,’ said the other; ‘the young physician, originally an expert surgeon, who within the last year or two has made a rising reputation in Paris?’
vi: − Doctor Manette, formerly of Beauvais, - another person said, - a young doctor, formerly a surgeon, who has gained rapid fame in Paris over the past one or two years?
tr: "Isn't it Doctor Manette from Beauvais?" said the other; "you know, the one who was originally a surgeon and has gained fame in Paris over the last few years, young Doctor Manette?"
es: »—The doctor Manette, a native of Beauvais, a young and skilled physician and surgeon, who for the past one or two years has become a true notable in Paris?—interjected the other.

en: “‘Gentlemen,’ I returned, ‘I am that Doctor Manette of whom you speak so graciously.’
vi: − Gentlemen, - I replied, - I am indeed Doctor Manette, to whom you have bestowed such kind words. −
tr: "Gentlemen," I said, "yes. I am Doctor Manette, about whom you have spoken so elegantly."
es: "—Gentlemen; I am, indeed, Doctor Manette, of whom you speak with excessive benevolence— I replied.

en: “‘We have been to your residence,’ said the first, ‘and not being so fortunate as to find you there, and being informed that you were probably walking in this direction, we followed, in the hope of overtaking you. Will you please to enter the carriage?’
vi: We went to your residence, - the first person said, - but unfortunately did not find you at home, and were informed that you might be walking in this direction, so we followed in hopes of catching up with you. Would you be so kind as to get into this carriage?
tr: "First, we went to your house," said the first one, "but unfortunately, we couldn't find you there; they told us that you might have walked this way, so we came here hoping to catch you. Now, would you please get in the car?"
es: "—We have been to your house—replied the one who had spoken first,—and not having had the luck to find you, although we were fortunate enough to be told that you were probably walking around these places, we followed you driven by the hope of catching up with you." Would you be so kind as to get into the carriage?

en: “The manner of both was imperious, and they both moved, as these words were spoken, so as to place me between themselves and the carriage door. They were armed. I was not.
vi: Both of them had a threatening demeanor and, upon finishing their words, they moved to force me towards the carriage door. They were armed. I was not.
tr: They both had a commanding demeanor, and as they said these things, they moved to position me between the car door and themselves. They were armed. I was not.
es: "The tone of his voice was imperious; while the words he left recorded were exchanged, they moved in such a way that left me positioned between them and the car door, and moreover, they were armed and I was not."

en: “‘Gentlemen,’ said I, ‘pardon me; but I usually inquire who does me the honour to seek my assistance, and what is the nature of the case to which I am summoned.’
vi: − Gentlemen, - I said, - excuse me, but I usually like to know who needs me and the condition of the illness that requires my attention.
tr: "Gentlemen," I said, "excuse me, but I usually like to know in advance which person is honoring me by needing my help and what kind of ailment the patient has."
es: "—I beg you to forgive me, gentlemen— I replied,—but it is my custom to ask who the people are who do me the honor of requesting my services and the nature of the case that makes my assistance necessary or convenient."

en: “The reply to this was made by him who had spoken second. ‘Doctor, your clients are people of condition. As to the nature of the case, our confidence in your skill assures us that you will ascertain it for yourself better than we can describe it. Enough. Will you please to enter the carriage?’
vi: − Doctor, - the second person replied, - your patient is a nobleman. As for the condition of the illness, we believe that your expertise will ensure that you understand it better than we can describe. That is enough. Would you be so kind as to get into the carriage?
tr: The response came from the second speaker. "Doctor, your patients are always distinguished individuals. As for the nature of the illness, based on our confidence in your skill, we know that when you see the patient, you will understand it much better than we could ever explain to you. This information should suffice. Now, would you please get in the car?"
es: "The one who had spoken second replied to me: "—Your clients, doctor, are people of high social standing." "As far as the nature of the case that necessitates your assistance is concerned, the confidence we have in your science and skill is a guarantee for us that you will understand it without the need for our explanations, which would surely be inadequate." "I believe what has been said is sufficient." "Would you be so kind as to mount?"

en: “I could do nothing but comply, and I entered it in silence. They both entered after me—the last springing in, after putting up the steps. The carriage turned about, and drove on at its former speed.
vi: I had no choice but to comply and silently got into the carriage. Both of them entered the carriage after me, the last one jumping in after folding up the steps. The horse-drawn carriage turned around and sped off as before.
tr: There was no choice but to submit; I got into the car silently. Both of them got in after me – the last one jumped into the car after lifting the step. The car turned around and sped off as quickly as it had come.
es: "I had no other recourse but to obey, and I did so without saying a word." Immediately, the two gentlemen followed me, with the one who entered last having picked up the stirrup. The carriage turned around and departed at a gallop.

en: “I repeat this conversation exactly as it occurred. I have no doubt that it is, word for word, the same. I describe everything exactly as it took place, constraining my mind not to wander from the task. Where I make the broken marks that follow here, I leave off for the time, and put my paper in its hiding-place.
vi: I recount this conversation exactly as it happened. I am certain that every word is accurate. I describe everything exactly as it occurred and force my mind to focus on this task. The parts I left unfinished later on are because I had to temporarily stop writing and hide this pen... ۩۩۩
tr: I'm writing this as it is. I have no doubt that this conversation is exactly word for word the same. Without allowing my mind to stray from the event, I am conveying everything exactly as it happened. Now, I will mark the end of this part, take a break from writing, and hide this paper in its secret place.
es: "I record the conversation here exactly as it happened; I can assure you that I am repeating it verbatim, word for word." "I describe everything exactly as it took place, restraining my imagination and preventing it from wandering." "The ellipses that you find in my account mean that I am pausing the task for another occasion and that I am hiding the document in the designated hiding place..."

en: “The carriage left the streets behind, passed the North Barrier, and emerged upon the country road. At two-thirds of a league from the Barrier—I did not estimate the distance at that time, but afterwards when I traversed it—it struck out of the main avenue, and presently stopped at a solitary house, We all three alighted, and walked, by a damp soft footpath in a garden where a neglected fountain had overflowed, to the door of the house. It was not opened immediately, in answer to the ringing of the bell, and one of my two conductors struck the man who opened it, with his heavy riding glove, across the face.
vi: The carriage passed through many crossroads, crossed the northern city gate, and went back onto the country road. About two-thirds of a mile from the city gate - at that time I did not estimate the distance, but on the way back I paid attention - the carriage turned off the main road and shortly thereafter stopped at a secluded house. The three of us got out of the carriage and followed a soft, wet dirt path through a garden with a neglected, overflowing fountain, to the main door. The door did not open immediately after the bell was rung, and one of my two guides swung a thick riding glove and struck the person who opened the door in the face.
tr: The car left the streets behind and passed through the northern exit gate, heading out onto the highway outside the city. After moving about two-thirds of a league from the barrier – at that moment, I couldn't estimate the distance exactly, but I paid attention later – the car left the highway and stopped in front of an isolated house. The three of us got out of the car and started walking, passing through the wet and soft path of a garden with a neglected fountain overflowing with water, until we reached the door of the house. Even though we rang the bell, it wasn't opened immediately, and after it was opened, one of my guides struck the man who opened the door in the face with the heavy riding glove in his hand.
es: "The carriage passed through many streets, went through the North Barrier, and soon advanced along a road outside the city." "At two-thirds of a league from the Barrier (I didn't calculate the distance then, but I did when I traveled it again), the carriage left the main road, and moments later it stopped in front of a solitary house." "The three of us jumped to the ground and advanced along a soft path in a garden, covered with grass, in the center of which a fountain had once flowed, until we reached the door of the house." "We were granted entry as soon as the bell rang, and the one who opened the door received a terrible slap from one of my companions."

en: “There was nothing in this action to attract my particular attention, for I had seen common people struck more commonly than dogs. But, the other of the two, being angry likewise, struck the man in like manner with his arm; the look and bearing of the brothers were then so exactly alike, that I then first perceived them to be twin brothers.
vi: That action did not bother me much, because I had seen people being beaten more than dogs. But the second person, equally angry, also swung his hand to hit the person opening the door in the same way; the appearance and demeanor of these two were identical, so at that moment I thought they were twins.
tr: I didn't find this behavior very strange, as I had often witnessed people being more infatuated with dogs than with ordinary humans. But the other man struck the person with his arm just as angrily and in the same manner; the brothers resembled each other so much in both appearance and behavior that it was only then that I realized they were twins.
es: "I confess that the act did not catch my attention, as I was very accustomed to seeing men of the lower class being treated by the nobles with less regard than if they were dogs." "Once inside the house, I could observe that the resemblance between my two companions was so remarkable that I immediately took them for twin brothers."

en: “From the time of our alighting at the outer gate (which we found locked, and which one of the brothers had opened to admit us, and had relocked), I had heard cries proceeding from an upper chamber. I was conducted to this chamber straight, the cries growing louder as we ascended the stairs, and I found a patient in a high fever of the brain, lying on a bed.
vi: From the moment we got out of the car at the outer gate (the gate was tightly locked and one of the two brothers had to open it for us to enter and then lock it again), I heard many screams coming from a room upstairs. I was taken directly to that room, the screams grew louder as we ascended the stairs, and I saw a patient with encephalitis fever lying on the bed.
tr: As soon as we got out there at the outer door (the door was locked, but one of the brothers opened it and then locked it again), I heard the shouting coming from one of the rooms upstairs. I was directed straight to this room; with each step on the stairs, the screams grew louder; finally, I found in front of me a patient lying in bed, suffering from brain fever.
es: "Since we jumped out of the carriage in front of the garden gate, which we found closed and was opened by one of the brothers, closing it again after we passed through, I had been hearing screams that originated from one of the upper rooms of the house." "They led me straight to the room from which the screams were coming, where I found a sick woman lying on the bed, suffering from a terrible brain fever."

en: “The patient was a woman of great beauty, and young; assuredly not much past twenty. Her hair was torn and ragged, and her arms were bound to her sides with sashes and handkerchiefs. I noticed that these bonds were all portions of a gentleman’s dress. On one of them, which was a fringed scarf for a dress of ceremony, I saw the armorial bearings of a Noble, and the letter E.
vi: The patient is a stunningly beautiful woman, still young; certainly not over twenty. Her hair was disheveled and her arms were tied to her sides with various scarves and handkerchiefs. I noticed that all the bindings were items belonging to a gentleman's attire. Among them was a fringed sash meant to be worn over formal attire, embroidered with the coat of arms of a noble family and the letter E.
tr: The patient was an extraordinarily beautiful woman and young; she was definitely not more than twenty years old. Her hair was disheveled and messy, and her arms were tied on both sides with sashes and handkerchiefs. I noticed that these bindings were parts of a man's clothing. One of them had the letter E and a coat of arms on a fringed scarf used for a ceremonial dress.
es: "The patient was a woman of wonderful beauty and very young; surely she was no more than twenty years old." "Her beautiful hair was in such complete disarray that it saddened the spirit, and the patient's arms were bound with strips of cloth." "I observed that these strips were pieces of a gentleman's suit, on one of which I saw the coat of arms of a noble with the initial E."

en: “I saw this, within the first minute of my contemplation of the patient; for, in her restless strivings she had turned over on her face on the edge of the bed, had drawn the end of the scarf into her mouth, and was in danger of suffocation. My first act was to put out my hand to relieve her breathing; and in moving the scarf aside, the embroidery in the corner caught my sight.
vi: I noticed this in the very first minute I saw the patient; because in her restless struggle, she had turned her face towards the side of the bed, with one end of the bandage in her mouth, posing a risk of suffocation. My first action was to reach out and pull the bandage out so she could breathe easier; and at that moment, I immediately saw the sign embroidered in one corner.
tr: I saw this as soon as I began to examine the patient; because during all her restless thrashing, the poor woman had turned face down towards the edge of the bed and the tip of her scarf had entered her mouth; she seemed to be suffocating. My first task was to ease her breathing, and as I put the scarf aside, the embroidered crest on its corner caught my eye.
es: “I made all these observations within a minute of having entered the room. It happened that the patient, whose agitation was dreadful, turned face down, one of the straps holding her got into her mouth, and I saw that she was in danger of suffocating. Naturally, I removed the strip, and that was when I discovered the little embroidered coat of arms on it.

en: “I turned her gently over, placed my hands upon her breast to calm her and keep her down, and looked into her face. Her eyes were dilated and wild, and she constantly uttered piercing shrieks, and repeated the words, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ and then counted up to twelve, and said, ‘Hush!’ For an instant, and no more, she would pause to listen, and then the piercing shrieks would begin again, and she would repeat the cry, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ and would count up to twelve, and say, ‘Hush!’ There was no variation in the order, or the manner. There was no cessation, but the regular moment’s pause, in the utterance of these sounds.
vi: I gently turned her around, placed my hand on her chest to reassure her and keep her lying still, and looked into that face. In her eyes, the pupils had dilated and become vacant; she kept screaming shrilly and repeatedly saying the words “My husband, my father, my brother!” then counting from one to twelve, and then exclaiming, “Hush!”. She only paused to listen for a moment, no more, then the shrill screams continued, and the same words were repeated “My husband, my father, my brother!” and she counted to twelve again, then “Hush!”. It repeated like that, unchanged. Never stopping, except for the brief pauses between the delirious words.
tr: I gently turned him over, placed my hand on his chest to calm him down, and looked at his face. His eyes opened wide like saucers, and he frequently let out piercing screams that penetrated one's soul, muttering, "My husband, my father, my brother!"; then he counted to twelve and said, "Shh!" He paused for a moment to listen to his surroundings, then resumed the piercing screams, followed by again saying, "My husband, my father, my brother!" counting to twelve, and saying, "Shh!" There was no difference in either the sequence or the manner of these actions. He did not take any breaks except for the brief pause before saying those words.
es: "I turned the patient onto her back, placed my hand on her chest to calm her and make her stay still, and looked at her face." "Her gaze was horribly dilated, and her clenched lips were repeatedly shouting these words: 'My husband... my father... my brother.'" "Then she would count to twelve, remain silent for a few seconds listening with all the attention of her soul, and start shouting again 'My husband... my father... my brother,' and again count to twelve and again pause to listen." "There was not the slightest variation in her tone, gestures, or voice." "—When did this state of affairs begin?

en: “‘How long,’ I asked, ‘has this lasted?’
vi: − How long has it been like this? - I asked.
tr: "Since when has it been like this?" I asked.
es: —I asked.

en: “To distinguish the brothers, I will call them the elder and the younger; by the elder, I mean him who exercised the most authority. It was the elder who replied, ‘Since about this hour last night.’
vi: To distinguish these two brothers, I will refer to them as the older brother and the younger brother; I call one the older brother because he appears to be the most authoritative. The older brother himself answered: − Since around this time last night.
tr: To distinguish between the brothers, I will call one big and the other small; the one I call big, who is more authoritative, responded, "Since around this time last night."
es: "In order to distinguish between the two brothers, I will call one the elder brother and the other the younger, understanding by the elder the one who exercised greater authority." "—Since last night at this time—replied the older brother.

en: “‘She has a husband, a father, and a brother?’
vi: − Does she have a husband, father, and siblings?
tr: "Does she have a husband, a father, and a brother?"
es: "—Does she have a husband, father, and brother?"

en: “‘A brother.’
vi: − A younger brother.
tr: "He/She has a sibling.""
es: »—He has a brother.

en: “‘I do not address her brother?’
vi: − Aren't you her brother? −
tr: "Am I speaking with the sibling right now?"
es: »—And am I not speaking with that brother at this very moment?

en: “He answered with great contempt, ‘No.’
vi: No, - he replied with utmost contempt.
tr: "No," replied the man with a sneer.
es: "—No—he replied with a tone of deep contempt.

en: “‘She has some recent association with the number twelve?’
vi: − Has she recently had anything to do with the number twelve?
tr: "Has something happened recently with the number twelve?"
es: »—Has anything related to the number twelve happened to her recently?»

en: “The younger brother impatiently rejoined, ‘With twelve o’clock?’
vi: The impatient younger one interjected: − Twelve o'clock? −
tr: The little brother impatiently interrupted, "It's about twelve o'clock."
es: "—With number twelve?—repeated the younger brother impatiently.

en: “‘See, gentlemen,’ said I, still keeping my hands upon her breast, ‘how useless I am, as you have brought me! If I had known what I was coming to see, I could have come provided. As it is, time must be lost. There are no medicines to be obtained in this lonely place.’
vi: There, sir, - I said, still holding my hand on her chest, - if you take me away like this, I am helpless! If I had known beforehand what I would see, I would have brought the necessary items. As it is, this is a waste of time. In this desolate place, how can one find medicine?
tr: My hand is still on the patient's chest, "Look, gentlemen," I said, "you brought me here but it was of no use! If you had explained the situation, I would have come prepared accordingly. Now we will waste time. There is no place to find medicine in this desolate area.'"
es: "—You can convince yourselves, gentlemen, of how uselessly you have brought me here, just as I am," I said, my hands still placed on the patient's chest. "If I had known what was happening, I would have come equipped with what was necessary, whereas now we are wasting time miserably." "In a place as isolated as this, it is not possible to find medicines."

en: “The elder brother looked to the younger, who said haughtily, ‘There is a case of medicines here;’ and brought it from a closet, and put it on the table.
vi: The older brother looked at the younger brother. −
tr: The younger brother, with an arrogant air, said, "There is a medicine box here," and took the box out of a cupboard, placing it on the table, while the elder one looked at him.
es: "The older brother looked at the younger one, who replied in a haughty voice: "—We have a first aid kit here." »Moments later, he took it out of a cupboard and placed it on the table...

en: “I opened some of the bottles, smelt them, and put the stoppers to my lips. If I had wanted to use anything save narcotic medicines that were poisons in themselves, I would not have administered any of those.
vi: “There is a chest full of medicine here,” the younger brother said arrogantly, then pulled a small chest from the cupboard and placed it on the table... ۩۩۩ I opened a few bottles, sniffed them, and brought the lids to my lips. I would not use these unless I needed anesthetic drugs with toxic substances.
tr: I opened and smelled some of the bottles and brought the stoppers to my lips. Under different circumstances, I wouldn't have been able to give any of these drug pills that act as poison on their own.
es: "I opened some jars, smelled them, and brought their caps to my lips." "If I had needed to administer any non-narcotic or non-toxic substance to the patient, I certainly wouldn't have medicated her with anything that the medicine cabinet contained."

en: “‘Do you doubt them?’ asked the younger brother.
vi: The younger brother asked: − Can't use them?
tr: "Did you not trust the medicines?" asked the little brother.
es: "—Don't they inspire confidence in you?—asked the younger brother.

en: “‘You see, monsieur, I am going to use them,’ I replied, and said no more.
vi: − “Sir, I have no choice but to use them,” I replied and said nothing more.
tr: "Alright, monsieur, I will give it to you in a moment," I replied, and said nothing more.
es: "—You can see, sir, that I am going to use them— I replied simply.

en: “I made the patient swallow, with great difficulty, and after many efforts, the dose that I desired to give. As I intended to repeat it after a while, and as it was necessary to watch its influence, I then sat down by the side of the bed. There was a timid and suppressed woman in attendance (wife of the man down-stairs), who had retreated into a corner. The house was damp and decayed, indifferently furnished—evidently, recently occupied and temporarily used. Some thick old hangings had been nailed up before the windows, to deaden the sound of the shrieks. They continued to be uttered in their regular succession, with the cry, ‘My husband, my father, and my brother!’ the counting up to twelve, and ‘Hush!’ The frenzy was so violent, that I had not unfastened the bandages restraining the arms; but, I had looked to them, to see that they were not painful. The only spark of encouragement in the case, was, that my hand upon the sufferer’s breast had this much soothing influence, that for minutes at a time it tranquillised the figure. It had no effect upon the cries; no pendulum could be more regular.
vi: I found it very difficult to give the patient the medication, and only after many attempts did I manage to administer the desired dosage. Because I planned to give the medication again after a while to monitor its effects, I sat down next to the bed. Sitting in the corner of the room was a shy and frightened woman assisting (she was the wife of the person who had opened the door). The house was damp and decayed, with sparse furnishings - clearly, it had only been temporarily occupied recently. Several thick, old curtains had been nailed to the windows to muffle the sound of the screaming. The patient continued to scream in the same rhythm, after "My husband, my father, my brother!" she would count to twelve, then "Shh!". Her madness was so intense that I had to untie the straps binding her hands, but carefully, so her arms wouldn't flail and harm her. The only small consolation in this situation was that my hand placed on the patient's chest had a calming effect, helping her to be calm for a few minutes. But it didn't stop the screams; they were more regular than a swinging pendulum.
tr: After a considerable struggle, I managed to administer the dose I wanted to the patient. Since I intended to give the same amount again shortly and observe its effects, I sat right by the bed. A timid and downcast woman (the wife of the man downstairs) who was taking care of the patient had shrunk into a corner of the room. The house was damp, falling apart everywhere, and very carelessly furnished – it was clearly being used temporarily and had been recently moved into. Old thick fabrics had been nailed to the windows to reduce the intensity of the sharp screams. These screams, cries of "My husband, my father, my brother!", counting up to twelve, and "Shh!" sounds followed each other in a regular pattern. The fit was so severe that I hadn't untied the restraints preventing him from moving his arms, but I checked to make sure they weren't causing pain. The only thing that encouraged me in this situation was seeing that my hand placed on the poor man's chest had a calming effect and that this comforted him, even if only for three to five minutes. On the other hand, it had no effect on the screams; frankly, no pendulum could operate so regularly.
es: »Not without having to struggle with great difficulties, and after a long while, I managed to get the patient to take the dose of medicine that I deemed appropriate. Since my intention was to repeat the medication and observe the effects that the first dose had on the patient, I sat at the head of her bed. Sitting timidly and obviously shy in a corner, there was a woman who was taking care of her, married to one of the individuals from downstairs. The house was dirty, poorly maintained, and furnished, evident signs that they had occupied it very recently and that their intention was to stay there for a very short time. They had temporarily hung some drapes in front of the windows, undoubtedly to prevent the patient's screams from reaching the outside. She continued screaming as she had when I arrived, repeating the same words in the same order: «My husband... my father... my brother», and then counting up to twelve. Her convulsions were so violent that I did not deem it prudent to free her from the straps that restrained her, although I adjusted them to make them less bothersome. The crisis did not respond to the medication, but I observed that the pressure of my hand on the patient's chest had such an influence on her that after a few minutes she calmed down. However, it did not have the same effect on the screams, which continued with the regularity of a pendulum.

en: “For the reason that my hand had this effect (I assume), I had sat by the side of the bed for half an hour, with the two brothers looking on, before the elder said:
vi: Because my hand had the effect of calming the madness (I think so), I sat by the bed for half an hour, while the two brothers stood watching, and finally the older brother spoke: −
tr: Since the elimination had such an effect (I think it did), I sat on the edge of the bed for about half an hour with my siblings' eyes on me; then the older one said:
es: "I had been sitting by the bed for half an hour under the gaze of the two brothers when the elder said:

en: “‘There is another patient.’
vi: There is one more patient.
tr: "There is one more patient."
es: "—We have another patient."

en: “I was startled, and asked, ‘Is it a pressing case?’
vi: I started and asked: "Is it urgent?"
tr: I was taken aback; "Is it an emergency then?" I asked.
es: "The news alarmed me, and I asked: "—Is the case urgent?"

en: “‘You had better see,’ he carelessly answered; and took up a light.
vi: "It's best if you go check on the patient," he answered vaguely; then picked up the lamp... ۩۩۩
tr: With a nonchalant air, he said, "You'd better see it," and took a lamp in his hand.
es: "—It would be better if you saw it with your own eyes—he replied to me in a negligent tone, taking a light...

en: “The other patient lay in a back room across a second staircase, which was a species of loft over a stable. There was a low plastered ceiling to a part of it; the rest was open, to the ridge of the tiled roof, and there were beams across. Hay and straw were stored in that portion of the place, fagots for firing, and a heap of apples in sand. I had to pass through that part, to get at the other. My memory is circumstantial and unshaken. I try it with these details, and I see them all, in this my cell in the Bastille, near the close of the tenth year of my captivity, as I saw them all that night.
vi: The patient is lying in the room beyond the second staircase.
