The room was like an attic above the horse stable; part of the ceiling was low and whitewashed, while the other part was open all the way up to the edge of the tiled roof, with visible crossbeams. In the open-ceiling area, there were straw, bundles of firewood, and a pile of apples stored in sand. I had to pass through that area to get to the other side. I remember it very vividly and precisely. I recall every detail so clearly that even in the Bastille prison, after nearly ten years of captivity, I still remember it as if I had seen it that night.
tr: The other patient was lying in one of the back rooms opposite the second staircase, in a place like an attic above a stable. A part of this area was covered by a low ceiling with plaster; the remaining part opened to the roof covered with tiles, and there were beams across. In this section, dry grass and straw were piled up for burning, and apples were placed on a pile of sand. I had to pass through here to get to the other section. All the details remain vividly in my memory. As I approach the end of my tenth year of imprisonment in this cell in the Bastille, everything is in my mind with all the details as it was that night.
es: "The second patient lay in a room situated at the back of the house, a room that was really nothing more than an attic placed above a stable." "Part of the attic had a very low roof and part did not." "Under the covered part, there was hay and straw stored, and the rest contained firewood and farming tools." "I remember all these details so well that it seems as if I am seeing them at this moment just as I saw them that night, despite being locked up for ten years in my cell in the Bastille."

en: “On some hay on the ground, with a cushion thrown under his head, lay a handsome peasant boy—a boy of not more than seventeen at the most. He lay on his back, with his teeth set, his right hand clenched on his breast, and his glaring eyes looking straight upward. I could not see where his wound was, as I kneeled on one knee over him; but, I could see that he was dying of a wound from a sharp point.
vi: Lying on his back on a layer of straw on the ground, with his head resting on a pillow, was a handsome young farmer - a youth of about seventeen years old at most. He lay on his back, teeth clenched, right hand clutching his chest, and his eyes blazing as he stared straight up. I couldn't see his wound when I knelt on one knee beside him, but I knew he was about to die from a stab wound.
tr: On the dry grass on the ground, with a pillow under his head, lay a handsome peasant boy – he couldn't have been older than seventeen. His teeth were tightly clenched, his right hand claw-like on his chest, and his fiery eyes stared straight at the ceiling as he lay on his back. When I knelt on one knee and leaned over him, I couldn't see where his wound was; but it was not hard to tell that he had been injured by something sharp and was about to die.
es: "On a pile of hay and with his head resting on a pillow, lay a young man with a peasant-like appearance, a handsome face, and who could not have been more than seventeen years old." "He was lying on his back, with clenched teeth, his right hand clenched over his chest, and his gaze fixed on the ceiling." "I knelt beside him; and although I could not find the wound he had received, I immediately saw that he was dying from a wound caused by a sharp instrument."

en: “‘I am a doctor, my poor fellow,’ said I. ‘Let me examine it.’
vi: − I am a doctor, poor you, - I said. - Let me examine you.
tr: "I am a doctor, my friend," I said. "Let me take a look at your wound.""
es: "—I am a doctor, my poor friend— I said; —let me examine you."

en: “‘I do not want it examined,’ he answered; ‘let it be.’
vi: − I don't need an examination, - he replied, - just leave it.
tr: "I don't want you to look," said the boy; "never mind."
es: "—I don't want to be recognized; leave me alone—he replied."

en: “It was under his hand, and I soothed him to let me move his hand away. The wound was a sword-thrust, received from twenty to twenty-four hours before, but no skill could have saved him if it had been looked to without delay. He was then dying fast. As I turned my eyes to the elder brother, I saw him looking down at this handsome boy whose life was ebbing out, as if he were a wounded bird, or hare, or rabbit; not at all as if he were a fellow-creature.
vi: The wound lay under his hand, I coaxed him to lift his hand for me. It was a sword wound that pierced the chest from twenty or twenty-four hours ago, but even if treated immediately, it could not have been saved. In just a moment, he will die. When I turned towards the brother, I saw him looking down at the handsome young man who was dying with an indifferent gaze, as if the victim were a bird or a hare rather than a fellow human being.
tr: The wound was under my hand, and I eased it a bit to allow me to pull my hand away. It was a sword wound that had occurred twenty to twenty-four hours ago, but even if it had been immediately attended to by skilled hands, there was no chance of survival. The boy was dying rapidly. When I turned my eyes to the older brother, I saw that he was looking at this handsome young man, whose life was fading away, not as if he were a wounded person, but as if he were a wounded bird or rabbit.
es: "The wound was located below his right hand, which took me no small effort and many attempts to separate." "It was a stab wound received twenty to twenty-four hours earlier, a mortal stab wound, even if all the aid of science had been provided the second it was inflicted." "He was dying in spurts." "I searched with my gaze for the older brother's, and observed that he was watching the wounded boy with the same indifference with which he would watch a bird, a hare, or a wounded rabbit." "It was clearly noticeable that he did not see a human being in the boy."

en: “‘How has this been done, monsieur?’ said I.
vi: − Why did it come to this, sir? - I asked.
tr: "How did this happen, monsieur?" I asked.
es: "—Who caused you that wound, sir?—I asked.

en: “‘A crazed young common dog! A serf! Forced my brother to draw upon him, and has fallen by my brother’s sword—like a gentleman.’
vi: − A mad dog! A serf! Forced my brother to draw his sword and he fell under my brother's blade... like a nobleman.
tr: "This boy is a rabid, common dog! Villager! He forced my brother to draw his sword and got wounded by his sword –like a gentleman."
es: "—Bah!" "Why talk about a miserable servant... a dog?" "He forced my brother to fight against him, and fell under his sword as if he had been a knight."

en: “There was no touch of pity, sorrow, or kindred humanity, in this answer. The speaker seemed to acknowledge that it was inconvenient to have that different order of creature dying there, and that it would have been better if he had died in the usual obscure routine of his vermin kind. He was quite incapable of any compassionate feeling about the boy, or about his fate.
vi: There was no trace of compassion, sorrow, or humanity in that response. The speaker seemed to acknowledge the inconvenience of having someone from a different class die here, and it would have been better if he had died in some obscure corner like other lowly beings. He had no sympathy whatsoever for the young man or his fate.
tr: His response did not contain the slightest bit of pity, sadness, or humanity. He seemed more disturbed by the fact that this creature from another world was dying there; it would have been better if it died in its own dark corner like a parasitic animal. There was not an ounce of compassion in his heart for either that young boy or his fate.
es: "In the tone of the reply, there was neither a shadow of pity, nor a shadow of sorrow, nor a shadow of remorse."

en: “The boy’s eyes had slowly moved to him as he had spoken, and they now slowly moved to me.
vi: The farmer's gaze slowly turned towards the speaker and then slowly turned towards me.
tr: While he was talking, the boy's eyes slowly turned towards him, and then slowly turned towards me.
es: "The eyes of the dying man turned towards the one who had just spoken, then fixed on me."

en: “‘Doctor, they are very proud, these Nobles; but we common dogs are proud too, sometimes. They plunder us, outrage us, beat us, kill us; but we have a little pride left, sometimes. She—have you seen her, Doctor?’
vi: − Doctor, they are very arrogant, these nobles; but we lowly peasants also have moments of pride. They rob us, seize us, beat us, kill us, but sometimes we still retain a bit of pride. My sister... have you met my sister, doctor?
tr: "Doctor, these nobles are very proud; but we, the common dogs, can also be proud, sometimes. They rob us, crush us, beat us, kill us, but we still have a bit of pride left, sometimes. Have you seen her... the girl, Doctor?"
es: "—Doctor—he told me;—those nobles are very haughty; but we too, the miserable dogs, have our pride. They rob us, they loot us, they outrage us, they vilify us, they beat us, but all of that is not enough to drown our haughtiness. She... have you seen her, doctor?

en: “The shrieks and the cries were audible there, though subdued by the distance. He referred to them, as if she were lying in our presence.
vi: Here, you can still hear the screams, though the distance has muffled the sound. He spoke as if his sister were present here.
tr: "Even though there was a distance, the screams and wails could be heard from there. The boy had talked about the girl as if she were lying next to us.
es: The cries of the unfortunate woman reached there, albeit very muffled by the distance. The wounded man referred to the one who gave them as if she had been by his side.

en: “I said, ‘I have seen her.’
vi: − I have met her, - I said.
tr: "I saw," I said.
es: "—I have seen her, yes— I replied.

en: “‘She is my sister, Doctor. They have had their shameful rights, these Nobles, in the modesty and virtue of our sisters, many years, but we have had good girls among us. I know it, and have heard my father say so. She was a good girl. She was betrothed to a good young man, too: a tenant of his. We were all tenants of his—that man’s who stands there. The other is his brother, the worst of a bad race.’
vi: − That's my sister, doctor. They, these nobles, have had the outrageous right for years to violate the chastity of our sisters, but we still have virtuous girls. I know that, and I've heard my father say so. My sister is a virtuous girl. She was betrothed to a good man, also a tenant of his. We are all his tenants... the one standing there. And the other one is his brother, the worst of this vile family.
tr: "She is my sister, Doctor. These nobles have every kind of disgraceful right, for years they used our sisters' chastity and virtue as they wished. But there were good girls among them too. I know, I had heard this from my father too. My sister was a good girl. She was engaged to a good young man, one of this man's tenants. We were all tenants of his – the man standing over there. The other one is his brother, the worst of a bad lineage."
es: "—She is my sister, doctor. Those nobles may have had shameful rights over the modesty and virtue of our sisters for many years; but among us, there are still good girls, girls who know how to resist their violence. I know it, and I have heard my father affirm it as such. My sister is one of them. She had a romantic relationship with a young man, also good and honest, a vassal of this noble who is there... we were all his vassals... The other is his brother, the vilest representative of his despicable race.

en: “It was with the greatest difficulty that the boy gathered bodily force to speak; but, his spirit spoke with a dreadful emphasis.
vi: He had to muster all his strength to speak, but he spoke with a terrifyingly strong voice. −
tr: The boy's body could barely find the strength to speak; but his soul was screaming as if it were shouting.
es: "The unfortunate man had to make truly superhuman efforts to be able to speak; but if he lacked physical strength, he had an abundance of spiritual strength, and he spoke with extraordinary fortitude."

en: “‘We were so robbed by that man who stands there, as all we common dogs are by those superior Beings—taxed by him without mercy, obliged to work for him without pay, obliged to grind our corn at his mill, obliged to feed scores of his tame birds on our wretched crops, and forbidden for our lives to keep a single tame bird of our own, pillaged and plundered to that degree that when we chanced to have a bit of meat, we ate it in fear, with the door barred and the shutters closed, that his people should not see it and take it from us—I say, we were so robbed, and hunted, and were made so poor, that our father told us it was a dreadful thing to bring a child into the world, and that what we should most pray for, was, that our women might be barren and our miserable race die out!’
vi: We have been plundered by the one standing there, like all other destitute peasants... forced to pay taxes without mercy, forced to work for him without pay, forced to grind our grain at his mill, forced to feed his flock with our meager crops, while we couldn't even keep a single bird for ourselves, plundered to the extent that if we had a bit of meat to eat, we had to eat it in fear, with doors locked and barred, hiding it from his men for fear of having our food stolen... That's right, we were plundered, hunted, and stripped to such poverty that my father said bringing a child into this world was a crime, and the most fervent prayer was for our women to be barren so that this wretched race would perish!
tr: "Here, the man standing over there robbed us; after all, they are superior beings, and we are the dogs beside them – they collect merciless taxes from us, make us work for them without any payment, force us to grind our wheat in their mill, compel us to feed their pet birds with the handful of wheat we have, and do not allow us to keep even a single bird of our own. Robbery and plundering had become so rampant that if we found a small piece of meat, we would eat it behind closed doors in fear that their men might see it and take it from us – in other words, we were so robbed, so captured, and so impoverished that my father would tell us how terrifying it was to bring a child into this world and would say that we should pray for our women to be barren so that our wretched lineage would come to an end.""
es: "—That man over there robbed us with the coldness and indifference with which those beings of a nature superior to the human rob us, the common dogs... he stripped us without compassion, forced us to work without paying us, to take our wheat to his mill, to feed his poultry with our crops, but imposing the death penalty on anyone who dared to take one of them, he plundered and robbed us to such an extent that if ever, by God's mercy, we had a scrap of meat to put in our mouths, we ate it terrified, first barricading the doors and windows of our poor houses, so that his people wouldn't see it and steal it from us. I repeat that they stripped us in such a way, harassed us in such a way, made life so impossible for us, that a thousand times I heard my father say that it was an immense misfortune for us to bring a child into the world, and that we should pray to God to condemn all the women of our caste to sterility, so that it would be extinguished once and for all.

en: “I had never before seen the sense of being oppressed, bursting forth like a fire. I had supposed that it must be latent in the people somewhere; but, I had never seen it break out, until I saw it in the dying boy.
vi: I have never seen anyone speak of their oppression with such blazing anger. I thought that feeling must have been simmering within them, but I had never seen it erupt until I met this dying peasant. −
tr: I had never seen the feeling of oppression erupt in such a way and turn into a fire before. I had guessed that this feeling was hidden somewhere inside people, but I had never seen it manifest in this way before this struggling child.
es: "Never had I witnessed the explosion of the feelings of the unfortunate oppressed; I supposed, yes, that deep in their souls they harbored immense amounts of hatred against their oppressors; but their outburst was a new spectacle for me until that night."

en: “‘Nevertheless, Doctor, my sister married. He was ailing at that time, poor fellow, and she married her lover, that she might tend and comfort him in our cottage—our dog-hut, as that man would call it. She had not been married many weeks, when that man’s brother saw her and admired her, and asked that man to lend her to him—for what are husbands among us! He was willing enough, but my sister was good and virtuous, and hated his brother with a hatred as strong as mine. What did the two then, to persuade her husband to use his influence with her, to make her willing?’
vi: But doctor, my sister was already married. My brother-in-law, poor man, was ill at the time, and my sister married the man she loved to take care of him in our hut... which the one standing there called a kennel. My sister had only been married a few weeks when that man's brother saw her and lusted after her, demanding his brother to lend him my sister... Such is the fate of us husbands! His brother agreed, but my sister, being virtuous and decent, ended up hating his brother as much as I did. I don't know what those two did to force my brother-in-law to persuade his wife to comply.
tr: "Still, my sister got married, Doctor. The poor man had an ailment at the time, my sister married this man she loved, so she could take care of him in our cabin –that man would probably call it a doghouse. It had only been a few weeks since they got married when that man's brother saw her, liked her, and asked her husband to lend her to him –the authority of husbands like ours means nothing! The man was quite willing, but my sister was a good and honorable woman and hated that man's brother at least as much as I did. So what did these two do to persuade her husband to convince my sister, to influence her in this matter?"
es: "—Doctor, my sister got married, despite everything. Her poor fiancé was in bad health at the time, and my sister married him to care for him in our cabin... our kennel, as that monster in front of us would say. She had been married for only a few weeks when she had the misfortune of being seen by that man's brother; he liked her, and with the greatest naturalness in the world, he asked his older brother to lend her to him. What did it matter that she was married? Husbands are such insignificant things among us!... The older brother agreed without any inconvenience, but my sister was good and virtuous, and moreover, she detested her admirer as much as I do. What do you think the two brothers did then to get my sister's husband to exert all his influence over her until she was forced to yield to their vile desires?

en: “The boy’s eyes, which had been fixed on mine, slowly turned to the looker-on, and I saw in the two faces that all he said was true. The two opposing kinds of pride confronting one another, I can see, even in this Bastille; the gentleman’s, all negligent indifference; the peasant’s, all trodden-down sentiment, and passionate revenge.
vi: Staring intently at me, the young man's gaze slowly shifted to the person standing over there, and through both faces, I knew that everything he said was true. Two different prides were confronting each other, and right here in the Bastille dungeon, I could still clearly see the indifferent defiance of the nobleman clashing with the trampled and seething hatred of the peasant.
tr: The child's eyes, fixed on me, slowly turned to the men watching him, and when I looked at these two faces, I saw that everything the boy had said was true. Even here, in the Bastille, I can see the clash of two opposing kinds of pride; the utter indifference of the noble gentleman and the intense emotions and passionate revenge of the peasant.
es: "The boy's eyes, fixed until then on mine, slowly turned towards those of the nobleman, in whose face it was not difficult for me to read the truth of the charges made against him." Even here, in the interior of the Bastille's tomb where I have been for so many years, I believe I can see the two kinds of pride, perfectly distinct, reflected in the two faces: indifference and coldness breathed from the gentleman's; furious desires for revenge from the peasant boy's.

en: “‘You know, Doctor, that it is among the Rights of these Nobles to harness us common dogs to carts, and drive us. They so harnessed him and drove him. You know that it is among their Rights to keep us in their grounds all night, quieting the frogs, in order that their noble sleep may not be disturbed. They kept him out in the unwholesome mists at night, and ordered him back into his harness in the day. But he was not persuaded. No! Taken out of harness one day at noon, to feed—if he could find food—he sobbed twelve times, once for every stroke of the bell, and died on her bosom.’
vi: You know, doctor, these nobles have the right to yoke us lowly people to their carriages and whip us to pull them along. They treated my brother-in-law like that. You know they have the right to keep us outside in the garden all night so that the frogs and toads stay silent, allowing the nobles to sleep peacefully. They kept my brother-in-law out in the cold frost all night, and in the morning they tied him to the cart again. But my brother did not submit. No! One day, he was untied at noon to eat... if he could find food... he sobbed twelve times, each sob like the chime of a clock striking noon, and then died in my sister's arms.
tr: "You know, Doctor, it is among the rights of these nobles to harness and drive dogs like us in front of their carriages. They harnessed and drove my sister's husband to the carriage: You know, it is also among their rights to keep us on their lands all night to chase away the frogs and ensure they sleep well: they made the poor man wait in that terrible fog all night and harnessed him to the carriage the next day. But he still wasn't convinced. No! Then one noon, while he was unhitched from the harness to eat –if he could find any– he cried, sobbing exactly twelve times, breaking into sobs every time the bell struck the hour, and died in his wife's arms."
es: "—You know, doctor, that one of the rights of those nobles consists of harnessing us, who are miserable dogs, to their carts and forcing us to pull." "Well, they harnessed my sister's husband, properly geared, to a cart, and forced him to pull it." "You know, doctor, that among the rights of those nobles is the right to force us to spend the nights on their lands, imposing silence on the frogs so that their croaking does not disturb their noble sleep; my sister's husband spent the nights in the open and the days pulling the cart." "He did not let himself be persuaded... No!" "One day, when they freed him from the harness and dismissed him to go eat... if he could find something, he exhaled twelve sobs, one for each chime of the clock—it was noon—and died in my sister's arms."

en: “Nothing human could have held life in the boy but his determination to tell all his wrong. He forced back the gathering shadows of death, as he forced his clenched right hand to remain clenched, and to cover his wound.
vi: Only an extraordinary determination to expose the crime could sustain his life. The young man struggled against the encroaching darkness of death, still gripping his right hand tightly over the wound.
tr: The boy was clearly determined to stay alive until he finished recounting all this cruelty. Just as he exerted strength to tightly clasp his hand to his chest like a claw to close his wound, he was also pushing back the shadows of death attacking him with the same force.
es: »Only the desire to explain the grievance received sustained life in that dying body. Searching in his determination for energies he could not find in his body, he pushed away the shadows of death that invaded him and pressed his wound, through which his life was escaping, harder than ever.

en: “‘Then, with that man’s permission and even with his aid, his brother took her away; in spite of what I know she must have told his brother—and what that is, will not be long unknown to you, Doctor, if it is now—his brother took her away—for his pleasure and diversion, for a little while. I saw her pass me on the road. When I took the tidings home, our father’s heart burst; he never spoke one of the words that filled it. I took my young sister (for I have another) to a place beyond the reach of this man, and where, at least, she will never be his vassal. Then, I tracked the brother here, and last night climbed in—a common dog, but sword in hand.—Where is the loft window? It was somewhere here?’
vi: − Then, with the agreement and even the assistance of the one standing there, his younger brother took my sister away, despite the things I know my sister must have told his younger brother... what those things are, you will soon know, doctor... He took my sister away... to indulge himself for a while. I saw my sister crossing the street. When I got home to report the news, my father had a heart attack and died immediately, without having the chance to say a word that was weighing on his mind. I took my younger sister, I have another younger sister, to a hidden place far away from that savage, where at least my sister would never become his slave. Then, I followed the guy's trail all the way here, and last night I climbed into the house... a lowly dog, but with a sword in hand... Where is the attic window? Somewhere around here, right?
tr: "Then, with the permission and even the help of this man, his brother took my sister away: despite all the things my sister told him –and you will soon learn what she said, Doctor, perhaps you already understand– he took my sister away for a moment of pleasure and amusement. I saw them as they passed by me on the road. When I told what happened to the people at home, my father had a heart attack; but not a single word came out of his mouth that could express his pain. I took my little sister (I have another sister) to a place where this man couldn't reach her, at least where she couldn't be his slave. Then I followed his brother here and last night I climbed in like a dog but with a sword in my hand... I entered. –Where is the attic window? Wasn't it somewhere around here?'
es: "—With the death of my sister's husband, with the authorization of this man, and even with his material support, his brother violently took possession of the poor widow, whom he needed for his pleasures, for his momentary amusement." "I stumbled upon her on the road when they were taking her away." "I brought the news to our house, and upon hearing it, my father's heart shattered into a thousand pieces." "Immediately, I accompanied my younger sister—I have two... to a place where she would be out of that man's reach, to a place where she would not be his vassal." "I then returned, followed that noble's brother, and last night I confronted him, I, a despicable dog, but with a sword in my hand..." "Where is the window?... Wasn't there a window here?"

en: “The room was darkening to his sight; the world was narrowing around him. I glanced about me, and saw that the hay and straw were trampled over the floor, as if there had been a struggle.
vi: The room darkened in his eyes; the world around him was shrinking. I glanced around and saw trampled straw on the floor as if there had been a scuffle.
tr: His vision began to darken; the world around him was gradually closing in. When I looked around, I saw that the grass and hay were crushed, as if a struggle had taken place.
es: »Life was abandoning him, and with life, the light. I cast my eyes around and noticed that the hay and straw covering the ground were trampled and crushed, as if a fierce struggle had taken place there.

en: “‘She heard me, and ran in. I told her not to come near us till he was dead. He came in and first tossed me some pieces of money; then struck at me with a whip. But I, though a common dog, so struck at him as to make him draw. Let him break into as many pieces as he will, the sword that he stained with my common blood; he drew to defend himself—thrust at me with all his skill for his life.’
vi: − Hearing my voice, my sister ran in. I told my sister not to come close until he was dead. He came in here, first throwing some money at me; then he took a whip and lashed me. But even though I was a lowly person, I struck back, forcing him to draw his sword. Let him break his sword, stained with my lowly blood, into as many pieces as he wants; he had to use all his swordsmanship to defend himself and barely kept his life.
tr: "When my brother heard me, he immediately ran. I told him not to come inside until the man was dead. This man came inside and first threw some money at me; then he hit me with a whip. But I, as a lowly dog, hit him so hard that he drew his sword. With the sword stained by my lowly blood, he could cut me into a thousand pieces if he wanted; after all, he had drawn it to defend himself – and with all the skill he had acquired throughout his life, he stabbed me with it."
es: "—My sister heard me and came running. I told her not to come closer until her infamous abductor was dead. He threw some coins at me, and then struck my face with his whip; but I, despite being a despicable dog, slapped him until he was forced to draw his sword. Let him now break the blade of a sword stained with the blood of a villain, let him shatter it into a thousand pieces, it will always be true that he had to draw it to defend his life, and if he wounded me, it was by resorting to all his skill!

en: “My glance had fallen, but a few moments before, on the fragments of a broken sword, lying among the hay. That weapon was a gentleman’s. In another place, lay an old sword that seemed to have been a soldier’s.
vi: A few minutes ago, I saw broken sword fragments lying in the straw. The nobleman's sword. In another place was an old sword, possibly a soldier's sword.
tr: My eyes had caught the pieces of a broken sword lying among the straw on the ground a few minutes ago. This belonged to a noble. The old sword lying a little further away seemed to belong to a soldier.
es: Moments before, I had seen pieces of a sword scattered on the ground; it was a knight's sword. A little further on, on the straw, there was another old sword, a soldier's sword.

en: “‘Now, lift me up, Doctor; lift me up. Where is he?’
vi: − Now lift me up, doctor; lift me up. Where is he?
tr: "Lift me up, Doctor; lift me up, come on. Where is it?"
es: "—Help me up, doctor, help me up; where is that man?"

en: “‘He is not here,’ I said, supporting the boy, and thinking that he referred to the brother.
vi: − He's not here, - I said as I lifted the young man, thinking he meant his twin brother.
tr: Thinking that he meant his brother, I said, "He is not here," while supporting the boy to sit up.
es: »—He is not here— I replied, holding the dying man, believing he was referring to his brother.

en: “‘He! Proud as these nobles are, he is afraid to see me. Where is the man who was here? Turn my face to him.’
vi: − Him! The arrogant nobles are like that, yet he's afraid to meet me. Where is the person who was just standing here? Turn my face towards him.
tr: "Oh man! Like all nobles, he is so proud that he is afraid to look at me. Where is the man standing over there? Turn my face to him."
es: "—Of course!" "With all his noble arrogance, he is afraid of me!" "And the man who was here?" "Turn me towards him... I want to see him!"

en: “I did so, raising the boy’s head against my knee. But, invested for the moment with extraordinary power, he raised himself completely: obliging me to rise too, or I could not have still supported him.
vi: I followed, lifting the boy's head to rest on my knee. But at that moment, he suddenly gained extraordinary strength, he stood up completely, forcing me to stand up to support him.
tr: I rested my head on my knee and lifted it as the boy had instructed. But suddenly, an extraordinary strength came over the boy, and he stood up completely. He had forced me to straighten up with him, otherwise, I wouldn't have been able to support him.
es: "I did so, resting the boy's head on my knee; but he, with all his energies revived for a moment, stood up, forcing me to do the same to support him."

en: “‘Marquis,’ said the boy, turned to him with his eyes opened wide, and his right hand raised, ‘in the days when all these things are to be answered for, I summon you and yours, to the last of your bad race, to answer for them. I mark this cross of blood upon you, as a sign that I do it. In the days when all these things are to be answered for, I summon your brother, the worst of the bad race, to answer for them separately. I mark this cross of blood upon him, as a sign that I do it.’
vi: − Marquis, - he said, eyes wide open as he turned towards the other person, his right hand raised high, - when the day of judgment comes, I will make you and your entire family, down to the last person, pay for your crimes. I will make this blood cross mark and swear to you. On the Day of Judgment, I will make your sibling, the worst of this vile lineage, pay for their own sins. I will make this blood cross mark and swear to you.
tr: Turning to the man with eyes wide open and raising his right hand in the air, the boy said, "Marquis, when the day comes that you are held accountable for your actions, you and the worst of your lineage will answer for each and every one of them." "So that it is clear what I have done, I now draw a cross on you with my blood." "When the day comes that you are held accountable for your actions, the worst person of this evil lineage will also answer for each and every one of them." "So that it is clear what I have done, I now draw a cross on him with my blood.""
es: "—Marquis!—he shouted, with wide eyes and raising his arm.— The day will come when all men will have to give a strict account of their actions; for that day I summon you and all of yours, from the first to the last of your cursed race, to answer for your crimes. Let this cross that I stamp with blood on your face be a testimony of my summons. For the day when all men will have to give a strict account of their actions, I also summon your brother, the vilest of a vile and miserable race, to answer for his separately; on his face I stamp this other cross with my blood, as a testimony of my summons.

en: “Twice, he put his hand to the wound in his breast, and with his forefinger drew a cross in the air. He stood for an instant with the finger yet raised, and as it dropped, he dropped with it, and I laid him down dead.
vi: Twice, the young man placed his hand on the wound on his chest, and with his index finger, drew a cross in the air. He stood still for a moment with his finger still raised, and when his arm fell, his body collapsed as well, and I laid him down, already dead... ۩۩۩
tr: Then he placed his hand on the wound on his chest and drew two crosses in the air with his index finger. After his finger remained in the air for a short while, it fell to the ground; then he fell himself, and I straightened his dead body.
es: »Twice he brought his hand to the bloody wound on his chest and with his index finger traced two crosses in the air. He remained for a few seconds with his index finger rigid, raised, and then fell dead...

en: “When I returned to the bedside of the young woman, I found her raving in precisely the same order of continuity. I knew that this might last for many hours, and that it would probably end in the silence of the grave.
vi: When I returned to the woman's bedside, I saw that she was still screaming deliriously as before. I knew this condition could last for many hours and perhaps only quiet down in the grave...
tr: When I returned to the young woman, I saw that her madness continued with the same order and continuity. I knew that this could last for hours and perhaps end in the silence of the grave.
es: "When I returned to the room where I had left the sick woman, I found her delirious as I had left her, repeating the same words in the same order as always." "I immediately guessed that the crisis would last many hours and that it would probably end with her death."

en: “I repeated the medicines I had given her, and I sat at the side of the bed until the night was far advanced. She never abated the piercing quality of her shrieks, never stumbled in the distinctness or the order of her words. They were always ‘My husband, my father, and my brother! One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve. Hush!’
vi: I gave her the same doses of medicine as before and sat by the bed until late at night. She never stopped the ear-piercing screams, never mixed up the exact order of the cries. Always "My husband, my father, my brother! One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve. Shh!".
tr: I gave her another dose of the medicine I had given her before and sat by her bedside until late at night. There was no decrease in her sharp screams, nor any change in the sequence of the words she was saying. She kept saying the same thing: "My husband, my father, my brother! One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve. Shh!"
es: "I repeated the medicines and sat by the bed, where I remained until the night was already very advanced." "The cries of the sick woman continued with the same intensity, in the same order, without varying a single word." "My husband... my father... my brother... One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven, twelve."

en: “This lasted twenty-six hours from the time when I first saw her. I had come and gone twice, and was again sitting by her, when she began to falter. I did what little could be done to assist that opportunity, and by-and-bye she sank into a lethargy, and lay like the dead.
vi: Just like that for twenty-six hours since the first time I met her. I went back and forth twice and sat next to her, then she began to weaken. I did everything I could to treat her, and after a while, she fell into a coma, lying still as if dead.
tr: All of this lasted twenty-six hours from the moment I first saw him. I had gone back and forth twice and sat next to him again when he started to hesitate. In that short time, I did everything I could to take advantage of the opportunity, and he gradually became numb and lay there like a dead man.
es: »Thirty-six hours had passed since I first saw her, and the condition of the patient had not changed at all. I was sitting at the head of her bed when the crisis began to subside. The screams ceased, the tremors ended, and shortly after she was left lethargic, as if dead.

en: “It was as if the wind and rain had lulled at last, after a long and fearful storm. I released her arms, and called the woman to assist me to compose her figure and the dress she had torn. It was then that I knew her condition to be that of one in whom the first expectations of being a mother have arisen; and it was then that I lost the little hope I had had of her.
vi: Just like the wind and rain finally ceased after a long and fierce storm. I released her arms and called the maid to help me adjust the girl's posture and attire. It was then that I realized she was newly pregnant; and at that moment, I lost all hope of saving her. −
tr: After a long and terrifying storm, the rain and wind had finally subsided, it seemed.. I uncrossed my arms and called the woman to help better position her on the bed and to fix her torn dress. That's when I realized she was a woman carrying a baby in her womb, and thus, I lost the little hope I had for her recovery.
es: The screams ceased, the tremors ended, and shortly after she was left lethargic, as if dead. »I then called the nurse to help me place her properly in bed and arrange her clothes, torn in a thousand places, and then I realized that the unfortunate woman was pregnant, and I lost the little hope I had of saving her.

en: “‘Is she dead?’ asked the Marquis, whom I will still describe as the elder brother, coming booted into the room from his horse.
vi: Is she dead yet? - The voice of the Marquis, whom I called my brother. He had just dismounted and entered the room, still wearing his riding boots.
tr: The Marquis, whom I will still refer to as the elder brother, dismounted from his horse and came into the room in his boots, asking, "Is he dead?"
es: "—Is he dead yet?—asked the Marquis, who had just entered the room after a horseback ride.

en: “‘Not dead,’ said I; ‘but like to die.’
vi: − Not dead yet, - I said, - but she is close to death. −
tr: "No," I said; "but death is very near."
es: "—She hasn't died, but she seems dead—I replied."

en: “‘What strength there is in these common bodies!’ he said, looking down at her with some curiosity.
vi: These lowly people are so resilient! - He said as he bent down to look at her with curiosity. −
tr: "How strong the bodies of these miserable creatures are!" he said, looking at the woman with curious eyes.
es: "—What resilience these villains have!—he exclaimed, looking at her with curiosity.

en: “‘There is prodigious strength,’ I answered him, ‘in sorrow and despair.’
vi: There is extraordinary strength in suffering and despair, - I replied.
tr: "Pain and despair," I said, "harbor a tremendous power within.""
es: "—Sorrows and despair often endure the unspeakable— I replied.

en: “He first laughed at my words, and then frowned at them. He moved a chair with his foot near to mine, ordered the woman away, and said in a subdued voice,
vi: At first, he laughed mockingly, then he became annoyed. He pushed a chair closer to me with his foot, ordered the maid to leave, and lowered his voice to say: − Doctor, seeing my brother having trouble with these tenants, I suggested that he invite you to help.
tr: First, he laughed at my words, then he frowned. He pulled a chair next to mine with his feet; he ordered the woman to leave, then lowered his voice and said the following.
es: "My words initially provoked his laughter, but then he furrowed his brow. He pushed a chair towards me with his foot, told the nurse to leave us alone, and said in a low voice:

en: “‘Doctor, finding my brother in this difficulty with these hinds, I recommended that your aid should be invited. Your reputation is high, and, as a young man with your fortune to make, you are probably mindful of your interest. The things that you see here, are things to be seen, and not spoken of.’
vi: He pushed a chair closer to me with his foot, ordered the maid to leave, and lowered his voice to say: − Doctor, seeing my brother having trouble with these tenants, I suggested that he invite you to help. You have a reputation, and you are a doctor building your career, so perhaps you know how to look after your own interests. What you see here is something to be seen but not spoken of.
tr: "Doctor, when my brother got into trouble with these villagers, the first thing that came to my mind was to call you. You are a person of high repute and, as a young man with a bright future, you must be smart enough to look out for your own interests. Let what you have seen here stay here, do not let it go outside."
es: "—Doctor, seeing my brother in the difficulty he was in, I advised him to seek you out." "You enjoy an enviable reputation, but you still have to build your fortune, and I suppose that what affects your interests cannot be indifferent to you." "You are witnessing things that can be seen, but never spoken of."

en: “I listened to the patient’s breathing, and avoided answering.
vi: I listened to the patient's breathing and avoided answering.
tr: I listened to the patient's breathing and avoided responding.
es: "I pretended to pay attention to the patient's breathing and did not respond."

en: “‘Do you honour me with your attention, Doctor?’
vi: − Will you deign to listen to me, doctor?
tr: "Will you grant me the honor of listening to me, Doctor?"
es: "—Do you grant me the honor of listening to me, doctor?"

en: “‘Monsieur,’ said I, ‘in my profession, the communications of patients are always received in confidence.’ I was guarded in my answer, for I was troubled in my mind with what I had heard and seen.
vi: − Sir, - I said - my profession requires me to always keep my patients' secrets. - I answered cautiously because I was inwardly worried about the things I had seen and heard.
tr: "Monsieur," I said, "in my profession, the secrets of patients always remain secret." I was being cautious while answering, as what I had seen and heard had greatly disturbed me.
es: "—In my profession, sir, any information given to the doctor regarding the patients is understood to be confidential," I replied, avoiding any commitment, as what I had heard and seen filled my soul with misgivings.

en: “Her breathing was so difficult to trace, that I carefully tried the pulse and the heart. There was life, and no more. Looking round as I resumed my seat, I found both the brothers intent upon me.
vi: The girl's breath was so weak that I carefully checked her pulse and listened to her heartbeat. Still alive, but very weak. Returning to my seat and looking around, I saw both siblings staring intently at me... ۩۩۩ I write with great difficulty because the cold is like a knife cutting through, and I fear being discovered and thrown into the completely dark underground dungeon, so I must simplify this story.
tr: It was so difficult to hear the patient's breath that I tried to carefully check his pulse and heartbeats. He was alive, but just barely. As I sat back down and looked around, I saw the siblings scrutinizing me with attentive eyes.
es: "The breathing of the unfortunate woman was becoming so difficult that I had to search for signs of life in her pulse and the beats of her heart." "For this, I had to get up from the chair, and when I sat back down, I found myself face to face with the two brothers..."

en: “I write with so much difficulty, the cold is so severe, I am so fearful of being detected and consigned to an underground cell and total darkness, that I must abridge this narrative. There is no confusion or failure in my memory; it can recall, and could detail, every word that was ever spoken between me and those brothers.
vi: Returning to my seat and looking around, I saw both siblings staring intently at me... ۩۩۩ I write with great difficulty because the cold is like a knife cutting through, and I fear being discovered and thrown into the completely dark underground dungeon, so I must simplify this story. My memory remains completely clear and precise; I can recall and recount every word spoken between me and those two siblings.
tr: I am writing these lines with great difficulty; the weather is very cold, and I am so afraid of being caught and sent to an underground cell and being left in complete darkness that I will keep this writing short. There is no impairment or trouble in my memory; I remember everything I talked about with the brothers very clearly, word for word.
es: "I struggle to write with horrible difficulties. First of all, the cold is unbearable, and, on the other hand, I have a well-founded fear that they will find out that I am writing, in which case they would lock me in an underground dungeon where not a thread of light reaches, so I consider it prudent to shorten my narration as much as possible. My memory could not be fresher; I retain in it all the details, all the words that were exchanged between me and the two brothers.

en: “She lingered for a week. Towards the last, I could understand some few syllables that she said to me, by placing my ear close to her lips. She asked me where she was, and I told her; who I was, and I told her. It was in vain that I asked her for her family name. She faintly shook her head upon the pillow, and kept her secret, as the boy had done.
vi: She held on for a week. Until the last moment, I could only understand a few words she said to me by putting my ear close to her lips. The girl asked me where she was, and I told her; asked me who I was, and I told her. But trying to ask her name was in vain. She just gently shook her head on the pillow, and kept her secret, like her younger brother.
tr: The young woman agonized for a week. As she was about to take her last breath, I could understand very little of what she said when I brought my ear close to her lips. She asked me where she was, I told her; she asked who I was, I told her. I also asked her surname, but it was in vain. She gently shook her head on the pillow and, just like her sister, she kept her secret.
es: »For the span of a week, the sick woman was between life and death; closer to the latter than to the former. Towards the end of the week, I managed to understand some words she said to me, by placing my ear to her lips. She asked me where she was, and I told her; she wanted to know who I was, and I satisfied her curiosity; but it was in vain that I asked her for her last name; her head fell onto the pillow, and she kept her secret, as her brother had before her.

en: “I had no opportunity of asking her any question, until I had told the brothers she was sinking fast, and could not live another day. Until then, though no one was ever presented to her consciousness save the woman and myself, one or other of them had always jealously sat behind the curtain at the head of the bed when I was there. But when it came to that, they seemed careless what communication I might hold with her; as if—the thought passed through my mind—I were dying too.
vi: I didn't have the opportunity to ask any more questions until I informed the two brothers that she was rapidly deteriorating and couldn't survive another day. Until then, although no one was present when she was conscious except the maid and me, one of the brothers always suspiciously sat behind the curtain at the head of her bed whenever I was there. But when it reached this state, they seemed indifferent to any words she might entrust to me, as if I were also about to die - I had that thought.
tr: I didn't have the opportunity to ask her another question until I told the siblings that she was rapidly deteriorating and didn't have much time left. Until then, even though there was no one else with the young woman besides me and the peasant woman, one of the siblings was always sitting enviously just behind the curtain at the head of the bed where I was. But after the woman worsened, they didn't pay much attention to what we were talking about, so much so that I couldn't help but wonder if I was dying too.
es: "I had no opportunity to ask her new questions until after I informed the brothers that the sick woman was dying and would not live another day." "Until then, although neither of them let themselves be seen by the sick woman, sometimes one, sometimes the other, they were invariably found behind a curtain drawn at the head of the bed; but when I communicated my prognosis to them, it seemed they no longer cared if I spoke with the dying woman; they no longer tried to prevent the confidences that the one who was about to leave the world might make to someone who... was probably in the same situation."

en: “I always observed that their pride bitterly resented the younger brother’s (as I call him) having crossed swords with a peasant, and that peasant a boy. The only consideration that appeared to affect the mind of either of them was the consideration that this was highly degrading to the family, and was ridiculous. As often as I caught the younger brother’s eyes, their expression reminded me that he disliked me deeply, for knowing what I knew from the boy. He was smoother and more polite to me than the elder; but I saw this. I also saw that I was an incumbrance in the mind of the elder, too.
vi: I always noticed that they, out of pride, were very uncomfortable with the fact that the younger brother (as I called him) had dueled with a farmer, and moreover, a young farmer. The only thing that seemed to concern them was that the duel was extremely humiliating to the family's honor; truly ridiculous. I often caught the younger brother's gaze, a look that always reminded me that he harbored an intense hatred for me because he knew I had heard the farmer recount the incident. He appeared more gentle and courteous to me than the elder brother; but I still sensed that hatred. I also realized that I was a source of annoyance in the elder brother's mind as well.
tr: Every time I looked at them, I saw that both of them could not stomach the fact that the younger brother (that's what I call him) had fought a duel with a peasant boy. It seemed that the only thing that bothered them and stuck in their minds was the thought that this matter had dishonored the family and made them look ridiculous. Whenever I made eye contact with the younger brother, I understood from his gaze how much he hated me, after all, he knew what I had learned from the boy. He might have treated me more properly and politely than the older brother, but I could see it. Moreover, it was not hard to see that I was a burden on the older brother's mind as well.
es: "I always observed that the fact that the younger brother (I will continue to call him that) had crossed swords with a boy, and moreover a peasant and commoner, deeply wounded the pride of the two." "What seemed to affect them was not the misfortunes they had caused, but the thought that the aforementioned incident degraded the family and placed it in a highly ridiculous situation." "Countless times I caught looks in the younger brother's eyes that overflowed with hatred, although he apparently treated me with greater refinement than the elder." "Nor was it hidden from me that for the latter, I was an annoying obstacle."

en: “My patient died, two hours before midnight—at a time, by my watch, answering almost to the minute when I had first seen her. I was alone with her, when her forlorn young head drooped gently on one side, and all her earthly wrongs and sorrows ended.
vi: My patient died, two hours before midnight - according to my watch, almost exactly at the moment I first met her. Only I was beside her when that young, desperate head slowly tilted to one side, ending all earthly suffering.
tr: Two hours before midnight, my patient died – according to my watch, it coincided with the time I first saw him. When his young, distraught head gently fell to the side and all the worldly injustices and pains he had endured came to an end, I was the only one by his side.
es: "My patient died at ten o'clock at night." "I was alone by her side, she bowed her youthful head, her misfortunes on earth ended forever."

en: “The brothers were waiting in a room down-stairs, impatient to ride away. I had heard them, alone at the bedside, striking their boots with their riding-whips, and loitering up and down.
vi: Two brothers are waiting in the room downstairs, eager to set off. When I was alone by the patient's bed, I heard them whipping their boots with riding crops, pacing back and forth.
tr: The brothers were impatient to set off and were waiting in a room downstairs. While I was by the bed, I heard them hitting their boots with their whips and pacing up and down the room.
es: "On the ground floor of the house, the brothers were waiting."

en: “‘At last she is dead?’ said the elder, when I went in.
vi: − So, is it dead? - The older brother asked when I came downstairs.
tr: When I went down to them, the older one asked, "Did he finally die?"
es: "—Has he finally died?—asked the elder, upon seeing me enter.

en: “‘She is dead,’ said I.
vi: − She is dead, - I said.
tr: "He died," I said.
es: »—He just died— I replied.

en: “‘I congratulate you, my brother,’ were his words as he turned round.
vi: − Congratulations, - he turned and said to the younger brother.
tr: "Congratulations, brother," said the older brother who was turning around.
es: "—Be it well, brother—he replied, turning towards the younger one.

en: “He had before offered me money, which I had postponed taking. He now gave me a rouleau of gold. I took it from his hand, but laid it on the table. I had considered the question, and had resolved to accept nothing.
vi: Earlier, he had paid me, but I had declined. Now he handed me a bundle of gold coins wrapped in paper. I took it but placed it on the table. I had thought about this and decided not to accept anything.
tr: He had previously offered money, but I had postponed it. This time, he handed me a pouch of gold. I took it from his hand, but I placed it on the table. I had thought about this matter and decided not to take anything.
es: "They had already offered me money before, which I did not accept, saying that we would finalize that detail at the end." The older brother handed me a cartridge of gold coins, which I received from his hand, but then left on the table. I had thought over the matter, and from that reflection came the determined purpose not to accept anything.

en: “‘Pray excuse me,’ said I. ‘Under the circumstances, no.’
vi: − Excuse me, - I said. - In this case, no.
tr: "Please forgive me," I said. "But under these conditions, I cannot accept."
es: "—Excuse me— I said; —given the circumstances, I must not accept anything."

en: “They exchanged looks, but bent their heads to me as I bent mine to them, and we parted without another word on either side.
vi: The two brothers looked at each other, but then they bowed to me, I bowed back, and then we went our separate ways without saying a word... ۩۩۩ I am tired, tired, exhausted from my own misery.
tr: First, they looked at each other, then when I nodded in greeting, they responded in kind, and we parted without saying anything else to each other.
es: "The brothers exchanged a look, gave me a nod, which I returned with another, mounted their horses, and left...."

en: “I am weary, weary, weary—worn down by misery. I cannot read what I have written with this gaunt hand.
vi: The two brothers looked at each other, but then they bowed to me, I bowed back, and then we went our separate ways without saying a word... ۩۩۩ I am tired, tired, exhausted from my own misery. I cannot read what has been written by this emaciated hand.
tr: I am tired, tired, very tired –these pains have finished me. I cannot read what I have written with these skinny fingers.
es: "I feel tired, exhausted, worn out... I can't even read what my bony hand has written."

en: “Early in the morning, the rouleau of gold was left at my door in a little box, with my name on the outside. From the first, I had anxiously considered what I ought to do. I decided, that day, to write privately to the Minister, stating the nature of the two cases to which I had been summoned, and the place to which I had gone: in effect, stating all the circumstances. I knew what Court influence was, and what the immunities of the Nobles were, and I expected that the matter would never be heard of; but, I wished to relieve my own mind. I had kept the matter a profound secret, even from my wife; and this, too, I resolved to state in my letter. I had no apprehension whatever of my real danger; but I was conscious that there might be danger for others, if others were compromised by possessing the knowledge that I possessed.
vi: Early in the morning, someone had left a small box with gold coins and my name written on it at my doorstep. From the beginning, I was worried about what I should do. That day, I decided to write a private letter to the Minister about the two patients I was called to treat, and describe the place I had visited; essentially recounting everything. I knew the authority of the court and the exemptions the nobility enjoyed, so I wouldn't be surprised if this matter was never addressed; but I wanted to write it down to ease my mind. I kept this matter a secret, even from my wife; and I made this clear in my letter. I was not afraid of any danger to myself; but I understood well the calamity that could befall others if they knew what I knew.
tr: Early in the morning, a small box with my name on it and a pouch of gold inside was left in front of my door. From the very first moment, I felt uneasy and was thinking about what I should do. That day, I decided to write a special letter to the Minister about what had happened to these two patients I encountered and the place I visited; I was going to tell him everything. I knew the power of the Palace and how privileged the nobles were, and I didn't expect them to take this matter seriously, but at least I would have eased my own mind. I had kept the incident a secret even from my own wife, and I found it appropriate to mention this in my letter. I wasn't aware of the danger I would be in if others learned about it, but I was conscious that it could be dangerous for others.
es: »The next morning, very early, they brought to my house the cartridge of gold coins, placed inside a small box addressed to my name. I, meanwhile, after long meditations, had already resolved the code of conduct I was to follow. I decided to write that very day to the Minister, recounting the history of the two cases in which I had intervened and detailing the place where they occurred; in a word: to send him a detailed report, albeit with a private character. I knew how far the influences at the Court reached, the privileges and immunities enjoyed by the nobles were no secret to me, and, as a consequence, I supposed that my letter would yield no result; but even so, I wanted to ease my conscience. I decided not to reveal my secret to anyone, not even to my wife, and I made this clear in the letter addressed to the Minister. I did not believe that I was threatened by any danger; but I supposed that others would be, if I compromised them by making them privy to the secret I possessed.

en: “I was much engaged that day, and could not complete my letter that night. I rose long before my usual time next morning to finish it. It was the last day of the year. The letter was lying before me just completed, when I was told that a lady waited, who wished to see me.
vi: I was too busy that day, so by evening, I still hadn't finished writing the letter. The next morning, I woke up earlier than usual to finish it. It was the last day of the year. Just as I finished the letter and it lay before me, I was informed that a lady was waiting and wanted to see me... ۩۩۩ I increasingly lacked the strength to complete the tasks I had set for myself.
tr: I was so busy that day that I couldn't finish the letter that night. The next morning, I got up much earlier than usual to be able to finish it. It was the last day of the year. Just as my letter was newly finished and was in front of me, they told me that a lady who wanted to see me had arrived:
es: "I was so busy that day that I couldn't finish the letter until after nightfall." The next morning, I left the bed earlier than usual. It was the last day of the year. I had just put the finishing touches on the letter when I was informed that a lady was waiting to see me...

en: “I am growing more and more unequal to the task I have set myself. It is so cold, so dark, my senses are so benumbed, and the gloom upon me is so dreadful.
vi: Just as I finished the letter and it lay before me, I was informed that a lady was waiting and wanted to see me... ۩۩۩ I increasingly lacked the strength to complete the tasks I had set for myself. It was too cold, too gloomy, my senses were numb, and the darkness surrounding me was terrifying.
tr: Every day, I am drifting further away from the task I have committed myself to. This place is so cold, dark, and my feelings are so numb, with such a great gloom weighing down on me.
es: "At times I consider myself more incapable of completing the task I have imposed on myself." "The cold is so unbearable, the light so scarce, the paralysis of my faculties so complete, the darkness of my soul so horrible!..."

en: “The lady was young, engaging, and handsome, but not marked for long life. She was in great agitation. She presented herself to me as the wife of the Marquis St. Evrémonde. I connected the title by which the boy had addressed the elder brother, with the initial letter embroidered on the scarf, and had no difficulty in arriving at the conclusion that I had seen that nobleman very lately.
vi: She is still young, graceful, and beautiful, but seems to be of fragile health. She looks very worried. She introduced herself as the wife of Marquis St. Evrémonde. I recalled the title that the peasant had called the brother, and the initials embroidered on that scarf, and easily concluded that I had recently met the very nobleman.
tr: The young person who came to see me was an attractive and very charming woman, but she seemed to have little time left to live. She was in great distress. She introduced herself as the wife of Marquis Evremonde. At that moment, I connected the name the boy used when talking about the elder brother with the letter embroidered on the scarf in my mind, and it was not difficult to conclude that I had seen that nobleman very recently.
es: »She was a young, kind, and beautiful lady, but marked by the bony finger of death. I found her in a state of intense agitation. She told me she was the wife of the Marquis of Evrémonde. I connected the title of Marquis that the dying boy had given to the older brother with the initial I discovered on the crested tie, and with such information at hand, it was not difficult for me to guess that the man from whom I had parted and the Marquis of Evrémonde were one and the same person.

en: “My memory is still accurate, but I cannot write the words of our conversation. I suspect that I am watched more closely than I was, and I know not at what times I may be watched. She had in part suspected, and in part discovered, the main facts of the cruel story, of her husband’s share in it, and my being resorted to. She did not know that the girl was dead. Her hope had been, she said in great distress, to show her, in secret, a woman’s sympathy. Her hope had been to avert the wrath of Heaven from a House that had long been hateful to the suffering many.
vi: My memory is still accurate, but I cannot recall every word of this conversation. I suspect that I am being watched more closely than before, and I do not know when I will be monitored. She partly suspected, partly discovered the main events of that cruel story, the story her husband was involved in, and the story of my being invited. She did not know that the other girl had died. Very distressed, she expressed that she hoped to silently share the compassion of a woman. She hoped that the heavens would not punish the noble family that had long been hated for causing so much suffering to many people.
tr: My memory is still intact, but I can't write down our conversation exactly. I suspect that I am being watched much more than before, but I can't be sure exactly when I am being watched. She had suspected some of the truths in the story of brutality, her husband's involvement in the incident, and my being taken there, and had discovered some on her own. But she didn't know that the young woman had died. According to what she said in great pain, she hoped to secretly meet with the young woman and show her mercy. Moreover, she hoped to keep God's wrath away from the house of those who had long suffered.
es: "Although my memory remains clear, it is impossible for me to record here the words that were exchanged in our conversation." "It seems that the lady had knowledge of the intervention I had in an event that she partly knew and partly suspected." "She did not know that the unfortunate young woman had died." "Her wishes, as she expressed to me while flooded with tears, were to visit her in secret and show her sympathy, and her desires, to avert the wrath of God suspended over a house that had long been the object of the hatred of so many whom it had plunged into the dark abysses of misfortune."

en: “She had reasons for believing that there was a young sister living, and her greatest desire was, to help that sister. I could tell her nothing but that there was such a sister; beyond that, I knew nothing. Her inducement to come to me, relying on my confidence, had been the hope that I could tell her the name and place of abode. Whereas, to this wretched hour I am ignorant of both.
vi: She had reason to believe that the other girl still had a younger sister, and her greatest desire was to help that younger sister. I can only say that there indeed was a younger sister, but beyond that, I know nothing more. Relying on my discretion, she eagerly came to see me, hoping I would reveal the name and whereabouts of this younger sister. But both of those things, until now, I have no knowledge of... ۩۩۩
tr: He thought he had a sister and his greatest desire was to help her. I told him that I was aware of the existence of such a sister; but I didn't know anything more. The reason he trusted me and came was the hope that I could tell him the name of that girl and where she lived. However, I was unaware of both.
es: "The purpose of that lady's visit, who had reasons to believe that the unfortunate victim of her husband left behind a younger sister, was to implore me to provide her with the name and location of the sister's residence, in order to help and protect her." "I could only respond that, indeed, such a sister existed; but I could not provide her with information that I did not know at the time, and still do not know as I write these lines..."

en: “These scraps of paper fail me. One was taken from me, with a warning, yesterday. I must finish my record to-day.
vi: These pieces of paper are causing me trouble. Yesterday, one was confiscated and I was warned. I must finish writing the story today.
tr: These pieces of paper got me into trouble. Yesterday, a guard took one and gave me a warning. That's all for today.
es: "I'm already out of paper." "Yesterday they took a sheet from me, I fear that the surveillance I'm under is tighter than ever, and today I must finish my story."

en: “She was a good, compassionate lady, and not happy in her marriage. How could she be! The brother distrusted and disliked her, and his influence was all opposed to her; she stood in dread of him, and in dread of her husband too. When I handed her down to the door, there was a child, a pretty boy from two to three years old, in her carriage.
vi: She is a good person, compassionate, and unhappy in her marriage. How can she be happy! Her brother-in-law does not trust her and even hates her; he uses every means to oppose his sister-in-law; she is terrified of him and also terrified of her own husband. When I escorted her to the door, I saw a beautiful little boy about two or three years old in her carriage.
tr: She was a kind-hearted, compassionate woman and was unhappy in her marriage. How could it be! Her husband's brother didn't trust her at all and didn't love her, and he influenced everyone by saying bad things about her; the woman had come to fear both him and her husband. When I escorted her to the door, I saw that there was a sweet little boy, about two or three years old, in her car.
es: "The lady was kind, with a compassionate heart, and very unfortunate in her marriage." "Her husband's brother hated her, distrusted her, and used all his influence against her." "She feared him, and also feared her husband." "When I accompanied her to the door of my house, after she said goodbye to me, I saw one of her children, who was waiting for her in the car, a beautiful child of about two to three years old."

en: “‘For his sake, Doctor,’ she said, pointing to him in tears, ‘I would do all I can to make what poor amends I can. He will never prosper in his inheritance otherwise. I have a presentiment that if no other innocent atonement is made for this, it will one day be required of him. What I have left to call my own—it is little beyond the worth of a few jewels—I will make it the first charge of his life to bestow, with the compassion and lamenting of his dead mother, on this injured family, if the sister can be discovered.’
vi: − Because of my child, doctor, - she said through her tears while pointing at the child, - for my child, I do everything I can to make amends. If not, my child will inherit all the grudges. I have a feeling that if this wrongdoing is not compensated by someone, one day my own child will have to pay that debt. All that I have... is worth no more than a few pieces of jewelry... I am determined to entrust it to my child as a primary duty, out of compassion for the deceased mother, to use it to compensate the harmed family, if it is possible to find that younger sister. -
tr: "For his sake, Doctor," she said, pointing to the child with tears in her eyes, "I will do whatever I can. Otherwise, with this name he has inherited, he will never see the light of day. It seems to me that if the price of these sins is not paid, one day he will suffer for it. Whatever I have left – which is only slightly more than the worth of a few jewels – I will leave to my son so that his first task, if his sister can be found, will be to bestow this burden of mercy and sorrow from his late mother upon this wounded family."
es: "—For the love of this innocent one, doctor," the poor mother, awash in tears, told me, "I must go, on the path of reparations, as far as my scant strength will allow." An inner voice tells me that the innocent son must atone for the crimes of his guilty father, if I do not offer some expiation for them in time. My primary concern must be to instill in his tender heart compassion for his fellow beings, and my final charge, to watch over the sister I seek, if I can find her.

en: “She kissed the boy, and said, caressing him, ‘It is for thine own dear sake. Thou wilt be faithful, little Charles?’ The child answered her bravely, ‘Yes!’ I kissed her hand, and she took him in her arms, and went away caressing him. I never saw her more.
vi: She kissed the little boy, then spoke lovingly to the child. - It's all for you. You must do exactly as your mother instructs, Charles? − Yes! - The child responded bravely. I kissed her hand, she lovingly embraced the child, and then left. Since then, I have never seen her again.
tr: Then the woman kissed and caressed her son, saying, "All of this is for you, my dear son." "You will do as I say, won't you little Charles?" she said. The child bravely replied, "Yes!" I kissed the woman's hand, and she took her son in her arms, kissed and caressed him, and left. I never saw that woman again.
es: »He then kissed the child and said to him: »—I do everything for you, Carlos. Will you forget my errands? "—Never—responded the boy resolutely.

en: “As she had mentioned her husband’s name in the faith that I knew it, I added no mention of it to my letter. I sealed my letter, and, not trusting it out of my own hands, delivered it myself that day.
vi: Since she mentioned her husband's name thinking I already knew it, I didn't add this detail to my letter. I sealed the letter and, trusting no one, personally sent it that same day.
tr: Thinking that the woman pronounced her husband's name knowing that I knew it, I did not mention his name in my letter. I sealed the letter and, since I could not trust anyone, I personally delivered it that day.
es: "I did not include in my letter a name that had been communicated to me confidentially." I closed it, and not wanting to entrust it to anyone, that day I took it myself to its destination.

en: “That night, the last night of the year, towards nine o’clock, a man in a black dress rang at my gate, demanded to see me, and softly followed my servant, Ernest Defarge, a youth, up-stairs. When my servant came into the room where I sat with my wife—O my wife, beloved of my heart! My fair young English wife!—we saw the man, who was supposed to be at the gate, standing silent behind him.
vi: That evening, the last night of the year, around nine o'clock, a man in black rang the bell at the gate demanding to see me and quietly followed my young servant, Ernest Defarge, upstairs. I was sitting beside my wife. - Oh, my beloved wife! My graceful English wife! - When the servant entered the room, we saw behind Defarge the silent stranger, who should have been waiting outside the gate.
tr: That night, the last night of the year, around nine o'clock, a man in black clothes rang my doorbell, wanted to see me, and quietly followed my young servant Ernest Defarge upstairs. When my servant entered the room where I was sitting with my wife –oh my wife, my dear wife! My beautiful young English wife!– we saw that the man who should have been waiting at the door was silently standing behind my servant.
es: "At night, it was the last of the year, around nine o'clock, a man dressed in black knocked at my door, said he needed to see me, and my servant Ernesto Defarge led him to my presence."

en: “An urgent case in the Rue St. Honore, he said. It would not detain me, he had a coach in waiting.
vi: There is an urgent case on St. Honoré Street, he said. It won't take much of my time because he already has a carriage waiting.
tr: "There is an urgent case on Rue St Honore," said the man. He said it wouldn't take much of my time and that a car was waiting downstairs.
es: "—An urgent case on St. Honoré Street—he said. "I left immediately."

en: “It brought me here, it brought me to my grave. When I was clear of the house, a black muffler was drawn tightly over my mouth from behind, and my arms were pinioned. The two brothers crossed the road from a dark corner, and identified me with a single gesture. The Marquis took from his pocket the letter I had written, showed it me, burnt it in the light of a lantern that was held, and extinguished the ashes with his foot. Not a word was spoken. I was brought here, I was brought to my living grave.
vi: The car brought me here, to this grave. As soon as I left the house, a black cloth from behind tightly gagged my mouth and bound my hands. From a dark corner across the street, those two brothers crossed over and just waved a hand to signal that they had recognized me. The Marquis took out the letter I had sent from his pocket, showed it to me, then burned it in the flame of the lantern he was holding and stamped out the ashes with his foot. Not a word was spoken. I was brought here, I was brought to this living grave.
tr: The car brought me here, to my grave. As soon as the house disappeared from view, someone from behind reached out and tightly wrapped my mouth with a black cloth and tied my arms. From a dark corner, those two brothers emerged and approached us, indicating with a single gesture that they recognized me. The marquis took out the letter I had written from his pocket and showed it to me, then burned it with the flame of a lantern he was holding and scattered the ashes with his foot. No one said a single word. I was brought here, to the grave where I was buried alive.
es: "In the street, a car was waiting for me... which brought me here, to the tomb." "We had barely lost sight of my house when unexpectedly they gagged me and tied my arms with ropes." "It didn't take long for the two brothers to come out to meet the car." "The Marquis took the letter I had delivered to the Minister out of his pocket, showed it to me, burned it with the flame of a lantern he was holding, and trampled on the ashes."
