"Not a word was spoken." "They brought me to this tomb, and here I remain."

en: “If it had pleased God to put it in the hard heart of either of the brothers, in all these frightful years, to grant me any tidings of my dearest wife—so much as to let me know by a word whether alive or dead—I might have thought that He had not quite abandoned them. But, now I believe that the mark of the red cross is fatal to them, and that they have no part in His mercies. And them and their descendants, to the last of their race, I, Alexandre Manette, unhappy prisoner, do this last night of the year 1767, in my unbearable agony, denounce to the times when all these things shall be answered for. I denounce them to Heaven and to earth.”
vi: If only during the many terrible years that have just passed, God had made one of those two brothers kindly inform me of any news about my beloved wife - even just a word to let me know whether she was alive or dead - then I would still think that God had not abandoned them. But now I believe that the mark of the cross is their fate because God has refused to show mercy. To them and their descendants, to the very last one, I, Alexandre Manette, an unfortunate prisoner, on this last night of the year 1767, in unbearable agony, swear that there will come a time when all these sins will be judged. I denounce them to both Heaven and Earth. ۩۩۩
tr: If during these terrible years God had touched the hard heart of either of these two brothers and brought me news of my dear wife –at least to tell me whether she was dead or alive– then I might have thought that God had not entirely abandoned these brothers. But now I know that the red cross is a deadly sign for them and that they will never partake in God's mercy. I, Alexandre Manette, sorrowful prisoner, on this last night of the year 1767, in unbearable agony, consign them and all their lineage to the day they will account for all their deeds, down to the last member. Surely, they will be held accountable both in this world and in the presence of God.
es: »If during the span of these horrible years, God had deigned to touch the heart of either of the two brothers, not to put an end to my dreadful captivity, but to give me news of my beloved wife... to tell me, if nothing else, whether she lives or has died, I would believe that, despite their wickedness, He has not completely abandoned them; but today I believe that the red crosses traced with blood by the dying boy have been fatal for them, I believe that Heaven has condemned them. As a consequence, I, Alexandre Manette, unfortunate captive, on the last night of the year 1767, denounce the two brothers and all their descendants, to the very last one, to the times that must inevitably come, when men will punish wickedness like that of which they have been guilty. I also denounce them to heaven and earth.»

en: A terrible sound arose when the reading of this document was done. A sound of craving and eagerness that had nothing articulate in it but blood. The narrative called up the most revengeful passions of the time, and there was not a head in the nation but must have dropped before it.
vi: As soon as the reading of this document ended, the entire court erupted in terrible commotion. A sound full of craving and eagerness resonated with only one thing: blood. This story had incited the most frenzied fits of revengeful anger of that time, and surely there was not a single head in all of France that did not bow in fear before that wrath.
tr: When the document was finished being read, a terrible noise erupted in the hall. It was the sound of an immense bloodthirstiness and agitation. The Doctor's writings had fanned the flames of the most vengeful passions of the time, and in this atmosphere, the people would not calm down until a head rolled before them.
es: Terrible roars followed the reading of this document. No words were heard, which the throats could not modulate, but roars that revealed an insatiable thirst for blood. Before that tribunal, and before that audience, there was no need to explain how Defarge possessed that terrible document that had just been made public, nor was there any need to make known that the name of that hated family had long been listed in the formidable records of Saint Antoine.

en: Little need, in presence of that tribunal and that auditory, to show how the Defarges had not made the paper public, with the other captured Bastille memorials borne in procession, and had kept it, biding their time. Little need to show that this detested family name had long been anathematised by Saint Antoine, and was wrought into the fatal register. The man never trod ground whose virtues and services would have sustained him in that place that day, against such denunciation.
vi: In the courtroom and amidst the chaotic shouting, it goes without saying that the Defarge couple had hidden these papers, along with other records taken from the Bastille prison that had been passed around, and had been waiting for the opportunity to disclose them. It goes without saying that this hated family had long been cursed by the people of the Saint Antoine district and was on the execution list. There was not a single person, no matter how virtuous and meritorious, who could escape that day with such an accusation.
tr: There was no need to ask the Defarges in front of the court and the spectators why they did not show this document along with the other Bastille documents that came into their hands during the ceremonial procession and why they kept these in their possession. There was also no need to show that this vile family had long been cursed by St. Antoine and recorded in the deadly register. No matter how virtuous a man was, no matter how important services he had rendered, it was unlikely that he would escape such an accusation on that day.
es: Before that tribunal, and before that audience, there was no need to explain how Defarge possessed that terrible document that had just been made public, nor was there any need to make known that the name of that hated family had long been listed in the formidable records of Saint Antoine. The man capable of defending the mortal upon whom such a grave accusation weighed had not been born.

en: And all the worse for the doomed man, that the denouncer was a well-known citizen, his own attached friend, the father of his wife. One of the frenzied aspirations of the populace was, for imitations of the questionable public virtues of antiquity, and for sacrifices and self-immolations on the people’s altar. Therefore when the President said (else had his own head quivered on his shoulders), that the good physician of the Republic would deserve better still of the Republic by rooting out an obnoxious family of Aristocrats, and would doubtless feel a sacred glow and joy in making his daughter a widow and her child an orphan, there was wild excitement, patriotic fervour, not a touch of human sympathy.
vi: And even worse for the condemned man, the accuser was a renowned Citizen, his close friend, and his father-in-law. One of the mad aspirations of the masses is to emulate the dubious virtues of ancient times by offering sacrifices and self-sacrifice before the altar of the people. Therefore, when the Judge said (and to say otherwise would risk his head being chopped off) that the esteemed doctor had greatly served the Republic by exterminating a detestable noble family, that he must surely feel proud and joyful for having made his daughter a widow and his grandchild an orphan, those words incited a frenzied patriotic emotion devoid of any humanity.
tr: The worst part for this man condemned to death was that the person accusing him was a citizen known to the public, a friend to whom he was deeply devoted, and at the same time, his father-in-law. One of the most outrageous demands of the people was to hold sacrificial ceremonies on the altar, taking national virtues from ancient times as an example. Therefore, when the President said that this good doctor of the Republic had done a great favor to the Republic by eradicating the roots of the disgusting aristocratic family and that he should undoubtedly feel a noble excitement and pleasure from this event, which left his daughter a widow and her child an orphan (if he hadn't said it, it would have been his own head on the line), there was an outburst of excitement and patriotic fervor in the hall; no one felt the slightest bit of pity.
es: The situation of the condemned was infinitely aggravated by the fact that his accuser was a very well-known and highly respectable citizen, his soul friend, none other than his wife's father. One of the most common aspirations among the populace was to imitate the public virtues of antiquity, to sacrifice oneself for the cause of the people, to immolate the tenderest affections on the altar of the Republic. This is why, when the President said that the good republican doctor did not hesitate to leave his daughter a widow and his grandson an orphan, in exchange for exterminating a family of pernicious aristocrats, the mobs gave free rein to a wild patriotic fervor, without any heartstrings vibrating with human sympathy.

en: “Much influence around him, has that Doctor?” murmured Madame Defarge, smiling to The Vengeance. “Save him now, my Doctor, save him!”
vi: − Can the doctor influence the people here? - Madame Defarge whispered while smiling at the Goddess of Vengeance. - Now save him, doctor, save him!
tr: Madam Defarge, smiling at Revenge, murmured, "The Doctor is quite influential, isn't he?" "Now let's see you save him, Doctor dear, go on, save him!"
es: "So you have surrounded him with powerful influences, eh, doctor?" murmured Mrs. Defarge, looking and smiling at The Vengeance. "Save him, doctor, save him now, if you can!"

en: At every juryman’s vote, there was a roar. Another and another. Roar and roar.
vi: With each verdict from the jury members, there was a roar from the crowd. Verdict after verdict. Roar after roar.
tr: A murmur rose with each jury member's vote. Again, and again. The murmurs followed one another.
es: The jurors expressed themselves through roars. Each vote cast was a roar, the verdict, a succession of roars.

en: Unanimously voted. At heart and by descent an Aristocrat, an enemy of the Republic, a notorious oppressor of the People. Back to the Conciergerie, and Death within four-and-twenty hours!
vi: All in unison. As a nobleman by lineage and by nature, as an enemy of the Republic, as a notorious oppressor of the people. Back to the Conciergerie prison, and to be executed within the next twenty-four hours!
tr: The decision was unanimously approved. He was both a heartfelt and a born aristocrat and an enemy of the Republic; he was a tyrant who had become the talk of everyone. He would return to the Conciergerie and be executed within twenty-four hours!
es: The verdict did not take long to arrive. Carlos Evrémonde, also known as Darnay, aristocrat by heart and blood, enemy of the Republic and fierce oppressor of the people, would return to the Conciergerie to be beheaded within twenty-four hours.

en: CHAPTER XI.
vi: Back to the Conciergerie prison, and to be executed within the next twenty-four hours!
tr: XI
es: XI.

en: Dusk
vi: 11. Gloom
tr: Twilight
es: SHADOWS

en: The wretched wife of the innocent man thus doomed to die, fell under the sentence, as if she had been mortally stricken. But, she uttered no sound; and so strong was the voice within her, representing that it was she of all the world who must uphold him in his misery and not augment it, that it quickly raised her, even from that shock.
vi: The unfortunate wife of the innocent man who had just been sentenced to death collapsed as if the sentence had ended her life. But she did not utter a word; she quickly overcame the horror because a strong inner voice urged her to remember that in this world, only she could help her husband face this, not bear additional suffering.
tr: The poor wife of the innocent man condemned to death was struck as if hit in the head when she heard the verdict. But she did not utter a word, and the voice inside her that said she was the only person in this world who could support her husband through this agony without exacerbating it was so strong that she quickly regained her composure, even shaking off the shock she had experienced.
es: The fierce sentence that condemned an innocent man to the ultimate penalty was for the unfortunate wife a sharp dagger that pierced her tender heart. However, the unhappy woman did not utter a complaint; in the depths of her soul, a powerful voice arose, marking the path of her duty, telling her that her obligation was to support her beloved husband instead of increasing his agonies with her own, and before the incantation of that voice, the young woman stood up proudly, overcoming the effects of the tremendous blow she had received.

en: The Judges having to take part in a public demonstration out of doors, the Tribunal adjourned. The quick noise and movement of the court’s emptying itself by many passages had not ceased, when Lucie stood stretching out her arms towards her husband, with nothing in her face but love and consolation.
vi: The judges had to participate in the street protest march, the court adjourned the trial. The sound of people noisily leaving the court through every exit still echoed as Lucie stood with her hand outstretched towards her husband, her face full of love and comfort.
tr: The court had adjourned because the judges needed to attend the demonstration outside. As the crowd noisily made their way through the rows and emptied the hall, Lucie stood with a loving and comforting expression on her face, arms open to her husband.
es: The judges adjourned the session to take part in the boisterous public demonstration that inevitably followed the incident at the hearing, and very soon, with all the doors of the Hall of Justice open, the public exited, indifferent to Lucía's pain, who stretched her yearning arms towards the platform where her husband remained.

en: “If I might touch him! If I might embrace him once! O, good citizens, if you would have so much compassion for us!”
vi: − If only I could touch him! If only I could embrace him once! Oh, good Citizens, if only you could sympathize with us!
tr: "If only I could touch her! If only I could hug her just once! Oh kind-hearted citizens, please have mercy on us!"
es: —If I could reach him, my God! If I could give him a hug, just one! Oh citizens! Search in your hearts for a remnant of pity and grant a plea that I make to you on my knees!

en: There was but a gaoler left, along with two of the four men who had taken him last night, and Barsad. The people had all poured out to the show in the streets. Barsad proposed to the rest, “Let her embrace him then; it is but a moment.” It was silently acquiesced in, and they passed her over the seats in the hall to a raised place, where he, by leaning over the dock, could fold her in his arms.
vi: Only one jailer remained along with two of the four who had arrested Darnay last night, and Barsad. The people had all poured out to watch the spectacle on the street. Barsad suggested to the others: − Then let her embrace him; just for a moment. They silently agreed and led Lucie across the rows of seats to the high platform where Darnay, if he leaned over the dock, could reach out and embrace his wife.
tr: Only two of the four men who came to get him last night, Barsad and a guard, remained beside Charles. Everyone had poured into the street to watch the show. Turning to those beside him, Barsad said, "Let her embrace him; but only for a minute." Barsad's suggestion was silently accepted, and they led Lucie through the chairs in the hall to a high place where, when her husband leaned from the dock, he could take her into his arms.
es: There were no more people left there except a jailer with two of the four individuals who had gone to arrest Carlos the day before, and Barsad. The public was already bustling through the streets. —Let him give a hug—proposed Barsad to his companions;—it's a matter of a moment. Those beasts softened. Lucía was able to reach the foot of the platform, and her husband, leaning over the railing, embraced her in his arms.

en: “Farewell, dear darling of my soul. My parting blessing on my love. We shall meet again, where the weary are at rest!”
vi: − Farewell, my love. This is the final blessing for the beloved. We shall meet again in the resting place of the weary souls!
tr: "Goodbye, my one and only love. Our child is entrusted to you. One day, we will meet again in the place where weary bodies rest!"
es: —Goodbye, my sweet soul!—he said. —I leave this world blessing the loves I leave behind in it. In the mansion where hatreds and human passions sleep, we will meet again.

en: They were her husband’s words, as he held her to his bosom.
vi: These were the words of the husband as he held his wife in his arms.
tr: These were the words that fell from Charles's mouth as he pressed his wife to his chest.
es: In the mansion where hatreds and human passions sleep, we will meet again.

en: “I can bear it, dear Charles. I am supported from above: don’t suffer for me. A parting blessing for our child.”
vi: − I can endure it, Charles. There is divine grace watching over me; do not grieve for me. Send our final blessings to our child. −
tr: "I can endure this, dear Charles. God gave me strength. Pray for our child."
es: —My misfortune is dreadful, dear Carlos; but I accept it with resignation. Do not suffer for me, for God protects me and sustains my strength. The last blessing for our angel, and farewell!

en: “I send it to her by you. I kiss her by you. I say farewell to her by you.”
vi: Send them to our child for me. I send this kiss to our child on your behalf. I send this farewell to our child on your behalf. −
tr: "I send my prayers with you. I send my kisses with you. Say goodbye to him for me."
es: —I send it with you, and by kissing you, I kiss both of you, and by saying goodbye to you, I say goodbye to both of you.

en: “My husband. No! A moment!” He was tearing himself apart from her. “We shall not be separated long. I feel that this will break my heart by-and-bye; but I will do my duty while I can, and when I leave her, God will raise up friends for her, as He did for me.”
vi: My love. Wait! Just a minute! - Charles Darnay was letting her go. - We will not be separated for long. This suffering will soon end my life; but I will fulfill my duty to our child as long as I can, so that when I pass away, God will send friends to help our child as He has helped me.
tr: "My dear husband. No! Wait a minute!" Charles was trying to pull himself away from her. "Our separation won't last long. This separation will break my heart more with each passing day; but I will fulfill my duty until the last moment, and when I leave our child one day, God will grant him good friends, just as He granted me."
es: —No... Dear Carlos, no! One more moment!—exclaimed Lucía, seeing that the condemned man was trying to free himself from her arms. —Our separation will not be long. I sense that my sorrows will soon put an end to my sad life; but as long as I have a breath of energy left, I will fulfill my duty, and when I leave our daughter, the merciful God who provided me with good souls that, with their love and selflessness, brightened my existence, will not withhold them from her.

en: Her father had followed her, and would have fallen on his knees to both of them, but that Darnay put out a hand and seized him, crying:
vi: Dr. Manette had been following his daughter, and would have knelt before both Charles and Lucie if his son-in-law had not reached out to stop him.
tr: Her father had followed Lucie and was just about to kneel before both of them when Darnay extended his hand to stop him and called out:
es: Her father had followed her, turned into a mute statue of grief, who would have fallen to his knees at their feet, had Carlos not prevented it.

en: “No, no! What have you done, what have you done, that you should kneel to us! We know now, what a struggle you made of old. We know, now what you underwent when you suspected my descent, and when you knew it. We know now, the natural antipathy you strove against, and conquered, for her dear sake. We thank you with all our hearts, and all our love and duty. Heaven be with you!”
vi: Charles exclaimed: "No, no! Father, you have done nothing, you have done nothing that requires you to kneel before us! We now know how hard you struggled in the past." We now know what you went through when you doubted my lineage, and when you found out the truth. We now know that you resisted and overcame your aversion to me because of your love for Lucie. We are deeply grateful to you, with all our love and filial piety, may heaven bless you!
tr: "No, no! What have you done, what have you done to make us kneel before you! We now know the great struggle you put up in the old days. We now know what you went through when you doubted my lineage and then became certain of it. We also know that for the sake of your dear daughter, you suppressed and overcame the justified hatred within you. We thank you with all our hearts, with our love and respect. May God protect you!"
es: —No... no!—he shouted, extending his arms—Have you committed any fault, to prostrate yourself on your knees before us? Ah, no! Quite the opposite! Now is when I fully realize the horrible tortures that tore your soul apart! Now is when I can gauge what you suffered when you suspected the blood that ran through my veins and the despair you must have felt when those suspicions turned into certainty! Now is when I understand the fierce struggles you had to fight against a natural antipathy, the efforts you necessarily had to make to overcome it! With all our hearts, we thank you! All our gratitude is yours, all our affection is yours. May Heaven bless you, as we bless you!

en: Her father’s only answer was to draw his hands through his white hair, and wring them with a shriek of anguish.
vi: The father could say nothing more than to run his hands through his silver hair in anguish and let out a cry of pain. −
tr: The only response Lucie's father could give was to run his hands through his white hair and tug at it with a scream of pain.
es: The old man could not answer, for his constricted throat was unable to articulate a word, and his body had no energy left except to tear at his hair and let out an occasional moan of anguish.

en: “It could not be otherwise,” said the prisoner. “All things have worked together as they have fallen out. It was the always-vain endeavour to discharge my poor mother’s trust that first brought my fatal presence near you. Good could never come of such evil, a happier end was not in nature to so unhappy a beginning. Be comforted, and forgive me. Heaven bless you!”
vi: There was nothing else to be done, - Charles said. - Everything has been decided. I have always strived in vain to fulfill the wish my mother entrusted to me, the very thing that led me to meet you from the beginning. Such cruelty cannot give birth to something good, a misfortunate beginning cannot lead to a happier ending. Please be at peace and forgive me. May heaven bless you!
tr: "It couldn't have been any other way," said the prisoner. "Everything has come to pass as it was meant to. The first thing that brought my mortal existence to you was my poor mother's futile desire to fulfill what she asked of me. No good would come from so much evil, and such a painful beginning would naturally not end with a happy conclusion. Rest assured and forgive me. May God protect you all!"
es: —It had to happen this way—replied the convict. —Everything has conspired to reach the fatal outcome we have arrived at. All the efforts I have made to satisfy that aspiration of my saintly mother, which she expressed the first day you met her and me, have been in vain. It would have been foolish to expect any good from such an abundant sowing of evils, to delude oneself into thinking that what began with fatal principles could have a happy ending. Have courage, and forgive me. May the merciful God shower you with blessings!

en: As he was drawn away, his wife released him, and stood looking after him with her hands touching one another in the attitude of prayer, and with a radiant look upon her face, in which there was even a comforting smile. As he went out at the prisoners’ door, she turned, laid her head lovingly on her father’s breast, tried to speak to him, and fell at his feet.
vi: Lucie let go of her hand as Charles was led away and she stood watching her husband, her hands clasped as if in prayer, her face glowing with affection, even with a reassuring smile. As Charles disappeared behind the door for the condemned, she turned back to rest her head on her father's chest, intending to say something but then collapsed.
tr: As Darnay was taken away, his wife had to let him go and looked after him with her hands clasped as if in prayer, a radiant expression on her face, and a comforting smile. When her husband reached the prison door, Lucie turned and rested her head lovingly on her father's chest, tried to say something to him, and then collapsed to the ground.
es: The spouses separated; and while the convict moved away among his guards, his wife remained looking at him, hands together in an attitude of supplication and with a radiant face on which a caressing and comforting smile predominated. However, no sooner had the condemned disappeared through the door that led to the prison, Lucia bowed her head like a flower cut at the stem, tried to speak, and collapsed to the ground.

en: Then, issuing from the obscure corner from which he had never moved, Sydney Carton came and took her up. Only her father and Mr. Lorry were with her. His arm trembled as it raised her, and supported her head. Yet, there was an air about him that was not all of pity—that had a flush of pride in it.
vi: At that moment, from a hidden corner where he had been standing motionless, Sydney Carton stepped forward to support her. His demeanor was not entirely one of compassion - there was a certain proud intensity on his face.
tr: Sydney Carton, who had been standing motionless in a remote corner until then, sprang up and lifted the young woman. Only her father and Mr. Lorry were beside Lucie. As he lifted her from the ground and supported her head, Carton's arms were trembling. However, he had an air that contained not just mercy, but also a hint of pride.
es: From the dark corner where he had remained hidden since the beginning of the trial, Sydney Carton then emerged and lifted the unfortunate woman from the ground. Only her father and Lorry remained with her. Carton's arm trembled as he lifted her, and yet his expression was not solely one of pity; there was a strong mix of pride in it.

en: “Shall I take her to a coach? I shall never feel her weight.”
vi: − Shall I take her to the carriage? She's very light, let me carry her.
tr: "Shall I carry it to the car? It's very light anyway."
es: —Shall I take her to the car?—he asked. —I won't feel her weight.

en: He carried her lightly to the door, and laid her tenderly down in a coach. Her father and their old friend got into it, and he took his seat beside the driver.
vi: Sydney gently carried Lucie to the door and softly placed her on the seat cushion. Doctor Manette and the old friend got into the carriage, while he took the seat next to the coachman.
tr: He carried Lucie to the car without difficulty and gently laid her on the seat. Following them, Lucie's father and her old friend Mr. Lorry also got into the car, and Carton took his place next to the driver.
es: In his arms, he carried her to the car waiting at the door, where he settled her in. The elderly doctor and the good Lorry sat beside her, and Carton settled on the box seat, next to the coachman.

en: When they arrived at the gateway where he had paused in the dark not many hours before, to picture to himself on which of the rough stones of the street her feet had trodden, he lifted her again, and carried her up the staircase to their rooms. There, he laid her down on a couch, where her child and Miss Pross wept over her.
vi: When the car arrived at the gate of the house where Sydney had stopped in the darkness just a few hours earlier, imagining himself walking on the rough stone that had once supported her steps, he carried her out of the car and up the stairs into the apartment. Once there, he laid Lucie down on the couch while the little girl and Miss Pross stood nearby, crying aloud. −
tr: Just a few hours earlier, when they arrived at the entrance where Lucie imagined stepping on uneven stones in the dark, Sydney Carton lifted Lucie into his arms again and carried her up the stairs to her room. When he laid her down on a couch there, her daughter and Miss Pross knelt beside her and cried.
es: Arriving in front of the gate, at the spot where hours earlier Carton had stopped trying to guess which stones Lucia's feet had tread upon, he took her out of the carriage, and in his arms, he proudly carried her up to her rooms, laying her down on a sofa. Lucita and Miss Pross were crying inconsolably.

en: “Don’t recall her to herself,” he said, softly, to the latter, “she is better so. Don’t revive her to consciousness, while she only faints.”
vi: Don't wake her up, - he whispered to Miss Pross, - it's better to let her be. She has only fainted, don't wake her up. −
tr: Carton said to Miss Pross in a low voice, "Don't try to bring him around, it's better this way. Don't wake him up, he just fainted."
es: —Do nothing to dispel her fainting.—said Carton to the last one in a very low voice. —She is better this way.

en: “Oh, Carton, Carton, dear Carton!” cried little Lucie, springing up and throwing her arms passionately round him, in a burst of grief. “Now that you have come, I think you will do something to help mamma, something to save papa! O, look at her, dear Carton! Can you, of all the people who love her, bear to see her so?”
vi: Oh, Mr. Carton, Mr. Carton! - Little Lucie exclaimed as she rushed to embrace him in her sorrow. - Now that you're here, please do something to help mama, do something to save papa! Oh, look at my mother, please! Of all the people who love her, how can you bear to see her like this?
tr: Little Lucie jumped up and threw herself around Carton's neck with great distress, crying out, "Oh Carton, Carton, dear Carton!" "I'm so glad you came, I think you'll do something to save my mother, and my father too! Oh, look at my mother, Carton! Can those who love her bear to see her like this?"
es: —Oh Carton, Carton!—cried Lucie, jumping onto Carton's neck and wrapping her arms around him. —Now that you have come, I don't doubt that you will do something to console mother, to save father. Look at her, Carton! Can you, can anyone who loves her look at her without their heart breaking into pieces?

en: He bent over the child, and laid her blooming cheek against his face. He put her gently from him, and looked at her unconscious mother.
vi: He bent down to little Lucie, pressing his cheek against the child's rosy one. He gently pushed the girl away and looked at Lucie, who was still unconscious.
tr: Carton leaned down to the child and pressed his own face against the child's glowing cheeks. Then he gently moved the child away and looked at the mother lying unconscious.
es: Can you, can anyone who loves her look at her without their heart breaking into pieces? Carton gave the girl a kiss, gently separated her little arms, gazed at the mother for a few seconds, and said:

en: “Before I go,” he said, and paused—“I may kiss her?”
vi: − Before you go, - he said, hesitantly - ... may I kiss your mother?
tr: "Before leaving," he said and paused –"can I kiss her?"
es: —Before I leave... can I kiss her?

en: It was remembered afterwards that when he bent down and touched her face with his lips, he murmured some words. The child, who was nearest to him, told them afterwards, and told her grandchildren when she was a handsome old lady, that she heard him say, “A life you love.”
vi: The few words he whispered as he touched his lips to hers would be remembered forever. The child, standing next to him, would later recount and, even in old age, tell his descendants that Carton had said: "For the life of the one you love."
tr: Later, it would be remembered that at the moment when Carton leaned down and touched the woman's face with his lips, he murmured something. At that moment, little Lucie, who was closest to him, would later tell them and, when she became a sweet old woman, her grandchildren, that she heard Carton say to his mother, "A life you love."
es: Later, witnesses of this scene recalled that, while their lips brushed the cheeks of the fainted one, they murmured a few words. The girl, who was the closest, said later, and repeated many times to her grandchildren when she was an old lady bent under the weight of the years: "It is a life you love."

en: When he had gone out into the next room, he turned suddenly on Mr. Lorry and her father, who were following, and said to the latter:
vi: As he walked into the next room, he suddenly turned to Mr. Lorry and Dr. Manette, who were following him, and he said to the doctor: − Just yesterday you still had a lot of influence, Dr. Manette; at least try again today.
tr: When Carton moved to the other room, he turned to Lucie's father, who followed him along with Mr. Lorry, and said;
es: In the adjoining room, where he found the doctor and Lorry, he said to the former:

en: “You had great influence but yesterday, Doctor Manette; let it at least be tried. These judges, and all the men in power, are very friendly to you, and very recognisant of your services; are they not?”
vi: As he walked into the next room, he suddenly turned to Mr. Lorry and Dr. Manette, who were following him, and he said to the doctor: − Just yesterday you still had a lot of influence, Dr. Manette; at least try again today. The authorities and everyone in power are very friendly to you, acknowledging your contributions, aren't they? −
tr: "You were very effective yesterday, but Doctor Manette; try once more. All those judges and influential people are very kind to you and are aware of your services, aren't they?"
es: —Yesterday you had a lot of influence, Doctor Manette; you must use it all. The judges, and all those who have some power today, are your friends and are grateful for your services; isn't that right?

en: “Nothing connected with Charles was concealed from me. I had the strongest assurances that I should save him; and I did.” He returned the answer in great trouble, and very slowly.
vi: There is nothing that could save Charles that I haven't tried. I was very confident that I could save him; and I did. - He replied with great difficulty, word by word.
tr: "Nothing about Charles was hidden from me. My belief in saving him was very strong; and I did save him." He had spoken this answer with great difficulty and very slowly.
es: —They hid nothing from me regarding Carlos. I harbored hopes, almost absolute certainty of saving him, and I saved him—replied the doctor, speaking very slowly and with a troubled expression.

en: “Try them again. The hours between this and to-morrow afternoon are few and short, but try.”
vi: − Try again. There isn't much time left until tomorrow afternoon, but keep trying.
tr: "Try again. We don't have much time until noon tomorrow, but try."
es: —Try again. Brief are the hours that separate today from tomorrow; but try.

en: “I intend to try. I will not rest a moment.”
vi: − I have the same idea. I will not sit still for a minute. −
tr: "I intend to try. There is no time to lose."
es: —I will try... I will not rest for a moment.

en: “That’s well. I have known such energy as yours do great things before now—though never,” he added, with a smile and a sigh together, “such great things as this. But try! Of little worth as life is when we misuse it, it is worth that effort. It would cost nothing to lay down if it were not.”
vi: That's good. I know capable people like you have done great things before... though never, - he added, with a smile and a sigh, - anything as extraordinary as this. But give it a try! Life isn't worth much when we waste it, but it's worth trying. If we don't try, life isn't worth a penny.
tr: "Beautiful. I know that you can do amazing things with the energy you have, just like you did before – but of course," he said, smiling and sighing, "this is truly a challenging situation. Still, try! When we waste our lives, it has no value, whereas life is worth this effort. If it weren't, it wouldn't be so hard to set it aside."
es: —It is what you must do. I have seen men with your energy accomplish great things, although never—he added, smiling and sighing at the same time—anything as great as what I am proposing to you. Try, however. The salvation of a beloved life is well worth that effort. —I will present myself to the Attorney General of the Republic and to the President—replied Doctor Manette,—as well as to others who need not be named.

en: “I will go,” said Doctor Manette, “to the Prosecutor and the President straight, and I will go to others whom it is better not to name. I will write too, and—But stay! There is a Celebration in the streets, and no one will be accessible until dark.”
vi: − I will go, - Dr. Manette said, - go see the prosecutor and the chief judge, I will go see others whose names I won't mention. I will also write letters, and... But wait! There's a festival going on outside, and we won't be able to meet anyone until the evening.
tr: "Now directly," said Doctor Manette, "I will go to the Prosecutor and the President and to other people whose names I do not wish to mention. I will write where I need to write and – But wait a minute! There is a celebration in the street and I won't be able to reach anyone until it gets dark."
es: —I will present myself to the Attorney General of the Republic and to the President—replied Doctor Manette,—as well as to others who need not be named. I will also write, and... But now I remember that public celebrations are being held today and that I will not be able to see anyone until it is night.

en: “That’s true. Well! It is a forlorn hope at the best, and not much the forlorner for being delayed till dark. I should like to know how you speed; though, mind! I expect nothing! When are you likely to have seen these dread powers, Doctor Manette?”
vi: − That's right. Wow! A hopeless hope, and even more hopeless when delayed until evening. Anyway, I still want to know how you intend to do it, that's all! I don't dare to expect anything! When can you meet those formidable authorities, Dr. Manette? −
tr: "Correct. Well! This is already a weak hope at best, and the situation won't be more hopeless just because it remains in the dark. But I would like to know what course of action you will take! Even if I have no expectations. When will you probably meet with those terrible powers, Doctor Manette?"
es: —It's true. Bah! In any case, it's a very remote hope; little is lost by waiting until night. I begin by saying that I expect nothing. Tell me, Doctor Manette, when do you think you will be able to see those formidable authorities?

en: “Immediately after dark, I should hope. Within an hour or two from this.”
vi: As soon as it gets dark, I hope so. Within one or two hours. −
tr: "I hope, as soon as darkness falls. That is, in a few hours."
es: —Immediately after nightfall; I believe within one or two hours.

en: “It will be dark soon after four. Let us stretch the hour or two. If I go to Mr. Lorry’s at nine, shall I hear what you have done, either from our friend or from yourself?”
vi: It will get dark quickly after four o'clock. Let's assume one or two more hours. If I come to Mr. Lorry's place at nine o'clock, I hope I will know the results of your actions, either from Mr. Lorry or from you yourself?
tr: "The weather gets dark around four. Let's extend the time by a few more hours. If I go to Mr. Lorry at nine o'clock, can I learn what you are doing from our friend or directly from you?"
es: —It will get dark shortly after four... Let's make the most of the hour or two we have ahead of us. If I show up at Mr. Lorry's house at nine, will I be able to know the result of his efforts?

en: “Yes.”
vi: − Alright.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Of course.

en: “May you prosper!”
vi: − Good luck!
tr: "Good luck with your work!"
es: —I hope they have good success!

en: Mr. Lorry followed Sydney to the outer door, and, touching him on the shoulder as he was going away, caused him to turn.
vi: Mr. Lorry followed Sydney to the door and as he was about to leave, he grabbed his shoulder to hold him back.
tr: Mr. Lorry accompanied Sydney to the outer door and, as he was leaving, touched his shoulder and turned him back.
es: He accompanied Lorry to the street door, where he said to him in a very low and sorrowful voice:

en: “I have no hope,” said Mr. Lorry, in a low and sorrowful whisper.
vi: − We have no hope, - Mr. Lorry said, his voice a whisper of agony.
tr: "I have no hope," said Mr. Lorry, in a low and sorrowful whisper.
es: —I expect nothing.

en: “Nor have I.”
vi: − Neither do I. −
tr: "I don't have one either.""
es: —Nor I.

en: “If any one of these men, or all of these men, were disposed to spare him—which is a large supposition; for what is his life, or any man’s to them!—I doubt if they durst spare him after the demonstration in the court.”
vi: If any of those people, or the whole crowd, had any intention of sparing Darnay; this is an illusion because his life or anyone else's means nothing to them!... But I think that even if they wanted to, they wouldn't dare spare Darnay's life after the public's reaction in the trial.
tr: "Even if any or all of those men had the intention to spare his life – which is a very big expectation; after all, what meaning does his or any human's life have for them! – I don't know if they could dare to do it after all the commotion in the courtroom."
es: —Even if any one of those men... even if all of those men were willing to grant him life... which is assuming too much, after what happened at the trial, I highly doubt they would dare to do so.

en: “And so do I. I heard the fall of the axe in that sound.”
vi: − I think so too. I smelled blood in their shouts.
tr: "I think so too. In that noise, I felt like I heard the guillotine drop."
es: —I doubt it too... The blade will not stop.

en: Mr. Lorry leaned his arm upon the door-post, and bowed his face upon it.
vi: Mr. Lorry leaned against the door frame, hiding his face in his arm.
tr: Mr. Lorry leaned his arm against the edge of the door and buried his head in his arm.
es: Lorry brought her hands to her face and let out some sobs.

en: “Don’t despond,” said Carton, very gently; “don’t grieve. I encouraged Doctor Manette in this idea, because I felt that it might one day be consolatory to her. Otherwise, she might think ‘his life was wantonly thrown away or wasted,’ and that might trouble her.”
vi: − Don't be discouraged, - Carton said very gently, - don't be distressed. I encouraged Doctor Manette like that because I thought it might somehow comfort Lucie, ease her mind. If not, she might think that everyone had given up on Darnay's life, and that would trouble her greatly. −
tr: "Don't lose hope," said Carton softly, "don't be upset. I encouraged Doctor Manette to this idea, thinking it might be a consolation for Lucie in the future. Otherwise, Lucie might think, 'My husband's life was wasted for nothing, it ended,' and put herself in distress."
es: —Do not despair... do not give in to despondency—said Carton with extreme gentleness. —If I have advised the doctor to work tirelessly, it is because his efforts, though they may be fruitless, will one day bring comfort to his daughter. If her father were to fold his arms, she might think that a life had been sacrificed without anyone making the effort to dispute it with the executioner.

en: “Yes, yes, yes,” returned Mr. Lorry, drying his eyes, “you are right. But he will perish; there is no real hope.”
vi: Yes, yes, that's right, - Mr. Lorry replied while wiping his tears, you are right. But Darnay will lose his life; there is no more hope.
tr: "Yes, yes, correct," replied Mr. Lorry, wiping his eyes, "you are right. But the end is very near; there is really no hope."
es: —Yes, yes, yes! You are right!—responded Lorry, wiping his eyes. —We will work; but he will die... there isn't an atom of hope left!

en: “Yes. He will perish: there is no real hope,” echoed Carton.
vi: − Yes. Darnay will lose his life; there is no more hope, - Carton repeated.
tr: "True." "The end is very near, there is really no hope," repeated Carton.
es: —It's true. He will die... There isn't an atom of hope left! —repeated Carton like an echo.

en: And walked with a settled step, down-stairs.
vi: Then he confidently stepped down the stairs.
tr: Then he walked down the road with determined steps.
es: Then he started walking with a firm step.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: 12. In the darkness, Sydney Carton stopped on the street, not knowing where to go.
tr: XII
es: Chapter XII.

en: Darkness
vi: 12. In the darkness, Sydney Carton stopped on the street, not knowing where to go.
tr: Darkness
es: DARKNESS

en: Sydney Carton paused in the street, not quite decided where to go. “At Tellson’s banking-house at nine,” he said, with a musing face. “Shall I do well, in the mean time, to show myself? I think so. It is best that these people should know there is such a man as I here; it is a sound precaution, and may be a necessary preparation. But care, care, care! Let me think it out!”
vi: 12. In the darkness, Sydney Carton stopped on the street, not knowing where to go. "At Tellson's Bank at nine o'clock," he muttered to himself. - In this moment, should I reveal myself? Probably yes. It's best that the people here know there is someone like me present; it's a wise precaution and possibly a necessary preparation. But be careful, be careful! You must think carefully!
tr: Sydney Carton stood in the middle of the street, unable to decide where to go. He said to himself, "At nine, at Tellson's," with a distracted expression. "Should I do something to make myself seen in the meantime? It would be good. It would be good for these people here to know that a man like me exists; it is both a prudent measure and a necessary preparation. But one must be careful, very careful! I must think it over thoroughly!"
es: Carton had traveled very little distance when he stopped, not yet decided about the place he would head to. —At nine o'clock at Tellson's Bank—he murmured. — From now until then, would it be wise for me to be seen? I think so. It wouldn't hurt for those people to know that a man like me is around here... it might be a wise precaution... a necessary precaution... Careful, Carton, careful...! Let's think it over again!

en: Checking his steps which had begun to tend towards an object, he took a turn or two in the already darkening street, and traced the thought in his mind to its possible consequences. His first impression was confirmed. “It is best,” he said, finally resolved, “that these people should know there is such a man as I here.” And he turned his face towards Saint Antoine.
vi: As his familiar steps followed the chosen path, he hesitated, turning into two or three darkening alleys, weighing the possible consequences in his mind. The initial thoughts were confirmed. − So it's for the best, - he finally decided, - the people here must know there is someone who looks like me. - And he headed towards Saint Antoine.
tr: Weighing his steps directed towards a certain object, he turned into a few streets on the road that was beginning to darken and tried to see the possible outcomes of the thought in his mind. His initial impression was confirmed. Finally, with a determined attitude, he said, "Absolutely, these people need to know that there is a man like me here." Then he turned his face towards St Antoine.
es: Suspending the journey already begun in a certain direction, he entered a dark and lonely alley and tried to weigh the pros and cons of his project, measuring with his imagination the scope and probable consequences that it might have. —No doubt; it's the best—he thought. —Those people must know that there is a man named Carton in the city. With determined steps, he set off towards San Antonio.

en: Defarge had described himself, that day, as the keeper of a wine-shop in the Saint Antoine suburb. It was not difficult for one who knew the city well, to find his house without asking any question. Having ascertained its situation, Carton came out of those closer streets again, and dined at a place of refreshment and fell sound asleep after dinner. For the first time in many years, he had no strong drink. Since last night he had taken nothing but a little light thin wine, and last night he had dropped the brandy slowly down on Mr. Lorry’s hearth like a man who had done with it.
vi: Defarge today has proclaimed himself as the wine seller in the Saint Antoine district. For someone familiar with this city, it is easy to find that place without asking anyone. After identifying the location, Carton walked out from those nearby streets, went into a restaurant to have dinner, and slept there. For the first time in many years, he did not drink strong liquor. Since last night, he had drunk nothing but some weak, diluted wine, and last night he slowly poured all the brandy into Mr. Lorry's fireplace as if he had renounced it.
tr: That day, Defarge introduced himself as the owner of a wine shop in the outskirts of St. Antoine. For someone who knew the city well, finding his house without asking anyone was not a difficult thing. Carton learned the location of the shop well and, after leaving the nearby streets again, he had a meal at a restaurant and then fell into a deep sleep. For the first time in many years, he had not consumed much alcohol that night. Since last night, he had only drunk slightly diluted wine, and last night he had slowly poured the cognac onto Mr. Lorry's hearthstone like a man who no longer had any use for it.
es: As Defarge had said that same day during the trial that he owned a tavern located in the Saint Antoine district, anyone who knew the city well would have little difficulty finding the tavern in question, without needing to ask anyone. Carton, therefore, left the dark alley and ate at a dining house, subsequently taking a nap. In many years, he had not drunk as little as he did that day. Since the previous night, he had only had a bit of watered-down wine.

en: It was as late as seven o’clock when he awoke refreshed, and went out into the streets again. As he passed along towards Saint Antoine, he stopped at a shop-window where there was a mirror, and slightly altered the disordered arrangement of his loose cravat, and his coat-collar, and his wild hair. This done, he went on direct to Defarge’s, and went in.
vi: At seven o'clock, he woke up feeling refreshed and went out again. While heading towards Saint Antoine, he stopped in front of a shop window with a mirror, adjusted his attire a bit, tightened his loose tie, raised the collar of his coat, and smoothed his messy hair. Then he walked straight to the Defarge tavern and went inside.
tr: When he hit the streets again after waking up refreshed, it was already seven o'clock. As he was heading towards St Antoine, he stopped in front of a shop window with a mirror and roughly adjusted his loosened tie, the collar of his coat, and his disheveled hair. Once this task was done, he headed straight to Defarge's shop and went inside.
es: Around seven o'clock he woke up and resumed his march. Upon reaching the San Antonio neighborhood, he stopped for a moment in front of a shop where he saw a mirror, and slightly adjusted the knot of his tie and disheveled his collar and hair. Having done this, he headed straight to the Defarge tavern and entered resolutely.

en: There happened to be no customer in the shop but Jacques Three, of the restless fingers and the croaking voice. This man, whom he had seen upon the Jury, stood drinking at the little counter, in conversation with the Defarges, man and wife. The Vengeance assisted in the conversation, like a regular member of the establishment.
vi: By chance, there were no customers in the shop at that moment except for Jacques Three, who had restless fingers and a booming voice. This man you had seen sitting on the jury; he was at the small wine counter, drinking and chatting with the Defarges. The Vengeance also joined the conversation, as a regular patron of this shop.
tr: In the shop, there was no one but Jacques Three with his crow-like voice, constantly moving his fingers. This man, whom he saw among the jury members, was leaning on the small counter, drinking his liquor, and chatting with the Defarge couple. Revenge, as if it were an ordinary member of this group, was mingling into the conversation.
es: He found no one in the establishment except Santiago Tercero, whom he remembered seeing that afternoon among the jurors, who was drinking and conversing with the Defarges, husband and wife. La Venganza, in her capacity as a member of the tavern, was attending the conversation.

en: As Carton walked in, took his seat and asked (in very indifferent French) for a small measure of wine, Madame Defarge cast a careless glance at him, and then a keener, and then a keener, and then advanced to him herself, and asked him what it was he had ordered.
vi: When Carton walked in, chose a seat, and ordered (in very poor French) a small portion of wine, Madame Defarge glanced at him indifferently, then looked more closely, and even more closely, and personally went over to ask what he had ordered.
tr: When Carton entered the shop and sat down, asking for a small wine (in poor French), Madam Defarge first gave him an indifferent look; then she examined him with a bit more curiosity, and soon after with even more curious eyes, and approached him to ask what he had ordered.
es: Carton, after taking a seat, ordered a glass of wine. Madame Defarge gave him an indifferent glance, then a more scrutinizing one, followed by an extraordinarily penetrating look, and finally approached him to ask what he wanted.

en: He repeated what he had already said.
vi: He repeats what he said.
tr: He repeated what he had just said.
es: Carton repeated what he had said before.

en: “English?” asked Madame Defarge, inquisitively raising her dark eyebrows.
vi: − The Englishman? - Madame Defarge raised her thick black eyebrows inquiringly.
tr: Madam Defarge raised her black eyebrows curiously and asked, "Are you English?"
es: —English?—asked the innkeeper, raising her eyebrows.

en: After looking at her, as if the sound of even a single French word were slow to express itself to him, he answered, in his former strong foreign accent. “Yes, madame, yes. I am English!”
vi: After looking at her as if it was very difficult to understand a word of French, Carton replied in a slightly foreign accent as before. − Yes, madame, yes. I am English!
tr: Carton looked at the woman as if he had difficulty understanding even the smallest French word, and then, with the same foreign accent as before, said, "Yes madam, yes! I am English!"
es: Carton, after looking at her for a long while, as if it were very difficult for him to pronounce a French word, replied with a very strong foreign accent: —Yes, ma'am, yes; English.

en: Madame Defarge returned to her counter to get the wine, and, as he took up a Jacobin journal and feigned to pore over it puzzling out its meaning, he heard her say, “I swear to you, like Evrémonde!”
vi: Madame Defarge turned back to the counter to get the wine, and while he held the Jacobin newspaper pretending to try to understand the tangled words, he heard her say: − I swear to you, just like Evrémonde!
tr: Madam Defarge returned to her counter to fetch the wine, and while Carton had taken a Jacobin newspaper in his hand, bending over the words as if trying to decipher what they said, he heard the woman exclaim, "I swear, just like Evremonde!"
es: The barmaid went to the counter to serve the wine, and Carton, while he took a Jacobin newspaper in his hands and pretended to make efforts to interpret the language in which it was written, heard the first one say: —I swear he looks like Evrémonde.

en: Defarge brought him the wine, and gave him Good Evening.
vi: Defarge brought the wine and greeted.
tr: Defarge brought the wine and wished him a good evening.
es: Defarge served the wine, bidding the customer goodnight.

en: “How?”
vi: Defarge brought the wine and greeted.
tr: "Sir?""
es: —What?—asked Carton.

en: “Good evening.”
vi: − What? − Hello. − Ah! Hello, Citizen, - Carton poured wine into his glass.
tr: "Good evening."
es: —Good evening.

en: “Oh! Good evening, citizen,” filling his glass. “Ah! and good wine. I drink to the Republic.”
vi: - Ah! Good wine. I drink to the Republic.
tr: "Good evening." "Ha, good evening citizen," said Carton, while filling his glass. "Ahh! The wine is also very good. I drink to the Republic."
es: —Good evening. —Oh... very good evening, citizen... and very good wine! I toast to the Republic!

en: Defarge went back to the counter, and said, “Certainly, a little like.” Madame sternly retorted, “I tell you a good deal like.” Jacques Three pacifically remarked, “He is so much in your mind, see you, madame.” The amiable Vengeance added, with a laugh, “Yes, my faith! And you are looking forward with so much pleasure to seeing him once more to-morrow!”
vi: Defarge returned to the counter and said, "It does look a bit similar." − I told you it's exactly the same, - the wife replied coldly. − He haunts her mind, madame. - Jacques Ba mediated. − What else! - The Goddess of Vengeance burst out laughing, interjecting. − And you are eagerly excited to meet him again tomorrow.
tr: When Defarge returned to the counter, he said, "Yes, it does resemble a bit indeed." Upon this, Madam replied sharply, "I tell you, it looks exactly like him." As if trying to ease the atmosphere, Jacques Three said, "Look madam, your mind is always on him." Warm-hearted Revenge laughed, "Indeed! You are eager to see him once more tomorrow!"
es: Defarge returned to the counter, saying: —It's true; he looks a bit like him. —And I repeat that he looks a lot like him! —replied the innkeeper harshly. —You have it so present in your memory...—observed Santiago Tercero. —I swear I don't forget him for a moment either!—exclaimed La Venganza, laughing. —And if I'm not mistaken, you're waiting for tomorrow to see him again.

en: Carton followed the lines and words of his paper, with a slow forefinger, and with a studious and absorbed face. They were all leaning their arms on the counter close together, speaking low. After a silence of a few moments, during which they all looked towards him without disturbing his outward attention from the Jacobin editor, they resumed their conversation.
vi: Carton slowly traced his index finger along each line and word on the newspaper page, pretending to be engrossed. The group of people leaned against the bar, huddled together, and spoke softly. After a while, they all fell silent and looked towards Carton, not disturbing his concentration on reading the Jacobin newspaper. They continued their conversation. −
tr: Carton followed the lines and words in the newspaper with a diligent and pensive expression on his face, slowly tracing them with his index finger. The others, with their arms resting side by side on the counter, were speaking in low voices. After a few minutes of silence, during which they watched Carton focused on his newspaper without disturbing him, they resumed their conversation.
es: Carton continued reading, following the lines of the newspaper with his index finger and giving his full attention to the reading. The Defarges, La Vengeance, and Jacques Three, heads together and elbows on the counter, were conversing in very low voices. After a few moments of silence, during which the four people had their eyes fixed on the diligent reader, who had neither eyes nor ears for anything but the newspaper, they resumed their conversation.

en: “It is true what madame says,” observed Jacques Three. “Why stop? There is great force in that. Why stop?”
vi: What madame said is true, - Jacques Three spoke up. - Why stop? It makes perfect sense. Why stop? − Well, well, - Defarge argued, - but one must stop somewhere.
tr: "Madam is right," said Jacques Three. "Why should we stop? This is an incredible power. Why should we stop?"
es: —I think your wife is right. Why stop until the end of the journey? The argument is very strong. —Whatever you want—objected Defarge—but we will have to stop somewhere.

en: “Well, well,” reasoned Defarge, “but one must stop somewhere. After all, the question is still where?”
vi: Why stop? − Well, well, - Defarge argued, - but one must stop somewhere. After all, where is the issue? −
tr: "It's all well and good," said Defarge, "but we need to stop somewhere. The whole issue is, where will we stop?"
es: —Whatever you want—objected Defarge—but we will have to stop somewhere. In reality, the only thing to agree upon is where to make that stop.

en: “At extermination,” said madame.
vi: When everything is eradicated, - Defarge's wife said.
tr: "When they are all destroyed," said the madam.
es: —After the extermination! —replied the innkeeper.

en: “Magnificent!” croaked Jacques Three. The Vengeance, also, highly approved.
vi: − Great! - Jacques Ba said in a booming voice. The Goddess of Vengeance also enthusiastically agreed.
tr: Jacques Three shouted, "Wonderful!" in a hoarse voice. Revenge also loved this idea.
es: —Magnificent!—howled Santiago Tercero. —Superb!—shouted Revenge.

en: “Extermination is good doctrine, my wife,” said Defarge, rather troubled; “in general, I say nothing against it. But this Doctor has suffered much; you have seen him to-day; you have observed his face when the paper was read.”
vi: − Extermination is the best policy, my dear, - Defarge said somewhat uneasily. - In general, I am not against it. But this doctor has suffered too much; today you saw him; you saw his face when those papers were read out. − I saw that face! -
tr: "Destroying them all is a nice idea, my dear," said Defarge, a bit troubled; "I am not generally against it. But that Doctor has suffered a lot; you saw the man today; his face when the paper was read."
es: —I profess the holy doctrine of extermination, and it goes without saying that, in general, I have nothing against it—observed Defarge. — But we must take into account that this poor doctor has already suffered a lot. Today you have been able to see it for yourselves, as you all must have noticed the expression on his face while the paper was being read.

en: “I have observed his face!” repeated madame, contemptuously and angrily. “Yes. I have observed his face. I have observed his face to be not the face of a true friend of the Republic. Let him take care of his face!”
vi: His wife's voice was angry and contemptuous. Yes. I saw that face! I saw that his face was not the face of a true friend of the Republic. Let him take care of his own face! −
tr: "Of course, I noticed what happened to your face!" the madam repeated, in a contemptuous and angry manner. "Yes. I saw your face. This face was definitely not the face of a loyal citizen to the Republic. Let them deal with it however they want!"
es: —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes! —replied the innkeeper, putting all the contempt and hatred of her fierce heart into her words. —I have noticed the expression on his face, yes; and I have seen that it was not the face of a true friend of the Republic; that is what I have seen.

en: “And you have observed, my wife,” said Defarge, in a deprecatory manner, “the anguish of his daughter, which must be a dreadful anguish to him!”
vi: You also saw how much his daughter suffered, - Defarge said urgently, - that also caused him terrible pain! − I saw his daughter, - said Madame Defarge. -
tr: Defarge, as if objecting, continued his speech, "Well, my wife," he said, "did you see the pain your daughter went through? Who knows how great a pain this is for her father!"
es: —And the cruel agonies of his daughter, agonies that must have greatly exacerbated his own, would not have escaped your notice—replied Defarge.

en: “I have observed his daughter,” repeated madame; “yes, I have observed his daughter, more times than one. I have observed her to-day, and I have observed her other days. I have observed her in the court, and I have observed her in the street by the prison. Let me but lift my finger—!” She seemed to raise it (the listener’s eyes were always on his paper), and to let it fall with a rattle on the ledge before her, as if the axe had dropped.
vi: Yes, I saw his daughter, not just once. I saw her today and many other times. I saw her in the courtroom, and I saw her on the street beside the prison. I only need to lift a finger!... - Madame Defarge seemed to raise her index finger and let it drop heavily on the counter in front of her, like the blade of a guillotine coming down. The eavesdropper's eyes remained fixed on the newspaper.
tr: "I saw your daughter too," replied the madam; "yes, I looked at her from time to time. Today I examined her closely, and I had examined her on previous days as well. I examined her both in court and on the street next to the prison. But now, it's necessary to raise this finger!" She raised her finger (the person listening to them never took his eyes off the newspaper) and brought it down on the edge of the counter with a loud thud, as if she were lowering the blade of a guillotine.
es: —I have also observed your daughter, yes—replied the innkeeper;—I have observed her many times; not just today. I observed her today in the Tribunal, and I have observed her on other days in the street, gazing at the prison walls. It is enough for me to lift a finger, for the blade to immediately drop and make her head roll.

en: “The citizeness is superb!” croaked the Juryman.
vi: − Excellent Citizen! - Jacques Three said gruffly.
tr: "This is an amazing citizen!" shouted the jury member in a hoarse voice.
es: —You are a prodigious citizen! —roared Santiago Tercero.

en: “She is an Angel!” said The Vengeance, and embraced her.
vi: − You are an angel! - The Goddess of Retribution hugged Mrs. Defarge tightly. −
tr: "She is an angel!" said Revenge and hugged the madam.
es: —An angel!—sighed Revenge.

en: “As to thee,” pursued madame, implacably, addressing her husband, “if it depended on thee—which, happily, it does not—thou wouldst rescue this man even now.”
vi: And you, - she insisted to her husband, - you are lucky you have no power; if you did, you would definitely save that son-in-law right now.
tr: Turning to her husband, "As for you," the lady continued mercilessly, "if it were up to you –thankfully it's not– you would still save this man even now."
es: —As for you—continued the implacable innkeeper, addressing her husband,—I am sure that, if it were up to you... which fortunately it is not... you would still be capable of saving that man.

en: “No!” protested Defarge. “Not if to lift this glass would do it! But I would leave the matter there. I say, stop there.”
vi: − No! - Defarge protested. - Not at all, even if I had the power to do so! But I am stopping this matter here. I say, stop it here. −
tr: "Hey!" objected Defarge. "Even if it were an easy thing, I wouldn't bother. But I would leave this job here. I'm saying, let's stop now."
es: —No!—protested Defarge—If by raising this glass I could save him, be sure that I would not raise it! But I would stop there; I repeat that I would consider my work finished.

en: “See you then, Jacques,” said Madame Defarge, wrathfully; “and see you, too, my little Vengeance; see you both! Listen! For other crimes as tyrants and oppressors, I have this race a long time on my register, doomed to destruction and extermination. Ask my husband, is that so.”
vi: Then see you again, Jacques, - Mrs. Defarge said angrily. See you again too, Goddess of Retribution. We will meet again! Remember that! I have put this entire family on the list for condemnation and destruction long ago, for all kinds of crimes of tyranny and oppression. Ask my husband if it's true. −
tr: "Look at me, Jacques," said Madame Defarge angrily; "you too, little Vengeance; both of you look at me! Listen now! I had already recorded this cruel and oppressive family to be destroyed for all the crimes they committed. If you want, ask my husband."
es: —You can see it now, Santiago—exclaimed the innkeeper, her eyes blazing with rage—You can see it too, my dear Vengeance... You both see it... You both hear it... For a long time, that race has been listed in my records as condemned to destruction, to extermination, for crimes that have nothing to do with tyranny and oppression. Ask my husband if I'm lying.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge, without being asked.
vi: It's true, - Defarge confirmed without anyone asking.
tr: Without being asked anything further, Defarge confirmed, "Yes, that's correct."
es: —It's true—replied Defarge, without waiting to be asked.

en: “In the beginning of the great days, when the Bastille falls, he finds this paper of to-day, and he brings it home, and in the middle of the night when this place is clear and shut, we read it, here on this spot, by the light of this lamp. Ask him, is that so.”
vi: − On the day this glorious time began, when the Bastille fell, my husband found the papers that were read in court today, my husband brought them home, at midnight, when the tavern was quiet and closed, we read them, right here, under this lamp. Ask my husband if it's true. −
tr: "At the beginning of these tremendous days, when the Bastille fell, he found that letter which is read today and brought it home, then at midnight, when no one was left in the shop, he closed the door and we read it right here, under the light of this lamp. If you want, ask him."
es: —In the early days of the great times, when the Bastille fell, my husband found the document that has been made public today, brought it home, and after midnight, when the establishment was closed and deserted, we read it in this very place and by the light of this very lamp. Ask him if I speak the truth.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge.
vi: It's true, - Defarge confirmed.
tr: "Yes, that's right," confirmed Defarge.
es: —It's true, yes—replied Defarge.

en: “That night, I tell him, when the paper is read through, and the lamp is burnt out, and the day is gleaming in above those shutters and between those iron bars, that I have now a secret to communicate. Ask him, is that so.”
vi: − That night, I told my husband after reading the papers, the lamp had run out of oil, and dawn was breaking through those shutters and bars, I said I needed to reveal a secret. Ask my husband if it's true. −
tr: "That night, after we finished reading the letter and the lamp went out, and when the first light of day filtered through the shutters and those iron bars, I told her that I would reveal a secret to her." "If you want, ask her.""
es: —That very night, after reading the paper and extinguishing the lamp, when the day began to filter through the cracks in the windows and the bars of the grilles, I told him that I had a secret to share with him. Let him tell you if I lie.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge again.
vi: It's true, - Defarge confirmed again.
tr: "Yes, that's right," Defarge confirmed again.
es: —It's true—agreed Defarge.

en: “I communicate to him that secret. I smite this bosom with these two hands as I smite it now, and I tell him, ‘Defarge, I was brought up among the fishermen of the sea-shore, and that peasant family so injured by the two Evrémonde brothers, as that Bastille paper describes, is my family. Defarge, that sister of the mortally wounded boy upon the ground was my sister, that husband was my sister’s husband, that unborn child was their child, that brother was my brother, that father was my father, those dead are my dead, and that summons to answer for those things descends to me!’ Ask him, is that so.”
vi: − I told that secret to my husband. I beat my chest with these two hands just like I am beating my chest now, and I said, "Defarge, I was raised by the fishermen on the coast, but my real family is the peasant family harmed by the Evrémonde brothers, as the papers in the Bastille prison recounted. Defarge, the sister of the peasant boy lying wounded on the floor, is my sister, that husband is my brother-in-law, the unborn child is their child, that peasant boy is my brother, that father is my father, those dead people are all my relatives, and only I am left to demand retribution from them!” Just ask my husband if it's true. −
tr: "I revealed my secret to her. Striking my chest with both hands as I am doing now, I said to her, 'Defarge, I grew up among the fishermen by the sea, and as it is written in that paper found in the Bastille, that peasant family abused by the two Evremonde brothers was my family. Defarge, the sister of the boy lying on the ground, wounded and at death's door, was my sister, that husband was my sister's husband, that unborn child was their child, that boy was my brother, that father was my father, those who died were my dead, and it falls upon me to seek justice for all of them!' If you want, ask her."
es: —And I told him the secret. I struck his chest with these two hands, as I strike it now, and I said: "Defarge; I was raised among fishermen on the beach, and the peasant family so outraged by the Evrémonde brothers, that family described in the paper found in the Bastille, is my family. Defarge, the dying sister of the mortally wounded peasant boy was my sister, the husband was my sister's husband, the fruit of their love that never opened its eyes to the light was my sister's child, and that peasant brother was my brother, and the father who died of grief was my father, those who died were my dead, and their cries for vengeance have been directed at me ever since..." Ask him if what I say is true.

en: “It is so,” assented Defarge once more.
vi: It is true, - Defarge confirmed once more. −
tr: Defarge was now tired of confirming, simply listening to the woman, and when she wanted him to confirm, he reluctantly agreed. It was time to confirm once again. "Yes, that's right," confirmed Defarge once again.
es: —That's right—confessed Defarge.

en: “Then tell Wind and Fire where to stop,” returned madame; “but don’t tell me.”
vi: Then show me where the wind and fire should stop! - Madame Defarge replied. Don't talk to me!
tr: "Then go and tell 'Wind' and 'Fire' where they should stop," replied the lady; "not me."
es: —And now, tell me if it is possible to put gates on the gale or extinguish the fire of hell! —replied the innkeeper. —But no; it is not necessary for you to tell me.

en: Both her hearers derived a horrible enjoyment from the deadly nature of her wrath—the listener could feel how white she was, without seeing her—and both highly commended it. Defarge, a weak minority, interposed a few words for the memory of the compassionate wife of the Marquis; but only elicited from his own wife a repetition of her last reply. “Tell the Wind and the Fire where to stop; not me!”
vi: Knowing the terrible reason for Madame Defarge's hatred, the two listeners were disgustingly delighted and wholeheartedly encouraged her, while the solitary guest over there, eyes glued to the newspaper, could still feel the woman's livid hatred. Defarge, the weak minority, interjected with a few reminders about the compassionate wife of the Marquis, but only made his wife repeat her earlier statement: − Then show me where the wind and fire should stop! Don't talk to me!
tr: Both listeners took a dreadful pleasure in the woman's deadly nature of anger – the other listener could sense that the woman had turned deathly pale even without seeing her – and both received it with deep respect. Defarge, as the powerless minority, attempted to say a few words reminding of the Marquis' compassionate wife; but his wife merely repeated her last words. "Go tell 'Wind' and 'Fire' where they should stop, not me."
es: The two listeners savored a horrible pleasure in convincing themselves of the implacable nature of the innkeeper's hatred, whose ghostly pallor the newspaper reader was seeing without seeing her face. Defarge, a minor insignificant, ventured a few words highlighting the compassion of the Marquis's wife; but he achieved nothing more than the repetition of his wife's last words: —Tell me if it is possible to put gates on the gale or extinguish the fire of hell!

en: Customers entered, and the group was broken up. The English customer paid for what he had had, perplexedly counted his change, and asked, as a stranger, to be directed towards the National Palace. Madame Defarge took him to the door, and put her arm on his, in pointing out the road. The English customer was not without his reflections then, that it might be a good deed to seize that arm, lift it, and strike under it sharp and deep.
vi: A few customers entered the tavern and the group inside dispersed. The English visitor paid for the wine, awkwardly counted the change, and then asked for directions to the National Castle like a stranger. Madame Defarge led the visitor to the door, took his arm, and pointed the way. The visitor couldn't suppress the thought that if only he could grab the arm of the innkeeper's wife, lift her up, and thrust a sword deep into her side, it would be a blessing for many people.
tr: Customers entered and the group dispersed. The English customer paid for what he drank, counted the coins with a bewildered expression, and as a foreigner. He asked how he could get to the National Palace. Madame Defarge escorted him to the door and pointed in the direction he should go, holding his arm. At that moment, what crossed the English customer's mind was how good it would be to grab that arm, lift it, and deliver a hard and deep stab underneath it.
es: The entrance of some patrons put an end to the conference. The Englishman paid the incurred expense and asked where the National Palace was. Mrs. Defarge accompanied him to the door, and there, placing her arm over his, indicated the way he should follow. The English patron felt the urge to lift that arm and strike its owner with a sure hand.

en: But, he went his way, and was soon swallowed up in the shadow of the prison wall. At the appointed hour, he emerged from it to present himself in Mr. Lorry’s room again, where he found the old gentleman walking to and fro in restless anxiety. He said he had been with Lucie until just now, and had only left her for a few minutes, to come and keep his appointment. Her father had not been seen, since he quitted the banking-house towards four o’clock. She had some faint hopes that his mediation might save Charles, but they were very slight. He had been more than five hours gone: where could he be?
vi: But then Carton silently left and soon disappeared into the darkness of the prison walls. At the appointed time, he went from there to Mr. Lorry's place and found the old man anxiously pacing back and forth. He had been with Lucie until just a few minutes ago before leaving to make it to this appointment on time. There has been no sign of Dr. Manette since he left this bank at nearly four o'clock.
