Lucie still clings to the faint hope that her father might be able to arrange something to save Charles. The doctor has been gone for five hours now; no one knows where he went.
tr: Ama yoluna devam etti ve çok geçmeden hapishane duvarının gölgesinde kayboldu. Kararlaştırdıkları saatte bu gölgeden çıkarak tekrar Mr. Lorry'nin evine vardığında yaşlı adamı huzursuz bir sıkıntı içinde odanın içinde bir aşağı bir yukarı yürürken buldu. Şu ana dek Lucie ile olduğunu ve onun yanından bu randevuya gelebilmek için birkaç dakikalığına ayrıldığını söyledi. Lucie'nin babası dörde doğru bankadan çıkmış ve bir daha görünmemişti. Babasının arabuluculuğunun Charles'ı kurtaracağına dair bir ümidi vardı Lucie'nin, ama bu yok denecek kadar azdı. Babası gideli beş saati geçmişti. Nerede olabilirdi?
es: Carton moved away from those places, soon circling the prison walls. At the appointed hour, he presented himself at Lorry's house, where he found the old man waiting for him, anxious and full of worry. The good banker informed him that he had been accompanying Lucía until moments before, and that he had parted from her to attend the agreed meeting; that they had not seen her father since he left at four in the afternoon; that Lucía harbored some hope that, through the doctor's intervention, Carlos might be saved, but that the hopes were very weak. The doctor's absence lasted five hours: where could he be?

en: Mr. Lorry waited until ten; but, Doctor Manette not returning, and he being unwilling to leave Lucie any longer, it was arranged that he should go back to her, and come to the banking-house again at midnight. In the meanwhile, Carton would wait alone by the fire for the Doctor.
vi: Mr. Lorry waited until ten o'clock but still did not see Dr. Manette return. He did not want to make Lucie worry any more, so he arranged to return to Lucie's house and would come back to the Bank at midnight. Meanwhile, Carton sat alone by the fireplace waiting for the doctor.
tr: Mr. Lorry waited until ten o'clock; but Doctor Manette did not come, and since he did not want to leave Lucie alone any longer, they decided it would be a good idea for Mr. Lorry to return to her and come back to the bank at midnight. In the meantime, Carton would wait by the fireplace for the Doctor.
es: Lorry waited for him until ten, and since he could not resign himself to leaving Lucía alone and without news for so long, they decided that Lorry would return to the house of the unfortunate woman, and that Carton would wait for the doctor's arrival. Lorry was to return to the Bank at midnight.

en: He waited and waited, and the clock struck twelve; but Doctor Manette did not come back. Mr. Lorry returned, and found no tidings of him, and brought none. Where could he be?
vi: He waited, waited endlessly, and the clock had struck twelve times but still there was no sign of Dr. Manette returning. Mr. Lorry went back, with no news from the doctor or from anyone else. Where could he have gone?
tr: Carton waited and waited, the clock struck twelve; but the Doctor was nowhere to be seen. When Mr. Lorry returned, he had neither heard from him nor brought any news. Where could he be?
es: Twelve o'clock struck and the doctor did not appear. Lorry returned, and neither found any news nor brought any. Where could he be?

en: They were discussing this question, and were almost building up some weak structure of hope on his prolonged absence, when they heard him on the stairs. The instant he entered the room, it was plain that all was lost.
vi: The two were discussing this matter, almost concluding that Dr. Manette's prolonged absence was a faint sign of hope when they heard the doctor's footsteps on the stairs. As soon as Dr. Manette stepped into the room, it was clear that all hope had vanished.
tr: They were trying to find the answer to this question, and just as a faint hope began to sprout within them during the Doctor's prolonged absence, they heard his voice on the stairs. As soon as he entered, they realized that everything was lost.
es: This was the point they were discussing, almost opening their hearts to hope, founded on the prolonged absence, when they heard his footsteps on the stairs. As soon as he appeared in the room, they saw that all was lost.

en: Whether he had really been to any one, or whether he had been all that time traversing the streets, was never known. As he stood staring at them, they asked him no question, for his face told them everything.
vi: Never know if the doctor actually met someone or was just going back and forth on the road. When Dr. Manette stared at them, no one asked any questions because the doctor's face had said everything.
tr: Had he really gone to see someone, or had he just wandered the streets all this time, it's unknown. While standing and looking at them, they didn't ask him anything, for his face told everything.
es: It has never been known whether he spent all the long hours of absence wandering aimlessly through the streets, or if he visited his acquaintances. He entered the room, remained with his gaze fixed on those who were waiting for him, and did not utter a word, nor did anyone speak to him, for the expression on his face clearly said that all was lost.

en: “I cannot find it,” said he, “and I must have it. Where is it?”
vi: − I can't find it, - the doctor said, - I must find it. Where is it?
tr: "I couldn't find it," said the Doctor, "I absolutely must find it. Where is it?"
es: —I can't find it—he said. —Where is it? I need it.

en: His head and throat were bare, and, as he spoke with a helpless look straying all around, he took his coat off, and let it drop on the floor.
vi: Head without a hat, neck without a scarf, and while the doctor spoke and helplessly glanced around the room, he took off his coat and let it drop to the floor.
tr: Her head and neck were uncovered, and with a helpless expression in her eyes, she took off her coat and threw it on the floor while speaking.
es: He came with his head bare and the front of his shirt open. After casting anguished glances around, he took off his coat and sat on the ground.

en: “Where is my bench? I have been looking everywhere for my bench, and I can’t find it. What have they done with my work? Time presses: I must finish those shoes.”
vi: − Where is my shoemaker's bench? I've looked everywhere but can't find it. What did they do with my unfinished shoes? It's urgent, I need to finish those shoes.
tr: "Where is my workbench? I looked everywhere but couldn't find my workbench. What happened to the tasks I had? I don't have much time left. I need to finish those shoes."
es: —But where is my stool? I've been looking for it everywhere without being able to find it. What have they done with my work? I need to finish those shoes... they are urgently awaited.

en: They looked at one another, and their hearts died within them.
vi: Carton and Mr. Lorry looked at each other, their hearts frozen.
tr: Mr. Lorry and Carton looked at each other and their hearts broke.
es: The two listeners looked at each other, dismayed.

en: “Come, come!” said he, in a whimpering miserable way; “let me get to work. Give me my work.”
vi: − No, no! - Dr. Manette still spoke in a miserable, whining voice. Let me work. Give me back my shoes.
tr: "Come on!" said the Doctor, whining in a miserable state; "let me get back to my work. Give me my bench."
es: —Well... well!—replied the old man.— My stool... my work started...! I repeat, it is very urgent!...

en: Receiving no answer, he tore his hair, and beat his feet upon the ground, like a distracted child.
vi: Not hearing anyone respond, he ruffled his hair, stomped his feet on the floor, like an angry child.
tr: When he received no response, he started pulling his hair and stomping his foot like a child gone mad.
es: Not receiving a response, he pulled his hair and stomped on the ground, similar to an angry child.

en: “Don’t torture a poor forlorn wretch,” he implored them, with a dreadful cry; “but give me my work! What is to become of us, if those shoes are not done to-night?”
vi: − Don't torment this poor, lonely, pitiable man anymore, - Mr. Manette pleaded with them in a terrifying scream. - Give me back the shoes! What will happen if I don't finish the shoes tonight?
tr: He cried out in a heart-wrenching manner, "Stop tormenting that poor man already," he pleaded with them; "give me back my workbench already! If I can't finish those shoes tonight, what will we do then?"
es: —Don't torment a wretched man!—he exclaimed, letting out a formidable cry. — Give me my work... for God's sake! What will become of us if I don't finish the shoes tonight?

en: Lost, utterly lost!
vi: Mad, completely mad!
tr: He had completely lost himself!
es: Lost, completely lost!

en: It was so clearly beyond hope to reason with him, or try to restore him, that—as if by agreement—they each put a hand upon his shoulder, and soothed him to sit down before the fire, with a promise that he should have his work presently. He sank into the chair, and brooded over the embers, and shed tears. As if all that had happened since the garret time were a momentary fancy, or a dream, Mr. Lorry saw him shrink into the exact figure that Defarge had had in keeping.
vi: Clearly, there was no hope of persuading or trying to calm the doctor down, without a word, Carton and Mr. Lorry both placed their hands on the doctor's shoulders, coaxing him to sit down by the fireplace and promising to let him make shoes immediately. Mr. Manette sank into the chair, dejectedly staring at the embers, and cried. Everything that had happened since the doctor left the attic of Saint Antoine seemed like a fleeting dream or illusion, and in Mr. Lorry's eyes, the doctor had reverted to the very person Defarge had once watched over.
tr: It was so clear that talking to him rationally or trying to bring him to his senses would be of no use – as if they had agreed among themselves – both of them placed their hands soothingly on the Doctor's shoulder and sat him down in front of the fire, telling him that his workbench would be brought to him shortly. The Doctor sank into the chair, gazing at the embers, and fell into deep thoughts, crying uncontrollably. As if everything that had happened since those days in the attic was just a fleeting dream or illusion, Mr. Lorry watched him shrink back into the state he was in while staying with Defarge.
es: It was useless to try to light a lamp that the fierce hurricane of misfortune had extinguished forever. To Lorry's horror, to Sydney Carton's terror, Dr. Manette was once again the shoemaker of the garret, the unfortunate idiot who years before had been handed over to the innkeeper Defarge.

en: Affected, and impressed with terror as they both were, by this spectacle of ruin, it was not a time to yield to such emotions. His lonely daughter, bereft of her final hope and reliance, appealed to them both too strongly. Again, as if by agreement, they looked at one another with one meaning in their faces. Carton was the first to speak:
vi: Though stunned and heartbroken by this dreadful collapse, both Carton and Mr. Lorry knew that now was not the time to give in to their emotions. They were forced to be strong as the doctor's only daughter could no longer rely on this last hope. Once again, without a word, the two looked at each other, their faces full of meaning. Carton was the first to speak: − The last chance, which was already slim, is now lost.
tr: Even though both were horrified and deeply affected by this desolate scene, it was not the time to succumb to such emotions. They thought of the utterly alone Lucie, who had lost her last hope and confidence. As if they had agreed once again, they looked at each other with the same expression on their faces. Carton was the first to speak:
es: Both impressed, affected by the same idea and understanding the need to overcome their emotions, they devoted themselves not to trying to revive that completely extinguished intelligence, but to calming the unhappy old man, promising him that very soon the bench, the tools, and the shoes would be returned to him. —He has succumbed to the blow, excessively harsh for him—said Carton.

en: “The last chance is gone: it was not much. Yes; he had better be taken to her. But, before you go, will you, for a moment, steadily attend to me? Don’t ask me why I make the stipulations I am going to make, and exact the promise I am going to exact; I have a reason—a good one.”
vi: Carton was the first to speak: − The last chance, which was already slim, is now lost. Yes, he should be taken back to Lucie. But before you go, please listen carefully to what I have to say for a minute. Do not ask why there are conditions as I will set, do not ask why there are promises as I will demand. I have reasons... legitimate reasons.
tr: "Our last hope has also ended, it wasn't much anyway. Yes, the best thing is to take him to his daughter. But before you go, will you carefully listen to what I have to say? But don't ask why I will propose these conditions and why I will ask you to promise me; there is a reason – and a good one at that."
es: — Yes; there is no choice but to take him to his daughter; but before doing so, would you be so kind as to give me a moment of your attention? I need to impose some conditions and extract a promise from you; but do not ask me the reason for the former nor the why of the latter, for I have a reason to keep them silent... and it is of great importance.

en: “I do not doubt it,” answered Mr. Lorry. “Say on.”
vi: − I have no doubt, - Mr. Lorry replied. - Please go ahead.
tr: "I'm sure it is," replied Mr. Lorry. "Please continue."
es: —I don't doubt it—replied Lorry. —Go on.

en: The figure in the chair between them, was all the time monotonously rocking itself to and fro, and moaning. They spoke in such a tone as they would have used if they had been watching by a sick-bed in the night.
vi: The person sitting on the chair between them kept rocking back and forth in a certain way and lamenting. The two people lowered their voices to talk as if they were sitting beside a patient's bed in the middle of the night.
tr: Meanwhile, the person sitting in the seat between them was monotonously rocking back and forth and groaning. They were speaking in low voices as if they were at the bedside of a patient at night.
es: In a chair placed between the two interlocutors sat the old man, rocking monotonously and sobbing. The interlocutors spoke in very low voices, as if they were beside the bed of a sick person.

en: Carton stooped to pick up the coat, which lay almost entangling his feet. As he did so, a small case in which the Doctor was accustomed to carry the lists of his day’s duties, fell lightly on the floor. Carton took it up, and there was a folded paper in it. “We should look at this!” he said. Mr. Lorry nodded his consent. He opened it, and exclaimed, “Thank God!”
vi: Carton bent down to pick up the doctor's coat that was lying tangled at his feet. As he picked it up, a small box that the doctor often used to store his daily work notes fell to the floor. Carton picked up the box, inside was a folded piece of paper. − We should take a look at this! - He said. Mr. Lorry nodded in agreement. He opened it and exclaimed: − Thank God! −
tr: Carton bent down to pick up the coat that was lying under his feet. At that moment, the small case in which the Doctor carried the list of his daily tasks fell to the ground. When Carton picked it up, he saw a folded paper inside. "We need to look at this!" he said. Mr. Lorry nodded in agreement. Carton opened the paper and exclaimed, "Thank God!"
es: Carton got down to pick up the doctor's frock coat from the ground. As he did so, a small box fell to the ground where the doctor used to keep the list of visits he had to make during the day. He picked it up and opened it, finding a folded paper inside. —Do you want us to see what this is?—he asked. Lorry nodded with a movement of his head. —Thank you, my God!—exclaimed Carton as soon as he unfolded the paper.

en: “What is it?” asked Mr. Lorry, eagerly.
vi: What is it? - Mr. Lorry asked anxiously.
tr: "What is it?" asked Mr. Lorry, curiously.
es: —What is it?—asked Lorry with a longing tone.

en: “A moment! Let me speak of it in its place. First,” he put his hand in his coat, and took another paper from it, “that is the certificate which enables me to pass out of this city. Look at it. You see—Sydney Carton, an Englishman?”
vi: − Wait! I will explain later. First, - he reached into his coat pocket and took out another piece of paper, - this is a pass that allows me to leave this city. Look at it. See...? Sydney Carton, an Englishman?
tr: "One minute! With your permission, let me explain this when the time comes," said Carton, and he put his hand into the pocket of his coat and took out another paper, "now this is the document that will allow me to leave this city. Look what it says – Sydney Carton, English, right?"
es: —A little patience; I will explain it to you in due time. First of all—he said, reaching into the inner pocket of his frock coat and taking out another paper,—you should see this, which is a certificate, thanks to which I can leave the city without inconvenience. Read it.... Sydney Carton, English subject...

en: Mr. Lorry held it open in his hand, gazing in his earnest face.
vi: Mr. Lorry held the paper open in his hand, attentively looking at Carton's eager face.
tr: Mr. Lorry took the document and fixed his eyes on Carton's excited face.
es: Lorry was left contemplating the paper.

en: “Keep it for me until to-morrow. I shall see him to-morrow, you remember, and I had better not take it into the prison.”
vi: − Please keep this for me until tomorrow. Tomorrow I will meet Darnay in prison, remember, and I should not bring this paper with me.
tr: "Please keep this for me until tomorrow. You know I am going to see him tomorrow, and it would be better if I didn't have this with me when I go to the prison."
es: —Keep it until tomorrow. You will remember that I have to visit the prisoner, and I don't think it's wise to take it with me to the jail.

en: “Why not?”
vi: − Why not? − I don't know; I don't want to carry it with me.
tr: "Why?"
es: —Why not?

en: “I don’t know; I prefer not to do so. Now, take this paper that Doctor Manette has carried about him. It is a similar certificate, enabling him and his daughter and her child, at any time, to pass the barrier and the frontier! You see?”
vi: − Why not? − I don't know; I don't want to carry it with me. Now let's look at the paper that Dr. Manette carried with him. It is also a similar pass, allowing him and his daughter along with the child, to pass through the city gates and borders, at any time! See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this pass yesterday, as a last resort to guard against misfortune.
tr: "I don't know; I found it appropriate not to take it. Now take this paper that Doctor Manette carries with him. This is a document, just like mine, that will allow the Doctor, his daughter, and his grandchild to pass the barrier and the border whenever they want; do you understand?" "Yes!"
es: —I don't know... A whim, perhaps, but I prefer not to wear it. Also take the paper that Doctor Manette carried in his pocket, which is another similar certificate, a safe-conduct allowing him, his daughter, and his granddaughter to pass through the Barrier and the border at any time. Do you see it?

en: “Yes!”
vi: See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this pass yesterday, as a last resort to guard against misfortune.
tr: "Yes!"
es: —Yes.

en: “Perhaps he obtained it as his last and utmost precaution against evil, yesterday. When is it dated? But no matter; don’t stay to look; put it up carefully with mine and your own. Now, observe! I never doubted until within this hour or two, that he had, or could have such a paper. It is good, until recalled. But it may be soon recalled, and, I have reason to think, will be.”
vi: See? − Yes! − Perhaps Dr. Manette obtained this pass yesterday, as a last resort to guard against misfortune. What date is the paper signed? But it doesn't matter; don't waste time investigating; keep it carefully along with my pass and yours. Now, listen to me! Until one or two hours ago, I never thought that the doctor had such a pass. The pass is still valid until it expires. But it may soon expire, and I have reason to believe so, certainly.
tr: "Maybe he did this as a last precaution against all the disasters that befell them yesterday. Is there a date on it? But it doesn't matter; no need to look; put mine next to theirs. Now look! Until an hour or two ago, I didn't think he had or could have such a document. This is very good, that is, until it is canceled. It could be canceled soon because I have valid reasons to think so."
es: —Probably he provided it yesterday, in order to take all kinds of precautions against the storm. What date does it have? But it doesn't matter; there's no need to take note of that detail. The essential thing is that you keep it together with mine and yours. Now then; listen carefully to my words, and do not forget them; until two hours ago, it didn't cross my mind that you might need that paper, which today is firm and valid, and will be so as long as it is not revoked. But they can revoke it; and moreover: powerful reasons make me believe that they will revoke it very soon.

en: “They are not in danger?”
vi: − Are they in any danger? −
tr: "They are not in danger, are they?"
es: —Are they in danger?

en: “They are in great danger. They are in danger of denunciation by Madame Defarge. I know it from her own lips. I have overheard words of that woman’s, to-night, which have presented their danger to me in strong colours. I have lost no time, and since then, I have seen the spy. He confirms me. He knows that a wood-sawyer, living by the prison wall, is under the control of the Defarges, and has been rehearsed by Madame Defarge as to his having seen Her”—he never mentioned Lucie’s name—“making signs and signals to prisoners. It is easy to foresee that the pretence will be the common one, a prison plot, and that it will involve her life—and perhaps her child’s—and perhaps her father’s—for both have been seen with her at that place. Don’t look so horrified. You will save them all.”
vi: They are in extreme danger. They are at risk of being denounced by Madame Defarge. I heard it from her own mouth. Tonight I overheard her words, which made me clearly see the danger awaiting them. Without delay, immediately after that, I went to meet the spy. He confirmed it to me. He knew of a woodcutter, living next to the prison wall, who was under the control of the Defarges, and he had informed Madame Defarge that he had seen Lucie frequenting that place... he did not mention Lucie's name... seeing Lucie making signs and gestures to the prisoner. It was very clear that this was a pretext for a common crime, conspiring with a prisoner, which would endanger Lucie's life... and perhaps her child's too... as both had been seen standing there. Do not panic like that. He will save everyone.
tr: "They are facing a very great danger. The danger is something like Madam Defarge denouncing them. I heard this from her own mouth. According to the words I overheard tonight, they are in big trouble. I found the spy without wasting any time. He confirmed what I said. He mentioned that a sawyer living near the prison wall was Defarge's man and that this man had told Madam Defarge about the woman who frequently signaled to the prisoners –Carton had not mentioned Lucie's name–. It is not hard to see that they will be subjected to an ordinary accusation, a prison conspiracy; such an accusation could cost them their lives –perhaps even the child's and maybe the father's too– because both of them have been seen there, beside her. Do not be afraid. You will save them all."
es: —They are in imminent danger. They are in danger of being denounced by the innkeeper Defarge; no one told me this; I heard it from her own lips. Tonight I overheard a conversation of that woman, and the conversation made me see the danger that threatens the doctor's family. Since I heard it, I have not wasted any time, I visited my spy, and my initial impressions have been fully confirmed. He knows that a wood sawyer, a creation of the Defarges, is ready to declare that he saw her (Carton never pronounced Lucie's name) signaling to the prisoners. It is not difficult to guess that there are plenty of reasons to base any accusation on the mentioned fact, a plot against the Republic, for example, whose consequence would be her death, who knows if also that of her daughter... perhaps even that of her father, for both have also been seen in the same place... Do not be afraid... you will save them all.

en: “Heaven grant I may, Carton! But how?”
vi: − God willing, we will save them, Carton! But how?
tr: "I wish I could save Carton! But how?"
es: —May Heaven will it, Carton! But how?

en: “I am going to tell you how. It will depend on you, and it could depend on no better man. This new denunciation will certainly not take place until after to-morrow; probably not until two or three days afterwards; more probably a week afterwards. You know it is a capital crime, to mourn for, or sympathise with, a victim of the Guillotine. She and her father would unquestionably be guilty of this crime, and this woman (the inveteracy of whose pursuit cannot be described) would wait to add that strength to her case, and make herself doubly sure. You follow me?”
vi: − I will tell you how. Everything depends on you, and there is no one better. This denunciation certainly will not happen from now until the day after tomorrow; perhaps not even for two or three days; but a week later, it is possible. You know that even mourning or sympathizing with a victim of the guillotine is a serious crime. Lucie and her father will certainly be guilty of this, and that woman, with her deep-seated hatred, will be waiting to denounce them for this crime to strengthen her position and ensure the conviction. Do you understand what I mean?
tr: "I will tell you how it will be. This depends on you, and no one else can save them but you. This new report won't be made by tomorrow; it will probably take two or three days; maybe even a week. You know, mourning and crying for the guillotine's criminals is a great crime. It is as clear as day that he and his father will commit this crime, and this woman will wait to add this heavy accusation to her charges, then she will show them as guilty. Were you able to follow me?"
es: —That is what I am going to tell you right now. I trust you, convinced that I could not put the matter in better hands. The new denunciation will not be made until the day after tomorrow... they will probably leave it for two or three days later, and it is even more likely that they will delay it for a week. You know perfectly well that in this blessed country, anyone who cries or sympathizes with a victim of the guillotine incurs the death penalty. There is no doubt that both she and her father will be guilty of the aforementioned crime, and I can assure you that the innkeeper, whose fierce hatred reaches inconceivable extremes, will wait until she has weapons that increase the strength of her denunciation and make the result doubly certain. Do you understand?

en: “So attentively, and with so much confidence in what you say, that for the moment I lose sight,” touching the back of the Doctor’s chair, “even of this distress.”
vi: − Listening very carefully, and believing in your words so much that, hearing you speak, we forget this sorrow, - Mr. Lorry touched the back of Dr. Manette's chair. −
tr: "You speak so carefully and so confidently," said Mr. Lorry, touching the back of the Doctor's chair, "for a moment I even forgot the pain inside me."
es: —With such attention, and so deeply convinced of the accuracy of what you assert, that I even momentarily forget this misfortune—he replied, extending his right hand towards the doctor's chair.

en: “You have money, and can buy the means of travelling to the seacoast as quickly as the journey can be made. Your preparations have been completed for some days, to return to England. Early to-morrow have your horses ready, so that they may be in starting trim at two o’clock in the afternoon.”
vi: You have money, and you can buy the fastest means to get to the coast for the journey. A few days ago, you had already prepared yourself to return to England. Early tomorrow morning, you must have horses and carriages ready so that you can depart exactly at two o'clock in the afternoon.
tr: "You have money and can obtain the necessary things as soon as you can travel to the opposite shore. Your preparations for the return to England were already complete. Have your horses ready early tomorrow, so you can set off at two in the afternoon."
es: —You should not encounter difficulties, as you have plenty of money, to reach the coast using the fastest means of transportation. You have already completed your preparations to return to England several days ago. Give orders for the horses to be harnessed tomorrow to start the journey at two in the afternoon.

en: “It shall be done!”
vi: − It will be taken care of!
tr: "Alright!""
es: —They will be.

en: His manner was so fervent and inspiring, that Mr. Lorry caught the flame, and was as quick as youth.
vi: Carton's enthusiastic and contagious demeanor made Mr. Lorry feel invigorated and agile like a young man. −
tr: Carton was in such an enthusiastic and excited state that this fire had also engulfed Mr. Lorry, suddenly making him feel younger and more lively.
es: —Didn't I say before that it was impossible to put the matter in better hands?

en: “You are a noble heart. Did I say we could depend upon no better man? Tell her, to-night, what you know of her danger as involving her child and her father. Dwell upon that, for she would lay her own fair head beside her husband’s cheerfully.” He faltered for an instant; then went on as before. “For the sake of her child and her father, press upon her the necessity of leaving Paris, with them and you, at that hour. Tell her that it was her husband’s last arrangement. Tell her that more depends upon it than she dare believe, or hope. You think that her father, even in this sad state, will submit himself to her; do you not?”
vi: You are a noble person. I told you that no one could be more reliable. Tonight, tell Lucie what you know about the danger that awaits and involves both her father and her child. Emphasize that because Lucie is ready to die with her husband. - He hesitated for a moment and then continued. - For the sake of the child and her father, urge Lucie to leave Paris immediately, at that hour, with you and her entire family. Tell her this is her husband's final arrangement. Tell Lucie that everything depends on this, more than she can imagine or hope for. According to him, in this unfortunate situation, would her father comply with his daughter's wishes?
tr: "You have a noble heart. Did I mention that there couldn't be a better man for this job than you? Tonight, tell her about the danger she is in, which also includes her child and her father. Emphasize this well, or else she will gladly lay her beautiful head next to her husband's." After a moment of hesitation, he continued as before. "For the sake of her child and her father, convince her that it is essential to leave Paris with you all at that hour. Tell her that this is her husband's last wish. Tell her that much more than she thinks or hopes depends on this. Do you think her father, in his current state of distress, would follow her advice?"
es: You have a heart full of nobility. Tonight, tell her that you know the danger looming over her head, and that this danger may also involve her daughter and her father. Insist on this point, because if you don't, it's likely that you won't achieve anything, as she, without hesitation, and even full of joy, would place her beautiful head next to her husband's, so that the same blow would make both of their heads roll. By insisting on the danger her daughter faces and the threat to her father, make her see the imperative need to leave Paris tomorrow at the indicated time, with them and with you. Tell her that it is her husband's wish, an express wish on whose fulfillment much more depends than she can suppose or expect. Don't you think that her father, despite the lamentable condition of his mind, will submit to his daughter's wishes?

en: “I am sure of it.”
vi: − I am sure he would.
tr: "I'm sure of this."
es: —I am sure of it.

en: “I thought so. Quietly and steadily have all these arrangements made in the courtyard here, even to the taking of your own seat in the carriage. The moment I come to you, take me in, and drive away.”
vi: − I think so too. Silently and quietly prepare everything right in this yard, even if he has to sit in the car ready. As soon as I meet him, I get in the car and leave immediately.
tr: "I thought the same." "Make your preparations in the courtyard here, quietly and quickly, and even take your place in the car." "As soon as I come to you, you will let me in and we will set off.""
es: —I supposed so. Above all, have everything ready for the indicated time. The car prepared, the horses hitched, and you all seated in your places. The moment I arrive, place me in the car, and off we go.

en: “I understand that I wait for you under all circumstances?”
vi: − So, in any situation, we have to wait for you?
tr: "Whatever happens, we should wait for you, is that right?"
es: —Should I await your arrival, no matter what happens?

en: “You have my certificate in your hand with the rest, you know, and will reserve my place. Wait for nothing but to have my place occupied, and then for England!”
vi: − You've already kept my passport along with everyone else's, and you must save a spot for me. No hesitation at all, I arrive and leave immediately, back to England! −
tr: "You know you have my exit document along with the others, make sure to reserve my spot. Just wait for me to arrive, then straight to England!"
es: —You have my safe-conduct in your possession, along with the others, a safe-conduct that entitles me to a seat. You will wait until that seat is occupied, and as soon as it is, to England as quickly as possible.

en: “Why, then,” said Mr. Lorry, grasping his eager but so firm and steady hand, “it does not all depend on one old man, but I shall have a young and ardent man at my side.”
vi: Oh, - Mr. Lorry grasped Carton's calm and resolute hand tightly, - then it's not just this old man to rely on, but we also have a passionate young man by our side.
tr: "Well, then," said Mr. Lorry, shaking Carton's excited but firm and strong hand, "this matter does not depend solely on an old man like me, because there will be a young and eager man by my side."
es: —In that case—remarked Lorry, giving Carton a firm handshake,—everything no longer depends on a poor old man, since I will have by my side a passionate and determined young man.

en: “By the help of Heaven you shall! Promise me solemnly that nothing will influence you to alter the course on which we now stand pledged to one another.”
vi: − With God's help, you will be satisfied! You must promise me firmly that nothing can change the plan we have committed to here.
tr: "With God's help, everything will happen!" "Now, please promise me that you will not change this plan we have made, no matter what.""
es: —With God's help, you will have it! Promise me now solemnly that for nothing in the world will you alter or modify anything we have agreed upon.

en: “Nothing, Carton.”
vi: − Certainly, Carton.
tr: "I promise, Carton.""
es: —Nothing, Carton; I swear.

en: “Remember these words to-morrow: change the course, or delay in it—for any reason—and no life can possibly be saved, and many lives must inevitably be sacrificed.”
vi: − Tomorrow, you must remember these words; if you change the plan or delay for any reason, you will not be able to save anyone and will certainly cause many people to sacrifice their lives.
tr: "Do not forget these words tomorrow; for whatever reason, if there is any change or delay in our plan, no one's life will be saved and unfortunately, many lives will be wasted.""
es: —Tomorrow, try to frequently remember these words: "A variation... a delay... whatever the cause it obeys, it can jeopardize the salvation of everyone's lives and inevitably lead to the sacrifice of many others."

en: “I will remember them. I hope to do my part faithfully.”
vi: − I will remember. I hope to fulfill my part.
tr: "I will not forget. I will try to fulfill my part exactly."
es: —I will remember them. I hope that God will give me the strength to faithfully fulfill my mission.

en: “And I hope to do mine. Now, good bye!”
vi: − And I hope to fulfill my part completely. Now, goodbye!
tr: "I hope I can do it too. Goodbye!"
es: —I also hope that I will not lack anything to fulfill mine. And now... goodbye.

en: Though he said it with a grave smile of earnestness, and though he even put the old man’s hand to his lips, he did not part from him then. He helped him so far to arouse the rocking figure before the dying embers, as to get a cloak and hat put upon it, and to tempt it forth to find where the bench and work were hidden that it still moaningly besought to have. He walked on the other side of it and protected it to the courtyard of the house where the afflicted heart—so happy in the memorable time when he had revealed his own desolate heart to it—outwatched the awful night. He entered the courtyard and remained there for a few moments alone, looking up at the light in the window of her room. Before he went away, he breathed a blessing towards it, and a Farewell.
vi: Though he spoke with a solemn and sincere smile and even kissed the old man's hand, he did not leave immediately. He helped Mr. Lorry lift Dr. Manette, who had been sitting and rocking before the dying embers in the fireplace, to his feet, put the doctor's hat and coat on, and soothed him to stop lamenting about finding the hidden workbench with the shoes. He walked beside the doctor, leading him to Lucie's courtyard, where the sorrowful girl kept vigil through the dreadful night, the girl who once was happy when he confessed his lonely heart to her. He stepped into the courtyard and stood alone for a few minutes, looking up at the light in her window. Before leaving, he sent a kiss and a final farewell to that place with the wind.
tr: Carton said these words with a sincere and dignified smile, and even kissed the old man's hand, but he did not leave his side immediately. He helped Mr. Lorry to lift the swaying body from in front of the dying embers, to put on his coat and hat, and to persuade this person, who was groaning and pleading about his bench and work, to go outside to find them. He walked beside him and supported him by directing him to the courtyard of the house; his sorrowful heart was watching the dreadful night – whereas once, when he opened his own ruined heart to him, he was so happy. Carton entered the courtyard and, looking at the light of his window, waited there for a few minutes. Before leaving, with his eyes still on the light, he prayed silently for him and said, "Farewell," to him.
es: He did not leave, however, although after pronouncing the farewell word, he brought to his lips and kissed the hand that Lorry extended to him. First, he helped the doctor up from the chair, put on his coat and hat, and encouraged him to leave, telling him they were going to fetch the stool and shoes he desired. He accompanied the two elderly men to the garden of the house where a wounded heart wept, so happy in other times, and when they left him alone, he remained for a few moments contemplating a window, whose shutters let out some threads of light, the window of her room. Before leaving, his heart sent a solemn farewell to the window wrapped in a beautiful cloud of blessings.

en: CHAPTER XIII.
vi: 13. In the Conciergerie dungeon, those who have been sentenced await their fateful day, their number equal to the weeks of a year.
tr: Thirteen
es: Chapter XIII.

en: Fifty-two
vi: 13. In the Conciergerie dungeon, those who have been sentenced await their fateful day, their number equal to the weeks of a year.
tr: Fifty Two
es: FIFTY-TWO

en: In the black prison of the Conciergerie, the doomed of the day awaited their fate. They were in number as the weeks of the year. Fifty-two were to roll that afternoon on the life-tide of the city to the boundless everlasting sea. Before their cells were quit of them, new occupants were appointed; before their blood ran into the blood spilled yesterday, the blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow was already set apart.
vi: 13. In the Conciergerie dungeon, those who have been sentenced await their fateful day, their number equal to the weeks of a year. Fifty-two people that evening will be swept away by the tide of the capital's life into the boundless sea. They have not yet left the dungeon, but new occupants have already been designated; their blood has not yet mingled with the blood spilled yesterday, yet the blood that will mingle with theirs tomorrow has already been chosen.
tr: In the dark prison of the Conciergerie, the prisoners of the day were awaiting their fate. Their number was as many as the weeks in a year. These fifty-two people would be swept away that afternoon by the tide of life in the city into the vast and immortal sea. Even before their cells were emptied, they had found new occupants; before their blood could mix with the blood spilled the previous day, it would mix with the blood to be spilled the next day.
es: Enclosed within blackened walls, the condemned of the day awaited the hour to ascend the scaffold in the sinister prison of the Concierge. They were as many as the weeks in a year. Fifty-two human lives were to be lost that afternoon in the insatiable sea that absorbs them all. Before their cells were emptied, those who would replace them had already been designated; before their blood flowed over the blood spilled the previous day, the blood that would mix with theirs the following day had already been set aside in a separate place.

en: Two score and twelve were told off. From the farmer-general of seventy, whose riches could not buy his life, to the seamstress of twenty, whose poverty and obscurity could not save her. Physical diseases, engendered in the vices and neglects of men, will seize on victims of all degrees; and the frightful moral disorder, born of unspeakable suffering, intolerable oppression, and heartless indifference, smote equally without distinction.
vi: Fifty-two people have been sentenced. From the seventy-year-old tax collector whose wealth couldn't buy his life, to the twenty-year-old seamstress whose poor and obscure status couldn't save her future. The plague, originating from the unintentional malice of humans, will seize victims from all walks of life; and the terrifying moral madness, born from indescribable suffering, unbearable oppression, and indifferent apathy, will strike down anyone.
tr: Two people's names were read aloud. Among them were many individuals, ranging from the seventy-year-old landowner whose immense wealth was not enough to buy his own life, to the twenty-year-old seamstress whose poverty and invisibility were not enough to save her. The diseases born from the evils and neglect affected all the victims equally; that dreadful moral decay, the unbearable pressure born from unspeakable hardships, and the heartless indifference struck everyone in the same way without any discrimination.
es: Fifty-two lives cut short, fifty-two victims, belonging to all social classes; from the wealthy seventy-year-old landowner, whose riches were of no use in prolonging his life, to the wretched laborer, whose obscurity and misery could not save him either. In the same way that physical diseases, which originate from the vices and neglects of men, claim their victims without regard to categories or ages, so too do the dreadful moral ailments, engendered by unspeakable sufferings, intolerable oppressions, and cruel indifferences, strike equally and without distinction of persons.

en: Charles Darnay, alone in a cell, had sustained himself with no flattering delusion since he came to it from the Tribunal. In every line of the narrative he had heard, he had heard his condemnation. He had fully comprehended that no personal influence could possibly save him, that he was virtually sentenced by the millions, and that units could avail him nothing.
vi: Alone in the dungeon, Charles Darnay harbored no illusions since he left the courtroom. In every line of the narrative read there, he heard his own sentence. He understood clearly that no personal force could save him, he had been virtually condemned by millions of people, and no one could do anything for him anymore.
tr: Charles Darnay, who was waiting alone in his cell, had not indulged in any idle fantasies since he came from the trial. In every line of the read statement, he had heard his own condemnation. He had understood very well that no individual effort would be enough to save him, that he was judged by millions, and that individual efforts would be of no use.
es: Carlos Darnay, locked in his cell alone with his thoughts, harbored no illusions since he left the Hall of Justice. In every word of the terrible narrative read there, he saw a death sentence, and it was clear to him that no human influence could save him, that virtually a sentence pronounced by millions of votes weighed upon him, against which individual efforts were of no use.

en: Nevertheless, it was not easy, with the face of his beloved wife fresh before him, to compose his mind to what it must bear. His hold on life was strong, and it was very, very hard, to loosen; by gradual efforts and degrees unclosed a little here, it clenched the tighter there; and when he brought his strength to bear on that hand and it yielded, this was closed again. There was a hurry, too, in all his thoughts, a turbulent and heated working of his heart, that contended against resignation. If, for a moment, he did feel resigned, then his wife and child who had to live after him, seemed to protest and to make it a selfish thing.
vi: However, he did not easily accept the fate awaiting him as the image of his beloved wife's face remained vividly imprinted in his mind. He clung tightly to life, finding it very difficult, very difficult to let go; if one hand grew weary and lost its grip slightly, the other hand would cling even tighter; and when one hand, having exerted all its strength to hold on to life, loosened its grip, the other hand would hold on firmly. Thoughts surged through his mind, and the fervent beating of his heart did not allow him to give in to death. If at any moment he felt discouraged by the thought of his wife becoming a widow and his children becoming orphans, he would see giving up as selfish and continue to resist.
tr: On the other hand, enduring all this was not easy while the face of his beloved wife was on his mind. He was tightly bound to life, and loosening this bond was difficult; if he tried to loosen it slightly from one point, it would strengthen even more at another point; even if he managed to break it with all his might, it would soon reattach. There was also an urgency in his thoughts, his heart was beating with great excitement and anger, resisting to not submit to his fate. If for a moment he seemed to submit to his fate, his wife and child, who would be left behind, would object, pointing out how selfish this situation was.
es: It was not, however, an easy task to resign oneself to dying, for someone like him who still kept the image of his beloved wife fresh in his mind. Very strong ties bound him to life, and it was hard, very hard, to see so closely the blade that would cut them forever. His thoughts tumbled over each other, agitated tumultuously in his chest, fought fierce battles among themselves, and in the end, they joined forces to contend against resignation. If he momentarily managed to calm them, the image of his wife immediately surfaced, the image of his tender daughter, he remembered that he was leaving them in the world, and he protested against it with all the strength of his soul, no less than if the sharpest selfishness were encouraging him in his chest.

en: But, all this was at first. Before long, the consideration that there was no disgrace in the fate he must meet, and that numbers went the same road wrongfully, and trod it firmly every day, sprang up to stimulate him. Next followed the thought that much of the future peace of mind enjoyable by the dear ones, depended on his quiet fortitude. So, by degrees he calmed into the better state, when he could raise his thoughts much higher, and draw comfort down.
vi: But that was only at the beginning. Soon after, he realized that the death he had to face was not shameful at all, and he felt more encouraged when he thought about how many people had walked that unjust path daily, and they still bravely trampled over death. Then he thought that it was his calm resilience that would help his loved ones live peacefully in the future. So gradually, he felt more at ease and could think about happier things for peace of mind.
tr: But all these were his initial feelings. Soon, the idea that the fate awaiting him was not something to be ashamed of, that many people were driven to this unjust path every day and faced it bravely, gave him strength. What followed was the thought that the inner peace and comfort of his loved ones depended on his own calm composure. Thus, as a result of these positive thoughts, Charles was able to gradually relax and calm down a bit.
es: It is true that these struggles did not last long. It wasn't long before the consideration that the death awaiting him did not carry the appendage of dishonor acted as a powerful stimulant, and the thought that many, as innocent as he, walked the same painful path he had to walk every day and with firm steps. He then thought of the future peace of mind that, after the initial moments, his loved ones left in the world would enjoy if they saw him accept death with manly fortitude, and in this way, little by little and by degrees, he began to regain his calm and immerse himself in reflections of a higher nature.

en: Before it had set in dark on the night of his condemnation, he had travelled thus far on his last way. Being allowed to purchase the means of writing, and a light, he sat down to write until such time as the prison lamps should be extinguished.
vi: Before nightfall on the day he was sentenced to death, Darnay was in that calm state of mind. Allowed to buy paper, pen, and a lamp, he sat down to write letters until the prison required the lights to be extinguished.
tr: These were the last thoughts wandering in his mind before night fell and everything turned dark, following his conviction. Since he had permission to get materials and light for writing, he sat down to write until the dungeon lanterns went out.
es: Before the night closed in, he had advanced most of the way on the journey of his resignation. Equipped with writing materials and a light, he took up the pen and did not put it down until the hour came when the prison regulations required the lamps to be extinguished.

en: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, showing her that he had known nothing of her father’s imprisonment, until he had heard of it from herself, and that he had been as ignorant as she of his father’s and uncle’s responsibility for that misery, until the paper had been read. He had already explained to her that his concealment from herself of the name he had relinquished, was the one condition—fully intelligible now—that her father had attached to their betrothal, and was the one promise he had still exacted on the morning of their marriage. He entreated her, for her father’s sake, never to seek to know whether her father had become oblivious of the existence of the paper, or had had it recalled to him (for the moment, or for good), by the story of the Tower, on that old Sunday under the dear old plane-tree in the garden. If he had preserved any definite remembrance of it, there could be no doubt that he had supposed it destroyed with the Bastille, when he had found no mention of it among the relics of prisoners which the populace had discovered there, and which had been described to all the world. He besought her—though he added that he knew it was needless—to console her father, by impressing him through every tender means she could think of, with the truth that he had done nothing for which he could justly reproach himself, but had uniformly forgotten himself for their joint sakes. Next to her preservation of his own last grateful love and blessing, and her overcoming of her sorrow, to devote herself to their dear child, he adjured her, as they would meet in Heaven, to comfort her father.
vi: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, expressing that he had no knowledge of her father's imprisonment until he heard it from her, and that neither he nor she knew that the ones causing this suffering were his own father and uncle until they heard the court read those papers. He explained to her that hiding his forsaken name from her was a condition - now clear - that her father had attached to his daughter's marriage contract, and it was a promise he had fulfilled on the morning of the wedding. He begged her, for Dr. Manette's sake, never to seek whether her father had forgotten the existence of that testament, or had been reminded of it (temporarily or permanently) by the story of the Tower of London prison he had told one Sunday afternoon under the plane tree in the garden. If Dr. Manette remembered anything about that testament, he would surely believe it had been destroyed along with the Bastille prison, as he had never heard mention of those papers among the remnants of the prisoners that the crowd had found and displayed to the world. He implored - though he added that he knew this was unnecessary - that she comfort Dr. Manette with all the affection she could give her father, because he had done nothing to blame himself for, and in fact, he had only selflessly united her and him. At the end of the letter, after thanking her for giving him all her love and happiness, and advising her to overcome her sorrow to care for their beloved child, he asked her to think of the day they would meet again in Heaven to console her old father.
tr: He wrote a long letter to Lucie, explaining that until he heard from her, he knew nothing about his father's imprisonment, just like her, he was unaware of his father's and uncle's involvement in this disaster, and he learned about it when the paper was read. He had already explained to her that the reason he hid the name he had stopped using was because it was a condition set by his father before their engagement – the reason for this was now understood – and that he still insisted on this on the morning of their wedding. For the sake of his father, he begged his wife never to ask his father whether he had forgotten about the existence of this paper or whether he remembered it during the story of the tower told under that beautiful old plane tree in the garden on a Sunday. Even if it had occurred to him, he undoubtedly assumed it had been destroyed along with the Bastille, because among the belongings of the prisoners that the public disclosed, there was no mention of this writing. Using every conceivable means, he asked his wife to comfort his father by reiterating that there was no need for him to blame himself, only that he had forgotten himself for their well-being and unity – adding that there was no need to say this. Then he begged her not to forget how much he loved her and how grateful he was to her, to bury her sorrow and dedicate herself to their beloved children and to comforting his father, saying that they would one day be reunited in heaven.
es: He wrote a very lengthy letter to Lucía, demonstrating to her that he had never had any news of her father's eternal captivity until he heard it from the man's own lips, and that, prior to reading the document found in the Bastille, he was as ignorant as she was of the direct culpability of her father and uncle in that sad event. He had already explained to her that, if he had concealed his true surname, a surname he had renounced, it was to fulfill a condition, whose reason he now perfectly understood, imposed by the doctor when giving his consent to the romantic relationship with his daughter, and ratified on the morning of their wedding. He earnestly begged her that, for the love of her father, she should never attempt to find out whether he had forgotten the existence of the document, or whether the story of the Tower of London told under the plane tree in the garden that summer night had reminded him of it. If he retained any memory of the document in question, he undoubtedly assumed it had been destroyed with the Bastille, seeing that it was not among the relics of the prisoners found by the mob and made so public that the entire world knew of them. He urged her—though adding that he already knew the recommendation was futile—to console her father, convincing him, by all imaginable means, that not only had he done nothing reprehensible, nothing that would have caused his misfortune, but that, on the contrary, he had always sacrificed himself for the happiness of his daughter and his daughter's husband. He ended by recommending that she try to overcome her sorrow, devote herself to her beloved daughter, and above all, that through sheer tenderness she console her father.

en: To her father himself, he wrote in the same strain; but, he told her father that he expressly confided his wife and child to his care. And he told him this, very strongly, with the hope of rousing him from any despondency or dangerous retrospect towards which he foresaw he might be tending.
vi: The letter to Dr. Manette, he also wrote with that intention, but he entrusted his wife and children to the doctor's care. He wrote very strong words asking for the doctor's help, hoping that his father-in-law would escape all the dreary and dangerous recollections of the past, which he foresaw would inevitably trouble him.
tr: He wrote a letter to Lucie's father in the same tone and expressed that he particularly entrusted his wife and child to him. The reason he emphasized this so much was his hope to keep him away from a potential state of despair and negative thoughts about the past.
es: He wrote another letter to the doctor inspired by the same thoughts, telling him that he entrusted his wife and daughter to his care. With vibrant phrasing, he made this request, not because he considered it necessary, but rather to lift his spirits and drive away retrospective thoughts, which he assumed would arise more strongly than ever.

en: To Mr. Lorry, he commended them all, and explained his worldly affairs. That done, with many added sentences of grateful friendship and warm attachment, all was done. He never thought of Carton. His mind was so full of the others, that he never once thought of him.
vi: Write to Mr. Lorry, entrusting everyone to him and explaining his property matters. Then, he adds a few sentences of heartfelt gratitude at the end of the letter and finishes. Darnay never thought of Carton. His mind was filled with images of others, not once remembering that friend.
tr: In the letter he wrote to Mr. Lorry, he entrusted everything to him and provided explanations regarding worldly matters. Then, adding sentences expressing how grateful he was for his friendship and warm interest, he finished the letter, and everything was over. Carton never crossed his mind. His mind was so occupied with others that he didn't think of him even for a moment.
es: He addressed a letter to Mr. Lorry, entrusting to his care the loved ones he was leaving behind and explaining all his earthly matters. He did not remember Carton. There were so many thoughts overwhelming him that they left no room for a person with whom he never had frequent interactions.

en: He had time to finish these letters before the lights were put out. When he lay down on his straw bed, he thought he had done with this world.
vi: He managed to finish writing the letters before having to put out the light. As he lay down on the straw bed, he thought he was ready to die.
tr: He had managed to finish all these letters before the lamps were extinguished. When he lay down on his bed, he thought that his work in this world was over.
es: When the lights went out and he lay down on the miserable straw mattress, he thought he had already finished with the world.

en: But, it beckoned him back in his sleep, and showed itself in shining forms. Free and happy, back in the old house in Soho (though it had nothing in it like the real house), unaccountably released and light of heart, he was with Lucie again, and she told him it was all a dream, and he had never gone away. A pause of forgetfulness, and then he had even suffered, and had come back to her, dead and at peace, and yet there was no difference in him. Another pause of oblivion, and he awoke in the sombre morning, unconscious where he was or what had happened, until it flashed upon his mind, “this is the day of my death!”
vi: But life calls him back and manifests in many radiant forms. Free and happy, he returns to the old house in Soho (though inside it resembles nothing like the real house), somehow escaping death, joyfully beside Lucie again, and she tells him all the hardships endured were just a dream, and he had never left at all. For a moment he forgets everything, then he finds himself sentenced to death and returns to her, dying peacefully, but nothing changes within him. Another moment of forgetfulness, and he wakes up in a foggy morning, not knowing where he is or what has happened, until he suddenly realizes, "Today is the day I die!".
tr: However, the world in its slumber called him back and showed itself to him in all its brilliance. Free and happy, he was back in the old house in Soho (though nothing inside matched the reality), with an incredible sense of peace and relief, he was with Lucie again, and his wife was telling him that it had all been a dream and that he hadn't gone anywhere. A sleep interval where he remembered nothing, then he saw the pains he had endured and returned to his wife's side, dead but peaceful, and there was no difference in between. Then another interval where he remembered nothing, and then he opened his eyes to a gloomy morning, unable to understand where he was or what he was for a moment, until that thought flashed in his mind, "Today is my execution day!"
es: However, he resurfaced during his sleep, and he resurfaced brilliant, charming. He found himself again in the quiet little corner of Soho, free, happy, content, in the company of his Lucia, who assured him that it had all been a dream, a nightmare, that they had never left England, that he had never been separated from her. This dream was followed by a pause of complete forgetfulness, after which he imagined that he lived with his wife, but dead, decapitated. Another pause of forgetfulness ensued, and he finally woke up in the morning, without realizing where he was or remembering what had happened the day before, until these words sprang into his mind in fiery characters: "Today is the day of your death."

en: Thus, had he come through the hours, to the day when the fifty-two heads were to fall. And now, while he was composed, and hoped that he could meet the end with quiet heroism, a new action began in his waking thoughts, which was very difficult to master.
vi: He had gone through such moments until the day when fifty-two heads would fall. At this moment, although he was calm and hoped to face death with silent bravery, new thoughts emerged in his mind, causing him concern.
tr: That's why the hours had passed like this until the day fifty-two heads would be cut off. Now, no matter how calm he was and hoped to face death with quiet heroism, a new idea, which was very difficult to control, had begun to emerge in his mind.
es: It was the day when fifty-two heads were to roll, one of them his own, and while resigned to his sad fate, he gathered his courage to endure it with calm heroism, his thoughts, very difficult to control, feverishly embarked on new paths.

en: He had never seen the instrument that was to terminate his life. How high it was from the ground, how many steps it had, where he would be stood, how he would be touched, whether the touching hands would be dyed red, which way his face would be turned, whether he would be the first, or might be the last: these and many similar questions, in nowise directed by his will, obtruded themselves over and over again, countless times. Neither were they connected with fear: he was conscious of no fear. Rather, they originated in a strange besetting desire to know what to do when the time came; a desire gigantically disproportionate to the few swift moments to which it referred; a wondering that was more like the wondering of some other spirit within his, than his own.
vi: He had never seen the instrument that would end his life. How tall was it compared to the ground, how many steps led up to it, where would he stand, how would he be pushed, were the hands touching him stained with blood, which direction would his face be turned, would he be the first or the last?... Even though he didn't want to, such questions kept intruding into his mind incessantly. They had nothing to do with fear; he was not afraid at all. On the contrary, they stemmed from a strange desire that kept haunting him, a desire to know what to do when the time came; a desire so immense compared to the fleeting moments on the scaffold; a bewilderment as if another soul, not him, was trying to understand.
tr: He had never seen the device that would end his life before. How high was it from the ground, how many steps did it have, where would he stand, how would they touch him, would the hands that touched him be stained red, which way would his face be turned, would he go first or last? These and many similar questions kept swirling in his mind, beyond his control, refusing to leave his thoughts. None of them stemmed from fear; there was no specific fear within him. Rather, it was an unsettling and strange desire to know what to do when the time came, and this desire was much greater compared to the brief time he would spend there; it was as if there was another soul within him wanting to learn all these things.
es: He had never seen the terrible instrument that hours later would cut his life short. How high above the ground the gloomy machine would be, how many steps the fatal staircase had, where it would be placed, whose hands would be responsible for placing him on the block, whether they would be stained with blood, which way he would turn his head, whether he would be the first or the last; these and other similar questions he asked himself over and over, hurriedly, not by his will, but by his overexcited imagination. Neither were they inspired by fear, but rather by a strange desire to know what he would do when the time came, a desire that was disproportionate to the fleeting moments to which it referred, an inexplicable curiosity felt by a soul different from his own.

en: The hours went on as he walked to and fro, and the clocks struck the numbers he would never hear again. Nine gone for ever, ten gone for ever, eleven gone for ever, twelve coming on to pass away. After a hard contest with that eccentric action of thought which had last perplexed him, he had got the better of it. He walked up and down, softly repeating their names to himself. The worst of the strife was over. He could walk up and down, free from distracting fancies, praying for himself and for them.
vi: The minutes kept passing by as he walked back and forth, the clock striking chimes that he would never hear again. Nine o'clock gone forever, ten o'clock gone forever, eleven o'clock gone forever, twelve o'clock about to pass. After a difficult struggle with the strange thoughts that had disturbed his mind, he finally managed to overcome them. He walked back and forth, silently calling the names of his loved ones. The most distressing inner conflicts had ended. He could walk back and forth, free from disturbing thoughts, to pray for himself and his loved ones.
tr: As he paced back and forth in his cell, time was slipping away, the hours striking minutes he would never hear again. Nine passed, ten passed, eleven passed, and twelve was approaching to pass forever as well. After struggling with all these confusing thoughts for quite a while, he regained some composure. Then, softly repeating their names, he walked up and down. The most challenging part of the inner struggle had ended. Setting aside the dreams that clouded his mind, he was able to walk up and down, praying for himself and his loved ones.
es: Time passed and the clock struck hours that the unfortunate man would never hear again. Nine, ten, eleven o'clock struck, and it was about to strike twelve. The condemned man walked more calmly each time. The worst of the internal struggle had passed. His imagination was no longer disturbed by absurd thoughts, he could now pray for himself and his loved ones.

en: Twelve gone for ever.
vi: Twelve o'clock leaves forever.
tr: Twelve went on forever.
es: The clock struck twelve.

en: He had been apprised that the final hour was Three, and he knew he would be summoned some time earlier, inasmuch as the tumbrils jolted heavily and slowly through the streets. Therefore, he resolved to keep Two before his mind, as the hour, and so to strengthen himself in the interval that he might be able, after that time, to strengthen others.
vi: He was informed that the final hour was three o'clock, and knew that he would be called before that time because the wagons carrying the condemned would rumble and roll very sluggishly through the streets. Therefore, he resolved that by two o'clock he must strengthen his own spirit firmly so that afterwards he could strengthen the spirits of others.
tr: He had been told that he would be taken at three o'clock; but he knew he would be called earlier because the cars were moving very slowly and heavily on the streets. Therefore, he prepared himself for two o'clock; this way, he would have time to both strengthen himself and give strength to others.
es: They had told him that the final hour that would strike for him in the world would be three o'clock, and he knew that they would take him out of the dungeon well before the indicated hour, as the death carts traveled very slowly on the way to the gallows. He supposed, therefore, that they would call him at two.

en: Walking regularly to and fro with his arms folded on his breast, a very different man from the prisoner, who had walked to and fro at La Force, he heard One struck away from him, without surprise. The hour had measured like most other hours. Devoutly thankful to Heaven for his recovered self-possession, he thought, “There is but another now,” and turned to walk again.
vi: Steadily pacing back and forth, with his arms folded across his chest, a man completely different from the prisoner who once paced in the La Force prison before, he heard the clock strike one without a hint of surprise. An hour passed like every other hour. Wholeheartedly thanking God for allowing him to regain his composure, he thought to himself, "Only one more hour," and continued walking.
tr: With his hands clasped on his chest, he walked back and forth with steady steps. He was a different man from the prisoner walking back and forth in La Force, and he was not surprised when he heard the clock strike one. This was no different from other hours. Thanking God with great sincerity for being able to pull himself together, he thought, "Now there's just one hour left," and turned around to continue walking.
es: With his arms crossed in front of his chest, he was pacing his cell when the clock struck one; he did not lose his heroic calm. Fervently, he gave thanks to God for having given him the strength to regain his composure, and he thought: "I have another hour left."

en: Footsteps in the stone passage outside the door. He stopped.
vi: There were footsteps on the stone-paved corridor outside the prison cell. He stopped.
tr: Then, he heard footsteps in the stone passage. He paused his walk.
es: The sound of footsteps echoed in the outer passage. The door of his cell opened and closed again without a sound.

en: The key was put in the lock, and turned. Before the door was opened, or as it opened, a man said in a low voice, in English: “He has never seen me here; I have kept out of his way. Go you in alone; I wait near. Lose no time!”
vi: The sound of a key being inserted into the lock, and turning. The door had not yet opened when a voice was heard, speaking softly in English: − He has no idea I'm here; I've been avoiding him for a long time. You go in alone; I will wait nearby. Don't waste time!
tr: The key was inserted into the lock and turned. Before the door opened or just as it was opening, a man said in a low voice in English, "You never saw me here; we didn't meet. Now go alone; I will wait here. Come on, don't waste time!"
es: The door of his cell opened and closed again without a sound. Someone said these words by the door, already open, or while they were opening it: "He has never seen me here, as I have always taken care to stay out of his way. Go in... I will wait outside... Don't waste time."

en: The door was quickly opened and closed, and there stood before him face to face, quiet, intent upon him, with the light of a smile on his features, and a cautionary finger on his lip, Sydney Carton.
vi: The door opened and closed quickly, and standing there facing him, silently, attentively, with a fleeting smile on his face, a warning finger placed on his lips, was Sydney Carton.
tr: The door had quickly opened and closed, and standing directly opposite, silently and resolutely, with a sparkling smile on his face, and his finger brought to his lips as if to warn for silence, was Sydney Carton.
es: In front of the prisoner appeared a man who looked at him smiling, calm. It was Sydney Carton.

en: There was something so bright and remarkable in his look, that, for the first moment, the prisoner misdoubted him to be an apparition of his own imagining. But, he spoke, and it was his voice; he took the prisoner’s hand, and it was his real grasp.
vi: Carton's face showed an unusually radiant expression, making the prisoner Darnay think for a moment that it was a ghost conjured up by his imagination. But Carton spoke, and it was indeed his voice; Carton took the prisoner's hand, and it was truly his hand gripping tightly.
tr: His gaze was so bright and impressive that, at first, the prisoner thought he was his own imagination. But when he opened his mouth, he realized it was his voice; Carton took the prisoner's hand, and the hand that grasped his was indeed his own.
es: Such was the expression on his face, so remarkable his gaze, that in the first instant the prisoner feared it was an unreal apparition, a product of his agitated imagination. But the apparition spoke, and the tone of his voice was that of Carton; he clasped the prisoner's hand, and his hand was a real hand, of flesh and bone.

en: “Of all the people upon earth, you least expected to see me?” he said.
vi: − You couldn't have expected to meet me and not someone else? Carton said. −
tr: "I was probably the last person you expected to see, wasn't I?" said Carton.
es: —I bet I am the last human being you would expect to see: am I wrong?

en: “I could not believe it to be you. I can scarcely believe it now. You are not”—the apprehension came suddenly into his mind—“a prisoner?”
vi: It's unbelievable that it's you. Even now, I still can't believe it. It's not you... - A sudden worry arose in Darnay's mind. - ... You haven't been imprisoned, have you?
tr: "I can't believe I'm seeing you. I really can't believe it. Or have you also" –he suddenly became worried– "been condemned?"
es: —I bet I am the last human being you would expect to see: am I wrong? —Not only did I not expect to see you, but even seeing you, I am doubting that the Sydney Carton I have known is standing before me... Are you also a prisoner?

en: “No. I am accidentally possessed of a power over one of the keepers here, and in virtue of it I stand before you. I come from her—your wife, dear Darnay.”
vi: − No. By chance, I have authority over a jailer here, and thanks to that, I am able to stand before you. She... your wife asked me to come, Mr. Darnay.
tr: "No. By a stroke of luck, I managed to influence one of the guards here, and that's why I'm standing before you now. I'm coming from her side now – from your wife's side, dear Darnay."
es: —No. Chance has made me the master of one of the jailers of this prison, and to that circumstance, I owe the fact that I am beside you. I come on her behalf... on behalf of your wife, my dear Darnay.

en: The prisoner wrung his hand.
vi: The prisoner tightly clasped Carton's hand.
tr: The prisoner rubbed his hands.
es: The prisoner silently extended his hand.

en: “I bring you a request from her.”
vi: − I am conveying her request to you. −
tr: "Your wife has a request from you.""
es: —And I bring the task of making a plea to you.

en: “What is it?”
vi: What is it? −
tr: "What is it?"
es: —What is it?

en: “A most earnest, pressing, and emphatic entreaty, addressed to you in the most pathetic tones of the voice so dear to you, that you well remember.”
vi: The most urgent and serious plea she has ever spoken in the most earnest voice that you are surely very familiar with and deeply remember.
tr: "With that touching voice you know and love so well, in the most heartfelt manner, persistently and stubbornly, they are begging you.""
es: —It is the most fervent plea, the most urgent, the most ardent of those that have been addressed to him by that voice which is so dear to him. Do not ignore it, because that dear voice addresses him with the most pathetic tone that has ever sounded in his ears.

en: The prisoner turned his face partly aside.
vi: The prisoner slightly turned his face away. −
tr: The prisoner slightly turned his head to the side.
es: The prisoner bowed his head without answering.

en: “You have no time to ask me why I bring it, or what it means; I have no time to tell you. You must comply with it—take off those boots you wear, and draw on these of mine.”
vi: There is no time left, don't ask why I am conveying the message or want to know the details; it's very urgent. You must follow... Take off the shoes you are wearing, and put on my shoes.
tr: "I don't have time to explain why I'm telling you this or what it means. You just need to do what I say – now take off your boots and put on mine."
es: —You don't have the time to ask me why I am the emissary tasked with making the plea in question, or to ask me for explanations about what it means, nor do I have the time to give them to you. Your duty... a sacred duty, is to obey without question... Take off your boots, and put on mine!

en: There was a chair against the wall of the cell, behind the prisoner. Carton, pressing forward, had already, with the speed of lightning, got him down into it, and stood over him, barefoot.
