vi: There is a chair placed against the wall of the room, behind the prisoner. Carton swiftly pushed Darnay to sit down, then stood up straight, his shoes already removed.
tr: There was a chair leaning against the wall behind the prisoner. Carton lunged forward, pushed him onto it at lightning speed, and stood barefoot at his head.
es: Attached to one of the walls, behind the convict, there was a chair. Carton, while speaking with lightning speed, had forced him to sit in the chair in question.

en: “Draw on these boots of mine. Put your hands to them; put your will to them. Quick!”
vi: − Bring me my shoes. Do as I say, use all your willpower. Quick!
tr: "Put on my boots. Be quick; hurry up. Quick!"
es: —Take off your shoes and put on these boots of mine... Quickly!...

en: “Carton, there is no escaping from this place; it never can be done. You will only die with me. It is madness.”
vi: − Carton, there is no way to escape from this place; it's impossible to escape. You will die with me. It's madness. −
tr: "Carton, there's no escape from here; we can never do this. You will die with me. This is madness."
es: —Carton... It is impossible to escape from here—replied Carlos, completely bewildered;—utterly impossible... You will achieve nothing but dying with me... It is madness....

en: “It would be madness if I asked you to escape; but do I? When I ask you to pass out at that door, tell me it is madness and remain here. Change that cravat for this of mine, that coat for this of mine. While you do it, let me take this ribbon from your hair, and shake out your hair like this of mine!”
vi: It would be madness if I asked you to escape; but did I say that? When I tell you to go out that door, then call me mad and stay here. Exchange your tie for mine; exchange your coat for mine. While you put on the coat, let me untie your hair ribbon, and you must shake your head to make your hair as disheveled as mine!
tr: "If I had asked you to run away with me, it would have been madness; but did I say such a thing? If I ask you to walk out that door, then tell me it's madness and wait for the scrap. Take off your tie and put on mine, take off your coat and wear mine. While you are changing these, I will take off that ribbon on your head and you also mess up your hair like mine!"
es: —It would be madness if I told you to escape; but have I even hinted at it? When I tell you to go through that door, answer me that it's madness and don't pay attention to me... Take off that tie and put on mine... That's it... Now the coat... We will exchange coats... Magnificent! Allow me to remove that ribbon that holds your hair, and to mess up your hairstyle a bit... that's it! Now you are as poorly groomed as I am.

en: With wonderful quickness, and with a strength both of will and action, that appeared quite supernatural, he forced all these changes upon him. The prisoner was like a young child in his hands.
vi: With extraordinary speed, and with almost superhuman strength of will and action, Carton forced Darnay to change clothes. The prisoner was like a child in his hands.
tr: It was with tremendous speed, a supernatural will, and an efficient power that all this was accomplished by Darnay. The prisoner was like a child in his hands.
es: With astonishing speed, with a willpower that seemed more supernatural than human, he transformed the prisoner in the blink of an eye. The convict seemed like a child without will in his hands.

en: “Carton! Dear Carton! It is madness. It cannot be accomplished, it never can be done, it has been attempted, and has always failed. I implore you not to add your death to the bitterness of mine.”
vi: − Carton! Carton! It's madness. It's impossible to escape, never has anyone escaped, many have tried and always failed. Please don't let my bitter fate drag you to death.
tr: "Carton! Dear Carton! This is madness. We will never succeed, we can never do this, it was tried before but no one succeeded. I beg you, do not add your own death to the pity."
es: —Carton... My dear Carton! It's madness... a folly! It's not possible to carry it out... It has never been achieved... Dozens of times they have tried and it has always resulted in the most resounding failure... For God's sake, my dear friend, I beg you not to increase my sorrows by sacrificing your life in vain...! Isn't it enough that I die?

en: “Do I ask you, my dear Darnay, to pass the door? When I ask that, refuse. There are pen and ink and paper on this table. Is your hand steady enough to write?”
vi: − Darnay, did I ask you to go out the door? When I say that, then refuse. There is paper and ink on the table. Can your hand still hold a pen steadily?
tr: "Do I want you to step out of that door, Darnay? If I ask for such a thing, oppose me. There are pen, ink, and paper on that table. Can you write without your hand trembling?"
es: —Have I by any chance told you, my dear Darnay, to go beyond that door? When I tell you, answer firmly that no, and the matter will be settled. I see paper, ink, and a pen on that table; do you have a steady hand? Can you write?

en: “It was when you came in.”
vi: − I was writing when you came in.
tr: "He wasn't trembling when he arrived."
es: —I had it firm when you came in.

en: “Steady it again, and write what I shall dictate. Quick, friend, quick!”
vi: − Then pick up the pen again and write as I dictate. Quickly, my friend, quickly!
tr: "Gene, take a note of what I'm saying. Come on, buddy, hurry up!"
es: —Well, it is necessary for him to be so again, so that he writes very clearly what I am going to dictate... Quickly, my friend, quickly!

en: Pressing his hand to his bewildered head, Darnay sat down at the table. Carton, with his right hand in his breast, stood close beside him.
vi: With a hand pressing his bewildered forehead, Darnay sat at the table. Carton, his right hand placed on his chest, stood beside him.
tr: Darnay sat holding his head in a state of confusion. Carton, on the other hand, stood right next to him with his right hand in the breast pocket of his coat.
es: Darnay, astonished, amazed, stunned, took a seat in front of the table. Carton, with his right hand placed on his chest, stood beside him.

en: “Write exactly as I speak.”
vi: − Write exactly as I dictate.
tr: "Write exactly what I say."
es: —Write down point by point what I dictate to you.

en: “To whom do I address it?”
vi: − To whom should I send this?
tr: "To whom shall I write?""
es: —To whom should I address the document?

en: “To no one.” Carton still had his hand in his breast.
vi: − To no one. - Carton's hand still rested on his chest.
tr: "To no one." Carton's hand was still on his chest.
es: —Nobody. Carton's right hand remained fixed over his chest.

en: “Do I date it?”
vi: − Write the date? − No.
tr: "Shall I write history?""
es: —Shall I set a date?

en: “No.”
vi: − Write the date? − No.
tr: "No."
es: —No.

en: The prisoner looked up, at each question. Carton, standing over him with his hand in his breast, looked down.
vi: The prisoner looked up after each question. With his hand still on his chest, Carton looked down. −
tr: The prisoner was looking up at every question. Carton, with his hand in his pocket, was looking down at him.
es: The prisoner raised his head every time he asked a question; Carton, without moving his right hand, looked at the ground.

en: “‘If you remember,’” said Carton, dictating, “‘the words that passed between us, long ago, you will readily comprehend this when you see it. You do remember them, I know. It is not in your nature to forget them.’”
vi: “If you remember,” - Carton read for Darnay to write, - “the private words between us long ago, you will understand immediately when you read these lines. You will remember those private words, I know. Because you are not one to easily forget.”
tr: "If you remember the conversation we had a long time ago," said Carton, slowly, "you will immediately understand what it means. You definitely remember it, I know. Forgetting is not something you would do."
es: "If you have not forgotten the words that passed between us," said Carton dictating, "you will easily understand this letter as soon as you read it." "I know positively that you remember them, for you are not one to forget quickly."

en: He was drawing his hand from his breast; the prisoner chancing to look up in his hurried wonder as he wrote, the hand stopped, closing upon something.
vi: He intended to lower his hand from his chest when the prisoner happened to look up with a confused expression at this urgent matter. Carton's hand stopped, gripping something tightly. −
tr: At this moment, Carton took his hand out of the pocket on his chest; the prisoner, taking advantage of the opportunity, lifted his head and looked at him with anxious curiosity and noticed that he had something in his hand.
es: The prisoner, who did not understand the meaning of what he was writing, unexpectedly raised his eyes and caught Carton in the act of taking his hand out of his chest. It stopped.

en: “Have you written ‘forget them’?” Carton asked.
vi: Have you finished writing “easily forget” yet? - Carton asked.
tr: "It's not for you, have you written it?" asked Carton.
es: —Have you written "they forget quickly?"

en: “I have. Is that a weapon in your hand?”
vi: − Yes. Is there a weapon in your hand? −
tr: "It's not for you, have you written it?" asked Carton. "I wrote, do you have a gun in your hand?"
es: —Yes. Do you have any weapon in your hand?

en: “No; I am not armed.”
vi: No, I have no weapon. −
tr: "No, I don't have any weapons on me."
es: —No; I don't have any weapons.

en: “What is it in your hand?”
vi: What are you holding in your hand then? −
tr: "What do you have in your hand then?"
es: —What does he/she have, then?

en: “You shall know directly. Write on; there are but a few words more.” He dictated again. “‘I am thankful that the time has come, when I can prove them. That I do so is no subject for regret or grief.’” As he said these words with his eyes fixed on the writer, his hand slowly and softly moved down close to the writer’s face.
vi: You will know soon enough. Keep writing; just a few more words. - Carton continued to read. - “How grateful I am that the time has come for me to prove those words. I do this without any regret or sorrow.” - As he read, he stared intently at the writer, Carton's hand slowly and discreetly moved closer to Darnay's face.
tr: "You will learn soon." "Keep writing; it's almost done." Then he dictated again. "I am very happy to see the days when I can prove the truth of my words." "Don't be upset or distressed because I did this." While saying these words, his hand slowly, gently descended to the prisoner's face, his eyes fixed on him.
es: —In a moment you will know... Continue writing, as there are very few words left... «I thank God who allows me to prove them with deeds. I would not want what I do to be a cause of sorrow or sadness for anyone.» While he dictated these words, his eyes fixed on the one who was writing, his right hand moved cautiously closer to the face of the prisoner.

en: The pen dropped from Darnay’s fingers on the table, and he looked about him vacantly.
vi: The pen fell from Darnay's fingers onto the table, and he stared around in a daze.
tr: The pen fell from Darnay's fingers onto the table, and Darnay looked at Carton with empty eyes.
es: The pen fell from Darnay's hand, who looked around with a dazed expression.

en: “What vapour is that?” he asked.
vi: − What was that breath?
tr: "Where did this mist come from?" he asked. "What is this steam?"
es: —What steamer is this?—he asked.

en: “Vapour?”
vi: - Darnay asked.
tr: "Something passed before my eyes."
es: —Steam?

en: “Something that crossed me?”
vi: − Breath? − A strange breath passed across my face?
tr: "Did I smell something?""
es: —Yes... a smell that bothers and stuns me.

en: “I am conscious of nothing; there can be nothing here. Take up the pen and finish. Hurry, hurry!”
vi: − I didn't see anything; there's nothing strange here. Finish writing. Quickly, quickly!
tr: "I didn't notice anything; but such a thing can't happen here. Take the pen and finish this. Hurry up, come on!"
es: —I perceive nothing... It is not possible that vapors are being inhaled here... Take up the pen again and let us finish... Quickly, quickly!

en: As if his memory were impaired, or his faculties disordered, the prisoner made an effort to rally his attention. As he looked at Carton with clouded eyes and with an altered manner of breathing, Carton—his hand again in his breast—looked steadily at him.
vi: As if his memory had faded, or his faculties had become disordered, the prisoner tried to concentrate. While Darnay looked up with a dazed expression and his breath changed to rapid gasps, Carton kept staring at Darnay, his hand again placed inside his coat. −
tr: The prisoner, who seemed to have his memory damaged or lost his faculties, tried to concentrate. With blurred eyes, barely breathing, he looked at Carton, who –with his hand again on his chest– was staring back at him intently.
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: “Hurry, hurry!”
vi: Quickly, quickly!
tr: "Come on, hurry up!"
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: The prisoner bent over the paper, once more.
vi: The prisoner bent over the paper again.
tr: The prisoner leaned over the paper once more.
es: The prisoner, whose breathing had become labored, and whose face reflected the disorder of his faculties, leaned over the paper ready to write.

en: “‘If it had been otherwise;’” Carton’s hand was again watchfully and softly stealing down; “‘I never should have used the longer opportunity. If it had been otherwise;’” the hand was at the prisoner’s face; “‘I should but have had so much the more to answer for. If it had been otherwise—’” Carton looked at the pen and saw it was trailing off into unintelligible signs.
vi: − "If we don't take this opportunity," - Carton's hand cautiously and discreetly lowered, - "we will never have another chance." "If we don't take this opportunity," - Carton's hand close to the prisoner's face, - "so many difficulties will pile up later." "If we don't take this opportunity..." - Carton looked at the pen and saw the writing becoming illegible.
tr: "If it had been otherwise," said Carton as his hand slowly, carefully descended again; "I would not have seized that great opportunity. If it had been otherwise," and his hand was now in front of the prisoner's face; "There would be many more questions I would have to answer. If it had been otherwise..." Carton looked at the pen and saw that the writing was gradually turning into illegible marks.
es: "Had the course of events been different—continued dictating Carton, whose right hand was under the scribe's nose,—it is natural that I would have missed this opportunity; had the course of events been different..." Carton fixed his eyes on the pen and saw that it was scribbling unintelligible signs.

en: Carton’s hand moved back to his breast no more. The prisoner sprang up with a reproachful look, but Carton’s hand was close and firm at his nostrils, and Carton’s left arm caught him round the waist. For a few seconds he faintly struggled with the man who had come to lay down his life for him; but, within a minute or so, he was stretched insensible on the ground.
vi: Carton's hand no longer reached for his chest. The prisoner stood up abruptly with a reproachful look, but his nose was covered by Carton's right hand, and his waist was tightly held by Carton's left hand. Darnay weakly resisted for a few seconds against the man who risked his life to save him; but after just a minute, Darnay lay unconscious on the floor.
tr: Carton did not bring his hand to his chest again. The prisoner sprang up with a reproachful look, but Carton immediately clamped his hand over the prisoner's nostrils and wrapped his left arm around his waist, holding him tightly. Darnay struggled faintly with the man who was risking his life for him; but soon he lost consciousness and collapsed to the ground.
es: The prisoner straightened up suddenly, directing a look full of reproaches at Carton; but the latter's right hand moved closer and closer to his nose, while his left arm encircled his waist. The prisoner struggled weakly and for a few seconds with the man who had come to give his life for his; but before a minute had passed, he lay motionless on the ground.

en: Quickly, but with hands as true to the purpose as his heart was, Carton dressed himself in the clothes the prisoner had laid aside, combed back his hair, and tied it with the ribbon the prisoner had worn. Then, he softly called, “Enter there! Come in!” and the Spy presented himself.
vi: With swift hands and a resolute heart, Carton donned the clothes the prisoner had taken off, combed his hair, and tied it with the ribbon that had bound the prisoner's hair. Then he called softly: "Come in! Quickly!" - And the spy Barsad entered.
tr: Carton, with hands as faithful to his purpose as his heart, quickly donned the clothes the prisoner had set aside and tied his hair back with the prisoner's ribbon. Then he called out quietly, "Come in! Come on!" and the Spy entered.
es: Carton immediately put on the clothes that the prisoner had left minutes before, combed his hair better than ever, tied his hair with the ribbon that had previously held Darnay's, and said in a very low voice: —Come in... come in!... Two seconds later, the spy appeared.

en: “You see?” said Carton, looking up, as he kneeled on one knee beside the insensible figure, putting the paper in the breast: “is your hazard very great?”
vi: "See?" Carton looked up. He was kneeling on one knee beside the unconscious prisoner, placing the letter into the prisoner's chest.
tr: Carton, who was kneeling beside the man lying in a state of unconsciousness, lifted his head and said, "Did you see?" as he tucked the letter into his bosom, "how great the danger you are in is.""
es: —Do you see it?—asked Carton, raising his head, and then kneeling down to place the paper he had written into Charles's pocket. —

en: “Mr. Carton,” the Spy answered, with a timid snap of his fingers, “my hazard is not that, in the thick of business here, if you are true to the whole of your bargain.”
vi: "Is your risk too great?" "Mr. Carton," the spy replied with a hesitant snap of his fingers, "my risk does not lie there, in this matter, as long as you do exactly as promised."
tr: "Mr. Carton," said the Spy, snapping his fingers in an embarrassed manner, "if you stick to the bargain we made, I won't get into trouble.""
es: Didn't I tell you that your risk was insignificant? —My risk, Mr. Carton, is not in this—replied the spy,—but in you faithfully fulfilling what was stipulated.

en: “Don’t fear me. I will be true to the death.”
vi: − Don't worry. I swear I will do exactly as I said.
tr: "Don't be afraid. I am faithful to my word until death."
es: —Rest assured, I will adhere to the agreement until death.

en: “You must be, Mr. Carton, if the tale of fifty-two is to be right. Being made right by you in that dress, I shall have no fear.”
vi: − It must be so, Mr. Carton, if the story of beheading fifty-two people is true. If you keep wearing those clothes and do as you say, then I have nothing to fear.
tr: "If these fifty-two stories are true, you must already keep your word, Mr. Carton. If you can get through this situation in these clothes, there is nothing to fear."
es: —That is how it must be for the number fifty-two to be exact. As long as you complete it, dressed as you are right now, I fear nothing.

en: “Have no fear! I shall soon be out of the way of harming you, and the rest will soon be far from here, please God! Now, get assistance and take me to the coach.”
vi: − Don't be afraid! Soon, I will no longer be a danger to you, and as for the others, God willing, they will quickly leave this place! Now call someone to help take me to the car.
tr: "Don't be afraid! Soon, I won't be in a position to harm you, and hopefully, the others will have left here too! Now, someone help put 'me' in the car.""
es: —You have nothing to fear. I, who could harm you, will soon disappear from this world, thank God... Now, help me; or rather; take me to the car.

en: “You?” said the Spy nervously.
vi: − You? - The detective worriedly asked.
tr: "You?" asked the Spy, nervously.
es: —To you?—asked the spy with visible apprehension.

en: “Him, man, with whom I have exchanged. You go out at the gate by which you brought me in?”
vi: − So, this is the person, the one whose clothes I exchanged. You are leaving through the gate you brought me in, right?
tr: "Him," I say, "the man I switched places with. Will you leave through the door you brought me in from?"
es: —To him, man of God, to the prisoner with whom I exchange fate! Will he leave through the same door through which I entered?

en: “Of course.”
tr: "Yes."
es: —Of course.

en: “I was weak and faint when you brought me in, and I am fainter now you take me out. The parting interview has overpowered me. Such a thing has happened here, often, and too often. Your life is in your own hands. Quick! Call assistance!”
vi: Of course. − I was weak and dizzy when you brought me in, and now as you take me out, I have completely fainted. I cannot bear this eternal farewell. Such things often happen here, very often, life and death depend on you. Quickly! Call for help! −
tr: "When you brought me here, I felt weak and exhausted, and now as I leave, I feel even more exhausted. This farewell scene has worn me out too much. Such scenes must happen frequently here. Life is in your own hands. Hurry up! Call for help!"
es: —Well then; since I was weak and faint when I entered, it is only natural that I leave even weaker and fainter. The eternal farewell has affected me so much that I lost consciousness; this has happened here very often... too often. It is your responsibility not to make any blunders... Quickly... Call for help.

en: “You swear not to betray me?” said the trembling Spy, as he paused for a last moment.
vi: You swear not to betray me, right? - The spy said trembling as he hesitated one last time.
tr: The spy, trembling all over, paused for a moment and asked, "Do you swear not to betray me?"
es: —Do you swear that you will not betray me?—asked the spy, trembling.

en: “Man, man!” returned Carton, stamping his foot; “have I sworn by no solemn vow already, to go through with this, that you waste the precious moments now? Take him yourself to the courtyard you know of, place him yourself in the carriage, show him yourself to Mr. Lorry, tell him yourself to give him no restorative but air, and to remember my words of last night, and his promise of last night, and drive away!”
vi: − Oh, you! - Carton said, stamping his foot. - I have sworn already, proceed and do not waste precious time! You personally must take this person to that courtyard, you know the place, you personally must put this person into the waiting carriage, you personally must show this person to Mr. Lorry, tell him that fresh air alone will revive this person, no medicine needed, remind him of my instructions last night, and his promise last night, and set off immediately!
tr: Carton stomped his foot and said, "What are you talking about! Didn't I swear earlier that I would handle this, why are you wasting these precious minutes now? Take him to the courtyard we talked about, place him in the carriage yourself, hand him over to Mr. Lorry and tell him not to give any stimulants, that fresh air will be enough, and to remember what I said the last night and the promise he made to me, then leave quickly!"
es: —But man! Haven't I already solemnly sworn it?—replied Carton, stomping impatiently. —Why, then, waste now moments that are precious? Take him to the courtyard you know, place him in the carriage, take him to Mr. Lorry's side, tell him not to give him any medicine, that all he needs is air, to remember my words from last night, to keep the promise he made to me last night, and nothing more.

en: The Spy withdrew, and Carton seated himself at the table, resting his forehead on his hands. The Spy returned immediately, with two men.
vi: The spy withdrew and Carton sat down at the table, holding his head in his hands. The spy returned immediately with two others. − What’s going on here? -
tr: The spy left and Carton sat at the head of the table, resting his hands on his forehead. The spy returned immediately with two men beside him.
es: The spy withdrew, and Carton sat at the table, resting his elbows on it. Seconds later, the spy re-entered with two men.

en: “How, then?” said one of them, contemplating the fallen figure. “So afflicted to find that his friend has drawn a prize in the lottery of Sainte Guillotine?”
vi: One person said while looking at the body lying on the floor. - Too emotional upon seeing his friend win the Guillotine lottery?
tr: One of them, looking at the body lying on the ground, said, "What happened to this man?" "Did he find out that his friend won the grand prize in the 'Saint Guillotine lottery'?"
es: —Man!—exclaimed one of them, upon seeing Carlos lying on the ground. — Has it shocked him so much to see that his friend won the jackpot in the Santa Guillotina lottery?

en: “A good patriot,” said the other, “could hardly have been more afflicted if the Aristocrat had drawn a blank.”
vi: Too emotional upon seeing his friend win the Guillotine lottery?
tr: "If nothing had come out of the lottery for the aristocrat, a good patriot could not have been more saddened," said the other.
es: —Indeed, a good patriot would not have been more distressed if the aristocrat had been declared acquitted!—observed the other.

en: They raised the unconscious figure, placed it on a litter they had brought to the door, and bent to carry it away.
vi: They lifted the unconscious man, placed him on a stretcher they had brought to the door, and then carefully lifted it up. −
tr: They lifted the unconscious body, laid it on the stretcher they had left in front of the door, and bent down to take it away.
es: Between the two of them, they placed the unconscious person on a stretcher they had brought and took him away.

en: “The time is short, Evrémonde,” said the Spy, in a warning voice.
vi: No more time, Evrémonde, - the spy said in a warning tone.
tr: "We don't have much time, Evremonde," said the Spy, as if warning.
es: —Few hours of life remain for you, Evrémonde!—said the spy.

en: “I know it well,” answered Carton. “Be careful of my friend, I entreat you, and leave me.”
vi: − I know well, - Carton replied. - Please take care of my friend and leave me alone. −
tr: "I know," said Carton. "Please take care of my friend, now leave me alone."
es: —I know it very well—responded Carton. —Take care of my friend and leave me alone.

en: “Come, then, my children,” said Barsad. “Lift him, and come away!”
vi: Then let's go, you all, - Barsad said. - Carry this man up and let's go!
tr: "Alright then, children," said Barsad. "Lift it up and let's go already!"
es: —Let's go, my children—said the spy to his companions. — Let's move.

en: The door closed, and Carton was left alone. Straining his powers of listening to the utmost, he listened for any sound that might denote suspicion or alarm. There was none. Keys turned, doors clashed, footsteps passed along distant passages: no cry was raised, or hurry made, that seemed unusual. Breathing more freely in a little while, he sat down at the table, and listened again until the clock struck Two.
vi: The door closed and only Carton was left alone. Using all his hearing, he stood up, straining to catch any sound that might indicate suspicion or alarm. There was none. The sound of the key turning, the door slamming shut, footsteps fading down the corridors; no loud cries, no unusual hurried footsteps. Feeling more at ease, he sat down again after a while, continuing to listen until the clock struck two.
tr: The door closed and Carton was left alone. He listened intently outside to hear any suspicious situation or any sound suggesting danger. There was no sound. Locks turned, doors closed, footsteps passing through distant corridors were heard; no scream arose, nor was there any unusual commotion. Soon, when he started to breathe a bit more comfortably, he sat down at the table again and listened until the clock struck two.
es: The door closed, leaving Carton alone. He concentrated all the faculties of his soul in his hearing in case something sounded that indicated suspicions or alarms; nothing was heard. Keys turned in the locks, doors closed with a crash, footsteps receded, but no scream was heard nor was the usual order or tranquility disturbed. Carton, now calmer, remained seated in front of the table until two o'clock struck.

en: Sounds that he was not afraid of, for he divined their meaning, then began to be audible. Several doors were opened in succession, and finally his own. A gaoler, with a list in his hand, looked in, merely saying, “Follow me, Evrémonde!” and he followed into a large dark room, at a distance. It was a dark winter day, and what with the shadows within, and what with the shadows without, he could but dimly discern the others who were brought there to have their arms bound. Some were standing; some seated. Some were lamenting, and in restless motion; but, these were few. The great majority were silent and still, looking fixedly at the ground.
vi: Then he began to hear sounds that he was not afraid of, for he himself had given them a sacred meaning. Many prison doors were opened in succession, and finally, the door to his cell. A jailer holding a list in his hand looked at it and said briefly, "Follow me, Evrémonde!". And he followed to a large, gloomy room in the distance. That day was a bleak winter day, with darkness both outside and inside, he could only faintly see the others brought here to be bound. Some stood, some sat. Some wept, panicked; but they were few. Most were silent, eyes downcast.
tr: Then some sounds rose, but Carton was not afraid because he knew what they were. Doors opened one after another, and finally, it was his turn. A guard, with a list in hand, looked inside and simply said, "Follow me, Evremonde!" and took him to a large dark room in the distance. It was a dark winter day, and Carton could barely make out the other prisoners, who had been brought in with their arms bound, in the gloom both inside and outside. Some were standing; some were sitting. Some were crying and wailing, unable to stay still, but they were few in number. The vast majority were silent and had fixed their eyes on the ground without moving.
es: Then, sounds reached his ears that neither alarmed nor surprised him, simply because he knew perfectly well what they meant. Many doors were successively opened, until finally it was the turn of his cell. A jailer, equipped with a list, without stepping over the threshold, merely said: —Follow me, Evrémonde. Carton followed the jailer until they reached a dark, large cell, located quite a distance away, crowded with prisoners. Although the light was very dim, Carton could see that everyone had their arms tied, some were standing and others sitting, some were complaining while others were pacing restlessly and nervously. Most of them, however, remained silent and motionless, with their eyes fixed on the ground.

en: As he stood by the wall in a dim corner, while some of the fifty-two were brought in after him, one man stopped in passing, to embrace him, as having a knowledge of him. It thrilled him with a great dread of discovery; but the man went on. A very few moments after that, a young woman, with a slight girlish form, a sweet spare face in which there was no vestige of colour, and large widely opened patient eyes, rose from the seat where he had observed her sitting, and came to speak to him.
vi: While he was standing in a dark corner of the wall and several others from the list of fifty-two people were brought in after him, someone passing by suddenly stopped and hugged him as if they had known each other before. Carton secretly panicked, afraid of being discovered; but the person continued walking. Just a moment later, a girl he saw sitting on the bench suddenly stood up and walked towards him.
tr: Leaning against a wall in a dark corner, watching those brought in after him among fifty-two people, a man passing in front of him stopped and wanted to hug him as if he knew him. Carton panicked, thinking the man would notice the situation; but the man continued on his way. Shortly after, a young woman with a delicate young girl's body, with a pale, charming, and thin face and wide-open eyes full of patience, got up from the place where Carton had just been observing and came to talk to him.
es: While standing next to the blackish wall, he gazed at his fifty-one gallows companions, some of whom had entered after him, when a man stopped to embrace him. Carton shuddered, fearing he had been discovered, but the man continued on his way after giving him a hug. Moments later, a graceful little girl with lovely features rose from the ground and approached Carton.

en: “Citizen Evrémonde,” she said, touching him with her cold hand. “I am a poor little seamstress, who was with you in La Force.”
vi: Her figure still retained the features of a young girl, her gentle face unadorned, revealing a pale complexion and wide, patient eyes, she started a conversation: − Citizen Evrémonde, - she touched him with her cold hand. - I am a poor seamstress, who was imprisoned in La Force with you.
tr: "Citizen Evremonde," he said, touching him with his cold hand, "I am the poor little tailor who stayed with you in La Force, do you remember?"
es: —Citizen Evrémonde—she said, extending her cold hand;—I am a little seamstress who was your fellow prisoner in La Force.

en: He murmured for answer: “True. I forget what you were accused of?”
vi: − That's right, - he whispered in response. - I forgot, what were you convicted of?
tr: Carton murmured in response: "Correct. But I have forgotten what you are accused of."
es: —Ah, yes!—murmured Carton.

en: “Plots. Though the just Heaven knows that I am innocent of any. Is it likely? Who would think of plotting with a poor little weak creature like me?”
vi: − Conspiracy. Though God is my witness, I am completely innocent. How could that be? Who could conspire with someone as weak and poor as me?
tr: "With plotting a conspiracy. But God knows, I haven't committed any crime. Can such a thing be possible? Who would think of plotting a conspiracy with a poor and small creature like me?"
es: —It's true! What I don't remember is the accusation that brought you to jail. —They accused me of being a conspirator; but the good Lord knows that I am innocent. Can there be a conspirator who entrusts their machinations to a weak girl like me?

en: The forlorn smile with which she said it, so touched him, that tears started from his eyes.
vi: Her desperate smile moved him, his eyes welled with tears.
tr: As she said this, the sad smile that appeared on the woman's face touched Carton so deeply that tears began to flow from his eyes.
es: The smile with which the young girl accompanied her words moved Carton so deeply that tears came to his eyes.

en: “I am not afraid to die, Citizen Evrémonde, but I have done nothing. I am not unwilling to die, if the Republic which is to do so much good to us poor, will profit by my death; but I do not know how that can be, Citizen Evrémonde. Such a poor weak little creature!”
vi: − I am not afraid of death, Citizen Evrémonde, but I did nothing. I am willing to die if it would benefit the Republic, which has done so much good for the poor; but I do not understand why it has come to this, Citizen Evrémonde. I am so weak and poor!
tr: "I am not afraid of death, Citizen Evremonde, but I have done nothing. If my death will benefit the Republic, which will bring a smile to the faces of poor people like us, I certainly do not mind death; but I do not know how this will happen, Citizen Evremonde. After all, I am just a poor little creature!"
es: —I am not afraid to die, citizen Evrémonde, but I repeat that I have done nothing. I would even die with joy if the Republic, which they say is to make the poor happy, could gain some benefit from my death; but if I am to say what I feel, I do not believe that my death will serve any purpose, Evrémonde. What benefits could the Republic gain from the death of a weak creature like me?

en: As the last thing on earth that his heart was to warm and soften to, it warmed and softened to this pitiable girl.
vi: This pitiable girl deeply moved him, the last person in the world to make his heart ache.
tr: In this life, the last thing that would warm and ache your heart was this poor girl who warmed and ached Carton's heart.
es: The compassion that the girl inspired in Carton was infinite.

en: “I heard you were released, Citizen Evrémonde. I hoped it was true?”
vi: − I heard that you have been set free, Citizen Evrémonde. I hope that is true? −
tr: "I had heard that you were released, Citizen Evremonde. If only it were true!"
es: —I heard that you had been acquitted, Citizen Evrémonde, and I truly regret that it is not true.

en: “It was. But, I was again taken and condemned.”
vi: It is true. But I was re-arrested and sentenced. −
tr: "It was like that. But then I was caught again and sentenced."
es: —I was; but then they caught me again and have condemned me.

en: “If I may ride with you, Citizen Evrémonde, will you let me hold your hand? I am not afraid, but I am little and weak, and it will give me more courage.”
vi: If I were to ride in the same cart with you, Citizen Evrémonde, may I hold your hand? I am not afraid, but I am weak and small, and it would give me more courage.
tr: "Citizen Evremonde, if we end up in the same carriage, may I hold your hand? I am not afraid, but I am small and weak, it will give me courage."
es: —If they place us in the same cart, Citizen Evrémonde, will you allow me to hold your hand? It's not that I'm afraid; but since I am a child, your hand will give me the courage I lack.

en: As the patient eyes were lifted to his face, he saw a sudden doubt in them, and then astonishment. He pressed the work-worn, hunger-worn young fingers, and touched his lips.
vi: When those patient eyes looked up, he suddenly noticed the suspicion and then surprise in them. He tightly grasped her thin, weary fingers and brought them to his lips.
tr: When patience-filled eyes turned to his face, Carton saw a sudden doubt in them, followed by astonishment. He held the young fingers, worn from work and hunger, and brought them to his lips.
es: Carton saw that through the girl's eyes, as she fixed them on his face, first a cloud of doubt passed, and then one of astonishment.

en: “Are you dying for him?” she whispered.
vi: − You died in his place? - The girl whispered.
tr: "Are you sacrificing yourself for him?"
es: —Are you going to die for him?

en: “And his wife and child. Hush! Yes.”
vi: − And for his wife and children. Shh! That's right.
tr: "For his wife and child too. Shh! Yes."
es: —And for his wife and daughter... yes! —Oh! Will you allow me to hold your valiant hand in mine?

en: “O you will let me hold your brave hand, stranger?”
vi: − Oh, let me hold your brave hand, stranger?
tr: "Ah, allow me to hold your brave hand, stranger!"
es: Will you allow me to hold your valiant hand in mine?

en: “Hush! Yes, my poor sister; to the last.”
vi: − Shh! Alright, my poor sister, let us hold hands until the very end.
tr: "Shh! Alright, my poor brother, hold my hand until the very end."
es: —Yes, my unfortunate sister... until the very last moment.

en: The same shadows that are falling on the prison, are falling, in that same hour of the early afternoon, on the Barrier with the crowd about it, when a coach going out of Paris drives up to be examined.
vi: ۩۩۩ Just as the shadows were enveloping the prison, at the same hour in the early afternoon, darkness was descending on the city gate, covering the crowd surrounding it as a four-horse carriage leaving Paris stopped for inspection. −
tr: When the shadows falling over the prison fell upon the barricades surrounded by crowds at the same hours in the afternoon, a car that had set out to leave Paris was stopped for inspection.
es: The same shadows that envelop the condemned surround the crowds stationed at the same hour in the vicinity of the Barrier at the moment when a road coach, coming from the interior of the city, approaches to present the documents of its occupants.

en: “Who goes here? Whom have we within? Papers!”
vi: Who goes there? Who is in the carriage? Show your papers!
tr: "Who are you? Who are the people with you? Let's see your documents!"
es: —Who are the travelers? Let's see... the documents!

en: The papers are handed out, and read.
vi: The papers were presented for reading.
tr: The documents were handed over and he read them.
es: A hand presents the documents, which are read.

en: “Alexandre Manette. Physician. French. Which is he?”
vi: − Alexandre Manette. Doctor. French. Who is he?
tr: "Alexandre Manette. Doctor. French. Which one of you is this?"
es: —Alejandro Manette... doctor... French... Let's see; who is it?

en: This is he; this helpless, inarticulately murmuring, wandering old man pointed out.
vi: That's him; the finger points to an absent-minded, helpless old man, muttering incoherent words.
tr: Here it is; the old man, who is muttering and babbling incomprehensible things, is pointed out.
es: An extended arm indicates an exhausted old man who murmurs unintelligible words.

en: “Apparently the Citizen-Doctor is not in his right mind? The Revolution-fever will have been too much for him?”
vi: − Clearly, this Citizen Doctor is not mentally stable? Can't withstand the fever of the Revolution?
tr: "It seems that Citizen Doctor is not quite in his right mind, is he? The revolution's fire must have been too much for him."
es: —It seems that the citizen doctor has his faculties disturbed, doesn't he? The fever of the Revolution has burned his brain.

en: Greatly too much for him.
vi: Beyond his endurance.
tr: Indeed, this was too much for him.
es: —It seems so.

en: “Hah! Many suffer with it. Lucie. His daughter. French. Which is she?”
vi: − Huh! Many people can still endure it. Lucie. His daughter. French. Where is she?
tr: "Eh! Many people suffer from the same problem. His daughter Lucie. French. Who is this?"
es: —Bah! There are many who find themselves in his situation... Lucía, his daughter... French... Who is she?

en: This is she.
vi: There she is.
tr: That's it.
es: Who is she?

en: “Apparently it must be. Lucie, the wife of Evrémonde; is it not?”
vi: − Surely. Lucie, the wife of Evrémonde, right?
tr: "That's right, who else could it be? Lucie, the wife of Evremonde, isn't she?"
es: —This one.

en: It is.
vi: Exactly.
tr: Correct.
es: —This one.

en: “Hah! Evrémonde has an assignation elsewhere. Lucie, her child. English. This is she?”
vi: − Huh! Evrémonde has been assigned elsewhere, Lucie, her daughter. English. Is it her?
tr: "Eh! Evremonde has an appointment elsewhere. Lucie, his daughter. English. That's it."
es: —Very well. Evrémonde embarks on another different journey... Lucie, daughter of Lucie... English... Is this her?

en: She and no other.
vi: It's the girl.
tr: There it is, who else would be there?
es: —The same one.

en: “Kiss me, child of Evrémonde. Now, thou hast kissed a good Republican; something new in thy family; remember it! Sydney Carton. Advocate. English. Which is he?”
vi: − Kiss me, little Evrémonde girl. There, you have kissed a good Republican; a new thing in your family; don't forget! Sydney Carton. Lawyer. English. Who is he?
tr: "Kiss me, daughter of Evremonde. Now that you've kissed a good Republican, this is something new for your family; remember this! Sydney Carton. Lawyer. Englishman. Which one?"
es: —Give me a kiss, daughter of Evrémonde... You have kissed a good republican, a new thing in your family, don't forget it. Sydney Carton, lawyer, English... Who is he?

en: He lies here, in this corner of the carriage. He, too, is pointed out.
vi: He is lying there, in the corner of the carriage. A finger points in that direction. −
tr: He is lying in a corner of the carriage. He is also pointed out.
es: This one lying at the bottom of the car. —Is the English lawyer unconscious?

en: “Apparently the English advocate is in a swoon?”
vi: This English lawyer seems to be unconscious?
tr: "It seems the English lawyer has fainted, huh?"
es: —Is the English lawyer unconscious?

en: It is hoped he will recover in the fresher air. It is represented that he is not in strong health, and has separated sadly from a friend who is under the displeasure of the Republic.
vi: Everyone hopes the fresh air will help him regain consciousness. Clearly, he is not well, and has just sorrowfully bid farewell to a friend who was not favored by the Republic.
tr: It is hoped that he will recover in the fresh air. It is explained to the attendant that he is not in good health and is experiencing the sorrow of parting from a friend who has been subjected to the wrath of the Republic.
es: —Yes... his health is very broken, but the fresh air will undoubtedly do him good. He has just said goodbye to a friend of his who has had the misfortune of falling into the disfavor of the Republic.

en: “Is that all? It is not a great deal, that! Many are under the displeasure of the Republic, and must look out at the little window. Jarvis Lorry. Banker. English. Which is he?”
vi: − Just because of that? It's nothing to make a fuss about! Many people are not in the favor of the Republic and have to stick their heads into the guillotine. Jarvis Lorry. Bank employee. Englishman. Who is he? −
tr: "Is this the reason? This is not such an important thing! There are many who have faced the wrath of the Republic and had to look through that tiny guillotine window. Jarvis Lorry. Banker. Englishman. Who is this?"
es: —Does he faint over such a small thing? Many are those who incur the displeasure of the Republic, and the misfortune of many... Mauricio Lorry, banker, English... Who is the banker?

en: “I am he. Necessarily, being the last.”
vi: He is me. Of course, the last one.
tr: "It's me. I was the only one left anyway."
es: —It's me; it can't be anyone else, since no one else is left in the car.

en: It is Jarvis Lorry who has replied to all the previous questions. It is Jarvis Lorry who has alighted and stands with his hand on the coach door, replying to a group of officials. They leisurely walk round the carriage and leisurely mount the box, to look at what little luggage it carries on the roof; the country-people hanging about, press nearer to the coach doors and greedily stare in; a little child, carried by its mother, has its short arm held out for it, that it may touch the wife of an aristocrat who has gone to the Guillotine.
vi: It was Mr. Jarvis Lorry who answered all the questions. It was Mr. Jarvis Lorry who got off the carriage and stood with his hand on the door, answering to a group of officials. This group leisurely walked around the carriage, leisurely climbed onto the coachman's seat, and examined the few pieces of luggage on the roof; the villagers loitered around, crowded near the carriage doors, and looked inside with longing eyes; a child being carried by its mother stretched out its short arm as if wanting to touch the wife of the nobleman who had been guillotined. −
tr: It was Jarvis Lorry who answered all these questions. He had gotten out of the carriage and answered a group of officials at the door. The men slowly walked around the carriage and then slowly climbed up to the coachman's seat to look at the luggage on top; the crowd swarming around the carriage was pushing each other at the door, peering inside with greedy eyes; a small child in his mother's arms was reaching out to touch the wife of an aristocrat on her way to the guillotine.
es: Mauricio Lorry was the one who had answered the previous questions, Mauricio Lorry the one who had dismounted and, with his right hand resting on the carriage door, was responding to the interrogation of the barrier guard.

en: “Behold your papers, Jarvis Lorry, countersigned.”
vi: Check the papers again, Jarvis Lorry, they have been signed and confirmed.
tr: "Here are your documents, Jarvis Lorry, signed.""
es: —Take your documents, Mauricio Lorry...

en: “One can depart, citizen?”
vi: − Can we go now, Citizen? −
tr: "Can we leave now, citizen?"
es: Endorsed! —Can we proceed with the journey?

en: “One can depart. Forward, my postilions! A good journey!”
vi: You are permitted. Whip the horses, coachman! Safe journey!
tr: "You may go. Come on, coachman! Have a good journey!"
es: —Whenever it suits you. Onward, postilions, and have a good journey.

en: “I salute you, citizens.—And the first danger passed!”
vi: − Farewell, Citizens... And the first danger has passed!
tr: "Goodbye, fellow citizens. –Yes, we have overcome the first danger!"
es: —Greetings, citizens... The first danger has passed.

en: These are again the words of Jarvis Lorry, as he clasps his hands, and looks upward. There is terror in the carriage, there is weeping, there is the heavy breathing of the insensible traveller.
vi: Again, it was Mr. Jarvis Lorry speaking as he clasped his hands and looked up to the sky. Inside the carriage, there was fear, the sound of crying, and the heavy breathing of an unconscious traveler.
tr: These words also belonged to Jarvis Lorry, who was looking up with his hands clasped. There was terror in the carriage, there were tears, and the heavy breath of the unconscious passenger filled the air.
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: “Are we not going too slowly? Can they not be induced to go faster?” asks Lucie, clinging to the old man.
vi: − Why is the car going so slow? Can't we tell them to go faster? - Lucie asked, holding onto the old man. −
tr: Lucie grabbed the old man's arm and asked, "Aren't we going too slow? Can't we go faster?"
es: —Don't you think we are walking too slowly?—asked Lucía, crying, holding onto the embrace of good Lorry.

en: “It would seem like flight, my darling. I must not urge them too much; it would rouse suspicion.”
vi: That would look like we're fleeing, my dear. We mustn't urge them too much; it would arouse suspicion. −
tr: "Then we would look like we're running away, my dear. We shouldn't push them too hard; it would arouse suspicion later."
es: —If we ran faster, it would look like we were fleeing; it's not advisable; we would arouse suspicion.

en: “Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued!”
vi: Look behind, look behind, see if we're being followed? −
tr: "Look back, are they following us?"
es: —Look back...

en: “The road is clear, my dearest. So far, we are not pursued.”
vi: The road is clear, my dear. So far, no one is following us.
tr: "There is no one on the road, my beautiful child. They are not following us."
es: Are they not chasing us? —No, my dear, no; so far they are not chasing us.

en: Houses in twos and threes pass by us, solitary farms, ruinous buildings, dye-works, tanneries, and the like, open country, avenues of leafless trees. The hard uneven pavement is under us, the soft deep mud is on either side. Sometimes, we strike into the skirting mud, to avoid the stones that clatter us and shake us; sometimes, we stick in ruts and sloughs there. The agony of our impatience is then so great, that in our wild alarm and hurry we are for getting out and running—hiding—doing anything but stopping.
vi: The carriage passed by scattered clusters of houses, a few here and there, solitary farms, dilapidated buildings, dyeing workshops; tanneries, and similar places, then open fields and roads lined with bare trees. The cobblestones were uneven under the horse's hooves, then deep mud engulfed the sides of the carriage. At times, the carriage plunged into slippery mud to avoid the bumpy rocks in the middle of the road; at other times, the carriage got stuck in muddy ditches. The agony of impatience was so great that in a frantic panic, the passengers just wanted to escape and run away - hide - do anything as long as they didn't have to stop.
tr: We pass by houses in twos and threes, deserted farms, dilapidated buildings, paint shops, and tanneries, and then through streets lined with wide fields and leafless trees. In front of us, randomly laid hard cobblestones, and on either side of us, soft and deep mud. Sometimes, to escape the stones that clatter and shake the carriage, we plunge into the mud at the edges; sometimes into the wheel tracks and puddles. At such moments, the torment of our impatience increases so much that, in a frantic rush and hurry to escape –and hide– we move forward without stopping.
es: The fugitives leave behind one or two-story houses that line the road, farms, abandoned labor houses, ruined tanneries, lonely fields, avenues winding between rows of leafless trees. They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits.

en: Out of the open country, in again among ruinous buildings, solitary farms, dye-works, tanneries, and the like, cottages in twos and threes, avenues of leafless trees. Have these men deceived us, and taken us back by another road? Is not this the same place twice over? Thank Heaven, no. A village. Look back, look back, and see if we are pursued! Hush! the posting-house.
vi: Leaving the open fields, the carriage again sped through ruined buildings, solitary farms, dye works; tanneries, and similar places, then again through scattered clusters of houses, and leafless tree-lined roads. Have these people deceived us into turning the carriage back by another route? Isn't this the place we crossed twice already? Thank God, it's not. A village. Look behind, look behind, to see if we are being followed? Hush! We've reached the relay station!
tr: We are passing again through wide fields, dilapidated buildings, deserted farms, dye houses, tanneries, and then again through streets covered with leafless trees where there are houses in twos and threes. Were these men deceiving us and taking us back by another route? Hadn't we passed through the same place before? Thank God, no. A village. Look back, look back and see if we are being followed? Shh! The resting place of the postal carriages.
es: They run along rough and uneven paths, crossing thickets, sometimes jumping over thick layers of stones, sometimes getting stuck in deep mud pits. Their impatience, their agony is so great that they see nothing, notice nothing, think of nothing but reaching the port of salvation as soon as possible. The horses are harnessed again. New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: Leisurely, our four horses are taken out; leisurely, the coach stands in the little street, bereft of horses, and with no likelihood upon it of ever moving again; leisurely, the new horses come into visible existence, one by one; leisurely, the new postilions follow, sucking and plaiting the lashes of their whips; leisurely, the old postilions count their money, make wrong additions, and arrive at dissatisfied results. All the time, our overfraught hearts are beating at a rate that would far outstrip the fastest gallop of the fastest horses ever foaled.
vi: Leisurely, the four horses were unhitched; leisurely, the carriage stood in the narrow road, no longer drawn by horses, and incapable of moving; leisurely, four new horses appeared, one by one; leisurely, two new grooms followed the horses, drinking wine and coiling their whips; leisurely, the two old grooms counted money, miscalculated the total, and were dissatisfied with the result. All the while, our fearful hearts were beating faster than the fastest galloping horse in the world.
tr: Our four horses are slowly being untied from their reins; the carriage, without its horses and as if it will never move again, stands slowly on the tiny road; then slowly, one by one, new horses come into view; the old coachmen slowly count their money, making mistakes and coming up with improbable results. Throughout this entire time, our burdened hearts beat so fast that even the fastest horses in history couldn't make such a noise while galloping.
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest.

en: At length the new postilions are in their saddles, and the old are left behind. We are through the village, up the hill, and down the hill, and on the low watery grounds. Suddenly, the postilions exchange speech with animated gesticulation, and the horses are pulled up, almost on their haunches. We are pursued?
vi: Finally, the two new horsemen mounted their saddles, while the two old ones stayed behind. The carriage once again sped through villages, up hills, down slopes, and ran across waterlogged lowlands. Suddenly, the two coachmen waved their hands and talked animatedly, causing the carriage to stop abruptly, making the four horses rear up as if they were about to jump. Is someone chasing us?
tr: Soon, the new coachmen take their places and the old ones fall behind. We pass the village, climb the hill, descend, and then reach the low-lying wetlands. Suddenly, the coachmen's conversations become lively and cheerful, and they quickly pull the reins to stop the horses. Are we being followed?
es: New postilions take the seats while the former ones rest. They pass through a village, laboriously climb a ramp, crest the hill, descend the opposite slope, and enter less arid lands... Good heavens! They are being chased!

en: “Ho! Within the carriage there. Speak then!”
vi: − Hey! You in the carriage! Speak up! −
tr: "Hey! You in the car." "Tell me, let's see!""
es: —Ah, the carriage...! Stop!

en: “What is it?” asks Mr. Lorry, looking out at window.
vi: What's the matter? - Mr. Lorry asked, looking out the carriage window.
tr: "What?" asks Mr. Lorry, sticking his head out the window.
es: —What's happening?—asks Lorry, sticking her head out the door.

en: “How many did they say?”
vi: − How many people did they say?
tr: "How many were they?""
es: —How many have there been today?

en: “I do not understand you.”
vi: − I don't understand what you mean?
tr: "I don't understand you." "...
es: —I don't understand.

en: “—At the last post. How many to the Guillotine to-day?”
vi: − ... At that final station. How many people are going to the guillotine today?
tr: In the last post. How many people went to the guillotine today?"
es: —I don't understand. —How many have kissed the Holy Guillotine today?

en: “Fifty-two.”
vi: − Fifty-two. − I was right!
tr: "Fifty-two.""
es: —Fifty-two.

en: “I said so! A brave number! My fellow-citizen here would have it forty-two; ten more heads are worth having. The Guillotine goes handsomely. I love it. Hi forward. Whoop!”
vi: A beautiful number! My Citizen friend here kept saying it was forty-two; it deserves ten more heads. The guillotine is wonderful. I like it that way. Hey! Move on! Hoo!
tr: "I told you! The number is big! The guy next to me was saying forty-two; so it means ten more heads will roll. The guillotine will take care of them nicely. Very nice. Let's go then. Deeh!"
es: —Good! Good number! My good fellow citizens here would have liked to dispatch so many; but they were ten less... The Guillotine works admirably... Good for the Guillotine...! Long live the Guillotine...! I adore it...! Onward!

en: The night comes on dark. He moves more; he is beginning to revive, and to speak intelligibly; he thinks they are still together; he asks him, by his name, what he has in his hand. O pity us, kind Heaven, and help us! Look out, look out, and see if we are pursued.
vi: The night is falling. The unconscious traveler began to move; he was regaining consciousness; and he spoke coherently; he thought he was still with his friend; he asked his friend, by name, what he was holding in his hand. Oh merciful God, have mercy on us, and help us! Watch out, watch out, are we being chased?
tr: The night is falling pitch dark. The faint passenger is stirring; he has started to come to his senses and say understandable things; he still thinks you are beside him; he addresses you by name and asks what you are holding in your hand. Oh, Almighty God, please have mercy on us and help us! Be careful, look and see if they are following us.
es: The night closes in. Carlos begins to move... he comes back to life... he says intelligible words. He thinks he is still next to Carton and asks him what he has in his hand... God in Heaven! Have mercy on the fugitives!

en: The wind is rushing after us, and the clouds are flying after us, and the moon is plunging after us, and the whole wild night is in pursuit of us; but, so far, we are pursued by nothing else.
vi: Only the wind whistling behind them; and the clouds swirling behind them, and the moon plunging behind them, and the wild night chasing them; besides that, up to this moment, nothing was chasing them.
tr: The wind is chasing us, the clouds are flying after us, the moon is circling above us, and the wild night is pursuing us, but so far nothing else has followed us.
es: Behind them flies the swift wind, behind them rush the clouds, behind them runs the moon, the shadows of the night follow them tirelessly; but, fortunately, until then, no one else runs in their pursuit.

en: CHAPTER XIV.
vi: Only the wind whistling behind them; and the clouds swirling behind them, and the moon plunging behind them, and the wild night chasing them; besides that, up to this moment, nothing was chasing them.
tr: Fourteen
es: Chapter XIV.

en: The Knitting Done
vi: Only the wind whistling behind them; and the clouds swirling behind them, and the moon plunging behind them, and the wild night chasing them; besides that, up to this moment, nothing was chasing them.
tr: The Knitting is Finished
es: END OF THE SOCK

en: In that same juncture of time when the Fifty-Two awaited their fate Madame Defarge held darkly ominous council with The Vengeance and Jacques Three of the Revolutionary Jury. Not in the wine-shop did Madame Defarge confer with these ministers, but in the shed of the wood-sawyer, erst a mender of roads. The sawyer himself did not participate in the conference, but abided at a little distance, like an outer satellite who was not to speak until required, or to offer an opinion until invited.
vi: 14. The final stitch At the same time fifty-two people were waiting to meet their fate, Madame Defarge held a grim and dreadful meeting with the Vengeance and Jacques Three of the Revolutionary jury. Madame Defarge did not consult with these executors at the tavern but in the hut of the wood-sawyer, formerly a road-mender. The wood-sawyer was not allowed to join the meeting but stood waiting a little distance away, like a lowly servant who could only speak when permitted, and could only have an opinion when needed. −
tr: At the same hours, while fifty-two people awaited their fate, Madam Defarge, along with Jacques Three from the Committee of Vengeance and Revolution, had formed a dark and ominous council. Madam Defarge was meeting with these deputies not in the wine shop, but in the hut of the sawyer who was formerly a road worker. The sawyer did not personally attend this meeting; like a satellite that neither spoke unless asked nor expressed opinions unless solicited, he waited a little distance away.
es: At the very hour when the fifty-two were awaiting the moment to form too close a relationship with the Guillotine, Madame Defarge, The Vengeance, and Jacques Three were holding a sinister secret council. The conference did not take place in the tavern, but in the wood-sawyer's workshop, who had once been a road mender, and he was not admitted to it, but forced to remain outside at a respectable distance.

en: “But our Defarge,” said Jacques Three, “is undoubtedly a good Republican? Eh?”
vi: But our Defarge, - Jacques Three said, - is clearly a good Republican, right? Why is that? −
tr: "But our Defarge," said Jacques Three, "is undoubtedly a good Republican, isn't he?"
es: —In any case, our Defarge is a good republican, isn't he?—asked Santiago the Third.

en: “There is no better,” the voluble Vengeance protested in her shrill notes, “in France.”
vi: No one is better in this France, - the shrill and rapid voice of the Vengeance protested.
tr: Chatterbox Revenge shouted in a shrill voice, "There is no one better than him in France."
es: —There is none better in all of France—responded La Venganza warmly.

en: “Peace, little Vengeance,” said Madame Defarge, laying her hand with a slight frown on her lieutenant’s lips, “hear me speak. My husband, fellow-citizen, is a good Republican and a bold man; he has deserved well of the Republic, and possesses its confidence. But my husband has his weaknesses, and he is so weak as to relent towards this Doctor.”
vi: − Quiet, Vengeance, - Madame Defarge frowned slightly and placed her hand on her assistant's lips - listen to me. My husband, Citizen Defarge, is a good Republican and a brave man; he deserves to be valued and trusted by the Republic. But my husband also has a weakness, he is soft-hearted to the point of being moved by that old doctor. −
tr: Madam Defarge, with her eyebrows slightly furrowed, brought her hand to her assistant's lips and said, "Calm down, Vengeance, listen to me carefully. Citizen husband, is a good Republican and a brave man; he has rendered great services to the Republic and has earned its trust. But he has some weaknesses, he is weak enough to show mercy to this Doctor."
es: —Calm down, my dear Vengeance—replied the innkeeper, placing a hand on her lieutenant's arm and slightly furrowing her brow. —Before expressing opinions, it's advisable that you listen to what I'm going to say. My husband, as a citizen, is a good republican and a man of valor; he has served the Republic well and has its trust; but my husband has his weaknesses, and one of the greatest, surely the greatest, is his fondness for the doctor.

en: “It is a great pity,” croaked Jacques Three, dubiously shaking his head, with his cruel fingers at his hungry mouth; “it is not quite like a good citizen; it is a thing to regret.”
vi: How pitiful, - Jacques Three said gruffly, shaking his head doubtfully, his cruel fingers hovering over his hungry mouth. Then he is not entirely a good Citizen; it is a pity.
tr: Jacques Three shouted in a hoarse voice, "What a pity," and shook his head skeptically with his cruel fingers in his open mouth; "this is not befitting a good citizen at all; very bad."
es: —It's a disgrace!—exclaimed Santiago Tercero, shaking his head with an enigmatic expression. —Those weaknesses are unbecoming of a good citizen... What a pity!

en: “See you,” said madame, “I care nothing for this Doctor, I. He may wear his head or lose it, for any interest I have in him; it is all one to me. But, the Evrémonde people are to be exterminated, and the wife and child must follow the husband and father.”
vi: − You see, - said Madame Defarge, - I don't care about that doctor. Whether he loses his head or not, it doesn't matter to me. But the Evrémonde family must be exterminated, his wife and children must follow him. −
tr: "Look," said the madam, "I don't care about this Doctor at all. Whether his head stays or goes, it's all the same to me. But no one from the Evremonde family should remain; his wife and child should follow him."
es: —What matters least to me is the doctor—replied the innkeeper.— As for me, he can keep his head on his shoulders or lose it; it makes no difference to me; but the Evrémonde race must be exterminated, it must disappear from the earth, and consequently, the wife and daughter must follow the husband and father to the other world.

en: “She has a fine head for it,” croaked Jacques Three. “I have seen blue eyes and golden hair there, and they looked charming when Samson held them up.” Ogre that he was, he spoke like an epicure.
vi: His wife has a head fit for the guillotine, - Jacques Three growled. - I have seen the heads of women with blue eyes and blonde hair, and each one was attractive when Samson held it up. This bloodthirsty person speaks like a gourmet.
tr: Jacques Three shouted again in his hoarse voice, "The woman's head is too beautiful for this job." "I had seen blue eyes and blonde hair there before; when Samson lifted them, they looked magnificent." He spoke with all his cruelty, like a connoisseur of taste.
es: —And what a beautiful head it is, if there ever was one; a head that is screaming for the Guillotine—replied Santiago Tercero. — There is nothing as thrilling as seeing a little head with blue eyes and golden hair hanging from the hands of our good Samson.

en: Madame Defarge cast down her eyes, and reflected a little.
vi: Madame Defarge bowed her head in thought for a moment. −
tr: Madam Defarge lowered her eyes and thought for a while.
es: Mrs. Defarge lowered her eyes and remained in a reflective attitude for a few moments.

en: “The child also,” observed Jacques Three, with a meditative enjoyment of his words, “has golden hair and blue eyes. And we seldom have a child there. It is a pretty sight!”
vi: The child as well, - Jacques Three said, savoring each word, - also with blond hair and blue eyes. I rarely see children go to the guillotine. Must know! −
tr: Jacques Üç, "Also, the child has blonde hair and blue eyes," he said with absent-minded pleasure, "and we don't often see children there. It's a pleasant sight!"
es: —The girl also has golden hair and blue eyes—replied Santiago Tercero. —Moreover, we are rarely granted the pleasure of seeing girls of her age on the stage. It will be a magnificent spectacle.

en: “In a word,” said Madame Defarge, coming out of her short abstraction, “I cannot trust my husband in this matter. Not only do I feel, since last night, that I dare not confide to him the details of my projects; but also I feel that if I delay, there is danger of his giving warning, and then they might escape.”
vi: In short, - Madame Defarge had passed the moment of contemplation, - in this matter, I do not trust my husband. Since last night, not only do I feel that I dare not disclose the details of this plan to him; but I also feel that if I hesitate, there is a risk he will alert them to escape.
tr: Madam Defarge, "In short," she said, snapping out of her reverie, "I cannot trust my husband on this matter. I've been thinking since last night, and it's not a good idea to tell him the details of my plan. Moreover, if I delay, there's a danger that my husband might warn them, and thus they could escape."
es: —Speaking frankly—said the innkeeper's wife, shaking off her abstraction,—in this matter, I do not trust my husband. Not only am I convinced since last night that I should not confide the details of my plans to him, but also that, if we lose any time, he is very capable of warning them of the danger they are in, in which case, they will escape us.

en: “That must never be,” croaked Jacques Three; “no one must escape. We have not half enough as it is. We ought to have six score a day.”
vi: − Absolutely not, - Jacques Three exclaimed, - no one is to escape. At the moment, we have only half the number that need to be executed. We should be executing one hundred and twenty heads each day. −
tr: "Such a thing must never happen," shouted Jacques Three; "no one should escape. We are only at half the number we want. A hundred and twenty heads must roll every day."
es: —They won't escape, no... not one or half!—grumbled Santiago Tercero.—They will all fall, to the last one! We must reach sixty daily!

en: “In a word,” Madame Defarge went on, “my husband has not my reason for pursuing this family to annihilation, and I have not his reason for regarding this Doctor with any sensibility. I must act for myself, therefore. Come hither, little citizen.”
vi: In short, - Madame Defarge continued, - my husband has no reason like I do to annihilate this entire family, and I have no reason like he does to show mercy to the old doctor. Therefore, I must act on my own. Come here, little Citizen.
tr: "In short," continued Madam Defarge, "my husband does not care as much as I do whether this whole family is exterminated, and I am not in a position to show understanding to the Doctor. Therefore, I must fend for myself. Come here, little citizen."
es: —In a word—added the innkeeper's wife,—neither my husband has the reasons I do to demand the total extermination of that race, nor do I have the reasons he does to treat the doctor with consideration. Consequently, I must disregard him and act on my own. You may enter, citizen—she concluded, addressing the sawyer.

en: The wood-sawyer, who held her in the respect, and himself in the submission, of mortal fear, advanced with his hand to his red cap.
vi: The sawyer, holding the red hat in his hand, approached respectfully and obsequiously before Madame Defarge out of fear for his life.
tr: Under the influence of the mortal fear he felt, the sawyer, showing respect and obedience to the woman, approached with his red hat in hand.
es: He obeyed, trembling, the sawyer, who appeared with the red cap in hand.

en: “Touching those signals, little citizen,” said Madame Defarge, sternly, “that she made to the prisoners; you are ready to bear witness to them this very day?”
vi: − Short citizen, - Madame Defarge's voice was cold, - regarding the matter of Madame Evrémonde signaling to the prisoners; are you ready to testify today? −
tr: Madam Defarge, "Little citizen, regarding the signals the woman sent to the prisoners," she said in a stern tone, "are you ready to testify?""
es: —Regarding the signals you saw that woman making to the prisoners, are you willing to support them with your statement at any time, citizen?—asked the innkeeper.

en: “Ay, ay, why not!” cried the sawyer. “Every day, in all weathers, from two to four, always signalling, sometimes with the little one, sometimes without. I know what I know. I have seen with my eyes.”
vi: Yes, yes, why not! - The wood-sawyer exclaimed. - Every day, rain or shine, from two to four in the afternoon, always signaling, sometimes with a child, sometimes alone. I know for sure. I saw it with my own eyes.
tr: "Of course, why not!" shouted the sawyer. "The woman, regardless of snow or cold, sent signals every day from two to four o'clock, sometimes with a child, sometimes without. I know what it was. I saw it with my own eyes."
es: —Why not? From here, I have seen her every day, rainy or clear, cold or hot, from two in the afternoon until four, sometimes with the girl, other times alone, and always making signals. These very eyes have seen it.

en: He made all manner of gestures while he spoke, as if in incidental imitation of some few of the great diversity of signals that he had never seen.
vi: He spoke while gesticulating wildly, as if mimicking various random signs that he actually didn't see.
tr: While saying these things, he made all sorts of hand and arm gestures, as if he were repeating some of the various signs he had never actually seen.
es: While speaking, he made a great variety of gestures with his hands that I had never seen before.

en: “Clearly plots,” said Jacques Three. “Transparently!”
vi: − The scheme is clear, - said Jacques Three. - Without a doubt! −
tr: "It is clear that there is a conspiracy," said Jacques Three. "Very obvious!"
es: —Plots... machinations... it's undeniable—replied Santiago Tercero. —Can we count on the jury?—asked the innkeeper.

en: “There is no doubt of the Jury?” inquired Madame Defarge, letting her eyes turn to him with a gloomy smile.
vi: Is the jury certain of that? - Madame Defarge turned to ask the person, with a sinister smile.
tr: Madam Defarge, with a sorrowful smile, turned her eyes to him and asked, "Well, what will the jury say to this?"
es: —Not at all.

en: “Rely upon the patriotic Jury, dear citizeness. I answer for my fellow-Jurymen.”
vi: − Trust the patriotic jury, Citizeness. I vouch for the Citizens of the jury.
tr: "You can trust the patriotic jury, dear citizen. I say this on behalf of my friends on the jury."
es: It is a patriotic jury, citizen. I vouch for all its members.

en: “Now, let me see,” said Madame Defarge, pondering again. “Yet once more! Can I spare this Doctor to my husband? I have no feeling either way. Can I spare him?”
vi: − Now let's see, - Madame Defarge pondered. - Another matter! Can I spare the old doctor for my husband's sake? I don't care about him. Can he be spared? −
tr: "Wait a moment," said Madam Defarge and fell into thoughts again. "Alright then! Shall we spare that Doctor for my husband's sake? For me, his presence or absence does not matter. But shall we spare him for my husband's sake?"
es: —Another thing...—added the innkeeper, pondering. — Let's see..... Can I forgive the doctor for my husband's sake? It's all the same to me... the doctor is indifferent to me... Can I forgive him?

en: “He would count as one head,” observed Jacques Three, in a low voice. “We really have not heads enough; it would be a pity, I think.”
vi: He also counts as a head, - Jacques Three whispered. - Currently, we are short of heads; it would be a waste to let him go, I think.
tr: "Another head for the doctor," said Jacques Three, in a low voice. "We haven't reached a sufficient number of heads yet; I think it would be a pity."
es: —It would be one more head—observed Santiago Tercero. —Heads are beginning to be scarce... soon they will be even scarcer... I think it would be a shame to pardon him.

en: “He was signalling with her when I saw her,” argued Madame Defarge; “I cannot speak of one without the other; and I must not be silent, and trust the case wholly to him, this little citizen here. For, I am not a bad witness.”
vi: − He also made signals together with his daughter when I met her, - reasoned Madame Defarge. - I cannot accuse this one without accusing the other; and I must not remain silent and leave all this to that man, Citizen Short. Because I am also a legitimate witness.
tr: "When I saw him, he was also signaling next to his daughter," Madam Defarge supported; "it wouldn't be right to accuse the daughter and not the father; that's why I must not remain silent and should not place all the blame on this little citizen. I'm not a bad witness either."
es: —When I found him in front of the place where we are, he was making the same signs as his daughter—said Mrs. Defarge. —If I speak of one, I must necessarily speak of the other. On the other hand, it is not possible for me to remain silent, so I place all the responsibility of the case on this citizen. He will declare whatever he wants. As for me, the only thing I can say is that I will never be a false witness.

en: The Vengeance and Jacques Three vied with each other in their fervent protestations that she was the most admirable and marvellous of witnesses. The little citizen, not to be outdone, declared her to be a celestial witness.
vi: The Goddess of Vengeance and Jacques Three loudly argued over praising Madame Defarge as the most wonderful and admirable witness. Not to be outdone, the short Citizen also called her a divine witness.
