tr: Revenge and Jacques Three, heatedly objected and competed with each other to say that the madam was the most commendable and magnificent witness. The little citizen, on the other hand, claimed she was a divine witness in order not to be left out.
es: La Venganza and Santiago Tercero demonstrated as clear as daylight that, far from being a false witness, they had always been a mirror of admirable and wonderful witnesses, and the citizen sawyer, not wanting to be left behind, protested to heaven and earth that Mrs. Defarge was a celestial witness.

en: “He must take his chance,” said Madame Defarge. “No, I cannot spare him! You are engaged at three o’clock; you are going to see the batch of to-day executed.—You?”
vi: − You must accept the risks, - said Madame Defarge. - No, I cannot spare him! You have an appointment at three o'clock; you will go to see the execution of the people today... And you?
tr: "Let the man try his luck," said Madam Defarge. "Alright, I won't keep him separate from the others! At three o'clock, you are on duty; you will go to watch the group to be executed today. –And you?"
es: —Let his fate be fulfilled!—said the innkeeper. —No; I cannot forgive him... I suppose, citizen, that you cannot make yourself available at three today, for I believe you won't deny yourself the pleasure of watching today's batch, right?

en: The question was addressed to the wood-sawyer, who hurriedly replied in the affirmative: seizing the occasion to add that he was the most ardent of Republicans, and that he would be in effect the most desolate of Republicans, if anything prevented him from enjoying the pleasure of smoking his afternoon pipe in the contemplation of the droll national barber. He was so very demonstrative herein, that he might have been suspected (perhaps was, by the dark eyes that looked contemptuously at him out of Madame Defarge’s head) of having his small individual fears for his own personal safety, every hour in the day.
vi: This question was directed at the wood-sawyer, who hastily replied affirmatively and took the opportunity to add that he was the most enthusiastic Republican, and in fact, would be the most miserable Republican if anything prevented him from enjoying the afternoon pleasure of smoking his pipe while watching the fun of the national razor. He said this so fervently that it could be suspected that every day and every hour he also feared for his own safety; and from the dark look Madame Defarge gave him, full of contempt, it seemed she might also be suspecting this.
tr: The question was directed at the sawyer, and he immediately responded positively. He was already looking for an opportunity to declare himself the most enthusiastic Republican, and if anything were to deprive him of the pleasure of puffing on his pipe while watching that peculiar national barber in the afternoon, he would turn into the most miserable Republican. His mannerisms were so exaggerated while saying these things that one might suspect he had small personal fears about his own safety at every moment (which, judging by the contemptuous dark eyes Madam Defarge fixed on him, was probably the case).
es: The sawyer immediately replied that he would not miss such a beautiful spectacle for anything in the world, which gave him the opportunity to add that he was the most fervent republican, and that he would consider himself the most desolate of republicans if one day he was prevented from smoking his pipe while watching the beautiful operation of the National Barber's Razor.

en: “I,” said madame, “am equally engaged at the same place. After it is over—say at eight to-night—come you to me, in Saint Antoine, and we will give information against these people at my Section.”
vi: She said: − I also have business there. After it's all done, come see me at eight o'clock tonight, at Saint Antoine, and we will go denounce these people at the district committee at my place.
tr: "Me too," said the madam, "I will be there. When the work is done – that is, around eight in the evening – come to me, to St Antoine, so we can report these to the people in my area."
es: —I will also attend—replied the innkeeper. —After the performance ends... at eight... yes; it's a good time... at eight you will come to find me at San Antonio to denounce those individuals in my section.

en: The wood-sawyer said he would be proud and flattered to attend the citizeness. The citizeness looking at him, he became embarrassed, evaded her glance as a small dog would have done, retreated among his wood, and hid his confusion over the handle of his saw.
vi: The sawyer said he would be proud and honored to accompany Citizeness Defarge. Citizeness Defarge glared at him, and he awkwardly avoided her gaze like a frightened dog, retreating to stand among his pile of wood, hiding his embarrassment behind the handle of his saw.
tr: The sawyer said he would be greatly honored and pleased to serve her. But then, feeling ashamed of her gaze, he scurried out of her sight like a small dog and retreated among his logs, taking up his saw to try to conceal the turmoil within him.
es: The sawyer replied that it would be a great honor and immense satisfaction for him to attend the appointment given by the lady.

en: Madame Defarge beckoned the Juryman and The Vengeance a little nearer to the door, and there expounded her further views to them thus:
vi: Madame Defarge signaled to the juryman and the Vengeance to move closer to the door and explained her intention to them more clearly: −
tr: Madam Defarge signaled to the jury member and Revenge to come a little closer to the door and elaborated on her thoughts to them:
es: Mrs. Defarge approached the workshop door, signaled to Santiago Tercero and La Venganza, and once they were by her side, she clearly explained her points of view to them.

en: “She will now be at home, awaiting the moment of his death. She will be mourning and grieving. She will be in a state of mind to impeach the justice of the Republic. She will be full of sympathy with its enemies. I will go to her.”
vi: His wife will be at home now, waiting for her husband's death. She will mourn and grieve. She will be in a state that violates the laws of the Republic. It will fully reveal its affection for the nation's enemy. I will go to its place. −
tr: "His wife will arrive home soon, waiting for her husband's death. She mourns and sheds tears. She is now in a state of doubting the justice of the Republic. Therefore, she has sympathy for its enemies. I will go to her."
es: —Surely she is at this moment in her house, waiting for the news of her husband's death—he said. —In her pain and despair, she will not only mourn the misfortune that afflicts her, but she will also criticize the justice of the Republic. All her sympathies will be with the enemies of the people; thus, I will go to see her without losing a moment.

en: “What an admirable woman; what an adorable woman!” exclaimed Jacques Three, rapturously. “Ah, my cherished!” cried The Vengeance; and embraced her.
vi: You are truly admirable; you are truly admirable! - Jacques Ba exclaimed joyfully. − Oh, how adorable! - The Goddess of Vengeance exclaimed as she hugged Madame Defarge tightly.
tr: Jacques Üç, in a drunken state, exclaimed, "What a magnificent woman, what a magnificent woman!" Revenge also shouted, "Ah, you are a saint!" and embraced her.
es: —What an admirable woman! What an adorable patriot!—exclaimed Santiago Tercero, whose enthusiasm reached the indescribable. Revenge embraced her, crying in a rapture of admiration.

en: “Take you my knitting,” said Madame Defarge, placing it in her lieutenant’s hands, “and have it ready for me in my usual seat. Keep me my usual chair. Go you there, straight, for there will probably be a greater concourse than usual, to-day.”
vi: − Take my knitting with you, - Madame Defarge handed the items to her assistant, - and have it ready for me at my usual seat. Keep my seat as usual. Go there now, go immediately, because today there will be more spectators than usual.
tr: Madam Defarge said, "Take my knitting," and handed it to her assistant, "and put it where I always sit." "Hold my usual chair for me." "Go there directly now, there might be a bigger crowd than usual today.""
es: —Take my knitting—replied Madame Defarge, placing it in the hands of The Vengeance,—and have it ready for me in my usual seat. Go straight there, don't waste time, as it is almost certain that there will be more people than usual today.

en: “I willingly obey the orders of my Chief,” said The Vengeance with alacrity, and kissing her cheek. “You will not be late?”
vi: − Ready to obey the leader, - The Vengeance eagerly said and kissed Madame Defarge's cheek. - You won't be late, will you?
tr: With enthusiasm for revenge, "I will gladly carry out your orders, chief," he said, kissing him on the cheeks. "You won't be late, right?"
es: —With all my soul, I will obey my boss's orders—answered La Venganza, kissing the barmaid on the cheek. — Will you take long?

en: “I shall be there before the commencement.”
vi: − I will be there before it starts. −
tr: "I'll be out of there before they start."
es: —I'll be there before the show starts.

en: “And before the tumbrils arrive. Be sure you are there, my soul,” said The Vengeance, calling after her, for she had already turned into the street, “before the tumbrils arrive!”
vi: And before the execution cart arrives. Make sure to come early, dear, The Vengeance called after her, as the other had already stepped out onto the street - before the execution cart arrives!
tr: Revenge, "Come before the cars arrive. Don't be late, my dear," he shouted after her, for madam had already turned into the street "before the cars arrive!"
es: —I'll be there before the show starts. —Try to arrive before the carts—replied La Venganza.

en: Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand, to imply that she heard, and might be relied upon to arrive in good time, and so went through the mud, and round the corner of the prison wall. The Vengeance and the Juryman, looking after her as she walked away, were highly appreciative of her fine figure, and her superb moral endowments.
vi: With a slight wave to indicate she had heard and would surely be on time, Madame Defarge walked through the mud and around the corner of the prison. The Vengeance and the juryman watched her, admiring the graceful figure and steadfast spirit of the woman walking away.
tr: Madam Defarge lightly waved her hand as if to indicate that she had heard and would be there on time, and trudged through the mud, turning the corner of the prison wall. As Madam walked away, Vengeance and the jury member, who were watching her, spoke with great admiration about her graceful demeanor and superior morals.
es: The tavern keeper left the workshop at a brisk pace, soon disappearing from sight. Many were the women in that era whose moral silhouettes cannot be contemplated, despite the distance of time, without horror and disgust; but among them, there was none so inhuman, so fierce, so ruthless, as the one we now leave heading to the residence of the unfortunate Dr. Manette.

en: There were many women at that time, upon whom the time laid a dreadfully disfiguring hand; but, there was not one among them more to be dreaded than this ruthless woman, now taking her way along the streets. Of a strong and fearless character, of shrewd sense and readiness, of great determination, of that kind of beauty which not only seems to impart to its possessor firmness and animosity, but to strike into others an instinctive recognition of those qualities; the troubled time would have heaved her up, under any circumstances. But, imbued from her childhood with a brooding sense of wrong, and an inveterate hatred of a class, opportunity had developed her into a tigress. She was absolutely without pity. If she had ever had the virtue in her, it had quite gone out of her.
vi: In those days, the terrifying molding hand of fate had caused many women to become horribly corrupted, but none were as frightening as the cruel woman walking on the road over there. With a strong and stubborn personality, sharp and quick-witted, a heart of stone, and even a beauty that radiated resentment and determination, anyone who saw her would immediately recognize; clearly, she was a person created by chaotic times. But from a young age, she had harbored a deep awareness of injustice and a profound class hatred, and this era had turned her into a fierce tiger. She knew no compassion. If she ever had any compassion, that feeling had long since died.
tr: In that era, there were many women who had been worn down by the harsh effects of the times; but none were as terrifying as this ruthless woman who marched forward resolutely. Her strong and fearless character, solid intuition and swiftness, and tremendous determination not only made her appear stern and harsh but also allowed her beauty, which instinctively highlighted these traits, to become even more pronounced during these challenging times. Since childhood, she had turned into a tigress due to her contemplation of injustices and the class hatred that had taken root within her. There wasn't the slightest bit of mercy in her. If she ever possessed this virtue once, it was now completely gone.
es: Many were the women in that era whose moral silhouettes cannot be contemplated, despite the distance of time, without horror and disgust; but among them, there was none so inhuman, so fierce, so ruthless, as the one we now leave heading to the residence of the unfortunate Dr. Manette. She was a woman inaccessible to fear, inflexible, intelligent, cunning, and resolute, endowed with that special beauty that instills in the spirit of its possessor a firmness and animosity that forces others to pay instinctive homage to the expressed qualities. Had she lived in a less troubled time, had she moved in a different theater, who knows if she might have been the glory of her sex; but a victim from childhood of social injustices, grown in an atmosphere of implacable class hatred, she became a tiger. She was utterly devoid of pity; and if ever virtue nested in her soul, she had extirpated it many years before, leaving not a trace of it.

en: It was nothing to her, that an innocent man was to die for the sins of his forefathers; she saw, not him, but them. It was nothing to her, that his wife was to be made a widow and his daughter an orphan; that was insufficient punishment, because they were her natural enemies and her prey, and as such had no right to live. To appeal to her, was made hopeless by her having no sense of pity, even for herself. If she had been laid low in the streets, in any of the many encounters in which she had been engaged, she would not have pitied herself; nor, if she had been ordered to the axe to-morrow, would she have gone to it with any softer feeling than a fierce desire to change places with the man who sent her there.
vi: It meant nothing to her that an innocent person had to die for the sins of their forefathers; she did not see this person but only saw the evil predecessors. It meant nothing to her that this person's wife would become a widow and their daughter would become an orphan. She only knew that the punishment was not enough, because they were natural enemies and her prey, therefore they had no right to live. Appealing to her was hopeless because this woman no longer had any compassion, not even for herself. If she were to collapse on the battlefield in some fight she had joined, she wouldn't regret her life; and if she herself were to face the guillotine tomorrow, she would feel nothing but a fierce desire to behead the one who had brought her to the scaffold.
tr: It meant nothing to him that an innocent person was going to death because of the sins of their ancestors; it wasn't just him in front of him, they were all there. It also meant nothing to him that his wife would be a widow and his daughter an orphan; this punishment was too little, because they were his natural enemies and prey; therefore, they had no right to live. Since there was no mercy within him, there was no point in begging him, not even for himself. If he were to be defeated and laid low in one of those frequent struggles in the streets, he would not pity himself, or if he were to go to the guillotine tomorrow, he would feel nothing but the desire to send the man who sent him there to death in his place.
es: What did it matter that an innocent person died for sins committed by their ancestors? Her relentless fury did not see the first, but the last. Nor did it matter to leave a poor woman widowed or her daughter orphaned; rather, she considered the punishment insufficient since it involved her natural enemies, her prey, beings who had no right to live. Trying to appease her was useless, for she lacked the ability to feel compassion, not only for others but even for herself. If in any of the many encounters in which she took part she had fallen under the hand of her enemies, she would have accepted her misfortune as something natural and ordinary, and if they had forced her to climb the fatal staircase ending at the guillotine, she would have offered her neck without any other feelings arising in her fierce soul than a rabid desire to trade places with the man who sent her there.

en: Such a heart Madame Defarge carried under her rough robe. Carelessly worn, it was a becoming robe enough, in a certain weird way, and her dark hair looked rich under her coarse red cap. Lying hidden in her bosom, was a loaded pistol. Lying hidden at her waist, was a sharpened dagger. Thus accoutred, and walking with the confident tread of such a character, and with the supple freedom of a woman who had habitually walked in her girlhood, bare-foot and bare-legged, on the brown sea-sand, Madame Defarge took her way along the streets.
vi: That is the sentiment that Madame Defarge harbors beneath her tattered cloak. The wrinkled cloth, draped haphazardly over her body to form a cloak, was peculiar; her jet-black hair seemed even more lustrous under the coarse red hat. Hidden in her chest was a loaded pistol. Concealed at her waist was a sharpened short sword. Equipped as such, Madame Defarge set out with the confident stride of a determined person, with the easy grace of a woman accustomed from childhood to walking barefoot on the brown sand.
tr: Here is Madam Defarge, carrying such a heart under that coarse attire. The outfit she wore carelessly suited her in a strange way, and her black hair looked much fuller under that cheap red cap. She had a loaded pistol hidden in her bosom. And a sharp dagger at her waist. Madam Defarge, fully equipped like this, moved through the streets with the confident demeanor of a character of this style and the agile ease of someone accustomed to walking barefoot and bare-legged on the beach since her girlhood.
es: Such was the heart that beat beneath the coarse dress of Madame Defarge. Dirty, ragged, it was still a dress, even if it presented a gloomy appearance, just as her abundant mass of black hair, poorly contained within the red cap, did not fail to offer some attraction. Hidden in her bosom she always carried a loaded pistol and at her waist a long, sharp dagger. Thus attired, walking with a confident step, with that freedom of movement typical of a woman who since childhood has gone wherever her desires or whims have taken her, barefoot and bare-legged, the tavern keeper Defarge left street after street behind her.

en: Now, when the journey of the travelling coach, at that very moment waiting for the completion of its load, had been planned out last night, the difficulty of taking Miss Pross in it had much engaged Mr. Lorry’s attention. It was not merely desirable to avoid overloading the coach, but it was of the highest importance that the time occupied in examining it and its passengers, should be reduced to the utmost; since their escape might depend on the saving of only a few seconds here and there. Finally, he had proposed, after anxious consideration, that Miss Pross and Jerry, who were at liberty to leave the city, should leave it at three o’clock in the lightest-wheeled conveyance known to that period. Unencumbered with luggage, they would soon overtake the coach, and, passing it and preceding it on the road, would order its horses in advance, and greatly facilitate its progress during the precious hours of the night, when delay was the most to be dreaded.
vi: At this moment, as the carriage on the road was waiting to complete its journey, the escape plan for Miss Pross and Jerry Cruncher had been carefully devised; this was the difficult issue that had caused Mr. Lorry to worry last night. Having Miss Pross follow behind would be the best way to lighten the carriage's load and minimize the time spent on document checks and passenger interrogations; because the success of this escape depended on saving every second along the way. Finally, after careful consideration, he proposed that Miss Pross and Jerry, who were free to leave the city, should set off at three o'clock using the fastest carriage available at that time. Without being burdened by luggage, they would quickly catch up with the four-horse carriage, overtake it, and run ahead to hire horses in advance; this way, they would save precious time during the night, which is when delays are most commonly encountered.
tr: While making plans for the carriage that was now waiting to take its final load and for this journey, the matter of how to take Miss Pross had greatly occupied Mr. Lorry's mind last night. This was necessary not only to avoid overloading the carriage but also to minimize the time spent during the inspection of the carriage and passengers at the barricades; for their escape could depend on the few seconds gained here and there. After a series of anxious thoughts, Mr. Lorry finally suggested that Miss Pross and Jerry, who had permits to leave the city, should depart at three o'clock by the fastest means available at that time. Since they had no luggage, they would catch up with them shortly, or even get ahead to prepare the horses in advance, and while everyone was in fear of being late, they would have made this journey in the valuable hours of the night much easier.
es: It will be necessary for us to make a small digression in order to clarify some points that the reader might find obscure. The previous night, when Lorry was finalizing the preparations for the fugitives' journey, the difficulty of bringing Miss Pross with him was a source of great concern for him. Not only was it highly desirable to avoid excess baggage that might hinder their progress, but also to minimize the time spent at the Barrier for examining documents and identifying travelers, as the salvation of all could depend on taking advantage of or losing mere seconds of time. After long considerations, and not without carefully weighing the disadvantages and advantages, he had proposed leaving Miss Pross and Jeremiah Lapa, who could leave the city whenever it suited them, with orders to start their journey at three in the morning, using one of the lightest carriages then known. Free from the encumbrance of luggage, they would soon catch up with the gentlemen, and might even leave them behind.

en: Seeing in this arrangement the hope of rendering real service in that pressing emergency, Miss Pross hailed it with joy. She and Jerry had beheld the coach start, had known who it was that Solomon brought, had passed some ten minutes in tortures of suspense, and were now concluding their arrangements to follow the coach, even as Madame Defarge, taking her way through the streets, now drew nearer and nearer to the else-deserted lodging in which they held their consultation.
vi: Seeing that this arrangement had the potential to help the urgent situation, Miss Pross gladly accepted. She and Jerry had seen Mr. Lorry's carriage depart, knew who Solomon had brought, endured ten tense and miserable minutes, and were now making final preparations to follow the previous carriage. Meanwhile, Madame Defarge was making her way through the streets, getting closer and closer to the desolate house where only two servants were discussing.
tr: Miss Pross, who had the opportunity to provide a real service in this urgent and dangerous situation, welcomed all these arrangements with joy. Together with Jerry, they had seen the departure of the carriage, understood who the person brought by Solomon was, and after writhing in curiosity for about ten minutes, they had followed the carriage as the final stage of the plan. Meanwhile, Madam Defarge, advancing through the streets, was getting closer to the deserted house where all those plans were made.
es: Miss Pross gladly accepted a proposition that offered her the opportunity to render some important service to her loved ones. She and Jeremiah had met the person whom her brother Solomon had brought in a fainting state in a carriage, had seen off the travelers, had spent ten minutes in terrible anxiety, and were making the final preparations to set off and catch up with the carriage at the moment when the tavern keeper Defarge was approaching the house, with intentions that the readers know perfectly well.

en: “Now what do you think, Mr. Cruncher,” said Miss Pross, whose agitation was so great that she could hardly speak, or stand, or move, or live: “what do you think of our not starting from this courtyard? Another carriage having already gone from here to-day, it might awaken suspicion.”
vi: − Now what do you plan to do, Mr. Cruncher, - Miss Pross said, so tense that she didn't know how to stand or speak.- What do you think about the idea of not departing from this yard? Another carriage leaving from here might arouse suspicion.
tr: "What do you think now, Mr. Cruncher?" said Miss Pross, she was so distressed that she could barely speak, stand, move, or even live; "Shouldn't we start our journey from this courtyard? A carriage already left from here today, it might arouse suspicion."
es: —What do you think, Mr. Lapa?—asked Miss Pross, whose agitation was so great that it neither let her speak, nor move, nor stand, nor live.— What do you think of our trip? The departure of two carriages in such a short period of time is bound to arouse suspicion; at least, that is what I fear.

en: “My opinion, miss,” returned Mr. Cruncher, “is as you’re right. Likewise wot I’ll stand by you, right or wrong.”
vi: −You're right, Miss, - Cruncher replied. - Whether right or wrong, I'll follow your advice.
tr: "If you ask me, madam," said Mr. Cruncher, "you are right. In the end, whether right or wrong, I will do whatever you say."
es: —My opinion, miss, is that you are right—replied Lapa—. I also believe that I will always support whatever you say, whether you are right or wrong.

en: “I am so distracted with fear and hope for our precious creatures,” said Miss Pross, wildly crying, “that I am incapable of forming any plan. Are you capable of forming any plan, my dear good Mr. Cruncher?”
vi: −I'm so confused because I'm both scared and anxious for our dear ones that I can't think straight, - Miss Pross burst into tears.- And can you think of anything, dear Mr. Cruncher?
tr: "I have such great fear and hope for our dear ones," said Miss Pross, exclaiming excitedly, "that I am not in a position to make any plans. Dear Mr. Cruncher, are you in a position to make a plan?"
es: —To such an extent do fear and hope for the fate of our masters drive me mad—replied Miss Pross, crying inconsolably,—that I am incapable of forming any rational plan. And you, Mr. Lorry, my dear Mr. Lorry, do you feel capable of forming any reasonably rational plan?

en: “Respectin’ a future spear o’ life, miss,” returned Mr. Cruncher, “I hope so. Respectin’ any present use o’ this here blessed old head o’ mine, I think not. Would you do me the favour, miss, to take notice o’ two promises and wows wot it is my wishes fur to record in this here crisis?”
vi: −As for the future, there's a lifetime to think about it, - Cruncher replied, - I hope so. But right now, I’m sure this head of mine can't think of anything. Would you be so kind as to listen to two promises and also an oath I want to make at this critical moment?
tr: "Well ma'am, something like this might happen in the future," said Mr. Cruncher, "but right now, in my old age, I can't think of anything. Would you like to hear the two promises I made and the oaths I took during this difficult time, ma'am?"
es: —Regarding the afterlife, miss, I believe so—replied Jeremiah Lapa;—but regarding the present use of this blessed head I carry on my shoulders, I fear not. Would you, miss, take charge of two promises or vows that I wish to make, as a perpetual reminder of the crisis we are in?

en: “Oh, for gracious sake!” cried Miss Pross, still wildly crying, “record them at once, and get them out of the way, like an excellent man.”
vi: −Oh, dear Lord! - Miss Pross exclaimed, still sobbing, - record them right away, say them quickly so we can discuss, please speak fast.
tr: "Oh my God!" Miss Pross exclaimed excitedly again, "say it properly so we can continue on our way."
es: —God help us!—exclaimed Miss Pross, crying out loud.— Make those vows or promises immediately, do them without losing a moment like the good Christian you are.

en: “First,” said Mr. Cruncher, who was all in a tremble, and who spoke with an ashy and solemn visage, “them poor things well out o’ this, never no more will I do it, never no more!”
vi: −First, - Cruncher trembling all over, spoke with a pale, serious face, - if those poor people escape this, I will never do that job again, never!
tr: "First of all," said the trembling Mr. Cruncher, with an ashen pale and serious face, "let these poor souls be saved, I will never do this job again, never!"
es: —The first thing I promise—said Lapa, trembling like a leaf and with a pathetic expression,—the first thing I swear, is never to do again some little things I used to do before... No; never again.

en: “I am quite sure, Mr. Cruncher,” returned Miss Pross, “that you never will do it again, whatever it is, and I beg you not to think it necessary to mention more particularly what it is.”
vi: −Of course, Mr. Cruncher, you will never do it again, whatever it is, and I ask you not to specify what that job is.
tr: "Whatever that thing is you mentioned, Mr. Cruncher," said Miss Pross, "I am sure you will not do it again and please do not think that you need to explain to me what it is.""
es: —I am quite sure, Mr. Lapa, that he will never do them again, whatever those little things may be, which do not need to be mentioned.

en: “No, miss,” returned Jerry, “it shall not be named to you. Second: them poor things well out o’ this, and never no more will I interfere with Mrs. Cruncher’s flopping, never no more!”
vi: −No, Miss, I won't specify it. Second, if those poor people escape this, I will never stop my wife, Mrs. Cruncher, from sitting down to pray again, never!
tr: "No, madam," replied Jerry, "I will not tell you. Secondly, once these poor souls are freed, I will never interfere with Ms. Cruncher's work again!"
es: —No, miss; I will not mention them. The second thing I promise, the second thing I swear, is not to involve myself again in Mrs. Lapa's prayers. No; I will never again prevent her from spending her entire life on her knees.

en: “Whatever housekeeping arrangement that may be,” said Miss Pross, striving to dry her eyes and compose herself, “I have no doubt it is best that Mrs. Cruncher should have it entirely under her own superintendence.—O my poor darlings!”
vi: −Whatever your household situation is, - Miss Pross tried to wipe her tears and calm down, - I am sure that Mrs. Cruncher has every right to do as she wishes...Oh, my poor dear ones!
tr: "Whatever this matter is in your house," said Miss Pross, wiping the tears from her eyes and trying to pull herself together, "it would be best if Ms. Cruncher had complete control over it, of course. –Oh my poor ones!"
es: —You will do very well.—replied Miss Pross, drying the tears that blinded her. — Let your wife take care of the household matters... Oh... my poor young lady!

en: “I go so far as to say, miss, moreover,” proceeded Mr. Cruncher, with a most alarming tendency to hold forth as from a pulpit—“and let my words be took down and took to Mrs. Cruncher through yourself—that wot my opinions respectin’ flopping has undergone a change, and that wot I only hope with all my heart as Mrs. Cruncher may be a flopping at the present time.”
vi: −I even dare to say... - Cruncher continued in an exceedingly long-winded manner as if preaching, - ... and I want you to remember my words and convey them to Mrs. Cruncher...that my thoughts on her sitting down have changed and I sincerely hope that at this very moment Mrs. Cruncher is at home sitting down.
tr: Leaning forward anxiously as if giving a speech from a podium, "In fact, madam," continued Mr. Cruncher, "you personally remember what I said and tell Ms. Cruncher, explain to her how much my thoughts on praying have changed and how much I now wish she were praying.""
es: —I believe it is appropriate to state, miss—replied Lapa as if he were speaking from the top of a pulpit,—and I would like you to convey my words to Mrs. Lapa, that my opinions regarding prayers have undergone a radical change, and that with all my heart I wish that Mrs. Lapa were on her knees and praying at this moment.

en: “There, there, there! I hope she is, my dear man,” cried the distracted Miss Pross, “and I hope she finds it answering her expectations.”
vi: − That's right, that's right! I hope so too, sir, - cried Miss Pross in distress, - and I hope she gets everything she prays for.
tr: "Yes, yes, yes! I hope he is praying now, dear Jerry," cried the ecstatic Miss Pross, "I hope all his prayers are answered."
es: —Oh, yes! I hope she is praying, and I hope Heaven kindly listens to her prayers!

en: “Forbid it,” proceeded Mr. Cruncher, with additional solemnity, additional slowness, and additional tendency to hold forth and hold out, “as anything wot I have ever said or done should be wisited on my earnest wishes for them poor creeturs now! Forbid it as we shouldn’t all flop (if it was anyways conwenient) to get ’em out o’ this here dismal risk! Forbid it, miss! Wot I say, for-bid it!” This was Mr. Cruncher’s conclusion after a protracted but vain endeavour to find a better one.
vi: − God will punish... - Cruncher continued, becoming more solemn, slower, and increasingly verbose, - ... if I say or do anything to harm these dear ones! God will punish if we don't sit down, if convenient, to pray for their escape from this danger! God will punish, sister! I'm telling you, punish! - That was Cruncher's conclusion after rambling without finding a better way to say it.
tr: Mr. Cruncher, in a very solemn, very slow manner, and even more as if he were giving a speech, continued, "God help us," he said, "whatever I have said or done, may it benefit these poor creatures! God help us, (if it will help them get out of this terrible situation) let us kneel and pray! God help us, madam! Please help us, God!" Mr. Cruncher had tried to end his words in a better way, but it had not worked.
es: —I curse—continued Mr. Lapa with greater solemnity than ever—I curse everything I have done and said against the good souls who pray and spend their time on their knees! I curse all mortals who at this very moment are not on their knees and praying for the Lord to deliver us safely from this mortal danger in which we find ourselves! I curse, miss... I curse...! The good Lapa lowered his head after searching in vain for a few seconds for something else to curse.

en: And still Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came nearer and nearer.
vi: But Madame Defarge was still advancing along the road, getting closer and closer. −
tr: Meanwhile, Madam Defarge, who was progressing steadily on her path, had approached the house.
es: —If divine mercy wills that we ever reach our homeland—replied Miss Pross,—you can be absolutely certain that I will repeat to Mrs. Lapa everything you have just said in such eloquent language; and whatever happens, at all times you will find me ready to testify to your excellent intentions...

en: “If we ever get back to our native land,” said Miss Pross, “you may rely upon my telling Mrs. Cruncher as much as I may be able to remember and understand of what you have so impressively said; and at all events you may be sure that I shall bear witness to your being thoroughly in earnest at this dreadful time. Now, pray let us think! My esteemed Mr. Cruncher, let us think!”
vi: If we ever get back home, - said Miss Pross, - you can trust that I will tell Mrs. Cruncher everything I remember and understand from your very eloquent words; I will certainly testify that you were completely sincere in this dreadful moment. Now, pray that we come up with something! Dear Mr. Cruncher, let's think of a way!
tr: "If we can return to our homeland one day," said Miss Pross, "you can be sure that I will tell Ms. Cruncher as much of your impressive words as I can remember and understand, and you can trust that I will testify that you were completely serious about this matter during this terrible time. Now let's think, please! Dear Mr. Cruncher, let's think, come on!"
es: —If divine mercy wills that we ever reach our homeland—replied Miss Pross,—you can be absolutely certain that I will repeat to Mrs. Lapa everything you have just said in such eloquent language; and whatever happens, at all times you will find me ready to testify to your excellent intentions... But let us think, Mr. Lapa... let us think!

en: Still, Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along the streets, came nearer and nearer.
vi: But Madame Defarge was still advancing along the road, getting closer and closer. −
tr: Madame Defarge, still advancing steadily, was now much closer to home.
es: After a long period of deep meditation, Miss Pross said:

en: “If you were to go before,” said Miss Pross, “and stop the vehicle and horses from coming here, and were to wait somewhere for me; wouldn’t that be best?”
vi: If you go ahead, - said Miss Pross, - and prevent the carriage from coming here and wait for me somewhere, wouldn't that be better?
tr: "If you go ahead," said Miss Pross, "and prevent the carriage and horses from coming here, and wait for me somewhere, wouldn't that be better?"
es: —Don't you think it would be wise, Mr. Lapa, to order the car to wait somewhere else instead of coming here? If you like my suggestion, you could go out to give the notice, and I would go to the agreed-upon spot.

en: Mr. Cruncher thought it might be best.
vi: Cruncher thought that was the best way.
tr: Mr. Cruncher thought that this was a very good idea.
es: Jeremías Lapa replied that the plan seemed right to him.

en: “Where could you wait for me?” asked Miss Pross.
vi: − Where can you wait for me? - Miss Pross asked.
tr: "Where can you wait for me?" asked Miss Pross.
es: —Where could they be waiting for me?—asked Miss Pross.

en: Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he could think of no locality but Temple Bar. Alas! Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and Madame Defarge was drawing very near indeed.
vi: Cruncher was so bewildered that he couldn't think of any place other than the Temple Bar gate. Alas! Temple Bar was in London, hundreds of miles away, while Madame Defarge was approaching very close. −
tr: Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he couldn't think of any place other than Temple Bar. Oh no! Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and Madame Defarge had already gotten very close to the house.
es: So bewildered was Mr. Lapa that he could not think of a more suitable place than the sidewalk of the Temple Bar in London, next to Tellson's Bank. Unfortunate luck! The Tribunal of the Temple was hundreds of miles away, while the innkeeper Defarge was very close to the house.

en: “By the cathedral door,” said Miss Pross. “Would it be much out of the way, to take me in, near the great cathedral door between the two towers?”
vi: By the church gate, - Miss Pross said. - Meet me there, near the church gate with the two towers, would that be convenient for you?
tr: "At the cathedral door," said Miss Pross. "Would we be taking a much longer route if you picked me up at the cathedral door between the two towers?"
es: —Next to the cathedral door—said Miss Pross. —Do you think the cathedral door, between the two towers, is a good spot?

en: “No, miss,” answered Mr. Cruncher.
vi: − Convenient, ma'am, - Cruncher replied. −
tr: "No, ma'am," said Mr. Cruncher.
es: —It seems unbeatable, miss.

en: “Then, like the best of men,” said Miss Pross, “go to the posting-house straight, and make that change.”
vi: Then please, - Miss Pross said, - go immediately to the station and tell them to change the location.
tr: "Then like a proper man," said Miss Pross, "go straight to the relay station and change your horses.""
es: —Then, go to the post house and give the appropriate orders.

en: “I am doubtful,” said Mr. Cruncher, hesitating and shaking his head, “about leaving of you, you see. We don’t know what may happen.”
vi: − I'm worried about you staying here alone, - Cruncher hesitated, then shook his head. - What if something happens.
tr: Mr. Cruncher shook his head hesitantly, "I'm not sure about leaving you here alone. What if something happens to you?"
es: —The only thing that worries me—said Lapa, scratching his head,—is leaving you. We don't know what might happen.

en: “Heaven knows we don’t,” returned Miss Pross, “but have no fear for me. Take me in at the cathedral, at Three o’Clock, or as near it as you can, and I am sure it will be better than our going from here. I feel certain of it. There! Bless you, Mr. Cruncher! Think-not of me, but of the lives that may depend on both of us!”
vi: − Only God knows, - replied Miss Pross, - but don't worry about me. Just meet me at the church, at three o'clock, or earlier if possible, I am sure it will be better to leave from there than from here. I am certain of it. Go! God bless you, Mr. Cruncher! Don't think about me, but think about the lives depending on the two of us!
tr: "That is up to God now," said Miss Pross, "don't you worry. Pick me up at three o'clock or around three from the cathedral; it will definitely be much better than leaving from here. I am very sure of this. Let's go! God help you, Mr. Cruncher! Think not of me, but of those poor souls whose lives may depend on us!"
es: —Only God knows, it's true; but do not worry about me. Wait for me with the car at three o'clock sharp by the cathedral door, or as close as possible, which will certainly be less prone to mishaps than if we were to leave from here. God bless you, Mr. Lapa! Think not of our lives, which are of little value, but of the other more precious ones that probably depend on ours.

en: This exordium, and Miss Pross’s two hands in quite agonised entreaty clasping his, decided Mr. Cruncher. With an encouraging nod or two, he immediately went out to alter the arrangements, and left her by herself to follow as she had proposed.
vi: These words, along with Miss Pross's hands tightly gripping Cruncher's, earnestly pleading, convinced him. With a few encouraging nods, Cruncher immediately went to make arrangements, leaving Miss Pross alone as she had requested.
tr: These words and Miss Pross's pleading grip on his hands had convinced Mr. Cruncher. After nodding encouragingly a couple of times, he immediately went out to get ready and left Miss Pross alone, as she had suggested.
es: These words, and Miss Pross's attitude, who was extending her pleading hands towards him, finally convinced Lapa, who immediately left, ready to carry out the task.

en: The having originated a precaution which was already in course of execution, was a great relief to Miss Pross. The necessity of composing her appearance so that it should attract no special notice in the streets, was another relief. She looked at her watch, and it was twenty minutes past two. She had no time to lose, but must get ready at once.
vi: Miss Pross felt very reassured after thinking of the precautionary measures being implemented. Another reassuring thing was that she had the necessary time to tidy up her appearance so as not to attract attention when going out. She looked at the clock. Two twenty. She must not waste any more time; she had to be ready immediately.
tr: That they had taken such a precaution and implemented it immediately had greatly relieved Miss Pross. Changing her appearance so as not to be recognized on the streets was another source of relief. She looked at her watch; it was twenty past two. There was no time to lose; she had to get ready immediately.
es: It greatly helped to calm Miss Pross to see the precautionary measures being put into action. She also found comfort in the need to compose her outward appearance so as not to attract attention in the streets that could be dangerous. She checked the clock and saw that it was twenty past two. She couldn't afford to waste time.

en: Afraid, in her extreme perturbation, of the loneliness of the deserted rooms, and of half-imagined faces peeping from behind every open door in them, Miss Pross got a basin of cold water and began laving her eyes, which were swollen and red. Haunted by her feverish apprehensions, she could not bear to have her sight obscured for a minute at a time by the dripping water, but constantly paused and looked round to see that there was no one watching her. In one of those pauses she recoiled and cried out, for she saw a figure standing in the room.
vi: In this chaotic emotion, Miss Pross became afraid of being alone in the empty apartment, seeing ghostly faces peering out from every window frame. She then took a basin of cold water and began to wash her red and swollen eyes. Haunted by a burning fear, she didn't dare let the streaming water blur her vision for even a minute; she constantly stopped to look around to see if anyone was watching her. And in one such moment of stopping, she jumped and screamed upon seeing a figure standing in the room.
tr: Miss Pross, with the unease and fear brought on by being alone in deserted rooms and the feeling that someone was watching from behind every door, began to wash her red and swollen eyes with a bowl of cold water. She was so anxious and uneasy that she was disturbed by the momentary loss of vision when the water hit her face, constantly pausing to look around and make sure no one was watching her. During one of these pauses, she let out a scream, startled, because there was someone standing in the middle of the room.
es: Frightened at the thought of the loneliness in those deserted rooms, fearing to see eyes watching her from everywhere, gripped by unspeakable terrors, Miss Pross put cold water in a basin and began to wash her eyes, red and swollen from so much crying. Harassed by her apprehensions, she interrupted the washing every second to cast fearful glances around her. In one of those interruptions, she stepped back and let out a piercing scream, for she indeed discovered a person standing in the center of the room, looking at her.

en: The basin fell to the ground broken, and the water flowed to the feet of Madame Defarge. By strange stern ways, and through much staining blood, those feet had come to meet that water.
vi: The pot fell to the floor and shattered, water spreading to Madame Defarge's feet. Through many harsh and bloody paths, those feet had arrived here.
tr: The cup fell to the ground and broke, and the water flowed towards Madam Defarge's feet. These feet had traversed such merciless paths and had been stained with so much blood before meeting this water.
es: The basin shattered into a thousand pieces, and the spilled water reached the bare feet of the innkeeper Defarge. Strangely enough, those feet, which were seeking blood, encountered water.

en: Madame Defarge looked coldly at her, and said, “The wife of Evrémonde; where is she?”
vi: Coldly looking at Miss Pross, Madame Defarge asked: "Where is Evrémonde's wife?"
tr: Madame Defarge looked at Miss Pross with a cold expression and asked, "Where is Evremonde's wife?"
es: —Where is Evrémonde's wife?—asked the innkeeper coldly.

en: It flashed upon Miss Pross’s mind that the doors were all standing open, and would suggest the flight. Her first act was to shut them. There were four in the room, and she shut them all. She then placed herself before the door of the chamber which Lucie had occupied.
vi: Miss Pross suddenly remembered that all the doors of the room were open and would reveal the escape. Her first reaction was to close all the doors. All four doors leading to this room. Then she stood blocking the door to Lucie's private room.
tr: Suddenly, it occurred to Miss Pross that all the doors in the rooms were open, which could make it seem like they had escaped. Miss Pross's first task was to close them. She closed all four doors inside the room. Then she stood in front of the door to the room where Lucie was staying.
es: Quick as lightning, the idea struck Miss Pross's mind that the fact that all the doors were wide open would arouse suspicion of an escape plan. So she began by closing them all, and then positioned herself in front of the door leading to the room that Lucie had occupied until that day.

en: Madame Defarge’s dark eyes followed her through this rapid movement, and rested on her when it was finished. Miss Pross had nothing beautiful about her; years had not tamed the wildness, or softened the grimness, of her appearance; but, she too was a determined woman in her different way, and she measured Madame Defarge with her eyes, every inch.
vi: The dark eyes of Madame Defarge followed the swift actions of Miss Pross and fixed on her as the four doors were tightly closed. Miss Pross had no beauty at all; the years had neither tamed her stubbornness nor softened the rough features of her appearance. However, she was also a tenacious woman in a different way, and she scrutinized Madame Defarge from head to toe, examining every detail.
tr: Madame Defarge's dark eyes followed all this movement and, when it was over, fixed on Miss Pross. There was nothing about Miss Pross that could be called beautiful; the years had not tamed her wildness nor softened the harshness of her appearance; but she was a determined woman in her own way, and she fixed her eyes on Madame Defarge, scrutinizing her from head to toe.
es: With a fiery gaze, the innkeeper Defarge followed all the movements of Miss Pross, fixing them on her face once she saw her motionless by the door. Miss Pross was devoid of any kind of physical attractiveness. The years had not tamed her rustic roughness nor softened the sullen frown on her face. At the same time, she was a resolute woman; personal dangers did not frighten her, and far from being intimidated upon seeing Madame Defarge, she measured her from head to toe with a look of profound disdain.

en: “You might, from your appearance, be the wife of Lucifer,” said Miss Pross, in her breathing. “Nevertheless, you shall not get the better of me. I am an Englishwoman.”
vi: − Your face is just like Satan's, - said Miss Pross, breathing heavily. - But you won't defeat me. I am an Englishwoman.
tr: "You must be the devil's wife," said Miss Pross, breathlessly. "But you cannot defeat me. I am an Englishwoman."
es: —From your appearance, you could be the wife of Lucifer himself—Miss Pross said to herself. —But if you think you scare me, you're mistaken; I am English.

en: Madame Defarge looked at her scornfully, but still with something of Miss Pross’s own perception that they two were at bay. She saw a tight, hard, wiry woman before her, as Mr. Lorry had seen in the same figure a woman with a strong hand, in the years gone by. She knew full well that Miss Pross was the family’s devoted friend; Miss Pross knew full well that Madame Defarge was the family’s malevolent enemy.
vi: Madame Defarge looked at Miss Pross with contempt, but in that gaze, Miss Pross still recognized one thing: they were two adversaries. Madame Defarge saw her opponent as a tough, resolute woman, much like Mr. Lorry had realized many years ago when he first met the woman with the strong hands. Madame Defarge knew well that Miss Pross was a devoted friend to this family; and Miss Pross also knew all too well that Madame Defarge was the family's vicious enemy.
tr: Madam Defarge looked disdainfully, but it had not escaped Miss Pross's notice that she actually saw her as an equal. The firm, hard, and sturdy woman in front of her was the same woman with strong hands that Mr. Lorry had seen years ago. Madam Defarge knew very well that Miss Pross was the loyal friend of the family, and Miss Pross knew very well that Madam Defarge was the stone-hearted enemy of the family.
es: The innkeeper's wife looked at her with contempt in her eyes, though understanding that she was facing a formidable enemy. She knew very well that Miss Pross was capable of losing her life for the doctor's family, just as Miss Pross knew that the innkeeper's wife, Defarge, was capable of any evil when it came to the indicated family.

en: “On my way yonder,” said Madame Defarge, with a slight movement of her hand towards the fatal spot, “where they reserve my chair and my knitting for me, I am come to make my compliments to her in passing. I wish to see her.”
vi: − On the way there, - Madame Defarge lightly waved her hand making a sign towards the scaffold, - where someone has already saved a spot and kept the knitting for me, I stopped by to inquire about the mistress. I want to meet Miss Lucie.
tr: Madam Defarge said, "While I go to the place where they put my chair and knitting," lightly waving her hand towards the deadly area, "I thought I would stop by and convey my best wishes to Lucie. I want to see her."
es: —I was going to the place where I have a reserved seat—said Defarge, extending an arm towards the spot where the guillotine was set up,—and in passing, I wanted to congratulate the wife of Evrémonde. I need to see her.

en: “I know that your intentions are evil,” said Miss Pross, “and you may depend upon it, I’ll hold my own against them.”
vi: − I know your wicked scheme already, - said Miss Pross, - don't think that I won't resist.
tr: "I know how malicious you are," said Miss Pross, "but remember that you are facing me."
es: —I know your intentions are bad, and you can certainly count on the fact that you will find in me someone who will oppose you in carrying them out—replied Miss Pross.

en: Each spoke in her own language; neither understood the other’s words; both were very watchful, and intent to deduce from look and manner, what the unintelligible words meant.
vi: One speaks French, the other speaks English; neither understands the other; both are cautious, and through each other's facial expressions and gestures, they try to guess the meaning of the incomprehensible words.
tr: Both were speaking in their own language; neither understood the other; both were on alert, trying to deduce what the other was saying from their expressions and demeanor.
es: Each one spoke in their native tongue. Neither the barmaid understood a word of what Miss Pross was saying, nor did Miss Pross understand a word of what the barmaid was saying. However, they watched each other so intently that their gestures, their expressions, made the words intelligible that otherwise said nothing to their ears.

en: “It will do her no good to keep herself concealed from me at this moment,” said Madame Defarge. “Good patriots will know what that means. Let me see her. Go tell her that I wish to see her. Do you hear?”
vi: − It's no use for Lucie to avoid me at this moment, - said Madame Defarge. - True patriots will understand the meaning of such avoidance. Let me meet her. Tell her that I want to meet. Do you hear me?
tr: "At this point, there is no benefit for Lucie to hide from me," said Madam Defarge. "Good citizens know what this means. Let me see her. Go and tell her that I want to see her. Do you hear me?"
es: —Worse for her if you don't let me see her right now—replied the innkeeper.—The good patriots will soon know what that means. I want to see her... I need to see her... Go and tell her that I won't leave here without seeing her. Don't you hear me?

en: “If those eyes of yours were bed-winches,” returned Miss Pross, “and I was an English four-poster, they shouldn’t loose a splinter of me. No, you wicked foreign woman; I am your match.”
vi: − What's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander, - replied Miss Pross. - You wicked foreign woman, I won't lose to you.
tr: "If your eyes were a crane," said Miss Pross, "I would be a four-poster English bed, and you still couldn't move me an inch from my place. It's not that easy, you foreign woman. You can't defeat me."
es: —You insist on being left without eyes, and you are going to achieve it—replied Miss Pross. —Look at me, look at me with those fierce beast eyes, but don't push your luck, because I have a short temper. You might come for wool and leave yours between my nails.

en: Madame Defarge was not likely to follow these idiomatic remarks in detail; but, she so far understood them as to perceive that she was set at naught.
vi: Mrs. Defarge could not fully understand that peculiar language, but she knew well enough that the other party would not listen.
tr: Although Madam Defarge did not understand much of what he said, she could sense that a barrier had been put up in front of her.
es: Of course, Madame Defarge did not understand a word of the phrases that have been copied, but she fully realized that her interlocutor flatly refused to obey her commands.

en: “Woman imbecile and pig-like!” said Madame Defarge, frowning. “I take no answer from you. I demand to see her. Either tell her that I demand to see her, or stand out of the way of the door and let me go to her!” This, with an angry explanatory wave of her right arm.
vi: − You stupid pig! - Madame Defarge frowned. - I don't need to hear you speak. I need to see your master. Either tell him that I need to see him, or get out of the way so I can see him myself! - Her right arm angrily swung up to explain.
tr: Madam Defarge, "What a fool, what a pig of a woman you are!" she said, frowning. "Do not answer me. I want to see Lucie. Either tell her that I want to see her or get out of my way so I can find her!" As she said this, she waved her right arm angrily.
es: —Idiot... hungry pig face!—he muttered. —I want to see Evrémonde's wife! Either you go tell her right now, or you step away from that door and let me through!

en: “I little thought,” said Miss Pross, “that I should ever want to understand your nonsensical language; but I would give all I have, except the clothes I wear, to know whether you suspect the truth, or any part of it.”
vi: − Never in my life do I want to understand your nonsense language, - said Miss Pross. - But I would dare to give up everything, except the clothes on my back, to know if you have any suspicions.
tr: "I never thought I would ever want to understand your ridiculous language, but right now, I would give everything I have except the clothes on my back to find out if you doubt what the truth is or any part of it."
es: —I never imagined that I might need to understand that stupid language you speak; but the truth is that right now I would give everything I have, except the shirt on my back, to know if you suspect the whole truth or part of it.

en: Neither of them for a single moment released the other’s eyes. Madame Defarge had not moved from the spot where she stood when Miss Pross first became aware of her; but, she now advanced one step.
vi: No one took their eyes off each other for a minute. Madame Defarge was still standing in the same position as when Miss Pross first saw her; but now she had taken a step forward.
tr: For a moment, both of them looked at each other without blinking. Madam Defarge had been standing at the spot where Miss Pross first saw her until that moment, but now she had taken a step forward.
es: The two women stared at each other intently. The innkeeper, who until now had not moved from the spot where Miss Pross saw her when she was washing her eyes, took a step forward.

en: “I am a Briton,” said Miss Pross, “I am desperate. I don’t care an English Twopence for myself. I know that the longer I keep you here, the greater hope there is for my Ladybird. I’ll not leave a handful of that dark hair upon your head, if you lay a finger on me!”
vi: Miss Pross said: "I am an Englishwoman," Miss Pross said. "I can't take it anymore." My life isn't worth a penny, losing it wouldn't matter at all. But as long as I keep you here, my dear mistress still has hope. If you lay a hand on me, I'll make sure you end up bald with not a single hair left on your head!
tr: "I am British," said Miss Pross. "I can risk everything. My life is not valuable. The longer I keep you here, the better it will be for my little bird. If you dare to touch me, know that I will not leave a single hair on your dark head.""
es: —I am Breton and I am furious—said Miss Pross. —I don't give a damn about my life. I know that the longer I delay you, the more I ensure my lady's salvation... If you come any closer, I assure you I won't leave a hair on that head of yours.

en: Thus Miss Pross, with a shake of her head and a flash of her eyes between every rapid sentence, and every rapid sentence a whole breath. Thus Miss Pross, who had never struck a blow in her life.
vi: Miss Pross said while shaking her head, eyes glaring, and breathing heavily between her hurried words. Her voice was full of threats, even though she had never hit anyone in her life.
tr: Miss Pross was shaking her head from side to side and glaring at Madam during all these rapid sentences, and each sentence was coming out of her mouth in a single breath. On the other hand, Miss Pross had never struck anyone in her life.
es: It was the sentimental nature of Miss Pross's courage, a courage that filled her eyes with tears.

en: But, her courage was of that emotional nature that it brought the irrepressible tears into her eyes. This was a courage that Madame Defarge so little comprehended as to mistake for weakness. “Ha, ha!” she laughed, “you poor wretch! What are you worth! I address myself to that Doctor.” Then she raised her voice and called out, “Citizen Doctor! Wife of Evrémonde! Child of Evrémonde! Any person but this miserable fool, answer the Citizeness Defarge!”
vi: That courageous spirit moved Miss Pross to tears, which Madame Defarge mistakenly interpreted as a sign of weakness. − Ha ha, - Madame Defarge laughed loudly, - you coward! You useless thing! I will call the doctor. - Then she shouted loudly, - Citizen doctor! Wife of Evrémonde! Child of Evrémonde! Anyone but that miserable fool, answer Citizeness Defarge!
tr: Her courage stemmed from her emotions, and suddenly tears streamed from her eyes. Madame Defarge could not understand this courage and saw the tears as a sign of weakness. "Ha ha ha!" she laughed, "you poor thing! What did you think of yourself! I'd better talk to the Doctor." Then she shouted loudly, "Citizen Doctor! The wife of Evremonde! The daughter of Evremonde! Whoever is there besides this miserable creature I am speaking to, answer Citizen Defarge!"
es: It was the sentimental nature of Miss Pross's courage, a courage that filled her eyes with tears. The tavern keeper, not very practical in matters of sentiment, mistook the tears for weakness. —Ha, ha, ha, ha! Poor thing, and how little you're worth!—he exclaimed. —I want nothing to do with you... Citizen doctor!—he shouted. —Woman of Evrémonde, daughter of Evrémonde! Answer the citizen Defarge, miserable inhabitants of this house!

en: Perhaps the following silence, perhaps some latent disclosure in the expression of Miss Pross’s face, perhaps a sudden misgiving apart from either suggestion, whispered to Madame Defarge that they were gone. Three of the doors she opened swiftly, and looked in.
vi: Perhaps because of the ensuing silence, perhaps because of the expression on Miss Pross's face, perhaps because of a suspicion unrelated to the other two, Madame Defarge suddenly thought that those people had left. She quickly opened three doors and looked inside. −
tr: Maybe it was the ensuing silence, maybe it was the revealing expression on Miss Pross's face, or perhaps an independent suspicion whispered to Madam Defarge that they had left. She quickly opened the three doors and looked inside.
es: Perhaps the silence that followed her screams, perhaps the expression on Miss Pross's face, perhaps premonitions born in her dark soul, suggested to the innkeeper's wife the suspicion that the people whose blood she sought had fled. The fact was that of the four doors in the room she was in, she opened three and looked inside the rooms to which they gave access.

en: “Those rooms are all in disorder, there has been hurried packing, there are odds and ends upon the ground. There is no one in that room behind you! Let me look.”
vi: Every room was in disarray, showing signs of hurried packing, with things scattered all over the floor. So there's no one in the room behind you! Let me see.
tr: "All these rooms are scattered, as if someone quickly tidied up around here, a lot of knick-knacks are strewn on the floor. There must be someone in the room behind you! Let me take a look."
es: —I see everything in disarray, there is no one in these rooms, and I suspect that the one you guard is also deserted! I want to inspect it!—he shouted.

en: “Never!” said Miss Pross, who understood the request as perfectly as Madame Defarge understood the answer.
vi: − No! - Miss Pross understood the demand as clearly as Madame Defarge understood the reply.
tr: "Never!" said Miss Pross, and Madam Defarge understood this reply as well as Miss Pross understood her own intention.
es: —Never!—responded Miss Pross, who understood the words of the landlady as well as the latter understood her response.

en: “If they are not in that room, they are gone, and can be pursued and brought back,” said Madame Defarge to herself.
vi: − If they are not in that room, they have escaped, then we can chase after them and bring them back, - Madame Defarge said to herself.
tr: Madam Defarge said to herself, "If they are not in the room, they have gone, but they can be caught and brought back, of course."
es: —If they are not in that room, they have left; and there is still time to pursue them and catch up with them—thought Defarge.

en: “As long as you don’t know whether they are in that room or not, you are uncertain what to do,” said Miss Pross to herself; “and you shall not know that, if I can prevent your knowing it; and know that, or not know that, you shall not leave here while I can hold you.”
vi: − As long as you don't know whether they are in that room or not, you won't know what to do, - Miss Pross also said to herself. And you don't know that I won't let you know; whether you know or not, I will still prevent you from leaving here.
tr: Miss Pross said, "You won't know what to do unless you know whether they are in that room or not," she said to herself, "and if I don't give you the chance, you won't learn it; moreover, whether you learn it or not, I won't let you out of here."
es: —As long as you don't find out whether they are in this room or not, you won't know what to do—Miss Pross said to herself;—and I assure you that you won't find out if it's in my power to prevent it. Another thing; you won't leave here as long as I have hands to hold you.

en: “I have been in the streets from the first, nothing has stopped me, I will tear you to pieces, but I will have you from that door,” said Madame Defarge.
vi: − Since I was a child, I have been roaming the streets, nothing could stop me. I will tear you apart if you don't let me into that room. −
tr: "I have been on the streets since the first day, nothing has stopped me yet, I will tear you apart and still pass by that door," said Madam Defarge.
es: —I have not found a wall capable of blocking my way until today; be sure that I will tear you to pieces if you don't come out of that door—roared the innkeeper.

en: “We are alone at the top of a high house in a solitary courtyard, we are not likely to be heard, and I pray for bodily strength to keep you here, while every minute you are here is worth a hundred thousand guineas to my darling,” said Miss Pross.
vi: It's just you and me on this tall building with an empty yard, no one will hear anything. I hope I have enough strength to keep you here; every minute I keep you here is worth hundreds of thousands of guineas to my mistress.
tr: "We are alone with you at the top of this large house in a desolate courtyard, no one can hear us, may God give me strength so that I can keep you here longer, after all, every minute you spend here is worth the world for my little bird," said Miss Pross.
es: —We are alone in an interior room of a solitary house in a solitary neighborhood. It is not likely that they will hear us. You will not leave here, beast, for every minute I detain you is worth a world to my dear lady.

en: Madame Defarge made at the door. Miss Pross, on the instinct of the moment, seized her round the waist in both her arms, and held her tight. It was in vain for Madame Defarge to struggle and to strike; Miss Pross, with the vigorous tenacity of love, always so much stronger than hate, clasped her tight, and even lifted her from the floor in the struggle that they had. The two hands of Madame Defarge buffeted and tore her face; but, Miss Pross, with her head down, held her round the waist, and clung to her with more than the hold of a drowning woman.
vi: Madame Defarge rushed to the door. Miss Pross immediately swung her arms around her opponent's waist and held tight. Madame Defarge struggled, punched, and kicked to no avail; Miss Pross, with the fierce determination of love that is always stronger than hatred, held on tightly, even lifting her adversary off the ground in the struggle. Madame Defarge's hands slapped and scratched Miss Pross's face, but she ducked her head and tightened her grip around the other's waist, resolutely refusing to let go, like a drowning person clinging desperately to their rescuer.
tr: Madam Defarge rushed towards the door. Miss Pross, however, instinctively grabbed her tightly around the waist with both hands. Although Madam Defarge struggled and tried to hit, it was to no avail; Miss Pross, with the determination of love which is always much stronger than hatred, held her tightly, even lifting her from where they had fallen during the struggle. Madam Defarge was punching and scratching Miss Pross's face with both hands; but Miss Pross, with her head down, continued to hold her around the waist, clinging to her as if holding a drowning woman.
es: The innkeeper, having lost her patience, advanced resolutely towards the door. Miss Pross, guided by the instinct of the moment, grabbed her around the waist with both arms. In vain did the first try to resist and strike, for her antagonist, with that giant tenacity that love gives, always stronger than hate, not only held her but also lifted her off the ground in her arms. Defarge struggled furiously, slapped and slapped her enemy's face, scratched her mercilessly, but Miss Pross, who had lowered her head to defend herself, tightened the steel grip with which she imprisoned her waist more and more.

en: Soon, Madame Defarge’s hands ceased to strike, and felt at her encircled waist. “It is under my arm,” said Miss Pross, in smothered tones, “you shall not draw it. I am stronger than you, I bless Heaven for it. I hold you till one or other of us faints or dies!”
vi: Immediately after, Madame Defarge's hands stopped beating and lowered to grope around her waist. Miss Pross said in a breathless voice: "It's under my arm, you can't take it out." I'm stronger than you, thank God. I will hold you tight until one or both of us faints or dies!
tr: Soon, Madam Defarge's hands stopped struggling and reached for her wrapped waist. Miss Pross, in a muffled voice, said, "Under my arm," she said, "you can't take it out. Thank goodness, I'm stronger than you. I'll hold you like this until one of us faints or dies!"
es: The hands of the innkeeper stopped pounding and dropped to her waist. —Don't bother yourself—said Miss Pross;—it is under my arm and you won't be able to draw it. I am stronger than you, thank God, and I won't let you go until you faint or die.

en: Madame Defarge’s hands were at her bosom. Miss Pross looked up, saw what it was, struck at it, struck out a flash and a crash, and stood alone—blinded with smoke.
vi: Madame Defarge's hands moved to her chest. Miss Pross looked up, saw the object, swung her arm and struck hard, a flash, a bang, and she was left standing alone - her eyes blurred by gun smoke.
tr: Madam Defarge's hands went to her bosom. Miss Pross looked up, and seeing what was happening, struck with her hand, and with the strike, there was a sudden flash of light and an explosion, leaving her alone there, her eyes dazzled by the smoke.
es: Mrs. Defarge brought her right hand to her chest. Miss Pross saw the object that hand was drawing out. Quick as lightning, she raised an arm, struck a blow, and... a flash flared, thunder sounded, and she recoiled. The room was filled with smoke.

en: All this was in a second. As the smoke cleared, leaving an awful stillness, it passed out on the air, like the soul of the furious woman whose body lay lifeless on the ground.
vi: Everything happened in a flash. The terrifying silence as the smoke gradually dissipated, rising into the air like the soul of an enraged woman just departed from the lifeless body lying motionless on the floor.
tr: It all happened in an instant. The smoke dispersed, leaving behind a dreadful silence, and mingled with the air like the soul of the angry woman lying lifeless on the ground.
es: All of it lasted no more than a second. The smoke began to pour out of the window, carrying within its black spirals the soul of the woman who lay lifeless on the pavement.

en: In the first fright and horror of her situation, Miss Pross passed the body as far from it as she could, and ran down the stairs to call for fruitless help. Happily, she bethought herself of the consequences of what she did, in time to check herself and go back. It was dreadful to go in at the door again; but, she did go in, and even went near it, to get the bonnet and other things that she must wear. These she put on, out on the staircase, first shutting and locking the door and taking away the key. She then sat down on the stairs a few moments to breathe and to cry, and then got up and hurried away.
vi: At first, Miss Pross was terrified and stood far away from the dead body, then ran down the stairs to call for help in vain. Fortunately, she remembered the importance of this outcome, promptly calmed herself, and ran back up. Suppressing her fear, she went inside the house, even approaching the corpse to get the bonnet and necessary clothing. She dressed quickly, rushed outside, closed and locked the doors tightly, and took the key with her. After that, she sat on the stairs for a moment to breathe and cry, then stood up hurriedly and left.
tr: After the initial fear and horror she experienced, Miss Pross moved as far away as she could from the lifeless body and went downstairs to call for help in vain. Fortunately, she then thought about the consequences of her actions, came to her senses, and returned. Entering through that door again was terrifying, but she did it, and even went up to it to retrieve her bonnet and other belongings. She put these on by the stairs, closed and locked the door, and took the key. Then, after sitting on the steps to catch her breath and cry for a bit, she got up and hurried away.
es: The terribleness of the situation she found herself in made Miss Pross, at first, try to flee from the corpse and run down the stairs with the intention of seeking unnecessary and belated help; but fortunately, she realized the consequences in time to stop and retrace her steps. It was horrible to pass over the corpse, lying across the doorway; but she did so to retrieve the hat and other items she needed to take with her. She took them to the landing of the stairs, locked the door, sat down to let the terror that was choking her escape through her eyes, and once calmer, she got up and left.

en: By good fortune she had a veil on her bonnet, or she could hardly have gone along the streets without being stopped. By good fortune, too, she was naturally so peculiar in appearance as not to show disfigurement like any other woman. She needed both advantages, for the marks of gripping fingers were deep in her face, and her hair was torn, and her dress (hastily composed with unsteady hands) was clutched and dragged a hundred ways.
vi: Fortunately, her bonnet had a veil, otherwise, she would have had a hard time walking outside without being stopped and questioned. It was also fortunate that her appearance was naturally unusual, so her odd look did not make her stand out as much as other women. She needed both of these advantages because her face bore clear scratch marks, her hair was disheveled, and her hastily donned clothes were extremely wrinkled and untidy.
tr: Luckily, there was a veil over her hat, otherwise, it would have been impossible for her to walk through those streets without being stopped. Luckily, there was such a natural oddity in her appearance that her ugliness did not attract attention as it did in other women. Both were to her advantage, because there were deep scratch marks on her face, her hair was disheveled, and her outfit (hastily adjusted with trembling hands) looked as if it had been tugged at hundreds of times.
es: Fortunately for her, the veil of the hat was quite thick, because otherwise, it is likely that she would have been detained on the street. Fortunately for her, she was so ugly that the deep scratches she had received in the fight did not leave marks on her face that would have been left on another face more favored by nature.

en: In crossing the bridge, she dropped the door key in the river. Arriving at the cathedral some few minutes before her escort, and waiting there, she thought, what if the key were already taken in a net, what if it were identified, what if the door were opened and the remains discovered, what if she were stopped at the gate, sent to prison, and charged with murder! In the midst of these fluttering thoughts, the escort appeared, took her in, and took her away.
vi: When crossing the bridge, she dropped the house key into the river. Arriving at the church a few minutes before Cruncher and standing there waiting, she was lost in thought. If the key got caught in some fishing net, if they identified whose house the key belonged to, if they opened the door and found a corpse, if she was stopped at the city gate, thrown into prison, and accused of murder! While she was lost in these anxious thoughts, the escort appeared, picked her up, and took her away. −
tr: While crossing the bridge, he threw the key to the door into the river. Arriving at the cathedral a few minutes before his companion and waiting there, his mind was occupied with questions like, what if the key got caught in a net, what if they figured out what it was, what if they opened the door and saw what was inside, what if he was stopped at the exit and sent to prison and tried for murder!
