While Miss Pross was immersed in all these anxious thoughts, her companion appeared and took her along to continue on their way.
es: Upon crossing the bridge, she threw the house key into the river. She arrived in front of the cathedral door a few minutes before the time agreed upon with Lapa, and waited, filled with terror, at the thought that they might fish out the key she had just thrown, discover which house it belonged to, open the door, find a corpse, arrest her, and condemn her to death for the crime of murder. Such were the thoughts that agitated her when Lapa arrived.

en: “Is there any noise in the streets?” she asked him.
vi: Is there any noise on the street? - Miss Pross asked.
tr: "Is there any noise in the streets?" asked Miss Pross.
es: —Is there noise in the streets?—asked Miss Pross.

en: “The usual noises,” Mr. Cruncher replied; and looked surprised by the question and by her aspect.
vi: − As noisy as usual, - Cruncher replied; surprised by the question and her demeanor.
tr: "The usual sounds, that's all," said Mr. Cruncher; he seemed surprised both by the woman's condition and her question.
es: —The ordinary one—Lapa replied, not a little surprised both by the question and by the appearance of the one who asked it.

en: “I don’t hear you,” said Miss Pross. “What do you say?”
vi: − I can't hear you, - Miss Pross said. - What did you say?
tr: "I can't hear you," said Miss Pross. "What did you say?"
es: —I can't hear you... What are you saying?

en: It was in vain for Mr. Cruncher to repeat what he said; Miss Pross could not hear him. “So I’ll nod my head,” thought Mr. Cruncher, amazed, “at all events she’ll see that.” And she did.
vi: It was useless for Cruncher to repeat; Miss Pross couldn't hear a word. Cruncher thought in amazement, “Then I'll nod, surely she will see and understand.” And indeed she did. −
tr: Mr. Cruncher repeated his words in vain; Miss Pross could not hear him. "Then I'll nod my head," thought Mr. Cruncher, in amazement, "she'll see that in any case." And she did.
es: In vain did Lapa repeat over and over what he had said; Miss Pross did not hear him. —Wow!—thought Lapa.—I will make myself understood through gestures.

en: “Is there any noise in the streets now?” asked Miss Pross again, presently.
vi: Is there any noise on the street right now? - Miss Pross asked again immediately after.
tr: Miss Pross asked again shortly after, "Is there any noise in the streets right now?"
es: —Is there noise in the streets?

en: Again Mr. Cruncher nodded his head.
vi: Cruncher nodded again.
tr: Mr. Cruncher nodded his head forward again.
es: Lapa nodded affirmatively.

en: “I don’t hear it.”
vi: − I couldn't hear.
tr: "I can't hear."
es: —I don't hear anything.

en: “Gone deaf in an hour?” said Mr. Cruncher, ruminating, with his mind much disturbed; “wot’s come to her?”
vi: − Deaf after just an hour? - Cruncher wondered, his heart filled with worry. - What happened to her? −
tr: "Did she go deaf in an hour?" said Mr. Cruncher, confused and disturbed; "what happened to this woman?""
es: —Deaf as a post in an hour? That's strange!—thought Lapa— What could have happened to her?

en: “I feel,” said Miss Pross, “as if there had been a flash and a crash, and that crash was the last thing I should ever hear in this life.”
vi: It felt like there was lightning and thunder, and that explosion was the last sound I heard in this world. − This woman looks really strange!
tr: "It was as if," said Miss Pross, "there was a flash of light and an explosion, and that explosion was the last thing I heard."
es: —I saw a lightning bolt, I heard a thunderclap; and the thunderclap was the last thing I heard in my life—explained Miss Pross.

en: “Blest if she ain’t in a queer condition!” said Mr. Cruncher, more and more disturbed. “Wot can she have been a takin’, to keep her courage up? Hark! There’s the roll of them dreadful carts! You can hear that, miss?”
vi: - Cruncher was getting more and more anxious. - Did she do something to muster up courage? Listen! Those terrifying carriages are running on the road! Can you hear them, sister? − I can't hear anything, - Miss Pross said as she saw him mouthing words at her.
tr: "How strange he has become!" said Mr. Cruncher, now thoroughly disturbed. "Did he drink something to boost his courage? Listen! A lot of death carts are passing by! Do you hear, madam?"
es: —I find her completely changed... What could she have taken to gain courage? Because the truth is she doesn't seem to have a bit of fear... The noise of those damn carts...! Do you hear them, miss?

en: “I can hear,” said Miss Pross, seeing that he spoke to her, “nothing. O, my good man, there was first a great crash, and then a great stillness, and that stillness seems to be fixed and unchangeable, never to be broken any more as long as my life lasts.”
vi: - Oh, my dear, at first there was a loud bang, then after that it was dead silent, completely still, as if it would stay that way forever, as if it would be eternally quiet.
tr: Seeing that Mr. Cruncher was saying something to her, Miss Pross said, "I can't hear anything. Oh my friend, first there was a great explosion, then a great silence covered everything, and this silence never ends, it never changes, it feels like it will never end until the end of my life.""
es: —I can't hear anything, absolutely nothing—replied the good Pross, noticing the movement of her companion's lips. —A lightning, a thunder, and nothing more.

en: “If she don’t hear the roll of those dreadful carts, now very nigh their journey’s end,” said Mr. Cruncher, glancing over his shoulder, “it’s my opinion that indeed she never will hear anything else in this world.”
vi: − If she couldn't hear the sound of those dreadful carts approaching the execution ground, - Cruncher glanced over his shoulder at Miss Pross, - then I think she wouldn't be able to hear anything else in this world.
tr: "If he can't hear the sound of these death carts coming to the end of the road," said Mr. Cruncher, looking over his shoulder, "he will never hear anything again in his life."
es: —If he doesn't hear the rumbling of those horrible carts, I think he won't hear anything else in this world again—murmured Lapa.

en: And indeed she never did.
vi: And indeed it was so.
tr: Indeed, Miss Pross never heard it again.
es: He was not mistaken. Miss Pross remained deaf forever.

en: CHAPTER XV.
vi: And indeed it was so.
tr: XV
es: XV.

en: The Footsteps Die Out For Ever
vi: 15. The final echoes
tr: The Footsteps Fall Silent Forever
es: THE ECHOES FADE AWAY FOREVER

en: Along the Paris streets, the death-carts rumble, hollow and harsh. Six tumbrils carry the day’s wine to La Guillotine. All the devouring and insatiate Monsters imagined since imagination could record itself, are fused in the one realisation, Guillotine. And yet there is not in France, with its rich variety of soil and climate, a blade, a leaf, a root, a sprig, a peppercorn, which will grow to maturity under conditions more certain than those that have produced this horror. Crush humanity out of shape once more, under similar hammers, and it will twist itself into the same tortured forms. Sow the same seed of rapacious license and oppression over again, and it will surely yield the same fruit according to its kind.
vi: On the streets of Paris, the death carts rumbled loudly, harshly; resonating. Six carts carrying the daily ration of wine offered to La Guillotine. So many greedy, hungry monsters from the depths of imagination combined into one entity: the guillotine. However, in France, with its fertile land and climate, not a single blade of grass, leaf, root, bud, or ear of grain can develop under conditions as certain as those that have produced that horror. Crush humanity once more, and it will immediately writhe and proliferate under the hammer blow in the same deformed and twisted shape. Sow the same seeds of privilege, greed, and tyranny, and it will surely yield corresponding fruit.
tr: The death carts proceed along the streets of Paris with creaks and rumbles. Six carts carry the wines of the day to the guillotine. All those unimaginable greedy, all-consuming monsters seem to have gathered in a single body, transformed into the guillotine. In the rich soil and diverse climate of France, no bush, leaf, root, sprout, or peppercorn matures more distinctly than the conditions that create this fear. If you were to crush humanity similarly with hammers, it would return to its former troubled state. If you sow the same seeds of greed and oppression, it is clear that you will achieve the same result.
es: The vehicles of death bounce on the cobblestones of the streets of Paris, creaking lugubriously. Six carts carry to the guillotine the ration of wine with which it daily entertains its thirst. The devouring monsters, the insatiable monsters that human imaginations have forged since the very first moment of their activity, have merged into a unique realization, and this unique realization is called the guillotine. And yet, in France, with all its rich variety of climate and soil, there is not a blade of grass, a leaf, a root, a shoot, capable of reaching ripeness and maturity under more favorable conditions than those that produced that horror. The day that similar hammers crush and pound humanity, twisting it and erasing its form, it will reappear under the same violent and misshapen forms under which it reappeared then; the day the seed of rapacious license and oppression is sown, the same fruits that flourished and ripened then will flourish and ripen.

en: Six tumbrils roll along the streets. Change these back again to what they were, thou powerful enchanter, Time, and they shall be seen to be the carriages of absolute monarchs, the equipages of feudal nobles, the toilettes of flaring Jezebels, the churches that are not my father’s house but dens of thieves, the huts of millions of starving peasants! No; the great magician who majestically works out the appointed order of the Creator, never reverses his transformations. “If thou be changed into this shape by the will of God,” say the seers to the enchanted, in the wise Arabian stories, “then remain so! But, if thou wear this form through mere passing conjuration, then resume thy former aspect!” Changeless and hopeless, the tumbrils roll along.
vi: Six death carts rolled through the streets. O Time, mighty sorcerer, bring them back, they will become the royal chariots of supreme sovereignty, the carriages of the feudal aristocracy, the ornaments of dazzling courtesans, the churches that are not houses of God but dens of thieves, the huts of millions of starving peasants! No; this great and majestic sorcerer, acting under the command of the Creator, will never reverse all changes. In the ancient wise tales of Arabia, the prophets said to those transformed by magic, "If you have been transformed into this shape by the will of God, then so be it! But if you bear this form only by temporary enchantment, then return to your former self!". Unchanged and without hope, the death carts continued to roll.
tr: Six cars are moving along the streets. If the powerful magician, namely "time," were to transform them into the past, they would appear as the chariots of absolute rulers, the materials of feudal nobles, the dressing rooms of radiant and glamorous women, churches that are more nests of thieves than houses of God, and the huts of millions of starving peasants! But no; the mighty magician who enforces the order set by the Creator never turns the things he transforms back to their original state. In the wise tales of One Thousand and One Nights, he says to the enchanted ones, "If God has made you this way," "then remain so! But if you have come to this state through a temporary spell, then return to your former state!" The cars, in the same way, are moving forward desperately.
es: Six carts roll creaking along the streets. Transform them into what they once were, you, Time, powerful enchanter, reintegrate them to their former shape and condition, and we will see them changed into as many splendid carriages of absolute monarchs, into trains of noble feudal lords, into luxurious galas of dazzling Jezebels, into Synagogues that have ceased to be the House of My Father to become dens of thieves, into miserable huts of millions of famished peasants! No; the great magician who majestically disrupts the order established by the Creator, never destroys his transformations. "If the will of God has given you the form you affect, do not attempt to change it; but if you owe it to transient human conspiracies, regain the one you received from the Most High," say the magicians to the enchanted beings in the Arabian tales. The shadowy wheels of the carts, as they turn over the cobblestones, resemble a powerful plow that opens a deep furrow among the populace that fills the streets, with human heads on either side.

en: As the sombre wheels of the six carts go round, they seem to plough up a long crooked furrow among the populace in the streets. Ridges of faces are thrown to this side and to that, and the ploughs go steadily onward. So used are the regular inhabitants of the houses to the spectacle, that in many windows there are no people, and in some the occupation of the hands is not so much as suspended, while the eyes survey the faces in the tumbrils. Here and there, the inmate has visitors to see the sight; then he points his finger, with something of the complacency of a curator or authorised exponent, to this cart and to this, and seems to tell who sat here yesterday, and who there the day before.
vi: The sorrowful wheels turn as if plowing winding furrows among the crowded streets. The furrows of faces are plowed to the sides as the wheels roll steadily along the road. The people in the houses along the street have become so accustomed to this scene that many don't even bother to stand by the window to watch, and some, even if their eyes glance over the faces of the condemned on the vehicles, their hands do not stop the work they are doing. In some places, the people in the houses along the street have guests over who conveniently watch this procession; the host then proudly points out one prison vehicle after another as if a collector of antiques or a connoisseur is explaining who sat on those fateful vehicles yesterday or the day before.
tr: As the gloomy wheels of six carts turn, a crooked furrow forms among the crowd in the streets. Faces turn one way, then the other, and the plow moves forward smoothly. The people living in the nearby houses are so accustomed to this sight that many windows are empty; some just glance at the people inside the carts without pausing their work. In some houses, there are guests who come just to watch this; then the host, with the indifference of an exhibition organizer or an official, points to the carts one by one and tells them who was inside yesterday and the day before.
es: The shadowy wheels of the carts, as they turn over the cobblestones, resemble a powerful plow that opens a deep furrow among the populace that fills the streets, with human heads on either side. The neighbors of the houses are so accustomed to the horrendous spectacle that not a single face is seen on many balconies, and it is very common to see people engaged in some occupation who do not stop the movement of their hands as the carts pass, although their eyes turn to the carts to see who the unfortunate ones occupying them are.

en: Of the riders in the tumbrils, some observe these things, and all things on their last roadside, with an impassive stare; others, with a lingering interest in the ways of life and men. Some, seated with drooping heads, are sunk in silent despair; again, there are some so heedful of their looks that they cast upon the multitude such glances as they have seen in theatres, and in pictures. Several close their eyes, and think, or try to get their straying thoughts together. Only one, and he a miserable creature, of a crazed aspect, is so shattered and made drunk by horror, that he sings, and tries to dance. Not one of the whole number appeals by look or gesture, to the pity of the people.
vi: Some people sitting on the vehicle indifferently observed those scenes and everything on the final journey of their lives; others looked at life and the people passing by with regretful eyes. Some sat with their heads bowed, immersed in despair; there were also those who paid so much attention to their own appearance that they cast heroic glances at the crowd, as often seen in plays or paintings. A few closed their eyes, thinking or trying to concentrate their thoughts. Only one person, a miserable wretch, seemed to have gone mad, so stunned and exhausted by terror that he burst into song and tried to dance on the vehicle. Not a single person, by look or gesture, showed any plea for mercy from the people along the road.
tr: Some of the passengers in the cars are watching the surroundings and everything happening on their final journey with indifferent eyes, while others are observing with a lethargic interest. Some have their heads bowed, immersed in silent despair; others, aware of the significance of their gaze, are looking at the crowd with attitudes reminiscent of what they have seen in theaters and paintings. A few have closed their eyes, thinking or trying to gather their scattered thoughts. Only one, a poor creature driven mad, is so overwhelmed and intoxicated by fear that they are trying to sing and dance. Among all these people, not a single one is begging for mercy from others with their looks or movements.
es: Among those who ride the fateful carts, there are some who observe their surroundings with an impassive gaze and others who focus on it with fleeting interest. Some give palpable signs of silent despair, making the final journey with their heads bowed over their chests, while others hold them arrogantly high and cast looks of haughty disdain at the crowds. Many meditate or try to gather their wandering thoughts, closing their eyes for that purpose, while one, just one, a wretched being of repulsive appearance, seems so crazed with terror that he sings and even tries to dance. The expressions of the condemned vary infinitely, but not a single one awakens pity in the diamond-hard hearts of the people.

en: There is a guard of sundry horsemen riding abreast of the tumbrils, and faces are often turned up to some of them, and they are asked some question. It would seem to be always the same question, for, it is always followed by a press of people towards the third cart. The horsemen abreast of that cart, frequently point out one man in it with their swords. The leading curiosity is, to know which is he; he stands at the back of the tumbril with his head bent down, to converse with a mere girl who sits on the side of the cart, and holds his hand. He has no curiosity or care for the scene about him, and always speaks to the girl. Here and there in the long street of St. Honore, cries are raised against him. If they move him at all, it is only to a quiet smile, as he shakes his hair a little more loosely about his face. He cannot easily touch his face, his arms being bound.
vi: There was a motley crew of cavalry riding alongside the convoy of death row prisoners, and the faces of passersby often turned towards them with a few questions. It always seems to be a question because there is always a crowd jostling around the third carriage. The guards riding alongside that carriage always brandish their swords towards someone inside. Everyone is curious to know who the condemned person is; he stands at the back of the carriage, head bowed, conversing with an ordinary girl sitting by the side of the carriage and holding his hand. He is neither curious nor concerned about the surrounding scene and only talks to that girl. Occasionally, along the long St. Honoré street, many voices shout curses at him. If those words affect him, he only gives a faint smile while shaking his head, causing his disheveled hair to fall a bit more around his face. He cannot raise his hands to his face, as his arms are bound.
tr: There are a number of mounted guards right next to the cars, and people frequently turn their faces to them and ask something. It seems that the question asked is the same, as people always rush to the third car afterward. The mounted guards next to that car constantly point to a man inside with their swords. Everyone is curious about who he is; he, however, stands at the back of the car, head bowed, talking to a poor girl who is sitting on the side of the car and holding his hand. He doesn't care about being watched or the commotion he has caused and continues to talk to the girl. Along the long St Honore Street, people are shouting against him. He, however, does nothing but silently smile while shaking his head to push back the hair that falls on his face. Since his arms are tied, he cannot touch his face.
es: Some riders with a brutish appearance break the march, to whom the curious occasionally direct questions. Undoubtedly, these are always the same, as the answer invariably leads to a movement of the crowds towards the third cart. The riders with brutish faces who ride ahead also frequently point with the tips of their sabers to a man among those occupying it. The condemned man in question has aroused general curiosity; everyone wants to know who the man is who, with his back against the backrest of the third cart, is conversing with a little girl sitting beside him. He does not seem interested in the scene nor does he care about anything around him. In the street of San Honorato, the crowds shout against him; he responds to the shouts with a smile and energetic head movements that further dishevel his long hair, fallen over his face, which he cannot move away because his arms are tied.

en: On the steps of a church, awaiting the coming-up of the tumbrils, stands the Spy and prison-sheep. He looks into the first of them: not there. He looks into the second: not there. He already asks himself, “Has he sacrificed me?” when his face clears, as he looks into the third.
vi: On the church steps, waiting for the convoy of condemned prisoners, stood a spy and a prison guard. The spy looked into the first carriage: no one. He looked into the second carriage: no one. He was thinking to himself, "Has he betrayed me?" when his face lit up as he looked into the third carriage. −
tr: The prison rat Spy is standing on the steps of a church, waiting for the cars to arrive. He looks at the first car, it's not there. He looks at the second car, it's not there. Just as he is thinking to himself, "Did he sacrifice me?" he sees the third car and feels relieved.
es: At the top of a church's staircase, the spy whom Sydney Carton called the hangman's blackbird awaits the passing of the funeral procession. He fixes his gaze on the first cart: he is not there. He anxiously looks at the second... Neither there. His face reflects the fear that begins to invade him, but when he scrutinizes the third, he smiles with satisfaction.

en: “Which is Evrémonde?” says a man behind him.
vi: Which one is Evrémonde? - The man standing next to him asked. −
tr: "Which one is Evremonde?" asks the man behind him.
es: —Who is Evrémonde?—asks a man positioned behind him.

en: “That. At the back there.”
vi: There. At the back of the carriage. −
tr: "That one. The one standing at the back."
es: —That one... the one from the third cart.

en: “With his hand in the girl’s?”
vi: The one holding the child's hand? −
tr: "The man holding the girl's hand?""
es: —The one who talks with the girl?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes.

en: The man cries, “Down, Evrémonde! To the Guillotine all aristocrats! Down, Evrémonde!”
vi: − Down with Evrémonde! - That one shouted. - Send the aristocrats to the guillotine! Down with Evrémonde!
tr: Adam, "Die Evremonde! All aristocrats to the guillotine! Die already, Evremonde!"
es: —Die, Evrémonde!—immediately shouts the man in question. —To the guillotine with all the aristocrats! Die, Evrémonde!

en: “Hush, hush!” the Spy entreats him, timidly.
vi: − Shh, shh! - The spy fearfully pleaded. −
tr: "Shh, shh!" says the Spy immediately, timidly.
es: —Quiet... quiet...!—the spy exclaims timidly.

en: “And why not, citizen?”
vi: Why shush, Citizen? −
tr: "Why shouldn't we say it, citizen?"
es: —Why should I be silent?

en: “He is going to pay the forfeit: it will be paid in five minutes more. Let him be at peace.”
vi: He is about to pay for his crimes; in just over five minutes, it will be over. Let him be.
tr: "He will pay for what he has done, he has five minutes. Let's leave him alone now."
es: —Because he is about to pay for his crimes... In five minutes, he will have atoned for them... Leave him alone now.

en: But the man continuing to exclaim, “Down, Evrémonde!” the face of Evrémonde is for a moment turned towards him. Evrémonde then sees the Spy, and looks attentively at him, and goes his way.
vi: But the other man continued to denounce, and for a moment Evrémonde turned his face towards him and saw the spy standing next to him. He stared intently, then the carriage passed by.
tr: But the man keeps shouting, "Die Evremonde!" and Evremonde turns his face towards him for a moment. Then he sees the Spy, looks at him carefully, and continues on his way.
es: —Die, Evrémonde!—continues shouting that barbarian. Evrémonde turns his face towards the one who is shouting; he sees the spy, looks at him attentively, and continues on his way undaunted.

en: The clocks are on the stroke of three, and the furrow ploughed among the populace is turning round, to come on into the place of execution, and end. The ridges thrown to this side and to that, now crumble in and close behind the last plough as it passes on, for all are following to the Guillotine. In front of it, seated in chairs, as in a garden of public diversion, are a number of women, busily knitting. On one of the fore-most chairs, stands The Vengeance, looking about for her friend.
vi: The clocks all struck three, the furrow plowed by the crowd parted, advanced to the execution site, and stopped. The furrows of people plowed to the sides now filled back in behind the last cart coming, as everyone followed to the place where the guillotine was set up. Right in front of the guillotine, sitting on chairs as if watching public entertainment in a garden, were many women busy knitting. Standing on a chair in the front row, looking around, was the Goddess of Vengeance searching for her friend.
tr: The clocks show three, and the furrow moving through the crowd meanders and ends at the execution site. People scattered to the sides approach the last plow in small groups, as they all head towards the Guillotine. Right in front of it, there are many women sitting on chairs, knitting as if they have come to the park for amusement. Vengeance, standing up on one of the front chairs, is looking around for her friend.
es: The city clocks are about to strike three, and the plow veers off the straight path to reach the designated execution site. The lines of human heads that flanked the furrow opened by the plow up to that point gather in a throng around the guillotine that is about to be put into operation. In the front row, comfortably seated in chairs, exactly as if they were at the theater, there is a group of women, knitting with true fervor; among them, it was not difficult to spot La Vengeance, who seems restless and nervous.

en: “Thérèse!” she cries, in her shrill tones. “Who has seen her? Thérèse Defarge!”
vi: − Thérèse! - The woman shouted loudly, her voice shrill. - Has anyone seen her? Thérèse Defarge! −
tr: "Therese!" screams Revenge in its shrillest voice. "Has anyone seen her?" Therese Defarge!"
es: —Teresa!—she shouts, appealing to her most shrill register.—Who has seen Teresa... Teresa Defarge?

en: “She never missed before,” says a knitting-woman of the sisterhood.
vi: She has never missed a time before, - a woman in the knitting crowd spoke up. −
tr: "She had never missed one before," says a woman knitting in the group.
es: —It's the first time she's missed—replies one of the workers.

en: “No; nor will she miss now,” cries The Vengeance, petulantly. “Thérèse.”
vi: No, not this time either, - the Vengeful Goddess exclaimed impatiently. - Thérèse. − Call louder, - the other woman suggested.
tr: "No; now he won't miss it either," shouts İntikam, grumpily. "Therese!"
es: —No... it won't be missing today either...! Teresa!—roars La Venganza.

en: “Louder,” the woman recommends.
vi: - Thérèse. − Call louder, - the other woman suggested.
tr: "Louder," advises the woman.
es: —Scream louder—advises the woman who spoke earlier.

en: Ay! Louder, Vengeance, much louder, and still she will scarcely hear thee. Louder yet, Vengeance, with a little oath or so added, and yet it will hardly bring her. Send other women up and down to seek her, lingering somewhere; and yet, although the messengers have done dread deeds, it is questionable whether of their own wills they will go far enough to find her!
vi: Correct! Louder, Goddess of Vengeance, scream louder, and she still can't hear. Scream louder, Goddess of Vengeance, throw in some curses, but she still doesn't appear. Order other women to search for her up and down; but these female messengers, despite having done many terrible things, might not want to go far to find Madame Defarge! −
tr: Yeah! Scream Revenge louder, much louder, but he still can barely hear you. Even if you scream louder, Revenge, and even add an oath at the end, he won't come anymore. If you want, send other women to search for that madam who is writhing in pain somewhere; even if these women have committed terrible acts in the past, how hard will they try to find her?
es: Ah! Scream, Vengeance, scream: for as loud as your screams may be, it is difficult for you to be heard! Scream, Vengeance, scream... it doesn't matter if you accompany your screams with curses; neither the screams nor the curses will reach the ears of your boss! Send emissaries to search for her everywhere; even though it cannot be denied that these emissaries have accomplished difficult tasks, it is certain that they will not go to look for her where she is!

en: “Bad Fortune!” cries The Vengeance, stamping her foot in the chair, “and here are the tumbrils! And Evrémonde will be despatched in a wink, and she not here! See her knitting in my hand, and her empty chair ready for her. I cry with vexation and disappointment!”
vi: How unlucky! - The Goddess of Vengeance shouted and stomped on the chair. - The death cart is here! In just a moment, Evrémonde's life will end, and she's not here! I still have Thérèse's knitting. I'm so upset, I want to cry!
tr: "What luck!" shouts Revenge, stomping her foot hard on the chair, "the cars have arrived! Evremonde's shipment is imminent, and he's nowhere to be found! I have his knitting in my hand, his chair is ready. I'm going to cry out of anger and disappointment now!"
es: She has made a journey too long! —Bad luck!—silences La Venganza, furiously kicking—And the carts are already here...! And Evrémonde will be dispatched without her being here! While Vengeance calls out loudly for Teresa Defarge, the carts are unloaded.

en: As The Vengeance descends from her elevation to do it, the tumbrils begin to discharge their loads. The ministers of Sainte Guillotine are robed and ready. Crash!—A head is held up, and the knitting-women who scarcely lifted their eyes to look at it a moment ago when it could think and speak, count One.
vi: When the Goddess of Vengeance stepped down and sat crying, the carts began to unload the condemned. The executioners were already dressed and ready. Thud! - A head was raised, the women who were knitting a minute ago didn't even look up when the condemned were still breathing, now they all counted in unison: One! The second cart unloaded the condemned and drove away; the third cart approached.
tr: As revenge descends from the top of the chair for this purpose, the cars also begin to unload their cargo. The deputies of Saint Guillotine are waiting ready in their robes. Thud! – A head flies off and is shown to the crowd; the women knitting, who just a minute ago didn't deign to look at it while it was thinking and speaking, are now counting. One.
es: While Vengeance calls out loudly for Teresa Defarge, the carts are unloaded. The ministers of Saint Guillotine are dressed and ready to work... A blow is heard, a head rolls which one of the ministers immediately lifts in his hand, and the women, barely looking, continue knitting, saying as their only comment:

en: The second tumbril empties and moves on; the third comes up. Crash!—And the knitting-women, never faltering or pausing in their Work, count Two.
vi: The second cart unloaded the condemned and drove away; the third cart approached. Phập! - And the women knitting did not stop their knitting for a minute, and counted: Two!
tr: The second car also unloads its cargo and leaves; then the third one comes. Click! The women knitting continue to count without pausing or hesitating in their work. Two.
es: A blow is heard, a head rolls which one of the ministers immediately lifts in his hand, and the women, barely looking, continue knitting, saying as their only comment: —One. The scene repeats several times, without the women interrupting their work or stopping their counting.

en: The supposed Evrémonde descends, and the seamstress is lifted out next after him. He has not relinquished her patient hand in getting out, but still holds it as he promised. He gently places her with her back to the crashing engine that constantly whirrs up and falls, and she looks into his face and thanks him.
vi: The one considered to be Evrémonde got out of the carriage and the seamstress was helped out next. He did not let go but still held the humble hand of the girl as he had promised. He gently turned her back to the machine that was ceaselessly rising and falling with a loud noise nearby, and she looked at him gratefully.
tr: So-called Evremonde descends, followed by the seamstress girl. As promised, he has never let go of the girl's hand, not even while descending, keeping his patient hand steady. He gently presses the girl's back against the ever-working cutting mechanism, and she looks at him and thanks Evremonde.
es: The supposed Evrémonde ascends the fatal platform, holding the hand of the unfortunate girl, as he had promised, placing her with her back to the terrible blade, which rises and falls without interruption.

en: “But for you, dear stranger, I should not be so composed, for I am naturally a poor little thing, faint of heart; nor should I have been able to raise my thoughts to Him who was put to death, that we might have hope and comfort here to-day. I think you were sent to me by Heaven.”
vi: − Oh stranger, without you, I could not be this calm, for I am lowly and timid; without you, I could not think that God, who died for us today, could still bring hope and peace. I believe that God sent you to help me.
tr: "If it weren't for you, dear stranger, I could neither be this calm –for I am a wretched person by nature and my heart is very weak– nor could I share these thoughts with the person condemned to death and feel the hope and comfort that I feel here today. Surely, God sent you to me."
es: —If it hadn't been for you, my dear stranger, I wouldn't have the calm and resignation that I have, for I am a poor girl and my heart is weak. Nor would I have known how to elevate my thoughts towards Him who died for us, to Him whose mercy is today my only hope. I believe that it is the Heavens that have sent you to me on this day of trial. —Perhaps you are the messenger that the Heavens have sent to me—replied Carton.

en: “Or you to me,” says Sydney Carton. “Keep your eyes upon me, dear child, and mind no other object.”
vi: − Or she was sent to help me, - Sydney Carton said. - Just look straight at me, girl, don't worry about anything.
tr: "Or you to me," says Sydney Carton. "Keep your eyes on me, dear child, and don't worry about anything else."
es: — Fix your eyes on me, dear girl, and forget everything else.

en: “I mind nothing while I hold your hand. I shall mind nothing when I let it go, if they are rapid.”
vi: − I'm not worried at all when I hold your hand. I won't be worried at all when I let go, if it happens quickly.
tr: "When I'm holding your hand, nothing else matters to me. If they finish this quickly when I let go of your hands, I won't care either."
es: —As long as I have yours in my hands, I will be calm; and if I have to let go to embark on the journey, if the blow is swift, I will not fear it either.

en: “They will be rapid. Fear not!”
vi: − It will be very quick. Don't be afraid!
tr: "It will be over quickly. Don't be afraid!"
es: —The strike will be swift; don't worry.

en: The two stand in the fast-thinning throng of victims, but they speak as if they were alone. Eye to eye, voice to voice, hand to hand, heart to heart, these two children of the Universal Mother, else so wide apart and differing, have come together on the dark highway, to repair home together, and to rest in her bosom.
vi: The two of them stood among the thinning crowd of victims, but still conversed as if they were the only ones there. Eye to eye, word to word, hand in hand, heart to heart, the two children of Mother Nature, two beings so distant and different from each other, now met on the path to death, together returning to rest in the embrace of Mother.
tr: Even though they stand among a rapidly dwindling heap of victims, they speak as if they are alone. These two children of Mother Earth, although very different from each other under different circumstances, have come together on this dark path, eye to eye, hand in hand, heart to heart, to support each other and rest in their mother's embrace.
es: Although they were among the other victims, they spoke with as much freedom as if they had been alone. Those two children of the Universal Mother, unknown to each other until then, were going to make the final journey together, to appear together before the Creator, to rest together in Heaven.

en: “Brave and generous friend, will you let me ask you one last question? I am very ignorant, and it troubles me—just a little.”
vi: Brave and chivalrous friend, may I ask you one last question? I am ignorant and have a small query... just a minor thing.
tr: "Brave and honorable friend, may I ask you one last question? I am very ignorant, and this bothers me a bit."
es: —Brave and generous friend!—exclaimed the girl—May I ask you a question? I am very ignorant, and it is about something that troubles and mortifies me... a little bit.

en: “Tell me what it is.”
vi: − Please, go ahead.
tr: "Tell me."
es: —Ask whatever you want.

en: “I have a cousin, an only relative and an orphan, like myself, whom I love very dearly. She is five years younger than I, and she lives in a farmer’s house in the south country. Poverty parted us, and she knows nothing of my fate—for I cannot write—and if I could, how should I tell her! It is better as it is.”
vi: − I have a cousin, my only relative and also an orphan like me, whom I care for deeply. She is five years younger than me and is living on a farm in the south. Poverty has separated us, and she knows nothing about my fate... because I am illiterate and cannot write letters... and even if I could write, how could I tell her my story! It's better that my sister doesn't know. −
tr: "I have a cousin whom I love very much, my only relative, and like me, he is also an orphan. He is five years younger than me and lives on a farm in the south. Poverty separated us, and he has no idea what has happened to me –I can't write anyway– even if I could write, how could I tell him this! Maybe it's better this way."
es: —I have a cousin, my only relative, an orphan like me, whom I love very much. She is five years younger than I am and lives in a farmhouse, in the South. Poverty separated us; she is unaware of my misfortune and I cannot write to her... and even if I could... what would I say? It is better this way.

en: “Yes, yes: better as it is.”
vi: Yes, yes, it's better that way.
tr: "Yes, yes; this way is better."
es: —It's true: it's better this way.

en: “What I have been thinking as we came along, and what I am still thinking now, as I look into your kind strong face which gives me so much support, is this:—If the Republic really does good to the poor, and they come to be less hungry, and in all ways to suffer less, she may live a long time: she may even live to be old.”
vi: − What I thought on the way here, and still wonder about as I look at the resolute face that has supported me, is... If this Republic truly brings good things to the poor, helping them be less hungry and suffer less in every way, my sister would likely live longer, perhaps even to old age...
tr: "I was thinking while coming on the road and I am still thinking while looking at your kind and strong face that gives me strength, if the Republic truly helps the poor and reduces their hunger and suffering, my cousin may live long, even grow old.""
es: —What I have been thinking while they were bringing us here, and what I continued thinking now, is the following: if the Republic is truly to bring happiness to the poor, if thanks to it they suffer less hunger and their suffering is alleviated, my cousin may still live many years; it is even possible that she might grow old.

en: “What then, my gentle sister?”
vi: − And then what, little sister? −
tr: "What does it matter, my dear brother?"
es: —And what, my dear little sister?

en: “Do you think:” the uncomplaining eyes in which there is so much endurance, fill with tears, and the lips part a little more and tremble: “that it will seem long to me, while I wait for her in the better land where I trust both you and I will be mercifully sheltered?”
vi: Do you think that... - with tears welling up in eyes resigned without a hint of complaint, lips trembling slightly, - have I waited too long for my sister in Heaven, where I believe both you and I will be blessed by God to enter? −
tr: "I wonder," the girl's gentle, non-pleading eyes filled with tears and her lips parted further and began to tremble, "while I wait for him where I'm going – and I'm sure we will be protected with mercy there – will this time feel long to me?"
es: —If that is so, don't you think the wait will feel very long for me, there in that better world where I trust to be mercifully welcomed with you, in that world where you, she, and I will live eternally?

en: “It cannot be, my child; there is no Time there, and no trouble there.”
vi: Not long, little sister; there is no Time there, and no sorrow.
tr: "He won't come, my dear; there is no Time there, nor is there any trouble."
es: —No, my daughter, no; in that better world you allude to, Time does not exist, nor is there room for suffering.

en: “You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant. Am I to kiss you now? Is the moment come?”
vi: − You have greatly put my mind at ease! I am so ignorant. Can I kiss you now? It's almost time, isn't it? −
tr: "How you put my mind at ease! I am very ignorant. Can I kiss you now? Has the time come?"
es: —How much your words console me! I am so ignorant! Should I kiss you now? Has the moment arrived?

en: “Yes.”
vi: Yes.
tr: "Yes."
es: —Yes, my daughter, yes.

en: She kisses his lips; he kisses hers; they solemnly bless each other. The spare hand does not tremble as he releases it; nothing worse than a sweet, bright constancy is in the patient face. She goes next before him—is gone; the knitting-women count Twenty-Two.
vi: The girl kissed him on the lips; he kissed her lips; they solemnly blessed each other. The solitary hand no longer trembled when he let go; without a trace of impurity, that patient face was completely radiant and joyful. The girl went to the guillotine before him - and passed away; the women knitting counted: Twenty-Two.
tr: They kiss each other on the lips and bless each other with a solemn air. When he lets go of the girl's hand, it no longer trembles. A sweet, radiant determination has enveloped his patient face. The next person, the one who will go immediately in front, is him; the women knitting are counting. Twenty-two.
es: The girl kisses Sydney Carton's lips and Sydney Carton kisses the girl's lips. Their hands do not tremble as they part. "Goodbye." The girl's head rolls first... The women who knit count TWENTY-TWO.

en: “I am the Resurrection and the Life, saith the Lord: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever liveth and believeth in me shall never die.”
vi: "The Lord said: I am the resurrection and the life; whoever believes in me will live, even though they die. And whoever lives by believing in me will never die."
tr: "I am the Resurrection and the Life," said God. Whoever believes in me,. even if they die, will live, and whoever lives and believes in me will never die."
es: "I am the Resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, shall live eternally; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die."

en: The murmuring of many voices, the upturning of many faces, the pressing on of many footsteps in the outskirts of the crowd, so that it swells forward in a mass, like one great heave of water, all flashes away. Twenty-Three.
vi: Many voices murmured, many faces looked up, many feet jostled closer from the outer circle of the crowd, causing a wave of people to surge forward, then suddenly disappear. Twenty-Three.
tr: Murmurs are rising, everyone's face is turning that way, there's such a jostling at the edge of the crowd that the whole mass swells forward like a huge wave and then disappears. Twenty-three.
es: "I am the Resurrection and the Life; he who believes in Me, though he may die, shall live eternally; and whoever lives and believes in Me shall never die." The blade descends again, and the women count; TWENTY-THREE.

en: They said of him, about the city that night, that it was the peacefullest man’s face ever beheld there. Many added that he looked sublime and prophetic.
vi: ۩۩۩ Throughout the city that night, people told each other that among all those who went to the scaffold in Paris, he had the most serene face. Many people also say that he looks majestic and extraordinary like a prophet.
tr: That night, everyone in the city talked about how they had never seen a face as peaceful as his. Many people added that he looked so transcendent and sublime.
es: That night, nothing else was talked about in the city. Everyone said they had never seen a human face that reflected so much calm, so much serenity of spirit. Many added that his appearance was sublime and that a prophetic light shone in his eyes.

en: One of the most remarkable sufferers by the same axe—a woman—had asked at the foot of the same scaffold, not long before, to be allowed to write down the thoughts that were inspiring her. If he had given any utterance to his, and they were prophetic, they would have been these:
vi: Not long before, one of the most famous condemned criminals of that guillotine - a woman - when standing at the foot of the scaffold, requested to record her final thoughts. If you were to utter what you are thinking, if you could see into the future, you would have said: “I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, the Goddess of Vengeance, the jurors, the Judge, so many new oppressors arising as the old oppressors are destroyed, all will perish under this punitive machine before it is discarded and no longer used.
tr: One of the most notable victims of the same knife – a woman – had asked for permission to write down her thoughts shortly before her execution, at the foot of the same gallows. If Carton were also given the opportunity to express himself, he would have uttered these sublime words:
es: Some time before, one of the most notable victims of the guillotine, a woman, had written down, placed upon the dreadful platform, the thoughts that the horrible machine inspired in her. If Sydney Carton had given sensible expression to his own, and if they had been prophetic, they would have been the following:

en: “I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, The Vengeance, the Juryman, the Judge, long ranks of the new oppressors who have risen on the destruction of the old, perishing by this retributive instrument, before it shall cease out of its present use. I see a beautiful city and a brilliant people rising from this abyss, and, in their struggles to be truly free, in their triumphs and defeats, through long years to come, I see the evil of this time and of the previous time of which this is the natural birth, gradually making expiation for itself and wearing out.
vi: If you were to utter what you are thinking, if you could see into the future, you would have said: “I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, the Goddess of Vengeance, the jurors, the Judge, so many new oppressors arising as the old oppressors are destroyed, all will perish under this punitive machine before it is discarded and no longer used. I see a magnificent city and an enlightened people rising from this abyss; in their struggle for true freedom, in their victories and defeats, after many long years, I see this country gradually redeeming the evils of the present time and of what previously caused this turmoil.
tr: "I see that Barsad, Cly, Defarge, Vengeance, the Jury, the Judge, and the new tyrants rising from the destruction of the old order will perish by this treacherous instrument before its current use ends. I see a beautiful city and brilliant people emerging from this abyss, and for many years, in their struggle to remain truly free, in their victories and defeats, I see the evil of the past, which slowly pays its penalty and fades away, in these times.
es: "I see Barsad, Cly, Defarge, La Vengeance, the Jurors, the Judges, all the new oppressors of humanity who have risen terribly to destroy the old ones, fall under the sharp blade of the just instrument. I see from the depths of the black abyss a beautiful city and an educated people emerge, who, in their struggles for true freedom, in their triumphs and defeats, atone, for many long years, for the horrors of the current era and those of previous eras, and eventually erase them."

en: “I see the lives for which I lay down my life, peaceful, useful, prosperous and happy, in that England which I shall see no more. I see Her with a child upon her bosom, who bears my name. I see her father, aged and bent, but otherwise restored, and faithful to all men in his healing office, and at peace. I see the good old man, so long their friend, in ten years’ time enriching them with all he has, and passing tranquilly to his reward.
vi: I see those for whom I have sacrificed my life, living peacefully, usefully, prosperously, and happily, never to be seen again in England. I see her holding in her arms a child named after me. I see her father, old and frail, but recovered, devotedly treating the sick, and living comfortably. I see that kind old friend, who has been close to this family for a long time, still wholeheartedly dedicated to them ten years from now and peacefully receiving his reward in the afterlife.
tr: The lives for which I gave my life, in that England I will never see again, I see them peaceful, useful, prosperous, and happy. I see her with a child in her arms, bearing my name. I see his father aged and worn; on the other hand, improved and serving people in his clinic, and peaceful. I see the kind-hearted old man, their former friend who enriched their lives for ten years and peacefully received his reward.
es: "I see the lives of those for whom I give my own, gliding peacefully, prosperously, and happily, in that England that my eyes will never see again." I see her gently rocking in her lap a child who bears my name. I see her father bowed under the weight of years, but providing until the last moment of his life the aid of his science to his fellow men. I see the good old man, who for so many years has been her tender and selfless friend, enriching them with all he possesses and flying to the world where the reward awaits him that his virtues have earned him.

en: “I see that I hold a sanctuary in their hearts, and in the hearts of their descendants, generations hence. I see her, an old woman, weeping for me on the anniversary of this day. I see her and her husband, their course done, lying side by side in their last earthly bed, and I know that each was not more honoured and held sacred in the other’s soul, than I was in the souls of both.
vi: I see myself being given a revered place in their hearts, in the hearts of their descendants, for many generations to come. I see her, an old woman, shedding tears of sorrow for me on this day every year. I see her with her husband, at the end of their lives, lying together in a shared grave, and I know that I also hold a sacred and honored position in their souls, no less than the respect they have for each other.
tr: I see that I will have a sacred place in the hearts of their grandchildren and all subsequent generations. I see her, as an old woman, crying on this day every year. I see her and her husband lying side by side in their final resting place in this mortal world, their lives having ended, and I know that both have reserved the most honorable and sacred place for me in their hearts, just as they have for each other.
es: "I see that in their hearts they have erected an altar for me, and that this altar is passed down to their descendants, and that, many generations later, all the descendants of that beloved family pay sincere homage to the memory of the man who sacrificed his life for the sake of a sacred affection." I see her, already very old, crying for me on every anniversary of my death. I see her and her husband, sleeping in the earth the final sleep, and I know that, even after death, they honor and exalt my memory.

en: “I see that child who lay upon her bosom and who bore my name, a man winning his way up in that path of life which once was mine. I see him winning it so well, that my name is made illustrious there by the light of his. I see the blots I threw upon it, faded away. I see him, fore-most of just judges and honoured men, bringing a boy of my name, with a forehead that I know and golden hair, to this place—then fair to look upon, with not a trace of this day’s disfigurement—and I hear him tell the child my story, with a tender and a faltering voice.
vi: I see the child in her arms bearing my name becoming a successful person on the career path that I left unfinished. I see that young man with a resounding reputation, causing my name to also be honored and erasing all the stains I had inadvertently brought upon that name. I see that young man becoming the most just judge, a person honored by all, who will bring the son also bearing my name, with the familiar forehead and blonde hair, to this place - which by then will have become magnificent, free from the blemishes of today - and I hear him, moved and emotional, recounting my story to his son.
tr: I see the child, who carries my name and rests on his chest, walking the path I once walked and making a living. I see that he is very successful in his work, and my name shines with his light. I see the stains I placed on my name being cleaned. I see this man, the foremost of conscientious judges and honorable men, bringing his son, who also carries my name and has a familiar brow and golden hair, here – of course, by then, there will be no trace of the current ugly state here – and I hear him telling my story to his son in a compassionate and hesitant voice.
es: "I see the child she rocked in her lap, who bears my name, grown into a strong man making his way in the world, dedicated to the career that was once mine, and doing so brilliantly, that the glows illuminating his name also illuminate mine." I see the stains that tarnished the brilliance of my soul erased. I see the illustrious lawyer who bears my name, the most just of judges on earth, who has earned the respect and admiration of his fellow citizens, now old, very old, with a golden-haired child on his unsteady knees, who also bears my name, and narrating my story in a faltering voice.

en: “It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to than I have ever known.”
vi: It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done; it is a far, far better rest that I go to, than I have ever known."
tr: This is the best, the most correct thing I have ever done, and the end of this road is a sleep as beautiful, as wonderful as I have never known before."
es: "A thousand times more beautiful is what I do now than what I ever did."
